column2: It was soon alter the publication of "A Little Journey in the World" that I met Charles Dudley Warner at a field night of the University Club in Baltimore.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 14 -- To-day Attorney General Taylor, Auditor of State Hart, and Supreme Recorder T.B. Linn of the Order of Chosen Friends, with their attorneys, appeared in the Superior Court, where the State asked for a receiver for the Chosen Friends alleging that the order is insolvent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Secretary Root and Adjt. Gen. Corbln appeared before the Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-day to discuss the Army Reorganization bill. They informed the committee that it would be impossible to send home all the volunteers in the Philippines in accordance with the schedule now planned unless the bill was passed without delay.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- From the smoldering ruins of the Fredonia State Normal and Training School, which was destroyed by fire at 6 o'clock this morning, one charred body has been recovered, and it is now certain that seven persons perished in the fire.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 14 -- The day express, No. 8, from Chicago, on the Pittsburg. Fort Wayne and Chicago, at 6:30 o'cloek this morning collided with the Leetsdale accommodation, east bound, at Edgeworth, Penn., near here. Both trains were wrecked, and eleven persons were injured.
The Spartan team won two of its three matches with the Germania five in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Biscuit common sold from 37 1/2 to 37 1/4, closing there, and the preferred brought 91. Traction preferred opened at 54 1/4 and fell to 50 at the close. Linseed common sagged back to 8 for the common and 39 for the preferred. Small lots of Diamond Match were handled at prices ranging from 130 to 181, closing at the latter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Since the action of the Senate to-day there have been all sorts of rumors about what is to happen to the treaty and to Secretary Hay. An earlier report was that the President intended to ask the Senate to return to him the mangled remnants of the Hay-Pauncefote instrument, so that short work could be made of it by dropping the effort to ratify it.

It is a pretty sound theory of literature that almost everything written and printed is designed to be read, and that no writer of fiction and belles lettres feels the worse for having a large instead of a small number of readers. The "exclusive" fellows in literature may be very fine fellows and rarely gifted, but they are not often exclusive from choice.

Joseph M. Dickey and Edward B. Dickinson, who were appointed receivers of the Anglo-American Savings and Loan. Association by Justice Maddox of the Supreme Court, qualified yesterday and took charge of the company's office in the Home Life Building. At 2 o'clock in the afternoon the application made in the Federal Circuit Court by Pennsylvania shareholders for the appointment of a receiver came up before Judge Lacombe.
This is the season of college dinners, the season that might have been celebrated by Swinburne in his melodious line as to the "day that loses, the night that wins."

The Committee of Fifteen was formally restored yesterday to its full numerical strength by the choice of five new members. One vacancy, hitherto unreported, was caused by the withdrawal at the Rev. R.L. Paddock of the Pro-Cathedral. The new members of the committee are:

The publication of books designed to lead to a higher appreciation of music goes merrily on, and in this good work the Scribners are conspicuous. The second volume of The Music Lover's a Library, of which the first was published some time ago, now lies before us. It is Mr. Henry T. Finck's discussion of "Song's and Song Writers."

Tenderly and gracefully the author of "Nigger Baby and Nine Beasts" tells of the love existing between a girl and various animals. It is for the most part in California, where the episodes take place. Some ten of the stories are so natural that they look as if they were the actual experiences of a young life.

Pronouncing sentence of twenty years' imprisonment upon fourteen-year-old Alexander Stewart, the youngest murderer ever arraigned before him, Justice Edward L. Fursman, ordinarily grave and dignified, was so moved yesterday by the precocious depravity and utter indifference of the young prisoner that he bowed his head in his hands and wept bitterly, while the hardened court officers and hangers-on were visibly agitated.

Brooklyn, it is said, has been slow to demand library privileges. However true this may be, certainly she has not been equally slow in appreciating those privileges when once they were obtained. The Brooklyn Public Library has for its object the development of a municipally controlled institution on the lines of the largest possible free circulation of books, and under the new regime has progressed rapidly.

In his "Looking Backward" Edward Bellamy was probably the first person to voice the idea of a co-operative system of social reform resulting in an ideal state of existence, but Edward Bellamy is dead, and no steps have even been contemplated to so much as seriously consider the practicality of his ideas.

The National League of managers of professional baseball clubs yesterday complete the business on hand at the first section of their annual meeting by bidding defiance to the players' alliance and all threatening bodies, presumably including "Ban" Johnson's new American League. Then the meeting in the Fifth Avenue Hotel adjourned, subject to the call of the Chairman, to finish out the annual meeting some time in the Spring.

A series of musical entertainments called People's Symphony Concerts were begun last night in the hall of Cooper Institute. The object of these entertainments is to provide good music for persons of small means, and the prices are very low it is hoped, as was explained by the Rev. Dr. Eliphalet Potter in an introductory address, that the enterprise may eventually be endowed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The House to-day adjourned without disposing of more than half the War Revenue Reduction bill. General debate closed at 2 o'clock after which the bill was opened to amendment under the five-minute rule. A determined effort was made to reduce the tax on beer below the committee rate of $1.60 a barrel, but the Ways and Means Committee over-whelmed the opposition.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The gratuitous fling at the memory of Paul Jones which Mr. John Morley found inclination to embody in a line of his "Cromwell," though perhaps annoying, will hardly seem formidable to those acquainted with the character and mental habits of Mr. Morley himself.

Two bold robberies in east side jewelry shops, at widely divergent points, were affected within a couple of hours of each other yesterday, apparently by the same men. In both cases the victims were first attacked and rendered unconscious with a "blackjack."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your correspondent, H.M. Miller, on Page 822 of your issue of Nov. 24, is perfectly correct in his impression that no description of the physical characteristics of Christ have come down to us from His time. None of the evangelists gives us the least hint with respect to the personal appearance of Christ.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- Confidencs showed itself in the stock market to-day, and there was large trading, comparing favorably with business done the week following the Presidential election. The activity, however, was confined practically to Marsden, Alkali, Reading first preferred. Lehigh Valley, and Philadelphia Company, of Pittsburg.

If it be difficult to fix what is precisely Mr. Morley Roberts's point of honor as far as politics is concerned, the extreme brightness of his "Lord Linlithgow" cannot be questioned. The text bristles with the quill-like epigram. There is shown, too, a thorough acquaintance with the methods and the ways of great newspapers of London when important political measures are being discussed.

William J. Fryer, the architect, is experiencing the inconveniences of being a lover of pet dogs and the unpleasantness of being elected a Trustee -- without his knowledge -- of an organization which later is dissolved, leaving him the only available person who can be sued. This situation has arisen out of the dissolution of the American Pet Dog Club, which, a year ago, had an exhibition in the Metropolitan Opera House.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The literary and dally press have joined in asserting that the KcKee library; recently dispersed in part, contained the "only absolutely perfect Poe collection ever gathered together." According to Webster, the word perfect means "without defect or lack; complete."

The plot 125 by 100 at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-second Street has been sold by the Barney-Sheldon syndicate to the New York Realty Company, (Flake Dowling.) This transaction completes the resale of the property in the block bounded by Fifth and Madison Avenues, Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, formerly owned by the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum and purchased by the syndicate about a year ago.

Ex-Manager W.A. Oakley of the Columbia crew made public yesterday his report of the rowing finances of the university for the past season. It appears from the report that the expenses of the year were $8,553.50, and that this amount was covered by receipts from different sources which foot up to the same sum.

The only developments yesterday in respect to the reported new opposition to the American Sugar Refinery Company was an explicit denial from S.R. Shipley of Philadelphia, President of the Provident Life and Trust Company, that his company was in any way concerned in the opposition. The following special dispatch from Philadelphia to THE NEW YORK TIMES explains itself:

PEKING, Dec. 13 -- Li-Hung-Chang and Prince Ching have sent an official notification to the Ministers that they have received promised documents authorizing them to act on behalf of China in the peace negotiations and announcing that they are ready to proceed so soon as the Ministers desire.

Margaret M. Heppenheimer, twenty-six years old, wife of George Heppenheimer, a conductor employed by the Manhattan Railroad Company, of 246 West One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street, was held yesterday at the Centre Street Police Court in $2,000 bail for examination on charges involving forgery.

W.W. Kellogg of Chicago and John A. Hendrick of this city were the winners of the two games, played yesterday in the National Class B billiard tournament now in progress at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Neither game developed great interest on the part of the spectators. The afternoon match, in which Mr. Kellogg met Frank Billiter, the Minneapolis champion, was the longest of the finale series, occupying three hours and running 73 innings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- One of the most severe storms that ever visited San Francisco broke over the city at an early hour to-day and has raged in fitful gusts, rain and wind sweeping over the city with unusual violence, accompanied by thunder and forked lightning, a rather unusual occurrence in this city.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

In this volume are given somewhat more than one thousand quotations from the writers of all lands and times mainly concerning women. We give below some of the more striking of these sayings, but readers will find the entire collection quite as interesting perhaps as the passages here chosen:
In the interesting paper on "Misquotation," in THE REVIEW for Nov. 17, the author refers to Wordsworth's exquisite lines:
VICTORIA, B.C., Dec. 14 -- Papers from China that have reached here give interesting details of the escape of the Chinese Court from Peking.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Sir: In your review in yesterday morning's paper of the lecture by Mr. Churchill the night before you inform us that in an interview between your reporter and Mr. Churchill he stated that he had never written any letter in which he stated, referring to the Boers: "We had a 'good bag' to-day, ten killed, seventeen wounded."

Within one week after publication, the first edition of "Oriental Rugs," by John Kimberly Mumford, published by Charles Scribner's Son, has been exhausted. Owing to the time necessary in the color-plate work, the second edition cannot be ready much before February. It is quite astonishing that so many persons should be interested in the study of rugs.

Brenda is disobedient, a trifle cunning, conceited and of a jealous disposition. In fact, Brenda, is a disagreable girl. The author intends that Brenda shall be an example of a girl whose traits are not to be followed. As to Belle, that young lady is somewhat of a toady. There are four girls who make up the club.

Nearly 300 guests,attended the dinner tendered in the Hotel Savoy last night to the Civil Service Reform League by the Civil Reform Association of New York. Bishop Potter presided, the retiring President of the league, Mr. Schurz, being abesent.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The morning papers generally comment on the adoption of the Davis amendment to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty.

The most remarkable feature of the Weis Library is its location. It stands at the junction of two country roads known as the Valley and the Thomas Road, in Millcreek Township, Erie County, Penn., about six miles from the City of Eric.

This volume does a lasting service to thought, character, and spiritual religion in America. No biography of more intrinsic value has this season afforded. An Englishman of wide fame, in many respects Dr. Martineau was without a peer as a religious and philosophical teacher and devout champion of pure theism.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Every author is an editor. I make this assertion deliberately and after giving the theory herein set forth long and earnest thought. The editor of a magazine is the man who reads the numberless manuscripts thrust upon him and chooses a certain few as being available for his publication.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In a recent "History of Westchester County" there is reference to Major Andre, in which the author, as if Andre were a living person instead of a cool, dispassionate review, attacks his character with such apparent personal venom that I beg of you space in which to refute some of his allegations.
From The Cornhill. Montesquieu boldly defined a lord as "a man who s the King, speaks to the Minister, has a ebts, and pensions."

From The Fortnightly Review. One's own observation showed that the English had lost in many ways the popularity they once possessed in Belgium, and impartiality demands the admission that it was very much their own fault. "Our dear countrymen" are not seen at their best on the Continent, and the self-satisfied English colony in Belgium presents sharp contrasts with that Belgian society which, ignores its existence.

The result of the indoor baseball games played by the teams of the Ninth Regiment and Fourteenth Regiment at the former's armory last night was a surprise to all, inasmuch as the latter had easily defeated the former but two weeks before. As it was the game was close throughout. During the last inning, when the score stood at 9 to 8, the partisans of each side filled the armory with their din.

From The Forum. The insecurity of Chinese houses and the danger from fire make banks of deposit a necessity. All classes in China have bank accounts. The business of the banks is to discount paper, to negotiate bills of exchange, to loan money on land or on personal property, and to buy and sell the precious metals.

Pretty silk-covered coat hangers can be bought for $1.25. Portable hangers can be bought for the same price and they are treasures for the traveler. No one who has not seen the bad effects of hanging coats and jackets from hooks, been bothered by broken loops and stretched collars can appreciate the convenience of these things as they deserve.
Congratulations may be offered this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to:

The next move toward solution of the tangle in professional baseball, and settlement of the differences between the National League managers and the players, in all probability, will be announced to-day, and the result of a conference between Charles Zimmer, Clark Griffiths, and Hugh Jennings, the members of the committee representing the Players' Protective Association, and their lawyer, Harry Taylor, in Buffalo.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is with deep interest that every lover of his country and citizen of this great city witnesses the present movement in the direction of "Reform" and "Righteousness." The difficulties which lie in the way of this movement are certainly huge and apparently insurmountable.

There is a two-fold interest attached to the action of the French Chamber last Thursday in adopting the first paragraph of the Amnesty bill and an amendment excluding cases of espionage and treason from grace. It places the cause celebre forever beyond the realm of political discussion, and it leaves the verdict of the High Court of Justice in regard to those treasonably inclined persons DEROULEDE, GUERIN, and MARCEL-HABERT untouched.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 15 -- The most exciting man hunt that has been undertaken in Northern Maine since the United States Marshals went to storm the fortress of George Nadeau, away up the St. John River, is now in progress, Game Warden Herman Templeton and Guide Ben Woodward of Kineo having started for Baker Lake to capture "Old Pete" Fountaine, the king of all poachers.

If the average elevator man in the great down-town office building had the time and inclination to jot down in diary form the fragments of conversation dropped by the various tenants on the flying trips between floors during a month, a week, or even a day, the collection would make a weird and fascinating volume.

Clerk John H. Loos of the Naturalization Bureau of the Supreme Court, has received a letter from a Frenchman renouncing his American citizenship, to which Mr. Loos finds, himself unable to reply. The Frenchman, whose name is Jean Pierre Guinet, has affixed his certificate of citizenship to his letter, but Mr. Loos says he has no power to cancel it, and does not know how Guinet can obtain relief.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in last Friday's issue, entitled "The Churches and the East Side," ought to be read by every church member of Greater New York. We have heard much lately, and much that is true, about the apathy of the churches, which, in plain English, means the apathy of the church members.

An oft-quoted statement of the late Mr. Gladstone embodies a rank fallacy: "As the British Constitution is the most subtle organism which has proceeded from progressive history, so the American Constitution is the most wonderful work ever struck off at a given time by the brain and purpose of man."

THE HAGUE, Dec. 1 -- This morning appeared the latest photographs of the Queen of Holland. It was as if all at once, it had rained queens, for not only those shops that usually sell photographs flooded their windows with them, but all the "notion" shops, candy shops, and book shops sold them just as fast as the buyers could squeeze in to lay down their money.

Changes occurred in the leading teams in several of the local bowling leagues as a result of the past week's games. In the Harlem League the Belvideres jump from third to first place in consequence of having won both their matches of the week. In the American National tournament the Fidelias, having lost two games, drop from first place to third, the Columbia team taking the lead.
Florence Ziegfeld, Jr., has engaged the French eccentric dancers, Les Colinis, to appear with Anna Held in "Papa's Wife," commencing Christmas week at the Montauk Theatre, Brooklyn.
Controller Coler will to-morrow begin the payment to contractors of moneys which have been withheld on account of the legal fight over the prevailing rate of wages clause in the labor law.

Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, yesterday handed down his decision upon the application of James W. Carpenter and others for the appointment of a temporary receiver for the Anglo-American Savings and Loan Association. Judge Lacombe's decision was as follows:
PEKING, Dec. 15 -- The French report the approach on the Chinese Imperial City, of 10,000 men, Pao-ting-Foo, the French garrison, fifteen miles west, being attacked by the advance guard.

Columbia's athletes held their second annual indoor games at the Eighth Regiment Armory last night, and, despite a late start, ran off a lengthy programme of events in excellent style. Trials were necessary in most of the track events on account of the large number of starters. The open sixty-yard handicap run had thirty-nine entries, necessitating six trials and a final for its decision.

From Longman's. How the belief in the divine right of Kings -- their former source of so much strength -- arose in modern Europe, where the titles of dynasties have been so constantly disputed, it is very difficult to say; but the fact that it prevailed over so many disintegrating influences down to quite recent times, if even now it can be said to be extinct, is a signal proof of its tenacity end power.

A middle-aged New Yorker, who had been in poor luck, poor spirits, and poor health for some time, fell so far into the dumps that he could not be pulled out. He became a misanthropist, a pessimist, and a croaker. He soured on everything. He thought the world was as bad as it could be.

In the early days of opera in this city the arrival of a noted prima donna in the metropolis created, or was made to create, almost as much of a stir as did the recent visit of William J. Bryan during the Presidential contest. A grand reception was almost invariably extended to distinguished queens of song.

The attempt to colonize Jewish immigrants bad two objects -- to relieve the man and to drain the Ghetto. In this last it failed. In eighteen years 1,200 families have been moved out. In the five months from October to March last 12,000 came to stay in New York City. The number of immigrant Jews during those months was 15,233, of whom only 3,881 went further.

OTTAWA, Dec. 14 -- A Buffalo syndicate was organized over a year ago to build elevators in Montreal and to run a line of steamers between that port and the great lakes for the purpose of conveying grain to the seaboard. W.J. Connors of Buffalo and some of his associates were here during the week seeing the members of the Government in regard to this matter.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suppression of vice on the east side is at present one of the most absorbing topics of public interest. The compulsion of the police to abstain from receiving bribes to protect it, and to enforce the laws against it, is rightly the first step in the crusade for its overthrow.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The pertinent plea of "F.D.H." for State support of private schools is plausiable and obviously sincere. Whatever be our opinion of the problem, we sympathize with one who so ardently desires moral and Christian training of the youth of our country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent communication to your paper I remarked on the shameful neglect in our public schools of the physical and moral sides of education. I am pleased to learn that others have recognized the necessity of reform. The press should interest itself in this matter, and changes might be wrought in less time than usually is required "to reform."

Charles Cotesworth Beaman, who had been for more than twenty years a law partner of United States Ambassador Joseph H. Choate in the firm of Evarts, Choate Beaman, died of heart trouble last night at his home, 11 East Forty-fourth Street. He had been ill since Wednesday last.

Carefully stored away in the vaults of Columbia University Library is a small leather-bound book which in its way is the most curious in the whole collection of nearly half a million volumes. The name which has been given to this interesting piece of literature is "The Black Book," and this is seen to be particularly appropriate, for on the title page is written: "Book of Misdemeanors of King's College, New York."

America, first, represented by Harry Elkes and Floyd McFarland; Canada, second, represented by Burns Pierce and Archie McEachern; France, third, represented by Caesar Simar and Jean Gougoltz, and Germany, fourth, represented by Karl Kaser and Fritz Ryser. In that manner the leaders finished the six-day bicycle race at 10:05 o'clock last night, in the Madison Square Garden, which thus assumed a strong international tone.
In beginning his address at Ann Arbor ex-President HARRISON took pains to disclaim any intention to make a legal argument. The address supports the disclaimer by strong intrinsic evidence.

This was the clever way in which a well-groomed, well-poised, and self-reliant young woman, disposed of one of the genus "masher" who tried to force his unwelcome attentions on her. It happened on a recent afternoon on an Eighth Avenue surface car. When the young lady boarded the car all the seats were occupied.
WEDNESDAY, DEC. 19 -- By James L. Wells, partition sale, Peter A. Shiel, referee, Second Street, Unionport, north side, 305 feet west of Avenue A, 100 by 108, vacant.
"We've mothing but a memory to warm us."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- One reason has appeared why the Census Committee of the House is not likely to be as prompt in getting through a reapportionment of Congressional membership as the Census Committee of the Fifty-first Congress. The committee is divided, a vote to-day showing one majority in favor of the plan of Chairman Hopkins to continue the present membership of 357 in the next apportionment.

Dullness prevailed in most outside stocks yesterday, and with very few exceptions the day's transactions brought little change in quotations. The market, however, was fairly strong, and changes in prices were nearly all on the side of advances. The notable strength of the Stock Exchange market was not reflected to any large extent in curb market transactions, and there were few if any developments of any importance directly affecting outside stocks.

The stock market yesterday was buoyant and rampantly bullish. Prices went up with a rush all through the list under the stimulus of heavy buying for London account -- fully 75,000 shares being taken by foreigners -- and for the same large financial interests at home who lately have been conspicuous as purchasers.

From Chambers Journal. The Prince of Wales draws L40,000 a year, an inadequate sum considering the public duties relegated to him consequent on the practical withdrawal of the Queen from public life. It is however, supplemented by an annuity of L10,000 for the Princess of Wales and one of L36,000 yearly divided among his children.

The death of Louis H. Hilliard, the Bellevue insane patient who, according to Coroners' Physician Donlon, was strangled on Tuesday by three Bellevue nurses, was investigated yesterday by Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller in person. In consequence, the Commissioner discharged T. R. Davis, Edward Dean, and Charles Marshall, the three nurses employed in the insane pavilion who were with Hilliard when he died.

After an absence of several years from this country, Jean Gerardy, the celebrated Belgian cellist, makes his reappearance on to-morrow afternoon at Mendelssohn Hall. His present tour is under the direc- tion of Charles L. Young, and includes all the principal cities. Assisting Gerardy will be Aime Lachaume at the piano.

A lovely week in the world of music was that which has just come to an end. Those of us who cherish the high art of tones will think of it in the coming week, for on Tuesday night the fashionable opera season comes to crush the life out of honest music. Art must then be hurled into the outer darkness, where there are not diamonds and laces and low corsages.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- The local market has hardly as yet apparently "caught the bull step" that is on in New York. And yet the trading to-day was of good-sized proportions. The copper shares were inclined to drag much of the time, and none of them made any noteworthy gains.

National Committeeman Gibbs and Chairman Ten Eyck of the Executive Committee of the County Republican organization discussed with Senator Platt at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night the reorganization of the County Committee.

The Harlem flat was the cause of William N. Hyde's troubles. Hyde, who is a veteran of the civil war, is inured to all sorts of hardships in camp and field. His particular flat is at 460 Manhattan Avenue, but he was found early yesterday morning by a policeman, sleeping contentedly on One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, near Eighth Avenue, with his head pillowed on the edge of the sidewalk.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Springfield editor who referred to New York as "provincial" because within its great limits a few evidences exist of former days, such as an occasional horse car and some inferior piers, evidently does not know much of the city's history. A few of its achievements may not be out of place.

Corduroy is one of the materials which is universally becoming, and its revival is always welcome. This is a corduroy season, and many of the handsomest suits of the Winter are made from it. It comes in all colors and shades, and is made in all sorts and conditions of suits, from the elaborate street gown worn with handsome furs, to the bright-colored golf frock.
Sir William Van Home, President of the Canadian Pacific Railroad, arrived in this city yesterday morning from Cuba, and in the evening continued on his journey to Montreal.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. Dec. 15 -- Findlay S. Douglas of the Fairfield Golf Club won the chief trophy to-day in the golf tournament of the Atlantic City Country Club by beating W.S. Davis of the Lakewood Club by a score of 4 up and 3 to play. The weather was fair and cold.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Alarmed by the attitude of the opposing elements, the city administration has at last made some attempt to remedy certain evil conditions of life as found here. No one has very much confidence in the good faith behind these efforts at reform, and it is plain to most people that no remedy will be had while the present influences are still in power.
Hugh McLaughlin, the Democratic leader of Kings County, was seen last night at his home, but refused to discuss the police shake-up. Later in the evening, when speaking to a close friend, he said:

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- The police of this city and a number of private detectives are searching for Sophie Huykil Maloof, an eighteen-year-old Syrian girl, who was to have been married at noon to-day. Her trousseau, which cost $275, although paid for, is at the stoce where purchased. The police traced her to a Syrian cafe, from which she departed for home yesterday afternoon, according to the story of Naszar, the proprietor.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The local market received another setback to-day in a further decline in Asphalt of America 5s to 61 1/2. One week ago they were at 69. Last year they commanded 97. The present slump is due to an adverse decision affecting the title of the company to valuable asphalt beds in Venezuela.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The purchase by J. Pierpont Morgan Co. of the Pennsylvania Coal Company in the interest of the Erie Railway is looked upon in anthracite circles in this city as but incidental and preliminary to a still greater and closer alliance between the anthracite interests.

It is amusing, if not exactly enlightening, to watch the course of discussion upon the address of our honored guest, WU-TING-FANG, upon the differences and the resemblances between Christianity and Confucianism. To many readers the address seemed a sincere and intelligent endeavor to apprehend the meaning of Christianity upon the part of one who had not been reared in it, and who of course rejected its supernatural sanctions.

All arrangements have been made for the sporting show at the Grand Central Palace for the benefit of the family of the late Hugh S. Hart, and from all indications the affair will be a notable success. Effort has been made to gather the past and present champions of every branch of sport which can be put upon the stage in attractive style.

Six high priests of Buddha, representing the Great Japan Buddhists' Union, at their headquarters, at Kenninji Temple, in Kioto, Japan, have issued a circular letter in connection with what its signers describe as "The Chinese Emergency." It is addressed " To All the Ecclesiastics in the World."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The House today passed the War Revenue Reduction bill. The opposition sought to recommit the bill with instructions to report back a measure reducing the revenue at least $70,000,000, and including a provision for an income tax so drawn as to escape an adverse decision of the Supreme Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If you will pardon me for again intruding upon you I would ask to say a word in reference to your editorial of yesterday morning upon the subject of "Roman Catholics and the Schools."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in to-day's issue dealing with "The Problems of City Churches" gives expression to some plain truths which the "lay intelligence" perceives, but is unable, many times, to put into words. Your readers should be, and no doubt many are, like myself, grateful for your definite presentation of some of the problems the Church has to face.

FRIDAY, DEC. 21 -- By William M. Ryan, partition sale, Thomas F. Donnelly, referee, 294 Seventh Avenue, west side, 128.4 feet north of Twenty-sixth Street, 19.8 by 90.9, four-story brick building, with store; 346 Seventh Avenue, west side, 39.9 feet north of Twenty-ninth Street, 19 by 64, four-story brick building, with store; 245 West Thirty-first Street, north side, 225 feet east of Eighth Avenue, 25 by 98.9, five-story brick tenement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a human duty, to regard Minister WuTing-Fang with good-will and to compare notes with him, as he has volunteered to do with us. I cannot -- and assume that few among us can -- appreciate, however willing, Confucianism at its true value. And I must also assume that Mr. Wu cannot, nor his co-religionists, appreciate Christianity at its-true value.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- In the face of persistent rumors which have been in circulation here for several days, the officials of the Boston Ice Company, which controlled the bulk of the ice business in this city, today admitted that the American Ice Company of New Jersey has purchased a controlling interest in the Boston company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have had yellow journals in the State, but hitherto the Church has been free from anything of that sort. Perhaps if we had more of it in all the Churches there would be less complaint about "apathy" in the Churches. It would be strange if, after all, it should prove to be the cure which has been earnestly sought by many, but discovered by none.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The appointment of Col. John F. Weston as Commissary General of Subsistence, with the rank of Brigadier General, vice Gen. Eagan, retired, has resulted in the following promotions in the Subsistence Department: Lieut. Col. John J. Clague to be Colonel, Major William L. Alexander to be Lieutenant Colonel, and Capt. George B. Davis to be Major.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The following report from Lord Kitchener was received at the War Office yesterday morning:...

BRIGHTON, Ill., Dec. 15 -- Five men, posing as tramps, were permitted to lodge in the lockup here last evening. During the night they overpowered the Town Marshal, locked him in a cell and broke into the private bank of Blodgett Brothers. Several charges of dynamite were exploded, but the vault, which contained a large sum, was only partly wrecked, and the men gave up trying to secure it.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 15 -- James J. Hill, President of the Great Northern Railway, today made the following statement in answer to the reported absorption of the Erie Road, the report of his resignation as President of the Great Northern, and the allegation that he will take up the work of organizing a trans-continental line, taking in the Erie as a connecting link:

The men from Company I swept almost everything before them in the annual Fall athletic games of the Seventy-first Regiment, which were held last night in the armory, at Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. For the fourth consecutive time the J. Kennedy Tod Cup, which is awarded each year to the company team scoring the greatest number of points, fell to their possession.

Vaccination received a setback in Harlem yesterday, and the Board of Health will have difficulty in re-converting at least one man to recognize the virtues of the virus. The man is Charles Weisbecker, a wholesale butcher in the One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Market, where he employs several hundred men to handle meats.

SHWEIR, Mount Lebanon, Syria, Nov. 1 -- Burge Saffita is a modern village built on the ruins of an ancient Hittite town, and contains a burse or a tower of great antiquity, from which it takes its name. It lies several hours' ride northeast of Tripoli, in the heart of the district which for the last half century has been the scene of American missionary enterprise.

In the tournament of the Wholesale Drug Trade Association on Reid's Church Street alleys last night, the Dodge Olcott and Church, Dwight Co. teams each won two games, the National Lead and Seabury Johnson teams each won one game and lost one, and the Merck Co. and Lanman Kemp teams each lost two games.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 @ 65. There were no sales.

THE ADJUSTMENT OF THE CONGO-GERMAN EAST AFRICAN FRONTIER -- The agreement just arrived at in Berlin between a representative of the Belgian Government and the German Government in regard to the disputed frontier line in East Africa has not excited any apprehension in British diplomatic circles, although by it an end is put to all idea of connecting the British spheres in North and South Africa in accordance with the Kimberley treaty of 1894.

MONDAY, DEC. 17 -- By Philip A. Smyth, foreclosure sale, Daniel P. Ingraham, referee, 217 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, north side, 183 feet west of Seventh Avenue, 17 by 99.11, three-story brick dwelling. Due on judgment, $10.856.

Twenty years have brought many changes for the better in the civil service of the United States, and the National Reform League, which has just held its twentieth annual meeting in this city, may fairly congratulate itself on the progress of the cause for which it has worked.

One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, south side, 75 feet west of Broadway, for two seven-story brick flats, each 50 by 90.11; Geraldine Broadbelt of 62 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, owner; Henry Andersen of 1,181 Broadway, architect; total cost, $180,000.

It was everything the advertisement had said -- select neighborhood, five large, light rooms, and tiled bathroom; steam heat, electric elevator, butler's pantry, laundry, and steam driers. The two visitors, however, did not wax enthusiastic, and the elevator boy, who was showing the flat with the patient, far-away look common to those who have to deal with home-hunters, had mentally dismissed them as "a couple more blanked women amoosin' themselves."

MUNCIE, Ind., Dec. 15 -- Amos Rusie stated to-day that he had signed with President J.T. Brush of Cincinnati, to play with the Cincinnati team next season. He stated he would assure Brush a stronger club this year than in the past. His pitching arm is in good condition, and it will need little training.

The six-story brick building, 1 East Fourteenth Street, and which, with the Hanover Hotel, occupied the Fifth Avenue block between Fourteenth and Fifteenth Streets, was damaged by fire last night to the extent of $35,000.

Sporting circles last night were listening with interest to the latest tall tale of a limitless poker game, played Friday night in the Waldorf-Astoria, in which, it is said, more than $60,000 changed hands.

The third weekly shoot for the December Cup at the Crescent Athletic Club traps yesterday afternoon resulted in a tie between L.C. Hopkins and Dr. H.L. Keyes, each with a total of 46 targets. Hopkins had a handicap of 9 added to his score at the expert traps and 8 at the Magau traps. Dr. Keyes had the same allowance as Hopkins at the expert traps, but received I less at the Magau traps.

It is now two months since the arrival on this side of the Atlantic of Sir Thomas Lipton's second challenge for the America's Cup, and plans preparatory to the real work of the defense have been completed only within the past week. Sir Thomas, with the valuable experience of defeat behind him, spent a year of thought upon means for improving his chance of success before issuing his challenge.
The Chinese Minister, Wu Ting Fang, was the guest of honor at a dinner at the Lotos Club last evening, and several hundred members of the club gathered to welcome him.

Mrs. Anna B. Cannon, a widow, who lived with Her son Emmet, twenty-two years old, on the second floor of 295 South Fifth Street, Brooklyn, was burned to death in her apartments yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Cannon was at the head of the corset department of the Siegel-Cooper Company.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- The Executive Committee of the new Boston cup defender, which committee is composed of local yachtsmen, who will take charge of the new boat at the request of Mr. Lawson, held a meeting this afternoon at the office of Designer Crowninshield and discussed the boat in a general way with Mr. Crowninshleld.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me in the name of 260 clerks in Branch Station H to thank THE TIMES for publishing my protest against the tyranny of Superintendent Baldwin of this station. I deeply regret the necessity of writing anonymously. If Mr. Baldwin feels injured, the columns of THE TIMES will, I know in advance, be found available.

Mrs. James Speyer of 257 Madison Avenue, the Treasurer of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following list of contributions to the Woman's Fund to date, and adds that the returns give promise of the largest collection in the history of the Auxiliary:

Every American must have some interest in what is officially known as the "Executive Mansion" of the President of the United States, but has been unofficially known, for much more than half of the century of its duration, as the "White House." The building is a dignified dwelling of its class and time, and is worth respecting and preserving on account of its architectural merit as well as of its historical associations.
BERLIN, Nov. 29 -- Following is, the speech delivered by Andrew D. White, United States Ambassador to Germany, at the Thanksgiving Day dinner of the American colony in Berlin this evening:

PEKING, Oct. 23 -- The Empress Dowager is a firm believer in the first law of nature. Much as she says she would like to return to Peking, and grievous as have been the hardships of absence, she intends to feel assured of her personal safety, if not of the recognition of her sovereignty and of its continuance, before trusting herself within foreign lines.

Professional speculators taking pessimistic Views of the business situation, working to create scares and upset the security market's equanimity, have been badly punished. Such traders became very bearish a fortnight ago over what they declared was the certain prospect of money market stringency; and at the beginning of the past week they were not only of positive opinion but united in aggressive attacks upon quotations.

Every one would suppose that every woman -- every man, for that matter -- in the city or out of had everything needful in the way of silver for the toilet table and that there would be no wants to supply this year. But the opposite is the fact. More people are to have gifts of toilet silver this year than ever before.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $624,250. The banks now hold a surplus of $6,325,375 above the legal requirements.

MOUNT LEBANON, Syria, Nov. 1 -- Murfaa el Mylade, meaning the eve of the Christmas fast, that is, the 14th day of November, is the last day on which Oriental Christians may eat animal food until the 25th of December. The said day, therefore, is observed as a, high carnival on which even the very poorest make a desperate effort to secure butcher meat or fowl and make elaborate and sumptuous meals.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Money was firm, less plentiful, and in moderate demand to-day. Anticipations of an increased demand next week hardens discounts. Beyond a strong demand for gold in the open market for Continental account and the inquiry from India, Germany is the most disquieting factor momentarily.

Two investment purchases of valuable mercantile parcels within a week, several deals involving the finest class of unimproved property, as well as a goodly amount of business of the ordinary variety, appear to indicate that the revival of the last fortnight is of more than temporary character.

From Our Animal Friends. In a quiet part of southeastern London there is what is known as the "L. and S. W. Railway Orphanage." In this home there are 150 children whose fathers have died in the service of the London and Southwestern Railway. Bight thousand dollars must be found each year to meet the expense of feeding, clothing, and educating these boys and girls.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 15 -- The engagement is announced of Miss Sophy Hazeltine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mayo Hazeltine, to Judge John Randolph Tucker of Virginia, grandson of the late St. George Tucker and a grandnephew of John Randolph of Roanoke. It was at a house party last Summer that Judge Tucker and his fiancee met for the first time, despite the fact that they are second cousins.

From Frank Leslie's Popular Monthly. Studied, then, from its thoroughfares, Jerusalem looks for all the world like a huge rambling fortress, with fighting towers and dungeon depths. On either hand, instead of lines of houses, you have formidable and continuous walls pierced with low doors and body-wide stairs and iron-caged windows.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Charles Stewart Smith has answered the questions that, through the courtesy of your journal, I put to him; but his answers are not such as to satisfy me -- or those who think with me -- that he has discharged his important function wisely or well.
From The Imperial and Colonial Magazine. In the old days -- not good old days -- when East Indiamen went round the Cape, St. Helena was a great port of call and of revictualing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Senate will devote the greater part of its time this week to consideration of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty, if it should be necessary to do so in order to get the ratification resolution acted upon, and in case there is any surplus time it will be devoted to the consideration of the Ship Subsidy bill.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The market in all departments last week was firm, quite as much business being done as is usual at this time of the year. Consols and other gilt-edged securities were strengthened by the official statement that there will be no further Government borrowing at present. Foreign securities showed further advances, following the higher Continental prices, Chinese securities being from 1/2 to 1 1/2 points better.

Policemen and park keepers played battledore and shuttlecock wth the peddlers along the Hester Street border of the William H. Seward Park yesterday morning. By 10 o'clock there was hardly one of the vendors in the forbidden teritory, and the few who occasionally made spasmodic efforts to return to the park fence were hustled away with scant ceremony.

MANITOWOC, Wis. Dec. 16 -- The steamer Manhattan arrived here to-day with W.H. Shields and William McCauly, light house keepers on Squaw Island, and the bodies of Mrs. Shields and her niece, Mrs. Mary Davis. They were picked up Saturday afternoon in the lake, where they were found lashed to an overturned yawl.

Farmer Carl Carlson of Marlborough, N. J., appeared before Magistrate Zeller, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday morning, as complainant against Daniel J. Murphy, a bartender, of 107 Washington Street, and James Ford, a cabman, of 40 Greenwich Street. They invited Carlson to have a ride in a cab. and, he says, attempted to rob him when they reached Grand Street and West Broadway.

The following is a comparison of the average of bullion in the principal European banks last week and at the corresponding date last year. These figures are cabled weekly to The Commercial and Financial Chronicle:

While an ambulance surgeon worked over the body, of a young man found dead in bed with the gas turned on in the boarding house 23 West Seventeenth Street, yesterday morning, an elderly man in the adjoining apartment was dying because of the gas that filtered through into his room.

Lawyer George A. Logan of Brooklyn has filed with Controller Coler nine claims, aggregating $50,000 in amount, on behalf of Long Island farmers, for damages suffered by them through the operation of driven wells in the water supply system of Brooklyn.

Hugh McLaughlin, the veteran leader of the Kings County Democracy, at his home, 163 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, last night, expressed himself forcibly upon the police shake-up ordered by Chief Devery. The action of Chief Devery has aroused Mr. McLaughlin's indignation, and his expressions left no doubt that war to the bitter end between him and the Chief was now on.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The territory until recently in dispute between Brazil and France, and which has been decreed to belong to Brazil, as described in Prof. John Bassett Moore's article in to-day's NEW YORK TIMES, may shortly become the subject of a dispute between France and the United States under the Monroe doctrine.

The Rev. Dr. John J. Reed, pastor of the Washington Square Methodist Church, preached a sermon last night on "The New Journalism" to his congregation. Dr. Reed dwelt upon the great changes that have manifested themselves in the making of a newspaper in the past fifty years, contrasting the journalism of Franklin, Greeley, and Weed with that of to-day, and touching upon the enormous outlays of money involved in the conduct of a great daily.

The Rev. R. Heber Newton preached in the Church of All Souls on the subject: "Women in the State." His text was: "The inhabitants of the villages ceased, they ceased in Israel, until that I, Deborah, arose, that I arose a mother in Israel." (Judges, v., 7.) He said in part:

What at first glance makes the Boer victory at Magalies Berg significant is the fact that the Boers could have concentrated 2,000 men within twenty miles of Pretoria when for several months past, with the exception of the fluctuating hundreds that are accompanying BOTHA and DE WET in their puzzling manoeuvres, the bulk of the burghers in arms have practically been indulging in guerrilla warfare.
Hugh McLaughlin told a little story yesterday which those who heard it were inclined to think alluded more or less to Chief Devery and Commissioner York. Said the "Boss":

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 16 -- Minister Limontour's report of the financial condition of the country, made to Congress on the presentation of the annual budget, is a notable document. He estimates for the ensuing year a revenue amounting to $61,694,000, and expenditures of $61,677,990, and shows why he does not anticipate a large surplus for the coming year. He takes up the present financial situation, which is characterized by monetary stringency, and remarks:

MANCHESTER, Dec. 16 -- Although views are divided regarding the American cotton crop, there is a tendency to support the estimate of 10,250,000 bales. The stock at Liverpool is steadily increasing. The activity of fluctuation has recently rendered transactions in cloth more difficult. Producers are firm and buyers restrict their purchases, which consist mainly of seasonable requirements, which will not admit of postponement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read With great interest the two excellent articles published in your paper on the abolishment of the canteen as voted by the House, and I feel in duty bound to give ray views on the subject from personal observation.
LONDON, Dee. 17 -- The Magalies Berg affair is described as follows in a dispatch to The Standard from Rietfontein:...

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Dec. 16 -- There was an earthquake here last night about midnight, the most severe experienced in several years. It created a panic at the San Carlos Club, where a grand ball was in progress. It was preceded by a dull sound like a mine explosion. Two shocks were felt, the former being quite severe and the latter barely perceptible.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- A patient named Smith, at the St. Lawrence State Hospital, who was not considered at all vicious, yesterday made a murderous assault with a knife on an attendant named Cummings. Smith was in his room at the hospital pacing the floor and muttering:

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- There was lodged in the county jail here to-day under charges of burglary in the third degree a resident of Ardsley, heretofore highly respected. The charge is a most peculiar one. He was not placed in the regular ward for men, but was allowed the use of the women's department, that section of the prison having been vacant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- In the Senate on Friday, just before that body went into executive session, Senator Money of Mississippi made a motion to take up Senate Bill No. 602, which is a measure prepared to revive an old act to pay a large aggregation of claims, principally for cotton, made against the United States on account of the war of the rebellion.
BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- The following was received by The Globe from James Sweeny, hospital steward with the Twenty-ninth Volunteer Infantry at Catbalogan, Samar Island:

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 16 -- Dr. Edward Hagyard, chief veterinarian on the Daly ranch in Montana, has telegraphed to his brother. Dr. John Hagyard, here, to come to the Daly farm and take his place while he goes to New York with the thoroughbred horses to be sold by the Fasig-Tipton Company in January.

Muffled in furs from their head to their heels, the Speedway brigade defied the biting cold and the cutting north wind of yesterday morning and furnished several hours of excellent sport brushing their crack trotters and pacers. Cold as it was, the crowd that gathered to witness the sport staid until the last brush.

The Central Federated Union was in an uproar for two hours yesterday over union halls, union beer, and union cigars. There were complaints from various organizations that the letter carriers, the Actors' Protective Union, the Social Democratic Party, and other bodies were holding various entertainments in Grand Central Palace, which, it was declared, was a non-union place.

The committee of delegates who will represent the bowling clubs of Brooklyn at the American Bowling Congress in Chicago next month, have arranged a series of games between the six Brooklyn teams which will be sent to the National championship tournament in connection with the congress and as many other representative teams of the borough.

The Rev. Father Dennis P. O'Flynn of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph, at Washington Place and Sixth Avenue, had just begun the celebration of the mass at 10 o'clock yesterday morning when he noticed John Kennedy, one of his parishioners, who sat in a pew near the front of the church.

Among the members of the Grau English Opera Company which has Just concluded its season at the Metropolitan Opera House, there is one baritone with a most decided idea of his personal importance. A virulerit attack of what the boys call "chestivititis" caused him to rather ignore the people of the chorus and the employes at the front of the house alike.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- In financial circles last week attention was devoted chiefly to the affairs of the mortgage banks. The weekly financial reviews freely admit that the market was rapidly drifting toward panic until the syndicate of Berlin banks was organized for the protection of the holders of obligations of the Prussian Hypotheken Aktlen Bank.

Carnegie Hall was crowded yesterday afternoon for a lecture by ex-Judge Joseph Clarkson of Omaha, formerly a law partner of Senator Thurston, who is now devoting his time to his duties as a member of the Christian Science Board of Lectureship of the First Church of Christ, In Boston.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- The trial of Edgar C. Burnz for the murder of Herbert B. Fellows in Scarsdale on the night of Monday, Dec. 4, 1899, Will begin in the Supreme Court here to-morrow morning before Justice Martin J. Keogh and a jury. An extra panel of 100 jurors has been drawn, which will give 150 from which to select a jury.

The North German Lloyd Steamship Company has been much attacked in German industrial circles and in German newspapers recently because of the company's purchase of 1,000 tons of steel in the United States. At a public festival at Frankfort a few weeks ago Mr. Wiegand, the Director General of the North German Lloyd, defended the company from these attacks.

ROCKPORT, Ind., Dec.16 -- Two negroes, Jim Henderson and Bud Rowlands, who waylaid and brutally murdered and robbed Hollie Simons, a white barber, early this morning, were lynched in the Jailyard by a mob of 1,000 frenzied citizens to-night. The negroes were arrested early, and although Rowlands's clothing had blood stains on it the men asserted they were innocent of the crime.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 16 -- The nominations for class officers of the senior class of Harvard closed to-night. The class this year has returned to the plan of having the three leading societies -- the Hasty Pudding, D.U., and the Pi Eta -- combine and draw up a slate for the officers without any opposition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with great interest the plea of "An American" in your issue of to-day for an unfortified Nicaragua Canal, and admit that, if his premises are sound, he has proved his case. But his premises are unsound. The experience of the last few years proves them so.

Political economists will find little that is cheerful in the published French population returns for 1899. The excess of births over deaths amounts to only 31,000, or an increase of 0.20 per cent., which is the lowest figure reached since 1895, When deaths exceeded births by 17,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The revival of the preposterous report that the Columbia football team will be sent to California for a same during the Christmas holidays is most deplorable. Colleges are for study. Reasonable and wholesome athletics tend to encroach on study, especially when they take the form of great public intercollegiate contests.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Christmas holidays are at hand and the money market is in a manner thankful. Its profits have been good during half the year, and both banks and discount houses will be able to make satisfactory dividend announcements in the beginning of next month. In other respects, however, the time has not been comfortable, and is perhaps less so now than at any period since the end of June.

William Barrett of 400 West Fifty-third Street, employed as an Inspector by the Fidelity and Casualty Elevator Insurance Company, was a prisoner before Magistrate Mayo in the West Side Court yesterday morning charged with abandonment by his wife, Mamie Barrett of 122 West Fortyseventh Street.
MADRID, Dec. 16 -- The German training frigate Gnelsenau has foundered at the entrance to the port of Malaga, sixty-five miles northeast of Gibraltar, during a violent storm.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding weeK last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The enterprises described by Sir WILLIAM VAN HORNE in our columns yesterday morning is a substantial proof of the promise there is in the future of the Island of Cuba more convincing than a volume of official reports.

GIBRALTAR, Dec. 16 -- Charles Carroll Jackson of New York City, a saloon passenger on the Hamburg-American liner Columbia, which arrived here to-day, died of peritonitis aboard ship. The body was brought ashore here and is being embalmed for conveyance to New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to say that, while I am a regular subscriber to your esteemed sheet, I am at odds with you on one subject, and that is your derisive treatment of everything which is favorable to the unfortunate race which has opposed its power to that of the whole British Empire.

In a police force properly composed and properly governed there could be no possible need of such extended and sudden changes as have just been made in this city. Especially would it be impossible that such sweeping changes could be made without the approval and against the known wishes and judgment of the officials at the head of the force.

SLIGHT INCREASE IN THE POPULATION OF FRANCE. -- The fact that until 1897 for several years the birth rate in France had shown no great gain over the death rate created considerable discussion among sociologists, and even legislation was resorted to in order to remedy certain phases of the general tendency.

After months of preparation, the Arion Club, whose home is at Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, held its second orchestral concert of the season last night. The concert hall was decorated with evergreens and red silk streamers, and the guests filled it to the doors.

The sixteenth annual report of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital for the year ended Oct. 31, finely printed and illustrated with half tones, has made its appearance. The scope of the Post-Graduate Hospital is wide. It has, among other departments, a nurses' training school, dispensary, hospital laboratory, lying-in department, babies' wards, and, in general, makes provision as far as its means will permit for the treatment of the worthy poor.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The Secretary of State for War, William St. John Brodrick, has appointed a committee to deal with the question of War Office reform. The committee will consider the system of contracts and the possibility of further decentralization and more expeditious working.

The rotten spot in the Subsidy bill is the foreign tonnage provision. The advocates of the bill not only cannot defend that feature, they will not even tell the truth about it. They persuade many very intelligent men to assent readfly to the proposition that a subsidy for the encouragement of American shipbuilding is a good thing.

The weekly statement of the New York City Associated Banks, issued Saturday, showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $624,250. The banks now hold a surplus of $6,325,375 above the legal requirement. The changes in averages show a decrease in loans of $13,682,500, a decrease in specie of $5,149,100, an increase in legal tenders of $1,579,200, a decrease in deposits of $18,376,600, and an increase in circulation of $116,100.

Considerable irregularity developed in the outside market during the past week, and, generally speaking, transactions were on a smaller scale than during the recent past. The net results of the week as viewed from the final changes in prices were not as favorable as might be wished, but the market closed in probably better position than is indicated by the week's list of changes.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- With the mercury near zero, a light wind, and five inches of smooth ice, everything points to excellent sport in the regatta of the Orange Lake Ice Yacht Club, which is to be sailed Tuesday over courses on Orange Lake which were staked to-day. Four prizes have been set up for award in Tuesday's events.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The House Committee on Census, by a vote of 7 to 6, agreed to report the Hopkins Reapportionment bill, leaving the total membership of the House at 357, as at present, and rear-ranging a number of State delegations. The bill will not be taken up until after the holidays.

The Duke of Newcastle, Henry Pelham Archibald Douglas Pelham-Clinton, one of the wealthiest noblemen in England, arrived here yesterday on the Atlantic Transport Liner Minnehaha. His wife did not accompany him. As the ship warped into her berth a young man of English build and clear, ruddy complexion waved his hat from the dock, and in him the Duke recognized his brother, Lord Francis Hope, the husband of May Yohe.

Three sudden deaths that have occurred since Thursday last will have their effect upon the social attendance at the opera this evening. Owing to the death of her brother-in-law, William Stanhope Callendar, who married Miss Teresa Anthon, and which occurred on Saturday at Morristown, Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish will naturally not be present in the brilliant house.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 17 -- A cynical sneak thief, not satisfied with mere robbery, indulged in vulgar satire by altering his victim's Bible in Omaha last night.

It has not often happened to this community to lose within the week three citizens so useful and distinguished, in their respective ways, as Mr. OTTENDORFER, Mr. BEAMAN, and Judge BEEKMAN. Nay, the loss is the more striking and affecting because their several ways of serving the community of which they formed a part were really the same way.

Members of both the New York Stock and Consolidated Exchanges are preparing to have a big jubilee on Saturday next, when the Exchanges will close for a three-day holiday over Christmas, not to reopen until Wednesday morning. Each Exchange will have its own celebration, but from what can be learned of the preparations already made the jollification of the minor Exchange will, in point of enthusiasm, be little behind that on the larger board.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Officials who are conversant with Turkish affairs are rather skeptical of Great Britain's success in her reported determination to insist on payment of the Armenian claims.

Pinched by bitter poverty and denied the services of several physicians to whom he applied for treatment for his sick child, Henry Segol, thirty years old, of 110 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, took the little one in his arms on Sunday afternoon and went from one hospital to another seeking admittance in vain because the child had measles.

The final match for the bowling championship of the east side was rolled last night at the Germania alleys between picked teams representing the Harlem League and the American National tournament. The result was a victory for the Harlem bowlers, who won two of the three games very handily, losing one toy six pins.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- The village of Old Bridge is discussing the wedding of Robert Benson and Miss Kate Roller of that village. Last Tuesday evening the Methodist Church of Old Bridge conducted a supper in Crescent Hall there. Mr. Benson and Miss Roller met at this supper, and although they had not previously been engaged, decided some time in the evening to get married.

Mr. Jean Gerardy, the young Belgian violoncello player, who made his first bow to an American audience three years ago as a juvenile prodigy, has returned an adult performer, and yesterday reappeared in a recital at Mendelssohn Hall. His programme consisted of the following numbers: Saint-Saens's concerto in A minor, two movements of Haydn's concerto in D major, a sonata by Boccherini, Schumann's "Abendlied," the familiar aria of Bach, and Popper's " Papillon."

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- A conference on "Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration," under the auspices of the National Civic Federation, began here this morning. Steinway Hall was only half filled when the speaking began, but Secretary Ralph M. Easley of the Civic Federation declared that the numerous labor leaders present from various points of the country formed a good return on the invitations sent out.

Charges of misconduct and malfeasance in office have been preferred against District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner by Deputy Attorney General John Henry Hammond. Only five days are given the District Attorney in which to answer or appear in person before the Governor in his own defense.

That is a curious announcement which was made yesterday, that the progress at the negotiations with China had been arrested by Great Britain. Great Britain has shown, all through this wretched business, so much amiability and so strong a desire that the action of the Western world, including Japan, should be harmonious, that an objection on her part would carry a very particular weight.

DANVILLE, Ky., Dec. 17 -- Stuart Robson, the actor, had a narrow escape from death yesterday while traveling on the Queen and Crescent Railway. Two revolver bullets, coming from a hill top near the tracks, passed through the windows of Robson's compartment and shattered the woodwork over his head.

The inability to bring the Maurice Grau Opera Company into this city earlier than to-night worked to advantage in more ways than one. The eleven weeks' engagement concluded last Saturday night by the Metropolitan English Grand Opera Company brought more wear and tear on the interior furnishings of the Metropolitan Opera House than this house had ever before been subjected to.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Two more cases of smallpox developed in this city to-day, making three that are now being treated here, and the people of the city are panic-stricken.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 17. -- Fire entailing a loss of $400,000 and throwing 1,200 men out of employment practically destroyed the entire plant of the Brown Hoisting and Machinery Company early this morning.

The Church and Society of the Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street, near Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn, met last night and decided to issue a call to the Rev. Dr. Parkes Cadman, pastor of the Metropolitan Temple, Manhattan, to succeed the late Rev. Dr. A.J.F. Behrends in the pastorate of the church.

Clinton Marshall, one of the three Bellevue Hospital insane pavilion nurses charged last Wednesday by Coroners' Physician Donlon with having kicked and strangled to death Louis H. Hilliard, an insane patient, was arrested last night at the Bellevue Training School, foot of East Twenty-sixth Street, by Coroner Fitzpatrick and three Central Office detectives and remanded by the Coroner to the Tombs.

Hugh McLaughlin, the veteran leader of the Kings County Democracy, is ready for an open fight with Tammany Hall. He is ready to fight a Croker-Platt combination, and from statements made yesterday by Mr. McLaughlin to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter it was made plain that the Brooklyn leader has known of the friendly interchange of views between the representatives of Richard Croker in New York and those of Thomas C. Platt.
HARLEM OPERA HOUSE -- The change of bill brought Miss Olga Nethersole in her play of " Sapho," which will be continued for the remaining part of this week.

With a hotly contested game, in which John A. Hendrick of this city defeated Albert G. Cutler of Boston by a margin of only 3 points, the National Class B billiard tournament, which for the past two weeks has been in progress under the sanction of the Amateur Athletic Union at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, last night was brought to a close.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate Committee on Military Affairs to-day referred the Army Reorganization bill to a sub-committee consisting of Senators Hawley, (Rep., Conn.,) Proctor, (Rep., Vt.,) Sewell, (Rep., N.J.,) Cockrell, (Dem., Mo.,) and Harris, (Pop., Kan.)

In the following list "mtg" stands for mort- gage and "R.S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 ot consideration. This "considera- tion" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Aldace P. Walker, Chairman of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Board of Directors, returned from a Western trip, during which he attended the annual meeting of the road's stockholders. He says that traffic is very heavy, fruit shipments from Southern California especially having broken all records.

Draperies around the large painting "The Last Meeting," which for the last three months had been on exhibition at 1,132 Broadway, caught fire at 10:55 o'clock yesterday morning, and before the flames were extinguished they had gutted the building, destroying the picture and its accessories and placing half a dozen people in great peril.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- The Rev. Cyrus Augustus Bartol, D.D., for nearly twenty-five years pastor of the West Unitarian Church here and for a quarter of a century an assistant to the Rev. Charles Lowell, D.D., formerly pastor of the church, is dead, after a two weeks' illness from bronchitis.
The meeting of the Central City Committee of the Citizens' Union, at 42 East Twenty-third Street, last night, was marked by a large attendance. R. Fulton Cutting presided.

George W. De Lano, the lawyer and Trustee of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, was placed under cross-examination yesterday in the contest over the will of Helen C. Brush, in which she left the residue of her estate, over $50,000, to the church. Her brother, who is contesting the will, alleges undue influence on the part of members of the church in inducing his sister to make the will.

Trading in the outside market yesterday broadened out considerably, and a number of issues showed fair activity. Prices advanced in sympathy with the Stock Exchange market, and closing figures in many cases showed substantial net gains. The several groups of stocks each supplied one or more active issues, and all told the market showed more life than it has on any recent day.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 17 -- Mme. Schumann Heinck was to have given a recital here last night, and a couple of thousand people gathered in the Baker Theatre to hear her. To their astonishment, an employe of the theatre came forward and stated that the artiste had refused to sing. The house cleared as if by magic, and many expressions of disappointment were heard.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- "Major" Taylor, the colored bicyclist of Worcester, to-day signed an agreement to race in Europe during July and August of next year.

Henry Johnson's attempt to rob the store of M.E. Fajus W.B. Pahelram, importers of East India goods, at 15 East Seventeenth Street, will probably result in his losing his life. A private detective shot him in the head and stomach while he was trying to make his escape in the elevator.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 17 -- Senator Money's (Dem., Miss.,) intimation, on Friday last, to the Senate, that his cotton claim bill would have to be considered before the session is over, or something might happen, was not meant, according to the Senator's statement to-day, to be understood as a menace.

Henry Rutgers Beekman, a Justice of the Supreme Court, died suddenly yesterday morning in the vestibule of his own home, at 35 West Seventeenth Street. He had started for the County Court House when he became ill and returned home. Before he could use his latchkey and open the door he fell dead.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The Industrial Commission began a special session at the Manufacturers' Club here to-day, and representatives of all the important industries in Pennsylvania have been invited to appear. The first witness was J. Gordon Grey, Secretary of the Manufacturers' Club and head of the firm of Queen Co., manufacturers of optical goods.
BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 17 -- A resort which is intended to be an American Monte Carlo was opened to-day at Chesapeake Beach, a beautiful bluff on the Chesapeake Bay, in Calvert County, Md.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Col. John G. Parke, who was retired from the United States Army July 2, 1889, died at his residence here yesterday of a complication of diseases incident to old age.

The devotional fervor and the temporary renunciation of objects of dross by the feminine worshippers at St. Patrick's Cathedral have lately developed a new species of thief. As yet he has confined himself to the cathedral.

Tammany is simply out of money. Supplies from shame run low in Manhattan, for folks are aroused there. Brooklyn must be "worked." The officers who would not "work" are sent away. Those relied on to "work" it are put in their places. Thus the compact was broken, and that is why it was broken.
ATLANTA, Dec. 17 -- The Atlanta Journal this afternoon published an interview with ex-President Cleveland obtained by a staff correspondent at Princeton, N.J. Mr. Cleveland is quoted as follows:
Alderman Marks married Mr. Henry Lum, late of China, and Miss Dia Hia, a daughter of one of the exclusive Chinese families of Mott Street, in the City Hall yesterday.
The most striking fact in connection with the so-called Ship Subsidy bill now before the Senate is that it is not in the least adapted to secure a single one of its professed aims.

DAVID H. NICHOLS, Lieutenant Governor of Colorado from 1893 to 1895, died last night at his home, near Boulder, Col. He was born in Hardwick, Vt., in 1826. He was a veteran of the Mexican war. He had resided in Colorado since 1859.

The managers of the various telegraph companies which employ messengers in the financial district have announced their intention of taking active and stringent measures against the gang of what they call "grafters," who display much ingenuity in devising means to get money from the many banking and brokerage firms in that district.

Hall J. How Co. have sold to John Bannen the plot of four lots on the north side of One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, 143 feet west of St. Nicholas Avenue. Mr. Barmen will erect thereon a seven-story apartment house, with stores, from plans by Neville Bagge.

Controller Coler gave out yesterday his fourth itemized statement concerning the expenditures and per capita cost and other items of the city departments, taking the Department of Parks. He had previously given out similar statements, taking the Departments of Education, Fire, and Police. The object of the statements is to make the budget of 1901 readable for the general public, as in its regular form it is only understandable by those who issued it.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- The taking of testimony in the case of Oscar L. Booz, the former West Point cadet who died two weeks ago from injuries which his parents allege were inflicted at the West Point Military Academy, was begun to-day by the board of inquiry appointed by the Secretary of War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Just before adjournment, late this afternoon, the Senate gave its consent to a fixing of a definite time to vote upon the Hay-Pauncefote treaty.
