Senators Money (Dem., Miss.,) and Mason (Rep., Ill.,) had occupied the time of the executive session in making speeches upon the treaty, and when Mr. Mason, who was the last speaker, concluded, Senator Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) renewed his request to take a vote next Thursday.
The skating season opened yesterday, when the red ball was hoisted at Crotona and Van Cortlandt Paris Lakes in the Borough of the Bronx.
It was in the Kansas City platform of BRYAN that the Hay-Pauncefote treaty was condemned as "a surrender of American rights and interests, not to be tolerated by the American people."

Heavy seas and rough winds buffeted the Cunard Line steamship Umbria so fiercely on her just completed trip from the other side that she arrived here yesterday with her sides looking as if they had not been painted for years, her deck railings battered out of shape in many places and most of her deck furniture missing altogether.

One of the most exciting meetings in the history of the Republican Club was held last night at the headquarters of the organization, 450 Fifth Avenue. Interest centred largely in the make-up of the ticket presented by the Nominating Committee, as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Great Britain's objection to the protocol drawn up by the Peking envoys is to the use of the word "irrevocable." This word is also obnoxious to the United States, and there is no doubt that Great Britain will have American support in her efforts to amend the protocol so as to omit this word.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Bonds of the National Asphalt Company fell from 40 to 33 1/2 to-day, because of the action of the President of Venezuela, who on Dec. 13 attempted to annul the exclusive right of the company to mine asphalt in the State of Bermudez.

The State Court of Claims met yesterday in the City Court Building and took testimony in the claims of the heirs of John George Leake against the State. The action is to recover $86,608.35, the amount realized by the State from the sale of the property of Mr. Leake, which escheated to the State because he was supposed to have no heirs.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day, in the debate on the Amnesty bill, M. Vazeille (Radical Socialist) moved an amendment excluding forgers and false witnesses from its provisions, He explained that ordinary criminals should never be allowed to profit by amnesty.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17. -- There was a marked improvement to-day in some directions in the local list, but it was not uniform. While the prices in the general list were being braced by the buoyancy in New York, the Asphalt issues began to fall again, and this put a damper upon the improving tendency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The President and Mrs. McKinley are entertaining exSecretary and Mrs. Day of Canton, Ohio, who arrived at the White House to-day. The President gave an informal dinner party in their honor this evening.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- At the secret consistory held to-day the Pope appointed a number of Bishops, including Mgr. Keane, formerly Rector of the Catholic University at Washington, to the Archdiocese of Dubuque.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day argument was begun in two cases, the decision of which is expected to fix the status of Porto Rico and the Philippine Islands and other insular possessions acquired through the war with Spain, with respect to the United States proper, to say whether their people are citizens, and to indicate whether the Constitution follows the flag.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- The courtroom in the old Westchester County Court House was crowded this morning when the trial of Edgar C. Burnz for the murder of Herbert B. Fellows, Postmaster and station agent at Scarsdale, was begun before Judge Martin J. Keogh. It is understood that the defense will attempt to show that Burnz inherited insanity and was also a victim of excessive cigarette smoking.

The annual meeting of the National Rifle Association of America was held yesterday afternoon in the office of Gen. George W. Wingate, 20 Nassau Street, when a new Board of Directors and officers for the year were elected, and a considerable amount of accumulated business was transacted. The meeting was the first held since the reorganization of the association.

BOONEVILLE, Ind., Dec. 17 -- John Rolla, the third of the colored men implicated in the murder of Hollie Simons, the Rockport barber who was robbed before being killed, was hanged to a tree in the Court House yard by a mob of about 100 men from Rockport this evening. Two of his companions were lynched at Rockport last night for the same crime.

BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- Boston had a continuance of broad trading and further gains in prices among the copper shares. Montana was active, gaining to 333; Tri-Mountain was in brisk demand, with a gain of 1 1/4, to 20 1/4, some 1,500 shares selling in the morning. Parrot gained 1 1/4, to 50 3/4. Amalgamated, Isle Royale, and Old Dominion were prominent.

WEST POINT, Dec. 18 -- The military court of inquiry which began taking testimony in Bristol, Penn., yesterday, arrived at the Military Academy this afternoon and resumed the investigation of the charges of hazing and brutal treatment made by the parents of former Cadet Oscar L. Booz, who died a couple of weeks ago in his home, in Bristol, Penn.

In a market in which there were many features. Nickel Plate stocks were on the Exchange yesterday easily the leaders, the second preferred advancing over 5 points and the common and first preferred over 2 each on dealings showing much more activ- ity than for some time has been seen in the securities.

The song "Dear Midnight of Love," the words and music of which are by "Bathhouse John" Coughlin, Alderman of Chicago, has stirred up feelings of jealousy among the members of the New York Board of Aldermen. At the meeting held yesterday it became known that Alderman Coughlin had sent to each member of the New York board a copy of his song with a "Merry Christmas and Happy New Year from New York to Chicago."

Clinton L. Marshall, Edward O. Dean, and J.R. Davis, the three nurses from the Bellevue Hospital pavilion for the insane, who were arrested night before last on the charge of having beep instrumental in causing the death of Louis H. Hilliard, a patient in the pavilion, were taken before Coroner Fitzpatrick yesterday morning.

Trading in outside stocks yesterday was not as broad as on Monday, and there was a considerable falling off in the total of the day's transactions, but nevertheless a few issues showed much strength and considerable activity. Some stocks seemed to be in good general demand, but in many issues there seemed to be few buying orders.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- A rumor was current in railroad circles in Milwaukee early today that A.J. Earling, President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, had tendered his resignation with a request that it be acted upon immediately. To-day Mr. Earling said that there was absolutely no truth in the rumor that he had resigned or intended to resign.

Franklin Pettit has resold, through Charles E. Schuyler Co., the plot of about six and one-half lots at the south-west corner of Broadway and Sixty-seventh Street, fronting 112 feet on Broadway and 137 feet on the street. The buyer, August M. Bruggeman, will erect on the site a ten-story apartment hotel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Before the adjournment of the Senate to-morrow it is expected by the majority of that body that the Hay-Pauncefote treaty or what is left of that convention will be ratified, and the men who speak more confidently of the prospect are sure that the treaty, as amended, will be approved by Great Britain.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- In his speech at the annual conference of the National Union of Conservative Associations yesterday Lord Salisbury alluded to the war in South Africa.

HUGH, McLAUGHLIN's rage against Chief DEVERY is the most becoming emotion that has stirred his bosom for many years. The motive is ignoble, and therefore characteristic, but the desire to destroy DEVERY is so wholesome a passion that its base origin is readily overlooked.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 @ 65. There were no sales.

Chief William S. Devery went on his vacation yesterday morning. He did not, however, leave it to Senior Deputy Chief Moses W. Cortright to announce his season of rest from police duty to the force, but caused the following announcement to be sent to all commands and superior officers late on Monday night:

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The conference of employers and labor leaders held here under the auspices of the Civic Federation for the purpose of effecting a basis of permanent reconciliation between capital and labor ended its sessions to-night after adopting resolutions looking to the establishment of industrial peace.

We have received some confirmation, in the way of actual testimony, of the belief about the motives and action of Great Britain with reference to the peace negotiations in China, which we had announced without any special information, and solely upon what lawyers call "the reason of the thing."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- It was announced to-day that Great Britain had nothing, to do with the drafting of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty. The treaty as it went to the Senate was exactly as Secretary Hay wrote it, without the slightest modification by Great Britain. This announcement was made at the State Department, and it is taken to indicate that Secretary Hay means to give battle to his enemies.
Miss Jennie P. Demming, fifty-five years old, was found dead in her apartments, at 400 West Twenty-third Street, at 10:30 o'clock last night. She had been asphyxiated by illuminating gas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Senator Morgan, (Dem., Ala.,) Chairman of the Senate Committee on Interoceanic Canals, to which was referred the preliminary report of the Isthmian Canal Commission, to-day submitted a partial report thereon, in connection with the protocols of agreements with Costa Rica and Nicaragua, relating to the proposed canal, which were submitted recently to the Senate.

Wearing an air of mysterious importance Detectives Snydecker and Hahn, attached to the Oak Street Station, hurried into the Centre Street Court about 10 o'clock yesterday morning and in low tones asked of Magistrate Flammer a warrant for the arrest of the proprietor "of one of the biggest poolrooms down town."
The Municipal Assembly decided yesterday that the city should hold a twentieth century celebration at midnight on Dec. 31, and $5,000 may be appropriated for the purpose.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Dec. 18 -- Navigation on the chain of great lakes closed to-day. The last vessel up-bound with coal has arrived at Milwaukee, and the few boats which were carrying iron-ore cargoes have reached their destinations at the lower lake ports. By Saturday all the vessels which came inside the harbors to-day will be laid up for the Winter, and the work of repairing and rebuilding will have begun.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 18 -- There was evidence of increased interest over the will of Edgar B. Duryea, the starch manufacturer, when the hearing was resumed this morning, before Surrogate Seabury. The three daughters of Mr. Duryea, Mrs. Eva D. Thelberg, Mrs. Grace Sprigg, both with their husbands, and Mrs. Marcia V.D. Cox, were present.

-- Of the many mysteries connected with "Christian Science," not the least interesting and suggestive is that presented by the maintenance of a so-called Board of Lectureship, the apparent object of which is to send specially trained and instructed speakers from city to city, delivering speeches in public halls and so supplementing the work of the scattered "churches."

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- William A. Lewis, as Special Master, to-day filed a report in the Court of Chancery recommending a divorce in favor of Dr. Louis W. Dodson of Jersey City. The divorce is recommended on the grounds of desertion.

A documentary expose of the political pressure successfully exercised by Senator Thomas C. Platt, Irving L. Hommedieu, Republican State Committeeman of the Thirtieth Congressional District, and Col. William J. Youngs, Gov. Roosevelt's private secretary, to secure the contract for the Medina armory building for Filkins De Graff, their political friends, as against Thomas F. Whalen of Ogdensburg, a Democrat, whose bid was the lowest, was made in The New York Journal yesterday.

The committee of the National Civil Service Reform League appointed to investigate the condition of the Federal civil service and the enforcement of the reform law and rules under the present Administration, has submitted its report, in which it says:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to correct the surmise which closes the editorial about the White House in to-day's TIMES.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- A Peking dispatch to The Pall Mall Gazette, dated Dec. 17, says:

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- While neither Secretary William J. Youngs nor Adjt. Gen. Hoffman would deny the authenticity of the Senator Platt correspondence relative to the letting of the Medina Armory contract to Filkins De Graff, they refused to make any statement for publication. Secretary Youngs was at the Executive Chamber, but confined himself to the remark: "I will not discuss it and have no statement to make."

Team racing was the most interesting feature of yesterday afternoon's sport on the Speedway, when James Murphy's famous pacing team, Tom and Lotus, had a series of brushes that were among the best witnessed this Fall. The team was in unusually fine condition, and ready to meet all comers.

One peculiar feature in the career of Justice BEEKMAN was the fact that the public service which he rendered was chiefly outside of the range of his profession, while his profession itself was literally a vocation, in the old sense of the word -- an occupation to which he had been called by nature.

The sporting benefit for the family of the late Hugh S. Hart, turf reporter and sporting writer, drew a fairly good attendance to the amusement hall in Grand Central Palace last night, and with the advance sale of tickets netted nearly $500, for the fund. The entertainment was of a mixed character, a few vocal efforts being sandwiched in among such exhibitions of a sporting and athletic nature as could be put upon the stage.

A large audience of representative Brooklyn people assembled last evening in Association Hall, Fulton and Bond Streets, to do honor to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Richard Salter Storrs, at a memorial service held under the auspices of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences. A. Augustus Healy, the President, made the opening address, and introduced the other speakers, President Seth Low of Columbia University, and the Rev. Dr. Washington Gladden of Columbus, Ohio.

The programme for to-day is not an overfull one. The wedding of Thomas Entwisle Peters and Miss Gladys Whitin at Grace Church, at 8.30 P.M., will be the principal event of the afternoon. There are to be several "at homes." including those of Mrs. Charles Addison Miller of 26 West Thirty-seventh Street and of Mrs. Alfred Ely and Miss Helena Rutherfurd Ely, at 175 Second Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Arguments in the Porto Rico-Philippine cases, involving the status of those islands, were resumed in the United States Supreme Court to-day. The widespread interest in the cases was shown by a large attendance of prominent members of the bar and by a crowd of spectators which filled the public area and overflowed into the corridor.

Sigmund Stern, a law clerk, living at 270 Bowery, prided himself until yesterday upon his grasp of the intricacies of law. "Oh, you can't touch me legally, your Honor. I know the law, you know," he exclaimed in a confident tone, addressing Magistrate Crane in the Essex Market Police Court.

When Christian Science healers treat contagious diseases they do not notify the Department of Health that such cases exist, as it is against the rules of their Church, although it is one of the laws and rules which are mandatory as to all regular physicians. This fact was brought out yesterday at the hearing of the contest of the will of Miss Helen C. Brush before Surrogate Fitzgerald.

MEDINA DEPOT, N.Y., Dec. 18 --- Both Mr. L'Hommedieu, the Orleans County Republican leader, and Mr. Filkins, the Republican politician and quarry owner who was the senior member of the firm to which the contract for the Medina Armory was awarded, made statements to-night. Mr. L'Hommedieu says: "I was interested to the extent that I wished Filkins Degraff to obtain this contract.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Henry Labouchere, discussing the Hay-Pauncefote canal treaty in Truth, says:
Fire practically ruined the remainder of the stock or woolen goods of the late firm of William L. Strong Co., at 75 and 77 Worth Street, last night.

The final match for the bowling championship of the west side was rolled last night at Schlusing's Columbia alleys between picked teams representing the National and Columbia Bowling Leagues, respectively. The Columbia team, which was on its home alleys, won all three games, which made the result a tie on games, as the National team had won the three games in the first, series last week.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- "Great Britain's proposed alterations in the preamble of the joint note have been practically accepted by all the powers," says the Peking correspondent of The Daily Mail, wiring Monday. "Both Russia and Japan, whose support was regarded as doubtful, have agreed.

We note with satisfaction the signs of an organized movement in this city to promote the adoption of the general plan of charter revision proposed by the commission appointed by Gov. ROOSEVELT. The action of the Citizens' Union in this direction is likely to be followed and to be in itself influential.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- At the convocation exercises of the University of Chicago to- day President Harper announced that John D. Rockefeller had made another gift of $1,500,000 to the institution.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The whole day was occupied in a spirited contest over a Senate bill to change the terminal facilities of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company in this city and elevate the tracks of that company across the Mall, south of Pennsylvania Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- John G.A. Leishman, now United States Minister to Switzerland, was selected to-day to be Minister to Constantinople, and his name was sent to the Senate by the President.

An informal closed meeting of the Automobile Club of America was held last evening at the clubrooms, in the Waldorf-Astoria. The new President, Albert R. Shattuck, presided, and several members gave short talks regarding their touring experiences, both in this country and in Europe.

FILKINS was right. He understood PLATT perfectly. He was in need. One WHALEN of Ogdensburg, who shamelessly admits that he is a Democrat, had un- derbid the firm of FILKINS on a State contract for building an armory at Medina, and there were many reasons, among them the plain requirements of the law, for supposing that the contract would be awarded to the lower bidder.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- The stock market presented a cheerful aspect to-day. The dampening influence that had hung over the market in the form of persistent weakness in the Asphalt issues was partially removed by the official statement issued by the National and American interests, and the effect was beneficial upon not only the securities directly, concerned, but upon the market generally.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 -- The Supreme Court of Missouri, sitting at Jefferson City, today handed down an opinion in the case of the Star Publishing Company versus The Associated Press of Illinois, deciding the case unanimously in favor of The Associated Press.

The Rev. WILLIS E. DUDLEY, pastor of the First Congregational Church of Niagara Falls, died yesterday of typhoid fever. He was thirty-five years of age, a former newspaper man, and one of the most popular clergymen of Niagara Falls.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- The Republican majority of the House of Assembly met in caucus this afternoon in the Assembly' Chamber.

What will be, perhaps, to most American readers the most striking fact about Lord SALISBURY'S address yesterday before the National Union of Conservative Associations will be its omissions. We could not have expected him to refer to the question of the canal, even if that were as burning a question in London as it is in Washington, as we all know it not to be.
Vice Chancellor Emery at Jersey City yesterday continued the hearing in the divorce suit of James Bathgate of the Park National Bank, Manhattan, against his wife, Grace.
Capt. Edward Sycamore, who is to sail Sir Thomas Lipton's new challenger Shamrock II. in the International races next year, has been elected Deputy Mayor of Brightlingsea; England.
A Tufts College combination hockey team has been organized at College Hill. Arthur P. Williams, Jr., '02, was elected Captain, and A.W. Robinson, M.S., '03, manager.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A closed carriage drove up to St. Stephen's Church, at Pennsylvania Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, this afternoon. Although not more than half a dozen persons had entered the church before the carriage arrived, it was rumored that a wedding was to take place, and several people were idling near waiting for a glimpse of the bride and groom.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 18 -- The Princeton University hockey team was defeated here to-night at the ice palace by the Quaker City Club players by the score of 4 goals to 0. It was the return match between the two teams and Capt. Little's men were determined to retrieve the defeat of their first visit if possible.

Continued strength and activity showed in the stock market yesterday in the face of heavy realizing sales both for London and for home account. Recorded transactions passed the 1,200,000 mark, while the actual transfers of stock undoubtedly again went nearly to two millions.

The first night of foreign opera at the Metropolitan Opera House last evening brought for the sixteenth time the usual display of wealth and fashion in the boxes and orchestra stalls, and a house in which every seat was taken, and in which hundreds of men and women stood in the spaces back of the parquet the performance through.

District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner, with all of his assistants mentioned in the charges of Deputy Attorney General John Henry Hammond, alleging misconduct and malfeasance in office, will appear before Gov. Roosevelt in Albany Saturday to enter personal denial to each allegation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Much opposition is developing in the House of Representatives to the Hopkins plan of passing an Apportionment bill retaining the present membership of 357. The chief argument advanced by the sponsors of this measure is that the chamber of the House is now filled to its capacity, and that the members who sit furthest from the Speaker can neither hear nor be heard when they address the chamber.

The officers of the American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that the plans to acquire the properties of M. Guggenheim's Sons, the only large competitor with which the trust has tad to contend, were practically completed.

Officials of the Glucose Trust, otherwise known as the Glucose Sugar Refining Company, heard with surprise yesterday that a big plant for the refining of glucose was being projected by a combination of men most of whom are connected with the Standard Oil Company. Ground for this plant has already been broken at Shadyside, N.J., which is opposite West Sixtieth Street.

If Great Britain had not so many troubles of her own, mainly connected with South Africa, more attention would doubtless have been given, during the present session of Parliament, to the condition of things in China. The full reports of the debates on the address to the throne are interesting and instructive, but they do not shed much light on this particular topic.
Louis Stix, Treasurer of the Dry Goods Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following subscriptions from the trade received to date:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- To-morrow, according to agreement, the Senate will reach B. vote on the Hay-Pauncefote treaty, and will assert to the extent a two-thirds majority shall determine its co-ordinate right to negotiate treaties. The vote might have been taken to-day, for when upon Senator Lodge's motion the doors were closed and be called up the treaty, no Senator evinced a desire to speak upon it.

Anthony Comstoek, Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, yesterday issued a statement replying to the recent criticisms made by F. Norton Goddard respecting his attitude toward policy shops and his suggestions of legislative methods of dealing with them.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The United States Navy, by agreement with the Juvenile Court here, is to become a reform school for unruly Chicago boys. The John Worthy School, accordingly, will lose scores of the older lads sent there for correction. Boys out on probation and under supervision of officers will be picked up, and future candidates for the institution will be sent to the Government's training ships.

Gen. Francis Vinton Greene will not accept a re-election as President of the Republican County Committee. He has so declared in a letter to the executive branch of the organization, which met yesterday. Gen. Greene was not present, and William H. Ten Eyck presided. In his letter Gen. Greene said:

Chief of Police William S. Devery made it plain yesterday in a dictated statement that the police situation is narrowed down to an issue between him and Bernard J. York, President of the Police Board, and that the Chief's attitude toward the Willoughby Street Democracy is a minor factor in affairs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Board on Naval Construction to-day completed its report. Although lacking as it does the signature of one absent member, it is still subject to change. The result of to-day's meeting was to disturb slightly the scheme of award of contracts for the battleships and cruisers arranged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Senate to-day in executive session took up the treaty with Spain providing for the cession to the United States of the Philippine Islands of Cibutu, Cagayan, and Sulu and their dependencies, in consideration of the payment to Spain of $100,000.
Democrats of the Fifth Assembly District tendered to State Senator Bernard F. Martin a banquet last night at the St. Denis Hotel, in recognition of the twentieth year of his district leadership.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 19 -- On the first of the new year independent window glass manufacturers with a pot capacity from 900 to 1,000 will open offices in Pittsburg of a joint selling, agency company to be operated on the lines of the dissolved American Glass Company. An all-day meeting at the Hotel Henry, closing at midnight, organized the Independent Glass Company, chartered a few days ago under the laws of New Jersey.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity, above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The following table contains a statement of the popular vote on the 6th of November, 1900, in all the States of the United States, for Presidential Electors on the Republican, Democratic, Prohibition, People's Party, Social Democratic Party, and Social Labor Party, as officially ascertained.
NEWPORT, Dec. 19 -- The messenger boys of the telegraph offices were surprised to-day by receiving Christmas remembrances from W.K. Vanderbilt, Paul A. Andrews, and Dr. D.H. Hayden.

Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller announced yesterday that he would investigate thoroughly the allegations of Dr. Lent and Thomas D. Wright that patients in the insane and alcoholic wards of Bellevue Hospital are inhumanly and brutally treated. The Commissioner yesterday sent four deputies to interview, as far as possible, all the patients who were inmates of the wards during the time that Wright wag a patient there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The full Senate Committee on Military Affairs has adopted the Army Reorganization bill reported by its sub-committee. The measure is a complete substitute for the House bill, and while much of the language is the same as that of the House measure, there are numerous changes.

The annual meeting for the election of officers of the Medico-Legal Society was held last night at the Hotel St. Andrew, Seventy-second Street and Broadway. About forty members of the society were present, and the following officers were elected for the ensuing year:
CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- A proposition to sail the Canadian races off Buffalo at the time of the Pan-American Exposition has been received from F.B. Hower, Commodore of the Buffalo Yacht Club.
UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The Hamilton College football team has selected Nelson L. Drummond, '02, of Auburn, Captain for next season. Drummond plays left end.

Pawing the air wildly and gibbering to themselves, many Brooklyn elevated railroad conductors, on the verge of raving lunacy, sought their homes last night, a day that had tried their souls very happily over. It was all due to the new order abolishing smoking cars on the elevated in Brooklyn.

What is technically known as Group VIII. of the New York State Bankers' Association, really the bankers off old New York, representing one of the largest moneyed interests in the world, sat down to their annual dinner last night in the large ballroom of the Waldorf-Aatoria.

For the second night of the season of opera in several foreign tongues at the Metropolitan Opera House, Mr. Maurice Grau offered "Tannhauser and die Saengerkrieg auf Wartburg," grand romantic opera in three acts, the book and the music by Wilhelm Richard Wagner, first performed at the Royal Court Theatre in Dresden on Oct. 19, 1845.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Money was firm to-day, and discounts had a hardening tendency. There was much nervousness regarding future developments. The present rates are subject to the bank rate to-morrow, and will be relieved at midday, when it is decided.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19. -- Acting Adjt. Gen. Ward to-day received a cable message from Gen. MacArthur at Manila saying that Capt. Montgomery D. Parker of the Eighth Infantry died in the Military Hospital sit Manila on the night of the 17th inst. of dysentery and liver trouble. Capt. Parker was born in Massachusetts June 20, 1851, and was appointed Second Lieutenant of the Ninth Cavalry Sept. 1, 1879.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statement as to the "Equality of the Sexes" found in the "Heard About Town" column for Dec. 17, brings a quiet smile to the face. There seems to be work for each, and room for improvement in each. Possibly the "complaining" is a confession of weakness on the one side.

The methods used by Christian Scientists to obtain death certificates for members of their organization who die were disclosed at the hearing in the Brush will contest yesterday. The Scientists are absolutely opposed to physicians and the administration of medicines. One of the laws of the State requires that a physician shall sign a death certificate, and that he shall have been in attendance on the patient a certain length of time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The whole story of the bungle at Peking is now known, and it is apparent that there have been some very queer doings in that capital.

Prices moved irregularly on the stock market yesterday in the early trading, with strength appearing in some issues, and, because of profit-taking and short selling, heaviness in others. The general tone, however, was strong, and substan- tial interests continued in evidence as purchasers on a large scale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Attorney General Griggs recently attracted some attention by protesting to Congress against the proposition to erect a building for the Department of Justice, at a cost of about $1,000,000, that would be smaller than he considered desirable, and at a limit of cost that would compel its erection in a manner and with material that would not satisfy the improved taste in the matter of public buildings.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The War Office last evening would give no information regarding the reports of a Boer invasion of Cape Colony. The officials expressed the opinion, however, that the newspaper accounts were exaggerated, but at the same time admitted that probably the troops which have been employed in chasing Gen. De Wet would be diverted to deal with the invaders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The special committee appointed by Speaker Henderson to investigate the circumstances connected with the death of Oscar L. Booz held its first meeting to-day, and decided to enter upon the investigation immediately after the holiday recess.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Contracts were awarded to-day by the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company to the Neafie Levy Ship and Engine Building Company for the construction of one steel seagoing tug to be named the Carlisle. She will be 170 feet in length, 29 feet beam, and 15 feet draught, loaded, and is intended for service in the Philadelphia and Reading Transportation Line, operating between Port Richmond and New England ports.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- The Globe this evening says: "From a reliable source The Globe learns that the Hotel Touraine suicide, 'Edward Blake of New York,' about whom there has been so much mystery on the part of the hotel people, the Board of Health, the Medical Examiner, and the undertaker who prepared the body for shipment, was none other than Edward Blake Brace of London Park, Baltimore, Md.

An explosion of chemicals in the etching room on the third floor of The Herald Building last evening probably fatally burned two engravers -- Charles S. Hennessy, thirty-eight, of 722 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, and Fred Scheele of 16 Bergen Street, Brooklyn -- and seriously burned Herman Sorensten of 203 East Forty-sixth Street, Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Some unexpected trouble is looming up for Mr. Hopkins, the Chairman of the House Census Committee, and for his plan to reapportion the representation of the States in the Fifty-eighth Congress.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 19 -- In the hearing to-day on the petition for a pardon in the case of David L. Stain and Oliver Cromwell, both of whom are serving life sentences in the State Prison, at Thomaston, for the murder of John Wilson Barron, Cashier of the Dexter (Me.) Savings Bank, in February, 1876, the most notable testimony was that given by Charles F. Stain in the form of a deposition.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Dec. 19 -- The Earl of Hopetoun, Governor General of the Commonwealth of Australia, has requested William John Lyne, the Premier of New South Wales, to form the first Federal Ministry. Mr. Lyne is considering the proposition.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Ex-President Grover Cleveland contributes to this week's issue of the Saturday Evening Post of Philadelphia an extended article on the plight of the Democracy and the remedy. Mr. Cleveland begins by reviewing the history of the party, and he discusses its defects since 1864, in detail.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The most important evidence taken during the trial here of Edgar C. Burnz for the murder of Herbert B. Fellows, the Scarsdale station agent and Postmaster, was that at Mrs. Ida C. Angel of Scarsdale. Mrs. Angel testified that on the night of the murder she had given her son, Stephen Leroy, a fifty-cent piece with which to pay Station Agent Fellows the express charges on a package.
Vice Chancellor Emery at Jersey City has reserved decision in the divorce suit brought by James Bathgate of the Park National Bank, Manhattan, against his wife, Grace, which was concluded yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- Lehigh Valley and Reading first preferred dominated the trading in the Philadelphia market. In Lehigh Navigation there was a reversal of its course; of yesterday, the stock declining 2 points from last night's close. The story of a prospective lease of the property to the Jersey Central was declared, by officials of the Lehigh Company to-day to have been all imaginary.

Louis Stuyvesant Chanter, after securing the acquittal in General Sessions yesterday of Albert Albertson, charged with swindling Mrs. Mary O'Leary of $10,000, was amazed a short while later to be approached on the street by the weeping wife of his client, with the intelligence that Albertson had been rearrested on a similar charge as he came out of the courtroom.

CARLISLE, Penn., Dec. 19 -- In reply to a protest from Bishop Francis H. Hill of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, Major Richard H. Pratt, Superintendent of the Carlisle Indian School and an officer in the Tenth (colored) Cavalry, has written to Bishop Hill defending his assertions as to the benefits of slavery for the negro.

William C. Schermerhorn, Second Vice President of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, at Second Avenue and Thirteenth Street, yesterday presented to that institution $75,000. The money is to constitute a fund for the construction of a pavilion for patients afflicted with diseases of the ear.

When Moritz Rosenthal, the Roumanian piano whirlwind, made his first appearance before the connoiseurs of Gotham in the Fall of 1888 he was assisted in his concerts by a boy, who played the violin. This boy was an awkward youth, and the long Hessian boots which he wore did not add to the grace of his bearing, for they seemed to make him heavy-footed.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- The wife of John Duncan of Dayton, who ran away with George Matthews, her husband's farmhand, has returned, divorce proceedings have been stopped, and the couple have kissed and made up. It all came about through the good offices of Justice John M. Lucas of Prospect Plains.
The America bowlers of Elizabeth, N.J., won two games from the Corinthian team in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- George Mayor and Wilbur Olyan, both of Melrose, Lronx, had a lively ride this afternoon in a big steel motor vehicle which was capable of great speed. They started down the two-mile incline from Shannard Place toward the centre of the city. The street descends by a series of steep declines, at the foot of each being a level strip and then another drop.

Under the auspices of the Transvaal League there was held at Sherry's last night a meeting to arouse sympathy for the Boers in their struggle against England. An Englishman, Ernest Temple Hargrove, author of "World Politics," who spent eight months in South Africa during the heat of the struggle, spoke on "How Americans Can Help the Boers."
The America bowlers of Elizabeth, N.J., won two games from the Corinthian team in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- George Mayor and Wilbur Olyan, both of Melrose, Lronx, had a lively ride this afternoon in a big steel motor vehicle which was capable of great speed. They started down the two-mile incline from Shannard Place toward the centre of the city. The street descends by a series of steep declines, at the foot of each being a level strip and then another drop.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- While nothing had been heard from Mr. Conger up to a late hour to-night, regarding the agreement said to have been reached in Peking as to the terms of the joint China note, the officials confidently hope that the statements are correct, and that the way is now paved for its formal presentation to the Chinese plenipotentiaries.

MANILA, Dec. 19 -- To-morrow Gen. MacArthur will issue a proclamation warning the inhabitants of the archipelago that hereafter strict compliance with the laws of war will be required of non-combatants as well as combatants.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19. --The idea prevailed in the hog-product trading pit to-day that a number of prominent packers are about to lock horns as a result of an attempt on the part of the Cudahy interests to control the lard market, which, however, has only been partially successful up to the present time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Miss Frances Newlands, youngest daughter of Representative Newlands of Nevada, made her debut to-day at a tea at the town residence of her father, 1,607 H Street. This latest recruit to fashionable Washington has already enjoyed an extensive social experience, having seen something of English life in London with her aunt, Lady Hesketh, with whom she has spent several Summers.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Roosevelt arrived here from New York at 6:40 o'clock this evening and proceeded at once to the Executive Mansion. The Governor said that he intended to give a hearing on the charges preferred against Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, for alleged failure to prosecute offenders of the election law, on Saturday morning at the Executive Chamber.

Competition for the Abeel Trophy was begun last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, teams from Companies A, C, E, H, and K shooting. Company K, with a total score of 626, led by a comfortable margin among the fourteen teams competing last night, but thirteen teams from Companies B, D, F, G, and I have yet to shoot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Librarian Putnam of the Congressional Library has achieved a victory in the approval in committee of the amendment proposed by Senator McMillan of Michigan to the Legislative Appropriation bill by which $10,000 is to be allowed to pay the cost of keeping the Congressional Library and reading rooms open on Sundays from 2 o'clock in the afternoon to 10 at night.

BOSTON, Dec. 19 -- Boston had an active market and in most respects a strong one. Sugar was decidedly active; Chicago, Burlington and Quincy and Atchison were prominent; the good buying of Massachusetts Electric kept on, lifting the common to 27; Agricultural Chemical rose 5/8, to 27 1/2, preferred selling at 80, and Shoe Machinery was up 3/4, at 32 1/4.

A fire which caused a great deal, of excitement in the busy Borough Hall district, Brooklyn, and routed out the guests at the Clarendon Hotel, Washington and Johnson Streets, occurred at about 6 o'clock last evening in that house. For fear that the flames would spread through the hotel, and because of the close proximity of the Post Office and other large buildings, three alarms were sounded.

There were plenty of incidents connected with a big Harlem fire early last night, which was witnessed by an enormous crowd. The fire did $75,000 damage to the brick factory building 240, 242, and 244 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street and to the brown-stone dwellings at 254 and 256, next them.
Dr. CHARLES JAMES O'HAGAN of Greenville, N.C., one of the oldest and best-known physicians in that State, died suddenly Tuesday night of apoplexy.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Major Cuignet, who figured in the Dreyfus court-martial at Rennes, has been arrested and imprisoned in Fort Mont Valerien, where he is awaiting trial by court-martial on two charges.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 20 -- Oscar S. Straus, ex-United States Minister to Turkey, addressed the students of Harvard University in Sanders Theatre to-night on "The United States Doctrine of Citizenship and Expatriation."

Tenement house fires in Greater New York have been made the subject of an exhaustive special report issued in pamphlet form by the New York Tenement House Commission. The report, consisting of twenty-five pages with tables, was prepared by ex-Chief Hugh Bonner of the New York Fire Department and Lawrence Veiller, Secretary of the Tenement House Commission.

Company D of the Seventh Regiment, with a total score of 631, won the fifty-eighth competition for the Abeel Trophy, which was concluded last night at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-seventh Street. Company K's team, which made a score of 626 on the first night of the match, stands second to the winners.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- Prices dragged along to-day in a perfunctory way, with alternate movements of strength and heaviness, but with the drift downward. After three days of neglect Union Traction rose strongly, but it was alone in this respect. The news of a threatened revolution in Venezuela knocked the asphalt issues down again, but there was excellent buying of the first 5s around 62.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Very little effort is being made to keep secret the lines of the Lawson cup defender. The Crowninshield model already has been shown to a number of local yachtsmen. Some minor modifications are expected, but Mr. Crowninshield's chief ideas will be carried out in the construction.

The opening game of the Amateur League Hockey season at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening furnished a brilliant and spectacular contest. The New York Athletic Club won from the Hockey Club by the score of 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The closing argument in the Philippines-Porto Rico cases was made in the United States Supreme Court to-day, and the cases were submitted for the final adjudication of the court. The crowds which have filled the chamber since the cases were taken up were again on hand in re-enforced numbers, entirely occupying the quarters reserved for the bar and the outer area for the public.

J.G. Stowe, Consul General of the United States to South Africa, with headquarters at Cape Town, arrived here on his vacation on the new Red Star liner Vaderland yesterday. He has not been in America for three years, and leaves for his home in Kansas City, Mo., to-day in order to spend Christmas with his family, who left Cape Town in June last.

The withdrawal of Gen. FRANCIS V. GREENE from the Chairmanship of the Republican County Committee is a matter for regret to all who desire the regeneration of our city and its rescue from the evil organization that was fastened upon it in 1897 by the policy of the Republican machine at that time.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Gov. Roosevelt will dispose of the charges preferred against Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, on Saturday next. Col. Gardiner on that day will be given an opportunity at a public hearing to be given at the Executive Chamber to present in person or through counsel an oral argument in refutation of the allegations made against him.

PEKING, Dec. 20 -- Yesterday's meeting of the foreign envoys was protracted and somewhat stormy, owing to the desire to discover who discloses to the Chinese what every Minister has pledged to keep secret. Li-Hung-Chang invariably knows within two hours of tne close of a meeting what has happened.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The hawsers of both tugs which were towing the White Star liner Cufic parted on account of the heavy gale raging in the Irish Sea, and the steamer drifted on the Skerries, where the anchors were dropped in seventeen fathoms of water.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Hugh Jennings, first baseman of the Brooklyn National League baseball team, has finally decided to enter Cornell College of Law, to take a degree. He has been hired for three years by the Athletic Association to coach the Varsity baseball nine. Final arrangements were made and a contract with him for that time was signed by Manager Thomas to-day.
New cases of smallpox reported to the Board of Health yesterday show that the disease is gaining a foothold on the east side of the city. The new cases, six in all, are:
The Oriental team won three straight games from the Berkeley five in the National League tournament, on Starr's Alleys, last night, and scored 1,002 in the third game. The scores:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Representative Hopkins, (Rep., Ill.,) Chairman of the Committee on Census, to-day filed in the House the majority report on the Reapportionment bill reported by his committee, fixing the membership of the House for the next decade at 357, and gave notice that he would call up the bill immediately after the holiday recess.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 20 -- The hearing in the matter of the contest over the will of Edgar E. Duryea, the starch manufacturer of Glen Cove, was continued here to-day before Surrogate Seabury, but was adjourned before any material progress had been made in the examination of witnesses.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Gov. Roosevelt announced this evening that he had dismissed from office Dr. Peter M. Wise, President of the State Commission in Lunacy, on the charge of malfeasance in office. The Governor sets forth his reasons for the removal in the following memorandum:

The Army bill, as reported from the Senate Committee on Military Affairs, is probably, upon the whole, an improvement upon the Army bill as it passed the House. And this for the reason that it probably conforms more closely to the recommendations of the Secretary of War.

Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller was convinced yesterday that a number of nurses in charge of Bellevue Hospital's alcoholic ward have been guilty of brutality in their treatment of patients. Mr. Keller was indignant at the revelations brought forth by his investigation, but what the actual report, which he received, really contained he declined for the present to say.
The Senate changed the Hay-Pauncefote agreement by these amendments:

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- The Southern Pacific Company has let a contract to a local firm for 50,000 bricks to be used in lining the tunnels of the New Bay Shore Road to run through the hills of South San Francisco. This is said to be the largest contract of the kind ever entered into in the world.

"Down in the South," remarked a man at one of the clubs, yesterday, "there exists more of a religious atmosphere than there is here in the North. So most of the stories they tell have a sectarian flavor to them. One that I heard while in Charleston was entirely new to me, and it appeared to be so in the circle of gentlemen where I heard it.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The Coroner's jury which sat to-day at Harlington to inquire into the death of William Von Scheffler, coachman for Dr. Abraham E. Mosher of Griggstown, brought in a verdict that Von Scheffler came to his death as the result of a blow upon the head inflicted by a party or parties unknown.

Mrs. James Speyer, 257 Madison Avenue, the Treasurer of the Woman's Auxiliary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following additional contributions to the "Woman's Fund," of the current collection:

The Merchants' Association gave out yesterday an analysis of school expenses prepared by experts hired to do the work of examining the accounts of the various city departments and suggest changes for the economical administration of affairs.

The disciples of extreme Socialism and Anarchy in this city were assembled in harmony yesterday under one roof. This, it is declared, is without a precedent. The occasion was the funeral of Justus Schwab.

In the case of Buxbaum vs. Roemer, fought out yesterday in the Harlem Police Court, the attentive spectators learned through an object lesson that, after all, the fit of a pair of trousers is a matter of individual opinion.

Nathan Musher, note broker, whose remarkable financial career on the east side culminated in his conviction of forgery Friday, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Newburger to the Elmira Reformatory, where, by good behavior, his term of detention will reach only fourteen months. The maximum penalty for forgery in the second degree is five years in the penitentiary.
A bold robbery occurred yesterday afternoon in the vestibule of Koch's department store in West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.
MANILA, Dec. 20 -- The United States cruiser Albany, Capt. J.E. Craig, grounded on a reef in Subig Bay, but was floated off and has reached Cavite.
CAPE TOWN, Dec. 20 -- A Government memorandum, issued this evening, is as follows:

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Nearly all the morning papers have editorials on the action of the United States Senate in connection with the Hay-Pauncefote Canal treaty. They express regret, rather than surprise, at the supersession of the Clayton-Bulwer treaty, and unanimously declare that it will be impossible for Great Britain to accept the amended treaty.
PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 20 -- The Rev. John H. Robinson, best known as Dominie "Robinson, died at his home, on Hamilton Avenue, to-day.

Twenty-five miles on a bicycle in one hour plus one minute and fifty-five and a fifth seconds was the pace set last night on Madison Square Garden's ten-lap track by Frank L. Kraemer, the former amateur champion from Newark, N.J., who has recently joined the professional ranks. He won the first open professional twenty-five-mile race ever held in this city on an indoor track, and his time establishes a special competitive record.

The Labor Lyceum extending from 949 to 955 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, was burned yesterday afternoon, causing a loss of over $40,000. Several fireman were injured by a falling wall. It was a frame building. The flames spread so rapidly that forty-six labor organizations which met in the building lost all their records.

There was considerable irregularity in prices in the outside market yesterday, but at the close the majority of active issues showed better figures than those quoted the previous day. Activity developed in several issues which heretofore had supplied but a small part of curb transactions, notably in Sheet Steel preferred.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The suit of Charles Wertheimer, the London bric-a-brac dealer, against Count and Countess Boni de Castellane, to recover payment for art objects sold to the defendants, began this morning in the First Civil Chamber. The transaction taken as a test case involved the sum of 12,946f.
This is the story of a man and an idea. Or, perhaps, it would be better to say of an idea and a man; for the idea grew until it became so great that it overwhelmed and prostrated the man.

Mrs. Florence Carpenter Ives, a daughter of the late Frank B. Carpenter, the well-known historical painter, died yesterday at Quaker Hill, Dutchess County, N.Y. Mrs. Ives, who was a widow, was born in Homer, N.Y., forty-five years ago, and had been prominent in woman's work for some years.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Prof. Karl Becker, the German painter, whose eightieth birthday was celebrated two days ago, and who was then the recipient of a congratulatory address from the Berlin Academy of Arts, died to-day from influenza.
The organization of the Yale Fencers' Club has now been completed, and arrangements have been made for several contests with other teams.

A majority of the twenty-three dry color making firms in this country were represented at a meeting held in the Waldort-Astoria yesterday afternoon, when preliminary plans were drafted to form a combination of the various interests in the trade to the end of forming a dry color trust.

Friday again brings a lull in the gayeties of the early Winter season. There will be two or three receptions this afternoon, notably those to be given by Mrs. John Clarkson May to introduce her daughter, Miss Jay, and by Mrs. Charles Bulkley Hubbell, to introduce her two daughters, the Misses Juliette and Margaret Hubbell.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Money was in good demand and fair supply to-day. Discount's began very firm, awaiting the bank rate, and when it was announced that it was unchanged they were a trifle easier. Most of the bills go to the Bank. Business out-side was quiet. The Bank's decision leaves the market, in a state of the greatest uncertainty regarding the future.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 20 -- For sanitary reasons the Board of Education has decided, to do away entirely with the use of slates and pencils in the public schools of this city, and hereafter lead pencils and paper will be supplied instead.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 20 -- There is rejoicing in the home of Edward A. Cudahy, the wealthy packing-house owner and capitalist of this city. Edward Cudahy, Jr., who was kidnapped Tuesday evening, after being held thirty-six hours for a ransom of $25,000 in gold, which the young man's father unhesitatingly paid, has been returned to his family, and to-night the boy and his parents are receiving congratulations from relatives and friends throughout the country.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The Military Court of Inquiry, composed of Gens. Brooke, Bates, and Clous, got through a mass of evidence to-day, and to-morrow the cadets of the first class, among whom are Frank Keller, who fought Booz, and some of the men who saw the contest, will be examined.

The police situation, created by the hostility between Chief William S. Devery and President Bernard J. York had no development of importance yesterday. The four Police Commissioners met as a board, but there was no discussion or action on Chief Devery's "shake up" of Saturday. It was not even alluded to.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 20 -- The committee of the Players' Protective Association has sent out a circular letter to all baseball players of their association. The letter, after setting forth the action of the National League in ignoring at its recent meeting in this city, the players' petition for a change in the existing state of things, says:

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 20 --It is stated here that Archbishop Ireland of St. Paul will shortly make a tour of Cuba to investigate at the request of President Mckinley, certain matters in reference to the interests of the Catholic Church in the island
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The Peking correspondent of The Morning Post says:
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Lynn B. Wikoff of Richfield Springs Centre was elected captain of the Syracuse University football team last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- At the conclusion of the routine business in the Senate to-day, a resolution previously offered by Mr. Chandler (Rep., N.H.,) discharging the Committee on Contingent Expenses from consideration of the resolution authorizing an investigation of the right of W.A Clark and Martin Maginnis to a Seat in the Senate, was laid before the Senate.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Major Count Ferdinand von Walsin Esterhazy, (who figured so prominently in the Dreyfus case, and who was denounced by Mathieu Dreyfus as being the writer of the famous bordereau which brought about the two convictions of Capt. Alfred Dreyfus, on the charge of treason,) has sunk into utter misery.

Miss Katharine Grey (Mrs. John Mason) will probably return to the stage in a month or so to act Selma White in Leo Dietrichstein's dramatization of Robert Grant's "Unleavened Bread," at the Savoy Theatre. The Liebler Company, who own this play, have not yet formally announced the date of its production or the place.

There may be Senators, a few, not many, who are childish enough to believe that the ratification of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty with three amendments that destroy its original character and pervert its purpose has cleared the way for the construction of the Nicaragua Canal.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The cries of a baby saved the lives of his parents, aunt, and himself early this morning. Coal gas escaping from a stove would, according to the physician who was called in have killed them and the baby within a few minutes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Upon representations from interested parties the State Department has requested the Navy Department to have an American war vessel remain for a time in Venezuelan waters to give support to any representations that United States Minister Loomis may have to make to the Venezuelan Government in respect to the conflicting asphalt concessions in that country.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The cries of a baby saved the lives of his parents, aunt, and himself early this morning. Coal gas escaping from a stove would, according to the physician who was called in have killed them and the baby within a few minutes.

Those are the days of literary conversation. Perhaps many persons go calmly through the world without ever hearing any, but they must be hard of hearing. All sorts and conditions of men, and especially women, are reading all sorts and conditions of books, and they are all talking about them.

Uncle Silas Terry, the honest old keeper of the lighthouse, the author has drawn in a most natural manner. Silas has his peculiarities, and one is an antipathy for lawyers. Once one of the legal fraternity swindled Silas out of his hard-earned money, and he has not forgotten it. One stormy day Uncle Silas sees a stranded ship and witnesses the foundering of the vessel.

Byron A. Robinson, who lives in the apartment house at 356 West One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, and whose business, as given by the City Directory as that of an importer, at 78 Wall Street, was locked up last night in the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station on a technical charge as a suspicious person.

RAYMOND FULLER AYERS writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "The recent review hi your columns of 'Stringtown on the Pike.' by John Url Lloyd, while noting many meritorious points of the narrative, has passed over a predominant feature which to my mind overshadows its excellence as an entertaining work of fiction.

In spite of what the late Mr. Blackmore considered to be an "American idlosyncrasy" "Lorna Doone" continues to be this author's most popular book, in America at least. While his own desires were directed through a different channel for public approbation. "Lorna Doone" succeeded in spite of his indifference toward it.
BELFAST, Dec. 21 -- Vere Foster, the well-known philanthropist, died here, to-day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The River and Harbor bill was completed to-night, and Chairman Burton gave out a statement showing the amounts appropriated. The total is approximately $60,000,000, of which about $23,000,000 is in direct appropriations and about $37,000,000 in the authorization of contracts for continuous work.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 21 -- Four cards were completed in the women's golf handicap at the Country Club to-day, snow causing the withdrawal of several late starters. Miss Eleanor Ferrls won both net and gross score prizes. Summaries:

WEST POINT, Dec. 21 -- The military court of inquiry, which is holding two sessions daily at the West Point Military Academy, ferreting out the alleged brutal cases of hazing which are said to have been the cause of the deaths of Cadets Booz and Breth, will not be able to finish its work to-morrow, but it is said all of the desired testimony will probably be secured by the end of next week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the first time in many years I have had imposed upon me the responsibility of Christmas shopping, and which I regret to say has proved to be anything but complimentary to the women of this city. A more brazen, impudent, uncouth, ill-bred, and indecent specimen of womanhood has never before been on public exhibition, than those I came in contact with at --'s.

Bids for contracts not yet let on the last section of the rapid transit road, that portion between Forty-first and Forty-seventh Streets, running through Forty-second Street and up Broadway, were opened by Contractor John B. McDonald on Thursday. Five or six bids were put in, and it is understood that the name of the fortunate contractor will be announced in a few days.

BIBLIOGRAPHY -- The two new bibliographical societies in England seem to have quickly reached a very flourishing condition. The Type Fac Simile Society, whose membership list was filled almost at once, has already issued its first publication, a handsome set of forty-two plates, while the other association, the Bibliographical Society of Lancashire, is even more energetic.

A new and exceptionally bright and entertaining English comedy was acted for the first time in this country last evening by Daniel Frohman's permanent company, now established for the Winter at Daly's Theatre. "Lady Huntworth's Experiment" was written by Richard Claude Carton, the ingenious and witty author of "Lord and Larly Algy" and "Wheels Within Wheels," and it clearly belongs to the same peculiar type of contemporary comedy as those diverting plays.

Mr. William Winter then made an eloquent and Impressive speech. He told of his first youthful pilgrimage to the home of Longfellow and described eloquently the Cambridge he then knew, Continuing, he said:

Referring to the notice to stockholders of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, dated Dec. 19, the Committee on Securities of the New York Stock Exchange rules that all sales of stock of the company made on Wednesday last, except for cash, will be ex-rights. On all sales made previous to and delivered after Dec. 26, the seller must give the buyer an assignment of rights or a due bill for the same.

There can be no better review of this grim romance than has been already written by Mr. Bain in his admirable preface to the translation of Jokai's "Szomoru Napok." Mr. Bain explains the point of view of the novel by the circumstances under which it was written, "shortly after the collapse of the Magyar revolution of 1848-9, when Hungary lay crushed and bleeding under the heel of triumphant Austria and her Russian ally."

A clash took place last night between the freshmen and sophomores of the College of the City of New York in the concert hall of the Madison Square Garden during the annual debate between the Clionian and Phrenocosmian Literary Societies of the college.

DISTILLING OF AMERICA was an exception to the general course of the market, and was strong as well as active. The preferred stock in particular was in large demand, and on trading in about 3,000 shares the price advanced to 27 3/4. The stock closed at 27 1/2 bid, showing a net gain of 2 points. The common stock was much quieter, and enjoyed a smaller net gain.
The Fidelia team won two of their three matches with the Metropolitan five in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Boston had a great market, principally in the stocks possessing a Wall Street market. Sugar sold to the extent of some 12,000 shares in the morning dealings, with some 3,000 Atchison and 2,500 Chicago, Burlington and Quincy. Among the copper stocks Tamarack rose $36, to $326, later $320.

The "Salt-Box House" was built in 1758, and the history of its century and more of usefulness gives an opportunity to record many an old order that has changed and custom that has passed away. The name "Salt-Box House" was a colloquial title springing from the resemblance borne by the building to the wooden salt box that hung in the kitchen chimney.

We hardly think that Mr. Zangwill's new book will add to his literary laurels. While it is undoubtedly clever, nevertheless its plaint. It is, indeed, a pity that men and women in real life do not always talk in the bright, crisp way of Mr. Zangwill's characters. It they only did, how much more briliant a place to live in would this world be.

One hundred and fifty thousand dollars in gold was distributed in Christmas gifts by the American Express Company among its employes in the United States and Canada. Each of the 30,000 employes received a brand-new five-dollar gold piece of the mintage of 1900, together with a beautifully printed souvenir containing an abbreviated history of the company since its formation, in 1850, to the present day.

One of the points in which the Army bill, as reported to the Senate, is a better measure than that which passed the House, is the partial restoration of the canteen. The Military Committee of the Senate proposes that the sale of beer alone shall be permitted in the post exchanges.

Mr. Winston Spencer Churchill, who is now lecturing in this country, has contributed a striking character sketch of Lord Roberts to the January number of The World's Work, based upon intimate, first-hand study of the great soldier while Mr. Churchill was a war correspondent in South Africa.

Joint action by America and England looking toward the preservation of objects and localities of historic interest to all English-speaking countries was advocated last night at the meeting of the Society for the Preservation of Scenic and Historic Places, by C.R. Ashbee, a Councilor of the National Trust of Great Britain, organized for the same purpose.

Important developments in the affairs of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company will be soon announced. There are to be changes in the Board of Directors. New members to be elected will represent an influential banking interest and insiders of the Metropolitan Street Railway Com- pany.

Mr. S.V. White, following Mr. Stoddard, spoke of the other aspect of Mr. Stedman's career, of the love and esteem in which the poet is held in the active world of Wall Street, and Mr. Ripley Hitchcock, in a brief speech, dwelt upon the help, frequent and valued, Mr. Stedman had always been ready to extend to young writers.

That the mosquito is beneficial to mankind is the conviction of Charles M. Slade, cotton broker, of 50 Worth Street, this city resident of Englewood, N.J. For thirteen years the cotton broker has been laughed at, gibed at, and bullyragged by his business friends in the city and by the unregenerate of Jersey for his belief in the mosquito's usefulness in preventing certain diseases.

Considerable progress was made yesterday with the various reforms in Bellevue, which Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller has decided upon as a result of recent disclosures. The State Board of Charities at its annual meeting decided to institute an independent inquiry into the conduct of the hospital, directing the President to appoint a special committee of three for this purpose.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Ex-President Grover Cleveland made an address, this evening at the annual graduation exercises of the Pierce School.

During the recent meeting of the National Civil Service Reform League in this city a report was submitted from a committee practically covering the changes in the civil service since the first election of President MCKINLEY. It was a temperate and carefully guarded statement of facts as found by a committee composed of men from each party and without partisan prejudice.
BLOEMFONTEIN, Dec. 20 -- The details of Gen. De Wet's escape from the encircling British columns furnish one of the most remarkable incidents of the war.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 21 -- Thirteen-year-old Jennie Griffith proved conclusively last night that coolness and bravery are not confined to grown-up people, or even to boys. She ran across a burglar in the house, and, instead of screaming or fainting, she armed herself with a revolver, and, "getting the drop " on the intruder, compelled him to disgorge his plunder.

Now that a new magazine is well launched as a special record for the men who do things," may we not hope that the older magazine's will return to their first love, and give us more belles-lettres? There is always a class to be charmed by lovely Lamblike pieces, such as "The Man with One Book" and "Dear Old Books."

The formalities of the evening were closed by Mr. Stephen Henry Thayer's reading of a sonnet which he had written after reading Mr. Stedman's chapter on "Beauty" in "The Nature and Elements of Poetry."

The increase in the knowledge of Babylonia and Assyria during the last twenty years has boon such that it is not too much to say that anything written upon this subject before 1880 is now "hopelessly antiquated." The history of research into the antiquities of these countries may be divided as follows: 1320 A.D. to 1820, 1820-1872; 1872 --.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Dec. 21. -- Firebugs get two cottages on fire at Seaside, two miles from this place, this evening. The first blaze was seen in the cottage of Michael Rolland of Highlands. This faced directly upon the Shrewsbury River. A minute later flames also shot up from the cottage of Samuel Course of 382 West Thirtieth Street, Manhattan, which is next to the Rolland cottage.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- Charles H. Cramp, head of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company, appeared before the Industrial Commission to-day and gave some interesting testimony regarding marine architecture. He read a history of the industry in this city, during which he stated that from 1710 to the present time Philadelphia has led the country in shipbuilding.

"Lords of the North" tells the story of the fierce days of 1815 and thereabout, when the Northwest Company, with Indian allies, "carried war into the very heart of the vast territory claimed by its rivals, the Honourable Hudson's Bay Company."
SUBJECT -- Review. GOLDEN TEXT -- Thou crownest the year with Thy goodness. -- Psalms, lxv., 11.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Judiciary Committee of the House has fixed Jan. 11 for hearing the representatives of municipalities relative to the bill proposing to give the Federal courts means of enforcing their judgments against municipalities. An important departure from existing law is involved in the proposition, and one affecting all cities and towns which borrow money on bonds or otherwise.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The War Office made the following announcement last evening:

All the reports this week in relation to trade and business conditions tell of increased activity and general improvement. Testimony from many sources and by many people shows that, as compared with last Christmas, trade is much better -- manifests actual aggressiveness.

A board of survey to consist of Major Charles H. Noble, Twenty-fifth Infantry, is appointed to meet at the Indianapolis Arsenal Dec. 21 for the purpose of reporting up certain subsistence stores, reported to be unfit for issue, for which Major Charles Shaler, Ordnance Department, is accountable.

Minister Wu has written to Prof. Headland concerning this book: "By collecting and translating the Chinese rhymes into English, you have added a valuable contribution to the folk-lore of nations, and at the same, time, done a great service to juvenile literature by calling attention to the fact that children have the same thoughts and tastes in China as in America."

"Paris," writes the author of "Paris in Its Splendour," "like London and Rome, is not only the political, commercial, social, and intellectual centre of France, but it is an opitome and reflection of the national life and an illustration of the past history." It is in the carrying out of this idea that the book before us has been written.

MRS. SHERAWOOD writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Katrina Trask's "Lessons in Love": "A new book by Katrina Trasic must be hailed with enthusiasm, as there is a quality in her mind so original and so thoroughly unique that the reader rarely knows what to expect.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- Public interest in the trial of Edgar C. Burnz, charged with the murder of Herbert B. Fellows, the Scarsdale station agent and Postmaster, is unabated. Mrs. Annie E. Burnz, mother of the accused, who was on the stand when court adjourned yesterday, resumed her testimony to-day.

The Evelyn Nordhoff Bindery held its second annual exhibition of books and leatherwork at 114 East Twenty-third Street on Dec. 14 and 15 Fourteen volumes were on view, the bindings of which were executed by Miss Florence Foote, who continues the work inaugurated by the late Miss Nordhoff.

No Democrat will be in the least surprised to learn that Mr. CLEVELAND'S stirring adjuration is wholly unintelligible to W.J. BRYAN. Re-establish the old-time faith? I do not know what that means, says Mr. BRYAN. Mr.CLEVELAND must explain. Return from our wanderings?

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 -- A reporter for The North American to-night asked ex-President Grover Cleveland for his opinion on the ship subsidy bill now pending in Congress. He intimated that what he had said on that subject had not pleased the friends of the subsidy. He then dictated the following statement, which he said contained all he eared to say regarding the subsidy:

OMAHA, Dec. 21 -- Young Cudahy to-day located the house in which he was held by the kidnappers. It is at 3,604 Grover Street, and the boy recognized it by certain features which left no doubt of its being the right place.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- It was rumored about the Capitol corridors to-day that Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, against whom charges have been preferred, would endeavor to secure an injunction from the courts to restrain the Governor from taking any action in his case to-morrow.

There is no more important educational subject than that dealing with the co-operation between the public school and the public library. Each is an essential factor in the scheme of education, and the most strenuous efforts should be made toward formulating some practical and definite plan of co-operation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- One Vice President of the Red Cross and one member of the Board of Control to-day unequivocally approved the scheme of Frank D. Higbee to raise money for the Red Cross Fund by a series of watch-night meetings, at which subscriptions are to be received.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- John C. Covert, the United States Consul at Lyons, France, has sent to the State Department a supplementary report upon the subject of the prevention of hailstorms by cannon firing, which is generally in use among the wine growers of France and Italy.

Harlem society was surprised yesterday afternoon when the announcement was made that Miss Grace Wagner, the nineteen-year-old daughter of Robert C. Wagner of 1,911 Madison Avenue, an official of the Wagner Palace Car Company, was the bride of P. Roone Warner, a clerk in the Plaza Bank, at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Ex-Gov. Wolcott died at 3:40 o'clock this afternoon.
