Members of the Stock and Consolidated Exchanges were busy after the close of business yesterday making preparations for the Christinas, celebrations to be held to-day on the Exchanges, beginning in each case as soon as possible after the sounding of the gongs, at noon, indicating the suspension of business, not to be resumed until Wednesday morning.

In this volume of sentimental and occasional verse of which a brief descriptive notice has already been given, the President of the Atlantic Trust Company presents some very well-turned poems of observation and a few tuneful lyrics. These we are told are survivals from a poetic youth -- harmonious phrasing which have outlived in some quiet corner the hurry and bustle and mathematical exactness of financial life.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 21 -- Richard A. Wise, Congressman from the Second Virginia District, died suddenly at his home in Williamsburg this morning. He had been long a sufferer from Bright's disease.

"Urchins of the Sea", is the title at a rhymed story by Marie Oyerton Paine and Charles Buxton Going. The story details the movins adventures by flood rather than by field of three amusing little sca urchins named respectively Fopsy Pudgy, and Wobbled Jim. It is dedicated to the "Land Urchin Godfrey in some chariningly written and appreciative verses.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The storm appears to have reached its height during Thursday night, and while the gale is still severe and the seas very heavy, it is hoped that the worst is over. Stories of wrecks and damage are coming from all directions.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Brooklyn detectives were hunting yesterday for a clever young woman swindler, who succeeded by a bold method in robbing one of the big Fulton Street department stores of furs worth about $400. The woman visited the store and asked to be shown some sealskin sacques. She was handsomely dressed and impressed the salespeople as being a person of means.
PEKING, Dec. 21 -- Once more there is a pronounced hitch in the proceedings. The preliminary joint note has not yet been signed.

Charles Griffin Pease, M.D., D.D.S., C.S., who gave up the practice of medicine to follow Mrs. Eddy and Mrs. Stetson, was the star witness at the hearing in the contest over the will of Helen C. Brush before Surrogate Fitzgerald yesterday. He was the man who signed the death certificate showing that Miss Brush died of consumption.

What is clear concerning the recent negotiations with China is that our representative in Peking has been forcing his own views into the discussion of the terms of peace with very scanty regard to the obligations he is under to carry out the instructions of his Government. In fact, the obstinacy he has shown has verged upon bad faith.

The jury in the trial of Contractor Daniel Doody, indicted for perjury in connection with the trial of Robert W. Fielding, accused of conniving to defraud the City of Brooklyn while Deputy Commissioner of City Works, last night found Doody guilty of the crime charged. Doody, who had been under bail, was taken to Raymond Street Jail and locked up.

Henry Zeimer, convicted of subornation of perjujry in obtaining for Mrs. Byrde G. Herrick a divorce upon alse evidence, was yesterday sentenced to ten years in State Prison by Recorder Goff. Zeimer's plea for a light sentence was unavailing, the Recorder stating that he was a lawyer and an officer of the court, and that it was his duty to see that the laws were obeyed and not violated.

The article by Mr. Charles Milford Robinson upon another page pertains to a subject which it is perhaps too narrow to describe as "municipal embellishment." It is, in fact, the subject of making American communities, of all sizes, more attractive in the future than they have been in the past.
BOSTON, Dec. 21 -- Justice Colt, in the United States Circuit Court to-day decided in favor of the American Bell Telephone Company in the royalty suit brought by the Western Union Telegraph Company.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- Richard Jenks, employed by Henry Musculus, a grocer, of 132 North Ninth Avenue, Mount Vernon, was sandbagged and robbed Wednesday night by two highwaymen near the Morris Park race track. They beat him into unconsciousness, looted his pockets, carried off his overcoat and a new suit, and then tried to drown him in a ditch.

If there are any disagreeable features connected with the conduct of a big American circus on foreign shores, nothing to indicate that fact could be gleaned from James A. Bailey of the Barnum Bailey "Greatest Show on Earth." Mr. Bailey arrived in the city on Monday, after a decidedly rough passage across" on the Umbria.

From The Nineteenth Century. Looking round one Sunday in July upon the huge audience, chiefly composed of Germans and Americans of the lower middle class as they giggled and whispered or stared about them obviously indifferent and genuinely bored, one felt it was a matter for wonder why they were there at all.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The purchase of the Pennsylvania Coal Company and other changes in the companies and firms engaged in the mining and shipping of anthracite coal, spoken of as possibly to follow, call attention to the economic situation in that important industry.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May the opinion be offered that in the treatment of the amended Hay-Pauncefote treaty THE TIMES is for once out of joint?

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- Arrangements are practically perfected for the funeral of ex-Gov. Wolcott on Monday morning, at 11 o'clock. The services will be held in Trinity Church, and will be conducted by the Rev. Howard Brown, pastor of King's Chapel, which the ex-Governor's family attended.

ST. PAUL, Dec. 22. -- A suit involving several millions of dollars, the value of the telegraph lines along the route of the Great Northern Railway from St. Paul to the Pacific Coast, was decided this afternoon by Judge Lochren in the United States District Court in favor of the defendant, the Western Union Telegraph Company.

The announcement last week of the entrance into a religious life of Miss Mary Watts Keany, daughter of Gen. John Watts Keany, is one of the few such events which become known generally. There are a large number of women continually "leaving the world" for one reason or another, and many of them are from the poorer classes.

There was a lively race between ocean liners on the Atlantic last Wednesday. The test of speed was between the American liner St. Louis and the Cunarder Campania, both of which sailed from their English terminals on the 15th. The officers and engineers of both vessels ridicule the idea that such a thing as a race occurred.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I think it is the Rev. Dr. Robert S. MacArthur of Calvary Baptist Church who says Christians themselves are in a manner to blame for the late persecutions in China. He says: "The highest authorities affirm that the French Government has protected the Catholic hierarchy in overriding the laws and customs of the Chinese people.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 22. -- Edward Clark, aged sixty-eight, and his son, William, aged thirty-eight years, both of Camden, N.J., met horrible deaths while at work in this city to-day.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Loans were in good demand to-day and the supply was gradually lessening. Discounts were steady. The Exchequer invites tenders for two and a half millions Treasury bills, Dec. 28, to replace the million and a half falling due Dec. 30, and the million due Jan. 6, three-fifths to run a year and two-fifths six months.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The sentence on last Friday by Judge Furman of young Stewart, a boy of fourteen, and clearly a degenerate, to twenty years' imprisonment for manslaughter on his own confession, directs public attention to one of the grossest perversions of justice which has come to light in many a day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Senate committee has decided to allow the Frye bill to remain in abeyance until after the holidays, thus furnishing an indication that the best element of the Republican Party has become aroused, and from careful investigation has decided that it is not for the best interests of our party.

SAN JUAN, Port Rico, Dec. 22. -- Munoz Rivera and eight other leading Federals, after five days' trial by the local court, were to-day acquitted on the charge of resisting public authority. The charges were the outcome of the riots which occurred on the night of Sept. 14 last, when Senor Rivera's house was mobbed and 500 shots were fired.
Congratulations may be extended this week on the anniversaries of their weddings to

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Borough of the Bronx, with its population of a quarter of a million, and rapidly growing, has great need of a public library. With the exception of Westchester and Riverdale, which are situated on the edge of the borough, there is not in all this section of our great city north of the Harlem a free public library.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Even out of a pig's ear it may be possible to make something closely resembling a silk purse. We have read of the ingenious Westerner who compounded "commercial oysters" out of corn starch, salt, and gelatine. You may incubate eggs without the aid of the maternal Biddy, although, if she goes on strike, you cannot produce the genuine, original article.

Commissioner Keller of the Department of Charities yesterday morning transferred Otto W.F. Shutts, a graduate nurse of City Island Hospital, to duty in the alcoholic ward in Bellevue Hospital. Shutts is to be head nurse of the ward.

Governor-elect Odell announced last evening the appointment of Harrison K. Bird as his military secretary. Mr. Bird was Gen. Greene's private secretary while the General was Chairman of the County Committee. Mr. Bird is a New York City man and a graduate of Columbia University. The title given to Mr. Bird is that of Major Heretofore the military secretary of the Governor has been a Colonel.

The circumstances under which the religion of Buddha was introduced from India to China are matter of history; and unless we mean to doubt everything in Eastern history for which we have not the evidence of actual eye witnesses, the introduction into China of Buddhist teachers by the Emperor Mingti in the year 65 A.D. has a perfeet right to claim its place as a historial event.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- The State Department to-day made public the text of the joint note of the powers to China. The official statement follows:

Fifty little girls ate one of the best turkey dinners of their lives at the rooms of the Little Mothers' Aid Association, 304 East Twenty-first Street, yesterday noon. It was their Christmas dinner, and the little girls knew just how good it was from practical knowledge, for they cooked it every bit themselves.

From The Spectator. The neighborhood of a great waterfall bas become something more than a bait to tourists; it is the means of superseding steam and gas alike. It may be objected that waterfalls on such a scale as these are not to be found in England. Henry Kingsley, indeed, has described a Thames weir in terms which would hardly be exaggerated if applied to the falls of the Rhine.

BOSTON, Dec. 22. -- The death of ex-Gov. Roger Wolcott makes a vacancy in the Electoral College that is to cast the votes of Massachusetts for President and Vice President of the United States. Mr. Wolcott was elected as one of the two Electors at Large at the November election. It will be the first vacancy in the Electoral College of Massachusetts occasioned by death, in the recollection of the officials at the State House.

Christmas week brings a batch of new plays. The Garden Theatre has Mme. Bernhardt and M. Coquelin concluding their five weeks' engagement with "Hamlet" -- Mme. Bernhardt in the title role and M. Coquelin as the First Gravedigger. The Madison Square Theatre will offer George H. Broadhurst's latest contribution to the stage, a farce entitled "The House That Jack Built."

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 22. -- The annual report of the Superintendent of Education shows the relative cost of educating the two races in the public schools and the different degrees of interest taken in education by negroes and whites.

At this season of the year the fancy of the golfer naturally turns to the South. The beginning of activity on the Lakewood and Atlantic City links is the first indication that the season on Northern links has practically ceased. As the season advances many golfers, like the birds, flock further southward, and by the middle of January all of the popular links in Florida will be opened for play.

"Jimmy" Michael was dethroned last night from the premiership he has enjoyed as a middle-distance pace-following bicyclist by Harry Elkes, the young man from Glens Falls, N.Y., who has recently carried everything before him at both long and short distance riding.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22. -- The contract for the Tobin bronze for the Lawson cup defender was closed to-day and the metal is expected here at once. The lead is also on the way, and the mold for the keel is expected to be cast nest week, which is earlier than had even been hoped. The work of construction now will begin to be pushed as rapidly as possible.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- In the thirty-six-hole golf match on the Romford links to-day James Braid beat Bernard Nicholls of Boston, Mass., by 9 up and 7 to play.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. Two hundred and fifty years ago Nikon, a friar of Solovetsk, an island monastery in the White Sea, having quarreled alike with equal and superior, was set adrift in an open boat; he reached the mainland at Ki, a small cape in Onego Bay, wandered southward to Olonets, where he got together a band of followers, proceeded to Moscow, obtained the notice of the throne, got preferment, was soon made Patriarch.

DULUTH, Minn., Dec. 22. -- Steelmaking concerns all over the northern part of the producing districts of the United States are just now figuring with a good deal of interest the probable prices to be fixed for 1901 by the Lake Superior Bessemer Ore Association. This association meets late in January, and prior to that time the prices fixed by it more than a year ago are nominally in force.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was extremely light, except in a very few issues. Nevertheless, some substantial advances were recorded, and the fact that large gains were made on very small purchases of stock seemed to indicate that the market is really strong, notwithstanding the relative dullness which has prevailed for the past few days.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a matter of prime importance to our country which appears to be in order at this time. It is the elevation of the rank and weight of the voter.

Obviously it would be ill-advised to say much in advance of the notable dramatic performance we are promised this Christmas week, namely, "La Tragique Histoire de Hamlet, Prince de Danemark." translated out of the English verse and prose of William Shakespeare into modern French prose by MM. Eugene Morand and Marcel Schwob.

The situation with which the Committee of Fifteen will have to deal has already been considerably modified, or, rather, developed, since the time of the committee's appointment. Some of the change that has taken place is undoubtedly due to the creation of the committee and the character of the men placed upon it.

ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- Gov. Roosevelt announced to-night that he had removed from office Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, District Attorney of New York County, on charges preferred by Deputy Attorney General H. H. Hammond. At the same time the Governor made it known that he had appointed Eugene A. Philbin of New York City, a Democrat, to fill the vacancy.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- There will be a merry Christmas in England, though London is already one of the dullest spots in the United Kingdom. The fashionable world has incontinently deserted the metropolis and sought refuge in the country places.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 22. -- St. Louis is to have another race track, and its projectors claim it will rank with the best race courses in the country. A tract of 6,426 acres of land on Deimar Avenue, just outside the city limits, has been bought by J. G. Cella of Chicago and Joseph Adler of Fort Smith, Ark.

It was learned yesterday that probably the first official recognition ever taken of a cat as a regular member of the United States naval forces has been made by Naval Constructor Bowles of the Brooklyn Navy Yard. He has intimated to the men under him that none of the cats which prowl about the yard are to be annoyed or interfered with in any way.

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 22. -- The Novesti, discussing the Nicaragua Canal, says: "England is evidently incapable of opposing the United States, the fact being that America is rising proportionately as England is losing prestige."

"The foundations for many family troubles are laid very early in a girl's life," says the woman who is a systematic housekeeper. "I believe that every girl, as well as every boy, where it is possible, should have an allowance, and out of that they should be expected to clothe themselves and pay for their pleasures and amusements.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- Johnston Forbes-Robertson, the actor-manager, and Miss Gertrude Elliott, sister of Maxine Elliott, (Mrs. Nat C. Goodwin,) were married this afternoon at All Souls Church, South Hampstead. The wedding was a quiet one. There were no bridesmaids, but the bride was supported by Mrs. Madeline Ryley, the playwright.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22. -- Frank H. Morris of Ohio, Auditor of the War Department, was shot and instantly killed about 2:10 o'clock this afternoon by Samuel MacDonald, also of Ohio, recently a disbursing clerk of the Treasury, in the former's office at the Winder Building. MacDonald afterward shot himself, and also slashed his throat with a penknife.

Senator LODGE is fair-spoken in his expository statement about the amendments to the canal treaty. He satisfies the unthinking and places under lasting obligation those who like to put a decent face upon an indecent enterprise. We pay a high tribute to his intelligence when we say that TILLMAN could not have prepared such a statement, and to his morality when we add that ELKINS would not have thought it necessary.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- The excitement in New York did not arouse the Philadelphia market from its lethargic state, but on the contrary, only aggravated the languor by diverting attention from the strictly local securities. All the larger commission houses were busy, but their business was all in the New York market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 11. 1900, contained a striking editorial under the heading, "The Problem of City Churches." It was based upon the remarks of a speaker in the Chicago Baptist Ministers' Association, who was quoted as follows: "Unless the Church becomes a continuous vaudeville it cannot hold its congregations."

The match race between the fast little trotting mare Alice Barnes, 2:11 1/2, owned by E.E. Smathers, and "Fred" Gcrken's trotter The Monk, 2:08 1/2, on the Harlem River Speedway yestarday afternoon, ended in 1 very unsatisfactory manner, Mr. Gerken claiming a victory and Mr. Smathers declaring there was a foul.

Before a large and appreciative audience of women yesterday the brokers of the Stock Exchange proceeded to make merry in honor of the Christmas holidays, and for nearly an hour there was such a scene on the floor of the Exchange that even that amphitheatre of queer sights had never before witnessed.

QUEENS, L.I., Dec. 22. -- Joseph Fallert of Brooklyn won the main event of the New Utrecht Gun Club's weekly trap shooting tournament at the Inter-State Park traps near here to-day with the only clean score of ten straight kills made in the event. Summary:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 22. -- There is every indication that there will be much Christmas merriment here, for the trains are already coming in heavily laden with sojourners who come to enjoy the holiday season and the many sports and pastimes. The hotels and cottages are decorated with mistletoe, holly, and evergreens, and there is an air of good cheer everywhere.

LONDON, Dec. 22. -- However much one may hold the policy of our present Government in South Africa to be mistaken -- and from the first I have been its uncompromising opponent -- it is impossible to withhold admiration for the stolidity with which up to the present the country has faced an appalling situation.

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 22. -- The multiplicity of street railways in Eastern Massachusetts has given rise to numerous problems, among which none more nearly concerns the community than that of the joint use of tracks whereby through traffic may be accommodated without change of cars.

Controller Coler yesterday gave out his fourth partial analysis of the Budget for 1901, taking the Law Department. He has previously taken the Police, Fire, and Park Departments, and is giving one of the analyses every week. The object in the Controller taking the time and trouble to have the statements compiled is so that the average citizen may the more readily understand the Budget.

For the third time since Sept. 19, an attempt was made early yesterday morning to set fire to the five-story tenement house at 604 Columbus Avenue. The house contains thirteen families. On Sept. 19 and on Dec. 10 the incendiary succeeded in starting a serious blaze, which, however, was put out without more serious result than a panic.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 22. -- The work of putting together the new cup defender can now begin and be continued without delay, for the lead keel for the new boat was successfully cast to-day. There wasn't a hitch of any nature and the ninety tons of metal was poured from the heating furnace into the mold as slickly as though the work was an every day matter.

In point of volume the business the last week will compare favorably with that of any similar period since the recent resumption of active dealing, and there has also been a noticeable broadening of the market as shown in sales of business properties in the middle section of Filth Avenue, as well as in the down-town district.

ANTWERP, Dec. 22. -- The striking dock men became more defiant to-day, and their attitude resulted in several conflicts with the police, one of which was serious. During the morning groups of strikers interfered with the men who were coming from the provinces to take their places, and in several instances the new men were maltreated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The action of the Bowery Savings Bank in increasing the rate of interest for the past six months brought out interviews with officers of other banks, who say they cannot afford to pay 4 per cent. and that the rate may go down to 3 per cent. Now, let us see whether they have facts to support such a claim.

There was talk of the "New Democracy" and the "Old Democracy" in the Manhattan Club last evening. It has been many years since there has been such a genuine "love feast" as that held under the auspices of the club which Richard Croker threatened to put out of existence. It was the thirty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the club.

From Leslie's Weekly. The chances are that when "rooky" enlisted he intended nothing more than to serve out his three years' time. In a good many cases this is all he does serve. Yet it is a notable fact that the recruit who becomes the best soldier almost invariably elects to remain with the army for life.

The bank statement issued yesterday shortly before the close of business made a much more favorable showing than generally had been expected. Reserves increased $3,171,625, specie increased $1,385,700, legal tenders increased $820,000, while loans decreased $3,601,300, and deposits decreased $3,863,700.

From Chambers's Journal. The old church and an old market cross in the square near it are both worth inspection. The red bricks of the church walls were as mellow and bright with lichen as the houses of the town; and the chestnut trees by its porch yield a shade which the Crecy gossips no doubt relish in the dog-days.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 22. -- More tramps are brought before the five Justices of Port Chester in the course of a day than are arraigned in many other towns in a year. Port Chester is a terminus for freight trains, and the hoboes ride out of New York, alight at Port Chester, and then seek out the town constables whose professional card they may have.

PEKING, Oct. 29. -- Should peace terms move ahead on the basis proposed by the diplomatic representatives of the allied powers, the traditions and practices of centuries in Chinese affairs will be reversed and a revolution accomplished among a most conservative and exclusive people. If China were not helpless the outlook for a settlement on such terms would be most unpromising.

Ex-Police Inspector George R. Rhodes, who had been doing duty on the police force in Greenpoint for thirty years, and who was retired on May 4 at his own request, died from cerebral apoplexy at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon at his residence, 137 Milton Avenue, Brooklyn. He was stricken on Friday as he entered his house, after returning from a long walk.
A Meadow. There is a meadow in the West, Green, open to the sun and air; A thrill of joy, a throbbing breast, I could not cross it but in prayer.

Richard Croker's absence in Europe has caused the politicians to discuss the question whether the present leader of Tammany Hall will return to take part in the Mayoralty campaign. Many personal friends of Richard Croker believe that he will not take an active part, and may decide to remain in his country home at Wantage while the political battle is waged by his lieutenants.

CITY OF MEXICO, Dec. 10. -- The beggars in this city are not going to be left behind in the march of progress and reform. Righteous indignation surges in their ragcovered, unwashed bosoms, and they have gone on strike.

From Good Words. One day about the year 1818 George Cruikshank was passing Newgate on his way to the Exchange, when, seeing a crowd collected, he went forward to learn what was the matter, and saw that it was the execution of several men and women. He was horrified at the spectacle, and on inquiring, learned that the woman was being hanged for passing counterfeit onepound notes.

The Long Island League tournament is the first of the present season to finish its schedule, having been completed during the past week. The East New York Bowling Club won first prize, with a record of 12 games won to 2 lost. The Imperial team won second prize, and the Prospect and Manhattan fives will roll off a tie for third and fourth places next Wednesday evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your minor editorial department on Dec. 11 you say "the prices of tickets to see good plays well acted are now so high in this town that the poor man, if he goes to a first-class playhouse at all, must sit in the top gallery and peep over the rail."

FRANKFORT, Ky., Dec. 22. -- In the Court of Appeals the petition for a rehearing of the Kentucky-Indiana State boundary line dispute was overruled. In an opinion concurred in by a majority of the Judges, Judge Durrell holds that Kentucky has exclusive jurisdiction on the Ohio River to the low-water mark on the Indiana side.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 22.--Excellent sport was enjoyed here to-day when the second of the series of Winter road races was decided. The events were run off on Willis Avnue, a broad stretch of macadamized roadway, perfectly level. Summary:

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22. -- The failure of the American National Bank of this city carries down other institutions with it. The Economy Savings Bank, which occupied quarters in the same building, closed its doors to-day.

From The Nineteenth Century. The art of dressing well is one which all women, if they care for the subject at all, wish to possess. Only a few have it naturally, some fail lamentably, and most have to learn it by experience.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue for Dec. 16 you say editorially: "The Federal Government may not exercise within a State the right of eminent domain, * * * * a right which it exercises within a Territory, with or without the action of the Teritorial government."

EMILE ZOLA'S letter addressed to the President of the French Republic is characteristic of the writer's fine sense of justice as it is of his eloquent and aggressive rhetoric. But was it worth while? If the passage of the Amnesty bill in any way interfered with, the individual rights of the pardoned DREYFUS, limiting or annulling his right of further appeal, there would be abundant excuse for M. ZOLA'S determined opposition.

Lewis Nixon, Chairman of the Tammany committee to investigate the vicious conditions of the city, has caused some threescore gambling houses and poolrooms to close. Before Chief Devery went on a vacation he was furnished by Mr. Nixon with a list of thirteen gambling houses and poolrooms with evidence that their character was easily discovered, and the places ceased to "do business " and have remained closed.

BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Public attention was occupied almost wholly this week with crimes in high places. The sentence imposed on Sternberg, the millionaire banker -- two and a half years' imprisonment and five years' deprivation of civil rights -- for crimes against morality, satisfies the public conscience.
LONDON, Dec. 22. -- About forty pantomimes will be produced in and around London during the holidays. "Cinderella" being the most popular production, no fewer than nine versions being presented.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire once again to call the attention of the public to the apathy and indifference manifested by our municipal authorities to the shameful condition of the old burial place on St. Ann's Avenue, near One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, familiarly known as Bensonia Cemetery.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22. -- The Industrial Commission to-day heard testimony regarding the plate-glass industry by John Pitcairn, President of the Pittsburg Plate Glass Company. Mr. Pitcairn said the annual production by the consolidated companies was about 20,000,000 feet.

The elimination of grade crossings of steam railroads in New York State, under the act of 1897 authorizing appropriations of $100,000 per year to the Board of Railroad Commissioners to be expended for this purpose, is progressing at a rate which warrants the statisticians in promising that the work will be accomplished in about 400 years.
The weekly bank statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $3,171,625. The banks now hold a surplus of $9,497,000 above the legal requirements.

Fifteen-year-old Bertha Friedman of 252 East Third Street, who ran away from home after a quarrel with her mother two weeks ago and later narrowly escaped abduction in Summit, N.J., returned to her home last night.

The two hours business on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday exceeded all records in the matter of actually recorded transactions. From 10 to 12 o'clock no fewer than 1,006,179 shares were traded in, an amount that would be considered, even in the present active market, as a very fair full day's total, while during the dullness of last Summer it would have been looked upon as a creditable week's record.
Company B of the Twelfth Regiment won three games from Company E in the regimental bowling1 tournament on the armory alleys last night. The scores:

It is a merry Christmas, indeed, that Wall Street celebrates. The record is unique. The financial world takes its holiday without any cloud whatsoever threatening. Disturbances and even disaster in variety had been predicted, but only blitheness, confidence, and consequent buoyancy appear in this Christmas exhibit.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Instantly on receiving the demand for ransom Mr. Cudahy should have signed and sent to all the principal newspapers, far and near, a manifesto like this:

Broadway is now torn up by the tunnel sub-contractors between the Circle at Fifty-ninth Street and West One Hundred and Twenty-third Street, in twenty different blocks, including Fifty-ninth to Sixty-fourth, Eighty-second to Eighty-third, Eighty-fourth to Eighty-fifth, Eighty-sixth to Ninetieth, and from One Hundred and Fourteenth to One Hundred and Twenty-third Streets.

LINCOLN, Neb. Dec. 22. -- Sensational correspondents have injected many unpleasant features in the Senatorial fight in this State. There are nearly one dozen avowed candidates for the two positions in the Senate from Nebraska, and of these but one man is looked upon as sure of election.

From The National Review. In appearance the statutes hold good in their entirety; in reality many of them are never enforced, and probably could not be enforced in this year of grace 1900. This mass of custom, though perhaps it lies a little out of the track of the present subject, must be briefly attended to if we wish to get a clear idea of the enormous influence of unwritten law at Oxford.
BERLIN, Dec. 22. -- Count von Blumenthal, the oldest Field Marshal in the German Army, died last evening on his estate at Quellendorf, Duchy of Anhalt.

Gilford S. Bucklin of Mount Vernon and his wife, Jennie, who is the daughter of Edward Glardon, a dealer in artificial granite at 146 Broadway, with a residence in New Rochelle, are at present enjoying a novel kind of honeymoon. They were secretly married late in November, and on account of the dislike of the bride's father for the bridegroom he did not learn of the marriage until Friday.

Quite apart from the supernatural sanctions of Christianity is what may be called the Christmas feeling. Of all the solemn and affecting incidents of the Nativity, none is more affecting than the occasion which it made for the proclamation of "Peace on earth, good-will towards men."
ALBANY, Dec. 22. -- Gov. Roosevelt tonight announced the appointment of J. Proctor Clerke of New York City to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Justice H. R. Beekman.

"Devery will go within thirty days." This was the statement made by Senator Platt last night in his room at the Fifth Avenue Hotel. The Senator was talking about police legislation. He made it plain that Devery's removal is to be accomplished by Republican legislation at the coming session of the Legislature.

From The Fortnightly Review. Feasting and revelry and all the mad pursuit of pleasure are the features that seem to have especially marked this carnival of antiquity, as it went on for seven days in the streets and public squares and houses of ancient Rome, from the 17th to the 23d of December.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22. -- The Stewards this afternoon announced their conclusion in the case of the mare Donna Rita and the stable of T. Licalzi, suspended on Dec. 17. After an exhaustive investigation the Stewards decided to give Licalzi the benefit of any existing doubt and remove the ban announced against the stable, "with the understanding that no consideration will be given the mare Donna Rita for inconsistent racing."

GREENUP, Ky., Dec. 22. -- From noon tomorrow until it suits the pleasure of the State Board of Health Greenup County, with the exception of the town of Russell, will be in a state of absolute quarantine. It is the penalty for defiance of the health laws. Smallpox is epidemic in twenty counties of Kentucky, and Greenup is one of them.

The human Intellect, like "the service," has long been "going to the dogs." Old-fashioned people tell us that "nobody reads anything but newspapers and novels." Many critics in the serial reviews apologize for noticing a work that is not avowedly a work of fiction. Most reviewers have long dropped the hypocrisy of pretending to own any acquaintance with the subjects of historical, antiquarian, anthropological, mythological, and other erudite books.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 22. -- There has been considerable, talk in business circles the past week concerning the mystery which surrounds the Independent Match Company, the charter of which was filed Friday, Dec. 14, in the Baltimore County Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The religious discussion to which THE TIMES has opened its columns serves, with much collateral matter elsewhere, to demonstrate that, while the churches are apathetic, we are nowise in an irreligious age.

SIMLA, Nov. 15. -- The annual sojourn of the Government of India in these Himalayan heights is over and the place is fast becoming empty of officials in consequence. The Viceroy himself left here some three weeks ago for the purpose of making an extended tour throughout Western and Southern India before again meeting his Council at Calcutta shortly before Christmas.

"Speaking of dynamite and other explosives," said an expert blaster, "it is doubtful if there is another subject on which the average lay mind is more misinformed. Taking the Tarrant explosion, for example, more ridiculous theories have been aired by citizens in letters to newspapers giving the possible causes of the explosion than would fill a good-sized joke book.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 31. -- Sao Paulo is called the "Yankee City of Brazil." It is a surprise to the traveling American to find among the mountains or southern Brazil a town so thriving and so full of local push and activity as to suggest naturally an American character.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- Since Lord Kitchener's dispatch of Wednesday last reporting the crossing of the Orange River into Cape Colony by two bands of Boers, nothing official concerning events in South Africa has reached the public. Last night the news was most meagre. Reports were received from Cape Town that the railway had been torn up in three places north of De Aar.

Ferdinand W. Peck, Commissioner General of the United States to the Paris Exposition, arrived home on the American liner St. Louis yesterday. He was enthusiastic in his praise of the exposition in general and of the part taken by this country in the fair in particular.

From The Contemporary Review. The Beira Railway runs through such a fever district, and accidents are so comman an occurrence that the company employs a doctor entirely to look after its employes. He receives, I believe, some u800 a year and allowances -- at least, so I am assured. His life is a lonely and hard-worked one.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the Directors of the Bowery Savings Bank are to be commended for so carefully managing their institution as to earn four per cent., they are to me commended to a greater degree for the courage displayed in giving the depositors their due.

Arthur W. Milbury, whose appeals for money for educational work typewritten on the letter-head of the Committee of One Hundred on India Famine Relief have been declared to be unauthorized by the members of the committee, which has now passed out of existence, was not at his office, at 73 Bible House, yesterday, and it was said that he had not been seen about the building for a week.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., Dec. 23. -- The finding of the body of a man with one side of his skull crushed, early this morning in the yard in front of the Cotton Hollow roadhouse, a well-known resort a mile and a half south of this town, develops a mystery which the police say has every appearance of murder.

NEWS OF THE DISCOVERY OF EXTENSIVE COAL DEPOSITS IN RHODESIA CONFIRMED. -- The coal experts who were recently sent into Rhodesla, by the British South Africa Company have just published their report in Cape Town. The experts practically confirm the news concerning the discovery of coal which was published just before the waking out of the Boer war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Pension Commissioner Evans has inaugurated a new and more vigorous warfare on the pension attorneys. The business of obtaining fraudulent pensions has entered on a new phase, an organization into trusts or pools.
Gov. ROOSEVELT, in removing District Attorney GARDINER at this time and on the evidence submitted, has, we are convinced, committed a blunder that comes perilously near to being a political crime.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- All testimony concurs in representing the speculation on our Stock Exchange in your railroad shares as having reached unprecedented proportions last week. Every day and all day long the market was thronged with an excited crowd, one hour bidding madly for shares, and in the next selling them with equal fury.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 23, -- Capt, Heygate of the British Army is purchasing 50,000 cavalry horses and mules for the British Army in South Africa. He came here more than a year ago to buy horses and mules, but was ordered home a short time ago. But the unexpected renewal of hostilities has made the purchase of more horses and mules necessary.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Bolivia has made a formal request that the United States use its influence to settle the trouble between Bolivia ana Chile. The request has been denied.
BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- The electric trolley system is rapidly displacing the storage battery system on the busiest streets of Berlin.

MOUNT VERSION, N.Y., Dec. 23. -- Edgar Channing Burnz, the alleged degenerate and so-called cigarette fiend, may collapse before his trial for the murder of Herbert B. Fellows is resumed next Wednesday. While he was singing in the county jail at White Plains to-day, he broke down and wept like a child.

The decision handed down a few days ago by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of New York, declaring un- constitutional the law invalidating contracts for public work when the contractor does not pay the "prevailing rate of wages" will put a temporary stop, at least, to the withholding by the city of payments due for work performed, on the complaint of trade unions having no direct interest in the matter.

PARIS, Dec. 12. -- Just as the year 1900 is closing the French labor bureau authorities are publishing the advance sheets of the report on the strikes and other labor troubles of 1899. There were 740 strikes, involving 176,826 people, among whom were 23,417 women and 10,042 children employed in 4,290 establishments.
An epidemic of sore throat has broken out among the doctors in the J. Hood Wright Hospital, and volunteers, to take the places of the incapacitated men, were asked for yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 23. -- Last week the Berlin Boerse had a bad experience, beginning with the heavy declines in coal and iron shares, due to the Coal Syndicate's restriction of the output. During the latter half of the week quotations were at a standstill. Yesterday, however, they showed more firmness.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 23. -- A man and boy scantily clad and suffering from terrible burns and injuries received in the burning of their home were turned out of the City Hospital early this morning because of a quarrel between the hospital authorities and the police. The sufferers were Charles Loeffler, fifty-seven years old, and his son Joseph, aged nineteen years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The War Department has made public a series of reports made to Gen. MacArthur by the subordinate officers constituting the heads of the various bureaus and departments which have administered the civil affairs of the Philippine Islands during the last year.

SCRANTON, Penn., Dec. 23. -- Every one of the 300 car and barn employes of the Scranton Railway Company obeyed the strike order which went into effect at 5 o'clock this morning, and as a consequence only two cars were run in all of the Lackawanna Valley to-day. These two cars were manned by Superintendent Patterson and dispatchers, foremen, and clerks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Russia's proposal, made a long time ago, for the reference of the Chinese indemnity question to the Court of Arbitration at The Hague in case there should prove to be too great a diversity of opinion at Peking, is being seriously considered by the United States Government, although the particular emergency for which Russia proposed it has passed by.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- Patrick Furlong, once a policeman, who, in February, 1900, killed Edward Leach, a brother officer, and was sentenced to the penitentiary for fourteen years, has been pardoned by Gov. Tanner, and will take his Christmas dinner with his family in Chicago.

On the way to earn a little extra Christmas money by making himself useful at the wedding of his employer's daughter, Louis Goldberg, forty years old, of 342 Osborne Street, Brooklyn, met death yesterday morning at the Brooklyn entrance to the bridge.

"Jesus was unquestionably a unique personality, with methods characteristic of Himself. At His best He was the Jew with a special sympathy with the outcasts and sinners of society. He translated into His own life the Pharisaic doctrine that the repentant sinner stands higher than he who has never fallen, and the beautiful motto or the sage Hillel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23. -- "You can never solve the social problem by strikes; that is my opinion after twenty years' experience in the movement," said Peter Curran, Chairman of the General Federation of Trades Union of Great Britain, in speaking to the workingmen of Chicago to-day at a meeting held under the auspices of the Building Trades Council.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 23. -- The hull of the new defender to be built at Bristol for the Belmont syndicate is to be plated with the same quality of metal used in plating the Columbia two years ago. The first consignment of Tobin bronze arrived in Bristol this morning direct from Ansonia over the Consolidated Railroad in box cars.

The five-story brick factory building at 76 and 78 Ainslie Street, Williamsburg, was burned at an early hour yesterday morning, and several firemen were hurt, three by falling down the elevator shaft, a distance of fifteen feet.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 23. -- Theodore L. Poole, United States Marshal for the Northern District of New York State and member of the Fifty-fourth Congress from the Onondaga-Madison District from 1894 to 1896, was stricken with apoplexy this morning at 8 o'clock as he attempted to rise from his bed and died immediately.

We believe that the country will be found deeply to regret the fact that the United States has signed the note addressed to China, by the Powers, which was published by the State Department yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 24. -- Lord Kitchener's dispatches, breathing a confidence hardly justified by their contents, are almost the only available news from the seat of hostilities in South Africa; hut telegrams from Capt. Town depict the situation in anything but roseate views.

VINELAND, N.J., Dec. 23. -- There was a big congregation this evening in the First Congregational Church to hear a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Scoville upon the personal tax question. The minister took the ground that in many instances the imposition of personal taxes was unjust.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 23. -- The mysterious "dark" man in the Cudahy kidnapping case was arrested this afternoon by the police from the description given by Miss Maude Munshaw, who lives near the house in which Eddie Cudahy was held for ransom by his abductors. His name is Ed Johnson.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 23. -- President Robert Aull of the St. Louis Fair Association returned to-day from Memphis, where he went to attend a conference of Western turf officials who are opposed to the Turf Congress action in the matter of regulating racing dates.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Dec. 23. -- The new scale of wages which the Board of Directors of the amalgamated organizations of engineers, firemen, brakemen, conductors, and telegraphers employed by the Central Railroad of New Jersey have prepared for the railroad officials to accept, includes an average increase of $5 per month for the firemen, brakemen, and telegraphers.

The advent of the holidays is responsible for a considerable lessening of activity among the local bowlers. A number of the principal tournaments, including the Bank Clerks' League, Life Insurance League, Wholesale Drug Trade Association, Arehdiocesan Union League, Interclub League of Brooklyn, and the Twenty-third Regiment tournament are entirely suspended until after New Years, while all games are omitted to-night and to-morrow night, and few Year's eve and New Year's night.

The audience that gathered in the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday afternoon to hear a sermon by Bishop Potter a large one. In introducing the Bishop, Seth Low quoted from a sermon of Dr. Rainsford that he had heard in the morning. When Bishop lotter started to speak be said:

"Before the war," began the druggist whose memory and business date back to pre-civil war days, speaking of the drug business as it was compared to what it is at present, "a druggist always expected to do a good deal in the way of prescribing. In 1858 the College of Pharmacy graduated some six men where now hundreds are graduated.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 23. -- Dr. A. D. Williams, Assistant Surgeon of the United States Army, has arrived from Porto Rico, where he was detailed to make a report on conditions as observed by him on a march with soldiers across the island. That report was made to the Adjutant General, Department of Porto Rico, San Juan.

Ex-President Benjamin Harrison has declined the invitation to deliver an address before the Illinois Bar Association at Springfield on the celebration of Justice John Marshall's centenary in February next.

Frank Pomerpy of 2,251 Seventh Avenue, called at Bellevue Hospital late last night saying he had heard his wife, Louise, had been committed to the Island by Magistrate Brann, in the Harlem Court, Saturday for intoxication, and that she had been sent, to the alcoholic ward of the hospital, for recuperation.

LONDON, Dec. 23. -- On the whole the Stock Exchange last week displayed considerable firmness, and a fair amount of business was done considering the period of the year. Consols and some other giltedged securities showed fractional declines.
LONDON, Dec. 23. -- The War Office hag received the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria, Dec. 23:

The Speedway brigade of trotters and pacers were somewhat late in putting in an appearance on the stretch yesterday morning owing to the threatening weather, but when they did arrive they made up for lost time, and the result was some excellent sport. Not for weeks had the roadbed been in better condition, as the warm damp weather had brought the frost out of the ground and the harrows made the footing soft but firm.

District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner, who was removed Saturday by Gov. Roosevelt, has decided not to enter into a legal contest to retain his place. Col. Gardiner was in the city yesterday, but avoided newspaper men. He was at the Democratic Club most of the day, and attended a conference of his assistants to determine their course of action.
This was the unconventional note that a young matron on the upper west side of town handed her by her maid the other day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your leading article of Dec. 20, inst., under the above caption, and its successor in today's issue entitled "Next Steps," seem to presuppose, without qualification:

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23. -- As a result of the fatal termination of the amateur boxing bout last night at the Philadelphia Athletic Club between Joseph Kelly and Edward Sanford, who fought under the name of Frank Barr, all boxing contests have been prohibited for the present by the police authorities.

With the new year but a few days away, at which time more than one hundred million of dollars will be released for investment and other purposes, there can no longer be reason, so most New York bankers agree, for any fear of money stringency -- that much-paraded bugaboo, which, to the sorrow of wouldbe market value depressors, has failed to materialize.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- Samuel MacDonald, the Treasury clerk who shot and killed Frank H. Morris, Auditor for the War Department, yesterday, and then wounded himself, was in a precarious condition at the Emergency Hospital to-night, and his death is expected momentarily. MacDonald has been entirely conscious since his removal to the hospital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been directed to statements of Mr. Anthony Comstock respecting his course, concerning the Anti-Policy bill introduced in the Legislature last Winter at the instance of Capt. F. Morton Goddard.

The formal season of grand opera in many tongues commonly caters to two distinct elements in this town, the regular audience of opera night and the concert or Sunday night audience. Mr. Grau's stars had had their greeting from the first earlier in the week. Last night they were welcomed by the second.

A fire at 260 Avenue A, on the corner of East Sixteenth Street, at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning, sent nearly 100 shivering tenants into the cold street. It was discovered by Policeman Charles G. Fichtel in Mettleman's tea store.

The following letter was sent to The Outlook with a note stating that its author was Lieut. Col. JAMES PARKER, United States Army, a graduate of West Point and Rutgers College, and a son of CORTLANDT PARKER of Newark, N.J. Col. PARKER is in command of "an isolated province in Southeastern Luzon," with a population of some 50,000.

Thirteen-year-old Nettie Rosch, daughter of President John Rosch of the White Plains Board of Police Commissioners, given up by eminent New York specialists as a hopeless paralytic, not having had the use of her legs for nine years, returned to her home yesterday, after undergoing treatment in Brooklyn, apparently absolutely cured.

OMAHA, Dec. 24 -- Seven and one-half miles west of Omaha, on Center Street, in McArdle Precinet, and about a quarter of a mile west of the Big Pappio, in the Raddock grove on the south side of the road, the lantern with white and black ribbons attached, which was used to "flag" Mr. Cudahy in his drive, was found Thursday morning.

Eugene Ambrose Philbin, appointed District Attorney of the County of New York by Gov. Roosevelt to replace Col. Asa Bird Gardiner, removed, took the oath of office before Supreme Court Justice Morgan J. O'Brien in the latter's chambers in the Appellate Division at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- There was a desperate fight inside and outside the hotel known as the "Foot-and-a-Half House" here last night, and as a result one man is dead and another is dying. Several others are suffering from knife and pistol wounds which are more or less serious, and fully a score have cuts and bruises.

BRISTOL, R.I., Dec. 24 -- The second lot of Tobin bronze for Herreshoff's cup defender came, on the cars to-night. Like the lot which arrived last night, it is for the body of the hull, although that received to-night is for the topsides. The plates are about three-twentieths of an inch in thickness, from 14 to 18 feet in length, and from 3 to 4 feet in width.

There seems to be a good deal of mystery, according to the police stories, surrounding the death of seventeen-year-old George Schmidt of 335 East Eleventh Street, who died in "Sam's" restaurant, 99 Bowery, after fighting there with three men, who escaped.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- An opinion was rendered in the United States Supreme Court to-day in the case of Robert W. Workman vs. the City of New York. The case involved the liability of the city for damage done by the fireboat New Yorker to the British barkentine Linda Park during a fire at a wharf in the East River in 1893.

TUTUILA, Samoa, Dec. 9 -- Gov. Tilley has gone to New Zealand with the, Abarenda to get supplies of coal and, to have the ship repaired. Lieut. Commander E.J. Dorn of the Abarenda is now in charge of the station. Previous to leaving for New Zealand Gov. Tilley made official visits to all the districts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- It is due to an investigation set on foot by Gen. Otis, now in command of the Department of the Lakes, that a conspiracy to acquire vast mining claims in the Philippines has been exposed.

The cloud that overhangs Christendom at the end of the nineteenth century of the Christian era is not black, but yellow. The Chinese question has assumed great and formidable proportions. Doubtless, it is formidable, in great part, simply because, according to the Latin saying, it is unknown.

The lower stretch of the Harlem River Speedway was well patronized yesterday afternoon by road drivers and their fast steppers, who furnished some excellent sport. About the best and most interesting brush of the afternoon was between the famous bay gelding Alves, (2:09 1/2) owned by Nathan Straus, and the Chicago trotter Franker owned by C.K.G. Billings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Interest in the West Point Academy hazing affair has reached our pent-up Utica, as evidenced by the fact of the publication in your issue of to-day of the letter signed "R.D.P.," in which he holds up that institution to the scorn of the "patient taxpayers" of the country.

ROCKAWAY PARK, L.I., Dec. 24 -- The Oceanic Rod and Gun Club held a shooting tournament here to-day on the club's private plant at Rockaway Point. Clay birds were trapped exclusively, and some excellent scores were made. Dr. Louis H. O'Connell of New York City won a majority of the events with high scores.

Magistrate Brenner was greatly interested yesterday in the case of a young man who was arraigned before him in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn. The young man was Francis McDonald, twenty-two years old, and he was charged with vagrancy.

There will be more country parties to-day than for some years past on Christmas, and most of the country houses in and around Hempstead, Westbury, and Cedarhurst are open and filled with guests, and the country-club houses at Tuxedo, Meadow Brook, Cedarhurst, Ardsley, Knollwood, Westchester, and Dongan Hills, S.I., will be the mecca all day for the many well-known people who are still in the respective suburbs of which they are the social centres.
The following remarkable statement was made yesterday for publication by Mr. LEWIS NIXON, Chairman of the Tammany Committee for the Suppression of Vice:

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- We learn," says The Dally Mail, "that the reports of the serious situation in Cape Colony are fully confirmed. The invading Boers are receiving much assistance from the Cape Dutch. Railway communication between Cape Town and the North is almost entirely severed, partly by Boer operations and partly by rains.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 24 -- Russell E. Gardner, a vehicle manufacturer of St. Louis, has given $10,000 to his employes for a Christmas present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- As a result of a conference between the Secretary of War and Quartermaster General Ludington, it has been decided that no further action can be taken with regard to the return of the volunteers from the Philippines until Congress shall make provision for their replacement.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Dec. 24 -- Gov. and Mrs. Roosevelt's reception at District School No. 10, in this place, this afternoon, where they distributed Christmas presents to every pupil in the school, was very pleasing to them. The opening prayer was by the Rev. Mr. Russell, pastor of the Presbyterian Church.

ALBANY, Dec. 24 -- State Commissioner of Excise Henry B. Lyman to-day issued a statement concerning the operation of the State Excise law during the past year. He states that $61,289,275 have been collected in excise taxes since the Raines law went into operation, and in this connection says:

ST. PETERSBURG, Dec. 8 -- Reflective observers discover numerous resemblances between Russia and America which are not accidental or mere coincidences. Among such resemblances is the liberality of peopie of wealth toward public institutions. This liberality, almost foreign to the nations from which Russia has borrowed most, is the product in part of the same conditions which have lavished private wealth upon the American universities and technical and art schools.

Vaccinators of the Health Department are carrying on a systematic course of work to stop the spread of smallpox everywhere in the city, and it is the intention of Dr. Alonzo Blauvelt, Chief Inspector of the Bureau of Contagious Diseases, that every lodging house or boarding house sheltering any considerable number of patrons shall be visited before the week is out.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 24 -- The crew of six men of the three-masted schooner Marcus Edwards, brought into this port at 10 o'clock to-night by the United States lighthouse tender Cactus, tell of the fearful experience of clinging to the side of their capsized vessel in the icy waters of Long Island Sound from the early morning until 6 o'clock to-night, when they were discovered and their rescue effected.

As a result of a collision between two trolley cars in Williamsburg last evening one woman was instantly killed, two others probably fatally injured, while several persons received slight cuts and bruises. The accident happened at the foot of Broadway, the terminus of the Metropolitan Avenue and Grand Street lines.

-- Judging from the triumphant tone which marked the announcement by the Tammany vice suppressors of the closing at their command of nearly eighty gambling places; the members of the committee are proud of their work and are wondering when the expressions of public gratitude and admiration are to begin.

A number of firemen working to save August Melerdierck's hotel on the Hudson Boulevard, Guttenberg, yesterday, were so badly shocked by coming in contact with telegraph and telephone wires that they were obliged to stop work, although none was seriously hurt. Assemblyman Killian V. Lutz put an end to the trouble by climbing a pole and cutting the wires.

Although the lengthy and comprehensive programme of Christmas Day sports includes every reasonable outdoor recreation, the predominating pastime of the day will be trap shooting, both at live birds and clay targets. One of the largest and most important shoots of the day will be held at the grounds of the Carteret Gun Club at Garden City, L.I., where the annual competition for the Holiday Cup and several sweepstakes events will be decided.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 The American League No. 2 -- the only name which can be given the baseball organization until another is officially adopted -- will be launched in this city next Thursday. At a conference to-night between President Johnson of the American League. Attorney Thomas J. Navin of Detroit, and George W. Burnham, it was decided to call a meeting for that purpose.

From The London Mail. Weary of cheering and snap-shotting him, the Continental admirers of Mr. Kruger have been examining his hands with a view to obtaining fresh food for adoration. The Paris Vie Illustree publishes a photograph of Mr. Kruger's hands, as well as the professional opinion of a famous Parisian chiromancer thereon.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Sunday issue, Dec. 23, I find the following sentence in the article from The Spectator on "Electrical Power for England":

From The London Express. Busy men seem to find time to read, and in terms of the annual Academy plebiscite of the bees of the pulpit, literature, and the press, it would appear that some read exactly the sort of books one would expect them to read.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the demoralizing effect of tips in Bellevue Hospital suggests its application to every field on which it is practised. Tips are anything but an American custom, were not known here before the influx of Europeans lowered the standard of self-respect and would have been resented by American-born citizens in menial position as a gift of charity.

A proposition is on foot to change the new seven-million-dollar Hall of Records Building, at Chambers and Centre Streets, into a County Court House, to accommodate the various parts of the Supreme Court and the offices of the County Clerk, Surrogate, and Sheriff, and to put the offices of the Register, the Controller, and Corporation Counsel in the present County Court House.

The advance catalogue of the great sale of thoroughbred horses from the late Marcus Daly's Bitter Root Stock Farm, at Hamilton, Mont., has just been Issued by the Fasig-Tipton Horse Auction Company. In very condensed form, announcement is made of general facts concerning the sale, which will be one of the most important, if not actually the greatest sale of thoroughbred racing stock ever held in America.

F.T. Montell Sons, shipping agents, of G3 Pine Street, received word yesterday morning that the British steamship Antilia, for which they are the local agents, had gone ashore on the New Jersey coast about forty miles north of the Delaware Breakwater, on a reef known as the Great Egg Harbor Bar.

Perry Tiffany of 152 Madison Avenue has declared himself a bankrupt, and in a petition filed by him yesterday, he places the amount of his liabilities at $83,897 and his nominal assets at $66,200. Mr. Tiffany was formerly Vice President of the Sterling Supply and Manufacturing Company, railway supplies, the stock of which, at unknown values, figures largely in his assets.

"There goes a man," said the manager of the cafe in one of the Broadway hotels near Forty-second Street, "who, to my knowledge, has not paid for his dinner on any day this month, nor during the months of October or November, and I doubt if he did in September. Yet he lived on the best in New York all the time.

"The House That Jack Built," a threeact farce by George Broadhurst, produced at the Madison Square Theatre last evening, calls for small critical consideration. It is distinguished by the wild improbability, the reckless use of ancient theatric device, the silly and unexplalnable confusion of identities its author seems to regard as essential concomitants of farce, and it was obviously designated merely as entertainment for the frivolous.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The State Department has decided to send the amendments to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty to the British Government through two channels, one copy being transmitted to Lord Pauncefote, and the other through Ambassador Choate at London, who will present it to the Foreign Office.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of to-day, (Saturday,) in your editorial on "The Canteen," occurs this astonishing sentence: "On the other side are the liquor dealers and the theoretical prohibitionists, who are now found working together, not for the first time. One party or the other of them is evidently taken in by this alliance."

Because John Kiehl, druggist of Third Avenue and Thirteenth Street, sold to Miss Lillie Verona a chemical that turned her hair green instead of auburn she is now suing him for $5,000 damages. If she wins, however, Mr. Kiehl will not be out of pocket, for he is insured to the amount demanded against the consequences of possible mistakes.

Emanuel Popper on last Friday, through his counsel, Joseph Martin, applied to Justice Leventriv for the appointment of a receiver for the order of Chosen Friends, asserting that his wife had died and left a policy of insurance on which he could not collect. The Justice at once appointed Jacques H. Herts, who save bonds in the sum of $50,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent editorial in your most excellent daily, under the heading of "The Problems of City Churches," you mentioned some startling facts in conection with the Baptist ministers' conference of Chicago. You say that the ministers were quite agreed "that unless the church becomes a continued vaudeville it cannot hold its congregation.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 24 -- As a Christmas present to its employes, the Syracuse Rapid Transit Company announces that it will increase wages from 7 to 9 per cent., according to the length of service. About 250 men are affected.

The London Stock Exchange was open yesterday, and its record was a rousing exhibition of interest in American securities. British issues lagged, many English speculative favorites being even sensationally weak. Far away colonial promotions are not yielding such returns as London has been counting upon.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 24 -- E.H. Sothern resumed his tour to-night, after the long suspension of work caused by an injury to his foot, appearing with Miss Virginia Harned in Hamlet before a large audience.

It is easy to imagine that Gov. ROOSEVELT rose from the reading of the papers of yesterday with a feeling that his action in regard to the District Attorney had failed to impress the public mind as he supposed that it would. The World approved the action on general principles, and with little reference to the facts adduced in evidence.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Charles Loeffler, who with his son Joseph, was turned out of the City Hospital early yesterday morning alter their burns had been dressed, is back in that institution to-day.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Dec. 24 -- Sweeping changes among the officials of the Pennsylvania lines, East and West, will be announced on Wednesday it was authoritatively stated here to-day after a meeting of the Pennsylvania Board of Directors in Philadelphia.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 24 -- The Colonial Cabinet has decided to await action by the Imperial Government before determining upon a policy with respect to the renewal of the French shore modus vivendi, when it expires next Monday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 24 -- After hearing and denying a renewal of the motion for the discharge of the prisoner, Judge Phillips of the County Court to-day passed sentence on Peter Austin, who was convicted ten days ago of manslaughter in the second degree for killing his farm hand, Charles Brower, and throwing the body into an old well, fourteen years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Two young ladies, former school companions, were talking together about the principles of the so-called science which bears the name "Christian." One had become a Christian Scientist, the other had not. Said the latter:

EAST BRAINTREE, Mass., Dec. 24 -- The torpedo-boat destroyer MacDonough was successfully launched at the works of the Fore River Iron Company at noon to-day amid the ringing of bells and the blowing of whistles. Mrs. Lucy Charlotte MacDonough Reade of Philadelphia christened the vessel with champagne.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- The closing of the Holy Door took place to-day amid the utmost pomp of the Church. The entire Pontifical Court participated in the ceremonies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An article on Page 12 of this morning's issue of THE TIMES with the heading "Man Who Used Unauthorized Stationery to Solicit Funds Disappears" conveys an entirely erroneous and totally unwarranted impression which even the body of the article itself does not justify.

QUEENS, L.I., Dec. 25. -- The usual holiday match at 25 or 50 birds at the Inter-State Park traps was omitted to-day, and the day was devoted to five-bird sweepstakes, of which 16 were decided, in addition to two small matches. The conditions of the sweepstakes were the same throughout -- $3 entrance, birds extra, two high guns, and handicap rises.

CHICAGO, Dec. 25. -- Profs. J. Loeb and D.J. Lingle of the Chicago University have been experimenting for months on the muscles of the heart and have found, they assert that certain ions or products of the electrolytic decomposition of a solution of salt are the life-prolonging substances which work on the muscles through the blood.

Here is what one of the big men of the Stock Exchange has to say of the changes in the financial world that are taking place: "Mark this as a prediction. By 1910, and possibly within less time, members of the New York Stock Exchange will be trading in London securities, just as American securities are now being traded in in London.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25. -- Jockey Tod Sloan made his first appearance in the saddle to-day since his return from England. It was at Tanforan, in the Christmas Handicap. The race was won by Eddie Jones, an outsider, with Jenkins up. It was also Jenkins's first ride since returning from England.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 25. -- This has been one of the brightest and happiest of Christmas days in the history of Lakewood. The early morning opened gray, with an occasional flake of snow dropping, but by 10 o'clock a warm sun broke through the clouds and cheered the hearts of thousands of sojourners, who were prepared to enjoy the numerous celebrations in sports and pastimes and indoor entertainments that had been arranged.

Twenty-five thousand of the unfortunate poor of the city were gathered from the four quarters of the metropolis by the soldiers of the Salvation Army yesterday, feasted to the verge of dyspepsia, blessed, and sent back happy to cheerless tenements or the lodging houses of the municipality.

A correspondent yesterday took exception to our statement that, in the matter of the canteen, the Prohibitionists and the saloon keepers were in alliance, not for the first time, against the measure of practical temperance legislation which the establishment and maintenance of the army canteen have provided.

James Joseph Traynor, for twelve years manager of the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum in Fifth and Madison Avenues, and who, in other days, was a prominent Democratic politician, died early yesterday morning at his home at 40 East Fifty-first Street of asthma.

It would be interesting to see the text, which has not reached even the State Department, of the protest, or proviso, by which Mr. CONGER attempted to minimize the significance of his signature to the terms of peace laid down by a majority of the allies. Evidently we cannot unreservedly accept the version given even by the State Department, of the nature and effect of a document which that Department has not yet seen.

New Yorkers generally celebrated Christmas at home, with family parties and family dinners. The heads of families participated in the distribution of gifts to members of their household and their employes. This is how some individuals spent the day:

With Christmas in the past and the holidays begun, there will be a slight revival of gayety in town to-day. Some of those who went to the country for Christmas will return this morning to the city. The majority of the leisure element will not come in until after New Year's. In the continued absence of severe frost there will be meets and runs with the hounds at Meadow Brook and Lakewood.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 25. -- William Easton, the New York thoroughbred horse auctioneer, says that the American Breeders' Protective Association is wrong in theory and is perhaps a trust to discourage the small breeder. The theory of the association is to buy in cheap, underbred mares and fillies or high-bred ones of bad individuality and sell them without their pedigrees as work horses.

LONDON, Dec. 26. -- The position of Cape Colony is hanging in the balance. According to The Morning Post's Cape Town correspondent, everything depends upon the quantity of ammunition in possession of the disloyal Dutch residents, fifteen hundred of whom have joined the Boers in the Philipstown district alone.
She was only a tiny mite of a girl, and the paleness of her thin little face was heightened by the black ringlets that fell about her neck.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Dec. 25. -- Smallpox may stop work in the pineries of Northern Minnesota. The disease is ravaging the camps, having been brought in from Michigan, and the utmost alarm prevails. Two or three thousand woodsmen have already fled in an endeavor to escape the disease, and the indications are that unless stringent measures are adopted there will not be a man left in the pineries at the end of the present week.

In connection with the National bowling championships, to be decided at Chicago Jan. 8 to 12, inclusive, there will be held a woman's United States bowling championship, under the direction of the Women's Chicago Bowling Association. There will be three championships decided; for teams of five women, teams of three, and for individuals, so that the scope of the women's championship tournament will be identical with that of the men.

If the Committee of Fifteen pursues its work with relentless energy and Mr. NIXON'S Tammany Committee on Vice keeps its word, we shall presently have a new Mayor and a new Chief of Police. We do not see how these two committees can fail to find abundant evidence of neglect of duty by the two officials we have named.

Wall Street expects a live day to-morrow. The buoyancy at the close of last week, the boom preceding the Christmas holiday, naturally enough incites the expectation of continuing activity and strength, while developments during the Stock Exchange vacation add to the confidence of this anticipation.

When the Allan-State liner State of Nebraska reached her pier yesterday morning the officers and crew declared the voyage to have been the worst they had ever experienced in their seafaring lives. From the Irish port of Moville, from which she sailed on the 9th, for two weeks the vessel was tossed and rocked incessantly, hardly a moment's abatement of the frightful weather conditions being noticeable during all this time.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 25. -- Two trains on the Newark branch of the Erie Railroad met head on at Franklin Crossing to-night. A fireman was badly injured and many passengers were bruised and shaken up.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 25. -- The Country Club traps claimed the attention ot the largest party of the season this afternoon, the chief attraction being a twenty-five-yard handicap rise for a fifty-dollar trophy presented by George J. Gould, President of the club. Besides this special Christmas day event the party filled the afternoon with five-bird sweepstakes and miss-and-out competitions.

The North American Review will in its January number present an article on "The Simultaneous Newspapers of the Twentieth Century," contributed by Alfred Harmsworth, editor and proprietor of The London Daily Mail, published simultaneously each day in London and Manchester, who is due here to-day on the steamship Teutonic.

While a vaudeville performance was in progress in the Manhattan Music Hall, 104 and 106 Bowery, last night, a fire started in the cellar of the building and the flames darted up through the floor just behind, the back row of seats. There were about 500 people in the hall at the time, and a lively panic ensued.

Yesterday's good weather, backed up as it was by a holiday, served to Bring out the local harriers in great profusion. The various trails in and about New York were well filled by the lightly clad, speeding athletes, and some capital sport was enjoyed. Down at Bay Ridge there were several good runs.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 25. -- A dispatch from Mishawka, Ind., says: "The United States Rubber Company, the great Eastern trust which controls nearly all the rubber shoe industries in this country, has submitted in writing a proposition to the Mishawaka Rubber Boot and Shoe Company providing for the sale of the local concern.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Dec. 25. -- News of a terrible massacre of the reform forces in China and the beheading of twenty-seven of its leaders was received here to-day in a cablegram by W.A. Cumrow, Secretary of the Chinese Reform Association in America.
