Considerable interest was aroused by the publication in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday of the proposed project to change the plans of the new Hall of Records so as to convert the building into one that may be utilized for the purposes of the Supreme Court and the offices of the County Clerk, Surrogate, and Sheriff.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 25. -- The crew on the Chatham milk train on the Harlem Railroad, which was due to arrive at Mount Vernor at midnight on Monday, had a remarkable escape from death, while a passenger train which followed the milk train narrowly escaped destruction by the collapsing of Tanner's Bridge, over a creek midway between Dover Plains and Wassay.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 25.--A conference of Mr. Gorman, Gov. Smith, Chairman Vandiver of the Democratic State Committee, and other leading Democrats will be held before Jan. 1 to decide upon numerous petitions from Democrats of Baltimore City, as well as other parts of the State, urging the Governor to call an extra session of the Legislature.

Buchanan Winthrop died at his residence, 279 Fifth Avenue, yesterday, morning. Mr. Winthrop's death was a sudden one. He. played golf at Ardsley on Saturday last, and on returning home was taken ill with what proved to be appendicitis. He grew steadily worse, and an operation was performed on Monday night, from the effects of which he did not rally.
LONDON, Dec. 26. -- The Times this morning prints another long article upon the progress of American steel and iron competition, concluding as follows:

Thousands of people journeyed to the Harlem River Speedway yesterday and witnessed what was undoubtedly the liveliest and most interesting morning's sport this Fall. The gathering of trotters and pacers was an unrivaled one in point of speed and quality, while the crowd was a record-breaker for a holiday.

With five ugly contusions on his head, a battered face, and bleeding lips, Vincenzo Romei, twenty-six years old, of 224 East Ninety-seventh Street, scarcely able to stand, was arraigned yesterday morning in the Harlem Police Court on a charge of felonious assault. The arraignment was made by Policemen McGuire and Rosenfeld of the East One Hundred and Fourth Street Station.

One of the queerest cases of hallucination the experts on insanity at Bellevue Hospital have had is that of Jacob Marks, a waiter, of 441 Third Avenue, who was taken to them in a strait-jacket last night. He imagines himself to be the battleship Oregon, and he whistles, backs, and lights with imaginary Spanish war vessels and sinks them.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 25. -- The Christmas handicap of the Golf Club of Lakewood was held to-day under the most perfect weather conditions, and many entered into competitive play, mixed foursomes, and friendly matches. The links were comfortably filled throughout the day.

The desire of some of the Judges of the Supreme Court for better accommodations for their work than they now have is entirely legitimate and commendable. Their desire to gratify it by taking over a building authorized and planned and begun for another public purpose is by no means so legitimate.

The gunners of the Crescent Athletic Club had a busy day at the Bay Ridge traps yesterday, over 2,000 targets being trapped. The principal event of the day was the shoot for the Christmas Cup, a handsome silver trophy offered by the Shooting Committee. The conditions called for twenty-five targets at the expert traps and twenty-five at the Magau traps, with handicaps added.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 25.--A quartet of very interesting events comprised the trap-shooting tournament of the Hempstead Gun Club here to-day on its new grounds on Hempstead Heath. There was little or no wind, and the weather was almost perfect for fine shooting. Quite a holiday turnout witnessed the sport, and some good scores were made.

PARIS, Dec. 25. -- Christmastide was favored in France with bright, cheerful weather, and Parisians celebrated it in characteristic fashion. All the restaurants and cafes were crammed on Christmas Eve with festive supper parties, which did not disperse until early this morning. At midnight masses, with special musical attractions, filled the leading churches to overflowing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23. -- The following notice was posted to-day by the Secretary of Agriculture:

Throughout the city yesterday many institutions, charitable and religious, and private individuals provided Christmas dinners for thousands of poor people. In the Tombs and in all of the many city prisons, in hospitals, in churches, and in public halls there was Christmas cheer such as only turkey and cranberry sauce and other gastronomic delights can inspire.

The greatest work done for the establishment of National unity, and for the peace, strength, and order which flowed from National unity, was done by the first Secretary, of the Treasury of the United States. A work of like kind, on a broader field, with possible consequences even more important to the Nation and to the world, remains to be done in the finances of the country.

LONDON, Dec. 27.--The paucity and obscurity of the dispatches from South Africa give rise to renewed anxiety. Apparently the disturbed area of Cape Colony extends further south than it did last December, and Lord Kitchener does not appear to have had much success as yet in driving back the invaders.
A.H. PIERCE, the richest cattleman in Texas, died yesterday at Pierce Station, He was many times a millionaire, with vast interests in Texas.

The situation in parts of the Eastern Hemisphere, and antecedent events having relation thereto, can be made clear by a simple parable drawn, as all instructive parables should be, from a contemporaneous incident.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- A plan to recruit sailors for the United States Navy from the farms and country towns is now under consideration at the Navy Department. Recruiting now is carried on outside of the large cities, but it has not reached the interior sections remote from large centres.

Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court, yesterday adjudged Lawyer Joseph Martin, his son William J., and his client, Emmanuel Popper, in contempt of court. The Justice, on entering the order, made very severe comments on the practice of the Martins and said he would reserve punishment until after the parties had corrected what had been done in the proceedings, as the practice followed brought two other Justices into the case.

The team of the Roseville Athletic Association of Newark won three games from the Spartan five in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. Rentsch of the Spartans arrived only in time to roll the last seven frames of the last game. The scores:

It is evident that the modish world of New York has not yet recovered from the influence of the virtual three days' holiday which the falling of Christmas on Tuesday brought this year. This reaction, with the absence of a majority of the men and women who influence society doings, and who are still in the country, combines to make the week somewhat dull in town.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 26 -- Another Baltimore bank has closed its doors. Judge Stockbridge to-day, with the consent of the President and officers of the Old Town Bank, appointed Roger T. Gill of the law firm of N. Rufus Gill Sons receiver of the institution. Mr. Gill gave bond in the sum of $1,500,000, twice the value of the assets of the bank.

BOSTON, Dec. 26 -- They had to enlarge the official sheet to accommodate the record of Boston's morning dealings. Most of the activity came in Sugar, Atchison, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Federal Steel, but home features by no means were neglected, and there was large trading in Cochiti, Massachusetts Electric, and other stocks.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- After a Christmas recess of three days, the military court of inquiry resumed this afternoon its investigation of alleged brutal hazing at the West Point Military Academy.

EASTHAMPTON, L.I., Dec. 26 -- John E. Overton, State Game Protector, has secured the conviction of Warren Hendrickson of Springs for killing a deer that swam across from Gardiner's Island to Long Island. Hendriekson claims that the deer was about dead when he came ashore, and so he really did not kill him; but he was informed that even so he had no right to take possession.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Before the First Civil Tribunal of the Seine to-day Maitre Bonnat resumed his speech, begun on Dec. 20, when the case was adjourned for a week, on behalf of the Count and Countess Boniface de Castellane in the suit of Charles Wertheimer, a London bric-a-brac dealer, to recover payment for art objects sold to the defendants, the transaction taken as a test case involving the sum of 12,946f.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 4 -- El Liberal, a Government daily newspaper published here, continues to refer to efforts which it declares Dr. Adam Cardenas, the former President of Nicaragua, and others expatriated from this country, have been making to organize a revolution against President Zelaya.

A remarkable game of billiards characterized the opening of the contest for the Knickerbocker Athletic Club championship last night in the club rooms, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. Charles A. Norris, a Class A player, and Dr. A.B. Miller, a Class B player, were the contestants, and their match over the fourteen-inch balk-line table was watched with intense interest by a large delegation of club members.

Ohamls Ghiragosin of Harpoot, Armenia, was arrested yesterday on the charge of abducting a fifteen-year-old Armenian girl. Both the prisoner and the alleged victim, Luciak Kircorian, were steerage passengers on the Hamburg-American liner Pennsylvania, which arrived from Mediterranean ports on Saturday.

Asa Bird Gardiner, deposed as District Attorney by Gov. Roosevelt, relinquished his office yesterday to his successor, Eugene A. Philbin; and then, once more a private citizen, walked out on Broadway to hunt for quarters for a new office. District Attorney Philbin yesterday occupied himself until five o'clock familiarizing himself with his new duties and becoming acquainted with his staff of assistants.

The Board of Public Improvements yesterday voted against the plan to repay to property owners $2,500,000 collected for the Elm Street improvement. This is the end of a long fight which has been carried on by lawyers and property owners to induce the city to assume the whole cost of the widening of Elm Street.

Controller Coler will make the last bond sale of this century at the highest price ever paid for bonds of the City of New York. Bids for issues amounting to $3,555,00, bearing 3 1/2 per cent. interest. were opened yesterday. Of the issue $1,500,000 is to be used by the Department of Docks and Ferries, $1,610,000 for the new Hall of Records, and $445,000 for high schools and high school sites.

Thomas B. Williams, ex-member of the Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange, who, for twenty years, has been a familiar figure on the Exchange and on Wall Street, died yesterday at his residence, 41 West Thirty-seventh Street. He was born at Pine Ridge, Miss., on May 17, 1853, and was educated there.

This is the season of the year when peace on earth, good-will toward man, reigns, but for the past two Christmases there has been a sad gloom hanging over this country. To-day the United States is standing forth as one of the worst of all nations, for she is expressing ill-will toward man; she is at war.

The stock market yesterday, though irregular, and under the pressure of enormous realizing sales, was strong, and at the close actually buoyant. The opening, especially in such stocks as Sugar, Tennessee Coal, Brooklyn Rapid Transit, and St. Paul, was excited, each of these issues opening up from three to four points above the close of Saturday.

BERLIN, Dec. 26 -- In its yearly financial review, the Frankfurter Zeitung points out that one of the most important facts of the last twelve months has been the growing influence of the United States upon the economic situation of Europe.

There is a three-cornered fight among Democrats over the selection of a successor to F.B. Delehanty as a member of the State Board of Mediation and Arbitration. Mr. Delehanty recently moved from Albany to New York, and through the influence of ex-Senator Edward Murphy, Jr., who is related to him by marriage, was nominated for Judge of the City Court and was elected.

If Adolph Monnell Sayre, who is reputed to have become a millionaire in the past three years through the rise in Boston copper stocks, and who up to last July lived at 683 Fifth Avenue, does not appear within the next six weeks to defend a suit for $4,500 brought against him by Miss Maude H. Kirtland of Washington, D.C., whatever property he has in this city will be attached to satisfy her claims.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 26 -- James E. Howell, appearing for Henry E. Spinks of Ohio and other stockholders in the Asphalt Company of America, known as the American Company, appeared before Vice Chancellor Emery to-day and asked for a temporary injunction restraining the officers and others of the American Company from transferring certain stocks of the American Company to the National Asphalt Company, which is known as the Asphalt Trust.

The Board of Aldermen held the last meeting of the year yesterday, and voted not to "stop the progress of the next century," as was threatened by Alderman Bridges. They did other things. Senator McCarren, one of the trusted lieutenants of Hugh MeLaughlin, wanted a park scheme put through.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 26 -- It is now known that Pat Crowe was seen in South Omaha scarcely twenty hours before the abduction of Eddie Cudahy. On Monday night, Dec. 17, a well-known citizen of South Omaha conversed with him for nearly an hour. Just before they parted Crowe was questioned concerning his future plans, and laughingly replied: "Oh, I have something big on; you'll hear from me soon."

LOUSVILLE, Ky., Dec. 20 -- American capitalists have won a signal victory in Guatemala, according to a letter from United States Minister W. Godfrey Hunter, to his son in Louisville. Without any cash consideration whatever and in the face of strong competition from French, English, and German syndicates, the Central American Improvement Company, a Massachusetts corporation, comes into possession of the State Railroad of Guatemala, known as the Guatemalan Railroad.

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, Dec. 19 -- The Legislative Assembly of Porto Rico has been in joint session since Dec. 3, when the House of Delegates was duly organized. The predicted clashes and split-up of the Republican Party have not materialized. The House sessions are as harmoniously conducted as one could wish.

Corporation Counsel Whalen decided yesterday that a man who enlisted in the army after the surrender of Gen. Lee at Appomattox and before the issuance of the peace proclamation by President Lincoln was "in the civil war" and was entitled to all the privileges of a veteran of many battles.

Mrs. Barbara Dietz, the wife of William Dietz, a butcher, died on Christmas Day in the Flatbush Hospital. Her husband says that her death was the result of inhuman treatment to which she was subjected by a City Marshal and two attendants about ten days ago. The family lived at 123 Debevoise Street.

Contractor Daniel Doody, who was found guilty of perjury by a jury in the Kings County Court on Friday, yesterday was sentenced to five years at hard labor in State prison by Judge Hurd. Doody was indicted for perjury in connection with the second trial of Robert W. Fielding, charged with conniving to defraud the city while Deputy City Works Commissioner of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Mr. and Mrs. Levi Z. Letter last evening signalized their return to Washington after three years' absence by a large reception, which brought to their Dupont Circle home several hundred guests. The elaborate floral decoration usual on such occasions was dispensed with almost entirely.

That seems to be a well-taken point that appears in the Associated Press dispatches from Washington, apparently from an authorized and official source. It is that, since we ceased to fight for the rescue of the besieged legationers, we have no military force in China, and shall not be bound to send any, whatever happens in consequence of the terms of peace delivered by the allies.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Within the limits of Chicago, and scarcely ten miles from the City Hall, a bold and hungry wolf roams at night. Emboldened by hunger, the wolf is reported to have invaded Elmwood Cemetery, a mile west of the city, and to have dug part way to a coffin before being discovered and driven away.

William Moses Tebo, a wealthy and well-known citizen or Brooklyn, died at his homo, Crooke Avenue and St. Paul's Place, Flatbush, on Christmas morning of a complication of diseases. Mr. Tebo was born in the Province of Quebec on May 14, 1828. He moved to the State in early life and began work as a civil engineer and dredger.

-- People who complain about the manners of women in public places -- as did with particular vivacity, the other day, one of our readers who had strayed into a department store filled with holiday shoppers -- make a mistake when they ascribe the behavior which shocks them to anything except the very natural limitations of feminine courtesy.

In most parts of the list the outside market yesterday showed some increase in activity over the closing days of last week. Largely in sympathy with the active and strong market on the Stock Exchange, prices advanced considerably, and here and there were issues that showed fairly large totals.

LINCOLN, Neb., Dec. 26 -- The annual banquet of the Jefferson Club of Lincoln to-night at the Lincoln Hotel brought together nearly 300 representative men of the Democratic and Populist Parties of Nebraska, together with a number of leaders from other States. William Jennings Bryan made his first appearance at a public gathering since the election, and the greeting accorded him was never more hearty and spontaneous in his home city.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- In the course of a careful review, published in The Morning Post to-day, of the conditions existing at Peking, H.J. Whigham, the well-known newspaper correspondent and golf player, says there are now a quarter of a million inhabitants pursuing their ordinary avocations in the American quarter.
Is the younger generation of the Vanderbilts going into other than railway investments?

The fifty-sixth annual report of the Woman's Prison Association and the Isaac T. Hopper Home, 110 Second Avenue, showed a total of 169 inmates. The report recommends strongly the advisability of the "accumulative sentence law." On this the report says in part: "The majority of women sent to our correctional institutions are so-called 'rounders' -- women who have spent years alternating between prisons and liquor saloons.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- The evidence introduced to-day by the defense in the trial of young Edgar C. Burnz for the murder of Herbert B. Fellows, the Searsdale station agent and Postmaster, before Judge Keogh tended to show that the accused is a degenerate, whose moral weakness has been exaggerated by the excessive smoking of cigarettes.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- There is every reason to believe now that John Armstrong Chanler, the millionaire, who escaped from Bloomingdale Asylum at White Plains on Nov. 28 last, never intends to return to that institution as he said he would. Samuel B. Lyons, Superintendent of Bloomingdale, said to-day that he firmly believes that Chanler has gone for good.
Mrs. Mary Slater of 682 East One Hundred and Seventy-third Street was a silent spectator while her home was robbed in broad daylight by two daring burglars.

Mr. HARMSWORTH'S idea of a great consolidated newspaper, continental, dominant, combining all the cash and all the talents, is not new to us in this country. That iridescent dream has troubled the slumbers of many an editor and many a publisher, but it has never come to fulfillment, or anywhere near it.
Charles Frohman has engaged Otis Harlan and has made him a member of his musical comedy company which is presenting "The Girl from Up There."

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Dec. 26 -- The Directors of the Pittsburg, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad, otherwise known as the Pan Handle system, to-day declared a dividend of 2 per cent. on the preferred stock of the company, payable Jan. 15.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 26 -- Gov, Voorhees to-day decided the extradition case brought by the authorities of Bridgeport, Conn., to have Emma F. Richards, formerly of that city, turned over to them. The Bridgeport authorities say she was allowed to purchase by notes a livery stable in that city, and that on taking possession she departed with the horses and carriages, all of which she brought to Bergen County, in this State.
QUEENSTOWN, Dec. 27 -- The Japanese Government dredger Sente foundered last evening off Cork Harbor.

Frieda Lippert of 919 Park Avenue. Hoboken, has begun suit against Charles Peter, son of the well-known brewer of that town, for $30,000 damages for breach of promise. Miss Lippert in her complaint says she met Peter at Busch's Hotel, in Hoboken, on July 8 last when she returned from Germany, where she had been on a visit to relatives.

DOVER, Del., Dec. 26 -- Democratic leaders from all parts of the State to the number of about 150, and Including all Democratic Asemblymen-elect except three, held a conference here to-day to consider the situation relative to the election of two United States Senators by the Legislature, Which will convene Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Secretary Cortelyou to-day announced the following arrangements for the President's New Year's reception.
The Athletic Committee or the Knickerbocker Athletic Club has prepared an elaborate programme for its Winter Carnival of Sports, which will be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 4.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 -- Several changes were made in the organization of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day at a meeting of the Directors.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The War Office has begun the promised reform of the army in a sensational manner. It has demanded the resignation of Major Gen. Sir Henry Edward Colvile, commanding an infantry brigade at Gibraltar and recently commanding the Ninth Division of the South Africa field force.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 27 -- William H. Smythe, Secretary of the Masonic Grand Lodge of this State, was shot in the head in his offices in the Masonic Building here shortly after noon to-day. It is believed that he cannot live. Mr. Smythe claims a woman did the shooting, but the police have so far been unable to locate her.

The Chamber of Commerce, in apparent despair of securing a real reform in taxation from the Legislature, has again taken up its movement to induce the Legislature to adopt the principle of local option in the levying of taxes. We do not know how far that can be carried with the consent of the out-of-town members of the Legislature, but we have no doubt whatever that it is a just and expedient policy.

-- There are not a few municipal departments, the heads of which, when subjected to popular criticism, can reply, often with truth and always with some degree of credibility, that only those possessed of specialized information concerning the work done and the difficulties under which it is accomplished have any right to set themselves up as judges.

Alfred C. Harmsworth, editor and owner of The London Daily Mail, arrived in New York on the White Star liner Teutonic yesterday. He is accompanied by his wife, and comes to this country on a much-needed vacation. Most of his time in the country will be spent in visiting the various Winter resorts in Florida and other Southern States.

Trouble which has been brewing between the Provident Savings Life Assurance Society and some of its men came to a climax yesterday, when two of the employes were locked up in the West Thirtieth Street Station on a technical charge of the larceny of $500.

Dr. John J. Paulson of 148 Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, who at one time had a considerable reputation in that borough as a practicing physician, was arraigned before Magistrate Bristow in the Butler Street Police Court, yesterday, on a charge of vagrancy preferred by a policeman who had found him wandering about the streets.

Another case was before Justice Worcester in the Eleventh District Municipal Court yesterday involving rental of apartments in the Hartley apartment house, at One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Central Park, in which the defendant declares he was forced to leave on account of the presence of ferocious and obtrusive rats.

Henry A. Seymour, one of the partners of Seymour, Johnson Co., stock brokers of 71 Broadway, who failed in May last, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday, both individually and as a partner in the firm, so as to put the affairs of the firm into bankruptcy. He requested David Webster to join in the petition, but the latter refused.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- There was an unusually large attendance of spectutors at both the morning and afternoon sessions of the military court of inquiry at the Military Academy to-day. The fact that two witnesses from distant points would be called upon to testify was the cause of the increased interest.

Dr. Ulysses Higgins Brown of Syracuse, N.Y., one of the most prominent oculists in the country, was found lying unconscious yesterday morning inside the iron palings of a shallow areaway at 200 West Forty-fifth Street, the home of Richard King, a broker.

ANDERSON, Ind., Dec. 27 -- Mrs. Helen Karcher Miller, daughter-in-law of William H. H. Miller, Attorney General in the Cabinet of President Harrison, who yesterday abducted her son, alighted from a train in this city to-day after the child had again been taken from her, at Lawrence, where they spent the night.

The Republican County Committee at its adjourned annual meeting last night elected Robert C. Morris President and Chairman, and made three changes in the membership of the Executive Committee. To make Mr. Morris eligible for the Chairmanship he was chosen a representative from the Twenty-ninth District in place of the late William L. Strong.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Disguised as a woman, Pat Crowe, who is being sought by the police all over the United States on the charge of kidnapping Eddie Cudahy at Omaha, has been seen in Chicago within the last few days, and may still be hiding here, according to statements made tonight by Detective Sergt. James Storen, a Chicago police officer, who has arrested Crowe a number of times in the past.

The North American Company, which has been one of the conspicuous financiering companies of Wall Street, has passed into the control of J.P. Morgan, and is to be used by him to further the great coal deal known to the Street as the Coal Trust, of which the acquiring of the Pennsylvania Coal Company was the initial step.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Announcement was made to-day of the acquisition by the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company of the Pecos Valley and Northeastern Railroad. The line runs from Amarillo, Texas, where it connects with the Santa Fe system to Pecos City, a distance of 372 miles.

The stock market yesterday in the early trading was influenced by the lower prices sent over from London, and by a report industriously circulated on the floor that the bankers were to call a large number of loans and that money rates at the same time would be sent sharply up.

AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 27 -- Word was received here to-day that David R. Paige of New York has paid the last dollar of his indebtedness. The report was verified by City Commissioner A.T. Paige of this city, a brother of David R. Paige, who said:

Negotiations are understood to be pending for the acquisition of the Columbia Bank, a State institution located at Forty-second Street and Fifth Avenue, by the National City Bank. Rumors to this effect were current in Wall Street yesterday. It was said that President Stillman of the National City Bank, and William Rockefeller would soon be elected Directors of the Columbia Bank.
The Frank L. Fisher Company has sold for Josephine Halstead, for $35,000, the four-story dwelling 127 West Seventy-fourth Street, 20 by 60 by 100.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 27 -- The New Jersey State Teachers' Association met in the auditorium of the High School this afternoon. President Edward Shepperd called the meeting to order. Among the speakers were Gov. Voorhees, President Schurman of Cornell University, Controller Coler of New York, and Bishop Potter of New York.

ROCHESTER, Dec. 27 -- Health Officer Goler has made the statement that an epidemic of rabies is now raging in Rochester. "I do not think the situation," says Mr. Goler," can be described otherwise than as alarming. Its violence, I am persuaded, will equal that which marked the epidemic in Buffalo last year.

The wedding of Stuyvesant Fish Morris, Jr., and Miss Elizabeth Hillis Wynkoop was celebrated yesterday afternoon in Calvary Church, Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue. The Rev. Dr. J. Lewis Parks officiated. The bride had no maid of honor or bridesmaids. Her gown was of white silk crepe, over silk.

BARRE, Vt., Dec. 27 -- Chief of Police Patrick Brown is in a critical condition, with small hopes for recovery, on account of three bullet wounds inflicted by Italians early to-day. The Chief had been called to a hall in which an Italian Socialist society was holding a ball, to quell a row. Several persons were driven from the hall.
Army. The resignation of Major Henry P. McCain Assistant Adjutant General, of his commission as Captain of Infantry (Fourteenth Regiment only, has been accepted, to take effect Dec. 11.

The editor and proprietor of The Commoner, Lincoln, Neb., announced on Wednesday evening to a company of his fellow-townsmen that the periodical of which he is the head would have a monopoly for the next four years of contributions from the possible and even probable candidate of the Populist-Democratic Party for the Presidency.

Bishop Potter presided, and former Mayor Abram S. Hewitt was the principal speaker at a meeting which was held yesterday afternoon at the Pro-Cathedral, in Stanton Street, for the purpose of raising funds, for the extension of its work. A good many fashionable people from the different parishes in Bishop Potter's diocese were present.

JOHN C. GOODRIDGE, M.D., of this City died yesterday at Lakewood, N.J. He was a prominent young physician, with offices both in this city and in Perth Amboy, N. J. He was an alumnus of Williams College and a member of the American Geographical and the New England Societies.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Announcement was made to-day of the voluntary dissolution of the Syracuse Athletic Association upon Dec. 31.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Lord Armstrong died this morning at his home at Cragside.

Currier Bunker, stock brokers, at 52 Broadway and 21 Park Row, and with branch offices at Boston, yesterday made an assignment to William H. Bonynge of 149 Broadway. The firm is composed of Israel L. Currier, who is a member of the Consolidated Stock Exchange, having joined in July last, and Benjamin W. Bunker.

It is getting to be so much the fashion for men to step from the prize ring to the theatrical stage that no one should be surprised by the intrusion of Bernard Shaw's celebrated gentleman "bruiser," Cashel Byron, in the drama. Cashel is the hero of a new play which was "tried," and which, in its turn, severely tried the patience of the spectators, at the Herald Square Theatre yesterday afternoon.

In the line of prisoners that filed before Magistrate Pool, in the West Side Police Court, yesterday morning was one man with disheveled hair and a watery eye who was clad in the full uniform of a member of the Twelfth Regiment.

When Maud Hawthorne, a young married woman, was arraigned in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, charged with attempted suicide, she told a sad story. The young woman is twenty-two years old, and lived with her husband at 299 Marcy Avenue until Christmas Day, when she was deserted.

The Police Board held a meeting yesterday afternoon to advance sixteen Sergeants to Captaincies in as many vacant places. The appointees were chosen from a lift of twenty-five eligibles which had been sent to the board the day before. The vote of the Commissioners on the candidates was unanimous.

Though the transactions yesterday in the market for outside securities were not very large, there was considerable fluctuation in prices. Distilling of America was the most erratic of the active issues, but in a number of other issues as well variations of a point or more were noticed. The majority of the changes resulting from the day's operations appeared on the side pf gains, but in some few cases substantial declines occurred.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- The Yale basket ball team met the team composed of members of the Thirtieth Separate Company in the State armory to-night and defeated the Elmirans by a score of 24 to 4. The college boys won by superior team work and brilliant individual plays. The local guardsmen showed great pluck, but were fairly outclassed.

This evening will be devoted to dancing, both in town and country. The large colony of well-known people who have country houses in and around Morristown, Madison, Morris Plains, and the Oranges will meet at the beautiful country residence of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Thebaud, "Stone Acre," at Morris Plains, where a large dance will be given.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 1/2 @ 65. There were no sales.

For the first time since the days of the Great Eastern a craft of the six-masted type arrived in the harbor of New York yesterday morning. The vessel in question is the schooner George W. Wells, which was recently finished at the Bean Shipyards, in Camden, Me. She is the first six-masted sailing vessel to receive a registry in this or ony other country.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Richard Croker, who had been rusticating for several weeks in Carlsbad and Nice, returned to Wantage two days before Christmas, where he received a summons to appear Jan. 3 to reply to inquiries respecting his income in connection with the income tax.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Money was in good demand and firm to-day in view of the approach of the year-end. Discounts were steady, but there was little doing, even by the Bank of England, which handled most of the business.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- The fight which took place at the last annual meeting between the delegates of the Southern tracks and the Northern men is expected to be renewed at the special meeting of the Western Turf Congress here to-morrow.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Dec. 27 -- Sidney Miller, the seven-year-old son of Samuel D. Miller, and grandson of ex-United States Attorney General W.H.H. Miller, who was kidnapped by his mother last evening, was recovered early to-day by his father. Mrs. Miller and the child were found at Lawrence, six miles east of the city, asleep in the home of a man named Marshall, where they had obtained lodging for the night.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 27 -- For three years United States Secret Service officers have been searching for William H. Post, an escaped prisoner from Ludlow Street Jail, New York City. It has just been learned that Post has been buried in the Danbury Cemetery for over three years.

Mrs Louisa C. Hutchinson, who admits that she is "over seventy years old," and has been divorced from three husbands, has once more come into prominence in the courts. This time she wants a trust which she created in favor of husband No. 4 set aside. The setting aside of this trust is only the preliminary to another action to be legally separated from the man to whom she was last married.

The Cudahy incident at Omaha promises to give rise to an interminable and inconclusive discussion. It involves a subtle problem in casuistry -- or perhaps several such problems -- not unlike those which Oriental sages and story tellers were so fond of, and of which certain modern writers of romance have made good use.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Mrs. Lulu C. Jenkins, now of Chicago, will receive $4,000 for the lynching of her husband in Ripley County, Ind., three years ago. The money will be paid over by the eight bondsmen of exSheriff Henry Bushing, and is the result of a private settlement of the indemnity suit instituted by the widow three months after the murder.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- No definite organization was accomplished this afternoon by the baseball men who came to Chicago to promote the American League No. 2. The standard of salaries, by-laws, and the general lines of the final organization were discussed, but a telegram from Manning of Kansas City, saying he would be here with his representatives early to-morrow, caused the magnates to postpone final action until his arrival.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The following dispatch from Gen. Kitchener has been received from Pretoria, under Thursday's date:

The inquest into the cause of Louis H. Hilliard's death was begun yesterday morning at 11 o'clock, by Coroner Fitzpatrick and a jury in the Criminal Court Building. Hilliard died in the pavilion for the insane at Bellevue Hospital Dec. 12, and his death was followed by the arrest of three nurses, who are charged with assaulting him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Statistician of the Department of Agriculture estimates the United States wheat crop of 1900 at 522,229,595 bushels, the area actually harvested being 42,495,385 acres, and the average yield per acre 12.29 bushels. The production of Winter wheat is estimated at 350,025,409 bushels and that of Spring wheat at 172,204,096 bushels, the area actually harvested being 26,235,897 acres in the former case and 16,259,488 acres in the latter.

Denunciation of Gov. Roosevelt for the removal of Col. Asa Bird Gardiner from the office of District Attorney of this County was the feature of the meeting of the General Committee of Tammany Hall last night.

The question whether Europe is now, and will in future remain, dependent in large degree upon this country for coal continues to be one of great and almost exciting public interest. Our Consuls in every transatlantic country have submitted voluminous reports relative to the existing coal famine, and have emphasized with almost hysterical earnestness the undisputed fact that the European markets would now absorb large quantities of our coal if they could get it.

In a late sermon on the necessity or a truly liberal education for clergymen, Bishop Potter declared it to be an "intolerable impertinence that a man should stand in the pulpit and show himself so defective in matters with the knowledge of which he is charged as not to be able to pronounce the proper names of Scripture according to their classical derivation."

From the days of its ancient and middle and new empires to the present the land of Egypt has been the spoil of successive conquerors, and its defenseless position and the weakness of its native inhabitants have rendered it in turn the prey of African potentates. Persian and Macedonian Kings, Roman Caesars, Mamelukes, and Turkish Sultans.

The week of prayer with which the leading ministers of the country are preparing to open the new century is only the first step in an interdenominational movement to create a great revival all over the country at the beginning of the new century. This movement was suggested by the late evangelist, D.L. Moody, in a talk with William Phillips Hall, the business-man evangelist.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A fearful storm has been raging over England, Wales, and Ireland during the past twenty-four hours, and enormous damage has been done afloat and ashore. The full extent of the disaster will probably not be known for several days, as telegraph wires are down everywhere. As it is, the reports of shipping casualties that have already reached here are almost innumerable, while news of disasters inland is beginning to come in.

There is not much new to be said in treating of the week's developments in the business world. What changes there are are along the lines of betterment and improvement. In some trades unprecedented activity is reported. Retail trade has most benefited and holiday business is said to be abnormally large.

WEST POINT, Dec. 28 -- So far as regards the taking of testimony, the work of the military court of inquiry concerning the death of ex-Cadet Oscar L. Booz will be finished at the West Point Military Academy to-morrow afternoon.

It is hardly to be supposed that the children of the present generation, for whose edification the present volume can be warmly recommended, realize how rich they are not only in beautiful stories, but also in the wealth of detail lavished upon the preparation of volumes intended primarily for their gratification.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- By the close vote of 7 to 6, the Western Turf Congress decided to-night to rescind the rule limiting racing on Chicago and St. Louis tracks to dates between June 30 and Nov. 15. The old rule allowing racing between April 1 and Nov. 30 is now in force, as before the last annual meeting.

It is greatly to be hoped that the House of Representatives will not be coaxed or bullied into enlarging its own numbers in consequence of the census of 1900. The Census Committee has done quite the right thing in fixing the number of the House at the present figure. But of course the report was made before the "pressure" really began.

A verdict to the effect that Louis H. Hilliard came to his death from asphyxiation and fractured ribs caused by Jesse R. Davis, Edward O. Dean, and Clinton L. Marshall, was brought in at 9:06 o'clock last night, by the jury which had heard the evidence at the inquest before Coroner Fitzpatrick.

The long-expected defense of ex-Secretary of War Alger against the attacks made upon his administration of the War Department during the war with Spain is ready for issue. It will appear in the coming number of The North American Review under the title of "The Food of the Army During the Spanish War."

Columbia's freshman hockey team, the first one in her history, made its first appearance in the St. Nicholas Rink yesterday morning in a game with the Drisle, School hockey seven. Although handicapped by the absence of two of its regular players and by the presence of three graduates on the Drisler team, the blue and white managed to win without much difficulty by a score of 3 goals to 0.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The State Department is inclined to discredit the report from Peking that Li-Hung-Chang and Prince Ching have heard from Emperor Kwang-Su, and that the Emperor objects to the provisions in the joint note calling for the reduction of the forts and the permanent establishment of legation guards.

RANDOLPH C. LEWIS, Brooklyn, writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW regarding the morality of "Dr. Dale," says: "The sub-title describes it as a 'A Story Without a Moral.' In default of a specific moral the average reviewer pitches and drifts as a boat without an anchor, unless, indeed, he has caught at a floating straw in the shape of the neatly descriptive paragraph printed upon the outer paper cover of the book.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- At a meeting held this afternoon and evening in the Great Northern Hotel the Western Association of Professional Baseball Clubs was formed. No officers were elected, this action being deferred until next Wednesday, when an adjourned meeting will be held in this city.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Few things are more commonly understood than the frequent fate of genius to fail of adequate recognition during the life of its possessor. An example of unusual note, it seems to me, is furnished by Edwin Markham. If his verse has ever been equaled in point of sustained, purposeful strength in any language or any age.

A statement of operating expenses and earnings of the Southern Pacific Company for the year ended on June 30 last was issued yesterday. This is the first statement of the results of the operation of that system for the last fiscal year. The figures are as follows:

The continuation of unusually large transactions in the Stock Exchange market has apparently led to a directly opposite condition in the outside market. For the past few days the transactions there have been on a very small scale, and yesterday there was a still further decrease in business.

Mr. Charles Whibley, whose manner and choice of subject is always so thoroughly original, so entirely his own, in this book pictures for us new representative men of various races and times, to whom he applies Milton's words, "studious they appear of arts that polish life"; his entire volume being an exposition of the "Art of Life."

Charles S. Norris won his third successive billiard victory last night on the 14-inch balk-line table in the tournament now in progress for the championship of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. He defeated Albro Atkin more easily than any of his opponents thus far, rolling up the required 300 points at the completion of the forty-eighth inning to 145 for Atkin in forty-seven innings.

No doubt many of those who go to the opera at this period of the year are often filled with astonishment when they read the librettos of the operas. It must seem to them at times as if these play books were the work of honest yeomen in the dull Winter season in the spare hours between taking care of the horses and the cattle.

"The South Sea Pearler," by Louis Becke, and his latest work, is a good, clean, albeit rather sensational, "ship story," rather too hackneyed and bloody for "grown-ups," it is just the thing to make the sparkles fly in the adventure-loving eyes of a youngster. Lots of gory plots and bloody mutinies occur all along the "pearlery voyage," and great riches won by courage and stratagem keep the avaricious-minded in a continual state of pleasing excitement.

Although she pleaded guilty to a charge of burglarious entrance and attempted theft, and admitted that she had twice been convicted of grand larceny. Addie Johnson, a colored girl, was yesterday discharged by Magistrate Pool, sitting in the West Side Police Court.

Testimony given by the Rev. Robert L. Paddock was the feature of the opening day's proceedings in the trial of Police Captain John D. Herlihy, recently of the Eldridge Strict Station. The trial began at 2 o clock yesterday afternoon before the four Police Commissioners. Bernard J. York, President of the board, presiding.

Rumors of Chief Devery's early retirement were thicker than ever at Police Headquarters yesterday, but beyond denying the wildest of these none of the Commissioners nor the Chief himself would speak about the matter, and the day passed without positive developments.

The New York City Democracy was organized last evening to fight Tammany Hall candidates in the next Mayoralty contest. The new political association is the outgrowth of the movement started by exSheriff James O'Brien. A wider scope was given to the movement at a, meeting held last evening at 1,481 Broadway.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The discount situation is unchanged. Money is much wanted in connection with the settlement, and the tenders for Treasury bills. Applications for L1,500,000 at L96 2s. 6d. will receive 85 per cent., and for L1,000,000 at L98 Is. 3d. will receive 54 per cent. The Stock Exchange subscribed moderately.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 28 -- While the savings banks of this city paid out to-day about $250,000 to hundreds of timid depositors who held small accounts, the runs were soon checked, and the panicky condition of yesterday did not prevail. The old Baltimore Saving's Bank and one or two others were crowded at times with anxious people, but they were soon quieted.

The standard railway stocks were the features of the market yesterday, with notable advances in many of them. St. Paul, for instance, showed a net gain of 2 1/2 points, Northwest of 1 3/4. Rock Island of 1, Burlington of 3/4, Omaha of 1. Delaware and Hudson of 4 7/8, and Pennsylvania of 1 3/4.

Cutler School, although it has a hockey team fairly capable of holding its own with sevens of equal calibre, was decidedly outmatched in its game with a team composed of Cutler graduates at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. Although the lads tried desperately to defend their goal, their opponents tallied eleven points, and held their own goal unassailable.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Miss Atherton's estimate of the late Senator Davis, in your last issue, I can echo from sixteen years of intimacy. I shall always esteem it one of the privileges of my lifttime that I was allowed to know such a man as he. The last letter. I suppose, he ever wrote entirely with his own hand, lies before me.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 28 -- The subject of the education of the negro in the South has attracted more attention than any other brought before the Southern Educational Association at its meeting here. The most significant address made on this topic was one delivered to-night by Prof. Paul B. Barringer of the University of Virginia.
When Superintendent O'Rourke of Bellevue Hospital was informed of the verdict he said:

Four men instead of one. as was at first supposed, were shot in the affray in the Onawa Hotel Cafe, One Hundred and Twenty-fifih Street and Park Avenue, early yesterday morning, and one of them is dead. It was several hours before the police learned how serious the affair had been. The man who succumbed to his wounds was George Price, who died at his home, 215 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, yesterday afternoon.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It must strike many persons who keep a watchful eye on their children's schoolbooks that the dear old "reader" of our school days -- that book of the charming poems and stories -- is gradually passing away, and a new kind of child's companion, either literary or scientific in its tendencies, is taking its place.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Norman B. Ream and James J. Hill will go into the Directorate of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company at the next annual meeting. It is also rumored that J.J. Hill is to become President of the company.

"The Godly Seer: A True Story of Hi-awat-ha," has been arranged and collated from old sources, such as the rare Clark's "Onondaga," and the even scarcer Cadwallader Colden's "History of the Five Nations," published in London in 1750, as well as from other old writings.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Surrounded by some of the most prominent men in the financial, business, and social life of Boston, Secretary of the Navy John D. Long was the central figure at a banquet at the Algonquin Club to-night, when his achievements in public life were the theme of many speakers.

How came it about that William Pitt did not marry Miss Eden, the daughter of Lord Auckland? The celebrity of the man who ruled the destinies of England at an age when most of the aspirants for political position have been but at the very beginning of their careers has always made Pitt and his actions subjects of special interest.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- In the trial of Edgar C. Burnz for the murder of Herbert B. Fellows, the Scarsdale station agent and Postmaster, the District Attorney introduced as witnesses a number of distinguished insanity experts, whose evidence tended to show that the boy was rational when he committed the crime.

J.C. RESCUE, M.D., Dayton, Ohio, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "Thanks for your article in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 8 on Misused Words." Please keep up the war on murderous changes in our mother tongue. How about 'onto'? It is authorized by lexicographers and has support from its similarity to 'into' and 'unto,' but as to euphony it is horrible.

There has been one distinct and authoritative dissent from the chorus of Continental military critics, proclaiming that the South African war shows that England is, in a military sense, an effete Power. It has been entered by a high Austrian General, and, in the circumstances, must be taken to reflect the opinion of the Austrian General Staff.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- The market to-day took hold of the copper specialties and cut loose from the Standard Oil incubus. Thirty-seven mining stocks were traded in this morning, Old Dominion, Cochiti, and Centennialled in activity, Tamarack in extent of gain. The last named rose 10, to 350, later 346.

The home of Henry Babchin, which is over his jewelry store, at 24 Newark Avenue, Jersey City, was visited by a remarkably careful burglar early yesterday morning. He had gathered several articles which he carried into a room where Babchin's children, Lillian, eight years old, and Sylva, five, were sleeping.

For the first eleven chapters this book appears to belong to the large and increasing class of literature prompted solely by what an English writer has recently called "the cult of the country." It is the chronicle of two townspeople's doings upon an abandoned farm in the White Mountain region, and is told with the gusto that goes with a first time, a novel experiment, and a self-conscious abandonment to unconventional life.

The recent London sale of books and manuscripts, the property of the late Montague David Scott, M.P., and others, comprised many autograph letters of special interest. In one from Charlotte Bronte to "Dear Ellen," dated Aug. 23, 1849, the writer, after referring in anxious terms to the serious illness of her father, says:

Being engaged in the coal business him- self, his words carried more weight than would the declaration of an ordinary man. He is a big dealer from New England, who had been buying coal to try and satisfy the demands of his customers. "Like other dealers in my section of the countrys" said he, "I made a number of contracts with regular customers to supply their Winter coal at a fixed rate per ton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Senators Nelson and Turner, sitting as a sub-committe'e of the Senate Committee on Commerce, today heard arguments in support of the measure now pending in the Senate providing for the establishment of a National Standardizing Bureau.

ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 28 -- Daniel A. Heald, President of the Home Insurance Company, died at his home, Woodside, in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, at 3:40 this afternoon. Heart disease caused his death. He was at his office in New York yesterday, but not feeling well this morning and the weather being bad he did not go to the city.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 28 -- Charles Van Voorhis of this city, owner of the champion yacht Genesee, says the Genesee will not enter the trial races at Chicago next year to try for the honor of defending the Canada Cup. The Genesee is the winner of this cup and defender of the Fisher Trophy.
G.P. Putnam's Sons will shortly publish a story of a boyhood spent in a cattle country, by Melville Post of West Virginia. The book will be entitled "The Dweller in the Hills."

The days that are annually set apart in this community to bring to the attention of the benevolent the needs of the sick poor in our hospitals are once more with us. To-day is "Hospital Saturday," when our fellow-citizens of Jewish faith make contribution to the cause in the synagogues; while to-morrow is "Hospital Sunday," when it is the privilege of the Christian to do a similar service for the afflicted through the church offerings.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In connection with the well-deserved scoring given to Mr. Morley for classing John Paul Jones as a pirate, it may interest the readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW to know how our own most famous writers of naval history have treated the "founder of the American Navy."

William Westlake, one of the founders of the Adams Westlake Company of Chicago, and widely known as an inventor, died yesterday morning at his home, 4 Spencer Place, Brooklyn, of Bright's disease. Mr. Westlake was born in Cornwall, England, in 1831, and came to this country when sixteen years old.

Senator Thomas C. Platt, Governor-elect B.B. Odell, Jr., and Chairman George W. Dunn of the Republican State Committee were in conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel until after midnight last night consulting on matters which will receive the attention of the incoming Legislature. Although Mr. Odell denied that he had submitted a draft of his first annual message to Messrs.

After the glorification of the scarlet woman with pulmonary tuberculosis it was a great delight to all clean-minded people to hear an opera in which there was a celebration of the highest and holiest love known to humanity. This celebration came at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with Beethoven's "Fidelio."

A judgment for $300 was entered in the City Court yesterday against Emily Rigl, the actress. Back of the entry of the judgment is the story of the difficulty of process servers in reaching the actress.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 28 -- One little girl is dead and another is in a critical condition as the result, it is alleged, of being thrown into bonfires by boys. Two boys, John Eckert and Frank Wenzell, both ten years old, and living in the First Ward, are locked up charged with having caused the death of six-year-old Mamie Newbolli, who lived on Hudson Avenue.

For those whose New Year's resolutions include a plan for systematic reading, as well as from the interest of the subjects treated in the series of papers on books and their proper use, opening the volume, this little book will be found of much interest as well as of practical assistance.

If it is possible at this late day to find Stevensonians who do not own copies of his "Father Damien," they may be interested in knowing of this very bookish-looking reprint in volume form of one of the early issues of The Cornhill Booklet. The present edition of "Father Damien: An Open Letter to the Reverend Dr. Hyde of Honolulu," shows the most attractive typography, prettily designed head and tail pieces and initial letters.

Much interest has been manifested in the International Crude Rubber Company, which was incorporated on Monday to bring about the cessation of the rubber war. Little information was obtainable about it until yesterday, when Charles R. Flint issued the following statement from his office:

The last Saturday of the year, and of the century, will be a quiet one in New York, from the social standpoint. Numbers of people went out of town yesterday, to remain until Wednesday next, and still more will follow them to-day. The largest Contingent bound for any one place is that which left for Georgian Court, at Lakewood, where they are to be the guests.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 -- A mail pouch containing $100,000 in negotiable paper and an unknown amount of money was stolen from the Wyandotte (Mich.) station of the Michigan Central Railroad some time last night.

The tail enders met in the National League tournament on Starr's alleys last night, and the Germania team won two of its three matches with the America five, losing the third one by the narrow margin of five pins. The scores:

Amasa Thornton, the well-known Republican politician of this city, was married last night to Mrs. Mary Emma Steinman of 200 Bay Thirty-first Street, Bensonhurst. The marriage was celebrated by the Rev. A.H. Rennie of St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, in Bensonhurst. It had not been previously arranged, and took place while a Christmas entertainment was going on in the church.

Probably soon -- if not immediately -- after the interview with Zaccheus, Jesus and His Apostles left Jerico with the caravan of strangers which they had joined to go to Jerusalem. It was a journey of but a few hours, and they soon re-ached the little town of Bethany -- about "fifteen furlongs" out of the city.

The final blow to objectionable methods in Columbia sport has been struck by the Faculty Athletic Committee in a set of stringent rules and instructions to be sent to the managers of all athletic teams at the university in the future. These rules are severe and clearly stated, but not too severe to be unjustifiable.

Controller COLER is plainly intensely interested in the approaching campaign in this city. He talks about it and writes about it at frequent intervals to all sorts of audiences and in all eons of periodicals. To one has any reason to doubt the sincerity of his feeling or the earnestness of his desire to have the best attainable result from the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry F. Blount to-night gave a Christmas dance at their home, -- The Oaks, near Georgetown. The dance was in honor of the large house party of young people now being entertained by Mr. and Mrs. Blount.
The Livingston estate has sold the two four-story dwellings 4 and 6 East Forty-ninth Street, 50 by 100.5. It is said that the purchaser will erect a bachelor apartment house on the site.

The sensational failure nine years ago of Field, Lindley, Weichers Co., grain and stock brokers, was recalled yesterday by the filing of a petition in bankruptcy by Daniel A. Lindley, one of the partners, to get rid of the firm debts. The total liabilities are $3,101,877, and he has no assets. Mr. Lindley gives his occupation as a clerk at 27 William Street, and his residence at Montclair, N.J.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 28 -- Judge Kirkpatrick. sitting in the United States Circuit Court. District of New Jersey, here to-day, heard argument on the return of a rule to show cause why the Bay State Gas Company of New Jersey should not be restrained from disposing of its property and assets, and why the appointment of Henry C. Kelsey as receiver should not be made permanent.

To the Editor of The New York.Times: It is to be hoped that the word spoken by you and "L.W." against the "tipping" custom will arouse a widespread feeling in opposition to the baneful practice. Established usages come to an end slowly, and this because they usually have for their foundation something beneficial, some good purpose to serve, whatever painstaking search one may be compelled to make in finding it.
SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, Dec. 24 -- The trial of Luiz Munoz Rivera, the leader of the Federal Party, and considered by many, to be the ablest native on the island, has ended in his acquittal.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 20 -- The amazing conspiracy resulting in the abduction of young Eddie Cudahy, the only son of the millionaire packer of Omaha, and the payment of a ransom, continues to be an absorbing topic of conversation in this city. The ease with which the daring plot was consummated and the boldness with which the whole thing was designed and executed seem almost incredible at this day and time.

According to Prof. BARRINGER of the University of Virginia there is danger in educating the negro in the South because it will increase his capacity to compete with the whites in industry, and, since he can live much more cheaply, will convert him into an "economic menace."

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 29 -- To-day Prof. William A. Dunning of Columbia University read a paper before the American Historical Association on the "Break Down of Reconstruction." He declared that the men who handled the negro question about the middle of this century were strong in emotion but narrow in judgment, and labored under the delusion that the abolition of slavery meant a removal of every other obstacle immediately.

The first of the series of four indoor baseball games for the championship of the Armory Indoor Baseball League was played last night in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory between two picked teams representing all New York and All Brooklyn, and resulting in a dispute and the withdrawal of the Brooklyn team in the eighth inning.

An excited cabman and a well-dressed man, with side whiskers, faced each other in the West Side Police Court yesterday morning, and told their respective stories of midnight tribulation, excitement, and vicissitudes, with the scenes laid in and about the Tenderloin District. It was the well-dressed man, with the side whiskers, and not the cabman who was the prisoner this time, although this would not appear so from the demeanor of the two men.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Major Gen. Sir Henry Edward Colvile, whose resignation has been demanded by the War Office, but who refused to resign, and who arrived in England yesterday to demand a trial by court-martial, has made a counter-strike at the War Office in a 3,000-word statement, which he has given to the press.

Although the astronomical events for the first month of the new century will be as many and as attractive as those of the same month in average years, in one field, at least, of this science favors will be less lavishly bestowed than has been the case in many former years.

From Cassier's Magazine. In the last ten years the race for the transatlantic record has been far more interesting than any other period, for it has been in this decade that the great coal burners have been built. It is also the "twin-screw period" of ocean navigation, and with the twin-screws have come greater speed, more and heavier engines, and corresponding increase of boiler power.

From The Catholic Worm. Amalfi at the present day shelters some seven thousand souls and is a relatively lively little place, macaroni, paper, and soap being its chief products. The manufacturing of these articles forms an interesting study and shows how machinery can be employed to reduce manual labor without necessarily involving unpicturesque tall chimneys, black lowering clouds of smoke, or inartistic sights, noises, or odors.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- The first of four ocean-going steamships was launched at South Chicago to-day. The service is planned by Charles Counselman, who took occasion to say of the Ship Subsidy bill:

From The London Mail. The late Mr. Robert Arthington of Leeds was a millionaire who combined miserliness and philanthropy in an extraordinary degree. Inheriting a large fortune derived from brewing, he spent nearly the whole of his life as a recluse in a villa in the suburbs of Leeds, which was scarcely, if ever, entered by a woman, and, consequently, scarcely, if ever, swept.

From Everybody's Magazine. Posing is slow work, but tea, with hot frankfurters between unbuttered slices of bread, filled in the waits to every one's satisfaction. The Indian visitors were polite, but frank. It happened that a crust fell to the share of Iron Tail, whereat he promptly returned it to be exchanged for a slice from the inside of the loaf.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 29 -- Notice was received by Health Officer Dr. John S. Wilson from the State Board of Health tonight to enforce the State law applying to vaccination.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- It is creditably reported, according to a dispatch from Newcastle, dated Dec. 29, that Kruger has sent word that the burghers must lay down their arms or continue fighting on their own account, as no support from Europe can be expected.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- A brilliant spectacle was presented at the Theatre Francais tonight on the return of the Comedie Francais to its old home, which has been rebuilt on scientific plans since it was gutted by fire last March.

Columbia University, having an officially organizes basket ball team for the first time in its history, is planning a very active season, in contests with other colleges, military organizations, and Young Men's Christian Association teams. The candidates for the team have been practicing regularly for the last month under the direction of John Wendelken, and the men have been weeded out considerably from the original twenty candidates.

Crepe de chine is having its innings this year and throws into the shade some old favorites in the way of dress goods. The favorite material is worn in all shades and appears in street as well as evening gowns, house gowns, and in everything in the way of a gown that a clever modiste can suggest.

The operatic concert to be given to-morrow night at Carnegie Hall will mark the last appearance of Mme. Sembrich in New York this season, and the debut of the leading members of her opera company, among them Signor de Lara, Signor Rossi, Signor Bensaude, and Signor Dado, who will support her on the tour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Navy Department has issued a general order commending the courage and gallantry of Franz Anton Itrich, chief carpenter's mate, Unit- ed States Navy, and has awarded him a medal of honor and gratuity of $100.

To the Editor of The New York Times: How many of THE TIMES'S readers ever heard of the Swapping of cats? If the emphatic utterances of my Aunt Cynthia could be believed, this is the particular season of the cat-swappers, although, according to her sayings, a large number of them use birthdays and wedding days for the exchange of felines.

The body of the man who dropped dead in the room of Allen Darnell, at 217 West Fortieth Street, last Friday night, was identified, at the Morgue yesterday morning as that of John Vandervort, sixty-five years old, of 140 Mercer Street, Jersey City, and employed as a salesman in a wholesale dry goods store in this city.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 29 -- Georgian Court, the beautiful home of Mr. and Mrs. George Jay Gould, is the scene of a large house party. The host and hostess, with a number of guests -- among them Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs -- arrived here yesterday. Part of the company were driven to the Laurel-in-the-Pines, where the Goulds had engaged rooms for them, while others went to Georgian Court.

As no games were rolled in the local bowling tournaments on Christmas Eve and the following evening, fewer changes than usual were made in the standing of the clubs as a result of the week's games. In the National League tournament the Oriental team completed its schedule by winning three games from the Golden Rod five.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The cost of the Nicaragua Canal is estimated at over $200,000,000. The history of great engineering undertakings in connection with water show that estimates are generally considerably exceeded. It is estimated, I understand, by the Bureau of Statistics that the traffic that the canal would probably attract would be about 1,000,000 tons annually.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not more than seventy-five people now living in the United States will behold the dawn of the twenty-first century, and it therefore need not concern us very much what that period of time may have in store for us; but we may take a deep interest in what might be accomplished in the new century into which we will be fairly launched next Tuesday.

A year of phenomenal Wall Street records is closing. At the opening of business to-morrow -- the last day of the year -- quotations will be at a range not merely higher on an average than ever before recorded for standard American securities, but they will represent recent appreciation beyond precedent.

From The National Review. That the prejudice in favor of playing instead of working, loafing instead of preparing for a career between sixteen and nineteen years of age, should have ever arisen among the upper and middle classes of our fairly practical nation is as marvelous as that it has lingered so long.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Chairman John Joy Edson is determined, if good management and unusual enterprise on the part of an Inauguration Committee can overcome some unfavorable natural circumstances, to make the inauguration of President McKinley in 1901 as popular a success as it was in 1897.

The customary two performances took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday. At the matinee the opera was Puccini's "La Boheme," which had its second performance. The audience was large and enthusiastic, and there can be no doubt that the public has taken this melodious inconsistency into its favor.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited, has suspended payment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial article of to-day, "Fixing the Responsibility," you are a little too easy on the people of this city when you simply accuse them of "amazing folly in accepting a Chief Magistrate of whom they knew nothing at the hands of a big and very dirty boss about whom they knew much, and all of it bad."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In common with many other gentlemen who have spoken to me about it, I was impressed by the timely and important letter from Mr. Emmet Wells, which, appeared in your issue of Sunday, Dec. 23, under the title "A Plea for Pure Beer," and I am tempted to supplement it out of my own experience.

Report of the United States Commission of Fish and Fisheries. During the last two or three years several private beds of eastern oysters have been established in different parts of Willapa Bay, Washington, and they are reported to be doing well, possibly because it is somebody's interest to protect them from depredations of unprincipled persons.

From Pearson's. If the change of the centuiries took place at either of the equinoxes -- March 22 or Sept. 22 -- then, since on those days the earth's axis is at right angles to the plane of the orbit, and there is equal day and night all over the world, the matter would be very easily decided.

Ewaysert von Rouer, who admits being a Polish nobleman, but who is slightly out at the elbows at present, was a prisoner in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday morning, charged with swindling. The Count, whom wide experience and vicissitudes have not robbed of his debonair carriage, was confronted at the bar by three pretty servant maids, all of whom accused the nobleman of robbing them of their hard-earned wages.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 29 -- Alfred G. Vanderbilt and his future wife will be back in New York from their honeymoon trip to participate in some of the gayety there in the Spring, much of which will doubtless be given in their honor. They will take a house in New York, and one will be rented shortly.

From Harper's Magazine. Apache had not always rejoiced in a church. Some four years ago the Bishop had been holding services at Waywego, the nearest town to the north. After service a stranger came forward and invited him to Apache.

Gov. Roosevelt and President J.G. Schurman of Cornell University formally opened the Cornell Medical College yesterday afternoon in the presence of 250 specially invited guests. The Medical College, situated on First Avenue, and comprising the block from Twenty-seventh to Twenty-eighth Streets, was erected at a cost of $750,000 donated for that purpose to Cornell University by Col. Oliver H. Payne.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Boston had a continued active market, though mining stocks were less active and less pronounced in gains than yesterday. Boston has had little more than skim thus far in the "boom," so far as many of its stocks are concerned; there ought to be a chance for a great, broad copper stock speculation and perhaps it trill come when some people are good and ready.

From The Saturday Review. Vergil fancied that Augustus was bringing back the Age of Gold. The early Christians lived with all their feelings intensified by yearly or even daily anticipation of the second coming of Christ. The English Puritans looked forward to the reign of the saints on earth, and some epoch-making catastrophe which should plunge in the lake of brimstone all whose talents or manners gave grace or Cheerfulness to existence.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 29 -- Dr. Justus O'Hage, Health Commissioner of this city, has issued stringent quarantine orders against the City of Winona, where 500 cases of smallpox are said to exist. He called to-day upon the General Passenger Agents of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul and the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroads and instructed them that they were not to bring passengers from Winona to St. Paul.
The City of Detroit, Mich., tried standard time for just one week. Then the astute Common Council voted to abandon it and return to local time, regardless of railroad timetables.

The annual report of the Indiana, Illinois and Iowa Railroad for the year ended June 30, 1900, shows a net gain in the surplus over last year of $73,548. There was issued during the year $1,302,200 of capital stock, making a total of $5,000,000 issued. The additional stock was sold to aid the Streator and Clinton Railroad in the construction and equipment of its road.

The introduction of an opera new to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera, House might be called an event in the world of music. Puccini's "La Boheme" pleased the audiences which heard it on Wednesday night and yesterday afternoon, chiefly because it contained an abundance of flowing, sentimental melody.

SIMLA, Nov. 29 -- We are wondering whether we are to have on our hands another of those small wars which, ever since the occupation of the Punjab, more than fifty years ago, have succeeded each other with such bewildering frequency.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- Secret negotiations have been going on here for the last three weeks looking toward the control of the steel tube industry of the United States by organizing a combination, which, on completion, will be one of the most, gigantic trusts of its kind in the country, with over $150,000,000 capital.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Reviews of the year and century fill the weeklies and daily papers. In the broader field the writers find great satisfaction that America's part in England's history figures prominently. Sir Edwin Arnold signalizes the new century with a sonnet. Greeting Columbia, England says:
CHICAGO, Dec, 29 -- The Christmas weather here has been mild, and small boys who received sleds from Santa Claus are inclined to take a gloomy view of life.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, Dec. 24 -- The Legislature Assembly of Porto Rico adjourned on Saturday until Jan. 2. It had been in session eighteen days, and if one may judge from the work accomplished, the House of Delegates is decidedly not a success.
The Hockey team from Lawrenceville School defeated Andover last night in the St. Nicholas rink by the score of 2 to 1.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Money was in strong demand to-day. Most of the discount business goes to the Bank of England. It is expected that after the year-turn rates will be much easier, but they cannot be expected to fall far while Continental exchanges are so adverse.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A visitor who so greatly resembled the President as to pass for his "double" was at the White House to-day, and he came from New York.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Capt. Hank Haff, the skipper of four America's Cup defenders, was to-day engaged by Thomas W. Lawson as commander of the boat which he is building for the trial races next Summer. It was Mr. Lawson's wish to associate Capt. Nate Watson of the yacht Constellation in the command as a sort of sailing master, but Watson's engagements would not admit of this, so Capt. Haff will be in sole command.

From Scribner's. Uncultivated wastes of mud stretch everywhere, tainted by putrid ponds, and filling the spaces between the vast fields of millet, which cover the greater part of the land in North China. Thousands of big and little mounds dot the country, giving it the appearance, where not concealed by vegetation, of some vast prairie dog village.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Final details for the inauguration of Governor-elect Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., were completed to-day. Gen. Robert Shaw Oliver, commanding the Third Brigade, has appointed Major James L. Hyatt of the Tenth Battalion, Albany, Mar- shal of the parade.
