The great rival to the coming Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo for the entertainment and instruction or the world's sightseers next year will be the Glasgow International Exhibition, which will open in May and close in November.

The brief career of the Theatre Comique, at Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street, under its present management closed with a riot last night which blocked Broadway traffic while it lasted and brought out the reserves from the West Thirtieth Street Police Station. They reached the theatre just in time to save the furniture of the playhouse, if not the members of the company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The comment of THE TIMES upon public affairs is so broad and convincing that teachers read with great interest its remarks upon the public schools, although not always assured that the conclusions are drawn from a practical or sympathetic acquaintance with their work.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I see an article in your to-day's issue relating to the canteen, signed "J.W.," from which I quote the following:

John F. McIntyre, Senior Assistant District Attorney under Asa Bird Gardiner, tendered his resignation from office to District Attorney Philbin yesterday. Assistant District Attorney Charles E. Le Barbier was assigned to fill the vacancy temporarily.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr: W.J. Stillman, in a letter to The London Spectator in the year 1898, and, I think, in the number of the 8th of January of that year, tells the following extraordinary story upon the authority of the late Prof. Agassiz:

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Our Christmas feastings this year have hardly been on the usual scale or conducted with our wonted heartiness, but we have done our best to be cheerful. The customary dinners of benevolence have been held in all parts of the country to the satisfaction of the needy, and the degraded sections of the population have been ministered to.

PEKING, Nov. 10 -- Stories of loot, slaughter, and executions continue to reach here from the various parts of this province, which the allied troops are visiting, while from the south and west there are indications that the Chinese are apprehensive that invasions may be attempted in those quarters.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- The annual report of the State Department of Public Instruction will show that during the last school year the total expenditures for school purposes in this State increased $5,368,500, that the value of school sites increased $6,614,880, that the number of school children increased 19,574, that the number of teachers employed increased 856, and that the number of volumes in school libraries increased 16,688.

Capt. Robert Jex Blake, who is known to almost all the noted horse owners and patrons of the turf in the East, and who has a wide circle of friends among clubmen and promoters and patrons of outdoor sports, has reason to believe that he will soon come unto possession of a snug fortune through the death of a relative in England.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The Road Drivers' Association of New York will branch out on much broader lines during the new year than it has heretofore assumed, and plans are in contemplation that, if adopted, will undoubtedly make the organization one of the foremost in promoting all things that shall work to the best advantage of amateur reinsmen, road drivers, and harness horses throughout the United States.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 29 -- The contention that has been going on for a number of years among the heirs of P.T. Barnum culminated to-day by the filing of three deeds in the Town Clerk's office. The papers show that Mrs. Caroline C. Thompson of New York, a daughter of the showman, and Clinton Barnum Seeley, have resigned as trustees over Herbert B. Seeley of New York.

A model duplicating in detail the new Public Library building, which is being built on the site of the old reservoir at Bryant Park, was placed on exhibition for the first time yesterday. Employes of Carrere Hastings, the architects who are building the library, have been at work on the model for months.

The ninth annual intercollegiate chess tournament between Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton ended early yesterday evening in favor of the local university, whose players easily surpassed their rivals with plenty to spare. In the two team matches of the final round the New Yorkers defeated Princeton by 2 1/2 to 1;, and, much to every one's surprise, Harvard lost to Yale by the same score.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In your account of the religious celebration of Christmas, just past, you omit the distinctive feature or the occasion. You mention some of the services held during the day, but not those had before daylight. The 11 o'clock mass at the cathedral is noticed, without intimation of the early morning paeans sounded there over the Nativity, or of the continuous worship intermedial.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The gradual removal of the social barriers which formerly restricted English political and educational life was never better instanced than by the appointment this week of Joseph Owen to a Fellowship at Oxford.

WEST POINT, Dec. 29 -- The military court of inquiry investigating the case of ex-Cadet Booz, alleged to have died from the effects of hazing received at the Military Academy concluded the taking of testimony here this afternoon and adjourned until Monday morning, when it will reconvene at Governors Island, New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Nineteen years ago next April this city was thrown into a state of great excitement by the news that Capt. Henry W. Howgate, who had been at the head of the United States Weather Bureau, and had been under indictment and arrest for embezzlement of money amounting to about $100,000, had escaped from the officers who had him in charge.

From The Chicago Tribune. The benefactions of the year 1900 to educational institutions, libraries, art museums and galleries, charities, and churches by personal donations and bequests amount to the large total of $60,264,030 to date, or between $19,000,000 and $20,000,000 less than last year.

Almost every church in New York and Brooklyn will, in common with churches all over the world, mark the closing of the nineteenth century and the opening of the twentieth. In a majority of cases the celebration will take the form of a midnight service on the last day of the year, while some will hold "sunrise" meetings on the morning of New Year's Day and others will hold their end-of-the-century services to-day.

Members of Empire City Lodge, F. and A. M. of New York celebrated the first half century of its existence by a banquet at the Hotel Savoy last evening. Three hundred persons were present. After the members and guests had dined, a reception was held and dancing followed. Souvenirs were presented bearing in Silver letters the figures "1850-1900."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Chinese Legation has no information regarding the reported selection of a new Emperor. The State Department is also uninformed on the subject, and in view of the silence of the Ministers, the report is received with considerable skepticism.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The Liberal papers comment severely on the acceptance by the War Office of a contingent of Maoris from New Zealand for service in South Africa. The Star says:
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 29 -- The forty-sixth annual meeting of the New Jersey State Teachers' Association ended at noon to-day.

From The Contemporary Review. The basis of knowledge on which sanitation rests is furnished chiefly by the observation of facts on a large scale as they occur in actual life. Its aim has been the removal of conditions which experience has shown to be favorable to the propagation and spread of disease, and the substitution of other conditions.

WINSTED, Conn., Dec. 29 -- Miss Anna L. Ruffin, about forty years old, housekeeper in the home of Oscar A. Boerstock, at Norfolk, ten miles west of here, left that town this morning to meet her brother Adolph, a steam fitter, living at 53 Congress Street, Brooklyn, for whom she has been searching three decades.

At the annual banquet of the Arctic Club, held at the Marlborough Hotel last night. Dr. F.C. Gay, a member of the medical expedition to Manila two years ago, said that he had isolated the germ of dysentery which has killed so many soldiers and which for many years had been the bane of the army.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 29 -- The Government has just completed in Florida the largest and best equipped detention camp in this country.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. These comic philosophers mostly live in America. There only is the idea cultivated in literature. In England authors write only fact or fiction. But across the Atlantic there are hosts of clever men who are not ashamed to set down what whimsical ideas come into their heads.

Women are conspicuous in this week's vaudeville lists at the continuous houses, and the performances, like the previous week, are extended from two to three hours on New Year's Day, and the music halls are to give matinees. Miss Loie Fuller begins at Koster Bial's to-morrow her first engagement in America since her visit here four years ago.

The arrangements for the new century celebration in front of the City Hall have been completes. Yesterday the electricians were at work running electric wires from the top of the flag pole and all over the fron't of the building. Rows of electric lights will be placed along the edge of the roof, and red, white, and blue lights will be placed in bunches of 100.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The will of Henry G. Villard was offered for probate in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court to-day. The value of the estate is not given, but it is said to be several millions.

An experiment in track laying which, if successful, will be followed in the tunnel, is now being made in the Jamaica yards under the direction of John B. McDonald, contractor for the rapid transit railroad. When completed the track will be 1,200 feet in length. A ditch two and a half feet in depth and from eight to ten feet wide has been dug.

Even the very best-informed people have very erroneous impressions about the matter of savings bany deposits. There seems a common belief that after a space of years the accounts of depositors are closed and the money either turned into the surplus account of the bank or, used for building or other purposes.

We do not think it likely that the boy named by the Empress Dowager to be actual Emperor of China, subject to her intrigues, is the son of Prince TUAN, one of the chief anti-foreign politicians of China, and one of the justest objects of the vengeance of the Powers, whose paternal relation has so often been, adduced as a reason why he should not be delivered up to condign punishment.

The late Alexandre Dumas, the younger, once wrote a play called "L'Etrangere," in which he embodied a study of certain social conditions existing in France about the time the Second Empire gave way to the Third Republic. One of the prominent characters in this was the Due de Septmonts, representing a type of humanity which in these days would be termed "degenerate."

The late Alexandre Dumas, the younger, once wrote a play called "L'Etrangere," in which he embodied a study of certain social conditions existing in France about the time the Second Empire gave way to the Third Republic. One of the prominent characters in this was the Due de Septmonts, representing a type of humanity which in these days would be termed "degenerate."

An army officer the other day in a burst of confidence observed that, in his opinion, President McKINLEY had preserved a pretty fair average in Secretaries of War. What this commentator evidently meant was that Secretary ALGER was so much below the average and Secretary ROOT so far above it that the average between them was a fair balance.

To the Editor of The New York Times: AS a workingman I have been very much interested, as have my shopmates, in the letters in THE TIMES on the question as to why more people do not go to church. The result of my observation is that Catholics go to church and are faithful to their religious duties because they recognize their Church as a divine institution whose laws and clergy must be obeyed.

Miles McDonnell, who is accused of shooting four men one fatally, in a fracas in the Onawa Hotel. Park Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, early Friday morning, was yesterday remanded by the Coroner to the Tombs without bail, charged with the murder of George Price of 215 East One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street.

Of the forty or fifty men and boys singing this hymn in the mission at 760 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, on Friday evening, none was there whose voice was lifted higher than the thin tenor of seventeen-year-old John McGuey of 1,635 Atlantic Avenue. Near the close of the hymn two voices of deep bass that had not been heard before joined in the singing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Cleveland writes about the "plight of the Democracy" as the once familiar "veteran observer" who in retirement and ease occasionally fans into transient flame the dying embers of a burned-out enthusiasm. His own summary of his academic essay is like the adjurations in the newspapers, bello-flagrante, to the Generals in the field.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 29 -- The struggle for the United States Senatorship is still in doubt, with both sides professing to be absolutely confident of the outcome. Col. M.S. Quay and his lieutenants claim positively that they have enough votes pledged to organize both branches of the Legislature and insure his election.

From The Fortnightly Review. The growth of a naval policy in Germany has received more attention from publicists than the growth of the German mercantile marine. We need not stop to discuss whether it is wise for Germany to aim at being a first-class naval power. The fact is that her development as an ocean carrier and colonizer compels her to increase her naval strength.

Letter to the Editor of The London Spectator. It has been asserted that, in a general way, the Boers' eyesight is two miles longer than the British. School Board authorities have hinted that a large percentage of London children grow up short-sighted because their vision is bounded by the end of the street.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Edgar C. Burnz has been found guilty of murder in the second degree for killing Herbert B. Fellows, the Scarsdale station agent and Postmaster. His trial was begun in the Supreme Court, before Justice Keogh, on Dec. 17, and came to a close to-night.

Hugh T. and Neal W. Goodwill, the sons of aged Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Goodwin of 1,303 Amsterdam Avenue, summoned their gray-haired mother to the Harlem Police Court yesterday, alleging that the latter had defamed Hugh's character by calling him publicly a jailbird.

HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 26 -- The Constitutional Convention has not been in session for several weeks, but the different sections thereof are busily at work considering various clauses of the plans which have been offered by Senores Rivera, Quesada, and Maura, from which it is hoped and expected a Constitution will be wrought.

Excavation was begun yesterday morning on the property at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, preparatory to the erection there of what it is believed will be the finest apartment hotel in this city, if not in the world. Col. John Jacob Astor will build on this site a sixteen-story structure, having a frontage of 75 feet on Fifth Avenue and 150 feet on Fifty-fifth Street.

From The Fortnightly Review. The growth of a naval policy in Germany has received more attention from publicists than the growth of the German mercantile marine. We need not stop to discuss whether it is wise for Germany to aim at being a first-class naval power. The fact is that her development as an ocean carrier and colonizer compels her to increase her naval strength.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Edgar C. Burnz has been found guilty of murder in the second degree for killing Herbert B. Fellows, the Scarsdale station agent and Postmaster. His trial was begun in the Supreme Court, before Justice Keogh, on Dec. 17, and came to a close to-night.

Hugh T. and Neal W. Goodwill, the sons of aged Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Goodwin of 1,303 Amsterdam Avenue, summoned their gray-haired mother to the Harlem Police Court yesterday, alleging that the latter had defamed Hugh's character by calling him publicly a jailbird.

HAVANA, Cuba, Dec. 26 -- The Constitutional Convention has not been in session for several weeks, but the different sections thereof are busily at work considering various clauses of the plans which have been offered by Senores Rivera, Quesada, and Maura, from which it is hoped and expected a Constitution will be wrought.

Terror-stricken at the thought that he had killed his brother-in-law, Abraham Beckerman, a cigarmaker, thirty-one years old, who lived at 107 East Eighty-eighth Street, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by shooting.

A gathering filled every available inch of space in Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon at the mass meeting for men, held under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Associaiion. Gov. Roosevelt was the principal speaker, and copies of his address had been sent in advance to more than 100 cities and towns of the United States and Canada, to be read before similar meetings.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 30 -- Charles Bach and Emma Bucher, who have many aliases, were arrested yesterday charged with working a new form of the matrimonial agency swindle.

The general relation of the people at large to the hospital has greatly changed within recent years. The hospital is now considered a beneficent institution, not only for the poor, but for the people of moderate means and even for the wealthy. Going to a hospital does not mean, either, that the case is practically hopeless.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener:

OYSTER BAY, >L.I., Dec. 30 -- The longdrawn-out contest over the ownership of Dosoris Pond, begun in 1896, has been ended by a decision of the Court of Appeals. This decision affirms the judgment of the Appellate Division, which affirmed the judgment of the Special Term on the opinion of Judge Wilmot M. Smith, before whom the action was tried.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 30 -- For the first time in ten years the leading winning stallion of America is owned by a strictly private breeding establishment, Castleton Farm belonging to Millionaire James R. Keene Son, a firm which breeds its horses to carry its racing colors and not for the market.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 30 -- John Smith, a broommaker employed by the Sehneiderwind Broom Factory, has positively identified "Pat" Crowe as the man who in his presence rented the Schneiderwind house on Grover Street, which was used as a prison for "Eddie" Cudahy while he was being detained for the $25,000 ransom.

QUEENSTOWN, Dec. 31 -- The British steamer Lake Megantic, Capt. Taylor, from Liverpool, Dec. 25, and Queenstown Dec. 26, for St. John, returned to Queenstown Harbor yesterday morning after a terrible experience in the gale.

A symposium of ideas and opinions as to the distinguishing features of the Christian life and work of the century just closing was presented last evening to his congregation by the Rev. Dr. John F. Carson, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. Dr. Carson preached on "The Conspicuous Religious Movements of the Nineteenth Century."

The following is a list of bonds which do not appear in their proper alphabetical order in the "Complete Bond Quotation List" on Pages 4 and 5, but are here so arranged. Opposite each is placed the name of the system under which they are given in the table referred to:

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Twelve hundred men satisfied their hunger yesterday at the "Penny Lunchroom," 290 Clark Street, which has just been opened as an experiment by the St. Luke's Society. The undertaking has proved so successful that nineteen other rooms will be opened in different parts of the city during the next few days.

AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 30 -- The annual report of State Bank Examiner Fremont E. Timberlake shows there are 51 savings banks in the State, whose assets amount to $71,076,211; 17 trust and banking companies, whose assets are $13,293,402; 33 loan and building associations, whose assets are $2,862,178.

BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- The prevailing tone of the Boerse last week was feeble. The Wall Street boom did not affect Berlin, except in Northern Pacifies and some other Americans. Reports from the iron and coal centres continued unfavorable, and shares fell interruptedly upon continual sales by outsiders.

ALBION, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The Rev. Charles Flahrer, pastor of the Universalist Church which was built by the late George M. Pullman in 1893 at a cost of $75,000, tendered his resignation to-day. The Rev. Mr. Flahrer has, been in feeble health from paralysis since May last. He came here from Grand Rapids, Mich,. and is a leader in the denomination, being President of the Universalist State Convention.
PEKING, Dec. 30 -- The Chinese plenipotentiaries have been unexpectedly ordered to sign the preliminary joint note, and have notified the foreign envoys to that effect.

-- Instead of sharing the pleasurable emotions which we experienced on discovering in The Shipping World of London an editorial article written by somebody apparently possessed of a minute knowledge of American military history. The Richmond Dispatch demonstrates fierce rage against both the British writer and ourselves for crediting SHERIDAN with refusal to burn homes in the Valley of Virginia.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- London stock brokers are very apprehensive as to the results of to-morrow's dealings. Bear traders for the last fortnight had been concentrating their attacks on the Whitaker Wright shares, and, had these assaults failed, the results must have been quite as sensational as was the suspension of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The seventy-footer Rainbow arrived in the harbor from Bristol, R.I., and dropped anchor off the Hawkins yard. The Rainbow has been recently repaired at Herreshoffs' and launched to make room for the building of the new cup defender. The yacht will be hauled out and laid up for the Winter at the Hawkins yard, where her sister craft Mineoia is already berthed.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- State Superintendent of Banks F.D. Kilburn has completed the annual report of his department for the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1900, and has forwarded the same to be submitted to the Legislature.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 30 -- State Senator Washburn of Crawford County, who was elected two years ago as a Populist with Democratic and Prohibition indorsement, issued a formal statement tonight, announcing that he had allied himself with the Republican Party, and will participate in its councils and organization.

The biennial meeting of the Union of Orthodox Hebrew Congregations was held yesterday at the Eldridge Street Synagogue, with representatives from ninety-six orthodox congregations in the United States and Canada.
On the Stock Exchange for the week ended Saturday, Dec. 29, total transactions in- cluded 5,013,690 shares of stock, $20,028,950 bonds, including $128,050 Government and $10,000 State bonds.

TACOMA, Washington, Dec. 30 -- Korean advices received to-day state that it has become known at Seoul that the Korean Emperor is a partner with Leigh Hunt of New York in his ownership of the gold mines at Usang.

There was no lack of good sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, when the cream of New York City's trotting and pacing stock turned out in full force and flocked to the stretch ready to display their speed to the hundreds of spectators who were attracted by the bright, mild weather, and lined both sides of the roadway from Washington Bridge north to Dyckman Street, where the horses were started.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- We are ending the year rather pleased with ourselves at having escaped a 5 per cent, bank rate. That, however, will be our bugbear still when the new year comes, for I see not the slightest prospect of cheap money.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 30 -- Bishop Charles B. Galloway, President of the General Board of Education of the Methodist Episcopal Church in the South, has received advices that the watch night services Monday night in the churches throughout the South will be the most enthuisiastic in the history of the Church.

At Temple Beth-El, Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday morning, the Rev. Dr. Kaufman Kohler delivered a lecture entitled "The Parting of the Centuries." Dr. Kohler took his text from the book of Habakkuk, iii., 2: "O Lord, revive Thy work in the midst of the years, in the midst of the years make known."

The Brooklyn police have in custody a blackmailer who is accused of slandering for many months past Miss Augusta Stutz, doughter of Louis Stutz, a wealthy provision dealer, of 809 Broadway, Brooklyn. The man, who described himself as John Hanna, nineteen years old, of 902 Broadway, was arrested Saturday night at a rendezvous he gave to take $15,000 as hush money.

The knotty problem of how to adjust relations between mistress and maid is in ever-recurring topic in the newspapers, and in the jangling duet, voiced by the alleged down-trodden slavey and the apparently irate housekeeper, no via media seems as yet to have been evolved to smooth over these difficulties.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Dec. 30 -- Three men were killed in Abbeville, this State, last night as the result of a drunken man's spleen and malice. Two of them were the Sheriff of the county and a highly respected Northerner, William Kyle of Massachusetts, who had been superintending the building of a cotton mill in Abbeville.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly allow me to say a word or two on the opinions expressed by Editor Harmsworth, and reported in to-day's TIMES. In the first place, is it not rather late in the day to repeat the assertion that the war in South Africa is "for the old cause of 'no taxation without representation' "?

MONTREAL, Dec. 30 -- With the dawning of the new century Canada will see an end put to the lotteries which have disgraced the country for several years. By a law passed at the last session of Parliament these lotteries were made illegal, and the new law comes in force on Jan. 1", 1901.

There is a growing conviction among the statisticians of the lumber industry that a timber famine is imminent in the near future, and that under the most favorable conditions of systematic forestry it will be impossible to grow wood fast enough to permit the maintenance of the current rate of consumption.

Many teams were out yesterday on the local trails in the weekly cross country runs, and some sharp, spirited racing was witnessed. Over in Long Island City the Star Athletic Club held a big invitation run, that brought together a number of regulars, while representatives of the National Athletic Club, Brooklyn Athletic Club.

WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 30 -- The one hundred prisoners locked up in the Westchester County Jail at White Plains, who were the companions and friends of Edgar Channing Burnz, the nineteen-year-old murderer, who was sentenced by Justice Keogh to Sing Sing Prison, for life, when they heard on Saturday night that he had been convicted, made a desperate effort to escape, but the attempt proved ineffectual.
Gov. Nathan O. Murphy of Arizona is at the Holland House, and will go to Washington to-morrow to continue his efforts to have that Territory admitted as a State.

Hiram Hitchcock, the last of the original members of the firm that opened the Fifth Avenue Hotel, died there yesterday forenoon of pneumonia after a brief illness. He caught cold at the dinner given by the New England Society at the Waldorf-Astoria on, Dec. 22, but attended to business matters until last Wednesday, when he was compelled to take to his bed.

According to Mr. Louis WINDMUELLER, the subsidies proposed for ships are not only mischievous in their distribution, but needless. He suggests in an article in The North American Review three modes of stimulating the building of a merchant marine which he thinks far more practical and effective.

While ex-Justice William N. Cohen has prepared five bills affecting the New York Police Department and says that a sixth is in contemplation, Senator Platt said last night that only two will be introduced in the next Legislature. These are for the single-headed Police Commission, which will be handed in on the first day of the session, and that creating a non-partisan Bureau of Elections.

Secretary and Treasurer Rodgers of the Albany City Tract and Missionary Society was waiting on the American Line pier when the steamship New York arrived yesterday morning. He had gone to meet his daughter Mary, who is the wife of Frans August Larsen, a missionary of the Christian and Missionary Alliance.
Net changes for the week of 1 point or more in the more active securities were:

The funeral, of "Major, Mite," the Liliputian comedian, who died from enlargement of the liver and intestinal consumption at the New York Hospital last Friday, was held from the residence of John T. McKain, 135 West Sixteenth Street, yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Henry Mottet, the pastor of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion, Twentieth Street and Soxth Avenue, conducted the services.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Refunding operations under the financial act of March 14 last close to-day, the books of the Treasury Department having been open to the exchange of bonds for a period of nine and one-half months. In discussing the subject to-day, Assistant Secretary Vanderlip said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: While the disgraceful management of Bellevue Hospitol being discussed I It wise to give my experience of Friday, the th that. Upon my advice a lady, a member of my chuch a woman of character and standing in the community was taken to Bellevue Hospital on Thursday last.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Under the Police bill fathered by Senator Platt, which will be introduced on the opening day of the session, the office of Chief of Police of Greater New York is to be abolished. The bill is to provide for a single Police Commissioner and two Deputy Chiefs, one for Manhattan and the Bronx, and the other for Kings, Richmond, and Queens Counties.

CAIRO, Dec. 31 -- Sparkes Bey. with 800 soldiers is now on his way to Bahr-EI-Dagal, toward the stations lately evacuated by the French. He received aealad orders, which were not to be opened until he is on the spot of his mission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Minister Conger has confirmed the report that the Chinese Plenipotentiaries have been ordered to accept the joint note, and Prince Ching requests further conference. No confirmation has, however, been received of the report that the Plenipotentiaries have been instructed to secure a modification of certain provisions, including that for the destruction of the forts.

Bimon Strasburg, relator in the mandamus suit to compel the removal of the Pabst Hotel Portico, in Forty-second street, died last Thursday, and win buried on Sunday. This ends all effort to have the obstruction removed, so far as private now tin now on the docket -- is concerned.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 -- Judge Bahrs to-day granted the Countess Festetics, born Ella Haggin of New York, an absolute divorce. Incidentally the Judge scored the Count severely for his indifference, neglect, and cruelty and for his evident mendacity in his answer, in which he tried to blacken his wife's reputation.

District Attorney Philbin yesterday requested the resignations of Assistant District Attorney Henry W. Unger and Deputy Assistants Daniel O'Reilly, Forbes J. Hennessy, and Charles E.F. McCann. The appointment of Franklin Pierce and George W. Schurman, full assistants, and Howard S. Gans, deputy assistant, followed the resignations.

FLUSHING, L.I., Dec. 31 -- Such a sporting welcome as the new century will receive in the sporting line at this town to morrow will surpas anything ever attempted heretofors. The Flushing Athletic Association will held a big open handicap cross-country run, the main feature of which will be the presance of Maswell C. Long, the amastour champion sprister and winner of numerous international races at the Paris Exposition last year.

Bernhard Galewakt has bought from Adolph Goldame the plot, 125 by 100, on the north side of One Hundred and Third Street, 125 feet west of First Avenue, and has resold the property to Well Mayer for Improvement.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Dec. 31 -- On the eve of the organisation of the Legislature Harrisburg is to-night a seething tur oll of political excitement. The first official more of the Republican legislature-elect in the form of a caucus of members of the House resulted in what appears on the surface to be a Quay victory.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- W.W. Gibbe, who arrived home to-day from Pittsburg, gave out a statement regarding the report that he is interested in a proposition to form a combination of the steel-tube concerns in this countuy. He said.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Gov.-elect Odell arrived in Albany this afternoon at 2:30 o'clock. The simplicity of his entry was a subject of marvel. When he stepped from the train, accompanied only by his private secretary, James G. Graham, there was not a soul to meet or to greet him. It was a nasty day.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- Boston had a brisk market in Sugar, Federal Steel, National Tube, Atchison, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Union Pacific. Mining shares generally were rather slow, although they held firm: Amalgamated rose, on the impetus given in New York: Baltic rose to 31 1/2 and Wolverine advanced 1 1/2 to 48 1/2.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- President Charles D. Macdonald of the Chicago Golf Club, former amatour champion, and one of the best golfers in the United States, will sever his official connection with Chicago golf when the annual election of the Wheaton organization takes place Jan. 19. Mr. Macdonald, whose business interests demand his residence in New York, will be succeeded by Robert S. McCormick, one of the pioneer members of the club.

Louis Stix, the Treasurer of the Dry Goods Auxilary of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following additional subscriptions to the collection now in progress. The amount already received exceeds the total for the dry goods trade in any previous collection:

LANSING, Mich., Dec. 31 -- Articles of association of the Detroit United Railway Company, capitalized at $12,500,000 were filed with the Secretary of State here to-day, together with o franchise fee of $6,000. The new company will take out the franchises and property of the Detroit Electric Street Railway.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The final payments in completion of the purchase of the Ely-Copperfield Mines, Copperfield, Vt., were made to-day to Robert F. Strains of Boston and his associates by George Westinghouse of Pittsburg and his associates, and the Ely copper mines now pass into the absolute ownership and possession of the Westinghouse Electric Company.

OMAHA, Dec. 31 -- At a specially called meeting of the City Council that body today unanimously adopted a concurrent resolution offering a reward of $25,000 for the apprehension and conviction of the persons who abducted Edward Cudahy, Jr., on the night ot Dec. 18. For the arrest and conviction of one, the resolution provides a reward of $8,000, for two $15,000 will be paid, and the whole amount is offered for the three principals.

The closing day of business of the year 1900 was marked on the Stock Exchange by higher quotations almost general to the list. These better prices, following upon the sustained advances of recent days, made another batch of new records and put many quotations far above the high figures of a year ago.

Commissioner Dalton of the Water Supply Department made n requisition on the Board of Eastimate yesterday for issues of $2,250,000 for increasing the water supply of the city. Chief Engineer, Birdsall said yesterday that the city should spend $10,000,000 every year until the city's water supply was ample for every emergency.

Many of the most important trap shooting contests of the year are annually held on New Year's Day, and this, the first day of the new century, promises to be no exception to the general rule. On all of the local gun club grounds there will be competitions galore at both clay and live birds, and some very interesting contests are assured by the number and skill of the competitors.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Since Governor-elect Odell purchased a new team of horses some months ago, Duke, the old family horse, has been the especial property of Estelle, the Governor-elect's eight-year-old daughter. Miss Estelle is very fond of driving out behind Duke, and has conceived a strong affection for the animal.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -- To-night, at the Walnut street Theatre, Chauncay Olcott made his first appearance in "Garett O'Magh," a new romantic Irish comedy, of Which his manager, Auguatus Pitou, is the author. The new play is in four acts, with the scenes laid in and around Dublin, in 1812.

Labor's greeting to the twentieth century was given last evening in the Arlington Hall, on Eighth Street. Men who have fought the battle for the rights of the labor unions dined with Bishops, politicians, and leaders of thought -- with one poet -- all of whom were looked upon as the friends of the laboring class.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The engagement is announced of Miss Eather Hunt, daughter of the late Richard M. Hunt of New York to George M W of London, eldest son of Mrs. Edward M. Padelford of this city. Miss Hunt arrived in Washington yesterday for a visit to Mrs. Padelford at her K Street residence where the formal announcement of the engagement will be made.

The Century is dead; long live the Century! Yesterday was the Nineteenth, today the Twentieth. Some time last night the one died and the other was born. Here in New York the event took place at midnight. A moment of darkness at the City Hall, an instant's interlude in the singing, a hush among the crowd -- and the Old Century was buried.

NGTN, Dec. 31 -- Washington oned the old-fashioned custom, inserved here until recent years, n house on New Year's day to Twenty years age the daily Dec. 31 printed two or three pages of lists of people and houses to be open to callers on Jun. 1.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The Washington correspondent of The Daily Telegraph wires on interview with President MeKinley, in the course of which he expresed a wish that the United States and Great Britain might continue in amity during the new century. Mr. McKinley, according to the correspondent, said he hoped for the acceptance of the amended Hay-Pauncefote treaty and expected to see the Nicaragua Canal commenced thoroughly in his second term of office.

Mrs. Catherine Boerticia of East One Hundred an Twenty-fifth Street, who, it would appear, to passonately fond of a on Sunday afternoon in making her husband, a policeman, and an ambulance surgeon believe that she hae taken a bottle full of carbolic and in an effort to kill .

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The end of the Metropolitan English Grand Opera Company is announced. Managing Director Henry W. Savage, tonight at the Auditorium Theatre, where the company is appearing, gave out the infertion that when Washington is reached and the engagemoat there is filled, the company will be banded and all further dates will be cancelled.

APPELLATE DIVISION DECISIONS -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday announced decsions in nearly all the cases not already passed upon, whish have been argued berore that tribunal. No opinions were handed down, however These, it is understood will be given out on Friday.

In his bedroom, above a restaurant he conducted, at 101 Waxhington Street, Brooklyn, Gorge Deges, a Greek thirty-five years old, was found yesterday morning lying dead with a bullet wound in his neck and another in his heart.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 -- The actual lines of the Lawson cup defender were laid down at the South Boston yards of Lawley's shipbuilding Company here this afternoon. The lines were takes from the model of Destener Crownteshteld and George Lawley. Frod Lawley and Draughtman Danlets of Designer Crowninshield's iffice supertintenden the operation.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- The Metropolitan Express Company of Newburg was incorporated to-day, with a capital of $500,000 to do a general express business. The Directors and stockholders are Frank Platt, who subscribes for 4,996 of the 5,000 shares of the company's stock, and George Sewell Bonner, Francis G. Kimball, Charles L. Kingsley, and James T. Crane, all of New York City, each one share.
The annual report of superintendent King of the Cotton Exchange, issued yesterday at the close of business ded the following:

May Irwin will establish a model bacheior apartment house, which she will manage herself. According to Miss Irwin, most of the bachelor apartments here have failed to do all that was necessary for the comfort of their guests.
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Cape Town correspondent of The Daily Mail, who dwells upon the gravity of the position in Cape Colony, says:

An evidently Inspired article which appeared in the columns of Le Matin of Paris, Dec. 16, contained the following passage: "These matters [the Amnesty bill] once cleared up, the Prime Minister will demand in January the consideration of the Associations bill, which he has much at heart, for he regards it as the surest and most effective bill of Republican action."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Henry Miller made a decided hit in his new play, "Richard Savage," at the Lyceum Theatre here last night Mr. Miller, under the management of Wagenhals Kemper, presented this, the latest of Madeleine Lucette Ryley's productions, to a large audience, and the applause after each act left no doubt in the management's mind that they had scored a hit.

PEKING, Dec. 31 -- A representative of The Associated Press to-day had a personal interview with Li-Hung-Chang, who shows plainly physical evidence of his recent Illness, but whose mind has not been affected by his sickness and is as vigorous as ever.

Mrs. Mary Ertel, who shot and killed George Deges at 161 Washington Street, Brooklyn, on Monday morning, was arraigned in the Adams Street Police Court yesterday. There were present in the court Mrs. Helena Deges, widow of the murdered man, and the prisoner's husband and nineyear-old boy.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Important changes wore effected yesterday in the official staff in this city of the Erie and the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Roads.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Patrolman Thomas May chased a clothing-house thief a long way to-night, but the man escaped in the darkness. May saw the man at the Putnam station. He had a large bundle and this aroused suspicion. May accosted him, and the man tried to joke the matter off by saying the bundle contained the twentieth century's luck.

Important developments in the Bellevue scandals are expected this afternoon when the Medical Board holds its regular monthly meeting, and the Trustees of the Mills Training School for Nurses will hold a special meeting to consider the cases of the pupil nurses recently suspended by Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The new year will be marked by many retirements in the army and navy for statutory reasons, mainly on account of age.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- Although a question of a sailing master for the Lawson boat was practically settled by Mr. Lawson's statement on Saturday night, an earnest endeavor is being made to obtain the services of Capt. Nate Watson, who was prominently mentioned for the chief position when the yacht was first projected.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 1 -- A large consignment of Tobtin bronze plates for the hull of the new cup defender now building at the Herreshoffs yard hero arrived by freight early to-day from Ansonia, Conn. Each plate was crated separately and almost entirely hidden from view. In all, there were twenty-six crates, with a total weight of about seven tons.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Garrett J. Benson, a bitter enemy of State Committeeman William Barnes, Jr., of Albany, was defeated for the Senate Sergeant at Arms nomination in the Republican Senate caucus tonight by C.R. Hotaling. Benson was Sergeant at Arms of the Senate in 1897 and 1898, but was defeated for re-election through Lieut. Gov. Woodruff booming the nomination of Henry Jacquillard of Kings.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 1 -- Col. Quay was the unanimous choice of the joint convention of Republican Senators and Members, held to-night in the House chamber to nominate a candidate for United States Senator. The caucus was attended by 123 legislators, or 4 less than the number necessary to a choice in the joint convention of the Senate and House, which will be held Jan. 16.

It was scarcely necessary for the State Department to emphasize the absurdity of the report from Peking that an "armistice" had been proclaimed on behalf of the Powers, in view of such disposition as China had shown to meet their views. An armistice, as the etymology of the word itself implies, is a standstill of arms, a mutual suspension of hostilities in the course of war.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Jan. 1 -- There were several perilous escapes, hard work by the firemen, and much excitement at an early fire to-day in the Hotel Vendome, one of the oldest and most popular hotels in this city.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan, 1 -- The birth of the Now Year was momentous for the four men in the County Jail at Paterson, N.J., charged with the murder of Jennie Bosschieter. Two weeks from to-day one or all four of the accused men will be called to the bar to stand trial.

ALTOONA, Penn., Jan. 1 -- On a confessed defalcation of between $30,000 and $40,000, the County Commissioners have agreed to accept $25,000 from Tax Receiver James H. McCullough's bondsmen, and call his accounts square. He owes $25,000 on his 1898 duplicates and $50,000 or his 1899 duplicates.

SYDNEY, N.S.W., Jan. 1 -- The Earl of Hopetoun was to-day sworn in as the first Governor General of the Federated Australian colonies, amidst scenes of pageantry such as never before had been attempted in the antipodes. Scores of thousands of people participated in the demonstration, and general joy marked the occasion.

John T. Williams of 2501 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, editor of The Jeweler, a weekly trade paper, who had a New York office at 170 Broadway, sent word to his wife several days ago to come here and spend New Year's with him. After she had arrived last night, he killed himself while sitting with her in their room at the St. George Hotel, 19 East Twelfth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Dec. 30 appears an article entitled "A Workingman's Views," which deserves a reply because its writer labors under a serious misconception. He charges me with having made an "unjust and almost virulent assault" upon Mr. Robert Fulton Cutting in these columns several weeks ago! So far from it, I said that I had "a very hearty admiration" for Mr. Cutting.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 1 -- Ignatlus Donnelly, who had been prominent for many years in politics and literature, died here to-night. He was taken Ill suddenly at the home of his father-in-law, Barton Hanson, this evening, and in spite of the efforts of his physician, failed to rally.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- The Railroad Commissioners this afternoon issued an order compelling the Boston Elevated Railway Company to equip all street cars in Boston with vestibules. The order provides that the road shall have cars vestibuled on two lines of the system by Dec. 1 next, but the company is given four years in which to equip all its cars in that manner.

The status of Chief William S. Devery was discussed yesterday, in relation to the single-headed police bill to he introduced at the first session of the Legislature. The outline of the bill was published in THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday. Some of the persons interested wanted more details to enable them to have a full idea of the scope of the measure and how it applied outside of the Police Commissioners and the Chief.

FLUSHING, L.I., Jan. 1 -- The drag hunt of the Flushing Riding Club was the feature of one of the biggest days in sports ever planned and successfully carried out in Flushing. The meet was at Sixteenth Street and Broadway, and twenty-six riders participated in the event. A park of eight hounds were slipped at the throw-off.

The play by Paul Kester, (who may still be rolled on to make his mark as a dramatist some day.) in which Ada Rehan is now acting at the Knickerbocker Theatre, to the positive and unbounded delight of her audiences, (she has drawn three large ones thus far.) is an antique combination of the frivol of farce, the intrigue of comedy, and the superficial device and "suspense" of melodrama.

Mrs. Louisa Merritt, whose husband, Richard A. Merritt, is a florist, of 927 Park Avenue, yesterday afternoon fell from the root of the house in which she lived through the airshaft to the pavement, a distance of sixty feet, and was instantly killed. Almost every bone in her body was broken.
ALBERT GRAMMAR EAVES, President of the Eaves Coastwise Company, died on Monday night, aged fifty-three years. The funeral will be held in St. Mark's Church, Mount Kisco, N.Y., to-morrow.

Fire, originating in a tailor's store in the basement of the seven-story apartment house known as the Sorrento, at 136 and 138 Madison Avenue, at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, did $5,000 damage and created a great deal of excitement among the tenants. Directly over the tailor's store of J.S. Jones, which is located on the Thirtyfirst Street side of the basement, are the handsome offices of Drs. George J. and John N. Heimer, csteopathists.

Can the Administration give any encouragement to the hope that the war in the Philippines will be ended during the present year? It began early in February, 1899. It has lasted almost two years. "We have won many victories, we have killed a good many Tagals, and they have killed or captured a good many of our troops.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A great many at my friends and myself, all citizens of the State of Montana, have read and discussed the editorial contained in the Issue of your paper of the 13th inst., entitled "Mr. Clark's Vindication."

New Year conviviality came near costing Joseph Emm, a German laborer, of 203 East One Hundred and Fourth Street, his life. He made merry among his friends during New Year's eve and at a late hour returned to his home at pence with all the world. Upon going to bet he turned off the gas in his room.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- August De Weill, who is alleged to have been the prisoner who, on Saturday night, concocted the plan to escape from the jail by starting a fire, and who failed then because Jailer Johnson, seeing the fire could do no harm, refused to enter the cage, escaped this morning.

ALBANY, Jan. 1 -- Gov. Odell took hold of the helm of State to-day amid the greatest inaugural ceremonial and display in the history of the State. The military end of the programme was the most noticeable feature, there being more muskets and blue coats in evidence than have been seen in Albany in two decades.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The Lakewood Hold is full of pleasure seekers from far and near, who are enjoying to-night the hotel's New Year's ball. The great lobby of the hotel is beautifully festooned with evergreens, while the ball room in its new and pretty decoration of pink and gold is a much admired "set off" to the great throng of dancers.

Yesterday's fine weather brought out the trail followers in force, and the various cross-country courses had their share of contestants. The first run of the new century was that of the Williamsburg Athletic Association, which left the clubhouse of the organization in Williamsburg just after midnight yesterday morning, over thirty athletes participating.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -- The Fox Hill Golf dub of Staten Island to-day defeated the Atlantic City Country Club in a match golf game of 36 holes by the narrow margin of two up. In the first 18 the Atlantic City club led by one, but in the second half, mainly the result of the good playing of E.S. Knapp, the visitors managed to win out on the last two holes.

An overturned car, with every window in it smashed, and filled with panic-stricken people who wore unable to get out through the doors and finally escaped from it through the windows, was the result of a collision last night between a Twenty-eighth Street cross-town car and an Eighth Avenue trolley car.

Mayor Van Wyck called at the City Hall yesterdny and announced a number of appointments and reappointments to political places. There was no crowd at the office to shake hands with Mayor Van Wyck and wish him a happy new year, and the Mayor did not seem anxious for any such courtesies to be paid to him, for he kept in his private office while he was in the City Hall.

The holiday live-bird shooting contests at Inter-State Park yesterday drew the largest attendance of the present season, the gunners and spectators completely filling the available accommodations. The tournament was under the management of the New Utrecht Rod and Gun Club, and, while a dozen or more clubs were represented by noted trap shooters, the New Utrechts were the most numerous.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 1 -- At Livandia the Czar yesterday reviewed the Russian troops that have returned from China. His Majesty passed in front of the detachments and then ordered a march past. As each company passed the Czar thanked the troops for their services. Dinner was served to the soldiers in their barracks, where the Czar passed about from one table to another addressing remarks to individual soldiers.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- The Fifteenth Separate Company basket ball team met its first defeat this season to-night at the hands of New York's Twenty-third Street Young Men's Christian Association team, National champions, by the decisive score of 29 to 18. The visitors played a perfect pass and block game, and outgenerated the home five at critical points.
Senator CLARK of Montana has found a defender in the Chairman of the Democratic State Committee of his State, Mr. WALTER COOPER, whose letter we print this morning.

-- Monday night's exercises at the City Hall gave fitting recognition to a moment which, though its distinction from other moments was an entirely artificial convention, nevertheless possessed no small amount of real significance, and therefore well deserved the attention it received, there and elsewhere.

Mayor Van Wyck did not take any part in the official welcome by the city to the twentieth century, arranged by a joint committee of the Municipal Assembly. Mayor Van Wyck did not appear on the steps of the City Hall while his picture in heroic size in red, white, and blue lights was blazing across the park.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 2. -- Nominations of candidates for United States Senator were made, in both branches of the State Legislature to-day. The following names were presented in the Senate: M.S. Quay, Republican; Congressman John Dalzell, independent Republican; ex-Gov. Robert T. Pattison, Democrat; ex-Congressman Simon P. Wolverton, Democrat: John Stewart, Republican; Congressman William Connell, Republican; George F. Huff, Republican, and National Committeman James M. Guffey, Democrat.

GREENWICH, Coun., Jan. 2. -- The Assessors to-day filed the grand list of taxable property of the town with Town Clerk James R. Meade, and anxious property owners have been perusing it to discover how much they have been assessed, whether the valuation of their property has been increased, and whether their neighbors have been let off more easily than themselves.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 2. -- Another letter, printed with a lend pencil, was received by E.A. Cudahy this afternoon, demanding the withdrawal of the reward for the kidnappers. The fact that the address was printed in similar style to the former ones save rise to the suspicion that it was from the same source, but Mr. Cudahy stated tonight that he did not attach the slightest significance to it.

Corporation Consel Whalen submitted to Mayor Van Wyek yesterday a report of the transactions of the Law Department for 1900. It shows the enormous litigation in which the city has become involved since consolidation. The City of New York is dependant in 3,719 actions brought to force the city to pay what the Legislature termed "the prevailing rate of wages," and there are now pending in all 11,145 cases against the city.

District Attorney Philbin yesterday announced his purpose of personally co-operating with the Committee of Five and the Committee of Fifteen. He assigned Assistant District Attorney George W. Schurman. recently appointed, to confer with the representatives of the two committees and to investigate forthwith any evidence either might have ready to submit.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 2. -- The Evenining Telegram to-day printed illustrated plans of the new Herreshoff cup defender, and says in regard to them that the length and beam of the new bout will be greater than the Columbia's or the Defender's, while the draught will be less, the form easier, the power largely increased, and the speed estimated fully eight minutes better over a thirty-mile course than the Columbia's.

NEWPORT, Jan. 2. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt arrived in Newport by the early morning train on a flying visit from New York. As usual, when in Newport, he staid at the Muenchinger King cottage. Early in the morning he went to Harborview, where he and Miss French spent a vary busy day making final arrangements for their wedding.

Conditions in the outside market yesterday were practically those which prevailed on the closing days of the year, and the same dullness continued in most stocks on the list. The issues that were actively traded in were exceptions. Prices, how-ever, were fairly well maintained, and most of the day's net changes were on the side of advances.

QUEENS, L.I., Jan. 2. -- Splendid birds and close shooting served to make the thrice postponed inter-State handicap shoot off here to-day at the Inter-State Park grounds an excellent contest. John P. Daniells of New York; Harold Money of Oakland, N.J.; John S. Fanning of San Francisco, Cal., and Stephen M. Van Alien of Jamaica, N.Y., who had won previous events, were eligible.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with the re-payment of loans to the Bank of England, and was easier, the release of dividends increasing the supply. Discounts were firm. The local loans issue is believed to have reduced the likelihood of an advance of the Bank rate to-morrow.

Justice Bischoff of the Supreme Court, after nearly a year's deliberation, handed clown a decision yesterday, which, if sustained by the Court of Appeals, means that the Metropolitan Street Railway Company will have no right to run cars on Lexington Avenue from Forty-second Street to the Harlem River, nor operate the One Hundred and Sixteenth Street crosstown line.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The situation foreseen by the State Department when it objected to the use of the word "irrevocable" in the China joint note has come to pass. China is seeking a modification of the note, which is directly in line with the American policy, and the word "irrevocable" prevents the powers from acceding to it unless by unanimous consent.

Entries for the stakes and great handicaps, to be run at Spring and Pall meetings of the Brooklyn and Coney Island Jockey Clubs and the Brighton Beach Racing Association, closed yesterday, and nominations already have been received in such numbers that there is every promise for an unusually large number of horses in all the more important events.

Policeman Rosenfeld of the East Eighty-eighth Street Station yesterday arraigned in the Harlem Police Court a prisoner whom he had captured during the early morning, after a three hours' chase over housetops, through back yards, over fire escapes and fences, around corners, in and out of cellars, arresting the man at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Third Avenue after a final spurt on street cars from Ninety-seventh Street to One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Senator Ahearn of Manhattan introduced a bill to-day which authorizes New York to spend $12,000 for the purchase of property along the water front for clock purposes. It is asserted here that the measure is backed by the big warehouse combination in Brooklyn, which was capitalized at $25,000,000, but is now in the hands of a receiver, who is winding up its affairs.

Steps were taken yesterday by the Merchants' Association, through President King, to have a bill drawn providing for construction of pipe galleries alone the line of the Rapid Transit Railway. William R. Corwine of the association will visit the Rapid Transit Commissioners and some of the city officials to-day to arrange for a bill to be introduced early in the session of the legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- Senator Bacon introduced a resolution before the holiday adjournment which directed the Secretary of War to transmit to the Senate the report of Abraham L. Lawshe, "Giving in detail the result of his investigation, made under the direction of the War Department, into the receipts and expenditures of the Cuban funds."

The Great American Five and Ten Cent Store Company at 10 West Fourteenth Street with a branch note at the South Salina Street, Svracuse made an Assignment here yesterday to John Gruenberg Michael Levi is President and Morris S. cou Treasurer and Secreatry. The company was incorporated laws,

Last Tuesday the Commonwealth of Australia came into existence, and thereby were established new bonds of relationship between a sovereign and subjects occupying a remote colony. It is the third step in the development of the British Empire as a political institution. It is good to recall at this time that with the first step -- the recognition of the rights of Crown colonies -- the name of our own FRANKLIN is associated.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 2. -- The House probably will dispose of the Reapportionment bill this week, although Chairman Burton of the River and Harbor Committee is inclined to contest the right of way with the Census Committee. The Reapportionment bill, carrying out as it does a Constitutional requirement, is a matter of higher privilege than an appropriation bill, and if Chairman Hopkins insists, it probably will be given priority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The general expectation among Senators is that the first few days of the time of the Senate after reconvening to-morrow will be devoted to consideration of the Army Reorganization hill, but there is some disposition to make an arrangement for a division of time that will permit of the continued presentation of the Ship Subsidy bill during a part of each day.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 2. -- The steamer Canada, having Field Marshal Lord Roberts on board, anchored off Osborne at 11:45 A.M. to-day. The ships in the roads were gayly dressed, the sea front was elaborately decorated with bunting, and Venetian masts with festoons adorned the route to Osborne House.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- British yachtsmen are preparing to give Sir Thomas Lipton every assistance in thoroughly testing the Sham rock II. Kenneth M. Clark of Paisley has purchased. C.D. Rose's Distant Shore Principally for the purpose of using her as "trial horse" with the new challenger.

Judge Foster, in General Sessions yesterday, denied the motion to dismiss indictments now pending against Policeman William Spolasco, formerly attached to the General Sessions Court squad, and Mrs. Susie Greenwald, charging both with attempting to extort from Mrs. Elizabeth Fitzgerald, a Tombs prisoner, money which the two asserted would be used with Judge Newburger and District Attorney Gardiner to effect her release.

The first business day of the year 1901 on the Stock Exchange was marked by active trading and buoyant quotations, prices advancing generally throughout the list. The high record was almost equaled, recorded transactions running beyond the 1,500,000 mark, while actual transactions must have totaled over two millions.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Jan. 2. -- The British steamer Ivytlene, Capt. Millburn, from Hamburg. Dec. 13. for Willmington, N.C., went ashore in a snowstorm last night at La Mancho, and is likely to become a total loss.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 2. -- Charles R. Westervelt, former Cashier and Secretary of the Dime Savings Institution, who was arrested last July charged with having embezzled $45,000 of the bank's funds, plended guilty to-day to two indictments for forgery and not guilty to two indictments for embezzlement.

George W. Howard, who in September last married a daughter of Henry Hawkes, a rich Democratic politician of Brooklyn, was locked up in the Adams Street Police Station last night accused of bigamy. He was arrested at 6 o'clock last evening in his apartments in the New Amsterdam Hotel, Manhattan, at the instance of his brothor-in-law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The annual distribution of seeds is about to begin, and Secretary Wilson said of it to-day: "The distribution of garden seeds is not a matter of particular pride with the Agricultural Department, but it is one of our duties, and we endeavor to discharge it. All the seeds sent out will be tested for germination, purity, and variety.

Another abuse which has just come to light in Bellevue Hospital is that small sums are extorted from the poor patients under penalty of being sent to the Island. Commissioner Keller says he has proof of this.
LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Lord Roberts figures largely in the papers this morning, and there is a chorus of eulogistic editorials.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Senator Slater, in the Senate, and Assemblyman Morgan, in the Assembly, introduced two anti-Ramapo bills this morning. Both measures are the same in text as prepared by the Merchants Association of New York and printed several days ago. The first bill is very brief. It reads:

The woman who was taken to the Presbyterian Hospital on Tuesday night with a bullet wound just below the heart, and whose male companion disappeared as soon, as the surgeons had taken her in charge, was identified yesterday as Mrs. Louisa, Pflrsig, twenty-five years old, the wife of Hermann Pflrsig, a waiter in a, west side restaurant.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- The first briefs to be filed in the cases involving the relation of the United States to their insular possession, which are to be argued in the United States Supreme Court next week, were submitted to-day. There are eight of he cases, and briefs were filed In two of them, the cases of Curios Armstrong and of Samuel B. Downes.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- Gov. Odell began his first day of routine work as Governor of New York State this morning. He walked to the Capitol, reaching his office just as the clock struck 10, and promptly set about altering a number of things that were unalterable routine under Gov. Roosevelt. First of all he abolished the daily seances that have been held with the newspaper men for the past two years.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- In a dispatch to The Times from Peking, dated Dec. 31. Dr. Morrison elves the text of the Russo-Chinese agreement for the Russian protection of the Manchurian Province of Fen-Ting. Russia, he says, consents that China shall resume the civil government on the following conditions:

HAVANA, Jan. 2. -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention is consedering two promulgations of the future relations between Cuba and the United States. One of these affirms, in the first place, an acceptance of the Monroe doctrine and the establishment of friendly relations with all nations, together with a resolution to proceed In all cases in complete accord with the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 2. -- The Assembly was called to order by Clerk Archie E. Baxter. A large floral piece of rectangular shape, with the figures "11" in immortelles and three gavels, signifying eleven years of service us Assemblyman and three as Speaker, rested on the Speaker's desk. It was the gift of several members and friends from Chautauqua County.

All records were broken for Clearing House exchange yesterday, and as n result of the heaviest dividend and interest payments of recent years the clearances reached $427,003,000. The previous high record was on Thursday last, when the day's exchanges aggregated $364,013,290.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some years since a party was started in the West called "Grangers," who went for and compelled the railroad companies to change their mode of doing business by selecting members of Legislatures. Governors, and, I think, members of Congress, and passing laws which convinced the railroad companies that they could not do just as they pleased when the people called a halt.

The Rock Department will start this week the largest improvement to the water front ever planned. Funds are available from the proceeds of a bond sale of over $1,090,000 issued for building docks on the water front of the Hudson River. The section to be improved is from Bloomfield Street to Twenty-third Street on the North River.

BOSTON, Jan. 2. -- Ten men started in the six-day bicycle race at Park Square Garden to-day, the pistol shot being given at 1:03 P.M. Among the riders was Gougoltz, who it was said last night had given up.

Edmond Bruwaert, the French Consul General, who arrived here on La Gascogne on Sunday, after a sojourn of seven months in Europe, announced yesterday that one of his objects in going to Paris was to make an effort to secure an appropriation of $50,000 for the French Hospital at 322 West Thirty-fourth Street, in this city.

"Now, in studying the questions whether the new possessions are part of the United States, and their free, civilized inhabitants citizens of the United States." writes ex-President HARRISON in his article in The North American Review, "the Constitution should naturally be examined first."

The graphic quality, the vitalizing touch in the chapter of "Reminiscences" signed with the name of Clara Morris in the January number of McClure's Magazine make it easy and entertaining reading. But to one who remembers well the first performance of "Man and Wife," and the first appearance of Clara Morris in the little rose-tinted Fifth Avenue Theatre.

The American Sugar Refining Company yesterday reduced the price of granulated sugar to 5 1/2 cents per pound, and the National Sugar Refining Company, which is made up of a number of independent companies, reduced its price so as to bring it down to the same as that of the trust. Arbuckle Brothers also announced that they had met the cut, thereby putting all refiners on the same basis.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 3. -- Edward C. Remme, cashier of the German National Bank or Newport, Ky., was arrested to-day by United States Marshal Compton upon a warrant issued at the instance of Bank Examiner Tucker. Owing to the shortage of $195,000 of Frank M. Brown, as assistant cashier and bookkeeper, the bank was recently placed in the hands of Tucker as receiver.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Lord Roberts yesterday received a right royal welcome on his return to London after a year's absence in South Africa. The crowds were not so dense nor no demonstrative as during the recent war celebrations, but people paid from 3 to 10 guineas for seats in Piccadilly and St. James's Street balconies.

LISBON, Me., Jan. 3. -- H.E. Webber, a well-to-do farmer of Lisbon Village, about two miles north of this place, killed himself in a peculiar manner during last night. Traces of a body were found about the barnyard this morning, and an investigation showed that Webber had blown himself to pieces.

MILTON, N.D., Jan. 3. -- William Barry, a middle aged and wealthy farmer living near this place, to-day came to Milton and surrendered himself to the authorities, saying that he had killed Andrew Hellen, his hired man.

WASHINGTON, Jun. 3. -- The Chief Justice and Mrs. Fuller gave a dance for young people this evening, in honor of Miss Fuller, the youngest of their seven daughters and a debutante of this season. A dinner of twenty-four covers at the residence of the Chief Justice preceded the dance, which was given at Rauscher's.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- Fast freight lines will probably be abolished or their number greatly diminished as a result of the "community ownership" or amalgamation of interests that has lately taken place among the big railroad interests in this country. The discontinuance of ticket commission payments was the first step taken by the amalgamated interests to stop the worst evil from which passenger affairs have been suffering.

To help in the reorganization and rehabilitation of the Democratic Party on old-line principles is the avowed purpose of a new Democratic club organized yesterday. The articles of incorporation were filed and the organizers are shown to be ex-Senator Jacob A. Cantor, ex-Assembly-man Perez M. Stewart, and others.

Jack Park, the golf professional of the Essex County Country Club, Orange, sails for his home in Musselburg, Scotland, this week, where he will remain until Spring. This is the first visit he has made to his home since coming to America several seasons ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the call of the National Central Committee of the "Twentieth Century National Gospel Campaign" to special prayer for the evangelization of the world, may I make some suggestions?
The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday. There was a large attendance, and Morris K. Jesup presided.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- A committee from the American Asiatic Association, with headquarters in New York, called on the President to-day and presented a memorial expressing emphatic approval of the efforts made to hasten a settlement of the questions at issue between the powers and the Government of China.

The supreme power of the people is at the command of Gov. ODELL for the achievement of the reforms and the savings he has had the courage to recommend. He need have no fear that anybody will stand in his way. Nobody can. No boss, no machine, no Legislature, no party will have the hardihood to oppose openly the measures of public morality that he proposes in his message.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 3. -- The consignment of steel plates for the new yacht, which arrived last Saturday, has been taken into the north shop of the Herreshoff works, where the plates will be made into a mast, the second of its kind used in a Herreshoff cup defender. Boom and gaff will also be of steel, all built to resist the great strain consequent upon carrying a big sail plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The radical element among the House Republicans who favor cutting down the representation from the Southern States in which the franchise is abridged, suffered defeat to-day because a number of their colleagues refused to act with them. The issue was precipitated quite unexpectedly.

A mass meeting under the auspices of the Presbytery's committee in the interest of the twentieth century fund was held last night in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. The object of the meeting was to altimulate interest in the extension of all Church work with the opening of the twentieth century.

The will of Theodore Saltus, which was filed in the Surrogates' office yesterday, is one of the simplest testaments ever placed on record, considering the fact that it makes bequests to various institutions as well as providing for the widow of the testator.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The ill-regulated, but on the whole, gentlemanly, dog has of late come in for a good deal of abuse at the hands and pens of those who write to THE TIMES. Yet I think I could show them a more offensive animal, and one whose offense carries less excuse with it.

Contracts have been signed for the sale or the two eight-story buildings 141 to 145 Wooster Street and 149 to 153 Wooster Street, each 75 by 100. These properties are on the west side of the street, the southerly one being 170 feet north of Prince Street, and are separated by a twenty-flve-foot lot covered by a four-story structure.

Residents of Jerome Avenue and other streets in that section of the Bronx presented to the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners yesterday afternoon two petitions asking for an extension of the subway from Lenox Avenue across the Harlem and north. The petitions were presented by Fielding L. Marshall and William D. Peck, who addressed the board and asked for a hearing some day in the near future.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Jan. 3. -- An accident occurred at the Pine Ridge Colliery of the Algonquin Coal Company to-day, which resulted in the death of two men and the fatal injury of two others. The mine, owing to a cave-in, had not been in operation for some time past, and considerable gas had accumulated in the workings.

Diadomo Cupo, a bandmaster, yesterday sued the Jersey City, Hoboken and Paterson Railroad Company in the First District Court, Jersey City, before Judge Grouse, to recover $120 for alleged violation of contract. Cupo, who lives in New York claimed that he had a contract to play with his band in the procession that took place in Paterson on Sunday, Aug. 12, in celebration of the assassination of King Humbert.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Money rates wore unsettled to-day, the future being regarded with the greatest uncertainty. The supply was reduced appreciably by repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts were firm, but dealers were cautious, owing to the condition of the exchanges.

Closely fighting for every slight advantage, and constantly furnishing brilliant and spectacular hockey, the sevens of the St. Nicholas and Brooklyn Skating Clubs last evening played a tie game at the St. Nicholas Rink. The score was 4 -- 4, and, as the contest was one of the championship series, it will have to be played over again.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Robert P. Porter, who was Census Commissioner when the eleventh census was taken, and who has just visited Washington after an absence of several months, manifests a natural interest in the work of his successor in the Census Office. He has been looking over the returns, and makes some deductions therefrom.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3. -- The Philadelphia market succumbed to the weakness in New York, and the day was one of heavy trailing and extensive liquidation, over a million shares coming over the tape up to 2 o'clock. The attitude was one of inconsistency, for the market here had not risen with Wall Street, and it was felt that it ought not to respond to the reaction.

The hearing of evidence in the trial of Capt. John D. Herlihy, upon charges of inefficiency, conduct unbecoming an officer. and violation of department rules, while he was in command of the Eldridge Street Precinet, was continued yesterday at Police Headquarters. The hearing began shortly after 2 o'clock, and was continued until 7:30 last evening.
