We continue to receive from Washington complaints of the conduct of Mr. CONGER in China, all to the effect that he misrepresents the Government of the United States in that country. These complaints have an official or "semi-official" air which gives them more importance than they would otherwise have possessed.

Senator HANNA publishes in The Independent of this week a careful defense of the Ship Subsidy bill which bears the name of Senator FRYE, but of which Mr. HANNA is the chief advocate. The question of authorship is a delicate one on which it is not necessary to enter; no one, we believe, is disposed to withhold credit from the Committee of Twenty-five, composed principally of beneficiaries of the bill.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday presented little of interest until the lest hour, when some sharp declines occurred, as a result of the break in the market on the Stock Exchange. A number of market orders were given which, though the amounts of stock involved were small, sufficed to bring about considerable declines.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- The Hudson River is covered with ice and lightly closed from Kingston northward to Albany. The freezing has not been as good as usual because of a strong wind which blew from the northeast for several days before the ice stopped forming, in consequence of which the water was full of drifting grass and weeds blown from the shoals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- Without a murmur of dissent and without a word of comment, the Senate to-day displaced the shipping subsidy bill from its privileged position as "unfinished business." and substituted for it the Army Reorganization bill. Since the second day of the present session the shipping bill had been the unfinished business with the understanding that it should not interfere with the consideration of the Army Reorganization bill or of appropriation bills.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Tour "Problem in Casuistry" (Dec. 28) is, as it seems to me, easily solved. The question is not what the average parent would do in such a case, but what should he do and why should he do it?

Lewis M. Nixon and Warley Platzek of the Tammany Hall Investigating Committee called on District Attorney Philbin and Assistant District Attorney Schurman yesterday to arrange for the submission of evidence in the committee's hands against disorderly houses and gambling resorts in the "red light" district and elsewhere.

-- That element of humor which the Cudahy kidnapping case has hitherto completely lacked is now supplied by the discovery that the man arrested near the Pine Ridge Agency was not, as the first reports had it, the redoubtable PAT CROWE, but one DENNIS of Boston, who is vaguely, and yet perhaps adequately, described as "a collector of specimens."

BOSTON, Jan. 3. -- A good sleep evidently did the nine riders in the six-day bicycle race at Park Square Garden a great deal of good, as when they started this afternoon on the fourth day of the race all were fresh and bright.

Coroner Hart yesterday began the inquest into the death of George Price of 215 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, who was shot and killed in the Onawa Cafe, Park Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street, on last Friday morning by Miles McDonnell. McDonnell and Thomas Kennedy of 161 East One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street were sworn enemies.

At a dinner given in his honor at the Hotel Savoy last night ex-Senator John Ford was presented with a handsome silver loving cup. The dinner was given to Senator Ford by his Republican friends of the Nineteenth Senate District, which he represented at Albany for five years. It was at the close of his legislative career that his friends decided to show their appreciation of his work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The Navy Department to-day issued orders detaching Rear Admiral A. Kautz from his post as Commander in Chief of the Pacific Station, to take effect Jan. 28. Admiral Kautz's retirement takes place soon after. He will be succeeded by Rear Admiral Casey, Commandant of the Philadelphia Navy Yard, Rear Admiral G.W. Stummer has been detached from the command of the Port Royal Station, and will succeed Rear Admiral Casey.
ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- State Treasurer Jaeckel to-day reappointed Barnet J. Davis of Wayne County his deputy for a term of two years.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Hattle Ford, five years old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Ford of Chicago, and grand-daughter of Warwick Ford of Chester Hill, this city, died to-night after an hour of agony following the eating of several pills containing belladonna and strychnine.
CAPE TOWN, Jan. 3. -- The military authorities are preparing for all contingencies. It has been decided to transfer the Boer prisoners from the camps to transports.

Capt. George Deg Catlin, Forty-third Infantry, United States Volunteers, (First Lieutenant Second United States Infantry,) having tendered the resignation of his volunteer commission, is honorably discharged from the volunteer service of the United States, to take effect Jan. 2.

If any individual Senator or Representative had the responsibility to sustain that is divided among the members of the Military Committees of the Senate and the House, he would not be able to stand it. He would consent to make some immediate regulation. The urgency of the case is matter of common notoriety.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 3. -- Mrs. George W. Howard of Cambridge, whose alleged husband has been arrested in New York on a charge of bigamy, is very ill to-night from the effects of the exposure, and is denied to all callers. Her sister, Mrs. McCarter of Cambridge, is with her.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- The State Board of Health, issuing its monthly bulletin, today devotes the greater part of it to discussing the fact that there are outbreaks of smallpox in seventeen places in the State. The report says in part:

The Bristol City Line steamship Kansas City, which rescued the White Star Line steamship Cufic, in latitude 51.34 and Line tude 21.24 on Dec. 9. after her propeller had been carried away in a terrific Rule, arrived in port yesterday morning. When picked up by the Kansas City the Cufie had signaled for assistance.

The stock market yesterday had the first healthy reaction since the commencement of the present upward movement in prices, nearly two months ago. Profit taking on a large scale appeared during the day, while short selling in a much greater measure also made its influence felt.

The clear crisp weather of the last few days has made country life so enjoyable that many of the people who went, out of town to the country clubs and to join house parties in the suburbs for the new year's holidays have not yet returned, and would remain through the week were it nut for the Whitney ball to-night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 3.-- It was learned to-day from an authoritative source that important changes are soon to be made in the operating divisions of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company which will involve a reduction in the number of divisions from eighteen to eleven and affect substantially the whole system of the company.
The New York Central has called for bids for contracts for many of the costly improvements which it is to carry out at various points along its line.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 3. -- In the second game of a series of four to be played with teams of the Western Pennsylvania Hockey League, Yale was defeated by Duquesne to-night by the score of 5 to 1. Yale was outplayed at every point. The game last night with the Bankers resulted: Yale, 5; Bankers, 5.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 3. -- Both houses of the Michigan Legislature assembled in joint session to-day to hear the message of ex-Gov. Pingree and the inaugural message of Gov. Bliss. Mr. Pingree prefaced his message with some extemporaneous remarks, in which he attacked the courts, the Legislature, and the press.

At the last session of Congress Senator HOAR introduced a bill to increase the salaries of Judges in the United States courts. It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and reported favorably, with some amendments. We give below the actual salaries paid to Judges of the various courts and the salaries proposed by the bill:
CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The Tribune will print the following story to-morrow:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- The Booz Congressional Committee, which was recently appointed by Speaker Henderson for the purpose of making inquiry into the cause of the death of Oscar L. Booz and to investigate hazing in general at the Military Academy, began the taking of testimony to-day. Three sessions were held, covering a period of time from 9 o'clock in the morning until midnight.

The most impressive sign Just now about the Academy of Design is its vitality. Divorce from house and home has no effect in the way of abatement of zeal, nor does the fact that it is still a tenant of the Society of Artists in the Fine Arts Building, on West Fifty-seventh Street, put a damper on its activity.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 4. -- According to information which has reached here, the two side organizations of the National and American baseball leagues are off, and it will be war to the knife between the National League and "Ban" Johnson by a third organization, nearly equal in strength to the National League.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- A dispatch from Minister Loomis at Caraeas received to-day at the State Department has convinced the Administration that the so-called "asphalt war" is rapidly assuming serious proportions. This much was admitted, although the dispatch was withheld. The gravity of the situation was in fact given as a reason for suppressing Mr. Loomis's news.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4. -- "This is about the fortieth time Aguinaldo has been killed." laughed Senor Sixto Lopez, the Filipino agent, when he was shown the report today, that the insurgent leader was dead, which had come through President Wheeler of the University of California, and was based upon the statements of Filipino students in his charge.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 4. -- Candidates for the University of Pennsylvania baseball team have been asked to report to Capt. Flavell at Franklin Field on Jan. 14, and a strong nine is expected. The team will take a longer Southern trip this season, going to North Carolina and taking two weeks to play its six games.

Whatever may be thought of the procedure of the allies at Peking in beginning with an ultimatum, and with an ultimatum that covered all the essential points in dispute, the acceptance of it by China stops any other Power from protesting at this stage. If consequences injurious to the allied cause are shown to proceed from any of the demands, the proclamation that they are "irrevocable" will not prevent them from being modified beyond recognition.

So much has recently been said of Rowland Robinson, the creator of Uncle Lishn, Sam Lovel, Antoine, and Granther Hill, that Mrs. Julia C.R. Dorr's paper on that charming writer and even more interesting man in the current number of The Atlantic comes with unusual force and value, from the fact that Mr. Robinson's personality was so little known, even to the majority of constant readers.

MARIETTA, Ohio, Jan. 4. -- One of the most brutal of crimes was committed this evening at Hackney Morgan County, by which Miss Nellie Morris, aged nineteen years, handsome and accomplished, lost her life. As Miss Morris was returning home from the Post Office, by way of a path through the fields, she was accosted by Walter A. Weinstock, a young man, aged eighteen years, who lived near her home.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Gen. Richard Napoleon Batcheider, Quartermaster General of the Army from 1890 to 1896, died here this afternoon at 2:25 o'clock.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- The astonishingly strong tone in Wall Street was reflected largely here, but the only marked impression upon prices was in stocks that have a collateral interest with New York, notably Reading, Pennsylvania, Northern Pacific, and St. Paul. Gains of 1 to 3 points were made in this group.

Counting chickens before they are hatched notoriously leads to unsafe statistical conclusions. The public therefore will receive with due allowance the itemized tables of the savings to be effected in the State administration by adopting the recommendations of the Governor's message.

MANILA, Jan. 4. -- Gens. Wheaton and Bates report many small captures, the destruction of insurgent camps, and the selzure of supplies, animals, and other necessities. Among the captures in smith's district was Col. Techon, the insurgent Governor of Tarlac.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 4. -- Discussing the statement made by Gov. Pingree in his last message, that Gen. Alger's ignoring the claims of the great steamboat interests, with representatives in New York, for the shipping of the Spanish soldiers to Spain, was responsible for much of the opposition to him, the ex-Secretary said to-night that there were no bids made by any American line.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners to-day rendered two decisions on complaints made by the Broadway Board of Trade of Brooklyn against the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company. The board decides that it is without jurisdiction to compel the granting of transfers on the street surface cars operated by the company at Myrtle Avenue and Broadway and at Lorimer Street and Broadway, and that complaint is dismissed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The attitude of Russia in Manchuria has given rise to considerable apprehension here. As indicated in recent news dispatches, a series of regulations has been promulgated by the Russian Government for the administration of affairs in Manchuria, which would seem to the officials here to warrant an apprehension that a permanent occupation of that territory, with its population of 20,000,000, is in contemplation.

In a pleasant way, Mr. Jonquin Miller tells of his early experiences with bears. It adds much to the interest of a story when, at the conclusion, if you would like to know the name of the lad who had the scrimmage with bruin, you learn that it was Joaquin Miller in person. The author thinks that the bear is a very much abused creature, and not half as bad as represented.

F. Arthur Westbrook, thirty-five years old of Kingston, N.Y., died at the Roosevelt Hospital yesterday afternoon from heart disease, resulting from an overdose of trional. He was found in a semi-conscious condition in his room at the Rossmore Hotel, at 10 o'clock in the morning, and a physician was summoned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- In the fourteenth annual report of the Inter-State Commerce Commission the recommendation is made to Congress that there be legislation permitting railroad to make pooling contracts. The report was submitted to Congress today. In it recent railway consolidations are discussed at length.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The House today had another spirited struggle over the Olmsted resolution to investigate the abridgment of the suffrage in certain Southern States, with a view to reapportionment upon the actual basis of suffrage. It was finally referred to the Census Committee, where the opposition desired it to go originally.

It is gratifying to observe that no Senator was found, when the question actually arose, to oppose the taking up of the Army bill, or to "antagonize" it, as they say in Washington, with the Ship Subsidy bill. It would have needed a Senator of brazen boldness, a very Gorman, to insist upon preferring a scandalous private job to a measure of National urgency.

Charles E. Schutte, the son of Charles Schutte, the brewer, was before Justice Leventritt in the Supreme Court yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus brought by his wife ordering him to produce in court their two-year-old daughter, Veronica Schutte. The child was not in court, and on Mr. Schutte's application the hearing of the writ was adjourned until to-day.

Yesterday's transactions in the outside market were even smaller than those of the previous day. Prices, however, in many instances recovered sharply from the low figures or Thursday, the strength being due in large part to the phenomenal strength of the inside market. Many fractional net gains were recorded, and in not a few stocks advances of a point or more showed in the final figures.

The Roman Catholic reader will accept this book as entirely trustworthy and enjoy it without any doubts or difficulties whatsoever. It is published with the formal and express consent of the ecclesiastical censor and the Archbishop of New York. The book is written in a attractive manner, though how much of this is due to the original writer and how much to the translator is indeterminable.
BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- The blue prints of the completed sail plan of the Boston cup defender have been given to Wilson Silsbee by Designer Crowninshield.

QUINCY, Mass., Jan. 4. -- Charles E. Hanley, the head of the syndicate which is to build the ninety-foot centreboard yacht as a candidate for the America's Cup defense, when asked to-day concerning the report from Chicago that Roland C. Nickerson of East Brewster had given $20,000 toward the new yacht, denied positively that such was the fact.

As this book does not pretend to be an exhaustive catalogue of all the paintings and illustrations connected with Shakespeare and his work, its value very largely depends upon the quality of the author's discrimination, and perhaps the worst we should say of this is that it does not conform to our own.
WASHINGTON, Jun. 4. -- In the Senate today Mr. Lodge (Rep., Mass.,) favorably reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations the following resolution, and asked for its immediate consideration:

WASHINGTON, Jan 4. -- For five hours to-day the Senate discussed the Army Reorganization bill. The debate took a wide range at times, but was confined principally to the question of the necessity for the increase in the regular army provided for in the pending measure.

A meeting of the men who intend to organize the new Democratic Club will be held next week. It was announced yesterday that a change would be made in the articles of incorporation, and that instead of the organization being known as the Samuel J. Tilden Democratic Association it would simply be called the Tilden Club.

A service to thinkers along lines of pure spirituality, appliod Christianity, and social evolution has been done by presenting to the public Dr. Arthur T. Pierson's "Forward Movements of the Last Half Century." Some may object that so broad a title should be given to a work manifestly dealing with only a class of forward movements.

The New York Central Railroad has decided to erect a large office building on the property at the corner of Depew Place and Forty-second Street, which is now occupied by the "annex" to the Grand Central Station, and which is used exclusively for incoming trains. The building will be erected as soon as circumstances will permit.

ALBANY, Jan. 4. -- Gov. Odell read with interest this morning the comments on his recommendations as to taxation of savings banks and trust companies' capital. He appeared rather amused at the objections raised and said:

A man who described himself as Herman L.Cohen, and who, the police claim, is a member of a gang of swindlers, was held for examination in the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, on a charge of swindling Frank L. Gould of Brentwood, L.I., out of $300.

"The triumphal entry" is a very unfortunate title to give to the entrance of Jesus of Nazareth into Jerusalem at this Passover time. For it was in no sense a triumph. It neither marked the overthrow of opposition, nor the inauguration of new and more successful methods. He had often come into the city before, but it was on foot, and either alone, or attended only by His chosen twelve.

The Causes of Our Present Municipal Degradation was the subject that was discussed from many standpoints at a dinner given by the City Club last night. Not only were the causes the subject or discussion, but the speakers presented plans for the betterment of the city, prominent among them being those put forward by Bishop Potter and Samuel L. Clemens, (Mark Twain.)

Any one who is sensitive both to the pecullar lack and to the peculiar charm of Walter Pater's style will recognize an especial fitness in bringing out an edition de luxe of his works. The wonder is that they did not come into this world already dressed in their best, since Pater in what might be called an ordinary walking suit is not clad according to his deserts.

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- The supply of money for large quotations did not respond to-day to the firmness of discounts. The latter were somewhat unsettled. Operators are considering measures for maintaining or raising outside rates.

That was a very enterprising intellect which has just been extinguished by the death of Ignatius Donnelly. His name suggests an Irish extraction and a Jesuit education. However that may be, was born in this country, and his intellectual performances were such that the unfriendly foreigner would be tempted to describe him as characteristically American.

"SWEET HAMPSTEAD," -- Mr. Eliot Stock of London announces for early publication of new book to be published in a limited edition. "Swet Hampstead and Its Associations," by Mrs. Coroline White. The book will be a handsomely printed, large 860 volume of about 400 pages, fully illustrated by original sketches, portraits and drawings of notable people, historic houses, and picturesque localities, and will be issued to subscribers at 15s. net.

A READER of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW writes concerning "Old Books." "May Harris's appeal in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 29 for more general reading of a past generation should meet with a ready response, particularly from those who have charge of young people's education.

The inaugural exhibition of the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts weapopened last week, having been briefly delayed. The opening was without formality, but this quiet and unostentatious character of the function was not, perhaps, unbecoming. There are about a hundred pictures on exhibition, the list including enough good works by modern American artists to make a fair display in that field of art.

There is one sign of the times which the educators of the country would do well carefully to note. If we are not mistaken, it indicates a demand for a radical change of policy in the conduct of public schools. We refer to the frequent and, as it seems to us, the increasing protests against the large relative expenditure on what are called the "higher" schools.

Francis M. Morrison, an attorney of Worcester, Mass., who represents the interests of the Brothertown tribe of Indians in the dispute over the settlement of the Six Nations' two-million-dollar judgment, has sent a communication to THE TIMES in reply to certain statements made by attorney James B. Jenkins of Oneida, N.Y., in a dispatch published in this paper on Dec. 30 last.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The British Ambassador has communicated to the Secretary of State a dispatch recently received by him from the Marquis of Lansdowne, commending the gallant conduct of certain Americans who distinguished themselves last Summer during the attacks on the Legation quarter in Peking.

Richard Donnelly, a nurse in the pavilion for the insane at Bellevue Hospital, was suspended yesterday by Commissioner of Charities Keller as a result of his reading of the minutes of the investigation into the death of Louis Hilliard, made by the Coroner's Jury. Donnelly was employed as a night nurse in the pavilion for the insane at the time when Hilliard died there.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In a recent issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW I find a remarkably fair and appreciative critcism of my new book. "The House of Egremont." I gather from it that THE SATURDAY REVIEW thinks the historical part of the story, and especially the tenderness with which James II. is treamed, is open to suspicion.

Hall J. How Co. have sold for Erastus Titus, two lots on the north side of One Hundred and Twelfth Street, together with two abuting lots on the south side of One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, 350 feel east of Lenox Avenue.

The third and latest volume in a projected series of "Literary Histories" -- those of India and Ireland having led the procession, with a literary history of the Jews announced soon to follow -- is Prof. Barret Wendell's "A literary History of America." The Professor of English in Harvard University who has written upon American topics before, upon English composition and upon Shakespeare and Elizabithan, literature, should be amply equipped for the work just completed.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In an article recently written by Dr. M. Dunn Corey on the health of children, she argues that the curriculum of the public schools of to-day is no more injurious to the health of children than was that of a generation ago, and that the ill-health of so many children is not caused so much by overstudy as by improper food and care at home.

The overwhelming success attained in London by "Herod," the new play by Stephen Phillips, in which Beerbohm Tree has surpassed himself, makes anything pertinent to this rising young English litterateur, which is also new, exceedingly timely. Previous articles devoted to Mr. Phillips have dealt entirely with his productions.

MEMORIAL MONUMENT JUDICIALLY SANCTIONED. -- The refusal of the Supreme Court at Special Term to continue a temporary injunction awarded to Mary L. Parsons, in her suit as taxpayer, to restrain "the Sailors and Soldiers Memorial Arch Commission of the City of New York " from erecting a proposed monument in Riverside Park, near Eighty-ninth Street, has been sustained by the Appellate Division.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 4. -- Taking of testimony in the great Honduras contract litigation commenced this afternoon in the Prudential Building before Nicholas W. Bindsell, representing the United States District Court. The action is instituted by the Honduras Company of Georgia against the Honduras syndicate of New Jersey.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 4. -- From what was learned yesterday in connection with the cup defender under construction at Bristol, a fair idea can be obtained of the beam breadth of the new boat. It is from a knowledge of the sweep of bilge curve of one of the frames that is to be placed in the forward section of the boat that the inference is drawn.

The roadbed of the Harlem River Speedway was in condition for speeding yesterday afternoon, for the first time since Sunday, and the consequence was an unusually large gathering of fast steppers. who furnished some lively sport in the stretch.

Of the multitude of books that have been inspired by the Spanish-American war or the questions of policy that have grown out of it. "The History of Colonization" is one of the most valuable. It is both timely and exhaustive, a work that distinctly fills a want which, if not long felt, is sufficiently pressing.

Passengers in an east-bound Fifty-ninth Street car which reached Madison Avenue at a few minutes before 11 o'clock yesterday morning were greatly surprised to see a well-dressed, elderly man slip from his scat and fall heavily on the floor of the car. Dr. A.R. Kleeberg of Gt. West One Hundred and Fourteenth Street was a passenger on the car, and, bending over the man, saw he was dying.

BOSTON, Jan. 4. -- Boston had a good day. Trading was very active in Sugar, Atchison, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Federal Stock, National Tube, and Union Pacific, while home specialties by no means were neglected. Erie Telephone was sold down 14 1/2, to 82 1/2, but rallied to 95, later receding to 92.

District Attorney John P. Clarke declared last night, when seen with regard to the case of George W. Howard, who is charged with having more wives than the law allows, that he was confident that he could convict Howard of bigamy even without the assistance of the woman in East Cambridge, who, it is alleged, the accused man married in 1890.

The editor of this memoir of the Baroness de Bode, Mr. William S. Childe-Pemberton, in his preface states that if excuse be considered necessary for adding one more to the list of memoirs bearing upon the French Revolution, he hopes it will be conceded that this record breaks new ground, briefly summarizing the scope of the book as follows:

The Hon. GEORGE S. BOUTWELL, is a wise and consistent adviser of the anti-imperialists. Some dreamer sent him the working plans for a new party, based on anti-imperialism, the gold standard, tariff reform, civil service reform, and the hunting down of the trust octopus.

Evidence tending to show that Miles McDonnell, who shot and killed George Price and wounded three other men in the Onawa Cafe, One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Park Avenue, Friday of last week, acted solely in self-defense and drew his pistol only after shots had been fired at him, was given at the Price inquest before Coroner Hart by several eye-witnesses of the affray yesterday.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 4. -- Among the banknotes which the Chinese paid to the foreign Consuls as indemnity for the missions destroyed at She-Klung were u5 notes that had been raised to u15 notes and u10 notes that had been raised to u100 notes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The State Department is making a strong effort to secure an understanding among the powers to serve as a basis for the adjustment of the question of indemnity to be paid by the Chinese Government.

Indiana in History and Literature.* In what appears to be an interesting series, called "National Studies in American Letters," and in which "Old Cambridge" and "Brook Farm" have already received recognition, "The Hoosiers" now appears, written by Mr. Meredith Nicholson.

By losing one game to Our Council, Royal Arcanum, last night, the Fidelias lost their last chance for first place in the National League tournament and will now finish second to the Orientals. Had they won all three games last night they would have tied the Orientals for first place, and would have had another opportunity to win first prize.

The Rev. Dr. S. Parkes Cadman, pastor of the Metropolitan Temple, at Seventh Avenue and West Fourteenth Street, has accepted the pastorute of the Central Congregational Church, Hancock Street, near Kranklin Avenue, Brooklyn. His predecessor in the place was the late Dr. A.J. F. Behrends.

It was not all comedy at the hearing in the trial of Capt. John D. Herlihy, at Police Headquarters, yesterday afternoon. The testimony related to general conditions in the Twelfth Precinct, and there was an impressive moment when Miss Rebecca Goodman, a young milliner, was on the stand.

-- Our contention that the so-called revelations in regard to Bellevue Hospital were not revelations at all, but very old stories, to no small part of the New York community, is strikingly corroborated by an editorial article in the current number of The Medical Record. "The necessity for reforms in the management of Bellevue Hospital," the writer of the article begins, "has been painfully apparent for a long time."

Henry Holt Ca, espect to add three new volumes to their English Reading Series this month. The first will be "Selections from Pope," edited by Dr. E.B. Reed of Yale; the second, "Burke's Speech on Conciliation of America" edited by D. V. Thompson of the Sachs School, New York, and "Swift's Prose Selections."

Peter Curran, who came here five weeks ago as the fraternal delegate of the British trade unions to the convention of the American Federation of Labor, spoke last night in Arlington Hall, under the auspices of the Social Democratic Party, on Socialism and trade unionism in England.

In the days when our forbears took their reading very seriously they cherished a famous book called commonly "Fox's Martyrs." It lay between Baxter's "Saint's Rest" and Taylor's "Holy Living," and was as unquestioned Sunday reading as "Pilgrim's Progress" or "Narratives of Remarkable Conversions."

Wall Street yesterday was treated to a phenomenal display of strength and activity in the stock market. In point of activity, indeed, all past records were surpassed. Actually recorded transactions ran to the largest total ever known -- 1,827,400 -- while, if stop orders and other unrecorded transactions were to be included, the total business for the day would, it was estimated, easily reach the enormous aggregate of 2,500,000 shares.
LONDON, Jan. 5. -- The following Colonial Office appointments were announced last evening:

Internal strife in the brewing corporation of George Ringler Co., growing out of family quarrels, came to the surface at a hearing in the Harlem Police Court yesterday in the case of August Friebel, a former bookkeeper, who, with another employe, is accused of having stolen about $21,000 the money which passed through their hands.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 5. -- In preparing for the contests next Summer on board the Bristol cup defender William Butler Duncan and Capt. Urias Rhodes are to be reinforced by under officers, who, it is agreed, are the best racing men in the judgment of Capt. Rhodes. In his line First Mate Howell is reported to be second to none in the command of a crew of seamen.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- The annual report of the State Board of Regents, which will be submitted to the Legislature next week, will show that the number of institutions of secondary education in the university Dec. 15 was 705, of which 104 are incorporated academies, 505 high schools and academic departments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- Following the announcement that a controlling interest of the Jersey Central has been secured for the Reading Company comes the announcement that Drexel Co. have purchased the remaining 75,000 shares of Lehigh Valley stock belonging to the estate of the late Asa Packer, and also the holdings of the Lehigh University of the stock of that company.

TRENTON, Jan. 5. -- The session of the New Jersey Legislature begins on Tuesday next. The re-election of United States Senator Sewell will be its first important act. The principal contests will be over the surplus now on hand. The State's income continually keeps ahead of its expenses, because of the flood of fees and taxes on corporations.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 5. -- Plans are being made for a series of intercollegiate basketball games at the Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo, either the coming Spring or Fall. Jesse Dann, Chairman of the Committee on Sports, has written a letter to Manager Jennings of the Crimson team asking him to consider the matter, and in reply Jennings has stated that Harvard will surely be represented if the series can be arranged.

Charles Hutchinson Kerr died on Friday of pneumonia at his residence in Jersey City. Mr. Kerr was a familiar figure in down-town banking circles in New York, having been in the employ of the Hanover National Bank for nearly thirty years. He was born in Galashields, Scotland, sixty-five years ago, and came to this country when a young man, being engaged in mercantile business before entering the service of the Hanover National Bank.

From The Saturday Review. A certain amount of cant is prevalent about bricks and mortar being less important than the living agent, and as to barn-like buildings being none the less homes of spiritual activities. Doubtless a cathedral ought to be a radiating centre of learning and leadership in good works through-out a whole diocese, as well as a noble edifice and a pattern of dignified worship.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this enlightened day, the dawn of the twentieth century, let us, before we sit in harsh judgments on the apparently cruel acts of others, be sure we are informed as to the facts on both sides of the case, so that we can be more fair in our judgments, before we convict, in our minds, those who have been accused of cruelty and, perhaps, of murder.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter from "H.A.C." in your paper of Jan. 4 in respect to the "spitting nuisance," which may be termed the spitting crime since this violation of decency has been made also a violation of law, describes what everybody sees who rides on the Sixth Avenue Elevated.

Wall Street was treated to a surprise yesterday, when just about noon the official announcement was quietly made that the control of the Central Railroad of New Jersey had passed to the Heading Company through the efforts of J.P. Morgan Co. Mr. Morgan's firm, it was announced, had secured control of the Jersey Central, had offered the same to the Reading Company, and the latter company had accepted the offer.

The entire Philharmonic Orchestra (75 pieces) of Leipsic, under the direction of Hans Winderstein, will arrive in America toward the end of February for a sixty-day tournee under the management of Mrs. Norma Knupfel. The first concert will take place on Friday evening, March 1, at Carnegie Hall, New York, after which all the leading cities throughout the country will be visited.
Martinus Sieveking, the Dutch pianist, now in this country, will give a recital at Mendelssohn Hall Jan. 18.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- The course of wheat to-day was ruled by sentiment, May closing 1 1/4@1 7/8 over yesterday. At the beginning and at the end of the session in the wheat pit, bullishness of a decidedly strenuous order made the market an exciting one, while the period between these extremes was marked by great nervousness.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Jan. 5. -- The engagement is announced of Miss Martha W. Borsum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Borsum of this city, to William C. Fiedler, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H.F. Fiedler of Newark, N.J.

BERLIN, Jan. 5. -- The Reichstag and Diet reassemble on Tuesday. The Diet's session takes place earlier than expected, so as to allow an ample discussion of the remodeled Canal bill, which will be introduced next week.

Secret Service men late Friday night and yesterday morning arrested eight persons who have been engaged in making and circulating counterfeit coin. The men had two plants in operation in this city, and Chief Hazon of the Secret Service estimates that 75 per cent. of the counterfeit silver that has been in circulation in this vicinity resulted from their efforts.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 5. -- A public meeting, called by the committee appointed to secure subscriptions to purchase the Rogers locomotive Works, was held this evening in the City Hall. About 150 citizens attended, among them being some business and professional men, but a majority consisted of former employes of the works.

BOSTON, Jan. 5. -- In another of the cyclone finishes for which he is famous, "Bobbie" Walthour of Atlanta, Ga., the Southern champion, and the seventy-three-hour world's champion, won the international six-day bicycle race at Park Square Garden, which ended to-night. He did not let himself out until the last lap, and when he did it did not seem as if any of the others were riding at all.

ANNAPOLIS, Jan. 5. -- The first test-pile for the foundation needed for the new cadets' quarters has been down several weeks with sixty toils of iron upon it. The vacating of houses upon the site of the proposed building is in progress, and the laying out of the grounds for the foundations will be shortly commenced.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 5. -- The new building now being erected for Harvard's Semitic Museum attracts attention to one of the most interesting special collections in the United States. This collection, founded in 1889 by a gift of $10,000 from Jacob H. Schiff of New York, illustrates the life and thought of the Semitic peoples, undent and modern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Secretary Root to-day denied a statement which is being freely circulated to the effect that he predicted that the Philippine war would come to an end with President McKinley's reelection. This statement was to-day made the text of an editorial article in a Washington newspaper, coupled with criticisms of the Secretary on his failure as a prophet.

At the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon that member of Wagner's great tetralogy which is always selected when dismemberment begins, "Die Walkure," was sung for the first time this season. Awny back in the seventies the Pappenheim-Adams company hurled this work upon the stage of the Academy of Music to the confusion of an unprepared public.
From The Century There was once a Woman whose Husband Depended on the State of the Market for his Daily Toast. One day he Appeared before Her with a Sad Countenance.

From The Forum. The absolute necessity of labor as a remedial agent, both physical and moral, is universally recognized by all penologists. Those who are most positive in their convictions on this subject are the prison wardens. They have found that the hardest prison to conduct, with reference to the physical and moral welfare of the prisoners, is one in which the men languish in idleness, leading to insanity and bodily degeneration.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- One of the largest and most brilliant weddings of the Winter took place to-day at All Saints' Cathedral, in this city. The contracting parties were Charles E. McElroy and Miss Harriot Langdon Parker.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Solicitor Penfield of the State Department to-day heard Gen. Franels Greene and Lawyer Bean of New York in reference to the conflicting asphalt concessions in Venezuela. These gentlemen represent the New York and Bermudez Company, which has been in possession of the asphalt concessions for the past tweleve years, and whose property is now claimed by the La Felicidad concessionaries under later title from the Venezuelan Government.

From The Popular Science Monthly. Among the records of the most remote antiquity we find little to lead to the conclusion that geometry was known or studied as a branch of mathematics. The Babylenlans had a remarkably well-developed number system and were expert astronomers, but so far as we know their knowledge of geometry did not go beyond the construction of certain more or less regular figures for necromantic purposes.

The Republican propramme for legislation at Albany was deckled on after many conferences at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. Gov. Odell carne down from Albany and help a long consultation with Thomas C. Platt. The politicians were gathered about the hotel in groups. It was the largest congregation of Republican leaders from above the Harlem for many weeks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 30th ult. "Workingman" has a communication which, because it voices a certain grievance of his class, merits careful consideration. He makes the following statements:

"Good breeding and fine table linen go together." said the man of linens. "You will always find it the case. You can almost judge the refinement of the individual by the quality of her table linens. It is by no means the people of the greatest wealth who buy the finest linens, and women with very little money frequently have linen of a beautiful quality.

A thoroughly surprised audience that had filled every available seat in the Savoy Theatre last night, prepared to witness a performance of "Mistress Nell," by Henrietta Crosman and her company, was dismissed shortly before the time for the curtain to rise, owing to differences between Maurice Campbell, Miss Crosman's husband, who manages her company, and Manager Alfred Aarons of the theatre.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- The new century was hailed in this city with a noisy welcome. The Mayor had ordered that all saloons be closed at midnight Monday, but little attention was paid to his mandate, either by the saloon keepers, their customers, or the police. Some of the places closed their doors at 12 o'clock upon several hundred people, who kept up the caroasal till morning.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Replying to charges against the Women's Christian Temperance Union in a recent communication in THE NEW YORK TIMES. I desire to say that:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 5. -- Two handicap golf competitions were played to-day on the two golf courses of Lakewood. The Country Club had the liveliest day that it has seen this season, and the largest number of golfers that has taken part in a competition on its links for some time turned out to try for the gross and net score prizes offered by the club.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- E.H. Plumacher, United States Consul at Maracaibo, has sent the following report to the State Department:

Wall Street was yesterday treated to another phenomenal display of activity on the stock market, all previous Saturday records being easily surpassed. Recorded transactions ran beyond 1,150,000 shares for the two hours, nearly 150,000 more than on the previous best day, which was Saturday, Dec. 22.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Jan. 5. -- Andrews Brothers gelding, Lee Cuyler, won in the matinee road races here to-day in straight heats. The races were contested on Willis Avenue. There were two classes, a free for all which was won by Lee Cuyler handily, and a 2:50 Class, which went to Climax, driven by his owner, Duryea Summaries:

All modern smokeless powders consist either of nitro-cellulose of some special degree of nitration, or of a mixture of different grades, either with or without the addition of nitroglycerine. Tri-nitro-cellulose or guncotion of the highest nitration, is two difficult to work and shrinks too badly to permit of its being used alone.

From The London Chronicle's War Letter. From Koomati Poort I drove to Barberton, making forced marches, and reached it in two days. The whole country, cool after the rains, was green with the promise of Spring. Little rivulets trickled where before had been dry Sand, a parched arid desert had become a flower garden.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Senator Pettigrew is making use of his brief term in the Senate to impress its members with his ingenuity in vexing them with troublesome propositions. He did not approve of the refusal of Secretary Root to send to the Senate the report of Abraham L. Lawshe on expenditures in Cuba.

Ralph S. Lansing, thirty years old, an assistant to William J. Gibson, counsel to the Government in the United States Appraisers' Stores, jumped out of the ninth story of the Appraisers' Stores Building, at Greenwich and Christopher Streets, shortly after noon yesterday. He fell upon the down-town track of the Ninth Avenue elevated railway, and was instantly killed.
ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Bishop Wigger died shortly after midnight this morning. He had been ill with pneumonia for about a week, but not until yesterday was his life despaired of.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A letter from James A. Harvey in THE TIMES of Dec. 23 on the Woman's Christian Temperance Union gives so many mistaken and prejudicial statements in regard to the Woman's Christian Temperance Union that one of its members asks THE TIMES in the interest of fair judgment to give space for a few words in regard to that organization and its work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I want to know something. I am little better than a common civilian, but cannot help thinking and theorizing, and I have been compelled to criticise the conduct of our forces in the Philippines. I want to find out whether I have been an idiot or the military managers have been idiots.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The text of the report on the River and Harbor bill, which appeared to-day, makes a servere arraingnment of the large expenditures, aggregating $19,903,360, on the Missouri River, with an array of figures showing that the traffie is insignificant compared with that of other waterways which have received far less from the Government.

In the following list "mtg stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Fire Marshal Peter Seery reported yesterday to Commissioner John J. Scannell on the fire and explosions in the building of Tarrant Co. on Oct. 29 last, which he began to investigate early in November. The disaster resulted in the loss of seven lives. Ten buildings were destroyed and thirty-five more or less damaged, and the property loss was about $1,200,000.

RED BANK, N.J., Jan. 5. -- In all probability the ice yachting season on the North Shrewsbury River will begin in earnest on Monday. On the north and south shores the ice is at least six inches thick, and the only weak spot is in the middle of the river, which has had only three nights' freezing.

Amid the veriest riot of melodrama, of the most childish and pictorial sort, which has temporarily taken the place of horseplay farce as the chief theatrical staple, comes "Mrs. Dane's Defence," a play by Henry Arthur Jones, which has all the technical merit of a play by Pinero, and nearly as good an average of literary merit.

That the amount of business transacted in the last few days does not compare favorably with the standard established during December need not be made the basis of unfavorable comment. The beginning of the new year is not only the occasion of a serious holiday interruption to business, but it is also the time when large interests are concerned fully as much with the winding up of old affairs as with engaging in new enterprises.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When in 1878 I became a citizen and was invited to join either one of the dominant parties I earnestly, as well as diligently, inquired of men who were active and high in the councils of these parties to point out clearly in what essentials both these parties differed from each other.

From The London Globe. Good gravel has so largely come into request that many suburban lands with that valuable substratum are quarried to a considerable depth before being sold on building lenses. But it is essential to restore a level surface, as even the most speculative builder would hesitate to run up "neat villa residences" in deep holes.
HAVANA, Jan. 5. -- The divisions of the Constitutional Convention have rendered a crystallized report upon the subject of a Constitution for the island in twenty-five sections.

To the Editor of The New York Times: This city has reformed with a vengeance. The old antiquated and superannuated blue laws passed in 1795, which for nearly a century have lain dormant and moulding with public contempt, have boon resurrected and are now being enforced. One of these I ran up against in trying to get shaved on Sunday.

From Ainslee's Magazine. The weekly bill of a vaudeville theatre usually represents a fair proportion of striking individual turns to a balance of general variety. Dramatic sketches or acrobatic acts which require the full stage alternate with monologists and singers that need only the space of the first entrance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- A friend of a member of the Cabinet of President McKinley, one of those who expect to remain a part of the next Administration, was amused and astonished a few days ago by hearing a Cabinet friend suggest that the official family of the President might be changed materially by the dread on the part of those who have consented to remain of going through "four years more" of Cabinet dinners.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The collier Caesar has left Gibralter on route for Hampton Roads.

Nelson Van Kleek, eighteen yours old and Alleen Crossman Wilbur the sixteen-year-old daughter of Charles F. Wilhur, Supervisor of the twelfth Federal census in this dry, eloged and were married on Memorial Day of last year, and have succeeded in keeping it secret until the present time.

When Clara Owen, colored, was arraigned in the Harlem Police Court yesterday four crumpled policemen stood by and regarded her vengefully but respectfully. The four men appeared as if they had been at the mercy of a Kansas cyclone. One of the number wore a heavily bandaged finger in a sling and walked with a limp.ve

PEKING, Jan. 5. -- A meeting of the Protestant missionaries was held to-day to consider the terms of the joint note of the powers to China. A majority of the missionaries spoke on the subject. The consensus of opinion was that the note is not comprehensive enough.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In regard to the started Gospel campaign, Mr. Ernest C. Saundors points to the important confession of shortcomings of the Church in practicing the teachings of Christ. I agree with him, and believe that ought to be the first step to be taken.

The Independent is out with its visual church statistics, which still are somewhat unusual, for some items that are eagerly looked for by those who have a passion for figures are omitted. There is but one total in all the five pages. The reasons given by the compiler, who writes under his own name rather than under the shelter of an editorial, may or may not be deemed sufficient.

FREMONT, Neb., Jan. 5. -- To-day this county has been the scene of some very exciting events growing out of the murder of Herman Zahn at Snyder, last night. The bandits were pursued by bloodhounds all night and finally run to earth by Sheriff Kreader and posse near Scribner, thirty miles from the scene of the crime.

Jacob Radino, window cleaner in the employ of the Window Cleaning Company of New York and Brooklyn, was killed yesterday by a fall from the sixth-story window of the building at 113 and 115 Bond Street, while engaged in his occupation. At all the windows of the building, which is being put in readiness for occupancy, are ron bars to protect them from the shutters.
The second evening concert of the Kneisel Quartet will be given in Mendelssohn Hall on Tuesday evening at 8:15 o'clock, with the following programme:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Mayor Ashbridge of Philadelphia, Senator Penrose of Pennsylvania, and a large delegation of members of the Valley Forge National Park Association, comprising seventeen patriotic societies and the Daughters of the Revolution, appeared before the House Committee on Military Affairs to-day to advocate the project of having the Government acquire the historic camp of Valley Forge, occupied by Gen. Washington and the Continental Army at the crisis of the Revolutionry War.

A dinner and social meeting of the Travelers' Protective Association was held at the Cosmopolitan Hotel. Chambers Street and West Broadway, last night. President George F. Dodge of the New York association presided.

Probably more important conventions than have ever been held at any one place on this side of the Atlantic within the last ten years will be held at Buffalo during the six months in which the Pan-American Exposition will be open there. Not only local and State conventions will be in session during that period, but National conventions as well.

PEKING, Nov. 16. -- Diplomatic persistency in demanding the return of the Emperor to the capital and the futility of the efforts in that line have bred a suggestion that, if his coming be much longer deferred, the Powers unite in naming an Emperor and establishing him in authority. The idea would be to force the Empress Dowager to active measures to dispute the title or to let it go by default.

Perhaps the public attention has not been sufficiently drawn to the purposes and progress of the Appalachian National Park Association. It was formed only late in 1890 by citizens mainly of North Carolina, but including also representatives from South Carolirua, Georgia, Virginia, West Virginia, Kentucky, and Tennessee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: No more important subject is touched upon than the article in this week's issue of The Saturday Evening Post, entitled "The Merchant Marine," by the President of the International Navigation Company and of the American Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers.

The revival of Wagner's "Der Filegende Hollander" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night fell on the fifty-eighth anniversary of the first performance of the opera in Dresden on Jan. 2, 1843. Although it is true that this work begins to sound antiquated because of the naivete of its music, it must nevertheless continue to have a deep historical interest for the student of Wagner.

On Friday The Evening Sun published a long and detailed statement of the conditions in the Eighth Assembly District. The following is the introductory summary and the facts received minutely in the body of the article fully sustain the astonishing assertions of this summary:
Do chicken hawks kill chickens? Ex-Gov. Glick of Kansas says very emphatically that in his opinion they do not.

Miss Anna Potter, cousin of Bishop Henry C. Potter and daughter of the late Bishop Horatio Potter, died on Friday night at her home, 44 East Twenty-fifth Street, in the seventieth year of her age. She had been ill only a short time having been in the best of health until recently.

From The Review of Reviews. John Tenniel was born in London in 1820. He was educated at a private school, and early developed a taste for drawing and painting. He never studied art, however, in any regular way, but was self-taught, like most of our American cartoonists.

Continuous vaudeville is flourishing and few unfamiliar names are found among this week's contributors. At Proctor's Twenty-third Street Theatre vaudeville, devoid of dramatic trimmings, will be offered, the leaders being the Neusky troupe of Russian dancers and John Kernell, the Irish comedian in a new monologue act.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 5. -- The announcement is made by the Yale authorities that two of the remaining three buildings of the Old Brick Row on the college campus will be pulled down next Summer, as will the Treasury Building. The buildings doomed to go are old North College and Lyceum.

PROXIMATE CAUSE OF AN EXTRAORDINARY ACCIDENT. -- While a boat of the Forty-second Street and Weehawken Ferry was entering the slip, on the New Jersey side, it struck with such violence against the north side of the rack of the slip that Stephen Cash, Jr., a boy six years old, who, with his mother and child sister, was a passenger, was thrown to the deck flat upon his back.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit a regular loader a few words concerning your editorial of to-day charging ex-President Harrison with "making fun of the Constitution" in his article in The North American Review.

"That story about the young dry goods clerk, Howard Berliner, who found $700 on Broadway the other day and received $2 for returning it, besides being arrested on suspicion that he was perhaps a thief, is another instance of how there isn't always much inducement for a fellow to be honest," said a well-known tailor, whose establishment adjoins one of the big uptown hotels, yesterday.

From The National Review. What is really wrong in the English service is the awful "system" under which the soldiers live and die. The "system" is a truly terrible monster pervading, everything, smothering everybody with pipe clay, and binding them hand and foot with red tape, shedding a blight on the whole army.

From now on the athletes at New York University will be kept actively at work in competition for places on the various teams. With the return from the Christmas recess, there was a marked increase in activity in all of the organizations. The University Tennis Association held a meeting and elected C. Galwey, 1901, President.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- A number of glassware manufacturers of Pennsylvania and the Eastern States have held daily meetings here within the past week, looking to a combination in the trade. Joseph P. Whitney of the Whitney Glass Works is said to be the leader of the movement. Twenty of the largest concerns are said to have signed an agreement regulating the business.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 5. -- The annual report of the State Labor Commissioner to the Governor, made public to-day, shows a remarkable advance in all departments of industry in the last year. The report states that the record of brisk business enterprise in the State in the last twelve-month "shows Connecticut to be the most complete and ingenious industrial section of the world."
To the Editor of The New York Times: I find in to-day's TIMES cable from London the following paragraph given as a part of Lord Kitchener's speech in Pretoria to a meeting of the burghers:

Very little life showed in the market for outside securities yesterday. As for some days past, interest was centred in the Stock Exchange market, and securities traded in on the curb received little or no attention. A few issues developed some slight activity, and here and there substantial advances appeared, but, all told, the day's transactions brought little change in the general position in the market.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not surprising that Mr. Alfred Harmsworth has run away from tabloid journalism in London to soek solace in a pastime which will impose on him the other extreme -- for fishing cannot be enjoyed in tabloid form; fish are not progressive.

"What we are going to do about the servant question here in New York, I don't know," said a woman yesterday, who is brought closely in touch with it and knows both sides of the matter thoroughly as far as it relates to the better class of servants and the better class of housewives to be supplied with servants.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- As a result of a protracied series of experiments with salt solutions, the efficacy of which in prolonging life was recently announced by Prof. Locb of the University of Chicago, two prominent physicians here claim to have demonstrated that in cases of great loss of blood by disease or injury normal salt solution used as a restorative will save life even when 90 per cent. of the blood has been lost.

The first business week of 1901 is the phenomenal week of New York Stock Exchange history. New records have been made every day, many of them extraorainary. In volume of transactions past business has been far outreached, the tickers of the Stock Exchange being on several days unequal to the task of quoting anything like the actual volume of the trading.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After having enjoyed your editorial pages of New Year's Day with very great zest. I trust you will permit me to call attention to one more enterprise so peculiar to the nineteenth century and which so intimately concerns the prosperity of the masses as to deserve at least a passing notice.

From Chambers's Journal. It has been ascertained by examination of monuments containing heart burials that a small metal vase, or jar, or box, about five or six inches in diameter, has served as the depository for the organ so generally considered the seat of the affections.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5. -- The boom on Wall Street was felt here only through the coal shares, and even in these this market did not reap the full benefit; for, while Reading common sold in New York at 35, the highest in Philadelphia was around 16, or a New York basis of 34. This was a golden opportunity for long-patient holders, and they lost no time in taking advantage of it.

From The London Truth. That there should be a ship canal uniting the Gulf of Mexico with the Pacific is to the interest of all nations, but more especially of the United States, as it would connect by a sea passage their Eastern and Western States. In 1850 the Clayton-Bulwar treaty was signed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent editorial you confessed to being in the dark as to the reason of our difficulty in dealing with the Filipinos. I believe the difficulty to be that we have shown no disposition to secure for the Filipinos the objects they have at heart.

MANILA, Jan. 5. -- The decision of the Philippine Commission in regard to the San Jose Medical College case (the point being whether that institution is owned and controlled by the United States Government or by the Church) unanimously refers the settlement of the questions involved to the courts, and provides Trustees, who, with the assistance of the Attorney General of the Philippines, will inaugurate and prosecute the litigation.

ALBANY, Jan. 5. -- Divorce, which has been greatly aggravated during the past year by the operations of the divorce mills in New York City and Buffalo, will be discussed at length at the annual gathering of the State Bar Association in this city on Jan. 15.

GOLDSBOROUGH, N.C., Jan. 5. -- Ex-Gov. Curtis H. Brogden is dead. He was born on a farm in Wayne County, N.C., in 1815. His early days were spent at farming, but he found time to attend the district schools with fair regularity and to devote some of his leisure to rehearsing in the militia.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the close of every year many of us subject ourselves to rigid self-examination. It is not a comfortable ordeal, but it is necessary. Most of us are aware of our faults and shotcomlngs. Our conscience tells us when we err. It is to our credit that we are sorry for our sins of commission and of omission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The War Department is treating the charges made by Major E.L. Hawkes against Col. Helstand of the Adjutant General's department with contempt.

From The Atlantic Monthly. What is the cause of the greatly increased burden imposed upon the average modern citizen for the expense of government? Is it the result of reckless extravagance by public officials, and the needless multiplication of useless offices, or does it afford substantial benefits to the community?

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the letters published by you, written by the above, it seems to me that the latter was very much more considerate to Dr. Cuyler than the preacher seems to appreciate.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 5. -- Theodore Marburg, a millionaire tobacco manufacturer, Director in the American Tobacco Company, and a well known art collector in this city, has presented the Johns Hopkins University with a collection of rare and beautiful antiques from the Island of Cyprus.

The friends and relatives of Miss Marie Louise Ackerman, who disappeared about a week ago, and who is supposed to have eloped with George Emmons Wentworth, a young lawyer, who has been married for five years, and who, up to a week ago, was living with his wife at 323 Amsterdam Avenue, are still in ignorance of the whereabouts of the couple.

SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Charles Collins, who had been sent from Dutchess County to the prison here on Feb. 8, 1897, for five years and two months for robbery, was discharged to-day and immediately re-arrested by Detective Daniel McNaily and City Detective John Clancey of Trenton, N. J., on charge of shooting at and attempting to rob Abram L. Smith, a conductor on the Pennsylvania Railroad.

A private owner who allowed a piece of ground so costly as the Fifth Avenue front of Bryant Park to lie unused would be regarded as guilty of great extravagance. All the more if he had excavated a hole upon the site and then omitted to go on with his building.

From The London Express. Some curiously interesting matter has lately been unearthed from an old order book of the Twentieth Regiment, the "Minden boys," now the Lancashire Fusiliers, which emanated from the heroic soldier Wolfe when Colonel of the regiment, about 1750.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- While the Senate was in session for more than three hours to-day little in the way of important legislation was accomplished. The committee amendments to the Army Reorganization bill, to which no objection had been raised, were agreed to, but none of the contested amendments was considered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noticed the letter of "Diogenes" in your paper of last Sunday and cannot allow its statements to go unchallenged. I have known Senator Beverldge for eighteen years, since he became a sophomore in college, and a more unfair comparison than that of, your correspondent could not be made.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 5 -- The tremendous increase in the price of cotton has caused every Southern city to close the year 1900 with a season of great prosperity. From all the cities depending largely upon cotton for their business come stories of increased bank clearances. The South has unquestionably been blessed during the closing year of the century.

"The general mercantile conditions between the United States and Honduras have continued apace of the steadily increasing business of former yours. Owing to a slump in the market price of coffee, this statement at first sight may not seem borne nut by the actual figures of the total export.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The commerce of the great lakes for 1900 seems likely to show a larger tonnage movement than in any preceding year. Chicago was in the lead as a receiving port for hard coal a total of 678,094 tons having been unloaded on her docks. Milwaukee ranks second, with receipts of 476,502 tons, and then come South Chicago and Duluth.

Portland and the State generally have had a most prosperous year to look back to and promising future looms in view. As for several yearn past grain shipments have exceeded those of Sun Francisco and Puget Sound ports combined. she is a strong second in importance in the shipping business on the Pacific Coast.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- One aspect of Europe's industrial position deserves prominence, namely, the effect of the greatly increased state of expenditure upon the consuming power of the various peoples as distinct from their Governments. Putting out of sight altogether the abnormal outlays induced by actual war, there has been going on for many years pant a race among the great powers of Europe as to which could spend the most on fighting services.
HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- The American colony in Havana said with a sigh some two months ago that the season was going to be a very quiet one socially, that there would be absolutely no gayety.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Secretary Root has tranmitted to the Chairman of the Senate Military Committee a protest signed by Claude V. Morris, Secretary of the New York State Veterinay Medical Society, against the proposed amendment to the Army bill providing for a corps of veterinay surgeons. In doing so he sent the following explanatory letter to Mr. Hawley, Chairman of the committee:

The commercial conditions between the United States and Bolivia have Improved tremendously during the past year. As against a total of $180,000 in exports from the United States to Bollvia during the year preceding The total exports for the year just passed were $375,000. The amount in oue year has been more than doubled.

In regard to the present and future conditions of trade and industry in our city we are much pleased to state that the optimistic views which were expressed last year have. In a great measure, been fulfilled. We may say now that for the second time in our history have the eyes not only of the entire United States, but of the world been turned to our const in the most marked degree.

A review of the coal trade of the United States for the year 1900 shows concentration of interests which have been more pronounced then in many years preceding. The process may be said to have been going on for quite a time in the anthracite branch, for surely the parties so largely in control have not been idle since the year of the failure of the so-called " combine " of 1892.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- "With the close of the Nineteenth Century and the beginning of the Twentieth." said Secretary of the Treasury Gage. "we have abundant cause to be gratified with our progress as a nation and with the share of prosperity that we are enjoying -- a prosperity, it is also gratifying to know, that has been accorded in a measure to other nations."

The official estimate of the corn crop of the United Stales for 1900 was recently declared by the Department of Agriculture to be 2,105,000.000 bushels from 83,300,000 acres. In the amount produced it has been but three times exceeded in the history of the country. In yield per acre it the frequently been surpassed.

SYDNEY, Dec. 5 -- The business outlook in Australia and New Zealand is of and unpreccdcntcdly bright character, commercial men of every clasp being unanimous in predicting a continued expansion of trade, both export and import, during 1901. A more auspicious time for the inauguration of the Australian Commonwealth could not have been chosen.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 5 -- There was an increase of iron ore shipments from the Lake Superior region for the your 1900 of about 1,000,000 tons over the last, or any preceding, season. The business of the year has amounted to 19,330,918 gross tons.
BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Does Germany stand on the brink of an economic crisis?
The year just closing has boon one of great and funeral prosperity among merchants, Jobbers, and manufacturers generally, and results, as a rule, are highly satisfactory.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Two firemen narrowly escaped losing their lives last night while responding to an alarm for a small fire. The men are Louis Hasser, the driver, and Thomas Hallowell, a pipe man of Chemical Engine No. 1. The chemical was driven down Main Street by Hasser with George Muth in the seat with him, while Hallowell stood on the back step.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 5 -- Short crops in the great Spring wheat belt in the Northwestern States, the tremendous yield in Kansas, with the resulting aggressive competition between those sections; ravages of the Hesslan fly in Michigan, Indiana, and Ohio; unsatisfactory traffic rates, and a small export trade all served to lower the flour millers' profits in 1900, until complaints are made that no year in the past two decades has been less bountcous.

At yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union Eugene A. Johnson, Delegate of the Manhattan Musical Union, protested against the admission of the American Federation of Musicians to the body. Delegate O'Brien of the Granite Cutters' Union, denounced Johnson, saying he was trying to establish a musical trust.

HAVANA, Dec. 31. -- The beginning of the now century finds Cuba in a financial and commercial condition different in every particular from what it was over before. The state of uncertainly which the revolutionary period brought about is changing as rapidly as the condition will permit. Prosperity is fast succeeding distress.

SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Warden Johnson was to-day notified by a telegram from the Governor of the reprieve for twenty days granted to Lorenzo Priori, who was to have been executed this week. Gov. Odell on the telephone confirmed the telegram. He said that friends of the condemned man had laid before him a long petition declaring they could prove his innocence.

Italy will prove herself, in the near future, one of the best fields for American importations. Both the exports and the imports between the two countries are far ahend of those of preceding years. This is so especially of the exports of the United States to Italy.

John Geiger, a lithographer, living at 161 Avenue C. was arrested at midnight last night charged with having assaulted his wife and two of his daughters, after making repeated demands for money from them. Geiger had a pocket-knife in his hand and was threatening to " carve " each member of the family.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- The Cornell Athletic Council yesterday met and approved of the date for the intercollege 'Varsity boat race at Poughkeepsie, which will be held either July 2 or 3. The date for the second crew race in which Columbia, Pennsylvania, and Cornell will be entered, was fixed for May 30.
Trade Conditions at the port of duluth during the season ending Dec. 31,1900, have been favorable -- fully up to former years.

Joseph Brossi, an Italian laborer, thirty years old, of 446 East One Hundred and Fifteenth Street, was a prisoner in the Harlem Police Court yesterday morning charged with holding Charles Timmers, seven years old, of 1,631 Avenue A, over a bonfire until the boy's hands were frightfully burned and the hair on his head was completely singed off.

Cleveland is the greatest iron on market in the world. Within the past decade the 5,199,080 gross tons ore were received and in 1899 this had inereased to 11,278,611, this latuer figure being 61,79 pecent of the total product of the Lake Superior district during that season. The figures for 1900 not yet tabulated.

Capt. Walsh and two of his dectectives of the Eldridge Street Police Station, raided, at midnight last night, an alleged gambling room in the rear of a saloon at 57 Alien Street. The proprietor of the saloon. Morrl Tinteltaub, and reputed proprietor of the gambling room, was arrested, together with ten players.

LONDON, Jan. 6. -- This morning's news from Cape Town is again unsatisfactory. Martial law has been proclaimed at Maimesbury and would have been proclaimed in other districts but that the Cabinet meeting called Saturday was unable to agree as to its advisability.

CAIRO, Dec. 18. 1900. -- The commercial and financial condition of Egypt during the passing year has been exceptionally depressing. The Transvaal war having broken out the last quarter of the past year prevented capitalists from investing money, while in the serious reverses of the British Army in the early part of the war frightened away people, who otherwise might have embarked on commercial speculation.

There have been perhaps more active years in electrical development than 1900 -- as in the great trolley boom -- but none more prosperous, none in which enterprise has been so varied. Electrical industries in this country date only from the second quarter of the century, but the "securities" created in them during the period of sixty years represent not less than, and probably far above, $3,000,000,000.

Patrick Madden, nineteen years old, of 123 Fremont Street, Jersey City, was dying at the City Hospital last night from a fractured skull. William Horn, twenty-two years old, of 357 Jackson Avenue, was locked up on a charge of atrocious assault, and Michael Killeen, twenty-one years old, of 37 Fairmount Avenue, was held as a witness.

OTTAWA, Jan. 5. -- The favorable business conditions in Canada which THE TIMES outlined in January lost have continued, as was predicted. The year has been one of general prosperity in the Dominion. Nor does any sign of falling off appear. The coming year seems certain to be an equally lat one; in no great line of production or trade does slackness exist.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6. -- Edward Corrigan, the well-known turfman, arrived last night from San Francisco on his way to Chicago. Mr. Corrigan said he would sail for England on Jan. 15. "Ten of my horses were shipped from New York today," he said. "They are Corinne. Sardine, and eight unnamed two-year-olds.

Six men composing the crew of the little Nova Scotian schooner Pavia, three of them being part owners in the diminutive ocean-going craft, arrived in New York on the North German Lloyd liner Kalserin Maria Theresia yesterday. Their ship is adrift on the high seas as a result of a smashing she received from the stern of the great liner last Tuesday morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6. -- Coach Ward and Capt. Flickwir of the University of Pennsylvania crews have culled upon all new candidates to report for practice on the machines Jan. 15. Members of last year's crew will not be expected to begin training until after the mid-year examinations, which occur the last week in January.
