-- Imitation can be the severest condemnation, as well as the sincerest flattery, and it was doubtless with the intention of expressing in characteristic way his disgust, natural to all patriotic Americans, at the impudence of the anti-imperialists that Mr. CLEMENS, at the City Club dinner, professed " a strong aversion to sending our bright boys out to the Philippines to fight with a disgraced musket under a polluted flag."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6. -- The consideration of the Reapportionment bill will be resumed to-morrow in the House. The indications point to a final vote on the measure Tuesday, but the fight over the basis of apportionment is a bitter one, and the debate may be prolonged. The outcome is not clear.

In the year just closed the mines of the United States produced metals, other than iron and steel, of a total value of $255,000,000, in round figures. of this total gold furnished $105.000.000. lead $21,000,000, copper $10,000.000. lead $21.000.000. and zinc $10.000.000. the remaining $8,000.000 being made up by the minor metais, such as quicksilver, aluminium, untimony, nickel. and others.

It is one of the humors of events that the day the Inter-State Commerce Commission submitted its report embodying a recommendation for the authorization of pooling among the railroads the consolidation of the Central Railroad, of New Jersey with the Lehigh was announced. The previous day had brought the publication of the practical consolidation of the St. Paul line with the Great Northern, giving a continuous control from Chicago to the Pacific.
Gen. James Cavanagh, seventy-eight years old. is dying at his home, 44 Third Place, Brooklyn. The sacrament of extreme unction was administered yesterday.

To summarize the situation in the tobacco Industry, the past year has been a fortunate our for the trade. An enormous business has born done, and failure have been singularly rare. Probably never before has the industry been in so solvent and flourishing a condition, and it is with the highest of expectation for a continuance of this that I cordially welcomed the new year.

Something of a sensation has been caused in medical circles in Brooklyn by a statement made by Dr. Montague R. Leverson of Bay Ridge to the effect that he has treated thirty smallpox patients without reporting one of the cases to the Board of Health, as is required by law of all physicians.
Absence of any end of the year data will prevent my giving you any very authentic information.

One of the most notable developments of the year was the steadily growing business of the railroads of the country, as shown by their weekly and monthly statements of earnings. Although the returns of 1900 were excellent in every way. those of 1900 surpassed them. In some weeks the improvement was remarkable, and in only one week was a net decrease shown, and that a most insignificant one.
The annual meeting of the Beth Israel Hospital, 206 East Broadway, was held yesterday afternoon, and was largely attended. Kaufman Mandel presided.

With her buck broken, both legs fractured, a fracture of the skull, and serious internal injuries, Mrs. Angelie Betrio, fifty-five years old, of 505 East Twelfth Street, was last night taken to Bellevue Hospital. She had fallen from the fourth floor landing of the fire escape in the rear of the building at that number, and there was scarcely a sound bone left in the woman's body.

Bishop Potter preached a special sermon to men at the services last night under the auspices of St. George's Men's Club, in St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square. Women were admitted only to the galleries of the church. Invitations had been sent to all the clubs and labor organizations in New York.

Between fifty and sixty boys and young men, ranging in ages from fifteen to twenty-five years, and a few of them colored, were corralled in the pool and billiard room of Albert Canfield, on the second floor of the building, at 291 Eighth Avenue, in a raid last evening, by the police of the West Twentieth Street Station.

We think we may say, with moderation and modesty that the Annual Financial Review issued to-day by THE TIMES can be read with interest and profit by all inteligent business men, and that it is substantially indispensable to a careful and thorough study of the deeper and broader currents of business in the year just closed.

There is difference of opinion as to the ultimate effect of arrangements through large banking house in this city for the control of great railroad and coal interests to prevent competition and yield larges returns to stockholders. These moves appear to more popular in Wall Street than in industrial circles.

There was a large and representative gathering of road drivers and their fast steppers on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning. They came from all parts of New York, Brooklyn, and Jersey, and the consequence was a series of brushes seldom witnessed in the stretch. It was ideal weather for the sport, and the roadbed, which was a trifle hard for the trotters, suited the pacers to perfection.

The Nicaragua Canal will have a bearing on the commercial conditions existing between the United States and Nicaragua which will probably draw the two republics into closer relations than any other Central American or Southern American country is likely to approach. The future of Nicaragua, as the future of all countries, depends upon the investment of foreign capital and on the extent of foreign immigration which can be induced.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- The Board of Governors and about 500 members of the New York Athletic Club inspected to-day the ruins of the Summer home of the club on Travers Island, which was destroyed by fire on Saturday, and discussed the plan of building a new clubhouse.

ALBANY, Jan. 6. -- Just what Gov. Odell meant when he referred in his message to the need of amendments to the State laws governing the taxation of corporations is explained by an investigation of the taxes paid to the Controller of the State.

New York, the Financial Centre of the World -- great strides have been made toward this goal, and the pace grows. What in 1900 was accomplished -- and tremendous was that accomplishment -- is but suggestive of what 1901 promises.

At the close of the year it is well to look at our balance sheets and see what has been done during the twelve-month. THE TIMES to-day will be full of statistics from the balance sheet of the Nation; but there are certain points to be deduced from this array of figures which may escape the notice, for the moment, of those who comment upon them.

The last year in the nineteenth century was the most interesting one in the export trade. For the first time it dawned upon the American people that, commercially speaking, the world was their inheritance, and that with proper patience time and labor there are few markets in which they cannot enter.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- John C. Sims. Secretary of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, and well known in railroad circles throughout the country, died at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital at 1:30 o'clock this afternoon. Mr Sims was operated upon on Dec. 11 to relieve him of an acute attack of appendicitis.

The continuation of what the brewings trade consider an exorbitant war tax, with the competition which it serves to aggravate are factors that have combined to seriously affect the prosperity of the brewing industry, and have left little cause for satisfaction with the results of the year's business, although its volume showed a great increase.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 1, 1900 -- The year opened with the best augurlea for the immediate future. The previous year had been one of remarkable development and prosperity throughout the country. The total trade showed an unprecedented increase of 20 per cent, over that of 1808, and had doubled within the decade.

The cotton trade of the world has rarely been so puzzled over the probable outcome of the American cotton crop, for any year after Jan. 1. sine careful atatisties of the ncrenge, movement, and consumption have been recorded, as they are at the beginning of the twentieth century.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 The selection of membere of the various Senate and Assembly committees in about completed but untill they are read at the session of the Legislause on Wednesday night they will be subject to many change at the solicitation ot surly leaders in the State and country.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- The New Year opened with a remarkable plethora of money. Although Brussels and Paris have discontinued discounting here, the mortgage banks have resumed lending, their position having been immensely strengthened by the meeting a week ago of the Prussian Hypotheken Aktien Pank and the Deutsche Grundschuld Bank.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 6 -- Major Barak G. Thomas, known as the Nestor of the American turf, undoubtedly one of the foremost and most successful old-school breeders in America, is dangerously ill at his home on Main Street, here. Major Thomas was taken to his bed shortly after the December thoroughbred sales, and his physician, Dr. Kinniard, decided that his malady nearly approached pneumonia.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 6. -- Congressman James F. Stewart of this district will next week meet in conference a delegation of prominent silk manufacturers of this city. New York, and other silk centres who are interested in legislation to govern the manufacture and sale of silk goods.

Magistrate Flammer had a complicated case before him yesterday in the Jefferson Market Court. The prisoner was William G. Tigpen, who lives at the Victoria Annex, Broadway and Twenty-sixth Street. He was charged with stealing a twenty-doller gold certificate from John Crutcher, a furniture dealer of Atlanta, Ga., at the Marlborough Hotel, on Saturday.
Controller Coler delivered an address last evening at St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, State Street, Brooklyn, on "Public Office and the People."

A French officer wrote to the French Premier and to the Minister of War, making grave charges against the Minister of Foreign Affairs. He attempted to confirm his charges by introducing through a Nationalist Deputy in the Chamber a statement questioning the authenticity of a document in the Dreyfus dossier, a document which, while it established the moral innocence of DREYFUS, was not permitted to have legal weight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- For the first time in ten years the output of gold in the world for a calendar year falls below that of the previous year. From 1800, when the world's product was $118,000,000, to 1899. when it had risen to $300,000,000, the yield increased year after year by the steady, uninterrupted development of great ore deposits in the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6. -- By the death of P.D. Armour, a now power has arisen in the world of commerce, Jonathan Ogden Armour, aged thirty-five, is in control of the Armour millions and an army of 20,000 employes. This means control of the enormous business of the firm, which reaches around the world and amounts to $150,000,000 a year.

CINCINNATI, Ohio. Jan. 6. -- The Blaine club of Cincinnati, the largest political organization in Ohio, has officially abandoned us proposed trip to the inauguration at Washington next month, for which two special trains had been chartered. The committee that visited Washington reported that it could not make arrangements for quarters such us the Blaine Club members were accustomed to.

The course of exchange in the markets of any one country generally indicates how that country's accounts stand with the rest of the world. There are cases, however, where exchange may be influenced by other causes than the more state of, say, our account with Europe. One such cause was the fear of disturbance in our monetary system several years ago.

The public will refuse to believe that the extraordinary delay in bringing the appeal of ROLAND B. MOLINEUX before the Court of Appeals for hearing is due to any other underlying cause than negligence. But negligence may be culpable, and where delay in determining the fate of a man under sentence of death is unreasonable and inhuman, blame attaches unless good cause is shown.
The year and the century close on the most prosperous conditions in the cotton bell since the war.

NEWPORT, Jan. 6 -- Miss Elsie French has selected an original set of decorations in the cloak and coat room at Harborview for the use of the guests who will attend the wedding breakfast and reception on Monday afternoon next.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 6. -- The First Reformed Church congregation saw $2,000 worth of notes and mortgages burned from the pulpit this morning. They represented the whole of the debt of the church, and it was announced there was $300 in the treasury.

Tauching the condition of trade and industry in our city at the close of the past yeariand the promise for the coming year. I would say that the retail trade as a whole has been about normal. The volume of business in the large department stores was very gratifying. The result. in profits. I am informed, has. been most satisfactory, and will exceed the expectations of many of the merchants.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your account of the filing of the " Briefs in the Porto Rico Cases." published in this morning's issue, as usual is the best and completest. As you are no doubt aware, the section of the Constitution applying to these cases is in the article relating to States, viz.:

The 1,600 or more druggists of New York are about to adopt a plan for uniform prices for proprietary medicines, which is now one of the important features of the trade. A meeting was held at the College of Pharmacy Building on Saturday and reports were received showing that about 95 per cent, of the druggists favored the plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- When the Government reports of a year ago showed the rade of that year to have been the largest in the history of the United States. with a total just rising above $2,000,000,000 it was considered so gratifying a figure that if it had not been in the following year there would have been no surprise.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Turkish Government has furnished Dr. Thomas Norton, who was appointed United States Consul at Harpoot, what are known as traveling papers, constituting a safe conduct to enable the doctor to proceed to his post. There is reason to believe that this action forecasts a compliance by the Turkish Government with the request of the State Department for a regular exequatur fur Dr. Norton.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 7 -- Sir Ernest Mason Satow, British Minister to China, has proposed to the other foreign envoys the draft of a commercial treaty with China based upon the following conditions:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The Board of Directors of the Reading Company to-day decided to accept the proposition made by J.P. Morgan concerning the purchase of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, and President Joseph S. Harris will to-morrow go to New York to confer with Mr. Morgan and Charles Steele regarding the financing of the deal.

The plans of the General Carnegie Company for improving the site of the old Sixth Avenue car stables with an apartment house will probably suffer a serious setback through proceedings begun yesterday to foreclose an eight-hundred-thousand-dollar mortgage on the property held by the Sixth Avenue Railroad Company.

It will be a disgrace to the Democratic minority in the Senate if Mr. HANNA is allowed to carry out his threat to pass the Ship Subsidy bill at this session. Undoubtedly there is a majority of the Senate in favor of the bill. Mr. HANNA has arranged that with his accustomed energy and astuteness.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 7 -- Yale University Hockey team played its first match here to-night, and gave the Quaker City champions the hardest game of the season. The score of 3 goals to 1 in favor of Philadelphia inadequately shows the character of the struggle, which from start to finish was last and brilliant.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 7 -- Harvard's track team began training for the season's work to-day, when 125 men reported to Capt. Hallowell and Trainer Graham for light gymnasium work. Real work will not begin until next week, when it is expected 250 men will be in training. The prospects of a good team are very bright.

The little United States transport Ingalls arrived here yesterday, after an exciting voyage from San Juan and Havana. Off the Florida coast she encountered a gale that lasted forty hours. Her steering gear was badly damaged, the big wheel being smashed to pieces and the wooden grating around it washed overboard.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- There was heavy trading to-day in Atchison, both common and preferred, over 7,000 shares selling in the morning. Chicago, Burlington and Quincy sales also were heavy, over 10,000 shares being disposed of in the first half of the day. Union Pacific, Sugar, and Federal Steel also were in brisk demand.

Mrs. Astor gave her annual ball at her residence, 842 Fifth Avenue, last night. This ball is perhaps the most regular and representative function of fashionable New York society. It has been given by Mrs. Astor on the first or second Monday of each recurring January for over a quarter of a century, save for a few years when the hostess was in mourning.

Papers will be served probably to-day in a suit to recover about $800,000 from former Directors of the American Malting Company. The proceedings are brought by Ernest Plarrius of the Produce Exchange in the interest of himself and a number of other stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Representative Lovering (Rep., Mass.,) introduced a bill to-day "to make the currency responsive to the varying needs of business at all seasons and in all sections."
LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Andre Mesager, the French composer, has been appointed manager of the Covent Garden opera, in succession to Maurice Grau.

The Tammany Hall investigating committee of five met yesterday afternoon. Commissioner John W. Keller was absent on account of illness. The committee was in executive session an hour, and then Chairman Nixon made this official statement:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Senator Pettigrew's answer to the announcement that the Commerce Committee expects to force a vote on the Ship Subsidy bill by resorting to night sessions, is a defiance of the programme that assumes that he is ready to submit rather than bear the weariness of night work, and will let the bill go through rather than "sit up with it."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The interest taken by public men in the effort of the Asphalt Trust to prevent the Venezuelan Government from ousting it from what it considers its property in Venezuela is very keen. The asphalt concern has had the moral support of several Senators in its work at the State Department.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- Money was easier today. The supply was augmented by the release of consols and dividends. Discounts were affected sympathetically.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- At a meeting of the stockholders of the Boston Electric Light Company, held in this city to-day, it was voted to lease the property of the company to a new organization to be formed by J.P. Morgan Co., for a term of not more than ninety-nine years, at an annual rental of 10 per cent.

MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 7 -- This afternoon Secret Service Agent E.P. McAdams arrested on Royal Street, this city, Capt. C. W. King, Quartermaster and Supervisor of the Government work at Fort Morgan, Ala. Capt. King had just received $1,000 in bills from J.H. Hobson, a contractor on Government work at the fort.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A notable speech was delivered in the Senate to-day by Mr. Lodge, (Rep., Mass.) Addressing the Senate on the amendment of the Military Committee striking out the provision in the Army Reorganization bill for a veterinary corps, he discussed briefly, and principally in the form of a colloquy with Senator Bacon (Dem., Ga.,) the Philippine question and the necessity for an army of 100,000 men.
F.A. Bruen has sold for David V. Johnson and another to Mary Y. Morton the four-story building 88 West Houston Street, northwest corner of West Broadway, 20 by 100.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 7 -- Biting, kicking, and continually trying to escape from his attendants during a three-thousand-mile trip, so he could leap oft the train, Arthur Humbert, a New Yorker, was brought all the way from Seattle, Washington, on Sunday night to White Plains by his brother and a soldier of the United States Army, and confined in Bloomingdale Asylum as a lunatic.

Business in the outside market yesterday was fairly well distributed, but the volume of transactions was small. Trading was probably more active than at the close of last week, but attention was so diverted by the enormous trading on the board that little interest in outside issues was manifested.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hand you herewith a copy of a letter which appeared in a recent number of the North China. Daily News, written by a foreign resident of China of many years' standing, which gives an accurate description of the commercial situation in Manchuria, and the risks that other nations run in allowing Russia to become possessed of that section of the Chinese Empire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- In accordance with a unanimous agreement made in the House to-day, a reapportionment bill will be passed before the adjournment to-morrow, but it is not at all certain to-night that it will be the bill reported by Mr. Hopkins from the Census Committee. Although Mr. Hopkins expresses the greatest confidence that the House will stand by his bill, he does not seem able to find his majority easily.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- To the pending Army Reorganization bill Senator Vest of Missouri to-day offered the following amendment: "The officers in charge of the West Point Military Academy shall make and enforce such rules and regulations as will prevent the practice of hazing; and any cadet found guilty of participating in such practice shall be expelled from the Academy, and shall not be reappointed to the corps of cadets therein."

Miles McDonnell, who shot and killed George Price and wounded three others in a shotoing affray in the Onawa Cafe Dec. 29 last, was yesterday prevented from going scot free for Price's killing, by Arthur Blue, a Coroner's juryman, at the inquest before Coroner Hart.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 7 The calculations of ice yachting experts were upset to-day in what was expected would be the finals for the club pennants in the ice yacht races of the South Shrewsbury ice Yacht Club at Branchport. The two events on the card were for the first and second class championship pennants.

Commissioner of Charities John W. Keller yesterday deposed Superintendent W.B. O'Rourke of Bellevue Hospital and appointed in his stead and to the Superintendency of the other city hospitals -- Harlem, Gouverneur, and Fordham -- Dr. George Taylor Stewart, the Superintendent and the Chief of Staff of the Metropolitan Hospital, on Blackell Island.

It was announced yesterday by Secretary Bogatsky of the Hebrew Bakers' Union that the strike committee is in favor of asking Magistrate Crane, who is now sitting in Essex Market Court, to arbitrate the strike of the Hebrew bakers.

Engaged to be married to one man and loving another, Ada Lemmon, twenty-four years old, living at 238 West One Hundred and Sixteenth Street, confessed her bitter secret to her widowed mother yesterday afternoon. Then, when the latter upbraided her for her so-called heartlessness and ungratefulness, she quietly left her home and, going to the Park Hotel, 1,520 Park Avenue, ended her trouble by sending a bullet into her temple.

One of the most promising facts concerning the negotiations about to be opened at Peking is the reported inability of LI-HUNG-CHANG to take an active part in them, because that aged and foxy person has been, for at least a decade, the hired man of Russia in Chinese councils.

With the steamship Coya, which reached here on Sunday and now lies in the Erie Basin, there was brought into port one of the most interesting wreck stories of the last twelvemonth. The unfortunate vessel was the San Augustin, owned by the Compagnie Generate Transatlantique. She ran against a rock in Smyth Channel, one of the numerous passages of the Straits of Magellan, on Nov. 27 last.

Germany is suffering from the lack of free capital. The symptoms so clearly described in the Berlin letter published in THE TIMES Annual Financial Review yesterday point unmistakably to overinvestment. Capital has been locked up, immobilized, almost as fast as it has been produced.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The Congressional Committee appointed for the purpose of inquiring into the alleged hazing of former Cadets Oscar L. Booz of Bristol, Penn., and John E. Breth of Altoona, Penn., resumed the taking of testimony at the Lafayette Hotel this morning. The committee attached much importance to the testimony of to-day's witnesses.

Charles D. Wood, thirty-three years old, an Assistant Professor in English Literature in Brown University, committed suicide yesterday afternoon at the home of his brother. Dr. Walter A Wood. 80 Halsey Street, Brooklyn, by hanging himself to a doorknob in his room. Prof. Wood came to Brooklyn yesterday on a leave of absence from the university to rest and try to recover his normal state of mind.

The Secretary of the New York State Veterinary Society has done himself and those whom he represents much credit by sending to Mr. ROOT the letter which Mr. ROOT in turn has sent to the Chairman of the Senate Military Committee with a commentary of his own.

Edna May, wearing a gown which seemed to be made of cloth of gold and richly bejeweled, was revealed at 8:40 o'clock last evening on the stage of the Herald Square Theatre, standing in the centre of an iceberg which had just been struck by lightning in an artificial thunderstorm manufactured only six miles from the north pole, by a party of American scientists.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- In business and in politics Gov. Odell has long been noted for his remarkable aptitude for mastering detail. He is bringing his talent in that direction to bear upon State affairs. To-day he sent for several heads of departments and put them through a searching cross-examination.

Close finishes marked the majority of the brushes on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon, where there was a select gathering of trotters and pacers. Among the early brushes was a three-cornered tilt between Louise Mac, driven by A.B. Gwathmey: Birdie R., driven by A. F. Thompson, and Malacca, driven by Nathan Straus.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The Board of PoorLaw Guardians of Weobly, Herefordshire, has declined, on patriotic grounds, to accept a gift of pictures and books from William T. Stead for the workhouse, forwarded through Lady Henry Somerset.

Caleb H. Jackson, Vice President and Manager of the United Electric and Power Company, was arrested at his apartments at the Plaza Hotel yesterday and arraigned later in the Yorkville Police Court on the charge, as manager of the company, of violating the smoke ordinance. The power house of the company is at 407--419 East Twenty-eighth Street, and numerous employes of the concern have been arrested recently on the same charge.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Chicago will be the Mecca for bowlers this week. All the leading tenpin artists in the country will be here within the next few days to exhibit their skill on the lacquer-covered alleys. The tournament competition for the championship of the United States begins tomorrow afternoon, and if the hopes of the local promoters are realized the tourney will be the greatest in the history of the game.

Alvan S. Southworth, an old-time newspaper man, traveler, and author, died suddenly yesterday morning in a lodging house at 386 Third Avenue. Southworth, although a man of brilliant attainments and with acquaintances ranging from Princes to the habitues of lodging houses, had for over twenty years lived an unsettled life.

NEWPORT, Jan. 7 -- The decorators and electrical workers are now in possession of Harbourview, where the wedding reception and, breakfast of Alfred G. Vanderbilt and Miss Elsie French will occur Monday. Mrs. French, Miss French, and Mrs. Eaton were directing the final arrangements for the event.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- The anthracite stocks ruled the Philadelphia market to-day. All other interests were subordinated. Reading common sold at 18 1/2, the first preferred at 37 1/4, and the second at 23 1/2. Long patient holders jumped at the opportunity, and many of them exchanged their storks for cash.

Judge Rufus B. Cowing, in General Sessions, yesterday, charging the January Grand Jury, directed the especial attention of that body to the alleged existence of vicious conditions and violations of the laws, to which the police are said to be both blind and deaf, and requested that due investigation of the matters complained of be made by them.

MANILA, Jan. 7 -- Gen. MacArthur has ordered the deportation of Gens. Ricarte, Del Pilar, Hizon Llanera, und Santos to the Island of Guam. Nine regimental and four subordinate officers, with eight civillians, including Trias, Tecson, and Mabini, notorious assistants of the insurrectionists, have also been ordered to be deported.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Manhattan Elevated Railway Company of New York City is making an effort to secure a further reduction in the valuation of its property subject to taxation in that city.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 7 -- A project is on foot for the organization of a university basket ball team at Princeton. Baskets will be placed in the gymnasium this week, and it is expected that the call for candidates will be made on Wednesday and the team organized a few days later. The students having the movement in charge are making inquiries into the arrangement of it schedule.
ANSONIA, Conn., Jan. 7 -- The largest foreign order ever filled in this city is now completed and awaiting shipment. It consists of 1,000,000 pounds of wire for a trolley road in India.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 7 -- President Cowen of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company puts no faith in the stories about a "vast transcontinental system." Although closely connected with Mr. Hill in railroad affairs, Mr. Cowen says he is not speaking for him, but the Baltimore and Ohio President says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Assistant Secretary of Stale and Mrs. David Hill gave their first evening at home to-night, their residence on K Street being filled by a distinguished company from 9 o'clock until midnight. Mrs. Joel Dorman Steele of Elmira, who has arrived to spend the Winter in Washington, helped to receive and friends of the hostess contributed to an informal musteale.

ALBANY, Jan. 8. -- The State Board of Charities and the State Commission of Prisons are not legislative creations, but have their being from the Constitution of the State. This being so, the question has been raised whether it will not require a Constitutional amendment to carry into effect the recommendations of Gov. Odell with regard to these two boards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- The War Department has been informed of the death at Manila to-day of First Lieut. Louis P. Smith, Assistant Surgeon, United States Army. Lieut. Smith was born in and appointed from the District of Columbia in November, 1896. In November, 1899, he sailed for the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- By a vote of 165 to 102 the House to-day accepted the reapportionment plan proposed by the Burielgh bill, which increases the membership of the House during the next decade from 357, the present membership and the membership proposed by the committee or Hopkins bill, to 386.

LONDON, Jan. 9. -- Lord Raglan, Under Secretary of State for War, who was interviewed yesterday regarding the serious trend of events in South Africa, the possibilities of peace, and the action the War Office is taking to mend matters, said:

Details will be found in other columns concerning the purchase of the old Real Estate Exchange property by the Chamber of Commerce and the sale or a large plot at Fifth Avenue and Elghty-seventh Street, to Henry Phipps of Pittsburg, Penn.

BOSTON, Jan. 8. -- There was lessened interest and smaller volume of business in the market to-day, with prevailing heaviness in pfices. Agricultural Chemical was the leading home specialty, dropping under pressure from 32 1/4 to 29, on sales of some 3.000 shares, in the morning, with a rally to 30 in the afternoon. The preferred lost 1 1/2, to 80.

Hockey at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening between the sevens of the New York Athletic club and St. Nicholas Skating Club was chiefly noteworthy for the splendid team work and impregnable defense of the wearers of the Mercury Foot. These two things gave them an easy and somewhat tame victory over their opponents by a score of 4 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Postmaster General Charles Emory Smith to-day sent to the House of Representatives a report showing the results of a complete and exhaustive expert investigation into the cost, operation, c., of the pneumatic tube postal service, with a view to determining whether the service should be owned, leased, extended, or discontinued by the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- George Woodruff, the football coach, who has had charge of the University of Pennsylvania football teams for several years past, may sever his connection with the university. A meeting of the Athletic Association will be held to-morrow, and it is practically certain that the question will be decided one way or the other.

The first annual meeting of the New York Zoological Society since the opening of the zoological garden in Bronx Park was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Henry F. Osborn, Chairman of the Executive Committee, presided in the absence abroad of Levi P. Morton, the President.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Bowlers from nearly every large city in the United States were present this afternoon when the first National tournament of the American Bowling Congress opened. Preceding the tournament, a business meeting of the officials of the congress was held, nothing but routine business being transacted, however.
Superintendent Blair of the Department of Outdoor Poor says that there are probably 130,000 to 200,000 persons suffering from grip in New York City at the present time.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- William J. Bryan was the guest of honor at the annual banquet of the Chicago Bryan League, which was held to-night at the Sherman House. Some of the preliminary addresses were of considerable length, and it was after midnight before Mr. Bryan, who had the last place on the programme, rose to make his address.
CAPE TOWN, Jan. 8. -- The Central Peace Committee at Kroonstad has issued a circular, in the course of which it says:

James B. Regan, proprietor of the Pabst Hotel, at Forty-second Street and Broadway, will receive to-day another ultimatum from James P. Keating, Commissioner of Highways, in relation to the portico of the hotel, which squats on the public domain and takes up an area worth more than $38,000.

HONOLULU, Jan. 1. -- A letter has come from Delegate Wilcox, at Washington, to the Central Committee of the independent Party asking the appointment of a committee to examine Hawallan youths who wish to enter West Point Military Academy and to forward recommendations as to five youths, with photographs.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 8 -- N.H. Frazer, Tax Collector of Bullock County, Ala., has been notified that his son, Bass, an eighteen-year-old student at the Technological School here, has been kidnapped and is held for a ransom of $5,000. The boy was seen here last on Saturday, Jan. 5.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- A suit for $100,000 indemnity has been brought against the Portuguese Government by Dr. Herbert McAuley, a well-known North Side physician. The case is now in the hands of the State Department officials in Washington.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 8. -- Application was made in the United States Circuit Court to-day for the appointment of a receiver for the Cuban Land and Steamship Company. The application is made by Benjamin K. Taylor. Orrin M. Lambert, and Joseph H. Young, who charge that the company has been mismanaged and that it is now insolvent.

MANILA, Jan. 8. -- The Philippine Commission has completed the code for the government of municipalities. It will be enacted next week and supersede the military order of last March, under which many barrios (wards or districts) were organized. The general municipal elections take place in December.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 8. -- Judge Dixon, in opening the January term of the Supreme Court here to-day, charged the Grand Jury to investigate the report published in a local paper to the effect that a prominent person here had recently been concerned in the drugging of a young girl, who escaped the fate of Jennie Bosschieter only through the prompt services of physicians.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- During the legislative session of to-day the Senate had under consideration the much-mooted canteen question, in connection with the Army Reorganization bill. The Senate Committee, in effect, restored the provision for a post exchange, or canteen, which had been stricken out of the bill by the House.

ROCHESTER. N. Y., Jan. 8. -- Twenty-eight dead bodies lie at the morgue and twelve persons, more or less seriously injured, lie at the different hospitals in the city to-night as a result of the terrible holocaust which early this morning occurred at the Rochester Orphan Asylum. Of the dead, twenty-six were children of both sexes, ranging in age from two or fourteen years, while the remaining two were adults.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8. -- Argument was begun in the United States Supreme Court at 3:35 o'clock to-day in the Porto Rican customs cases, now before that court. The consolidated cases were taken up, and F.R. Coudert spoke in behalf of the plaintiffs against the Government in the cases known as the De Luna case.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8. -- Lehigh Valley was the feature of the market to-day, 16,000 shares being sold in the first two hours on an advance to 34 1/4, and back to 33 1/8; later there was another rise. The price ruled higher than at any previous time since 1896. The advance, of course, is based on future developments, with the present accompaniment of manipulative influences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The President is still suffering from his cold, and on the advice of Dr. Rixey has decided to stay in his room for three or four days. There will be no Cabinet meeting to-day, and the invitations for the diplomatic reception to-morrow night have been recalled. The reception will be held at a future time not yet decided upon.

It is gratifying to observe that the drift of opinion in the House of Representatives itself, as shown in the debate yesterday, is the same as that of the country at large, upon the question of reapportionment. That is to say, the House agrees that it is already too numerous for the proper and orderly transaction of its business.

PATERSON, N. J., Jan. 8. -- The first case taken up by Judge Dixon in the Supreme Court to-day was the application of George J. Kerr for a separate trial on the indictment charging him with assaulting and murdering Jennie Bosschieter, and of Walter C. McAllister for removal of the indictment to the Supreme Court, to the end that it may be reviewed and quashed on several technicalities.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 8. -- In the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to-day Judge Severens delivered the opinion of the Court in the case of the New York Life Insurance Company against the Commissioners of Cuyahoga County, involving bonds of Cuyahoga County amounting to $225,000.

An event extraordinary in pigeon shooting took place at Inter-State Park, at Queens. L.I., yesterday, when the latest challenge match for the Du Pont Championship Trophy, the prize in many sensational races at the traps, was shot for by two of the most famous and popular pigeon shooters in America.

George W. Howard, the electrician who married Helen P. Hawkes, the youngest daughter of Henry Hawkes, Superintendent of Construction in the Water Supply Department of Brooklyn, when, according to the police, he had a wife living in Cambridge, Mass., was indicted on a charge of bigamy yesterday by the Brooklyn Grand Jury.

Cornelius Vanderbilt, inventor of the newly patented locomotive firebox, received his first official acknowledgment as a mechanical engineer last night, when he responded to the invitation to read a paper on his invention before an audience of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 12 West Thirty-first street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Bachelors' Cotillion gave its first dance of the season this evening at the National Rifies' Armory, with 300 guests in attendance. Mrs. C. C. Glover, wife of an ex-President of the club, acted as hostess of the evening for the officers, who are Jesse Brown, P. Lee Phillips, George Howard, Richard Merrick, Capt. Charles McCawley, Commander Thomas Rogers, and Gist Blnlr.

Ex-Judge Charles L. Benedict died in his apartment at the Buckingham Hotel at 8:30 o'clock last evening of heart disease, after a long illness. It was failing health that led him to retire from the bench in February, 1897, but he had been up and about until very lately, and was only confined to his bed for the last week of his life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The United States has laid before the powers a plan for taking the indemnity question out of the hands of the envoys at Peking and having it settled by a conference of representatives of the powers. The State Department, in making this proposition, has suggested Washington as the place of conference.

What was expected to be a contested annual election of the New York Association of the bar last night, with two tickets in the field, turned out a unanimous affair with only one ticket, and that the regular one.
PARIS, Jan. 8. -- Parliament reassembled to-day. Great animation was manifested on the floor of the Chamber of Deputies, and the tribunes were crowded.

The official statement made on Monday by Chairman Nixon of the Tammany Committee of Five that there exists a combine for the levying of blackmail on gamblers contained nothing that is new to those who have been following the course of events in police circles for the past year. In his statement Mr. Nixon said:

William S. Flugg of 109 University Place, who appeared in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday afternoon as the complainant against a waiter in a restaurant on Sixth Avenue, who, he said, had assaulted him without provocation, was characterized by William Downs, the proprietor of the restaurant, as the meanest man on earth.

The French ball opened at Madison Square Garden last night a little larger and a little gayer than in past years, but it was the same old gathering. The whole interior of the garden had been transformed so as to represent an actual scene in the Champs Elysees, and the night's pleasure opened with a series of grand tableaus and illuminated floats.

As the result of a saloon quarrel, John Sohl of 423 West Twenty-fifth Street is in the New York Hospital from a fractured skull, and his friend, Harry Heincken of 331 West Twenty-seventh Street, spent the night in prison on n charge of felonious assault. Sohl is forty years old, has a family, and is foreman of a coal yard on West Twenty-fifth Street.

SANTIAGO, Cuba. Jan. 8. -- Telegraphic orders were received this afternoon removing Isidro Grinon, Mayor of Santiago, from office, and placing Senor Giro, Vice Mayor, in charge of the affairs of the municipality. This action is the result of the investigation of a commission, consisting of an army officer, an expert accountant, and a member of the Chamber of Commerce, into charges of irregularity in the conduct of municipal affairs.

A collection of twenty-five landscapes and seascapes by George H. McCord, A. N.A., may be seen for the following ten days at one of the Clausen Galleries, 381 Fifth Avenue. American, Dutch, and English scenes alternate round the walls of the little gallery, punctuated here and there by a French townscape, like the view of Morel near Fontainebleau from the riverside at nightfall.

Undoubtedly, when things come to that pass, in a public institution, that three of the persons employed therein have to be indicted for manslaughter in the first degree, in consequence of their official malfeasance or nonfeasance, it is time that there should be a change. Mr. KELLER, luckily, made his change just before, and not Just after, the finding of the Grand Jury.

If Galveston had been as well protected by sea walls before the great storm as it has been since by its newspapers, it could have offered bold defiance even to the sea. For the Galveston newspapers are fine products of the New South, with courage equaling their enterprise, and hardly had the waters heaped up by the cyclone begun to subside before they urged the rebuilding of another city on the stricken site.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Mr. Choate had an interview regarding the Chinese situation with Lord Lansdowne at the Foreign Office yesterday, but little headway was made. The discussion was confined to the difficulties of the powers in agreeing to China's answer to their demands, which will necessitate further negotiations.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 8. -- The one hundred and twenty-fifth session of the New Jersey Legislature opened to-day. The lobby and galleries of the two houses were crowded with spectators, and the members' desks were loaded down with flowers.

We cannot imagine any disposition of an important public question sillier and more cowardly than that yesterday accepted by the Military Committee of the Senate. That was the proposition, made, we are sorry to say, by Senator HOAR, that a commission should be appointed "to investigate the effect of the army canteen."

CHICAGO, Jan. 8. -- Superintendent of Schools E.G. Cooley has been assigned a novel task in connection with his duties as the head of Chicago's public school system. In accordance with a resolution adopted by the Board of Education Committee on School Management, Mr. Cooley has been asked to revise the rules of football and present them at the board meeting to-morrow night.

Prices showed considerable irregularity in the market for outside securities yesterday, but except in a few issues there was no increase in transactions. A good demand for bonds was reported, one of the evidences of the current demand for investment securities resulting from present large disbursements in the form of dividends and interest on bonds.

Mon "high in the councils" of Tammany Hall, but not as high up as Richard Croker, may have been receiving money from the gambling "combine" according to the latest statement of Lewis Nixon, Chairman of the Committee of Five.

"My Lady Dainty." a namby-pamby, inarticulate composite of farce and sentimental drama, was acted at the Madison Squarc Theatre last night, much better than it deserves to be acted, by Herbert Kelcey, Effic Shannon, and their company. Madeline Lucette Ryley concocted this piece, and it is quite the feeblest production of her frequently diffusive and incoherent but generally lively and entertaining pen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The State Department received advices to-day from Consul General Gudger, at Panama, indicating that the Colombian revolution had again assumed a serious aspect. He states that the Colombian Government announces that the revolutionists are approaching Panama and are making preparations for a fight, which is likely to occur soon.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Jan. 8. -- The final race for the championship pennant for firstclass yachts in the series of club races held by the South Shrewsbury Ice Yacht Club was sailed this afternoon. Last night's freeze hardened the ice, putting it in excellent condition. A light westerly breeze prevailed.

George Balrd, fifty-six years old, and his wife, Emma, forty years old, were found dead in their apartments on the third floor of 45 Sumner Avenue, Williamsburg, yesterday morning, while two pet dogs belonging to the couple were unconscious in the room. Death was due to asphyxiation from illuminating gas.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The principal feature of the assembling of the two houses of the Legislature to-night was the appointment of committees and clerks, and the reception of a list of appointments by the Governor. A number of minor appointments were made in the Senate and also in the Assembly.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your Issue of to-day, John J. Rooney condemns Lord Kitchener's South African policy as worse than Weyler's in Cuba. In the same issue, Benedict Prieth denounces British officers for profaning "the most sacred house of worship in China with their typical British vulgarity."

NEWPORT, Jan. 9. -- The floral decorations for the wedding of Miss French and Alfred G. Vanderbilt on Monday next will be more elaborate than was at first intended. The decoration of the church will be begun immediately after the services on Sunday, and the work will be continued all night.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- The bill abolishing the bi-partisan Police Board in New York City end providing for the appointment of a single Commissioner by the Mayor, subject to removal, without charges, by either the Mayor or the Governor, was introduced in both branches of the Legislature to-night. The measure was introduced by Senator Stranahan in the Senate and by Mr. Kelsey in the House.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- A.B. Wegner, physical director of the Young Men's Christian Association in this city, and two of the athletes In classes In his department. P.D. Jennings und J. Nicholson, claim to have beaten the world's record in the rope vault. The previous world's record is 8 feet 6 inches, held by Edmunds of Chicago.
The following new securities were yesterday listed by the Listing Committee of the New York Stock Exchange:

HAVANA, Jan. 9. -- The American Commission, under the superintendence of Dr. Reed, which has been making experiments at Quemados as to the propagation of the yellow fever germs by the mosquito, has obtained extremely satisfactory results.

Interest in the work of the Tammany Committee of Five centred yesterday in a hope that Chairman Nixon or some other member of the committee might be induced to throw additional light on Mr. Nixon's statement that Tammany itself has no interest in the blackmail derived from the protection of vice in this city, but that there existed in the organization a "combine" which operated on its own hook entirely distinct from the parent organization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- Capt. Reiter of the navy, who is supervising work on the new battleship Wisconsin, at San Francisco, has recommended that the plan of putting the ship in commission on the 1st prox. be reconsidered. When that plan was arranged, the fact was overloooked that Feb. 1 falls on Friday.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9. The body of Bishop Winand Michael Wigger now lies in state in St. Patrick's Cathedral, this city.

STONE RIDGE, N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Mrs. Adrienne L. Terwilliger, whose elopement last April with Silas Wells, a well-to-do resident of this place, caused much comment in the neighborhood, has returned. She left a husband and four little children to flee with the man she thought she loved. She returns to find herself divorced, her husband dead, and her children in the custody of a stranger who has been appointed their guardian.

ALBANY. N.Y., Jan. 9. -- Inspector Robert W. Hill, who was detailed by the State Board of Charities to Investigate conditions at Bellevue Hospital, New York City, has reported. In his report Inspector Hill reviews nil the facts well known in the case of Louis Milliard and the action of Commissioner Keller thereon.

The damage caused by the big fire which occurred early yesterday morning at Erie Basin. Brooklyn, is estimated at about $500,000. The large dock of the Beard estate was destroyed, the British tramp steamship St. Dunstan gutted, the steamboat Idlewild of the Starin Line almost entirely destroyed, the steamship Coya, owned by William R. Grace Co., damaged, and hundreds of bales of jute burned up.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- There was a short but interesting list of Cabinet receptions this afternoon, Mrs. Gage, Mrs. Root, Mrs. Griggs, and Mrs. Charles Emory Smith being at home to visitors.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 1/2@65 1/2c. There were no sales.

MARSEILLES, Jan. 9. -- Dispatches from the village of Faraman, near which the French mail steamer Russie, from Oran. Algeria, stranded on Monday in a violent storm, say that all efforts to reach the steamer have failed.

The establishment of a National Textile Chamber of Commerce was one of the subjects discussed yesterday at the thirty-sixth annual meeting of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers at the Hotel Savoy. The idea is that the trade shall have a body which may decide, without reference to the courts, disputes which may arise between manufacturers and dealers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9. -- A mass meeting of citizens, of which Bishop Potter of New York was the central figure, was held in the Academy of Music to-night for the purpose of taking preliminary steps in starting a general crusade against vice in this city. The big building was crowded, most of those present being women.

We cannot think of anything, in the sane line, more pleasing and reassuring to believers in the democratic system of government in these United States than the announcement, made by The Associated Press, that the renomination of Senator HOAR to the seat which he has so long filled is likely to be unanimous.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., Jan. 9. -- A passenger train pf the Central Railroad of New Jersey on the New York and Long Branch Road was run Into by a Insight locomotive of the Lehigh Valley Road as the train was crossing the Lehigh Valley tracks north of Perth Amboy Station about 8 o'clock this morning.

The portico and inclosed balcony of the Pabst Hotel, in West Forty-second Street, which squat on the public sidewalk and occupy an area valued by experts at more than $38,000, will be removed if James B. Regan, the proprietor, obeys a final and peremptory order served on him by James P. Keating, Commissioner of Highways, or if Mr. Keating acts as he threatens in case of non-compliance by Regan.

The song with an acrobatic accompaniment, obligate, as one might say, is one of the oldest of all the "turns" of the variety theatres. One comedian sings the song, another tumbles about in time with the music. If the performers are a mixed team, the woman will sing while the man jumps and turns somersaults.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 9. -- Upon the reconvening of the United States Supreme Court to-day, F.R. Coudert. Jr., resumed his argument in the Porto Rican cases, continuing his contention that Porto Rico is not foreign territory, and hence that it is incompetent fur the Government authorities to levy and collect duties upon articles imported from Porto Rico to New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 9. The question of the hour here is whether or not there will be found room in Gov. Odell's plan of economy for Louis F. Payn of Chatham, formerly Superintendent of Insurance and George W. Aldridge of Rochesier, formerly Superintendent of Public Works. Both of these gentlemen are seeking vindication at the hands of the present State administration.

A comedy of complications, in which court, theatre, lawyers, and policemen figured was brought about yesterday and last night as the result of a judgment for unpaid salary secured by Jennie Joyce, the divorced wife of Phil Daly. Jr., against Alexander Hashim of Hashim Brothers, theatrical managers.

George B. Herztg, who for several months has been trading with the Imcha and Amana Indians of the Andes, who spend the best part of their lives in trapping the chinchilla, a little rodent whose pearly gray fur forms one of the most expensive as well as desirable skins, returned to New York on the steamship Niagara yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 9. -- The Wisconsin prints an interview with a "railway authority." in which it is stated that legal obstacles are in the way of the Great Northern-Northern Pacific-Chicago. Milwaukee and St. Paul deal. The Wisconsin's informant says there are laws in Minnesota and the Dakotas which forbid combinations, lease, or other traffic arrangements between and among parallel, Competing lines, which the named railways are.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- There are daily manifestations of concern by Senator Hanna, the only conspicuous worker for the enactment of the Shipping Subsidy bill, and the character of the announcements made with the approval of the promoters of the measure is calculated to increase rather than diminish fear for its passage.

BOSTON, Jan. 9. -- Boston's particular specialties were dull to-day. Interest centred in National Tube, Federal Steel, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Union Pacific, and the ever-prominent Sugar. Some 3,000 shares of Tube, 4,000 of Union Pacific, and 2,000 of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy sold in the morning.

Business in the outside market yesterday continued on a small scale and little of interest was developed by the day's transaction. Prices were again irregular and the declines were even more numerous than on the previous day, though in but few cases did the losses assume large size. Some few advances resulted from the day's trading, but the market was weak.

The will of John Charles Gibney of New York, Pennsylvania, and the Republic of Colombia, South America, which was filed in the Surrogates' office yesterday, disposes of property worth several milllion dollars, yet the petition and affidavit accompanying the will say that the testator was worth only $100.

LONDON, Jan. 9. After he had been assailed with cries of "Turn him out!" hoolings, and other hostile interruptions, the Marquis of Dufferin and Ava. Chairman of the suspended London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited, at the extraordinary general meeting of the company called for to-day, succeeded in appeasing the wrath of the shareholders toward himself.

District Attorney Philbin yesterday requested the resignations of Deputy Assistant District Attorneys Cornelius J. Collins and Patrick H. Loftus. The appointment of Jerome Monks, son of former Dock Commissioner Monks, to be a Deputy Assistant, was also announced. Mr. Monks is a member of the law firm of Russell. Tucker Monks of 45 Broadway, and is about twenty-six years old.

What Capt. Titus of the Detective Bureau calls a "triumph of continuity in detective work" was achieved yesterday by Detective Sergeants Murphy, Stripp, and Gain when they arrested James Delasell and Charles H. Gardner on a charge of swindling. Delasell, who is also charged with forgery and perjury, is fifty-seven years old, and says he is a broker, though the police say he is a hatter.

Cornelius Alvord, Jr., former note teller of the First National Bank, pleaded guilty yesterday to three counts in the indictment charging him with having stolen $620,000 from the bank during the past three years. He Will be sentenced next Tuesday, and is at present locked up in the Ludlow Street Jail.

Robert Bryan, alias "Sailor Bob," alias "Jack" Harris, wanted in Philadelphia for complicity in the murder there on Friday night last of the Rev. Father Riegle, a priest of the Roman Catholic Church, was arrested in this city last night by Detective Sergeants Reap and Holland of the Central Office.
Is Mr. NIXON'S Committee of Five plunging into a blind alley to bring up against a dead wall? It looks as though that were to be its melaneholy and some-what ludicrous fale.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue jaw provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 5O cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

MANILA, Jan. 9. -- The act for the organization of the Metropolitan Police of Munila has boon passed by the Philippine Commission. The force will consist of three companies selected from the volunteer soldiery.

WILLIAM B. RUDD, formerly Quartermaster General on the staff of Gov. Bulkeley, died at his home in Lakeville, Conn., yesterday, aged sixty-two years. He was a son-in-law of ex-Gov. Holley and was President and Treasurer of the Holley Manufacturing Company of Lakeville.

To-day's social programme is again full of incident. Mrs. William R. Sands will give a large luncheon for women in honor of her niece, Miss Lillian S. Tyler, at the Metropolitan club Annex. The wedding of Mr. D'Oench and Mrs. Alice Grace Holloway, daughter of ex-Mayor Grace, will Cake place this afternoon at the ex-Mayor's residence, 31 East Seventy-ninth Street.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 9. - A newspaper of this city publishes a letter from Slan-Foo announcing that the Emperor has fully decided to return tn Peking to administer the reformed Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9. -- Heavy soiling by Virginia and, Ophir. When several thousand shares of each were thrown on the market by a well-known broker, there was a rush to realize smong small speculators that carried these stocks and the whole market rapidly downward. The lump probably is due to some unfavorable development which has not yet been reported.

The wilding of Edward Walker Scott. Jr., of Virginia, and Miss Adeline Chandler Pierson, younger daughter of Gen. J. Frederic Pierson and Mrs. Pierson, was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride's parents. 20 West Fifty-second Street. The bride, whose gown was of white satin, made severely plain, wore a veil of tulle edged with point lace, and carried a bouquet of white lilacs.

-- Controller COLER continues every once in a while to charge the New York public and press with the display of cruel inappreciation in the case of the late Street Cleaning Commissioner JAMES McCARTNEY. The Controller's charge was last made in a speech delivered in a Brooklyn church, and it took this form: "People said that the streets of New York were not as clean as before, though they were cleaned by the same men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The House today considered the River and Harbor Appropriation bill Little progress was made. In a bill carrying such a vast sum for local improvements many are bound to be disappointed, and there is considerable soreness among the members who fail to get what they want.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9. -- The Island of Guam is to be the American St. Helena. The action of Gen. MacArthur, recently reported from Manila, in exiling twenty-six Filipino Generals and civilians to Guam is simply the first step. If it should prove a success, other leading Filipinos will be banished also.

New and sensational developments occurred yesterday In the investigation of the Bellevue scandals. Friction was reported between the Medical Board and Commissioner Keller. Eight more of the Mills Training School nurses have resigned and twelve are to follow very soon.

Mr. BRYAN is the most contented man in the United States. There is no end to the joy that fills his soul as he looks out upon the world that has treated him so well, and, in the words of Faust when his dearest wishes had been realized, exclaims, "Just stay with me, thou art so fair."

Pleasant personalities and reminiscences characterized the Albany Society's seventh annual reunion, for which about 200 members and Bursts assembled at Delmonico's last evening. The speeches which followed the dinner wore largely personal, and the witticisms and humorous allusions to members evoked frequent and hearty laughter.
ALBANY, Jan. 9. -- Senator Elsberg gave an explanation of his tax bill introduced to-night. The provisions of the bill are as follows:

There was one feature in the speech from the throne delivered before the Prussian Diet last Tuesday which foreshadows a repetition of those interesting stenes which characterized the session of that particular Legislature a year ago last Autumn -- the announcement of a new Canal bill.

ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 9. -- The annual stockholders' meeting of the Second National Bank was held yesterday afternoon, and Capt. Ambrose M. Matthews and Horton D. Williams were dropped from the Board of Directors. In their places were chosen former Mayor George H. Hartford and John Oxenbridge Heald.

About 300 Columbia students assembled yesterday afternoon in Havemeyer Hall for the purpose of organizing a new rowing club and of taking stops which will assure a prosperous future for the sport at the university. By far the must important proposition of the meeting was made by Francls S. Bangs. '7s. who proposed a plan from the aalumnt by which crew expenses are guaranteed and a new beathouse on the Harlem River is promised.
The Golden Rod five won two games from the team of Our Council, Royal Areanum, in the National League tournament, on Starr's Alleys last night. The scores:

The records of the Board of Health contained two additional smallpox cases yesterday. They were Patrick Joyce, fifty years old, of the Melrose Lodging House. One Hundred and Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, and William King, fifty yearn old, a letter carrier, of 206 West Sixty-second Street.

Americans sometimes have their difficulties, even upon festive and effnsive occasions, in accepting the casual Briton who may be presented to them as a "representative of our common race." But no enlightened American has ever had any difficulties of that kind with respect to Lord DUFFERIN.
BALTIMORE, Jan. 10 -- A man who gives his name as Morris Chaules was to-night placed under arrest in this city on a charge of having secured goods through false representation.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The combined opposition to the barge canal scheme, through Assembly man S.W Smith of Columbia County, to-day introduced a bill to compel the listening of personal property. Mr. Smith claims that the barge canal proposed would only benefit big shippers, without aiding in reducing the price of commodities.

Oliver Adams, allas "Harry" Adams, who, the police say, is an old-time offender, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday morning by Detective Sergt. McCafferty of the Central Office, charged with impersonating an officer. He was arrested on Wednesday night by Detective Sergts. McCafferty and Sam Price, who had been looking for him for several days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The House Committee on Naval Affairs to-day practically completed the Naval Appropriation bill, but it will not be in shape to be made public until to-morrow or Saturday. The question of the increase of the navy, which usually entails the largest contest, was easily settled this year by the acceptance of the recommendation of the Secretary of the Navy for two battleships and two cruisers.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 10 -- Harbourview was a busy place to-day. From early morning until late this evening workmen were arranging the decorations and fitting up the electric lights. Every thing is to be completed early Sunday evening.

An alleged conspiracy to swindle the Colonial Life Insurance Company of America, which has Its principal office at 43 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, was made public yesterday. The Hudson County Grand Jury on Wednesday afternoon indicted Thomas J. Kelly, thirty-two years old, recently of 37 West Twelfth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Solicitor General Richards resumed his argument in the Porio Rican cases when the Supreme Court convened to-day. Before taking up the line of his argument he make reply to a question by Justice While as to the meaning of the words "the territories," as used by Chief Justice Marshall in the Loughborough case.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Michael O'Malley was killed in a trolley accident in Hastings early this morning by his carriage being run into by a trolley car. Thomas Kane, the motorman of the car, was severely injured. The accident happened a little after midnight. The scene is a lonely one, just across the Yonkers city line.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 -- To-morrow the Missouri Board of Health will meetin special session at Jefferson City for the purpose of outlining a plan to curb the epidemics of smallpox, grip, and diphtheria now rampant in Missouri.

The event of to-night will be Mrs. Ogden Mills's annual dance. This is always one of the features of the Winter season, and, unless Mrs. Mills is absent or in mourning, is as fixed an event upon the calendar as is the ball given by Mrs. Astor. Mrs. Ogden Mills will, as usual, receive alone.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Rumors are again extant of a deal whereby the International Navigation Company will absorb the Atlantic Transport Line. At the general office of the International Navigation Company here Rodman Griscom. The manager of the line, peremptorily refused to either deny or affirm the report that his company had purchased the Atlantic Transport Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- John B. Garrett announced to-day that he will retire on Tuesday next from the Vice Presidency of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company. This decision was communicated to President Walter in November last, and he has remained in office since that time at Mr. Walter's request.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Secretary of the Treasury Gage, Horace White of New York, and several other prominent financiers to-day appeared before the House Committee on Coinage, Weights, and Measures, at the request of the committee, and gave their views on the Overstreet, Levy, and Hill bills to maintain the parity of money of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Considerable progress was made to-day by the Senate with the Army Reorganization bill, but the final vote upon the measure seems to be as far off as ever. To-day's proceedings were characterized by several sharp colloquies, some of which were of a decidedly personal character.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Republican Senators who take the business of the Senate seriously and who are in favor of the Ship Subsidy bill, as well as those Senators of the Republican Party who are not for the bill, treat the report that Senator Hanna (Rep., Ohio,) has threatened to have an extra session of the Senate if this session fails or refuses to pass the shipping bill as unworthy of contradiction.

We suppose that Mr. NIXON is convinced by this time that his voluntary excursion into politics in connection with the work of his committee is unprofitable and embarrassing. It is always hard to establish a negative, especially when all the logical inferences from known facts are against you.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The negotiations toward the formation of another American iron and steel combination, which have been carried on recently in London, reached a point this evening where their culmination became practically assured.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- It is with evident reluctance and concern that the United States has abandoned its effort to induce the powers represented at Peking to select some country other than China in which to continue the negotiations for the settlement of the Questions at issue between the powers and the Chinese Empire.

The premium list for the twenty-fifth annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, to be held in Madison Square Garden, beginning Tuesday, Feb. 19, and continuing through Friday, Feb. 22 was announced yesterday. The number of classes opened is largely in excess of the number at any former dog show in America, and the divisions in each class are also numerous, with equally generous provisions.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 10 -- The Jeffries-Ruhlin fight on Feb. 15 has not been declared off by the Saengeriest Athletic Association of Cincinnati, notwithstanding reports to-day to the contrary, but more formidable opposition than ever heretofore developed to-day against having the fight pulled off in Cincinnati.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Boston specialties were dull this morning and mining stocks were neglected, with the prevailing tone heavy. National Tube shares led in attractiveness to traders, 5,700 shares of the common and 1,400 shares preferred selling. Chicago Burlington and Qulncy, Union Pacific, and Sugar continued active.

Fire broke out in the slables of the Ninth Avenue horse car line, corner of Fifty-fourth Street and Ninth Avenue, shortly after 8 o'clock last night, and before the flames were under control the interior of the building was badly damaged. When the fire was discovered the entire force of stablemen, assisted by outsiders and policemen, ran into the stables and cut loose the 414 horses that were in the stalls.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Admiral Schley's flagship, the Chicago, has sailed out from Monte-video for target practice.

The extraordinary purchases of art objects made by Count Boni de Castellane and his wife and the huge indebtedness incurred on the strength of the Gould millions to the London bric-a-brac dealer, Ashep Wertheimer, were brought up in the Supreme Court again yesterday before Justice Beach on an argument to continue the temporary injunction restraining the Gould estate from paying any portion of her income from the property to the Countess Anna de Castellane.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Lehigh and Reading issues continued to-day to control the market, and the tone was decidedly improved. Denials that the former road is to come under the control of the latter found credence, and there was an attitude of expectancy for new developments. The belief seemed to be gaining ground that, the New York Central was after the property.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mark Twain's speech at the City Club dinner should bring to him the homage of his confreres if only for its outspokenness. For myself, regarding the so-called war in Manila as an effort to lynch the humble Washingtons and Hancocks of that region, I hall Mark Twain's utterance as a sursum corda to the intellectual leaders and public teachers of America.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- In connection with the resignation of Deputy Attorney General John Henry Hammond, Attorney General Davies to-day made a statement which has occasioned some surprise. M.r Hammond was appointed to look after the preparation and prosecution of election law violations in New York City.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- "Five thousand Boers, supposed to be trekking west from Vryburg," says the Cape Town correspondent of The Dally Mail, "are now making their way into the heart of Cape Colony. The supposition is that they have captured several small garrisons on the way."

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Bowling for two-men championship began to-day in the annual tournament of the American Bowling Congress, all of the five-men teams, with two exceptions, having completed their games. Two-men teams monopolized the alleys all day.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve increased u1,673,000; circulation decreased u726,000; bullion increased u470,438; other securities decreased u3,544,000; other deposits decreased u315,000; public deposits decreased u1,827,000; notes reserve increased u1,638,000; Government securities decreased u4,000.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 1/2@65c. There were no sales.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 10 -- The darkness of the day and the gloom outside made the obsequles over the body of the Right Rev. Winand M. Wigger, late Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark, in St. Patrick's Cathedral this morning even more impressive and imposing than they would have been had the day been clear and bright.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Senator Joseph Wagner's bill relating to the payment of taxes on personal property by persons removed from the State has caused a sensation among legislators of both houses who have been tinkering with taxation problems for several sessions past. The bill is very short as to text, merely inserting nine words to the present general tax law arid omitting nine words.
BRIDGETON, N.j Jan. 10 -- The three children of Joseph Lloyd caused the city's search last night and to-day.It was thought they had been drowned in the pond in Temmbling Dain but they were no

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 10 -- The bending of the frames for the new cup defender at Bristol has been rushed along so well since Monday that quite two-thirds of the entire job of bending is completed. Although the larger part of the frames have passed through the hands of the benders, the work of truelng is only well begun.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 10 -- The Nassau County Clerk's office is very shorthanded, the attaches of the office being afflicted with the grip. First Deputy County Clerk Harry Starr was stricken, but returned to his desk after a few days' confinement to his home. Deputy Starr had hardly returned to duty before County Clerk Patterson was forced to retire.

MELVILLE W. FULLER, JOSEPH H. CHOATE, and JAMES C. CARTER are the highly respectable names of the American members of the General Committee appointed for the purpose of devising and executing an appropriate memorial to the late Lord Chief Justice of England, Lord RUSSELL of Killowen.

Hotel proprietors of the city, known collectively as the Hotel Men's Association of New York. following their yearly custom, gathered together as their guests last night at Delmonico's 300 of the city's distinguished men, to partake of the twenty-second annual banquet of the association. The dinner was no dreary function of stilled formality.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- It was stated in authoritative quarters to-day that the Chinese pienipotentiaries signed the joint note yesterday, thus concluding the preliminary stage of the negotiations. It was added that this important step was insignificant, compared with the difficulties to be met with between the powers themselves, whose clashing interests will have full play in the coming discussions.

Representatives of twelve automobile clubs net yesterday afternoon in the office of President A. R. Shattuck of the Automnobile Club of America, at 11 Broadway, to discuss means for placing substantial sign posts upon the leading highways. President Shattuck represented the Automobile Club of America, and the other clubs with delegates in the conference were the Automobile Clubs of Baltimore, North Jersey, Philadelphia, Long Island, Westchester, Rhode Island, Bridgeport, Massachusetts, Brooklyn, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey.

There is more than a hint of the influence of Maeterlinck in the queer and gloomy little play called "The Marriage of Guineth." by Florence Wilkinsou, which was performed with abundant zeal by Mr. Sargent's pupils in the Empire Theatre yesterday afternoon. The scene is a castle in a town of Brittany, and the time the fiftenth century.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- The State Forest Preserve Board and the State Board of Health to-day approved the site recommended by the Trustees of the State Hospital for the Treatment of Incipient Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

WEST POINT, Jan. 10 -- The Congressional committee investigating hazing at the Military Academy devoted a large part , of the day to an examination of Cadet William R. Bettison of Kentucky, who said he has been President of the first class for two years. The inquiries to-day were devoted principally to bringing out the style of fighting practiced by the cadets.

The market for outside securities yesterday was dull and weak. Some few advances were recorded, but in most parts of the list the day's closing quotations showed recessions in price, which, in some instances, were substantial. In no part of the market was there any change from the more or less lifeless conditions which have prevailed for so many days past.
