After six months' negotiations the Pratt Whitney Company of Hartford, Conn., yesterday passed into the hands of the Niles-Bement-Pond Company of New York, which has plants in Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey. The Pratt Whitney Company will continue as a distinct and separate organization.

Ex-Register Hugh McLaughlin, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, is opposed to the idea of making the offices of Sheriff, County Clerk, and Register of Kings County salaried positions. Yesterday afternoon Mr. McLaughlin, in discussing the matter, attacked the bills now in the Legislature, which aim to do away with the fee system in Kings County.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- When Secretary Root was informed of the decision in the Neely case, he said:

Further weakness appeared in the outside market yesterday, and the only issues that showed much activity were several that declined rather sharply. At the close of the day, however, some recoveries occurred which marked quotations up a little, so that the day ended at somewhat better prices than the worst.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 14. -- Although the amateurs have been playing over the new eighteen-hole course for ton days, trying its merits, there was no real match until to-day, when A.H. Fenn, the professional, played the best ball of Charles B. Corry and George Dutton, both members or the Oakley Club.

Professionalism was the dominating feature in the stock market yesterday. All day long stocks were under pressure by the room traders, who were aggressive sellers around the room, using as arguments for their bear campaign the probability of gold exports and the lower prices sent over by London, these prices being proclaimed to indicate apprehension in London as to the general market future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14. -- Just at the close of a day of dreary discussion of technical details of the Army Reorganization bill, Mr. Teller, (Silver Rep., Col.,) speaking to an amendment he had offered, delivered a sensational denunciation of Gen. Eagan, ex-Commissary General of the United States Army.

ALBANY, Jan. 14. -- Assemblyman J.P. Allds, at the head of the Ways and Means Committee, broke the record to-night by putting in the Appropriation bill for the year commencing Oct. 1. 1901. It carries a total fixed appropriation for the year of $15,402,678, which will enter into this year's tax rate as against the sum of $16,014,469.97 last year, or a reduction of $521,791.
Members of the Cotton Exchange to vote on Thursday upon an amendment which makes the initiation fee for membership in the Exchange $10,000 and limits the number of memberships to 450.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 14. -- President Kinnane and Matchmaker Sullivan of the Phoenix Athletic Club of this city announced to-day that negotiations are on with William A. Brady and William Madden with a view to securing the Jeffries-Ruhlin fight in the event of the contest being declared off at Cincinnati.

BOSTON, Jan. 14. -- Mr. and Mrs. Alfred G. Vanderbilt arrived in Boston on a special train this afternoon. Their coming was a great surprise, as it had been stated that they would spend their honeymoon on the much-advertised "Farm" near Newport. Just after 4 o'clock -- 4:11, to be precise -- the special arrived at Back Bay station, and from the middle car of the train the couple alighted.

EAST HARRISON, N.J., Jan. 14. -- The trap shooting competitions of the Hudson Rod and Gun Club of Jersey City, decided here to-day on the club's grounds, produced some close contests at the traps. Dr. Louis H. O'Connell, Albert A. Schoverling, Henry Bock, and Charles F. Dudley made the best scores in a series of well-contested events.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14. -- The University of Chicago baseball schedule which has just been announced includes about twenty-five games, as against thirty-six last year. About half of the games this year will be played on Marshall Field. Two of the Michigan games will be played at Ann Arbor and two of the Northwestern games at Evanston.

NEWPORT, Jan. 14. -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, the second son of Mrs. Cornellus Vanderbilt, was married to-day at noon to Miss Ellen French, the second daughter of Mrs. Francis Ormonde French. The ceremony took place at the Zabrlskle Memorial Church of St. John the Evangelist, in the presence of a large gathering of relatives and friends who had come from New York and Boston to be present at the event.

Work on the Columbia 'Varsity boat crew was begun yesterday afternoon by Head Coach Ed Hanlan and Capt. F.B. Irvine. Six of lost year's 'Varsity eight reported, together with many new candidates, making a total of about fifty men. The number of candidates is always small at the beginning of the season.

The franchise tax law will continue to be an unjust and inequitable measure until the special franchise corporations join with the Legislature in the attempt to devise a rational and fair method of assessment in place of the present secret guesswork system followed by the State Board of Tax Commissioners.

It is announced that a movement of considerable extent is on foot to press in the next session of Congress the Constitutional amendment making the term of the President six years and forbidding a re-election. The movement is said to have some strength in the West and still more in the South.

NEWPORT, Jan. 14. -- Nothing could be more satisfactory than the way in which everything in connection with the Vanderbilt-French nuptials passed off to-day. Even the slipper which the guests threw after the newly married couple lodged oil top of the carriage quite out of reach of the coachman, and was carried triumphantly down the road.

-- Nothing could more clearly reveal the intellectual status of the people who oppose vaccination than a letter which we have just received from a resident of Morris Heights, this city, who is offended because we called attention to the fact that, of all the inmates of a lodging house in which a case of smallpox appeared, only two men who refused to be vaccinated contracted the disease.

To the Editor of The New York Times: An acquaintance takes pride in the fact that he has retained the programmes of theatre, opera, concert, , performances that he has attended during many past years. A collection of programmes or this sort, and where one has attended the performances represented, especially if the period covered is fifteen or twenty years, cannot but be of rare value and interest to the possessor.

A decision handed down by the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court yesterday will serve to limit the powers of City Marshals. It appears from the decision that up to now the Marshals have been accustomed to serve legal papers in any borough of the city, and that they were exercising more authority in that respect than the Sheriff of the county.

Edward Farry, a brick manufacturer of Matawan, N.J., yesterday applied to Vice Chancellor Pitney at Jersey City for an order requiring the Farmers and Merchants' of Middletown Point to produce its books and make an accounting. Farry, through Peter Bentley, his counsel, alleged that he opened an account with the bank in December, 1892.

Lovers of good music will find much cause for regret in the following letter, for it means that there will be no more Kaltenborn concerts, at least under the management which for the last two years has made them such an attractive feature of Summer life in New York:
LONDON, Jan. 14. -- At the adjourned meeting to-day of the stockholders of the London and Globe Finance Corporation, Limited, it was resolved to voluntarily wind up the concern.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 14. -- There is every indication to-night that the bitter struggle for the United States Senatorship will terminate to-morrow with the election of Col. M.S. Quay, the nominee of the joint Republican caucus. The Democrats will vote for Col. James M. Guffey of Pittsburg, and the anti-Quay Republicans are expected to distribute their votes among several "favorite sons."

The residence of Burton N. Harrison, a lawyer, with offices at 120 Broadway, was robbed yesterday afternoon of a considerable quantity of jewelry and other things which the members of the family, on the advice of the police, refuse to enumerate.

A death from smallpox occurred in Brooklyn last evening. The victim was Benjamin Trauaofski, a Russian Jew, fifty-four years old, who lived at 31 Boerum Street with his wife and two children. All that the officials of the Health Department could discover of the case was that Dr. James Huber of 113 East Broadway, Manhattan, was called to attend the man yesterday, and on his arrival found him dead.

Frank A. Keeney of the Oxford Club, Brooklyn, scored the first victory in the billiard tournament for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, begun last night in the Hanover Club, Brooklyn. He defeated Arthur Townsend of the Hanover Club by 300 points to 252, in fifty-six innings, the game being at 14-inch balkline.

McVickar Co. have bought for a client the stable property 1.340 and 1.342 Broadway, 43.1 by 100, together with the dwelling 171 West Forty-fifth Street, 20 by 73.3, the two parcels forming an "L" surrounding the northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-fifth Street. The property is sold by Helen McGraw Smith, who was represented in the deal by Brokers J. Romaine Brown Co.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 15. -- Gov. Stanley is indignant over the lynching at Leavenworth. He says it will result in the establishment of the death penalty in Kansas, as it should do.

In the face of favorable dividend action on the part of the Directors of three companies in the so-called steel group -- American Tin Plate. Federal Steel, and National Tube -- Wall Street was yesterday treated to the sight of decided weakness in the entire steel group, with especial heaviness in two of the issues in which the most favorable developments were announced.
KROONSTAD, Orange River Colony, Jan. 14. -- The success of the Burgher Peace Committee in distributing among the republicans Paul Botha's book. "From Boer to Boer," has infurnited Gen. De Wet.

ALBANY. Jan. 15 -- The Pabst Hotel is in Senator Elsberg's district. Senator Elsberg brought in a bill legalizing the portico over which there has been such a protracted fight in Albany, but for some reason he did not care to introduce it himself. He prevailed upon Senator Grady to introduce it.

The arrest of Peter Rensing, nineteen years old, of 2,472 Eighth Avenue, charged with perjury by agents of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, is the latest development in the court history of the tragic death of Capt. George B. Rhoads of the Seventh Regiment, who was killed by an Eighth Avenue trolley car in June, 1899.

Ferdinand Poggenburg played the best game of billiards Last night at the hanover Club. Brooklyn that has been seen this season in amateur circles. He met Frank Gardner the billiard champion of the Crescent Athletic Club and defeated him easily In a fourteen inch balk-line game by 300 points to 141.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 15. -- After several weeks of seeming lethargy the Finance Committee of the Senate appears to have gone to work upon the War Revenue Tax bill as if it intended to report it. A member of the committee said to-night that at the session to-day a disposition was shown to complete a bill, but that no substantial progress was made in the direction of deciding what changes should be made in schedules.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 15. -- Fred Alexander, the negro who on Saturday evening attempted to assault Miss Eva Roth, and who, it is supposed, assaulted and killed Pearl Forbes in this city in November last, was taken from the Sheriff's guard by a mob to-day and burned at the stake at the scene of the Forbes murder, half a dozen blocks from the centre of the city.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator Elsberg introduced a bill to-day that provides for the reduction of the fee for incorporation in the State from one-eighth of 1 per cent. to one-fiftieth of 1 per cent., to carry out the strenuous recommendations of Deputy Controller Theodore Gilman, made to the Legislature.
MANILA, Jan. 15. -- Thirty insurgents who have been sentenced to be deported to the Island of Guam, were taken on board the United States transport Roseerans to-day. She will sail to-morrow.
LONDON. Jan. 15. -- Money was in fair demand, plentiful, and easy to-day. Discounts were steady. Much caution was manifested, owing to the uncertainty of the outlook.

The swearing off of personal taxes began yesterday in the Department of Taxes, in the Stewart Building. As early as 8 o'clock there was a line of fifty persons. At 10 o'clock the tax officials had more than they could do. One door was used for those assessed for less than $10,000 and one for persons assessed over $10,000 and for corporations.

Prices were under some pressure in the outside market yesterday, and a number of declines showed in closing quotations. A few issues showed considerable strength, and succeeded in making net gains notwithstanding the general tendency of the market, but all told the day was unfavorable, both in the matter of prices and in that of transactions.

Local society has resumed its normal attitude now that the Vanderbilt-French wedding is over, although, with the exception of a lull in the entertaining, there was no perceptible difference in the ranks of fashion. Yesterday, however, was a day of receptions and an evening of dinners. The dance given by Col. and Mrs. John Jacob Astor was, of course, the most prominent of all the entertainments.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 15. -- The result of last night's Union Republican caucus, when sixteen members of the Legislature nominated J. Edward Addicks for United States Senator, lent interest to the initial vote for the two Senatorships, taken separately by the two houses of the General Assembly today.
The estate of Henry Bradley Plant, which is valued at $17,000,000 is the prize in a legal battle which is being fought before Justice Levemritt in the Special Term, Part III., of the Supreme Court.

PATERSON. N. J., Jan. 15 -- The Boss chieter murder case was replete with startling incidents to-day, and the three men -- Walter C. McAllster, Andrew J. Campbell, and William A. Death -- who are accused, with George J. Kerr, of having caused the death of the mill girl, underwent a terrible ordeal.
RALEIGH. N. C., Jan. 15. -- Charles B. Aycock was inaugurated to-day as Governor of North Carolina. In the course of his inaugural address he said:
LONDON, Jan. 16. -- The Government has decided to send large reinforcements to Lord Kitchener, and the War Office in carrying out this decision has determined to enlist 3,000 yeomanry volunteers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with pleasure and amuscment the letter in your to-day's issue from my anonymous critic, " Russ," in reply to my communication condemning Lord Kitchener's reconcentrado order and policy in South Africa. " Russ " hurls at me the awful charge that I am an Irishman.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator Samuel Slater introduced a bill to-day which he says is aimed at the notorious "boardwalk" dancing resorts existing at Coney Island. The Senator believes that the way to compel these resorts to quit business is to charge them a license which shall be too expensive for them to pay, As a whole, his measure is permissive, giving the resorts a legal status that they do not now enjoy.

DENVER. Jan. 15. -- Thomas M. Patterson was to-day elected United States Senator in succeed Edward O. Wolcott. Mr. Patterson was the nominee of the Democrats, Populists and Silver Republicans, receiving seventy-four votes out of a total of eighty-seven cast at the joint caucus last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A dispatch was received at the State Department to-day from Minister Loomis, announcing that the Venezuelan Government had seized two vessels belonging to the Orlnoco Shipping and Trading Company, and purposed vising them against the " revolutionists." What he means by the " revolutionists " is not explained.

GENEVA, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- At the semiannual meeting or the Board of Trustees of Hobart College held here to-day the petition of the students for a new athletic field was grunted. The present field has been destroyed by the erection of new buildings. Work on the new field will be begun at once

ALBANY. Jan. 15 -- The New York City single-Headed Police Commission bill was taken up by the Assembly Committee on the Affairs of Cities to-day a reported out favorably without amendment by a vote of 7 to 3. The vote on the bill was on strict party lines. All the Republicans on the committee voted to report it with the exception of Messrs.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 15. -- President H.F. Whitcomb of the Wisconsin Central Railway Company denied to-day that there is any truth in the story that another ocean-to-ocean railway scheme is being worked, so far as his line is concerned. Mr. Whitcomb said he knew nothing whatever of the scheme.

After creating a disturbance in a saloon at 129 Rowery at midnight Monday night. Jhon Stafford, twenty-six years old, a private in the United States Marine Corps, attached to the Brooklyn Navy Yard, was killed by a blow on the chin struck by John Henry, the bartender of the place, who was attempting to eject him.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 15. -- The two houses of the Legislature held short sessions to-day, and then adjourned until next Monday evening.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Senator Hanna denied with contemptuous emphasis the report that reached him to-night that it had been announced that he would withdraw the Shipping Subsidy bill in a few days in consequence of the manifest impossibility of getting it through the Senate during this session.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 15. -- Some progress was made by the Senate to-day in the consideration of the Army Reorganization bill. One amendment that has created much debate was disposed of and an intimation made that a vote would be reached " very soon." To-day's debate opened with statements by Mr. Pettus. (Dem.. Ala..) Mr. Bate. (Dem.. Tenn..) and Mr. Cockrell. (Hem . MO..) members of the Committee on Military Affairs, in opposition to the measure.

In the following list " mtg " stands for mortgage and " R. S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps snail be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $5OO of consideration. This " consideration " has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except, in the rate cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Attention was called to the fact to-day that the bills providing for a new Prison Commission and a State Board of Charities permit the Governor to designate as two members of each board "members of the Land Board or Constitutional State officers." The question at once arose as to what State officers will be eligible for designation under that provision.

BALTIMORE. Jan. 15 -- Plans of New York and Philadelphia parties supposed to be identified with the Reading Railroad interests for the securing of the Western Maryland Railroad for a new route to tidewater from the anthracite coal fields are maturing. The Mayor and Finance Commissioners have received a direct offer from Edwad Lauterbach acting in cojunction with the Manhattan Trust Company, to buy the road.

It would have been a great pity if the Supreme Court had found that the law of the United States effectually sheltered one of the employes of the United States who had been charged with swindling in Cuba, and had taken refuge in this country. Whatever the technical ground on which such a decision might have been reached, the actual result of it would have been most mortifying.

For the first time in several seasons Mrs. John Jacob Astor gave last evening at her residence, 840 Fifth Avenue, a large dance. This entertainment was not as elaborate as the ball given by Mrs. Astor, the hostess's mother-in-law, last week, nor was the invitation list so catholic. It was, however, an entertainment which could hardly be called a "small dance," the fashionable name for anything where less than 500 guests are asked.

CLARKSBURG. West Va., Jan. 15 -- William Browne. night operator at Flemington a point on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, went to sleep at his post at 4 o'clock this morning, and his nap prevented a frightful wreck.

The annual meeting of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, which was held in Philadelphia yesterday, was a demonstration of the complete control now exercised by J.P. Morgan Co., not only over that railroad, but over the entire anthracite coal road combination. There were six new Directors elected and six members of the old board were re-elected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15. -- Four years ago, President McKinley was sworn into office from a platform built out in front of the Senate end of the Capitol, because the consent of the House of Representatives could not be obtained to the use of the half of the east front that is under control of the House.

Mrs. Harriet Crehan, the mother of Miss Ada Rehan, the actress, died at her home, 165 Coffey Street, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon. She had been ill for about a week. Death was due to bronchitis. Mrs. Crehan's daughters, Mrs. Oliver Byron and Mrs. Harriet Russell, were with her at the time of her death.

When the three-masted schooner Norwood, which sailed for the Orient on Nov. 15, 1899, had cleared the Hook and stretched away for the Far East, hidden away in her forepeak was discovered James Pearley Haynes, fourteen years old, a stowaway from Portland, Me. He was an orphan, but had been carefully looked after and educated by an uncle and aunt, the former of whom was the master carpenter of the Boston and Maine Railroad.

The Business Men's Republican and Sound Money Association gave a jubllee dinner last night at Delmonico's. More than 300 of the men who marched up Broadway on Nov. 3 last for McKinley and Roosevelt were the diners.

BOSTON, Jan. 15. -- The autograph genealogy of George Washington, at the auction sale of the Clark collection of prints and autographs here to-day, brought $1,750. The book went to Dodd, Mead Co. of New York, who, is is understood, purchased it for the account of George W. Vanderbilt.

ALBANY, Jan. 15. -- Senator William Willets Cocks of Old Westbury was to-day busily engaged in framing his bill for the abolition of capital punishment. He proposes that any person found guilty of murder, first degree, shall be confined in prison during the term of his natural life, and that those convicted of murder in the second degree shall be imprisoned for thirty years, with no reduction of the term of servitude for good behavior.

The wedding of William V.B. Kip, son of Dr. Isaac L. Kip and Mrs. Kip, and Miss Elisa Strong, daughter of Col. John M. Strong of Syracuse, N.Y., was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the residence of the bride's cousin, Mrs. Samuel J. Penniman, 8 East Seventy-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA. Penn., jan. 15 -- Fiftyseven candidates for the University of Pennsylvania crews reported to Coach Ward to-day in the clubhouse at Franklin Field. Of this number thirty-six signified their desire to try for the Varsity crew, find twenty-one youngsters are anxious to secure scats in the freshman boat.

HARRISBURG. Penn . Jan. 15. -- After a memorable struggle which had continued for several years. Col M. S. Quay. regular Republican nominee for United States Senator, was elected to-day by the Pennsylvania Legislature to fill the vacancy created by the expiration of his term on March 4, 1899.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 15. -- Solicltor General Richards to-day made reply to Mr. Smith's argument in the Hawaiian insular case, now on hearing before the United States Supreme Court. In this case, he said, it was obviously the intention of Congress, as soon as practicable, to treat the territory as a part of the United States for legislative purposes, so that the revenue and commercial laws which apply in the United States should operate there.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 15 -- Yale defeated Trinity to-night by a score of 26 to 6 in a basket ball game for the collegiate championship of the State.

It was learned yesterday, although Bishop Potter declined to discuss the matter, that his plan to form a large vigilance committee, as suggested by him in his recent address on " God and the City," at a noonday meeting in St. Paul's Chapel, has taken firm root and tnat such a committee has been organized and will be ready for active work very shortly.

With the present extraordinary Mayor of the City of New York admonition is vasted and remonstrance futile. But we hope it will be remembered by the people that at a time when their attention was fixed upon the official corruption and the dreadful moral conditions that have been shown to be prevalent, this Mayor grave them an annual message exclusively devoted to the bonded debt, the expenditures, and the financial condition of the municipality

MEEKER. Col., Jan. 15 -- An unlucky stumble all but placed Col. Roosevelt within the grasp of a Rocky Mountain grizzly yesterday, but the coolness of the New Yorker and the persistency of his companions' fire served to win for them another trophy. After slaying the lion Saturday morning the party proceeded to the Keystone Ranch.

PHILADELPHIA. Jan. 15. -- Lehigh Valley was again the feature in the Philadelphia market, the interest centring largely in the personnel of the new Board of Directors. The stock was irregular, fluctuating between 327/8 and 338/4, and closing around 33. Trading generally was dull and prices were off.
NUREMBERG, Jan. 15. -- Johann Faber, the pencil manufacturer, is dead.

Bear traders became more aggressive in the stock market yesterday than on any day since election, and by concerted raids in a number of specialties, notably the steel group, succeeded in causing some sharp declines and in producing an appearance of weakness in the rest of the market, though they did not succeed in forcing any liquidation.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 15. -- While the Senate was in executive session to-day an effort was made to secure confirmation of the nomination of James S. Harlan, son of Justice Harlan of the United States Supreme Court, to be Attorney General for Porto Rico, but action was prevented by the objection of Senator Pettigrew.

--" Jersey justice," as Illustrated by the progress of the trial in Paterson of the men charged with the murder of the BOSSCHIETER girl, suggests most of all, perhaps, a comparison between the speed with which a jury was secured there and the time which would have been consumed in the same task here.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The three cadets who testified to-day before the Congressional committee which is investigating hazing at the academy were severely handled by members of the committee. Cadet Dockery, who was one of the witnesses, acknowledged in his testimony that he had exercised a number of cadets, including MacArthur.

In the annual rifle competition of the Seventh Regiment for the company team championships, which was continued on the armory ranges last night, the teams of Company K scored totals of 1,061 for the Edward Kemp trophy for teams of twenty-five men and 2,007 for the Col. Emmons Clark trophy for teams of fifty men.

Miss Gertrude May Chase, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cotton Chase, and C. Monteith Gilpln were married last evening at All Angels' Protestant Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Morris Kemp of Trinity Parish, assisted by the Rev. S. De Lancey Townsend, rector of All Angels'.

Edwin Arden Noblett, whose checkered career is well known in the financial district and in the courts of the county, was placed on trial before Recorder Goff in General Sessions yesterday, charged with obtaining $10,000 from Edward H. and Walter S. Watson of 115 Broadway under false pretenses.

The taste for small entertainments seems to prevail generally in society this Winter. Many of them are really very large affairs, but the term implying only that a few were asked prevents ill-feeling on the part of those the honor of whose company was not requested.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Nicaragua Canal matters have been brought forcibly before the public by means of an editorial in The Daily Telegraph of yesterday, and a lengthy dispatch from the American correspondent of The Times. Each takes an exactly opposite view. It is stated officially that neither can be taken to represent the Government's views, for the excellent reason that these views are not yet concentrated into a decision.

J. Prevost Mason, third teller of the Continental National Bank, 7 Nassau Street, was arraigned yesterday morning before United States Commissioner Shields charged with embezzling $12,000 belonging to the bank. Mason, who had worked his way up from an ordinary clerkship, had been employed in the bank for twenty-seven years and was one of its most trusted employes.

MANILA, Jan. 16 -- The Philippine Commission has passed acts giving, in domestic products, the Jolo Archipelago free trade with all Philippine ports, and providing for the issuance of licenses to masters and mates of seagoing vessels.

In the Plant will case yesterday Justice Leventritt, in Special Term, Part III., of the Supreme Court, overruled the motion made by the attorneys for the defendants to dismiss the suit. Justice Leventritt said that the motion to dismiss on the ground that the court had no jurisdiction involved such weighty legal questions that he was unable to answer them offhand.

Three Western lines, the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, the Colorado Midland, and the St. Louis and San Francisco, have been accused by General Passenger Agents of other Western systems of a violation of the spirit if not the letter of the anticommission agreement which was entered into about a year ago by railroads in various parts of the country, and which prohibited the paying of commissions to ticket agents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of Capt. Francis T. Bowles to be Chief Constructor and Chief of the Bureau of Construction and Repair of the Navy Department. Capt. Bowles will succeed Admiral Hichborn on March 4, the date of the letter's retirement.

BOSTON, Jan. 16 -- The report of an attachment against Josiah Quincy causes some surprise here. Although the exMayor has always been considered a poor man, comparatively speaking, it was not supposed that he was in financial straits. He and H.W. Bates of Boston are the owners of the concern known as The Financial News, which publishes hourly stock reports and operates a ticker service.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Biscuit common showed a sagging tendency to-day, opening at 39 and declining to 37 5/8, with a close at 37 3/4. Metropolitan Elevated preferred also went off from 79 3/4 to 79, closing at 79 1/2. South Side elevated declined half a point to 98 1/2. The rest of the list was practically unchanged.

About two hundred students interested in track and field athletics met yesterday in Havemeyer Hall, at Columbia University, to consider plans for the coming season. Trainer Ernest Hjertberg spoke to the men and said that he wished to turn out a team during his first year at the university which would be thoroughly representative of the institution.

"Chief Devery has no intention of retiring or of acquiescing in any action of the board to this end. He will stick to the last. If any act of the Legislature removes him from office he will leave the department without a pension. But he will be tenacious of his rights and seek legal redress for any deprivation of office which an enactment like the single-headed Police Commission bill might bring about."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Quietness ruled in the stock market to-day. The general attitude was one of waiting for something to happen in New York in regard to recent anthracite deals. The coalers were weak. Lehigh Valley opened at 32 7/8, and after advancing 1/4, sold down to 31 1/4, around which figure there was considerable buying for New York account.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Until Mr. Kruger shall have intimated in some formal way to the Administration his intention to visit the United States and to pay his respects to the President, the Administration will not feel called upon to express any opinion as to whether he will be officially received or not.
TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 16 -- Gov. Stanley decided to-night that he would not issue an offer of a reward for the arrest of the perpetrators of yesterday's negro-burning in Leavenworth.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Charles A. Gardiner of New York to-day replied to ex-President Harrison. whose recent address at Ann Arbor was devoted to his views on the status of the insular possessions of the United States. The reply was made before the State Bar Association in a paper on "The Constitution and Our New Possessions," as follows:

Boleslas Bohnzinsky, a Russian, fifty-five years old, who has for the past twelve years been known among the artists of this city as a model, was held in $5,000 bail in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, on a charge of barglary. Bohnzinsky was arrested in Central Office Detective Boyle last Thursday as he was trying to sell two large paintings in a Sixth Avenue pawnshop.

Wall Street was filled yesterday with a variety of disquieting and disturbing, though rather indefinite, rumors in relation to the steel and iron trade in general and Federal Steel in particular. It was declared with much positiveness that the continuing weakness of the steel stocks in the face of favorable dividend declarations was significant of facts now known only to insiders, but which in time would be bound to develop.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Tewksbury, the famous runner, and Baxter, the champion high jumper, are likely to be declared ineligible to represent the University of Pennsylvania this season.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The State Bar Association this afternoon held its closing session, at which the subject of divorce was thoroughly discussed. While no formal action was taken, it was evident that the association is opposed to the bill as it is now drawn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The property of the Asphalt Trust has been attacked by un armed force of Venezuelans. The trust has a private army of its own on the scene and the attacking force has ordered the Americans to lay down their arms. The Scorpion has been ordered to the scene of hostilities and there is every likelihood that other American warships will be sent there.

Mrs. Lavinia H. Chaplin, who acted as nurse to Anne Maria Winters, whose will bequeathing her $2,000,000 estate to her youthful husband. Byram L. Winters, is being contested, resumed the stand before Justice Bischoff and a jury in the Supreme Court yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- The first Trask lecture before the university students this year was given in Alexander Hall tonight by President Arthur Twining Hadlev of Yale University. President Hadley spoke on "Government by Public Opinion," and said in part: "There are three distinct means by which the social activity of large bodies of men can be regulated -- political machinery, self-interest, and public opinion.
George R. Read has sold for James H. Stebbins to Charles A. Gould the three-story building 64 Wall Street, north side, between William and Pearl Streets, 25.5 by 99.

It will no doubt be agreed by a very great majority of the officers of the United States Army that the army law which is to come oat of the successive "amendments" of the Senate and of the House will be by no means as good a measure as that which the Secretary of War originally introduced.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Judgment in the Castellane-Wertheimer suit was to-day postponed for another week.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 16 -- The Legislature, in joint convention, elected E.W. Carmack United States Senator for the term beginning March 4, 1901.

The arrest of Peter Rensing on a charge of perjury growing out of the damage suit brought by Mrs. Elizabeth B. Rhoads for the death of her husband, who was killed by a Metropolitan Company trolley car June 10, 1899, drew out further conflicting statement yesterday from the opposing attorney.

HELENA, Mont., Jan. 16 -- W.A. Clark was elected United States Senator to-day on the first ballot. It required 17 votes to elect, and he received 57 of the 93 cast. His election was greeted with cheers that came from the spectators who crowded the galleries of the Auditorium, where the balloting took place as well as from many of the lawmakers on the main floor.

Nearly 600 persons enjoyed last night at the Waldorf-Astoria the second annual banquet of the Jewelers' Association and Board of Trade, it was an elaborate affair. Major A.K. Sloan, President of the association, officiated as toastmaster.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 16 -- That Jennie Bosschieter, the mill girl, was not poisoned -- that the four men accused of causing her death took her on that fatal ride over the Goffle road merely to revive her -- such the defense proved to be when Lawyer Michael Dunn sat down after his opening address for McAlister, Campbell, and Death this morning.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 16 -- The seventh council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations closed to-night and will meet in St. Louis in 1903. A standing committee was appointed on circuit preaching, to employ field secretaries, to organize country congregations, and for such missionary work as the Jews have not done heretofore.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The Pabst Portico bill has been referred to the Senate Committee on Cities, but no date for a hearing upon it has been set. Senator Grady said to-night that a hearing upon it would undoubtedly be granted it desired. The bill has not been introduced in the Assembly, and Senator Grady states that probably it will not be.

LONDAN, Jan. 17 -- An important report has been received from Johannesburg to the effect that Gen. De Wet has crossed the Vaal and joined forces with the Transvaal commandoes. If true, this probably means the concentration of the 7,000 Boers, with several guns, for another big attack.
Mr. QUAY is reported to be exceedingly pleased with the "vindication" secured through his re-election to the United States Senate.

Brilliant billiards was again the characteristic feature of the championship tournament last night at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players. It was the third competition, and the last pair of the six competitors. J. Byron Stark of Wilkesbarre, Penn., and Edward Gardner of the Passaic Club, New Jersey, were the centre of an appreciative group of 500 or more billiard enthusiasts.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Gov. Odell said to-day that he had not as yet received a protest from the United Charities, said to have been sent to Albany, against the abolish- ment of the Board of Charities and the appointment of a single-headed commission. Tho Governor intimated, however, that such protests had been anticipated.

The conditions that prevailed on the earlier days of the week in the outside market continued yesterday, and, with the exception of a few stocks, transactions were on an even smaller scale. Prices were irregular and net losses appeared in a number of issues, although here and there in the list strength appeared.

Miss Marie Louise Ackerman and Lawyer George Emmons Westworth, who eloped from this city about three weeks ago, deserting his wife, with whom he lived at 25 Amsterdam Avenue, have been heard from in Chicago.

The Committee of Fifteen met yesterday, but the only business transacted which could be made public was that the report of the Sub-committee on Legislation had been accepted, with minor changes. The report protests against giving the power of removal of the single head of the Police Department under the proposed law to both the Governor and Mayor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If the following protest against the theatre box office nuisance is in your judgment worth paintings as a warning or timely advice to theatregoers in the metropolis of the United States, please let it appear in your paper and help some to know what reception they may expect to meet with when they apply at the box office for seats.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Wu Ting Fang, the Chinese Minister, addressed both the Senate and the Assembly of New York to-day, end later was accorded an audience with Gov. Odell. The addresses of the Chinese diplomat created the impression that at some time in his career he has made a visit to the blarney stone.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am amazed at the indifference with which the press and people of this State have received the Governor's proposal to abolish the State Board of Charities.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 16 -- The American Tin Plate Company, which moved its entire office force from Chicago to New York a few months ago, held its annual meeting to-day. A dividend of 8 per cent., payable in quarterly installments, was declared on the common stock. This is the first dividend which has been declared on the common stock.

The annual dinner of the first panel Sheriff's jury took place at Delmonico's last evening, about 220 men prominent in politics and business circles Hitting down at the seven long tables. The National colors were draped behind the Chairman's seat and also decorated other parts of the dining hall.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- The forger for whose extradition the United States authorities are asking is Sigmund Hertz, alias Emden, of New York City. He is supposed to be on board the steamer Corinthian, which left Halifax Sunday, Jan. 7, for Queenstown and Liverpool. The police of those cities are watching for him.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- A duel with swords was fought to-day between Urbain Gohier, the well-known anti-military writer and author of "The Army Against the Nation," and M. Lataple, a journalist, who considered himself insulted by one of M. Gohier's articles in L'Aurore.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 16 -- Dissatisfaction with the riding of Jockey May during the meeting caused the stewards to suspend him to-day, pending an investigation. The stewards also decided to refuse further entry of the horse Spurs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- In the course of the debate in the Senate to-day on the Army Reorganization bill a number of the Senators vigorously denounced the practice of hazing at West Point. The matter was brought up by Mr. Allen, (Pop., Neb.,) who declared that brutality had been developed at West Point which would not be expected to exist among barbarians.

"The disposition of the people and the Government of Nicaragua is most friendly toward the United States, not only with regard to the proposed canal, but in other matters," said William B. Sorsby, United States Consul at Greytown to a TIMES reporter at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Boston had a busy morning in Federal Steel, 6,000 shares of it selling in the first two hours and one-half. Sugar. Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and Tube also were active, 9,000 shares of Chicago, Burlington and Quincy selling in the morning, the stock being in eager demand.

Ex-President HARRISON declared in his Ann Arbor address upon the status of our new possessions that "a legal argument upon this subject is quite outside of my purpose." As Mr. HARRISON treated the question as one of law, not of policy, it is hard to see how he expected to convince the public judgment by arguing a legal question in a lay manner.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16 -- James A. Mount, who retired Monday at noon from the office of Governor of the State of Indiana, died very suddenly at 6:45 o'clock tonight in his apartments at the Denison Hotel. He had attended a reception tendered by Mrs. Mount to a number of prominent ladies of the city, during the afternoon, and shortly after the guests departed he started out for a walk.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R.S" for revenue stamp. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances ill the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortage, exempt in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- By ruling of the Appellate Court, in a decision handed down by Judge Horton yesterday, the Linseed Oil Trust became liable for damages which may aggregate a large amount. The case is that of the Heath Milligan Manufacturing Company against the National Linseed Oil Company, which was reorganized two years ago and became the American Linseed Oil Company.

ALBANY, Jan 17 -- Assemblyman Remson of Brooklyn to-day introduced a brief bill which is of far-reaching importance as affecting the canals,and incidently the railroad interestss of the State. The bill is on which is said to have the in dorsement of the Chamber of Commerce of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- It is difficult to make out, from statements made by different Senators, just what the Republicans hope to do in the caucus or conference to be held to-morrow, but several Senators who have talked about it had no hesitation in saying that its importance had been greatly overestimated.
LONDON, Jan 18 -- The "Stop-the-War" Committee yesterday passed the following resolution:

The eighth conference of Foreign Mission Boards in the United States and Canada was continued yesterday in the Fourth Avenue Preshyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. George Scholl, Evangelical Lutheran, of Baltimore presided. The most imponant feature of the morning session was not on the programme.
The sixteenth annual meeting of the American Protective Tariff League was held yesterday at the league headquarters in this city. General officers and standing committees were elected as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Representative and Mrs. Fowler of New Jersey entertained at dinner to-night in honor of the Speaker and Mrs. Henderson. Among the guests were Gen. and Mrs. Ludington and Commissioner of Pensions Evans.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Senate Committee of Military Affairs to-day discussed the question of hazing at the West Point Military Academy and there was a unanimous expression of opinion in reprobation of the practice and to the effect that those guilty of it should be summarily dealt with.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Not in many years has there been such confusion at the capital in regard to the social programme as there is just now. A plan was prepared before Christmas by the President and Mrs. McKinley for the entertainment of the Diplomatic Corps, the judiciary. Congress, the Army and Navy, and the public.

Miss Martha Davis Bessey, for the last twenty-two years connected with the art department of Tiffany Co., and an artist of merit, died from a stroke of apoplexy last Wednesday, at the residence of her friend, Mrs. Smith, 225 East Fiftieth Street. Miss Bessey's sudden death was a great shook to her associates and many friends throughout the Tiffany establishment.

QUEENSTOWN, Jan. 18 -- The Allan Line steamer Corinthian, Capt. Henry, which left Halifax Monday, Jan. 7, for Queenstown and Liverpool, arrived here at 10 o'clock last evening with some difficulty. Sigmund Hertz of New York City, for whose extradition the United States authorities are asking on a charge of forgery, was on board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- S.R. Knott and T.G. Bush, as arbitrators, have rendered a decision of the question submitted to them by the various railroad lines in interest, as to what are fair and equitable rules on cotton from Alabama, Mississippi, and Tennessee junctions to Carolina mill points.

The local Republican organ in Albany, The Evening Journal, calls the attention of the Democratic papers of the State to what it calls the "good faith" of the Governor in insisting that Col. BURT shall be replaced by a Democrat duly accepted as such by the organization. It trusts that the Democrats will give the Governor credit for this maintenance of what it plainly regards as the rights of the opposition.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- There was little spirit in the market to-day, and there was special weakness in Bethlehem Steel in sympathy with Cambria. The stock, which on Jan. 2 was at 20 fell to 17 1/2 and closed at 18. Cambria stock fluctuated between 16 5/8 and 17 1/2, improving slightly on yesterday's closing price.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- After many meetings and conferences, the Association of Purchasing Agents adopted a constitution and elected officers at a meeting held to-day. The organization is composed principally of women who buy supplies from big retail firms in Chicago for country customers.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Jan. 17 -- The latest announcement made in this section concerning the gigantic projects of the Carnegic Company is to the effect that shipyards and a dry dock are to be built the coming Spring at Conneaut, and that work will begin on these plants at about the same time that operations on the construction of the tube works begin.

The suit of Charles H. Ivison and the several heirs-at-law of William B. Ivison the publisher, who died at the Hoffman House, May 30, 1896, to break his will which made David B. Ivison, a nephew of Rutherford, N.J., the sole beneficiary, with one exception, was called in the Supreme Court yesterday afternoon before Justice O'Gorman and a jury.

Grand Central Station was busy yesterday with many meetings of Directors of various lines of the New York Central system. The most important of these was the meeting of the Board of Directors of the New York, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad. A dividend of 5 per cent, was declared on the first preferred stock and a dividend of 2 per cent was Jeelared on the second preferred stock.
LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Money was wanted to-day nnd discounts were steady. There was much uncertainty whether gold would leave New York for Paris.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- The evidence in the Bosschleter case being all in, the legal wrangle for the lives of Walter C. McAlister, William A. Death, and Andrew J. Campbell was begun to-day. It was expected that the speechmaking of the lawyers in the summing up would be ended early in the afternoon, and that the case would go to the jury late in the day.

Preparatory to the formal opening of the new clubhouse of the New York Yacht Club to-morrow, a private view of the building and its appointments was afforded a number of invited guests by former Commodore E.M. Brown of the committee on New Clubhouse. Secretary J.V.S. Oddie, and Whitney Warren, the architect of the building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- As a demonstration in honor of the seating of a single Senator and as an elaborate and beautiful floral spectacle, the return of Matthew Stanley Quay of Pennsylvania to the Senate to-day was unique in the history of the body. Within the memory of the oldest Senators nothing approximating to-day's seene ever was witnested in the Senate on a similar occasion.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 17 -- The painters, carpenters, and calkers employed at Lewis Nixon's shipyard are on strike over the employment of non-union men in those branches by the firm. Over one hundred men are involved, as the machinists also quit work.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Scorpion sailed to-day from La Guayra to the point where the employes of the New York and Bermudez Company are besieged by Venezuelans. It is improbable that she will get there before Sunday morning, and as the last report from the scene of hostilities indicated that a fight was imminent it will probably have taken place before the warship arrives.

The Committee of Five, moved by the statement emanating from the District Attorney's office that the evidence submitted by that committee as a result or its vice investigations is valueless, will strengthen and corroborate the matter already in the hands of the Public Prosecutor by supplementary testimony, supported by affidavits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- During the session of the Senate to-day the Army Reorganization bill was discussed at length by Mr. Money, (Dem., Miss.,) Mr. Comas, (Rep., Md.,) and Mr. Bate (Dem., Tenn.) Mr. Money attacked that portion of the bill which confers upon the President discretionary power to increase the strength of the army.

In the list of plans filed for new structures yesterday the price in the item reading. "No. 171 East Broadway, for a six-story brick flat, with stores, 26.1 by 83.6; Y. Goldberg of 133 East Broadway, owner; F. Ebeling of 97 Seventh Street, architect; cost. $2,000," should have been $20,000.

It is a decade of years ago, if indeed it be not more, since Lord ROSEBERY put himself at the head of the "Imperial Federation" of Great Britain and her colonies. The federation was evidently a Customs Union, a Zollverein, if it had any purpose at all, and aimed at a series or preferential tariffs.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Samuel Eberly Gross, the real estate dealer and author of "The Merchant Prince of Cornville," says he will ask the United States Circuit Court to restrain M. Coquelin from playing "Cyrano De Bergerac" at the Illinois Theatre, as he has been announced to do.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- Secretary Root was confined to his home to-day with the grip, but as he was able to sign the routine official mail, it was not necessary for any one to act as Secretary in his stead. The Secretary has not yet acted on the report of the military court of inquiry in the cases of ex-Cadets Booz and Breth, and his illness will delay action still further in that matter.

Tho Pabst Hotel portico and inclosed balcony were yesterday judicially declared to be illegal and incumbranees on the sidewalk by Justice Daniel F. Maktin, sitting in the Tenth District Municipal Court. The suit was instituted by the Law Department against James B. Regan, proprietor of the Pabst Hotel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 17 -- Capt. William E. Green of the baseball team met the candidates for Princeton's nine to-day and gave them some instructions regarding the eligibility rules which govern this branch of the university's sports.

It is better from every point of view that the United States and Venezuela should settle their differences by reason, argument, and law than by means of warships. We must assume that President CASTRO'S attempt to dispossess the asphalt company is made in pursuance of what he supposes to be the laws of his country.

Four negro sailors, members of the crew of the American bark Ella, were arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields yesterday, charged with mutiny. The men are Edward Wade, Frank Jones, Joe Goodwin, and Zenas Silva. John Randem, colored, is also included in the charge, but he has not yet been arrested.

The Holland Society gave its sixteenth annual dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria, and the function was the largest in its history, nearly five hundred diners being at table. The principal feature of the dinner was the presence and address of ex-President Grover Cleveland, who, in speaking on "Conservatism," made his first public utterance on the Philippine question.

LOGANSPORT, Ind., Jan. 17 -- Marvin Kuhns, the dosperado who has terrorized Northern Indiana for weeks and boldly defied the officers of two States, by a singular fatality finds himself in the Cass County Jail, in the very town in which he made a desperate battle for life and liberty on the afternoon of Dec. 10.

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- The celebration of the bi-centenary of the Kingdom of Prussia began this morning in the midst of all the pageantry befitting such an occasion. The weather was cold and clear, and all Berlin was in holiday attire. Many thousands of flags waved from housetops and windows.

"Speak what thou canst of the Accomplishment of Desire," is the demand that one of Mr. KIPLING'S characters, an Indian Mohammedan of princely blood, sojourning in London, imputes to his like correspondent remaining in India.

Alexander Jansen arrived in town recently from Denver, Col., and engaged an apartment at 5 Water Street. Then he went out to view the skyscrapers and other features of interest. He soon concluded that, as a rule, the residents of this city are much more sociable and obliging than the denizens of Denver, for in almost no time he met a well-dressed and suave gentleman, with whom he soon became very friendly.

Under the title "Things in General," former Police Commissioner Frank Moss last night delivered an address in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street. The address was the first in a series on social and civic questions that will be delivered under the auspices of the Young Men's Society of this church during the present Winter.

The Republican Senators will meet in conference this morning to see what can be done with the various bills on which there has been some quarreling among them, and especially with the Ship Subsidy bill.
An increased attendance was noticeable yesterday afternoon and evening at the Bicycle Show in the Madison Square Garden.

The stock market yesterday all day long was feverish and unsettled, being generally depressed because of the unfavorable developments in the steel and iron trade, pessimists recalling that just such developments were to a large extent the influencing factors in bringing about the last sharp decline in the market some months ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The battleship Wisconsin was accepted by the Navy Department to-day subject to the usual three-months' reservation. No date has yet been set for putting this vessel into commission. The matter will be settled in a short time.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The several measures providing for the more definite establishment of the gold standard were again under consideration to-day before the House Committee on Coinage, Director of the Mint Roberts being heard, and letters being read from prominent financial experts.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- There was much comment among Senators and Assemblymen to-day upon the statement which George L. Rives. Chairman of the Charter Revision Commission, is reported to have made last night at a meeting held under the auspices of the Citizens' Union, in the United Charities Building, in New York.

The Prinzessin Victoria Luise, the twinserew cruising yacht recently completed for the Hamburg-American Steamship Company, arrived in port at the end of her maiden voyage across the Atlantic yesterday. The service for which she is designed is a departure in the transatlantic passenger service, as she will not carry mail or cargo, but will be utilized in the excursion business entirely, carrying only first-class passengers.

Somewhat greater activity showed in the outside market yesterday, but prices remained irregular, and again closing quotations showed a number of recessions, while elsewhere in the list net gains appeared. The transportation stocks were especially weak and were more active than they had been on any day recently.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- It may be stated absolutely that there is no dissension over the New York City Elecetion Bureau bills. It is understood to-day that the Raines bill will be passed and the other one dropped. It is the consensus of opinion that it is much wiser to incorporate the proposed changes in the general elections law than to have a special bill.

ALBANY, Jan 17 -- Two hundred representatives of agricultural interests who are attending the annual meeting of the State Association of County Agricultural Societies and the State Association of Town Agricultral Societies paid their respects to Gov. Odell at the Executive Chamber today. After shaking the delegates by the hand, the Governor addressed a few words to them.

NOROTON HEIGHTS, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Considerable excitement was occasioned among the 600 inmates of Fitch's Home for Soldiers and Sailors, the State institution here, by an order from the Executive Committee of the State Hospital Board posted yesterday, requiring all inmates of the home to be vaccinated excepting those in the hospital who are excused by the doctors after being examined.
At a meeting of the Republican County Committee, hold at the Murray Hill Lyceum last night, President Robert C. Morris, who was in the chair, announced the following standing sub-committees:

A.A. Hutchinson and Victor K. McElheny, Jr., who are suing the former Directors of the American Malting Company to "compel them to pay back to the company the amount of its capital which they had wasted and dissipated in the payment of unearned dividends and in the payment of $400,000 discount on its bonds, as well as in other acts of waste," yesterday issued a circular letter to the Stockholders of the company.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Ruskin, in a very few words, clearly, defined the true value and uses of art when he wrote: Every work of art states a true thing or adorns a serviceable one." The test embodied in this incisive statement applies to all manifestations of the artistic in their many and varied applications.

Before the opening of the Paris Exposition, the Storthing determined to bring out a work descriptive of Norway and its resources, and the task was placed in the hands of Prof. Sten Konow of the Uni versity of Christiana and Prof. Karl Fischer of the University Library. The leading specialists in Norway having been called upon to contribute, the resultant is a most valuable and instructive volume.

The Philobibion Club of Philadelphia is gradually coming to the front as a leader in subjects that appeal to book lovers. It was established five or six years ago and is rapidly outgrowing its present quarters. On Tuesday, Jan. 8, it held a special meeting in the H. Josephine Widener Branch of the Free Library of Philadelphia.
MANILA, Jan. 18 -- It is rumored that Aguinaldo visited his mother in Cavite Province and narrowly escaped capture during the recent round-up of one of the villages in Cavite.

There was a lively sequel to proceedings in a suit for separation in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, when the defendant in the action met the plaintiff's lawyer upon leaving court, and assaulted him. Lawyer Hugo Wintner applied to Justice Dickey for alimony and counsel fee for Mrs. Charles Wuest, whose husband is a professor of music.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have read with great interest in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of the 12th inst. the criticism of Judge Dykman of the new history of Westchester County, recently published by the New York History Company, regarding the account of the capture of Major John Andre.

LONDON, Jan. 18 -- Notwithstanding the Bank of England has reduced the floating supply of cash by nearly L2,000,000, it still continues so large that it is difficult to maintain rates. Though the Bank reserve was increased by a like amount, it is still more than L3,000,000 below that of a year ago, showing there is something needful to attract gold.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the last Presidential campaign the possibilities under the Financial act -- that is to say, its defects -- were one of the issues of the election. And this position, whatever be the blame, by implication, attaching to the Republican Party for having made such a law and for pretending that it was complete and satisfactory, was unquestionably correct as to facts.

Bishop Potter yesterday made a further defense of his proposed Vigilance Committee to combat vicious civic conditions, which has been attacked by Chairman William H. Baldwin, Jr., and other members of the Committee of Fifteen on the ground that young men working in such an organization would be subjected to temptations that might result in their moral injury.

Although the new theatre in course of construction at Muinich is not intended to compete with the famous Baireuth "Temple" -- the very Mecca of the Wagnerites -- something akin to alarm has been felt by the powers that be.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Jan. 18 -- The coal miners of Trinidad and Southern Colorado generally may join the strike now involving all the rest of the State. If they do Cripple Creek's only source of fuel will be cut off and the camp must close.

The property at the southeast corner of Broadway and Maiden Lane, known as 100 to 172 Broadway, together with 2 Maiden Lane, adjoining, have been sold, and will be the site of a new office building, probably sixteen stories in height, to be erected by the George A. Fuller Company.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The House spent the entire day to-day on the bill to refer to the Court of Claims the claims of the William Cramp Son Ship Building Company of Philadelphia, for alleged dam ages due to the delay of the Government in furnishing armor plate and material for the battleships Massachusetts and Indiana, and the cruisers New York and Columbia.

Arthur Townsend, the Hanover Club billiard champion, and Frank Gardner, the holder of similar honors in the Crescent Athletic Club, were the competitors last night at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, in the fifth game for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Jan. 18 -- A fire which broke out at the plant of the Frank Jones Brewing Company, Limited, here this morning caused a loss of $15,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 18 -- With a few exceptions, the Philadelphia list was inclined to heaviness to-day, and especially did this apply to Pennsylvania and the Readings. Pennsylvania was off 1 1/2 at noon and sold at 73 during the afternoon, the decline being due to the proposed issue of new stock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some years ago, in my native city, I heard they were to put in a gymnasium at the Young Men's Christian Association rooms, where the boys could use the boxing gloves. I said to one of the Directors, "You will bring up a Nation of prizefighters."

WASHINGTON, Jan, 18 -- Just before 6 o'clock this evening the Senate finally disposed of the Army Reorganization bill. The measure having originated in the Senate, the final question was not upon its passage, but upon agreeing to the Senate amendments. They were agreed to by a vote of 43 to 23.

C. Harold McChesney, New York, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "Yes, I think your correspondent, Mr. Arthur Gutterman's, edition of Shakespeare is 'defective.' In my edition Hamlet manages, by one ruse or another, to 'remove' all in a lump everybody, even poor Laertes, (a manly young fellow, too, whose only fault seems to have been that he loved his father and his sister too dearly,) who could possibly continue the Danish dynasty.

Wagner's "Die Walkure" was sung at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the second time this season. The audience was one of good size, and its enthusiasm was commensurate with the merits of the performance. These were in advance of those discerned in the first representation.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- The annual report of State Commissioner of Excise Henry H. Lyman was transmitted to-day to the Legislature. The report gives the usual statement showing the financial transactions for the fiscal year 1900, which is as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- In the office of the Superintendent of Public Works the bill, introduced by Assemblyman Remsen of Brooklyn yesterday, for the repeal of Chapter 935 of the Laws of 1890, entitled "An act to amend the transportation corporation law by extending its provisions to canals and other waterways, and reducing the minimum of capitalization," is viewed with suspicion.

Great astonishment was occasioned in social circles both in Harlem and Mount Vernon yesterday by the announcement that John M. Dearborn, a business man of the latter place, and Mrs. Cornella Weeks Cornwell of 45 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street, a prominent member of the Harlem Philharmonic Society, both well beyond middle age, had been quietly married and had started for Old Point Comfort on their wedding tour.

BOSTON, Jan. 18 -- Capt. Hank Haff came to Boston to-day to talk over matters relating to the Lawson yacht, and with Capt. Watson was in conference at different times with Designer Crowninshield, Adrian Wilson, the salimaker; George F. Lawley. C.F. Adams, second, and C.E. Hodges, the latter of the Board of Managers.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan, 18 -- For several days United States District Attorney, William Michael Byrne has been working among the legislators at Dover with a view of solving the deadlock over the election of two United States Senators Mr. Byrne has been in favor of a plan to elect Col. Henry A. Dupont and John Edward Addicks as the two Senators.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: When Tammany regained control of this city in 1898, there was a general cry that the high schools established under Mayor Strong's administration would be abolished. So far, however, Tammany has not shown such a violent opposition to high schools as has a gentleman outside that organization -- Mr. Coler.
The annual election of tile Republican Club on Monday evening promises to be very exciting.

GOSHEN, Ind., Jan. 18 -- Andrew Carnegie has notified the managers of the Local Library Association by wire that he will donate $15,000 toward a public library building for this city. Goshen is the smallest city Mr. Carnegie has ever assisted.

Mayor Van Wyck, at the meeting of the Board of Estimate yesterday, found fault with the East River Bridge Commission, of which Lewis Nixon, head of the Tammany Committee of Five, is President, and accused them of not attending to their business.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Twenty-six of the trust companies whose principal offices are in New York and Kings Counties, according to their annual reports made to the State Superintendent of Banking on Jan. 1, this year, show total resources of $407,369,722. This is a gain over a year ago of the same companies, with one exception, of $106,110,208.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Attorney General and Mrs. Griggs gave their first formal dinner party of the year this evening, when they entertained the Chief Justice and Mrs. Fuller, Justice and Mrs. Harlan, Justice and Mrs. Shiras, Justice and Mrs. White, Justice McKenna, Senator and Mrs. McMillan, Mrs. Audenried, Miss McKenna, Assistant Postmaster General Johnson, and Assistant Attorney General Beck.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Much is said of the books that are written expressly for the children of to-day. It is a debatable question whether the many children's books of this age are as conducive to forming good literary taste as was the reading during childhood of the standard books of the olden time that were written for adults, but were read by children because of a dearth of other reading.

When Jesus closed His interview with the Greeks who desired "to see" Him it was late in the afternoon of our Sunday. Withdrawing from them, He left the Temple, and accompanied only by "the twelve," He went out of the city on foot to Bethany. There He lodged that night. The next morning -- our Monday -- He returned with "the twelve" and without any such demonstrations as marked the day before.

Richard Tjader, formerly a foreign missionary and an associate of the late Dwight L. Moody, has caused no little excitement in Presbyterian circles. Not long ago he organized the International Missionary Union, a body that is regarded as a rival by those interested in the Presbyterian Foreign Mission Board and similar bodies in other churches.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- Prices on the Bourse today opened dull. Spanish 4s were weak on the Carlist agitation and less favorable exchange. Later they hardened slightly, influenced by the firmness of Metropolitans and some tractions, and prices closed, all around, better.

A WEEKLY READER writes: "I notice a letter from your correspondent Mr. De Wolfe in your last number. Having taken some interest in the matter myself, enough to have studied it. I to showthat Mr. Do Wolfe is mistaken in some respects.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Controller Bird S. Cold of New York spoke before the Outlook Club of this city to-night. His subject was "The City of New York." His address was a defense of what he called the greatest city in the world.

Murray H. Hall, the woman who masqueraded as a man for more than a quarter of a century, and the secret of whose sex came out only with her death last Wednesday night, at 145 Sixth Avenue, was known to hundreds of people in the Thirteenth Senatorial District, where she figured quite prominently as a politician.

The literary department of one of our esteemed contemporaries used to have a good deal of unmerciful fun with what it described as "the Columbia College School of Fiction." Perhaps the fun was as unjust as it was unmerciful. But it cannot be denied that it was fun, and refreshing to the disinterested and carnal man.

The writer of a recent letter to the editor of one of our contemporaries called attention to the manner in which the early literary lights of New England managed to get a liberal culture out of college courses arranged on much less generous plans than those of the present day.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The Gazette last evening announced that Major Gen. Sir Henry Edward Colvile, who recently commanded the Ninth Division of the South African Field Force and later was in command of an infantry brigade at Gibraltar, had been placed on the retired list with pay.

The will of Catherine, Harsen Skatts, a cousin of John Harsen Rhoades, President of the Greenwich Savings Bank, was filed in the Surrogates' office yesterday. Under the will the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary receives $5,000; the Protestant Episcopal Church of Manchester Centre, Vt., $2,500; the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Jersey, $2,000. and the Home of St. Giles the Cripple, Brooklyn, $1,000.

The accidental taking up of one of the ordinary six-shilling novels so commonly issued in London at the present day, Mrs. Steel's "The Hosts of the Lord," published by William Helnemann, revealed such an unusually good title page that the whole subject seemed worth a careful investigation for the sake of comparison.

CARLISLE, Penn., Jan. 18 -- The Carlisle Indian baseball team has arranged its schedule for this year, and the list of her opponents includes Princeton, Yale, Colum- bia, Fordham, Cornell, Harvard, University of Pennsylvania, University of Rochester, Washington and Jefferson, Albright, Pennsylvania State College, Dickinson, Mercersburg, Lebanon Valley, Gettysburg, Susquchanna, and Bucknell, and runs from April 6 until June 19.
"When a man bucks against the rail roads, he must expect to be run over."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have been much interested in Judge Dykman's letter about Andre's captors, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 12. The statement contained in my "Crisis of the Revolution" (Page 27) that the captors humbered eight, instead of seven, is based on, first, the evidence of Samuel Youngs, a former Surrogate of Westchester County.

We publish in another column a letter from a correspondent commenting unfavorably on an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 5 as to higher schools. It seems to us a very good example of the unfortunate confusion of mind that exists on the subject we discussed.
OSBORNE, Isle of Wight, Jan. 18 -- The following official announcement regarding the Queen's health has been made:

From The London Publishers' Circular. The books of 1898, the year of the Spano-American war, were 110 fewer than those of 1897. The books of 1899, when our Boer war began, were about the same in number as those of 1898. All the year 1900 that war has worried us, and our book list shows a fall of 418.

Justices of the Peace James R. Murphy and Charles P. Sweeney of Jersey City were standing at Erie and Thirteenth Streets Thursday night, when they were approached by a well-dressed couple, who asked to be directed to the nearest Justice.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 18 -- Brown University gave the University of Pennsylvania an admirable lesson in hockey here to-night at the Ice Palace by winning the first intercollegiate match by the score of 7 goals to 0. While the forwards and W. Gardiner, at point, showed some improvement over previous exhibitions, the team as a whole is decidedly weak, and has apparently not given much thought to the rudiments of the game.

Irregularity and heaviness were again yesterday the features of the stock market. Bear pressure was in evidence throughout the day, and on two distinct occasions, once in the early forenoon and later, in the afternoon, concerted raids were made, causing in some instances material recessions.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: As the compiler of a bibliography of Henry D. Thoreau. I have been deeply interested in Mr. Spofford's communication concerning Emerson's contributions to The Dial, and this because from Mr. Spofford's copy of that periodical, containing Emerson's contributions, "marked by Mr. Emerson's with his initials," some errors of mine are corrected.

The thirty-first annual reunion and ban quet of the New York Association of Hamilton College Alumni in commemoration of the one hundred and forty-third anniversary of the birth of Alexander Hamilton, was given last night in the Hotel Savoy. Fifty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue. The banquet hall was tastefully decorated with American flags and the college colors.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 18 -- Seven boxing bouts and ten wrestling contests took place at the second nights session of the Amateur Athletic Union championship tournament. The majority of the contests were rather clever, but the out-of-town contestants again carried off the honors. Summaries:

To the Editor of The New York Times: There was a time, I have been told, when I could not go to sleep without my bottle; during a subsequent period of my youth I did not go to sleep before I had a licking; of late I have not been able to slum ber peacefully before I have read THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Bccoming tired of her rubber nipple, which was hung about her neck with a piece of twine, and wishing to pay on the floor with Edward, her twin brother, little Dora Damroch, fourteen months old, who lived on Ninth Street, between Avenues C and D, Unionport, started to climb down from her high chair where her mother had left her yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The Republican Senators decided to-day not to set a date, at least for the present, for taking up the Nicaragua Canal bill. The decision was reached after an hour and a halt spent in caucus, and was unanimous. The caucus was called largely because of Senator Morgans importunities on behalf of the bill, and an earnest effort was made to find a satisfactory solution of the problem.

ALBANY, Jan. 18 -- Legislators opposed to the enlargement of the State canal system have set to work to sidetrack the $62,000,000 improvement proposition that has been submitted by State Engineer and Surveyor Bond, and upon which that official has been busily figuring for several months past.

FREDERICK M. BIRD, South Bethlehem, Penn., writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "Mr. William L. Stone, in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Dec. 15, is right enough in defending Manor Andre's memory; but he need not have repeated Lamb's foolish story (1800) about the hymn 'written a few days before his execution,' (1780.)

Major John J. O' Connell, First Infantry, is detailed as a member of the examining board to meet at Fort Riley, Kan., for the examination of Officers for promotion, vice Capt. Charles W. Farber, Eighth United States Cavalry, who is relieved as a member of the board when officers who are senior to him in rank are being examined.

The Board of Estimate, at the meeting yesterday, appropriated $4,025,000 for the improvornent of the water supply of the city.
