After the meeting the city officials interviewed agreed that this appropriation marked the end of any effort to make a contract with the Ramapo Water Company for a supply to the city.
WEST POINT, Jan. 18 -- To-days sessions of the Congressional committee which is investigating hazing at the Military Academy were extremely interesting.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The orders to the Scorpion to proceed from La Gunyra to Guanoco have been countermanded and she will remain at La Guayra, where her pres once is regarded as necessary.

James P. Keating, Commissioner of High ways, did not yesterday tear down and remove the portico and inclosed dining room balcony of the Pabst Hotel, which incumbet the sidewalk in Forty-second Street, between Seventh Avenue and Broadway. Mr. Keating was not restrained by law from so acting in accordance with his ultimatum of Jan. 8.

Two men made a desperate attempt to steal the day's receipts of Maillard's candy store, in the Fifth Avenue Hotel, at 11:45 o'clock last night, and would have succeeded had it not been for the courage of Henry Mathey, the cashier, who refused to hold up his hands when one of the robbers covered him with two big revolvers and ordered him to do so.

PARIS, Jan. 18 -- George W. Ochs was to-day decorated by the French Government with the Legion of Honor. The decoration was conferred on account of the notable success achieved by Mr. Ochs in publishing the Exposition Edition of THE NEW YORK TIMES. This is the first time such an honor has been conferred on an American journalist.

YONKERS, N.Y. Jan. 18 -- Two cars on the Union Traction Company's lines crashed into each other this afternoon 300 yards east of the Dunwoodle station, on the line between this city and Mount Vernon. Two persons were severely injured and a dozen or more slight cut by flying glass.

BOSTON, Jan. 17 -- The best planned complete editions have a wicked way of going beyond control and refusing to become complete within set limits, and hero is the library edition of Dr. Edward Everett Hale's works ending without the promised sermons, which, in pulpit phrase, are "reserved for another occasion."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- In the Republican Senatorial caucus to-day Senator Hanna expressed his desire to have the Ship Subsidy bill passed upon during the present session of Congress, and said that with the Army bill out of the way he should ask that the decision arrived at early in the session to press the Subsidy bill be adhered to.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Murder in the second degree was the verdict brought in to-night by the jury before whom Walter C. McAlister, Andrew J. Campbell, and William A. Death have been on trial since Monday morning. The men charged with having caused the death of Jennie Bosschieter, the mill girl, heard the verdict that may mean thirty years' imprisonment for them with unmistakable signs of relief.
Fordham Council won three straight games from Claremont Council in the Royal Arcanum tournament of the Borough of the Bronx on Pump's North Side Palace alleys last night. The scores:

According to advices received by Dun's, St. John reports both wholesale and retail quiet, but up to the average, while prospects for Spring are fair. Seasonable weather has stimulated trade at Halifax, and is favorable to lumbering. Mining operations continue active and staples are well maintained.

Joseph Williams, said by Superintendent McCuliagh to be "Scar-Faced Hennessy." a lender of the election colonizers alleged to have operated from Assemblyman Honeck's saloon and Raines law hotel, at Twenty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, during the recent election, was convicted of aiding and abetting illegal registration in General Sessions yesterday before Judge Newburger.

Shooting in a gale of wind against a lot of good birds were the conditions that confronted the Sheepshead Bay Rod and Gun Club members yesterday on their grounds, just back of the Coney Island Jockey Club race course. Ira McKane and Henry J. Montanus killed straight in a field of twenty, and then on the shoot-off, McKane won, killing two straight, the conditions being miss and out, Summaries:

Hidden away on the west wall of the little east room, an apartment only fit for paintings of small dimensions rather preciously wrought -- like Mr. Carle J. Blenner's "Cup of Tea," the figure of a lady painted like a miniature -- is a large, boldly brushed canvas by C.W. Hawthorne, called "Splitting Fish."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- Ever since the Army bill became a subject of discussion in Congress it has been the chief topic of conversation at the War Department, and there have been warm controversies between those who favored the Secretary's plan for securing control of all staff appointments and changes and the others who behave that the inherent evils of the staff as now constituted have been over estimated.

Individual efforts were good but team work sadly lacking in the first hockey game of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic Leagues series at the Clermont Avenue Skating Rink, Brooklyn, last night. The Polytechnic Preparatory School of Brooklyn and the Brooklyn Latin School teams opposed each other.

The residents of Brooklyn are becoming greatly alarmed over the repeated burglaries which are being committed nightly, and last night there was talk of the formation of a Vigilance Committee. The clothing store of Samuel Ferrares, at 681 Grand Street, was entered early yesterday morning and stock valued at $250 carried off.

HOHOKUS, N.J., Jan. 18 -- Burglars broke into the Allendale station of the Erie Railroad last night at 11 o'clock. A young man and woman who were waiting for the 11:30 train heard glass being broken. The young man looked in the station window and saw a man in the office. The young man pulled a revolver on him, but the burglar got away.

Louis Stuyvesant Chanler made a vigorous protest to Recorder Goff yesterday when Samuel Johnson, charged with grand larceny, whom Mr. Chanter had been as signed to defend, entered a plea of guilty to petty larceny at the instance of the District Attorney, and without Mr. Chanler's knowledge.

The Camera Club is making ready for its annual auction of photographic material, whereby the members exchange all sorts of articles belonging to the gentle art of the kodak and indulge at the same time in the luxury of bidding up one's own and knocking down the other fellows contributions.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The amended Hay-Pauncefote treaty was discussed at a lenghty Cabinet council yesterday. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Marquis of Lansdowne, has taken no action so far, he will probably emoody the result of the deliberations in a dispatch or in an interview with United States Ambassador Chonte on Monday or later.

Cornelius J. Rooney, Cleric of the Hudson County Health Board, at Jersey City, devoted nearly four weeks labor to preparing a tabulated statement of the vital statistics of the county. He finished it on Thursday afternoon, and was so overjoyed that he neglected to place the document in his desk, but left it lying on a table.

A NEW EDITION OF GEORGE ELIOT. -- In the forty years since "Scenes of Clerical Life" appeared anonymously in England the place of its author in English literature, while not beyond dispute, has remained, for the most part, secure. Evidently she gains admirers with age. A new edition of her complete works, called the "Personal" edition, will be published in March by Doubleday, Page Co.
Ex-County Judge R.O. JONES of Utica died yesterday from pneumonia. He had been ill only since Tuesday. He was fifty-eight years of age.

The history of this famous vessel, a apirited picture of which under full sail, after the painting by Marshall Johnson, forms the frontispiece of the present volume, is much more than the history of a single vessel, however famous. The book is an outgrowth of Mr. Ira N. Hollis's paper written for The Atlantic, in commemoration of the hundredth anniversary of the launchiug of this old ship.

There appeared in THE TIMES of Tuesday last, among the items of minor local news, one which stated that Mrs. MARY FERRAND, an employe in an up-town department store, had been "forced to undergo vaccination," and that bipod poisoning had followed, of so severe a character that amputation of the woman's leg might be necessary.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 64 1/2 @65 1/2. There were no sales.

Doubtless that was an impressive celebration of a memorable event that was celebrated in Berlin on Thursday with so much military pomp. The Prussian monarchy was a thing of small beginnings. Not till half a century after its establishment by the coronation of the first King of Prussia did the little kingdom cut much figure in the polities of Europe.

Of the address made by President Jacob Gould Schurman at the banquet of the Cornell Alumnl, in this city last Saturday, a report was printed in Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES: A reference which President Schurman made to the death of Moses coit Tyler, omitted from that report, should find a place here.

MANILA, Jan. 18 -- The public discussion of the General Code of Government for Municipalities began to-day. Commissioner Dean C. Worcester outlined the bill and explained the changes from the general orders of the Military Governor, under which many local Governments were operating. Commissioner Worcester offered two amendments, disqualifying from voting and holding office men who violate their oath of American allegiance or who remain in armed opposition after February.

President O'Brien of the Board of Education yesterday received an acknowledgment of the receipt of the check for $27,907,02 sent on Jan. 6 as a donation by the children of the public schools of New York to the children of the public schools of Galveston.

"H.B.F.," New York, commenting upon the notice of Robert G. Ingersoll's works which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 5, writes: "You omit reference to the rarest trait of his character, considered apart from his natural gifts of oratory and almost matchless command of our language.
Fredcrtck A. Gilbert of Brookline, Mass., dropped dead last night while dining with friends at the New York Club, Thirty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue.

One question asked of two witnesses took up the entire day in Part X. of the Supreme Court yesterday where the Winters will contest is on trial before Justice Bischoff and a jury. It was one of the longest hypothetical questions that has been put to experts in the Supreme Court for some time. It was just 4,200 words in length.

The State Library School at Abany, N. Y., from time to time invites speakers from outside the pale of librarianship for addresses on various phases of literary work. On Jan. 10 George Iles gave the students some account of_the aid extended him by the libraries of New York as he wrote "Flame, Electricity, and the Camera."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 2 Judge Dykman contributes a most intereating account of the main facts connected with the capture of Major Andre in the War of the Revolution.

The interest in this book of Anthony Wilkin among the Berbers of Algeria is largely in its being a record of travels in it comparatively unexplored region of Algeria and among a race measurably removed from the Arabs, Moors, Turks, and Jews, with whom we are more or less familiar. The Berbers call themselves noble and descendants of a mighty race, whose culture once spread from the Atlantic to the Red Sea.

There is only one more day for the bicycle show in the Madison Square Garden, and this evening the exhibit of bicycles and, to some extent, automobiles, will be over. The attendance yesterday exceeded all previous days, and there was not an exhibitor who was not kept busy explaining new things and giving, if necessary, practical demonstrations.

In February, Messrs, Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge will sell in London an important series of letters and documents, in the autograph of and addressed to William Penn. There is Penn's "Last will and Testament made and writt in my own hand this twentyth day of ye 8th month of ye year 1705 in ye 60 year of my age."

FLOYD R. SMITH, Brooklyn, N.Y., writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "It was with great surprise that I read the defense of Andre and the attack on his captors in the last issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW. The writer seems, at several points, to lay himself open to severe criticism by making statements which, if not absolutely untrue, are at the best very misleading.

BERLIN, Jan. 18 -- Among the principal events to-day in connection with the celebration of the bi-centenary of the Kingdom of Prussia were the presentation of congratulations to the Emperor from foreign powers, a solemn service in the Schloss Chapel, and a banquet in the castle this evening to the visiting Princes, the foreign Ministers, and the great notabilities of the empire.

In the following list "mig" stands for mortgage and "R.S." for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- It is announced that Arnold Boecklin, the painter, died on Jan. 18 in Fiesole, Italy.

S.S. ALSOP, Enfield, N.C., writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "In the January number of Harper's Magazine Mr. Woodrow Wilson makes the statement that eighty years before the set tlement of Jamestown by the English, in 1528, a Spaniard named Vasquez de Ayllon settled the same point of land with a colony of 500 Spaniards, who built houses and planned to keep a butting colony.

According to testimony given in the Harlem Police Court yesterday the family of William McShane of 317 West One Hundred, and Thirty-sixth Street lives very poorly indeed when the husband and father is sober. When McShane is handicapped with strong drink, however, the wife and children, it was learned, gained free access to his trousers pockets and lived on the fat of the land.

The second novel of the Harpers' American Fiction Series will be issued in February under the title of "The Sentimentalists," by Arthur Stanwood Pier. The third novel, which will be published in March, will be called "Martin Brook," and is by Morgan Bates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The sad plight of the Russie, ashore on the coast of France, which has called forth the sympathy and prayers of the many thousands cognizant of their suffering and peril, leads me to urge upon the Government to require all vessels, sailing from whatever port, to carry mortar lines and rockets, such as are in use in all the lifesaving stations along our coast.

PROF. WILLIAM GOODELL FROST. President of Berea College, Kentucky, writey to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "You will excuse me for some special interest in the criticism of the character of the Kentucky mountaineer as exhibited in the popular novel entitled Stringtown on the Pike, which has appeared in your columns.

Robert Atkins of 2,432 Seventh Avenue, managing clerk for the real estate firm of Whitehouse Porter, at 509 Fifth Avenue, committed suicide yesterday by shooting himself through the heart in a room at the Colonial Hotel, at One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Eighth Avenue. Financial difficulties are said to have been the cause of the suicide.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18 -- The case of Col. Henry B. Freeman of the Twenty-fourth infantry, who yesterday was nominated by the President to be a Brigadler General in the regular army, is without precedent in the history of the army. He was placed on the retired list of the army yesterday by operation of law on account of age with the rank of Colonel.
Mrs. John A. Foster, the "Tombs Angel," after securing the release of Nora Donnelly, a girl charged with shoplifting, fainted in the corridor of the Court of General Sessions yesterday.
CACTUS FLOWER, Orchard, Hanch, Dewey, Arix., writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW:

No retired statesman ever gained reputation as a sage by such an utterance as that of ex-President CLEVELAND at the annual dinner of the Holland Society. We expect our wise men to tell us, not merely that we are in a bad way, but what we ought to do to set ourselves right.

The report of the forty-eighth annual meeting of the Congregational Church Building Society shows that, with the single exception of 1897, in which the board was busy disbursing the Stickney Fund, more has been accomplished during the past twelve months than in any previous year in the history of the society, which extends back to 1853.

Details of the proposed issue of securities of the Erie Railroad, by which it is intended to carry out the purchase of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, the Erie and Wyoming Valley Railroad Company, and the Delaware Valley and Kingston Railroad Company from J.P. Morgan Co., are contained in a long circular to shareholders issued yesterday by the Directors of the Erie Railroad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Depositors in the savings banks of the State expected to have a little rest this year, but we find what is unusual, that the same fight for the surplus is to be continued this year. Gov. Odell, with his powerful influence, is to help the looters. Many of us are small depositors.

Recent French official statistics are attracting much attention among thoughtful students of social problems in that country. They show conclusively what has long been known in a general way, that at the present rate of artificially restricted increase of population, a death rate normally high and an infant mortality abnormally so, France is relatively losing ground, and that if existing conditions continue operative it must sink to insignificance among the nations.

Could we but perpetuate them, those books that are never written, what a garden of culture we should have! What rare, sweet flowers of thought have been "born to blush unseen and waste their sweet nose on the desert air."

The mystery surrounding the murder of Meyer Weisbard, the jewelry salesman, whose body was found in a trunk on the stringers of Pier 11, East River, on Wednesday, baffied the police more than ever yesterday. When Chief of Detectives Titus gave an interview late last night he said that nothing practically, barring the running down of scores of rumors and stories, had been accomplished.

The junior class at Yale hopes to turn out a winning athlete in some of the coming truck games in J.S. Spraiker, a New Yorker who entered Yale from the Berkeley School, and is now in the law department. He made a record in the high jump at the Yale games last year of 6 feet 3 inches, and has covered 23 feet in the broad jump.

Gen. Andrew J. Mackay, a veteran of the civil war, died after a few days illness in his room, at 205 Greenwich Street, yesterday morning. He was Quartermaster General on the staff of Gen. George H. Thomas, who at one time commanded the Array of the Cumberland.

Messrs, Dodd, Mend Co. have recently issued in an edition limited to 110 copies an interesting bit of Stevensoniana. Stevenson says in one of his letters: "A Oulda romance we have been secretly writing, in which Haggard was the hero, and each one of the authors had to draw a portrait of him or herself in a Ouida light.

M.C.S., New York, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "Your recent article on 'Christmas in Song and Story' was of special interest. I should like to add to your list a humanly winning chapter, full of spontaneity and happy youthful comradeship, entitled 'How the Hive Hummed at Christmas'; it is in 'The Bennett Twins, by Grace M. Hurd.

When there appeared early this month from the house of Cotta, in Stuttgart, a volume called "First Bismarck's Briefe an scine Braut und Gattin," it was supposed that striking revelations were to be made concerning Bismarck's relations with the Prussian sovereigns and Government. But the volume contains love letters, pure and simple, the distinguished correspondent rarely touching upon politics.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- The Peking correspondent of The Daily Mail, wiring Saturday, says:

The annual report of the Public Librarles division of the New York State Library at Albany for 1000 contains returns from 1,035 librarles. Of these 460 are free for lending to the public, and, containing 2,187,125 volumes, circulated last year 8,452,445. The free librarles lent, to the people an average of 23,157 books daily, 1,163 for each 1,000 of the population, and 367 for each 100 books in the librarles.

Ww have already pointed out the precarlousness of the present European demand for American coal, for general industrial use. The greatest assurance of permanence in our coal exports to Europe seems to be in the grades especially adapted for distillation in gas retorts. Good gas coals are scarce in Europe, and will never be cheap.

The last week has been a record breaker for deaths of old residents of Staten Island. Michael Van Name, eighty-five years old, a lifelong resident of Mariner's Harbor, died from old age. Elizabeth Rintoul, aged seventy-six years, died at her home, in New Brighton. Catherine Smith, seventy years old, died at Port Richmond.

The teams of Company H of the Seventh Regiment competed for the Kemp and Clark Trophies on the armory ranges last night, making a total of 1,048 for the Kemp Trophy for teams of twenty-five men, and scoring 1,991 for the Clark Trophy for teams of fifty men, which gives them fourth place so far in both competitions.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 19 -- The Amateur Athletic Union championship tournament closed to-night with thirteen contests in the finals for boxing and wrestling. Each bout was of champion order, and the big majority of the medals were carried away by out-of-town people.

The heroic figure of Jean de Reszke in "Le Cid" posing chiefly as a foil to the ballet, and the fact that the ballet music is decidedly the best in the score of the work, suggested by force of contrast the unsuccessful attempts of Wagner to raise the operatic ballet above the level of a mere display of pretty women in graceful motion.
NEW HAVEN, Jan. 19 -- Yale's new buildings, which are planned to be ready for occupancy at bicentennial next October, are being pushed ahead at a rapid rute.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The reports from Havana that the Cuban Constitution may be completed in time to be considered at this session of Congress has led to discussion in Congressional circles as to the procedure likely to be adopted on a document of this character. It is expected that the Constitution will be forwarded to the President and by him submitted to Congress, probably with recommendations.
PEKING, Sept. 25 -- "Here are two rolls of mandarin silk, about twenty yards. How much shall I say for the mandarin silk?"

Wall Street speculators have suffered a bad shake up during the past week. All long of stocks, and most of them heavily overloaded, they have been confronted with a reaction which day by day has grown more vigorous. The setback scored represents in conspicuous stocks a recession of tens of millions of dollars.

Misery, squalor, and wretchedness, accentuated by an almost cealseless struggle with hunger and cold are the portion of these "livyeres" in Newfoundland. Their little hamlets are perched in the rifts in the almost unbroken hills, and the fierce storms sweep the sort almost to their doorsteps; while for seven months of the year their coast is blockaded with ice, and they are cut off from all communication with the outside world.

For perfectly apparent reasons, the actual names of the persons interested are not used in this series of little stories.

If Man may, with a respectful wonder and interest, contemplate and criticise the vagaries of feminine fashion. Woman has in turn a claim to note and comment upon masculine habits. Now a rumor has lately spread in regard to these which decidedly concerns her. It is reported that the custom of snufftaking, which seemed to have gone almost entirely out of vogue, is to be widely and generally resuscitated.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Theatrical managers are said, by those who know them, to resemble gamblers in the matter of being superstitious. However this may be in a general way, an example of such superstition has just occurred at the Ambigu Theatre, which is the Adelphi of Paris. The Ambigu is now playing a new place.

Nat Good win and Maxine Elliott will begin their annual New York engagement to-morrow night at the Knickerbocker Theatre. Their first play will be H.V. Esmond's comedy. "When We Were Twenty-one," which was their attraction last season. At the Victoria Theatre the same night will be shared by a new musical comedy which will be presented by Mathews and Bulger, entitled "The Night of the Fourth."

Whether New York is at a disadvantage as compared with cities nearer to great water powers, in the matter of cheap sources of electricity available for power, light, and heat, is a question of great interest to all classes of our citizens, and especially to those who are large consumers of anthracite and gas.

"Noel," says the strip of white cloth stretched across the entrance "Noel," announce the cards posed upon the goods; "Voyez, voyez -- pour Noel," cry the attendants, red-handed youths.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Judging from this evening's papers, interested persons admit the death, or, at least, the moribund condition, of the latest "vice crusade." If with this admission the clergy would retire and politicians would desist in their efforts to make capital for party politics out of existing conditions, a certain number of us would be genuinely rejoiced.

Freight and passenger officials of certain Eastern lines in positions of varying importance are feeling some uneasiness regarding the security of their positions, and are indulging in speculation as to what effect the growing tendency of railroad consolidation will have on their utility as railroad officials.

The election for President of the Republican Club is being hotly contested. The two candidates, ex-Judge W.M.K. Olcott and Gen. Tremain have many friends who are working constantly for votes. The friends of Judge Olcott have had an expert examine the registry of voters as published and discovered that Gen. Tremain, although a resident of 105 East Eighteenth Street since 1804, has never voted from that address.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial on the removal of CoL Burt reminds me of a recent remark of 3, prominent member of the Republican organization, which was to this effect: "It has been said that an organization candidate can never be elected Governor or this State, but one has been elected, and he will show what can be done in partisan politics."

No matter where a man may go or what may betall him, he will never feel the same throb as when he first hears the "whin" of a rattleshake, followed by the blood rdling biss that denotes the territory creature is about to strike. The danger from the rattleshake is as great to-day as it ever was, and the man who starts alone down any rock canyon is liable to need one or more.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The interest upon the part of the public in the Ship Subsidy bill continues, and the attention of the taxpayer daily increases, and a result indicates a growing popular sentiment against the measure. That no trust has yet been formed pending its passage is natural.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 19 -- Govani Cotille, Giuseppe Silvani, and Giuseppe Marino, Italians, are held at the Police Headquarters here on suspicion of being concerned in the murder of Meyer Weisbard, whose body was found in a trunk in New York a few days ago.

Each of the attempts made by France, since the beginning of the nineteenth century, to obtain, if not repose at least stability, has left behind it a certain quantity of floating wreckage, tossed hither and thither as events change, and often accumulating in vast sargasso seas of obstruction at the entrance of every part of refuge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- The Naval Appropriation bill was reported to the House to-day with an elaborate statement of its provisions by Chairman Foss of the Naval Committee. The bill carries $77,016,635, the largest ever reported to the House from the Committee on Naval Affairs. This is $11,803,718 above the bill of last year and $10,229,395 below the estimates submitted by the Navy Department.

The well-known words, "The shadows lengthening as the vapors rise," probably express man's earliest notion of measuring time. They indicate the germinal idea of the sun-dial. The subject is full of interest, and leads into many curious bye-paths of learning. Who made the first sun-dial is lost in the mists of antiquity.

Tradition has it that Rabelais died saying, ''Je vais chercher le grand Peut-etre." Another story which was known soon after his death tells how the Bishop of Evreux possessed a Galen, annotated by Rabelais. By the side of a passage in which the elder doctor denied the immortality of the soul, the younger and greater had written, "Hie vero se Galenus plumbenm ostendit."

When Charlotte L. Jones of 479 West Twenty-second Street was married to Henry D. Garrett, in October, 1895, in Jersey City, she believed that he was a reputable lawyer, with offices at 280 Broadway. Her father, W.P. Jones, a business man of this city, had taken the trouble to look up his future son-in-law, and what he learned was eminently satisfactory to him, for he made no objection to the wedding.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposition to extend the term of the Presidency of the United States seems now to be taking a serious shape. I sincerely hope that the American people will give this matter more dellibrate thought before adopting that proposition as a form of government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Naval Arch is taken down, and Madison Square knows it no more. It was so remarkable a monument both in purpose and design, that it deserves a better fate than to exist merely in recollections and photographs. This letter is but another word said for it while its memory is yet green; a word which, it is to be hoped, may not be the last one.
COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 20 -- 2:10 A.M. -- Queen Victoria lies at death's door. She was stricken with paralysis to-night.

Andrew Carnegie was seen at his residence, 5 West Fifty-first Street, last night, and was asked for an expression of opinion concerning the rumors of combinations of interests in the steel trade, especially as they related lo the reported consolidation of Federal Steel and Steel and Wire interests, and more particularly in relation to the fact that the Carnegie Company was spoken of in the rumored combinations.

There are two points in the recent rather gloomy discussion of American competition by Lord ROSEBERY, Mr. CHAMBERLANIN. The London Times, and the writers in the quarterlies which are calculated to cause some surprise, when we think how long the study of the problem of trade and industry has engaged the best minds of England.

Architects of this city and from various parts of the Suite met in the rooms of the Architectural League of New York, yesterday, to discuss the provisions of a proposed bill requiring those who wish to practice the profession to undergo an examination and be duly registered if they prove themselves competent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- President Castro of Venezuela has won a victory over the United States. The precipitate return of the Scorpion to La Guayra, ordered by the Navy Department yesterday, is due to the determined attitude of the Venezuelan Government, and leaves that Government in a stronger position.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The remarks of the Rev. Dr. Van de Water at the annual dinner of the Sheriff's first panel jury, us reported in THE TIMES of to-day, call for some comment. It seems to me that the remarks of the Chaplain of Columbia University were Indiscreet, to say the least.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have boon an interested reader of all that THE TIMES has reported of the investigation of hazing at the United States Military Academy, and have greatly admired THE TIMES'S editorials on that subject. The people will be very glad to have the military authorities spurred up to greater efforts to crush out the hazing nuisance, but, for one.

VIENNA, Jan. 1 -- The South African war naturally occupies a considerable space in the reviews of the past year published by the Vienna papers. The most interesting article, from this point of view, is one in the Neue Freie Presse, which appears over the signature of Max Nordau. In this the readers of the paper will, for the first time, perhaps, have found the real truth about the Boer.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Whatever the faults of the British may be, lack of camdor concerning their own weaknesses is not included among them. Depreciation of British enterprise and British commercial and laboring methods has become a hobby with the speakers and newspapers, wherefore the reports of a wave of commercial depression sweeping over Germany and Russia fall on welcoming ears here.
PARIS, Jan. 19 -- The Due de Broglie died at 8:55 o'clock this evening from cancer of the tongue.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- The Coroner to-day held an inquest in the case of Father Riegel, the Roman Catholic priest whose body was found in the hallway of a house on North Eighth Street two weeks ago to-day, stripped of his outer clothing and minus a considerable sum of money and other valuables.

COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL ON RAILROAD RIGHT OF WAY. -- A spark from the locomotive of a train of the Port Jervis, Montlcello and New York Railroad Company, in May, 1898, after a prolonged drought, caused a fire to be kindled on the right of way of the road through a woodland in Deer Park, Orange County, N.Y.

The New York Exchange for Woman's Work, after twenty-three years of labor and waiting, is to own its own home. On the 1st of February it will hold the title deeds for the property which it now occupies at 334 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 -- Our new navy has grown conscious of its fuss and feathers and right to speak up in matters pertaining to nautical fashion and ceremony; and the Navy Department purposes starting the new century and the year by inviting an international conference to discuss the methods and amenities of future maritime ceremonies.

Theoretically, there is now no season in Paris, just as, theoretically, there are no fashions. This means that one section of society is still sulking with the republic. The idea is that it will be inconsolable until the King comes back, and that it disdains all those, mundane vanities in which it has no better leader than a President and his wife.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday did not show a larger total than has been usual of late on the closing day of the week. Practically no change in the course of the market showed, and prices moved along the lines which they assumed earlier in the week. Very few issues showed any activity at all and in none were the ansactions on more than a moderately large scale.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Edwnrd Sycamore, the Captain of the new challenger for the America's Cup, has arrived in London from Glasgow. Heretofore he has refused to be interviewed, but he has at last talked with a representative of The Associated Press, to whom he said:

The Social Reform Club has appointed a joint committee of representatives of labor unions and reform societies to arrange for a conference at 15 University Place on Feb. 17 to start a tenement reform movement. It is proposed to agitate for the improvement of the better class of tenements and the doing away altogether with others.

BOSTON, Jan. 19 -- There was active selling of Amalgamated in Boston, but the price did not get so low as in New York. It closed at $7 1/2 in Boston, a net loss of 4 1/8 for the week. Montana sold up 3 to 313 ex-dividend, later dropping to 304, and closing at 308, which makes a net gain of 1 for the week allowing for the dividend.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- British Army reform, it is learned, will consist chiefly in an endeavor to improve the existing methods of general military training rather than in any attempt to eradicate individual defects. With a more fully developed home army, the administration believes that many of the drawbacks existing at present will gradually disappear, whereas ruthless reform would only result in disorganization and chaos.
The medical men who protested a year or two ago against the airy nothings which then did duty for fashionable headgear dubbed them in their indignation "Neuraigia Traps."

BERLIN, Jan. 19 -- Andrew D. White, the United States Ambassador, and Mrs. White gave a musicale to-night. One hundred and twenty-five persons were present, among them being Princess Anton von Radziwill, Countess von Osten-Sacken, and Baroness von Gersdorff.

In portraits of people taken reading or writing a letter, (a favorite pose.) a crane almost invariably appears -- cranes being trained by the Japanese to play the part of carrier pigeons. Of course, a far more bulky correspondence can be intrusted to them, and one of the most charming sights the country offers is the arrival or departure of such feathered postmen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you allow mo a few lines on two very important subjects? First, the little speech delivered by the Rev. Dr. Van De Water at the Sheriff's jury dinner, and, secondly, the letter of your correspondent. Robert B. Roosevelt, in to-day's issue.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 19 -- The verdict in the Bosschieter case was the principal topic of conversation here to-day. In every shop, in every public place, the fate of Walter J. McAlister, Andrew J. Campbell, and William A. Death was discussed. So far as could be judged from a general expression of opinion, the verdict pleased.

MARSHALL, Mich., Jan. 19 -- Two large mortgages were filed here to-day by the Grand Trunk Western Railway Company. The first, which is for $15,000,000 bearing 4 per cent. interest for fifty years, runs to the Farmers' Loan and Trust Company of New York City and Daniel Wood of Indiana.

The tramp question is becoming a serious one, even in Now Mexico. Tramps are learning that New Mexico has an ideal climate, and they are drawn hither, especially in Winter time, for they share with other people the idea that New Mexico is as warm as Florida.

I wonder that Greeks are so fond of cats -- the National type in Greece being so clearly birdlike. Now, as we all know, Aristotle held that every human being resembles one or the other of the animals. And there is a National face, with its human-animal type. Greek men are often eagle-like; Greek women, mostly parrot-like, or linch-like.

ALBANY, Jan. 19 -- Bishop H.C. Potter and the Rev. William R. Huntington, the pastor of Grace Church, New York, will write protests to Gov. Odell against his recommendation for the abolishment of the State Board of Charities. Such was the information given to-day by one who claimed to know of the intention of the two distinguished divines.

In a beautiful valley of the Adirondacks, protected from the north winds by Sunrise Mount, and within view of Mounts Marcy, McGregor, and White Face, is the Sanitarium Gabriels, maintained by the Sisters of Mercy of the Diocese of Ogdensburg. It is an institution for the treatment of persons suffering from tuberculosis in a curable stage.

We are in the habit of dating the beginning of modern, us distinguished from mediaeval, history at the sixteenth century. But it seems as if, in political history, we had been antedating it by some centuries. It is only with the American Revolution and the French Revolution and the English Reform bill that the existing political era has come into being.

The body of William Cagger of Brooklyn, who died in Richmond, Va., on Thursday, was brought to Brooklyn yesterday. The funeral will be held from St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church to-morrow morning. The burial will be in Holy Cross Cemetery, Flatbush.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The removal by the Governor of Silas W. Burt is a serious blow to the cause of civil service reform. There was probably no person in public office in the United States who had Col. Burt's experience in the administration of the system, or who was so well qualified to administer it.

It was learned in Jersey City yesterday that the Grand Jury devoted several hours on Friday to an investigation of Prosecutor James S. Erwin's course in procuring an indictment of the Freeholders by a previous Grand Jury for exceeding their appropriations, and then going before the court and procuring a nolle in the case.

LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Our aged Queen I fear is dying. To-day she is one day older than her grandfather, George III., who died Jan. 20, 1820, and she has occupied the throne nearly sixty-four years, longer than any other sovereign of England. It is said that the harrowing anxieties and disappointments of the South African war have brought on the present collapse, and one may well believe that this is the truth.
The taking of the census of the Dominion of Canada is to be begun April 1, and is expected to be completed in two weeks.

Chirles B. Macdonald, Chairman of the Nominating Committee of the United States Golf Association, said yesterday that the list of officers for election at the coming annual meeting had been completed and sent to Robert R Kerr, the Secretary, fur official announcement. Mr. Kerr was out or town yesterday, but it was said at his office that the report had been received and would probably be publicly announced to-morrow.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 19 -- Harvard has adopted a new rowing system for the coming season, a system similar in many respects to that used in football last Fall. There will be no head coach. The work of developing a crew will be left to a council of experienced oarsmen, and that council will be responsible for the crew's failure or success.

New York Journalism: How it Had its Rise and What It stands For, was the subject of an address delivered before the students of Columbia University by Francis W. Halsey on Thursday. The lecturer traced the development of the New York newspaper from its earliest beginning to its present state.

The relatively short time in which the case just closed in Paterson was tried, with no slightest suspicion that all the requirements of decency, order, and justice were not satisfied, is something that ought to set the Judges and lawyers or this State thinking very hard.

Madison Square Garden, without its annual Sportsmen's Show, would lose a large part of its attractiveness as a resort for Winter amusement and recreation. That popular exhibit, which has come to be one of the show features in New York life, is still over a month in the future, an it will not open until March 2, but the chief plans are already completed, and some striking novelties have been arranged.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacao, Jan. 19 -- (Via Haytian Cable.) The United States auxiliary cruiser Scorpion, (Lieut. Commander N. Sargent commanding,) has just arrived here. She recently left La Guayra, (the port of Caracas,) and brings the latest news of the Venezuelan trouble. The situation is described as being serious.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 19 -- "Personal Recollections of Abraham Lincoln" was the subject of an address by ex-Senator Dawes before the Men's League to-night. Although Mr. Dawes is now in his eighty-third year, his intellect is as bright and vigorous as ever. The address partook rather of the nature of an informal talk, as the audience gathered about Mr. Dawes, who was seated in a large armchair before a glowing open fire.

BRISTOL Jan. 19 -- The New cup defender being built at Bristol will not only be an improvement over the Columbia in powerful boat, and of a type with no radical departure from that which it has more than once been proved can carry a large sail area, can be easily driven to high speed, and is of a seaworthiness that is faultless.

The principal feature of the past week on the local bowling alleys was the quadble victory of the Metropolitan team in the American National tournament, which moved them from second to first place in that series. They have only two more games to play, and will probably who both of them, and so obtain first prize in the tournament.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just come across an article by one "Prof. P.B. Barringer" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the 29th ult. on "Negro Culture" that attracted my attention. Not that it contained any brilliancy or evolved any new ideas, but because of the stopendous asinine conceit and cruelty that leads any one to air such views as these.

Musty old bank ledgers would seem to be about the last resort of a professional romancer in search of material. Yet properly used they have their share. Those of the Bowery Savings Bank, for a single example, fairly bristle with them. That some of these have been revealed is due to the policy of President Hicks.

In Persia, on a morning after the vermin had been particularly vigorous, I said something caustic about getting back to God's country. An Armenian, who had reposed in utter comfort in the same caravanserle, heard it and smiled. Being an Armenian, he hated the Persians, probably. Incidentally, the Persian reciprocates.
The imports of dry goods and general merchandise for the week were valued at $10,983,978. The imports of specie amounted to $28,546 and the exports of specie to $2,780,681.

WEST POINT, Jan. 19 -- The Congressional investigation of the West Point Military Academy has borne fruit sooner than expected. To-night, when the Congressmen were hurrying their inquiries to a termination, the cadets of all four classes held a meeting in Grant Hall and unanimously decided to abolish exercising and hazing of every form, as well as the practice of "calling out" fourth-class men.

I suppose that all will admit that it is most desirable in the interest of maritime nations that there should be a ship canal through Central America. When the Clayton-Bulwer treaty was agreed to we possessed certain territories in South America, namely. British Honduras, a perfectly valueless possession, and we claimed a treaty protectorate over the Mosquito Coast, where a town called Greytown had been built which seemed to belong to no one.

President Feitner of the Department of Taxes and Assessments announced yesterday that the list of taxpayers assessed for taxes on personal property would not be given out for publication until Monday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On viewing the needs of the nether social world and the pains taken for their alleviation by trained workers of social problems, we cannot full to admire and praise the zeal, the devotion, and, within limits, the success demonstrated.

"The Climbers" owes its vitality to the superficial verity of some of its pictures of social life, the strength and interest of some of it's episodes, and its scenic ingenuity. Its first act, all except the climax is worthy of Augier. That great Frenchman never devised a cleverer satirical scene than the opening episode of this new play, or a more humorous passage than the sale of the dresses.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the proposed amendment to a city charter, how would to inclu an amendment to the following effect:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Would you be Kind enough to inform your many readers about the rights of property holders in reference to the trespass of telephone and other electric companies, who order men to go on the roofs of houses to lay or string wires and make repairs for their system?

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19 -- Charles H. Jones, President of the York Southern Railroad Company, has issued a call for the stockholders of that company at York on Feb. 2 for the purpose of considering an agreement of consolidation with the Baltimore and Lehigh Railroad. The question will be decided by a vote of the stockholders.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The paragraph in to-day's TIMES respecting the charitable bequests of the late Samuel Lewis is somewhat contradictory of the contemptuous tone pervading the biographical sketch which appeared in your paper of Monday. The spirit which so disposes of nearly one-fourth of a large estate is scarcely in consonance with that of the "flinty hearted," usurious personage such as you described Mr. Lewis to be.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 19 -- The project for building a driveway along the base of the Palisades, as planned by the Palisades Commission, has developed a still greater scheme, which may result in the creation of the most magnificent boulevard in the country. The wealthy men of the Tuxedo Park Association and prominent citizens living on the west bank of the lower Hudson River are interested, and definite steps have already been taken.

The funeral of Murray Hall, the woman who for more than thirty years posed as a man, was held from her home, 148 Sixth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. There were about twenty persons on the sidewalk in front of the house at 3 o'clock, when the body was taken from the house. The burial was in Mount Olivet Cemetery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why is it that a man thinks he has as much right to expectorate on the floor of a car, in the face of a disgusted public of presumably decent people, as he has in the privacy of his dressing room?
Judge ROSE of the High Court of Justice of Ontario died at Toronto yesterday morning after an illness of a few days, aged fifty-six.

An interesting story from the life of the late Count Blumenthal is related in the German weekly Nation. In July, 1800, Gen. von Blumenthal had, as known, written a letter to his wife from the seat of war, and had confided it to the Prussian military post. This field post was captured by the Austrians, and Blumenthal's letter appeared in Viennese papers.

The jury which has been considering the case brought by Christian Bilnn, in the Supreme Court, against Julia Schwarz for the recovery of property at Eightieth Street and Broadway, which it is alleged he conveyed to her while he was insane, announced to Justice Truax yesterday that it could not agree.

Nothing but distrust of the American character could have brought ex-President CLEVENLAND into his present frame of mind. It is permissible to hope that our administration of the Philippine Islands may prove to be a rich blessing to the native population and of no disadvantage to ourselves.

The Taxpayers' Alliance, the North Side, Board of Trade, and citizens of the Bronx gave a dinner last night in honor of the Charter Revision Commision, in the Schnorer Clubhouse, at One Hundred and Sixty-third Street and Third Avenue. Judge Ernest Hall presided, and there were about 100 persons present.

The male among most animals is the more handsomely clothed, which perhaps, we may attribute to sexual selection. The gray hens in Spring select their mates, after an amusing competition, in which the black cocks dance, chuckle, spread their plumage, and behave in a very ostentatious manner.
To the Editor of The New York Times: A very interesting item of news came to me to-day. I think the good people of New York ought to know about it, so I drop you these lines.

LYNN, Mass., Jan. 19 -- The Rev. J.H. Van Buren, for the past ten years rector of St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Lynn; for three years Archdeacon of the Lowell Diocese, and for five years one of the Bishop's examining chaplains, has announced that he will resign his rectorship to respond to a call for missionaries to Porto Rico.

The service of the summons and complaint in the action brought by Caspar Becker, a wealthy resident of Philadelphia, as guardian ad litem of his eighteen-year-old son, John Bernhard Becker, for an annulment of the youth's marriage with Rosa Gutman. who had been a servant in the Becker household, was yesterday set aside by Justice Beach in the Supreme Court.

There was the usual plenty of musical entertainment yesterday. In the afternoon the third matinee concert of the Boston Symphony Orchestra took place at Carnegie Hall. Despite the bitter mood of the weather there was a large audience. The programme consisted of Tschalkowsky's fifth symphony, Cesar Franck's symphonic variations for piano and orchestra, and Liszt's symphonic poem, "Les Preludes."

SHANGHAI, Dec. 1 -- When merchants who handle the foreign trade for China strike their balance sheets at the end of the year, the showing in the aggregate will hardly reflect the depressed condition of general business. In the first half of the year imports were larger than for any corresponding period.
The programme for the sixth week of the opera season at the Metropolitan is as follows:

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 19. -- A majority of the members of the legislative committee which has investigated the charges preferred by David McCall, a Democratic member of the House, against Congressman Joseph W. Bailey, who is a candidate for United States Senator at the election to occur next Tuesday, to-day completed their report, recommending the adoption of the following resolutions:

I feel confident that I can count on the courtesy of the press, as the only medium available to me, to enable me in express to the people of London my heartfelt and sincare thanks for the generous reception accorded to me on my arrival in the metropolis, which touched me more than I can describe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In "Workingman's" communication in your issue of the 13th inst., and in his previous article in regard to the non-attendance of workingmen on church services, he advances three distinct propositions, as follows:

In the hands of an able surgeon -- as Prof. E. Bergmann illustrated before the Association of German Naturalists and Physicians in 1899 -- the X rays become a most precious means of exploration. The growth of the bones, from birth till matured age, could be studied with their aid, and the various causes which retard growth (rachitism, tuberculosis) or produce midgets could be ascertained.

Sir, as I look back upon my sensations during the anxious minutes which I, in common with some 2,000 others, passed when there was an alarm of fire at the Grand Theatre at Islington, yesterday, I recall a symptom which, it seems to me, may have some scientific interest. Twice in my life have I been horribly frightened, but the symptoms have been quite different on the two occasions.
LONDON, Jan. 19 -- Discounts to-day were easy and difficult to maintain, in view of the plenitude of money and foreign competition for bills.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 -- Strength characterized the opening of the market, with Philadelphia Electric the most active stock. In view of the assessment on Monday, the stock showed surprising buoyancy and continued strong. It opened at 6 and kept this figure throughout the day, except for one small transaction.

LIVERPOOL, Jan. 19 -- The White Star Line steamer Cymric, Capt. Lindsay, from New York, Jan. 9, for this port, which arrived at Queenstown yesterday morning and proceeded here, was in collision in the Mersey this morning with the British steamer Carib Prince.

Nothing more stupid, illiberal, or better calculated to set every one by the ears than the so-called reciprocal policy was yet invented. In order to obtain an undue, and often unmerited, advantage over a competitor, adherents of this principle are quite willing to set all their neighbors quarleling and care not a jot so long as they get their pound of flesh.

Another way in which the aristocracy has been affected by the progress of the century has been not precisely in manners or morals as in that intermediate country which lies on the border line between manners and morals. Manners, strictly speaking, have perhaps rather suffered in being democratized.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to me that the blame for the shameful proceedings at West Point should be placed upon the officers in command rather than upon the cadets, who have been allowed to run riot after the manner of boys of their social class.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The communication in yesterday's TIMES, signed "A Plain Citizen." meets, in my opinion, a ready response in the thoughts of many stockholders of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, who have been kept in the dark as to the effect upon their Investments of the recently reported transfer of the control to J.P. Morgan and others.

Who shall wonder that our past indulgent treatment of the vagrant has had the effect of perpetuating and multiplying this class of social parasite? The dictum of wise Sir Matthew Hale, uttered just two and a half centuries ago, is irrefutably true:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I do not think your obituary notice on the death of Sam Lewis, the London mcney lender, published in your issue of the 14th inst., is written either in a spirit of fairness or generosity. At all events, part of the statements you record against him are devold of truth.
M. Warley Platzek of the Tammany Hall investigating committee declared last night that the committee had not ceased preparing evidence for the District Attorney or in sending him information.

Amid universal expressions of satisfaction by the exhibitors, and with the largest attendance of the week, the Bicycle Show came to an end last night in Madison Square Garden. The crowd became noticeable early in the afternoon, and in the evening the throng surrounded some of the more attractive booths three and four deep.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial opposing a change in the present four-year Presidential term it might be argued further that the short-term idea is truly American in essence. It represents the "eternal vigilance" which is the price of our liberty and of our rights, and it puts into effect it our body politic that principle of constant regeneration which is inseparable from life and progress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an editorial of Jan. 15 about second Presidential terms, you justly discriminate between a President's desire for re-election by the people and his desire for renomination by the politicians. The Presidential question aside, what a pity it is that any of our officers need renomination at all!

CHICAGO, Jan. 19 -- President John Lambert of the American Steel and Wire Company said to-day that he had no knowledge of the reported purchase by the Federal Steel Company interests of a controlling interest in the stock of the Steel and Wire Company. "I know nothing about the Federal Steel Company having acquired stock in our company," said President Lambert.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- At least two of the three men convicted of the murder of Jenme Bosschieter will be called upon to testify at the trial of George J. Kerr, the remaining prisoner, which, it is generally believed, will begin a week from to-morrow. These witnesses will be Death and Campbell.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Capt. Green of the baseball team has announced that ex-Capt. Arthur Hillebrand has been chosen coach for the baseball team, and that he will arrive here about April 1 to take entire charge of the candidates. Cage practice will begin about Feb. 20, and Catcher William Clarke of the Boston league team will arrive here in March to assist in the preliminary practice.

NIAGARA FALLS. N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Another river fatality must be added to the already horrible record Niagara has made, the result of boating accidents above the falls. The latest victim is John Weisen, a machinist, aged about thirty-five years, married, who leaves a wife and three children to mourn his death and his foolhardiness in going duck hunting on such a dangerous stream as the Upper Niagara in mid-winter.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- George W. McGinnes, a wealthy retired merchant of this place, was found frozen to death in the garden of his home this morning. He was eighty years old. For several years his mind had been deranged.

VIENNA, Jan. 21. -- The announcement of the dangerous illness or Queen Victoria caused a feeling of consternation in Vienna. Emperor Francis Josoph, who was profoundly moved, sent messages to the British Embassy yesterday for news. Victoria, who, if the last news I hear is correct, is in the article of death." He then prayed as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- A bill will be introduced by Merton E. Lewis of Monroe to relieve mortgages from taxation, and it is known that Gov. Odell will sign it immediately if the Legislature, in addition, passes the proposed bills to tax the surplus and undivided profits of trust companies, banks, and insurance companies.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Our money market still wallows in the slough of cheap credits, and nothing the Bank of England can do lifts it for more than an hour or two. Last Wednesday the Stock Exchange payments produced a momentary shortage, and about u2,000,000 was borrowed at the Bank for three or four days at 3 1/2 per cent.
"It is a duty of a Magistrate to save and not make criminal," said Magistrate Crane at Yorkville Court yesterday, when by his convincing arguments he induced a complainant to have mercy on two boys.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- The long-expected duel between the Count de lubersac and Baron Robert de Rothschild was fought with swords at 11 o'clock this morning, on Baron Edmond de Rothschild's estate at Boulogne-sur-Selne. The carriages with the principals, seconds, doctors, and a few friends arrived there from Paris shortly before 11.

The bill recently introduced in the House by Representative LOVERING of Massachusetts, a member of the Committee on Banking and Currency, to provide greater elasticity for the currency, can hardly receive much attention at this late date, but it will at least serve to direct public opinion and the opinion of the House toward a real need in our currency system.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- It is learned here that Emperor Francis Joseph has presented James A. Bailey, the American circus proprietor, with a gold cigar case set with diamonds, rubies, and sapphires, accompanied by an autopraph letter.

YONKEES,N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The complainant in an assault case which came before City Judge Kellogg this morning told a somewhat startling tale, and would have told more had the Court not cut him short and turned him over to the police, that they might obtain the details and work upon the case.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Jan. 20. -- The little town of Wathena, Kan., just across the Missouri River, is in a panic over the wrecking of the State bank, whose cashier. Frank Harpster, blew out his brains and thus escaped lynching at the hands of the townspeople, more than 230 of whom are rendered penniless by the wild-cat speculations of the cashier with the bank's funds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Senate Committee on Finance was in session the greater part of to-day, making an effort to complete consideration of the War Revenue Reduction bill in order to be able to present its report to-morrow. It did not succeed, but the work was so nearly completed that it is believed one or two more meetings will suffice for that purpose.
COWES, Isle of Wiht. Jan. 21. -- 5:15 A.M. -- The Queen is in a comatose condition, and is regarded as passing away. She is unconscious.
Special missionary services for children wore held in thirteen Episcopal churches in and about this city yesterday afternoon.

It is proposed to erect an eighteen-story hotel on the site of the old Hotel Brunswick, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street. The task has been undertaken by the Brunswick Hotel Company, of which Richard Olney, ex-United States Secretary of State; Oliver Ames of Boston, and Charles T. Barney of 101 East Thirtyeighth Street are the Directors.

HAVANA, Jan. 20. -- John Sheridan, who has been in charge of the Money Order Department of the Havana Post Office, was arrested to-day and formally accused of the theft of $1,300, $1,235 cash and a sixty-fivedollar check, sent from the Postmaster at Guantanamo Dec. 6. He confessed his guilt and admits having destroyed the check.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 20. -- There was considerable comment here to-day over the discovery that Charles Crawford, the negro who shot his wife, Sarah, and then himself at his brother's home, at 232 Central Avenue, last night, and was pronounced dead was taken to Mullin's morgue, was there found by Joseph Murphy, an assistant, to be alive.

OMAHA, Jan. 20. -- There is a new suspect in the Cudahy kidnapping case. This time it is Frank Sherekleff, alias Eddie Burke, the outlaw who robbed William F. Pollock on a train near Missouri Valley, Iowa, in 1892 of $15,000 worth of diamonds. Some time in November Sherekleff was paroled from the Iowa Penitentiary, to which he had been sentenced for seventeen years, and is said to have been in Omaha early in December.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The London papers this morning review her Majesty's long and illustrious reign, and dilate upon the wonderful influence she wielded in European politics for so many years. "We all know," says The Daily Mail, "that there is danger of losing perhaps the greatest personal force of our times."

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Frank Britton, a well-known insurance agent of this city, has brought suit against a chemical company which manufactures a hair vigor. He asks $25,000 damages for alleged injuries.

Expressing himself as strongly in favor of woman's rights, in the past, the present, and the future, Mark Twain, at the annual meeting of the members of the Hebrew Technical School for Girls, last night said that he believed that if women had the right of suffrage such corruption as is said to exist in this city would be swept away.

After more than a week of almost continued reaction, the stock market will open to-day for business in a much stronger position, technically, than at any time since election. Weakly margined accounts and those built on the "pyramiding" system no longer threaten.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When Grover Cleveland penned, in the seclusion of his Princeton library, that thoughtful but rather sober-keyed speech which he delivered before the Holland Society last evening he should have taken counsel of the eminent descendant of the Dutch race who is the author of "Fisherman's Luck" as to its possible effect on his audience.

The drug store of J.L. House, at Albany Avenue and St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, is at present a wreck, as the result of a runaway. Opposite the drug store, on Albany Avenue, is the St. John's Roman Catholic Home for Boys. This is surrounded by grounds and situated on the top of a little hill.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 21. -- Yesterday at Osborne, hedged around with intense secrecy, began with a touching scene. Amid the bright sunshine, in marked contrast to the gloomy skies of Saturday, there drove out from the palace grounds a carriage containing wreaths for the tomb of Prince Henry of Battenberg, in the little church at Whipplngham, about ten minutes' ride from the royal residence.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- Business on the Boerse during the week was stagnant, but prices were fairly firm. Outsiders showed less inclination to sell shares, and the volume of business sunk to low proportions. The Boerse failed to respond to the violent fluctuations in New York, which were the cause here of renewed reserve regarding American railroads, of which the German holding has lessened.

The daily papers printed a dispatch on Thursday from Washington to the effect that the Post Office Committee of the House of Representatives had reported the Post Office bill carrying appropriations for the current year, but that they had declined to report any appropriation for even the maintenance of the postal tubular system now in use in this city.

So far as they have come to hand, the results of the Reichsrath elections recently held in Austria and Bohemia show that the status of the retiring Parliament has not been altered in a way that can promise a settlement of the question which has distracted the dual monarchy, and which, combined with nearer antagonisms of race and language, had rendered legislation impossible.

-- According to the head of the Bureau of Records of the Brooklyn Health Board, the excess of deaths over births shown year after year in the reports of the Brooklyn statisticians is due simply to the fact that while every death of necessity finds a place in the tables, a considerable number of births are never recorded.

The Coppers' Union has started an agitation against a bill which the Brewers' Association has introduced in the National Senate to do away with the issuing of separate revenue stamps for one-sixth, one-eighth, and one-quarter barrels of beer. The association says the multiplication of sizes leads to unnecessary trouble and expense, which would be avoided if only barrels and half-barrels were sold.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- As an offset to the many and varied bulleting sent out by the "press bureau" of the Ship Subsidy bill, a number of Senators and other political leaders opposed to the measure to-night joined in issuing an analysis of the bill, showing, as they understand the measure, to whom the subsidies will go in the event of its passage.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- It is probable that the Legislature will discuss this week the proposition to take away from the Lunacy Commission the power it possesses at present to audit the bills of its extensive bureau.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Over 2,000 persons saw the Atlantic City LifeSaving Crow rescue Capt. Bermain Sharp of Dorchester, N.J., and his crew of three men. Marc Sharp, a brother; Jacob Willis of Atlantic City, and Joseph P. Harris of Augusta, Ga., from the two-masted schooner A.P. Coleman, which struck on the bar off the inlet about 4 o'clock this afternoon.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- The following is the substance of an interview with the Prince of Wales, which is to appear shortly in a London magazine. There is every reason to believe it is perfectly genuine, and it is understood to be the first interview in which his Royal Highness has been directly quoted:

We learn from last Thursday's telegrams that England has received through The London Times a "bitter invocation to Great Britain not to give anti-English Americans an opportunity for exultation over her surrender" respecting the Senate's amendments to the Nicaragua Canal convention.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- There is every reason to believe that the Senate Cities Committee will report favorably the New York Police bill this coming week, for the Republican leaders have concluded to have the bill on Mayor Van Wyck's desk on Jan. 25.

The protest and appeal of the Merchants' Association of this city in the matter of the pneumatic tube service for the transmission of mails within the city deserves the careful attention of every Representative not only of this State but of the entire country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Senate will take up the Legislative, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill Monday, as soon as possible after convening. There is little in the bill that ordinarily would create debate, but it does not seem improbable that several days may be required to act on it.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Throughout the United Kingdom yesterday was a Sunday of auxiety and suspense. No one in England outside the circle of the Court knew the jeal condition of the Queen or the nature of her disease. The bulletins threw but little light on the universal question whether death was imminent.

It is gratifying to note that the contractor for the New York underground rapid transit road is experimenting with a view to minimizing the nuisance of vibration and noise attending the running of trains in the tunnel. For this purpose he is now constructing a section of 1,200 feet of track to be tested experimentally.

Yale and Princeton opened the local intercollegiate hockey season last week, and games will now continue at short intervals until the middle of March. The feature of the season still so young has been the disqualification of the Columbia hockey team by the Faculty Commit on on Athletics at the university.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the prospect of the much-talked-of bill reducing the revenue tax being passed by Congress, permit me to say a few words in favor of the far more rational course advocated by your valuable paper.

The following is a list of bonds which do not appear in their proper alphabetical order in the "Complete Bond Quotation List," on Pages 4 and 5, but are hero so arranged. Opposite each is placed the name of the system under which they are given in the table referred to:

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Emperor William and the Duke of Connaught, with their suites, who left Berlin Saturday evening, arrived hero last night shortly after 6 o'clock, and were received by the Prince of Wales, who came here from Osborne House for the purpose.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- The proprietors of many private employment agencies are charged with evil practices in the conduct of the business by the Superintendent of the New York State Free Employment Bureau, in New York City, in his annual report to the Legislature. He says:

George Musson, the cashier in William Berri's Sons' carpet warehouse, on Fulton Street, Brooklyn, who lives at 114 South Elliot Place, Brooklyn, is at present looking for a witness upon whom he can call in bringing charges against Patrolman John Berry of the Classon Avenue Police Station, who he says insulted his wile last Thursday.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

A solution of the troubles at the Military Academy has been reached by the action of the cadets now in attendance. Their voluntary agreement among themselves to abolish all forms of hazing out of respect, as they avow, for the public opinion so strongly expressed in the last few months is creditable to them, and was rightly recognized by the Chairman of the congressional committee.

Most of the games in the local bowling tournaments which were postponed on account of the absence of a number of the prominent local teams at the Chicago tournament two weeks ago will be decided during the coming week, and at least five of the local leagues -- the Columbia, Harlem, North Side, American National, and Greater New York -- series will come to an end for the season.

YONKERS, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- Elias Masuras, the Greek who contended when he rushed into Police Headquarters with a big gash, under his left eye a few days ago that an attempt had been made upon his life because he would not obey an injunction by Anarchists to kill a prominent American, did not stick to his story on the witness stand to-day.

Mayor Van Wyck pounded his desk with his fist yesterday and glared at Julian D. Fairchild, one of the East River Bridge Commissioners. In return Commissioner Fairchild pounded his fist on the Mayor's desk and from the height of over six feet glared down on Mayor Van Wyck. This incident happened near the end of one of the most spirited conferences held in the Mayor's office.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- Boston trading was fair in volume, with heavy selling of Amalgamated Copper a marked feature. Tube also was sold freely, and there was good volume of trading in Chicago, Burlington and Quincy. Quincy mining fell 9, to 165, on the declaration of a $3 semi-annual dividend where $4 was declared six months ago and $5 a year ago.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 21 -- According to Le Petit Bleu, bubonic plague is raging among the British troops in Cape Colony, and many deaths that are attributed to enteric fever and dysentery are really due to plague.

PASSAIC, N.J., Jan. 21 -- Dr. George T. Rundle was injured by a train on the Lackawanna Railroad at Delawanna last night. He was taken to the Pussaic Hospital, where he died this morning. Dr. Rundle drove to Delawanna to respond to the call of a patient. He started to return and drove rapidly along the road which leads from Washington Avenue to the river road.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Jan. 21 -- The Rev. Charles Stelzie will deliver a series of sermons on the workingman and the Church, with the causes and the extent of the gulf between them, beginning next Sunday evening. In gathering his facts he sent out 200 letters to laborers and labor union leaders asking these questions:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senator and Mrs. Hanna gave their first dinner party of the year last evening, when their guests were the Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Gage, the Attorney General and Mrs. Griggs, the Postmaster General and Mrs. Smith, Senator and Mrs. Wetmore, Senator and Mrs. Feraker, Senator and Mrs. Fairbanks, Senator Depew, Mr. and Mrs. Merriam, and Miss Phelps.

The Hotel Virginia property, covering the small block bounded by Broadway and Eighth Avenue. Fifty-eighth Street and the Grand Circle, purchased recently by the Central Realty Bond and Trust Company, has been resold by that corporation to Mrs. Mary A. Fitzgerald of Litchfield, Conn. The consideration was a little less than $300,000.
FRED P. WILSON, a prominent business man of Malone, N. Y., and ex-Sheriff of Franklin County, died suddenly at his home; there yesterday of angina pectoris.

Whan the police believe to be another case of murder by "knock-out" drops was revealed yesterday upon investigation into the death of Margaret Travis, the domestic employed in the St. Luke's Home, who was found dead in a hotel room with Clarence A. Davis, to whom she was engaged to be married.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Assemblyman Remsen was under no misapprehension when he introduced his bill repealing the chapter of the transportation laws relating to canal corporations. He was perfectly well aware that his bill repealed the whole chapter, including the clause which prohibits any railroad company from owning stock in a canal corporation.

WICHITA, Kan., Jan. 21 -- Mrs. Carrie Nation came back to Wichita to-day after her recent incarceration, under a smallpox quarantine, and the net result of ten minutes of work by her this afternoon are two wrecked saloons, the pieces of which are being sold to-night for souvenirs. Mrs. Nation was assisted by Mrs. Julia Evans, Mrs. Lucy Wilholt and Mrs. Lydia Muntz, all of the local Women's Christian Temperance Union organization.

Four men were seriously burned and otherwise injured by an explosion of gas which occurred late last night in the excavation for the rapid transit tunnel in Fourth Avenue, near Twenty-second Street. The Injured are:

Through trains of the Fifth Avenue and Brighton Beach Divisions of the elevated system of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company were running over the bridge yesterday. The first through train crossed the bridge at 10 o'clock. This service will be continued every day between 10 A.M. and 4 P.M., but will not be in operation during the rush hours.

The annual election of officers of the Republican club last night was very closely contested. General Henry E. Tremain defeating ex-Judge W.M.K. Olcott by two votes. The best of feeling prevailed, and when the result was announced at midnight Mr. Olcott paid a glowing tribute to his successful opponent.

GEORGE WASHINGTON was born on Feb. 11, Old Style, in the year 1732. In the present year and century the difference between Old Style and New Style is thirteen days.
