The anniversary of WASHINGTON'S birth, therefore, falls on the 24th of February, not on the 22d, which the laws of every State but one in the Union have made a holiday for its commemoration.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 21 -- County Prosecutor Emley said to-day that he would place on trial as soon as possible George Kerr. jointly indicted with McAlister, Campbell, and Death for the murder of Jennie Bosschieter. The Prosecutor said, however, that the civil calendar in Judge Nixon's court would first have to be cleared before Kerr's case can be taken up.

"The Night of the Fourth" is the pyrotechnically suggestive title of a new variety farce performed with much vivacity and appreciable skill to the delight of a big crowd at Hemmerstein's Victoria last night. When n piece of this description is dull it is speedily condemned, but when one is as lively as this it will generaly run through a season profitably.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 21 -- No action was taken at the Democratic legislative caucus for the selection of a Senatorial candidate to-night. The caucus adjourned until 10 o'clock to-morrow morning.

HERLIN, Jan. 21 -- In consequence of attending the obsequies of the late Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar, a number of persons of high rank contracted the measles in the infected schloss. The Duke Recent of Meeklenburg-Schwerin and the Duchess, who is a daughter of the late Grand Duke, are down with the disease, as is also the young Grand Duke of Saxe-Weimar himself.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 21 -- The manager of the University of Pennsylvania gymnastic team returned home from Princeton to-day, whither he had gone to arrange a meet with the Orange and Black. There was a possibility of having both Yale and Princeton in joint meets with the University of Pennsylvania, but as both these colleges wanted the latter part of February, it was impossible to suitably arrange for both.
The London Saturday Review undoubtedly reflects the feeling of a considerable part of the English people in the following remarks in its issue of Jan. 12:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whatever charges foreigners may make against the Anglo-Saxon, they must at least admit that he is willing enough to acknowledge his own faults. The most virulent of Continental newspapers and speakers could not fulminate more bitterly against England and America than do some of the journals and public men of the two great English-speaking countries.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Gov. Odell to-night decided not to interfere in the case of Lorenzo Priori, the convicted murderer of Vincenzo Garagusi, and the convicted man must die.

The Board of Managers of the State Charities Aid Association, of which Prof. George F. Canfield is President, dissenting from the suggestion implied in the statement attributed to Gov. Odell that the society's oversight of State charitable institutions is sufficient and that further supervision by the State Board of Charities is unnecessary, adopted as an official statement of their views, at a meeting yesterday, the following:

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Controller Edward C. Knight to-night reported to the Legislature that property to the value of $723,344,832 is exempted from taxation in the cities of the State. This includes Government, State, county, and city real estate, churches, parsonages and cemeteries, schools, charitable institutions, and real estate purchased with pension money.

It will lead to errors of judgment and perhaps to grave mistakes of policy if the Washington authorities should take Germany quite seriously in its ambitious plans to cripple this country and restrict our industrial growth and commercial expansion. Primarily, the Germans do not understand that behind what they are pleased to regard as an intolerable aggressiveness are resources and advantages with which equal competition is impossible.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Post Office Committee of the House to-day reported the Postal Appropriation bill. The appropriation for pneumatic tubes was left out. The report that the bill was reported last week probably arose from the fact that the committee made its decision to exclude the tubular appropriation last Tuesday.

MANILA, Jan. 21 -- The act establishing the Department of Public Instruction was passed by the Philippine Commission unanimously to-day, after a debate between Commissioner Moses and Judge Taft (President of the commission) over the section permitting religious instruction in school-houses.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- In the absence of Leader Alids at to-night's session of the Assembly, Mr. Kelsey of Livingston assumed the leadership.

The Knickerbocker bowlers not only two of their three games with the Claremont team in the North Side League tournament on Pump's North Side Palace alleys last night, but also made a now high team score for the tournament of 967. The scores follow:

St. George Kempson of Metuchen, N.J., editor of The New York Insurance Journal, who has been in the Middlesex County Jail since November for contempt of court, was yesterday taken to Chancery Chambers, Jersey city, where argument was heard as to his further punishment. Kempson was married in 1882.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Senate in executive session to-day confirmed the nomination of James S. Harlan to be Attorney General of Porto Rico. The final vote was reached after a discussion of more than two hours' duration, and when announced stood 43 to 21 in favor of confirmation.

New BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- Thomas Davis of Keasbey, near Perth Amboy, has been arrested for the murder of John Welland of Keasbey, who died on Saturday from concussion of the brain, brought on it is claimed, by a fall following a blow from Davis. Weiland, who was about thirty-five years of age, was playing pool at the Catherine Inn. Keasbey, on New Year's night, when he accidentally struck Davis with his cue.

With the exception of the large dance at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Sloane, there were only a few receptions, luncheons, and bridge whist clubs meeting in town yesterday. Monday is never a very brilliant day, and even the opera was not as well attended as usual. The funeral of Mrs. George Henry Warren in the morning was held at Trinity Chapel and there were many present, notwithstanding the early hour.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Assemblyman Morgan to-night introduced two hills repealing the law prohibiting Brooklyn from entering Suffolk County for wator. One hill repeals the special act of 1893, and the other the provision of the Creator New York charter bearing upon this act.

If Fifth Avenue from Twenty-third Street to Forty-second has become the quarter where the dealers in objects of the fine arts have congregated, a similar movement into Fourth Avenue has taken place on the part of dealers in antiquities and bric-a-brac. Almost all the old furniture and old jewelry men, vendors of pottery and oil paintings, brasses and old bronzes, have drawn together on or near Fourth Avenue between Twenty-third Street and the tunnel.

NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 21 -- Prof. Elisha Gray of Highland Park, Chicago, was taken ill in the street and died at Newtonville last night. He had been visiting Arthur J. Mundy and his brother in Newtonville, and had made arrangements to go to Maine to-day. During the afternoon yesterday Prof. Gray complained of feeling ill and consulted Dr. Talbot, who told him he had a slight acidity of the stomach.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Under a report from Bangkok, dated Nov. 18, 1900, Consul General Hamilton King sends all interesting account of the extraordinary living habits of the Slamese. Mr. King says that one who has never been outside of the United States can hardly form in his imagination a picture of what living means to the plain people of Slam.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21 -- The will of Bishop Wigger was admitted to probate to-day. The entire estate, both real and personal, is left to Archbishop Corrigan of New York. Bishop McDonnell of Brooklyn, and Bishop McQuaid of Rochester, as joint tenants. They are also named as executors.

At the opening of the market for outside securities yesterday there was exceedingly light demand for stock, and this condition prevailed to the close of the day. With two or three exceptions among the low-priced stocks no issue showed even moderate activity, the dullness being more marked than on any recent day.

There are barely five weeks more of this session of Congress, and this means not more than twenty-five days for general legislation, including all the appropriation bills. In these circumstances, if the honest opponents of the outrageous Subsidy bill cannot use up all the available time in pertinent discussion of its innumerable faults and vicious provisions we greatly underrate their powers.

Time was when the oyster business in this town was, for the amount of capital invested, a good paying one. It paid so well, in fact, that capital was attracted to it by a number of small investors. Sharp rivalry had the usual result. Profits were cut down, and it became hard work for even the best managers to get along and make money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- In all probability something definite will be received shortly throwing light on what is happening in Venezuela. Lieut. Commander Sargent reports that he is going to Curacao, nominally to coal. It is suggested at the State and Navy Departments that he is going there so that he may send dispatches without fear of their being tampered with by the Venezuelan Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The abolition of the canteen on Government reservations may prove embarrassing in a way that has just occurred to some officers at the War Department. There are tenants of the Government in the hotel business both at West Point and Fort Monroe, one at the former place and three at the latter.

For the first time in the history of the tea trade in America, trailing in tea for future delivery was made yesterday at the New York Coffee Exchange. R. St. G. Walker, Superintendent of the Exchange, conducted the first call, and William Mitchell, a coffee man. had the honor of making the first bid.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- The scenes about the Mansion House yesterday exemplified the intensity of the common anxiety which has made all interests here akin. Thousands gathered there as the day wore on, and nothing could be more impressive than the profound silence with which the announcements of the alternating phases of the crisis were heard.

While twenty passengers slept peacefully in a rear car of the Federal Express yesterday morning, their car, the St. George, slipped backward on its track aboard the transport ferryboat Maryland and hung suspended over the waters of the North River. The Maryland was on her way from the Harlem River terminal of the New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The torpedo boat Bailey has come to grief again. The accident which disabled her in this case was peculiar. While lying at Newport, about to undertake a trial trip, the intense cold froze the water in her boilers, bursting a number of the tubes. The boat has been sent back to New York for repairs, and the trial board has been ordered home.

The tenth annual meeting of the Consumers' League of the City of New York was held in the Assembly Hall, 156 Fifth Avenue, yesterday afternoon. The large hall was crowded with the women members of the league and their friends, only a few men being among the audience.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, British West Indies, Jan. 21 -- The arrivals to-day from Venezuela confirm the critical state of affairs in that republic. A former Venezuelan Minister asserts that the politicians at Caracas are making a determined raid on the Bermudez Asphalt Company. He adds that they tried it before, on a modest scale, squeezing $30,000 out of the company, when the United States Minister, Francis B. Loomis protested and stopped further action of this description.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 21 -- Junior Promenade week started in to-day with the usual festivities that make the week the climax of the year's social life at the university. There are over 900 guests of the undergraduates in town, and apartments at the principal hotels are at a premium.

Edward Gardner, the Passaic Club billiard expert, threw a decided surprise into the billiard camp at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, last night, when the championship tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players was resumed Gardner mot the former winner of many hard-fought matches.
PARIS, Jan. 21 -- The dispatches from Osborne are eagerly followed here. The evening newspapers publish more frequent editions, which are quickly sold.
ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- Gov. Odell sent this message to the Legislature to-night:

At the trial of Police Captain Herlihy, which was resumed yesterday before the Police Commissioners, five witnesses for the defense testified that Capt. Herlihy did not use any abusive language toward the Rev. Robert L. Paddock on the night of April 26, 1900, as has been alleged by Mr. Paddock.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- At the opening of to-day's session of the Senate the Chaplain, in his invocation, referred with deep feeling to the condition of Queen Victoria.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have carefully read the article signed "Theatregoer" published in your columns of Jan. 17, and would like to add my protest also concerning the box office nuisance now so rampant in this city.

The following list of examiners for the year 1901, appointed by the College Entrance Examination Board of the Middle States and Maryland, was given out yesterday at Columbia University by Prof. Butler, the Secretary of the board:
Edmund Courtlandt Stanton, for many years Managing Director of the Metropolitan Opera House, died Sunduy at Bournemouth, England, in the forty-seventh year of his age.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to indorse the remarks of your correspondent, Mr. William Payne, in your Sunday issue of Jan. 18 and to add an amendment relative to street numbers. The existing state of things in regard to street signs and numbers in this city is simply an infamous outrage, not only upon non-residents visiting us for business and other purposes, but upon our own citizens.

Further strength developed in the stock market yesterday, with quotations advancing quite generally through the list. The buying was much the best of any that has appeared in recent days. The strength of St. Paul, Northern Pacific, Great Northern, Burlington, Union Pacific, and all the coal stocks was noticeable, and it was generally commented upon that much of the buying advancing them came from the same interests who were most active in the recent rise.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 -- Favorites fell by the wayside at Tanforan to-day, second choices finishing first in most events. Lester Reiff will be seen in the saddle to-morrow. He will have the mount on Slapdash. Sam Loates, the English jockey, accompanied by his wife, arrived tonight. Results: One Mile -- Marshal Neil, 115 pounds. (Bullman.) 1: Grafter, 112, 2; Bonnie Lissak, 110, 3.

VICTORIA, B.C., Jan. 22 -- International unpleasantness, which seemed inevitable yesterday, has been obviated by the sensible action and forbearance of A.R. Milne, C.M.G., Collector of Customs of this port, and Capt. Tozier, commander of the United States Revenue cutter Grant. The Grant put into this port yesterday, having on board twenty-two Japanese, seized by an armed party of the cutter on Waldron Island.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- These bills were in- troduced in the Senate to-day:

"When night dogs run, all sorts of deer are chased." So when the tax man starts out with his beaters and crashes through the forest on a hunt for assessable personal property, the heavens are darkened by the innumerable multitude of wild fowl that are flushed by his up- roar, but among them are seen strange, surprising shapes before which the most relentless hunter would lower his gun in wonder.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 63 1/2 @ 64 1/2. There were no sales.

That of which "the memory of man runneth not to the contrary" is literally "immemorial." But for the arts of writing and reading it would be so to all intents and purposes as it still is to the inhabitants of savage countries, and the untaught inhabitants of civilized countries, who have nothing behind their own memories but vague and uncertain tradition.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 23 -- Queen Victoria is dead. The greatest event in the memory of this generation, almost the most stupendous change in existing conditions in England that could be imagined, has taken place quietly, almost gently, upon the anniversary of the death of Queen Victoria's father, the Duke of Kent.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The Privy Council will meet in London to-day, and the proclamation of the King will take place thereafter at all places required by custom.

The motion for a change of venue to be made by counsel for Nurses Dean, Marshall, and Davis, indicted for the killing of Louis Hilliard in the Bellevue Insane Pavilion, before Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court, to-day will be opposed by Assistant District Attorney Le Barbier.

ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Twelve measures carrying into operation Gov. Odell's reform recommendations are now before committees of the legislature. Three additional bills of this character will be introduced within a few days. The measures already introduced provide for the following radical changes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Four days of anxiety, in a large measure, prepared official Washington for the news which was flashed across the cable this afternoon from England. So it happened that all things that could be decently done in anticipation of the death of Queen Victoria had been disposed of and all was in readiness for the execution of the formalities which are indispensable to such occasions.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- All the morning papers appear in heavy mourning borders, with editorials eulogistic of the dead Queen and recalling the leading events and characteristics of her reign. Very few political references as to the future are made. The Dally Mail says:

In an interesting and closely contested pigeon shooting match on the grounds of the Carteret Gun Club at Garden City, L.I., yesterday between two of the most noted trapshooters in the East -- Robert A. Welch of New York and Harold Money -- Welch achieved a well-earned victory by killing 88 birds of the 100 released for each man.
CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- To Robert Dawson belongs the distinction of being the first man of Chicago to declare his intention of renouncing allegiance to King Edward VII. of England.

Inspector Cross was the chief witness at the trial of Capt. John D. Herlihy at Police Headquarters yesterday. Mr. Sexton was the only one of the Commissioners absent from the hearing. Capt. Herlihy was called to the stand to testify at the conclusion of Inspector Cross's examination, but at the suggestion of President York the hearing of his testimony was postponed until today, when he will be the first person called.
INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Jan. 22 -- When notified of the Queen's death to-day, ex-President Harrison said:

Frank H. Potter, a nephew of Bishop Potter, who gave his address as 29 Lafayette Place, which is the Episcopal See House, was a complainant in the West Side Police Court yesterday morning against George S. Hoesmer, a promoter, of 6 West Ninety-ninth Street, who was charged with intoxication and disorderly conduct.
The Municipal Assembly has been "holdind up" certain plans and changes in the rapid transit tunnel route which the Commissioners and Contractor McDonald are anxious to have passed.

Miss Annie Early Wheeler, second daughter of Gen. Joseph Wheeler, who served as a Red Cross nurse in the Cuban and Phil- ippine campaigns with her distinguished father, undermining her health in the feverladen climates, is slowly recovering from a serious attack of appendicitis at the private sanitarium of Dr. John A. Wyeth, 19 West Thirty-fifth Street.

The tolling of the bell of Trinity Church and, the lowering to half mast of flags on many buildings apprised New Yorkers shortly after 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon that Queen Victoria had passed away.

BOSTON, Jan. 22 -- American Telephone was the strong feature in the Boston market, rising 5 to 162 1/2, on continued good buying. Business was of fair volume in Sugar, Federal Steel, National Tube, and Chicago, Burlington and Quiney, with Quiney mining the weak spot in home specialties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Gen. Grosvenor has greatly excited the owners of steam launches all over the country, and he is hearing from them. On Dec. 14 he introduced a bill amending an act passed in 1897 providing for the regulation of the use of vessels propelled by gas, fluid, naphtha, or electric motors, and it was sent to the Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries.

PITTSBURG, Jan. 22 -- The famine in freight cars has reached a crisis. The situation has become so bad at the Homestead mills that it is claimed a shutdown may be necessary. It is said that 5,000 tons of plates now congest the mill yards. The egut agents say that it is simply impossible to afford much relief to Pittsburg.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- The news of the death of Queen Victoria had been hourly expected in Berlin, and on its arrival special editions of the newspapers sold like wildfire, the announcement being read with silent and respectful sympathy. The fact that Empress Augusta Victoria started today for Homburg to be near Dowager Empress Frederick added to the sad circumstances of the occasion.

Victor McCarthy, ten years old, of 713 Cortlandt Street, West Hoboken, yesterday won the hearts of the Sisters at St. Mary's Hospital in Hoboken by his concern for his mother. He was picking coal on the Erie Railroad tracks when he was struck by a train. His right arm was broken and mangled.

Ferdinand Poggonburg encountered another defeat last night at the Hanover Club in the championship billiard tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, Arthur Townsend, the billiard champion of the Hanover Club, vanquished the veteran in the fourteen-inch balkline by 300 points to 223.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- The news of the death of Queen Victoria was known in Paris at 8 o'clock last evening through special editions of the evening papers, which newsboys carried throughout the city. Great sympathy was expressed on all sides.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 22 -- The Rock Island Railroad has undertaken a job of surveying that is large, interesting, and unusual. In the southern and southwestern parts of Oklahoma Territory there are 3,800,000 acres of lands that have been owned by the Wichitas, Kiowas, Comanches, and Apaches, but which those tribes have ceded to the United States.

Lewis Waldron of Waldron Brothers, proprietors of the dance hall at 216 West One Hundred and Tenth Street, was arraigned in the West Side Police Court yesterday afternoon for a violation of Section 218 of the Penal Code, which forbids the opening of dance halls on Sunday. Waldron and his brother Edward were present in the police court on a subpoena obtained by Policeman James Haggerty of Inspector Grant's staff.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Silence, gloom, and darkness characterize London to-night. From Whitechapel to Mayfair streets usually gay with nightly festivity are dark, deserted, and desolate, and this depression of the public mind is likely to continue for many days to come.

UTRECHT, Jan. 22 -- Mr. Kruger arrived here at midday. He was received by a committee at the railroad station, and was cheered warmly. As he drove to his hotel a choir sang patriotic songs. Mr Kruger thanked the crowd outside and the people sang the Transvaal National Hymn. It is understood that lie will remain here several weeks.

A little more life appeared in the outside market yesterday, but in few stocks did the trading amount to much more than the recent averages. Prices, however, were better and several substantial recoveries resulted from the day's operations. There was a little better demand for the copper stocks, and this group showed more activity than it did on Monday.

Ex-State Senator Edward Floyd-Jones died suddenly yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Conde R. Thorn, 35 East Sixty-third Street. He was a member of a family that has been very prominent in Long Island's history for more than two centuries, and within the past two years six of its members have passed away.

The firing of the international salute of twenty-one guns from Castle Williams, on Governors Island, yesterday morning caused every body in hearing distance to wonder for whom the courtesy was intended. There was no foreign man-of-war in port, it was not the anniversary of any great historical event, so far us any one could ascertain, and there was no person of a rank to entitle him to the honor in the neighborhood.

Army. Second Lieut. Ralph P. Brower, Third Artillery, will report to Col. Jacob B. Rawles, Third Artillery, President of the examining board appointed to meet at the Presidio of San Francisco, for examination us to his fitness for promotion.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The Senate Committee on Cities to-day favorably reported the single-headed police bill for New York City. Tin bill as reported contains the two amendments which are said to have been suggested by the Governor. One of them provides that the Mayor shall not reappoint as Police Commissioner the man whom the Governor has removed.
It looks as if the majority in Congress had determined to break down the system of appointments for merit instead of for political favoritism.

-- If the people of Cincinnati are to be judged by the fraction of them that made such a remarkable display of coolness and courage in a burning theatre Tuesday evening that city's population must be appreciably superior in at least one respect to the common run of humanity and the origin and exact nature of their superiority ought immediately to be investigated.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Jan. 24. -- One of the most disastrous fires from which this city has ever suffered began at 8 o'clock last night, and notwithstanding the heroic efforts of the entire fire department, the progress of the flames was not checked until 1 o'clock this morning.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 23. -- Democratic members of the House to-day bitterly opposed the adoption of a resolution of respect to the memory of Queen Victoria. They used every possible method to break a quorum and defeat the resolution, but were unsuccessful. It was passed by a unanimous vote finally, nearly all Democratic members refusing to vote.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The King entered his capital at 12:55 P.M. yesterday, and proceeded to Marlborough House. Dense crowds, beginning at St. James's Street, had lined the entire route to Victoria Station from an early hour. The Mall and the front of Buckingham Palace were especially thronged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to many letters from old soldiers in all parts of the Union, who misunderstand the special privileges granted them in regard to obtaining land in the Comanche-Kiowa Reservation. I would make the following statement if you will allow me space in your columns:
The present Mayor of New York is a singular character. There is something, little as he may like to think so, far more British than American in his obstinate singularity.

ALBANY. N.Y., Jan. 23. -- A certificate of increase of membership of the Board of Directors of the Saratoga Association for the improvement of the Breed of Horses, from five to thirteen, was filed to-day with the Secretary of State. The certificate is signed by William C. Whitney as President and Andrew Miller as Secretary of the association.

Reports of the serious illness of James R. Keene were circulated in the financial district late yesterday afternoon. At the office of Talbot B. Taylor Co., 30 Broad Street, where Mr. Keene makes his headquarters, it was stated that Mr. Keene was not ill. He had suffered somewhat from an attack of grip, but was feeling very much better.

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- The State Banking Department to-day announced aggregate statistics compiled from the reports of the fifty-seven trust companies, filed on Dec. 31, 1900, which operate in this State. The aggregate total resources of $797,983,512 is greater than the aggregate on Jan. 1, 1900. by $125,792,844, of this grand total the trust companies of Greater New New York are credited with $754,282,831.

The case of Emil Locwenthal against THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which the plaintiff sought to recover $10,000 damages for the publication of alleged libelous matter, was heard, yesterday in Part III, of the Supreme Court before Justice Scott and a jury. The jury after a few minutes' deliberation brought in a verdict for the defendant.

Advancing prices were the order in the Stock Market yesterday, with substantial strength appearing quite generally throughout the list. The market was free from all foreign influences during the day, the Exchanges abroad being closed because of the Queen's death; nor was any attention paid to the mutterings of the pessimists that prices would certainly come lower from London to-day on the reopening of that market.

Emil L. Boas, General Manager of the Hamburg-American Line, entertained a number of his friends at a luncheon on board the company's new twin screw cruising yacht, the Prinzessin Victoria Luise, at the Hoboken terminal of the line, yesterday afternoon. During the luncheon speeches were made by Mr. Boas, Mayor Fagan of Hoboken, Capt. Sauermann, who commands the new vessel, and Mr. Whittemore of the engineering department of the line.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- King Edward VII. came to London yesterday, and, at a meeting of the Privy Council, took his accession oath, received the oaths of allegiance of the Privy Councilors, and addressed them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an American who has always been proud of his birthright and citizenship, I, like many others, am heartily ashamed of the pettiness or Richard Croker's Mayor of New York City in refusing to half-mast the flag as a tribute to the memory of England's Queen.

It takes a very daring memory indeed to go back to the time when VICTORIA became Queen of England. Whoever avows to remember it by the avowal makes himself a man of extreme old age. And even to recall the marriage of the Prince of WALES is become a proof of that venerability which, in the eyes of a younger generation, is with great difficulty to be distinguished from senility.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23. -- Of the Managers' Association of America, incorporated at Albany, the President, Lincoln J. Carter, says: "This is an attempt to put our business on a proper basis, to protect the traveling manager from the injustices and oppression he suffers from theatre managers on the one hand and from the irresponsible acts of employes on the other.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Gov. Odell disapproves of the bill introduced by Assemblyman Remsen of Brooklyn repealing Chapter 935 of the Laws of 1896 relating to transportation companies in the State other than railroads. The Governor sent for Mr. Remsen and had a plain talk with him on the subject.

The flag on the Grant Tomb at Claremont Heights was at full mast yesterday. The Park Department officials followed the order of Mayor Van Wyck in refusing to order the flags lowered to half-mast on the City Hall as a tribute to the memory of Queen Victoria. Mayor Van Wyck's action caused no much comment yesterday that his Honor called the reporters into his office and dictated a statement explaining his reasons.

The Civil Service Reform Association has discovered evasions of the civil service laws which are likely to to lead to important developments. Secretary McAncny made public yesterday a statement of the abuses which have been discovered in the municipal service. About the only places now exempt from civil service examinations are for laborers.

PEKING, Jan. 20. -- The agreement was delivered by the Chinese plenipotentaries last Wednesday afternoon, thus relieving the anxiety of the foreign envoys, who had begun to fear that in spite of the promises made, something might occur to prevent delivery.

Mark Salisbury, a foreman for the tunnel sub-contracting firm of Holbrook, Cabot Daly, was assaulted Tuesday. He asserts that his assailants were union iron-workers who have a grievance against the firm over the employment of workmen. Salisbury was walking on Fourth Avenue near one of the subway pits when he was suddenly set upon by four men.

With twelve teams ready when the call for the start was made, the one-mile relay race, the last event of importance on the programme, was decidedly the feature of the joint games held last night in the Forty-seventh Regiment's armory, Marcy Avenue and Lynch Street, Brooklyn, by the Forty-seventh Regiment's Athletic Union and the Brooklyn Athletic Club.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Jan. 23. -- John Coffee, one of the Creek baned which has been terrorizing penceable Indians was arrested to-day by Marshal Bennett and will be tried before Commissioner Sanson. It is feared his friends will attempt to rescue him, and the feeling of insecurity has been intensified.

LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 23. -- The first num ber of The Commoner, the weekly paper published by William J. Bryan, was issued this afternoon. It is a neat-appearing sheet, typographically. The following is the salutatory:

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 23. -- Charles E. Finney, manager of M. Guggenheim's Sons of New York, the smelters; Charles S. Gleed of Topeka, a Director of the Santa Fe Railroad, and Lucien V. Blake, head of the electrical department of the University of Kansas, met at the Hotel Baltimore to-day to discuss a proposition that may produce most important results to smelters and owners of mines of precious metals.

Frank Hoffman, the twenty-four-year-old son of Capt. Henry Hoffman, the well-known horseman of 83 Linden Boulevard. Flatbush, Brooklyn, committed suicide last night by drinking carbolic acid. His family is unable to issign any cause for the deed except that he was temporarily insane.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the people of New York should be mortified at the attitude of Mayor Van Wyck in refusing to half-mast the City Hall flag on the death of Queen Victoria is natural. But the action of Van Wyck is only characteristic of the man, as exemplified in his treatment of the Spanish Captain just before the war with Spain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- The House to-day, after passing the District of Columbia Appropriation bill, considered the Naval Appropriation bill in committee of the whole. It was agreed that general debate should be limited to one hour. Mr. Foss, (Rep., Ill.,) Chairman of the Naval Committee, who was in charge or the measure, explained its salient features.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- Boston had a steady market to-day with some increase in interest among the copper shares and a general feeling, noticed everywhere on the street, that the long-hoped-for broadening of activity in coppers was near at hand. The belief is that the Montana troubles in which the Standard Oil is involved are near settlement.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Friends of Gen. Brooke and Gen. Otis, who yesterday felt their respective charges had more than a good chance to become Lieutenant General before Gen. Miles attained that rank, are not so confident to-night. While Gen. Miles is away from town and has not moved a hand in the matter, a number of his friends in Congress interested themselves and to-night his supporters seem to have won a complete victory.

When the trial of Capt. John D. Herlihy was resumed at Police Headquarters yesterday only two of the Commissioners -- President York and Mr. Abell -- were present. Mr. Hess came in about an hour later.

Arthur Townsend, the Hanover Club billiard champion, and J. Byron Stark of Wilkesbarre, Penn., were the winners last night in the two games played at the Hanover Club. Brooklyn, for the championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players. Townsend defeated Edward Gardner of the Passaic Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23. -- Mr. Rawlins, (Dem., Utah,) who had endeavored vainly to discuss the Senatorial situation in Utah under a question of personal privilege at the opening of the Senate, was recognized, and within the latitude afforded by the Senate rules, read some articles from Salt Lake and Washington newspapers dealing with the Senatorial situation, and discussed them.

STEPHEN PARSON MYER, a well-known contractor died at Louisville Tuesday of pneumonia, aged seventy-two years. Mr. Myer built a number of railroad lines in the South, but his greatest work was the building of the Colorado Midland. He also built a section of the Chicago Drainage Canal.
Three hundred or more members find guests of the Manufacturers' Association of New York assembled last night at the eighth annual banquet, which was given at the Union League Club in Brooklyn.

Nothing but the wretched condition of the City Government under the present Mayor could make any reasonable man listen for a moment to an argument in favor of giving to the Governor of the State as well as to the Mayor of the city the power to remove the head of the Police Department.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 23. -- When the fact was made known that the Faculty Committee of the University of Pennsylvania had taken final action in the case of Baxter and Tewksbury, the crack track men, there was considerable surprise among both graduates and undergraduates of that institution.

The team of Joseph Wild Co. won both their matches in the Commercial Bowling League series on the Monarch Palace Alleys last night, defeating the R.G. Dun Co. and the Edison Electric fives, while the R.G. Dun Co. team beat the Edison Electric Co. bowlers. The scores:

ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Senator Martin today introduced a bill to regulate the conduct of employment agencies in New York cities of the first and second class, and placing them within the control of the police. Senator Martin says the measure was suggested by the abuses which have been and are now being practiced in the City of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With much surprise I read in this morning's TIMES an editorial headed "A Confusion of Dates," and the more I have thought over it the more certain I am that the writer is in error. He says: "The anniversary of George Washington's birth falls on the 24th of February, not on the 22d.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest the letters of "A Theatregoer," "A Lover of the Play," and "A Bohemian," and although the object of their letters is good, the method by which they week to redress their grievances is doomed to failure, judging by past experience, for the wall of their woes is likely to fall upon deaf ears so far as the theatrical managers are concerned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Consideration of the Shipping bill was resumed this afternoon by the Senate. At the instance of Mr. Frye of Maine, who relinquished the chair temporarily to take charge of the measure on the floor, it was made the unfinished business of the Senate, thus, restoring it to its privileged position.

Sixty-five pictures, comprising the first night's offering of a miscellaneous collection belonging to Thomas Kirkpatrick, were sold last night at the American Art Galleries for $12,985. The highest price was realized for Hagborg's "Morning Gossip on the Sea Shore." a group of six flsherfolk lounging on the beach.

Curlers practically took possession of Van Cortlandt Park Lake yesterday to witness the competition of one of their most important contests. This was the championship Mitchell Gold Medal match, which is emblematic of the club championship of the Grand National Curling Club of America.

A few stocks in the outside market yesterday showed greater activity than was the rule on the earlier days of the week, but the list as a whole did not develop any new life. Further improvement in prices appeared in some parts of the list, a few substantial advances appearing in the final quotations.
BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- The Official Gazette contains the following imperial rescript:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23. -- The sharp decline preceding the closing in New York found little reflection here, and the Philadelphia market was comparatively strong. The Readings, Lehigh Valley, Philadelphia Electric, and the steel stocks were features of the day, all rising in price. A block of 2,000 Philadelphia Company stock was traded at 41 1/2.

BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- All the papers are highly appreciative of the late Queen Victoria, and concur in culogizing her virtues as a sovereign. But, while praising her character they add general political reflections unfriendly to Great Britain, particularly in connection with the Boer war.

ENTERPRISE, Kan., Jan. 23. -- Mrs. Carrie Nation began her crusade hero to-day, demolishing a saloon and delivering a street lecture. She arrived on an early morning train from Wichita and went at once to the home of C.B. Hoffman, a well-known Populist leader. A temperance meeting was held at the house at 2 o'clock, attended by a dozen or more women.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 23. -- Vice Chancellor Emery heard testimony to-day in the divorce suit brought by Frank J. Birley of Hackensack against his wife Hattle, on statutury grounds. "Ed A." is named in the suit. That is the signature on letters sent from Dobbs Ferry to "M. Hilton," which is alleged to be the fictitious name under which Mrs. Birley hired a mail box.
ALBANY, Jan. 23. -- Gov. Odell's recommendations sent to the Senate on Monday night as to amendments to the New York City charter did not state all his objections to the report of the commission.

The Speedway brigade turned out in full force yesterday afternoon, and for a couple or hours before sunset made things very lively on the macadam roadway north of Dyckman Street, which was in excellent condition and seemed to suit the trotters to perfection. Among the first to reach the drive was A.B. Gwathmey, behind his favorite pair, Tiverton, 2.23 1/4, and Salient.

BOSTON, Jan. 23. -- The pattern of the bronze shell of the Lawson yacht has been forwarded in the East Braintree loundry, and to-morrow the shell which will hold the bulb lead keel will be cast. The patterns for the stem and stern pieces are not yet completed at lawley's but will be sent to East Braintree as soon as made.

BERLIN, Jan. 23. -- The Berlin courts have rendered an adverse decision against the divorced Countess von Wedel-Berard, whose book entitled "My Relations with His Majesty Emperor William II., Revelations About the Regicide in Italy, and the Dreyfus Affair in the Light of Truth." made a great sensation last year.

The British Constitution is so sure a reliance against any jar incident to the succession to the throne that the world will look with a more eager interest for evidences of King EDWARD'S influence upon the foreign relations of his Government than for any exercise of his power in its domestic concerns.

Inspector Thompson's men, Helnatz and Friede, acting under instructions from "higher up," descended upon an alleged poolroom at 43 West Twenty-fourth Street late yesterday afternoon, within a stone's throw of the reputed location of one of the largest betting establishments in the city, capturing one half-sick woman, the alleged proprietress of the place, and three large white placards with the New Orleans entries printed thereon.

The Woman's Municipal League held a mass meeting at Cooper Union last evening to discuss the recommendations of the Charter Revision Commission. Several speakers addressed the meeting, among others being Controller Bird S. Coler, James L. Wells, Edward M. Shepard, and Prof. Frank J. Goodnow.
MILAN, Jan. 24. -- Verdi's health showed a slight Improvement this morning, after a critical night; but it is feared he will not recover.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 24. -- Gazzam Gano, who was President of the Amazon Insurance Company, which wound up its business in 1893, received a mysterious letter as he sat at his desk in the Central Trust Office. 115 East Fourth Street, this morning. The missave was postmarked Kansas City, and is as follows:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for cach $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

That Shamrock II. will recapture the America's Cup, that there is a possibility of the Kaiser coming over to view the races, and that Sir Thomas Lipton is leaving no stone unturned in his efforts to got a boat that will carry back across the Atlantic the coveted trophy of American yachting supremacy were a few of the things that David Barrie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Senor Don Augusto F. Pulido. the Venezuelan Charge d'Affaires, was asked to-day as to the reported impending arrival in Washington of Fabricio Conde, stated in the press dispatches to be an accredited official envoy from the Venezuelan Government, bearing representations relative to the asphalt dispute, to be presented to the State Department.

Mrs. Annie Hornby, wife of Frederick Hornby, a well-known real estate operator of Brooklyn, has brought suit in the Supreme Court, that borough, against her husband and James Gascoine, President of the Broadway Bank, Brooklyn, and a business associate of Mr. Hornby, for the cancellation of a deed to real estate, which, the plaintiff claims, she was induced to sign under fraud, duress, and undue influence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- To-day's session of the Semite was devoted to the Indian Appropriation bill. During the consideration of the appropriation for Indian schools Mr. Butler (Pop., N.C.,) said he had visited such schools, and observed that there were present taking advantage of the beneflts children who were, not Indians, and he asked what proportion of Indian blood was necessary to secure admission to such schools.

The hearing of the petition of Mrs. Catharine Hancox, who asks to be declared a bankrupt, was begun before Referee George C. Holt, at his office, 34 Pine Street, yesterday afternoon. According to the schedule which was submitted to the referee. Mrs. Hancox's liabilities have been fixed at $10,314,01.

ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 24. -- The Czar left Livadia yesterday on the royal yacht, taking a train for Sebastopol, whence he started in the evening for St. Petersburg. The Court goes into mourning for Queen Victoria on its arrival here.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- Mrs. George Cornwallis-West, (who was Lady Randolph Churchill and previous to her marriage, Miss Jennie Jerome, of New York City,) who had several unusual opportunities of meeting Queen Victoria, has written the following:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Among the callers at the White House to-day was Capt. O. J. Humphrey of San Francisco, who was presented to the President by Senator Perkins. Capt. Humphrey visited the Executive Mansion as its the special envoy of California Commandery No. 1. Knights Templars, of San Francisco, to personally present to President McKinley an invitation from the commandery to meet with it upon his visit to the pacific Coast the coming Spring.

A commotion was caused in Judge Garretson's court in Long Island City yesterday when a juryman fell in a dead faint while the Judge was delivering his charge. The case, which was that of Kenworth against Bogart, which had occupied all Wednesday afternoon and almost all yesterday morning.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 24. -- While crazed with drink this morning Mrs. William Mitchell of Groton shot her husband in the forehead with a 32-calibre revolver, inflicting a dangerous wound, the ball lodging in the brain. The woman was arrested. Mitchell recently inherited a large estate from his uncle, Col. William Mitchell of Groton.

There is an organization now forming, to fight the leadership of Richard Croker in Tammany Hall. One of the leaders of the new movement is John C. Sheehan, who was leader of Tammany Hall after the abdication of Richard Croker, several years ago. When Mr. Croker came back to this country Mr. Sheehan was ousted from the leadership, and he has been making a fight to keep control of the Ninth Assembly District organization since.

Benjamin D. Silliman died yesterday morning at his home, corner of Plerrepont and Clinton Streets, Brooklyn. He was ninety-five years old. Mr. Silliman had been ill about a week with bronchial pneumonia. Despite his extreme age, it had been thought on Wednesday that he had a chance of recovery, but a change for the worse in his condition took place early yesterday morning, and he sank rapidly.

Cats, rabbits, and guinea pigs received the blue-ribbon badge of high-class merit yesterday at the poultry show in the Madison Square Gardon, as well as several hundred additional birds and other members of the feathered tribe. The attendance was much larger than on the opening day, and all the birds looked in the prime of condition.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- In the Senate this morning Senator Wilcox of the Committee on Penal Institutions reported favorably on the bill for the appointment of a State Commissioner of Prisons and abolishing the State Prison Commission. It fixes the term of office of the Commissioner at four years instead of three.

The opening games of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League, which is composed of the New York Athletic Club, the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, the Catholic Club, the Harlem Wheelmen, the West Side Republican Club, and the Harlem Republican Club, were rolled last night on the alleys of three of the clubs.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- The Appellate Division has handed down a decision in the matter of the application of Attorney General Davies to have the Court of Appeals review the decision of the lower court in the Ice Trust matter. It decides that the Attorney General can go to the upper court and appeal from the adverse decision given in the lower court.

Society has so much to amuse it these days that the twenty-four hours pass with almost lightning-like rapidity. The mornings are devoted to all kinds of pursuits, and the afternoons to luncheons, receptions, and bridge whist, while the evenings are divided between dinners and dances.

USURIOUS DISCOUNT BY PRIVATE BANKS. -- A suit involving an interpretation of the General Bunking Law of 1892, brought by one Italian against two others, which was recently finally decided by the Court of Appeals, has probably been the subject of judicial consideration by a greater number of Judges than any other case in this State.

By the action of the Rabid Transit Board yesterday resolutions were readopted providing for the underground extension to Brooklyn. Plans are to be forwarded at once to the Municipal Assembly and to the Park Board for approval, and if there are no unusual delays on the part of the city authorities, actual construction on the extension is likely to begin not later than next January, and possibly before.

Trading in the market for outside securities yesterday developed very few new features, and practically the only events of interest were sharp advances in three or four stocks. Except in the low-priced stocks very little activity was shown, and in most issues the day's transactions were confined to a few hundred shares.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Mrs. Adele Oakley Dean has won her suit for divorce against her husband, Arthur Dean, a member of the banking firm of John A. Dean Co., of Exchange Place, New York, so far as the recommendation of the Master in Chancery goes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The House today continued consideration of the Naval Appropriation bill, and practically completed it before adjournment. One small matter went over until to-morrow. The debate up-on the present bill has lacked the interesting and sensational features of recent years.

After a two days' session the sub-committees of the Trunk Line and Central Passenger Associations yesterday agreed to recommend certain rates from-various points to Buffalo, to be, effective, during the coming Pan-American Exposition. Between New York and Buffalo there will be sold three different round-trip tickets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Chairman Hull of the House Military Committee sums up the essential points the agreement, on the Army Reorganization bill, reached yesterday by the conferrees of the two houses:

W. Bayard Cutting, President of the Tenement House Commission, was yesterday summoned before Deputy Commissioner of Buildings John Guilfoyle in Brooklyn, and asked to explain several alleged violations of the law discovered in the tenement building's owned by the Cutting estate on Thirty-ninth Street, between Second and Third Avenues, Brooklyn.
LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The Court will go into mourning for one year.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- London yesterday witnessed a sight the like of which only a very few people now living had ever seen before. King Edward VII. was proclaimed at various points of the metropolis with ceremonies exactly following ancient precedence.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- The New York City Police bill and Bureau of Elections bill were both advanced a legislative notch to-day. In the Senate Chairman Stranahan of the Committee on Cities, not having received any word from New York respecting a hearing upon the bill, decided to push it along without further delay.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- A protest against the bill to abolish the State Board of Charities and substitute therefor a single Commissioner, signed by Bishop H.C. Potter, Dr. Huntington of Grace Church. Archbishop Corrigan, Bishop Farley, Father Lavelle, the Rev. Lyman Abbott, and others will reach Gov. Odell to-morrow.
LONDON, Jan. 24. -- Money was in quiet demand to-day. New York's exports of gold are expected to benefit London only indirectly.

The announcement that Mr. BRYAN has started a newspaper does not at first sight go with the announcement that he is about to undertake a trip around the world. Either project is defensible. But nobody has heretofore tried to combine them. When a man starts a newspaper, it is his invariable custom to "hang around," at least for a few weeks, to verify his expectations about how it is going to go.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Assemblyman Keenan said to-day, in discussing his bill providing for "the submission of the question of the separation of certain territory in the City of Greater New York under a single municipal administration to be known as the City of Queens, to a vote of the people":

The hard tolling folk of Brownsville, a picturesque, if not beautiful, section of Brooklyn, were somewhat staggered yesterday to learn that there was a big bunch of coupon-clipping millionaires "in their, midst." This came to light through an application to Justice Dickey, in the Supreme Court, yesterday morning for the incorporation of the "Millionaires' Club."

A little after midnight this morning there was a free fight at Twenty-ninth Street and Broadway which kept all the policemen In the neighborhood working hard-for over half an hour before order was restored. A long line of cabs are generally drawn up along Twenty-ninth Street, and it was near along these that the flght started.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The committee which is investigating the hazing of Cadet Booz had before it to-day the last witness who will be called on to testify. He was F. H. Cunningham, a teacher at the Hamilton Institute, New York City, who formerly was a cadet at West Point. He was the tent-mate of Cadet MacArthur, a son of Gen. MacArthur, who was severely hazed, according to the testimony adduced at West Point.

Arthur Townsend, who has been showing up in brilliant style in the billiard championship tournament for the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, which has been in progress for nearly two weeks at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, continued his good work last night by defeating J. Bryan Stark, 300 points to 137, at fourteen-inch balk line.

The will of Oswald Ottendorfer, editor and proprietor of The New Yorker Stants-Zeitung, was offered for probate in the Surrogates office late yesterday. The testator leaves over $200,000 to charitable and educational Institutions. He also remembers the employes on the Staats-Zeitung by giving $50,000, to be divided among them.

With the annual ball of the Old Guard, which was held last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, that organization celebrated the seventy-fifth year of its existence. The ball last night was probably the most brilliant and successful of any the Old Guard ever gave. The crush at the door was tremendous.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Assemblyman Dempsey to-day introduced a blanket bill with regard to charges upon street railways, elevated railways, and ferries of New York City during what he designates as "workers' hours." Mr. Dempsey's bill provides as follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Two additional tax bills, which, it is understood, have the approval of the Governor, were introduced to-day by Mr. Lewis of Monroe. One covers the proposed tax of one per cent, on trust companies and the other applies to shares of stock in banks, which are made to pay one per cent, on their value.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the stock Exchange at 63 1/2@65. There were no sales.

Yesterday was the dullest day the Stock Exchange has had for several months. For the first time since election transactions fell much below the million mark, barely 750,000 shares beins traded in all day. It was rather a novelty in its way when the tape actually stood still, sometimes failing for several minutes to record a single transaction.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Jan. 24. -- Marshal Bennot has just received a telegram from Bristow. Indian Territory, announcing that 1,000 armed Creeks, stationed two miles from there, are preparing to attack the town, and pleading for protection. Marshal Bonnet end Agent Shoffet are swearing in large numbers of deputies, whom they are forwarding to the scene of the trouble.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Senator Aldrich. (Rep., K.I.,) Chairman of the Senate Committee on Finance, to-day reported ate War Revenue Reduction bill back to the Senate. The committee reports a complete substitute for the bill as it passed the House. Senator Aldrich made a statement explaining the changes, which arc as follows:

Thomas Knott Lees, for many years Vice President of the Consolidated Gas Company of Brooklyn, died at his home, 5 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon of cerebral paralysis. He was born in Derby, Conn., in 1819. For a number of years he was engaged in business in New Haven, and in 1860 came to New York.

Euphrosyne is having a hard time of it in the current comic stage plays. The quality of the humor in "Vienna Life." which is musically and pictorially charming, is best illustrated in one of the showiest remarks of the funny man, to wit: "I may look wealthy, but I am not. All is not Gould that glitters."

Consideration of the evidence submitted by the Tammany Committee of Five to the District Attorney, and understood to be against police officials in whose districts the committee has unearthed vicious and disorderly resorts, will be begun by the Grand Jury Monday, or the early part of next week.

MONTREAL, Jan. 24. -- To-day business is practically stagnated in Montreal as a consequence of the disastrous fire which took place in the centre portion of the city, and crowds of thousands of people throng the narrow streets around the burned district, which is a scene of desolation.
Wordy encounters between counsel and Commissioners marked the progress of the trial of Capt. Herlihy at Police Headquarters yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue at this date appeared on editorial under the caption "The Mayor and the City Hall Flag," in the course of which you sny: "The Mayor of New York has the unique distinction of being the one person among the countless millions of sons of English-speaking mothers who refuses to see that the case is one, not for following precedents, but for making them."

To the Editor of The New York Times: To me as a British subject and to most Englishmen to whom I have spoken on the subject, it seems the height of folly to give Mayor Van Wyck the "bold advertisement" of which for the sake of the faction he represents he is so ardently enamored. That he intended to insult England and slight the memory of the late Queen there can be no doubt.
CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- Ex-Judge Lorin C. Collins, in speaking of the coming city election, said to-day;

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Now that so many millions of people throughout the civilized world are bearing affectionate testimony to the memory of Queen Victoria, the following little story may be of interest to your renders as showing an unexpected broad-mindedness on the part of a monarch who had been accustomed to flattery all her life.
The President has sent to Congress a special message on the Philippine situation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Senator Chauncey M. Depew delivered a set address in the Senate to-day in favor of the Shipping Subsidy bill, which, he said, is the only remedy for the present stagnation in the merchant marine.

Friday is always a busy day in society. It Is a day chosen by so many hostesses for the "at home," which may be either informal or a very elaborate entertainment. There were so many of these yesterday that Fifth Avenue was crowded all day with handsome equipages, in which were beautifully gowned women, who were on a round of visits.

When we speak of the Victorian age of literature we probably do nut always measure the significance of our words. It is not discernible that the good Queen who has just passed away had any direct influence on the literary product of her reign. Indeed, she has been quoted as speaking in terms of admiration of Marie Corelli, a fact which might indicate that she was not of the purest taste in letters.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- "Ben" Leavitt, the well-known theatrical manager, died this forenoon of typhoid-pneumonia. He had been ill ten days. At first he was believed only to have pneumonia, but within the last day or two symptoms of typhoid rover became manifest.

OBERLIN, Ohio. Jan. 25. It was announced in chapel this afternoon that John D. Rockefeller had signified, through J. W. Cowles of Cleveland, a Trustee of Oberlin College, his willingness to give $200,000 toward an endowment fund of $500,000 now being raised for the college, provided the entire amount shall be raised by the first of next year.

The difficulty of securing convictions of disorderly persons arrested in the Red Light district was testified to by a number of policemen at the trial of Capt. John P. Herlihy yesterday. Several of the witnesses declared that they had been reprimanded by Magistrates for bringing such prisoners before them unless they knew just what had been said by the prisoners to persons they accosted.
MADRID, Jan. 25. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 77.50. Gold was quoted at 35.62.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 19 there are several ironical and acrimonious letters regarding my article on Major Andre. To these I shall give no reply. I tried to write fairly, and to give, my impressions on this subject.

In this the new volume in the Library of Literary History Prof. Barrett Wendell has produced an exhaustive work on America. The volume is divided into six books, entitied "The Seventeenth Century," "The Eighteenth Century," "The Nineteenth Century." "Literature in the Middle States from 1798 to 1897," "The Renaissance of New England," and "The Rest of the Story."

To the Editor of The New York Times: What a remarkable article that was in yesterday's TIMES --" German Protection against America!" You do not seem to know, or you do not want to admit, that Germany has no protection against America in any way comparable to the protection America has against Germany.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 26. -- The royal family yesterday took their last look at the features of the dead Queen. About 10 o'clock in the morning the coffin was taken into the bedroom, where were waiting King Edward, Emperor William, the Duke of Connaught, Sir James Held, and the royal ladies.

CHILDREN SENT WEST FROM JUVENILE ASYLUM. -- The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday, by a divided vote, hold that an order of the Special Term erred in directing that the authorities of the New York Juvenile Asylum restore to Giuseppe Billotti, his three children, James, Rosie. and Annie, which he in 1898 gave into its possession.

Twenty-two delegates, representing twelve clubs in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, met yesterday at 6 East Ninth Street for their second annual meeting. The business resolved itself into the election of officers for the coming year and the adoption of some changes in rules which it is expected will contribute wider interest to the competitions held by the association this year.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Jan. 25. -- Major Andrew J. McGonnigle, a retired officer of the United States Army, died here last night. He entered the regular army as a Captain in the Quartermaster's Department in 1865, his appointment being based on his brilliant service as a volunteer in the civil war. He became a Major in 1882 and was retired March 4. 1893.
FRANKFORT, Jan. 25. -- Baron Wilhelm von Rothschild, head of the banking firm of that name here, died at noon to-day.

The Honorary Secretaries of the Durer Society of London, Campbell Dodgson, and S. Montague Peartrec, 9 Henrietta Street, Covent Garden, London, announcr the puplication of the society's third portfolio of reproductions of fine originals by Albert Durer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After its editorials, the most interesting feature of THE TIMES is its correspondence. The letters that appear in its columns from day to day are fair specimens of a very intelligent public opinion. Of course, these letters do not cover every region of thought or every field of endeavor.

In discussing the modern magazine and its audience, with a well-known illustrator recently, he remarked that "the writer owed a large debt to his illustrator." It is in leed the "picture magazines" that attain the large circulations. Those that deal with literature alone have to be content with a comparatively small sale.

There is little new to be said this week in respect to trade conditions. Of developments there has been none of consequence, though it is a gratifying fact that the steady improvement and progress noted since election conntinue. Even in iron and steel, about which there lately has been so much direful talk, the actual trade conditions are reported excellent, many large orders having been placed.

R.A. DIX. New York, writes to. THE NEW YORK TlMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "A year or so ago, Hubbard of Roycroft fame issued an edition of Emerson's essay on 'Friendship' bound with his usual care. A copy was sent to a friend in Massachusetts who recently wrote RH follows: Some friends came over one evening with that Emerson, and we read 'Friendship' together.

The more one blames the Chinese Government the more he must pity the Chinese people. That is almost an axiomatic statement of the case of any human people whatever which has been betrayed by evil rulers into an untenable position of which enemies have taken advantage. Experts report that Chinese are some-what more stolid and apathetic, in their calm contemplation of any human suffering not their own than the inhabitants of the Western World.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Both houses of Parliament yesterday afternoon received identieal messages from the King and voted condo,ance with his Majesty on his be-reavented and congratulation on his accession to the throne.

Commenting upon the artistic printing which is being done by the London Guild of Handicraft, who have acquired the presses of the late William Morris, and hope to "continue the traditions" of good printing established by the Kelmscott Press, a recent short newspaper article continues in the too familiar strain so often heard, that William Morris and his followers put forth books which are inaccessible to all but a few wealthy collectors.

There was an enthusiastic meeting of the City Democracy last evening in the headquarters. 1,481 Broadway. Henry Mann presided. Resolutions denouncing Richard Croker were passed. The speakers were applauded whenever they spoke of mismanagement in the City Government. The resolutions adopted follow:

USURIOUS DISCOUNT BY PRIVATE BANKS. -- A suit involving an interpretation of the General Banking Law of 1892, brought by one Itallan against two others, which was recently finally decided by the Court of Appeals, has probably been the subject of judicial consideration by a greater number of Judges than any other case in this State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The report that the Senate committee in the amendments it suggested to the War Revenue Reduction bill removed the tax from cosmetics, perfumeries, chewing gum, and sparkling wines is erroneous. The committee reduced the tax on some medicinal preparations and removed it from others, but left it on the articles mentioned as in the existing law.

When James R. Howe took the office of Register of the County a year ago he surprised the politicians and Brooklynites generally by announcing that he would devote the surplus fees of his office to some public purpose. Mr. Howe. however, declined to make known just what he proposed to do with the money and his intentions in the matter remained an interesting secret.

In bumpers of wine and with speech and song the Associated Scottish Clans of New York last evening celebrated at the Marlborough Hotel the one hundred and forty-second anniversary of the birth of Robert Burns, Scotland's immortal bard. But in the midst of their expressed loving loyalty to their poet the Scotsmen did not forget the gloom that hangs over all English subjects.

WINSTED, Conn., Jan. 25. -- During the past few weeks the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has discharged scores of employes, among the number some of their oldest and most reliable hands, because of their failure to pass examinations required by the company.

This sketch of the intimate life of England's new sovereign is presented with much sympathy and with great discretion. It brings the reader into close relationship with the man, showing him where he has touched the public heart, recounting at close range his life at Sandringham. In the country, at Marlborough House, as a student, observer, and churchman; as a husband and father, as the arbiter of fashion and the patron of the race track.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have been much interested in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW article by Mr. Loomis on "The True Value or Bartlett," as I have a little book which has been constructed upon the theory he happily advocates. The title is "In Maiden Meditation," by "E.V.A.," and it was published in 1894 by A.C. McClurg Co. of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The House today adopted the conference report on the Army Reorganization bill. The report was submitted by Mr. Hull, Chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs.

LONDON, Jan. 25. -- A feature commented on in the money market to-day was the large addition to the Bank reserve, which is now nearly L21,500,000. The considerable depletion of the markets supply, the hardening of short loans, and the large decrease of Government securities are attributed to the Bank borrowing in the market.

Mr. I.T. Williams was a collector of paintings without regard to the nationality of their authors. He was a friend of the late Daniel Cottler, who introduced to New York a great many modern painters, especially Dutch and French painters, so that his taste in the fine arts was naturally to a large extent influenced in their direction.

For the fourth consecutive year Arthur K. Keane of the New York Athletic Club yesterday won the figure skating championship of the National Amateur Skating Associations of the United States and Canada, contested at the St. Nicholas Rink. Keane, in the opinion of the throe judges, was perfect in his work compared with the other competitors, and he gained a perfectly clean score, never making a misplay or trifling error.

A commotion was caused in Judge Carretson's court in Long Island City yesterday when a juryman fell in a dead faint while the Judge was delivering his charge. The case, which was that of Kenworth against Bogart, which had occupied all Wednesday afternoon and almost all yestorday morning.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Chief Justice Depue of the Supreme Court, who was reappointed last week, will retire from the bench on Nov. 16 next, when he will have completed thirty-five years on the bench. His resignation, which was filed with Gov. Voorhees yesterday, will enable the Governor, before he retires from office, to appoint another Republican as Chief Justice.

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Dr. Lyman Abbott delivered the fourth of his Lowell Institute lectures on "The Rights of Man" tonight. His evening topic was "Industrial Rights," and he held his big audience closely for an hour and a quarter.

CHECOTAH, I.T., Jan. 25. -- H.G. Turner of Brush Hill, where the Snake band of Indians arc supposed to be in ramp, was in Checotah this morning, and says there is no truth in the report from Eufalfu of an Indian uprising. The Indians, he says, who are supposed to be indulging in the war dance are at work.

It is a funny little tempest in a teapot that is agitating Boston. There has been a theory -- in the newspapers at least -- that the Queen of Boston's social world was Mrs. "Jack" Gardner. Whether with or without reason, the world at large has come to believe that her social position was assured and akin to that of Mrs. William Astor in this city.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 25. -- Stuart Robson was seen here to-night for the first time as Tony Lumpkin in "She Stoops to Conquer."

In almost every church in New York tomorrow some ceremony, more or loss formal, according to the church, will be observed in commemoration of the denth of Queen Victoria. In the majority of the churches these services will be very slight, and will consist of little more than a referance to the life of the Queen in the prayers and in the sermon.
DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 25. -- Steps have actually been taken under which lake shipyards will enter into competition with the yards of the Atlantic Coast.

The New York alumni of Dartmouth College gave their thirty-seventh annual dinner last night in Delmonice's. The dinner was one of the most successful and largely attended in the history of the association, and the guests drank to the health of Alma Mater, applauded the speakers' praise of Daniel Webster, the college's greatest alumnus, and told reminiscences of their college days till the morning hours.
LONDON, Jan. 26. -- It is reported that Emperor Nicholas and the Empress will attend the funeral of Queen Victoria.

The individual Briton has not approved himself, except to himself, as a man of tact. The landlords and servants and follow-travelers of the Continent of Europe, whose undying hatred it is his pride and pleasure to deserve, would not admit his sensibility at all. Throughout Europe, in fact, the British tourist is in the position of HORACE'S miser, whose consolation it was when the populace hissed him, to applaud himself.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 25. -- There was much excitement at the Ice Palace here to-night, when before the largest crowd of the season and in the fastest and in the best hockey frame played on the local rink. Brooklyn defeated Quaker City in a championship game by the score of 1 goals to 3.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The usual serenity of the Friday morning session of the Senate was disturbed to-day by the breeze created by the introduction by Senator Rallies of a resolution cailing on the Controller to report as soon as possible all facts concerning the United States Deposit Fund.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25. -- Charles B. Cory of the Oakley and Ardsley Clubs carried off the subscription cup this afternoon by doing some good work and defeating both Sidney Carpenter of the Philadelphia C.C.A. in the morning and winning the finals against E.A. Mulliken of Boston in the afternoon.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 25. -- Anne Longfellow Pierce, sister of the poet Longfellow and wife of the late George W. Pierce, is dead here, aged ninety years and ten months. She lived in the old Longfellow house, on Congress Street, all her life. The house now goes to the Maine Historical Society.

When the saddening rumors that Jean de Reszke hail lost his voice came from London the lovers of the most poetic or all dramas, the most passionate of all love songs, the most subtle of all musical expressions of the human heart, said one to another. "Who will be our Tristan now?"

With but one more victory to gain to possess the billiard championship of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players. Frank A. Keeney of the Oxford Club, Brooklyn, encountered his first defeat last night in the tournament that has been in progress for two weeks at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Jan. 25. -- D.A. McPherson and Hodgson Brothers, dealers in butter and cheese, were burned out this morning. About 25,000 boxes of cheese are said to have been destroyed. McPherson's loss is about $250,000; insurance, $232,000. Hodgson Brothers' loss is about $10,000, fully covered by insurance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 25. -- Crusados, at 30 to 1, made his first appearane in the two-year-old race at Tanfaran Park to-day, and wan handily. He is by Emperor of Norfolk, and it owned by "Lucky" Baldwin. The Winter Handicap, worth $6,000; will be decided to-morrow. Results: Seven furlongs -- Impromptu. 112. (Henry.) 1: Thracla. 107. 2: George Dowey. 109, 3. Time -- 1:81.

To the Editor to The New York Times: The Rev. Dr. MacArthur raises the issue of the superiority of Christianity over Confucianism. He cites the susperiority of the treatment of women. Does the reverend gentleman refer to the theory or to the practice of Christianity? If the former, he is perfectly correct; if the latter, he errs to on unpardonable extent.

There is a very general impression that the ordinance of the Health Board against spitting in a public conveyance cannot be enforced, because no penalty is affixed by law to the commission of the offense. This impression is a mistaken one. There is a definite and pretty severe penalty provided by law, quite sufficient, if applied, to check all but the most reckless, and sufficient to deter even them from a second offense.

Turning over the leaves of Mr. Stedman's "New American Anthology" to see how many new poets he had turned up. I came on a bit of verse entitled "Little Wild Baby." that seemed to me out of the common to which the name of Margaret Thomson Janvier was attached. Wondering if thin were a sister or cousin of our late, Ambassador to Provence.
