It has been proclaimed from a literary housetop of good standing and whispered in confidence in the more secluded alleys of Inkdom that Barrle's Tommy is a study of the literary temperament.

Secretary Long wants the city to cede to the United States Government a part of Blackwell's Island to be used as a parade and drill ground for marines and sailors. The promise of the Navy Department is to maintain in a marine band, build docks, and establish on the island a National park to be used by the people the same as other parks, except the limitations as to the drill ground.

The annual dinner of the West Side Republican Club, which was held at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening, partook of the nature of a Republican lovefeast. About 400 members of the club were present. The guests of honor were Gov. Benjamin B. Odell, Gen. Stewart L. Woodford. Judge Henry Howland, Curtis Guild, the Rev. G. E. Strebridge, Samuel T. Maddox.

A Boston correspondent, in a most courteous spirit, sets forth the evidence which convinces him that we were in error in saying that the Ship Subsidy bill has no serious popular support and is not demanded by the shippers. We gladly call attention to his letter and the facts cited by him.

A history of literary criticism would contain many striking examples of critics famous in their days who, in writing of books afterward to become celebrated, went wrong. In the Jan. 12 Issue of Literature, the periodical published by The London Times, are reprinted several notices that appeared in British reviews sixty, seventy, and even eighty years ago, which afford interesting illustrations of this fact.

A site has been selected for the Woman's Hotel, and work on that structure will, it is believed, be carried forward at an early date. The property decided upon is that now occupied by the House of Industry, conducted by the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, a plot running through from Twenty-ninth to Thirtieth Street, just east of Madison Avenue, and having a frontage of 75 feet on either street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I want to enter my protest against the impertinent writer of the first paragraph of the Topics of the Times in to-day's NEW YORK TIMES. I consider myself a "reputable" member of this community and I warmly indorse the action of the Mayor in keeping the flag at the top of the flagstaff.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 25. -- Mayer Seymour, in the crusade against vice in this city, and after a conference with the Excise Commissioners, License Inspectors, and Chief of Police, gave orders that these departments must work in harmony to stamp out vice in concert halls and cafes where women are employed as waitresses.

We published Sunday morning an interesting table of the cities of the German Empire having a population in 1900 of more than 100,000, with the increase since 1895, when the last census was taken. They were 32 in number and the increase varied from 7 per cent, to as high as 60 per cent, in the five years.

Readers who delight in a well-written book of travel will make no mistake if they select Anna Bowman Dodd's "Falatse, the Tour of the Conqueror," as a volume which will furnish a full measure of attractive reading and be a variable addition to the library shelf. Those who are familiar with Mrs. Dodd's former volumes.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Leader Allds, during the session of the Assembly to-day, offered some amendments to the Governor's Prison Commission bill, by way, as it was said, of compromise, which, if they are to stand, will necessitate the revision of all the single-headed commission bills advocated by Gov. Odell.

In the first draft of the Constitution by which it is proposed to establish the Island of Cuba as a free, independent, and sovereign nation, it will be observed that the federal system provided for is only in form comparable to ours. There is a central Government, with its President. Congress, and judiciary, and there are department Governments, with their Assemblies and Governors, corresponding to our States with their Legislatures and Governors.

WASHINGTON, Jan., 26 -- Contracts for naval work, aggregating no less than $7,500,000, were signed at the Navy Department to-day by President Oreutt and Judge Payson, representing the Newport News Ship Building and Dry Dock Company. The contracts were for one sheathed armored cruiser of 14,500 tons, to cost $3,882,000, and for a similar cruiser unsheathed to cost $3,775,000.

The dinner at the Hotel Savoy last night of the Associate Alumni of the College of the City of New York was attended by more than two hundred graduates of the college and their guests, prominent among the Hitter being Gov. Odell, who, before dinner, held a reception in the parlors adjoining the banquet hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Guggenheimer ordinance recently passed by the Municipal Assembly requiring corner property owners to place street signs on their dwellings made with "five-inch porcelain letters set on a blue ground," was doubtless in the interest of the Trenton potteries, and would, if placed, give the street corners the appearance of a full-fledged crockery shop.
From The Gentleman's Magazine. Tuesday, 15 -- Napoleon's birthday. The Admiral complimented him on the occasion, and his attendants appeared in dress uniforms.

We have already had occasion to refer to some amazing views of the English Constitution entertained and expressed by some of our esteemed contemporaries here in New York, and by at least one of our esteemed contemporaries in London. The fact is that unless one has taken the trouble to make himself historically clear about the British monarchy, it is idle and misleading to guess about it.

Charles F.W. Neely, the ex-Chief of the Bureau of Finance of the Cuban Post Office Department, who was arrested in Rochester last May charged with embezzing $36,000 of the department funds, sailed yesterday for Havana in custody of two United States Marshals on the Ward Line steamship Mexico.

Old Sing Sing Prison, whose name for sixty-seven years has been linked with the punishment of violators, big and little, of the criminal statutes of the State, has been prenouneed an altogether inadequate and unfit abode, even for convicts, principally on account of its dangerously unsanitary condition, by a commitiee of the Prison Association, who will recommend to the State Health Board its condemnation and demolition

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Post Master General and Mrs. Smith entertained at dinner this evening Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. Gage, Attorney General and Mrs. Griggs, ex-Gov. and Mrs. Cornell of New York, Dr. and Mrs. Rixey, Miss Miller, and Representative Robert Adams were the guests.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 26 -- Many thousand people lined the route over which 600 subjects of the Czar followed one of their number to his Bravo to-day. A band of 100 pieces, over the carriages, and a hearse led the procession and the sailors followed the body over six miles, chanting the requiem odes of the Greek Church.

The indications are that the session of the Legislature this year will see introduced many measures which will directly concern the industrial corporations doing business in this State. The message of the Governor and the recommendations of the State Controller contain many suggestions, which, if they find expression in bills introduced into the Senate and the Assembly, will need careful watching from several standpoints.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Diligent inquiry at the Capital to-day fails to discover any strone expectation there that there is to be an extra session of Congress, and no understanding that the President has intimated that he looks for an extra session. The talk about an extra session is always heard just before the close of a short session, but us a leading Republican Senator said this evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The various statements published from time to time about John C. Sheehan organizing an anti-Tammany faction for the purpose of defeating Croker at the coming Mayoralty election are truly sickening. I would like to know on what ground of merit Mr. Sheehan assumes to place himself at the head of such an organization.

JAMESTOWN, N.D., Jan. 26 -- Alfred Dickey died at 2:45 P.M. to-day. He had the office of Lientenant Governor in 1889 and 1890, the first years of Statehood. He was World's Fair Commissioner for North Dakota at Chicago in 1893. He left considerable wealth, and was one of the best known men in the State.

Dr. William L. Simpson, a specialist in obstetrics, and who was associated with Dr. H.F. Hurvey in the medical firm of Harvey Simpson, the office of which is at 22 West Twenty-seventh Street, committed suicide at noon yesterday in his apartments at the Hotel Gerard. The carriage was waiting at the door of the hotel at the time, ready to take him and his wife out for a drive.
Gov. Odoll was at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday and held conferences with the Republican lenders of the Legislature and Senator Platt.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If The London chronicle is desirous of finding an actual Revolutionary parallel of the treatment said to have been accorded to the peace envoys in De Wet's camp, an incident of the revolt of the Pennsylvania line in 1781 will apply far more closely then the execution of Major Andre.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 -- At a special meeting of the stockholders of tho Illinois Central Railroad to-day the capital stock of that system was increased $6,000,000. The total capitalization is now $66,000,000. The new issue, which is to be sold at par to present stockholders, will be used for the purchase of new equipment and other improvements.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Multam in Parvo. "God, save King Edward VII." Less than twenty years ago the area of the three kingdoms was given. including the islands, an 120,892 square miles. Of this area 666 privileged persons owned 30.7 square miles, or nearly 25 1/2 per cent. of the entire kingdom!
To the Editor of The New York Times: Are the American people not giving altogether too much prominence to the lowering or not lowering of the City Hall flag to half-mast in honor of Queen Victoria?

Magistrate Teale was called upon yesterday in the Myrtle Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, to pass upon an interesting question in barroom etiquette. The question was: Is it good form to remove your false teeth and place them on the bar when gorging yourself with smoked herring and pickled pig's knuckles at the free lunch counter.

In his "Intorductory Notes" to the Year Book of Grace Parish for 1901, which was distributed among its parishioners yesterday, the Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington, rector of the church, dwells at considerable length upon proposed changes in the edifice itself and in adjacent property which it owns.

Victor Hugo never learned how to draw. In 1825, at the times of his tour through Switzerland, he had taken on his album a few. sketches, which he himself characterized as "naifs" but these of course were merely souvenirs of travel.

The managers of the South Carolina inter-State and West Indian Exposition which will be opened at Charleston on Dec. 1 next, have completed arrangements for the erection of the different buildings and the laying out of the grounds.

The resume of a report dealing with the problems of bettering the condition of the French merchant marine, made by M. Thierry, Deputy from Marseilles, in the name of the Budget Committee of 1900 of the French Chamber of Deputies, has been sent to Washington by A.M. Thackard, United States Consul at Havre.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 -- The third section of the Cuban Constitution, as submitted by the Central Committee to the Constitutional Convertion, on Monday, relative to rights guaranteed by the Constitution, was discussed by the convention to-day. The first twelve articles of the section were accepted without debate, and it looked as though much work would be accomplished at this sitting.

Mr. William J. Bryan of Nebraska is now "in front of a big job" -- a trying, terrifying, and dangerous job -- as editor of The Commoner. At first, he will certainly be pleased to see the piles of letters in his publication office, each of them containing a dollar bill for a year's subscription to his paper, and some of them bearing words of flattery for the editor himself.

From Good Words. Mr. Bouverie, who sat for the Kilmarnock burghs and was a well-known figure in the House of Commons, referring in later years to such occasions, said that he remembered many exciting hustings scenes, but he thought that the Ayrshire nomination of 1852 was the greatest scene of tumult that he had ever witnessed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- There is reason to think that a happier outcome to the controversy over the Nicaragua Canal is probable than appears on the surface. The reason is that the considerations which most influence public opinion are leant influential in guiding official decisions. "We will build the canal in spite of our engagement not to," shout the canal boomers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a humble citizen of the United States and also a daily reader of your paper, I should like to make a few comments upon the action of the Mayor of this city in not lowering the flag over the City Hall in respect to the death of Queen Victoria.
To the Editor of The New York Times: "De mortuis nil nisi bonum." I readily grant at the outset that nothing but good can be said of the long life of the old lady who died a few days ago at Cowes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Shame on the Mayor of New York for refusing to half-mast the flags of the chief city of America as a becoming and proper tribute to the honored memory of the great Queen and noble woman whom the whole world -- except Tammany Hall -- unites in mourning!

Controller Color, Charities Commissioner Keller, and Commissioner of Corrections Lantry are opposed to the plan of the Navy Department to make a public park and drill ground of the property at the northern end of Blackwell's Island. Controller Coler said yesterday that, instead of a park, a hospital should be established there, as the present institutions under the control of the Charities Department are overcrowded.

There is a rather shabby little shop on a rather shabby street not far up town, where a business is done that would not be suspected from outside appearances. It is from this shop that many of the wealthy residents of the city get their fine furniture in old designs, either the genuine article or a superior reproduction.

BATAVIA, N.Y., Jan. 26 -- Thomas and William Morton, twin brothers, who lived together at Bergen, died this morning, the former at 3 o'clock and the latter at 7, both being victims of pneumonia.

College professors who are incidentally millionaires are the exception, even in these roseate days of the twentieth century. Learning and wealth never were the best of friends, and it is not many days ago that a prominent light of the Faculty of Princeton publicly lamented that so many of his professorial brethren had to endure the slings and arrows of knowing that they were more impecunious than most of those whom they had to teach.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The ripple of decent sentiment against spitting in public conveyances is bringing to the surface many facts of interest, among which an important case is that of spitting car conductors. Permit me to add another instance of official disregard for law by spitting policemen.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Consul Henry W. Diederich, writing from Berlin to the State Department, under date of Dec, 14. says:

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 26 -- To one who docs not know how quickly Lakewood recovers from a spell of bad weather, it will seem incredible that within three or four hours after a severe rainstorm -- a storm that has flooded links and turned the roads into rivers of mud -- scarcely a trace of water can be seen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your criticisms in your editorial of the 19th inst., "Untried Paths," upon the recent utterances of ex-President Cleveland and of ex-President Harrison seem to me neither discriminating nor Judicious. You say: "We expect our wise men to tell us not merely that we are in a bad way, but what we ought to do to set ourselves right."

COWES, Jan. 27. -- A number of leading newspaper correspondents Were admitted to the Chapelle Ardente, at Osborne House, yesterday. The approaches to Osborne House were as rigorously guarded as ever. A cordon of police, the men standing at intervals of a few yards apart, entirely surrounded the building itself.

Decided strength showed in the stock market yesterday under the leadership of St. Paul, which was bought aggressively throughout the morning by lending financial interests, who insist that the deal with the Northern Pacific-Great Northern is now practically completed, every obstacle being overcome.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note two able suggestions touching Governors Island. One of those suggestions is from a picturesque Sunday contemporary of yours, and is that the island be surrendered to the city by the United States Government and converted into a place of residence, with fine apartment houses, a co-operative store like Tuxedo,

LONDON, Jan, 20 -- Events have moved so swiftly this week that we cannot yet realize the change the Queen's death has brought. The word King is unfamiliar in people's mouths and memories linger around the name of the deceased monarch. Thanks to the world-girdling electric telegraph volumes of expressions of sorrow have poured in upon the country unprecedented since time began.

Philip Sternbach, up to the first of the year in the employe of H. Herrman, Sternbach Co., a large importing house at 568 Broadway, shot himself dead on the sidewalk on West Eighty-sixth Street, near Central Park West, last night. He was within a block of the home of his brother Morris, a member of the firm.

To The Editor of The New York Times: The basis for the absolute right of property is the right to life. Any other right of property, based upon prior possession or labor expended must yield to tills absolute right or to State regulation in the direction of that equality which must be the aim of just legislation.

BRISTOL, Jan. 26 -- As the Bristol boat takes shape in being framed out, it is seen more and more plainly that there is no danger but that the America's Cup will be strongly defended this year, and that no matter what speed Shamrock II. may attain she will meet a vessel worthy of her next August.

From a golfing standpoint, the past week was the most important since the Northern tournament season closed, Thanksgiving week. With the announcement of officers nominated for the United States Golf Association and the Metropolitan Golf Association, and the second annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, many different Interests of the game were roused to activity, and plans for the coming season are already taking definite form.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 26 -- In a series of racquet matches brimful of brilliant play at the Philadelphia Racquet Club to-day, a quartet of local crack players met four of the experts of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York, and after some remarkable skill, volleying, strategic playing, and general all-round good work, honors were even at the end.

Last week was hardly to be compared with the one immediately preceding it in the matter of large deals, but it may be confidently asserted that published reports, as is not infrequently the case, have afforded during the last few days a far from adequate idea of the amount of business that is being transacted.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. Like most of the Russian sectarians, the Doukhoborist commit little or nothing to writing; indeed, it is related of them that until recently the only book dealing with their faith was a bitter satire written by an Orthodox professor of the University of Klef, which they in their simplicity accepted in all good faith as a concise statement of their doctrine, indeed as their Thirty-nine Articles, and were duly thankful for.

The death at the Central Park Zoo of the infant grizzly bear is greatly to be regretted. The infant grizzly was removed from its mother's care, and its nourishment and education were undertaken by an amiable fox terrier with a temperament as antithetical to the ursunine as could well be imagined.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 26 -- Congressman-elect Emmett Tompkins of the Twelfth Ohio District to-day sent to Congressman John L. Lentz his answer to the notice of contest served upon him by Mr. Lentz some Weeks ago. Mr. Tompkins enters general and specific denial to all the charges made by Mr. Lentz that corrupt methods and means were used to secure his election.
ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 14 -- Great importance is attached here to the army reorganization plan which is about to be submitted by the Swedish Government to the Rigsdag at Stockholm.

LONDON, Jan. 26 -- The alter effect of Queen Victoria's death on business is vital and remarkably widespread. It particularly affects dealers in all sorts of clothing and furnishings and all goods connected with amusements, festivities, theatricals, and dinners. Black is the only color displayed in the shop windows throughout the empire.

From The Geographical Journal. The Dwarfs are of two types -- blackskinned, with a good deal of stiff, curling black hair about the body, and rod or yellow skinned, with a tendency to redness in the hair of the head and yellowish-gray in the hair growing, on the body. Some of the Dwarfs, especially when young, had quite hairy bodies, and the women not infrequently had incipient whiskers.

Aug. 14-10 A.M. -- We passed the most dreadful night of the whole siege. We were grouped together as closely as possible, and had to yell at the top of our voices to make ourselves heard. It is one of the mysteries of the stege that we are still of this world. We had our five cannon fired and many large guns were being fired upon us from the imperial wall.

In The Contemporary Review for this month, under the title of "The Chinese Wolf and the European Lamb," Mr. E.J. Dillon presents in harrowing details an account of the massacres of the Chinese by the so-called allied European soldiery. For want of humanity the writer accuses the Russians, the French, and the Germans.

"Unleavened Bread," a dramatization or Robert Grant's much talked-of novel, by Leo Ditrichstein, was remarkably well acted in the Savoy Theatre last night, and is likely to be a live theatrical topic for a few weeks at least. It was received with abundant applause by an uncommonly friendly and appreciative audience.

In the tournament of the Wholesale Drug Trade Association on Reid's Church Street alleys last night, teams of Colgate Co. and Church, Dwight Co. each won two games, the teams of the National Lead Company and Seabury Johnson each won one game and lost one, and the teams of Merck Co. and Lanman Kemp each lost two games.

SHANGHAI Dec 8 -- Foreigners in china may not have the best time in their lives in last year, but it is not noticed that they have gone away in large numbers, or that they have the slightes wish to go. There are many worse places which to live, and few better according to the experience of the majority who have settled here.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 26 -- By the death of Benjamin D. Silliman, the title of Yale's oldest living graduate falls to Leman Woodward Cutler of the class of 1829. The announcement of Mr. Cutler's succession to the title is made to-day by the university authorities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The very grave questions lately argued before the Supreme Court concerning the power of the United States to acquire and govern new territory are reducible to the single issue of National potency or impotency. The United States is either potent or impotent in that regard.
MILAN, Jan. 27 -- Giaseppe Verdi died at 2:30 o'clock this morning. The dispatch printed in the Patris of Rome announcing his death yesterday morning was premature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Let me add my quota of grievances against the superlative insolence of the ticket sellers at the box offices of the majority of New York theatres. I cannot see that Wallack's or Daly's are losing anything through the courtesy of their employes, and in consequence, we patronize these theatres; also the Empire, for this very reason.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been greatly interested in the debate going on in your columns as to why more people do not go to church, especially in the letters of "Workingman" and Mr. Thomas Conyngton. Mr. Conyngton says the best evidence of the attitude of the Church is to be found in the books written on social problems and the pages of the representative periodicals.

The days and nights roll on, and Winter is getting a bit aged and perilously near that stage when lingering in the lap of Spring of the season Feb. 20 that gave to the will be practically great deal has passed.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- The recommendation of Gov. Odell for the abolishment of certain of the State boards and the substitution of single Commissioners to take the place of each board done away with is not a new proposition. When David B. Hill was Governor, he made a similar suggestion.

All details of the organization of the Gentlemen's Driving and Field Club of Monmouth County, N.J., have been completed, and the association, with an office at the West End Hotel, Long Branch, and headquarters in New York at the Rossmore Hotel, Broadway and Forty-second Street, has announced a promising programme for the coming Summer season.

That Mayor Van Wyck was mistaken in his statement that the flag on the City Hall had never been half-masted on account of the death of a foreign ruler was brought to light by The World yesterday morning. There was printed therein a copy of a resolution adopted by the Board of Aldermen on June 26, 1894, two days after the assassination of President Sadi Carnot of France.

For a good many years I was in the habit of seeing the Queen very often. Secretaries of Legation, it is hardly necessary to say, did not ordinarily get an opportunity of talking with her. For that matter, the conversation with which she favored chiefs, and other important persons, was usually limited.

LONDON, Jan 26 -- Money was in fair supply to-day, but was harder, there being much uncertainty regarding the immediate future. Discounts were sympathetically firm, the joint stock banks not being disposed to take three months bills at anything below 4 per cent.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 22d inst. an article headed "Rural Free Mail Delivery" and signed C.E.S. deserves a little airing.

W.G. Frank, the champion indoor bicycle rider of the Eighth Regiment. won the two-mile bicycle handicap race last night, but lost the one-mile event at the conclusion of the bicycle races held in the Eighth Regiment Armory. Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. The events were held under the auspices of Company E of the regiment and the Associated Cycling Clubs of New York.

From The Contemporary Review. The wounded oyster mends its pain by making pearls out of it, but only in the medium of sun and sea. Pain draws out hidden virtues from our nature when we receive the environment of the infinite as devout men, like Aeschylus and Hosea in the ancient world.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26 -- At the annual conference of the Captains and managers of the Yale and Harvard crews, held in cambridge this afternoon, it was decided to hold the Yale-Harvard race at New London June 27. There will be three races -- the Varsity four-oared the freshman eight, and the Varsity eight, coming in the order named.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- Miss Loraine Edson, daughter of Joseph R. Edson of this city, and Lieut. Herman Walter Schull of the Second United States Artillery, now stationed in Cuba, were married this evening at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, the Rev. Dr. Elliott officiating. The bridegroom and his best man, Lieut. Herbert W. Wigmore, and the ten ushers nil wore the full uniform of their rank and corps.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- Boston trading was quiet; a feature was strong buying of Dominion Iron and Steel, carrying it up 1, to 23, while Dominion Coal rose 1, to 35 1/2. The general market, while quiet, was firm. National Tube was bought well, and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy was in good request. Pere Marquette preferred rose 1, to 77, and Boston Elevated 1 1/2, to 164.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- An evening paper tells this romantic story of one of the most promising young business men of Boston, who achieved all his remarkable success while a student at Harvard. Clarence Bush came to Harvard from a farm in Western New York four years ago. He had no money.

The security market is irregular. During the past week it has not been active. The professional talent of the Stock Exchange, including the regiment of lesser traders, hammered quotations vigorously, but they accomplished little. In so far as a market movement is concerned, no discernible influence has counted for much.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The aunual dinner of the Gridiron Club, composed of Washington correspondents, was given tonight at the Arlington Hotel. About 200 guests and members were at the handsomely decorated tables. Among the guests were distinguished men in all walks of public life -- Cabinet officers, members of the Supreme bench.

The message of the President on the condition of the Philippines, with the reports of the Secretary of War and the Civil Commission presents a very plain and an immensely important problem to Congress. This is succinctly stated by Secretary ROOT:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your valuable paper of Jan. 6 we noticed, under the above heading, a more sensibly written article than usually appears upon this vexed question. As the "so-called question" is put in the form of an ever-present difficulty to those who employ servants, might they not try a very simple remedy, which we will suggest?

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26 -- As the result of a friendly boxing match between George R. Ainsworth, a Harvard student, and Curtiss L. Crane of Brookline, Mass., his most intimate friend, the latter is lying dead at the Cambridge morgue. The accident occurred in Ainsworth's room, in Craigie Hall.

A little more than $16,000 has already been contributed for the proposed memorial in Boston of the late Gov. Roger Wolcott. Many of the contributions are in small amounts, and children seem to be eager to old.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Jan. 26 -- Whatever may be the justice or the injustice of the Curtis act, it is certain that this law is lately entirely responsible for the threatened uprising of the Greek Indians in this part of the Indian Territory.

The stronger tone that showed in the market for outside securities on Friday was continued yesterday, and not gains were made in a number of issues. The market was not quite as active us on the previous day, but business was relatively large compared with the first days of the week.

The report that Andrew Carnegie has bought the apartment house at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Ninely-flrst Street was revived yesterday. Title to the property stands in the name of Wolf Kroenthal, and rumors of its sale to Mr. Carnegie have been frequent ever since the latter began to acquire the land on the north side of Ninety-first Street, at the rear of his mansion on the Fifth Avenue front of that block.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 15 -- The ice is here, and in consequence all Holland is on skates. Even the approaching great event, the Queen's wedding, seems for a brief space forgotten. For some time past the Hollander of the south has been envying the Hollander of the north, for the newspapers were full of the splendid skating in Groningen, Zwolic-Hoorn, and Leeuwarden.

The Rev. Dr. J.G. Bass, who was for more than thirty years the Chaplain at Kings County Penitentiary, died yesterday at his home, 431 Waverly Avenue, Brooklyn. He was eighty-four years old and had been ill for six weeks.

Devotees of the old Scotch game of curling are justly disgusted with the weather which the present Winter seems disposed to give them. Only two good days for competition have been vouchsafed them this season, and the frequent postponements of interesting matches have made the veteran players think some hard things, even if they have not cared to frame their uncomfortable thoughts in words.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is evident, even to the most casual observer, that the streets of New York are in a very disgraceful and filthy condition. The late Col. Waring showed us that it was possible to keep the streets of our threat city clean; he also showed us that it was possible to keep, trucks from being stabled in the streets. His successors have done neither.

From The Gentleman's Magazine. With the acceptance of the imperial title at Versailles in 1871, on the very day when. 170 years before, Frederick I had adopted the royal name at Konigsberg, it might have seemed that the separate history of Prussia had merged in that of the German Empire.

TRENTON, Jan. 26 -- A canvass of the legislators, particularly those from Central and Southern Now Jersey, shows that there is need of an aggressive campaign of education, if the New York and New Jersey Joint Commission on the Palisades expects to get a particle of support, either morally or financially.

THE HAGUE, Jan. 15 -- It has been often said that photographs lie, and since I have had the honor of being introduced to President Kruger I am at least convinced that attractive individuals are often made the opposite in a photograph.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- The preparations for Queen Victoria's funeral are gradually assuming definite form. It promises to be the most tremendous pageant of the generation. The influx of members of royal families and representatives of foreign countries will be so wholly unprecedented that the Court officials are finding it difficult to procure suitable accommodation, the royal palaces being totally inadequate.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With a great many apparently able thinkers agreed that human wretchedness is caused in the main by overpopulation, it seems rather novel that your correspondent, "Henry Nelson," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of the 22d inst., should look on a decreasing population as a "serious thing."

With a team of former substitutes and a valueless goal keeper, Columbia, though contesting bravely to the end, could accomplish nothing against the Princeton hockey seven in a championship game at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. It was the nine and White's opening contest, and many supporters and well wishers turned out, only to see Columbia finally go down in defeat by a score of 8 -- 1.

Capt. Titus, Chief of the Detective Bureau, and Capt. Martin of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station, are trying to find a fashionably dressed young man who calls himself "Dr. Moore " and claims to be connected with the J. Hood Wright Hospital. There is a warrant out for his arrest on a charge of assault and battery, and the officers think they have several more cases against him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is evident, even to the most casual observer, that the streets of New York are in a very disgraceful and filthy condition. The late Col. Waring showed us that it was possible to keep the streets of our threat city clean; he also showed us that it was possible to keep, trucks from being stabled in the streets. His successors have done neither.

Capt. Titus, Chief of the Detective Bureau, and Capt. Martin of the West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street Station, are trying to find a fashionably dressed young man who calls himself "Dr. Moore " and claims to be connected with the J. Hood Wright Hospital. There is a warrant out for his arrest on a charge of assault and battery, and the officers think they have several more cases against him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency today voted, 6 to 4, in favor of reporting the Overstreet bill, maintaining at all times the parity of the standard silver dollar with gold. Two Democrats, Driggs of New York and Thayer of Massauhusetts, voted with the Republicans in favor of the bill.

BOSTON, Jan. 26 -- The dimensions of the Lawson cup defender were made public this afternoon by Designer Crowninshield. The figures show the boat to be somewhat larger more powerful than the Columbia and although no data are furnished as to sail area, the increase in wetted surface indicates square feet over the 1899 defender indicates that the Boston boat will probably carry considerably more canvas.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 26 -- Mrs. Carrie Nation caused a great flurry among the saloon keepers of Topeka, to-night, and as a result was roughly handled by a mob. Mrs. Nation arrived in Topeka at 6:40 o'clock this evening and immediately hunted up a newspaper reporter with a request that she be shown some of the leading saloons or the city.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 26 -- A new industry is developing in Minnesota which will revolutionize flax culture, in the production of flax fibre for linen manufacture. This new departure is due to the energy of a woman, Mrs. Oscar N. Olberg, who has spent the past six months in Europe making an Investigation of flux fibre culture.
ROME, Jan. 26 -- The Pope's Encylical on Socialism was issued to-day. It is dated Jan. 18.

From The American Catholic Quarterly Review: The part which China itself may take in the struggle is still harder to anticipate. At the present her people seem hopeless against modern war, with its scientific weapons and careful discipline; but France seemed scareely more likely to successfully resist the armies of Europe when Brunswick issued his famous proclamation.

In the list of officers of the New York Botanical Garden there is one whose name attracts the attention of the outsider, from the unusual nature of the office. It is that of Honorary Floral Photographer. This title is given to Cornelius Van Brunt, whose colored photographs of flowers have become widely known within the last few years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- Senator Proctor, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, to-day presented to the Senate the report of that committee on the oleomargarine bill. The report is favorable to the bill, but Senator Heitfiled presented a minority report adverse to it. The majority in their report say:

Policeman Fiath of the Vernon Avenue Station, Williamsburg had an exciting chase and encounter with a burglar early yesterday afternoon. Fiath was joined in the chase by over 200 persons. The fugitive, who was a negro, was finally captured, and fought the officer before he would submit to arrest.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Put it plainly before the common-sense of any one: Could man, woman, or child fall, striking their unprotected knees upon a wooden floor several feet below, without breaking the kneecap or seriously injuring the joint? Yet this is what former Cadet F. II. Cunningham testified yesterday before the Congressional West Point Investigating Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26 -- The Yale basket ball five defeated the Harvard team to-night by the score of 41 to 16. From the start Yale outplayed Harvard. There was a large attendance of students at the game. Capt. Clark of Yale distinguish a himself by scoring 25 points, earning 12 field goals.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Jan. 20 -- Robert S. Fosburg was placed under arrest here this forenoon, charged with manslaughter in causing the death of Miss May L. Fosburg, daughter of a prominent Buffalo (N.Y.) contractor, here on Aug. 20 last. The prisoner, who is a brother of the victim, was indicted at the recent sitting of the Berkshire County Grand Jury.

Letter to the Editor of The London Standard. Sir: There are some simple rules about Winter cold which it seems desirable to draw attention to as being possibly of some practical use. It is known that the spotted surface of the sun waxes and wanes in a cycle of about eleven years. The time of growth of the snots is usually less time that of decline, (say four years to seven.)

During the last twenty-five years a great change is observable in the attitude of our people toward Christianity. They have certainly great reverence for the life and teachings of Christ; they have largely outgrown the old prejudice against studying the Bible. They do not, indeed, accept the Christ of popular theology, but they believe in the spirit of Christ.

It is known that the spotted surface of the sun waxes and wanes in a cycle of about eleven years. The time of growth of the snots is usually less time that of decline, (say four years to seven.)

They have certainly great reverence for the life and teachings of Christ; they have largely outgrown the old prejudice against studying the Bible. They do not, indeed, accept the Christ of popular theology, but they believe in the spirit of Christ.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- The sweatshop problem the conditions existing in the tenement houses of New York City, and the effect of the new license law for dwellings in which articles are manufactured are treated at length by State Factory Inspector Williams in his report to the legislature. Among other things he says:

Pictures of the late Queen of England have always been a salable commodity in this town. Collectors and such men as make a fad of extra illustrating volumes had to have them. In some way or other most of the Grangerized books have portraits of the Queen introduced. So for the older and more valuable etchings, engravings, prints, and photographs there has been a sufficient demand to make them scarce enough to command fair prices.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So much has been said, and much more will be said, on the life and career of the Queen, that it seems superfluous to dwell upon those fruitful themes at greater length. Allow me, however, to call attention to the first official title she bore through life.
We are not proud of the attitude of the junior Senator from New York on the Ship Subsidy bill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Frank H. Hitchcock, Chief of the Section of Foreign Markets of the Agricultural Department, has just issued his annual review of the trade of the United States in agricultural products. In the course of his report he says:

Two boys were drowned and the lives of about fifty others were imperilled yesterday afternoon, while skating on a pond back of the Evergreen Cemetery, just over the border line of Williamsburg. The accident was caused by the ice giving way. Of the number, about thirty, including several young girls, were thrown into the icy water and reseued with great difficulty.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- The news of the death of Queen Victoria affected the German Boorses only slightly, although some realization selling was caused in consequence of the closing of the London Stuck Exchange. The stagnation of the previous weeks continued, the only department showing any life last week being the domestic Government funds.

No explanation which was given yesterday concerning the suicide of Dr. William J.Simpson, who shot himself in the head in the Hotel Gerard at noon on Saturday, explained the cause for the act.The body was removed from the hotel to the Curran undertaking establishment, at 464 West Fifty first Street, late on Saturday night.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- On the eve of the American League meeting to perfect its organization for the coming baseball season, to formally complete the signing of the ten-year agreement, and to turn over in trust to President Johnson the ground leases and 51 per cent. of the stock of the eight clubs in the league, the American League managers made a public statement to-night.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27. -- Bishop Potter of New York City preached in St. Paul's Church this evening on "Missions." White the Bishop spoke highly of the work of Christian missionaries in the Orient, he was outspoken in his condemnation of the tradesmen, bankers, travelers, and promoters who have flocked to the East from Europe and this country.

MILAN, Jan. 27. -- Although preceded by a struggle for life that lasted two days, Verdis death when it came was peaceful. He did not regain consciousness. When he passed away he was surrounded by relatives and intimate friends.

Fire Engine No. 8 from East Fifty-first Street, answering an alarm for a fire in the flat house at 980 Third Avenue last night, in an effort to avoid a collision with a hansom cab which got right in the engine's way, was driven into an elevated pillar near Fifty-eighth Street.

MATAWAN, N. J., Jan. 27. -- Fire wiped out the principal business section of this place last night, causing a loss of over $100,000. The flames would have destroyed the entire village but for the aid given to local firemen by the Keyport brigade.

With the recent conclusion of the championship billiard tournament of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players, at the Hanover Club, Brooklyn, a few quiet days will follow in big amateur competitions, untll the Class A championship renews the activity on Tuesday night, Feb. 5, in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club.

Copyright, 1901, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Many of our dealers in credits are actually looking for a reduction in the bank rate this week, I hardly see how this can occur, but should it be advanced to over the 5 per cent, rate made at the new year it will be regarded as a fresh grievance against the present management of the Bank.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 27. -- This morning Emperor William received from the hand of the Duke of Connaught his sword on his appointment as a Field Marshal of the British Army. In the presence of the households of King Edward and the dead Queen, as well as a number of British and German naval officers, his Majesty has expressed great delight at the appointment.

From The London Chronicle. The cloud which has so suddenly arisen between us and America is moving rapidly now, and increasing as it moves. Two copies of the new Hay-Pauncefote treaty, as amended by the Senate, are to be laid before the British Government at once, one by our Ambassador, Lord Pauncefote, the other by Mr. Choate, the American Ambassador in London.

Congratulations were freely indulged in at the annual meeting of the Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday, the reports presented giving evidence of increased prosperity and progress. The meeting was held in the dispensary building, 149 East Sixty-seventh Street, and was largely attended.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- A variety of subjects, including appropriation bills, the War Revenue Reduction bill, the Ship Subsity bill, and to some extent, the Phillippine question, will claim the attention of the Senate the coming week. On Monday Mr. Towne Pop. Minnop will speak on the problems involved in the Government of the Philippines.

The technical problems of construction, which gave the engineer more or less anxiety a few years ago in connection with very high buildings, seem to have been solved. Apparently there is no more difficulty in going up forty stories than thirty. The development of the structural steel industry and the application, to architecture of the principles of bridge construction, seem to have made buildings of this class enduring, stable, and safe.

From The Boston Transcript Recently there has been some dissatisfaction expressed by employes of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad with the sight, color, and hearing tests which they are required to pass in order to retain their positions. The claim was made that some of the older men had lost their places because they were unable to pass the tests, which they think are unusually severe this year.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Yesterday throughout the kingdom all places of worship held services in memory of Queen Victoria. At St. Paul's Cathedral there was an unusual scene. Before 9 o'clock in the morning an enormous crowd attired in black streamed to the vast edifice from all directions, and by 10 o'clock it was packed.

Glowing eulogies of Queen Victoria, were delivered in churches of all denominations throughout the city yesterday, in many of which the pulpits were draped with the British and American flags and mourning emblems. In some churches prayers were offered for King Edward VII. Mayor Van Wyck came in for criticism for falling to half-mast the flag on the City Hall when the news of the Queen's death was received.
A small hole in 100 feet of rubber hose is destined to cause startling exposures of the methods of certain contractors in furnishing supplies in the City of New York.

The Merchants' Association is mailing 12,000 copies of a circular to all merchants in the city, calling attention to the dangers of the Personal Property Listing bill, recently introduced in the Assembly by Assemblyman S. W. Smith, from Columbia County, and known as Assembly Bin 119. This bill, they claim, is a revival of the old Listing bill in its worst form.

The special committee of the Civil Service Reform League -- Richard Henry Dana of Boston, William Dudley Foulke of Indiana, and Silas W. Burt of New York -- has prepared a report on superannuation in the civil service, in which it unanimously recommends as the best remedy for superannuation a system requiring life insurance on the deferred annuity plan by all employes during probation, as a prerequisite to final appointment.

After several weeks of heaviness the stock market in the closing days of last week took on a tone of decided strength -- strength, so expert testimony runs, that is likely to be continued now for some time to come. The market in the days of its recent heaviness went through a process of liquidation only natural after the sustained rise following election.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- So far as surface indications go, the corporations seem to be rather indifferent to Gov. Odell's tax measures, designed to put an additional burden of $9,000,000 annually upon them. That they contemplate no resistance to the Governor's plan to abolish the State direct tax by making them furnish the required revenue for the needs of the State is a hope which even the Governor does not entertain.
HAVANA, Jan. 27 -- In an open letter to La Lucha, Senor Varona says:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Queen Victoria's life, reign, and death formed the theme in many Washington pulpits to-day, while in must of the local churches of all denominations fitting reference was made to the demise of the ruler of the British empire. At Epiphany Church an elaborate service in memoriain was celebrated at 11 o'clock.

"Just now," said the woman of all trades. "I am engaged in washing down a house, Cleaning house? No. not a bit of it. That is a favorite work of mine, but I call it by the old name. This house I am putting in order is a handsome brownstone which had become streaked on the outside as such houses will, and I am washing it.

The Rev. Maltbie D. Babcock, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, at Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, preached a sermon there yesterday afternoon which caused considerable comment among the large congregation with which the church was filled. He attacked the custom which has been prevalent of late of progressive euchre parties at which valuable prizes were offered and denounced playing cards for prizes an gambling.

The sixth Sunday night concert attracted a large attendance to the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The soloists were Mme. Suzanne Adams, Miss Maryill, and Miss Carrie Bridewell, and Messrs. Salignac, Journet, and Scotti.

HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 27 -- A number of well-known men and women from New York and Philadelphia, together with the leading citizens of the town of Hampton, Joined the students and Faculty of Hampton Institute in the public exercises hold here to-day to honor the memory of Gen. S.C. Armstrong, founder of the Institution, which stands foremost among our American schools for Industrial education.

Two terrific seas, mountainous in size and herculean in strength, staggered the French liner La Gaseogne, smashed two of her lifeboats twisted and broke the rails on her starboard quarter, frightened her 400 steerage passengers almost out of their wits, and gave to her saloon passengers a feeling of terror which will cause them to remember for many days to come the transatlantic voyage that ended at the French piers, on North River, yesterday afternoon.

Some of the most expert trail followers in the metropolitan district participated yesterday in the weekly cross country runs of the various local clubs. The event under the auspices of the Star Athletic Club started froin the clubhouse, corner of Vernon Avenue and Fourteenth Street, Long Island City.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Indian Commissioner Jones has received the following dispatch of yesterday's date from Agent Shoenfelt, at Muskogee, Indian Territory, regarding the Indian troubles:

It became known yesterday that the home of Frank Johnson, chief accountant of the Custom House, who lives at 64 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, had been looted by burglars on Friday night last, and $500 worth of jewelry stolen. One extraordinary feature of the robbery was that it had been attempted the night before, presumably by the same burglars, one of whom was surprised in the kitchen by Mr. Johnson, but made his escape.

From The London Standard. ZEERUST, Dec. 2. -- On the march, in camp, or even during a fight, one cannot help nothing now full South Africa is of animal, bird, and insect life, and, with the breeding season here now, nature is at her best. The birds, especially are very pretty with their gave feathers, the red cardinals, blue s and blue startings, golden orioles, and little finalies like Java sparrows, with red beaks.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of Now York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The attempt of the Willoughby Street organization to capture the German-American Citizens' League of Kings County, elect County Clerk Paul Huberty President, and thwart the reform movement started by Otto Kempner, almost precipitated a riot yesterday afternoon at a meeting in Schwaben Hall.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- If Gov. Odell's tax bills do not pass and the direct tax is not abolished New York City will have to pay more than 65 per cent. of the entire State tax.

A "corner" in the January option caused the greatest excitement on the Cotton Exchange yesterday, and the shorts were badly squeezed. On Saturday January cotton sold at 10.20, and it opened yesterday at 10.30. The quotation was steadily advanced until, at 11 o'clock, an hour after the opening, the remarkable figure of 12.75 was reached, an advance of 255 points from the opening.

As the result of two deals, entirely independent of each other, the entire block front on Central Park West, between Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets, will change hands in the near future. Hall J. How Co. have sold for Joseph H. Godwin to the Leopold Kahn Company the plot at the northwest corner of Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street, 106 feet on the avenue by 125 feet on the street.

In the tournament of the New York Inter-Club Bowling League last night the Knickerbocker Athletic Club five won two of their three games with the Harlem Republican Club team on the alleys of the latter club and lost the third. The scores:

Van Cortlandt's strong rink of curlers captured their second important trophy yersterday in the National Curling Clubs series of games. They defeated the well-known Edwards family rink at Van Cortlandt Lake in the final match for the Gordon medal, emblematic of the rink championship. by 22 points to 9.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The following named are players who have signed contracters with the Rochester Baseball Club; William L. Lush, New Haven, Conn.; Joseph Bean Cambridgeport, Mass.; George Smith, Allegheny, Penn.; Harry O'Hagan, Newark, N.J.; Edward Greminger, Canton Ohio; Edward Dixon.

Four Americans, James A. Woodward, William A. Humphrey, John Hill, and John A. Bell, all of Baltimore, Md., were sent to Navassa Island in October last by the Navassa Company and have since been shut out from communication with the outside world.
ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The following bills were introduced to-night in the Senate:

One notable event and many minor affairs, such as receptions, teas, and athomes, were characteristic of yesterday, and also will be of to-day. Yesterday it was the Gerry cotillion, and this evening it will be the Charity ball. Other hostesses have kindly put aside whatever arranged dates they might have had, so that the "coast is clear," to use a homely expression.

OMAHA, Jan. 28. -- Passenger Agents with headquarters in Omaha to-day received a notice from Secretary of War Root stating that the Government would in the future in shipping troops and supplies give preference to bond-aided roads. The notice called particular attention to the fact that the Central Pacific Road is very largely indebted to the Government, and will receive as much Government patronage as possible.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- In spite of the emphatic denials given to the statement that Emperor William expressed displeasure at the failure of the Reichstag to adjourn as a tribute of respect to the memory of Queen Victoria, many members of the Reichstag accept the report as genuine. It appears that the decision of the Reichstag was dictated by German and British precedents.

Two persons were killed and seven injured in a collision in the east end of the Weehawken Tunnel, between a passenger train and a gravel train on the West Shore Road yesterday morning. The victims were at work on board a construction train at the time and were all employed by the West Shore Railroad Company.

Within the grim, gray walls of Sing Sing Prison yesterday George W. Howard, confessed and sentenced bigamist, began paying the penalty of having more wives than the law allows. When he walked into the Kings County Court yesterday morning for trial he surprised the crowd of curious spectators gathered there by pleading guilty, without any show of defense whatever.

Gov. ODELL'S former relation to active politics must have given him a large knowledge of the tricks of patronage hunters that will be of use to him in protecting the public service against their forays. A bill to create party patronage would have to be most cunningly drawn, we should say, to elude his experienced eye.

LONDON, Jan. 29. -- It was officially announced late last evening that King Edward had ordered Saturday, the day of Queen Victoria's funeral, to be observed as a day of general mourning. All the banks will be closed and business suspended. Only the stores in the poorer quarters will open.

Fire Commissioner Scannell said yesterday that "Agent" Willlam L. Murks, for years a close personal friend of the Fire Commissioner now has a practical monopoly in furnishing supplies to the Fire Department "Agent " Marks, according to Commissioner Scannell, is at the head of a "combination," and collects commission from nearly every company furnishing goods to the Fire Department.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Jan. 28. -- Five persons dead and one severely injured. two engines and ten loaded cars wrecked, is the result of the mistake of a train crew this afternoon between Petroleum and Volcano Junction, on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.

PARKERSBURG, West Va., Jan. 28 -- Company B. Baylor Light Horse, Twelfth Virginia Cavalry, will hold a reunion at Charlestown Feb. 11 for the purpose of celebrating the birthday of Comrade Charles Broadway Rouss of New York. The morning meeting will be held at Washington Hall, at which Capt. Milton Rouss, brother of Mr. Rouss, will preside.

CHICAGO, Ill., Jan. 28. -- The meeting of the owners of the baseball clubs of the American League opened at noon to-day, and with the exception of a short recess in the evening, it continued until midnight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- It has been decided that the funeral service here in memory of Queen Victoria shall take place in St. John's Episcopal Church on Feb. 2. coincident with the service in England. Bishop Satterlee, the Rev. Dr. Mackey-Smith, rector of St. John's, and the Rev. Dr. McKimm, rector of the Church of the Epiphany, will officiate.
LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Money was firm and wanted to-day, and discounts were steady. A possible reduction of the bank rate was freely discussed.

MANILA, Jan. 28. -- George T. Rice, editor of The Daily Bulletin, who was ordered by Gen. MacArthur to be deported because of the publication in his paper of allegations against Lieut. Commander William Braunersreuther, Captam of the Port, sailed today. It was ordered that he be held as a prisoner until his arrival at San Francisco.
LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Sir John W. Maclure, Bart., Member of Parliament, died this morning, in the sixty-sixth year of his age.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If I may be allowed to make a prophecy, or, more correctly, a prediction, it is that a very few years more will bring an end to the present concentrated essence of inhospitallty known as the afternoon tea, or "at homes."

JACKSON, Ky. Jan. 28. -- Mail Carrier Richie arrived here to-night, bringing further news of the desperate battle of Marshal Hollifield and posse with the moonshiners on Elkborn Creek Friday morning. Later developments show that the Marshall was not killed, but made his escape and, with the exception of a frightful wound on his head is uninjured.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The bill Introduced by Assemblyman H. Wilson, giving authority to the Commissioners of the Land Office to grant and convey to the United States certain lands under water in the Harbor of New York at Governors Island, and to cede jurisdiction to the United States over said lands, came up in the Assembly to-night and was strongly opposed.

BALTlMORE, Md., Jan. 28. -- President Edwin Warfield of the fidelity and Deposit Company of Baltimore went to New York to-night to consult Frank H. Platt, Vice President of the company, concerning the $30,000 bond of Charles F.W. Neely, former Director of Finance of the Cuban postal service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- The Senate turned from the grind of appropriation bills to-day to listen to a speech, which partook of the character of an oration, from Senator Towne of Minnesota. As his reputation as an orator had proceded him, there was much interest in his speech today, which was in advocacy of his resolution for a cessation of hostilities in the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 -- "The talk about an extra session," said a Senator this afternoon, "is very weak when it is found necessary to refer to the Importance of approving the Cuban Constitution as a reason for bringing the Fifty-seventh Congress together before the regular meeting day in December next.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 28. -- Hume Smith, President of the Chamber of Commerce, in his annual report, submitted to the Directors to-day, made the frank admission that Baltimore's grain trade is shipping away to Philadelphia, New York, and Boston. He says:

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rate cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The State authorities are indignent over a report that oleomargarine is being supplied to the students in the State School of Forestry in the Adirondacks. The alleged discovery was made by agents of the State Department of Agriculture. Four tubs of oleomargarine were seized.

At a meeting of the Clearing House Committee yesterday afternoon, the various phases of bank and trust company legislation now before the legislature in Albany were discussed, and as a result a committee, consisting of Messrs. Tappen, Baker, and Simmons, with Manager Sherer as Secretary, was appointed to go to the capital, if necessary, and to take such other means as it considered necessary to oppose the bills taxing banks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Assemblyman Bell, introducing a bill in Albany making provisions for a retirement fund for Greater New York teachers, should have more wisely thought out where a permanent fund could be created by the act.

FREDERICK, Md., Jan. 28. -- The Frederick and Philadelphia train, leaving here at 3 o'clock this afternoon over the Pennsylvania Road encountered a snowdrift at Sharret's Cut, twenty miles north, where it became completely snowbound and remained so until 7 o'clock this evening, when the four coaches with their passengers, were extricated from their derilous position.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 28. -- Mrs. Carrie Nation to-day invaded the office of Gov. William E. Stanley in his chambers in the Capitol Building, and for a solid hour arraigned the Chief Executive of the State for his failure to close the saloons of Kansas. Then in turn she visited the offices of Attorney General Goddard, County Attorney Nichols.

Some of the more rabid Audubonites and opponents of birds' feathers as trimmings for women's hats have gone so far as to claim that the shooting of gulls and terns to secure their feathers for trimmings has resulted in their practical extermination. There are a few score of men and women who can tell them to the contrary.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 28 George J. who was jointly indicted with McAuster, Campbell, and Death on a charge of criminal assault and murder in the first dcgree, in connection with the death of Jennie Bosscchster, was unexpectedly brought into court this morning before Judge Dixon.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- The will of the millionaire pork packer and grain dealer P. D. Armour disposes of an estate valued at $15,000,000, according to statements made in an application for letters testamentary filed in the Probate Court here to-day by Malvina B. Armour, widow of deceased, and J. Ogden Armour, his son.
ROTTERDAM, Jan. 28. -- The steamer Holland, from London, was sunk while entering Nieuwewaterweg (at the entrance of the River Maas) this morning. The vessel parted amidships.

There was a hearing yesterday before Justice Dickey, in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, on the motion of Mrs. Augusta M. Burton to vacate the judgment of absolute divorce obtained against her by her husband, the late William A. Burton, Justice Dickey took the papers, and said that he would probably appoint a referee to take testimony.

Clyde Fitch's "Barbara Frietchie" is not essentially a war play or a stirring melodrama. It is rather a domestic tragedy, with love as its dominant and all pervading theme, love overcoming all obstacles and triumphant in death, and it does not lead itself so readily to exhibition on a large stage as plays like "Monte Cristo" and "Que Vadis."
MANILA, Jan. 28. -- Reports from Southern Luzon say there is much dissaffection in the insurgent camps. A thousand persons swore allegiance to the United States in a church at Malabon Sunday.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- The report of the State Board of Charities went to the Legislature to-night. The most interesting features of it to the members of the Legislatures were two indirect references to Gov. Offices recommondation that the State board be abolished. The Governor's policy for the administration of the State charities, without being named, was severely criticised.

The report of the Taft commission recently sent to Congress by the President contains the first statement at all full and definite as to the problem of the friars in the Philippines. It is apparently a very candid statement of a complicated and difficult problem, as to which the commission submits only suggestions, not having arrived at a final opinion of the best course to be pursued.
CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 28 -- The story of a despetate encounter with burglars, in which an old man twice fought off his assailants, although dangerously wounded, was learned from the police to-day.

EVANSVILLE, Ind., Jan. 28. -- Cities and towns along the Ohio River have begun a crusade against the negroes. The entire trouble dates back to the lynchings of the negroes as Rockport and Booneville for the murder of the white barber Simmons at Rockport last month.
Army. First Lieut, Louis T. Hess, Assistant Surgeon is relieved from further duty in the Division of the Philippines.

ALBANY, Jan. 28. -- In the Senate to-day Assemblyman Snyder's bill providing for the payment of Erie County employes twice a month was received and advanced to a third reading on motion of Senator Davis.

In his remarks at the meeting of the Clearing House Committee yesterday Mr. J. EDWARD SIMMONS pointed out that if Gov. ODELL'S bill for the taxation of bank shares becomes a law the banks of New York City will have to pay annuul taxes amounting to about 3 per cent, of their capital and net profits.

The City Committee of the Citizens' Union met last night in executive session, and for two hours discussed phases of the coming municipal campaign. Because of the incompleteness of the organization of the union in Brooklyn the selection of ten additional delegates at large was deferred.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 63 1/2@65. There were no sale.
HAMPTON, Va., Jan. 28.-- Hampton Institute concluded its celebration of Founder's Day to-day by the dedication of a now building, which received the name Cleveland Hall" in honor of Charles Dexter .

A correspondent of The Sun sends that journal a full report of Lord ROSEBERY'S gloomy remarks at Wolverhampton upon the probable decline of British trade, and follows it up with some observations of his own, tending to confirm Lord ROSEBERY'S views. On the other hand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- When the Senate convened to-day the presiding officer. Mr. Frye, called attention to a dispatch received from the Directory of the Federal Party in the Philippines, praying that action be taken on the measure to enable the President to establish a civil government in the islands.

On Thursday night there closes in the galleries of the National Arts Club one of the most unusual and yet generally interesting exhibitions of the season, that of work by men who have studied animals in conditions of wild life.

-- New York City's postal facilities, never adequate for the city's needs, are now not far from a complete breakdown. The overworking of the employes, long a cause of just complaint on their part, no longer suffices for the prompt handling of the mountains of mall matter that, daily accumulate here, and the congestion formerly characteristic of certain limited seasons of the year now extends over the whole of it.

On Thursday night there closes in the galleries of the National Arts Club one of the most unusual and yet generally interesting exhibitions of the season, that of work by men who have studied animals in conditions of wild life.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- Something of a laugh is going around this afternoon over the variance of opinion between Gov. Odell and the State Tax Commission on the question of a direct State tax. Gov. Odell has urged the abolition of a direct tax as one of the most advantageous of things and has had tax bills prepared so as to meet the State expenses indirectly.

The American Steel and Wire Company, through its Directors, yesterday practically passed the dividends on both the preferred and the common stock of the company until the next meeting of the Directors in March. In so doing the company has come into the ranks of those which hereafter will pass upon the dividends to be paid quarterly instead of declaring them in a lump sum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senators and members of the House are becoming doubtful about the expediency of cutting down the revenues of the Government to the extent of $40,000,000 to $30,000,000 annually, chairman Cannon's announcement that appropriations for this session promise to foot up $800,000,000 and the request of the Secretary of the Treasury for deficiency appropriations of about $14,000,000 have set them to thinking.

A disastrous fire started at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning in the two-story and basement brownstone house 102 East One Hundred and Eighteenth Street, occupied as a dyeing and cleaning establishment by Eugene Le Pienne, who lives with his wife, Ernestine, and his son, Eugene. Jr., fifteen years old, on the second floor of the house.

There was something of a sensation among the guests at the second annual dinner of the Arkwright Club last night when Andrew Carnegie expressed himself freely on the controversy which has been going on between himself and the State of Pennsylvania, and publicly declared his allegiance to the State of New Jersey.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 29 -- Property losses estimated at more than half a million dollars were sustained in a fire early to-day in the business district of this city. The losses are estimated as follows:

The American Steel and Wire Company, through its Directors, yesterday practically passed the dividends on both the preferred and the common stock of the company until the next meeting of the Directors in March. In so doing the company has come into the ranks of those which hereafter will pass upon the dividends to be paid quarterly instead of declaring them in a lump sum.

Yale University will be made $100,000 richer. It Is understood, by a clause in the will of Benjamin D. Silliman, who died at his homo, Clinton and Pierrepont Streets, Brooklyn, on Thursday. The document has not yet been filed in the Surrogate's office, but the will, it is said, was read on Monday afternoon at the Silliman residence.

COWES, Isle of Wight, Jan. 30 -- Queen Victoria's coffin will be borne from Osburne House by the Queen's Highlanders on Friday at 1:45 P.M. to a gun carriage. The household of the late Queen, the royal servants, and the tenantry will be drawn up on the carriage drive. The Queen's pipers will lead the procession through the King's Gate to Trinity Pier.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The New York Police bill was taken up at the opening of the session. Senator Grady immediately moved to recommit it and to strike out that clause which gives the power or removing the Superintendent or Commissioner of Police to the Governor. Senator Grady then launched into an extended argument against the bill, saying:

Chief Examiner IRELAND of the Municipal Civil Service has done well in publishing one of the letters received by him intimating the belief of the writers that money can aid them in passing the examinations. He adds: "When such a communication is received, the writer's name is noted and no application from him for any, position whatever is thereafter accepted."

"This community of interest business of which we hear so much in connection with the operations of J. Pierpont Morgan has at last reached at least a portion of the agricultural community. Florida fruit and truck growers have set the pace and the commission men of this city have an entirely new situation to face," remarked one of them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The President to-day transmitted to the Senate a communication from the Secretary of State accompanying the annual report upon the foreign relations of the United States. The President himself takes advantage of the opportunity to express his commendation of the Consular reports. He says in his message of transmittal:

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Vice Chancellor Emery heard-argument to-day on an application in behalf of Charles Frohman for a preliminary injunction to restrain the production by Manager Jacobs of the Columbia Theatre of the play "L'Aiglon." Affidavits were presented by Mr. Jacobs denying that his play is an infringement on the play written by Edmond Rostand and translated by Louis W. Parker, such as is used by the Frohman companies.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 29 -- Considerable disappointment was manifested in American cricket circles last Autumn because the usual international matches had to be abandoned at the last moment, as a result of a misunderstanding concerning the leadership of the Engllsh team. In order to avoid any such undesirable termination of this year's negotiations, the international Committee has decided to complete its arrangements at an earlier date, and, with this object in view.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 29 -- Cables to the Trinidad papers from Caracas are severely censored. The Venezuelan Government threatens three American reporters with forcible expulsion and is rigorously suppressing press dispatches to the United States. Even diplomatic messages are tampered with.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- In the Assembly today the hill introduced by Mr. Wilson giving authority to the Commissioners of the Land Office to grant and convey to the United States certain lands under the water at Governors Island, and to cede Jurisdiction over the same to the United States, was ordered to third reading, with an immaterial amendment proposed by Mr. McKeown of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Senators and members of the House are becoming doubtful about the expediency of cutting down the revenues of the Government to the extent of $40,000,000 to $30,000,000 annually, chairman Cannon's announcement that appropriations for this session promise to foot up $800,000,000 and the request of the Secretary of the Treasury for deficiency appropriations of about $14,000,000 have set them to thinking.

George M. Smith was sentenced to eighteen months in State prison by Judge Foster yesterday for obtaining $300 from William H. Hopper at 1.518 Webster Avenue as security for the faithful performance of duties of rent collector. Hopper alleged that Smith, who made a pretense of conducting a real estate business at 150 Nassau Street, had swindled several young men out of various sums amounting to $1.400 on similar pretenses.

"This community of interest business of which we hear so much in connection with the operations of J. Pierpont Morgan has at last reached at least a portion of the agricultural community. Florida fruit and truck growers have set the pace and the commission men of this city have an entirely new situation to face," remarked one of them.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment will report out to-morrow morning for amendments and reprinting the Krum bill taxing transfers of property. Over fifty amendments were made at the committee meeting. most of them being purely technical, a word of two having been omitted in the original draft.
