Lee Gong Yee is now the administrator of the estate of Ling Shee Foo. He was appointed yesterday by Surrogate Fitzgerald, and, in addition to being the first Chinaman who has held such an appointment under the laws of this State, he also has the satisfaction of knowing that he is in a position to secure money due him from the estate of the laundryman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The publication in to-day's NEW YORK TIMES of the facts about the Venezuela uprising aroused keen interest at the State Department. While the department had recelved advices indicating the existence of disturbances in Venezuela from Minister Loomis and other sources, nothing was known of their extent, and until a few days ago there was nothing to indicate that there was anything more than sporadic riots and general unrest.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The State Medical Society met in its ninety-fifth annual session here to-day. Dr. A.M. Phelps, President, in his address to the society, attacked the bill of Senator Grady which provides that hospitals shall not be liable for malpractice cases. He said:

Musical rather than dramatic, primarily, was the performance of "The Tragedy of Death," a symbolical drama by Rene Peter, done into English by Edwin Star Belknap, at the Emperie Theatre, yesterday afternoon, but until it has the advantage of performance by a larger and betterequipped orchestra, more closely in touch with the spirit of the work, and of singers of greater vocal and interpretative skill than those employed yesterday.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 29 -- The oil from the great Lucas gusher near Beaumont may become the property of the State of Texas. State Land Commissioner Charles Rogan to-day discovered that the Public Free School Land act passed by the Legislature in 1883 contains a provision that all oils and minerals found on school lands on and after the date of passage of the law shall belong to the State.

Many dealers in Fire Department supplies have during the past two days been making complaints to Controller Coler that they could not furnish the department with any goods because the "combination" by which "Agent" William L. Marks, the close personal friend of Commissioner Scannell, controls the business.
John J. Redner, proprietor of a respectable hotel and restaurant at Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue, adjoining the Murray Hill Theatre, makes serious charges against the police.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The House today, in Commit too of the Whole, considered the Agricultural Appropriation bill. Mr. Wadsworth, (Rep., N.Y.,) Chairman of the Agricultural Committee, explained the salient features of the measure, which carries $4,377,220 for agricultural purposes, being an increase of $353,730 over the amount or the current law.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The entire detective machinery of the United Kingdom and the Continent has been set in motion to protect the royal personages and other notable people now gathering in London. Unwieldy as the Continental secret services ofton appear to be, every effort is being made to unify them, in order that no injury may befall any royal personage attending the obsequies of Queen Victoria.

Affidavits were presented by Mr. Jacobs denying that his play is an infringement on the play written by Edmond Rostand and translated by Louis W. Parker, such as is used by the Frohman companies.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- Some curious evidence was presented to-day during the trial of a suit for libel brought by R.K. Turnbull, an American newspaper man, against B.A. Hawksley, counsel for the British Chartered South Africa Company. The latter accused Turnbull of having, while employed by The Dally Mail, instigated a confidential clerk named Wallis to abstract confidential letters referring to the Jameson raid from Hawkaley's office.

The legislative Committee of the City Club will hold a meeting to-night, and last evening there was a discussion by members of the council of the organization with reference to matters pending before the Legislature. The club and the council will meet on Wednesday of next week.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- There was an Odd Fellows funeral in Cryptic Hall this evening when Cryptic Lodge, No. 75, I.O.O. F., held obsequies over the remains of William Lucas, who is said to have been the oldest Odd Fellow in the State. Mr. Lucas's age is not known, but he was close to ninety years.

The trap shooting competitions held at Intor-Stale Park. Queens. L.I., yesterday, under conditions that let in Runners of all clauses and from all points, drew the largest attendance that any open event of the season has brought out. and us an all-day shoot was the most conspicuous success in its line that the Pigeon Shooting Association has had this year.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 29 -- The Kansas State Temperance Union, which is holding its annual convention here, to-day subscribed over $100 to purchase a gold medal for Mrs. Carrie Nation. Mrs. Hutchinson, President of the State Women's Christian Temperance Union, was made Chairman of a committee to design and purchase the medal.

That interesting female crusader who has excited the attention of Kansas by first hitting with a hatchet every head she saw of a barrel supposed to contain ardent spirits, and then by bearding the Governor of Kansas in his den, has succeeded in concentrating the attention of Kansas upon herself.

Two matches in the New York Inter-Club Bowling: League series were rolled last night. At the New York Athletic Club the home team won two of its three games with the Catholic Club five, losing one by two pins, and on the Harlem Wheelmen's alleys the West Side Republican five won two or three, games with the home team.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Mrs. Minnie Eden, it is said, tried to emulate Mrs. Carrie Nation last night. She is now suffering from two fractured ribs, a broken hand, and several cuts and contusions. Charges of assault are preferred against Mrs. Eden's husband. Oscar Eden. Wendel Repstein, and Mr. and Mrs. August Kimminsky. The latter couple conduct a saloon at 5,130 Haltead Street.

WASINGTON, Jan. 29 -- In the House to-day Mr. White, (Rep., N.C.,) the only colored member of the House, made a speech in defense of the political rights of the colored man. Personally, Mr. While said he eared little about the reduction of representation in the South. True, he said, it would further intrench the Republican Party in power and enable it to dispense with the loyal support of the negro race.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The New York Police bill passed the Senate to-day by a vote of 31 to 14. The division was on strict party lines, but while all the Republican Senators voted for the bill upon its final passage, Republican sentiment in the Senate was not unanimous as to the wisdom of its enactment.

Personally, Mr. While said he eared little about the reduction of representation in the South. True, he said, it would further intrench the Republican Party in power and enable it to dispense with the loyal support of the negro race.

Chief Examiner IRELAND of the Municipal Civil Service has done well in publishing one of the letters received by him intimating the belief of the writers that money can aid them in passing the examinations. He adds: "When such a communication is received, the writer's name is noted and no application from him for any, position whatever is thereafter accepted."

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 29 -- Property losses estimated at more than half a million dollars were sustained in a fire early to-day in the business district of this city. The losses are estimated as follows:

Many dealers in Fire Department supplies have during the past two days been making complaints to Controller Coler that they could not furnish the department with any goods because the "combination" by which "Agent" William L. Marks, the close personal friend of Commissioner Scannell, controls the business.

ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- The New York Police bill was taken up at the opening of the session. Senator Grady immediately moved to recommit it and to strike out that clause which gives the power or removing the Superintendent or Commissioner of Police to the Governor. Senator Grady then launched into an extended argument against the bill, saying:

Application for the probate of the will of Benjamin D. Silliman was made yesterday afternoon to Surrogate Abbott in Brooklyn by Edward Mitchell and Grosvenor H. Hubbard, the executors of the instrument. While the will itself was not filed, the executors presented a synopsis of the instrument.

BRISTOL, R.I., Jan. 30 -- All of the pieces of metal going into the construction of the Belmont cup defender are being smoothed up with unusual care, for the purpose of not only producing a boat that will show the finest workmanship, but also with the view of eliminating every atom of dead weight above the water line.

A meeting of Brooklyn Democrats opposed to the Willoughby Street, and Tammany Hall organizations was held last night in the Real Estate Exchange Building on Montague Street. The session was held behind closed doors, but among those known to be present were ex-Senator M.J. Coffey.

Seven games instead of, the usual six were rolled in the Life Insurance Bowling League tournament on Ehler's Alleys last night, the odd one being a postponed match between the Metropolitan and Mutual teams. The Mutual Life team No. 2 won three games and lost one. the Mutual Benefit and Prudential fives each won two games and lost one, and the Metropolitan team lost four games.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Another New York Bureau of Elections bill has been prepared mid has received the indorsement of the Republican organization of New York City and the Republican legislative leaders. After a conference between W.J. Atterbury and William H. Ten Eyck, Chairmen, respectively, of the Kings and New York County Republican organizations, and the Elsberg special committee appointed to revise the bill, the following measure has been agreed upon.

By a decision of Justice Bischoff, rendered in the Supreme Court yesterday, Mrs. Alberta P. Tracy is declared entitled to redeem property at 160 East Eighty-first Street, and other parts of this city, from foreclosure, the defendant in the suit being Francis Frey, who came into possession under a mortgage from a Mrs. Annie Dolan, to whom the property was sold by Mrs. Kate Maria Williams.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- John de Peyster Douw died here to-day, aged eighty-nine years. He was born in Albany, and, having inherited a competency, never engaged in any business. He was prominent in the militia during the civil war, and between 1835 and 1845 held the positions of Judge Advocate in the Third Brigade, Aide de Camp to the Major General of the Post Division, and Inspector of Cavalry, with the rank of Colonel.

A machine-made Senator can be trusted to vote as his maker bids him. But a legislator o votes against his convictions for a vicious bill which his party organization has ordered the legislature to pass is a poor sort of public servant. This appears to be the position of Senators ELLSWORTH and MARSHALL, in respect to the Stranahan Police bill.

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, Jan. 30. -- Senor Andrade, the former President of Venezuela, sailed for Santiago de Cuba and Havana yesterday, incognito. It is rumored that he intends meeting a filibustering expedition which Is reported to be on its way to Venezuela by way of Cuba. He is said to have purchased arms and to have arranged the details of the expedition when in New York, last Autumn.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Miss Downey of the Apawamis Golf Club made a woman's Rolf record hero to-day by going around in 93. This is the best done by women players on the new course so far, but may be lowered before the season closes. Her card was:

Fire broke out at 4 o'clock yesterday morning in the Hotel Jefferson, 102, 104, and 108 East Fifteenth Street, between Irving Place and Fourth Avenue, and before the firemen got the flames under control two women were killed, a score were more or less severely injured, a dozen thrilling rescues were made, and the lives of over 150 guests were imperiled.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The procession which il escort the body of Queen Victoria cross London on Saturday, as indicated by the War Office orders, issued last evening, will be a gorgeous military pageant. Detachments of forty regiments, with an almost equal number of distinctive uniforms, embracing all arms of the service, will make a constantly changing picture.

WINDSOR, Jan. 30 -- The funeral service in St. George's Chapel on Saturday will begin at 2 o'clock. The body will, it is expected, arrive at Windsor at 1:30 P.M. The route to the chapel will be lined by troops two deep.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Every savings bank doing business on Long Island, by its report for the year ended Dec. 31, 1900, shows increased resources when compared with the previous year. The greatest gain is shown in the resources of the Williamsburg Savings Bank of Brooklyn, which is $3,160,000. The Brooklyn Savings is the next in order, with $1.400,000 added during 1900.

Affected neither by the reports that the St. Paul deal was "off" nor by the engagement of a considerable amount of gold for export, the stock market yesterday opened strong and, with the exception of a midday reaction, held so throughout the day, substantial advances appearing in a number of conspicuous issues.

GLASGOW, Jan. 30 -- In the framework of the America's Cup challenger already set up are, The Associated Press learns, indications of some striking departures from conventional yacht designing, The most noticeable of these is that the bulk of the yacht is thrown extraordinarily far forward. The timbers at present in position suggest the framework of the old bluff-bowed type of yacht more than the modern racing yacht.

ALBANY, Jan. 30 -- The annual reception of Gov. and Mrs. Odell to the State officers, members of the Legislature, Judges of the Court of Appeals, and other public personages and their wives, was held this evening. The Governor's military staff was present. The reception was one of the largest ever held at the Executive Mansion.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- Lord Rosebery presided this morning at a special meeting of the Royal Scottish Corporation called in London to pass resolutions expressing sorrow at the death of Queen Victoria and of congratulation on the accession of King Edward VII. There was a crowded attendance.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The State Department is inclined to discredit the report from Port of Spain to the effect that twenty-five Americans, deserted by their negro employes, are holding out against a band of attacking revolutionists. It is pointed out that if it were true, minister Loomis would certainly have notified the department.

Controller Coler made public yesterday a report of alleged overcharges by William L. Marks for supplies furnished to the Fire Department. Some of the bills of "Agent" Marks, who, prior to Commissioner Scannell's incumbency, never did one dollar's worth of business with the Fire Department, and since has had a practical monopoly in furnishing engines, hose, trucks, and other equipment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- President McKinley to-day received a Congressional delegation of considerable size at the White House. It consisted of about twenty members of the New York delegation in the House and a number of Representatives from Southern States. The object of the visit was to urge the claims of Col. Bertram T. Clayton of Brooklyn, the Representative from the Fourth District, to a commission under the new Army bill.

The Mathews Bulger Company, which came into this city from Boston with a farce called "The Night of the Fourth" a fortnight ago, intending to fill at least a five weeks engagement, will terminate its stay at the Victoria Theatre next Saturday night. The remaining part of its time has been purchased by the management of the succeeding attraction, "My Lady," which at present is being presented in the Columbia Theatre, Boston.

Fire Commissioner SCANNELL'S defense of the noble virtue of constancy to friends reveals a perfect understanding of the Tammany philosophy of politics. I do buy about all the supplies of the Fire Department through this agent MARKS, said the Commissioner. He is my friend. I believe in sticking by friends. I shall stick by MARKS.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 30 -- It was learned here to-day that a secret examination of the accounts has just been made in every department of the Merchants' National Bank, one of the leading financial Institutions of thin city, a fact which gave rise to no little interest and curious surmise as to the reasons for it.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- There will be at least a week's delay in the further consideration of the Now York Single-Headed Police bill passed in the Senate yesterday. Majority Leader Allds of the Assembly will be absent until next Tuesday, so that there is little chance of anything being done before his return.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Frances Duncan of 300 Arch Street and John Thomas Engeman of Brooklyn took place this evening at 5 o'clock in St. Andrew's Church, the Rev. Dr. Armstrong, the rector officiating Miss Duncan was given away by her brother, William D. Duncan.

Consternation was caused last night on the Lexington Avenue cable branch of the Metropolitan Street Railway by a broken strand or the cable which got entangled successively in the grips of two north-bound cable cars, causing runaways and collisions, and creating a panic among the passengers, three of whom were seriously injured while many others received cuts and bruises.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30 -- A cargo of beet sugar from Russia is held up at this port at the instigation of American beetsugar manufacturers, who have demanded that an increased duty be imposed on the product. The Directors of the National Board of Trade and the National Association of Manufacturers held secret meetings here to-day and determined upon immediate action to try and avert a commercial breach between this country and Russia.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- It has become evident that Gov. Odell is very much in earnest in his desire to have the tax bills recommended by him passed, and the impression appears to be strong here that the measures will go through.
"No! So help me God!" was the emphatic way in which Capt. John D. Herlihy answered a question put to him by his counsel. Louis J. Grent. at Police Headquarters yesterday afternoon.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 30 -- The hockey match here to-day between Huntington and Valleyfield, two Canadian teams, was intensely exciting, resulting in a score of 8 to 2 in favor of Huntington. Both teams played strong games. In the last hair, Gurham, right wing of Valleyfield, fell and was carried off the ice.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- It is within the bounds of temperate statement to say that no more remarkable hearing upon any proposed piece of legislation has ever occurred at the Capitol in Albany than that which was given to-day upon the Bell bill to prevent Christian Scientists from practicing their art.

A tribute to Adon Smith, who for more than twenty years was the foreman of the Second Panel Sheriffs Jury, was the occasion for an impressive moment at the panel's annual banquet at Delmonico's last evening. While the two hundred or more guests drank a silent toast the orchestra played "Should Auld Acquaintance Be Forgot."

It is part of the tactics of those who are trying to push through the Hanna-Payne Subsidy bill to meet a demand for amendment by some provision which, to the eyes of those who are not familiar with the facts, meets the objection, but which in reality preserves all the benefits which the bill originally gave to the specially favored interests.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- The House Committee on Banking and Currency acted to-day favorably on the bills "to amend the National banking laws so us to permit National banks to consider and treat their surplus as capital in the restrictions on loans" and amending the banking law as to the designation of public depositories.

The Trustees of the Kings County Co-operative Building and Loan Association caused much surprise yesterday by announcing that the association had decided to wind up its affairs and go out of business. The association was organized about thirteen years ago, and its offices are at 103 Broadway, Brooklyn.

MANILA, Jan. 30 -- All the Filipino leaders or the Federal Party assert their continued fealty to the Catholic Church, excepting Buencamino, Rosario, and Ner. The Church authorities, while intimating unofficially that there is no intention of returning the friars to the localities where the people object to them, have not assured the representatives of the Government to this effect.

"When at cat stole off an wenter way I knowed dat trouble was a-comin," solemnly declared big George Russell, the colored cool of the American schooner Albert Mason yesterday afternoon. Together with the skipper and four other stalwart seaman, he was rescued at sea last Sunday morning by the New York and Porto Rico Company's steamship San Juan.

LONDON, Jan. 30 -- The demand for money man brisk to-day, and the supply was reduced to the extent of compelling borrowers to rely on the Bank of England, where they were charged 5 1/2 per cent for loans of a few days. Consequently, discounts were firm. The pressure is expected to be temporary, though the idea of a reduction of the bank rate to-morrow is less pronounced.

"Consumption is an eminently preventable and curable disease," said Dr. S.A. Knopf, speaking to the members of the Stony Wolde Building Fund Committee, at the residence of Mrs. Samuel M. Jarvis, the Dakota, 1 West Seventy-second Street, yesterday afternoon. "It is curable in nearly all climes, not only in California and Colorado, but also in New York and New England.
ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The following bills were introcUiced in the Assembly to-day:

No doubt that was a curious phrase in the proclamation at Pretoria of the accession of EDWARD VII, and one that was calculated to excite the attention which it has in fact excited. He was proclaimed there, it seems, as King of Great Britain and Ireland, Emperor of India, Defender of the Faith, and so forth, and also as "Supreme Lord of and Over the Transvaal."

ANTHONY, Kan., Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Carrie Nation was outdone here to-day when a band of Woman's Christian Temperance Union women, headed by Mrs. Sheriff of Danville, Kan., completely wrecked the fixtures in four "joints," smashing plateglass windows and mirrors right and left and turning gallons of liquor into the gutters.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- The Tax Listing bill, which has caused such a storm of disapproval from the New York City Merchants Association, is to be changed. Assemblyman Sanford W. Smith has prepared a number of amendments which he believes will overcome objections. One of them is to relieve persons from making a detailed statement of each individual asset.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- Speeches were made in the Senate to-day in opposition to the Ship Subsidy bill by Mr. Turley (Dem., Tenn.,) and Mr. Jones, (Dem., Ark.) Mr. Turley, the first speaker, began by pointing out the large expenditures involved. He declared that already the shipping interests had unusual privileges, under the tariff, the postal bounty laws, and in many other ways.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 -- A conference of Democrats and their associates of the Populist and Silver Republican faith will be held to-morrow as a result of the declaration yesterday by Mr. Frye that he intended to push the consideration of the Ship Subsidy bill to the exclusion of all other business, yielding only to a vote of the Senate.

Some of the country's successful men told the young men of John D. Rockefeller, Jr.'s, Bilbie class last night of those things which had contributed to their success and sought to impress the lessons upon their younger hearers. The occasion was the first reunion of the honorary members of the Young Men's Bible Class of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- "It is reported unofficially," says the Cape Town correspondent of The Dally Mail, "that Gen. De Wet has entered Cape Colony with a fairly strong force.

A remarkable collection of yachting cups and trophies, such as probably was never, before gotten together, is now on exhibition at the new clubhouse of the New York Yacht Club, in West Forty-fourth Street.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The State Medical Society, after discussing the status of the Pathological Institute of the New York State Hospitals and in view of the fact of the serious danger of its work being crippled, decided to make an appeal to Gov. Odell for the full maintenance of that institution.

Justice McAdam, in the Supreme Court, yesterday sustained the writ of certiorari obtained by the Salvation Army for the re- view of the assessment placed on the property at 120-124 West Fourteenth Street and 316 East Fifteenth Street. The officers of the Salvation Army contended that the Fifteenth Street structure was used as a charitable institution, and the property on Fourteenth Street solely for religious purposes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- Representative Landham (Dem., Texas.) submitted some romarks to-day in the House on the question of the reorganization of the Democratic Party. He was given a very attentive hearing by his political colleagues. He reviewed the lines of cleavage within the party with a view to ascertaining whether there was not a common ground upon which the various elements in the party could be reunited for a future purpose.

It appears that the widow and executrix of the chosen sculptor of the Sherman Statue in Washington is in effect advertising for some sculptor, American or European, but preferably American, to come in and complete that work of art in accordance with the intentions of her late husband.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Telegrams received to-day from the West announce the receipt of a new circular from the United States Rubber Company, informing the wholesale dealers of a cut in prices of 35 per cent, and 10 per cent, from the list on first-class goods and of 35, 10, and 10 per cent, on seconds, making a flat 18 per cent, reduction from present quotations. The new prices go into effect to-morrow.

The eleventh annual German Charity Ball, given under the auspices of the Bachelor Circle of the German Liederkranz, Jung Arion, and the Beethoven Bachelors, took place at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The occasion in every respect was successful, the receipts amounting to $10,000, which will be given to the following German institutions in this city:

A peculiar story was told in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon by Dr. George W. Cashing of 221 Schermerhorn Street, who was in court to secure the annulment of a marriage he was alleged to have contracted. Dr. Cushing is a specialist on nervous diseases, and has been an instructor in the Long Island Medical College.

The most gallant rescue effected on the Atlantic during the past few months by a westward-bound vessel occurred on the morning of Jan. 18, when the German steamship Barcelona rescued the crew of the Russian bark Cuba in latitude 50.30 and longitude 13.10. The crew of fifteen had been for days struggling for life.

Magistrate Joseph M. Deuel, President of the City Magistrates, read his annual report at the adjourned meeting of the City Magistrates last evening. It showed that there were fewer arrests during the last year than during any other year since 1893. During the calendar year 1900 93,389 prisoners were arrested and arraigned, as against 98,917 during the previous year. Of the total number of prisoners 73,219 were males and 20,170 were females.
ST. PAUL, Jan. 31 -- President J.J. Hill of the Great Northern returned from New York to-day. In answer to a question about the reported St. Paul deal, Mr. Hill said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- A report from Minister Loomis at Caracas, dated to-day, indicates that the revolution is near an end in the opinion of the Venezuelan Government, in view of a decisive victory gained over the revolutionists near Carupano. Another battle is reported to have occurred recently near La Cuevas, in which both sides lost several hundred men.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- A special train yesterday morning brought to Charing Cross Station a number of members of Continental royal families. Among those who arrived were the Crown Prince of Sweden and Norway. Prince John George of Saxony, the Prince of Saxe-Altenburg, Prince Princess of schaumburg-Lippe, and their respective suites.

Contrary to expectations, the Apawamis Golf Club of Rye did not recieve the award last night, at the annual meeting of the Metropolitan Golf Association, for the metropolitan championship this year. The meeting was held in the Metropolitan Club, and was attended by delegates from twenty-nine clubs out of the forty-four that are in the association.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The State officials are worried, and Gov. Odell is responsible for their uneasiness. The Governor has sent to each of them a request for a detailed statement of the expenditures of his office for the past two years. It is not the work involved in the preparation of these statements which is causing the State officials worry; it is their anxiety as to the purpose of the Governor.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Jan. 31. -- Steve Brodie, actor, alleged bridge jumper, and pugilist promoter, died at the White House at 10:15 o'clock to-night. He was surrounded by his wife, a daughter, the physician, and his friends. The end had been expected the whole of the day, as he lost consciousness early this morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- With a few Republican Senators plainly at work endeavoring to bring the Shipping Subsidy bill to a vote and the stock market referred to as expressing the confidence of stock operators in the passage of the bill, a good deal of talk is heard here of the sort that was common while the sugar schedules of the Tariff bill were under consideration in the Senate Finance Committee.

Arthur Herbst, who said he was stopping at the waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a representative of the Atlas Manufacturing Company of Chicago, was attracted to the scene by the glow in the sky that could be seen from the hotel. He wandered over to the fire, going through Thirtieth Street.

A postponed game between the GermanAmerican and the Greenwich teams in the tournament of the Bank Clerks' Bowling League was decided on Reid's Church Street Alleys last night in addition to the six regular games, making seven in all. The German-American team won three games, the Home team won two, and the Phenix and the Lloyds Plate Glass teams each won one game and lost one.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Charles B. Cory of the Oakley Club, Boston, made the best score, 74, in the qualifying round this morning for the President's Cup tournament. For leading the field he received a medal. The second medal went to Clayton Dixon of the Huntington Valley Club, Philadelphia, for scoring 75.

Half a hundred persons, including firemen, were injured, over 2,000 lives were imperiled, upward of $1,000,000 worth of property was destroyed, almost an entire block was burned, and a Fire Department engine was wrecked as the result of two explosions which took place yesterday in the building of the William Wicke Company, cigar box and label manufacturers, at Thirty-first Street and First Avenue.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are two sides to every question, and on reading in your valued paper to-day a wail on the "sham" of reception giving I feel impelled to say a word on the other side.

No definite Information was to be obtained yesterday concerning the investigation of postal affairs now going on in Jersey City, but an anonymous letter throwing some light on the subject was sent to the local newspapers.

Trading in the outside market yesterday showed even a smaller total than that recorded on the earlier days of the week. Only three or four stokes were in any large demand, while by far the largest part of the list was entirely neglected. As was natural under the circumstances, there were not many changes of importance in prices, and those that did occur were about evenly divided between gains and losses.

-- One hardly knows whether to be the more amazed that resolutions demanding a courteous expression of regret for the death of Queen VICTORIA should have been prepared by members of both branches of our municipal Legislature, or that news of the existence of those resolutions should have led to the instant adjournment and wild flight of the members of both branches.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- At the funeral service over the body of Queen Victoria at Windsor few beyond the actual members of the family will see much after the procession has entered St. George's Chapel, which will be divided by a carved screen, back of which the services will be conducted, invisible to most of the non-royal invited guests on the other side.

Nobody questions the material advantages that would come to Prussia had the Kaiser's pet scheme for connecting the Rhine with the Elbe not been condemned by the sovereign's personal party in the Diet in the Fall of 1899, and nobody now doubts that the elaborated form of the scheme which was recently introduced would, if legislated, promote the industrial and commercial welfare of the Prussian Kingdom to a still greater degree.

Music society, and a dash of athletics were agreeably blended yesterday afternoon and evening at the ladies' day reception in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. The annual Winter ladies' day is one of the attractive social features of the year in the Knickerbocker headquarters, and yesterday proved no exception to the rule.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The system of selling tickets for places of amusement is radically wrong, and certainly could be remedied if the managers would seriously undertake to do it. At various times spasmodic attempts have been made to eliminate "scalping," but no permanent relief has resulted, for these efforts have not struck at the root of the matter.

TOPEKA, Kan., Jan. 31. -- Mrs, Nation started on a crusade against the Topeka "Joints" at 8:30 this morning. She called on live of the beet places, but was ejected from the first one visited, despite her protests that she merely wanted to lecture. A crowd of several hundred people followed her down the street.

The woman who registered at the Park View Hotel, 55 West Forty-second Street, on Wednesday evening as "Mrs. C. Patterson, 1039 Chestnut Street, Philadelphia," and who afterward attempted suicide by taking chloroform, left Bellevue Hospital at 7:15 o'clock last evening. Her identity remains a mystery.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The Senate Committee on Finance to-day reported a number of amendments to the War Revenue Reduction act. The following is a new section:

Advancing quotations were quite generally the order in the stock market yesterday, with actual buoyancy developing in a number of standard securities. The buying, aggressive in many quarters, was by houses acting for substantial banking interests who apparently have been content lately to let the market take its course without any endeavor to put prices higher.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- Boston's market continued quiet and steady. Atchison was bought well, and Chicago, Burlington and Quincy continued in good request. Sugar was neglected and Federal Steel and National Tube were quiet. Kansas City, Fort Scott and Memphis rose 2 more, to 65, a net rise of 22 1/2 this month; Kansas City, Memphis and Birmingham sold at 37, a gain of 13 for January.

It was estimated that at least fifty persons were more or less severely injured in one way or another at the afternoon and evening fires. Many of these did not report their hurts. Following is a list of those who did:

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31. -- After a hard fight of many years duration the first successful competition to the Standard Oil Company's pipe line has been completed. The new line, which is the United States Pipe Line is now finished from the oil fields of McKean County to tidewater in Delaware Bay.

The first night of "The Climbers" there was a loud call for Mr. Fitch after Act III., and when Miss Bingham and her company had endeavored half a dozen times to silence the cries by standing in the snow-storm on the bank of the Bronx and bowing, the author appeared on the scene looking as if he would have preferred to be in a less severe climate.

The electric illumination for the PanAmerican is exercising the wits of the authorities of the exposition. The ordinary method of giving brilliant effects at night to buildings is to outline the chief architectural members with rows of electric bulbs. This has been done hitherto with little understanding, because the men who have the work to do are engineers, not artists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley are entertaining Mr. and Mrs. W.B. Plunkett of Adams, Mass., who are making a short visit to Washington on the way from Florida.

A cablegram was received yesterday by a Danish merchant in this city from Copenhagen, in which it was stated that a committee of the Danish Parliament which was appointed to consider and report on the proposition to sell the Danish West Indian Islands to the United States Government, on conditions directly presented by Secretary of State Hay, had made its report in favor of such sale.

A "Sidney Carton" of real life was led up to the bar of the Yorkville Court yesterday morning. He was shabbily clad in a thin Summer suit, and stood shivering as he faced the Magistrate. His feet were wet, and he looked bedraggled, sick, and despairing. Beside him stood the complainant, Henry Nicholsburg, a prosperous real estate agent and builder.
That is a harsh phrase which Bishop POTTER, as reported by our esteemed contemporary The Journal, has applied to the police force of this city, "An army of looters."

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 31. -- Although the New Jersey system of drawing jurors is viewed with favor in other States, and has given rise to much favorable comment, especially since the Bosschieter murder trial, all the members of the New Jersey bar do not look with favor on the system. Among the latter is ex-Judge Thomas S. Henry of Newark.

Many mysterious hints were heard in Wall Street yesterday as to the outcome of the adjourned meeting of the stockholders of Brooklyn Rapid Transit to be hold to-day. One of the series of reports hart it that two of the Directors will resign, their places being filled by representatives of the Pennsylvania Railroad.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- Senators Slater and Elsberg, constituting the sub-committee of the Senate Judiciary Committee, this morning agreed on certain amendments to the proposed New York Bureau of Election law. This committee has been considering the Stranahan bill and the Raines bill, which differ in the mode of establishing a bi-partisan board, the former providing for appointment of the Commissioners by the Mayor, the latter that they shall be elected by the people.

Justice MacLean of the Supreme Court gave out a statement yesterday in which he explained his reasons for not excusing a juror who had been called to serve in an action for damages against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company when it was proved that this juror was an employe of the company.

A remarkable game of hockey was played between the sevens of the Crescent Athletic Club and the St. Nicholas Skating Club at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The score of 7 to 1 in favor of the Crescents would indicate usually a one-sided and uninteresting contest, but as a matter of fact, the game was extremely exciting and a splendid example of fast, clean work.

COWES, Feb. 1. -- A glittering crescent of light Stretches from Cowes to Portsmouth. It consists of ten miles of warships, which lie at anchor, ready to take their part in to-day's ceremonies, when the navy will pay a last magnificent tribute to the sovereign whose reign was marked by the greatest naval progress in the history of the nation.

ALBANY, Jan. 31. -- The Senate convened at 11:15 o'clock this morning, with Lieut. Gov. Woodruff presiding. Senator Parsons's chair and desk were draped in black and on his desk was a basket of calla lilies, tied with purple ribbons.

The civil list containing the names, residences, nature or position, length of service, and salary or all employes of the City Government was published yesterday as a supplement of The City Record. The list contains 400 printed pages and contains the names of about 42,000 persons.

The residence of the late Col. Lawrence Kip, a four-story brownstone-front dwelling on a plot 33 by 110, at the southwest corner, of Fifth Avenue and Fortieth Street, has been sold for Mrs. E.L. Kip, through Broker E.S. Willard. The buyer's name or particulars regarding his plans for the future of the property were not obtainable yesterday.

While making an effort to pass a north-bound Third Avenue trolley car last evening. Driver Charles Speak of Engine Company No. 33, located in Great Jones Street, Between Hbirteenth and Fourteenth Streets, cross-town car going west.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You printed on Saturday a letter entitled "Justice for the Criminal's Family," signed by "Equity." It is certainly unjust to influence public opinion by consideration only for the "criminal's family." If sympathy and aid are to be invoked for any family connected with criminal cases let them first be directed toward the family which has suffered wrong at the hands of the criminal.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31. -- That "Cyrano de Bergerac" sprang from the brain of the poet Rostand before "The Merchant Prince of Cornville," by S.E. Gross of Chicago reached Paris, is the opinion of M. Coquelin, who appeared before E.H. Sherman, Master in Chancery of the United States Circuit Court, to-day.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 31 -- There was considerable activity here to-day in the Reading issues, reflected from New York. Here the gain reached only a half point for the common and but 3/9 for the first preferred. Choctaw common exhibited considerable strength, at one time advancing 5/8, to 41 7/8.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31. -- After an eventful legislative experience, beginning with the present session of Congress and covering about two month, the bill for the reorganization of the United States Army to-day passed its last stage in Congress, and now goes to the President for his signature.

Representatives of about thirty women's clubs met at the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, yesterday, and formed a committee to consider the matter of a mass meeting of women. The object of the meeting will be to express the sympathy of the women with the work of the Committee of Fifteen.

THE TIMES has entire sympathy with the professed desire of the Governor and the Legislature to secure a fair contribution from all classes of the community to the expenses of the State -- a contribution in proportion to the means of each class made in such form as to be surely and economically collected.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 31. -- The crusade against saloons begun by Mrs. Carrie Nation has caused the business men in several of the large Kansas towns to organize a movement for the resubmission of the prohibitory amendment to the people, with very fair prospects of success. There is not a town in Kansas that does not boast of from one to fifteen saloons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not possible that any one who read the papers or listened to any of the numerous campaign speeches made previous to the election can have forgotten the manner in which all anti-imperialists and Bryan in particular were accused of continuing the hostilities in the Philippines.

The Bellevue Hospital management under the Superintendency of William B. O'Rourke, recently deposed by Commissioner Keller, was condemned in unmeasured terms in a presentment handed up to judge Cowing by the January Grand Jury yesterday just prior to its discharge for the term

The sale of the thoroughbred horses from the Bitter Root Stud, Hamilton, Mon., the property of the Marcus Daly estate, in Madison Square Garden yesterday went with a rush, the Fasig-Tipton Company, in charge of the offering, hurrying matters that the sale might be completed in two days instead of three, as was planned originally.
LONDON, Feb. 1 -- It is officially announced that King Edward has definitely decided to open Parliament in person Feb 14.

As the days, go, yesterday was dull. In any other Winter it might have been called even gray, but this season, when there is so much going on, a space of twenty-four hours without a crowded calendar is looked upon as quite out of the ordinary. There was one dance in the evening, the Cinderella.

MANILA, Jan. 31. -- The act organizing Municipal Governments in the Philippines was passed by the United States Commission to-day, after the adoption of amendments, including a provision disqualifying from voting and holding office any person who after April 1 is in arms against, or aiding those opposing, the United States authority.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 31 -- The arrest of Dr. Ada Sheehan Horman, her husband, and her son, Clyde Sheehan, here to-day on a charge of trying to secure money by extortion and threats has led to the discovery of a letter in Mrs. Horman's room which is said to be in the same handwriting as the "Eloise T." letters sent to Mrs. Cudahy in omaha offering to reveal the kidnapper of Eddie Cudahy for money.

A cleanly janitor sometimes unwittingly makes himself a nuisance. That was the case in more than one instance Wednesday. Not anticipating the snowfall, some of them indulged in their usual custom of washing off the sidewalks shortly before the snow fell. It was then cold enough to have the water remaining on the walks freeze into very smooth and treacherous ice.

Senator Krum said he desired that the bills be reported and take their proper place on the calendar and not be referred back at the present time in their present shape. "I myself will at the proper time move to recommit them," he said.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Will you allow me to enter a feeble and futile "kick" against what seems to me the undeserved and undiscriminating laudation showered on a recent book -- none other than that product of a reputedly aristocratic mind, "Elizabeth and Her German Garden"?
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The House Committee on Judiciary to-day reported favorably bills for an additional United States Circuit Judge in New York City.
HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- Bids for raising the wreck of the United States battleship Maine were opened to-day.

It is a common impression that, the public men at the time of the first Continental Congress and later at the formation of the Constitution Showed in their speech and writing a higher standard of all that goes to make good English than their successors of the present day.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. Kenyon West, in a recent SATURDAY REVIEW, says in the course of an article on the historian Bancroft: "While Minister [to England] one of Bancroft's most important services was his success in procuring a favorable modification of Great Britain's navigation laws."

The Directors of the Saratoga Racing Association yesterday announced that H.D. McIntyre, for many years Secretary of the Brooklyn Jockey Club and associated with all the race-track ventures of P.J. and M. F. Dwyer, has been appointed Assistant Secretary of the Saratoga Club, and that Frederick Rehberger, Secretary of the Queens County Jockey Club and also an office employe of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, has been appointed chief clerk of the Saratoga Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The War Department intends to so slowly in the interesting experiment which the new army law permits it to make of encouraging the Pilipinos to become American soldiers. There are no regular military organizations of Filipinos now, unless the squadron of Philippine cavalry is so considered, and the War Department has not received enough information about that organization to know whether it is a success or not.

The check to the Governor's taxation campaign in the Senate is probably due to a variety of causes, some of which are not readily to be understood by the public, but it undoubtedly gives an opportunity for reflection to all concerned, to the interests affected by the campaign as well as to the Governor.

A gentleman who is familiar with the Venezuelan situation said yesterday: "The reports to hand that the local authorities of the district in which is locatet the New York and Bermudez Company's plant have demanded the surrender of the arms and ammunition in the hands of the American citizens at Guanoco are no doubt correct.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Jan. 31, 1901, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,094,595,878, a decrease for the month of $4,595,432. The debt is recapitulated as follows:

One of the most delightful of this season's books is the modest little blue volume in the Golden Treasury Series, which contains in compact, convenient form, Miscellaneous Pieces by FitzGerald, which Mr. William Aldis Wright, the editor of the "Letters and Literary Remains," is, it would seem, entirely justified in assuming would be interesting to bring together, although many of these selections have already appeared in one form or another.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 1 -- The Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company has purchased fifty acres of land in the northeast suburbs of the city. Large shops and buildings to cost $50,000 will be erected at once.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Feb. 1 -- George W. Allen filed a suit for divorce this afternoon from Lydia J. Allen. The plaintiff charges his wife with habitual intoxication. He asks for the custody of his two young sons, Whitelaw Reid Allen and Walton Holker Allen, who were taken from the home of the Allens in Princeton, N.J., to New York a few days ago by their older brother, Thomas Allen, III.

RALPH A. LYON, P.O. Box 1, Baltimore, Md.: "I wish to exchange 'The Reign of Law,' by James Lane Alien, and the pamphlet. 'A Controversy and Some Opinions,' (containing an attack upon Mr. Allen by the President of the Bible College, which figures in the book, and the former's reply,) for a complete set of The Bibelot for 1899 or 1900.

Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst, President of the Society for the Suppression of Crime, is hot on the trail of ex-District Attorney Gardiner on account of the dismissal, months ago, of several indictments found on the evidence of the society's agents against sundry reputed poolroom and gambling house keepers.

"She was the shortest lady when she stood up and the tallest when she sat down that I ever saw." Such was the opinion of a masseuse at Aix, one Charlotte, who had the honor to be a very great favorite with the Queen, and this criticism accounts for much that is otherwise impossible to explain, in the different pictures of the Queen.
Peter James of Yazoo City, Miss., has presented an observatory and a two-thousand-dollar telescope to the Millsaps College, Jackson, Miss., as a memorial to his father.

The Rev. JAMES M. KERWIN, rector of St. Mary's Cathedral at Galveston, Texas, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "In THE SATURDAY REVIEW Of Jan. 5 John W. Chadwick reviews Abbe Fouard's 'The Last Years of St. Paul.' have no comments to make on the criticism, but I have a decided objection to the use of 'Romanist' in your columns.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Devereux Emmett of Garden City defeated Sidney Maddock of the Crescent Athletic Club in the golf tournament here to-day by the narrow margin of 1 up. George Dutton of Oakley won from A.W. Black of Lakewood, but not easily, for Black held him until the last hole, which was excellent work for the latter.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Molly Elliot Seawell labors through two columns of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW to demonstrate the truth of a proposition involving so many contradictions that her failure is less surprising than her attempt. Possibly she had another object than the one advanced.

Prince Francis Josef Marie Jean von Auersperg, whose marriage to Miss Florence Elsworth Hazard, daughter of E.C. Hazard, the wealthy wholesale grocer, at Shrewsbury Manor, N.J., June 14, 1899, was one of the society events of that Summer season, and who now is house surgeon at the Bayonne City Hospital, has filed a petition in bankruptcy in this city, with liabilities $290,729 and no available assets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Shipping bill was kept steadily at the front in the Senate to-day. Senators Rawlins, (Dem., Utah,) and Berry, (Dem., Ark.,) occupied most of the time to-day in speeches of vigorous opposition. A spirited discussion was precipitated by an amendment offered by Mr. Clay, (Dem., Ga.,) proposing to link the Nicaragua Canal bill with the Shipping bill.

The sale of the George N. Tyner collection of paintings, at the Waldorf-Astoria last evening, served to fill the Grand Ballroom with all audience that, in large part, was present distinctly through curiosity. A picture, sale there is still a sufficiently rare occasion to appeal to those who have time to kill, and that element made its presence felt last night through frequent comings and goings while the sale was in progress.

While going to a fire at 133 West Twenty-sixth Street last evening Hook and Ladder Truck No. 7, located at Twenty-eighth Street and Third Avenue, overturned at Sixth Avenue and Twenty-eighth Street, throwing the driver, Frank Scheneff; the steersman, William J. Tully; Lieut. Patrick Graham, and eleven other firemen to the pavement.

So much has been written about the South African war and the right of the Boers or English to dominate that land that it seems little could be added to enable us to come to a tolerably correct conclusion as to the merits of the respective combatants. The majority of writers have written from a prejudiced, sentimental, or academic point of view.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- According to the reports submitted by the savings banks of the State for the year 1900, those in Manhattan in every instance show increased resources over the totals of 1899. The Seamen's, with its $58,000,000 resources, shows the greatest gain, which is $4,200,000. The Bowery Savings has a gain of $2,250,000, the Bank for Savings $3,200,000, the Emigrant Industrial $3,013,000, the German Savings $2,500,000, and the Greenwich Savings $2,800,000.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- From Victoria Station to Paddington Station the streets of London are now draped in purple, black, and white. In St. James's Street is a perfect blaze of purple of all shades. Piccadilly is gorgeous. Some of the clubs are entirely veiled with purple cloth, relieved by white bows and rosettes.

The death of Verdi, the great Italian opera composer, calls to mind the indebtedness, of opera to works of pure literature. Curiously enough, this fact escapes the average operagoer or else the average operagoer is so ignorant that he does not know it. Verdi, for example, was indebted to famous literary works for some of his finest inspirations.

The dividends paid by the mining companies in the United States in January, as collected by The Engineering and Mining Journal, aggregated $9,015,604, made by seventy concerns. Were the dividends paid by private and other companies that do not report added to this total the amount would greatly exceed that reported above.
The fifth public rehearsal of the fifty-ninth season of the Philharmonic Society of New York took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Tho programme was as follows:

The Suburban Council team won three games from the Claremont Council five in the Royal Arcanum bowling tournament of the Borough of the Bronx on Pump's North Side Palace alleys last night. The scores:

Dwight and Drisler Schools furnished an interesting game of hockey in the opening championship interscholastic contest at the St. Nicholas Rink yesterday afternoon. Dwight School, though lacking in a good goal keeper, finally managed to win out through the superiority of her team play by a score of 4-3.

The Harriman syndicate has at last secured control of the Southern Pacific Company through the purchase of the stock of that company held by James Speyer. THE NEW YORK TIMES, some months ago, announced that this syndicate, in which, among others, J.P. Morgan and W.K. Vanderbilt are interested, was seeking control of the Southern Pacific Company.

A delegation of fifteen women from Bedford Park called on Mayor Van Wyck yesterday and told tales of woe. Mayor Van Wyck looked incredulous when Mrs. F. Dowe, the speaker for the delegation, related how the people of Bedford Park counted the recent fall of snow as a "godsend, and that the housekeepers were melting it in order to secure the necessary water to cook with."

If we are to take the history of the time as really governed by Cabinets and diplomatists, the difficulty of finding any adequate hero becomes an impossibility. Froude had started apparently with the belief that Elizabeth would take the leading part. The English Nation was beginning its great career, and (he said in 1852) Elizabeth's part was "to recognize, to love, to foster, and to guide."

Mr. Roden's little volume may be considered the second part of Oscar Wegelin's "Early American Plays, 1714-1830," for it is a record of the American plays which have been published since the latter date. Old playgoers may turn over the pages of "Later American Plays" with the feeling that the compiler has left much to be desired.

Dr. Gross has rendered a service to all students of English history by his admirable bibliography, which will be henceforth an indispensable aid to the study. It contains over 3,000 numbers of books and articles relating to British history up to the end of the Middle Ages, and, with the subsidiary items included in the notes, the sum total cannot be much less than 5,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Chief Willis L. Moore of the United States Weather Bureau has issued this forecast of February weather:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A petition containing charges against Robert W. Wilcox, the Hawaiian Delegate in the House of Representatives, was submitted, to-day to the House Committee on Elections No. 1, which has other petitions against Wilcox before it. The charges are made in writing by George D. Gear of Hawaii, who submitted letters purporting to be copies of letters written by Wilcox to Filipino officials.

There seems to be one invariable method of making an anthology of English verse nowadays. You take Palgrave's Golden Treasury (which was really selected by Lord Tennyson) and then add to it your own favorite poems, and the result is a new selection. In a measure this is what Mr. Quiller-Couch has done in his "Oxford Book of Verse."

Francis Richard Stockton was the guest of honor at a reception by the Authors Club, at its home, in the Carnegie Building, on Thursday evening. The occasion was marked by appreciative tributes to the author and general friendliness to the man. Both were expressed in speech and song, and several original poems read in honor of the guest of the evening removed even a suggestion of prosiness.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 1 -- The annual banquet of the Lawyers' Club was held to-night in Oraton Hall, when the centennial of John Marshall taking the oath as the first Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court was celebrated.

MANILA, Feb. 1 -- Archbishop Chapelle to-day, in response to a request for a statement of his position on the Question of the friars, said he must decline at the present juncture. He considered that the time was inopportune and might cause embarrassment to the United States Government and the commission concerning pending matters of which he could not speak.

BOSTON, Feb. 1 -- The Boston market blossomed into activity this morning. Over 5,000 shares of Sugar changed hands in that time, with 7,000 Atchison and 6 Chicago, Burlington and Quincy. In home specialties Boston Water Power easily led, 7,700 shares selling in the morning, with price up 1 3/8, at 4 3/4, besides 400 shares of the old stock, sold at 3.

Aggressive strength showed in the stock market yesterday under the stimulus of important developments in the railroad situation -- developments forecast by THE NEW YORK TIMES some months ago, but at that time vigorously and officially, denied as altogether beyond the range even of possibilities.
WINDSOR, Feb. 1 -- The cover of the great stone sarcophagus at Frogmore has been slowly rolled away.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In his letter on the above subject in your issue of Saturday, "T." finds fault with boxing being taught at St. Bartholomew's Chapel clubroom, and an exhibition of the science under the auspices of Drs. Greer, Bottome, and Sturgis. Presumably, he would be still more shocked at a display of pugilistic skill by one of those reverend gentlemen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The ground for President Castro's seemingly inexplicable defiance of the United States in the asphalt matter is beginning to come out. The Venezuelan Dictator has planted himself firmly on the identical ground which the United States has so often been obliged to take when foreign Governments have made demands on it -- the double nature of the political system here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A paragraph which is understood to represent the views of the Administration with respect to Cuba appeared in the newspapers to-day. According to this article the Administration is greatly interested in the outcome of the Cuban Constitutional Convention as to whether this country will be recognized as having rights in certain directions paramount to those of any other nation.

PORTSMOUTH, Feb. 1 --Three special trains brought down from London early this morning the members of the Houses of Lords and Commons, the diplomats and other officials, and the correspondents. The members of Parliament and correspondents, the latter representing every nation, embarked on a small steamer and were entertained at luncheon as guests of the Admiralty.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is commendable strength of character shown by you in publishing a communication under this heading in this day's TIMES. There is probably no other paper that would have dared to publish a letter whereby the public is warned that the same forces which defeated Mr. Low in 1897 will again try to defeat any other save a Tammany candidate this year.

HOT SPRINGS, S.D., Feb. 1 -- Mrs. Pearl Carley Hunt of New York City has secured a divorce from her husband, R. Howland Hunt, on the ground of desertion. Last Monday W.K. Vanderbilt and a large party of New York people of social prominence came here to be present at the granting of the divorce.

The thought of it recurs as the weeks pass, and the Christinas number, with their more than usual competition of special features, are half forgotten.

COWES, Feb. 1 -- Although it lacked the spectacular grandeur of the naval display, the ceremony of taking the body of Queen Victoria from Osborne House to the royal yacht Alberta was of almost equal interest.

THOMAS McGAW, the proprietor of the Queen's Hotel, Toronto, died yesterday at his residence in Toronto. He had suffered from diabetes.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Feb. 1 -- Game Constable Jacob Abrams was found dead in his house here to-day under peculiar circumstances. Neighbors found him lying on the floor covered with two overcoats and with a coating of gold leaf on his upturned face.

The irritable race of writers is not the most envious tribe of men. Far from it. When the news of the battle of Manila Bay came, a judicious naval officer interjected a curious comment upon the universal gratulation. "And to think," he said, "that every naval officer of flag rank is now damning Dewey for his luck."

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- The Dally Telegraph says to-day: "In the annals of a thousand years and the records of our island dynasties there has been nothing to equal or approach the opening scene of the last progress of the Mother of her People. The first stage has been traversed in the most regal and gracious burial that ever passed over English sea and land."

Halsey Corwin, an ex-Controller of the City of Brooklyn, died on Thursday night at his home, 1,400 Pacific Street. Mr. Corwin had suffered from dropsy and heart trouble for a long time. He was born in this city in 1835, and had made his home in Brooklyn since 1867. He was elected an Alderman-at-Large in 1883, and re-elected in 1885.

CAMBRIDGE, Feb. 1 -- Never in the history of baseball at Harvard has the prospect of having a winning team been stronger than it is this year. All the men with one exception are back, reliable "Bill" Reid is at the helm again, and with a team of veterans behind him, Harvard's nine should be one of the strongest that she has ever had.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- The market responded to the boom in New York and there was considerable activity, with firm prices in the Readings, Philadelphia Electric, and Lehigh Valley. Lehigh Valley advanced 1/2. Railways Company General sold at 2 7/8, and was wanted by brokers representing the management at 2 3/4.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The hearing on the Bell bill to prevent Christian Scientists from practicing their art will be resumed next Wednesday, and the second hearing promises to be of even greater interest than the first.

"The Private Life of King Edward VII. (Prince of Wales 1841-1901") will be definitely published by D. Appleton Co. next week. As may be gathered from the extracts, which we presented last Saturday, the work presents a vivid and intimate picture of the personality of the man who has just become England's sovereign.

Some improvement showed in prices yesterday in the outside market, but transactions were on a scale even smaller than that of Thursday. The market was favorably affected by the greater strength, and activity of the Stock Exchange trading, but there were few or no specific developments to influence prices of outside stocks.

In this, as in that, our Lord is sitting on the Mount of Olives, in the dusk of the early evening, and alone with His disciples. In this, as in that, He is giving them instructions concerning His second coming.

Brewers and saloon keepers in this city and throughout the state have been making bitter complaint on the ground that it was possible under the Raines law for citizens to mulct them of large sums of money by instituting civil proceedings against them for violations of the law, which were not brought in good faith.

The women's municipal government class of the League for Political Education had an exciting time yesterday. Miss Adele Fielde, the teacher, gave the members an object lesson in a visit to the Tombs. The inspection began with a visit to the boys' prison, where chairs were provided and a talk was given by Mr. Wlllard, who is in charge of the educational work among the boys.

"If necessary to secure their passage, the tax bills affecting banks, trust and insurance companies will be made caucus measures," said an officer of the Republican State Committee at the Fifth Avenue Hotel last night.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Judge Dykman's recent critical review in your columns of certain statements of fact in the chapter of the new History of Westchester County devoted to the capture of Andre calls for a candid reply from me as the author of that work. At present I am not disposed to join with any formality in the controversial discussion that Judge Dykman's article has excited.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading the "prophecy" of Three Thirty Three in your paper to-day, and laughing over his very unhappy ideas regarding the delightful entertainment known as the "afternoon tea," I beg that you will allow me space for a few words on the other side of the subject.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Bids for the construction of three protected cruisers were opened at the Navy Department to-day. Neafie Levy of Philadelphia, at $2,740,000; the Newport News Shipbuilding Company, at $2,741,000, and the Bath Shipbuilding Company, at $2,750,000, appear to be the successful bidders for the three cruisers.

Another evidence of the understanding between steel interests was forthcoming yesterday, when Welles, Herrick Hicks, the brokers of 15 Wall Street, who had for some time been advertising for proxies to be voted at the American Steel and Wire meeting, announced that they desired no further proxies and returned those which had been sent them.

While there have been no important developments in trade circles during the week all the reports that come to hand tell of continued improvement. Seasonable weather has done much to stimulate those lines of trade which heretofore have been inclined to dullness, and to this largely is due the betterment reported in boots and shoes, woolens, and, generally, Winter goods.

Mrs. Mary Johnson, sick and destitute at the age of 102 years, was yesterday taken from her two-room apartment at 314 West Twenty-first Street and conveyed in an ambulance to Bellevue Hospital. A stout patrolman carried the little old woman tenderly down the stairs while she made a joke about the performance.

Here is a curious Juvenile which in allegorical form portrays, by the personification of mental traits, such as cheerfulness, temper, patience, c., their cause and effect upon character. Cheerfulness, of course, with the aid of patience and other worthy attributes conquers in the end, but the conflict is often discouraging, and defeat is frequently near at hand.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- McAlister, Death, Campbell, and Kerr, the assailants of Jennie Bosschieter, have begun to serve their long terms of imprisonment in State prison. They arrived at the Clinton Street station of the Pennsylvania Road at 8:50 this morning. Thence the prisoners, who were in charge of Sheriff Stuhr and a Deputy, and handcuffed in pairs, walked to the prison, a mile and a half distant.

PORTSMOUTH, Feb. 2 -- When the Alberta entered Portsmouth Harbor at 4:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon, with the minute guns in the forts sounding and the bells of all the churches of the city tolling, Nelson's frigate Victory fired a salute from muzzle-loaders. The marines manning her stood at arms.
Controller Coler decided yesterday to hold up the bills for hose supplied to the Fire Department by "Agent" William L. Marks because of reports that it was of poor quality.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: There are in New York certain valuable historical papers, too valuable to be permitted to remain in private hands or to rest outside or some safe depositors. They recall, it is true, a time of bitterness and struggle, but they are in the category of such data as are necessary for accurate history, and as curios their value is inestimable.

Mr. P. De Roo informs us in his preface that it was while delving in the Vatican archives to obtain information concerning "the much-slandered" Pope Alexander VI. that he came upon stray bits of information pertaining to the religious state of America before the Spanish discovery which spurred him on to the compilation of the work now under consideration.

Grahams Policy, ex-cashier of the Hoffman House. Manhattan, who has been in Raymond Street Jail, Brooklyn, because of his refusal to obey an order of the court demanding that he make an accounting of the estate of his sister, Sarah Jane Quin. was yesterday taken from jail long enough to testify in a suit in the Brooklyn Supreme Court, before Justice Wilmot M. Smith.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It is never agreeable to destroy pleasant fancies and beliefs, but really the statement of Mrs. Thomas Barrington in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW is a draft upon credulity which is a little too large.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Secretary of the Navy has received an interesting letter from Gov. Allen of Porto Rico, formerly Assistant Secretary of the Navy. The communication sets at naught the many alarming reports telling of distress and poverty among the islanders, and chronicles a constantly growing measure of prosperity in Porto Rico.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 1 -- President Cowan and First Vice President Murray of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company came here unexpectedly to-day and made an important announcement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing in THE TIMES the official reports of the unsanitary condition of the Sing Sing State Prison, which is a breeder of malaria and typhoid fever, and being touched by the awful situation of the inmates, (many of them ought to be out and many persons who are out ought to be in,) I make a suggestion through your paper to the State officials.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- Half a million of those who a few days ago were Queen Victoria's subjects, lining the shores of the Solent yesterday, witnessed a majestic pageant and bade a last farewell to their late beloved ruler. The display was a fitting tribute from a nation owning Nelson for its hero to its dead monarch.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your interesting "versions" of the capture of Andre have induced me to add this very valuable account of the arrest. The paper on which it is printed is tanned and stained with age and for years has lain hidden between the pages of an old scrapbook belonging to my father:

A pretty blue-eyed baby, hardly six weeks old, was deserted last night by a young man and an old woman, in a cab which they had hired to take them from the West Shore Ferry at the foot of West Forty-second Street to the Long Island Railroad Ferry at the foot of East Thirty fourth Street.

-- Fierce condemnation is heaped by Fire and Water upon Fire Marshal SEERY'S report on the Tarrant explosion, which is described as the work either of a man who has not told all he knows as to where the responsibility for the disaster lies, or of one incompetent to express any opinion at all upon the subject.

A very elaborate entertainment was given last evening by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Mackay at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was a dinner dance, and it embraced an entire evening's amusement. The dinner, which was served in the Astor Gallery at a great S-shaped table, was followed by a cotillion in the East Room, and then by a supper in still another apartment, with entirely different arrangement of tables and decorations.

LONDON, Feb. 2.--The body of Queen Victoria is now lying before the altar of St. George's Chapel Royal, at Windsor. To-day it was carried through the capital city of her empire. Her family, with Kings and Princes and representatives from every part of the world, had assembled to pay their last tribute to her.

Twenty small milk dealers along the upper east side, who were offering for sale adulterated milk, were gathered in by Board of Health Inspectors in a recent unexpected Sunday raid, and their capture revealed the tact that on Sundays milk may be bought much cheaper in many portions of the city than on any other day of the week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Just now, when the subject of expectoration in public conveyances is being agitated, it might be interesting to learn from good authority what difference, if any, exists between the throats of men and women. Is there a difference in the throats of the sexes, or does it lie wholly in early training?

LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 2 -- The Nebraska Legislature may fail to elect a Senator. The third week of balloting for Senator has resulted in no election, the leading contestants, D.E. Thompson, Assistant Secretary of War Meiklejohn, State Senator F. M. Currie, and Edward Rosewater, editor of The Omaha Bee, developing no substantial gains and their vote showing no losses.

Yale's champion hockey team had Pennsylvania completely at her mercy in the intercollegiate championship game at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The score of 15 to 0 shows how badly the Quakers Were outclassed. In the second half, especially, Yale scored goal after goal in such quick succession that it was difficult to keep track of them.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 2 -- The oldest resident of Newport cannot recall the time when there was so much building in hand among the cottage colony as that of to-day, as a walk along the "Summer colony" plainly tells. The work in hand includes the construction of many new villas and general renovations and extensive improvements.

Charles Wesley wrote hymns as naturally as the lark sings. "He lisped in numbers for the numbers came." His hymns Were the outcome of his successive experiences. Birth, marriage, death; his own or his friends' joys and sorrows; Scripture story; and the defeat of the Pretender; earthquakes, battles, epidemics -- all furnished him with topics.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several of your correspondents have lately asserted that the spitting habit is due to the ubiquitous catarrh. This is only partially true. It is due very much more to the want of self-restraint, habits which seem to be approved in various ways and grades of society.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 2 -- Charles Nicole, one of the chief solicitors for the Mutual Fidelity Company of Baltimore, has been arrested in Chambersburg, Penn., on a charge of conspiracy to defraud. Nicole has been soliciting for the Mutual Fidelity Companies of Baltimore and Delaware in that part of Pennsylvania, and the arrest was made at the request of the authorities of Franklin County, Penn.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 2 -- John I. Waterbury, President of the Manhattan Trust Company of New York, is unable to enter the one-hundred-and-fifty-thousanddollar mansion he is erecting here. This is the result of a dispute between Mr. Waterbury and the firm of Sturgis, Hill Co., New York contractors, who are building the house.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- Among the visitors at the Atlantic works to-day, where the Lawson cup defender is in process of construction, was Rear Admiral Sampson of the navy yard, accompanied by Naval Constructor Baxter and Commander Kearney of the Steam Engineering Department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of this morning I saw a letter from "Bohemian," in which he attacks the legality of my suggestion as to the suppression of the theatre ticket speculator nuisance. He asks the question, "How, then, can the Legislature interfere in the regulation of this private property?"

With two weeks more of the regular season, New York will be very gay until Lent, which is now knocking at the portals of society, shall have effected its entrance. Each day brings news of new entertainments, and with the closing seances of the dancing classes and all these other affairs, there will hardly be an evening on which something is not taking place.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- With every circumstance of splendid pomp befitting the obsequies of so mighty and well-beloved a monarch, all that is mortal of Queen Victoria was to-day borne through the streets of her capital. The solemn magnificence of yesterday's opening phase of these last rites was fully maintained.
