ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- Public services in honor of the memory of Queen Victoria were held to-day at All Saints' Cathedral in this city. They were attended by State and city officials, members of local English societies, clergymen of varied denominations, and citizens in general.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 2 -- At the recent term of the United States Court held in this city during the trial of a white man by the name of W.M. Crowder, the commission of a crime was brought to light which has changed the entire course of life of a young man and a young woman and well high wrought a tragedy.

With the unexpected refusal of the Apawamis Golf Club to loan its links to the Metropolitan Golf Association for the metropolitan championship this year, popular opinion is now turned toward Baltusrol, Tuxedo, Nassau County, and Lakewood, all of which came forward at the recent annual meeting with generous offers to do their best toward insuring the success of the coming championship.

The second concert this season in New York by the Pittsburg Orchestra will be given in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening, Feb. 12. Again is the programme representative of Victor Herbert's modern tendencies, and after the success of the orchestra in the same hall last month this programme offers pleasant anticipation:

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 2 -- Trolley legislation, petitions have been fast and furious this week. Over a score of new petitions have gone into the House, representing all sorts and conditions of capital throughout the State. There is much criticism among railroad lawyers over the status of many of the companies asking for new trolley charters.

In the field of athletic sport the newest popular favorite, and one that is gaining partisans with a rapidity that is second only to the golf stampede, rejoices in the remarkable name of "squash." The evolution of a pastime is conspicuously and perfectly illustrated in this oddly named but now almost universal game.

"They tell me I should have been a lion trainer," said the woman who is the proprietor of an aristocratic private country 'zoo,' where many city pets make long visits on the occasions of their masters or mistresses being out of town, on account of illness, or for various other reasons. "All animals seem to like me," went on the zoo proprietor, "and I can do anything with them.

PORTSMOUTH, Feb. 2.--The body of Queen Victoria was taken from the royal yacht Alberta this morning to a special carriage, and conveyed to the King's train, which started for London at 8:53 A.M., amidst the boom of the guns from the forts. The scene was pathetic and imposing.

From The Montgomery (Ala.) Advertiser. Our esteemed contemporary, The Macon (Ga.) Telegraph, is again -- or still -- contending that the Southern Democrats should assume the leadership of the party. It says:

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- A solemn requiem mass for the repose of the soul of Queen Victoria was celebrated at a special service by the Cowley Fathers at the Church of St. John the Evangelist, to-day. The Rev. Father C.M. Field made a brief address of eulogy. A communion service followed the requiem.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES has recently discussed the question of personal taxation with great fairness. The great trouble is its inequality. Here, for example, is a true and by no means an uncommon case. A trustee has a personal estate of $100,000 to invest for the support of a widow and four dependent children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- In the presence of a distinguished assemblage, including the President of the United States and his entire Cabinet, impressive tribute to-day was rendered to England's dead Queen. The ceremony occurred at St. John's Episcopal Church, beginning at 11 o'clock this morning, and was distinctly official in character.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Sunday last you print a communication signed by William A. Bradish which proposes that the car companies be compelled to furnish a "small spittoon beneath each seat." Now, I must frankly confess that I don't see that this would be altogether satisfactory from a sanitary standpoint.

These are hard times for the makers of railway maps. Each week, almost every day, brings changes in "territory." The latest and greatest of these changes are involved in the transaction, yesterday officially announced, of the taking over of the Southern Pacific system by the Wall Street syndicate of which E.H. Harriman is nominally the head.

John B. Merrill, District Attorney of Queens County, talked last night at Ozone Park of the indictments for neglect of duty and maintaining a nuisance found by the Queens County Grand Jury against James P. Keating, Commissioner of Highways of Now York City, and incidentally the indictment of "Battle Axe" Gleason's Woodside Water Company, the gravamen of the finding being the condition of Jackson Avenue, Long Island City.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 2 -- Harvard to-day defeated Brown at hockey for the second time this year by the score of 9 to 2. The ice was in fine condition, and both teams played a fast game. Brown, however, was completely outclassed and was able to get the puck past Manning but once each half.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 -- The sorrow occasioned in this city by the death of Queen Victoria found formal expression to-day in memorial services held in many of the churches under the auspices of the allied British-American societies. As a token of respect for the memory of the dead Queen the Stock Exchange and the Commercial Exchange were closed to-day.

WINDSOR, Feb. 2 -- The service over the body of Queen Victoria in St. George's Chapel Royal this afternoon was one of the most marvelous sights of all the funeral ceremonies. It only lasted from 3:20 to 4 P.M., but for three hours previously the great personages of the United Kingdom had waited patiently for the arrival of the funeral procession.

It was noised about at the auction sale of Marcus Daly's horses that ex-Secretary William C. Whitney, having become thoroughly tired of making money, had decided to take a long and rather needed rest. Gossips had it that the first step in this direction will be when he goes to his house in Aiken, S.C., taking along with him a string of the best saddle and hunting horses he owns.

ALBANY, Feb. 2 -- John Henry Farrell, editor and proprietor of The Albany Times Union, died to-night from heart disease after eight days' illness. He was born on the Abbey farm, near this city, Sept. 1, 1839. In 1855 he entered the employ of the late Luther Tucker of The Cultivator and Country Gentleman, with whom he remained eighteen years.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 2 -- The action taken by the Yale Corporation this week in dropping all required work for sophomore year is regarded in Yale circles as being by far the most important step taken by President Hadley since he came into office.

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- At daylight to-day great crowds began to assemble at every point of vantage along the route of the royal obsequies. So peaceful and noiseless was the progress of the ingathering hosts that the constantly swelling throngs and the rhythmic tread of the assembling troops seemed to accentuate the solemn stillness.

PRETORIA, Feb. 2 -- Gen. De Wet had 3,000 men in his command when he crossed the Thaba N'Chu line going southward. The Boers have collected in force in the Eastern Transvaal in order to facilitate their escape.

From the days of Herodotus we find phrases employed by the Greeks which exhiblt a satiric ill-humor about suffering. The gods are pictured as envying human happiness, and therefore giving men little of it; it was even said that human happiness 'provoked the anger of the gods. In their tragedy, which was a State education, natures is shown as cruel to the good and mysterious in malignity.

Uncle Sam's large and well-organized Secret Service is made up mostly of men who come properly under the head of detectives with police powers, but it has its class of bona fide spotters, whose entire duty it is to ingratiate themselves with persons suspected of having designs to evade the Custom House duties and to warn the baggage Inspectors at this end of the impending swindle.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 2 -- An official statement was made to-day by the Players' Association in session in this city. It is addressed to the members of that association and in part is as follows:

LONDON, Feb. 2 -- It is unnecessary to repeat the story of the military pageant into which the late Queen's funeral has been converted. You will have enough and to spare on that subject, from other sources. I may, however, say that the torrents descriptive writing with which the papers are filled meet much less response from the public than might be supposed.

Hundreds of the employes of Bloomingdale Brothers and their friends attended the annual ball of the Bloomingdale Brothers' Mutual Aid Association at the Madison Square Garden last night. The great hall was illuminated with many electric lights, and was beautifully decorated with flags and flowers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have an anecdote of the late Queen Victoria which so well illustrates the words of the American in a speech in London of "her queenliness as a woman and her womanliness as a Queen," and which I am sure has never appeared in print and I think should not be lost.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The House spent the day until 3 o'clock in the consideration of the Post Office Appropriation bill. The struggle over the question of restoring the appropriation for pneumatic service and the reduction of railway mail pay were precipitated by amendments offered, but no action was taken.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The attempt to enforce the State law taxing personal property by the present Board of City Tax Commissioners is exciting much public discussion, and, while one gentleman asserts in your columns that the present tax is, in his opinion, "a premium on perjury and a punishment of truthfulness," another of opposing views justly intimates that opinions alone are not conclusive.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Resorters in search of change from the humdrum of the city descended in a small-sized army upon Lakewood on Saturday, and the great hotels of the place recorded larger numbers of guests than have ever before been noted here in January. Page after page was added to the changeful stories told by registers at the Lakewood Hotel, Laurel-in-the-Pines, and Laurel House.

A dramatist who has no fewer than four original plays, not "dramatizations" or adaptations, running in metropolitan theatres, in a season when the output of American drama has been even smaller than usual, seems fairly entitled to the foremost place among his fellow-craftsmen. Clyde Fitch, is the author of "The Climbers," now drawing crowds at the Bijou Theatre, and of "Barbara Frietchie," lately put forward with large pictorial effects at the Academy.

DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 1 -- There is among shipbuilders of the great lakes a decided recession from the policy in force for years -- that of building ships as large as can be made. A type of steel ship about 400 feet long and of about 5,000 gross tons' capacity now seems to be the thing most shipowners want, and most of the forty steel freight vessels building on the lakes are of that type.

Sensible and honest opponents of the subsidy scheme will be more disgusted than surprised at the announcement by Senator JONES of Arkansas that the Democrats are not united in their efforts to defeat this outrage.

John A. Hendrick and Dr. L.L. Mial, both veteran billiard players and members of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, will have the honor of opening the Class A championship billiard tournament, which will begin on Tuesday night in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street.

Holiday greetings from the remotest parts of the civilized world continue to arrive at the General Post Office in accordance with a pretty custom established years ago under which Postmasters of all large offices in the Postal Union exchange the compliment's of the season at New Year's.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I would like to add my voice to the chorus of indignation raised by the long-suffering theatregoers of New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Army Reorganization bill is now a law. It was signed by the President at 12:40 P.M. to-day.

James O'Connell, President of the International Association of Machinists, started last week on a tour through the principal cities throughout the United States to arrange for the nine-hour workday campaign of the machinists, which goes into effect next May. He has visited some of the Eastern cities and this week will communicate with the local unions in the Western cities over which his organization has jurisdiction.

Thomas Ward, alias "Dublin"; Thomas Bennett, and William McConnell were arrested last night by Detectives. Dean and Hahn of the Oak Street Station, in a store on the ground floor of 43 Oliver Street, at pistols' point. The men are well known to the police, who say they have been robbing business houses of valuable merchandise.

Services resembling in some measure those which took place in England over the body of Queen Victoria were held in a number of churches in this city yesterday. They were characterized by great solemnity. Scarcely any of the churches could have held larger congregations. In fact, many sad-faced men and women were unable to obtain admission.

Two games of curling were played yesterday on Van Cortlandt Lake, and a small army of spectators was attracted to the scene to watch the enthusiasts of this famous Scotch sport. One of the events was for the Royal Caledonian Medal, and this occasioned an unusually hot match between the St. Andrew's and Yonkers Club rinks.
The weekly statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $5,960,625. The banks now hold a surplus of $24,838,825 above the legal requirement.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 2 -- Hugh Kerr, father of George J. Kerr, one of the four assailants of Jennie Bosschieter, died at 3:20 this afternoon. Mr. Kerr was a strong and robust man up to the day of his son's arrest, but almost from that time his health began to fail.

"Agent" William L. Marks sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday some affidavits and an answer to the charges made by Controller Coler that the city is being mulcted in large sums of money through orders for supplies furnished to the Fire Department, and also that the department is being furnished with an inferior line of goods.

PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 2 -- To-day witnessed the crowning event of the four days' meeting of the Young People's Society of Christian Endeavor, in observance of the twentieth anniversary of the organization of the first society, when a bronze memorial tablet was unveiled at Williston Church, the birthplace of the movement.

The week has witnessed continuing activity in the same classes of property which have engaged attention for some time past, with enough in the way of new features to show that the recent favorable movement of the market is becoming steadily broader in its scope. In this connection mention may be made of a deal just closed involving 250 lots in the WestChester Avenue section of the Bronx.

MANILA, Feb. 2 -- Lieut. Hicken and a detachment of thirty of Company M. Forty-fourth Regiment, while crossing a river Tuesday night were surprised by insurgents gathered at Fiesta San Lucia, Island of Cebu. They were attacked in front and on both flanks by a hundred rifles and more bolomen.

We have freaqently had occasion to point out that the difficulty with the police can be remedied only by beginning at the top. Practically the lowest in rank of the officials responsible for the condition of the police is the Chief, whose control over all below him is nearly absolute.

EAST GREENWICH, R.I., Feb. 2 -- Seneca N. Tayler, the St. Louis lawyer, who was a friend of the Fosburg family at Pittsfield, working in their behalf, arrived here from Providence this afternoon and went to the jail where he interviewed William McCaughey, one of the so-called wire gang, who is serving time for thefts.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The Senate met at 11 o'clock to-day, and with the exception of an hour and a half at the beginning of the session, devoted the entire day to the discussion of the Ship Subsidy bill. Mr. Turner (Fusion, Washington,) and Mr. Mallory (Dem., Fla.,) were the speakers on behalf of the opposition.

Apropos of this sxibject of rattlesnakes, the remarkable statement may be quoted, recently made by Prof. Edmund J. James of the University of Chicago, to the effect that death from rattlesnake bite is a great rarity. He has been working for twenty years, he says, to obtain a well-authenticated case of death from such a cause.
HLIFAX, N.S., Feb. 3 -- Halifax being the military headquarters in British North America, was the chief city of mourning in Canada.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- A special from Terre Haute, Ind., says: "Alice Nielsen limped through 'The Fortune Teller' before a packed house here. The singer is suffering severely from a sore in her foot caused by wearing a wooden shoe in 'The Singing Girl.' The foot became infected with the coloring matter from her stocking at Louisville.

Hamburg, the sixty-thouaand-dollar thoroughbred stallion bought by William C. Whitney at the Bitter Root Stud sate in Madison Square Garden Wednesday night, and shipped from New York to Kentucky on Friday, reached Lexington last night, after a trip of a little more than twenty-four hours.

The bowling games of the past week made a number of changes in the standing of the clubs in some of the principal tournaments. In the New York Royal Arcanum League series De Vinne Council was scored against for the first time and lost the lead to the Yonkers team, which came up from fourth place by winning two more games during the week.

MEXICO, Jan. 23 -- The Day of the Kings is one of the most attractive festivals held in Mexico. Aside from being an occasion for religious rejoicing, El Dia de los Reyes is celebrated with delightful family reunions and merrymakings. While, as with many of the old customs, such festivities are slowly changing in outward manifestations, it must not be concluded that their significance is forgotten by those who enter into them.

For the third time in as many weeks a Woman has been beaten, bound, gagged, and robbed in her own home in the Borough of the Bronx. The victim of the latest robbery, which occurred yesterday at noon, was Mrs. Anna Of, wife of George F. Of, a manufacturer of picture frames, with whom she lives in the pretty Queen Anne cottage 892 Prospect Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- As the end of the session of Congress rapidly approaches, a feeling of excitement begins to be manifested on many grounds, which it is not difficult to make out as arising from the concentration of interest in a situation involving a great many conflicting elements, rather than anxiety in the fate of any one measure.

According to a fellow-traveler, the trip of Richard Croker on the Lucania to Europe was very unpleasant. The story of the voyage was told last evening at the Fifth Avenue Hotel by a prominent New Yorker, whose business leads him to journey across the ocean frequently. Here is the story of Mr. Croker's personal discomfiture:

PROVIDENCE, Feb. 2 -- In comparisons regarding progress of construction on Columbia and the new boat now being built at Bristol, there is nearly a month's difference in favor of the Belmont craft. The first of the Columbia's frames were ended up on the lead keel on Feb. 20, 1899, while the first frames were set up on the Belmont Syndicate craft on Jan. 24, of this year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: How is it that this box office question is becoming the mouthpiece of a few so-called theatregoers, who do nothing else but hurl abuse at the man in the box? Why not attack the manager who employs the man in the box? Go to his office. He is always in, and has plenty of time to argue the matter with you, without restricting himself to certain limits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I feel that the people of this city owe the reform in the matter of spitting in public conveyances largely to your action in giving free expression to their views. The result is merely another example of the power of public opinion.

There is a man in New York who remembers the occasion of Queen Victoria's wedding with great distinctness, for, as a small boy, he was, given a piece of her wedding cake. That was not until the cake had had time to gain in richness by standing, for the sailing vessels of those days took time to cross the water.

In his remarkable book, "The American Commonwealth," Prof. Bryce says: "No feature in the Government of the United States has awakened so much curiosity inthe European mind, caused so much discussion, received so much admiration and been more frequently misunderstood than the duties assigned to the Supreme Court and the functions which it discharges in guarding the ark of the Constitution."

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 -- President C. M. Hays of the Southern Pacific Company, when asked if he thought the sale of the controlling interest in the company to the Harriman syndicate would lead to important changes of management or policy, said:

The miniatures that went to the Paris Exposition were an attraction yesterday for the crowds of ladies who flocked to the annual exhibition of the Society of Miniature Painters; but without the Paris exhibit there would be enough to interest those who care for this branch of painting at all.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2.--Senator Spooner to-day authorized the statement that if it should become necessary he would move the substitution of the Oleomargarine bill as the regular order of business in the Senate instead of the pending Ship Subsidy bill.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2. -- George B. Dutton of the Oakley Golf Club, Boston, won the President's Cup here to-day by defeating Devereaux Emmett of the Garden City Club by two holes. It was an uphill game for Mr. Dutton," for at one time his opponent had him four down, but by keeping a steady nerve he made a beautiful recovery and won, amid the cheers of an enthusiastic gallery.

CINCINNATI, Ohio. Feb. 2 -- The promoters of the Jeffries-Ruhlin fight, scheduled to be held in this city Feb. 15, are disconcerted and discouraged to-night on account of what is considered a final declaration from Gov. Nash that the fight cannot take place in Ohio. The Directors of the Saengerfest Athletic Association have been in continuous session to-day.

"There are two things that militate against good service in these days," says a woman who has had much experience in the domestic question and understands the subject from the standpoint of both mistress and maid. "The old-fashioned housekeeper has disappeared and the modern mistress of a house expects and exacts too much from her servants.

James A.H. Bell, best known to residents of Brooklyn through the gift of his library containing 10,400 volumes to the Brooklyn Library in June, 1898, died yesterday from the grip, at his home, 45 Sands Street, Brooklyn, in his eighty-fourth year. Mr. Bell had been ill for about fourteen weeks.

W.S. Lilly in The Fortnightly Review. The English peasantry, once deemed the finest in the World, have left the soil of England. They have flocked to the great cities. Our villages are half populated. And what a population -- consisting chiefly of the maimed and the halt and the blind, the rheumatic, the paralytic, and the moribund.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Readers of THE TIMES no doubt have been interested in reading the remarks of Mr. Carnegie, Colgate Hoyt, and others in relation to the way of getting on in life. But it is the words of Mr. Carnagie to which I wish to call especial attention. His advice to young men I do not think wise on the subject of amusements.
The third matinee concert in the Kneisel Quartet series will be given on Tuesday afternoon at 2:15 o'clock in Mendelssohn Hall with the following programme:

Joseph P. Kennelly, proprietor of a restaurant in Columbus Avenue, between Eighty-third and Eighty-fourth Streets, and said to be one of the closest and best friends that Police Commissioner John B. Sexton has, was arraigned in the West Side Police Court yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Miss Helen Hay, the beautiful young daughter of the Secretary of State, has repeatedly given evidence of a desire for a more serious renown, than that which is already hers by virtue of her social prominence. She has inherited her father's literary tastes, and has written some poems which have attracted considerable attention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to occupy part of your valuable space in order that I may reply to a fulmination of the "United Irish-American Societies," which appeared in your issue of the 29th inst.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Senator Teller has made a suggestion that may enable the Administration to see that there need be no extra session of the two houses of the Fifty-seventh Congress to carry out any plan for self-government that may be provided by the Cuban Constitution now in preparation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the majority of persons religion and politics are as widely divergent as the poles; they see no relation whatever between them nor any reason why there should be.

A murder followed a drunken brawl in The Tiger saloon, at the corner of Twenty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, yesterday morning. John O'Brien, said to be a laboring man, was killed, and the patrolmen of the West Thirtieth Street Station were last night instructed to look out for Eugene O'Hara, who is wanted in connection with O'Brien's death.

Controller Bird S. Coler delivered the principal address last night at the ninth anniversary of the founding of the Washington Heights Young Men's Christian Association, which was held in the Washington Heights Baptist Church, at Convent Avenue and One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, President Gillie of the association presided.

At a meeting of delegates to the United Singers of Brooklyn held yesterday afternoon in Arion Hall, on Wall Street, Williamsburg, the resignations of fourteen singing societies were received. Of this number six were accepted and the others held in abeyance in order that an effort may be made to have them remain in the organziation.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Legislators are just beginning to comprehend the far-reaching significance of the bill introduced by Assemblyman Bedell of Orange County last week, placing all the gas, electric light, heating, and power companies of the State under the control of the State Railroad Commission.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 3. -- Fire from an unknown cause destroyed the large plant of the National Wire Company at Fairhaven early this morning, entailing a property loss estimated at $325,000. The plant consisted of two one-story buildings, which covered about five acres of ground space, and all except the wire nail department was reduced to ruins through the lack of facilities for fighting the flames.

MANILA, Feb. 3. -- Fewer than 400 persons attended the meeting called to-day by Senor Buencamino at the Rizal Theatre, in the Tondo Ward of Manila, to inaugurate the "Evangelical movement." Considerable interest was manifested in the proceedings, and there were some expressions of approval of the addresses.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Secretary Long has addressed the following letter to Senator Morgan:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Gov. Odell's message recommending economy is not consistent with his proposed tax bills. We need less expenditures, not more taxes. The only desire of politicians seems to be to tax everything in sight. They cunningly array different classes of property owners against each other.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Bishop Thoburn, missionary Bishop in Asia of the Methodist Episcopal Church, made an address this afternoon in the First Methodist Church that created something of a stir among his audience, inasmuch as he launched into a review of the political questions likely to arise from recent events in China and the death of Queen Victoria.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The body of Queen Victoria has been protected by guardsmen in the Albert Memorial Chapel, at Windsor, since it was deposited there yesterday. The officials of the royal household at Windsor Castle visited the chapel to-day, as well as a number of friends, and admired the great display of wreaths.

LONDON, Feb. 4. -- The Daily Mail this morning publishes a column article by C.H. Cramp of Philadelphia in favor of the Ship Subsidy bill. While he does not believe the bill a perfect measure, he says it will give the United States a chance to secure an honest share of the ocean carrying trade.

Henry C. Lake of Fredonia, Chautauqua County, who was a member of the Assembly in 1862, is visiting his nephew, Justice John Woodward of the Supreme Court, in this city. Mr Lake is one of the oldest ex-Assemblymen. Although eighty-four years old he is more active than a majority of men a quarter of a century his junior.

Hector Resconsci, a dealer in leather goods at 297 Eighth Avenue, returned to his store from a bicycle ride last night, to find a man packing up a lot of alligator pocketbooks and other valuable things. The man was six feet tall, Resconsci says, and he threatened to burn the leather dealer up if he said a word.

The recent acquirement of the Pennsylvania Coal Company and the Central Railroad of New Jersey by the anthracite combination raises an interesting question as to the outcome of the effort to control the anthracite trade. The first movement in that direction had its origin twenty-one years ago with Mr. Franklin B. Gowen, who committed suicide after the failure of his schemes had dawned upon him.
One body and fragments of another were found last night in the ruins of Wicke Co.'s cigar-box factory at First Avenue and Thirty-first Street, which was destroyed by explosions and fire on Thursday.

RECENT DEVELOPMENTS IN WIRELESS TELEPHONY. -- A recent number of Le Figaro contained an article by M. Emile Gautier, which, after stating that "the first step has been made toward the discovery of wireless telephony," proceeded to give an account of the experiments recently conducted by a M. Maiche, who "is now able to transmit speech through the earth for a distance of 1,000 or 1,200 yards."

Fourteen landscapes at the Durand-Ruel Galleries represent the way in which Mr. Henry C. Lee looks at the familiar forest, hill, and river views of the Highlands of the Hudson, near West Point. One old Hudson River school has looked at similar views from the individual standpoint with more or less success.

The little frame Methodist Church in West Fifty-sixth Street, just east of Tenth Avenue, was crowded to the door at the service last night by a congregation that was made up largely of butchers. They were not all members of the church, but had assembled to listen to a sermon on the Sunday-closing movement which has just been inaugurated by the Benchmen's Association of Retail Butchers of Greater New York.

Wall Street will resume business today with warrant for increased confidence. The week just passed has done much to give assurance to the Street not only of the inherent strength and stability of the market, but of the probability of a further and material advance in prices.

There is much severe criticism of the plan of the Governor for turning the charities of the State over to a commission of which two members will be State officers, selected by the methods of party conventions and attached to party ideas of the use of public employment as party patronage.

Difficult to account for is the popularity pf one painter while the world gives his comrade the cold shoulder, his comrade, who may be his superior in some things that are of more importance than the best quality the successful man has to show. Take Jean Baptiste Madou, for an example, since one of his pictures, " The Jolly Musicians," turns up among the Edward Kearney paintings at the American Art Association.

An audience that packed Carnegie Hall from the extreme limits at the rear of the stage to the furthest seat in the topmost balcony assembled yesterday afternoon, the occasion being the mass meeting "in honor of a womanly Queen and a queenly woman." It was an audience eminently characteristic of New York, in that it comprised the heterogeneous elements that go to make up its cosmopolitan population.

In discussing the probable action of the Republican organization in the event of the retention of John B. Sexton and Willlam S. Devery on the police force under the proposed new law, Senator Platt yesterday intimated what might happen.

Another shipwrecked skipper with his crew was brought into port yesterday. The men had been rescued far out on the Atlantic by the German tank steamship Washington on the morning of Jan. 25. When sighted by the Washington their vessel, which was the British schooner Devon, a diminutive craft of 107 tons, was waterlogged and in a sinking condition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Although Chicago had been warned of the coming of a heavy snowstorm, the city was not prepared for the elemental fury that swept in this morning from the northeast on the wings of a howling wind. The storm burst shortly before 10 o'clock in the morning, and before two hours had passed, the city was crippled, the streets were filled high with drifting snow, and traffic was at a standstill.

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, Feb. 3. -- The mass meeting of representative planters, merchants, and taxpayers held in this city last evening to protest against the Hollander Revenue bill adopted a resolution to take every means to nullify the measure by inducing the United States Congress to disapprove it.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 3. -- A circular bearing the name of the Rev. J.M. Rich, pastor of the Episcopal Church of St. John the Divine, at Hasbrouck Heights, has caused a great deal of comment among the congregations of his own and other churches. The circular is headed: "Catholic Church Catechisms," and consists of a series of questions and answers. Among them are the following:

-- Three hundred animals, including representatives of about all the varieties that are kept in captivity, perished at Baltimore Wednesday in the fire which destroyed the Bostock Menagerie, and it is noted as a curious feature of the disaster that every one of the poor creatures met its agonizing death in perfect silence.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 3. -- It is known now by the promoters of the Jeffries-Ruhlin fight that Gov. Nash has announced his ultimatum that there shall be no fight to the Saengerfest Athletic Club and to more than 1,000 petitioners from the business men of Cincinnati, and has also instructed Prosecuting Attorney Hoffheimer and Sheriff Taylor to take steps to prevent the bout.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Senate will continue its discussion of the Ship Subsidy bill during the first half of the present week, with probable interruptions during the morning hour of each day. There will probably be a movement to secure night sessions on the part of the friends of the Shipping bill Monday or Tuesday, and other strenuous efforts will be made to secure a vote upon the bill.

On the strength of the description of one of her assailants, given by Mrs. George F. Of, who was beaten, bound, gagged, and robbed by five men in her home at 892 Prospect Avenue on Saturday, Detectives Baker, Gerrity, Everett, and Foster last night arrested Herman Merz, twenty-six years old, of 743 St. Ann's Avenue.

It has seemed to THE TIMES that the months immediately following the Presidential election of 1900 were not a propitious time for discussing the reorganization of the Democratic Party. The practical purpose of reorganization, as we understand it, is the building up of a party that shall deserve and win the confidence of the people and elect its candidates at the polls.

A sonata in B minor for violin and piano by Rubin Goldmark was produced in Boston on Monday evening by Franz Kneisel. Philip Hale writes of it in The Boston Journal: "The sonata played last night is not a work of pronounced originality or force or beauty, and I wonder why Mr. Kneisel thought it worth while to produce it.

We publish in our financial columns this morning a communication from an unusually well-informed source, under the title "Checks to Combination," reciting some exceedingly interesting and significant facts in the history of the anthracite trade and past efforts to combine and control it.

It is not uncommon in these days to hear the system of appointment for merit and fitness only, and without regard to political associations, denounced as un-American. Just a hundred years ago this question was raised on the accession to the Presidency of THOMAS JEFFERSON, after his predecessor, JOHN ADAMS, had been filling a good many places solely from among the Federalist Party.

The work of church extension in the Bronx, under the direction of the Episcopal Church, is progressing rapidly. Three missions have teen started in that locality, all of which give promise of strength in the future. For the establishment of these missions the Lay Helpers' Association of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew is responsible, the work being carried on under the care of the Rev. Dr. C.C. Tiffany, Archdeacon of New York.

Copyright, 1901, THE NEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, Feb. 3. -- All kinds of finance business have been seriously interrupted by the death of the Queen, and on Friday the banks, Stock Exchange, and most of the factories and shops throughout the metropolis, and, indeed, throughout the kingdom, were closed for the funeral.

There was no lack of good, lively sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning, when a small but very select gathering of light-harness horsemen and their favorite fast steppers amused a large crowd of spectators. The footing was heavy and uncertain in spots along the upper stretch, which was abandoned early in the day for the lower stretch, between High Bridge and the beginning of the macadam pavement.
Prof. Felix Adler of the Society for Ethical Culture spoke at Carnegie Hall, corner of Fifty-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue, yesterday morning, on "The Ethical Teachings of Christ."

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Feb. 3. -- Chitto Harjo, or "Crazy Snake," the leader of the war ring Creek Indians and seventeen of the minor leaders of that tribe have been landed in the Federal jail here, where they will be held pending trial for treason. The Indians were brought here from Henrietta under escort of Troop A, Eighth Cavalry, and United States Marshal Bennett and his posse.

The police of West New York, N.J., yesterday arrested Adolph Itken, who for the past fifteen years, it is alleged, has been swindling the widows of civil war veterans by representing himself as a Government pension agent. Itken, they claim, has a half dozen different aliases and has operated in nearly every State in the country.

ST. JOSEPH, Mo., Feb. 3. -- The wrecking of "joints" at Hiawatha, Kan., which began there yesterday under the leadership of the temperance people, was completed to-day, and when it was finished not a "joint" in the town remained. The proprietors have fled.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- The most striking features of the Berlin Bocrse last week were the continued improvement in fixed interest-bearing securities and the decline in industrial shares. The former showed great activity, prices advancing. The new Bavarian fours, recently subscribed at 100 1/2, reached 102 bid yesterday.

BLOOMSBURG, Perm., Feb. 3. -- At 1 o'clock this morning Thomas McHenry, a well-to-do lumber merchant and farmer, residing near Bohrsburg, Columbia County, was shot by an unknown assassin, and death ensued six hours later. Mr. McHenry was aroused from his sleep by a noise in his barn, and he arose and went to the barn to investigate.

Evelyn B. Baldwin of the Baldwin-Ziegler expedition for the discovery of the north pole, who since the 1st of December has been in Europe purchasing the equipment that is to be used in the expedition to be undertaken this Summer, returned to New York on the American liner New York yesterday.

There was enacted in the little town of Arlington, near Newark, N.J., yesterday morning a tragedy of no common order. As a result the Rev. John Kellar, rector of the Trinity Episcopal Mission in that place and secretary to Bishop Starkey of Northern New Jersey, lies at his home, possibly dying.

Daniel Barriell, an Italian, twenty-three years old, of 326 East Sixty-third Street, was locked up in the East Fifty-first Street Station last night charged with the abduction of Agnes Pevniko, sixteen years old, of 1,336 First Avenue. The man had the girl in a room at 763 Third Avenue. She says he promised to marry her.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 3. -- Thomas Corcoran and Michael Connoughton, who live at the boarding house of Mrs. Bond, at 48 South Fifth Avenue, this place, had a narrow escape from death by coal gas to-day. There is an old furnace in the house, and it has been out of order for some time.

The River and Harbor bill as it passed the House contained an appropriation for deepening and widening the channel between Governors Island and the shore of Long Island, commonly called Buttermilk Channel. There is some doubt whether the Senate will retain this item of the bill.
By an enabling act of the Legislature the school children of New Hampshire are to decide by their votes in June next what shall be the State flower.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Maynard N. Clement, Chief Deputy under Commissioner of Excise Lyman, was interviewed to-day with regard to the charges brought against Royal R. Scott, who is connected with the legal department of the State Excise Bureau, at 1 Madison Avenue, in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The Army Appropriation bill making provision for the army under the plan of reorganization recently enacted, was completed to-day by the House Committee on Military Affairs and reported by Chairman Hull. It carries approximately $118,000,000, as against estimates of about $130,000,000 made by War Department officials.

John Gormley was arrested at Hoboken yesterday, charged with a fiendish crime, if the allegations made against him are true. Gormley has been in trouble before. His wife is at present an inmate of the Hudson County Penitentiary. During her absence he had been boarding at the apartments of Mrs. Mary O'Keefe, at 512 Grand Street, Hoboken.
LONDON, Feb. 4. -- Edward J. Hopkins, the well-known organist, is dead.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As showing how some at least of the policy holders in insurance companies feel about the proposition to tax the surplus of such companies, I inclose a letter signed by a number of policy holders, and to-day forwarded to Superintendent of Insurance Francis Hendricks, calling on him to oppose the passage of the law.

There was not a great deal on the tapis yesterday. The miserable weather interfered with some of the "at homes." The programme was all arranged for the evening. There were two entertainments. The first was the vaudeville affair given toy Mr. and Mrs. Carlos de Heredia to celebrate their tin wedding, and the other was a small dinner dance given by Mr. and Mrs. R. W. De-Forest.

BERLIN, Feb. 4. -- Home funds were firm on the Boerse to-day. Chinese were harder. Locals fluctuated and improved on bear covering. Discount Houses reserved their attitude owing to the rate of London exchange.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 4. -- Thieves who entered Robert McCullough's residence on Van Houten Street yesterday morning carried off only a single pair of trousers, but in a pocket of the trousers were seven bills, each of the fifty-dollar denomination. The police say the theft was committed by some one who knew of Mr. McCullough's habit of carrying his money in his trousers pocket.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- Assemblyman Adler of New York to-night introduced a tax bill which is intended to increase the State tax on the gross earnings of racing associations from 5 to 10 per cent.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- King Edward has caused the following message to be published in The Gazette:

Prof. George H. Gunton and Lemuel E. Quigg had a spirited passage at arms at the meeting of the Republican Club last night. The organization had assembled to discuss the report of the committee to consider the conclusions of the Charter Revision Commission.

"WASHINGTON. Feb. 4. -- The Senate will to-morrow receive the nominations of one Lieutenant General, three Major Generals, and ten Brigadier Generals. The friends of Gens. Brooke and Otis have practically given up claiming that Gen. Miles will not receive the Lieutenant Generalship, and the latter's friends will be very much surprised if he is not appointed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Quartermaster General Ludington has received a dispatch announcing that the United States transport McPherson is aground on the Cuban coast, but says that there is no danger whatever, and the grounding is described as not of a serious character. The McPherson started from Matanzas for Havana in a heavy fog and grounded after going a short distance.

The hundredth anniversary of the day on which JOHN MARSHALL took his seat as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court has been observed with notable dignity and enthusiasm in all parts of the country, and especially in Washington, in which capital he was the first to preside over the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- John Marshall Day was commemorated in Chicago by the bench and bar, the public schools, and by thousands who gathered this afternoon at the Auditorium, where the principal exercises were held. Federal courts, as well as the civil and criminal courts of Cook County, were closed.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 4. -- Numerous royal personages are arriving at The Hague to attend the wedding of Queen Wilhelmina and Duke Henry of Mecklenburg-Schwerin. Her Majesty, attended by the Queen mother and Duke Henry, met Grand Duke Vladimir of Russia, his daughter, Grand Duchess Helene, and his son, Grand Duke Boris, at the railway station this afternoon.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 4. -- The horses of Eastin Larabie, which have been wintering here since the last campaign, were shipped this afternoon to Sheepshead Bay, where they will be put in charge of Peter Wimmer. Among the lot were Kinley Mack, winner of last year's Brooklyn Handicap and Suburban Handicap; Sharpshooter, High Order, Flying Torpedo, Julia Hanover, and five two-year-olds by the best sires in Central Kentucky.

In yesterday's security market appeared the first opportunity for a reflection of the Southern Pacific-Union Pacific transaction which amazed Wall Street just as the Stock Exchange was closing for the holiday at the end of last week. About 120,000 shares of Union Pacific and over 100,000 shares of Southern Pacific changed hands.

Archer Harman, a well-known financial operator and railroad contractor, with offices at 27 Pine Street, and who is an associate of ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt in several business enterprises, was arrested in the Navarro apartments, where he resides, yesterday, having been indicted last week by the Grand Jury for the alleged larceny of $23,000 worth of South American securities from St. George Lane Fox Pitt of England.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 4. -- Cleveland men formerly conspicuous in the manufacture of bicycle parts and accessories, have organized the Automobile and Cycle Parts Company, with an authorized capital stock of $5,000,000, and purchased from the American Bicycle Company the following properties:

JACKSON, Miss., Feb. 4. -- In a communication to-day to the State Attorney General the Mississippi Railroad Commission has called attention to the recent consolidation of the Mobile and Ohio with the Southern Railway. The commission declares such consolidation is in violation of the clause of the Constitution prohibiting the amalgamation of competing lines.

PEKING, Feb. 4. -- To-morrow will be held the first joint meeting between the foreign envoys and the Chinese plenipotentiaries. Only Li-Hung-Chang and Prince Ching have plenipotentiary rights. The other Chinese have merely the status of advisers.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 4. -- Mrs. Nation this afternoon met the first defeat in her saloonsmashing career. Later, at the police station, she laughingly declared that it was by no means her Waterloo, and she would soon again be at her chosen work. With six women, each armed with new hatchets, she had started out at 3 o'clock to wreck a restaurant in East Sixth Street that also dispensed liquors.

Army. A board of medical officers, to consist of Col. Alfred A. Woodhull, Assistant Surgeon General; Major Louis A. La Garde, Surgeon, and Capts. William C. Borden and Frank R. Keefer, Assistant Surgeons, is appointed to meet at the Army Medical Museum Building, Washington, Feb. 11, for the examination of candidates for admission to the Medical Corps.

In his charge to the February Grand Jury, which was empaneled yesterday, Judge McMahon made no mention of "vice," and expressly stated that there was nothing of especial interest to call to the jury's attention.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The publication of the list of 100 pictures intended for the use of high schools throughout the State by the Regents has called forth a good deal of criticism, principally from artists, because the list does not include copies of the most famous pictures in the world. Some of the pictures omitted from the list were not included because they represented the nude in art.

"Tosca," a melodrama in three acts by G. Puccini, was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time in the United States. The audience was a large one, and there was abundant enthusiasm from the devoted band of Italians who always support the work of their countrymen.

New York Central is seeking to lease the Manhattan Elevated Railway system. This THE NEW YORK TIMES learns from responsible authorities, chief of which is a Director of the Manhattan Company itself. At any time the deal may be finally perfected.

BOSTON, Feb. 4. -- The shell casting for the lead keel of the Lawson Cup defender was drawn from the sand to-day, and so far as a superficial examination showed, was perfect. The shell is of composition metal 30 inches at the widest and tapering to a point. Its length is about twenty-six feet.

The Windsor Arcade is near enough to completion to give a fair idea of what is to be expected as a substitute for the Windsor Hotel. The dreary void left by the destruction of that building by fire is at last filled, and the residents of Fortysixth and Forty-seventh Streets, near Fifth Avenue, are no longer reminded of the distressing scenes enacted before their eyes when that frightful catastrophe occurred.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 4. -- The memory of the late Chief Justice John Marshall was honored to-day in appropriate exercises in the hall of the House of Representatives. Addresses were delivered by President, Warnerholt of the Georgia Bar Association, Burton Smith, Presiding Justice Lumpkin of the Supreme Court, and others.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Secretary Root has made answer to the Senate resolution calling for a statement as to why the Filipino leader Mabini had been deported to Guam:

GLASGOW, Feb. 4. -- In conversation with a representative of The Associated Press, Capt. Sycamore, who is to command Sir Thomas Lipton's yacht Shamrock II., strongly approved of the proposal to abandon the arrangement allowing each boat two clear minutes in which to get started. He favored the flying start, now almost universal in yacht racing.

The little community of Arlington, N. J., is still throbbing with excitement over the shooting on Sunday morning of the Rev. John Kellar by Thomas G. Barker. The sympathies of the community seem to be equally divided between the man who asserts that he shot to avenge his wife and his victim.
LONDON, Feb. 5. -- A dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria, Feb. 3, says:

BOSTON, Feb. 4. -- Boston trading broadened in good earnest to-day, and a large business was done. Over 10,000 shares of Atchison changed hands in the morning. Chicago, Burlington and Quincy was a prominent favorite, with Sugar, Tube, Steel, and Union Pacific showing pronounced activity.

Some time ago, while the Army bill was still pending in Congress, we took occasion to point out what a strong argument in favor of one of the Secretary's propositions was furnished by the campaign in China. The remark takes new point from an article, "Observations on the Peking Relief Expedition," published by The North American Review and written by Capt. CROZIER, Chief Ordnance Officer on the staff of Gen. CHAFFEE.

MARLBORO, Mass., Feb. 4. -- Mrs. Charles Brigham, who last week labeled saloons with Scriptural texts and scared saloon keepers with threat that she would copy the work of Mrs. Nation, continued her crusade this afternoon, in spite of the snowstorm. Her favorite label was "Wine is a mocker."

In several parts of the list the market for outside securities yesterday showed considerable activity. The purchase of stocks on a fairly large scale resulted in considerable improvement in prices, but these changes, although fairly large, were not general. The bulk of the day's business was supplied by the steel stocks and the St. Louis Street Railway issues, most of which were notably active.
The following is the poem by Alfred Austin, the Poet Laureate, which appeared in The Times (London) on Jan. 23:

An exciting chase by a big crowd up Madison Avenue last night ended in the capture of a well-dressed young man after a fierce struggle, during which he tried to kill Patrolman Patrick Conroy of the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, who made him prisoner.
An exciting man hunt startled every one In the neighborhood of South Perry yesterday afternoon.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, Feb. 4. -- The Rev. Dr. Elmer E. Whittaker, pastor of the First Methodist Church of this city, has introduced an innovation in religious circles. He advocates the use of large display newspaper advertising, set in heavy black-faced type, as a means of increasing the number of converts and the attendance at church services.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4. -- All the members of the Western Jockey Club were present at a meeting to-day at which the club was formally organized, and formally placed in operation.
Fire was discovered yesterday morning at 11:55 o'clock in Public School No. 83, a Grammar and Primary School for boys in One Hundred and Tenth Street, just East of Third Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, one of the most important and most general supply bills of the Government, was completed to-day by the House Committee on Appropriations. The bill appropriates $59,703,084, which is $10,889,197 less than the estimates and $5,748,221 less than the bill for the current fiscal year.

The Harlem Wheelmen team won two of three closely contested games with the Harlem Republican Club five in the New York Interclub Bowling League series on the Republican Club alleys last night. The scores:

A gang of train robbers has been systematically robbing the Adams Express Company for several weeks past. Officials of the company say that the losses may aggregate over $20,000. The robberies were all committed while the goods were in transit from Philadelphia to New York, and reports of missing goods have been increasing from day to day, each report snowing a larger amount of goods taken than the previous one.

Stephen Jennings Wilson died early yesterday morning at his home, on Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, L. I., aged ninety-seven years. He was the oldest resident of this village, and the oldest officeholder on Long Island, if not in this State. He had been Collector of Taxes for School District No. 1 for more than twenty years, and since the incorporation of the village, in 1893, had served as Collector of village taxes.
Daniel B. Freedman has bought from the Hayes estate, 56, 62, 64, and 66 West Fiftyfifth Street, four-story brownstone-front dwellings, each 18.4 by 100.5.

ALBANY, Feb. 4. -- In anticipation of a sharp debate on Senator Grady's motion to recommit Gov. Odell's bills taxing savings banks and insurance and trust companies, which was scheduled to be taken from the table to-night, there was a large attendance at the session of the Senate. The galleries were crowded, and all available floor space was occupied.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- The President and Mrs. McKinley to-day issued invitations far the diplomatic dinner for Thursday, Feb. 14.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4. -- Upon the motion of Mr. Allison, (Rep., Ia.,) the hour of 11 o'clock was fixed as the time of meeting by the Senate for its daily sessions until otherwise ordered.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 4. -- Crew work at Yale took on new life to-day when Capt. Augustus Blagden called out the 'Varsity candidates and divided them into three Squads. This is the first step toward the ultimate choice of the champion eight that has been taken this year.Capt. Blagden has insisted on the presence of last year's veterans in the gym rowing tanks from now on, and all of the old oarsmen responded to-day.

WINDSOR, Feb. 4. -- The last honors have been paid to Queen Victoria. Her body now rests peacefully near that of her husband, in the beautiful mausoleum at Frogmore. The final ceremonies were of a more funereal and pathetic character than any which preceded them.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The bill providing for a single Commissioner of Police for New York City was mailed to Mayor Van Wyck to-night. It passed the Assembly to-day by a vote of 101 to 43. The vote was on strict party lines. It was taken after a whole afternoon devoted to debate, in which very little interest was manifested.
Representatives of twenty-two cycling organizations and of nineteen cycle tracks were in attendance at the annual meeting of the National Cycling Association, held yesterday at the Astor House.

The Collins Building and Construction Company yesterday filed plans at the Department of Buildings, through Architect Henri Fauchaux, for a seven-story brick limestone and terra cotta apartment house which will accommodate fifty-six families when completed. The building will be erected at a cost of $240,000 on the plot 128 by 99.11, on the north side of One Hundred and Fortieth Street, 272 feet east of Seventh Avenue.
The meeting of the two dancing classes last evening and the dinners given by various patronesses who took their guests afterward to these dances, helped to make It quite a busy evening in society.

Even after the proofs that President McKINLEY has given to all soldiers and to all civilians interested in the welfare of the army, which now more than ever before means the "safety, honor, and welfare of these United States," all such persons must have been gratified and more or less relieved to read the list of promotions which he yesterday sent to the Senate.

A regular monthly meeting of the Directors or the Maurice Grau Opera Company was held in the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. After it terminated Mr. Grau announced that nothing but a general discussion of the operatic season thus far was held, and the plans for next season were not brought up.

Blanche Bates, one of the most popular and most variously gifted of the actresses of this hour, began an engagement at the Garden Theatre last evening, where, under the joint management of Charles Frohman and David Belasco, she acted Cigarette in a new stage version of Ouida's once familiar romance "Under Two Flags," made for her by Paul Potter.

A dividend of $20 a share was declared yesterday on the stock of the Standard Oil Company, being as large a dividend as the company ever paid. The payment will be made March 15, and will require the disbursement of nearly $20,000,000. In March of last year a twenty-dollar dividend was paid, but with this single exception the dividend declared yesterday is double any previous dividend.

One arrest was made yesterday in connection with the robbery of an express car of the Adams Express Company on the Pennsylvania "Owl" train shortly after midnight last Sunday morning, while the train was en route from Philadelphia to Jersey City. "The arrest was made in Philadelphia, and the prisoner was a young colored man.

They came through the swirling wind which swept across City Hall Park yesterday all decked out in new bonnets and fancy furs, and with cheeks reddened by the cold. They were a delegation of women from Bedford Park, headed by Mrs. Frank Le Count Dowe, and their mission was to force the city officials to put water enough in the mains so that the housewives would have water with which to "cook and wash clothes."

In an interview in The Evening Post Mr. COLLIER, the new President of the State Civil Service Commission, submits some sensible remarks regarding the requirements and working of the present law which it is the duty of the commission to administer.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 5 -- Mrs. Carrie Nation and three followers to-day wrought damage to the extent of $1,500 in "The Senate," the finest equipped "joint" in Topeka. She did more, for she gained the first police protection given her since she started out on her saloon-smashing career at Wichita, a month ago.

The meeting of the Municipal Council yesterday was marked by some lively scenes. President Guggenheimer had to use his authority twice to force members to conduct themselves in a parliamentary manner. The first discord arose over the appropriation of $80,000 for a pumping station in the Bronx District, the passage of which was urged by the people of Bedford Park.

Walter G. French, a commission merchant, of 116 Warren Street, yesterday entered suit, against the Mercantile Exchange for the purpose of restraining the Executive Committee of the Exchange from carrying out the provisions of an amendment to the by-laws adopted at a meeting held on Dec. 28 last.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- President, pro tem. Ellsworth called the Senate to order to-day, the Lieutenant Governor being delayed on departmental business. A score of petitions of individuals and insurance companies were received against the Insurance Tax bill. Petitions against the Savings Bank and the Trust Company Tax bills were also received and referred to the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment.

Addison Cammack, the retired Wall Street stock broker and operator, died yesterday morning at his city home, 31 West Fortyninth Street, in his seventy-fifth year. He had for several months suffered from Bright's disease.

William R. Corwine, Secretary of the Merchants' Association, talked to the Social Reform Club last night on the subject, "Shall the City Build the Pipe Galleries?" He said he had been unable to find anybody who did not agree with him on the general proposition of the benefit of pipe galleries, although some had had different opinions as to the details to be considered in bringing about the building and management of the galleries.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- The Reading and Pennsylvania issues ruled in the market to-day; there was also a good demand, for Lehigh Valley, of which but little was found. Reading common gained 7-16 and the first preferred 7/8. A dividend of 1 1/2 is expected to-morrow. An unexpected spurt in Pennsylvania during the last half hour was the subject of excited comment.

John A. Hendrick won the first game in the Class A billiard championship tournament, held last night in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. He defeated Dr. L.L. Mial in a 400-point 14-inch balk-line game by 400 to 377 points. Both of the competitors are members of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, and have been well known for several years in the realm of amateur billiards.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- In the Lakewood team match against the "AllComers," played this morning, the Lakewood players were defeated 15 to 33. The Lake-wood team was made up of picked golfers, and contained some good players, but these were paired against better material, as was proved.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- In the Senate Committee on Cities there was a so-called hearing to-day upon the bill introduced by Senator Grady legalizing the portico erected in front of the Pabst Hotel at the intersection of Forty-second Street, Broadway, and Seventh Avenue in the City of New York. Senator Grady, who introduced the bill, called it up in committee.

The contest by her brother of the will of Helen C. Brush, who left nearly all of her property, to the First Church of Christ, Scientist, was resumed yesterday before Surrogate Fitzgerald. The direct charge was made that Augusta E. Stetson, called "The First Reader" of the Church, had used undue influence in order to get Miss Brush to make the will.

While no one at Police Headquarters, yesterday would deny that another "shakeup" of Police Captains may occur any day, the rumors of transfers that on Monday were said to be contemplated were pronounced premature. All that Chief Devery would say on the subject was: "I make the transfers -- at this end," intimating that he had no control over the rumor mongers or "third houses" of any of the boroughs.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The State is now being called on to appropriate money to defray the expenses of the investigation into the affairs of ex-District Attorney Asa Bird Gardiner's office, in New York City, and, according to claims and estimates made at to-day's meeting of the Senate Finance Committee, the investigation instituted last February, which was not the one that resulted in Mr. Gardiner's removal, will cost the State more than $40,000.

BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- Boston had a broad, active, and strong market to-day. Activity was pronounced in Tube, Steel, Atchison, Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, Massachusetts Electric preferred, and Butte, and there were numerous other features of interest. Massachusetts Electric preferred rose 1 7/8, to 80 1/4, later 79, with, the common up 1, at 26 1/4; in the morning 2,000 shares of the preferred changed hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Senator and Mrs. Foraker entertained at dinner this evening the Attorney General and Mrs. Griggs, Senator and Mrs. Wetmore, Senator and Mrs. Hanna, Mrs. Frederick Dent Grant, Mr. and Mrs. William R. Merriam, Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. McCormick, Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Wetmore of New York, the Rev. and Mrs. Mackay-Smith, Miss Phelps, and Mr. and Mrs. Glover.

Seven jurors out of twenty-eight special talesmen examined were the net result of four hours of examination and challenging by prosecution and defense in the second day of the retrial of Samuel J. Kennedy, the Staten Island dentist, once convicted of the murder of "Dolly" Reynolds, in the Grand Hotel, on the night of Aug. 15, 1898.
To the Editor of The New York Times: As a dally reader of your paper, I take the liberty of asking you if you will give the following letter your earliest consideration:

In the following list " mtg " stands for mortgage and " R S " for revenue stamps. The war revenue-law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This " consideration " has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

District Attorney Philbin will be requested by Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst's Society for the Prevention of Crime to resubmit to the February Grand Jury the complaints against nine persons indicted for bookmaking upon the evidence of the agents of the society, and whose indictments were subsequently dismissed, without notification to Dr. Parkhurst and without opposition from the District Attorney.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- It is beginning to be generally believed that a close connection exists between the revolutionists in Venezuela and Colombia. The two nations have, been hostile for some time, and this unfriendliness has lately been approaching an open breach. Neither wants war If the same result can be obtained by other means, and it is now reasonably certain that each Government is encouraging the revolution against the other.

The Tammany Hall politicians got mixed up in a whirlwind yesterday when Street Cleaning Commissioner Nagle announced that he had fined the Uvalde Asphalt Paving Company $4,100 for failure to clean certain streets under its contract with the city.

HORACE SILSBY, the inventor of a fire engine, died in Seneca Falls, N.Y., yesterday after an illness of several weeks from a complication of diseases. He was sixty years old. He leaves a wife, one son, and two daughters.
PEKING, Feb. 5 -- The Chinese Plenipotentiaries, Prince Ching and Li-Hung-Chang, had a protracted meeting this morning with the foreign envoys.

Much reading of the English newspapers, and especially of those which discuss trade matters, would give one the impression that the English people are extremely ill-natured. The petulant tone in which they discuss phases of foreign competition would warrant this conclusion.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 5 -- To-day was marked by further receptions in connection with the forthcoming marriage of Queen Wilhelmina and Duke Henry of Mecklenburg-Scherwin. Additional guests arrived at the palace, and there were more choral serenades. Everybody is wearing a rosette or other favor.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 5 -- One of the first effects of the arrangement recently effected between the Union Pacific and the Southern Pacific has been to secure better accommodations for the traveling public from the Southern Pacific. It has never waited in Ogden beyond the time agreed upon for the Union Pacific when it has been late.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- Among the bills considered by the Senate Committee on Cities to-day was the bill introduced by Senator Ahearn placing, the Jewish papers in New York City upon the same footing with regard to city advertisements as the German papers.
Sliver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock-Exchange at 61@63. There were no sales.

The conditions and date for the ninth Grand American, Handicap, the most important pigeon-shooting even of North America have been determined by the Inter-State Shooting Association, and April 3. at InterState Park. Queens, L.I., have been announced as the time and place set for the famous trap shooting competition. which will be renewed under practically the same regulations that have governed in the past four years.

The skaters of Brooklyn to the number of several hundred reveled on the ice at the Clermont Avenue Rink, Brooklyn, last night, where an excellent programme, including many novelties on the ice, was provided by Manager Mosher. In the new events many noted amateur skaters appeared, the fun winding up with a broom ball game, the pastime without rules, in which everything is permitted, and which caused much merriment.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 5 -- The Ohio Supreme Court to-day gave a decision by which the Arbuckles win a big victory, over the Sugar Trust. The style of the caserin court is the Woolson Spice Company against John Arbuckle. The Woolson Company is controlled by the Sugar Trust. Mr. Arbuckie secured some stock in the Woolson Company, and claimed the right, to examine its books.

The Knickerbocker Athletic Club bowlers won three games from the Catholic Club five in the New York Inter-Club Bowling League tournament on the Knickerbocker Athletic Club alleys last night. The scores:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Mr. Aldrich is quoted to-night as positively asserting that the Shipping Subsidy bill will be passed by the Senate before the close of the session. This is accepted by the indifferent supporters of the measure, as well, as those who are positively opposed to it, as indicating Mr. Aldrich's satisfaction with his review of the situation he has created.

Mayor Van Wyck was visited yesterday by a delegation from the United Irish-American Societies of the City of New York, who presented to him a resolution praising him for refusing to lower the flags on the City Hall to half mast on the death of Queen Victoria. Mayor Van Wyck said in reply to the speech of Daniel F. Colahan, who headed the delegation:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- Clarence V. Wallace, a contracting agent, is lying critically ill at home, as a result of an encounter last night with a negro highwayman, who secured $68 and escaped. The assault occurred in front of the Fourth Street entrance to the Bourse, where Mr. Wallace has an office, and at a time when the street was crowded with persons returning from work.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 29 -- Outgivings at Peking as to the intention of the Empress Dowager or the Emperor to make speedy return to the capital may be put down as an example of what is permitted by diplomatic license. No names are attached to these announcements, which periodically appear, but they are not pure inventions, and they may be truthfully classed as official.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I write to ask if there is any law or Board of Health regulation as to the closing of the front doors of the cars of the New York City surface railroad during, cold weather? I rode from Brooklyn Bridge to Harlem in Car 1,526. Conductor 1,219, to-night, arriving at One Hundred and Thirtieth Street at 11:30 P.M.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When will so-called Christians learn to be practical? No man to-day will make any sacrifice individually for the cause of Christ or the Church. He may give out of his abundance liberally, but he is too keen a business man to sacrifice his real estate and sell a prominent corner for half its value to prevent a saloon being opened.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The War Office issued a very heavy South African casualty list yesterday, showing, in addition to 13 killed and 77 wounded in action. 82 deaths from disease since the beginning of the present month.

Roughness that all but developed into rowdyism, stood out prominently in the hockey games at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last evening between the sevens of the New York Athletic Club, and the Hockey Club of New York. Both teams were so busy knocking each other down that they had little time to bother with scoring.
Slawson Hobbs have sold for Mrs. Hattie Mendelsen to a client for occupancy 315 West Eighty-eighth Street, a four-story brownstone dwelling, with dining room extension.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 5 -- Prominent railroad men here say that the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific, Denver and Rio Grande, and Rio Grande Western Railways will soon be under one control, and that the financiers now arranging this consolidation are in control of the new company just organized by Senator-elect Clark of Montana to build a line from Salt Lake to Los Angeles, Cal.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- The Merchants' Association of New York City has sent its answer to the queries about the Ramapo Repeal bill raised by Edward Lauterbach and the Assembly Committee on Cities is now in charge of the matter. The brief, which is quite lengthy, closes by saying that the law m existence at present should be repealed because:

Because he did not want to frighten his seventeen-year-old daughter, who was lying in her room critically ill, President W. H. Birchall of the Borough Bank refrained from shooting the fleeing burglar, who had got into his residence, at East One Hundred and Eighty-fourth Street and Creston Avenue, in the Bronx.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- When the Senate Judiciary Committee had under consideration to-day the bill introduced by Senator Elsberg repealing the special jury law for Greater New York there was in the possession of Chairman Stranahan a letter, knowledge of which was needed to enlighten the proceedings.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- When Senators Audett, Fuller, and Marshall voted with the Democrats last night in favor of Senator Grady's motion to recommit the Governor's tax bills to the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, Lieut. Gov. Woodruff was both surprised and chagrined. Mr. Woodruff had been up in the Adirondacks for a few days, and was unaware of the intention of the Brooklyn Senators to continue their stand against the Governor's measures.

No matter how good the sleighing is, few people enjoy it on Manhattan Island, for the reason that there are very few sleighs. Leaving out of consideration a little scraping through mud with light cutters that followed the light snowfall last week, mostly for magnums of champagne offered as prizes to first comers by genial roadhouse managers, yesterday was the first day of sleighing in this city.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- Senor Giberga, in the course of a patriotic address, before the Constitutional Convention to-day, the most stirring speech yet made in the convention, said he was in sympathy with the desire of the Revolutionist's to form an independent Government, but he wished to warn the delegates to proceed intelligently, as a misstep now might result in losing forever that long-sought goal which other republics had reached during the last century.

ROSSLAND, B.C., Feb. 5 -- Charles A. Hinckley, alias Charles S. Morris, has been arrested in Conconoly, a mining camp in Washington, just south of the boundary line. Hinckley was the paying teller of the West Side Bank, New York, from the time it started, in 1868, to May 14, 1881. On that day he disappeared and with him went $97,000 of the bank's funds.

People passing the jewelry store of Marcel Silverman, at 3,056 Third Avenue, near One Hundred and Fifty-sixth Street, about 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon were attracted by the knocking on the door of the proprietor, who appeared to them to be sick. They tried the door, which was locked, and Silverman opened it.

Fire in the five-story tenement house at 267 West Fortieth Street early yesterday morning, created the wildest excitement among the tenants, many of whom were rescued from imminent danger of burning to death. The rear of the house from the second floor to the roof was wrecked, and the top floor was completely gutted.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- John Brisben Walker, Jr., of Irvington, is made the defendant in a suit brought by his wife, Isabel B. Walker, for a divorce. Supreme Court Justice Keogh has signed an order, on the application of Attorney William H. Blain of 271 Broadway, appointing Robert L. Raymond of Boston, a lawyer, to take testimony of Mrs. Jennie R, Reinhard of 31 Newbury Street.

The Committee of Two Hundred and Fifty, which has for its avowed object the passage of the amendments to the charter recommended by the committee appointed by the Legislature to revise the charter, held its first meeting last night in the assembly hair of the United Charities Building.

New interest was lent to the Arlington (N.J.) shooting mystery yesterday by the statement that Thomas G. Barker, who shot the Rev. John A. Kellar last Sunday morning, would himself take the initiative and prosecute his victim for the wrong which he alleges his wife suffered at the hands of the clergyman: The assertion was made that it would be proved by witnesses at the, proper time that the assault charged had been perpetrated.

In all communities halt a century ago and in some communities to-day a charge made by a woman against a man such as has just led to a homicidal assault in Arlington, N.J., would be almost universally accepted as true without inquiry or any demand for evidence to support it.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad has its headlights set in the direction of Chicago, over the Chicago and Eastern Illinois Railroad. H.H.
