Porter, the Federal Steel man, and former President of the latter line, is anxious to sell the road, which he controls by virtue of the ownership of the majority of the stock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our concern in the South African war is not alone one of sympathy, but of interest. The United States was the first-to recognize the International Association, of the Congo, had aided in its birth, had secured its political existence, and had acquired rights for American citizens in its territory.

-- Later information as to what happened when the Grand Opera House in Cincinnati was burned the other day supplies no explanation as to why the endangered people were so extraordinarily self-possessed, but it adds, on the contrary, to the astonishment created by the first reports of their behavior.

Henry Ungrich, Jr., manager of the Sheffield Farm Dairy, with headquarters at 281 Lenox Avenue, and Robert J. Cronie, Superintendent of the United States Detetctive Bureau, with offices at 41-43 Maiden Lane, were held in $1,000 each for examination in the Harlem Police Court yesterday on a charge of shooting a burglar who broke into the offices of the Sheffield Farm Dairy on Monday night.

Robert Barr Todd, formerly justice of the Supreme Court of Louisiana, and a descendant of a famous old Kentucky family, died at the residence of his daughter, Miss Sallie C. Todd, 347 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, Monday night. Judge Todd came to this city in search of health last July. He has suffered for a long time from a complication of disorders.

BUFFALO, Feb. 6 -- Louis Nethersole said to-night that the "Sapho" company would play in Milwaukee next week, and might end its tour at St. Louis the week following, returning to New York to disband. Mr. Nethersole to night received the following telegram from his sister:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- The delegates to the conference having for its object a National federation of churches and Christian workers to-day adopted a constitution for the new organization and elected officers. The constitution gives the organization the title of the National Federation of Churches and Christian Workers.

The New York Athletic Club team won three closely contested games from the Newark Athletic Club five in the Athletic Bowling League tournament on the New York Athletic Club alleys last night. The scores:

SING SING, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- Lorenzo Priori, convicted of the murder of Vincenzo Garaguso in New York on Dec. 11, 1808, died here in the electric chair to-day. After his death the following statement left by him was made public by Father Athanasius of the Church of the Most Precious Blood, in Baxter Street, New York, who had been attending him:

BOSTON, Feb. 6 -- Another gas sensation was sprung in the House this afternoon, when Mr. Skerritt of Worcester offered an order for the appearance before the bar of the House of Thomas W. Lawson, the well-known financier and yachtsman, who took a prominent part in last year's investigation of the Boston gas situation.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- The House devoted the entire day to the Post Office Appropriation bill, and the bill was still pending when the House adjourned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Senator Hale to-day submitted to the Senate a number of communications from the Secretary of the Navy concerning naval affairs. One of these is a list showing the names of vessels purchased for the navy during the war with Spain, together with the prices paid, and also a list of such vessels which have been sold, together with the prices received for them.

Morris Silverman, the jeweler who was discovered lying behind a locked door in his store, at 5,056 Third Avenue, late on Tuesday night with a bullet wound in the back of his head, died yesterday morning in Fordham Hospital after declaring that he had been shot by burglars who had attempted to rob his store.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 -- A lumber yard, sawmill, and fourteen houses in the western part of Havana, near El Cerro, have been destroyed by fire, with a total loss of $700,000. The mill and yard, the property of Pedro Estanillo, show a loss of $300,000, against which there is insurance to the amount of $93,000.

Gayety is on the wane. There are still a number of dinners, but very few large dances. Philadelphia will contribute one affair this week in the shape of the midwinter dance, which is a large subscription affair and to which many New Yorkers will go. On Monday, Feb. 18, there will be a bal masque at Copley Hall, in Boston, which is under very fashionable patronage.

PEKING, Feb. 6 -- As had been arranged at the meeting of the foreign Ministers and Chinese plenipotentiaries yesterday the proceedings were conducted orally, no writings being presented to the Chinese. A formal indictment against the twelve officials whose punishment had been demanded by the powers was read, however, though Kang-Yi and Li-Ping-Heng are dead.

"Lovers' Lane," a new play, treating of rustic life in a familiar fashion, but not without appreciable smartness, and a hint or two of novelty in the pictorial details, was produced in fine style at the Manhattan Theatre last evening and was received with manifest approval. Mr. Clyde Fitch wrote this piece and it is a much better thing than his latest crazy patch at a neighboring theatre.

THE TIMES has been reproved by some of its most respectable and well-meaning readers (not that they are not all respectable and well meaning) for its suggestions, from time to time, that perhaps the missionaries in China, even the American missionaries in China, were in some degree responsible for the tension which, issued in the deplorable situation which we have to recognize.

Trading in the outside market yesterday showed more activity than it has on any day within two or three weeks. Although a few issues supplied the bulk of the day's transactions, trading on a smaller scale extended to more stocks that had appeared in the record of any recent day. The Steel stocks were the most active and perhaps the strongest issues, although substantial advances appeared in various other parts of the list.

ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Feb. 6 -- It is feared that a serious marine disaster has occurred off St. John's within the last forty-eight hours. A quantity of wreckage belonging apparently to a large and well-found vessel has drifted ashore near Torbay, seven miles north of St. John's. It is believed that a ship and crew have been lost, and indications point toward the schooner Challenger from Cadiz as the likely victim.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with considerable interest your dispatch in Monday's paper from Hackensack entitled "Catholic Church Catechism." The article said that the circular sent out by the Rev. John M. Rich of the Church of St. John the Evangelist, at Hasbrouck Heights, was causing a great deal of comment among the members of the church.

ROME, Feb. 6 -- The Government was defeated in the Chamber of Deputies to-day by a vote of 318 to 102 at the close of the debate on the dissolution of the Labor Exchange at Genoa, which has lasted several days.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 6 -- It is announced that as a result of a hearing given by the Joint Committee on Ways and Means of the Missouri House and Senate to prominent Christian Scientists, the public health commitee will strike out those paragraphs of a medical practice bill now before the Legislature specifying "That all persons professing to heal the sick or afflicted" must undergo examination by a State medical board.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- President pro tem. Ellsworth presided at this morning's session of the Senate. Gov. Odell sent his nomination of Samuel E. Shipp as manager of the Middletown State Hospital, in place of John E.S. McCroskery, whose term has expired. It was referred to the Finance Committee.

In record-breaking time the twelve men who will pass upon the guilt or innocence of Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, on trial in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court, for the second time, charged with the murder of "Dolly" Reynolds, was selected yesterday from the panel drawn by Special Jury Commissioner Gray.
BERLIN, Feb. 6 -- The National Zeitung says to-day:
Furbelows and laces, furs and feather boas, topped off by "perfect loves of bonnets," gave to Surrogate Fitzgerald's court yesterday an unusual air of femininity.
Rumors that there was a mutiny aboard a sailing vessel anchored somewhere near this city caused considerable excitement along the water, front yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Feb. 6 -- A fatal collision ocurred on the Ontario and Western Railroad at Hurleyville, Sullivan County, to-day. An engine with a snow flange used to clear the rails of snow, crashed into a passenger coach attached to a milk train, which had stopped at a siding to allow another train to pass.

The first of the series of indoor games arranged for Columbia's athletes was held in the gymnasium yesterday, and resulted in the breaking of five records, new figures being made in the mile run, 440-yard run, 40-yard dash, shot put, and running high jump. The pole vault was the only other event.
"Equitable taxation is one of the most important issues that confronts the people of this State."

SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 6 -- The Confederate Veterans' Association of Savannah last night passed resolutions protesting against the invitation to President McKinley to attend the reunion of Confederate Veterans in Memphis.

LONDON, Feb. 6 -- It has transpired that a man in jail in England, who was sentenced in December last to four years imprisonment for robbing a woman in the streets of London, is Charles Allen, one of the Post Office robbers who escaped from Ludlow Street Jail, New York City, in 1895.
CITY OF MEXICO., Feb. 6 -- The Rev. Dr. Eliphalet Nott Potter, brother of Bishop Henry C. Potter of New York, died of heart disease at 6:45 o'clock this evening at the Hotel Jardin in this city.

Mrs. Nation, the saloon wrecker, who threatens to come here with her little hatchet, wax hauled, oratorically, over the coals at this week's meeting of the Miscellaneous Section of the Central Federated Union. Many delegates from unions connected with saloons attended the meeting and said that her threatened invasion of New York should be stopped.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Secretary of War Elihu Root has written the following letter to Majority Leader Allds in response to the latter's inquiries regarding the proposed Wilson bill ceding lands under water about Governors Island to the Federal Government so that the island may be improved:

In a recent number the Berlin Kreuz Zeitung had the following frank, but not very amiable, reference to the economic situation in England, with particular regard to the influence of the United States upon the immediate future:

NEW ROCHELLE, Feb. 6 -- A man, his wife, and their four children were found asleep in the snow in the woods near Larchmont early this morning by John Robinson, a night watchman on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad. He saw a small fire burning in the woods and went to investigate.

Mrs. Charlotte B. Lawlor resumed the witness stand yesterday before Justice Chester and continued telling how she believed she had lost money through, her cousin, Dr. Charles Bucklin, an eye and ear specialist, in the management of her estate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- During the afternoon session the Senate passed the War Revenue Reduction bill. A determined, but unsuccessful, effort was made to reduce the tax on bank checks, and to provide that telegraph and express companies should bear the burden of the tax on-messages and packages sent.
LONDON, Feb. 6 -- The Earl of Kimberley, Liberal leader in the House of Lords, is suffering from congestion of the lungs. His condition is not regarded as serious.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Beginning at 8 o'clock this evening the first of a promised series of night sessions was held to discuss the Shipping bill. The entire sesion was devoted to a continuous round of intellectual pyrotechnics. Practically every question that has been or is likely soon to be before the Senate was discussed, but very little time was devoted to the pending measure.

The announcement of the promotion of Capt. J. Franklin Bell from the rank of Captain in the Seventh United States Cavalry to that of a Brigadier General is at present causing considerable stir in army circles. According to several officers, the promotion is absolutely without a precedent since the civil war.

BOSTON, Feb. 6 -- Boston had another active day and there was a large volume of business in numerous stocks. Over 5,000 shares of Federal Steel common and 2,000 shares of the preferred changed hands in the morning, along with 3,000 shares of National Tube, 1,000 Atchison common, 3,000 Atchison preferred, 4,300 Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, 2,500 Water Power, 3,000 Copper Range, 1,200 Union Pacific, 1.800 Old Dominion, 1,000 Dominion Coal, and so on.

The potentate who has absolute rule over the miniature Empire of Morocco, under the title of Emir-al-Mumenin, is evidently a young man of considerable foresight, when viewed in the light of comparison with his late predecessor in office or with his co-religionist, the Sultan of Turkey.

One of the largest meetings in the history of the organization was held by the City Club last night, when pending legislation was discussed. The Council of the club submitted a long report, of which the following is a synopsis:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- The Board of Directors of the Reading Company, which company controls the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company and the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, to-day declared a semi-annual dividend of 2 per cent. upon the $28,000,000 of first preferred stock.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6 -- "I don't believe Mrs. Nation is heading for Chicago to wreck saloons," said Mayor Harrison to-day, when told that Mrs. Nation had announced her intention of visiting this city with her followers.

In polished phrases Bishop Potter advised the Bowery last night to emigrate to China. There was some doubt in the minds of his hearers as to just what was to be accomplished there by such a hegira, whether the Bowery was to civilize China or merely to continue there its more or less mythical search for work.

MANILA, Feb. 6 -- Theodorio Carranza, a prominent and wealthy Spanish merchant and hemp and cocoanut buyer, was arrested this afternoon, charged with furnishing supplies to aid the insurgents. Carranza is also a partner of D.M. Carman, an American contractor and owner of boats, who had considerable transportation contracts with the Government.

The approval of the city officials was given yesterday to Battery Park as the site for a naval arch to commemorate the deeds of valor by the United States sailors. Mayor Van Wyek gave his approval of the site selected by a committee of the Naval Academy Alumni Association, and he said that $1,000,000 should be raised for such a purpose.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 6 -- The wedding eve of Queen Wilhelmina and Duke Henry of Mecklenburg-Schwerin shows a Winter carnival holding sway over The Hague. It is an ideal evening, clear and cold. Already 100,000 Hollanders, with many foreigners, have been added to the population of the city, and trains from all quarters of this ancient kingdom are bringing thousands more.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Senator Raines has introduced a State Constabulary bill, putting all the cities' police under State control. It is understood that it is put in merely for discussion this year and without intention on the part of the majority to force it.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- A joint caucus of Republican Senators and Assemblymen tonight met in the Assembly Chamber to nominate a State Superintendent of Instruction and a State Regent to succeed the late Hamilton Harris.

The steam lighter New York, otherwise known as No. 11 of the New York Central Railroad Company's fleet of transports, caught fire at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, while lying between Piers D and E at the foot of West Sixty-seventh Street. Before the end of the fire one fireboat had been summoned, an alarm had been turned in on land, and the hose of half a dozen tugs had been busy on the burning transport.

When Mr. Mark Twain with dauntless pocketbook withstood the extortionate cabman he climbed to a notable height of civic distinction, the loftiest his feet had ever trod. He had become a soldier in the war of liberation, and an enslaved community was grateful to him. He was invited to many public dinners and began to make speeches with great rapidity.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 -- There was considerable activity in the market to-day and prices in the main were steady. There was a good market for Lehigh Valley around 33 1/2 and for the Readings at slightly advanced prices. Pennsylvania, after selling at 75 11-16, reacted a point and did not recover much.

ALBANY, Feb. 6 -- Chairman Stranahan of the Senate Committee on Cities to-day favorably reported to the Senate the bill introduced by Senator Grady to legalize the Pabst portico, at the intersection of Forty-second Street, Broadway, and Seventh Avenue. The bill was reported without amendment.

-- Opportunities to commend the present Commissioner of Street Cleaning have not been very frequent, and therefore it is with the greater joy that we seize the chance to express sympathy and satisfaction with his rage against the officials of the Uvalde Asphalt Paving Company for their very apparent reluctance to prevent, or even to minimize, the cruel exploitation of the poor laborers engaged in the work of snow removal.
At a meeting of the Board of Governors of the Automobile Club of America, held yesterday, the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Judge Kirkpatrick, in the United States Court to-day, filed an opinion refusing to make permanent the temporary appointment of Henry O. Kelsey as receiver for the Bay State Gas Company of New Jersey. Judge Kiricpatrick also dismissed the receivership without prejudice to the case if it should be pressed to a final hearing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections to-day reported unanimously Senator Chandler's bill to prohibit corporations engaged in inter-State or foreign commerce, National banks, or corporations organized under the authority of Congress from contributing to political campaigns.

It is not only or mainly because "all the world loves a lover" that everybody is inclined to sympathize with the enthusiastic Hollanders in their rejoicings over the marriage of their young Queen. It is true that the event carries back the minds, even of the vast majority of readers who cannot themselves remember it, to another marriage of a young Queen, who has just passed away as a very old Queen.

BOSTON, Feb. 7 -- Benjamin K. Woolf, musical and art critic of The Boston Herald, died to-day. Mr. Woolf was very well known as a playwright and musical composer, his best-known dramatic work being "The Mighty Dollar." He was the author of the opera "Westward Ho."

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 7 -- The loss of life in consequence of the great petroleum fire at Baku, Russian Transcaucasia, has not yet been definitely ascertained, but it is known that some hundreds of persons have perished.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Nation addressed both houses of the Legislature to-night on the saloon traffic. She presented herself at the door of the House with the request that she be allowed to speak. The request was voted upon and by a large majority Mrs. Nation was allowed to speak. Some few voted no.

Detectives for the prosecution spent yesterday in Arlington continuing the work of ferreting out statements tending to show that Mrs. Barker was a delicate woman, suffering from hysteria, and that she imagined the charge she brought against the Rev. John A. Kellar.
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- All the morning papers comment upon the Steel Trust in the United States.

Lawn tennis champions and others interested in the sport, assembled at the Waldorf-Astoria last night for the twentieth annual meeting of the United States National Lawn Tennis Association. A few changes in rules and other subjects upon the technique of the game occupied a large part of the delegates' attention, and it was after midnight before the conference was closed.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The Yachting World asserts that Sir Thomas Lipton wished to withdraw his challenge for the America's Cup after the death of Queen Victoria and to postpone the contest for a year, but that, on consideration of the injustice it would work toward the United States am after consulting the highest authorities, he decided to adhere to the original plans.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 7 -- This was another lively day for the ice yachtsmen of the North Shrewsbury River Club. There was some disappointment over the failure to sail the Commodore's race because of the illness of Commodore Samuel W. Morford, who has been laid up with the grip. A large fleet of third-class yachts were ready to try conclusions for the handsome silver prizes donated by Mr. Morford.

Charles Threshie, the Boston representative of the present Class A championship billiard tournament, now being played in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, won his game last night in the third match of the series. He defeated by the required number of 400 points at fourteen-inch balkline Dr. L.L. Mial of the home club, the latter scoring 345 points.
LONDON, Feb. 7 -- The rate of discount of the Bank of England was reduced to-day from 5 to 4 1/2 per cent.

Carl Arnold, the only son of F.A. Arnold, of 152 West One Hundred and Fifth Street, who made a fortune before he gave up his cafe at One Hundred and Eighth Street and Amsterdam Avenue two years ago, killed his supposed wife and himself with a pistol yesterday morning in the apartment of Cornelius Barrett, on the fifth floor of 168 West One Hundred and Seventh Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce yesterday a report was read from the Committee on State and Municipal Taxes regarding the Tax Listing bill and other tax legislation now before the Legislature. The Tax Listing bill was condemned, the committee enunciating as its belief that the measure would drive capital from the State.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Feb. 7 -- Justice Dickie, in the suit brought by Charles Hollister against Edward Valentine for alienation of Mrs. Hollister's affections, to-day instructed the jury to consider a North Dakota divorce null and void, and of no more effect than if no such thing was ever in existence.

District Attorney Philbin has interested himself in the case of Albert T. Patrick, now in the Tombs charged with forging Millionaire William M. Rice's name to checks, and the matter will be pushed to a conclusion under his direction at once.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Chairman Southard of the House Committee on Coinage to-day received from William J. Bryan the latter's view of the pending bills before the House making the standard silver dollar redeemable in gold. After thanking the committee for the courtesy of inviting his views, Mr. Bryan says:
ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Senator Audett of Brooklyn this morning introduced an important amendment to the present school law. Describing the measure, he says:
LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The correspondent of The Daily News at The Hague says he hears that after the honeymoon Queen Wilhelmina intends to make a tour of the European Courts.

Brown University's hockey team, though lacking in speed and finished play, but powerful on account of its heavy weight and excellent body checking, defeated the Yale seven, champions of the last two years, in an intercollegiate match at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening, by a score of 1-0. a Brown was the main factor in furnishing a most exacting and close fought contest that was a surprise to followers or collegiate hockey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Administration assumes, in discussing the Cuban Constitution and the conditions for its adoption by this Government, that the Cubans have not forgotten that there were responsibilities and obligations to be observed by them before the United States could be expected to regard with satisfaction and a sense of security the Cuban willingness to become a free and independent, government.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Local stocks were active and generally strong. Linseed was in better demand at 7 7/8 @ 8 1/4 for the common and 36 3/4 @ 37 1/4 for the preferred. Diamond Match also was higher, selling from 139 to 139 3/4, closing at 139 1/4. Strawboard improved to 34 3/4 and Biscuit common was traded in at 39 3/4 @ 40.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Another of the administration's tax bills -- that proposing to tax the surplus of savings banks 1 per cent. -- was the subject of a combined attack at a joint hearing of the Senate and Assembly Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment in the Senate Chamber this afternoon.

The second and last of the dinner dances organized by Mrs. Frederic J. de Peyster and J. Montgomery Strong, assisted by a number of others, was given at Delmonico's last night. There were thirty-one patronesses of these two dances, and each patroness was entitled to eight guests, seven for the dinner and a "stag" to come in later for the dance.

Seligman Kontour, an Austrian mathematician, with flowing locks and an air of profound melancholy, appeared in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon and earnestly sought protection from a chambermaid who he said was constantly endeavoring to clean up his room during his absence.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Prior to taking up the calendar in the House this morning Speaker Nixon asked the members to make their arguments on bills as brief as possible. No such time as two hours and a half should be devoted to any measure, unless it should happen to be one or great political importance.

After buoyancy at the opening of yesterday's market there came a searching reaction, most of the active stocks falling substantially. Attending this decline was a multitude of rumors, many of them representing business disturbance. The much-mooted iron and steel deal was reported upset, the coal deal was interrupted, gold exports in larger volume were to start.

Richard Pine Coffin, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, asked Justice Fitzgerald to issue a permanent injunction restraining the Erie Railroad Company from carrying out an agreement to purchase the Pennsylvania Coal Company, the Erie and Wyoming Valley Railroad, and the Delaware Valley and Kingston Railroad at a price of $37,000,000.

John Jones and his wife, Nellie, of 14 Rutgers Street, have been married only two years, but in that brief period, according to the story told by Mrs. Jones in the Essex Market Court yesterday morning, the temperature of the husband's affections for his wife, once exceedingly high, has gene down almost to zero.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the Single-Hearted Prisons Commission bill. It is sald the Governor will tender the appointment of Commisisoners of Prisons to Lispenard Stewart. the President of the Prisons Commission, which was abolished by the bill signed to-day.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Doubt as to the nature of the ceremonial to be observed at the opening of Parliament on Feb. 14 has been set at rest by an official announcement that it has been definitely determined that King Edward will open his first Parliament with full State ceremonial.

Capt. John D. Herlihy, formerly of the Eldridge Street Station, who was on trial on charges of neglect of duty and of conduct unbecoming an officer, was on the witness stand for cross-examination yesterday. ExJudge Olcott began with a personal Question, for which he made apologies.

Samuel J. Kennedy, dentist, of Staten Island, making a second fight for acquittal of the charge murdering Dolly Reynolds in the Grand Hotel Aug. 15, 1898, won several preliminary skirmishes in the opening battle of the lawyers, before Justice Fursman in the Criminal Branch of the Supreme Court yesterday.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Feb. 7 -- At the Jacob yard, this place, the general activity is noticeable. Alterations on W. Gould Brokaw's schooner yacht Amorita are practically completed, but all information regarding it is still withheld. The interior alterations on C.L.F. Robinson's British-built cutter Hester are rapidly progressing.

Army. Surgeon John W. Ross United States Navy, retired, having been assigned to duty under the War Department, will proeeed to Havana and report to the Commanding General, Department of Cuba, for assignment to duty.

Our esteemed contemporaries The Journal and The World are doing a public service the nature and extent of which they seem little to suspect in publishing everything they can lay hands on of the opinions, upon current affairs, of WILLIAM J. BRYAN, sometime, and till further notice, the candidate of one of them for President of the United States.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- The following bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day:
SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Feb. 7 -- The car Boston, which was built more than two years ago by the American Palace Car Company to exploit an invention, has been tied up here by an injunction two years.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- Crying out that drugs were the agents of the devil, a half-dozen women followers of Dowie, the faith cure leader, adopted the tactics of Mrs. Carrie Nation yesterday and wrecked several drug stores on the West Side. In some instances there were hand-to-hand fights with the druggists.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Minister from Austria-Hungary and Mme. Hengelmuller were this evening the ho ts at one of the notable dinners of the season.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 7 -- The end of a feline flirtation came to-day, when a splendid tigress, belle of the cage, was killed by one of her companions in the cage. Six splendid Bengal tigers were shipped here two weeks ago from New York by Gil Robinson, the intention being to exhibit the six in a cage, something, it is claimed, had never been done before.
ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Senator Wagner to-day introduced a bill to secure the registration and licensing of builders and the supervision of the building trade in the City of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 7 -- Quite a good deal of adverse comment has been caused among rowing circles of the University of Pennsylvania by the report which has come from Cornell to the efffect that the Ithacans do not view kindly the invitations to Wisconsin, Syracuse, and Georgetown to take part in the annual Poughkeepsie regatta.

It has always been hard for New York to get the ear of Albany, but never harder than during the present session of the Legislature. The report of the Charter Revision Commission, prepared, by men representing the wishes and the interests of this community, gets no attention from the lawmakers, while bills which public opinion in New York by all its authorized organs opposes are favorably reported from committees and hurried to enactment.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Ebeneza Griffith, who mysteriously disappeared a few days after her marriage, returned to this place last night, after an absence of two years. About two years ago Mr. Griffith made known through the columns of a newspaper that he was tired of bachelor life, and desired the companionship of a wife.

Renewed reports of cuts in west-bound freight rates brought out yesterday the fact that there is a Traffic Managers' Committee in existence in this city which has such extensive powers that it comes very close to constituting a combination of the kind which Eastern railroad officials recently stated to be not in existence in trunk line territory.

ALBANY, Feb. 7 -- Senator Krum, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, this morning received from E.R. Kennedy an array of arguments and facts which has quite surprised the members of the Joint Committee of the Senate and House. He was present at the hearing on the Insurance Tax bill, and entered a vigorous protest against its enactment.

We are indebted to The Evening post for an account of the manner in which WALTER H. COGGESHALL came to resign his place as Inheritance Tax Appraiser. In substance, it is that he was forced to resign, after a few weeks' enjoyment of his "snap," because his incapacity was at once obvious and complete.

PHILLIPSBURG, N.J., Feb. 7 -- A serious wreck occurred at 5:45 o'clock this morning on the Lehigh Valley Road, at Green's Bridge. The milk and paper train, which left New York about 3:30 A.M., with ten cars, seven of which were loaded with empty milk cans and three with newspapers and mail matter, was running sixty miles an hour.

-- Corporation Counsel WHALEN, weeks and weeks ago, formally and without qualification advised Commissioner KEATING that it was then, and long had been, both the right and the duty of the latter, by causing the immediate removal of the Pabst Hotel portico, to put the owners of Forty-second Street -- the public, to wit -- again in possession of valuable property of which they had been wrongfully deprived.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having read the editorial in your today's issue, "Certainly False but Probably Funny," I gratified the curiosity thereby excited, and read Mr. Mark Twain's article in The North American Review, to which you refer.

GREENVILLE, Penn., Feb. 7. -- Train No. 5, the New York-Chicago Limited, on the Erie Railroad, was wrecked this morning within the town limits. Five passengers were dead when taken from the wreck, several are missing, and there are many badly injured.
To the Editor of The Sew York Times: "R.P.K.," Jan. 30, states as a fact or positive declaration that Trustees of savings banks must set aside whatever surplus they decide upon.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 7 -- In the hearing on the application for an injunction against the Jeffries-Ruhlin prizefight Feb. 15, the defendants offered testimony to-day and will continue to-morrow. This means two days to each side for testimony, and that the arguments will be made Saturday and the decision of Judge Hollistor probably will be reserved until next week.

There is no doubt that day by day the end of the very gay season proclaims its presence near at hand. There are now very few large entertainments left on the cards, and nearly all the series of dinners and the days at home will cease to be when Ash Wednesday dawns less than a fortnight from now.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 7 -- An unknown female, emulating the crusade of Mrs. Nation, to-day entered a saloon at Eleventh and Lloyd Streets, seized an armful of pool balls and hurled them about with such good aim that the mirrors and other glass-ware about the place were quickly demolished.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Controller Bird S. Coler is an ambitious young politician with a turn for economy and reform -- both much neeeded in this Tammany-ruled city. He has discovered and stopped a number of wastefel and corrupt expenditures of the city's resources and exposed cheating that has been going on for years; all of which is very good and reflects credit on Mr. Coler.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were on a larger scale than on the previous day, and at the same time prices showed more irregularity. The market was strongest at the opening, when some sharp advances occurred, but the irregular movement of prices during the afternoon, in some instances, materially cut down the earlier gains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Knowing that you are always willing to lend your valuable influence in behalf of the suffering and distressed, I want to make an appeal to you. I saw some days since that a bill had been introduced by some zealous member of the Assembly to have the price of gas in this city reduced to 75 cents a thousand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Senate discussed the Ship Subsidy bill to-day in two sessions. In the day session Messrs. McLaurin (S.C.) and Morgan, (Ala.,) both Democrats, made speeches upon it. Mr. McLaurin announced his intention to support the bill and Mr. Morgan opposed it in vigorous language.

The United States Revenue cutter Gresham yesterday morning put a quick stop to the mutiny aboard the Standard Oil Company's ship Astral. Lieuts. Haake and Elberoth, accompanied by a crew of five armed sailors, went aboard the ship and arrested three sailors -- William Gray, Joseph Barbe, and Edward Dempsey -- who Capt. Dunham, the skipper of the sailing vessel, said were responsible for all the trouble.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 7 -- An official of the National Tube Company has received a telegram from President E.C. Converse, which stated that the papers for the purchase of stock of Andrew Carnegie had been signed, but the deal was not closed.

Charles A. Hess, the Republican politician and ex-district leader, added considerable spice to what was already a live lawsuit on trial before Justice McCarthy in the City Court yesterday. Mr. Hess called the defendant in tlie action a "liar and a thief," and then when questioned further went into more specific details.

We cannot too often repeat that no Democrat in the Senate can refuse to use all the means the rules of that body place in his hands to defeat the Ship Subsidy bill. One who does so refuse exposes himself to the reasonable suspicion that he is influenced by such selfish inducements as the wealthy and organized interests behind the bill can only too easily offer.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am sincerely grateful to the writer of the article in this morning's TIMES entitled "America's Interest in South Africa" for the clear and earnest manner in which he points out our duty in the present state of affairs there. I take no stock, however, in the commercial phase of his argument, as no selfish element should affect our consideration of the moral questions at stake.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 7. -- Wilhelmina, Queen of Holland, was to-day married to Duke Henry of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, who becomes Prince of the Netherlands by proclamation in The Court Gazette of this evening.

Major Gen. Otis, as a native of Rochester, was the guest of honor at the annual dinner of the Society of the Genesee at the Waldorf-Astoria last night. While, however, he was received with enthusiasm by the members of the society, who toasted him, cheered him, and even made him the subject of two poetical addresses, he also came in for a little criticism.

"Class legislation" is the cry raised against the act of 1896 creating the office of Special Commissioner of Jurors. The act does indeed make distinction between classes. It aims to exclude from the jury panel in criminal cases certain classes of citizens, to wit, the ignorant, the prejudiced, and the incompetent.

The New York Athletic Club team won two of its three games with the West Side Republican Club five in the New York Interclub Bowling league tournament on the West Side Republican Club alleys last night. The scores:

According to reports to Dun's, at St. John weather has been unfavorable for trade, and shipments to British ports show a decrease, but collections are fair. Although quiet in some lines, trade at Quebec on the whole is satisfactory, and collections up to the mark. Montreal reports dry goods payments on the 4th fairly met, but not quite as good as a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Among the subjects discussed at to-day's Cabinet meeting were the Cuban Constitution and the possible necessity for an extra session of Congress. Attention was called to the paragraph in the President's message to Congress at the beginning of the Fifty-sixth Congress, in which he said:...

The negotiations that have been under way for some time looking to the consolidation of the General Chemical Company and the New Jersey Zinc Company have been brought to practical completion, and a new company, with a capitalization of $64,000,000, is to be formed to take over both properties.

What happens when a fragile object comes in contact with a solid one has been known since the time of AESOP. It is a pity that railroad managers do not seem to "sense" the principle involved in the ancient fable.
LONDON, Feb. 9. -- Earl Roberts's detailed mail dispatches, ranging from Feb. 6 to Nov. 15, 1900, were gazetted last evening. They fill 157 quarto pages, and make up the official history of the war.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- When the Ship Subsidy bill was taken up to-day in the Senate, Mr. Frye (Rep., Me.,) made an appeal that a time be fixed for a vote upon the pending measure. He was exceedingly desirous for a vote. Personally, he said, he had no more desire for night sessions than any other Senator.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: Will you Kindly permit me to say a few words to my fellow-readers of your invaluable paper?

All students of folk-lore know that versions of the story of the "House that Jack Built" may be found in the legendary verse of at least five different languages, but the origin of this nursery tale is shrouded in the same shades of impenetrable mystery which envelop the source of the tradition of St. Christopherus and the fairy realm romance of Cinderella.

The present state of the negotiations with China sufficiently shows how foolish and futile it was for the Powers to insert that word "irrevocable" in the statement of their demands, and how sensible it was for our Government to object, until its objections were nullified by its representative on the spot, to the inclusion of that word.

An interesting book sale has just noon concluded at Libbie's auction rooms in Boston, in which Audubon's "Birds of North America" brought $308, which we believe in the highest price ever realized for this work at auction. The item was in seven volumes, all in fine condition, "Birds of North America" has steadily increased in price since 1876, when a copy was sold in this city at the Menzies sale for $175.

From The Literary News for February. While every magazine and newspaper in every country is giving its readers statistics regarding the book production of the year that ended a century the thoughts come and stay: Which of the books born in 1900 will be alive in the year 2000? Which show the elements even of the life of an ordinary generation?

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 8. -- Mrs. Carrie Nation, the Kansas "joint smasher," attended by a delegation of Topeka supporters and admirers, arrived here late this afternoon, and to-night she addressed a fairsized audience at the Academy of Music. F. W. Emerson, pastor of the First Christian Church of Topeka, introduced Mrs. Nation as "the bravest and noblest woman in Kansas," whereupon the audience gave three rousing cheers for her.

Interesting as are Mrs. Marshall's books, this memoir of a noble and useful life will be found even more fascinating: the whole "brief record," as the daughter and editor of the book, Beatrice Marshall, calls her biographical sketch, being largely told in extracts from her mother's diaries and letters, supplemented and woven together by her own recollections.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- Senator Elsberg has arranged for a hearing next Thursday before the State Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment upon the bill introduced by him to amend the tax law by providing for the apportionment of State taxes and for local option in taxation. This is the tax measure to which, the New York Chamber of Commerce has given its approval.

Theodore Nye of 152 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, a flour dealer on the Produce Exchange, is to bring a suit against the estate of Thomas G. Shearman, the well-known lawyer and single-taxer of Brooklyn, with his sister, Mrs. J.C. Topping, of 72 Columbia Heights, to recover their interest in a trust fund of $20,000, which was administered by Mr. Shearman.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- Elevated stocks were favorites in the tracing to-day. Lake Street in particular was in urgent demand. It opened at 10 1/8, touched 12, and closed at 11 5/6. Oyer 5,800 shares were sold. The bonds of the company also showed strength, the incomes selling at 47 and the debentures at 99 3/4@100.

The investigation by Capt. Mallett of the Metropolitan Line steamship Whitney of what he supposed was a floating iceberg of small dimensions off Faulkner's Island in the early hours yesterday morning resulted in the rescue of six frozen, famished, and almost dead seamen.

From The London Times. The splendid MS. of the "Evangelia Quatuor," which for over sixty years has been in possession of the Earls of Ashburnham, has this week been sold by private treaty by Messrs. Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge to a purchaser who does not wish his name to appear, but who, it may be said, is not an inhabitant of England.

No scholarly reader of the reports of the official proceedings taken upon the death of Queen Victoria can have omitted to take notice of the excellent English in which they were couched. It was more than "good." It rose to, and kept, a high rhetorical level. As Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman said in the House of Commons about the report of the meeting of the Privy Council that accepted the new sovereign, it was "stately language."

David Hunter McAlpin, the millionaire tobacco manufacturer and philanthropist, died at his town residence, 40 West Fifty-eighth Street, shortly after 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He was eighty-five years old. Death was due to an attack of apoplexy, which came on while Mr. McAlpin was attending a meeting of the Board of Directors of the Eleventh Ward Bank on Tuesday last.

At the Metropolitan Opera House last night Massenet's "Le Cid" was sung for the third time this season. The audience was one of good size, and it apparently enjoyed the performance. The cast was the same as at the previous performances, except that Miss Adams replaced Mme. Melba as the gentle Infanta, and Mr. Journet sang the Count do Gormas, instead of Mr. Plancon.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 8. -- Mrs. Carrie Nation, the temperance crusader, is alleged to have backed down last night for the first time since she started out to destroy the illegal traffic in liquor in Kansas. About thirty of her followers had gathered in secret to arrange a night raid on Topeka saloons.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 8. -- E. Romario, an Italian saloon keeper here, to-day bought fifty rats and mice and stored them behind his bar for protection against Mrs. Carrie Nation, who arrives here at noon to-morrow and lectures at the Young Men's Christian Association in the evening. The Prohibitionists of Des Moines have decided to make no demonstration for Mrs. Nation nor to give her any public recognition.

After the many dances and entertainments given on Thursday, Friday was hardly gay by contrast. There were not many dinners, and a very few dances. Of these latter, Mrs. Church's class was the most important. To-day again there is a very small list of events. Mrs. James Speyer and Mrs. H. De Berkeley Parsons and Mrs. Daniel Bacon give dinners, and the Badminton Club meets this afternoon.

MANILA, Dec. 27. -- The following is the text of Gen. MacArthur's proclamation to the Filipinos issued Dec. 20, ordering that martial law be strictly enforced and classifying all who committed an act inimical to the United States as traitors:

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- George Foster, former cashier at the South Danvers National Bank of Peabody, Mass., was arrested by Deputy Marshal Waters to-day, charged with embezzling $3,600 from that institution. The arrest was the outcome of the appointment of a receiver for the bank.

MANILA, Feb. 8. -- Since the arrest of Theodore Carranza and D.M. Carman, a former Califorinan, (who are charged with furnishing supplies to aid the insurgents,) evidence has been rapidly developing tending to show that not the Carman Company alone, but many business men in Manila have been having relations with the insurgents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- A report received at the State Department from United States Consul Fleming, at Edinburgh, Scotland, sets forth an alarming decline in the metal industry of Great Britain, calls attention to the lamentable lack of thorough technical education among British engineers, and discusses the mooted question as to whether the heavy exportation of coal from Great Britain should continue.

The plaster model of a statue of Nathan Hale designed for the campus at Yale stands in the studio of William Ordway Partridge. The face bears an expression of calmness, and, with hands crossed behind his back, the counterfeit presentment of the patriot is suggestive of anything hut strife.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8. -- The stock market was strong to-day, with the exception of Marsden and Union Traction, which showed a tendency to yield. The pronounced development was an advance in Lehigh Navigation to 67%. There was repeated bidding for Lehigh Valley at 33 and better.

Through the courtesy of James Lane Alien. author of "The Choir Invisible" and "The Reign of Law." we are permitted to print a letter from Harriet Beecher Stowe, giving her impressions of Kentucky slaveholders, as derived from personal knowledge of them obtained while she was living in Cincinnati.

George J. Gould and Helen M. Gould have been appointed receivers for the income of their sister, Anna, Countess de Castellane. The appointment was made yesterday by Judge Lacombe, in the United States Circuit Court, on the application of Eugene Fischhof, a resident of Austria.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 8. -- In the Chamber of Deputies to-day a petition asking Belgium to offer to arbitrate between Great Britain and the Transvaal was favorably reported by a commission.

Mr. WILLIAM ALLEN WHITE'S study of our RICHARD CHOKER, in the current number of McClure's Magazine, is of course interesting. It is the tentative explanation, by a clever man, of a chronic enigma. Here is a city of great wealth and enterprise, and in some respects of great enlightenment.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- It is understood on the best of authority to-day that the Congressional reapportionment scheme for the State as so far prepared has not met with the approval of Gov. Odell, and that a new one has been prepared that contemplates leaving the up-State districts practically as they are, except as to renumbering.

A writer in the "Contributors Club" of the December Atlantic says that "we Americans plume ourselves on our sense of humor," and adds, "never was assumption more Pharisaical. Our humor has not ripened long enough in the cellar to have the tender mellowness of the best English vintage."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The Senate today considered the Naval Appropriation bill. The bill was read in full, the committee amendments, except in two instances, being agreed to. An amendment was reported from the Naval Committee and agreed to, providing that the promotion of officers of the navy and Marine Corps, made on account of war services, shall not interfere with the regular promotion of officers.

It is to be regretted that people give as a general thing so little definite thought to the choice of words -- the formation for themselves of an individual and cultivated vocabulary. One is so careless in the choice of the word caught up for workaday use -- "any old thing" -- why not? The "fine" words may be kept for better occasions.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly insert the following in correction of an erroneous impression appearing in an editorial to to-day's issue?

Ida M. Tarbell has revised her "Napoleon," which has reached a sale of 100,000 copies, and will reissue it this month through McClure, Phillips Co., under the title of "Napoleon and Josephine.'' The original elaborate illustrations will be preserved in the forthcoming edition, which has been supplemented and enlarged through the addition of a sympathetic sketch of the first Empress of the French.

deserves the warmest commendation. A more beautiful brochure one could not desire. The type and hand-made paper are attractive features. The photogravure portrait from a crayon drawing of Barry's, made in 1859, is unique among VVhittier portraits, and is so beautiful that it should become the portrait by which Whittier will be known to coming generations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- Minister Wu-Ting-Fang is in danger of getting into trouble unless he becomes more discreet in his public utterances. The officers of the Administration have been watching his course lately with considerable irritation and apprehension. Many of his recent utterances have given offense to the Government, and the most serious of all is his letter to the Society of the Genesee.

The splendid MS. of the "Evangelia Quatuor," which for over sixty years has been in possession of the Earls of Ashburnham, has this week been sold by private treaty by Messrs. Sotheby, Wilkinson Hodge to a purchaser who does not wish his name to appear, but who, it may be said, is not an inhabitant of England.

In the tournament of the Royal Areanum Bowling League, Borough of the Bronx, on Pump's North Side Palace alleys, last night, the Suburban Council bowlers won three games from the Morrisania Council team. The scores:

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- As was the case yesterday, there was a great rush to buy and sharp advances in the first hour and a half to-day, and then comparative quiet during the middle of the day, while stocks sold to realize profits were absorbed.

PEKING, Feb. 8. -- The more widely known the demands of the foreign envoys are among the Chinese, the more the belief spreads that the Court will not accept them, especially the demand for the punishment of Gen. Tung-Fu-Siang, who practically controls the entire Chinese Army, apart from the troops with the Court, and who is now in the province of Kan-Soo.

HERMAN SIEGEL, Wide Water, Va., writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, says: "In THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Feb. 2 I noticed some rhymes entitled: 'The Rhyming Sovereigns.' It may interest you that a few days ago I saw some similar rhymes which, in my judgment, supersede those published by you.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 8. -- Three hundred guests attended the annual banquet of the Syracuse Chamber of Commerce here to-night. Gov. Odell was the guest of honor and spoke in response to the toast, "State Government."

The more closely the tax bills before the Legislature are examined, the more they seem to be constructed on the grabbag principle. A heavy hand is thrust deep into a receptacle of unknown contents and as much as possible is clutched. The rights, needs, and duties of the owners of the contents and those of the grabber are equally ignored.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The State Board of Health bill, providing for a single-headed commission, on the order of second reading in the House this morning, was amended by Mr. Kelsey so as to give to the Deputy Commissioner the same powers conferred upon the Commissioner during the latter's absence from the city. The bill as amended was then advanced to third reading.

Fine sport on the Harlem River Speedway was enjoyed yesterday afternoon, when the light-harness horsemen of this city turned out in full force for the first time this Winter with their fast steppers hooked to cutters. For several days there had been promise of good sleighing on the Speedway, but the high wind kept the reinsmen from taking advantage of it.

R.P.R. of New York writes: "The several articles which have appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW on this beautiful book have been interesting and instructive reading, more particularly the exhaustive statement in the issue of Jan. 26. It may be safely stated that Mr. Mumford's work is one of the best books issued in the United States during the year 1900.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- The report that Emperor William has conferred upon Lord Roberts the Order of the Black Eagle, although not officially confirmed, is now accepted as true. A number of confirmatory dispatches from London are published today.

Announcement was made yesterday that Kuhn, Loeb Co. had underwritten an issue of $40,000,000 of Union Pacific 4 per cent. first mortgage and collateral trust ten-year gold bonds. The issue is made for the purpose of raising funds wherewith to pay for the stock of the Southern Pacific Company, which was recently acquired.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were on a smaller scale than they were the preceding day, but prices were less irregular. American Bridge still headed the list in point of activity, and the total shown by this stock was greatly in excess of the trading in any other issue. A few sharp advances occurred, but in most cases prices were not very materially changed.

Franz P. Kaltenborn, the violinist who recently left his wife, who furnished the funds for the Kaltenborn concerts of the last two Summers at the St. Nicholas Garden, followed her to Philadelphia Wednesday, and, going to her room at the Hotel Bingham alter midnight, found her in company with Carl Hugo Engel, whom she installed as the leader of her musical organization after Mr. Kaltenborn's departure.
The Jewish "Feast of the Passover" and the Christian feast of "The Lord's Supper" are very closely connected, both historically and spiritually.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 8. -- Advices from Baku this evening announce that the fire has been extinguished. Ten factories and five depots were burned, containing altogether 35,000,000 poods (over 1,260,000,000 pounds) of naphtha and naphtha refuse. It is estimated that the losses will exceed 6,000,000 rubles.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Princeton students to-night, examinations being over, made merry at the annual Glee Club concert and the junior promenade. Fair visitors and their chaperons began to arrive in town early in the day, and the hotels were taxed to accommodate the students' guests.

A judgment for $1,883.75 which was obtained against Smith M. Weed on Jan. 10 last was the cause of an examination before Justice Conlan, in the City Court, yesterday. The judgment was obtained by Charles I. McLaughlin, and his counsel had secured an order to examine the officers of the Trust Company of New York, of which Mr. Weed is a Trustee, in order to find out the amount of his assets.

More than 200 women, representing fifty different organizations, held a conference yesterday afternoon at the Tuxedo, Madison Avenue' and Fifty-ninth Street, and discussed plans for a big mass meeting of women to be held early in March to rouse public sentiment against the protection of vice in this city.

William K. Aston will erect a fourteenstory building at the northwest corner of Wall and Water Streets, on a plot 92 by 50.9, now occupied by the old Tontine Building and the adjoining structure, known as 82 Wall Street. Mr. Aston has bought these properties from the estate of Peter J. O'Donohue for a little less than $400,000.

BRISTOL, R.I., Feb. 8. -- Much of the fastening work on the cup defender building here for the Belmont syndicate is to be effected by means of electricity, an electric plant with powerful dynamos having been installed in the boat sheds last year by Designer Herreshoff when he felt sufficiently confident that an order would be placed with him for an all-metal boat to defend the America's Cup.

Three meetings have been held by Harlem pastors and laymen looking to the undertaking of aggressive evangelistic work under the direction of Col. Henry H. Hadley. The work proposed consists of meetings on week night for the special advantage of laborers for the underground railway contractors, for boatmen along the Harlem Hirer, and especially for uplift effort in the vicinity of Broadway and One Hundred and Tenth Street.

J.B.C. McKee, the Philadelphia competitor in the Class A billiard championship, carried off the honors of victory last night in the fourth game of the tournament, which is being held in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. He met John A. Hendrick of the home club, and the old-time champion of Connecticut, and defeated the latter at 14-inch balk-line by 400 points to 394, the closest game of the series.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- George H. Phillips, the young Board of Trade plunger, who made a lot of money in the November corn deal, has found out that wheat cannot be bulled under present conditions. A portion of his May holdings went overboard today through brokers, and more of the same line will doubtless be unloaded before the close of the week.

There have been no significant trade developments during the week, but it is a gratifying fact that, Quite generally, the steady betterment noted these several weeks past continues. The more seasonable weather reported from almost every quarter has stimulated trade in many lines that heretofore have been inclined to dullness, this notably so in clothing, rubbers, and woolen goods.

Contrary to general expectations, the stock market yesterday opened strong, in some instances indeed almost buoyant. More, the strength was well maintained throughout the day, the close showing net gains quite general to the list.

One of Canada's representative hockey teams, that of the Montreal Club, gained a clever and comparatively easy victory over the seven of the New York Athletic Club in the third of the international matches, at the St. Nicholas Rink, last evening, the score being 6 to 1. The two main factors in the Canadians' success were their excellent stick work and speed.

THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of last week was through and throughout such a Stockton number that what I intend to say may seem a little like crowding, not the mourners, but the rejoicers. Nevertheless, as Mr. Gilder said in his remarks, you seldom hear Mr. Stockton laugh -- you often see him smile.

A man with a black beard and a Yiddish accent, and evidently laboring under extreme excitement, came out of Police Headquarters yesterday and, reaching the sidewalk, swore an oath that he would get justice from the Police Commissioners, or, failing that, would appeal to the courts. The man said he was Raphael Blume, a shoe merchant at 324 Third Avenue, and he said that Inspector Cross had denied him justice.

It may interest readers to know the number of books and periodicals received by THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW during the twelve months ended Jan, 31. The periodicals included in the following total are exclusive of those received by the regular exchange department of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A reader of THE TIMES who signs himself "A Christian Patriot" says in a letter which we printed yesterday that our note of warning against the total untrustworthiness of Mr. Mark Twain's burlesque history of the Philippine transaction has prompted him to read Mr. Twain's article, and he likes it.

Representatives of organizations opposed to the domination of Tammany Hall in municipal affairs were in session behind closed doors at the Waldorf-Astoria until midnight last night. A plan was mapped out, and this will be left to the management of a Committee of Sixty, to be appointed at an early day, and which will be comprised of members of every anti-Tammany organization in Greater New York.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- It is understood here that by a new arrangement all the street railways south of Boston owned by the Massachusetts electric companies are to come under one management and be known under the title of the Old Colony Street Railway. Robert S. Goff of Fall River will be the General Superintendent.

Ex-Sheriff "Jimmy" O'Brien, who has been the leader of a political faction which has figured more or less in every campaign for years, and who is well known to nearly every public man in the city, has been sued by his wife, Ella Abbie O'Brien, on account of alleged abandonment and non-support.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I read with lively interest in THE TIMES of last Saturday that Dr. Conan Doyle was to treat the world to some more of the professional adventures of his friend Sherlock Holmes. I scarcely think that this announcement will occasion acute surprise in the breast of the experienced "dear reader."

Henry Hentz was unsuccessful on the trial of his suit against Theodore A. Havemeyer and others, to recover for services rendered to the firm of Havemeyer Elder, and that result was yesterday upheld by the Appellate Division.

The appearance of Senator Timothy D. Sullivan at Tammany Hall last evening before the meeting of the Executive Committee caused the assembled politicians to whisper to one another: "There must be something doing, or 'Big Tim' Sullivan would not be here." Senator Sullivan does not often visit headquarters to attend routine business meetings.

THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW'S series of "Authors at Home," printed a few years ago, contained a sketch of Mr. Stockton's house at Convent Station. N.J. As many readers know, he has since removed to Charles Town, West Va., where he has a residence bearing the name Claymont.

Brave in all its trappings borrowed from this side and from that, the Thirty-fourth shows itself at the old accustomed stand as gay and lively as any of the preceding exhibitions of the American Water Color Society. Here is the Venetian Building on Fourth Avenue once more, from which the Academy has expatriated itself.

HOMO SANE, Roxbury, Mass., writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "All lovers of Mrs. Humphry Ward's 'Eleanor' may be grateful to the critic of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW for her appreciative and sympathetic review of that rare and exquisite work. The fundamental law in 'Eleanor' shows a high-minded woman stooping to treachery to maintain her fancied rights.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noted with interest a communication from H. Payne which appeared recently in your columns. In it he protested against criticisms upon the rich for lavish expenditure. I quite agree with the writer that "the spender and not the hoarder" is to be praised, and would be the last to deny the intellectual and moral force of beautiful surroundings.

According to the testimony given in the Brush will contest yesterday Christian Scientists are not content with usurping the powers of regular physicians, but they also "cure" clocks that have a habit of being out of order, and can at will cause canary birds to grow new feathers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- A special meeting of the Ways and Means Committee today for the purpose of acting on the Revenue Reduction bill resulted in something of a surprise by the adoption of a resolution, submitted by the minority through Representative Richardson of Tennessee, for a disagreement to the Senate amendments in bulk and requesting a conference with the Senate.

For the first time since the many reports have been in circulation concerning the proposed transfer of Mr. Carnegie's holdings in the Carnegie Steel Company, and incidentally telling of the alleged formation of a "billion-dollar steel trust," an official statement on the general subject was forthcoming yesterday.

One fact made clear in the recent movement of the security market is that the strongest financial interests of the country are interested in the improvement that values are showing, and are co-operating to make such improvement still greater. Throughout the whole market this shows.

Police Inspector Kane, backed by fifty big bluecoats, prevented last night the giving of an entertainment in the Athenaeum, a large meeting hall at Atlantic Avenue and Clinton Street, Brooklyn, which, the police claimed, was to have been held for the benefit of the Anarchistic Brotherhood which has its headquarters in Paterson, N. J.

The only new plays announced for tomorrow night are a romantic extravaganza by R.A. Barnet entitled " My Lady," with which the Victoria will reopen after being closed a week, and a new Augustus Thomas farce called "On the Quiet." at the Madison Square Theatre, in which William Collier will be seen in the leading role.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the various arguments that have been advanced against the ill-advised attempt of Gov. Odell to transfer the supervision of the charitable institutions from a board of twelve disinterested citizens to a commission of political appointees, I fail to notice reference to one point that should appeal to every lover of our Constitution.
"This case of a Christian Scientist curing typhoid fever with ice cream reminds me of a case of appendicitis that I cured with a beefsteak," said a physician yesterday.
The Grolier Club is showing an exhibition of the selected works of the Poets Laureate of England. Admission is by card, from 10 to 6, closing Feb. 16.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The whole length of Pennsylvania Avenue, from the Capitol to just beyond the White House, has suddenly witnessed an irruption of carpenters, timber, booths for watchmen and storage, and a litter of incomprehensible material out which observation stands of artistic design and within the reach of the slenderest purse are to be constructed.
The Arkansas Legislature has decided upon the apple blossom as the State flower. The Arkansas Federation of Women's Clubs wanted the passion flower chosen.

From The Spectator. Many will remember the death of Miss Helen Faucit, the actress, who had trod the boards with Edmund Kean and learned her art from Macready and Farren. Others will recollect Mr. Francis William Newman, a brother of the Cardinal, who was born before Pitt and Fox died, and was admitted to a fellowship at Balliol College in 1826.

Devotees of sleighing, skating, and other lovers of the weather of real Winter, were rather hopeful yesterday morning when they left their homes. The snowflakes were coining down thick and fast at 9 o'clock, and the temperature was falling at a most satisfactory February rate.

The expected letter from the Secretary of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, which is said to contain a request for several minor changes in the conditions for the coming races for the America's Clip, was received by Secretary Oddie of the New York Yacht Club yesterday morning, and a meeting of the Racing Committee of the club to consider the communication was called for to-morrow evening at 9 o'clock.

The disappointment created by the failure of the Tammany Hall investigating committee to make a report to the Tammany Hall Executive Committee on Friday afternoon was tempered by information given out yesterday to the effect that the investigating committee had reported progress, and that its official existence had been continued.

Charles Silber of 108 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn, was before Magistrate Flammer in the Harlem Police Court yesterday, charged by his wife, Adelaide, with having sent a threatening letter to her brother, Charles Hauptner, who has a furnishing store at Broadway and Thirty-third Street. The letter, which was read in court, is as follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Gov. Odell has been gathering some facts upon the treatment of savings banks in other States. He finds that in most of them the savings banks are corporations which are run for the benefit of the corporation, and that all are taxed. Most of the mutual savings banks outside of New York are in New England, where every one of the States imposes a tax upon the surplus.

An express train and a switch engine came in collision about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the yard of the Grand Central Station, near the Forty-sixth Street bridge. While no one was injured, there was quite a panic among the passengers.

NEWTON, N.C., Feb. 9 -- A case occurred here this week that shows how dangerous it is in matters of life and death to take anything for granted, instead of proving conclusively all the facts necessary to make out a charge of murder. A man of the name of Simon Hawser, about eighty years old, who lived alone, a few miles from this town, was found dead in his home.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I learned yesterday that water began to fail above the first story in the higher houses of Bedford Park at least four years ago. At about that time a ten-year contract was made to sell the "surplus" water to the Westchester Water Company.

Practically speaking, this is the last week of the season. In ten days Lent will begin, and with it come the Lenten amusements. The sewing classes are all organized for the season, and the Badminton and Bowling Clubs have begun their sessions. New York, however, fashionably considered, is becoming less and less a place of permanent residence.

For the past ten years theatregoers and other pleasure seekers who walked on the Broadway of the Tenderloin after dark were wont to glance aside to the curbing at the attenuated harmonies of a hand-organ. The glance showed them a ragged old man grinding out the wheezy greeting of age to youth, but it also showed a grizzly haired dog hard by with a basket half full of coin in his mouth.

BLOEMFONTEIN, Feb. 5 -- The text of a portion of the letter from Piet De Wet, Chairman of the Peace Commission, to his brother, Christian De Wet, appealing to the latter to surrender, published in The Post to-day, is as follows:

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 1 -- As the annual report of the Sanitary Officer of this city is now out, it is interesting at this time to take a general survey of the work which has been performed by the American authorities in Havana toward making it what it should be, a clean, beautiful place, a desirable resort for our Northern people who cannot or do not care to undergo the rigors of the Winter season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Various statements have been made concerning the bill now before the Legislature of this State known as the "Bell bill." We desire to make a statement concerning this measure, which is of vital importance to the public.

At the Metropolitan Opera House the usual two performances took place yesterday. Puccini's "Tosca" was to have been given in the afternoon, but the outer portals bore placards announcing that, owing to the indisposition of Miss Ternina, the opera could not be given, and that "Aida" would be given instead.

Alderman P. Tecumseh Sherman, son of Gen. W.T. Sherman, has written a book on his two years of service as a member of the New York Board of Aldermen. "Inside, the Machine" is the title of the book. Alderman Sherman was never inside the Tammany machine, which controlled the business of the Board of Aldernien, but was a member of a small Republican minority who were given small chance to direct public affairs.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- "I am keeping careful watch on American affairs," said Richard Croker in the course of an interview to-day, " but I have no intention of talking to the American press on political affairs at home. There have been many things attributed to me which are entirely untrue. But I have no need to rush into print to reply to them.

LAKEWOOD, N.J, Feb. 9 -- Lakewood has this week shown signs of awakening from the social, quietude which immediately followed the holiday festivities, and with a few affairs of cottage interest during the week there have come announcements from all sides which promise varied pleasure for a resort presence which will soon attain full numbers.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- After a strong openins this morning the market became wild. Sugar reached 141 1/4; Chicago, Burlington and Quincy went to 141 1/2, a rise of 3/4; American Steel and Wire went up 1/2, Union Pacific 1/8, Amalgamated sold off 7/8, Baltic went up 1, Copper Range 2 1/2. Old Dominion 1 1/4, and Centennial 1.

From The Nineteenth Century. Every one tries to become like the fashionable ideal, and this endeavor often meets with a good deal of success. The power of adaptability latent in the female form especially has always struck me with admiring wonder. For instance, if the ideal has a small waist, most women will, somehow or other, have a small waist, too, to the great detriment of their health and activity.

A bit of the Orient was brought to the Madison Square Garden last night for the delectation of the thousands who had gathered within the great hall to attend the fifth annual ball of the Siegel-Cooper Company Employes' Association. The Oriental bit of flavoring came in the shape of a Japanese wedding, when Yassi Nomoura San and O Matsukasa San were made man and wife, according to the ancient Japanese rites.

It is the strain within the bowels of the working chamber, unnoticed, generally, while there; the change on coming into the outer air that the sand hog (the workman) dreads. Under an air pressure, the blood is forced away from the extremities; it is driven from the exterior into the central organs, especially toward the brain and the spinal cord.

REDBANK, N.J., Feb. 9 -- An ice yacht racd was sailed on the North Shrewsbury to-day over the regular ten-mile course. There was a heavy snowstorm at the time, the snow being driven by a thirty-mile wind from the northeast. The snow fell so thick that the boats were out of sight when about 100 yards from the home stake.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- In strict accuracy the subject that has been most gossiped about this week in London is the clerical libel suit decided yesterday. The plaintiff is, or was, an American clergyman, and the disclosures made in court are suggestive of many thoughts on morals better not uttered. I merely mention the subject as a chronicler to show the popular temper and pass to matters of more importance.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 -- There will be racing at both the Tanforan and Oakland tracks next week. The only feature of the war between the two tracks to-day was the address of Prince Poniatowski, President of the San Francisco Jockey Club, to the horsemen at Tanforan. He defined the position of his association, and told the owners that they must choose between the two tracks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- It was made known to-day that it is the intention of the Administration, even if the Cuban Constitution should prove to be satisfactory, to keep the troops in Cuba for some time after the election and inauguration of the officers to be elected under it. The election, of course, will not affect the Military Government at all, nor will it change the situation materially.

Lincoln's Birthday is not likely to be celebrated with any great competitive activity on the links in the metropolitan district. There may be some playing for practice and amusement, but whether the weather becomes warmer or colder, the facilities for good scoring will be decidedly poor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Quite a number of your contemporaries recently have been publishing obituaries on the late lamented Queen Victoria, referring to her as Queen of England. Why not Queen of Ireland or Queen of Scotland as well? How would it sound to American ears to refer to Mr. McKinley as President of New York State?

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- It has just transpired that, included in the two volumes of Eugene Field's newspaper contributions recently published by Charles Scribner's Sons, there are printed as the work of Field a number of poems which were written by his friend, the Rev. Dr. F.W. Gunsaulus.

Four policemen and two prisoners had a narow escape from death or injury yesterday, when a team hitched to the patrol wagon of the West One Hundred and Fifty-second Street Police Station, in which they were all seated, ran away and dashed through the streets for a distance of three-quarters of a mile.

Twelve hundred enthusiastic spectators watched the hockey team representative of the best material in New York go down in defeat before the able seven of the Montreal Hockey Club in the fourth international match at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening.
