New York yielded for five goals, and could not gain one point herself, making the final tally 5 -- 0 in favor of the Canadians.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am still under the impression that Mr. Leonard Tuttle is incapable of an impartial view on the subject of personal property taxation.

The residence of Morris Jacoby, at 243 East Sixtieth Street, was entered by a burglar and ransacked some time on Friday night. The intruder overlooked a number of valuable things, including several hundred dollars in cash, and the proceeds of his crime were comparatively insignificant.

An innovation in bicycle races on armory floors is announced for the games of Company K, Eighth Regiment, and the Union Settlement Athletic Club on March 9. The usual mile novice race is replaced by a half-mile novice, the shorter distance requiring the racers to keep up top speed all the way, and being ample to demonstrate the relative ability of the competitors.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- In all the homage paid to King Edward, Queen Alexandra is little heard of. "Proclamation by the King" in big, black type, parades itself curiously on the London hoardings, and the young blood of England is insensibly fired by the idea that a manly, almost martial, ruler once more controls their destinies.

SEATTLE, Washington, Feb. 9 -- The steamers Victorian, from Skagway, and Bertha, from Port Valdes, have arrived here, the latter with two men, both of whom were maimed for life in their efforts to find fortune in the Cook Inlet country.

BANGOR, Feb. 9 -- Maine is a Yankee State, if there is one such anywhere, the proportion of foreign-born residents, or even of immediate descendants of foreign-born people, being small, yet there are in the State four quaint and prosperous settlements that show how gregarious and how thrifty are the Irish, the Dutch, the French Acadians, and the Swedes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 9 -- In the first intercollegiate basketball series between the freshmen of the leading universities to-night the Yale freshman team defeated the Columbia freshmen by the score of 16 to 14. The game was a close one until less than five minutes before its close. Tweedy of the Yale team did the best work, throwing six goals.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 9 -- A company has been formed for the construction of a modern Summer hotel. The company has already had considerable stock subscribed. The intention is to have $900,000 subscribed for when the hotel is begun.

The bill introduced by Mr. Weekes providing that the examination of jurors as to their qualifications shall be conducted exclusively by the Court was discussed much by lawyers and Judges of the city yesterday. Many members of the judiciary and some practicing attorneys were asked for their opinions on the bill.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Justice Grantham has granted an injunction against Lady William Beresford (formerly Lilian, Duchess of Marlborough) entering or running in any races, or selling the Derby favorite, Volodyovskl, or other horses leased by the late Lord William Beresford from Lady Meux. As executrix Lady Beresford claimed the right to fulfill the engagements of the horses.

The disposal of the entire racing stable of James Butler of this city and the East View Stock Farm, East View, N.Y., which will be the feature of the first evening of "the 400" sale at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday evening will be a source of lasting regret to all supporters of clean racing, as the Butler string has been particularly prominent in this respect.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the purpose of bringing to the attention of other readers of your paper as well as to the public officials responsible for the present condition of affairs as regards the Bronx water supply, I ask you to insert in your news columns the following letter:

The production of Puccini's "Tosca" -- to which even the management persists in prefixing "La" was the musical incident of the past week. Perhaps the first duty of to-day is to emphasize the fact that Mr. Grau deserves the greatest possible credit for the presentation of the two works of this interesting Italian composer, and for the admirable manner in which he has put them on the stage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- During almost the entire session of to-day the Senate had under consideration the Naval Appropriation bill. Practically the bill was completed when it was laid aside for the day, all of the committee amendments being adopted, but as the measure was about to be placed on its passage Mr. Butler (Pop., N.C.,) precipitated a discussion of the armor plate question.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Seven inches of snow fell in Chicago during the storm which started yesterday afternoon, and which raged until this morning, resulting in an almost complete tie-up of many of the cross-town car lines, and seriously interrupting the suburban train service. So blinding was the fine snow, driven by a northeast wind, which at times reached a velocity of over forty miles an hour, that many accidents resulted.

Bronx Borough public schools are so overcrowded that thousands of children are obliged to attend only half-day classes, while there are many who are receiving no instruction at all. This condition of affairs has aroused the indignation of public-spirited citizens and officials, who are working hard to effect a remedy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Ever since the speech of Minister Wu in Carnegie Hall, some weeks ago, in which he ventured to compare, to some extent, the tenets of the Christian faith with those of Confucius, a very interesting discussion, not to say debate, has been going on in the public press respecting the comparative merits of these most widely known and advocated moral codes.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Since the reduction of the Bank rate money has taken a turn decidedly upward, partly owing to heavy repayments of loans to the Bank, partly to borrowings by the Bank to make the newrate effective, and partly to the issue of the war loan, and closed at 3 per cent. Discounts hardened sympathetically.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9 -- This afternoon C.L. Tappin of Westbrooke and C.F. Watson, Jr., of the Essex County Club played in a foursome against Clayton Dixon of Huntington Valley and A.W. Black of Lakewood. The latter were defeated by 1 up.

To the Editor of The New York Times: At last the public knows what are the ingredients of the XXXX ale which, is poured down the throats of the thirsty in such quantities. The local unions of brewery workmen have an Executive Committee, and a Secretary, Mr. Ernest Bohm, a very truthful and honest man on whom we can rely for a fair statement.
DANIEL GAGE, the millionaire iceman of Lowell, Mass., died Friday night of pneumonia.

THURSDAY, FEB. 14. -- By Herbert A. Sherman, partition sale, 305 Fifth Avenue, east side 28.9 feet north of Thirty-first Street, 28 by 150 four-story brownstone-front building, with store and a two-story brick stable at the rear, to gether with right of way through an alley to Thirty-first Stret: also,

Investment buying has shown a substantial increase during the week, while the continued activity in many sections -- much of it of a speculative character, to be sure -- has kept the volume of business well up to the high standard recently established.

CONCORD, N.H., Feb. 9. -- Dr. Irving A. Watson, Secretary of the State Board of Health, returned from Harrisville last night, and reported fifteen cases of smallpox in that town of 750 inhabitants. In Dr. Watson's opinion, the situation is serious. Dr. Watson also found one case at Milford.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 31 -- If the pockets of the foreign residents of China could be turned inside out for the benefit of some one wishing to cross the Pacific, passage money could no doubt be scraped from the exhibits, but there would probably be little surplus, and it is quite safe to say that in the majority of cases no money whatever would be forthcoming.

PEABODY, Mass., Feb. 9 -- Interest in the South Danvers National Bank case today centred in the announcement that the alleged Boston borrower from the bank, who has been mentioned many times in connection with the case, is John W. Dickinson, a stockholder.

"If some women are extravagant, there are others who balance the scale with their economies," says a New York business man. "I was taking my luncheon at a downtown restaurant the other day when a shabbily dressed woman came in.

Counterfeiting copper cents would hardly seem to offer profit sufficiently commensurate with the risk to engage the activities of a gang of expert corners, but the arrest of a thirteen-year-old girl discloses the fact that this work has long been in progress in this city, and that those who have carried it on have garnered, if not a fortune, much more than a handsome living from their clandestine toil.

The League for Social Service is taking a deep interest in a recently launched movement to have the city acquire property and erect upon it model tenements, to be rented by the municipality. A petition is being extensively circulated asking the Legislature to allow the city to go into the real estate business in this way, and it already has many signers, who believe that the plan is worth trying, at least as an experiment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's TIMES you remark: "So when Mark Twain * * * starts in to lecture us about the things of State that have made all heads ache these two years, the result is neither fish nor flesh. It may be good red herring."

According to the authorities of Bellevue Hospital, there are not a few habitual drunkards, both men and women, who look upon the alcoholic ward as a kind of second home. Time after time they go on sprees, and with equal frequency are taken to the ward, to be cared for until they have recovered enough energy and strength to start out into the world anew.

MONDAY, FEB. 11. -- By Philip A. Smyth, foreclosure sale, Otto A. Rosalsky, referee, 141 West Twenty-seventh Street, north side. 475 feet west of Sixth Avenue, 25 by 98.9, three-story brick tenement, with four-story brick tenement at the rear. Due on judgment, $16,134.

Discarding all polemics, modern thought is inclined to believe in the theory of evolution as far as religions are concerned. It need not hurt our susceptibilities to think that man's first appreciation of his Maker was but a low one. Gradually and by degrees it has come about that we have at last obtained through divine mercy some glimpses of Him.

Superintendent Blodgett of the New York and Long Branch Railroad has announced extensive alterations and improvements in the roadbed and equipment. When these improvements are made it is the intention to run express trains between Jersey City and the shore at a speed of sixty to seventy miles an hour.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your invariable courtesy in admitting to your columns the correspondence of those of your readers who disagree with your views on the various questions of the day encourages me to take issue with your editorial of Feb. 1 relating to the Sherman Statue.

The French Canadians disliked the American colonists (with whom they had constantly throughout their history been fighting) a great deal more than they did that to them, at that time, harmless abstraction, "The King of England." The French Canadians had not been happy in their relations with their own mother country.
CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Secretary George C. Sikes of the Street Railway Commission has returned from an extended Eastern trip, bringing with him much information concerning subways and street railways.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To me one of the most interesting and incomprehensible incidents connected with the death and funeral of Queen Victoria has been the entire refrain of the Irish people both in Ireland and in the United States, as well as the Roman Catholic Church, from any participation whatsoever in the affair, either by word or deed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All who are interested in the future of higher education in this country are feeling no little concern on account of the recent troubles at Leland Stanford Junior University, preceded as they have been by similar disturbances elsewhere. Such occurrences cannot be frequently repeated without inflicting serious damage upon the cause of intellectual progress.

CINCINNATI, Feb. 9 -- The situation is more complicated than ever to-night regarding the contests here next Friday night between Martin and Childs and Jeffries and Ruhlin. It was thought that arguments would be completed to-night before Judge Hollister on the application for a permanent injunction against the proposed contest.

Somewhat of a sensation was caused at Bellevue Hospital last evening, when it became known that Commissioner Of Charities Keller had discharged Day Nurses Trevor and Blakely and Night Nurses Gordon, Berger, and McKee, who were on duty in the insane pavilion. The charges against the nurses are carelessness and unfitness.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 9. -- Mrs. Nation's tour through the western part of the State to-day took on a new feature, and was in a sense a triumphal journey. She made a dozen addresses from the platform of a RocK Island passenger train in the towns she passed through to come to Des Moines to deliver a lecture.

LONDON, Feb.9 -- Speculation is rife as to the date of King Edward's coronation, some people maintaining that it will take place as early as September, but probably the year of Court mourning will be strictly observed, the coronation not taking place until Februaiy, or later, in 1902.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9 -- The question of the fit salary for Aldermen is being mooted just now, and the Aldermen have been asked to state what they think the position is worth, and also what sum they will vote for. Alderman McCormick is of the opinion that a good citizen should be willing to serve his city for $1,500; Alderman Wulff believes that $10,000 is none too much.

BRISTOL, Feb. 9 -- In many respects the work of building the Bristol cup defender during the week past has been progressing well, notwithstanding the fuel that the usual force of steel workers employed when a cup defender is building at Bristol are not in evidence. Trouble was encountered in securing a sufficient number of skilled steel workers when the job was commenced.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 9 -- It is reported that when the will of Mrs. Augusta J. Weeks of this place is filed for probate at Riverhead before Surrogate Petty on Monday next, a notice of contest will be filed by the testatrix's adopted daughter, and also by one of Mrs. Weeks's brothers and one of her nieces.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- Dr. Alfred Russell Wallace, the distinguished English naturalist and scientific associate of Darwin, has found in the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard the nearest approach to his ideal of what a museum should be. In his latest volume, "Studies Scientific and Social," Dr. Wallace says that the museum "is far in advance of ours as an educational institution, either as regards the general public, the private student, or the specialist."

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your editorial of the 7th inst. on Mark Twain's scathing satire upon England's Chamberlain and our McKinley, I have the honor to differ with you, most radically. Though a constant reader of THE TIMES, I have no sympathy with your attempts to uphold this Administration's course in the Philippines, nor find excuses for that which thousands regard as a stupendous moral crime.

Sixteen years before the death of John W. Irving, which took place in 1898, he made a will in which he directed that the residuary estate be divided into two equal parts. One-half of this was to be used n the purchase of a vault in Greenwood Cemetery and the other half was to be sed in the maintenance of that vault.

Wallace F. Lyons, Principal of Public School No. 155, known as the Mount Hope School, is again under investigation. A grievance committee of a dozen persons who have, or had, children at the school, went to the headquarters of the Board of Education yesterday to complain of Mr. Lyons, whom they accuse of being un amiable, arrogant, and unjust in matters of promotion.

It looks as if definite action might even yet be taken by Congress at this session with reference to providing such measure of civil government for the Philippines as the Executive may feel it safe to establish. The amendment to the Army Appropriation Dill proposed toy Senator SPOONER is in accord with the request of the President submitted at the close of the last month.

From Blacfcrwood's Magazine. A noticeable feature about the Boers is their extreme modesty and reticence with regard to their fighting experiences. It is the hardest thing in the world to "draw" a Boer into a description of his share in an action, but once "drawn," no map could show more faithfully than his memory the disposition of his own and the enemy's forces on the day in question.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- The Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott made some startling statements on the rights of the negro in the South during his eighth lecture on "A Study in the Problems of Democracy" to-night. He said he applauded the attempt in recent years to have the best elements, govern in the South.

We have already taken occasion to commend the spirit of the President's nominations to the Senate for promotion to the rank of general officer in the United States Army. They showed the desire of the President to apply the principle of promotion for merit at the very first stage at which it could be lawfully applied.

The new ribbons are in, and they are something to dream of. There are wide sash ribbons that are wonderfully attractive, with great, soft splashing of flowers upon them, one purple fleur de lis upon a white ground, and others of different combinations of flowers and combinations of colors. There are Empire wreaths of flowers surrounding some big, soft hydrangeas, perhaps, and combined with wavy bow knots.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed in your paper this morning a complaint from a gentleman about the coldness of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit cars.

In any comment upon the actors who took up new roles in the new plays of last week Blanche Bates must have the first place. Perhaps to those playgoers who had seen her in "The Great Ruby" and "The Musketeers," "Naughty Anthony" and "Mme. Butterfly," she revealed no new powers in her portrayal of the melodramatic heroine Paul Potter adapted so freely from Mile, de la Rame's Cigarette.

Our London correspondent's gloomy vaticinations seem to be more than commonly justified to-day. Lord ROBERTS'S report of the South African war has been published in London, with such excisions, it is there intimated, as caution dictated to the War Office. Excisions and all, it is a very discouraging document to be issued by the returning chief of a victorious army, which was the character given to Lord ROBERTS on his return.

From The World's Work. No one a stranger to the Boer country can conceive how it lends itself to guerrilla warfare. It tools a good part of our little American regular army and a fair number of Mexican troops two years, more or less, to finish off "the Kid's" band of Apaches, and during this time the chief crossed the Rio Grande a half-score of times.

"The very first statement is a lie," was the way Dr. Alonzo Blauvelt, Chief Inspector, Division of Contagious Diseases, characterized an interview regarding smallpox in this city which appeared in The Times-Democrat of New Orleans on Feb. 6.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I respectfully beg to call to the attention of THE TIMES a bill now pending before the Legislature, compelling the closing of butchers' shops in this city on Sunday. This is a meritorious measure, interfering with the rights of no one, and it is in the interest of butchers generally, employers and employes alike, several thousand of whom have signed a, petition advocating its passage.

BOSTON, Feb. 9 -- A letter received today from a member of Company H of the Signal Corps, doing service at Jaro, Iloilo, contains several interesting statements concerning the situation. The letter is dated Dec. 23. The writer says that there are two big leaders whom the American soldiers are after.

Two of the local bowling tournaments -- the National League and the North Side League -- were concluded last week, and the final scheduled games were rolled in the Harlem League tournament, the latter resulting in two ties, yet to be decided.

To the Editor of The New York Times: When will the men of New York learn to be men? It is an outrage and beyond all the laws of decency that a woman, as soon as she goes outside of her home, must be prepared to put up with the insults and abuses that men choose to approach her with.

Hugo Becker, the cello virtuoso, who recently made a successful appearance here with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, will give a concert at Mendelssohn Hall on Tuesday afternoon with the assistance of Katherine Ruth Heyman and Sara Anderson. Mr. Becker will be heard in the sonata in F major of Richard Strauss with Miss Heyman, in a suite by Valentini, and in minor pieces by Cesar Cui and Fitzenhagen.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thank you for the delightfully satirical editorial of even date -- " Certainly False, But Probably Funny " -- which reprimands Mark Twain for his recent censure in public speeches and magazine articles of the Administration and its policy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "An Anglican Catholic" has taken up the cudgles in defense of the "Catholic Church Catechism" as used by the Rev. J.M. Rich of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. In his letter to THE TIMES he insists that Mr. Rich is not "teaching [his people] anything Roman or new."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The report of the special Congressional committee which investigated the hazing of Cadet Booz and the general subject of hazing at West Point to-day was submitted to the House of Representatives by the Chairman of the committee. Representative Dick, together with a hill making stringent regulations against hazing, fighting, and all brutal practices.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with deep interest the article by "Jay" on the "Coal Combination" which appeared in your issue of Feb. 4.

From The Popular Science Monthly. An interesting result of the century has been the establishment of a general similarity between shooting stars and meteorites. This idea was first suggested by Chladni in 1798, but it has remained for Newton, Adams, and Schiaparelli to give it shape and proof.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 9 -- In reference to the controversy growing out of the soliciting of funds for a statue of Nathan Hale by a number of New York graduates of Yale, President Hadley to-day gave out the following statement:

A comedy of errors stirred the politicians and old inhabitants of the "Amen Corner" of the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday. One of McCullagh's deputies, wearing heavy goloshes, came noiselessly down the corridor, with a mysterious air which would have done credit to Old Sleuth himself.

MADRID, Feb. 9 -- The carriages of the Papal Nuncio and the Minister of the Interior were stoned to-day in Toledo Street, but no damage was done. Jesuit establishments at Valencia and Valladolid were the scenes of anti-Jesuit demonstrations. Stones and other missiles were thrown at the buildings.
Mr. Harold Bauer will give two pianoforte recitals in Mendelssohn Hall on the afternoon of Feb. 21 and 26, at 3 o'clock. The advance sale of seats will begin at Schuberth's on the 12th inst.

Patrolman Alonzo C. Hubbard, until last week an attache of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station, under command of Capt. Kear, has been transferred to the Oak Street Station. On Friday night of week before last Hubbard arrested J.P. Kennelly, the restaurant proprietor of Columbus Avenue, a personal friend of Police Commissioner Sexton.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is money, money all the time -- the common basis with reference to which almost every question, big and little, is discussed nowadays. "Money" and "business" furnish the main prop of what your correspondent, Archibald Barklie, has to say in THE TIMES of Sunday on the subject of "The Irish and Ireland."

A bill which aims to prohibit Brooklyn railroads from collecting fun rare from passengers unless seats are provided has been prepared by the "Women's Reform Club of Brooklyn for introduction in the Legislature at Albany. If the measure should become law, it is believed that it would revolutionize the methods of local traction companies.

I remember making an address in my own State, illustrated -- as I thought -- by a few apposite quotations. The audience listened attentively for more than two hours. I made substantially the same speech a few days later in a little country town in Maine, but I noticed that my hearers were restless and that a number of them left the hall.

If you have saved somebody's life and you want the United States Government to give you a medal, do not go to the United States Life Saving Bureau and tell the story of your heroism in person to Capt. Charles A. Abbey, the Inspector of Life Saving Stations, for if you do you will not be awarded the medal you seek.

Forty of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Alumni had dinner at the Arts Club, West Thirty-fourth Street, last night. President Pritchett of the institute was unable to be present on account of illness. Among those present were Henry M. Howe, the metallurgist of Columbia University; George A. Freeman, Henry D. Hibbard, Loring R. Miller, and Alexander Rice McKim.

Death has a call and the sexton a put on even the wariest broker. Addison Cammack, always a picturesque figure, was to me an interesting one. In face and manner decidedly aggressive, he suggested an ironclad, with a long protruding ram and no end of torpedoes and high explosives up his sleeve, so to speak.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The consideration of the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill in the House to-day developed something of a sensation when Representative Brown, (Rep., Ohio.) standing in the centre of the Republican side of the chamber, made a speech strongly condemning a colonial policy and urging that Congress should at once give assurance to the Filipinos that the purpose of the United States was to give them independence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is unusual for one of your editorial staff to make such a statement as that contained in your issue of this date on the royal marriage in Holland to the effect that "the reigning family of Great Britain draws one of its most illustrious strains" from the house of Nassau.

Transactions in the outside market yesterday were considerably smaller than they had been for several days, yet the total trading was much in excess of that usual on Saturday. In some parts of the list it was evident that prices were under pressure, and some declines were brought about, but the market as a whole showed strength, and the upward movement of the previous days was continued in a number of issues.

The Dock Builders' Protective Association reported yesterday that a strike of dock builders, involving between 400 and 500 men, has taken place on a number of piers in New York and Brooklyn. The piers involved are Pier 31 East River, New York Central docks, at West Sixty-fifth Street; pier at the foot of Grand Street, Brooklyn, and a pier at Fort Lee, N.J.

BERLIN, Feb 9 -- Anglo-German relations and their supposed modifications, owing to Emperor William's visit to England, form, just now, the all-engrossing topic here. Since his Majesty's return, all Germany has been engaged in the discussion.

A man, who said he is Charles F. Smith, was arrested by Detectives Armstrong and Donohue of the West Sixty-eighth Street Station yesterday at Broadway and Forty-second Street, on the charge of passing numerous worthless checks. The management of the Hotel Empire, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street, say they have been swindled by the man, and that Smith and his wife engaged an expensive suite in their place several weeks ago, and lived extravagantly.

During my twelve years' association with Sir Arthur Sullivan on the stage in his comic operas in conjunction with W.S. Gilbert -- the finest librettist of our time -- I found him most courteous even to the humble members of the company. He had reason frequently to complain, but his complaints were kindly expressed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Seven old frontiersmen, relics of the days when the Pacific Slope was a wild region populated chiefly by Indians and wild animals, visited the President to-day. One of them Vent to Oregon in 1844, when there were not over 300 white men in the entire region north of Missouri and west of the Missouri River.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 10 -- Three thousand male citizens of Topeka, in mass meeting here to-day, decided that the numerous "joints" of the city must close their places. They issued an ultimatum, giving the "jointists" until Friday next at 12 o'clock noon to quit business. If this shall not be done, warning was given that a thousand armed men would immediate move on the "joints" and remove them by force.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- A yacht to be faster than the Genesee, the Rochester, N.Y., boat, which won the international championship from Canada last year, is being designed in the East. The designer of the yacht is Charles G. Davis of Chicago, formerly of the Hanley Construction Company of Qumcy, Mass.
EAST LONDON, Cape Colony, Feb. 9 -- Details have been received here of severe fighting at Tabaksberg Mountain, forty miles east of the railway and about midway between Smalldeel and Bloemfontein.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- Three fires within a week, which are believed to have been incendiary, caused the Fire Commission to meet to-day and offer a reward of $500 for the arrest of the guilty person or persons.

Justice Wilmot M. Smith of the Supreme Court will sit in Special Term, in Long Island City, on Feb. 18, to hear the foreclosure suit instituted by the Long Island Loan and Trust Companay of Brooklyn, as trustee, against the Long Island City and Newtown Railway Company and others.

MADRID, Feb. 10 -- Late last evening, at the close of a meeting of the Students' Union on the occasion of a lecture dealing with the anti-clerical play "Electra," the students demonstrated and stoned the police. Four policemen, including two Lieutenants, and three students were badly injured.

Our remarks as to the practice of some of the teachers in the public schools of sending petitions, through their pupils, for signature in order to bring pressure on the Legislature to maintain the present system of salaries, has brought us many comments.

THE ENGLISH BOOK OF COMMON PRAYER . -- One of the many changes brought about by the Queen's death in British customs that have been practically unaltered during the last sixty-three years is the necessary reediting of the Book of Common Prayer at the Established Church. One of the first Orders of the King in Council, in accordance with the Act of Uniformity was to this effect.

Stone walls do not a prison make, perhaps, but as an obstacle to speedy marriage they are a little factor to be considered. There is no difficulty or difference between James H. Kerr, real estate agent, of US West Tweltth Street, and his fianceo Margaret Kavanaugh; in fact, Mr. Kerr was most active in her behalf in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, but just now there is a priaon wall between them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Representative Albert D. Shaw of Watertown, N.Y, formerly Commander in Chief of the Grand Army of the Republic, was found dead this morning in his room at the Riggs House. A physician, summoned immediately after the discovery of the body, pronounced death, due to apoplexy, probably about 2 o'clock in the morning.

MANILA, Feb. 10 -- The attendance at the second Evangelical meeting in the Tondo Ward of Manila to-day was somewhat larger than the one held a week ago. There were not many Catholics present, and Senor Buencamino said the priests had directed them not to attend.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Should Tammany take proper advantage of the opportunities now being offered by the new Police bill to overcome recent popular prejudices through the appointment of a Commissioner and Superintendent acceptable to the public, nothing can prevent the organization from making a clean sweep in the coming Mayoralty election.

R. Pfortner won the weekly cross-country run of the Pastime Athletic Club over the six-mile Jerome Avenue course yesterday afternoon, with Peter McCarthy second, E. Rathgeber third, and E. Estoppey fourth. There were twenty starters, but half of them were so chilled by the cold wind that they quit at three miles.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 -- Not for months past had the Berlin Boerse experienced such excellent conditions as obtained last week. The upward movement in domestic Government funds gained considerable momentum, particularly Saxon 3s, which rose during the week 110 pfennigs; Imperials, which rose 130; Prussians, which rose 120, and Treasury 4s, which rose 70 pfennigs.

Services in memory of Dwight L. Moody were held yesterday afternoon in the West Side Branch of the Young Men's Christian Association, Fifty-seventh Street, near Eighth Avenue. Gen. O.O. Howard presided. J. Campbell White, representative of the association in Calcutta, talked about the influence the world had felt from the work done by the evangelist at his home, in Northfield, incidentally describing some interesting conditions now existing in India.

MADRID, Feb. 10 -- The banquet given at the Palace last evening by the Queen Regent in honor of Prince Charles of Bourbon, who will wed the Princess of the Austurias, and of his parents, the Count and Countess of Caserta, was an extremely, brilliant affair. A band of halberdiers played during the function.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 10 -- The lecture of Mrs. Carrie Nation, the joint-smasher from Kansas, advertised to be given at the Auditorium on Tuesday night under the auspices of the Chicago Press Club, has been declared off. Believing from the result of two days seat sales which aggregated less than $12, that the lecture would be a financial failure, the directory of the club decided to abandon the project.

PEKING, Feb. 10 -- Coun von Waldersee is very much dissatisfied with the conduct of the French troops near Pao-Ting-Foo, and also with their avowed intention, in spite of his protests against it, to organize an expedition to take possession or ShanSi. He takes the ground that expeditions, except for police purposes, or against bands of robbers, should not be undertaken during peace negotiations.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 10 -- There was the liveliest kind of a time here to-night incidental to the celebration of a wedding. One man was stabbed, another had a couple of ribs broken, and a hundred or more had bruised eyes and faces when the police arrived and cleared the hall.

Specimens of American "big" game will be conspicuous among the exhibits at the coming Sportsmen's Show in Madison Square Garden. The moose, which was missing in last year's show, this season will be represented by two splendid individuals, a bull and a cow, and their presence, with the addition of a few other inhabitants of the forest and plains that formerly were missing, will make the exhibit of game a most complete one.

Police Inspector Walter L. Thompson, whose penchant for creating exciting diversions at public entertainments has brought him prominently before the public eye and also brought him considerable trouble, lived up to his new-found reputation at the fifth annual ball of the Siegel-Cooper Company Employes' Association at the Madison Square Garden Saturday night by charging the assembled throne with his baton drawn just before the party broke up.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 10 -- John White of Mount Pleasant Avenue, who fell from a trolley car as it was rounding a curve on Front Street on the night of Jan. 26, died to-day in the City Hospital from a fractured skull.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- On the whole, the business of the Stock Exchange last week was fairly extensive. Prices were firm, with substantial improvement in some cases. There appears to be a good amount of capital seeking investment in non-speculative securities. The monetary situation also continues to improve.

Referring to the plan and scope of the work being done by the Legislation Committee, the City Club, through Secretary J.W. Pryor, yesterday called attention to the promises of the present Legislature in the following statement:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a special to THE NEW YORK TIMES from Washington, dated Feb. 4. concerning "The Coming D.A.R. Congress," the statement is made that "the fundamental principles of the organization favor the elec- tion of a National woman for the position of President General and it will be ad- visable to have as President General a woman of as much National position as possible."

AUSTIN, Texas, Feb. 10 -- The official opinion rendered by Acting Attorney General Robert A. John, that the State owns all oils and minerals discovered on State lands that were sold between the years 1883 and 1889, has caused a big stir among the oil prospectors In the new Beaumont district.
LONDON, Feb. 11 -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener, the Commander in Chief in South Africa:

CHICAGO, Feb. 10 -- Of the ten railroad Presidents who attended the Illinois Cen- tral banquet Saturday night, only three remained in the city to-day. They were E. H. Harriman, the executive head of the great roads west of Chicago, in the Morgan combination; C.E. Perkins of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy, and B.L. Winchell of the Kansas City, Fort Scott and Gulf Road.

A meeting held for the purpose of engaging, interest in the popular education of both whites and negroes in the South, at which Booker T. Washington was the principal speaker, packed the Central Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-seventh Street, near Broadway, to the doors last night. The meeting was under the auspices of the Armstrong Association of this city, and President Daniel C. Gilman presided.

For thirty years or more the Children's Aid Society has bestowed more than an ordinary share of its attention to the education and moral training of the children of Italian immigrants who, in increasing numbers, within the period named, have been landed here. When first undertaken it was upon a very lim- ited scale.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 -- Two persons dead, five others badly injured, and a financial loss of $2,500 is the summary of damage caused by a fire that occurred in a four- story brick dwelling on Harrison Avenue early this morning.

Charles E. Hopper, a wealthy businessman of 77 Bidwell Avenue, Jersey City, last night turned detective and landed in the West Thirtieth Street Station House a Bowery beggar who had used abusive language when his importunities for money were refused.
The Hartford (Conn.) Times enumerates fifty-five kinds of wild birds that can be found during February within a radius of fifteen miles of Hartford.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- The market has beaten the Bank, which a week ago was confident of being able to control rates and maintain them at 5 per cent. In the middle of the week, however, discount had been driven down to 3 1/2 per cent., and there was talk of its sinking still further, so Thursday the Bank could do nothing but yield.
In response, to a sharp ring at his telephone bell yesterday afternoon, the Sergeant at the Tenderloin Police Station jumped up and heard, a woman say over the wire:

CINCINNATI, Feb. 10 -- Notwithstanding the proceedings in court here and the attitude of the Governor at the State Capital, this has been a busy day with the sporting men in Cincinnati. All outward signs look like the eve of a great coming event with them.

Until last night the good folks of Bronxdale had no idea that one of their neighbors owned a pet that could set the whole district wild with excitement. But they found it out when the little raccoon of "Patsy" Moran slid between the bars of his cage just before dusk and started on the rampage.

ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 10 -- His name cannot be found on the pay roll of the city Fire Department, but he is one of the hardest workers, and is always first at the fire. His name would look a little remarkable, to say the least, on a municipal pay roll, for he answers to the sobriquet of Lobster, but it is certainly a cognomen that ill befits him.

BOSTON, Feb. 10 -- Cassius Clay Powers, a well-known lawyer, died to-day at his residence in Brookline. He leaves a wife and daughter. Mr. Powers was born in Pittsfield, Me.; was graduated from Bowdoin College in 1869, and was admitted to the Kennebec County Bar in Maine in 1871, and to the Suffolk Bar in Boston in 1872.

-- As seen by the pious editor of The Chicago Interior, the condition of affairs in Cuba is neither promising nor pleasant. The independent Cubans, he says -- meaning thereby, doubtless, the Cubans who desire immediate independence --" would be fighting among themselves already, and devastating the island, if our troops were not in possession.

Wall Street will resume business today with its confidence in the market not one whit diminished -- firm in the belief that whatever temporary fluctuations may be, market values will work materially higher. This is the testimony of representative bankers and brokers, as shown by the opinions published in these columns yesterday.

SANTIAGO DE CUBA, Feb. 10 -- The United States transport Rawlins went hard aground this morning on a coral reef near the wreck of the United States collier Merrimac. She arrived at daybreak, anchored in the bay, and then started to return to Nispero Cove, near the mouth of the harbor, where is situated the Morro Castle wharf, intending to embark the troops of the Tenth United States Infantry for New York to-day.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 10 -- Several of the Baltimore City Directors in the Western, Maryland Railroad are of the opinion that Edward Lauterbach of New York, repre senting a syndicate of New York and Philadelphia capitalists, will have to increase his bid for the city holdings in the stock of the road, as his offer of $5,500,000 is not enough.

Lovers of fine billiards have enjoyed more than one night's treat in the games last week for the Class A championship at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. Five games have been played, one-half the tournament number, with the exception of the final match in which Wilson P. Foss. the present Class A champion, will defend his title, and two of those games have had unusually close finishes.

According to the charges made by Detective Dean of the Oak Street Police Station and Agent King of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, Wells Marshall, a young man who was arraigned in the Centre Street Police Court yesterday morning on a charge of cruelty to children, has been running a school at 13 Oliver Street where during the past month boys have been scientifically taught the art of begging.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Feb. 10 -- One of the most dastardly robberies ever perpetrated in this part of the country was committed near McKay, a hamlet in Ashland County, about midnight Saturday night.

Prof. Morris Moore of the University of Rome has written an account of an audience which he had with the late Queen only a few months ago. The Royal Raphael Academy of Urbino elected her an honorary member of the society, and Prof. Morris Moore, the President of the academy, was deputed to convey the artistic gifts unanimously voted by that assembly to her Majesty.

If the prosperous dwellers on Central Park West had looked out of their windows early yesterday morning they would have seen a long line of private coachmen driving toward the Park, into whose western entrance they streamed. Coachmen may be seen there any day, but as a usual thing their rigs are far more conventional than those they drove yesterday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 10 -- Prompt and active work by the authorities at Manila, Iowa, to-day resulted in the arrest of three men who are supposed to have been implicated in the theft of a United States Express Company safe which contained about $40,000.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

Croton water in selling for 10 cents a pail in High Bridge, where the water supply, which has been going from bad to worse for the past month, failed entirely yesterday. The whole population are depending upon two old wells and what little water can be drawn from a hydrant at One Hundred and Sixty-fifth Street and Jerome Avenue, which is half a dozen blocks from the centre of population in the village.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Senate has confirmed the following nominations: To be Lieutenant General -- Major Gen. Nelson A. Miles.

Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy's chances of ultimate acquittal of the charge of murdering Dolly Reynolds in the Grand Hotel two years ago were, in the opinion of the exAssistant District Attorneys prosecuting him, materially diminished yesterday when the announcement was made to Justice Fursman by Lawyer Moore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Teller resolution, or tailpiece to the resolutions adopted by Congress April 18, 1898, directing the President to employ the land and naval forces of the United States for the expulsion of Spain from Cuba, reads as follows:

The Democrats in the Senate cannot readily give up the notion that there is a Constitutional difficulty in the way of administering the new territory acquired by the United States through the treaty with Spain. We venture to commend to their careful attention the views of ALBERT GALLATIN, Secretary of the Treasury under Mr. JEFFERSON, whose arguments finally prevailed with the President.
OTTAWA, Feb. 11 -- Sir Wilfrid Laurier, speaking in the House of Commons to-day in reply to R.L. Borden, leader of the Opposition, said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read this morning the editorial in THE TIMES about the accident on the Erie Road, commenting on the supposed fact that the mail car in advance of the combination car was a steel car, which telescoped the combination car behind it on account of the weight and superior resisting power of the steel mail car next the locomotive.

The thirty-first annual report of the Board of Trustees of the German Hospital and Dispensary of this city, which has just been made public, describes in detail the work that has been done during the year 1900 toward the erection of an annex to the hospital, at Seventy-seventh Street and Seventh Avenue.

BELGRADE, Servia, Feb. 11 -- King Alexander, who was at Nish when he received the news of the death of his father, immediately summoned the members of the Cabinet to meet at Konak, where he communicated the information to them officially.

In the Parkway Gun Club's trap shooting tournament yesterday at Dexter Park, Brooklyn, twenty-one contestants lined tip for the main event, the club shoot. Dr. A.A. Casey, Frederick Lebohner, and Dr. L.H. O'Connell tied for first place, missing one bird each. The scores:

On account of the interest shown in the exhibition of the collection of etchings and engravings by and after the work of Meissonier, at the galleries of William Schaus, 204 Fifth Avenue, and because of the requests of those who have been unable to give the collection the study they desire, it has been decided to extend the time of exhibition anothr week.

Louis H. Schortemeier led in the Hudson Gun Club trap shooting tournament, held at Harrison, N.J., yesterday. Competing in the eleven events, he won four with straight scores, and was in ties in three others. The summaries:
In the New York Inter Club Bowling League tournament, on the Knickerbocker Athletic Club alleys, last night, the home team won three games from the Harlem Wheeelman five. The scores:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to thank you for your very fair and impartial editorial on the shocking accusation and cowardly assault on a priest of the Episcopal Church in Arlington. As an Episcopalian and a member of a family of Churchmen, I am grateful that the Rev. Mr. Kellar is given the benefit of the doubt.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- There was an important conference this afternoon in the Governor's office on the tax bills. Those called in for consultation by the Governor were Speaker Nixon, Senator Krum, Chairman of the Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment, and Assemblyman Lewis, Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Secretary Hay to-day received Messrs. Nicoll and Lindsay of New York, counsel for the New York and Bermudez Company, and they argued for Governmental action in behalf of the company in Venezuela. These gentlemen have been in Washington for three days, and were expected to obtain an elaborate hearing before the State Department, at which they were to make an exhaustive exposition of the Asphalt Trust's cause.

The Secretary of the Treasury loses no proper opportunity to try to educate public opinion as to the defects of our system of bank currency and the disadvantage they impose on our commerce at home and abroad.

For the first time since the death of his father, the young King of Italy has now the opportunity to give official expression to his ideas as to how he intends to govern his country under the Constitution. The selection of the successor to Signor SARACCO cannot fail to indicate to a very large degree the attitude of the Throne on a number of important questions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is with pleasure I read this day that England is about to send out thirty thousand more mounted troops to South Africa. This will, it is to be hoped, once and for all, silence the nonsense about the King stopping the war, for, in the first place, he would not if he could, and, in the second, he dare not if he would.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- The Assembly Com- mittee on Public Health has decided to shut out the rank and file of Christian Scientists at the next hearing upon the bill to prohibit them from treating disease. The hearing will take place Wednesday, and will be the last given on the bill. It will be held in the committee's room instead of the Assembly Hall, which was used for the two former hearings.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Assuming that the evils of Crokerism have a substantial basis in fact, but two alternatives present themselves. Either the majority of New Yorkers are unintelligent, or else they are blindly and willfully neglectful of their duty. We know that the people of this city are intelligent, because they themselves say that they are, and the whole press of New York has time and again proclaimed the fact.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me once more to make use of the columns of your valuable paper, that I may reply to a communication from " Ed. R.," entitled "Mr. Rich and His Catechism." " Ed. R." states: "It is not new, though it was Roman, to hold the doctrine of extra ecclesiam nulla salus."

Commissioner of Highways James P. Keating yesterday commenced the work of removing the pipes of the Woodside Water Company under Jackson Avenue, Long Isl- and City. His men worked hard for several hours, but failed to get even one length out, as when the first length, at the corner of Davis Street, was broken open it was found filled with water at a great pressure.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11 -- E.P. Ripley, President of the Santa Fe, said to-day: "I have heard,that there have been many reports of late in Wall Street to the effect that there will be another move toward the consolidation of Western roads which will include the absorption of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe by another road.

HARTFORD CITY, Ind., Feb. 11 -- All oil well that surpasses the famous gusher drilled recently at Beaumont, Texas, was struck in the Blackford County oil field this forenoon. The unexpected and tremendous output is not yet under control, and five acres of land surrounding the marvelous producer are inundated with the crude oil.

Letter in Princeton Alumni Weekly. I saw in a recent issue of a newspaper an article headed "J. D. Archbold gives $400,000 to Syracuse University," and a train of thought was thus started which impels me to appeal through your columns to the alumni of Princeton on the subject of endowment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Committee on Claims of the Senate is not working overtime, but it is making a large record in its reports. A short time ago THE NEW YORK TIMES published a list of the claim bills the committee then had reported, the amount proposed to be taken out of the Treasury to satisfy its reports being about $14,000,000.

The annual banquet of the Silk Association of America was held at Delmonico's last evening. The guests cheered and cheered again every name which was mentioned in the speeches, and broke out into song upon the slightest provocation. All this, too, as was admitted by Mr. Catholina Lambert, Vice President of the association, after a year's bad business.

Rates through the Washington Gateway to the Pacific Coast from New England and Eastern points Will not be changed so as to conform with those charged through Albany and other Northern gateways. This decision was reached yesterday at a meeting of representatives of all the passenger associations in the country, which was held in the rooms of the Trunk Line Association, at 143 Liberty Street.

LINCOLN, Feb. 11 -- To-morrow night, it is believed, will mark the beginning of the end of the Nebraska Senatorial dead-lock. Seventy legislators, three more than necessary to elect, and lacking but two of the entire Republican membership, have signed a call to go into caucus to-morrow night and abide the result.

The Racing Committee of the New York Yacht Club met last night to consider the contents of a letter received Saturday from Hugh C. Kelly, Secretary of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, in connection with the challenge for the international yacht races.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The close of the late century has been so industriously utilized as a point of selfgratulation by the "patriotic" and the "progressive," it may not be amiss to inquire what in the way of timely monition has failed of emphasis by the far-sighted and the conservative.

The local health authorities were considerably wrought up yesterday morning when it came to their knowledge that the authorities of Mount Vernon had during the night deliberately dumped a malignant case of smallpox into the city hospital for contagious diseases on North Brother Island without asking the authority of the local Board of Health.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- After the Senate to-day had passed the Naval Appropriation bill, Mr. Hanna (Rep., Ohio) moved to take up the Ship Subsidy bill. Mr. Jones (Dem., Ark.) demanded the yeas and nays. The motion prevailed by a vote of 33 to 14. Mr. Caffery (Dem., La.) addressed the Senate in opposition to the measure.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 11 -- George M. Valentine, who is serving a term in State prison for having defrauded the Middlesex County Bank, was brought from prison, at Trenton, to-day, to appear as a witness In the suit of Edward S. Campbell, receiver for the bank, against the Manufacturers' National Bank of Newark, tried in the Circuit Court, before Judge Swayze and a jury.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- In the Assembly tonight Mr. Kelsey called up his New York City Bureau of Election bill, for the purpose he said, of substituting the Elsberg bill for his. To this Mr. McKeown of Kings objected, saying that it would give the introducer quite an advantage. Thereupon Mr. Kelsey gave notice that he would call up his bill for amendment and substitution to-morrow morning.

To the Editor of The New York Times: By all means, as two of your correspondents suggest, urge this country to intervene in the South African struggle. Commercialism would derive still further credit by adding, in the furtherance of our commercial interests, to the already existing difficulties and the great bloodshed thereof.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with interest your editorial in to-day's issue entitled "Our Missionaries in China." In it you give the opinion of Lord Salisbury to the effect that missionaries in the foreign field were "an international nuisance"; also that the cause of the recent trouble in China was largely due to missionaries interfering in matters with which they had legitimately nothing to do.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The Speaker and Mrs. Henderson were the guests of honor at a dinner party this evening, their hosts being Representative and Mrs. Thropp of Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The President to-day sent to the Senate the nominations of James H. Wilson of Delaware and Fitzhugh Lee of Virginia, now Brigadier Generals of Volunteers, to be Brigadier Genorals in the regular army.

WINSTED, Conn., Feb. 11 -- Miss Winifred Cook, aged twenty-one, a teacher in the W.L. Gilbert Home for Children, was shot and instantly killed in the Home this morning by her former accepted suitor, John T. Hayes, formerly Lieutenant of Company I, Fourth Regiment, Connecticut National Guard.

QUEMADOS, Cuba, Feb. 7 -- The grounding of the army transport McPherson near Matanzas early last Monday morning (Feb. 4) furnished an exciting experience to some of the military folk aboard of her. About 6 o'clock, in a dense fog, she struck on some jagged lava rocks known thereabout as the Diente-perro, or Dog's Tooth.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 -- A dispatch from Dover, Del., says: "This will be a critical week in the Senatorial fight. It is expected that the National Administration will formally urge the Republican legislators, probably by request from the National Committee, to elect two Republican Senators without specifying who they shall be.

The water famine in the Bronx was partly relieved Sunday night, and it is promised by Commissioner Dalton that by tomorrow night the entire borough will once more be habitable. The section which was relieved Sunday night was that on the heights on Jerome and Ogden Avenues. The relief came without warning when, about 8 o'clock Sunday night, all the water pipes in the houses in that locality began to sing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So much has been said protesting against the imposition of a tax on the surplus of savings banks that I wish to lay before your readers the following facts showing why, in my opinion, the tax is a just one.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest your editorial entitled "Lord Roberts's Report," and also, not unmixed with amusement, your London correspondent's remarks anent South African affairs in general. Your correspondent seems to revel in pessimism. With your knowledge of public opinion in England today, I cannot understand such an editorial being written in sincerity.

The "hearing" on the single-headed Police Department bill was held in Mayor Van Wyck's office yesterday at 11 o'clock. The public took no interest in the hearing, and there was not a person present who was willing to speak for or against the bill.

District Attorney Philbin will to-day and to-morrow make a final examination, with Assistant District Attorney Schurman, of the evidence submitted to the former by the Tammany Committee of Five, after which he will definitely decide whether the mass of matter sent him will go before the Grand Jury or into the waste basket.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- The marriage of Miss Mary Condit-Smith and Richard Stewart Hooker, United States Marine Corps, took place to-day at noon at the Church of the Epiphany, in the presence of a congregation which filled that spacious edifice to the doors. The bride's gown was of white liberty satin with yoke and sleeves of Renaissance lace.

Trading in curb securities yesterday was of fairly large proportions, with considerable breadth, although the dealings were not evenly distributed. The movements of prices showed general moderate advances, which in the main were well held.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The most delicate question now of vital interest in this hemisphere is, What relation should exist between the United States and Cuba? Let me proffer some observations on the subject, first expressing the opinion that the initiative should come from Cuba, and that the United States should be reluctant to use any pressure upon Cuban action until the fullest opportunity for deliberate consideration has been enjoyed.

Charles Threshie, the Boston Athletic Association billiard champion and winner of the Class B championship in 1899, beat John A. Hedrick of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club last night in the sixth game of the Class A championship series. He made the required 400 points, at fourteen-inch balk line, in fifty-nine innings, to 277 for Hendrick, in fifty-eight innings.
The contestants of the will of Helen C. Brush expect to finish their testimony tomorrow. It is understood that Mrs. Stetson, the First Reader of the Church, will then take the stand.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Just how much confidence is to be inspired in the capacity of the Cubans to assume all the privileges and responsibilities of free government evidently remains to be ascertained by something more than an inspection of the Constitution, about which so much has been said here, and which, according to well-informed Americans in Havana, seems to be taken more seriously here than it does in Cuba.

The stock market yesterday suffered from pressure from various sources. In the first place London was a seller of stocks on fairly liberal scale, while there was a disposition on the part of many speculators and room traders to "even up" over the holiday -- a disposition that induced to not a little selling.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I have received a great many letters of inquiry since my last communication to your paper, I send you a short supplemental article, answering the questions most generally asked.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- After a stormy debate over the question of the right of the Senate to substitute for the bill sent to it a new War Revenue Reduction act, the House decided to-day, by a vote of 233 to 3S, to ask for a conference on the measure. The Speaker named Messrs. Payne, Dalzell, and Richardson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Orders were prepared at the War Department to-day for the organization, assembling, and equipment of the ten additional regiments authorized by the army reorganization law. According to these orders, the new cavalry and infantry regiments will be designated and located as follows:

Almost all of the recently arrived London papers devote large amounts of their more or less valuable space to comments upon the acts of one R.K. TURNBULL, whom they all call an "American journalist," and over whose shoulder they all aim many a hard blow at "American journalism."
The purchase of a Christmas tree on Dec. 24 last led to the arraignment of the purchaser before Police Justice Hoos, in Jersey City, yesterday, on a charge of bigamy.

The principal event of last evening was the dinner dance given by Mrs. Frederick Gallatin for her daughter, Miss May Gallatin. As this had a number of dinners before it, the debutantes, who form a great part of the social world just now, were nearly all guests at one or another of the entertainments, and met later at Mrs. Gallatin's.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some one has said that progress is built on mistakes. Permit an old reader of THE TIMES to prophesy that you will see a confirmation of this, as also a repetition of history, in the operation and possible extension of the pneumatic tube distribution of mails in New York and elsewhere, which the newspapers appear to be encouraging and Congress considering.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 -- Personalities, threats, and loud talk were frequent in the House to-day after it had resolved itself into Committee of the Whole to consider the Diplomatic and Consular Appropriation bill.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 11 -- It was pretty generally rumored to-day in the Carnegie Building that if the amalgamation was effected, some of the offices will be moved to New York. In case this is true, the executive, general banking, costs, statistics, and other similar departments will be taken to the metropolis, leaving here only the operating and a portion of the order department.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 -- Assemblyman Rodenbeek, Republican, introcduced a bill to-night designed to reach further than any of the tax bills so far introduced. Mr. Rodenbeck, in describing his bill, attacks Gov. Odell's proposed tax bills. He says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thanks are due to "S.S.R." for his timely appeal to the wealthy of New York to advance to the city the $80,000 neces- sary to relieve us during this temporary water famine. Like him, I am an old resident of Franklin Avenue, near One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Street, Bronx Borough.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Previous to the publication of The Associated Press dispatch regarding the reply to be sent by Great Britain to the United States relative to the amended Hay-Pauncefote treaty, the United States Embassy in London was as uninformed as the public concerning the nature of that reply.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your Washington co-respondent is in error in stating that Gen. Chaffee is the only officer promoted to general rank who entered the regular army as a private. I have not the data at hand to speak as to prior cases, but the present list contains one other such case.
VIENNA, Feb. 11 -- Ex-King Milan of Servia died at 4 o'clock this afternoon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That is a very interesting and unique paragraph in to-day's TIMES anent the Thibetan mission to St. Petersburg. The Birschevija Viedomosti is, I believe, a semi-official organ, and, as you say, it may voice Russia's real position as to the Thibetan-Russian entente, which means the swallowing up of Thibet.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 11 -- Seaboard Air Line stocks and bonds were excited here to-day. In explanation of the heavy dealings leading members of the Stock Exchange say they had received positive information from New York that interests identified with the First National Bank of that city had acquired enormous blocks of the issues, and that they are still buying.

Harvard's splendid hockey team broke up Tale's team work, smashed her defense, smothered her attack, and finally won from Eli's intercollegiate champion seven by a score of 4 to 0, in the most noteworthy collegiate hockey match of the season, played in the St. Nicholas Rink last even- ing.

MADRID, Feb. 12 -- Yesterday, a day awaited with some anxiety in official circles, passed off more quietly than several days of late. Just after nightfall an idle crowd, chiefly composed of street gamins, gathered on the Puerta del Sol, but when shouts arose the Civil Guards charged and cleared the space, after which there was no disturbance.

Apparently England is threatened with another form of "Americanizing." Her conservative papers charge to our example the political tactics and the rude diplomacy of Mr. CHAMBERLAIN. Most of the changes in her journals are sadly traced to the influence of ours. Her aristocracy is being enriched and diluted at once by American marriages.

Dr. L.L. Mial, the Knickerbocker Athletic Club billiardist, who was beaten in Saturday night's sensational game in the Class A billiard championship by one point, won his match last night over J.B. C. McKee of Philadelphia by 400 points to 327. The game, as are all in the series, was at fourteen-inch balk line, and the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club was comfortably filled with enthusiasts.

Skaters and curlers held possession of Van Cortlandt Lake all day yesterday, and notwithstanding a biting northwest wind that blew wildly over the lake in the afternoon, neither the crowd nor the fun diminished materially until darkness sent the army of young men and women homeward bound.

Simons -- McNamee. The wedding of Charles Dewar Simons, Jr., and Miss Jessie Vanderbilt McNamee, daughter of Mrs, James McNamee, and granddaughter of the late Jacob Vanderbilt, was celebrated at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon in St. James's Church, at Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.
ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- "I did not suggest these tax measures after a couple of weeks' consideration, or even a month. I have been studying the matter for four years, and I know what I am talking about."

To The Editor of The New York Times: The solid objections are: The proposed "surplus" tax law would most probably be declared unconstitutional and void as impairing the obligations of existing contracts. It is "double taxation," and contravenes legislative precedents. The companies now pay taxes on premiums collected in almost every State and country in which they operate.

MADRID, Feb. 12 -- Whispered rumors, which are not supported by tangible facts, say that Madrid is on the verge of a tu- mulr. The Government is calmly proceeding to carry out the details for the wed- ding of the Princess of the Asturias to Prince Charles of Bourbon, but the street corners, the clubs, and the hotel corridors teem with menacing stories.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 12 -- The ninetysecond anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln was celebrated here tonight by the Jefferson, Jackson, and Lincoln League with a "dollar dinner" at the Columbus Auditorium. There were fully 1,500 people seated at tables, which occupied the floor of the immense hall, and 1,000 were seated in the galleries, which had been thrown open to spectators.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Fifteen well-known trap shooters representing New Utrecht, Carteret, and Chatham Gun Clubs, took part in the sport at the Country Club traps to-day. There was a strong gale from the west, and a lively lot of birds formed the habit of sailing down the wind with an erratic speed, which bothered the shooters at times.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- The Secretary of the Treasury has imposed a countervailing duty of 64 copecks, or about 32 cents per pood, (a little over 36 pounds,) on ail refined sugars imported into the United States from Russia. In his order addressed to O.L. Spalding, Assistant Secretary in charge of customs, Mr. Gage says that he has taken this course in order to get a mooted question before the courts.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 12 -- The preparation for the contest between Jeffries and Ruhlin and between Martin and Childs have proceeded here to-day the same as usual, and the promoters expect the events to take place on time next Friday night. Over $1,000 was taken in for tickets to-day, making an aggregate of over $45,000 to date.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Between the wrecking of yachts and upsets, the North Shrewsbury River ice yachtsmen had a lively time of it to-day. The wind blew with great force from the northwest, threatening to tear the boats to pieces, and it succeeded in breaking three of them. The yachts that succumbed to the onslaughts of the strong gale were Capt. George Coley's Rocket, Daniel Asay's Zero, and Edward Asay's Daisy.

BOSTON, Feb. 12 -- The celebration of Lincoln Day at the State House was made notable by the joint Assembling of both houses and an eloquent address by Senator Hoar, who was recently re-elected from the Massachusetts Legislature for the fifth time. In the course of his address Senator Hoar said:
Pratt's Institute basket ball team overwhelmed the Yale freshman team in the former's gymnasium, in Brooklyn, last night. The score was 31 to 8.

The ninety-second anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln was celebrated last night by the Republican Club of the City of New York by a banquet which was attended by over 450 guests, who assembled in the great ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Four skating races on Verona Lake, near Montclair, N.J., yesterday, drew a large number of skaters who enjoy witnessing a good speed test on ice, but the excellent weather also brought out a still larger number who went for the enjoyment of skating itself. Harry McDonald, who has been the star competitor in the two previous Verona Lake contests, was not among the racers yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The third and last Bachelors' cotillion of the present season took place last evening, when Washington society was seen at its best at the National Rifles Armory. The stage was banked in palms and a profusion of giant pink carnations and La France roses. The roses were later used as favors.

LONDON, Feb. 12. -- The settlement requirements increased the demand for money, and there was a restricted supply. Discounts were firm. There was little business doing. The joint stock banks were not working freely, beyond the general carry-over.

KINGSLAND, N.J., Feb. 12 -- James Gorman was killed and many hundred dollars' damage to buildings done to-day by the explosion of a quantity of dynamite. The explosion was the result of German's attempt to thaw out several sticks of the explosive. Gorman's body was torn in half by the explosion, and so Sadly mangled that it would have been unrecognizable had it not been known who he was.

Americans in the London market yeserday were generally firm, with excepional strength showing in Atchison, which, London hears, is to be materially benefited by some pending developments. New York brokers themselves did little buying on the London Exchange, and the strength of the international stocks was or that reason considered all the more gratifying.

With the exception of the Star Athletic Club there were cross country runs held in all sections or the metropolitan district yesterday, and some smartly contested events marked the day's pastime over the heavy trails. The thaw which set in on Monday continued, and where the ground was not covered with snow, the trails, especially those in the open, were heavy, with deep, thick mud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The House today voted to expunge from The Record the anonymous letter reflecting upon Perry S. Heath, which was read at the instigation of Mr. Sulzer, (Dem., N.Y.,) during the exciting session of yesterday. The letter appeared in The Record this morning. Mr. Knox, (Rep., Mass.,) called up the alleged infringement of the privileges of the House.

A good many of our readers know that the uneasiness of the British manufacturing interests in respect to American competition has attracted the notice of The London Times, and that it has endeavored to enlighten the British public by a series of able and elaborate articles upon "American Engineering Competition."

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 12 -- Prompt work by policemen saved lives at a small fire last night. Policeman Stucky saw smoke coming through the transom of Adam Wocisgky's grocery store at 497 Market Street and found a blaze in the rear of the store. Stucky rapped for assistance, and sent in an alarm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The House today passed the Army Appropriation bill. Mr. Hull, (Rep., Iowa,) Chairman of the Military Affairs Committee, made a brief explanation.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 12 -- Nearly the entire plant of the Rochester Tumbler Works of the National Glass Company, the largest and finest in the world, located at Rochester, Penn., was destroyed by fire that started about midnight. The loss will amount to about $500,000, and is believed to be covered by insurance.

It is the testimony of a number of observers at Washington from all parts of the country and of both parties that the personal views of many of the Republican Senators are opposed to the Ship Subsidy bill, though most of these will vote for the bill if a vote is reached.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- With only one dissenting voice," says the Copenhagen correspondent of The Daily Mail, "the Financial Committee of the Landsthing has approved the sale of the Danish West Indies to the United States."

The unexpected happened to Charles T. Smith, who has been living by his wits, when he entered the West Side Police Court yesterday. The two women whom he had married, and whom he hoped by his cleverness to keep apart, had come together and had him held for bigamy. This, too, when he was in the clutches of the law and not able to wriggle out of the scrape conveniently.

That respect which the Western Powers have been engaged so earnestly in wooing from China by means of "punitive expeditions," pending negotiations and even after negotiations have begun, they are still engaged in conciliating by like methods.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The committee of prominent members of the Presbyterian Church appointed to consider the question of a revision of the creed, for report to the next General Assembly, to be held in May. resumed its sessions here to-nignt after an adjournment of some weeks. All the members were in attendance except ex-President Harrison and Judge Daniel R. Noyes.

Shortly before 9 o'clock last night, two men supporting a third walked into the West Thirtieth Street Station House. Sergt. Townsend was in charge, and in the room were several policemen, detectives, and reporters. The men who had entered were colored. The latter described themselves as Charles Hawell, twenty-one years old, and James Miller, twenty-three years old, both of 495 Seventh Avenue, and Charles Lawrence, twenty-one years old, of 152 West Twenty-seventh Street.

SAN FERNANDO, Luzon, Philippine Islands, Feb. 12 -- Bacolor and all the towns adjacent to the railroad, whose names are historic on account of the fierce battles of the earlier periods of the American occupation, turned out to welcome the United States Philippine Commission as it proceeded northward on its first trip to organize provincial Governments.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- During practically the entire session of the Senate to-day the Agricultural Appropriation bill was under consideration. After six hours of consideration, the bill was little more than half completed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The Senate today passed a bill appointing a commission, consisting of the President of the Society of the Army of the Tennessee, the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Library, and the Secretary of War, to select a site in the City of Washington and have designs prepared for a memorial or statue of Gen. U. S. Grant, the cost of which shall not exceed $250,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- Justice Gaynor's change of mind on the bill to repeal the special jury law was the cause of much embarrassment to Senator McCarren to-day when the bill was under consideration in the Senate. On Feb. 4 Justice Gaynor wrote a letter to Chairman Stranahan, of the Senate Cities Committee, in which he urged the defeat of the bill.

Clasping her baby in her arms, and shrieking for help, a woman stood at the third-story window of a frame tenement at 159 Myrtle Avenue, between Gold and Prince Streets. Brooklyn, early yesterday morning, while a sheet of flame from the lower stories was threatening her every moment.
