The New York Athletic Club will hold its annual pool and billiard championship tournament, beginning Feb. 25. The pool competition, at 125 balls, will be played first, and the billiard event will follow, 200 points, fourteen-inch balk line.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 12 -- Henry Buermeyer, President of the National Amateur Skating Association of America; "Sam" J. Montgomery, Secretary of the same organization, and George D. Phillips, the well-known figure skater, have been appointed officials for the combined championships of Canada and the United States, which take place on Saturday on the Montreal Amateur Athletic Association's track.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- President Castro has claimed the right to override the decisions of the Venezuelan courts. This is the explanation now given of the Asphalt Trust's refusal to submit the matters in dispute with the Warner-Quinlan people to litigation, and this is why they are still making desperate efforts to get the Administration to take more stringent measures than mere diplomatic warnings against Venezuela.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 12 -- War was declared here to-day by the owners of six tracks against the new Western Jockey Club. The six racing associations which were not allotted dates when the new jockey club was recently organized, held a meeting here to-day and reorganized the old American Turf Congress, perfecting their plans for the circuit during the coming season and allotting the dates.
MADRID, Feb. 12 -- Don Ramon de Campoamor, the poet, philosopher, and statesman, is dead.

HONESDALE, Penn., Feb. 12 -- Mrs. William Henderson and Miss Minna Pistor, both of Hoboken, N.J., came here to-day and identified Otto Schumann, the Seeleyville (Penn.) hermit found frozen to death recently. Schumann was the son of wealthy German parents, and had an income of from $2,000 to $3,000 annually.

Charles J. Ross, an actor in burlesque, who has a large personal following in "first night" music hall auidences, appears as Cardinal Richelieu in the travesty of "The Three Musketeers" at the Victoria. Of the quality of the verbal humor in that piece, by the way, a fair example is found in the interchange of badinage between two of the musketeers.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Daniel E. Melville, the Staten Island plumber, who is wanted to testify in the Kennedy murder trial, arrived in Jacksonville to-day on the Clyde Line steamship. He positively denies that he left New York with tickets purchased by the police to prevent his testimony.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- King Edward has sanctioned the, official programme of the ceremonial to be observed in the House of Lords at the opening of Parliament to-morrow. The great officers of State and others will assemble at the entrance of the House of Lords. The King will alight from the State carriage, and the procession will move to the Robing Room in the following order:

-- A long and careful investigation made by a committee appointed by the San Francisco alumni of Leland Stanford Junior University into the circumstances attending the departure of Dr. Ross from that institution has convinced its members, according to a report they have just made, that, though it was a case of practical dismissal, and not of voluntary resignation, no infringement on the right of free speech was involved.

The large room of the galleries of the American Art Association has seldom been more crowded than was the case yesterday afternoon, when the dispersal by auction of the ancient textiles belonging to Vitall Benguiat was begun. So great was the interest in the sale that at one time there was not even standing room for all those desiring to be present.

James P. Keating, Commissioner of Highways, in pursuance of his vow to tear up the two and a half miles of the Woodside Water Company's main under Jackson Avenue, Long island City, at all cost, was on the ground early yesterday morning, with Deputy Commissioner W.N. Shannon, and remained until dusk.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- The hearing upon the bill to abolish the State Board of Charities was held to-day in the Senate Chamber before the joint committee composed of the Senate Committee on Judiciary and the Assembly Committee on Ways and Means. There was a large delegation of charitable workers from all over the State, and a number of addresses were made in opposition to the proposed change.

Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid gave last evening at their residence, Madison Avenue and Fiftieth Street, a large musicale which was one of the most notable entertainments of the season. The artists who sang included Mme. Melba, Miss Bridewell, and Signor Scotti. The entire house was thrown open.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The Weekes Anti-Policy bill was given a hearing this afternoon before the Assembly Committee on Codes. Anthony Comstock, agent for the Society for the Prevention of Crime, while appearing in favor of the bill, thought there were a great many defects in it, and submitted to the committee a substitute bill which, he claimed, would meet all emergencies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A corps of engineers has for some months been surveying the Valley of the Ten-Mile River, with the view of acquiring its waters for the City of New York. This great city will in the future need more water, and, in view of its probable growth, it is imperative that the supply should be permanent.

ALBANY Feb. 13 -- From the beginning to the end of the hearing before the Senate Committee on Judiciary to-day upon the Ramapo Repeal bill, a very tense feeling prevailed. There were statements made which were sensational, and there were word passages which were sharp and angry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Administration is undoubtedly hoping that the advice it gave to the Cubans, a week or more ago, when authorized announcement was made of the dissatisfaction of the President with the Cuban Constitution so far as completed, will accomplish good results and assist the Administration in helping the Cubans toward that free government promised to them.

The followers of Christian Science thought they had scored a point yesterday at the Brush will contest before Surrogate Fitzgerald when they succeeded in setting a witness for the contestants to admit that a rubber plant which had been in a state of decline suddenly began to take on new life.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Assemblyman Fish is sorry that he introduced Assembly Bill No. 395, which amends the stock corporation law relative to the sale of corporate franchises and property because it is being generally charged that the bill is for the purpose of continuing the Ramapo Water Company in power, even though its charter should be repealed.

In the first of his letters to Senator Stranahan, dated Feb. 4, Justice Gaynor said: "I have always been opposed to the so-called jury law, and asked for its repeal, and have been in favor of making the general jury panel down here as good as the so-called special jury panel, on what I have deemed the correct theory, that every one is entitled to as good a jury as any one else."

News of the drowning of the two sons of Alexander C. Humphreys was received here yesterday. They were on the Nile, near Cairo, with their father, who is the well-known chemist and head of the firm of Humphreys Glasgow, which has offices here and in London and Liverpool. Cromby, the younger son, who was only six years old, fell into the river, and his brother Harold, aged twenty-four plunged to the rescue.

The indoor speed skating championships of America, under the auspices of the National Amateur Skating Association and the Amateur Skating Association of Canada, were held at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The feature of the contests was the final heat of the 220-yard dash. Belden of the New York Athletic Club, Wray of the West Farms Athletic Club, and McDonald of Hiffley School had qualified.

BOSTON, Feb. 13 -- Boston's market opened well, but there was no repetition of Monday's excitement. In the copper stocks first prices were higher in many cases than the closing Monday, but they also were the highest of to-day, and considerable reaction took place.

Sportsmen, naturalists, and others interested in the preservation of game gathered at the Hotel Marlborough yesterday in attendance upon the third annual meeting of the League of American Sportsmen. Delegates were present from almost every State in the Union, and from Alaska and the District of Columbia as well.
LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The hour fixed for the opening in state to-day of the first Parliament ot King Edward VII. is 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

The attempt of the Tammany members of the Board of Aldermen to approve the new map of Queens County was a signal failure yesterday. During a debate of an hour charges were made that the map would present to the Standard Oil Company, the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company, and the Calvary Cemetery corporation property rights of great value.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Senate held two executive sessions to-day with the result that all the Presidential nominations to the office of Brigadier General were confirmed. The nominations which caused discussion were those of Gens. Bates, Wood, Grant, and Bell. Senator Pettigrew (Sil., S.D.,) criticised Gen. Bates's nomination because that officer had negotiated the Sulu treaty, which treaty he attacked sharply.

The full list of stakes for this Summer's meeting at Saratoga has been completed by H.G. Mcintyre, Racing Secretary of the Saratoga Association, and the programme, consisting of nine events for two-year-olds, seven for three-year-olds, six for three-year-olds and upward, and three fixtures for hurdle and steeplechase horses, was announced yesterday.

In several parts of the list the market for outside securities yesterday showed considerable activity. Moreover, transactions in smaller amounts were made in a large number of issues, and trading was probably broader than on any day recently. Prices developed considerable irregularity, and a number of early advances were subsequently reduced by more or less sharp reactions.

Oscar S. Straus, who was recently elected President of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, presided for the first time in that capacity at the monthly meeting yesterday. William H. Parsons, the retiring President, introduced Mr. Straus in a brief speech.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Between union labor and the proposed new steel trust, which may arise through the sale of the Carnegie interests to J. Pierpont Morgan's syndicate, a gigantic struggle may follow over the question of the nine-hour work day, which union machinists throughout the country plan to inaugurate this Spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The ceremony of counting the Electoral vote for President and Vice President cast at the election last Fall took place in the hall of the House of Representatives at 1 o'clock today, at a joint session of the Senate and House. The method of counting the vote is prescribed with great detail by the statute and was followed literally to-day.
CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Ex-Attorney Generals Miller and Harmon were both in Chicago to-day. They appeared to be in accord on the settlement of the trust problem. Said Mr. Miller:

The New York Athletic Club team won three straight games from the Knicker-bocker Athletic Club bowlers in the Athletic Bowling League series, on the Knicker-bocker Athletic Club alleys last night. The scores:

SAN FERNANDO, Luzon, Philippine Islands, Feb. 13 -- At Bacolor a bill applying the Provincial Government act to the Province of Pampanga was passed in the presence of a crowd, which included representatives of all the twenty towns in the province. The appointments of the officers of the province were immediately announced, as follows:
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 13 -- The Government is enforcing drastic measures against a continuation of the student troubles.

With the wind blowing across the ice of Van Cortlandt Lake with the force of a lusty tornado all day yesterday, over fifty Scotch enthusiasts of the ancient game of curling turned out, undeterred by the weather, to play their annual competition for the John Dewar Silver Cup. The sport was kept going until after 6 o'clock, for two rounds of the contest were played, and the semi-final and final rounds will be finished to-day.
ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The following bills were introduced in the Assembly to-day:

-- Utah, like New York, has recently, been compelled to deal with a rather serious outbreak of smallpox, but the health authorities there, less fortunate than our own, have been hampered in their efforts to control the disease by the opposition of a small but noisy and energetic group or anti-vaccinationists, who, for reasons easily imagined, have been much more successful in deluding public opinion than our own group of the same sort.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The German Ambassador, Dr. von Holleben, gave a large reception this evening, when the Embassy in Massachusetts Avenue was the centre of all fashionable Washington, fully 700 guests being in attendance.

C. Fred Conklin, the Chicago amateur billiard champion, won his third game last night in the Class A championship series, played in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. He beat, at fourteen-inch balk line, John A. Hendrick of the home club, by 400 points to 363.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners and Controller Coler appeared before the Municipal Council yesterday to advocate the extension of the rapid transit tunnel under the East River to Brooklyn at an estimatedcost of $8,000,000. This was the first step in obtaining the sanction of the municipal authorities to this work.

NEWARK, N.J., .Feb. 13 -- George M.Valentine, the ex-cashier of the wrecked Middlesex County Bank, at Perth Amboy, was brought from the State-prison to-day on a writ of habeas corpus, and appeared as a witness for the defense in the suit brought in the Circuit Court by Edward S. Campbell, as receiver for the wrecked bank, against the Manufacturers' Bank of this city.
Discussing the iron and steel situation, The Iron Age will to-day say:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The general survey of foreign trade introductory to the volume on "Commercial Relations with the United States," which formed the subject of special letters from the President and the Secretary of State to Congress, has Just been published by Frederick Emory, the head of the Bureau of Foreign Commerce and compiler of this matter, in the shape of a special number of the "Advance Sheets of Consular Reports."

John N. Golding has sold for Edward F. Scarles to Thomas F. Byan, Vice President of the Morton Trust Company, the old Minturn mansion at the northwest corner of Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, a four-story brownstone dwelling, with a stable at the rear, on a plot 51 by 125.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 13 -- Virginia Harned (Mrs. E.H. Sothern) made her debut as a star at the Euclid Avenue Opera House this afternoon in "Camille." The actress received an enthusiastic reception and before the second act was finished she had won an artistic triumph. Her Camille differs in many ways from the well-known interpretations of the character.

Controller Coler and Prof. Felix Adler met last night at a gathering of the Federation of East Side Boys' Clubs and for an hour both addressed the audience and, incidentally, each other, giving their respective views of reform in municipal affairs. The meeting took place in the auditorium of the Educational Alliance's building, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, where the members of the various clubs packed the hall to the doors.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- There was an unexpected ending to the annual dinner of the Lincoln Legion of this city last night. The affair broke up in a row, and there was a narrow escape from fisticuffs. The trouble was started by former Assemblyman Alfred E. Smith of Mount Vernon, one of the Platt-Burns faction of the Bepublican Party in this county.

Over 1,500 dogs will be shown to the canine-loving public next week in the Madison Square Garden when the annual exhibit of the Westminster Kennel Club opens, on Tuesday. To be literally exact, there are 1,543 dogs, and they are divided into 2,125 entries, some dogs being in two or more classes.

That seems to be an inspired, if not an official, declaration which has been made from Washington, on the part of Senator JONES of Arkansas, concerning the future policy and programme of the still so-called Democratic Party. It is enough to say that the programme of the unhappy persons who find themselves in control of the Democratic organization is for a third nomination of BRYAN, twice defeated, to show how hopeless is the outlook.

The usual result of premature governmental interference with private enterprise is to surround monopolies with safeguards they could never have erected for themselves and to make them more formidable than they could have become if left to work out their own problems in their own way, under the conditions of unrestricted competition.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Trading in coal stocks was active again to-day and the market was bullish. The transportation stocks were leaders in the trading. There was continued good buying of Lake Street Elevated and Union Traction. Lake Street showed a further advance to 16 5/8, although the close was at 15 1/4.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 13 -- The new features to-day in the Carnegie-Morgan negotiations, according to the Pittsburg Leader, are that the deal will be closed Friday; that President C.M. Schwab will be the head of the new company to be formed, and that Andrew Carnegie is to receive a sum larger than has been given in any of the many estimates sent out from New York.

MADRID, Feb. 13 -- As was anticipated, the funeral to-day of Don Ramon de Campoamor, the poet and statesman, was attended with serious disturbances. The weather was beautiful, and enormous crowds gathered along the route taken by the funeral cortege. Those who followed the body included the members of the Academy and the Ministers of Justice and Public Instruction.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The Lord Mayor, the Sheriffs, and the Aldermen, robed in mazarine blue gowns, accompanied by civic officers, sword bearers, mace bearers, and other attendants, with a deputation from, the London County Council, proceeded in state carriages to St. James's Palace yesterday to present to the King loyal addresses on behalf of the City of London.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The best guarantee of peace between the United States and Venezuela is that the State Department has secured from the representatives of the Asphalt Trust, who have been here this week, a promise that they will not resist the long threatened attack on their property, if it should be made.
Miss Zelie de Lussan, contralto, formerly of the Metropolitan Opera House, will appear on the variety stage in Brooklyn on Feb. 25.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Chairman Henry of the Assembly Committee on Public Health was induced by the Christian Scientists today not to carry out his announced intention of having the final hearing in the committee's room, instead of the Assembly chamber, as heretofore, and excluding the rank and file of the Scientists.

Must Cuba, though thoroughly dependent upon us for protection and defense, and absolutely essential to our safety, nevertheless have more freedom thrust upon it than Vermont or Massachusetts or New York? Our Congress is capable sometimes of extraordinary things, but it is hardly capable of that.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- According to the present plans of the War Department the army is to be recruited to its full authorized strength of 100,000 men. The regular army now consists of about 67,000 men, including the troops in the Philippines, so that the new enlistments are limited to about 33,000 men.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 13 -- Shortly before the Delaware Legislature convened the Society of Friends of this city started an agitation for the abolition of the whipping post and pillory as means of punishment in this State. The agitation has resulted in extending this punishment instead of abolishing it.

Cross-examination by. Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy's counsel yesterday during the latter's second trial for the murder of Dolly Reynolds, elicited from Dr. Ernst J. Lederle, one of the prosecution's chief witnesses, testimony regarded as highly favorable to the accused dentist, which was not adduced at the former trial.

NEWPORT, R.I., Feb. 13 -- The revenue cufter Dexter rescued five vessels in Dutch Island Harbor to-day from being crushed by heavy ice. The vessels were jammed in the ice or were being dragged on a lee shore by the heavy pack ice. The Dexter's lookout saw as she entered the harbor several signals of distress.

In the tunnel used by the Madison Avenue surface car line, between Thirty-fourth and Forty-second Streets, at the point where a stairway leads up to Thirty-eighth Street, a tall and sturdy young man yesterday attacked Mrs. Louise A. Pryor, the wife of Dr. William R. Pryor, the well-known specialist and professor in the New York Polyclinic Institute, who is a son of Ex-Justice of the Supreme Court Roger A. Pryor.

According to a story told yesterday by Capt. Titus of the Detective Bureau, Mike Nolan, a well-known crook, is at present kicking himself because he allowed two other thieves to rob him. under the impression that they were detectives in the pursuit of their duty. Nolan is also exeerating the perfidy of his former bosom friend, a gentleman known as "Jigger" O'Brien.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- There was mone of file old-time enthusiasm at the annual assembly of the League of American Wheelmen, which was held at the Lafayette Hotel here to-day. There was but a handful of delegates present, and even the President, Conway W. Sams of Baltimore, was among the absentees.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Early this morning the crew of Conductor William Gilligan's freight train discovered the body of a man lying on the Erie tracks a few miles west of here. Beside him lay a shotgun. The man was well dressed and had evidently been dead only a short time, as his body was still warm when found.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 13 -- The Philadelphia market showed considerable strength early to-day. Philadelphia Electric led the trading movement, and over 10,000 shares changed hands immediately after the opening. The high price for the day was 8 3/8; toward the close it got down to 8. The Asphalt securities were the feature in point of strength.
There is some danger lest the measure pending at Albany which is of the nearest interest to the people of the city may fail, simply through want of popular interest enough to secure its success.

HAVANA, Feb. 13 -- The finishing touches were to-day given to the Constitution by the Editing Committee, which will report the corrected project to the Constitutional Convention, to-morrow, when it will undoubtedly be adopted.

The harness Horses of the Fasig-Tipton Company's "400" auction sale crowded hard on the straggling revelers of the cake walk in Madison Square Garden yesterday morning, the bustle of converting the great hall into a speed and show ring for trotters and pacers beginning while there still was a crowd left over from the fantastic entertainment of the night before.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- The State Board of Tax Commissioners experienced a great deal of difficulty one year ago in getting local boards of assessors to perform properly the duties imposed on them under the Franchise Tax act. A great deal of time was lost in correcting errors made by the local boards.

Chief Devery late yesterday afternoon sprung a surprise at Police Headquarters by announcing a number of changes, the most significant of which was the transfer of Inspector Donald Grant from the Fifth Inspection District (Manhattan) to the Seventh Inspection District, (Brooklyn.) His place in this borough is to be filled by the transfer of Inspector James W. Kane, who had charge of the Seventh Inspection District, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Late to-night, after a busy and eventful day, Mrs. Carrie Nation left Chicago for Topeka to stand trial there. Physical exhaustion, partial loss of her voice, and the disinclination of officials to listen to her, to some extent interfered with the programme she had mapped out for the day.

Yesterday was comparatively quiet socially after the storm of Tuesday. But the lull was only temporary, and today again will be one of the busiest of the season. Last evening Mr. and Mrs. Whitelaw Reid gave a musicale, which is described in another column, and which was the most notable entertainment of the evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the sake of showing England that it is not too late for her to relent and secure herself the comfort of not murdering a great people, it is necessary to call her attention to the signs that Lord Roberta's success in driving the Boers from every position had nothing in it intrinsically fatal to the Boers, whose role was necessarily, from the first, that of guerrillas.

The trial of Jesse R. Davis, one of the three Bellevue nurses indicted for manslaughter in causing the death of Louis H. Hilliard, patient in the pavilion for the insane, began in earnest yesterday with the introduction of the testimony of Mrs. Marie Hilliard, widow of the dead man. The six remaining members of the jury were selected, and Assistant District Attorney Pierce opened the State's case in the three hours of the morning session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The House devoted itself to-day to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill. General debate upon the measure was completed, and the bill was read for amendment. Little actual progress was made, however. During the debate the opposition opened a general assault upon the extravagance of the present Congress.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Although President Jeffery does not confirm the report, it is said, upon the best of authority, that George Gould and others connected with the Harriman syndicate are to-day in full control of the Denver and Rio Grande Railroad. Mr. Gould and his associates will be made Directors at the next annual meeting.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your special from Washington published in the issue of the 19th, bearing upon the effect made upon Government officials by the utterances of Minister Wu Ting Fang was read with considerable amusement.

There was abundant trouble yesterday for Michael Angelo Salvatore Marlo Valeri, Count dl Verschetti, House of Savoy, address refused, accused, of grand larceny and attempted blackmail by Mrs. Mattie Hughes Browne, poetess, and of several other things not quite so wicked by two other women.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- From an absolutely reliable source it is learned that Gen. Weyler has not only proclaimed martiat law in Madrid, but has posted his troops in such a manner as to command every part of the city. The downfall of the Ministry is said to be certain, and that of the Government possible.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As your reading of history apparently begins after the Revolutionary war, I must explain that the letters to which I referred were private ones, written by Hutchinson and Oliver in Massachusetts to Thomas Whately in England several years before, the Revolution.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Assemblyman Gardiner at Monroe to-day introduced a bill providing that within five days after the passage of the act the Governor shall appoint four Commissioners to prepare and submit on or before the 1st day of February, 1902, a revision of the tax-law and the laws relating to the assessment and collection of taxes.

We doubt if the really strong trusts will seriously oppose the policy of repealing the high tariff duties on their products. Not that their managers are enamored of the obvious justice of the policy, but, being convinced of its justice, and of the certainty that it is to come sooner or later, they will prefer to adjust their plans to it rather than make a futile fight against it.

NATCHEZ, Miss., Feb. 14 -- The New Orleans and Northwestern Railway, operating from Natchez to Bastrop, La., was to-day formally transferred to the Gould system. The property does-not lose its identity, and will be operated with C.G. Garner of St. Louis as President. The Goulds will soon have a through line between St. Louis and New Orleans.

Absence of science, speed, and skill marked the championship hockey match at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening between the sevens of the Hockey Club of New York and the Quaker City Hockey Club, in which the local team won by a score of 4-2. Both teams played a rough game, and that no one was ruled off was due more to the leniency of Referee Howard than to any mildness in the play.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment to-day gave a hearing upon the bill providing for local option in cities as regards the liquor traffic. The principal speakers in favor of the bill were Dr. J.Q.A. Henry, State President of the Anti-Saloon League; the Rev. T.E. Tower, and the Rev. Norman Plazz.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The President, acting upon the recommendations of Secretary of the Navy Long, has revived the Sampson-Schley controversy in the Senate by sending to that body a revised list of the promotions made during the war of 1898, including the advancement of Rear Admiral Sampson over Rear Admiral Schley, and other promotions of officers who took a conspicuous part in the battles with the Spanish forces in the Carribean Sea.

-- Friends of the late WILLIAM L. WILSON, desirous of giving permanent and appropriate expression to the respect and esteem which his high character, his broad patriotism, and his many public services so well earned, have determined to endow in his name a Chair of Economics at Washington and Lee University, the institution to which Mr. WILSON devoted the last years of his life.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 14 -- The storm now raging throughout Western New York is the fiercest ever seen in many of the counties, and is responsible for much suffering among the live stock. All train service is delayed and freights are stalled in the snowdrifts on several roads. The rural mail carriers in many districts are unable to cover their routes, and already there is a noticeable rise in the price of provisions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Senate devoted practically the entire day to the Agricultural Appropriation bill but the measure was not completed. During the discussion of the bill Mr. Hale of Maine and Mr. Lodge of Massachusetts sounded notes of warning against the enormous appropriations being made by the present Congress.

In the Fire Insurance Bowling League tournament, on Reid's alleys, last night, the Liverpool and London and Globe and the Home teams each won two games, the Underwriters and Hanover teams each won one game and lost one, and the Phenix and Lancashire teams each lost two games. The Underwriters' made a new high team score of 906.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- On the resumption of business after the recess which followed the royal ceremony in the House of Lords yesterday, the Lord Chancellor read the King's speeceh, and the Marquis of Waterford (Conservative) moved the address in reply. He is, perhaps, the youngest member to whom the honor has ever been accorded.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 -- A report that W.W. Gibbs had retired from the American Iron and Steel Company was confirmed at Mr. Gibbs's office to-day. It is also said, though not officially, that Mr. Gibbs yesterday sold out his interest of 100,000 shares for $1,000,000 to G.H. Sternbergh, who was elected President and General Manager of the company in place of Arthur Brock.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Attorney General and Mrs. Griggs entertained at dinner this evening. Their guests were chiefly from resident circles.

Senator Chauncey M. Depew, in a speech before the Transportation Club last night, condemned and ridiculed the "fresh-water Senators," as he called them, who opposed the Ship Subsidy bill, and at the same time defined his position toward this bill and, incidentally, his view of his attitude in his capacity as United States Senator from New York and Chairman of the Board of Directors of the New York Central Railroad.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The opening of the first Parliament of the new reign witnessed the usual competition on the part of members of the House of Commons to secure seats. Despite the arctic weather, the members stole up to the doors of the House shortly after midnight, Mr. J.H. Johnstone, (Conservative,) member for the Northwest, or Horsham, Division of Sussex, having the place of honor at the head of the line.

Mrs. Thomas G. Barker of Arlington had her first interview yesterday with her husband since his incarceration in the Hudson County Jail at Jersey City, after the shooting of the Rev. John Keller. She arrived at the jail at 3:15 o'clock in the afternoon in a coach, and was accompanied by Mrs. Germond and a representative of Marshal Van Winkle's office, who refused to give his name.

The negotiations looking to a consolidation of the Vickers Sons Maxim Company, Limited, of England, the Cramp Ship and Engine Building Company of Philadelphia, and the Midvale Steeel Company of Nicetown have beeen satisfactorily concluded. All important matters that hitherto have been in dispute have been adjusted and announcement of the actual consolidation is likely to be made now at any time.

James Henry Smith, gave last evening at Sherry's a dinner dance. This entertainment has been discussed for weeks in New York society, and all kinds of wild and improbable stories have been current as to the gorgeousness of the decorations, the Expensive favors which were to be the attraction of the cotillion, and the possible list of guests.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Brooklyn's threatened water famine was amply discussed this afternoon before the Assembly Cities Committee at the hearing on Mr. Morgan's bill to provide for the construction in Forest Park, Queens County, an additional storage reservoir for use in the Borough of Brooklyn, which will be reported favorably to-morrow to the House.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 14 -- The new eligibility rules that have been adopted by the Yale athletic managers and that will be submitted to the university at a mass meeting to-morrow evening are a great advance over anything of the kind attempted before at Yale.

Between 800,000 and 900,000 shares were dealt in upon the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, and quotations as a rule showed advances. Those stocks which were most dealt in advanced most. Again, Sugar Trust was, however, a drawback to the general market, and the 65,000 shares of that stock which were quoted did not help market sentiment.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The Ramapo Company's memorandum in reply to the brief presented to the Assembly Committee on Cities on the subject of the Morgan Repeal bill was received by the members of the committee yesterday. In the memorandum was this statement:

Justice Fursman's decision during Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy's second trial yesterday barring the testimony of handwriting experts not familiar with the accused man's writing and who had never seeen him write was regarded as another signal victory for the Staten Island dentist in his struggle for acquittal of the charge of murdering Dolly Reynolds two years ago.
CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- The Record to-morrow will say:

Trading in the outside market yesterday was lighter, and at the same time price were even more irregular than they were on Wednesday. Some few issues showed decided weakness, and in a number of others quotations fell slightly below the record of the previous day, while relatively few stocks advanced to better prices.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The joint committee of the Senate and Assembly Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment to-day gave a hearing in the Assembly Chamber to the Elsberg bill to amend the tax law by providing for the apportionment of State taxes and for local option in taxation. This is the bill which is especially advocated by the New York Chamber of Commerce.

Conferences over the steel deal went on in the Mills Building yesterday and lasted some hours. They were under the auspices of J. Pierpont Morgan, who was represented by Ms legal adviser, Francis Lynde Stetson. Those who had a share in them were ex-Judge E.H. Gary, President of the Federal Steel Company: Max Pam of counsel for this and other interests, and William Nelson Cromwell of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell.

Charles B. Bostwick. Charles B. Bostwick a member of the insurance firm of Saterlee, Bostwick Martin, died yesterday at his home, in Ogdensburg, N.Y. Mr. Bostwick was a son of Charles Byron Bostwick and Elizabeth Corre, and was born in White Plains. N.Y., in 1826.

Thomas F. Lewis, the President, and John H. Kampf, the Financial Secretary of the Brooklyn City Co-operative Building and Loan Association, have been suspended from office by the Board of Directors of the associatlon for failing; as alleged, to report to the board that a certain person was in arrears in his subscriptions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- The granite Harvard shield, at Gray's Hall, just under the third-story hall window, was painted last night, the act probably being another of the deeds of some candidates for a Harvard secret society. The background of the shield was painted green and the open books of the shield upon which is the Harvard motto "Veritas" were painted red.

Traffic was practically suspended in New York Harbor yesterday on account of the ice jam, from which there was no relief until the afternoon, when the tide changed. And the relief then afforded was of no great benefit to water craft.

There is one aspect of the crusade of Mrs. NATION against the saloons which has not received so much attention as it perhaps deserves. The crusader herself declares that she is engaged in protecting the American home, and that to smash the saloon, which is its rival, is a duty she owes to her sons and grandsons, as well as to those of other American women.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 14 -- George M. Valentine, who wrecked the Middlesex County Bank, was brought from State Prison again to-day to continue his testimony in the suit brought by Receiver Campbell of the County Bank against the Manufacturers' Bank of this city.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- John G. Redmond, M. P., in the course of an interview in the lobby of the House of Commons last evening, said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The events in connection with the sale of the old New York Custom House to the National City Bank, which heretofore has been the subject of much comment, occupied the centre of the stage during the debate on the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill in the House to-day.

The star attraction of the Fasig-Tipton Company's "400" horse sale in Madison Square Garden yesterday was the offering, early in the evening, of the John Splan pole team, Maggie and Marian Messenger, splendidly matched young bay mares, of whom Splan expressed the conviction that they can trot a mile in 2:15.
LONDON, Feb. 15 -- The Duke of Cornwall and York's absence from the ceremonies yesterday is explained as due to a cold. It is denied that he has suffered a relapse.

It is a maxim of the law, that every man must be held to intend the consequences of his own acts. In accordance with this principle, it is possible to give credit to Gov. ODELL for the sensible and practical outcome that appears likely to result from at least one of the projects of taxation proposed or approved by him.

The Purim Association gave its charity ball of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The affair was a financial as well as a social success. The organization distributed over $135,000 in money, food, and clothing during the past year. The presence of those who attended the ball meant an addition of $15,000 to the relief fund.

PLAIN FIELD, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Mrs. Carl Sells and two children, who occupy rooms on the top floor of the Love Building, on Broad Street, in Westfield, had a narrow escape from losing their lives in a fire in the structure early this morning. The flames cut off egress by the stairway, and the woman and children appeared at the windows, screaming piteously for help.

It certainly cannot be complained that the British public is not now quite aware of the serious and formidable nature, of the task it has undertaken "to establish British supremacy in South Africa," as The London Times proclaimed, at the outset of the war, to be its purpose. We have not seen a clearer evidence of the fact than that furnished toy an article in The Saturday Review on "English Immigration into South Africa."

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- With an amount of pomp not seen in connection with a similar ceremony since the year 1861, when Queen Victoria opened Parliament in full state for the last time in her reign, the first Parliament of the reign of Kins Edward VII. was ppened by the King yesterday afternoon.

Charles Threshie, the Boston amateur billiard champion, gave one of the grandest exhibitions of billiards last night in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club that has ever been seen in amateur tournaments in this vicinity, if not in this country. In many respects it was a unique game and will long be remembered by the large number of billiard enthusiasts who watched it and cheered it repeatedly from start to finish.

Thomas J. Minnock was the principal witness yesterday in the trial of Jesse R. Davis, one of the Bellevue nurses charged with being responsible for the death of Louis H. Hilliard, in the insane pavilion last December. Minnock feigned insanity in order to investigate the institution at Ward's Island, but his ruse was discovered at Bellevue at the time Hilliard was brought in.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Trading was a little quieter to-day, and prices, in some instances, were a shade easier. The market was featureless. Lake Street Elevated was in fair demand between 14 1/8 and 15, but there was no rush to buy. Union Traction was quiet at 13 7/8 for the common and 57 for the preferred.

MADRID, Feb. 14 -- When Madrid awoke this morning it found itself under military rule. A proclamation was posted announcing the enforcement of martial law in consequence of the inability of the civil authorities to cope with the disturbances.

William Smith, alias William Lindon, an ex-convict, who has just finished serving an eight-year sentence in Sing Sing, entered the home of Homer Heminway, a thread merchant, living at 8 West Fiftyfirst Street, yesterday morning, and was caught while running away with $600 worth of silverware and jewelry which he had stolen from the premises.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- The seniors defeated the juniors to-day in the Harvard class hockey series by 2 to 0. The championship now lies between the seniors and the freshmen.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Feb. 14 -- There will be no contest between Jeffries and Ruhlin or any one else in Saengerfest Hall, in this city, to-morrow night, and no other date has been fixed for the event. Neither will there be any mobilization of troops outside of the hall or anywhere else to-morrow night or any other time in this city to keep Jeffries and Ruhlin from meeting there.

Ice continued plentiful in the rivers and harbor yesterday, although the sunshine and constant battering of vessels broke it up so that much of the floe was carried out to sea in the afternoon. There were a few accidents, notably those following the sudden rush of vast quantities of ice toward the Narrows at about 1 o'clock.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- A ten-million-dollar syndicate has just been formed here to build and operate the largest sugar refinery on this continent. The refinery is to be-operated as an independent concern, and will own its own steamers. The property along the river front desired, by the new corporation has been acquired, and the plans for the new plant have been completed.

The author of this book, Albert G. Robinson, was staff correspondent in the Philippines for one of the leading evening papers of this city for about six months -- from July, 1808, to February, 1899 -- and the volume is largely made up of letters written home for publication.

Mr. Basil Champneys's "Memoirs and Correspondence of Coventry Patmore," Iately issued in two large volumes, aggregating nearly nine hundred pages, shows the most delightful typography, paper, arrangement of page, and all other mechanical details; it being the work of the Chiswick Press; while its illustrations, and notably the portrait of Coventry Patmore by Sargent, painted in 1894, and now in the National Portrait Gallery, add very materially to the interest of this charming book.

We have already referred in these columns to the instruction, admonition, and reproof we and our readers, confident of our ability to express ourselves elegantly in foreign tongues, may derive from the amazing efforts of foreigners to make themselves understood in ours. The last lesson of this kind was taken from, a pamphlet of the Holy Kingdom of Hungary explaining to our citizens the favors granted for their encouragement in founding industries within its jurisdiction.

A semi-official statement made last evening in regard to the steel deal appears to establish that a formal announcement of results will not be made before next Monday, that in the main the features of the original plan of amalgamation or "community of interest" or "harmonizing" will be maintained, and that the deal will be consummated, and that matters have so far progressed that the incorporation papers of the blanket concern are being drafted.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Assembly Cities Committee reported to the House to-day for amendment and reprinting the Wilson bills, making the offices of Sheriff, Register, and County Clerk of Kings County salaried ones. The amendments increase the number of offices to be created under the bills; and both raises and cuts down salaries.

"I think there ought to be some sort of an investigation into the methods of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company. It has come to such a pass that many lawyers hesitate to accept a case against the company through fear of attacks upon themselves. This is a matter of common notoriety among lawyers, and some of the Judges here know it.

Controller Coler was cheered as "the Tammany candidate for Mayor" at the beefsteak dinner given by the political followers of Commissioner of Corrections Lantry during the early hours of yesterday morning. The outburst was a surprise to the politicians gathered in the Grand Central Palace to eat steaks and drink ale.

A special hearing was held yesterday before, the Committee on Streets and Highways of the Board of Aldermen on the extension of the Rapid Transit Tunnel to Brooklyn. Alderman Bridges presided. President Alexander E. Orr of the commission was present, as also, were Chief Engineer Parsons, Edward M. Shepard, and Commissioners Langdon arid Rives.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity, above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Some slight increase in the number of transactions in the outside market appeared yesterday, and in the matter of prices the day was more favorable than Thursday. Fewer declines occurred, and a number of those of the previous day were followed by more or less substantial recoveries.

The recent sale of William Harris Arnold's collection of American first editions was remarkably successful, most of the important items bringing record prices. The following list gives a careful selection of the books of chief value, together with the highest previous records. The prices at former sales are mostly taken from Foote's, 1894; Maxwell's, 1895; Bierstadt's 1897, and Roos's, Mackay's, and McKee's, each in 1900:

An Englishman has just-published a collection of the good things written by the satirists of his country, and some very good things indeed they have written. Almost simultaneously with the appearance of this volume there appeared in The Fall Mall Gazette a suggestion that the patron may have to be revived to support talented young authors who have not been able to make their way.

Senator DEPEW is evidently in bad temper over the criticism that has been visited on his support of the Ship Subsidy bill. When your habitual humorist allows himself to lose control of his temper he is in a weak situation. He is apt to take himself too seriously, and the twisting of facts and logic which is a legitimate device of his joking betrays him into the hands of his critics.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Feb. 15. -- The abundance of good rowing material at the University of Pennsylvania has renewed the agitation of sending a crew to represent the red and blue at the Henley regatta. To-day there was an informal meeting of several of Pennsylvania's loyal supporters, and it was the consensus of opinion that a trip abroad was feasible.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- There was a Sharp but good-natured and amusing exchange of wit in the Senate to-day between Mr. Tillman (Dem., S.C..) and Mr. Beveridge, (Rep., Ind.) It took place in the course of the debate preceding the passage of the Agricultural Appropriation bill.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- On the Exchange to-day trading in Lake Street Elevated was active, but little progress in the direction of higher prices was made on the morning call. The stock opened at 14 3/4, advanced almost immediately to 15 3/8, and then sagged back to 14 1/2 at the close. Union Traction was quiet, notwithstanding the story that the road was involved in consolidation negotiations of some kind.

AN OLD NEW YORKER sends to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW his recollections of McDonald Clarke: "There was for some years a beggar about the lower part of the city who was, apparently, very old. He was a chunky, heavily built man, and had long white hair down over his shoulders and back, in the Ben Franklin style.

Owing to the lawyers for Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy being unprepared to begin their defense yesterday, the trial of the accused dentist went over until Monday. The prosecution has not yet completed its case, but has only one or two witnesses to swear before closing.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In your issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW for Dec. 15 is a communication from Mr. P. Lee Phillips of the Map Department in the Library of Congress on "Early New York Maps and Views," which contains some rather surprising statements about their dates and order of publication.

SEATTLE, Washington, Feb. 15. -- A dispatch from Victoria, B.C., says a disastrous mine accident took place to-day at the Union Mines, owned by the Welling Colliery Company, of which James Dunsmuir, the Premier of the province, is the principal shareholder.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15. -- There were no scheduled golf tournaments or special contests here to-day, but the links were crowded from morning until night with foursomes and matches that partook much of a social nature. One record was broken.

THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW desires to express its sincere thanks to Harper's Weekly for the very cordial recognition which it gave, in its issue of Feb. 16, to the work THE SATURDAY REVIEW, during the past four and one-half years, has been doing to promote an understanding and appreciation of the best literature of the day.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- The market was dull to-day. Philadelphia Electric was the most active feature. The price dropped to 7 5/8, and a bid of that figure was made for 60,000 shares. Both the common and preferred shares of National Asphalt were off 1/8 or more; United Gas declined 1/2: the Readings fell backward, and so did Cambria Steel.

G.R.M. writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW from Asbury Park: "Mr. Barry's prompt denunciation of the outrage perpetrated upon him and his work by the editor of a magazine has just reached me owing to long absence from the city. During my absence I learned of a case compared with which Mr. Barry's was most considerately handled.

In the opinion of Mr. Howells, the sanguinary tale of adventure has obtained a place in the favor of the multitude that is a menace to mental and moral well-being. Despite this fact, however, the majority of our critics apparently consider realism to be the dominant note of the contemporary novel, and that, too, in accordance with popular taste, which demands verisimilitude at any cost.

Fiction in the March Century, besides "The Helmet of Navarre" and "Her Mountain Lover," will include "Surabhi,'' by Flora Annie Steel, author of "Tales, from the Punjab," and "On the Face, of the Waters." "Surabhi" was only a cow, but she was much more to old Gopal, the Brahman, who owned her.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15. -- The Victoria hockey team of New York lost a close and fiercely contested match to-night at the Ice Palace, Quaker City downing the New Yorkers by the score of 3 goals to 2. Line-up:

MRS. ARTHUR BRONSON. -- There lately died in Florence a lady who for many years was intimately, identified with the Italian visits of English and American artists and men of letters, who in "that" land whose beauty time cannot wither and whose infinite variety custom can never stale," sought inspiration or repose.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 15. -- The Pittsburg Leader says that from a reliable source it was learned that the deal with Andrew Carnegie will be closed by the payment to Mr. Carnegie of $22,500,000 in cash. He is to receive, in addition, $1,500 per share for his stock, and will be paid in bonds.

HAVANA, Feb. 15 -- Governor General Wood left Havana this afternoon for a two days' rest at Batabano. With him went the special committee appointed by the Cuban Constitutional Convention to draw up a proposition defining the future relations between the United States and the Republic of Cuba.

Columbia will not have a new boathouse on the Harlem this Spring. Such has been the decision of the graduates; in view of the failure of the students to raise $5,000 before Feb. 12. The crews will probably be put on the Harlem in about a month and will be housed with one of the Harlem clubs, as was done last year.

In the current number of The American Printer Mr. John H. Dingman of Charles Scribner's Sons presents an entertaining and instructive article on "The American Publishers Association," the formation of which last year caused considerable comment unions bookmen as to its objects. Mr. Dingman sketches the development of the book trade in this country, showing that such a union or alliance among the publishers was inevitable if they were to maintain their proper integrity.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- President Schurman of Cornell University, one of the principal speakers at the Board of Trade banquet in this city last night, made a statement in regard to the so-called religious troubles in the Philippines.

The William Harris Arnold sale was notable in many ways. The collection consisted of rather more than 700 volumes, by, about, or in some way connected with eight of the best known of the early group of prominent American authors -- Bryant, Emerson, Haw-thorne, Holmes, Longfellow, Lowell, Thoreau, and Whittier.

BOSTON, Feb. 15. -- At attempt was made on the life of Miss Edith Talbot, a member of the Bowdoin Square Theatre Stock Company, as she was leaving the theatre a few minutes before 10 o'clock last night. One shot was fired at her, which would doubtless have entered her heart had not her left arm been thrown upward.

It is no disrespect to Justice FURSMAN to say that his ruling as to the admission of the testimony of experts in handwriting is not final. As we understand it and from a layman's point of view it is not undesirable that it should be reviewed, and even reversed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Under the leadership of Mr. Cannon, Chairman of the Appropriations Committee, a long filibuster consumed the time of the House today. Mr. Cannon desired the House to proceed with the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, in spite of the fact that under the rules it was "private bill day."

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Can you or one of your readers give me some information about librarianship? Where can a woman study it? How long is the course, and what are the requirements? Is it a well-paid occupation? I should be glad of some idea in regard to the salaries of librarians, especially in libraries connected with colleges or universities.

In the tournament of the Royal Arcanum Bowling League, Borough of the Bronx, on Pump's North Side Palace alleys last night, the Bronx Council team won three games from the Fordham Council five. The scores:...

The unusual and somewhat spectacular sight of a big bay steer swimming up the East River, fighting his way through the ice and against the tide, attracted many hundreds of people to the Manhattan bank of the river yesterday afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- In the bill now on its third reading in the Senate providing for a single Commissioner who is to assume the duties of the existing Forest, Fish, and Game Commission and the Forest Preserve Board, this clause has been inserted:...

LANCASTER, Penn., Feb. 15. -- George W. Brintnall, who died here yesterday, was one of the famous soldiers of the rebellion. When scarcely more than fifteen years of age he enlisted as a drummer boy. At the battle of Shiloh he displayed remarkable coolness and bravery, and was afterward known by the sobriquet, "The Drummer of Shiloh," a title perpetuated in song and drama.

The season of Lent, which begins next Wednesday, is observed in this city more and more each succeeding year. This year Episcopalians will increase by one the number of noon-hour services to be held in the business quarter, and Congregationalists will lead the growing number of nonliturgical communions that observe the season.

The garb in which Mr. Worthington G. Ford's "George Washington" is presented by Messrs. Goupil Co. of Paris and Charles Scribner's Sons of New York is such as might be expected to array the final and finished picture of the foremost figure in American history. It appears in three sumptuous editions, each limited in the number of copies issued, and sold only by subscription.
For more reasons than one, it is no easy matter-to write of Mr. Henry James.
MADRID. Feb. 15. -- Spanish 4s closed today at 77.80. Gold was quoted at 37.80.

Speaking of his panacea for the overcrowding of England, CARLYLE observes: "A free bridge for emigrants! We should then be on a par with America itself, the most favored of all countries that have no Government; and we should have so many traditions and mementos of priceless things that America has had to cast away."
BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The Lokal Anzieger says King Edward's speech at the opening of Parliament yesterday is more remarkable for what it omits than for what it says, adding:

A difference of opinion among the advocates of the Apportionment and Local Option Tax bill was developed at the hearing before the Senate Committees on Taxation and Retrenchment, on Thursday. In reply to a question from Chairman KRUM, ex-Senator GUY, representing the Merchants' Association of this city, said that he thought the effect of the bill would be the abolition of the tax on personal property, at least in the City of New York.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- King Edward, accompanied by Queen Alexandra, this morning inspected, at Buckingham Palace, 350 officers and men of Strathcona's Horse, (who sailed from Cape Town on the British steamer Lake Erie Jan. 20, and who were landed at the Albert Docks yesterday morning.)

The proprietors of a new venture, "The Doves Press," Messrs. T.J. Cobden-Sanderson and Emery Walker, Hammersmith, W., London, have issued a list of books, printed and in preparation, the typography of which may be said to be almost, if not entirely, equal to the work of the Kelmscott Press.

Our esteemed contemporary. The World's Work takes up, in its current number, a subject to which some attention has from time to time been given in the pages of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW. It is in effect the tendency of our modern higher education in this country away from literature.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Feb. 15. -- Oberlin M. Carter, ex-Captain of Engineers, United States Army, was brought from the Federal prison to the United States District Court here to-day to hear arguments for his release pending the appeal of his habeas corpus proceedings in the United States Supreme Court.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 15. -- In getting Gov. Smith to call an extra session of the Legislature to change the election laws so as practically to disfranchise 30,000 negroes in Maryland Arthur P. Gorman, it appears, is playing the greatest political game of his life. A leading Democratic lawyer who knows all about the extra session scheme says:

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Dear to the heart of both author and publisher is the boom that brings a book into notice. I do not believe that any boom, however skillfully managed, can make an unreadable book successful, but if a book has positive merit, a boom may make its fortune in circumstances in which the book might otherwise never be known outside of the newspaper offices to which press copies had been sent.

Total transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday fell short of a million shares, but there were notable changes in the market value of a long list of stocks -- changes almost wholly on the side of advances. Some stocks jumped points at a time. This was true particularly of Delaware and Hudson, where, on transactions of less than 28,000 shares, a rise of over ten points was scored, most of the gain being maintained.

Prosecutor James S. Erwin of Jersey City on Wednesday visited the Rev. John Keller at Arlington and received from him an account of the assault made upon him when he was shot on Sunday, Feb. 3. Mr. Erwin declines to make any statement in regard to the interview, but from other sources the salient features of Mr. Keller's' statement were obtained.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15. -- The Princeton hockey management announced the cancellation of the games with Canadian teams and the trip north will not take place. The game with the University of Pennsylvania, which was to have taken place to-night, has been postponed until Feb. 19.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- The New York Central Railroad Company has purchased the Niagara Elevators, Nos. 1, 2, and 3. The Western Transit Company, the Central's lake line, owns City Elevators A and B, with a capacity of 1,200,00 bushels of grain. With the acquisition of the Niagara elevators the Central will have a storage capacity here of over 3,200,000 bushels.

GEORGE L. CONROY, Brooklyn, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "While reading, with interest, the 'Rhyming Sovereigns' in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Feb. 2 and 10, it occurred to me that the like might be done with the names or our Presidents. I don't recollect ever having seen any doggerel of this kind in connection with America's Chief Magistrates, but submit the inclosed, which I believe is correct historically, if not poetically.'

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Reports of storms which have prevailed in this section during the past few days are coming in slowly. At Canandaigua the effects of the prevailing blizzard have been felt seriously. All trains are from four to six hours late. The 4:23 train, due there Wednesday, did not arrive until 5 o'clock this morning.

C. Fred Conklin of Chicago beat Charles Threshie of Boston last night in the tenth and concluding game of the Class A championship billiard series, played in the theatre of the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street. It was a royal championship finish of the most important amateur billiard tournament held in the United States.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- The Pall Mall Magazine will publish on Feb. 18 an interview with Mr. Kruger, in which the ex-President says:

ONE OF ELIZABETH'S LOVERS, writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, says: "Having just read in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Feb. 2 what the writer himself styles a feeble and futile kick' at Elizabeth, I cannot refrain from entering my protest against this injustice.
MADRID, Feb. 15. -- Absolute quiet prevails. The situation is much improved. All the troops have been withdrawn. The crisis is regarded as postponed, if not ended.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday handed down a decision in the case of Lucie E. Everdell et al. against Elizabeth Hill and Jacob F. Miller, as executors of Mary L. Everdell. The case involves some points in the law regarding "mutual wills." such as the courts seldom pass upon.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Appropriation bill and the General Supply bill will be ready in the Legislature on Monday night. The tax rate for the present year, which is to be fixed by the Legislature before it adjourns, will be about half the rate in force last year, if there is no hitch in the arrangements being made by the leaders.

The interesting selection of excerpts from the critical reviews of the famous Jeffrey, made by Mr. Arthur Guiterman and published in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW to-day, contains a passage from that same Edinburgh Review article on Wordsworth's "Excursion" which was included, on the evidence of another passage, among the "mistakes of critics" we reprinted from Literature a few weeks ago.

New York was nearer a fish and oyster famine yesterday than it had been for many a year before. Prices advanced very considerably, and one of the largest wholesale sea food merchants in the city said that if the present cold weather conditions continued there would be almost an absolute oyster famine within ten days or two weeks.

There was a strange scene in Part III, of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, when the trial of the suit of Miss Edith Ellen Peck against the Brooklyn Heights Railroad Company to recover $75,000, damages for personal injuries was begun.

Clarence Morgan, son of Henry A. Morgan, a prominent resident of Aurora, N. Y., has just been elected a Trustee of the Phillips Academy and the Andover Theological Seminary, being the first man from the State and City of New York to occupy a place on the board since the institution was founded in 1778.

The Pan-American Exposition at Buffalo has engaged the sculptors to such an extent that an exhibition by the National Sculpture Society this year was out of the question; so that in some sort the Architectural League has to fill the gap. The present exhibition is therefore under the sign of sculpture.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- George C. Ward of 34 Hill Street, who has been for the last eight years in the transatlantic mail service, has entered suit to set aside the will of his sister, Anna B. Ward, it is said that undue influence, possibly forgery, will be charged by the contestant.

William Henry Gunther. William Henry Gunther, eldest son of the late William H. Gunther, and head of the house of C.G. Gunther's Sons, fur dealers, of 184 Fifth Avenue, died at his home, 56 East Fifty-fifth Street, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He had been ill for a long while of a complication of diseases.

One of the most encouraging features in the "Ninth Annual Report of the East Side House" -- at any rate to persons interested in the circulation of literature -- is the story of the work done during 1900 by the Webster Free Circulating Library under the direction of Edwin White Gaillard, the librarian. The material of this library is of course particularly devised for the needs of the people in its immediate neighborhood.

PRUSSIAN AGRICULTURE. -- The recent debates in the Prussian Diet concerning the Government's contemplated tariff policy have revealed a strong opposition to what is regarded as the Ministry's capitulation to the Agrarians. Supreme Court Justice Gildersleeve repudiated yesterday that portion of the published report of the dinner of the New York Alumni Association of the Hudson River Institute held Friday night at the St. Denis, in which he is made to say, under the caption "Only Politicians Can Become Judges":

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 16. -- The will of Edward Eldridge Salisbury, formerly professor in Yale University, has been offered for probate. It is believed that the estate will amount to several hundred thousand dollars. Most of the property is in Boston.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Although the opening this morning was generally strong, reaction came in short order. Prom the highest point, Sugar went off 7/8. Chicago, Burlington and Quincy 3/4, St. Paul 3/8, Federal Steel 1/2, Amalgamated 3/4, New York, New Haven and Hartford 4. Copper Range, 46, up 1.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Here is another of those grievances with which so many newspaper readers run to the patient editor, as to a court of first or last resort, or both.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The effort made by Miss Frances Roberts to have her father, Dr. Charles H. Roberts of Ulster County, judicially declared incompetent to manage his property, which is estimated at $2,000,000, failed signally this afternoon, when Supreme Court Justice Herrick, fitting at Special Term in this city, dismissed an order which he had made requiring Mr. Roberts to show cause why such a commission should not be appointed.

DULUTH, Minn., Feb. 16. -- Another great metallurgical development is to be undertaken in Canada at once. The Clergue syndicate, situated at the foot of Lake Superior, will erect two immense charcoal blast furnaces, each of double the size of any charcoal furnaces ever built. These will be rushed to completion, and are expected to be ready to melt ore this year.

Wall Street was exercised a good deal a week ago when it was disclosed that the millionaires of the American Smelting and Refining Company were in a snarl grave enough to threaten sensational consequences. Two of them, Leonard Lewisohn and H.H. Rogers of the Standard Oil Company, had resigned, protesting against a business policy which they were quoted as condemning in terms that had a serious sound.

LENOX, Feb. 16. -- A large number of the Lenox cottagers came up from New York this week to enjoy the first really good sleighing of the season. Curtis Hotel has had a large number of guests, and some of the cottages are open.

Dealing has been if anything more general in its character during the last week, but with no sign, however, of a cessation of the activity in those sections which have for the last two months commanded the greater share of speculative attention. The upper Fifth Avenue district, between the Carnegie blocks and the Mount Sinai Hospital site, have shown a volume of business rivaling that which immediately followed Mr. Carnegie's purchases two years ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In this morning's issue you published an interesting letter upholding Mr. Wu and severely criticising the President and other officers of the Government for what he (the writer) calls childishness.

The "400" horse auction in Madison Square Garden, by the Fasig-Tipton Company was concluded yesterday, with the attendance undiminished, though there was a very considerable shrinkage in the prices. The best lots, however, had been sold earlier, and, though high-class horses were scattered through the last day's offering, the general average was below par, and the buyers chiefly were dealers and bargain hunters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Senate Committee on Appropriations to-day completed the Fortifications bill. It carries an increase over the House bill of $311,000. of which $225,000 is for the purchase of land on Cushings Island. Me., and the erection of batteries, and $1,000 for carriages for 12-inch mortars.

MADRID, Feb. 16. -- King Alfonso, the Queen Regent, and other members of the royal family drove about the city this afternoon, accompanied by the usual palace guard. The drive was without special incident. The city is perfectly calm. Martial law, however, will be continued until after the carnival, and will then be removed if the present tranquillity continues.

The opening of the new house of the New York Yacht Club reminds us anew and strongly what an interesting new quarter has sprung up in New York within the past decade. No New Yorker sojourning for even a few days in Chicago can have failed to notice that there is nothing in that town answering to middle New York, the quarter of hotels and theatres and clubs.

Farrell Hopper, sub-contractors of the Rapid Transit Railroad, have recently encountered an unlooked-for difficulty in their section, between One Hundred and Thirteenth and One Hundred and Fourteenth Streets and Lenox Avenue, in the shape of a running stream of fresh water, apparently in great volume.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Theatrical stock, which was depressed by the fortnight of mourning, is rising on the prospects that the King will give an impetus to the revival of old-time gayeties so soon as the official period of mourning has expired. Several new theatres are projected or building.

From The Fortnightly Review. I do not think there is in Italy a single statesman who has not, some time or other, denounced the Italian system of taxation as a cruel injustice to the poorest part of the community, yet one and all have been in their turn intrusted with the Government of the country, and each one -- Giolitti included, who was Premier in 1893 -- has done nothing to alter the denounced system.
The Boston Symphony Orchestra will come to town again this week. The programmes:

To the Editor of The New York Times: At the time of the great cataclysm at Galveston when several thousands of lives were swallowed up by the sea, I was about reviewing the causes thereof for your journal, but postponed my purpose until the great outpouring of charitable contributions from a sympathetic people should be collected for the fatherless children and distressed inhabitants whose homes and possessions were engulfed in that unparalleled catastrophe.

Yesterday's market was one of much irregularity, heaviness in the early trading being succeeded by strength which in its turn gave way to weakness, following the publication of the bank statement which showed a further large increase in loans and a decrease in surplus reserves. This showing, however, had generally been expected, and induced no liquidation, the only selling being for the short account.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- Emperor William's friendly conduct toward Great Britain recently, and the presumable motives which induced it, still form the favorite subject for discussion here. Therefore unusual interest was taken in Germany at the opening of the British Parliament; but the speech from the Throne, and the debates on the address in reply to it, were thoroughly disappointing because of the absence of any reference to Anglo-German relations.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The Duke of Westminster and Miss Shelagh West were married at St. Paul's Church, Knightsbridge, tins afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Much interest was excited in Administration circles by the speech in Boston of Commander in Chief Rassieur of the Grand Army of the Republic, in which he deplored the blocking of pension legislation by high office holders "wearing the bronze button," and announced his intention to make a report attacking the offenders, even if what he should say "reflects on the highest individual in this country."

From The Forum. Two years ago there were on record for taxation probably more than a million sheep in the one Sierra Reserve of California; and, in addition, there were the unrecorded thousands owned by roving Basque, French, and Portuguese herders.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: Has the Board of Health, the police, or any body or board the right or power to prevent those "night hawks" from prowling around the streets at night, with their nasty, filthy cabs? They never show themselves until after 12 o'clock at night to look for customers at ballrooms or other places, where people are apt to be out late; then they begin to ply their trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Count Cassinl, the Russian Ambassador, this afternoon received a cablegram from the Russian Foreign Office confirming the report of the issue of the decree imposing increased duties on certain American imports into Russia, and took steps to inform the State Department accordingly.
The annual meeting of the stockholders of the National Biscuit Company was held in Jersey City yesterday. President B.F. Crawford presented the following balance sheet as of Jan. 31 last

PATTON, Penn., Feb. 16. -- The discovery in a mine breach near Hastings to-day of the body of Charles Fetsco, the seven-year-old son of John Fetsco, a miner, disclosed a sad story of suffering. The boy had been missing from home for four days, and the discovery of his almost nude corpse in the big hole showed that he starved and froze to death after making a most desperate attempt to escape.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 16. -- The championship skating races of America were run off this afternoon on the open-air rink of the Montreal Amateur Athletic Association. The weather was perfect -- just mild enough after the zero spell of the past week to make it pleasant for the fur-elad spectators, of whom there were several thousand present.

Revenue Agent F.G. Thompson of the Internal Revenue office yesterday arrested Arthur J. Heinemann, who is a stamp broker and pharmacist at Wall and Water Streets. Heinemann's principal business is said to be that of a pharmacist, but in his establishment there is an allotment of space for a Sub-Post Office, which is confined by a wire partition.

ST. JOHN'S N.F. Feb. 16. -- Even in these days, when a billion-dollar steel plant is projected in the United States, the capitalist who moves with the times cannot afford to disregard the smelting enterprise that has just sprung into being at Sydney, Cape Breton, and which has been rendered possible by the existence of immense deposits of hematite iron at Belleisle, Newfoundland, the most remarkable ore formation of its kind in the world.

The Republican County Executive Committee met last evening and adopted the plan for the Congressional redistricting of New York under the Burleigh law. The City of New York will in the future be represented by nineteen Congressmen, instead of sixteen, the present number. The plan formally adopted last evening will be sent to Albany for approval by the legislature this week.

Policeman James D. Cotter of the Tremont Police Station was standing at the corner of One Hundred and Seventy-second Street and Jerome Avenue at 3:05 o'clock yesterday morning, when he saw a peddler's wagon containing three men. The moment the men noticed him they began belaboring the horse attached to the wagon and made him gallop.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 16. -- Judge Jesse J. Phillips of the Supreme Court of Illinois died last night at his home in Hillsborough. Judge Phillips had been ill for several months, and his death had been expected. He was born in Montgomery County, Ill., in 1837, and was graduated from Hillsborough Academy in 1857.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- People are asking: "Is the King going to follow Emperor William's example and be a monarch in the true sense of the word?"

There is a phrase in our London correspondent's cable letter this morning that is calculated to set people thinking. Speaking of the good humor of the London crowd that, for the first time in a generation or so, had a chance to see a royal procession to open Parliament "in state," he observes that whatever else it might prove, it seemed to prove that the crowd was "not hungry."
