PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 16. -- Henry Branch, the Division Judge of the Twenty-first Election District of the Twenty-fourth Ward, Philadelhpia, for the year 1900, was arrested in this city to-day. The warrant cites the following offenses:

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- On what is said to be good authority, it was stated today that an Ohio syndicate headed by A. L. and Tom Johnson of Cleveland has purchased the right of way for a trolley line from New York to Philadelphia.

John B. Merrill, the District Attorney of Queens County, had alively tilt yesterday at Police Headquarters in Brooklyn with President Bernard J. York of the Police Board. Mr. Merrill said a number of cutting things to Mr. York, one of them being that the head of the Police Board prejudged police cases.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A correspondent, George Frazier Miller, commenting on the letter of Minister Wu Ting-Fang declining to attend the dinner of the Society of the Genesee in honor of Gen. Otis, says: "His letter was to a private body, and the ill, if there be any, attaches to the society for making the letter public."
The weekly statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $7,510,175. The banks now hold a surplus of $12,852,450 above the legal requirement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The French Ambassador entertained at dinner this evening. His guests were the Austrian Minister and Baroness Hengenmuller, the Minister from the Netherlands, the Secretary of the Russian Embassy and Mme. de Wollan, Mr. and Mrs. George L. Bradley, Mr. and Mrs. Richardson, Mr. and Mrs. Walsh, Miss Alice Hay, Miss Deering, Miss Wallach, Commander Faramond, and Capt. and Mme. Vignal.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 16. -- Halil, the "Terrible Turk," met with an ignominious defeat in a wrestling bout at Haughton's West End Coliseum last night. According to the terms of the match, the Turk was to throw six local men within an hour, or forfeit his right to any portion of the purse.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- Columbia University's gymnastic team met Haverford College in their second annual dual exhibition here at Witherspoon Hall tonight, and, although the entertainment was net of a competitive nature, it proved conclusively that the Gotham institution of learning is represented by a team of athletes skilled in all the arts of amateur gymnastics.

The week which has just come to an end was one of the most active of a very busy musical season. At the Opera House, in which the largest shard of public absorption is centred, the week was originally intended to be one of celebration of the genius of Meyerbeer. "Les Huguenots" was offered to a small audience on Wednesday night and "L'Africaine" was to have been brought forward on Friday.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 1. -- War between Russia and Japan is always threatening in this part of the world. It became imminent in June, when it was known that a Russian agent had acquired at Masampo, on the south coast of Korea, privileges by which he transferred to his Government the right to establish a naval station there.

The season is over. On Wednesday morning Lent begins, and it is popularly supposed that society bows its head, garbs itself in sackcloth trimmed with ashes, and repents of its follies committed in the long carnival. Lent this year is really a boon. The fashionable season has been phenomenal, even for New York.

SYDNEY, Jan. 17. -- With the end of the Commonwealth celebrations in Sydney the real work of the federated States has begun, and already the elements of political discord, which so largely impeded the work of union, are becoming apparent. That the refusal of Mr. Barton to join a Federal Ministry under the leadership of Sir William L. Lyne was dictated by a desire to secure the Federal Premiership for himself, is now generally admitted.

Just as our ancestors, becoming disgusted with eating their fellow-creatures, one fine day left off serving them up to their tables; just as now, among flesh-eaters, there are many who refuse to eat the flesh of man's noble companion, the horse, or of our fireside pets, the dog and cat -- so it is distasteful to us to drink the blood and chew the muscles of the ox, whose labor helps to grow our corn.

There was a largely attended meeting of real estate and other business men at the Real Estate Exchange, on Montague Street, Brooklyn, at noon yesterday, to urge the repeal of the mortgage tax law. George E. Lovett presided at the meeting, which was addressed by Supreme Court Justice William J. Gaynor and Hermanus B. Hubbard, Justice Gaynor said in part:
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Sir Francis Cook (Viscount Montserrat in Portugal, and head of Cook Son, warehousemen, who married Tennessee Claflin of New York,) is dying. He was born in 1817.

From The Pall Mall Gazette. Both in "debt" and "doubt" the "b" is the result of sixteenth century pedantry. In all our earlier literature these words, which came to us through the French and not direct from the Latin, were correctly spelt "det" or "dette," "dout" or "doute."

"Taxation -- Existing and Pending Legislation Thereon." was the subject dismissed in ten-minute speeches by the speakers at the fifth annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of Brokers of the City of New York, which was held at the Hotel Manhattan last evening. Over 150 guests and members of the board gathered in the banquet hall.

Wilson P. Foss won the Class A amateur billiard championship of the United States last night for the second year. As holder of that title he met his challenger, C. Fred Conklin of Chicago, who earned the honor of playing the title holder in the deciding Class A championship by his victory over all the other competitors when the regular tournament finished on Friday night.

The address of Dr. SCHURMAN at Binghamton on Friday evening has aroused renewed interest in the question of "the friars" in the Philippines. Practically Dr. SCHURMAN takes the same view of the situation as did President TAFT of the Civil Commission. There is reason to think that it is the view to which the Administration is also inclined.

Through its admirable defense Columbia's reorganized hockey team, composed of former substitutes, made a remarkably good showing against Yale in a championship hockey match at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. While Columbia held Yale down to 5 goals, she herself was unable to tally, making the final score 5 to 0 in favor of the blue.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 16. -- President C.M. Schwab and H.C. Frick are expected home from New York to-morrow morning, after spending the greater portion of the week in that city in connection with the Carnegie Morgan deal.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Chairman A.C. Bartlett has announced the personnel of the National Joint Committee on Conciliation, and Arbitration in Industrial Affairs, to settle labor disputes throughout the country, which was authorized by the conference recently held in Chicago, under the auspices of the National Civic Federation.
Louis Stern gave a dinner last night at his residence, 993 Fifth Avenue, in honor of Gov. B.B. Odell, Jr. Those who assembled as Mr. Stern's guests to greet the Governor were:

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Lake Street Elevated practically monopolized the attention of traders on the local Exchange to-day. On the appearance of good-sized buying orders the stock opened at 14 3/8, and later advanced to 16, closing at 15 3/4. About 3,600 shares were traded in during the two-hour session, of which about 1,600 were handled at the best price of the day.

From The Spectator. Ireland was much infested with wolves, down to a period comparatively recent. That noble dog, the Irish wolfhound, has been bred from remote times for their destruction. Lord William Russell records in his diary that in 1596 he and Lady Russell went wolf hunting at Kilmainham -- quite close to the capital!

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of the visitors at the Harlem Dispensary, which is situated at the foot of One Hundred and Twentieth Street and the East River, having occasion to call frequently for treatment and not less frequently for medicines; yet, were it not for poverty, which compels me, the accommodations there extended could not induce me to go again after an initial visit.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- At the conclusion of the morning hour in the Senate to-day, when the unfinished business -- the Shipping bill -- was laid before the body, Mr. Spooner moved to proceed to the consideration of the Oleomargarine bill. By a practically unanimous vote the motion prevailed. Thus the Subsidy bill was displaced as the unfinished business, and the Oleomargarine bill was placed in that order.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "Believer" in his letter, headed "Missionaries and Their Ways," dated Feb. 7, makes this statement: "I know the trouble in one of the large provinces of China was mainly due to the tactics of the Roman Catholic missionaries, who with one hand tried to force the Chinese into their Church and with the other to rule the community with a rod of iron."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate or 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser, assumes payment of the mortgage.

PEKING, Feb. 16. -- A message from the Chinese Plenipotentiaries was delivered to the foreign Ministers before their meeting this morning. It contained the wording of an edict, dated yesterday, practically reiterating the recent dispatches. It sentences Prince Chung to commit suicide and Yu-Hsien (former Governor of the Province of Shan-Si) to be executed, both in the presence of a high Government official.

CRESCENT CITY, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Dr. W.L. McLeod and his wife were found dead in their residence this morning, The evidence disclosed that McLeod had killed his wife and then himself. Neither of the couple had been seen since last Saturday, and an investigation was made to-day by the Mayor and Sheriff.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You hit the nail on the head in your "Topics of the Times" comments on the Kansas situation in Tuesday's TIMES where you say: "The Topekans are not the victims of tyranny and oppression. They chose the officials they have, and if they do not like them they can get better without any bloodshed or violence."

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- The old cup defenders, the Columbia and Defender, now lying at the Hawkins yard, will, it is understood, soon undergo changes for the coming trial races against the new cup defenders now being constructed. In a few weeks the interior of the cabin of the Columbia will be completely overhauled and refitted, and other new attachments will be added throughout the boat.
"I hate," once remarked Confucius," the reddish-blue -- lest it be confounded with vermilion!"

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Enthusiasm ran high at the twelfth annual indoor meet and games of the Boston Athletic Association, in Mechanics' Hall, here, to-night, when a crowd that packed the great building to the doors gathered to witness contests that, from the number of entries and the many athletic organizations represented, had something of the aspect of a National tournament.

RALEIGH, N.C., Feb. 16. -- An extraordinary case of mistaken identity has just been developed here before Justice Montgomery of the Supreme Court in the case of George Johnstone, a white man, who has been unlawfully confined in the penitentiary for the past eight years.

There is a story belonging to the year 1790 or thereabout which illustrates the absolute lawlessness of the mob. A man living in Wapping, just outside the Tower of London, which was always garrisoned by troops, gave offense to his neighbors by complying with some obnoxious law. He received a warning that they intended to attack him, by which they meant that they were going to murder him.

Addison Cammack loved much to dwell upon the activities of his earlier days, seeming even fonder of relatively insignificant triumphs in his youth than of fortunes made in bigger fights in later Wall Street days.

The first strand of wire to be strung across the East River on the new bridge from anchorage to anchorage is ready. Engineer William Hildenbrand of the Roebling Company, which has charge of the cable construction, said yesterday that the wire could be shipped to this city from Trenton on a few hours' notice, and the work of placing it in position could be quickly done.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent "Dover Plains" evidently betrays himself as a Ramapo advocate when in his lugubrious communication he writes that "there are other sources of supply, any one of which would be really less expensive than this." Pray, let us hear from him where those places are.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Intimate friends of Mr. Richard Croker openly declare he will never re-enter active political life in America. Those who have seen Mr. Croker recently noticed his general physical weakness, which is said to be a form of nervous melancholia, entirely opposed to his usual activity.

The sentiment which animated the diners at the annual banquet of the American Protective Tariff League, held last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria, was pithily expressed by Senator Thurston of Nebraska, when at the beginning of his speech he proclaimed in a voice of contentment:

Mrs. Helen W. Watts, President of the American Female Guardian Society and Home for the Friendless, has been sued by a former teacher in one of the schools maintained by that institution for slander and libel. The former teacher, Elizabeth Foley, wants $10,000 damages, declaring that Mrs. Watts has kept her from obtaining any other position.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Announcement has just been made of the abandonment of the system of meteorological stations which have been maintained in connection with the Peruvian station of the Harvard University Observatory. The object for which they were established has been in large part attained, and, with the exception of the station at Arequipa itself, all will be given up.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 16. -- Judge Benet has created another sensation in South Carolina by a charge delivered recently to the Grand Jury in Anderson, and published to-day, in which he sets forth the existence of a system of contract slavery in Andersen County, which is characterized as lawless and an enormity.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Parliament has not been opened for a quarter of a century with such pomp as attended the ceremony last Thursday. Our new monarch evidently delights in pageants, and one car hardly realize that merely a fortnight has elapsed since the nation appeared to be mourning for the late Queen.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 16. -- The taking of testimony was continued to-day in the suit brought by the Honduras Company of Georgia against the Honduras Syndicate, a corporation of this State, for an accounting and transfer of all beneficial interests.

The ship subsidy has been killed for this session. It died hard. All possible influence was used to save it. Party discipline was exercised as strictly as the leaders dared and party ties were tightened until there was danger that they would snap. Collateral interests were summoned to the aid of the subsidy seekers' syndicate.

No announcement in regard to the steel deal was made yesterday. Francis Lynde Stetson, in whose offices the chief conferences have been held, declined to say anything except: "No announcement will be made from this office. Lawyers do not in such circumstances recite what has been accomplished."

There will be a rush of corporations now organized under the laws of the State of New York to New Jersey, West Virginia, and Delaware if the corporation tax law now before the Legislature receives the signature of Gov. Odell. It is estimated that 1,000 domestic corporations will at once Start to organize in other States so as to save about $2,500,000 annually in State taxes.

BRISTOL, R.I., Feb. 16. -- The yellow metal sheathing of the Belmont boat now glitters over the greater part of her underbody, with some of the plates attached to the midsection up to the water line. In a few days more every plate will be adjusted in its specified place if progress is kept up to the standard of the past week.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- The Philadelphia market was ragged to-day. The feature was a rise in the stock of the Western New York and Pennsylvania Railroad, which the Pennsylvania bought at 9, to 12 in the effort on the part of some interest to corral the outstanding 20,000 or more shares.

The Democratic Club was crowded with politicians last evening for the first time since Richard Croker left for Europe. They were all discussing and comparing notes as to the sensational reports that Mr. Croker was a nervous wreck at his home in Wantage, England, and would never return to fight a political battle.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Feb. 16. -- Four hundred and fifty thousand spindles were represented at the meeting of the Southern Cotton Spinners' Association, held in this city to-day. The meeting was called for the express purpose of effecting a curtailment in the production of cotton yarns, and the result is that for four months from March 1 the production will be reduced very considerably.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The House to-day made little progress with, the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill. The major portion of the time was spent in debating a proposition offered by Mr. Hill, (Rep., Conn.,) to strike out the appropriating of $100,000 for the free transportation of silver coin.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- George E. Roberts, Director of the Mint, was the guest of honor at the meeting of the Bankers' Club at the Chicago Athletic Club this evening, and delivered an address which was greeted with many manifestations of approval by the members of the club and their guests. Speeches were also made by a number of local financiers.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 16. -- Johns Hopkins University is to have an Archaeological Museum. Hebrew friends of the university will enjoy the distinction of being among the first contributors. The principal feature of the nucleus just now is a fine collection of Jewish ceremonial implements with a handsome case, the gifts of Henry Sonneborn, which will be set up in McCoy Hall in a few days.

Under the auspices of the Beth-El Sisterhood, a concert and dance were given at Sherry's last evening. The affair was planned for the purpose of aiding the philanthropic projects of the sisterhood, which is now in the eleventh year of its existence. About 1,000 persons were present.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 16. -- President Gilman and the Trustees of Johns Hopkins University are now confident that the million-dollar endowment fund will be raised in this city, and thus assure the gift of land valued at $750,000 for the new site, made conditional upon the raising of the endowment.

It became known yesterday that Bert Reiss, a prominent lawyer and Republican of Brooklyn, who was an unsuccessful candidate for Congress last Fall, had been the victim of a clever forgery involving an industrial stock certificate on which a loan or $15,000 was made by the Hamilton Trust Company of Brooklyn.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The demand for money was brisk to-day, though less keen. The supply was not large. Discounts were easier on gold arrivals, and the promise of more from France. It is anticipated that the Bank rate will be 4 per cent, next week.

It was housewarming day in the new home of the Automobile Club of America yesterday, at 753 Fifth Avenue, which is the Plaza Bank Building, occupying the Fifty-eighth Street corner. The new quarters of the Automobile Club comprise the entire second floor, which has been entirely refurnished and decorated to meet the needs of the club.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The religious wedding of Paul Deschanel, President of the Chamber of Deputies, and Mlle. Germaine Brice. (who were married civilly on Feb. 13,) took place to-day in the Church of St. Germain des Pres. President Loubet and a most distinguished assemblage were present.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In one of your sub-editorial paragraphs wherein you make lengthy reference to an Englishman who has written a letter to The London Standard commending many American examples of enterprise, you make out that he is "disgraceful" in "profiting by all American privileges" without assuming any "American responsibilities."

"Faust," the beloved of the matinee girl, was given at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon to a very large audience. Those who so to the opera constantly find one curious, feature at all performances of Gounod's masterwork, especially when it is given, at matinees, and that is the number of persons present who appear never to have heard the opera before.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- Washington's Birthday will be celebrated in the usual way, at the Hotel Savoy. A musicale will be followed by a supper and dance. Andrew D. White, the United States Ambassador, is Chairman of the committee.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- Col. Peter S. Michie, Professor of the Department of Natural and Experimental Philosophy in the Military Academy, died this morning after a short illness from pneumonia. He was sixty-two years old, and had been on duty here as professor since 1871. He was graduated from the Military Academy in 1863, and stood second in his class.

Wall Street sentiment is divided. Most of the professional traders on the Stock Exchange are bearish, and there is an extended short interest. Customers of commission houses have also shown some inclination to take the short side. It is easy in Wall Street to be cynical, for there have been abundant experiences persuasive in that way, some of them not too remote.

The games of the past week made some interesting changes in the standing of the clubs in the local bowling leagues. The Knickerbocker Athletic Club bowlers, who two weeks ago stood last in the New York Interclub Bowling League series, have since won six games in succession, and now rank second in that league.

HAVANA, Feb. 30. -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention held a secret session lasting several hours this afternoon considering the question of the future relations between the United States and the Republic of Cuba. The commission which met Governor General Wood at Batabano last night offered no formal report, but asked that the matter be considered in Committee of the Whole.

Fred Ramsay of Seventy-eighth Street and Fourth Avenue, Bay Ridge, and James Fulton, who lives on the Shore Road neat the foot of Seventy-ninth Street, spent four hours yesterday floating about in the Narrows on a cake of ice, which had broken off from the mass of ice packed about the shore at the foot of Seventy-ninth Street and floated out into the current before they could leave it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The last week but one of the present session of Congress will be an exceedingly busy one in the House. Much business remains to be disposed of, and the inevitable crowding which characterizes the closing hours of a Congress has begun already. The appropriation, bills, so far as the House is concerned, are in fairly good shape.

The fight against the Ramapo Water Company will be made in the Legislature this week. Politics will play a prominent part in the struggle, as the leaders, both Republican and Democratic, see in the Ramapo fight a chance to make party capital to be used in the Mayoralty contest this Fall.

PEKING, Feb. 17 -- A few days ago Count von Waldersee wrote to the Generals under his supervision notifying them to have all their available troops ready in two weeks for an expedition lasting eighty days. Today Gen. Chaffee and Gen. Voyron, the French commander, received letter's asking for their co-operation, and expressing a desire to know what forces they can spare.

A fire which started from some unknown cause shortly before midnight last night gutted the six-story brick storage warehouse at 49 Dean Street, Brooklyn, which is the property of the estate of George J. Muller, who died about a month ago.

Wilson P. Poss demonstrated conclusively in the Class A championship final match on Saturday night in the Knickerbocker Athletic Club that he is still the peer among amateur billiard players in the United States. Notwithstanding an abnormally slow start, when Poss did get going he reeled off points with a rapidity that made Conklin's game appear second rate, and it clearly had a depressing effect upon the Chicago champion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The statistics of the meeting of the Executive Committee of Arrangements for the inauguration of President McKinley give an idea of the extent of the coming demonstration. There will be 19,000 military in line, regulars and State organizations. Of civic organizations there will be 54, with 3,904 men, accompanied by 37 brass bands.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 17 -- The famous trotter, Early Bird, 2:10, arrived here to-night, to make the season in Kentucky. He came with a carload of other fine horses from New York. Among the lot was an imported thoroughbred stallion for Col. Milton Young, several head for John E. Madden, and a number to be sold at the Woodard and Shanklin sale here this week.

Mayor Van Wyck's disapproval of the Single-Headed Police Department bill was sent to Albany on Saturday evening by registered mail. Accompanying the bill is a message in which the Mayor states his reasons for vetoing it.

Unless some reciprocal agreement is reached between the United States and Russia whereby the American discriminating tariff against sugar imported from Russia and the Russian retaliatory excess duty of 30 per cent. on American iron manufactures may be moved, it is regarded by those In the steel and iron business that the Russian tariff will operate as an almost absolute prohibition against this line of trade between the United States and the Muscovite nation.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- That new loan was managed with delightful skill by our financiers and the Stock Exchange, and everybody is now going about declaring: "The muddle was only what you might expect. Our Chancellor of the Exchequer is an excellent farmer, but he knows no more about finance than about circle sailing."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The consolidation of more than half the railroad mileage of the country into a "community of interest" raises the inquiry as to the outcome of this tendency toward combination. Will it end in government ownership of these public utilities or will it result in positive regulation of all common carriers on a basis that will protect the public, while recognizing the property rights of the stockholders?

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Feb. 17 -- A suit for ejectment brought by W.E.T. Smith and others of the Manor of St. George, Brookhaven, against John J. Bartlett of Greenport, who represents the Brooklyn Water Syndicate, for the possession of Carman's River, the largest stream in the system bought by the syndicate three years ago, came before Justice Wilmot M. Smith in Special Term of the Supreme Court here yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Gov. Odell arrived in Albany to-night. When informed of Mayor Van Wyck's action in returning the Police bill Gov. Odell said he had no comment to make.

At the Temple Emanu-El, Fifth. Avenue and Forty-third Street, Dr. Joseph Silverman, the rabbi, took as his text yesterday morning the recent discussions by Minister Wu and Felix Adler concerning the relation of Christianity to Confucianism. In his discourse he endeavored to show how both the Chinese and Christian codes of ethics had sprung originally from Moses and were intimately connected in most essentials with the Jewish system of morals.

The large crowd of spectators who journeyed to the Harlem River Speedway yesterday morning in anticipation of seeing some lively brushing between the crack trotters and pacers of the road were disappointed, as the footing was so heavy that it was exceedingly dangerous to start a horse.

Willful misunderstanding or willful misrepresentation are charged by Miles M. O'Brien, President of the Board of Education, in his reply to the published report of the Merchants' Association of New York on the management of the public schools of the City of New York.

A large audience heard an address by Robert C. Ogden on "The Need of Individuality" delivered before the People's Institute at Cooper Union last evening. Mr. Ogden said that in looking over the list of speakers of the institute he noticed that he was the only man selected from the people.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Four negroes, who are alleged to be burglars, were arrested here early this morning, and are now in the county jail. The arrests were made by Policeman Herman Baar and Simeon Van Wettering, a builder.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The Boerse last week showed less demand for State funds, prices declining slightly until Friday, but yesterday there was a marked improvement. Imperial threes closed 8 prennigs down for the week, and Prussians 65. Among foreign rentes, Mexicans weakened upon the rumored illness of President Diaz.

Mrs. Katherine Montgomery, fifty years old, a domestic employed at 692 Third Avenue was probably fatally burned last night, and the entire tenement house was thrown into an uproar of excitement by a small fire resulting from an exploding oil lamp. Mrs. Montgomery was taken to the Flower Hospital by Dr. Brosier, who says she has little chance of recovery.

M. Gaston Deschamps, one of the bestknown literary reviewers of Paris, is now in America, where he hopes to tell students of the French language something about the theatre in France, and incidentally gain impressions of American life and character. He arrived yesterday on the Aquitaine and will be for a day or two the guest of James H. Hyde.

At the feast of the American Protective Tariff League on Saturday evening a special and successful effort was made to have the varied and toothsome fare entirely of American origin. The influence of the viands and the wines was perhaps responsible for the tendency of the speakers to recognize the necessity of tariff reform in a very general argument that such reform should be trusted only to friendly hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Lawyers of experience here who have observed closely the habits of the Supreme Court of the United States will not be surprised to see that court take more time than is generally believed will be the case to reach a conclusion on the so-called Porto Rican cases, involving the right of the United States to collect customs duties on goods imported from that island.

In so far as money market conditions are concerned there is no warrant, representative bankers declare, for any apprehension. Rates may temporarily work somewhat closer, but as for any actually high rates, much less any stringency, all the testimony is that that is quite out of the bounds of possibilities.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 17 -- Shrewd observers in St. Petersburg believe that the Russian Minister of Finance. M. De Witte, in imposing a discriminating duty on American manufactures of iron and steel, was animated not only by a desire to protect Russian sugar producers, but was eager to seize an opportunity to mobilize Russia's industrial army, with a view of proving its ability to stand the test of a tariff war.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Feb. 17 -- Col. Roosevelt was in Colorado Springs today, the guest of P.B. Stewart, who was one of the members of the hunting party in Rio Blanco County during the first three weeks of the ex-Governor's outing. A public reception will be tendered him in this city to-morrow afternoon at 5 o'clock.

-- Over in Trenton, which is in New Jersey, there is published a newspaper named, very modestly, as Jersey modesty goes, The Daily True American. To The Daily True American there came, of a day this week, one asking how the United States was compensated for abolishing slavery.
"Despite adverse criticism -- due, maybe, to partisan or political reasons -- I believe that New York is to-day the best governed city in the world."

A vision test was made at Arlington, N. J., by his physicians yesterday on the Rev. John Keller, who was shot by Thomas G. Barker. It was found that with his left eye the minister could distinguish objects such as a pencil, a watch, and a book. At how great a distance he could do this was not tested lest in the effort the patient strain the eye.

Firemen had to help a number of people to escape flames by fire escapes at 116 and 118 West One Hundred and Third Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues, a handsome apartment house, late yesterday afternoon. Five thousand dollars' damage was done, and the firemen worked three hours before they extinguished the blaze.
The argument as to the unconstitutionality of the Police bill, which the Mayor has sent to Albany with his veto of the bill, is a strong one.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Northeastern Saengerbund, taking in the territory of New York, Albany, Brooklyn, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Camden, Troy, and Washington, met here to-day, thirty-eight Directors being present. Major Karl Lentz of Newark, the President of the Directory, presided.

It is to be regretted that the generally admirable recommendations of the Charter Revision Commission, and especially those relating to the reorganization of the administration of the schools, should have been complicated with the change proposed in the regulation of teachers' salaries.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Stirred to a sense of the necessity for immediate action, the Illinois Manufacturers' Association will endeavor to assemble the leading manufacturers of agricultural implements in the United States in Chicago at an early date for the purpose of discussing the retaliatory tariff which the Russian Government intends to place in effect on March 1.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- At the Clearing House to-day balances between banks loaned at 2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 10@12 1/2 cents per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $16,069,700, against $10,742,945 a year ago to-day, and the balances were $1,413,020. The banks' statement shows excess reserve of $1,895,286, a decrease of $509,000.

Mrs. NATION has been for some weeks a joke. She has commonly been considered a pretty good joke. But nevertheless the joke has always been on Kansas. To have a grandmother going about and smashing property with impunity, and bearding the Governor in his den, and all that sort of thing, was evidently incompatible with a high state or even a tolerable state of civilization upon the part of the community which suffered it.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18 -- David J. Brewer, Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, delivered the fourth lecture in the Tale course this afternoon, on the "Responsibilities of Citizenship." He discussed the question of strikes, also the overriding of the law in lynchings and the exhibition of popular indignation over the lawlessness in the State of Kansas, Referring to the latter, Justice Brewer said in part:

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- When the debate on the address in reply to the King's speech was resumed in the House of Commons yesterday, Lord Cranborne, Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, said that Great Britain's principal interests in China were commercial.

Yesterday, for the carnival week, was not Well filled with social events. In fact, it was rather dull. Among the dinners was one given by Mrs. Francis McNeil Bacon for her sister, Mrs. Van Rensselaer Cruger. The opera was well patronized, and there was one dance -- that given by Gen. and Mrs. Lloyd S. Bryce for their daughters, the Misses Claire and Leila Bryce.

This week's engagement of Olga Nethersole's company in St. Louis, where it will play "Sapho," will terminate the season for this organization. The early and sudden disbanding of the company is due to the illness of Miss Nethersole. She will undergo a serious operation some day this week.
ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- There was an unusually large attendance at to-night's session of the House. In the absence of minority leader Frisble, that position was filled by Mr. McKeown of Kings.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- An invitation, association is to be formed, consisting chiefly of the larger athletic clubs, colleges, and rowing clubs. The plan has been developed to the present stage by those most actively interested at the Boston Athletic Association and the Union Boat Club.
CHARLES A. LELAND, former ex-State Representative and Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of New Mexico for a time, died at his home at Caldwell, Ohio, yesterday of consumption.
PEKING, Feb. 18 -- Great preparations are being made by the various commanders preparatory to the big expedition, especially in the matter of transportation.
LONDON, Feb. 19. -- The Berlin correspondent of The Daily Mail claims to have official authority to deny that it is seriously intended to send any expedition into the interior of China.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62@63c. There were no sales.
Charles Lanier, Treasurer of the Hospital Saturday and Sunday Association, reports the following additional contributions to the collection, still in progress:

TARLAC, P.I., Feb. 18 -- The United States Philippine Commission decided to-day that it would not be wise to postpone the organization of the provincial government in the Province of Tarlac. As the first step in the work of organization, the commission determined to appoint an American as Governor of the province, the selection falling upon Capt. Wallis O. ClarK of the Twelfth United States Infantry.

Active trading in the outside market yesterday was confined to three or four prominent issues while the rest of the list supplied but a small amount of business. Prices were irregular, but the majority of the day's changes were on the side of gains. In several instances the net advances were quite large.

Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy's counsel began their final effort to disprove the charge of murder hanging over the dentist yesterday by introducing in evidence the testimony of several of the accused man's fellow-residents of Staten Island, who swore positively that they had seen Kennedy on his way home at the time when, as the prosecution claims, he was at the Grand Hotel, where Dolly Reynolds met her death.

A poolroom concern on the second and third floors of the building 20 Dey Street was raided yesterday afternoon, during the height of business. This time there was no timely tip. The police learned of it only after actual raiding had begun by Detective Sergeants, who met District Attorney Philbin half an hour before under the impression that they were to hunt a murderer or to trace an escaped lunatic.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senator Hale, (Rep., Mc.,) Chairman of the Senate Committee on Naval Affairs, to-day introduced a bill for the revival of the grade of Vice Admiral in the navy, and authorizing the President to appoint two Rear Admirals to that office.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- Mayor Van Wyck's message vetoing the Police bill was handed down in the Senate to-night. It was not read and will not be printed. It was announced from the desk that Mayor Van Wyck's veto had been received and immediately the Chairman of the Cities Committee, Senator Stranahan, arose and said:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Republican members of both the Senate and the House are discussing the prospect of an extra session, with some serious references to the course of the Congress just approaching an end, and they do not find anything to encourage them in advising that the country should be asked to contemplate another Congress at work, imitating the tactics of that about to expire.

Army. Changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical Department: Major William P. Kendall, Surgeon United States Volunteers, will proceed to Fort Slocum, N.Y., and report to the commanding officer of that post for duty and to the commanding General, Department of the East, to relieve Capt. Charles M. Gandy, Assistant Surgeon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The Senate Committee on Commerce to-day concluded the consideration of the River and Harbor bill. Action upon several amendments heretofore adopted has been reconsidered and various House provisions recast, until the total appropriations have been reduced below that made by the House.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The House to-day, under suspension of the rules, passed the bill appropriating $5,000,000 for the Louisiana Purchase Exposition, which is to be held at St. Louis. The vote on the bill was 191 to 41.

The sixtieth competition for the Abeel trophy, the Seventh Regiment's historic prize for rifle teams of ten men, was completed last night, with the result that the trophy was transferred from the custody of Company D to the keeping of Company B through the superior marksmanship of the senior team of the successful company.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18 -- It seems to be settled beyond much doubt that Harvard will enter Weld and Newell crews and some singles in the American Henley at New London if the affair is held late in June and money enough can be raised. As it stands now Harvard, through the Weld and Newell leaders, has given a provisional reply.

The police of the Bronx, who, with the assistance of over seventy bicycle policemen, specially detailed for the purpose, have been hunting for weeks for a gang of men who have been robbing women there, think that at last they have succeeded in getting their hands on two of the highwaymen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- While the House to-day was considering the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill, Mr. Cannon, (Rep., Ill.,) Chairman of the Appropriations Committee, made a general statement regarding the status of the appropriations for this session. He was led to make it, he said, by remarks made in the Senate, (referring to Senator Hale's statement.) He said the situation was quite bad enough without exaggerating it.

Not unnaturally yesterday's stock market was nervous. Quotations ruled weak. At one time serious recessions were recorded. This was true especially of the iron and steel group. Indeed, it was chiefly on account of iron and steel uncertainties that the general market showed softness.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- The setting up of the Lawson boat in the shed at the Atlantic works will be delayed a few days because the stern post received last Friday has warped a trifle in the casting, and is not true. To make sure that there would not be any trouble with the rudder, which might not hang well on a post not perfectly true, it was decided to have another cast.

According to Dr. Allan McLane Hamilton, the alienist, a belief in Christian Science is a form of insanity, and he says, furthermore, that this form of insanity is likely to be contagious. The examination of Christian Scientists in the Brush will contest before Surrogate Fitzgerald was suspended part of the day yesterday in order to allow Dr. Hamilton to give expert testimony for the contestants.

The Subcommittee on Transportation of the Industrial Commission appointed by the President and Congress to investigate, the methods and conditions of the large industries or the United States began its New York. sessions at the Chamber of Commerce

The decision of "the Allies" in China to pursue the Chinese Government to its fastnesses is very sudden, very surprising. But the explanation is not novel at all, but many generations old. "Behold, my son, with how little wisdom the world is governed." That is a sentence which has been handed down as the utterance of a Chancellor of the sixteenth century.

With an attendance that included all the most arent devotees of racquets of New York, Boston, and Philadelphia, the racquet tournament for the National Amateur Championship began yesterday morning in the court of the Racquet and Tennis Club of New York, in West Forty-third Street, near Fifth Avenue.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 18 -- Mardi Gras festivities were begun formally to-day with the arrival of Rex and his retinue. The flotilla, consisting of some twenty vessels and a large number of tugs and excursion boats, arrived at the head of Canal Street at 2 o'clock.

If the ears of Richard Croker and other Tammany Hall officials did not tingle last night it was no fault of the speakers who addressed about 300 persons who attended the meeting which marked the opening of the Harlem headquarters of the City Democracy, better known as the "Jimmy O'Brien Democracy," at 50 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- There was Republican rebellion in the Assembly to-night. It occurred on the bill introduced by Mr. De Graw of Brooklyn, "to repeal Section 41 of the Penal Code, relating to the failure to file candidates' statements of election expenses."

TOPEKA, Feb. 18 -- To-night Mrs. Nation is in the county jail because she refused to give $2,000 bail under a peace warrant procured by the cold storage firm into whose place she and her crowd of "Home Defenders broke yesterday. Her day was spent in the courts.

One important step has been taken incidental to the formation of the "Billion Dollar Steel Trust." That colossal undertaking proposes more than merely the consolidation of leading iron and steel making plants. That is most important and by far the biggest thing in view; but the plans under way are comprehensive enough to include the acquirement of control of certain coal and iron railways operating in what will be the giant trust's territory.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Fully five hundred guests to-night attended the Assembly at the Arlington. The ball was voted the most successful of many years. Mrs. Elkins acted as hostess of the evening, receiving the guests in the first of the Vermont Avenue suit of parlors.

LONDON, Feb. 19 -- The first division in the first Parliament of King Edward VII., which took place yesterday, resulted in cutting down to 45 the Government's normal majority of 130. The interest caused by this unexpected event was heightened by Winston Spencer Churchill's first speech at Westminster and by a heated defense by Mr. Chamberlain of his own policy.

-- Moved by the revival in the Senate of the Sampson-Schley controversy, the editor of The Naval Service Gazette has decided to make public the details of a conversation which he had with Rear Admiral, then Commodore, SCHLEY on board the Brooklyn the day after CERVERA'S fleet was destroyed, while the thunders of the conflict were still ringing in the ears of that vessel's officers and men.
DEWEY THEATRE -- The Dainty Duchess Company is presenting an interesting olio, followed by a burlesque called "Queen of Bohemia."

Justice David McAdam in Part I. of the Supreme Court yesterday disposed promptly of the last vestige of an excuse for not taking down the portico and inclosed balcony of the Pabst Hotel, in Forty-second Street, between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, which squats on public property worth $34,000.

The Anti-Ramapo bills now before the Legislature have been made Democratic Party measures, and the Democratic Senators and Assemblymen from New York and Kings County received instructions yesterday to vote and work for their passage.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- The exercises connected with the graduation of the first class of cadets at the Military Academy took place in Cullum Memorial Building to-day, in the presence of the entire battalion and scores of their friends. The address to the class of seventy-three members was delivered by Gen. John R. Brooke, commanding the Department of the East, who also delivered the diplomas.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- In speaking to-day of his recent order imposing a countervailing duty on Russian sugars, Secretary Gage said:

It cannot be pleasing to Gov. ODELL and his immediate political advisers that in the game of politics now playing with reference to the police, Tammany, on the first appeal to the public reason, has distinctly scored.

The defense in the case of Jesse R. Davis, one of the Bellevue Hospital nurses charged with having caused the death of Louis H. Hilliard in the Bellevue insane pavilion on Dec. 12, was begun at the afternoon session yesterday, in Part II. of the General Sessions Court, before Judge Cowing and a Jury.

Abram S. Hewitt delivered the opening address on the subject of "The Children of New York " yesterday afternoon at the opening ceremonies of the National Exposition of Child's Work, in the Mechanics' Library Building, 18 East Sixteenth Street.

Two matches were rolled in the tournament of the New York Interclub Bowling League series last night, the New York Athletic Club team winning three games from the Harlem Wheelmen on the wheelmen alleys, and the Harlem Republican Club team winning two of their three matches with the Catholic Club five on the Republican Club alleys.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 18 -- The first production on any stage of Mary Johnston's "To Have and to Hold" took place here to-night at Nixon Zimmerman's Academy. The audience was one of the largest ever in the theatre, the entire seating capacity being sold before the opening of the doors. The house was distinctively a fashionable one, and it was most enthusiastic in its demonstrations of applause.

"Chief Devery has no intention of retiring or of acquiescing in any action of the board to this end. He will stick to the last. If any act of Legislature removes him from office he will leave the department without a pension. But he will seek legal redress for any deprivation of office which an enactment like the single-headed Police Commission bill might bring about."

It seems to us that Mr. GAGE has been hasty in courting reprisals from Russia by his action in imposing additional duties on the imports of sugar from that country on account of alleged export bounties.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 18 -- The Circuit Court to-day handed down its decision in the action brought by the Arbuckles, the New York coffee men, to have the Woolson Spice Company declared to be in contempt of court for refusing to allow the Arbuckles to examine its books.
The Minneapolis and St. Louis Railroad has joined the Western Passanger Association.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- United States Ambassador Choate saw the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Marquis of Lansdowne, yesterday afternoon, and discussed the Chinese and Nicaragua Canal questions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial to-day on the teachers salaries you say that the 4 mills provision of the Davis act is not a valid objection to that famous measure. Under that provision this year the Board of Estimate and Apportionment was compelled to appropriate some $400.000 in excess of the amount necessary for the payment of the teachers' salaries.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19. -- Prices for local stocks, as a rule, were steady on the morning call. Lake Street stock opened at 15 1/4, sold to 15 1/2, and closed at 14 7/8. The debenture bonds brought 100 1/4 and the incomes 57. Much of the buying of these securities apparently is of a good character.

Dr. Ashley A. Webber of Brooklyn and Stephen M. Van Allen of Jamaica, N.Y., of the New Utrecht Rod and Gun Club, met at Inter-State Park yesterday in a one hundred live pigeons shooting match for a stake of $200. Van Allen killed his twenty-five birds straight in the first quarter of the race, and was then made the favorite in the betting, and won by the comfortable margin of six birds.

The second annual indoor tennis championship meeting under the auspices of the United States Lawn Tennis Association was begun yesterday afternoon at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Six matches in the preliminary round and two in the first round were decided and some excellent play was seen.

Rural American drama has not developed greatly since the era of "The People's Lawyer," which in time resolved itself into the sketch called "Solon Shingle." A false accusation of theft was the dramatic basis of the emotional scenes of that old play, and the same incident serves well enough in Mr. Hoyt's much later piece, "A Midnight Bell," which has been successfully revived by the stock company at the Murray Hill Theatre this week.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- The bill to reapportion the Congressional districts of the State will be passed upon by special committees of the Legislature before it is introduced in the Legislature. The Senate committee will consist of five members to be appointed by the Lieutenant Governor and the Assembly committee of seven members to be designated by the Speaker.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- The hearing before the Assembly Committee on Cities to-day on the bill introduced by Senator Foley for the relief of John Williamson, assignee of the claim of the Jamaica Electric Light Company against the City of New York for electric light furnished to the city, brought out the story of a clever political trick.

The significant fact about the raiding of the gambling place in Dey Street is that it succeeded, so far as it was successful, because the police had no chance to permit a friendly warning to the offenders.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- When the debate on the address in reply to the King's speech at the opening of Parliament was resumed in the House of Commons yesterday, the Right Hon. Herbert Henry Asquith, (Liberal,) the ex-Home Secretary, characterized the speech of the Secretary of State for the Colonies, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, delivered on Monday evening, as a revival of the "billingsgate of the general election."

MONTREAL, Quebec, Feb. 19. -- The movement to dispute the possession of the Island of Anticosti by M. Menier, "the Chocolate King," has been recommenced. A petition was recently drawn up and addressed to Mr. Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, urging that the Island of Anticosti should be expropriated and fortified by the imperial authorities as a military post to command the entrance of the St. Lawrence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of a Scotsman in to-day's TIMES calls for a few words of comment. I am an Englishman by birth, but an American citizen. As an Englishman, I am satisfied to be counted one among a community made of all sorts of nationalities, and having no aspirations beyond the plain integer.

ALBANY, Feb. 19. -- The Senate Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment will to-morrow morning report favorably on the amended tax bills, that will, if they become law, net the State in the neighborhood of $3,000,000 annually. The bills are the acts taxing insurance companies, savings banks, and trust companies.

Evidence collected yesterday from witnesses caught in the great raid on the Parole Turf Club at 20 Dey Street, Monday afternoon, pointed to a very prominent city official as one of the backers of the place, and his arrest is likely to be an outcome of the affair, according to Assistant District Attorney Schurman.
Alfred Burrows, a member of the Consolidated Exchange, doing business at 71 Broadway as a stock broker, made a general assignment yesterday to Washington I. Conklin for the benefit of his creditors.

Mayor Van Wyck and Controller Coler and the Dock Board, of which J. Sergeant Cram is President, are likely to become involved in a dispute over the action of the Dock Board in authorizing condemnation proceedings to the amount of $12,000,000, unless the latter body takes speedy action to keep within its appropriation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The House to-day devoted considerable time to the Sundry Civil Appropriation bill. The item appropriating $100,000 for the investigation of underground currents and artesian wells in the arid land regions and the preparation of reports upon the best methods of utilizing the water resources of those regions led to a debate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The United States has made its protest against the proposition to send an army to invade Singan-Foo. It is in the form of a statement of the American position, which Minister Conger has been directed to present to the envoys at Peking. This, it is stated, is equivalent to the issuing of a new identical note.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It does seem as if there were brains enough in Congress to see the impropriety of lumbering up the National statutes by a never-ending list of bills as to the edibles of the earth, when one law would serve every purpose and work no injury to trade or manufacturing.

LONDON, Feb. 19. -- Money was fairly plentiful to-day and in good demand. Discounts were somewhat steadier. There was less talk of large receipts of gold from Russia and France, and there was a growing impression that, even with a reduction in the bank rate, the open market quotations are not likely to be much lower.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In calling the Englishman's failure to naturalize himself here disgraceful the writer of "Topics of the Times" does go too far, even for jocularity; so that it is no wonder he has provoked emphatic protests.

The Sub-Committee on Transportation of the Industrial Commission, now holding sessions in New York at the Chamber of Commerce, has been assured that J. Pierpont Morgan will go before the committee and testify. It is expected that Mr. Morgan will to-day communicate to the committee notice of when he will be able to testify.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The most brilliant social season of many years came to a close to-night with a state dinner at the White House, a fancy dress ball given by the Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Hill, and innumerable dinner parties.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- In the Assembly this morning, Speaker Nixon made a change of reference of Mr. Ahearn's Dollar Gas bill for Troy from the Cities Committee to the Gas, Electricity, and Water Supply Committee.

Professional pressure was again brought to bear upon the stock market yesterday, the campaign in this direction being helped by a variety of disturbing rumors. One of these told of threatened labor troubles in the anthracite district, another once more paraded a "hitch" in the steel deal; while, as on recent days, the tight money bugaboo was continued, in service.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 19. -- A fire which occurred in the Seventh Avenue public school here this morning caused considerable excitement for a time among the 600 scholars and 13 teachers. The fire started in one of the hot-air radiators on the first floor, but was seen by the Principal, Mr. Shaffer, before it had gained any headway.

Madison Square Garden was transformed into a little kingdom of dogs yesterday. It was a kingdom of aristocrats, nearly 1,500 dogs, all possessing long pedigrees, making a new record for the annual exhibits of the Westminster Kennel Club. The spectators, for the time being, were the subjects, and they acknowledged the sway of the dog by paying admiring court to him, in countless breeds and varieties.
A person vaguely described as a Senator gives to our neighbor The Sun a concise summary of the situation in the Legislative Department of the Government at Washington:

Mr. HEWITT has had an experience common to all men who become known as philanthropists either in practice or by precept. Since his address giving advice to rich men on the use of their wealth he has received several thousand letters, not asking for advice but for money.
Details in regard to the purchase of the Boreel Building by the Central Realty Bond and Trust Company will be found in another column.

It is likely that there was a good deal of searching of hearts among the members of the British Ministry when, on a critical division, it was made to appear that a majority of only forty-five remained to it after it had just resumed power with a clear majority of something like a hundred.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- The publication of the fact that the use of the Pension Bureau will cost the Government $35,000 and stop the pension business for several days, giving the employes a vacation not contemplated by law, has moved Representative Bell of Colorado to point out some other expenses incurred by the conversion of the Pension Bureau into a ballroom for the inauguration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While our lawmakers are casting around their Argus eyes searching for something more to tax, one cannot but ask why it is that the cat always escapes their notice, while the faithful dog is so persecuted. Because in rare instances some one of his tribe has been seized with hydrophobia, he must be tagged and muzzled.

MILL WOOD, Kan., Feb. 19. -- In a raid on a "joint" here by twenty masked men, heavily armed, late last night, Mrs. Rose Hudson, wife of the bartender, was Instantly killed. William Webb, one of the raiders, was shot through one arm, and two or three of his companions were slightly wounded. Young farmers composed the party.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 19. -- The House Committee on Municipal Corporations gave a hearing this evening on Assemblyman Kirkbride's bill permitting the construction of a boulevard along the ocean front, passing through Ocean Grove. A number of residents of Asbury Park and other points along the shore spoke in favor of the measure.

One of the fastest, most exciting, and most bitterly contested championship hockey matches of the season was played at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening, when the New York Athletic Club defeated the Brooklyn Skating Club by a score of 3 -- 1. Apart from the real issue of the game, protests were many. Capt. Howard of the New York Athletic Club began the matter by protesting Drysdale, the cover point on the Brooklyn seven.

A settlement has at last been reached in the litigation which has been carried on for some years by Thomas F. Ryan against the consolidation of certain Southern railroads into the greater Seaboard Air Line system, of which John Skelton Williams is President. The settlement was made under a decision of Daniel S. Lamont, Vice President of the Northern Pacific Railway, as arbitrator on the points in issue.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 19. -- The Republican Assemblymen held conferences to-day on the anti-Spring Elections bill. Mr. Meeker sought to have immediate action taken on a substitute bill drawn by him to correct some of the imperfections of Bill No. 234, and, in addition, providing that an outgoing Mayor shall not make appointments of any officers whose terms commence after the expiration of his own term.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- In the House of Commons last evening, in the debate on the address in reply to the King's speech. Thomas O'Donnell, Nationalist, Member for West Kerry, began a speech in the Irish language. The Speaker called him to order after he had spoken three or four sentences, reminding him that to speak Irish was an unknown practice in the House of Commons.
LONDON, Feb. 20. -- Commenting editorially upon various dispatches from and in regard to China The Times says:

One of the largest real estate deals of recent years was effected yesterday in the purchase of the Boreel Building, covering the entire block bounded by Broadway, Cedar, Thames, and Temple Streets, by the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company. The property has been held at $2,500,000, and while the exact consideration in the present transaction is not made public, it is said to be little less than that figure.

A fire which broke out on the third floor of the four-story brick building 253 and 255 Bowery, last night, caused much excitement among the large audience on the first and second floors known as the Empire Music Hall. The two upper floors are occupied by the owner and manager of the place, Casper Iba. He was in the gallery of the music hall when a waiter informed him of the fire.

BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- At the Clearing House to-day, balances between the banks loaned at 2 per cent., and New York funds sold at 15@16 2-3c per $1,000 discount. The exchanges were $24,189,747, against $21,871,505, a year ago to-day; the balances were $l,465,476. The stock market was slow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -- At a meeting of the Academy of Political and Social Science to-night, the subject for discussion was "The Isthmian Canal." The most interesting paper read was that of Col. Peter C. Hains of the United States Army.

That is a very good work which Mr. COLER has been doing within these past few days. It issued, yesterday, in the announcement that the repeal of the Ramapo act of 1895 had been made a party measure by the Democratic Party. "Blessed are they that sow beside all waters."

After terrorizing the occupants of his mother's boarding house with a big revolver, Albert St. John, twenty-eight years old, of 193 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, himself received a wound that may result fatally. Incidental to the affair, Detective Charles T. Belger of the Fifth Avenue Station had a narrow escape from being mortally wounded.
Efforts to still further strengthen the alibi Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy's counsel have been building up for the dentist accused of the murder of Dolly Reynolds two years ago, were continued yesterday.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., Feb. 19. -- A sixty-foot steam yacht is being laid down at the Jacob yard for E.H. Weatherbee designed by Cary Smith. The yacht will be of shoal draft, capable of speeding about fourteen or fifteen knots per hour. The boat will be principally for daily use between the owner's Mamaroneck residence and New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -- At a meeting of the University of Pennsylvania Rowing Committee to-day to take action regarding the sending of a red and blue crew to row at the Henley regatta this year the result of the discussion was that the project met with the approval of the entire student body and college in general and that the eight would go if $4,000 is guaranteed within the next thirty days.
Dr. GEORGE L. KIRBY, Superintendent of the State Hospital at Raleigh, N.C., died there last night. He had been Superintendent since 1894.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 19. -- To marry the man she nursed back to health four years ago, Miss Maybel Manley, niece of Joseph H. Manley, Vice Chairman of the Republican National Committee, slipped away from her home, in Menominee, Wis., and came to St. Louis. She is now the wife of Dr. W.A. Borland of Nashville, Ark. The wedding took place last night at the Planters' Hotel.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I find that your columns contain this morning yet another sermon abstract on the relative merits of the religious teachers that form the title of this letter.

OMAHA, Feb. 19. -- The police have under arrest James Callahan, charged with complicity in the abduction of Edward Cudahy, Jr., on the night of Dec. 18, 1900. Callahan was arrested last Saturday, but the police have kept it a secret until to-day in the hope of securing other arrests.

PITTSBURG, Feb. 19. -- The latest labor move in the great steel combination is the announcement that President T.J. Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association, with a committee of officers, will leave for New York this week to persuade Mr. Carnegie to have inserted in the transfer of his holdings a clause permitting the organization of the employes of the combines by the Amalgamated Association or any labor organization.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19. -- A resume of the operations of the Pension Department of the Pennsylvania Railroad for the first year of its operation has been published. There was authorized to be paid in pensions during the year $244,019,97. The retirements during the year numbered 1,292.

Dr. Frederic A. Cook, the arctic explorer, returned yesterday on the steamship Oceanic, having been on a visit to Belgium. In Brussels he attended a meeting of the scientists interested in the recent Belgian expedition toward the north pole. More than a hundred men assembled for the meeting, all of them contributing something for the report of the venture that is being published by the Belgian Government.

With the exception of three or four prominent issues yesterday's market for outside securities showed little activity. In parts of the list decided weakness developed, and closing prices in many instances were considerably below those of the previous day. The steel stocks were all at a lower level, reflecting the declines which occurred in the steel stocks traded in on the Stock Exchange.

The Police Commissioners yesterday left the Headquarters of the force swept and garnished for the single-headed commission, In one session they dismissed the charges against Capt. John D. Herlihy by a vote of three to one, President Bernard J. York voting against such action, thereby securing Inspector Adam A. Cross against charges and trial as Herlihy's superior officer.

Charles McNamara, a taxpayer of 272 Flushing Avenue, Long Island City, applied to Supreme Court Justice Wilmot M. Smith yesterday for an injunction to restrain Highway Commissioner James P. Keating from tearing up the highway on Jackson Avenue, to remove the pipes of the Woodside Water Company.

Commissioner Peter F. Meyer came to the defense of the Dock Board yesterday and accused Controller Coler of bad faith in announcing to the Board of Estimate on Tuesday that he, Mr. Coler, had recently discovered that the Dock Board had authorized condemnation proceedings to the amount of $12,000,000 prior to the enactment of the law giving the Board of Estimate jurisdiction in such matters.

Thomas L. Greene, Vice President of the Audit Company of New York, and Thomas F. Woodlock, railroad editor of The Wall Street Journal, were the witnesses heard by the Subcommittee on Transportation of the Industrial Commission at the Chamber of Commerce yesterday. At the conclusion of Mr. Greene's testimony, Committeeman John L. Kennedy stated:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Mr. Lentz (Dcm., Ohio.) precipitated two sensational debates in the House to-day in the course of the consideration of the General Deficiency Appropriation bill.

Ash Wednesday is never an exhilarating occasion in society. Yesterday was no exception to the rule. It was very dull indeed. The meeting of sevying classes and the regular Wednesday at the Knickerbocker Bowling' Club were perhaps, the only diversions of moment. Even the opera was not well patronized by society.

The statement of Mr. HERMAN SIELCKEN published in THE TIMES yesterday iluminates the Russian sugar tariff situation. The justification of Secretary GAGE'S course in imposing the countervailing duty on Russian sugar, which prompted the Russian Government to levy retaliatory and prohibitive tariff rates on our iron and steel products, depended upon a question of fact.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- In his inaugural message Gov. Odell advanced his belief that there had been profligacy in State expenditures. He pointed out some instances of which he had knowledge in which the State's funds had been improperly spent. One of the extravagances cited by him was the too free engagement of special attorneys.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 20. -- Special Master in Chancery Schuyler B. Jackson has filed his report with the Chancellor advising that Dr. Herman Cohn be given a decree of divorce on the ground of desertion. The story told by the testimony shows that the young physician met his wife while studying for his medical degree at Columbia.

Hedwig Lange, the popular young actress of "emotional" and tragic characters in Mr. Conried's German company, acted the title role in a translation of Sardou's "Fedora" at the Irving Place Theatre, for her benefit, last night. There was a large and demonstrative audience, and the general performance has not been surpassed in dexterity and finish by the Irving Place players this season.

SAMUEL CAMPBELL, a broker of this city, died suddenly yesterday at his home, The Lindens, South Orange, N.J. He was the eldest son of the late George W. Campbell, and was in his fifty-ninth year. He leaves a wife and a son and a daughter.

These are troublous days for the Brooklyn trolley car conductors who absent-mindedly pocket fares without registering them. Some of the stockholders of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company have become worried of late at running across conductors in Wall Street watching quotations and toying with the market.

There was a large attendance at the annual meeting of the Larchmont Yacht Club, held at Delmonico's, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, last night. The prizes won during the past year were exhibited and were greatly admired, particularly the Postley Cup for the seventy-footers, won by Yankee.

In the tournament of the Life Insurance Bowling League on Ehler's alleys last night the Mutual Life Insurance Company-team No. 2, won three games and lost one. The Mutual Benefit team won two games and lost two, the Fidelity and Casualty team won two games and lost one, and the Germania team lost three games.

MANILA, Feb. 20. -- At Pagsanjan, Province of Laguna, yesterday, Lieut. Vaughan of the Thirty-seventh Infantry arrested Fernando Rustan. General Agent of the Tabacaleria Company, on the charge of having aided the insurgents. Abundant documentary evidence against the prisoner has, it is asserted, been secured.

Five unhappy looking detectives caught by District Attorney Philbin in his unexpected raid on the poolroom at 20 Dey Street Monday, which the five and three companions had been assigned to obtain evidence against, spent an uncomfortable quarter of an hour each in a little star chamber inquisition conducted in the law library of the District Attorney's office by Justice Jerome yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- Opponents of the Hatch bill to abolish side doors of saloons, and remove the screens, lined up in force this afternoon at the hearing given by the Assembly Excise Committee on the bill.

Evidence of the vast resources of the local National banks is found in their reports of their condition Feb. 5, instant, furnished at the call of the National authorities. The hank statement of last Saturday gave aggregate figures which showed that deposits in the associated banks amounted to more than $1,011,000,000, against $821,018,100 in 1900, and $897,172,300 in 1899.

BOSTON, Feb. 20. -- Money is comparatively quiet. Clearing House rate, 2 per cent. New York funds, 10 and 15 cents discount. Call loans, 3@3 1/2; time money, 4 1/2@ 5. Clearing House exchanges, $24,217,716; balances, $2,074,432. The stock market closed strong.

There was a jolly party gathered at the Democratic Club last evening. The politicians "in the know" who heard the talk carried on in such a happy way between Mayor Van Wyck and Police Commissioner John T. Sexton declared that at the present time Sexton was way ahead of the other candidates in the race for the Police Commissionership under the new bill, which is sure to become a law in about ten days.

Play in the indoor lawn tennis tournament for the National championships in the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street, was continued yesterday until the gray twilight made invisible the white-covered balls, but, pushing the contests as fast as possible, the preliminary sets still were uncompleted.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The Asphalt Trust has made a strong plea to the Suite Department to reconsider its determination not to intervene in Venezuela. It has been bringing great pressure to bear upon the department to make it change its attitude and compel the Venezuelan Government to take action favorable to the trust without submitting the question to the courts.

The evidence of censored dispatches and a Knowledge of the deep-rooted causes of the Spanish situation indicate that the tranquillity is all on the surface. Unless remedial measures be at once substituted for those of strangulation. Spain may soon experience the terrors of a civil war of almost infinite complication.

LONDON, Feb. 21. -- The reported determination of the House of Representatives at Washington to inquire into the question whether the United States has broken the treaty of 1871 by permitting the exportation of horses, mules, and cither supplies to the British forces in South Africa has created more academic interest than practical concern in the Government departments here.

RANTOUL, Ill., Feb. 20. -- Fisher, a little hamlet in the northwest corner of Champaign County, was to-day the scene of a bold bank robbery which was nearly successful. At 10 o'clock this morning, Arthur Hyer, a tough, living at Fisher, entered the private banking institution of F.B. Vennum, and, presenting a revolver, compelled the cashier to hand over all the money at hand.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- At the regular monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the Lehigh Valley Railroad Company to-day W.S. Bissell of Buffalo tendered his resignation, and H. McK. Twombly of New York was elected as a Director in his place. Mr. Twombly was also made a member of the Executive Committee.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- In the Senate to-day the Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment reported favorably the Insurance Tax bill and the Sayings Banks bill, with amendments as heretofore outlined, and the Trust Company Tax bill. The bills now become general orders and may be passed on Friday.

Richard Wagner's immortal comic opera, "Die Meistersinger," was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time this season. The audience, despite the fact that M. Jean de Reszke's inability to sing was announced yesterday morning, was one of good size. This was as it should be.

Fast and scientific play in the racquet tournament for the National amateur championship in the court of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club, with the results in doubt until officially announced by the referees, yesterday made competitions of a nature to delight the athletes and racquet enthusiasts who crowded the gallery.

Mrs. Augusta E. Stetson, "chief healer," "first reader" or pastor, and the business head of the First Church of Christ, Scientist, made some startling statements yesterday in the contest over the will of Miss Helen C. Brush. She tried "Christian Science mind reading" in court. Her subject was John M. Bowers, the lawyer opposing the Church.

The property of the Board of Home and Foreign missions of the Presbyterian Church, at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, having frontages of 131 feet on the avenue and 150 feet on the street, has been purchased by Thomas F. Ryan, President of the Morton Trust Company, through Broker John N. Golding, for about $400,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The arrangements for the wedding of Miss Anne Depew Paulding, niece of Senator Depew, and Lieut. John R. Edie, United States Navy, which was to take place at St. John's Church in this city on April 17, have come to a sudden end, and, according to a statement by Senator Depew this evening, the engagement is canceled.

Second Lieut. Pierce A. Murphy, Seventh Cavalry, now on duty at the United States Military Academy, will proceed to Philadelphia and report to Lieut. Col. David J. Craigle, Eighth Infantry, recruiting officer, for recruiting duty, to relieve First Lieut. Melvin W. Rowell, Fifth Cavalry, who will join his troop.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- In the Senate to-day the Babcock Assembly concurrent resolution asking the United States Senators to support the Grout Anti-Oleomargarine bill was received. Senator Ellsworth spoke against the idea of advising United States Senators, and moved that the matter be laid on the table.
The Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad yesterday published its annual report for the year ending Dec. 31, 1900. The income account for 1900, compared with that of 1899, shows:
