One of the appropriation bills introduced this session which are most worthy to arrest the attention of the thoughtful patriot, is that for the support of the Military Academy. And this, among other reasons, by reason of its extreme modesty. While millions are flying about, it is still the day of small things at West Point.

BOSTON, Feb. 20. -- Gaston Deschamps's first lecture, in Sanders Theatre this afternoon, was attended by a large audience of students and of people from Cambridge and Boston. "Les Maitres du Theatre Contemporain" was the subject which the distinguished critic chose, and he treated of Augler, Dumas fils, Meilhac, Halevy, and Sardou.

The stubborn defense of Samuel J. Kennedy, on trial for the second time for the murder of Dolly Reynolds in the Grand Hotel two years ago, ended yesterday with the final appeal for acquittal made to the jury by Lawyer Robert Moore in summing up the accused dentist's case.

Capt. John D. Herlihy, formerly of the Eldridge Street Station, has been exonerated by the Police Board of the charges brought against him, which grew, out of the letter sent to Mayor Van Wyck by Bishop Potter, who complained of an alleged insult to the Rev. Mr. Robert L. Paddock, rector at the Pro-Cathedral, in Stanton Street, and of the immoral conditions prevailing in the "Red Light" district.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The conferences held by Ambassadors White and Choate with the Foreign Ministers at Berlin and London, in which the Chinese question is said to have been touched upon, were probably the result of dispatches sent to them by the State Department, in which the instructions to Minister Conger were repeated.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 20. -- The vigilance of officers was all that saved "Slick" Slater, a white man, twenty-seven years old, from being lynched by an infuriated mob tonight. He assaulted seventeen-year-old Lottie Gerberick Monday evening, and was captured by Topeka officers the next day in Carbondale, twenty miles from here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The suggestion of a park at what is now known as Fort George is a very deserving one. Unfortunately it is too late to preserve any but a very small part of the fort itself, which chiefly occupied the ground on Which is now seated a charitable institution.

That is a very curious semi-official explanation of the Graf VON WALDERSEE'S threat to take the road once more and "punitively" kill a number of Chinamen and Chinawomen, and punitively burn a number of Chinese villages, which is conveyed from Peking by the explanation that this threat upon the part of the esteemed Field Slarshal was a "bluff," intended to accelerate the progress of the slow negotiations.

The first session of the annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association was held yesterday morning in the small ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The session was devoted to routine business, and the reading of reports, principal among which was the report of the Secretary, W.C. Bryant of The Brooklyn Times.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Feb. 20. -- Vice Chancellor Reed has signed a decree ordering the sale of the Cape May, Delaware Bay, and Sewell's Point Railroad Company, the trolley line along Cape May's beach front. This sale is made to satisfy the claims of the holders of the $300,000 of bonds of the company, on which interest has not been paid for some time.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- The air about the Capitol to-day was thick with the vapors of Ramapo. The Democratic opposition had on full steam. As soon as the Assembly opened Mr. Fitzgerald, on behalf of the minority, put in a bill which is an exact copy of the Morgan Repeal bill, which is now before the Assembly Cities Committee.

Jesse R. Davis, one of the Believue nurses charged with the death of Louis H. Hilliard, who is being tried on a charge of manslaughter in Part II of the Court of General Sessions, went on the stand in his own behalf yesterday and told the story of the death of the insane patient.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20. -- There was a somewhat general decline in stocks to-day, nearly the whole list selling off slightly. The largest trading was in Philadelphia Electric. The bond department was quiet. In the main the prices for investments held firm, although the Asphalt issues looked weaker.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- A marvelous system of State canals, the boats to be run by electricity and to be 100 feet long by 25 feet wide, with a draught of 10 feet, and to travel in fleets going from Albany to Buffalo in less than three days, is the plan presented by State Engineer Bond and a capable board of engineers to Gov. Odell.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Three saloons in this city were damaged to-night by admirers of the methods of Mrs. Carrie Nation. The total damage suffered by the three proprietors will amount to several hundred dollars. The smashing was done in each instance by a different person and necessarily so, as the police gathered in the smashers with great promptitude and locked them up.

The statement made by President Maurice F. Holahan of the Board of Public Improvements after the raid on Levien's poolroom on Monday afternoon last led to revelations yesterday. Frank, the alleged wayward son, whom Mr. Holahan was looking for when District Attorney Philbin was looking for Levien and his fellow-clubmen, talked.

BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- Mrs. Marion Butters, who operates a laundry for the cleansing of fine fabrics at 774 Columbus Avenue, will soon come into possession of $200,000. The fortune was left by her husband's father, who stipulated that his daughterin-law should be his heir only on condition that she did not marry again.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- The survivors of the wreck of the third section of the "Nellie Bly Express" were brought to Camden, N.J., in a special train. Six of the injured were removed to Cooper Hospital, and the others who could stand the journey were transferred, and after an hour's wait in Camden were taken to Atlantic City along with the passengers who were not hurt.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 21. -- The Commercial Gazette has received from its New York staff correspondent the following statement:

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- In the Assembly today Mr. McKeown of Kings offered an amendment to the bill of W.H. Smith to widen and improve One Hundred and Thirty-fifth Street, west of St. Nicholas Avenue, which was on the order of third reading. Mr. McKeown said his amendment would prohibit the construction of railroads upon that thoroughfare after the improvement was made.

The bill jointly Introduced at Albany by Senator MARSHALL, and Assemblyman WILSON, providing that passengers in surface and elevated railroad cars in Brooklyn who are not provided with seats shall be carried and transferred for a fare of 2 cents, while from those who are seated 5 cents may be exacted, suggests some perplexing complications as likely to result from it should it become a law.

WEST POINT, Feb. 21. -- The Academic Board of the Military Academy has passed a resolution of regret at the death of Prof. Peter S. Michie, who, the resolution declares, "exemplified in Ms official and private life those qualities of integrity, devotion to duty, and professional intelligence which this Academy seeks to impress upon its graduates."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The Senate today discussed the resolution offered by Mr. Jones (Dem.. Ark..) to discharge the committee on Judiciary from consideration of the so-called Anti-Trust bill and to proceed to the consideration of that measure. There was considerable debate on the resolution, but no action was taken.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In the discussion of the General Deficiency bill in the House to-day a long dispute arose over some items for extra pay for certain employes of the House. Mr. Maddox, (Dem., Ga.,) Mr. Loud, (Rep., Cal.,) and others endeavored to ascertain what extrea work these employes had performed.

In the neighborhood of Jefferson and Lewis Avenues, Brooklyn, last night everybody was singing the praises of sixteenyear-old Elsie Wanner because of the pluck she displayed at a fire which partially destroyed her home, 494 Jefferson Avenue, yesterday. The girl was painfully burned as a result of her courage in working to rescue members of her family.

The annual banquet of the New York Lumber Trade Association was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. Gov. Odell was the guest of honor. He arrived nearly an hour late, having missed a train at Albany. The Governor held a brief reception and received about 200 lumbermen.

When coffee and cigars came on, one of the party at the table had a story to tell of how F. Hopkinson Smith, on one of his trips last Summer, had a little fun with a party of drummers that were occupants with him of the buffet car of a train bound for Chicago. Mr. Smith was dressed in rather unconventional fashion, in a suit that was noticeable because the figure was a large plaid.
ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- These bills were introduced in the Senate to-day:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Gen. F.V. Greene is busy here every day arranging the details of the inauguration parade, and every day brings some new report of additions to be made to the line of paraders. After much discussion and consultation of precedents it has been decided that when the President and Presidentelect goes to the Capitol on the morning of March 4, he will be accompanied by Senator Hanna.
The labors of the Tammany Committee of Five may soon come to an end, according to a statement made yesterday by Lewis Nixon, Chairman of the committee. Mr. Nixon said:

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- The State Board of Railroad Commissioners, under an act passed by the last Legislature, to-day authorized the Fifth Avenue Stage Coach Company to make several extensions of its line in New York City as follows:

Confirmation of the report that England is likely to accept the Hay-Pauncefote treaty as amended by the Senate would be received with much satisfaction by sober-minded Americans. Her acceptance of the treaty would not only make it possible to undertake the construction of the canal, but it would remove a probable cause of ill-feeling between the two countries, which is a matter of greater importance even than an isthmian canal.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The new Apollo Theatre, of which Mr. Lowenfeld is manager, was opened last evening with "The Belle of Bohemia." The audience was distinguished by the presence of many members of the Diplomatic Corps and people prominent in the theatrical world. The entire house was filled by invitation, no seats being sold.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Senator Mc-Comas's inclination to help the passage of the bill to revive the grade of Vice Admiral in the navy, with the expectation that it will be followed immediately by the advancement of Rear Admirals Schley and Sampson, does not appear to have provoked extended opposition from the friends of Rear Admiral Schley, although they are aware that if two nominations are made Sampson's will come first.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21. -- One of the worst collisions in the history of the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad occurred at about 5:30 o'clock this evening, at Rusling's Siding, near Bordentown, and about eight miles south of Trenton. The "Nellie Bly" express, from New York for Atlantic City, came into collision with passenger train No. 330, running from Camden to Trenton.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- Among the cases decided by the Supreme Court at Springfield to-day is the test suit brought to determine the limit of bonded indebtedness the city may incur under the new revenue law. The court sustains the decision of the lower court, which was adverse to the city, denying the right of the Council to add to the present debt.

The Sub-Committee on Transportation of the United States Industrial Commission, which has been holding sessions in New York, and one of the principal objects of whose coming here was to hear testimony from J. Pierpont Morgan, has decided that, owing to the pressure under which Mr. Morgan is now placed in planning the great steel trust, the powers of the commission will not be exerted in securing his testimony this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Gen. F.V. Greene is busy here every day arranging the details of the inauguration parade, and every day brings some new report of additions to be made to the line of paraders. After much discussion and consultation of precedents it has been decided that when the President and Presidentelect goes to the Capitol on the morning of March 4, he will be accompanied by Senator Hanna.

At just about the hour for the beginning of the matinge performances at the "con-, tinuous" vaudeville houses In" New -York yesterday all the "White Rats", struck. The "Rats" were a large proportion of the performers scheduled to go on during the afternoon and evening. Such a scurrying around for actors and actresses then resulted as has seldom, if ever before, been known in New York.

Gov. Odell left Albany yesterday without signing the Single Headed Police Department bill. The Tammany politicians and Mayor Van Wyck waited all day to hear that the Governor had made the bill a law, and it was said at the City Hall that the Police Commissioner had been decided on and would be named by Mayor Van Wyck at once.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Presiding at the annual meeting of the South Durham Iron and Steel Company, Limited, at Stockton yesterday, Sir Christopher Furness, the Chairman, said he did not fear the effect of the Carnegie and Morgan Steel Trust.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21. -- The survivors of the wreck of the third section of the "Nellie Bly Express" were brought to Camden, N.J., in a special train. Six of the injured were removed to Cooper Hospital, and the others who could stand the journey were transferred, and after an hour's wait in Camden were taken to Atlantic City along with the passengers who were not hurt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The afternoon session of the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution was occupied in the nominations of candidates for the several offices, and in the evening the voting was conducted. The results of the balloting will not be announced before to-morrow.

PEKING, Feb. 21. -- Prince Ching and Li-Hung-Chang, the Chinese plenipotentiaries, have received telegraphic instructions from the Court to notify the Ministers of the powers that an edict has been issued regarding the punishments of Chinese officials, in conformity with the demands made by the Ministers, as follows:

Hopkinson Smith, on one of his trips last Summer, had a little fun with a party of drummers that were occupants with him of the buffet car of a train bound for Chicago. Mr. Smith was dressed in rather unconventional fashion, in a suit that was noticeable because the figure was a large plaid.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- A new bill, not exempting mortgages entirely from taxation, but only imposing a tax of one-half of 1 per cent. upon them, instead of 2 1/2 per cent., will be the result of the hearing held This afternoon by the joint Committees on Taxation of the Senate and Assembly. Gov. Odell has signified his approval of such a measure, and its passage would insure his signature.
Gutman, Nathan Co., Baltimore, Md.; A. R. Dyott, notions and linens; 28 Howard Street: Everett House.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 21. -- After a prolonged debate to-day the Senate decided to leave out of the Post Office Appropriation bill all provisions for the establishment or maintenance of the pneumatic tube service, so that as the bill now stands the service will have to be discontinued after July 1 next.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The new Apollo Theatre, of which Mr. Lowenfeld is manager, was opened last evening with "The Belle of Bohemia." The audience was distinguished by the presence of many members of the Diplomatic Corps and people prominent in the theatrical world. The entire house was filled by invitation, no seats being sold.

There is something peculiarly narrow and Boeotian in the attitude of Senator HALE of Maine toward the pneumatic tube mail service. Senator FRYE, on Thursday, being in the chair, successfully employed the pending point of order to defeat the amendment to the Post Office Appropriation bill providing $500,000 for the service and repealing the law forbidding contracts for its extension.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The Senate today discussed the resolution offered by Mr. Jones (Dem.. Ark..) to discharge the committee on Judiciary from consideration of the so-called Anti-Trust bill and to proceed to the consideration of that measure. There was considerable debate on the resolution, but no action was taken.
Gutman, Nathan Co., Baltimore, Md.; A. R. Dyott, notions and linens; 28 Howard Street: Everett House.

HAVANA, Feb. 21. -- The Cuban Constitution, first submitted by the Central Committee to the convention at the public session of Jan. 21, was signed to-day. One copy was sent to Gov. Gen. Wood and the other placed among the records of the convention. The attendance was not large, falling considerably short of that of the opening day, and not equaling the attendance of many other public sessions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In the discussion of the General Deficiency bill in the House to-day a long dispute arose over some items for extra pay for certain employes of the House. Mr. Maddox, (Dem., Ga.,) Mr. Loud, (Rep., Cal.,) and others endeavored to ascertain what extrea work these employes had performed.

ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- Senator Plunkitt introduced a bill this morning which makes some radical changes in the New York City civil service schedule, especially in its application to civil war veterans. The bill provides that all rules adopted by the Municipal Civil Service Commission relating to Schedule G. wherein such schedule relates to applicants for employment who have not been assigned to any work during the year, shall not apply to civil war veterans.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21. -- Among the cases decided by the Supreme Court at Springfield to-day is the test suit brought to determine the limit of bonded indebtedness the city may incur under the new revenue law. The court sustains the decision of the lower court, which was adverse to the city, denying the right of the Council to add to the present debt.

The Rev. Dr. S.D. McConnell, rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, astonished his hearers by declaring, at a nooday Lenten meeting yesterday, that there were twice as many churches on Brooklyn Heights as there should be, and that they were not exerting one tithe of the influence they should exert.
BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The Vossiche Zeitung publishes a communication from a correspondent at Niu-Chwang, who says:

WASHINGTON. Feb. 21. -- After a prolonged debate to-day the Senate decided to leave out of the Post Office Appropriation bill all provisions for the establishment or maintenance of the pneumatic tube service, so that as the bill now stands the service will have to be discontinued after July 1 next.

Gov. Odell left Albany yesterday without signing the Single Headed Police Department bill. The Tammany politicians and Mayor Van Wyck waited all day to hear that the Governor had made the bill a law, and it was said at the City Hall that the Police Commissioner had been decided on and would be named by Mayor Van Wyck at once.

The more clearly Mrs. NATION'S performances are brought into the "keen sunlight of publicity" the less admirable do they appear. Her small Kansan joke of addressing the Judge, who was forced, doubtless much against his will, to take cognizance of her case, as "Your Dishonor" is not the best Kansan idea of a joke.

PEKING, Feb. 21. -- Prince Ching and Li-Hung-Chang, the Chinese plenipotentiaries, have received telegraphic instructions from the Court to notify the Ministers of the powers that an edict has been issued regarding the punishments of Chinese officials, in conformity with the demands made by the Ministers, as follows:

In the neighborhood of Jefferson and Lewis Avenues, Brooklyn, last night everybody was singing the praises of sixteenyear-old Elsie Wanner because of the pluck she displayed at a fire which partially destroyed her home, 494 Jefferson Avenue, yesterday. The girl was painfully burned as a result of her courage in working to rescue members of her family.

MANILA, Feb. 22. -- A. Riola, a Manila druggist, has been arrested and communications from Aguinaldo, dated in Isabela Province, Northeastern Luzon, have been seised in his store. The matter is being investigated, but the exact extent of the information thus supplied has not yet been disclosed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I read from time to time with much interest the various conflicting articles upon religious matters, and I eagerly seek to find some truths which I can make personal use of.

Confirmation of the report that England is likely to accept the Hay-Pauncefote treaty as amended by the Senate would be received with much satisfaction by sober-minded Americans. Her acceptance of the treaty would not only make it possible to undertake the construction of the canal, but it would remove a probable cause of ill-feeling between the two countries, which is a matter of greater importance even than an isthmian canal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Senator Mc-Comas's inclination to help the passage of the bill to revive the grade of Vice Admiral in the navy, with the expectation that it will be followed immediately by the advancement of Rear Admirals Schley and Sampson, does not appear to have provoked extended opposition from the friends of Rear Admiral Schley, although they are aware that if two nominations are made Sampson's will come first.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The afternoon session of the Congress of the Daughters of the American Revolution was occupied in the nominations of candidates for the several offices, and in the evening the voting was conducted. The results of the balloting will not be announced before to-morrow.

The Republican County Committee sounded the keynote of the organization on the Mayoralty contest at the meeting held last evening. The committee by unanimous action pledged itself to support a non-partisan municipal ticket, and to co-operate with all other organizations, social or political, to rid the city of the "extravagant" rule of Tammany Hall.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Presiding at the annual meeting of the South Durham Iron and Steel Company, Limited, at Stockton yesterday, Sir Christopher Furness, the Chairman, said he did not fear the effect of the Carnegie and Morgan Steel Trust.

No verdict having been reached, after many ballots by the jury, in the case of Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, charged with the murder of Dolly Reynolds, Justice Fursman, at 10:30 o'clock last night, ordered the twelve jurors locked up until to-day at 10 o'clock, when, if an agreement has been reached, he will open court to receive it.

The Sub-Committee on Transportation of the United States Industrial Commission, which has been holding sessions in New York, and one of the principal objects of whose coming here was to hear testimony from J. Pierpont Morgan, has decided that, owing to the pressure under which Mr. Morgan is now placed in planning the great steel trust, the powers of the commission will not be exerted in securing his testimony this week.
BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The Vossiche Zeitung publishes a communication from a correspondent at Niu-Chwang, who says:

At just about the hour for the beginning of the matinge performances at the "con-, tinuous" vaudeville houses In" New -York yesterday all the "White Rats", struck. The "Rats" were a large proportion of the performers scheduled to go on during the afternoon and evening. Such a scurrying around for actors and actresses then resulted as has seldom, if ever before, been known in New York.

BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- Mrs. Marion Butters, who operates a laundry for the cleansing of fine fabrics at 774 Columbus Avenue, will soon come into possession of $200,000. The fortune was left by her husband's father, who stipulated that his daughterin-law should be his heir only on condition that she did not marry again.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 21. -- One of the worst collisions in the history of the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad occurred at about 5:30 o'clock this evening, at Rusling's Siding, near Bordentown, and about eight miles south of Trenton. The "Nellie Bly" express, from New York for Atlantic City, came into collision with passenger train No. 330, running from Camden to Trenton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- At the instance of the United States Government the powers have accepted the principle that no further individual concessions of territory in China shall be sought or obtained by any one power without international assent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reference to your quotation in the "Topics of the Times" column of your esteemed paper of to-day, allow me to say that The Electrical World and Engineer writer seems to be very much at sea in regard to telegraph working. To talk of the slowness of telegraphy compared with telephony is absurd.

BOSTON, Feb. 21. -- Miss Anna Gardner, a famous abolitionist, died at her home at Nantucket last Monday, aged about eightyfive. She published the call for the first anti-slavery convention at Nantucket, at which Frederick Douglass made his first public speech, and she was contemporaneous with Fanny Wright, Abbie Kelly, and Susan B. Anthony in the anti-slavery agitation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- At the instance of the United States Government the powers have accepted the principle that no further individual concessions of territory in China shall be sought or obtained by any one power without international assent.

To the Editor of the New York Times: It is about time that Congress let the people of New York City know what they are going to do about that bill appropriating money for a new Post Office, which is only an investment and will be returned from the rent now paid by the branch station on, Lexington Avenue and the internal revenue office.

The statement made by President Maurice F. Holahan of the Board of Public Improvements after the raid on Levien's poolroom on Monday afternoon last led to revelations yesterday. Frank, the alleged wayward son, whom Mr. Holahan was looking for when District Attorney Philbin was looking for Levien and his fellow-clubmen, talked.

The Republican County Committee sounded the keynote of the organization on the Mayoralty contest at the meeting held last evening. The committee by unanimous action pledged itself to support a non-partisan municipal ticket, and to co-operate with all other organizations, social or political, to rid the city of the "extravagant" rule of Tammany Hall.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES's articles on the Venezuela asphalt controversy between the so-called trust, its American contestants, and the trust against the Venezuelans, are exceedingly interesting to Americans who are watching the diplomatic course of events.

-- A favorable repor't was made yesterday by the Assembly Codes Committee on the bill prepared and advocated by Mr. THERON G. STRONG and Capt. P. NORTON GODDARD of this city with the purpose of putting an end to that particularly despicable and harmful form of theft known as "policy."

HAVANA, Feb. 21. -- The Cuban Constitution, first submitted by the Central Committee to the convention at the public session of Jan. 21, was signed to-day. One copy was sent to Gov. Gen. Wood and the other placed among the records of the convention. The attendance was not large, falling considerably short of that of the opening day, and not equaling the attendance of many other public sessions.

At the first glance it would seem that Tammany was defying the decent sentiment of the city to the very utmost in its course as to the new police law. Later developments may permit a different interpretation of its action.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Hanna, in his address at the Lincoln dinner of the Republican Club at the Waldorf-Astoria last Tuesday evening on "The Business Man in Politics," praised those business men who aided him in the last two National campaigns, and advised those present to assist in the election of a successful business man as the next Mayor of New York.

No verdict having been reached, after many ballots by the jury, in the case of Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy, charged with the murder of Dolly Reynolds, Justice Fursman, at 10:30 o'clock last night, ordered the twelve jurors locked up until to-day at 10 o'clock, when, if an agreement has been reached, he will open court to receive it.

MANILA, Feb. 22. -- A. Riola, a Manila druggist, has been arrested and communications from Aguinaldo, dated in Isabela Province, Northeastern Luzon, have been seised in his store. The matter is being investigated, but the exact extent of the information thus supplied has not yet been disclosed.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Two ice yacht races were sailed this afternoon, one for first and second class yachts and the other for third-class boats. A fair breeze blew from the westward, but the boats carried full sail. The entries in the first class were George Coley's Rocket and James B. Weaver's Scud.
GEORGE P. HIER of Syracuse, formerly a cigar manufacturer, died yesterday at his home, aged seventy-five. He was one of the wealthiest citizens of Syracuse.

It wasn't exactly an affair where an expectant nation was besought in flawless rhetoric to observe or depart from -- as the case might be -- "the tradition and heritage of him whom we delight to call the father of his country, George Washington." Nor did the diners politely stand until the last had found his appointed place.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Bishop Potter of New York was the orator of the day at the University Day celebration of the University of Pennsylvania, held in the Academy of Music this morning. His subject was "The Wider Outlook." Bishop Potter gave a review of the life of Washington, and then, referring to "the situation which confronts the American scholar to-day," said.

Mr. HEPBURN of Iowa seems an egregious kind of lawgiver. It is true that he has rivals. But we do not know any member of Congress of whom the saying of Sir BOYLE ROCHE is more justified. "He never opens his mouth without putting his foot in it." The "Hepburn amendment" to the Nicaragua treaty was glory enough, one would suppose, for one session, or even for one Congress.

FANNY KENNISH EARL writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW; "It might not be amiss to suggest to your correspondent L.S. Mott in regard to Zangwill's 'curious mistake' that if Tennyson had not borrowed his 'crown of sorrow' from Dante, as shown by 'C.E.H.' in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Feb. 9, he might have borrowed it from Chaucer:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- A step which is believed to be a preliminary for the unification of the National Democratic Partywas taken to-night, when 200 Pennsylvania Democrats and some from other States met at a dinner in the Bullitt Building. No organization stood sponsor for the meeting and all shades of Democrats were represented.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Gov. Odell has pardoned Latimer E. Jones, who was convicted in New York in June, 1897, of forgery in the second degree, and sentenced to Sing Sing for five years and six months. His allowance for good behavior cut this sentence short, and if he had not been pardoned he would soon have been a free man.

Car No. 663 of the Sixth Avenue Electric Road, on its way north at 6:30 o'clock last evening, crashed into another car of the Forty-second Street cross-town line at Sixth Avenue and Forty-second Street with such force as to spill all the passengers of both cars in a heap and cause a panic among them in the scramble to get out.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- In the House of Commons yesterday the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick. Secretary of State for War. replying to Mr. Mansfield, (Liberal,) took occasion to offer an explanation regarding the retirement of Major Gen. Colvile, for which he (Mr. Brodrick) has been so much criticised.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- A mortgage tax to raise $12,500,000 is what is proposed in place of the exemption of mortgages from taxation. The new bill will provide for a tax of one-half of 1 per cent, on mortgages, and will be so drawn as to compel the mortgagee to pay the tax. Mortgages will be relieved from local taxation.
H.L. PINER, Austin, Texas, again calling attention to "The Misuse of Words," writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW:

Methodist ministers of the three local annual conferences, soon to meet, are agitating the question of the removal of the pastoral time limit, and there is much unrest in Methodism here and elsewhere in consequence. The New York Conference meets in Central Church, Yonkers. There are four very desirable openings, and under ordinary conditions first grade men from outside the Conference would be brought in to fill them.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Senator Morgan of the Committee on Foreign Relations has made a minority report upon the resolution declaring that the ratification of the HayPauncefote treaty is not a condition precedent to the construction of the Nicaragua Canal, and that the United States should proceed with that work regardless of the existence of the Clayton-Bulwer agreement.

With variable weather and wind, and light that was good, bad, and indifferent, according to whether the sun was out or snow flurries obscured the view, the conditions were trying to the last degree at the finish of the wing-shooters' competition for the National amateur championship and the William Payne Thompson Cup at the traps of the Carteret Gun Club, at Garden City, L.I., yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22. -- The celebration of the twenty-fifth annual commemoration day at Johns Hopkins this morning was especially signalized by the resignation of its President, Daniel Coit Gilman, and the announcement that friends of the university have almost succeeded in raising the fund of $1,000,000 necessary to secure the completion of the recent conditional gift to the university of a magnificent tract of land ror a new site for the institution.

On Feb. 13 and 14 Bangs Co. held an important sale, disposing of a large number of books of great value and interest. Chief among these, perhaps, was the uncut copy of the first edition, 1859, of FitzGerald's version of the "Rubalyat," which was sold for $260, as THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW said last week.

The case of Thomas Murray, as administrator of the estate of his son, William Murray, against Charles Heninger has been placed on the calendar in the Supreme Court for trial next week. According to the present schedule of the court, it will be called in Part VIII. on Monday next, and will be reached for trial on Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- A combination of the stained glass manufacturers of the United States was formed here to-day to fight the big glass trust. For several weeks the leading concerns in the glass decorative line have been negotiating with the trade in general to combine for protection against the giant trust.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22. -- The Pacific Mail steamer City of Rio de Janeiro ran on a hidden rock while entering the Golden Gate early this morning in a dense fog. She sank a few minutes after striking.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22. -- Millions of dollars will be added to the assessment rolls as the result of a decision just announced by the Supreme Court, which holds that the property of religious and educational institutions is subject to taxation under certain conditions.

The series of remarkable letters from a special correspondent sent to the United States by The London Times, which appeared in that journal during the Summer of 1900 and since the beginning of the present year, have just been republished in book form,* and their value as a contribution to current technical and commercial literature can thus be better appreciated than when read in installments.

Maurice Thompson died at his home, in Crawfordsville, Ind., a week ago yesterday. Ere this, most of our readers who may not have read his books have learned from the obituaries in the daily press that he was a charming interpreter of nature; in fact, his work may be said to bear the same relation to the naturalist as that of Mr. Henry James does to the rhetorician.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- In spite of the great secrecy with which the deliberations of the Cabinet are always guarded, it can be asserted that one of the subjects under discussion at yesterday's meeting was a dispatch from Lord Pauncefote which, it is understood, dealt with the probable attitude of the United States toward Great Britain's counter proposals in the Nicaragua Canal matter.

"I read in THE TIMES the other day a report from the United States Consul at Liverpool, I think, that jam had now become the national dish of the Britisher. Perhaps that is one reason for the increased demand for sweets that there is coming to the trade in all parts of the town just now," commented a member of one of the largest houses in the country that deals in fancy groceries.

It was easy to tell the prize-winning dogs yesterday at the Dog Show, in Madison Square Garden, for every pen which held a prize winner, whether it were first, second, third, or a club special, was adorned with tickets designating the honor won, and the merest novice had the satisfaction of making a critical inspection of the blueblooded canines.

Mr. Dutt's civic and literary standing is such as to recommend his book to the attention of intelligent readers. Of Indian birth and religion, he has acquired distinction in the Indian civil service, has been lecturer on Indian history at University College, London, Is a barrister of the Middle Temple, has translated the "Ramayana" and "Mahabharata" into English verse, and has written able books -- "Civilization in India" and "England in India."

Controller Coler was heartily cheered last night at the annual dinner of the Colonial Club when he rose to speak to the toast of "Our City." A few of the enthusiastic diners even shouted, "Mayor," "Mayor," thus giving voice to their personal preference for Mr. Coler as a candidate for the Mayoralty.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- The second annual National squash tournament for the championship of America, held under the management of the Court Tennis and Racquet Club of Tuxedo developed more interest than had been expected, owing to the entries of nearly all of the best squash players in the country.

For a time last evening the police of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station thought they might have another race riot on their hands because of trouble started between a gang of boys known as the "Market Kids" and various colored men in different parts of the precinct.

The Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury has sent a letter to the Collector of Customs in New York which embodies an interesting decision, for it confirms the prohibition of importing the Paris edition of "L'Aiglon," the American copyrights of the work in French being held by Brentano's.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- There is in the office of the State Controller "$13,000 worth of new metal furniture, put in by the Art Metal Construction Company of Jamestown, N.Y., under a contract for which no advertisement was made, and for which there was consequently no competition. It is understood here that two prominent members of the Legislature are large stockholders in the Jamestown Company.

If Lord LANSDOWNE were dependent upon the newspapers of the realm for his understanding of the amended Hay-Pauncefote treaty he might send it back to us with comments that would make even our not easily abashed Senate hold its breath. In fact, a Minister who took the view that the British newspapers take would be capable of anything.

Rounsevello Wildman was born on March 19, 1864, at Batavia, N.Y., being a son of the Rev. Dr. Edwin Wildman. He was educated at Genesee Wesleyan Seminary and Syracuse University. At the university he led his class in athletics.

The annual meeting of the American Newspaper Publishers' Association came to an end last night with the dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, which was the most successful and largely attended of any in the history of the organization.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Not the least of the holiday programme for to-day was the match play for the golf championship of South Florida. The defeats of C.B. Gory of Oakley and H.M. Forrest of Philadelphia were surprising, the first-named being beaten this afternoon by C.F. Watson of Essex County one up over twenty holes.

Few names so widely known as that of James Burnet, Lord Monboddo, are at the same time to the public intelligence names only. Beyond a somewhat facetious association of Monboddo with monkeys, and a recollection of certain trenchant animad-versions of the great Samuel, recorded by Boswell, the world, even the reading world, knows little of one of the most eminent of an eminent group of Scotsmen of the eighteenth century.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The annual exhibition of the Princeton gymnastic team wasAeld in the university gymnasium this afternoon. A large crowd witnessed the performance. "L'Eschelle," performed by C.A. Lyon, P.J. Jones, and J.K. Savage, was liberally applauded. J.K. Savage's club swinging, T.D. Cunningham's trapeze balancing, and P.A. Moore's baton swinging were all well received.

There has been placed on exhibition at the New York Society Library, 109 University Place, the first public library of New York. This is a curious collection of a little over 100 volumes, mostly theological, given by the Rev. John Sharp, "Chaplain to her Majesties Forts and Forces in the Province of New York, in America," under the Earl of Bellomont.

If it was Count WALDERSEE'S threat to start another punitive expedition, exceeding all its predecessors in savagery, which brought the Chinese Government to the terms of the allies, the "Commander in Chief of the Allied Forces in China" is, to that extent, to be congratulated.

M.B. ROBERTSON, Short Hills, N.J., writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW: "One word more upon the subject of 'A Novel Collection,' of which Sarah Jeannette Burke writes in your last issue. Undoubtedly, she is right in saying that the joys of such a collection 'rival those of the antiquarian or the lover of old china or Oriental draperies.'

The disaster which has befallen a student in the University of Princeton is an additional demonstration of the folly of plagiarism. The McClean prize of $100 is offered for the best-written of the eight junior orations. It has for more than a quarter of a century been the custom at Princeton to publish the winning oration in the Nassau Literary Magazine, which exchanges with all the other university magazines.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In to-day's TIMES "An Artist" writes a letter complaining at length of the fashion of disposing the hair at present usual among women. He explains why it is unnatural and what an architect would call "unconstructive," and deduces therefrom that it must be ugly.

Failing to reach an agreement as to the guilt or innocence of Samuel J. Kennedy, charged with the murder of Dolly Reynolds two years ago, twelve tired jurors, after twenty-three hours of continuous argument and consideration of the evidence for and against the defendant adduced in the three weeks trial, were discharged by Justice Fursman at 3:40 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

On Tuesday, Feb. 19, Miss Catharine Elmer Mills read at a meeting of the Morristown Chapter of the New Jersey Society of the Colonial Dames of America a paper by Mrs. Sarah Ellen McCurdy, the wife of Mr. Richard A. McCurdy, President of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, upon a historical building still standing in that town and known during the period of the Revolution as Norris's Tavern.

It will, of course, be necessary to await the full report of State Engineer BOND before forming an opinion of the merits of the plan he recommends for the treatment of the canal problem. So far as appears from the brief abstract furnished from Albany, the plan of the State Engineer has much in common with that proposed by the commission of which Gen. F.V. GREENE was Chairman.

At the annual dinner of the Employing Bookbinders, at the Savoy Hotel, on Feb. 16, the speakers included Louis Windmuller, Dan Beard, and Robert Rutter. It was the largest gathering ever assembled by the bookbinders since their association was organized, five years ago. Mr. Windmuller, in the course of his address, related the following anecdote of Mark Twain:

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Proceedings have been started on behalf of Viscount Hinton, who at one time played an organ in the London streets, to eject the youthful Earl Poulett from Hinton House, pending the trial of the question of his right to the earldom.

Mrs. John Wren, the mother of a baby one week old, probably owes her life to the quick wits of three firemen of the Tenth Battalion, who were called out early yesterday morning to extinguish a blaze in the five-story tenement house in Which she lives, at 445 East Eightieth Street. The fire started in the basement, and had gained considerable headway before it was discovered.

This is an interesting yet not altogether successful attempt to produce a fac simile of a small scrap book, the property of Abraham Lincoln, and containing the substance of his views in regard to "negro equality" and slavery entertained prior to his election to the Presidency of the United States.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Joseph Motorte, twenty-six years old, was brutally murdered at Avondale to-night by two men who lay in wait for him and beat his head to a jelly with a balestick. His two companions escaped a similar fate by running.

The late Judge COOLEY was of the opinion that the Inter-State Commerce Commission would never be able to exercise effective restraint upon the railroads until an amendment to the Constitution should give it power within the States as well as between the States. President THOMAS of the Erie Railroad told the Industrial Commission on Thursday that the Inter-State Commission serves no purpose except to hear statements of grievances which it is powerless to redress.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- The difficulty existing between the association of vaudeville managers and the White Rats of America was felt in this city to-day, where one of the Proctor houses is located, when several of the principal performers were absent when the curtain rose. To-night's "turns" at the theatre were mostly by amateurs.

The January number of John Murray's The Monthly Review contains an interesting article on Col. Wilks and Napoleon. Lord Rosebery, in describing the latter and his St. Helena circle, says: "Bertrand had an agreeable singularity; he wrote no book." But Julian S. Corbett, the writer of the present article, assures us Bertrand was not the only St. Anthony to thus resist temptation.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The Raines State Constabulary bill, the passage of which Gov. Odell may advocate, in view of Mayor Van Wyck's insistence upon the selection of Devery as Chief Deputy Commissioner, creates a uniform police system for cities throughout the State. It provides that on and after June 1, 1901, there shall be a new State department, to be known as the State Department of Police.

The amalgamation of the Trust Company of New York with the North American Trust Company was unanimously agreed to by the Directors of the former company at a meeting held yesterday, when the proposition, made by the latter company through its President, Oakleigh Thorne, was discussed.

The anniversary of Washington's Birthday was in the main a quiet holiday in this city yesterday. There were flag raisings, banquets, celebrations, and meetings of all sorts of societies, but the gray skies and chill winds kept a great many people indoors who otherwise would have attended them.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: On two different occasions lately long articles have appeared in your columns written by Judge Dykman, criticising the "New History of Westchester County," and also Mr. Abbatt's history, entitled "The Crisis of the Revolution," as to the accounts there given of the capture of Major Audre.

Paul Laurence Dunbar's new novel, "The Fanatics," will be published in the Spring by Dodd, Mead Co. Last year this author, who sometime ago had made his literary debut by a volume of verse, published two novels, "The Strength of Gideon" and "The Love of Landry," both of which met with considerable success.

Among heroes not heroic, Dick Heldar stands first, and one cannot resist the suspicion that Miss Eugenia Brooks Frothingham's "The Turn of the Road" was written with the conscious intention of showing how a brave man could bear the horror of blindness and how surely his very bravery would bring him reward.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 22. -- Although the situation arising out of the RussoAmerican tariff controversy is unquestionably full of peril, neither well-informed Americans nor well-informed Russians anticipate an unbreakable dead-lock. The most hopeful feature of the case is the fact that the political relations between the two powers remain absolutely unaffected.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The Woman's Christian Temperance Union and the clergymen of Buffalo this morning presented to the Senate, through Senator Raines, a petition against the proposal to permit saloons in Buffalo keeping open all day and all night, Sunday included, during the Pan-American Exposition.

Mr. Parsons has written one of the most interesting and suggestive of recent books about China. He enjoyed the unique experience of traveling through the Province of Hunan, making a survey of the route for the Hankow-Canton Railroad meanwhile and noting his observations of cities and people that no foreigner had seen before.
February, the shortest of all the months, is the one most crowded with the birthdays of famous people.

A stirring moment in an affair of more than usual picturesqueness occurred at the silver anniversary banquet of the Sons of the Revolution at Delmonico's last evening, when to the tune of fife and drum a committee, headed by S. Franklin Stanton, marched through the lines of cheering guests, holding aloft a magnificent loving cup, designed as a gift to Frederick Samuei Tallmadge, who for seventeen years has been President of the society.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22. -- Banks, the Stock Exchange, Board of Trade, railroad offices, and most of the schools were closed to-day in memory of the birth of Washington. During the afternoon 5,000 school children gathered at the Auditorium, where, under the auspices of the Union League Club, they were addressed by Frederic Harrison, the English author and philosophical critic, on "George Washington."

A correspondent not unknown in current literature and journalism sends to us, apropos of last week's article on "The Languages One Speaks," a copy of a label taken from a bottle of vermouth from which he was served many years ago at "l'Hermitage," on the Bronx, long the home of the late Pere Baudouin, of blessed memory, and of his variegated assortment of guests.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Perhaps you will kindly allow me to say a word or two in answer to E. Beal, who writes in to-day's TIMES in defense of Joseph Chamberlain. He says that Mr. Chamberlain cannot be blamed any more than others for having underestimated the task of subduing the Boers.

Columbia beat Williams last night by the narrow margin of four points in the dual intercollegiate athletic meet held in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory, Broadway and Sixty-eighth Street. Nine events were in competition, first and seeond only to count, and the blue and white floated triumphant at the close of a wellfought meeting by a margin of four points.

The volume under notice tells of a man who surrendered all things to God. George H.C. Macgregor's days were short, for he died when he was thirty-six, but there does not seem to have been an hour of his existence not devoted to good works. The subject of this biography is best known in the United States for the prominent position taken by him in the labors of the Christian Endeavor Society.

No page of history is more fascinating than that which tells of the brilliant Saracenic civilization of Spain, and none is more pathetic than that whereon is written the story of the downfall of this exotic empire and the ultimate expulsion of its founders.

It was a strange chance which led the late Rowland E. Robinson to assemble so many of the personages of his former books in "Sam Lovel's Boy," his last complete work, and it is with melancholy pleasure that one again meets the kindly philosopher, Uncle Lisha; stout old Gran'ther Hill, Huldah and Sam, Mrs. Purington, and Antwine, and with them watches the growth of the hero.

It is certainly not original to say that Mr. Apthorp's volume on "The Opera, Past and Present," in Scribner's Music Lovers' Library, fills a long-felt want, but it is in the main true. Most music lovers have especial predilections, and the majority or those who find joy in sweet strains are operagoers.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Twelve killed and about thirty injured is the record of the result of the collision of trains last night at Rusling's Siding, near Bordentown, on the Amboy Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad. It is known that all bodies have been removed from the wrecked trains.
ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Gov. Odell is considering three ways of meeting the challenge thrown down to him by Mayor Van Wyck in the retention Of Chief Devery. They are these:

The net outcome so far of the attempt to reform our police force from Albany is to transfer the entire system to the reckless hands and outworn conscience of Col. MICHAEL C. MURPHY, who, since the days of TWEED, has been in pretty near the worst sense of the term a "Tammany man."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Senate today passed the Post Office Appropriation bill. There was a long debate on a proposition to discontinue the appropriations for fast mail facilities from New York to New Orleans via Atlanta, and from Kansas City, Mo., to Newton, Kan. While the debate was protracted, it was not particularly lively.

At the ,Church of the Holy Rosary, East One Hundred and Nineteenth Street, near Pleasant Avenue, to-morrow evening at 7:30 o'clock, solemn vespers and benediction will be held. The Rev. William G. Murphy, assistant curate, who has just returned from Rome, will confer the pontifical blessing on all members of the congregation.
"Are you a Rat?" "No." "All right. Come in." This was the dialogue of the variety stage door yesterday.

Dr. Lyman Abbott, in an address the other day, the substance of which was published in all the newspapers, took occasion to recur to an old and wellworn thesis, the soundness of which has become increasingly disputable. The thesis was that the habit of reading was an excellent and commendable practice, and that it did not matter so much what you read at first, so long as you acquired the habit.

Though the New York Stock Exchange was closed yesterday, local operators were not altogether idle, many orders being placed by them in the London market. A number of the up-town offices of the large Stock Exchange houses were kept open for the convenience of customers who desired to trade in London.

In "Eastover Court House" we have the first of a series of twelve novels to be published during the year written by new American writers, and dealing with various phases of contemporary American life.

Gov. Odell yesterday morning signed the bill abolishing the bi-partisan board of four Police Commissioners and the office of Chief of Police, and substituting for them a single Commissioner to rule the force. In the afternoon Mayor Van Wyck appointed Col. Michael C. Murphy to the position of Police Commissioner, and ex-Police Commissioner John B. Sexton as President of the Health Board, to succeed Col. Murphy.

This new volume of the Contemporary Science Series, edited by Havelock Ellis, will prove a storehouse of treasure to the large ard increasing number of students of that supremely important subject of which it treats. It is not only replete with information, but is luminous and suggestive in its interpretation of "some of the most interesting and important phenomena of human beginnings in the individual and in the race."

This book is distinctively English, and appeals more to the soldier than to the civilian. It comprises the memoirs, diary, and correspondence of Capt. Charles Boothby of the Royal Engineers, serving in the British Army under Sir John Moore in England's memorable campaign on the Peninsula during the years 1804 to 1809.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 22. -- Pat Crowe has been heard from, under circumstances that indicate that he is soon to make a public apeparance. E.A. Cudahy is in receipt of a letter bearing Crowe's signature. The handwriting has been tested by comparison, and it is the opinion of the Pinkertons, Chief Donahue, and other authorities that the signature is genuine.

K.W.K. New York, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW as follows: "Does one out of ten readers read poetry? Whenever I hear read discussions about poets or poetry, I am reminded of the story an English bard -- Aubrey de Vere -- tells about Wordsworth and Tennyson.

There was little else talked of yesterday among the friends of Councilman John T. Oakley, the Tammany leader in the Fourteenth Assembly District, but his speech in response to the toast, "Our City," delivered at the dinner given to Assemblyman Harburger. The dinner began on Friday night, but this toast was not reached until the small hours of yesterday morning.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The performance of "The Lash of a Whip," at the Lyceum Theatre to-morrow evening, will be the only theatrical novelty in New York this week. It is an adaptation from the French farce entitled "Le Coup de Fouet." by Maurice Hennequin and George Duval. Wallack's Theatre changes its attraction by offering Louis Mann and Clara Lipman in Leo Deitrichstein's comedy entitled "All on Account of Eliza," which has been seen in this city before.
Clinton P. Paine, head of the banking house of Clinton P. Paine Co., Baltimore, speaking of the prosperity of the South generally, says:

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- The Chronicle will announce to-morrow that Mrs. Emmons Blaine or this city has turned over to Chicago University, the Chicago Institute of Pedagogy, which will represent an addition to the university endowment of nearly $2,000,000. The institute was started by her some years ago by an appropriation of $750,000, and since that time she has made additional gifts to it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Two volumes of the testimony and exhibits in the Cuban postal investigation were reported to the Senate to-day. They consist in the main of a mass of figures, the only new matter of popular interest being statements made by ex-Director General Rathbone and E. P. Thompson, Postmaster at Havana, in reply to Fourth Assistant Postmaster General Bristow's criticisms of their conduct.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23. -- Waring disposed of his field easily in the San Mateo Handicap at Tanforan to-day. Results: Five furlongs -- Skip Me, 103. (O'Connor.) 1; Mamie Hildreth, 100, 2; Birdie Stone, 102, 3. Time -- 1:04 3/4. One mile -- Topmast, 109. (O'Connor.) 1; Donator, 106, 2; Alee, 104, 3. Time -- 1:48 1/4. Hurdle handicap, mile and three-quarters -- Periwig, 125, (Brodie,) 1: J.O.C., 165, 2; Choteau, 120, (Bennett,) 3.

It is a point of honor with the Catalan of high or humble position to repudiate his Spanish nationality. He hints disgust Of the bullfight as an alien institution. Even with a stranger he is loath to converse in Castilian. Some Baroelonese shopkeepers, until the police interfered, used to Supplement the seductive "Ici on parle Francais" with a satirical announcement, "Aqui se habla Espanol."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The frequency with which both Cubans and Americans appeal to the War Department in matters relating to the government of the island, together with the comments elicited by various measures, has led the department to believe that its policy is not as well understood as was supposed and has induced it to make a statement in regard to the relations between the War Department and the local Cuban Government.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- T. Suffern Tailer of the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club was pitted against Fred F. Carey of the same club in the semi-final round of the annual squash tournament, which constituted the main feature of the second day's play. The match was stubbornly contested from the start, both men being in fine form and playing at their best.

This is to say requiescat in pace to Trilby. It is probable that never before was such a requiem pronounced over another Trilby or one of her kin. The departure of these is usually the signal for rejoicing, for Trilby was a turkey. That Trilby was an unusual bird goes without saying, and to do full justice to her good qualities would require a Dr. John Brown.

The final in the racquet tournament for the National amateur championship, with Clarence H. Mackay of New York and Quincy A. Shaw of Boston, left to fight out for the honors of the competition, yesterday made a finish to the competition that approached as near to the sensational as any contest ever held by the exclusive and conservative New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

Holcombe Ward, the star tennis player in Harvard, but who entered the indoor tennis tournament of the United States from the Orange Tennis Club, won the championship singles in that event yesterday, beating Calhoun Cragin, champion of the Seventh Regiment Tennis Association, in three straight sets.

Vice President-elect Theodore Roosevelt, bronzed from his Western trip, and attired in a dark overcoat and Rough Rider hat, walked into the Criminal Courts Building yesterday afternoon like any other ordinary citizen, and after hunting around the four sides of the building for an elevator in service stepped into one of the old-fashioned cars.

Golfers have an interesting week before them, as events of National importance in the golf world are to be settled at the annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, which will be held Thursday night at Delmonico's. The list of officers for election has already been announced, and as no opposition has developed to the selections of the nominating committee, unanimous election for all is assured.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Army Appropriation bill was taken up by the Senate to-day. The bill as it passed the House carried $117,847,749, but as reported to the Senate it was cut down to $115,854,049.
Magistrate Leroy B. Crane, from the bench in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday advocated the adoption of Mrs. Nation's tactics in the matter of ridding the city of "crap" games and policy shops.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Kindly permit a few lines in reply to "An Old Man in Doubt."

The fatal combination of the careless servant and the can of kerosene in lighting a fire was exemplified again yesterday morning in an accident to Marie Hoerick, fifteen years old, in the employ of Nathan Sherry, a tailor, at 259 Delancey Street. Last night she was dying in Gouverneur Hospital.

Because a man charged with a revolting crime sat beside him for a moment in the Morrisania Police Court yesterday morning, Joseph Sanders, a private in Battery A, at Port Hamilton, himself a prisoner, fell upon and beat him savagely before the court attendants could interfere. There was much excitement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Inauguration arrangements are very well advanced, and before the week is out all the plans of the committees of arrangements will have been completed. Out of the piles of lumber along Pennsylvania Avenue, near the White House, the Court of Honor and the President's reviewing stand have been evolved; not without somewhat mystifying those who had detected a departure from old plans.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In replying to the unwarranted attack which Dr. Harris makes in to-day's issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES upon my lecture on "Chinese, Christian, and Jewish Ethics." I ask him and other critics to consider the fact which I emphasized last Sunday, that Jesus Himself acknowledged His indebtedness to Jewish, especially to Mosaic, teachings.

Fewer changes than usual were made in the standing of the clubs in the local bowling tournaments during the past week. The greatest shake-up occurred in the Morning Newspaper Bowling League, in which The Bulletin displaced The Journal from the lead, THE TIMES went from fourth to third place, The World moved from fifth to fourth, and The Herald from third to fifth place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Daughters of the American Revolution assembled today to complete the work of their Tenth Continental Congress and to adjourn. After the election of National officers many delegates returned to their homes, and the attendance on the closing day of the congress was comparatively small.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 23. -- So far the arrival of Lent has in no wise affected the social life of Lakewood. As for the hotels, these have been more than ordinarily crowded, Washington's Birthday and the golf tournament having formed a double attraction which served to bring down a large number of visitors.

Amendments of a sweeping nature to the rules governing the intercollegiate athletic competitions, the admission of seven colleges that formerly were outside the fold, and the election of officers for the ensuing year made up the most important part of the business transacted yesterday at the annual convention of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America, held at the Fifth Avenue Hotel.

The largest consolidation of banking and trust corporations ever effected was announced yesterday by the North American Trust Company, the control by which of the Trust Company of New York was announced in yesterday's NEW YORK TIMES. The present consolidation, however, involves nearly a dozen different corporations, which will be under the control of the North American Trust Company, and will have a capitalization of something like $50,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The people living or doing business in Pennsylvania Avenue are preparing for a rich harvest, and many of them have already begun to reap it. Inauguration Day is the one day in four years when the Washingtonian, if he lives on the line of march, has nothing to do but lie back and let riches roll in on him.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- Money was in good demand to-day, and somewhat easier. The pressure was partly relieved through large amounts obtained from the Bank of England. Discounts were firm on the dearness of money. The approach of the carry-over of mines Monday restricted business.

A dry goods clerk with a mistake to answer for, a distracted mother, and a group of mounted policemen hastily engaged in rounding up a multitude of baby carriages and divers and sundry babies, excited One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street yesterday afternoon for the space of several minutes.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a sad and a strange thing that "An Old Man in Doubt." whose letter appears in this morning's paper, has not found in his diligent reading of the Bible the "Solid foundation to stand upon." For the Bible tells a man so plainly that Jesus Christ is that solid foundation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nothing in THE TIMES is more interesting and helpful to the ninety-and-nine than the Hewitt discussion on the rich and the poor. Our ex-Mayor has a fine heart. He has also the prayers of the poor, and he dies well who has that.

C.A Dana, Columbia's new football manager, has the season's schedule of games well under way, and the list thus far outlined promises to be quite as stiff as last year's, when Columbia tackled the teams of the larger colleges almost in succession.

It is somewhat curious, writes a correspondent, that, although frequent complaints are made of the over-representation of Ireland in the House of Commons, nothing is ever said of its over-representation in the House of Lords. Yet the disproportion between relative population and representation is far greater in the latter than in the former house.

Richard Mansfield, in whose occasional utterances about the theatre and the actor's art all the world is mightily interested, because he is a great actor with original ideas, has lately permitted himself publicly to express the opinion that Mr. Carnegie, who gives so much money to found libraries and things, ought to endow a theatre.
ROME, Feb. 23. -- As a result of poor crops and the heavy snowfall, great misery exists in the Apulia district. Thousands of persons are without shelter and bread.

PEKING, Feb. 23. -- Sir Robert Hart (Chief of the Chinese Imperial Maritime Customs) has sent to the Ministers of the powers a strongly worded letter of protest against the seizure of his property to increase the area of the legations. It has been taken by Austria, France, Germany, and Italy.

The farms which her late Majesty held for the longest time, and which became widely known, wore at Windsor. They are not large, considering the wonderful success of the animals bred there. One, Shaw Farm, is a grazing farm with only 120 acres of arable. The other, the Flemish Farm, covers 400 acres, of which 240 are arable.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested in a letter which appeared in your issue of Feb. 22, headed, "An Old Man's Doubts," in which the writer bewailed the bewilderment of mind into which he was plunged by the conflicting creeds of the various churches calling themselves Christian.

The failure to understand the situation in the Philippines is inexplicable to any one familiar with the course of events in the Islands since the victory of Manila Bay. These facts were within easy reach of every one. That the people of the country are not familiar with them can only be attributed to indifference to the situation in the earlier part of our occupation, after the intoxication of Admiral Dewey's victory had expended itself.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is ill-work stirring up a dead issue, but a few statistics may prove interesting:
W.H. CRONKHITE, owner of the Cronkhite Opera House, Little Falls, N.Y., died yesterday of erysipelas. He was forty-seven years old.

TRENTON, Feb. 16. -- Many lawyers and even laymen in this State find much interest, as well as amusement, in considering a new phase of the jury system known as the "butter and milk juries" of New Jersey. There has sprung into existence a general prejudice among farmers and residents in rural districts against the attitude of the State in prosecuting under the pure food act.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- The strike of the White Rats Association against the vaudeville managers is lively in Syracuse. To-day Manager Charles P. Salisbury, who has taken the Dunfee Theatre, announced a bill of White Rat stars for his opening week, beginning Monday. The syndicate house, the Grand, has received from the managers' association assurance of unlimited financial support.

Lewis F. Nixon, Chairman of the Tammany Committee of Five, sent a cablegram to Richard Croker yesterday, protesting against the appointment of William S. Devery as First Deputy under Police Commissioner Michael C. Murphy.

The Legislature Committee, of the Republican County Committee met yesterday in Long Island City for the purpose of giving a public hearing on all bills introduced by Assemblyman Vacheron. Opposition to every measure presented developed, and the hearing finally ended in a wrangle. The Chairman was assailed on all sides, and he adjourned the hearing despite the protests of the entire membership of the committee, who wanted to hold an executive session.

There was some lively sport on the Harlem River Speedway yesterday afternoon when Mrs. David Lamar, driving the handsome little pacer Royalto, won several hotly contested brushes in good style. After several warming jogs up and down the lower stretch which proved that Royalto was in prime form and condition, Mrs. Lamar turned the little pacer to a good start with the pacer Nettie B., 2:16 1/4, driven by her husband.
Boston pays $166,000 a year for its schoolhouse janitors, and the schoolhouse janitors' opinion is that the city gets off cheap.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- After some debate to-day the Senate passed the Fortifications Appropriation bill, Mr. Butler, (Pop., N.C.,) in opening the discussion, spoke of the large appropriations contained in this and other measures. In particular he criticised the appropriation of $225,000 for the purchase of Cushing's Island, Maine, for fortification purposes.

RUSSIAN INTRIGUE IN THE SOUDAN. -- The return of Col. Harrington, the British Agent, to his post at Addis Ababa, in Abyssinia, is said to have been signalized by the discovery that during the last few months Russian influence has been greatly augmented at Menelek's Court in a way which the British Government will find it hard to combat.

BRISTOL, R.I., Feb. 23. -- The new cup defender under construction at Bristol, from a passing view does not appear to occupy any more room in the south construction shop than did the Columbia when she was being built in 1899. A few feet in increase of length over all over that of the Columbia would hardly be noticed.

Maurice Barrymore strode into the headquarters of the White Rats yesterday afternoon. Approaching Deputy Chief Rat Armstrong and waving in one hand a dozen of so newspapers of various editions, he cried:

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23. -- Secretary Hester's Cotton Exchange statement for the week ending Feb. 22, issued to-day, shows a decrease in the movement of cotton into sight compared with the seven days ending this date last year, of 41,000, an increase over the same days year before last of 43,000.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 23. -- Harvard's mysterious society, commonly known as the "Med Fac," has been brought into prominence again this year by the perpetration of four daring acts of vandalism. The last of these, the blowing up of the old college pump, occurred on Thursday, and to-day the question which has puzzled Harvard men for the last forty years is again on every lip -- Who are the "Med Facs?"

The bill before the Legislature to prevent the imprisonment of persons who, after making a deposit on a small bill of goods, find themselves unable to keep up to the requirements of the contract, was recently indorsed by the employes of the installment houses to such an extent that they have formed themselves into a union to protest against the frauds practiced by these "companies" throughout the east side.

William M. Mellette, for thirteen years manager of the Bell Telephone Company at Rochester, N.Y., and for ten years previous manager for the Western Union Telegraph Company at Syracuse, N.Y., tried to end his life yesterday afternoon by cutting his throat. The attempt was made at the home of W.A. Delaney, 345 West Twentyseventh Street, and Mellette was found by Airs. Delaney.

John Feeney of 60 East Houston Street rushed through flame and smoke on the fourth floor of that house last night to save the lives of Raymond and Florence Hoefler, children, who had been locked in their rooms by their mother. They were carried out safely by Feeney, who was not injured. The fire did $200 damage.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- The draft of the Cabinet's decision on the Senate's amendments to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty is in process of being drawn up in the Foreign Office. It is quite possible the reply to Secretary Hay's note may be transmitted through Lord Pauneefote instead of through Mr. Choate, though Lord Lansdowne has not yet indicated which medium he prefers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: New York is being torn up from end to end to build the new subway, and miles of soil will consequently be exposed for months, if not years. Such, conditions have always created malaria in the past, as when the elevated road was built. Already physicians report an increase of malaria on the fashionable west side, which, will undoubtedly multiply when milder weather sets in.

From all the professional schools in Roumania the Jews are excluded, from the colleges of preceptors, from the naval schools, from the military ones, from all boarding schools. They have tried to reopen their own schools, which, at the invitation of the State, they closed in 1860; but here their endeavors are hampered in every possible way by the authorities.
"Yes, Sirs! Cut in two by an iceberg! That's what we were."

Anton Mock, a carpenter, twenty-eight years old, of 64 North First Street, Williamsburg, was rescued from an infuriated crowd last night by Policeman Connors of the Bedford Avenue Station, after the man had wantonly broken the left leg of elevenyear-old Benjamin Voneski of 63 North First Street, and inflicted other injuries, from which the boy is in a critical condition in the Eastern District Hospital.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the bill now pending in the State Legislature, which provides for establishing an electrical laboratory at Union College, your editorial of Feb. 16 calls to mind a similar bill which was passed last year providing for a State school of ceramies at Alfred University.

Controller Coler sent to Mayor Van Wyck yesterday a letter showing how the Dock Commissioners have condemned $9,716,000 worth of land for which the city has $3,874,150,35 to provide for payments, thus leaving a deficiency of $4,341,849,65 of funds available for Dock Department purposes.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- It was announced to-day that, desiring to stimulate yachting competitions during the coming Summer, which promises to be one of unprecedented interest to yachtsmen, Thomas W. Lawson has offered several cups for open competition, through the Hull-Massachusetts Yacht Club, of which he is a member.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The pathetic plaint of the "Old Man in Doubt" will find a sympathetic echo in the hearts of many readers, and he will, I trust, receive kindly suggestions to the quiet of his soul.

We are threatened with a revival of snuff-taking. These being days of popular hygienic science, the first question for the gros public is not unlikely to be similar to that asked by one of Dr. Abernethy's innumerable patients: "Does a moderate use of snuff injure the brain?" "No," replied the famous physician, "for no man with an ounce of brain would ever dream of using it."
In the course of a letter, dated Dec. 4 last, from an American army officer in Peking to a friend in this city, the writer says:

The prompt and insolent defiance of Tammany to the Albany people seems to have taken the Governor and his advisers by surprise. It is intimated that there has been a breach of faith, and that a verbal understanding that Tammany would not reinstate DEVERY if his banishment from the police was not definitely provided for in the law has been broken.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several of your correspondents have lately given many excellent reasons for the conversion of the land around Port George into a public park. Perhaps you will allow me to appear in print on the subject, to strengthen their plea, not perhaps by argument, but by the addition of one more voice.
