Gradually New York, socially, is being reduced to the status of midsummer. There are certain seasons when there is an absolute full in the doings of society. With the beginning of Lent, after a very busy year, every one who can leaves town for relaxation in the country of abroad. The travel this year abroad has not been very heavy.
MANILA, Feb. 23. -- Gen. Cailles has issued a proclamation offering ten Mexican dollars apiece for the heads of Americans.

A woman who gave her name as Miss Virginia Waters of 257 West Thirty-fourth Street, went into the West Thirtieth Street Police Station last night and said that she had been robbed of a diamond and sapphire ring valued at $2,500. She was handsomely gowned and wore a number of fine jewels.

The Industrial Commission of the United States, the sub-Committee on Transportation of which held sessions at the Chamber of Commerce in this city last week, has now been in existence more than two years. More than $150,000 has been expended by the commission in gathering testimony and between fifteen and twenty volumes of reports are being prepared, containing the results of the commission's work.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial this morning entitled "The Brooklyn Railroad Problem," in which you pass unfavorable judgment upon the Two-cent Fare bill for standing passengers, you say, "Probably the Woman's Reform Club has not considered all the results which might follow its enactment."

About 250 persons assembled in one of the rooms at Sherry's last evening to hear Edward Howard Griggs give the first lecture in his Saturday evening course on "The Divine Comedy of Dante." His subject last evening was "The Mediaeval World and the Life of Dante." He was introduced by the Rev. Robert Collier.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- A death blow has been dealt to this city's hopes of its proposed public improvements. The Supreme Court has decided that Chicago has no right to increase the limit of its bonded indebtedness. This was the case brought to test the question upon which all the contemplated improvements of the city depend.

An agitation has been started by several prominent Bronx Borough business men in favor of the bill introduced in the Asssembly by Assemblyman Henry Bruckner "to erect the County of the Bronx from the territory now comprised within the limits of the City of New York north and east of the Harlem River and known as the Borough of the Bronx, in the County of New York.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller, Mr. and Mrs. William Rockefeller, and James Stillman of New York arrived at Palm Beach in Mr. Rockefeller's private car this morning.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 8. -- There will apparently be no end to the discussion over the responsibility of the missionaries for the anti-foreign outbreak. Chinese opinions are untrustworthy, because they are dictated by political or personal interest. A declaration by Li-Hung-Chang that the missionaries brought on the trouble does not signify that he really thinks so, but that it suits his purposes so to declare.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- The hearing on the bill to repeal the mortgage tax developed a humorist, who imparted interest and entertainment to an otherwise dull proceeding. The humorist was John H. Simonson of Oyster Bay. Mr. Simonson, who is a man of advanced years, looks like a "character," and his looks do not belie him.

The air around the Metropolitan Opera House has been thick of late with rumors as to the probability that there would be no season of opera next Winter. The question has finally been settled, and those who have been trembling lest they would have no one to worship next year may now possess their souls in patience.

Nor do the men who sell milk and its various products lie in bed till the sun rises. There are a couple of European dairies in Athens whose proprietors keep cows; but they do business mostly with the foreigners and with those Greeks who ape foreign manners. Your genuine Athenian believes the goat to be the proper milk-producing animal, and he regards the cow in this connection about as we Americans do the mare.

HAVANA, Cuba, Feb. 17. -- The many and increasing number of pleasure tourists arriving at Havana testify that the merits of Cuba as a Winter resort are becoming known. The supervision of the sanitary requirements by the United States Army Surgeons, together with the cleaning of the streets of Havana, has practically removed the fear of yellow fever, and cases of the dreaded calantura are few and far between.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My letter referring to the attitude of the American press toward England, or rather Britain, having elicited one or two replies that show I have, perhaps from my own fault, been misunderstood, I will be glad if you will allow me a few words in explanation.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 23. -- Although there were not many top-notchers in the mid-winter tournament of the Country Club ot Lakewood, which was brought to a close this afternoon, there were so many competitors on about the same equality that it proved one of the most enjoyable tourneys that has been held in this vicinity for some time.

As the outer wheels of the "L" train slid along the rails of the Bleecker Street curve there went up from them a sound that might have been the wailing of lost souls. The man with the sensitive face and the great coat shuddered. The man from whose coat an opium pipe stuck out edged nearer his companion of the shudders.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 23. -- The Board of Relief filed the tax book of the town with Town Clerk Mead to-day, and it proved a great surprise and disappointment to the numerous wealthy taxpayers, who felt assured that the arguments presented by their attorneys would bring about an abatement of their taxes, which this year were raised by the Assessors all round.

Antonio Pucci, a contractor, yesterday secured a stay from Justice McAdam pending an appeal by him from an order of Justice Fitzgerald adjudging him in contempt for disobeying an injunction issued by Justice Gildersleeve and fining him $250, with the alternative of imprisonment until the payment of the fine.

There have, of course, been various improvements effected in the House of Commons in recent years -- the electric light, the telephone, and the lifts to the ladies' and reporters' galleries; but in other respects the House of Commons is still strangely behind the times. No self-respecting member ever dines there if he can dine elsewhere.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 23. -- The Southern States, from Texas to the Atlantic Coast, were given their first taste of Winter last night and to-day, snow falling in many places from Charleston, S.C., to Central and Northern Texas, and almost to the Gulf. The storm, which was over the West Gulf Coast last night, moved rapidly to the east during the night and was central to-day over Northern Florida.

A part of Napoleon's misunderstanding of human nature was his misunderstanding of the national spirit -- as Prof. Sloane expresses it, "his contempt for nationality." Oh this subject there is an interesting passage in Lord Rosebery's book:

The recent negotiations with reference to the consolidation of iron and steel interests in this country have aroused much discussion as to the enormous amount of capital, or capitalization, involved, and some of our more excitable contemporaries have manifested alarm and indignation at what has seemed to them an overwhelming accumulation of "money" and "money power" in a few hands.
The imports of dry goods and general merchandise for the week were valued at $9,096,084. The imports of specie amounted to $155,135, and the exports of specie to $1,001,645.

Such a gathering of Republican cohorts as assembled at the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday afternoon had not before been seen since the Presidential election last November. The possibility of action on the part of the Governor with reference to the appointment of ex-Chief of Police Devery as Deputy Commissioner by Commissioner Murphy was responsible for the assembling and for the atmosphere of suppressed excitement which pervaded the place.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- At to-day's session of the Executive Council of the American Federation or Labor, President Gompers submitted the text of a letter addressed to the workingmen of Porto Rico, which was approved and ordered to be forwarded. The letter says:

The headquarters yesterday of Col. Michael C. Murphy, the single Police Commissioner, were "in the saddle." First Deputy Commissioner William S. Devery filled his ample chair at his big desk in the office he has occupied since he was appointed Chief of Police of New York City just as though nothing had been changed in his office and functions.

LONDON, Feb. 23. -- Parliament has held seven sittings and has done no business. When it may be allowed to begin work appears to rest with the United Irish Party. It is stated that Balfour means to close the debate on the address at the latest on Tuesday night, because financial necessities are compelling the Government to bring forward supplementary estimates for the current year at the earliest convenient date.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Great satisfaction is expressed at the appointment of Col. Ward as Permanent Under Secretary of State for War on the retirement of Sir Ralph Henry Knox next April. Col. Ward distinguished himself by his organizing ability during the siege of Ladysmith. The morning papers congratulate Mr. Brodrick, Secretary of War, on the appointment, pointing out that it proves his earnest desire for thorough reform.

PEKING, Feb. 24 -- The full text of the imperial edict regarding punishments was sent last evening to the Ministers of the powers. It is almost identical with the unofficial reports, but the Ministers say that there is a little confusion in its terms with reference to strangulation and suicide, but that this is not important.

John Calhoun, thirty years old, a laborer, was taken from his home at 326 East Seventieth Street last night and locked up in the East Sixty-seventh Street Police Station. The charge is felonious assault. SergtQuigley said last night that he feared he would have to make it murder before morning.

The Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Plymouth Church, last night introduced a new idea in church work in Brooklyn, which promises to become popular in that borough. Desiring to interest as many young men as possible in the church. Dr. Hillis felt that something should be added to the ordinary attractions of the services to draw them there.

The annual meeting of the Hebrew Infant Asylum was held yesterday afternoon at the institution, One Hundred and Sixty-first Street and Eagle Avenue. There was an attendance of several hundred members, and the annual report, which was a favorable one, showed that there were 152 infants in the asylum against 98 for the previous year.

There is little or no improvement in the water supply of the Borough of the Bronx, and so serious has the matter become that many tenants are vacating their premises and moving to a part of the city where they can at least get enough water to wash with, which is denied them in many portions of the Bronx.

The big bell of the Oil Exchange at Oil City, Penn., interrupting with its brass note the unfinished business of the day, scattered the ringside. But instead of hurrying off for suburban or out-of-town homes, the brokers gathered about the windows, apparently awaiting some event of which they had whispered, and whose shadow had been discerned in the shadowless room by those skilled in reading the signs of such things.

ALBANY, Feb. 24 -- Gov. Odell will ride at the head of the New York troops in the inaugural parade in Washington. He will be on horseback. Recently a friend of the Governor's made him a present of a high-class riding horse. Since he acquired the horse the Governor has been "practicing up."

Five women arrested on a charge of loitering on the streets were arraigned before Magistrate Pool in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday. Three were discharged, and of the remaining two, one was an attractive-appearing girl of about eighteen, who gave her name as Marion Kendall and her address as 269 East Eleventh Street.

From noon yesterday to almost midnight the White Rats of America were busy giving their first independent benefit in the Academy of Music. They announced in the evening that they had realized between $9,000 and $10,000 on the venture. Senator Timothy D. Sullivan is said to have paid $3,000 for one seat.

Mrs. CHARLOTTE TALBOT died suddenly yesterday at her residence, 62 Fifth Avenue. She was in her ninety-second year, and was the daughter of the late Samuel N. Richmond of Providence, R.I. She was the widow of Charles N. Talbot of this city.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- Last week the Stock Exchange did only a moderate business. The reduction in the rate of the Bank of England slightly stimulated purchases for investment, but consols were lower on the week.

Ex-Mayor Josiah Quincy of Boston is reported as saying that he is not seeking to boom anybody for the Democratic nomination for President in 1904, and that, in his opinion, it is altogether too early to be bothering one's self or the party about that.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 24 -- There is more than one path, which leads to success on the turf, and among the most remarkable and at the same time disreputable was chosen by William Brannon, who is now living a retired life in Covington with the notoriety of being the most marked man ever connected with racing in this country.

Passengers on a Columbus Avenue car near Seventy-fourth Street were witnesses of an argument and a quarrel last night that kept excitement at a high pitch while it lasted. George D. Crooks, twenty-nine years old, of 65 West Ninety-fifth Street, a small man, and wearing fine clothes and eyeglasses, and Joseps Dyer, forty-five years old, an Irish laborer, of 320 West Forty-seventh Street, were the disputants.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- In the House the last week of this Congress will be mainly occupied with conference reports on the Appropriation bills and the other numerous measures now being fought over by the managers of the two houses. The last of the general appropriation bills went to the Senate on Thursday, and the House has its decks pretty well cleared for the final contests with the Senate.

Citizens and property owners of the Borough of the Bronx are organizing for the purpose of supporting Assemblyman A.M. Cooley's bill, which provides for a five-cent fare on all railways within the city limits. Such a law has long been desired by the residents of the Bronx, and especially by those in the outlying sections, who are now obliged to pay exorbitant car fares.

Louis Geroux, twenty-four years old, a French comedian who lived at 262 West Twenty-fourth Street, died Saturday night in the prison ward of Bellevue Hospital from pneumonia. Geroux was taken to the hospital on Feb. 16 after having been arraigned in the West Side Police Court on a charge of homicide.

James Fitton, assistant manager of the Hotel Donovan and for more than ten years night clerk at the Pacific House, in St. Joseph, had the pleasure several years ago, while on duty at the latter hostelry, of introducing Gen. B.M. Prentiss of Bethany, Mo., to Gen. Jo Shelby, the gallant Confederate leader, who was at that time United States Marshal for the Western District of Missouri.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your issue of Feb. 18 contains a report of the sermon of Rabbi Silverman, preached the day preceding, on the "Real Origin of the Golden Rule." Dr. Silverman, with Count Tolstoi, regards Jesus teaching of non-resistance (in the Sermon on the Mount) as not only literal, but as intended to be literally applied in the sphere of legislation and government.

SALEM, Oregon, Feb. 24 -- John H. Mitchell, Republican, was elected United States Senator at 12:30 o'clock this morning to succeed George W. McBride, whose term will expire March 4. His election was accomplished by a combination of 35 Republicans with 11 Democrats, making 46 votes, a majority of the Legislature.

STANFORD UNIVERSITY, Cal., Feb. 24 -- Dr. David Starr Jordan, President of Leland Stanford, Jr., University, discussing the report of the Committee of Economics on the dismissal of Prof. Ross from the university, said:

MANILA, Feb. 24 -- A largely attended meeting was held this morning in the Tondo Ward of Manila, under the auspices of the Evangelical Church, and a great open-air gathering in furtherance of Protestantism was held this afternoon at Pasay. The Rev. James B. Rodgers of the local staff of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, together with Senor Buencamino and others, is preparing articles on Church polity and government.

George L. Rives and Robert Fulton Cutting of the Charter Revision Committee who were to be allowed the privilege of the floor at yesterday's meeting of the Central Federated Union, failed to appeal and sent letters instead.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 24 -- The finals and consolations of the second annual championship squash tournament of America held under the management of the Tuxedo and New York Racquet Clubs were played off to-day in the new courts of the local club. In the morning T. Suffern Tailer of Tuxedo was pitted against Willlam Post, ex-squash champion and a member of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

A new bowling tournament this week is the Germania sub-tournament, which will begin this evening on the Germania alleys. Brooklyn. The teams scheduled for the first evening's play represent the Twenty-sixth Ward, Kings County, and Monarch Clubs.

Rabbi Joseph Silverman preached on Mohammedanism yesterday at Temple Emanu-El. He said that the founder of that religion was one of the strongest figures among all the world's great religious leaders. He described the development of the consciousness of power in the meditative Arabian shepherd, and the failure of his attempt to redeem his people from idolatry, atheism, and degradation by persuasion and argument.

Mrs. Augusta E. Stetson, "First Reader of the First Church of Christ, Scientist," lives in a handsomely furnished house at 24 West Seventy-second Street. She gets a salary of $5,000 a year from the church, and it has been said that her income amounts to many times that figure, because she teaches people the arts of the "healers" and does a little "healing" on her own account.

A special match at court tennis was played in the New York Racquet and Tennis Club yesterday afternoon between Thomas Pettit, the instructor of the Boston Athletic Association, and Alfred Tompkins, in which Pettit attempted to concede three aces in each game to his opponent, playing a match of three in five grames.

HAVANA, Feb. 24 -- Independence Day was celebrated with processions, mass meetings, and general demonstrations of rejoicings. This morning there was a parade of 10,000 school children bearing Cuban flags. They were reviewed by prominent politicians. Gen. and Mrs. Wood were showered with flowers by the children as they passed.
A man walked into the Macdougal Street Police Station last night, and, addressing Sergt. Kelly, said:

Press dispatches from Havana report that the proposition to be considered by the Committee on Relations of the Constitutional Convention contains these three provisions: First, Cuba is not to be used as a base of war operations against the United States: second, the commer- cial treaty shall provide, so far as possible, for free trade between the two countries: third, Cuba shall make no foreign treaties jeopardizing her independence.

Proceeding upon information supplied from Washington, the local Federal authorities have caused the arrest of a man describing himself as George Howard of Chicago, who is believed to be identified with a gang of swindlers who had been luring people across the Atlantic under the belief that a share of a rich gold mine was theirs.

The Brooklyn Democratic leaders spent yesterday in thinking things over. Prom all accounts they did some very heavy thinking, for the burden of their thoughts was Devery. How to get the local organization out of the dilemma in which it has been placed by the appointment of the ex-Chief as Deputy Commissioner, without sacrifice of dignity and prestige, was the vexing problem which the Willoughby Street leaders sought during the day to solve.

The Reiff brothers, Lestar and John, most, successful of the American jockeys who rode in England last year, have booked passage and will sail from New York for England on Thursday to report to Trainer John Huggins, under a contract made last season with the late Lord William Beresford.

So far as we are able to make out from the voluminous history of the causes of Prof. Ross's resignation from Stanford University in California, there is a certain want of freedom of speech in that institution and a worse want of common sense in nearly all who have had to do with the business.

A NEW BILL AGAINST ANARCHISTS IN ITALY -- One of the last acts of Signor Gianturco before he retired from the post of Italian Minister of Justice was to bring forward the scheme of a law against An- archists. It was done in reply to an interpellation in the Chamber inquiring what had been done since the international conference in regard to the suppression of anarchy.

LONDON, Feb. 24 -- When the bank rate fell to 4 1/2 per cent. it was a foregone conclusion that it would soon reach 4 per cent. Have we now got it finally? I am really not sure. We ought to, since credit is so multiplied by those very debt creations of the Government that, except when a special cause pinches the market, rates are pressed down.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- The prevailing tone of the Boerse last week was firm, but the volume of business was slight. The reduction of the Bank of England's rate and the announcement in the Prussian Diet by Herr Krefeld, Minister of Commerce, of the Government's intention to reform the Boerse law gave strength to the market.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The War Office has received the following dispatch from Lord Kitchener:

Dr. Henry Van Dyke of Princeton was the speaker before the People's Institute at Cooper Union last evening. His subject was, "Is There a Moral Law for Art?" Beginning with the general proposition that all men are able to distinguish between right and wrong, and that all therefore are called upon to live under the moral law, Dr. Van Dyke continued:

We tender to Mr. NIXON, the Chairman of the Committee of Purification appointed by CROKER, the assurance of our hearty sympathy. He is in a most embarrassing situation, and we fear that he is not likely to be relieved from it by his official godfather.

The School bill which Senator ELSBERG introduced a fortnight since is, as we understand it, intended to embody the portions of the Charter Revision Commission's recommendations which relate to the reorganization of the School Boards, while retaining the best features of the Davis bill, which the Charter Commission proposed to repeal.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been hold to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of John Hays Myers is a melancholy event in the lives of hundreds of young men and women in this city and elsewhere who passed their childhood in the old brick Grammar School No. 63, of which he was for many years the Principal.

RED BANK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Harry Van Schaick, who lived in Middletown Township, just across the river from New York, died last night from the effects of a revolver bullet in his head, which was fired by his own hand. Whether or not it was a case of suicide will probably never be known.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Republicans are viewing the police situation in New York with more composure and the likelihood Of reprisal by the Governor for Devery's appointment is diminishing.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 25 -- The white Rats refuse to appear at the Park Theatre here. The house is managed by Shea Wilton, who are in the Vaudeville Managers' Association. Shea Wilton have ten acts billed for this week, and the daily performances will be given, but none of the performers are Rats.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 -- Henry Schurman, a freshman at the Maryland University, was to-day driven from the grounds of the institution by his fellow-students, who pelted him with eggs in various stages of decay, dead cats, cabbages, and any other missiles on which they could lay their hands.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- The stock market failed to show any improvement in point of activity to-day, and the volume of trading was light. The supply of money is plentiful. Call loans, 3@4; time loans, 3 1/2@4 1/2. Complete transactions were as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- At the annual meeting of the Board of Directors of the Midvale Steel Company, held to-day, no action was taken on the recent offer of the Vickers Brothers and Maxim Company to purchase the Midvale plant. President Harrah and the old board were re-elected.

The the Editor of The New York Times: I see that the article in THE TIMES of Feb. 22, from "An Old Man in Doubt," has called forth several very prompt and mostly interesting responses in the Sunday TIMES, for which I am thankful.

After an unusually long session of the Tammany Hall Committee of Five for the Suppression of Vice, at which four of the members were present yesterday, Chairman Lewis Nixon presented this written statement:

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The Senate to-night took up the general orders -- the Insurance Tax bill. Senator Grady asked for an explanation regarding the amendments. Senator Krum suggested that Senator Grady read the bill. Senator Grady replied that he could get no information that way, but thought the Senator could best advise him as to the reasons for the changes and amendments.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Tammany's "first termers" are disgruntled. They received a hard lesson in Tammany discipline during the recess of the Legislature between last Friday and to-night. A number of these beginners thought they saw in the Ramapo situation an opportunity to distinguish themselves.

Six Central Office detectives who have been working for the past two weeks trying to find some clue in regard to a robbery of $10,000 worth, of jewelry in the Hotel Savoy, from Percival Kuhne, a banker of 13 William Street,, succeeded last night in recovering one of the stolen pieces.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Charles T. Yerkes to-day completed the sale of his remaining street and elevated railway interests in Chicago for $5,000,000. The purchasers are the Whitney-Widener-Elkins syndicate of New York and Philadelphia, a syndicate represented by Blair Co. of New York and Marshall Field, Norman B. Ream, and John J. Mitchell, President of the Illinois Trust and Savings Bank of this city.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Senator Malby gave notice in the Senate to-night of his intention to bolt his party's programme upon the Ramapo question. Just as the Senate was about to adjourn Senator Slater moved the Ramapo bill reported by the Senate Committee on Judiciary, and, at the same time, offered amendments to the title.

That was not only an interesting point that was raised by Senator MORGAN yesterday against the proposal of Senator FORAKER that the revenues from customs collected in this country on imports from Porto Rico shall be forthwith expended for the use and benefit of Porto Rico itself.

John L. Miller has sold the plot of eleven lots at the northeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Forty-fourth Street, 100 by 275. The purchaser of this property, whose name could not be learned yesterday, has also acquired from Andrew J. Connick, the vacant block front on the west side of Broadway, between One Hundred and Fifty-second and One Hundred and Fifty-third Streets, 200 by 125.

Charged with extortion, Etienne Bayer, formerly a wardman in the "Red Light" District, now President of "Bayer's International Detective Agency" and "agent" of the "New York Anti-Vice Society," with Louis Levene, a lawyer; Louis Gampel, a barber, and Julius Bayer, the ex-detective's son, were held in $1,500 ball for further examination by Magistrate Hogan, in the Centre Street Court, yesterday, when arraigned by Central Office Detectives Collins, Murphy, and Cooney.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The report of the Tenement House Commission, appointed by Gov. Roosevelt last year, was submitted to the Legislature, with a special message by Gov. Odell to-night.
ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- In transmitting the report of the New York City Tenement House Commission to the Legislature GOV. Odell says:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Admiral Sampson's friends are greatly exercised and not a little worried over his language used in protesting against the application of Charles Morgan, a gunner in the navy, to be examined for an Ensign's commission. Admiral Sampson in effect says that the men of the forecastle are, as a rule, by birth, breeding, and education unfit to be commissioned officers of the navy.

MACON, Ga., Feb. 25 -- United States District Attorney Marion Erwin said to-night, when informed of the decision reached by Commissioner Shields in the Greene and Gaynor case: "When the case comes to Georgia we will have to go over not only the great volume of testimony introduced before the New York Commissioner, but we will hove to add to it.

A cab horse became frightened in Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon and ran away with disastrous results. The animal finally wound up its flight by breaking a leg and had to be killed. One man had his skull fractured, another was seriously injured, and escapes were numerous from serious injury.

Judge John A. Blair of the Hudson County Common Pleas Court yesterday afternoon heard an application for bail for Thomas G. Barker, who is charged with having shot the Rev. John Keller of Arlington. The counsel for the defense intimated bad faith on the part of Prosecutor Erwin in failing to submit to the Court an affidavit of the condition of Mr. Keller.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate Committee on Relations with Cuba to-day reported an amendment to the Army Appropriation bill, in which the wishes of the United States regarding the future relations between the island Government and the United States are set forth and the conditions of withdrawal of the troops are specified.

Representatives of about twenty-five local corporations met at the rooms of the New York Board of Trade and Transportation, 203 Broadway, yesterday afternoon to consider stops to be taken to oppose the passage of the Corporation Franchise Tax bill now pending in the Legislature. William McCarroll of the American Leather Company presided and Prank S. Gardner, Secretary of the board, acted as secretary for the meeting.

CHICAGO, Ill., Feb. 25 -- George H. Heafford, formerly General Passenger Agent of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul, has been elected First Vice President and General Manager of the Morning Star Railway Company. This company, having a capitalization of $2,500,000, intends to build a line to develop the zinc deposits in Northern Arkansas.

The second week in Lent began quite auspiciously. The Monday Evening Bowling Club, the amateur theatricals for the benefit of the New York Business Women's Association, and the different dinners which were given made it quite a gay evening. Again to-day there will be much going on, although the principal entertainments will be dinners and musicales.

Statistics given in a Washington dispatch to The Tribune show that for the calendar year 1900 the exports of domestic products of the United States were greater than those of any other nation. The relative rank of the other great commercial nations is shown in the following brief table:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The words of the Rev. Alfred E. Myers of the Marble Collegiate Church hardly prove his contention. In fact, the words of the New Testament disprove his argument. Jesus is asked the question: "Is it lawful for us to give tribute unto Caesar or not?" But he perceived their craftiness, and said unto them, "Show me a penny.

MONTREAL, Feb. 25 -- A dispatch from Sydney, Cape Breton, brings the news that it is officially announced that the Morgan-Rockefeller syndicate, the new United States Steel Corporation, has secured control of the Dominion Iron and Steel Company of Sydney and of the Dominion Coal Company properties, at a cost of about $60,000,000.
The summing up of the counsel in the Brush will contest furnished a regular field day for spectators in the Surrogates Court yesterday.

MATAWAN, N.J., Feb. 25 -- In connection with the incendiary fire which excited the residents of Matawan early last evening, after the blaze was put out, an attempted lynching took place and the alleged firebug had a narrow escape with his life. The fire was in the rear of the residence of Mrs. Lydia C. Herbert, in the Bissell block, on Main Street.
PARIS, Feb. 26 -- A dispatch from Madrid to the Libre Parole says the resignation of the Azcarraga Ministry was tendered last evening and accepted by the Regent.

In the New York Athletic Club's championship pool tournament the opening contest last night was between Fulgratt and Tilt, the former winning by the score of 100 to 95, after a rather closely contested game. In the second game Bickel and Kane were the competitors, Bickel running out the 100 balls necessary to win when Kane had scored 62.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- To further the pleasure of fishing, shooting, and other sports in Richmond County, the Robin Hood Rod and Gun Club of Richmond County has been incorporated. The Directors are: George Connelly, Jr., and Thomas Foley, Jr., of Concord, and Louis Birkle of Stapleton.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I see that the old idea of taxing all mortgages in this State at one-half of 1 per cent., no matter how or/where they may be held, has been revived in the Legislature. The bill, as I understand it, requires the mortgaroer to pay the tax directly to the State, deducting the amount from the interest payable to the mortgagee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So the periodical complaint of woman, her appearance, her dress, and her general deceitfulness and desire to appear something she is not has begun again. This complaint dates back several centuries, for we read of one man in 1700 who in his arraignment of the fair sex quotes the following, as at that time an old satire:

MONTEREY, Mexico, Feb. 25 -- It was stated here to-day that as a result of the recent visit of Enrique Creel, the millionaire banker of Chihuahua, to New York City, steps have been taken looking to the pooling of a number of Mexico's large industrial concerns. An agent of Charles R. Flint of New York, who is to undertake this gigantic deal, is now on his way to Mexico, and will reach Monterey this week.

Louis Beckers. Louis Beckers, for more than sixty years, a well-known chemist and analyst, died on Sunday at his home, 82 St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, aged eighty-six. Mr. Beckers, who was a native of Westphalia, Germany, came to the United States in 1837, and was for many years associated with Powers Weightman, the Philadelphia manufacturing chemists, retiring, from a responsible position in their service a number of years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Senate is now engaged with the question of providing civil Government for the Philippines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The House today agreed to a partial report from the conferrees on the Naval Appropriation bill. It also concurred in the Senate amendment striking out the provision for two battleships and two cruisers. There was considerable debate, on this Senate amendment, on a motion by Mr. Rixey (Dem., Va.,) that the House concur.

The cause of most of the fun in the new farce called "The Lash of the Whip," in which Charles Frohman's comedians, that expert band of theatrical humorists, acted for the first time at the Lyceum last night is the audacious ruse of a gay deceiver whose amazingly ingenious wife has begun to suspect him.

James O'Brien, a stenographer, of 2,087 Broadway, after diligently studying a handbook on "How to Make Love," came to a realization yesterday of the fact that he might better have put in his time in looking up authorities on "when not to make love."

LONDON, Feb. 26 -- In the House of Commons yesterday, the Secretary of State for War, the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, discussing a motion to publish the proceedings of courts of inquiry, said it was still the purpose of the Government to make a general inquiry into the conduct of the war in South Africa, when the war was substantially ended.

The stock market yesterday was much excited at the opening. The list was strong, while the entire iron and steel group showed exceptional buoyancy. All Wall Street had come to business anticipating official disclosure during the day of the details in the formation of the colossal metal trust.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Money was in active demand to-day and was scarce. Discounts were firm, and little business was transacted.

At the annual meeting of the Medical Society of the County of Kings yesterday the Committee on Public Health, composed of Dr. E.H. Bartley, Chairman; Dr. B. Taylor Emery, and Dr. J.H. Raymond, presented a report of their investigation of the sanitary aspect of the water supply of the Borough of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Rear Admiral Sampson has vetoed the application of Charles Morgan, a gallant gunner on the cruiser New York, for the position of Ensign in the navy. The remarkable correspondence in which which this attitude of the Rear Admiral is unmistakably set forth is herewith appended:

United States Commissioner Shields decided yesterday that probable cause exists requiring the Gaynors and Benjamin D. Greene to be held to await a warrant for their removal to the Southern District of Georgia. The men are charged with conspiring with ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter to defraud the United States Government.

A tour through the "Red Light" district of Stanton, Rivington, and other streets in the Eldridge Street Station Precinct early this morning showed that everything was closed. The houses occupied formerly by disorderly tenants were in a great many cases entirely vacant, with a policeman in front of them.

Police Commissioner Michael C. Murphy was very much in evidence as head of his department yesterday. He did not camp out, as on Saturday, in ex-Chief Devery's room, but had his quarters near a blazing cannel coal fire in what was the sanctum of Jacob Hess's offices. Here came all persons of note who entered the Central Office.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The attention of tax reformers throughout the country is just now centred upon the State of Colorado.

TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 25 -- J.W. Adams was fatally wounded early this morning in a battle between three policemen and a band of citizens who made a midnight raid on a North Topeka wholesale liquor house. A large quantity of beer was destroyed before the crowd was dispersed.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- A call was issued to-day by Capt. Green of the Princeton University baseball nine for candidates from the freshman class for the several positions on the 'Varsity and freshman teams. More than thirty candidates reported at the 'Varsity cage, and were immediately set to work, being instructed by Capt. Green and later indulging in light practice.

Under the name of the United States Steel Corporation, the "billion-dollar steel combine" which J.P. Morgan and his associates have for some time been perfecting, was formally launched yesterday when the articles of incorporation were filed in Jersey City with the County Clerk of Hudson County.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- The historic schoolhouse situated at Dingman's, Pike County, Penn., a popular Summer resort, was destroyed by fire yesterday, together with its contents. It is believed that the fire was caused by a defective chimney. Some women were in the building the day before, cleaning up after an entertainment on the evening of Washington's Birthday, and it is thought that fire was left in the stove.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 -- Whitelaw Reid to-night delivered the first of the Isaac Bromley courses of lectures on "Journalism, Literature, and Public Affairs," before 800 students of Yale University.

LIVINGSTON, Mont., Feb. 25 -- Tourists to the Yellowstone National Park next season will find a new attraction in the shape of a wonderful new geyser which, if the accounts received in this city to-day are to be credited, will rival in magnificence any of the geyser attractions.

Whether the amendment to the Army Appropriation bill reported by Senator PLATT of Connecticut shall be adopted or not, the formulation of the terms and conditions upon which we are willing to intrust the Government of Cuba to its own people is timely and advantageous for the information of the public here and in Havana.

Chief Engineer Parsons of the Rapid Transit Commission yesterday announced that the underground railroad will be finished before the expiration of the time granted to Contractor McDonald. The work has been progressing so favorably, Mr. Parsons said, that at the latest by Christmas of 1903 trains will be run from the City Hall to the northern limits of the city.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 -- Policy playing in all its stages was discussed to-night on the floor of the Assembly Chamber, in the presence of a large audience, the fair sex predominating. Mr. Weekes's anti-policy bill, on the order of second reading, was opposed by Mr. Hyman of New York, who moved to strike out the enacting clause.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The editorial in THE TIMES to-day, "The Iron and Steel Combination," must have been a reminder to your many readers of the magnitude of the problem the people of the United States are soon to be called upon to solve.

KEMMERER, Wyoming, Feb. 26 -- Thirty-five men have undoubtedly perished in the fire which was discovered last evening in No. 6 Level of the Diamondville Coal Mine No. 1. Only one man in this level, John Anderson, was able to reach the main shaft and make his escape, so quickly did the fire spread through the level.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will THE TIMES give place to one of the class of '87 to second the words of "H.M. C., Class of 1889," in regard to the late John. H. Myers, Principal of Grammar School No. 63? It seems a reflection upon us if a man like Mr. Myers can pass away and leave scarcely a ripple.

Meyer, otherwise known as "Red" Davis, a clothesline peddler, who was arrested yesterday morning on a charge of larceny in the flathouse at 153 East One Hundred and Thirteenth Street, had a hand-to-hand struggle with the detective who arrested him on the fire-escape out-side the fifth floor, that came near costing both detective and prisoner their lives.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- Clarence Buckingham will take the position of President of the Northwestern Elevated Road to-morrow, when the changes are made by which the Yerkes element retires from the management of the property. Mr. Buckingham has been a Director and Vice President of the company for some time, and is one of the representatives of the Mitchell and Blair interests.

HAVANA, Feb. 26 -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention this afternoon, after a discussion of several hours, adopted one article defining the proposed relations with the United States, namely, that Cuba would not make treaties with any country which would endanger the sovereignty of the republic or allow the island to be made a base of war operations against the United States or any other country.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- A number of important bills were introduced in the Senate this morning.

There was not very much on the tapis yesterday, yet with the "Soiree Dramatique," several musicales, teas Toy Mrs. Edward Winslow and Miss Gurnee, and dinners given by Mr. and Mrs. Edmund L. Baylies, Mr. and Mrs. W. Storrs Wells, and H.G. Thaw of Pittsburg, and the various recitals and card parties, it could not, for the Lenten season, be called a dull day.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Senator Marshall's bill providing for the location of a public recreation ground containing a boardwalk on the ocean front at Coney Island, from West Thirty-seventh Street to West Fifth Street, in the Borough of Brooklyn, met with considerable opposition at the hearing before the Senate Cities Committee this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In the House to-day Mr. Dayton (Rep., West Va.,) presented the second conference report upon the Naval Appropriation bill. The report still left in issue the Senate proposition for the transfer of the Port Royal dry dock to Charleston, the authorization of three submarine boats, and the promotion of petty officers to the rank of Ensign.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The House was the scene of a sensational incident late this afternoon which threw that body into a violent state of excitement. For an hour the storm raged, ending abruptly when an adjournment was taken on motion of Mr. Payne, (Rep., N.Y.,) the floor leader of the majority.

The first official statement in connection with the United States Steel Corporation -- the new "billion-dollar steel combine" -- was given out yesterday from the office of J.P. Morgan Co., setting out the names of the companies to be included in the corporation and the offer made for the various stocks.

"It is necessary to believe in God to account for the half-hour lull in the gale that was raging in midocean, about 1,000 miles east of Bermuda, on the 13th," were the words of Chief Engineer Gaetano Casarino of the Italian liner Citta di Messina, in describing the transfer of twentyfour members of the crew of the Italian steamship Jupiter to the Messina on that date.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 -- The Rev. Dr. William C. Winslow of this city, Vice President of the Egypt Exploration Fund, to-day announced a remarkable discovery among the large number of papyri recently received by him for distribution among several universities. It is said to be the oldest fragment of the Gospels known.

Negotiations are now under way by the stockholders of the North American Trust Company, which practically absorbed eight other companies on Saturday last, to secure control of two other trust companies and to liquidate their business in the interests of the North American Trust Company.

The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club met last night at Sherry's and unanimously adopted the new rule of measurement which special committees of the New York, the Larchmont, and the Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Clubs recommended for adoption. The rule is to take effect from Jan. 1, 1902, any boats built after July 1 next to come under the rating.

The Strathmore Apartments, on the northeast corner of Broadway and Fifty-second Street, were badly damaged by fire and water early last evening. Three alarms were turned in, and the blaze illuminated the neighborhood for blocks around. A tremendous crowd collected, and the police reserves from the West Forty-seventh Street Station had great difficulty for a time in keeping the throngs back of the fire lines.

Detective Sergeants Rodden and Farrell of the Brooklyn Central Office yesterday arrested, in the Tenderloin, Manhattan, Dr. H.D. Wilbur, who has been sought for since Jan. 2 in connection with an alleged swindling game carried on at 22 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 -- The private bank of Palmer Mayer, at Des Plaines, twelve miles from Chicago, has closed its doors. It is said to have held deposits aggregating $20,000, of which $6,000 was village funds. Experiments with liquid air are said to have caused the trouble.

The Committee of Fifteen, close upon the announcement of the cessation, of the labors of the Tammany Committee of Five, descended last night upon ten alleged gambling houses in the Tenderloin, and two in the West Forty-seventh Street Precinct, with detachments of Capt. Thomas's policemen, capturing in this, the first of their raids, a few look-outs, doormen, and any quantity of gambling paraphernalia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The resignation of Frank A. Vanderlip, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, was announced, at the department to-day, to take effect upon the qualification of his successor, not later than March Mr. Vanderlip will at once become identified with the National City Bank of New York, for which institution he trill undertake a mission abroad, the nature of which is not exactly known.

The exclusive exhibition of foreign pictures by some of the clubs has nettled American painters from time to time, although the reason for such apparent neglect of the local artists in most cases may be sought in the fact that it is easier for the Art Committee of a club to borrow from the private galleries of members than to go about to the artists for exhibits.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Feb. 26 -- George Ward, a negro, who confessed to-day that he murdered Ida Finklestein, the young school teacher, who was found dying in a grove last evening, was taken from jail shortly after noon and lynched. Jailer Lawrence O'Donnell and three Deputy Sheriffs resisted the mob and were fired upon, all the deputies being wounded, though not seriously.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- The first strike in the general move for an advance in wages among the silk ribbon weavers, who met in Feist's Hall on Saturday afternoon last, was made at 8:30 this morning, when the 128 weavers employed in the mill of the Meding Manufacturing Company left their looms and marched out and down Grand Street, and thence to Harmony Hall, on Main Street.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 26 -- The will of Panlel A. Buckley, for many years a Cambridge newspaper publisher, was filed for probate to-day. The bulk of the property is given in trust for the use of Harvard University. John Buckley, brother of the testator, filed notice of a contest. The estate is estimated at about $50,000, In a codicil the testator sets forth the reasons for making no provision for his relatives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- Gen. Francis V. Greene, Grand Marshal of the inaugural parade, to-day issued his orders for that event. Major Gen. John R. Brooke will command the military grand division, and B.H. Warner of this city the civic grand division.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- There was extreme dullness in the stock market to-day, and nearly all of yesterday's firmness was lost. The bulk of activity was comprised in the shares of Lehigh Valley, United Gas, and Heading common, with the first named showing the greatest amount of recorded transactions.

Troop 2 carried off the honors in the eleventh annual mounted games of Squadron A, held last night in the armory, Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street. The athletic horsemen of Troop 2 won eight events handily, and the total number on the programme was eleven. Privates John Jerome Kelly and Henry E. Holt did the best individual work of the evening, each won two events, and Holt got one second.

Wall Street devotes itself to steel trade developments. Hardly any other business topic gets attention. The official announcement that the United States Steel Corporation is completed and that the merger into it of most of the important iron and steel properties of the country will now proceed disposes of all the stock jobbery tales of snarls and obstacles and possible failure.

PARIS, Feb. 26 -- To-day's session of the Chamber of Deputies ended with an uproarious scene such as had not been witnessed for many months. Heretofore the Chamber has discussed the Law Associations bill with much moderation and with an avoidance of, inflammatory language, but a word uttered this evening by Baron Xavier Reille, Deputy for Castress, provoked a storm which raged in the Chamber for fully half an hour.

President J.G. Schurman of Cornell University was down on the programme of the fourteenth annual banquet of the Life Underwriters' Association, which was held at the Hotel Savoy last evening, for a speech on "The Insurance of Nations." He embraced the opportunity for ventilating his views on the proper attitude of the United States toward the Philippines.

Pease Elliman have sold for W.G. Park the lot 32.6 by 100.5, on the north side of Fifty-first Street, 160 feet east of Fifth Avenue, to Builder John T. Farley, who will erect thereon an American basement dwelling of the highest class. The lot adjoins the new Union Club site at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street, and the price paid for it by Mr. Farley is reported at $110,000.

Thomas G. Barker, who shot the Rev. John Keller at Arlington, N. J., on Sunday, Feb. 3, is now at his home. He was released from the Hudson County Jail at 1:30 o'clock P. M. yesterday, though he was not formally set at liberty until 2 o'clock. This occurred at Judge Blair's private office, in the Weldon Building, in lower Jersey City.

No student of the tenement house question can fail to be impressed with the moderation and practicality of the report of the Tenement House Commission. The tenement house question is indeed a group of questions, including sanitary questions, sociological questions, and political questions.

About one hundred men last night attended a dinner at the Metropolitan Club, given to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the National Bank of North America. The bank's President, Warner Van Norden, presided. Among the prominent financiers present were the following: William F. Havemeyer, John H. Flagler, Alyah Trowbridge, M.D. Thatcher, H.H. Cook, H.F. Dimock, D.H. Houghtaling, and Salem H. Wales.

GUIGUINTO, Bulacan Province, P.I., Feb. 26 -- The United States Philippine Commission has arrived from Manila, and has organized a Provincial Government for this province, which until recently was controlled by the insurgents. The insurgent Col. Morels is still operating with his band of 300 men in a portion of the province.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The Cities Committee of the Assembly will to-morrow report favorably the Matthews bill for the establishment of a recreation park at the foot of Noble Street, Brooklyn.
The younger residents of the Fifth Ward, Brooklyn, thronged the Adams Street Police Court yesterday. They had only one topic of conversation -- the sad ending of the romance of Louise Duffy.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 26 -- Three children, locked in the home of their parents here this afternoon, while their mother ran out on an errand, were burned to death. One of them was taken out alive, but died in a few minutes in the arms of the fireman who dragged her from the house.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have noticed in your columns several letters referring to the taking of the land at Fort George as a public park, particularly in your issue of Feb. 21, signed by Mr. R.P. Bolton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- The threatening words of Senator Morgan (Dem., Ala.) uttered in the Senate last night, and indicating what appeared to be a determination to defeat the Philippine and Cuban amendments to the Army Appropriation bill, seem to have been taken too literally when first heard.
ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- Senator Slater has practically decided to split his anti-Ramapo bill so as to avoid all possible complications and remove all doubt as to its constitutionality.

Patrick Reddy, a contractor, of 78 West Twenty-eighth Street, and his foreman, Patrick Martin of 2,019 Lexington Avenue, were paroled by Magistrate Crane, in the Harlem Police Court, yesterday, when they were haled thither on the charge of reckless blasting. Later in the day there came to light for the first time the story of an exciting episode that took place as a result of the blasting for which they were arrested.

In the tournament of the New York inter-Club Bowling League last night, the Harlem Wheelmen team won three straight games from the Catholic Club five. The bowling of Dumahaut of the Harlem team, who averaged 195, was the feature of the match.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reference to your editorial on freedom of speech at Stanford University, let me, as a former student of the university and as one well acquainted with President Jordan, add a word. I believe the dismissal of Prof. Ross is an insidious rebuff to President Jordan's own great participation in the discussion of current questions.

Book prices are to go up. May 1 is the day set for the advance, and the absolute reign of the $1.50 book for 98 cents and $1.12 will be at an end. No trust has done this, but publishers by mutual consent have decided that it is to be so, and they have established most stringent regulations to enforce their decision.

ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 26 -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the law providing that contractors performing work on municipal or other public contracts shall pay the rate of wages prevailing in the locality where the work is performed, is unconstitutional, and in disposing of the question settled a number of disputes which have arisen between contractors and the authorities of New York City, involving the payment of $6,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- In both houses to-day, caustic comments were made on the action of Rear Admiral Sampson in the matter of the application of Gunner Charles Morgan. Mr. Allen, (Pop., Neb.,) in the Senate, asked Mr. Morgan (Dem., Ala.,) to yield the floor.

The Board of Aldermen and the Council met yesterday and adjourned out of respect to the memory, of Alderman Frank Dunn. Alderman McCall, the Tammany leader, introduced appropriate resolutions providing that the Aldermanie Chamber should be draped for thirty days. Alderman Dunn was forty-one years old, and represented the Twenty-fourth Assembly District.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26 -- The baseball season at Princeton was, inaugurated Monday afternoon when the first call for candidates for the freshman team, and candidates from the freshman class for the 'Varsity nine, assembled in the university cage, and took part in preliminary practice.

A double programme, embracing a shoot for the Dewar Challenge Cup, under the amended conditions governing contests for that trophy, and a match at 100 live birds, drew an unusually large attendance to the Inter-State Park shooting grounds at Queens, L.I., yesterday, and furnished excellent sport for both spectators and contestants.

The third evening concert of the Knelsel Quartet took place at Mendelssohn Hall last night. The programme consisted of Tschaikowsky's F major quartet, Opus 22; Dohnanyi's sonata in B flat minor, Opus 8, for piano and 'cello, and the Brahms quartet, for piano and strings, Opus 25. The pianist was Ernst Dohnanyi, whose sonata was heard here for the first time.
J. HANPOR FERRIS, one of the foremost builders of the town of Greenwich, Conn., died yesterday morning after a short illness, aged seventy-two years. He leaves a wife and three sons.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter of "An Old Man in Doubt" seems to have called out a great many replies, but none of these appears to suggest the only reasonable theory which answers the question, "If a man die, shall he live again? And where and how?"

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- The following table shows the total amount of resources of each of the classes of institutions subject to the supervision of the State Superintendent of Banking on Jan. 1 of each year since 1801. The figures are taken from the Banking Department's report, made to the Legislature to-day:

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 26 -- John R. Townsend of Arlington has begun suit for divorce against his wife, Ida E., on the ground of desertion. According to Townsend's bill he was married to Ida E. Deiter in Binghamton Oct. 22, 1884. One child, a boy thirteen, is living.

"Well, I see that 'Gatling Gun Howard,' as he was generally called, has met his fate at last," commented one of the army officers at the Grand Hotel after reading the war news from South Africa. "It was a wonder to me that he lasted as long as he did, for he was an intrepid and absolutely fearless fellow.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 -- In a hockey match brimful of rough and exciting play the All-Scholastic team of Pittsburg defeated the All-Scholastics of Philadelphia at the Ice Palace here to-night by the score of 4 goals to 2. It was one of the roughest games ever witnessed in the city, but Referee German was fully equal to the occasion and never hesitated an instant to deal summarily with refractory players.

The release of Mrs. NATION on bail from the Topeka Bastile was effected just in time to save the male portion of the human race from annihilation. A Michigan woman had formally notified Judge HAZEN, who seems to have been the committing magistrate, that if the illustrious prisoner was longer detained "we propose to raise the greatest army of women the world has ever known and wipe man out of existence."

"A Fool's Paradise," a three-act piece by Sydney Grundy, too obviously theatrical and artificial to, gain public favor in this hour, was used by some of Mr. Sargent's pupils at a matinee in the Empire Theatre yesterday as a medium for the exhibition of their accomplishments. The general performance was far above the amateur standard, and quite as good as most of the acting in the "popular price" stock companies.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 -- Secretary Root was in communication with Gen. Wood last night, and there was a long conference between them on the subject of the Cuban amendment to the Army Appropriation bill. The communication is by direct wire, and it is almost as direct as by long-distance telephone.

There was a flurry in the Queens County Court House yesterday morning, when a lawyer went running about the building declaring that a witness had been kidnapped from him while in the courtroom. The matter was brought to the attention of Judge Moore, but the Court could do nothing for the lawyer.
The new Police Commissioner's last official act at Police Headquarters yesterday was to dictate the following order, which was last night placed in the hands of every commander affected by it:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@ 63 1/2. There were no sales.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- In the House of Commons yesterday, on the resumption of the debate on the address in reply to the King's speech at the opening of Parliament, John Dillon (Irish Nationalist) said:

DOVER, Del., Feb. 26 -- The committee appointed last week by the House of Representatives to investigate the allegation of Representative Walter M. Hearn, Democrat, that he had been offered $2,000 to absent himself from the joint caucus and induce another Democrat to remain out of the joint session of the Legislature while the balloting for United States Senator was progressing last Thursday, met to-day to take testimony.

Like the defeated warriors in the poem, the Committee of Five is "few and faint, but fearless still." CARLYLE once had a good deal of rude fun with the idea of a "reforming Pope," when PIUS Ninth was expected to be one. But that is really mild compared with the notion of reforming Tammany.

ALBANY, Feb. 26 -- "Against the duplication of accounts in savings banks," says State Superintendent of Banks Kilburn in a report submitted to the Legislature today, "and against the practice of accepting deposits which properly belong in the banks of deposit or in the trust companies, it would be wise that the officers of the banks establish an inflexible rule, and that the law should require this from them.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 26 -- The Hackensack Armory, which was also the Opera House, was destroyed by fire to-night, and shortly after midnight the side walls began to tumble in. The building had been Hackensack's pride for a number of years, and when it was sold under foreclosure proceedings a couple of years ago, Company M of the Fourth Regiment was enabled to buy it through the liberality of the residents of the village.

The Committee of Fifteen is determined to break up the gambling syndicate in New York. The raids of gambling places in the Tenderloin Tuesday night was but the initial step in the crusade which is to be conducted. Other raids are to be made, it is understood, and the committee has determined not to stop until it has captured the "men who give the orders."

In the tournament of the Harlem Navy Bowling League on Thum Kahlsdorf's Harlem Palace Alleys, the Lone Star Boat Club bowlers won two games, the Ravens-wood team won one game and lost one, and the Scawanhaka Boat Club five lost two games. The scores:

To the Editor of The New York Times: A bill has been Introduced in the Senate by Senator Slater, and in the Assembly by Assemblyman Seymour, repealing the existent law so far as taxation of mortgages is concerned.

A dispute over a strip of land one and three-fourth inches wide and twenty feet in length promises to furnish no end of litigation in the Supreme Court. The defendant, who is alleged to be illegally holding the property, has obtained an injunction, which will prevent the plaintiff from building a six-story apartment house until the original action is disposed of.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Supplementing Mr. Chalmers Wood's letter in this morning's TIMES, headed "Some Mortgage Tax Questions," I submit below the provision which has been very generally Inserted in mortgages written in New York within the last five years.

CITY ISLAND, K.Y., Feb. 27. -- Ex-Congressman Ward's new keel sloop, designed by Gardiner Co., shows rapid progress at the Woods yard. The steel frame has already been set up and the planking will begin soon.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Ex-Senator John Laughlin of Buffalo practically made the assertion this afternoon before the Senate Judiciary Committee that the so-called Employers' Liability bill, introduced in the Senate by Senator Brackett and in the Assembly by Mr. Costello, was a bill put forward by the railroads to meet the Governor's suggestion of legislation and prevent the enactment of legislation that might help the employe.

The neighborhood of Warren and Columbia Streets, Brooklyn, experienced a smallpox scare yesterday as a result of the discovery of half a dozen cases of the dis- ease in three adjoining tenements on Warren Street, between Columbia and Hicks Streets. The discovery that the disease was epidemic in these houses was made when an investigation of a suspicious case was instituted by the Health Department.
HAVANA, Feb. 27. -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention in a public session this afternoon adopted the following declarations referring to the relations between the United States and Cuba:

The North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, which arrived yesterday, brought among her passengers a number of foreign musical artists who intend touring this country for the next four month, after which they will return to Europe. Prominent among them are Hans Winderstein and his entire Leipsic Philharmonic Orchestra, comprising seventy-five musicians and the two pianists Josef Hofmann and Josef von Slivinski.

BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- Chief Gunner Charles Morgan, United States Navy, whose name, has become known in connection with his application for consideration as one of a number of warrant officers to be advanced to positions in the line, and in indorsing which Rear Admiral Sampson expressed the hope to the Secretary of the Navy that promotions of this character would not be made, came to Boston to-day and called upon Admiral Sampson.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Angus Macintosh of Haledon, known for years as an eccentric character, died Monday evening of Bright's disease in the old stone house Where he had lived thirty years. His death leaves but one member of a family of four, all of them eccentric.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Not in years, has there been a debate in the Senate which in intense interest, excitement, and passionate oratory equalled that of yesterday which culminated in the adoption of the Spooner amendment to the Army Appropriation bill and the Cuban amendment to the same bill, offered by the Committee on Relations with Cuba, and then passed the bill itself.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange shrunk somewhat yesterday compared with the excited dealing's of the day before -- the group of metal stocks reaching aggregates materially smaller; Steel and "Wire Trust's total rose little beyond the 30,000-share mark, comparing with 165,000 shares quoted on Tuesday -- the net change in that stock and in most of the others being only fractional, though Tin Plate and National Steel shares dropped a point or two apiece.

According to The Iron Age, in its weekly review of the iron and steel trades situation, there has been a continuance of the buying of iron for steel making purposes, and the market is buoyant, with prices for Bessemer pig up to $15.50, Pittsburg, as compared with $13.25 a month ago. Gray forge has shared in the advance, and, in consequence, muck bars have risen, and such lines as iron skelp have followed.

BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- The market for commercial paper is steady at 4 per cent, for indorsements and choice four to six months' single names, and 4 1/2@3 1/2 per cent, for others. The supply of paper is increasing, but the demand continues good. On call, money ranges from 1 3/4@2 1/2 per cent.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- With Mark Twain and Will Carleton advertised as "top liners," the hearing before the Assembly Committee on Public Health to-day upon the Seymour bill to license osteopaths drew a big audience to the Assembly Chamber. Mr. Carleton did not speak, but Mark Twain did.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of last Sunday W. J. Henderson, reviewing musical affairs of the preceding week, says: "But what is to become of health in art if the inspiration of the composer is to be sought in the wild philosophy of a Nietzsche or a Nordau or in the hideous dramatic fantasies of a Maeterlinck or ah Ibsen? "

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- Quotations were firm in the market to-day, but dull and unprofitable conditions still lingered. There were a few slight advances, but nothing noteworthy. There is considerable money awaiting borrowers, and a number of long-time loans have been made as low as 3 1/2 per cent.

PEKING, Feb. 27. -- At the time the executions of Chi-Hsin and Hsu-Cheng-Yu were being carried out yesterday, the foreign Ministers held a meeting and determined, on the part of the majority, against further demands for blood.

This is the story of Willie Strasser and Katie Albrecht, of the love or the prentice painter for the girl who made paper lamp shades, of their courtship frowned on by parents, their devotion, their disappearance, and the family row that ensued.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The joint Senate and Assembly Cities Committees gave a hearing to the New York Charter Revision Commissioners this afternoon in order to ascertain if possible just what legislation will have to be enacted as an outcome of the Commissioners' recent report to the Governor.

NEWPORT, Feb. 27. -- De Blois Eldredge have rented Mrs. John G. Weaver's cottage in Berkeley Avenue to H. Ray Miller of New York, and Prof. C.W. Shields's cottage in Ruggles Avenue to George Gordon King for next season.

New developments yesterday in relation to the affairs of the United States Steel Corporation were enormous dealings on the curb in the new securities, in which brokers acting for Mr. Morgan were conspicuous; a statement by Judge Gary, President of Federal Steel, in respect to the corporation and its benefits; and some more or less idle gossip about the underwriting plans.

While a force of Italian laborers were excavating in the vacant lot at 333 West Nineteenth Street early yesterday morning a massive brick wall, formerly the exterior of the cellar to a house that had stood on the spot, fell in and buried under its ruins four men. Two were killed outright.

No man, civilized or savage, Chinese or "foreign devil," can gainsay the essential righteousness of the awful retribution that has been taken at Peking. Both the Legationers and the missionaries were where they were under the shield of China. They were not slain in fair fight, but through foul perfidy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The first campaign of the "asphalt war" has been won by the Warrier Quinlan interests, as against the Asphalt Trust. This campaign has been conducted by the trust to secure the recognition of the affair as an international question in its present phase, and to induce the Administration to intervene without waiting for the action of the Venezuelan courts.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Feb. 27. -- This afternoon Darter identified as her assailant the negro "Doc" Reed, brought here, from New Castle. Last Thursday afternoon, on the streets of Irvington, she was assaulted and beaten into insensibility. She is yet in a dangerous condition. The negro was brought here handcuffed to an officer.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@63. There were no sales.

Lent has set in, at last, in earnest. The sewing classes, the charitable entertainments, the bowling and badminton clubs are now in full swing. In fact, the departure of Mrs. Astor marks the close of the New York season. There are still many in town, and there are yet many dinners. Miss Josephine Johnson gave a handsome dinner on Tuesday evening, and James J. Van Alen and a few others are still entertaining.

The Senate will perpetrate a double wrong, if, out of resentment at Admiral SAMPSON'S indiscreet expression of his views about the promotion of warrant of ficers, it should refuse to confirm the two Vice Admiral appointments. The President has sent to the Senate the names of Admiral SAMPSON and Admiral SCHLEY appointed toy him to that rank.

The organization of the new iron and steel combination shows that its scope and influence are somewhat more restricted than the original plan of its promoters was understood to contemplate. It has by no means absorbed all the facilities of production in any branch of iron or steel.

The Knapp estate tract on Washington Heights, owned by the heirs of the late Shepherd Knapp, has been sold, through J. Romaine Brown Co., to Loyal L. Smith. This property is immediately north of the so-called Columbia College tract, which was transferred on Thursday by Jacob D. Butler to Mr. Smith for a consideration of $342,500.
BOSTON, Feb. 27. -- Judge Brown of the United,States Circuit Court to-day decided against the American Bell Telephone Company in the famous Berliner patent case.

The National Baseball League and the Protective Association of Professional Baseball Players at the league meeting in the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday reached an agreement on the matters which have been under discussion since Monday, and a friendly alliance was formed which left the baseball onlookers convinced that the two had combined for the league's purpose of opposing Ban Johnson's American League.

Charged with murdering Millionaire Winlam Marsh Rice in September last, Albert T. Patrick, in the Tombs accused of forging the dead man's name to checks for many hundred thousands of dollars, was yesterday taken out of his cell for a brief breath of freedom, and almost Immediately recommitted without bail on the homicide charge by Special Sessions Justice Jerome, sitting as a Magistrate.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The Daily Chronicle has received a report, which it Relieves to be trustworthy, though it has no means of verification, that Gen. Botha has surrendered to Lord Kitchener. The paper says:

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- E.A. Cudahy, the Omaha packer, whose son was kidnapped to secure a reward of $25,000, is in receipt of an anonymous letter declaring that upon his assurance that the kidnappers will not be punished, all but $5,000 of the ransom money would be returned to him. The letter was mailed at Waukegan, Ill., yesterday and sent to Omaha.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- In the Senate this morning the Trainor bill for seventy-five-cent gas in New York City was reported favorably with amendments for reprinting and recommittal, and Senator Trainor asked for a third reading. Senator Goodsell objected and the bill went back to committee.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of Feb. 21 contained an Albany dispatch wherein, under the heading " Extravagance at Albany," it was represented that the annual expenses of the State Banking Department had increased since 1891 from $27,703,70 to $91,816,88 in 1900. I have not attempted to analyze the figures here quoted to determine their source, but they are clearly wrong.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Feb. 27. -- Within a week the price of Bessemer pig iron has advanced about $1 a ton. Since the purchase toy the Carnegie Company two weeks ago of 150,000 tons there has been a scarcity of iron, and this week but 1,000 tons were sold, the price being $14.75 a ton at the valley furnaces or $15.30 delivered in Pittsburg.

The verdict in a fifteen-thousand-dollar damage suit, trial of which was begun in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday, hinges on the question as to whether or not the singeing of a redhead duck or other fowl falls within the ordinary duties of a competent kitehenmaid. The case is brought by Augusta Skoglund, a cook, against Mrs. Mary S. Whitney.

GUIGUINTO, Bulacan, Feb. 27. -- Jose Serapio, an uncle of Aguinaldo, and formerly an insurgent Colonel, has been appointed Governor of Bulacan Province. There were several candidates, including two army officers, but the United States Commission was unanimously in favor of Serapio, who surrendered during Gen. Lawton's progress northward, and who has since been such a consistent friend of the United States that Aguinaldo published an order degrading him.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Republican conferrees nn the Revenue Reduction bill have reached an agreement on many of the items in controversy, in addition to those on beer, tobacco, bank checks, and medlcines, heretofore given.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Local stocks, especially the elevated issues, were strong today. The principal trading was in Metropolitan Elevated. The common opened at 31, advanced to 32 1/2 and closed at 31 7/8 the preferred advanced from 84 1/2 to 85 1/2, but closed at 84. South Side Elevated sold at 102 1/4, and Lake Street Elevated at 14 3/4@ 15 1/8.

The final conditions governing the America's Cup races as agreed upon between the New York Yacht Club and the Royal Ulster Yacht Club, challenging in behalf of Sir Thomas Lipton, were made public yesterday by Secretary J.V.S. Oddle of the New York Yacht Club. AS in the last international yacht race, the match is to be decided by the best three out of five races.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was extremely interested in and in sympathy with the "Artist" and "H. A. C.," and felt as if I would like to send a communication and tell them so, but thought that I would just wait and see if some woman would not precede me, either in approbation of their letters or to take up the cudgels for her sex.

The members of the Manhattan Club, to the number of more than 250, gave a dinner last night to the President of the club, Justice Charles H. Truax, and the affair was one of the largest and most elaborate that the organization has ever given. The dinner, the menus stated, was offered as a tribute to Justice Truax by the club, "in appreciation of his services toward the restoration of its prestige."
