BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The Cologne Volks Zeitung, the leading Centrist organ, argues to-day in favor of Germany maintaining a good understanding with Great Britain in order to have a freer, hand against the United States, adding:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Considerable amusement was caused among naval officers to-day by the publication in a New York paper of an article charging "Admiral Schley's friends" with having given out Admiral Sampson's now famous indorsement of Gunner Morgan's application, with the design of injuring Sampson's chances for the Vice Admiralty.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Philippine amendment as agreed to in the Senate is as follows:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Reports from Peking that Minister Conger has six months' leave of absence are unfounded. He has only sixty days' leave. It Is believed here, however, that when he returns to the United States he will apply for an extension of his leave, and that in time he will resign his post.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letters which have appeared from "An Old Man in Doubt" and others in relation to immortality are deeply interesting. A subject so personal to us all can but demand earnest attention from those who think. Its solution, however, is beyond our ken.

The annual dinner of the Brooklyn Bar Association, which was given last night in the Pouch Gallery. Brooklyn, took the form of a complimentary banquet and reception for Justice Edgar M. Cullen of the Court of Appeals. H.C.M. Ingraham, President of the Association, acted as toastmaster. Justice Cullen was introduced as "the man who was born to be a Judge, just as Emerson was born to be a poet."

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- The upward move-, ment of Motion stock during the last few days has revived the rumors that either the Big Pour or the Southern Railway will get control of this property in the near future. No doubt is entertained, that the Monon will be absorbed by one of the Morgan roads as soon as the Beattyville suit, now pending in the Supreme Court, has been decided.

Wilson P. Foss, the Glass A champion billiard player, broke all records for amateur games at 300 points, fourteen-inch balk line, last night in his exhibition match with Frank A. Keency in the Crescent Athletic Club, Brooklyn. Foss ran out his 300 points in 17 innings, giving him the recordbreaking average of 17 11-17.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The Rev. Dr. Robert Alexander, a widely known Presbyterian clergyman, and editor of The Presbyterian, died at his home, here, to-day, after an illness of five weeks. Death was due to a complication of diseases. Dr. Alexander was born in Belmont County, Ohio, in 1837.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As an appreciative reader of THE TIMES, I have watched, for editorial comment on the last Sampson episode, and, while what was said in the Topics of The Times column yesterday and to-day -- especially the latter -- was excellent as far as it went, it did not, in my opinion, go far enough.

Atlantic City for the amateur golf championship in the second week of September, Baltusrol for the women's championship during one of the first two weeks in October, and Myopia Hunt near Boston for the open championship at a date to be fixed by the Executive Committee were the awards for the three National golf championships made last night at Delmonico's by the delegates of the United States Golf Association.

Feeling runs high among the members of the Cropsey Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church at Bensonhurst. The joint Board of Trustees and Stewards has decided by one vote not to recall the Rev. Orrin Wilmer Snodgrass, who has guided the flock of that church during the last year.

-- In the address read by Surgeon General WYMAN at the recent Pan-American Medical Congress, something approaching discouragement was expressed at the small degree of success yet attained in the suppression of diseases known to be suppressible. Referring, among other diseases, to smallpox, Dr. WAYMAN said: "In vaccination we have an absolute preventive, and in the glyoerinized lymph we have a safe inoculating material absolutely devoid of the danger of exciting undue inflammation.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 28 -- The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dr. W.H. de Beaufort, said to-day in the Second Chamber of the States General that the exequatur of Herr Pott. Dutch Consul at Lorenzo Marques, had been withdrawn by Portugal because of the illegal importation of heliographs for the use of the Transvaal troops and the alleged wrongful issue of passports.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28 -- The appraised valuation of the estate of B.M. Shanley, according to the accounting just filed with Surrogate Ellor by John W. Whelan and W.G. Shiler, is over $6,000,000, including interest and dividends earned since Mr. Shanley's death. Of this amount nearly $600,000 is cash in banks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- Both the Senate and the House agreed to the report of the conferrees on the War Revenue Reduction bill to-day. In the Senate there was no debate on the report, but in the House there was a disposition on the part of some Democrats to open a discussion, which was abandoned when Mr. Richardson, the minority leader, advised the adoption of the report.

The disclaimer on the part of the New York Central Railroad of any intention to change the motive power employed for the movement of trains between Mott Haven and Forty-second Street will not impress the average citizen for whom the subject has interest as discreet or clever. It is characteristic of large corporations that they object to anything like premature announcement of their plans by subordinate officers.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- "The football player gets a little culture from his studies; he gets his education from his football," said Le Baron Russell Briggs, Dean of Harvard College, in discussing to-day before the Superintendents of the National Educational Association. "Some aspects of public school training."
LONDON, March 1 -- The Peking correspondent of The Daily Mail, wiring Wednesday, says:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 28 -- Rosslyn Ferrell, who shot and killed Charles Lane on the night of Aug. 10, 1900, to-day was executed in the electric chair of the Ohio Penitentiary.

The third supplementary estimate for the expenses of the German troops serving in China has just been issued in Berlin. The figures of this estimate are not in themselves very alarming, amounting only to some three-quarters of a million in our money. But the three supplementary estimates bring Germany's bill against China up to the considerable sum of $22,683.578.

The West Side Republican Club bowlers won two of three games with the Knickerbocker Athletic Club team in the New York Interclub Bowling League tournament on the West Side Republican Club alleys last night. The scores:

GREENPORT, L.I., Feb. 28 -- Fear is felt for the safety of the racing cutter Senta, now many days overdue. This boat, one of the fastest in England last season, left Southampton, England, on Jan. 22, under jury rig, to cross the ocean. She was consigned to the Greenport Yacht Basin and Construction Company here, which is anxiously awaiting her coming.
While Emil Cassi, who was a bugler of the Rough Riders in the Spanish-American war, was scouring the city for his wife, whom he thought to be lost, she was being held on a charge of shoplifting.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mark Twain, humorist, author, lecturer, critic of the Government, maligner of the flag, osteopath, and experimenter of "everything that comes along." has rung many changes upon the old cry of "personal liberty."

The chief events of yesterday were card parties, the meeting of the Bellevue Knitting and Sewing Class, at the residence of Mrs. John Vinton Dahlgren, and in the evening there were innumerable dinners. Mr. and Mrs. H. McN. Twombly gave one of twenty covers; Mr. and Mrs. George B. De Forest were among their guests. Mr. and Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer gave a dinner, and among their guests was J. Henry Smith.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28 -- On the Exchange to-day there was increased activity and strength. Practically all the transportation stocks were in good demand. West Chicago opened at 105, sold to 105 7/8, and closed there. North Chicago sold at 201. Union Traction common opened at 13 7/, sold to 14 7/8, and closed at 14 3/4, the preferred sold at 57 1/4 @ 58 1/4.

ALBANY, Feb. 28 -- The Raines Bureau of Elections bill, providing for a bi-partisan board for Greater New York, was passed to-day in both the Senate and Assembly. The vote was on strict party lines in both houses.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- This was an extremely dull day in the stock market, and prices generally showed no Improvement. Philadelphia Electric and the various traction issues showed a slight tendency toward higher prices, but could not maintain the gains.

The work of preparing the former cup defender Columbia for the coming season has been going on for some time at Hawkins's ship yard at City Island, where the yacht was laid up for the Winter. Carpenters and joiners have been aboard her for more than a week getting her into shape for the last duty which the noted racer owes to the America's Cup, that of helping to tune up the new defender.

Jesse R. Davis, the Bellevue nurse, on trial for three weeks past, accused of killing Louis H. Hilliard, an insane patient, in December last, was acquitted of the charge before Judge Cowing, in General Sessions, last night, by the jury after five hours' deliberation. The words of Foreman De Braekeleer were almost lost in the shouts of the court officers, directed toward him, to rise when addressing the court.

It is difficult to discover anything like pronounced confidence upon either side of the stock market; bear traders talk much of the height to which quotations have been raised, and the bull contingent is full of declarations to the effect that there is a speculative short interest in the market whose sponsors are inventing and spreading every manner of falsehood calculated to induce weakness.

Without much question, Mr. EVARTS was "a great lawyer." At all events, at the time of the death of CHARLES O'CONOR, he would have been acclaimed as without dispute the leader of the New York bar. And this was, in truth, his real distinction. Considering the number of able, alert, and well-equipped men who are always in the competition for it, it can never be esteemed a light or trivial distinction.

MATAWAN, N.J., Feb. 28 -- Smallpox has broken out in Keyport. But one case has as yet been reported. That is in the family of Abraham Huyler. His daughter Florence visited in New York, and when she returned she took the disease. The Huyler home has been quarantined.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 28 -- Mrs. Edwin Gould of New York, who is very fond of antiques, invested several thousand dollars in rare old pieces of furniture and bric-a-brac during her visit to New Orleans last week. In one Royal Street shop Mrs. Gould ordered $4,000 worth before finishing her ramblings about the establishment.

A joint reception, review, and parade of the Old Guard of Manhattan and the Fortyseventh Regiment of Brooklyn was enjoyed last night in the Forty-seventh Regiment Armory. Marcy Avenue and Lynch Street, by several hundred persons. The Old Guard numbeied about 300 officers and men, under command of Major S. Eilis Briggs.

The White Star liner Teutonic, which reached her dock yesterday, reports a calm passage across the Atlantic, with the exception of a few minutes last Sunday morning, when she was almost swamped by a huge wave.

One of the biggest shake-ups in the history of the Custom House occurred yesterday, when the Treasury Department, acting under suggestions from Collector Bidwell and Sureyor Croft, abolished the offices of thirty-one Staff Inspectors attached to the Sureyor's office and removed from office that number of Customs Inspectors who have been under the jurisdiction of the Surveyor.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $300 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

BOSTON, Feb. 28 -- The money market is certainly easier. Local rates unquestionably have been influenced by the weaker tone in New York. Sterling exchange is firm at an advance of 1/4 all around. Money rates, bank clearances, balances, and foreign exchange rates are reported to-day as below: clearing House rate, 2 per cent.; New York funds, 5c discount: call loans, 2@3; time money, 3 1/2@4; Clearing House exchanges, $21.147,922; balances, $1,627,984.

The fight which the residents of Long Island City are making against the approval of the proposed map of that section of the Borough of Queens, has developed the fact that with the exception of half a dozen streets the former municipality of Long Island City never took title to any of its streets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- The President to-day sent the following nominations to the Senate:

At Mendelssohn Hall yesterday afternoon a concert was given in aid of the fund to build a monument to Franz Liszt, the celebrated pianist and composer, in the city of his most famous activities, Weimar. The entertainment was the project of a resident pianist, Richard Burmeister, who played all of the piano numbers on the programme and had the assistance of Mme. Schumann-Heink to sing some of Liszt's songs.

William Maxwell Evarts, lawyer and statesman, died yesterday morning at his home, 231 Second Avenue, corner of Fourteenth Street. His death was due to an attack of pneumonia, which his enfeebled condition could not resist. Mr. Evarts had been very low on Saturday, and it was feared he would die of exhaustion, due to the gradual dissolution of his physical powers.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 28 -- The Sea Coast Railroad, formerly the South Jersey Railroad, to-day passed into the control of the Reading Company through the purchase of more than a majority interest in the common and preferred stock and the lien series "B" bonds by the Atlantic City Railroad, which, in turn, is owned by the Reading Company.

A legal fight for the possession of two children furnished considerable excitement in the Supreme Court yesterday. The father, taking a remark made by Justice Truax to signify that he could have the children, picked up one of them, a boy two and a half years old, and started from the courtroom.

PEKING, Feb. 28 -- Nothing has been done in the way of preparing quarters for the United States Legation Guard, although the arrangements for the other powers are well toward completion. The Temple of Agriculture, two miles away, would not be suitable for guard purposes. Should it be returned to the Chinese the troops would have to pitch their tents in the centre of the legation quarter.

In the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, Justice Keogh dismissed the complaint of Mrs. Augusta Skogland, a cook, against Mrs. Mary S. Whitney of 11 East Twenty-sixth Street, Manhattan, upon which the plaintiff sued to recover $15,000 for injuries alleged to have been sustained while in the defendant's service.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28 -- Whitelaw Reid to-night delivered the second and last of his lectures to the Yale students in the Isaac Bromley course, taking as his subject, "Newspapers as They Should Be."

The Treaty of Paris declares that "Spain relinquishes all claim to sovereignty over and title to the Island of Cuba." But she "cedes to the United States the Island of Porto Rico and other Islands now under Spanish sovereignty in the West Indies and the Island of Guam in the Marianas or Ladrones"; also "Spain cedes to the United States the archipelago known as the Philippine Islands."

Charles G. Gates, a son of John W. Gates, Chairman of the American Steel and Wire Company, was yesterday elected a member of the Stock Exchange, his admission being marked by a revival of the "hazing" of new members, which lately has been somewhat neglected.
JAMES PARK of Addison. N.Y., a prominent manufacturer of sashes, doors, and blinds, died yesterday. He was sixty years old.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 -- A day or two of energetic work in the Senate, after an understanding had been reached with ref erence to the Army Appropriation bill, has wonderfully changed the prospect for the closing week. Until a vote was taken on the Army bill there was no assuranre to anybody that several bills would not fail.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 28 -- Mme. Sarah Bernhardt, who is now playing at the Tulane Theatre here, has given the proprietor and employes at the St. Charles Hotel, where she has apartments, more to think about than the more romine of hotel life.

Exciting, aggressive, and dashing hockey in its superlative form was displayed at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening, when, before an uproarious crowd of nearly 3,000 persons, the New York Athletic Club wrested victory from the Crescent Athletic Club by 6 goals to 4, and so won the championship of the Amateur Hockey League of the United States from the club that held the title in 1898, 1899, and 1900.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt shows that at the close of business Feb. 28 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,087,019,001, a decrease for the month of $7,576,374.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The President to-day vetoed the House bill to refer certain claims for Indian depredations to the Court of Claims. The President points out that some of the beneficiaries under the bill already have had their claims disallowed by the Court of Claims and that all the claims should be disallowed on the principle that they arose during the pendency of war with the Indians.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Much criticism has been provoked from neurologists and others by the testimony of Prof. Austin Flint in the contest over the will of Miss Brush, Christian Scientist.

There will be a great exodus of Republicans from the city to Washington today to be present at the inauguration. Gov. Odell, accompanied by Major Bird, his Military Secretary, and other members of his staff, will arrive in the city from Albany early this morning, and go to Washington in a private car.

The Thomson Building, 38 Wall Street, a seven-story structure, on plot 21.6 by 96.4, has been sold by the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company to Nathaniel L. McCready, through Brokers Ogden Clarkson. Post Flagg, in which firm Mr. McCready is a special partner, will occupy part of the building upon the expiration of existing leases.

Stephen W. Baldwin, sales agent for the Pennsylvania Steel Company, denies emphatically a report emanating from Philadelphia that a new combination, made up of the Pennsylvania, the Bethlehem, and the Cambria Steel Companies, has been organized to fight the United States Steel Corporation. To the contrary, Mr. Baldwin declares that it will be a good thing for the trade if the United States Corporation is successfully carried through.

If there is not soon a "shake-up" in the Central Office Detective Bureau it will be because Commissioner and Chief Murphy, after possessing full information in regard to every man under the command of Capt. Titus, is convinced that none is unfit for the position he holds, whether he be a patrolman detailed to the Detective Bureau or a Detective Sergeant.

-- One does not hear, nowadays, when a steamer has an experience like that of the Teutonic on her last voyage over, quite so much talk about "tidal waves" as always resulted from such episodes a few years ago, but even now there seems to be a very general misapprehension as to what happens in these cases, and a still more general misapprehension as to why it happens.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Carrying out the policy inaugurated by the State Department when it changed its military force in China into a legation guard, the War Department has sent orders to Gen. Chaffee to still further reduce his force. The General now has under his command about 1,800 men, composed of Troops I, K, L, and M, Sixth United States Cavalry; Battery F. Fifth Artillery, and the Ninth Infantry.

The standing threat of the Queen, in Lewis Carroll's classic, to cut off the heads of those who disobey her, does not keep the Cheshire Cat from grinning nor the Hatter from having his little joke. It is the certainty, not the severity, of punishment, that holds criminals in check.
LONDON, March 1. -- The Statist, dealing with the steel combination in the United States, says:

Thomas Chatterton, the poet-prodigy, was born Nov. 20, 1752, of intelligent parentage, his father being a schoolmaster, as well as a noted numismatist. The poet was regarded as below par, mentally, in his early years, having a distinctly stupid manner. At the age of six and a half years his mother is said to have considered him "little better than an absolute fool."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 1. -- Ernest Hecht, on trial for the murder of Mrs. Louise Foster, told his story of her death to-day. He first described how he met the woman, and of their subsequent friendship and love. He maintained that their relations were platonic, and that there was an irresistible affinity between them.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 1. -- Nebraska's State Penitentiary, three miles from this city, was almost destroyed by a fire which started at midnight last night. The loss will be about $200,000, with no insurance. There was no disorder among the convicts, who were guarded by militiamen, hastily summoned from Lincoln.

Transfers -- First Lieut. Frederick W. Van Duyne, from the Eleventh Infantry to the Fourth Infantry, Company A; First Lieut. Clyffard Game, from the Fourth Infantry to the Eleventh Infantry, Company E.

Plans for what will be practically a new County Court House have been suggested to Morgan Slattery, the architects who do the city's work, by Justices Truax, Dugro, and Scott, as a committee representing the Justices of the Special and Trial Terms of the Supreme Court.

HAVANA, March 1. -- Senor Capote, President of the Cuban Constitutional Convention, called upon Governor General Wood this morning and informed him that the Convention felt itself in an embarrassing position, owing to the vote in the United States Senate. He said the delegates had not decided whether to continue the sessions or to dissolve.
ALBANY, March 1. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the bill of Mr. Fowler appropriating $170,000 for the rebuilding of the State Normal School at Fredonia, destroyed by fire some two months ago.
The Citizens' Council bowlers won both their games in the New York Royal Arcanum Bowling League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

It was stated yesterday by a man closely in touch with the work of the Committee of Fifteen that there would be no more raids for the present conducted by members of this committee. The first raid, it was said, accomplished all that the committee hoped to do, and that was but a step in the general plan the committee expects to pursue in capturing the "gambling syndicate."

It is no wonder that all the Powers which have any substantial commercial interests in the Far East should have risen up to remonstrate against the carrying on of separate negotiations between China and Russia, and especially to the transfer of these negotiations from Peking to St. Petersburg.

BOSTON, March 1. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in good supply at 2 per cent. New York funds were in better demand and sold at 5 cents discount and par for cash. Time money is freely loaned at 3 1/2 per cent. for four to six months on good mixed Stock Exchange collateral.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Will you kindly permit me, as one of the white men of the South, to say how sincerely regret that you should have given such favorable and conspicuous notice to the book by William Hannibal Thomas on the American negro? The book is a calamity; the general acceptance of its spirit and its methods would be little short of a catastrophe.

The town attractions were not many yesterday. As usual there were the meetings of sewing classes. The O.N. held its second session at the residence of Mrs. Frederick Neilson, 100 Fifth Avenue, and the Helpers met at Mrs. di Zerega's. The evening was devoted to a few dinners and the opera. The Evening Badminton Class met at Die Berkeley Armory.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- A special to The Record from Ann Arbor, Mich., says: "Michigan has re-entered the Intercollegiate Athletic Association this year, after an absence from membership dating back some four years. The occasion of again entering the games with the Eastern colleges is the prestige gained at Paris last Summer, and the fact that in Dvorak it can send a premier athlete.
BOSTON, March 1. -- Independence is the name selected by Mrs. Thomas W. Lawson for her husband's cup yacht. Mr. Lawson announced the selection this afternoon in the following statement:

The twentieth century National Gospel campaign is being waged with vigor. The movement has already been inaugurated in something like fifty leading centres. Requests to speak in various places for the purpose of organizing the work have been coming in so rapidly to William Phillips Hall.

Persons who have had occasion to consult that valuable British publication, "Whitaker's Reference Catalogue," must have wondered why a similar work had not been prepared in the United" States to do for American books what "Whitaker's" does for English. At last we have the longdesired publication presented under the title of "United State's Catalog."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 1, -- J.P. Ord has resigned the Second Vice Presidency of the General Electric Company. It was reported that Mr. Ord had resigned to become head financial man of the United States Steel corporation. Mr. Ord. however, denies positively that there is any truth in the report.

Columbia University gymnasts won the second annual gymnastic meet with Yale last night in the Columbia gymnasium by taking first place in all of the six events, winning the meet by thirty points to twenty-four. The worst the local collegians did was one third.

To the pagan Greek poet, Meleager, who had it in mind not without some slight regard perhaps for the preservation of his own lines -- to gather for coming generations a garland of Greek thought, the world is certainty no small debtor. His beginning of the famous Greek anthology, though it contained with his own less than fifty names, proved to be a felicitous and fertile foundation.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 1. -- Peter Karpovich, who shot at and wounded the Minister of Public Instruction, M. Bogoliepoff, last Wednesday, while the Minister was holding a reception, was expelled from Moscow University in 1896 for taking part in the students' riots there. He was also opelled from Dorpat University for the same reasons in 1898, and studied at the Berlin University in 1900.

BALTIMORE, March 1. -- The Maryland Brewing Company to-day defaulted in its payment of the half-yearly interest on $7,500,000 of bonds, and the Citizens' Trust and Deposit Company of Baltimore will to-morrow file a bill asking for receivers for the company and a sale of the property under foreclosure at the end of the sixty days required by the terms of the mortgage.

Through a quarrel between two women, Benjamin J. Hill, a prominent church member and a wealthy tea merchant or Brooklyn, has become involved in a story, which according to one of the women, discloses a double life and deception. One of the women in the case is Hill's wife, who lives at 213 Grand Street.

ALBANY, March 1. -- The recommendations of the New York City Charter Revision Commission are likely to become law almost as an entirety. There may be a few changes in the suggestions made by the commission, with reference to some details, but the Cities Committee of both Senate and Assembly without much doubt will enact the voluminous report of the commission into law.

MOUNT VERNON. N.Y., March 1. -- Frank Hocking, thirty-six years old, a house painter of this city, was arrested tonight upon allegations that he has living three more wives than the law allows. The arrest was due to an investigation made by the Rev. Edwin Flynn, pastor of the Catholic Church here.

The end of the Ramapo business in the Legislature, or what appears to be the end of it, is as unexpected as it is pleasant. A fortnight ago it seemed probable that the common and greedy interests which were divided between the two parties might keep Ramapo where it was, with the same monstrously indecent but entirely bi-partisan backing.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 1. -- A romantic circumstance surrounds the marriage of Miss Lillian Augusta Martin, daughter of Samuel Martin of South Main Street, Metuchen, to Edward Peters, for although, the ceremony was performed on Christmas Day, announcement of the wedding has only just been made.

LONDON, March 2. -- In the House of Commons yesterday Charles P. Scott (Liberal) asked the Right Hon. A.J. Balfour, the Government leader, at what date in 1899 the Government was informed that, if war ensued between the Transvaal and Great Britain as a result of the differences which were made apparent at the Bloemfontein conference, the Orange Free State would undoubtedly throw in her lot with the sister republic.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- Cornell University hockey team again demonstrated at the Ice Palace here to-night that well drilled team work and concerted play are bound to triumph over individual skill by defeating the University of Pennsylvania team by the score of four goals to one. The red and blue players made an able defense in the first half of the match, and even scored the first goal.
BALTIMORE, March 1. -- Parties interested in the big combine of the tin can manufacturers said to-night that the deal had practically been effected.

Wide interest has been taken this week in the action of the American Publishers' Association in making an agreement which, after May 1 next, shall cause its members to deal in copyrighted books at net prices, save in the department of school literature, the field of fiction being left to the action of individual publishers.

"There is no great genius without a tincture of madness." asseverated solemn old Seneca, being all the more positive about it no doubt because he himself stood in no peril of a writ de lunatico inquirendo. "Great wits are sure to madness near allied And thin partitions do their bounds divide."

The beautiful new building of the Providence Public Library is notable in many ways, but perhaps its most impressive and valuable feature and the one destined most strongly to affect, not Providence alone, but the whole country, is the room containing what is called "The Standard Library," a room not intended, Mr. William E. Foster says, for study, "but as a place for the enjoyment of the books, pure and simple."

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The resolution of Mr. Pettigrew to discharge the Committee on Inter-State Commerce from consideration of what is known as the Car Croupier bill, which requires sworn statements of all railway accidents to be filed with the Inter-State Commerce Commission, was laid before the Senate to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The House removed all possibility of an extra session to-day by concurring in the Senate amendments to the Army Appropriation bill. The vote stood 159 to 134. It was a strict party vote, with the exception that four Republicans voted with the Democrats. The bill How goes to the President.

The Rev. Dr. Henry van Dyke of Princeton University is well known as one of the sincere antagonists of all that is unclean or questionable in art, literary or otherwise. The substance of his talk to the members of the People's Institute on Sunday was, therefore, not at all surprising.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- Commander Tilley, the Naval Governor of Tutulia, reports to the Navy Department, under date of Auckland, Feb. 1, that, as an act of humanity, he has added a cannibal to the crew on the United States ship Abarenda. He gives an interesting narrative of how he came to give succor and shelter to the stranger.

Second Officer Emile Zander of the North German Lloyd Liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse is the owner of a portrait of the German imperial family that has an extraordinary history. The portrait is of the Emperor, Empress, and two of the younger Princes. Glued firmly to a piece of plate glass, suspended from the ceiling of his cabin, the picture never fails to attract the attention of visitors to Mr. Zander's apartment.

Sixteen clerks were yesterday advanced by Collector Bidwell from the first to the second grade in the Customs Service and designated to take the declarations of passengers, which work was done by the thirty-one Inspectors whose places were declared vacant on Thursday by the Collector and the staff of the Surveyor under whose jurisdiction they were abolished.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- Dullness again characterized the market, though the trading was generally at slightly higher prices. Local speculation took little cognizance of the reported organization of the Cambria. Bethlehem, and Pennsylvania companies to fight the Morgan steel combine, though Cambria improved 14 on small transactions.

PHILADELPHIA, March 1. -- Superintendent Luther of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company reported to-day that fight of the company's thirty-nine collieries are closed, owing to lack of water, and that unless the supply is soon increased more mines will cease operations. The water famine in the anthracite coal region is becoming alarming.

A man who gave his name as Fred C. Manning, and said he lived at the Dry Dock Hotel, but refused to give its location, was looked up in the West One Hundredth Street Station last night, charged with burglary. Capt. Schmittberger believes the man is a Western thief with a long record.

"John Vytal, a Tale of the Lost Colony," by William Farquhar Payson, is being published this week by Harper Brothers. The story concerns Raleigh's ill-fated Roanoke expedition, and we have among the immigrants to the New World the dramatist Christopher Marlowe.

CHICAGO, March 1. -- Linseed was the favorite on the Exchange to-day. Trading in both the common and preferred shares was active and prices showed a sharp advance. Several stories were set afloat in explanation of the display of strength, but all seemed to be based more or less upon guesses.

Titusville, Penn., will awake some morning to the fact that it has a monument to the early borers for petroleum which would not be out of place in one of the big cities of the Union. A symbolical statue is being modeled by Charles H. Niehaus for the architectural setting designed by Bingham of Boston.
WASHINGTON, March 1. -- The Senate to-night sustained a point of order against a Nicaraguan Canal amendment to the Sundry Civil bill offered this afternoon by Mr. Morgan.
A man, well dressed and about forty years of age, walked into the reception room at Bellevue Hospital at 1 o'clock this morning and asked for immediate treatment.

The pleasantry of the late WILLIAM M. EVARTS in a dinner table conversation with Senator DEPEW, to the effect that he attributed his long life, general good health, and ability to commit all sorts of gastronomic indiscretions to the fact that he never took any exercise, has been much quoted and very generally misunderstood.

ERNEST SETON-THOMPSON.-- Ernest SetonThompson, the authorr of "Wild Animals I Have Known," gave a lecture last "week Friday at 11 o'clock in the Carnegie Lyceum, his subject being "Selected Scones from Animal Land." Mr. SetonThorapson has made an extensive lecture tour, and this was the only occasion on which his friends hard had an opportunity to hear him in New York this Winter.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 1. -- In a fire to-day which destroyed the Leary Dye Works, a five-story brick structure at the corner of Platt and Mill Streets, two lives were lost, one man fatally injured, and ten other persons seriously hurt. The unidentified bodies, those of a man and a boy, are at the city morgue.
Under the caption of "1,000 for 40 cents," the following item recently appeared in one of the New York newspapers:

Andrew Lang presumably is the writer for The London Daily News who recently advanced the theory that no poet could possibly be a pessimist. The theory applies to poor poets as well as gifted singers, for it is based on the idea that no one who finds any great joy in life can be a pessimist -- that is to say, can believe that there is nothing worth living for.

"N.S.," Pittsfield, Mass., writing to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, says: "The mention of 'Editors' Ways' by your correspondents touches a responsive chord, because I have been used even worse by one of the leading magazines, and, singularly enough, the manuscript in question was a satire.

BANGOR, Me., March 1. -- Arrangements were completed here to-day for the erection of two more pulp mills on Penobscot waters, and it is expected that the plants will be completed and in operation before Jan. 1, 1902.

The Philharmonic Orchestra of Leipsic. Germany, conducted by Hans "Winderstein, gave its first concert in the United States last night at Carnegie Hall. The experiment of bringing an entire orchestra of this kind across the ocean is something different from the importation of Edward Strauss and his importation and should have been considered most anxiously by its projectors before it was undertaken.

That is an interesting and amusing summary which is given upon another page of the procedures of the Examining and Reading Committee of the Boston Public Library. The task which the committee has set itself is evidently invidious and it appears also to be superfluous.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1. -- Play in the woman's championship of South Florida began this morning with an entry list of about forty, of whom twenty-two turned in scores. Miss Downey of the Apawamis Club, Rye, N.Y., won the silver medal by going around in 85, which establishes a new woman's record here. Miss "Bert" Andrews of New York won the bronze medal, scoring 88.
ANNAPOLIS, March 1. -- The following letter from Admiral Dewey was read to the naval cadets this evening on the occasion of the opening of the lecture course.

The second part of the collection made by William Harris Arnold of this city, comprising over 300 books -- principally first editions of English authors -- and about 70 autograph letters and manuscripts possessing more than usual interest, will be sold by Hangs Co., without reserve in April.

For many years the people of the Borough of Richmond have demanded better ferry service and newer boats. But the ferry company was deaf. Then they went to the city, asking that it interest itself in their relief. But the city heard them not. Now they have asked the sovereign State of New York to intervene.

RICHMOND, Va., March 1 -- It is stated on what is regarded as unquestioned authority that in July the general offices of the Seaboard Air Line system will be removed from Portsmouth to Richmond. Parties interested in the Seaboard have purchased one of the largest office buildings here.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

A distinctly novel plan for missionary work by the league of American Wheelmen in the interest of good roads will be put into operation this year, beginning on June 13, when a "good roads" special railway train will start on a tour of the United States with the purpose of demonstrating to the farmers of the country the ends the L.A. W. has in view.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The death of the Queen naturally called forth all the resources and the enterprise of the London press. The illustrated papers issued what were in most cases the most elaborate numbers that have ever appeared. Not to disparage any of the others, it might be mentioned that The Sphere.

An unidentified man fell dead on the corner of Rivington and Pitt Streets last night at 6:30 o'clock. Shortly afterward Policeman O'Farrell arraigned three prisoners in the Madison Street Police Station.

So many travelers have writ fair and large their impressions of Northern Africa that it is only necessary to pronounce the word Sahara, Algeria, Tunis, or Tripoll to conjure up a multitude of more or less accurate pictures of mosques, bazaars, and camel-trodden streets, while the kaleidoscopic procession of gaudily dressed, swartskinned Moslems fill the mental stage like the grand chorus of an opera bouffe.
LONDON, March 2. -- The War Office has received the following from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria, March 1:

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Gov. Roosevelt's arrival in Washington had no brass band features and was entirely destitute of excitement. This was not the fault of the Washingtonians, who gathered at the Pennsylvania Depot to receive him at 4:10 o'clock, the hour at which his train was to arrive.

Mr. Jean de Reszke himself is authority for the statement that his name was not removed from the cast of "Gotterdammerung" for next Wednesday night because of alarm about his health. Re expects to be quite well enough to sing by that time. He has decided, however, that this year he will sing both or neither of the Siegfrieds.

PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- A stronger tendency in the steel issues, outside of the Morgan combine, was the only noticeable thing in the stock market to-day. This was due to the report that the Bethlehem, Cambria, and Pennsylvania Steel Companies will form a defensive alliance.

This, our third month of the year, used to be considered by the ancient Romans as their first month, the legal year beginning on the 25th day of the month, and they gave it the name Martins in honor of the god Mars. The ecclesiastical calendar of England also began with March until 1752.

GLASGOW, March 2 -- At a dinner party yesterday evening, at which the success of the Shamrock II, was toasted, Sir Thomas Lipton and George L. Watson replied. The latter mentioned that when Sir Thomas commissioned him to build the yacht he said:

NEWARK, N.J., March 2 -- Vice Chancellor Stevens grave a hearing to-day on the application to make permanent the order restraining the American Smelting and Refining Company from increasing its capital stock from $65,000,000 to $100,000,000 and from consolidating the interests represented by M. Guggenheim's Sons and other interests in the United States and Mexico under its management.

The water famine which threatens Brooklyn has led to a public-spirited movement to establish a distributing reservoir in Forest Park and to make other improvements in the water mains and sources of supply which will take away the danger from a disastrous conflagration on account of lack of water and provide a sufficient supply in reserve to avert the impending dangers because of water shortage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to say to "An Old Man in Doubt" that the question of immortality is not one capable of demonstration in identically the same way that a mathematical problem is, and yet the moral argument for immortality is so strong that it has convinced the great majority of the wisest and the best men of all the ages.
Firstly, the zebra is striped because it is to his interest to be conspicuous. Secondly, he is striped because it is to his interest to be invisible.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The position of the bills now in conference between the two houses is regarded to-night as satisfactory, and little fear is entertained that any of the important measures will fail.

Many important Wall Street men are away from business; there is an extensive Stock Exchange colony in Florida, and the list of absentees is likely to extend rather than shrink during March. This phase of current business affairs is much dilated upon by speculators who desire to see the stock market go down.

The disclosures regarding the alleged double life, which has been led by Benjamin J. Hill, a wealthy Brooklyn tea merchant and a church member, have caused much comment in the old Williamsburg section of the borough, where Mr. Hill's home is. The disclosures were made through the action of Mrs. Hill, who caused the arrest of Mrs. Belle Devlin, the woman who accuses Mr. Hill, on charges of assault.

Several unexpected upsets occurred in the standing of the clubs in the local bowling tournaments last week. In the New York Inter-Club League series the Knickerbocker Athletic Club lost second place to the West Side Republican Club and the Catholic Club replaced the Harlem Wheelmen at the bottom of the list.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The last of the big supply bills of the Government -- the General Deficiency measure -- was passed by the Senate to-day, thus clearing the decks for final adjournment of Congress. The indications now are that the Senate will do little more than consider conference reports during the remainder of the session.

Because she refused to affix her signature to testimony given by her in supplementary proceedings and insisted on having her own way in the matter. Mrs. Marie McKenzie Enright was threatened with commitment to Ludlow Street Jail for contempt of court by Justice Truax, in the Supreme Court, yesterday.

Arthur E. Howe was the star performer in the games of the DeWitt Clinton High School Athletic Association last night at the armory of the Eighth Regiment. He was the winner in three events: the sixty-yard junior dash, the sixty-yard hurdle, and the pole vault.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After the assault on Charles Sumner in the United States Senate Chamber, a meeting was held in the old Broadway Tabernacle to give expression to the feeling of indignation caused by that unparalleled outrage. Among the speakers were Henry J. Raymond, Lyman Trumbull, William M. Evarts, and Henry Ward Beecher.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 2 -- There is a great scarcity of water all through the upper section of New Jersey, and much alarm is occasioned thereby, especially among the farmers, who are compelled to drive their stock a long distance to the larger streams. Their cisterns and springs have long since run dry, and they are now confronted with a water famine that may prove very serious.

BALANGA, Bataan, March 2 -- Provincial government has been established in the last province of Brig. Gen. F.D. Grant's district. Gen. Grant, speaking to a representative of the press to-day, said he could not at present recommend the organization of civil governments in either Bulacan or Bataan Province.
The imports of dry goods and general merchandise for the week were valued at $10,954,867. The imports of specie amounted to $260,374, and the exports of specie to $1,295,404.

In a world by himself ex-President BENJAMIN HARRISON takes in hand an occasional pen to communicate to his fellow-men through the columns of The North American Review his musings upon current topics. He is ill-content with the way the outside world wags. Especially unacceptable in his view are the doings of the Administration of WILLIAM MCKINLEY.

OTTAWA, Ontario, March 2 -- Early this morning the House of Commons, by a vote of 125 to 19, passed Mr. Costigan's motion that an address be presented to King Edward asking that the portion of the coronation oath so offensive to Roman Catholics be eliminated.

BALTIMORE, March 2 -- The Baltimore, Chesapeake and Atlantic Railroad Company has made an offer for the Wheeler Transportation Line, which owns valuable wharf property on the Choptank and Tuckahoe Rivers in the eastern part of Maryland. The Pennsylvania Railroad controls the Baltimore, Chesapeake and Atlantic Company, and is gradually securing possession of every railroad and steamboat line on and to the Peninsula.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your leading editorial of this morning, concerning the War Tax Reduction bill, is a great disappointment, for it smacks more of the demagogue than of the statesman.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 2 -- Vice President C.W. Somers of the American Baseball League announced to-day that James J. Collins and Hugh Duffy, who played third base and centre field, respectively, for the Boston National League Club last year, have signed contracts with the American League.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed a couple of paragraphs in your London lettfer, in to-day's TIMES, which it seems to me should not be allowed to pass unchallenged. Mr. Alden's always interest ing communications are seldom marred by such a lack of knowledge as is evident in his remarks concerning "bridge."

BRISTOL, March 2 -- As there is now to be no flying start in the international cup races next August, according to the decision of the New York Yacht Club, every one familiar with the sport of yachting in Bristol breathes freer, the time-honored mode of starting with a preparatory gun fifteen minutes previous to the send-away, and a warning gun ten minutes later than the preparatory gun, being favored generally.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 2 -- The local police have succeeded in clearing away the mystery surrounding the recent incendiary fires in this city. They have the incendiary under arrest and have secured a full confession from the prisoner, who is John Bahr of this city. Bahr, who is twenty-one years old, served as a volunteer in the Third New Jersey Regiment during the Spanish-American war.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The mortgage tax question is of sufficient importance to justify its agitation until a just law shall have been passed.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The training ship Dixie, now on its way to Washington to participate in the naval display, ran aground off Maryland Point. At last reports she was still hard and fast.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 2 -- Troop A, Cleveland's crack military company, which is to act as personal escort to President McKinley in the inaugural parade, left here at 2 o'clock this afternoon over the Pennsylvania Railroad.

DULUTH, Minn., March 2 -- One thousand shares in the Lake Superior Consolidated Iron Mines, the Rockefeller organization of the Mesaba range, were sold here today at $78,000. They belonged to the widow of a Methodist preacher who was stationed here at the time of the development of the Mesaba range ten years ago, and who had in his flock the various members of the Merritt family, who discovered and opened the range.

An unusual interest attaches to the coming annual meeting of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, which is announced to be held at the Hotel Marlborough, in this city, on Saturday, March 16, for the reason that several matters of importance to the welfare of the association will come up for action and the manner of their disposition is likely to have a wide effect upon the future of the association.

Trying though the weather has been for building operations during the month of February, it did not materially interfere with work at the Pan-American Exposition buildings at Buffalo. Work on the Electric Tower, which will be one of the great show buildings of the whole collection, was practically completed during the past week, and the removing of the scaffolding about the figure of the Goddess of Light was begun.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Both the House and the Senate to-day passed the omnibus public building bill, carrying increases for forty public buildings. The Senate accepted the measure as it came from the House, without amendment.

One new play will be produced this week, while some revivals of interest will occur. The new play is a dramatization of "To Have and To Hold." and will be presented at the Knickerbocker Theatre by Charles Frohman. A new departure will be introduced at the Knickerbocker Theatre during the run of this play.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 2 -- During the day William H. Gale of the Providence police force received a dispatch from a New York undertaker saying that the body of Mr. Gale's brother, killed in a Bowery restaurant, had been turned over to him and asking instructions. Policeman Gale doubts that the dead man was his brother.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your issue of yesterday contains an article from Mr. Carver of Brooklyn in regard to "An Old Man's Doubts" in your issue of the 22d. Your correspondent of the 27th think an "analysis of the matter must prove of service." He asks "Of what is this old man afraid? Has he, like all other mortals, sinned?"

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The question of precedence at the inauguration ceremonies, which has been somewhat troublesome since foreign Governments began sending Ambassadors instead of Ministers to the United States, has been raised with regard to the allotment of seats in the Senate Chamber.

How could any one who looked like a doll and dressed like a fashion plate be anything but frivolous! The members of the club, which met around from house to house, felt sure that the pretty and frivolous one had not an idea in her head that was more practical than her own gowns.

Assistant District Attorney PIERCE has made an important announcement. Speaking of the employment of expert testimony he said: "Nothing is so destructive of law: nothing has caused so much disrespect for the courts. I can say here that this office will not pay out thousands of dollars for expert testimony in future.

LONDON, March 2 -- Is it peace? No, but it might he a truce. Thursday several of the least reputable of our evening newspapers flamingly published the assertion that Gen. Louis Botha had surrendered to Lord Kitchener, and one of them, controlled by the notorious Bottomly, went so far as to declare the story official.

A man asked a friend to stay and have toa. Unfortunately, there was no tea in the house, so a servant was sent to borrow some. Before the latter had returned the water was already boiling, and it became necessary to pour in more cold water. This happened several times, and at length the boiler was overflowing, but no tea had come.

LONDON, March 2 -- The release of the bankers' balances augmented the supplies of cash, but the payment of u3,000,000 for the latest issue of Treasury bills caused a demand and keeps the market firm, though there are indications of an easier tendency. The calls upon the market during the next few days, apart from the repayment of loans to the Bank, will be comparatively trifling.
LONDON, March 3 -- The elections yesterday for members of the London County Council resulted as follows:

SHANGHAI, Jan. 20 -- Woman in China enjoys the distinction of having escaped the admiration of foreigners. Her praises are unsung in the verses of other lands; she is not enshrined on the canvas of those whose ideals of outward being the world has adopted; she has flashed no wit upon the part of romance or dazzled it with her beauty.

Among English royal ladies Queen Charlotte is the best known snuff taker. Her Majesty used to add a teaspoonful of green tea to her box every morning. Frederick the Great's mother was subjected to a rebuke from her son for taking a pinch during the tedious ceremony of his coronation. In Germany it was then considered improper to take snuff before persons one wished to pay respect to or during conversation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The correspondence you are publishing on the immortality of the soul touches the heart of every thinking man. Any word, therefore, that can throw a single ray of light upon this questio vexata should be weighed with care.

Reports published in this column from day to day render unnecessary any statement as to the volume of current business; while it is at the same time gratifying to those who have for months and perhaps years derived cold comfort in the discovery of tendencies toward activity to be in a position to say simply that the activity is here.

ITHACA, March 2 -- As the days pass and the Football Committee of the Athletic Council still declines to give out the name of next year's coach, the opinion is gaining ground that the man who will next year teach the Ithacans their football will be Lieut. "Joe" Beachman, United States Army.

With the settlement of the all-important questions in National golf, at the recent annual meeting of the United States Golf Association, namely, when and where the big championships for 1901 will be played, the various clubs can now prepare for the coming season and arrange their tournaments so as not to conflict with the leading events.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to protest against a prevalent inclination to consider some of the historical parts of the Bible as allegorical or mythical. At a Broadway Episcopal church recently the preacher mentioned the Bible history of the "Fall of Man" as "a quaint childish story -- an allegory," and stated his belief that "the events did not actually occur as narrated."

Even in the brightest room, plants are never of so rich a green as those grown out of doors. In a dark cellar no chlorophyll is produced at all. Every one has seen potatoes growing there, with their long attenuated stalks and little, white leaves, which exist but for a time, and when the reserve material in the tuber is used up, wither away, because they have no light.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 2 -- The residence of Major Harry Cushing, U.S.A., retired, situated on Davenport Neck, was robbed last night. The burglary was not discovered until this morning, when Detective McSweene'y discovered the back door of the house open. Major Cushing is away, and the burglars had a free hand.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was on a smaller scale than on Friday, but the total was a large one for Saturday. The steel stocks remained the most active and prominent issues, but there was also considerable trading in a number of other stocks. The tone of the market was fairly strong and a number of advances showed in the final quotations.

There has been a good deal of stir in Washington of late about the embellishment of the capital. The American Institute of Architects, at its late session in that city, pleaded for a systematic and comprehensive treatment of the public improvements of Washington. It was a perfectly legitimate plea, seeing that the appearance of the capital is a matter, not merely of local, but of National pride and importance.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The President has issued a proclamation putting in force a new extradition treaty between the United States and Switzerland. Up to this point the two countries have been getting along in an unsatisfactory manner as to extradition matters under some very general provisions contained in two or three sections of the old treaty of amity and commerce, and it has been deemed better to modernize the arrangement.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The night session of the Senate was devoted largely to listening to a speech from Mr. Chandler urging an investigation of the election of W.A. Clark as a Senator from Montana. The galleries were crowded, and many Senators present were in full dress.

In the "Floresta Espanola" of Melchior de Santa Cruz the author has an anecdote of Cardinal Pedro Goncalcz. That prelate noticed that one of the priests in his retinue, a Biscayan, carried a short sword under his cloak. The Cardinal reproved him, and told him that it was wrong for a cleric to carry arms.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are four points in the letter of W. Wingrave Carver, in this morning's TIMES, upon which I should like to say a word. First, it seems to me that he is mistaken in assuming that if the "Old Man" suffers in consequence of his doubts, it must be from fear.

Society has settled down to a quiet and conventional Lent. Quite a number of the very fashionable set have departed for the country and for Florida and California, and a few have gone abroad. To mark these departures many dinners were given last week, and town was so gay that it was hardly possible to realize that it was actually the penitential season.

LONDON, March 2 -- George W. Lederer announces that he has completed negotiations to erect in New York City a big theatre, the exact duplicate of the London Hippodrome, a sort of compromise between a theatre and a circus.

At the beginning of March, with ten weeks or so of the normal dramatic season still unfinished, there is remarkably small promise of novelty in the managers' announcements. The season opens with a rush nowadays, in the very hottest weeks of the year, and wears itself out generally soon after New Year's.
Gen. Fitzhugh Lee is said to have expressed his intention to make his home in the West, now that he has been retired from the army.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Secretary Long to-day sent to the Senate the papers in the case of Gunner Morgan, including Admiral Sampson's famous indorsement and his own. The latter has never been published before. It has been known ever since the publication of the Morgan letter with the Rear Admiral's indorsement that Secretary Long did not approve of the position taken by Admiral Sampson.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 2 -- Manager Hanlon this afternoon strongly hinted that the National League would have its innings when the American League clubs try to play the men who propose to jump their National League contracts. Evidently the National League has not been idle while the new magnates have been gathering in their stars.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Don Enrico Ruspoli of Rome, Italy, was married today to Mrs. Jennie B. Bruton of Nashville. Tenn., by Mgr. Martinelli, the Papal Delegate to the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 2 -- The case of Witthaus versus Witthaus was again before the Supreme Court to-day, when Nicholas Cohen of the firm of Howe Hummel, counsel for Mrs. Bly C. Witthaus, made a motion before Justice Keogh, holding a Special Term of the Supreme Court, to vacate the decree of divorce which has been granted Mrs. Witthaus from her husband, Prof. Rudolph A. Witthaus.

Through the unique endeavor of a young author, poet, and idealist to dispose of a sufficient quantity of his works to enable him to accomplish the establishment of an immense circulating library of the best books to increase reading among humble people, his cherished aim, a most interesting romance of love and elopement of the young author and the daughter of a city official, hitherto carefully concealed, has just come to light.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Of the many answers which came to the pathetic plea of "An Old Man in Doubt," appearing in THE TIMES a few days ago, none, in my judgment, possessed the immediate value that ought in fairness be assigned to what W. Wingate Carver has to say on the subject in to-day's issue.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 2 -- Herbert, the twelve-year-old son of Seaman Nicholas, made a bonfire behind his father's barn to-day. The flames reached the barn, and all the contents were destroyed. The loss is $1,000.

The business men of Montreal are complaining bitterly, and justly, of an increase of 50 per cent in the rates of premium for fire insurance since the recent great fire in that city, which resulted in a three-million dollar loss. It should never be necessary for the companies doing a legitimate business to jump their premium rates about in this arbitrary fashion.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The interesting letter of A.S. George in your issue of Feb. 24, in answer to "An Old Man in Doubt," reveals a very common mistake in the thought of to-day. It is the mistake that James Lane Allen makes in his "Reign of Law." Like James Lane Allen, your correspondent sets over against each other in a false contrast science and theology.

In the classical times the body was esteemed and cultivated. In the Middle Ages asceticism was so rampant that the body was despised. This again reacted upon dress, so that the mediaeval costume was entirely opposed to the classical. The latter was always of the nature of drapery, an adjunct to rather than a concealer of the figure.
ROME, March 2 -- At the reception to-day upon the occasion of the anniversary of the birth and the coronation of the Pope, His Holiness made an address, in the course of which he said:

In Rubinstein's life, as in his music, there is the highest aim, a ring of passionate sincerity; yet over and over again, if only by a hair's breadth, we feel that he failed to grasp that perfect consummation which his splendid physical, mental, and emotional gifts ought to have secured for him easily.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Feb. 22 we notice an article with the pathetic heading "An Old Man's Doubts," in which we have found ourselves greatly interested, partly because it was written by an aged man, thereby appealing deeply to our sympathy, but also that the religious difficulties as stated by him are without question closely akin to what ten thousand other souls have encountered.

The testimony of lunatics or those partially insane in criminal actions involving the life or liberty of the accused person, never before passed upon by any criminal court of this State until the trial of the nurse, Jesse R. Davis, for the killing of Louis H. Hilliard, a patient in the Bellevue Hospital insane pavillion.

Bernard J. York, ex-President of the old Police Board, last night consented to his appointment as Second Deputy of Police, and it is expected that Commissioner Murphy will name him for the place to-morrow. As soon as Mr. York had informed James Shevlin of his decision. Mr. Shevlin left for Manhattan to see Commissioner Murphy and acquaint him with Mr. York's acceptance.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 2 -- The talk and plans of decades have finally taken form, and a railway connecting the great lakes with Hudson Bay is now actually under construction. The railway plunges hundreds of miles through an unbroken wilderness, with no cities, towns, or even villages to afford traffic.

Four employes of the Peniel Restaurant, at 39 Bowery, attacked a man who had gone there to eat, early yesterday morning, and who was unable to pay 6 cents for some food he ordered. They beat him until he fell to the floor. As he fell his head struck the edge of a revolving stool beside the lunch counter.

Within hailing distance of the Mercer Street Police Station and by the light of the lamps at the rear entrance of the Broadway Central Hotel, bold burglars broke into the building at 235 Mercer Street some time Friday night or yesterday morning and carried away nearly all the contents of the clothes manufacturing establishment of Simon Garbulsky, who occupies the third floor of the building.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Throughout to-day the House has been in the throes of the closing hours of the session, with many measures clamoring for attention and with crowded galleries looking down upon the weary legislators. Work began at 9 A.M. and proceeded until 5 in the afternoon, when a recess was taken until evening to permit conference reports to be framed.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have a proposition to submit to the readers of THE TIMES, in which they should be interested.

BOSTON, March 2 -- The week closes with the money market quiet and comfortably easy. There seems to be an abundance of funds for all requirements. No increase is noted in the demand. Note brokers all report a scarcity of commercial paper. Call money ranges from 3 to 3 1/2 per cent., with exceptions to the strongest borrowers on quick call at 2 1/2 per cent.
ALBANY, March 2 -- The other day a man brought a bill to Chairman Otto Kelsey of the Assembly Committee on Cities and, after explaining to Mr. Kelsey the provisions of the bill, said:

Flatfishes keep their white and blind side on the muddy or sandy bottom, and pretend that the upper and speckled side is a part of that bottom. This they do to avoid observation, for, in spite of their awkward shape they are swallowed at sight by pertinacious enemies, to the manifest discomfort of both.

Columbia's hockey team concluded its season last night with rather a bad defeat at the hands of Brown University by a score of 8 goals to 2. The game was the last of the preliminary intercollegiate championship series to be played at the St. Nicholas Rink, and was essentially the same in nature as the college matches that preceded it.

The Grand Central Palace was swarming with White Mice yesterday afternoon. They had come there to have a meeting to prepare for their ball on next Thursday night. As everybody knows by this time, the White Mice are chorus girls who have banded themselves together for social and philanthropic purposes.
Canadians have ever resented Rudyard Kipling'ss allusion to the Dominion as "Our Lady of the Snows." Goldwin Smith has now placated them by calling it " this Land of Sunshine."

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 3 -- George Francis Gilman of the system of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Stores throughout the United States, died suddenly at his residence in Black Rock from an acute attack of Bright's disease at 3 o'clock this morning. He was seventy-five years old, and reputed to be worth $40,000,000.
PEKING, March 3 -- The American preparations for departure are going actively forward. All supplies except enough for two companies, have been packed and marked for Manila.

-- Since Admiral SAMPSON'S views on the promotion of warrant officers to commission rank were published several naval offieers have expressed a carefully qualified disapprobation of them, and not a few have exclaimed over the unwisdom of putting on paper sentiments that were sure to make trouble if by any chance they reached the public eye; but a very large majority of the officers have preserved a profound silence on the whole subject.

CHICAGO, March 3 -- The Order of B'rith Abraham, a Jewish benevolent insurance organization, opened its biennial session here to-day in Medinah Temple. Three hundred and fifty delegates were present from 207 lodges in all parts of the United States, and an audience of local members running into the thousands.

When Commissioner Murphy visited Police Headquarters yesterday an activity prevailed such as had not been seen there on an ordinary Sunday in years. Capt. Westervelt, who was detailed in charge of the force, was on hand early, as also was Chief of Detectives Titus. Everywhere clerks and employes were at their posts.

Around midnight Saturday last several policemen of the Church Street Station were busy picking up wounded men from the sidewalk at the southern end of Washington Street. Few in that locality speak English well enough to enable the police to learn anything quickly, and it was Sunday before it was known that the wounded men had all run out of the saloon of John Jacobs, 13 Washington Street.

The London County Council, if it had achieved no other good work, would still deserve some measure of praise for the wise and regular additions it has made, and continues to make, to London's open space.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- In the House yesterday afternoon Mr. Daizell, (Rep., Penn.,) from the Committee on Rules, presented a resolution for the appointment of a special committee of seven members of the Committee on Insular Affairs, not more than four of whom shall be of one political party, to visit Cuba, Porto Rico, and the Philippines and report upon the conditions there.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Senator Raines, Chairman of the Committee of the Senate on Congressional Reapportionment, and Assemblyman Kelsey, Chairman of the committee of the Assembly, are in possession of drafts of the proposed Congressional Reapportionment bill which provides for thirty-seven members of Congress in this State, instead of thirty-four.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- John T. Devine of the Shoreham Hotel, who is Chairman of the committee having in charge the banquet at the Inaugural Ball, is a thoroughly unhappy and discontented citizen to-day. The caterer is Charles Rauscher, and on him Mr. Devine relied to get up the menu for the banquet.

Mrs. L.J. Watts, the janitress of the big flathouse 141 St. Ann's Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, has, she confesses, a soft heart. She also has, she regrets to add, some sixty or seventy cats. A combination of the two has led her to the Health Board, but they say they can do nothing for her.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

BANGOR, March 3 -- Men returning from the lumber woods of Northern Maine report that the depth of snow there is the greatest in fifteen years, and that, while log hauling is seriously interfered with, and traveling difficult, the most noticeable effect of the severe weather is seen in the suffering of wild animals.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Congress is hard at work getting ready for its final adjournment at noon to-day. There are still some bills of importance about which the two houses disagree, but it is believed by the leaders that all necessary legislation will be completed before adjournment.

There were persistent rumors, both in Manhattan and Brooklyn last night, that a strike of the employes of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system is to be brought about to-day. The men, it was declared, had given an ultimatum to the company, declaring against the wearing of khaki uniforms, recently ordered for the employes on all lines of the system.

LONDON, March 3 -- Those persons who calculated that the reduction in the bank rate would bring cheap money have been bitterly disappointed this week. Money has been harder to come by than when the rate was 4 1/2 Per cent., and on many securities it was quite as dear as when the 5 per cent. rate ruled.

The little Church of the Transfiguration set into Chinatown, but deriving its support from Little Italy to the west and the tenement-house districts outside of Chinatown, offered a spectacle last night at which even the stolid Chinese stared, while their more lively neighbors rushed about in excitement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to "An Old Man in Doubt" I would suggest that it does not seem necessary that one should be forced to a condition of chronic doubt because of numerous adverse doctrinal, or dogmatic, opinions, advanced by commentators, on religious teachings and crystallized into sectarianism.

Charles T. Wilson, a clerk in Gouverneur Hospital, was arraigned in Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning charged with subornation. At the request of the District Attorney's office he was remanded to Police Headquarters until this afternoon for a further hearing. Wilson was arrested late Saturday night by Central Office Detectives Berkley, Arfken, and Woolbridge at his home, in Henry Street, at the instance of District Attorney Philbin.

BANGOR, March 3 -- Ezra Robar, the king gumpicker of Maine, has camped all Winter on Porgie Brook, and when he comes to town this Spring he will have bags and bags of amber lumps to swap for the dollars of the druggists, who always pay the highest prices for the best gum. The life of a gumpicker, without doubt, is the most lonely that a man can lead.

Renewed confidence shows in Wall Street, and as a consequence all the predictions are of higher market values this week. Sixty millions of dollars were distributed by corporations on the first of the month in the form of interest and dividends -- money that will now seek reinvestment in the market.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- According to the hotel keepers, the number of people in town to-night is not more than one-third as large as it was four years ago. This estimate is based on the number of refusals made to would-be guests. In spite of the statement, all of the hotels are crowded to the utmost, and people have had to be turned over to boarding houses for accommodations.

MARSEILLES, March 3 -- A mob of seamen and stokers, who joined the strike of dock laborers, marched to the docks this morning and endeavored to induce the crews to quit the steamers. There was some disorder before the strikers were dispersed by the police.

ALBANY, March 3 -- There is a great deal of speculation here as to Senator Platt's statement "that a State Constabulary bill will be introduced next week and passed." The speculation is in regard to whether Senator Platt and those favoring a State constabulary law have a new bill differing from those proposed the past three years.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Washington is not so wildly enthusiastic over to-morrow's inauguration as it would be if there were about to be a change in the political personnel. This inauguration is very like getting the second installment of a continued story. So the city has not "spread itself" as it might and would have done had Mr. McKinley been succeeded by one of another political faith.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I was Interested in your editorial on Saturday morning on expectoration and the penalties to be imposed on the offender.

In introducing the Rev. Dr. Joseph Silverman, who spoke at last night's meeting of the People's Institute, in Cooper Union, on the subject of "The Great Vices of Our Times,"Charles Sprague Smith, Director of the Institute, referred to the " disappearance of the Ramapo evil," and said that the people of this city were indebted for the same to one man, Bird S. Coler.

For several years the State Fish Commission has been endeavoring to induce the legislature to raise the minimum limit at which brook trout may be killed from five inches to at least six, but regularly its requests have been refused. The commission this year again named six inches as the limit, but the Joint Committee on Game and Fish has declined to accept this, and insisted that five inches must remain the legal size.

GLASGOW, March 3 -- Sir Thomas Lipton. when interviewed to-day by a representative of The Associated Press on his return from his inspection of the Shamrock II., expressed himself completely satisfied with the workmanship and progress made.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Vice President-elect Roosevelt began his day by going to church. Col. Roosevelt is a member of the Dutch Reformed Church, but as there is no Dutch Reformed Church in Washington, Col. Roosevelt attended Grace German Reformed Church, at Fifteenth and O Streets Northwest, of which the Rev. John M. Schick is the pastor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was sorry that "Common Sense," in his letter of the 26th ult., had not explained a little more fully the reasons why the theory of reincarnation solved so many of the problems of life. It is simply because it goes hand-in-hand with the doctrine of absolute justice and unalterable law.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Of all the visitors here for the parade to-morrow, those which excite the most interest are the Porto Ricans. Of all the men flitting about the streets in uniform, none are more soldierly, and on every side there are words of the highest praise for their military bearing, their neatness, and their gentle-manly behavior.

The announcement of the marriage of Miss Blanche M. Covert of One Hundred and Second Street, near Columbus Avenue, and Arthur Corsp. a young lawyer, of 129 West Ninety-fourth Street, was made public yesterday. The couple called upon the Rev. Daniel Russell, rector of the Harlem Presbyterian Church, at his home in the Montana apartment house, 35 Mount Morris Park West, on Jan. 2 and said they wished to be married.
