WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Willis L. Moore, Chief of the Weather Bureau, has relieved many a Washingtonian and thousands of visitors from the fear that the inauguration ceremonies of to-morrow will be marred by predicting in a special bulletin fair weather for Monday.

MERCHANTVILLE, N.J., March 3 -- Henry Simmons, ninety years of age, dropped dead yesterday in the railway station here from a broken heart, it is believed. Simmons had been consigned to the Poor House by the authorities. He did not want to go, and always had a dread that this might be his fate.

Cross country runners were out in force yesterday, and the regular events scheduled weekly by the local outdoor clubs were well patronised. The Williamsburg Athletic Club held one of the largest and most successful runs of the day. The start was made from the club house of the organization on Withers Street, near Graham Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- That part of Pennsylvania Avenue which is nearest the Capitol has been utterly transformed. In honor of the inauguration of President McKinley, it has been converted from an unpretentious region of houses and small shops into a Midway Plaisance. From the foot of the Capitol, for several blocks up toward the northwest, it is a faithful copy of Coney Island's Bowery.

Sir MICHAEL HICKS-BEACH, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, in a speech in the House of Commons the other day comforted the nation by affirming the undisputed proposition that the proportion of the iron and steel exports of the United States which went to Great Britain was not much over 20 per cent, of the total, as shown by the returns for the year 1900.

TESTIMONY OF DETECTIVES IN DIVORCE -- Walker Winston's suit for divorce from his wife, Lillie Winston, was dismissed on the trial, in this city, three years ago. Mrs. Winston, besides denying the charges against her, set up counter charges in her answer, and also that she had procured a divorce in the Territory of Oklahoma.

SYRACUSE, March 3 -- Reports received here to-night say that the worst snowstorm of the Winter is now raging in Northern New York. The Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad has been forced to abandon its trains between Richland and Watertown, sending the through sleepers by way of Utica.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- President McKinley's promise to the Methodist ministers that the Sunday liquor law should be strictly observed to-day, was kept to the letter. That law is observed in Washington to an extent that prevails in very few cities, but on the Sunday before inauguration it has frequently been the custom to relax a little.

The arrival of the Cunard liner Lucania yesterday morning gave the clerks from the Collector's office who have superseded the staff from the Surveyor's office in taking the declaration of passengers their first real chance to get a clear idea of what most people's trunks contain. While everything had a new aspect and there was naturally some delay, the new force managed to dispatch the busines in hand in very good time.

PONCE, Porto Rico, March 3 -- Yesterday, as 400 emigrants were about to embark for the Daiquiri iron mines in Cuba on the British freighter Aldborough, Capt. Tarrant, the customs officials interfered on the ground that the Aldborough, being a freighter, could not be allowed to carry passengers from American ports.

"The Religion of Buddha" was Dr. Felix Adler's theme in his lecture before the Ethical Culture Society in Carnegie Hall yesterday morning. It was one of the series of discussions of great religions the society is conducting. The faith of the Hebrews and the teachings of Christ will be taken up in the next two lectures.

The decisions of the Court of Appeals on Friday in the two tax cases of People ex rel. National Surety Company vs. Feitner and others, and in Citizens' Savings Bank of Stanford vs. the Mayor, were important victories for the city, according to information furnished by the Corporation Counsel's office, both on account of the questions of law and the amounts of money involved in the litigations.

The shipping interest should not lack active and cordial co-operation from all who are interested in protecting the commercial interests of the Port of New York in its opposition to the Fuller bill (Senate No. 446) doubling the rates which may be collected by the owners or lessees of covered piers, wharves, and bulkheads for merchandise left thereon.

MARTHA A. SHANNON, wife of ex-Congressman Richard Cutts Shannon, died March 1 at her husband's residence in Washington. She was a cousin of the late Henry P. Spaulding, once President of the Central Trust Company; and in first marriage, wife of the late Charles B. Greenough, Esq., founder and first President of the Botanical Garden Railroad Company of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.

LONDON, March 4 -- W.E. King of Atlanta, Ga., who says he was a Lieutenant in the Seventy-first Regiment, New York Stale National Guard, while that regiment was in Cuba, has just returned to London frojn South Africa after serving for more than a year as aide de camp to Gen. De la Rev. the Boer commander, whom he left on Jan. 29.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- With the windows of the Presidential barouche tightly closed President McKinley rode up to the White House at about as near to 3 o'clock as it was possible to determine unless one had a chronometer to make it perfectly certain. The head of the escorting procession halted at the eastern entrance to the semi-circle in front of the official residence.

The Road Drivers' Association of New York has decided to hold the annual parade of road horses and rigs on May 11 this year, and at a meeting to be held to-night at the Rossmore Hotel will complete the arrangements for the parade, in addition to considering other important business of the association.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The New York contingent made a splendid showing in the parade, and the reception accorded them all along the line was flattering. They were all elated to-night over the impression they created, and especially so over the enthusiasm with which Gov. Odell was greeted.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "considera tion" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President McKinley affixed his signature to about a hundred bills passed by Congress. The greater portion of them were of a private character. The more important were the following:

Though total transactions on the Stock Exchange fell yesterday much below the million-share mark, there was pronounced strength throughout the whole market. No conspicuous stock was weak; most of the important issues advanced substantially. The iron and steel shares braced up and the industrial list generally scored rises, while all the standard railway shares made gains.

BOSTON, March 4 -- Money continues easy. Boston banks have lost $78,000 in the reserve and have $901,000 less in New York than a week ago. Loans have fallen off $367,000 and deposits have diminished $80,000. A loss is also shown in both legal tenders and specie. Foreign exchange is firm, with no change in rates.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- The Iroquois Club celebrated the centennial of Jefferson's inauguration with a banquet to-night. The speakers were Judson Harmon, ex-Attorney General; Judge M.F. Tuley, and exJudge T.A. Moran. All three speakers made earnest appeals to Democrats to ignore factional differences and go "back to Jeffersonian principles."

NEWARK, N.J., March 4 -- Vice Chancellor Stevens this morning decided against the application to take the depositions of Leonard Lewisohn and H.H. Rogers, exDirectors of the American Smelting and Refining Company, made on Saturday in connection with the application to make permanent the order restraining the company from increasing its capital stock from $65,000,000 to $100,000,000, and from consolidating the interests held by M. Guggenheim's Sons and other interests under its management.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The streets were brave with flags and other decorations all this morning, but long before the parade had begun to appear the rain had soaked them, and they were limp and bedraggled. Rain drizzled steadily down upon the solid banks of spectators, but did not seem to have much effect in dampening the enthusiasm.
HAVANA, March 4 -- The new Spanish baseball court was opened to-day. Gen. Wood and a number of Government officials attending the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- In how trifling a degree man has advanced over his savage ancestors, at least so far as the ornamentation of his person tells the story, was very markedly in evidence in to-day's parade. As a whole, he blazed in color. Badges red, badges gold, badges blue, and badges of all other colors were flaunted everywhere.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The fireworks which were to have been given in the White Lot to-night were postponed until tomorrow on account of the rain, and thousands of people were thus disappointed. It resulted, however, in a rather peculiar display of some of the characteristics of the American people.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 4 -- It has transpired that the Czar called a Council of the Ministers, which is an extraordinarily rare occurrence nowadays, for Feb. 8. The Czar asked the Ministers' advice in the case of Major Gen. Nicholas Orloff of the Military Academy, who secured permission, upon the outbreak of hostilities in Manchuria, to go to the seat of war.

Is the transfer tax law retroactive? This question will be settled in a novel proceeding just commenced in Brooklyn before Surrogate Abbott. The law was passed in 1896, and an effort is now being made to collect the tax on a legacy made under a will which came into operation over twenty years previous.

Assistant District Attorney Franklin Pierce says that he believes the examination of Charles L. Wilson will result in startling revelations. Wilson is the Bellevue Inspector who is charged with attempted subornation of perjury in having offered $50 to Joseph Greenberg of Gouverneur Hospital to testify falsely in the trial of Jesse R. Davis, the Bellevue nurse, recently acquitted on the charge of having caused the death of Louis Hilliard.
A handsome young English girl, sixteen years old, was married at the City Hall yesterday to Joich Takasugi, Japanese Vice Consul at New York. The bridegroom is thirty-five years old.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- In the closing hours of Congress this morning the two houses reached an agreement on the Sundry Civil bill, the only one of the great supply measures not disposed of, but the River and Harbor bill failed to pass, being talked to death by Senator Carter of Montana.

While working in the cable subway at Seventy-second Street and Lexington Avenue at 5:30 o'clock yesterday morning Thomas Robinson, an iron worker, of 100 East One Hundred and Seventh Street, was instantly killed. The top of his head was torn off by the grip of a passing car.

Richard H. Gatling has sold for Louis A. Richards to a client, for about $85,000, the seven-story business building 495 Broome Street, 21 by 84.11, with an "L" having a frontage of 21 feet at 359 West Broadway.

Very few of the people of the United States know that the "most gigantic business enterprise in the world" is the United States Postal Service, conducted "through their trustee, the Federal Government." This is the starting point of an article by HENRY A. CASTLE, Auditor for the Post Office Department, in the current number of The North American Review.

CINCINNATI, March 4 -- Next Wednesday the women of Cincinnati who have a hobby to wear or possess anything that is connected with the nobility will have an excellent opportunity to gratify it. There are three pairs of corsets stored away in the Government Building basement here, which will figure us a drawing card for dozens of women at the sale on March 6 of abandoned goods.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Trading in local stocks was somewhat quieter to-day. Lake Street Elevated showed a partial recovery from the decline of last Saturday, there being a fairly good demand for the stock between 14 and 14 1/2. Other transportation stocks all showed a firm tone, but there was little feature to the market for any of them.

A discussion held under the auspices of the Presbyterian Union of New York, at the Hotel Savoy, on the proposed revision in the Presbyterian creed, attracted a large audience of members of the union and their friends last night.

The decision of Judge BROWN in the United States Circuit Court for the District of Massachusetts declaring invalid the Berliner transmitter patent is significant in several ways, but chiefly because it will revive the discussion of one of the most unsavory scandals which has ever arisen in connection with the United States Patent Office.

That was a very suggestive statement of the British situation in South Africa which our London correspondent sent us for Sunday's paper. It is all very well for the organs of the British Ministry to talk of the degeneration of the Boer opposition to British supremacy in South Africa into a guerrilla warfare, and to attribute such continuance of opposition as there is to "simple ignorance."

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- The market showed a better tendency to-day than for a week past. Most of the trading was in two issues, Pennsylvania Railroad and American Alkali. The latter advanced 1/4. United Gas Improvement, though inactive, moved up to 125, compared with 124 1/4 on Saturday.

Bernard J. York, President of the Board of Police, recently legislated out of office, began yesterday to earn $4,000 a year as Second Deputy Commissioner through appointment by Commissioner Michael C. Murphy. The terms of the appointment recited that its duration would be "at the pleasure of" Col. Murphy.

At the annual meeting of the Harlem Regatta Association, held last night at the Marlborough Hotel, O.W. Erdall, manager of the Columbia University crew, announced that it was the intention of Columbia to challenge the Harvard 'Varsity crew, for a race on the Harlem River, to take place on Memorial Day.
LONDON, March 5 -- The Duke of Bedford, in the House of Lords, yesterday, started a discussion of army matters by asking for information on the military administration and the War Office.

Sweet, upon some occasions, are the uses of filibustering, and also the courtesy of the Senate. A generation ago there was a Senator from Kentucky, a leathern-lunged statesman set on fire presumably of Bourbon, who used to be put up by the Democratic minority to talk when there was any object to be secured by the mere lapse of time.

With so many members of the gay world absent in Washington to witness the inauguration, or off for Aiken, Palm Beach, , yesterday was decidedly a dull day in town. There were one or two sewing class meetings, several private lectures, a few small card parties, and in the evening some dinners.

LONDON, March 4 -- Though the demand for money was keen, with increased supplies, the tone was easier. Discounts sympathized with the position. The New York money market was watched with the keenest interest. The favorable Associated Bank return enhanced the impression that the usual Spring outflow from New York to the interior may be somewhat neutralized by the reinflow in connection with the applications of new issues of capital.

PARIS, March 4 -- In the Chamber to-day an exciting discussion followed the reception of the report of the special commission dealing with the cases of MM. Deroulede and Marcel-Habert, which recommended that the names of those Deputies be struck from the rolls of the Chamber.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The culminating event of the inaugural festivities was the Inaugural Ball, given to-night in the vast hail of the Pension Office. As a spectacular event, it was unparalleled in the history of Inaugural Balls, in the sumptuousness of arrangement, in the beauty of the decorations, in the elaborateness of the electrical effects, and the immense throng taking part in the function.

The Cleveland, Lorain and Wheeling Railway has been acquired by the Baltimore and Ohio. Railroad through a purchase of the majority of the stock of that company. This announcement was made yesterday by William Salomon, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio. The consummation of this purchase was foreshadowed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Feb. 19.

The ship's company that left this port on Jan. 24 in Jay Gould's old yacht Atalanta, transformed into the gunboat Restaurador, under Venezuelan colors, and equipped with gaudy naval uniforms and a certain picturesque hope of attaining to a man Venezuelan commissions, got back home yesterday on the Red D liner Philadelphia.

The will of Arthur E. White, a member of the stock brokerage firm of White Wainwright, 52 Broadway, was filed yesterday. The first request made in the will, that the testator's body be cremated, was not complied with, the burial being at Woodlawn. The testator was a bachelor and an active member of several clubs.

The strike of bridge railroad employes of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company, which, it was reported on Sunday night, would take place at 5 o'clock yesterday morning, failed to materialize. The employes declared yesterday that, although they had met and discussed their grievances against the company, they had no intention of striking.

The familiar and half-sarcastic saying about Mr. McKINLEY's keeping his ear to the ground embodies a very high tribute to his wisdom and statesmanship. We have probably never had a President who was more successful in integrating the popular will or who obeyed it more faithfully.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The point of greatest attraction along the route of the parade next to the President's reviewing stand in the Court of Honor was at the corner of Fourteenth Street and Pennsylvania Avenue, where Hanna's "throne" was situated. The so-called "throne" was a covered balcony of fair design commanding a sweeping view of the avenue.

"The" Allen's "West Side Club," at 80 Sixth Avenue, was raided in a spectacular manner for the second time within a week by Capt. Chapman of the Mercer Street Station late yesterday afternoon, in the presence of a large crowd.

LONDON, March 5. -- The demand for money to-day was moderate and supplies were abundant. The price for short money varied as much as it always does when the market is indebted to the Bank of England, and loans continue falling due Discounts were easy.

The design of the architect, Ernest Flagg, for the erection of the triumphal arch and water gate which the alumni of the United States Naval Academy propose to build at the Battery, will to-day be submitted to Commissioner George C. Clausen. He is expected by the committee having the matter in charge to approve of the plan.

LONDON, March 6. -- In anticipation of further interesting disclosures, the House of Lords was crowded yesterday when the debate on the War Office administration was resumed. The Duke of Cornwall and York and many Peeresses were present.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, March 5. -- Developments of the past twenty-four hours in Ashtabula indicate that an extensive iron industry is to be located on the banks of Lake Erie in close proximity to Ashtabula Harbor. G.J. Chapman and F.M. Weston, representing a big coal and iron company of Montreal, Canada, have secured options on a, tract of land comprising 400 acres.

To the Editor of The New York Times: While I have some hopes that this, with other complaints, may lead the management of the Philharmonic to in some way modify the superlatively uninteresting programme announced for this week, my main hope is that, should you print this, it may call forth letters from abler pens and open a general discussion of the poor programmes and sadly decreased attendance at the Philharmonic.

FREEPORT, L. I., March 5. -- Baptists and Congregationalists almost came to blows in St. Paul's Chapel, at Greenwich Point, last night, and Constable Frank Cornwell had to quell several petty quarrels between members of the two factions.

This is the phrase used by Mr. HENRY NORMAN to describe the protectionist policy of M. DE WITTE, the Minister of Finance of the Russian Empire. We do not know whether it is a term invented by Mr. NORMAN or by M. DE WITTE himself. Its meaning is a little obscure, but it has relation to one peculiar feature of the Russian policy at the present time.

ALBANY, March 5 -- State Superintendent of Banks F.D. Kilburn, in his report to the Legislature relative to building and loan and co-operative savings and loan associations, condemns the so-called "National" associations, and asks that the banking laws be amended so as to place them under the supervision of his department and prohibit speculative investments and impairment of capital through the payment of large salaries.

In answer to the letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES of yesterday, signed "J.M. S.," in which the writer made adverse comment on the proposed change in the County Court House and incidentally criticised Horgan Slattery, the architects who are to take charge of the changes. Justice Scott, who with Justices Dugro and Truax, is on the Building Committee, which is to use $2,000,000 for the changes in the building, said:

ALBANY, March 5. -- John Wilson Durant, who, according to the cable dispatches, was killed in a duel at Ostend, was an Albanian and came of a prominent family. He was in Albany last Autumn. He called on many of his old friends here, and said that he soon would return to Paris, where he said he and his mother were living.
The case of William J. Logan against John W. Simpson et al, was argued yesterday afternoon before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. Decision was reserved.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- Pennsylvania was the strong and active feature in the market, but it failed to show the gain recorded in New York. The Reading issues were a good second, and Lehigh was next in strength. Less important issues were affected by the buoyancy, and a number of them showed slight advances.
We wonder if the Committee of Fifteen fully understands the peculiar advantage it now has through the collapse of the Tammany Committee of Purification.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- Princeton and Pennsylvania Universities were scheduled to meet at the Ice Palace here tonight in a hockey match, but for some unexplained reason Capt. R.D. Little and Goal Keeper Paull were the only Orange and Black players to put in an appearance. These two had been in Washington attending the inaugural ceremonies, and came on fully expecting to join the remainder of the team here.
LONDON, March 6. -- The House of Commons sat very late in Committee of Supply, and after midnight the Right Hon. A. J. Balfour, the Government leader, applied the closure on the education estimates.

When Mr. Sothern and Miss Harned acted together in "The Adventure of Lady Ursula," at the Lyceum Theatre, the beauty and appropriateness of the stage pictures greatly increased one's enjoyment of the fanciful little play. Sothern, it seemed then, had never, with all the pains he had always taken in the setting his plays, produced so rich and tasteful pictorial effects.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The new Vice President was entertained this evening for the first time since his induction into office, his host being Senator Kean of New Jersey, one of his oldest friends. Mrs. Roosevelt was not present, having carried out her original plan of returning to-day to Oyster Bay, despite the many attentions and invitations which have been showered upon her.

The public will not readily accept the current rumors that there is danger that the practical plan devised by the existing commission to save the Palisades from further defacement, and protect them for all time, is in danger of failure because of lack of interest in the matter by the New Jersey lawmakers.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5. -- Vice Chancellor Stevens reserved decision this afternoon in the suit brought to make permanent the temporary injunction restraining the completion of the proposed consolidation of the American Refining and Smelting Company with the Guggenheim interests. Counsel for both sides asked that decision be rendered as quickly as possible, so that the losing side may get the case early before the Court of Errors.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The State Board of Regents in its March bulletin speaks of a new map of the State now being prepared by the State Geologist and to be issued by the New York State Museum this Summer. In describing the map the board says:

Prices were strong in yesterday's market for outside securities, and transactions were, on a fairly large scale. The steel stocks were not quite as active as they were the previous day, and they were at the same time more irregular. Business in the rest of the list was fairly well distributed, but several issues, which were especially active Monday, assumed places of much less prominence.

HAVANA, March 5. -- At the conference last night of the Cuban Constitutional Convention, many delegates favored the temporary suspension of the convention in order to allow the members, especially those from Santiago, Puerto Principe, and Santa Clara Provinces, an opportunity to consult the wishes of their constituents regarding the Senate amendment to the Army Appropriation bill.
SIMON WENBAN, President of the Tenabo Mining Company, died yesterday at San Francisco. He went to California in 1854 by way of Cape Horn.

From The Hartford (Conn.) Post. The Connecticut Humane Society has been investigating the condition of the children of James Madison Nott of Montville. Nott's wife died two months ago and since that time Nott has adopted the Christian Scientists' belief and has added a belief of his own to the effect that the Lord will take care of him without any effort on his own part.

The New York Press, the offices of which have been for several years in the Potter Building, at Park Row and Beekman Street, will soon have a building of its own at 9 to 13 Spruce Street, adjoining The Tribune Building. These properties, a plot having a frontage of 75 feet, have just been purchased from the various owners by Henry L. Einstein, proprietor of The Press, for $157,500.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 5. -- The intercollegiate golf tournament will be held on May 8 to 11. In addition to the Universities of Yale, Harvard, Columbia, and Princeton, which have always competed, the University of Pennsylvania will enter a team. The links upon which the tournament will be played have not as yet been chosen.

A replevin suit brought by Richard M. Jordan of the Jordan Stationery Company of New York against his wife, Mrs. Margaret Jordan, to recover possession of articles which Mr. Jordan testified were given to him by friends who did not know his wife, was heard by Judge Otto Crouse in the First District Court in the City Hall in Jersey City yesterday.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@63c. There were no sales.

LONDON, March 5. -- Richard Croker has seldom expressed his indignation at unauthorized newspaper interviews in such strong terms as he used to-day when shown a copy of a New York newspaper of Feb. 18, containing an alleged exclusive statement of his views regarding New York politics.

A woman, sixty years old, who was unable to walk more than a few feet, was, according to George Blair, Superintendent of the Outdoor Poor, brought to the Charities Pier, on which is his office, in a trolley car from the Isabella Heimath. One Hundred and Ninetieth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, and there left without word having been said to any one connected with his department of her presence there.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., March 5 -- Word was received here to-night announcing the death in San Francisco of Walter E. Stewart, Jr., son of Walter E. Stewart of this place. Stewart arrived in San Francisco Feb. 28 on the transport Indiana from the Philippines, where for almost two years he had been a Second Lieutenant, attached to the Third Infantry.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The State Department has prepared a series of circulars telling naturalized citizens exactly what they may expect if they attempt to return to their former homes. The circular is different in the case of each European country which has shown a disposition to hold its citizens to account when they emigrate to the United States and become naturalized.

With the exception of dinners, sewing classes, several Lenten lectures, and entertainments for charity, and two or three theatre parties, there was little doing yesterday and there will be little to-day. MiCareme will bring several notable affairs, including the Roman entertainment at the Constables, and at the Eastertide the numerous weddings and the last of the dancing class meetings will bring considerable gayety.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 5. -- The Athletic Association of the University of Pennsylvania made its first formal recognition of the Henley trip to-day by adopting a resolution authorizing the Rowing Committee to take any action in the matter that may seem proper, and expressing approval of the project.

Two men were burned to death in a fire which started this morning shortly after midnight in the stable and warehouse 226 Marion Street, Brooklyn. Eighteen horses also perished, and the fire, besides gutting the building in which it started, spread so rapidly that three frame cottages were very badly damaged.

Mrs. Mary Doyle of 1,456 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, went away from her flat yesterday afternoon, leaving it unguarded for several hours. When she returned toward dusk she found two men rummaging the place. They started for the door as she entered, and she blocked their way and screamed, but they knocked her down and ran.

ALBANY, March 5 -- The joint Committees on Taxation of the Senate and Assembly gave a hearing to-day on the General Corporation Tax bill, the fourth of Gov. Odell's propositions. There was much opposition to the bills from various corporation attorneys.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 5 -- The British steamer Camperdown, bound for New York, loaded with 20,000 sacks of sugar, is stranded on Cape Lookout Shoals, seven miles from the beach. The Captain of the life-saving crew has made three unsuccessful attempts to board the vessel and render assistance, but, owing to a strong head current, a high sea, and southwest winds, he has been unable to do so.
AMSTERDAM, March 5. -- Queen Wilhelmina and the Prince Consort entered this city in state this morning.

Charles Garez, a Brazilian, who has figured in several escapades which have entangled him with the police of the Tenderloin, was arrested yesterday morning and arraigned before Magistrate Deuel in the Jefferson Market Court, where he was held in $2,000 bail for trial. He is charged with enacting the role of "Peeping Tom" in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Jonas B. Spero was awarded a verdict for 6 cents damages against his brother, Samuel, in the Supreme Court yesterday. Incidentally John I. Greene, counsel for the plaintiff, wins a suit of clothes from the defendant. The action in which damages was recovered grew out of the business relations of the brothers Spero in a clothing store on Nassau Street.

ALBANY, March 5 -- After the Ramapo bill had been referred in the Assembly Mr. Doughty's bill to lay out and establish a public park at Edgemere, in the Borough of Queens, on the order of third reading, was laid over until to-morrow.
BRUSSELS, March 5. -- Benolt, the distinguished composer, is dead.

MANILA, March 5. -- The Philippine Com- mission has decided to double the appropriation of $1,000,000 for the improvement of Manila Harbor; and it has passed a bill accepting the transfer of the Manila Public Library.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5. -- The Senate had its closest vote of the session to-night on Assemblyman Marks's bill to permit the North German Lloyd Steamship Company to swing its ships in front of one of Hoboken's parks along the river front. The bill was advocated by Senator Hudspeth, who spoke of the great advantage this steamship company was to Hoboken in a commercial way.

That is a significant interview with Archbishop CHAPELLE which was published a day or two ago in The Sun. It was significant, quite apart from the importance of what the Archbishop had to say, that he, as the representative of the Papacy in the Philippines, should have judged that the time had come to make an appeal to American public opinion.

John E. Searles, the former Sugar Trust official, President of the American Cotton Company and a Director in many financial and industrial corporations, yesterday made an assignment for the benefit of his creditors to Edward F. Dwight of the law firm of Carter, Hughes Dwight. At the same time the announcement was made that he had resigned from his position as President of the American Cotton Company and that his resignation would be accepted.

The-long-delayed meeting of the Stewards of the Jockey Club for the adjustment of the coming season's racing dates for the Eastern racing associations was held yesterday, when the turf schedule of 1901 was arranged and racing officials for the year were appointed. August Belmont, whose illness was the chief cause for the delay, and who on Saturday returned from Florida, presided.

Justice William Travis Jerome sat as a Magistrate yesterday in the library of the Criminal Court Building and heard evidence in the cases of William Lewis, Arthur Moore, and William Campbell, who were arrested on Monday at " The" Allen's West Bide Club, 80 Sixth Avenue, as poolroom operators in the raid made by Capt.

VIENNA, March 5. -- Fists were again a prominent feature in to-day's session of the Reichsrath. A Czech Radical. Zazvorka, started the uproar by insisting on making a speech in the Czech language. The Acting President, Prade, prohibited him from speaking, whereupon Fressl, another Czech Radical, rushed up to the Presidential chair, snatched the papers from the desk and crumpled them into a ball.

BERLIN, March 5. -- In the Reichstag today, in the debate on the Foreign Office estimates, Herr Schaedler (Centrist) asserted that dissatisfaction was rife in Germany, and that the country desired information regarding the political significance of the Emperor's visit to England and the effect of the accession of King Edward.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- Dr. Richard J. Dunglison, an eminent editor and author of many valuable medical works, is dead at his home here of dropsy and heart failure, superinduced by pneumonia. Dr. Dunglison was a son of Prof. Robley Dunglison of Jefferson Medical College, and studied medicine under his father's direction.

LONDON, March 6. -- "The Chancellor of the Exehequer," (Sir Michael Hicks-Beach,) said a prominent member of the House of Commons last night, "will probably introduce a duty on sugar in the forthcoming budget, and will perhaps also add a countervailing duty."
"I had a pistol in my bosom; they did not search me at the station, for I had done nothing. But I could have killed him, as he did my poor Marie."

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- Mrs. A. Sidney Carpenter of the Philadelphia Country Club gave two handsome cups for a mixed handicap foursome golf tournament to-day, which resulted in a tie between H.M. Forrest of Philadelphia and Miss Darlington of Pittsburg and W.H. Davis and Mrs. A.H. McKee of Lakewood, with a score of 88 net.

BOSTON, March 6. -- The Independence, the Boston cup defender, will be entered in the trial races under the name of C.H. W. Foster, a Marblehead yachtsman, who is a member of Thomas W. Lawson's advisory board in the management of the boat's affairs and a member of the New York Yacht Club.

The shrinkage in the exports of American manufactures shown by the December foreign trade statistics and the preliminary returns for January is neither surprising nor alarming. It was foreseen and predicted at least four months ago, and every intelligent forecast of the business of 1901 announced that the changed conditions in Europe must inevitably be reflected in a contraction in the volume of our exports of manufactures during the present year.
OXFORD, England, March 6. -- The Rev. Dr. William Bright, Regius Professor of Ecclesiastical History and Canon of Christ Church, Oxford, is dead.

The controversy which has been in progress between the Association of Vaudeville Managers of the United States and the White Rats' Association was practically settled yesterday after the meeting of the managers in their office, in the St. James Building, when they decided, as a body, to abolish the 5 per cent. commission clause in the actor's contract, which has been the cause of the disagreement.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- The Brookline Swimming Club of Brookline, Mass., won another victory to-day in the water polo championship tournament at the Sportsmen's Show in the Coliseum. Their opponents, the St. Louis Turners of St. Louis, Mo., were outplayed at every point and were unable to secure a single goal.
ALBANY, March 6. -- By a vote of 91 yeas, no nays, the Assembly to-day passed the Weekes bill, prohibiting policy playing in the State.

At Police Headquarters quiet prevailed yesterday. Commissioner Murphy repeated his assertion that he was in command in the department. He denied that he had said anything against Patrick Divver, Tammany leader of the Second Assembly District, as was stated. In the afternoon the Commissioner was closeted with Mr. York and Controller Coler, arranging for the transfer of the Police Department's treasury to the Controller's care.

MOUNT VERNON, March 6. -- James Campbell to-night shot and seriously wounded Miss Dorothy Treulib, and then shot and so severely wounded himself that his death is a certainty. The girl has a bare chance of recovery, while Campbell's death may occur at any moment. The shooting occurred almost directly in front of the home of the girl's parents, and is said to have been caused by the girl's refusal to marry Campbell.

TRENTON, N.J., March 6. -- The debate of the session occurred this afternoon in the Senate. The subject under discussion was Senator Johnson's concurrent resolution providing for a constitutional amendment favoring biennial sessions of the Legislature. Mr. Johnson explained first that the resolution would have to be adopted by two succeeding Legislatures and receive an affirmative vote of the people before it could become operative.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 6. -- The Maryland Legislature, called to meet in extra session to-day to act on the proposed amendment to the election law, which, it is asserted, would disfranchise the negroes, is in a tangle from which it may be very difficult to extricate it.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 6. -- The propeller Homer Ramsdell of the Central Hudson Line to-day attempted to open navigation on the Hudson River between New York and this city. The run to West Point was soon made, the river being comparatively free from ice. North of Gees Point Light-house the ice was thick and hard.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Secretary of War Root has received the following cablegram from Judge Taft, President of the Philippine Commission:
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@63 1/2c. There were no sales.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A delegation from the Illinois Manufacturers' Association, headed by Martin D. Mann, had an important interview with the President concerning the countervailing duty on Russian sugars. They placed before the President arguments to show that the discrimination against Russian sugars might seriously injure the export trade to Russia if retaliatory measures were insisted upon, and that a general trade war against the United States might arise.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 4. -- To-day was the fortieth anniversary of the emancipation of the serfs. The students had been planning for some time to keep the day as a holiday, and perhaps make some demonstration, but no particular plans were made.

A case involving one of the most important questions within the whole realm of domestic economy came up for adjudication yesterday before Magistrate Mayo in the Harlem Police Court. The case was that of McDonald and others versus Moran. The chief complainant was Solon W. McDonald, the jeweler and dealer in valuable gems at 26 West Twenty-third Street, who has a handsome home at 532 West One Hundred and Forty-eighth Street.

The fight over the estate of Mrs. Anna Sutherland has been transferred from the Surrogates' to the Supreme Court, and Justice Blanchard and a jury are now listening to the testimony. The contest which is being made by Mrs. Catherine C.K. Hagan, a daughter of the testatrix, is on the ground that her mother was "an irresponsible spendthrift and a habitual drunkard" at the time the will was executed.

BURLINGTON, Vt., March 6. -- The Burlington, the Winooski, and the Colchester mills are financially embarrassed, and Col. B.B. Smalley of Burlington and Charles K. Cobb of Boston have been appointed receivers. This step was taken at the request of stockholders of the owners of the three concerns, which have been under one management, who petitioned the United States Court, and the receivers were named.

PARIS, March 7. -- The report that John Wilson Durant of Albany, N.Y., who has been living during the last two years with his mother at the Hotel Lafonde Tremoille here, was killed at Ostend in a duel with a Russian Count was an invention of his own.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Representative Cannon, Chairman of the House Committee on Appropriations, and Representative Livingston, the senior Democratic member of the committee, have prepared statements of the appropriations of the Fifty-sixth Congress, which will be printed in The Record to-morrow.

"Alfred Parsons, Lord Rosse of Burr Coth, Ireland," who was arrested on Tuesday in New Haven for trying to swindle President Hadley of Yale University, was yesterday identified by William H.H. Beebe, private secretary to President Seth Low, as the man who recently swindled Gen. Thomas L. James of the Lincoln National Bank out of $200.

ALBANY, March 6. -- In the Assembly today Mr. Bennet's so-called Anti-Divorce Mill bill, providing for the trial of divorce actions in open court, on the order of third reading, was recommitted for further amendment. Mr. Bennet accepted Mr. Kelsey's amendment striking out the clause that in counties having a population of less than 120,000 "reference may be granted to the County Judges."
MONTREAL, March 6. -- R.S. Logan, assistant to the General Manager of the Grand Trunk Railway, has been appointed Vice President and General Manager of the Central Vermont Road.

It is announced in The Tribune Washington dispatches that Col. WILLIAM CART SANGER of this State has been selected to replace Mr. MEIKLEJOHN as Assistant Secretary of War. It would be an extremely good selection.

There is no question that that was a most disgraceful scene which took place in the House of Commons in the small hours of yesterday morning. But about the responsibility for the disgrace there is much more question than the London press appears willing to allow. That press rushes to the conclusion that the whole occasion of the disturbance arose from the lawless and riotous character of the Irish members.

John E. Searles, who on Tuesday announced his failure, was yesterday at his office at 27 William Street. He was cheerful and active, but politely declined to talk of his misfortune. "See my assignee, Mr. Dwright," he said, "He will give any information that is to be made public. I have nothing to say."
LONDON, March 7. -- The Manchester sensation promises to rival the Westminster scandal.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Again to-day when the Senate convened the galleries were packed with people, a majority of whom, as on recent days, being visitors to the city. The Executive Gallery was ablaze with blue, gold cord, and epaulettes, the visitors being members of the staff of Gov. Yates of Illinois.
LONDON, March 7. -- When the House of Commons met at noon yesterday, in view of possible disturbances the whole police force on duty at St. Stephen's had been mobilized and reinforced by reserves.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 6. -- C.G. Herbert, a first-year student in the Harvard Law School, broke the intercollegiate strength test record this afternoon. His total was 1,869 kilogrammes, which beats by 60 all previous records.
First Lieut. Eugene P. Jervey, Jr., Tenth Cavalry, will proceed to Baltimore and enter upon recruiting duty, relieving Major Frederick Wheeler, retired.

We have not kept tally of the number of times Senator MORGAN has been snubbed by the Senate respecting his Nicaragua hobby. Yesterday it carried him quite beyond sympathy or even courtesy, for Senators smiled while he ranted and did not even pay him the compliment of remonstrance.

ALBANY, March 6. -- The Republican Senators to-night renewed their caucus on the important Brackett Corporation bill. During the discussion a surprise was sprung on the members by an announcement that the bill introduced by Mr. Fish in the Assembly is not identical with the bill under discussion.

Lewis J. McKenna, a clerk in the actuarial department of the New York Life Insurance Company, is in St. Luke's Hospital recovering from an operation, one of the rarest known to modern science, performed on him on Feb. 25 by a number of eminent surgeons.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 6. -- Albert Zimmerman, a resident of Pleasantville, committed suicide early to-day. After a quarrel Zimmerman shot his wife and shot at her father. Then he turned the gun on himself. Zimmerman was forty years old. The tragedy occurred in the Zimmerman home, six miles from this city, about 2:30 this morning.

ALBANY, March 6. -- Senator Raines this morning introduced the Congressional Reapportionment bill. All of the thirty-four districts of the State are more or less altered, the greatest changes occurring in the city districts. New York County gets two extra Congressmen and Kings County one.

PHILADELPHIA, March 6. -- The Philadelphia market suffered a notable depreciation in the volume of business as compared with yesterday. The railways again made up the most of the trading. In the morning prices advanced sharply in most of the list, but this improvement was followed by a general falling off in the after noon, which brought prices back again to around last night's closing figures.
A resident of New York who has exceptional opportunities for learning the real state of things in Venezuela made the following statement yesterday:

LONDON, March 7. -- Private information received in London this morning confirms the rumors of negotiations between Lord Kitchener. Sir Alfred Milner, and Commandant General Louis Botha. Nothing is known as to the actual presence of the Boer Commander in Chief at Pretoria, and no London paper publishes a statement that he is there, but it is reasonably certain that Gen. Botha is in either personal or very close touch with Lord Kitchener.

Wednesday always brings its sewing classes and its Lenten amusements, and last but not least its opera. The audiences at the Metropolitan during the Wagner performances have been especially brilliant, and only a few familiar faces are missed. It is also the season of musicales, although few are given in the middle of the week.

After having been tossed about on the Atlantic for nearly two months, the American schooner Edward H. Blake of Bangor, Me., arrived in port yesterday from Fernandina, Fla., and presented to her consignees for consideration one of the most remarkable logs ever written by a skipper.

Bishop Henry C. Potter addressed the students of Columbia University yesterday afternoon in Schermerhorn Hall on "What a Young Man Owes to His City." The assembly room was crowded, and many women were in the audience. Bishop Potter entered the room on the arm of President Seth Low, who introduced him to the audience with the following words:

Fernando Yznaga, who died yesterday at the Minturn Hospital from diphtheria, was one of the best-known men in New York and foreign society and club life. His sudden death produced a great shock in this city, where he had many friends. Mr. Yznaga was one of the most entertaining of men, very clever at epigram and repartee, and famous for quaint sayings.

The citizen infirm of body or of purpose who is never quite sure as to the best thing to do at the moment will find the new form of turnstile which is coming into use at the main entrances of well-appointed office buildings beneficially educational as a discourager of hesitancy.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Secretary Gage has just issued an order to customs officers that will oblige them to forego some of the courtesies heretofore extended to American travelers and will annoy those persons who have enjoyed the courtesies from year to year on their departure for or return from Europe.

The six-story building 62 and 64 Cedar Street, south side, between Nassau and William Streets, has been bought by the Mutual Life Insurance Company, through Brokers Horace S. Ely Co. The sellers of the property are Delancey A. Kane, S. Nicholson Kane, John I. Kane, and their three sisters.

BOSTON, March 6. -- The money market is irregular. To the strongest borrowers money is offered freely at low rates, but where collateral is not of the highest order, or where names are not so well known, rates are firmly held. Call money is in good supply at 3 per cent., and to special favored borrowers at 2 1/2 per cent.

BOSTON, March 6. -- Irving Long of Boston, the tall-ender in the pool tournament, surprised everybody to-night by defeating W.H. Clearwater of Pittsburg, 150 to 107. It was Long's first victory, and it seems singular that his victim should be one of the acknowledged strong men of the tournament. The score:

A learned but fanciful Shakespearean once declared his opinion that when the great English poet wrote his "Winter's Tale" he had in mind the two-part pictures that used to be common in his day, and tried to make a dramatic diptych. It would be, to argue no more curiously, to declare that the dramatizer of "Uncle Tom's Cabin" had in view a triptych; for the play is in three unrelated parts.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Our British friends have queer ways of doing things, sometimes -- or at least they appear queer when viewed from the American point of view. For instance, at a recent meeting of the Vestry of one of the parishes of London, it was reported by a committee having the matter in charge that arrangements had been made for the employment of an engineer and surveyor, to be advertised for.

A meeting was held yesterday at the rooms of the Real Estate Board of Brokers, 111 Broadway, to organize a movement against any legislation that has for its object the taxation of mortgages. Representatives were present from the Real Estate Exchange of Brooklyn, the Anti-Mortgage-Tax League of Brooklyn, the New York Tax Reform Association, the West End Association, and the North Side Board of Trade.

The Jumel Mansion and grounds, at One Hundred and Sixtieth Street and Harlem River, which were occupied by Gen. Washington as a headquarters, will come into the possession of the city as a public show place of Revolutionary relics through the action of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday.
Discussing the condition of the iron and steel trades The Iron Age will to-day say:

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Feb. 23. -- The political situation in Venezuela is very much more favorable to President Castro. The last political band at Carupano has been overcome and has disappeared. The Caracas newspapers say that Julian Acosta, recently captured, will be tried by a council of war.

The annual meeting of the Metropolitan District Cricket League was held yesterday at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club. An application for membership from the Kings County Cricket Club was favorably acted upon, and A.B. Lewis, A. Nugent, and G. W. Barnes were admitted to the meeting as regular delegates from that club.
Protectionists must not be too much elated by the report that Great Britain is about to place a tax on imported sugar. Such a tax would not necessarily be a protective tax.

A big black dog has been taken to the County Court House daily for several days. There has been considerable speculation among those who frequent the building as why the dog was such a regular attendant. The mystery was solved yesterday afternoon, when the case of Andrew Laguttuta against George E. Chisolm and Robert Wilson was set down for trial before Justice Giegerirh in Trial Term, Part VIII.

Mrs. Belle Devlin, who was accused of assaulting on Friday last Mrs. Elizabeth Hill, wife of a wealthy tea merchant of 213 Grand Street, Brooklyn, was held under $100 bonds to keep the peace by Magistrate Kramer in the Lee Avenue Police Court yesterday. Papers were also served upon Mrs. Devlin in a suit for $50,000 brought by Mrs. Hill for the alienation of her husband's affections.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., March 7 -- Chauneey Glover, a well-known resident of Cutchogue, was convicted to-day of forgery, and was sentenced by Judge Keogh in the Supreme Court to four years and four months in State Prison. When sentence was pronounced the prisoner fainted and fell to the floor. It was some lime before he could be revived.
CHICAGO, March 7 -- A special dispatch to The Record from Helena, Mont., says:...

ALBANY, March 7 -- In the Assembly this afternoon William W.H. Smith called up his bill oh the laid-aside calendar to prohibit nurses from being called as witnesses in criminal cases. Mr. Smith said his measure did not affect the Rice murder case in the least. He explained that his amendment was intended to pin down the nurses' testimony to strictly professional matters.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 -- "Alfred Parsons," or "Lord Rosse," the alleged swindler who was arrested here Tuesday, left New Haven for New York at 1:35 P.M. to-day in the custody of Detective Joseph D. Wooldridge of New York Headquarters. The prisoner this morning signified his willingness to proceed to New York without extradition papers.

Many of the property owners in the vicinity of Broadway and Astor Place will appear before the Board of Public improvements and oppose the opening of the proposed new street through a block of private property which will cost the city $1,500,000.

Senator PLATT, is disgruntled with the reported intention of the President to appoint Col. WILLIAM CARY SANGER as Assistant Secretary of War. He does not believe that the President intends to appoint Col. SANGER, "who is not only an anti-organization man, but is anti everything else in a political sense.

The Chamber of Commerce is to take up the crowding of trains on the elevated railroad, especially as it relates to congestion of traffic at the City Hall terminus of the Third Avenue line, and it will also take up an investigation relating to the congestion of traffic at the New York end of the Brooklyn Bridge during the rush hours of the evening.

LONDON, March 8 -- In anticipation of 4 lively debate and possibly exciting scenes, arising from the suspension of Irish Nationalists and the punishment proposal of the Government leader, the Right Hon. Arthur J. Balfour, there was a big attendance in the House of Commons yesterday. The visitors' galleries were filled, many peers and women being among those present.

The most interesting of the shooting competitions being held in connection with the Sportsmen's Show at Madison Square Garden, the trap events at clay birds, conducted on the roof shooting ground, came to an abrupt end yesterday, much to the regret of the growing number of visitors who found the lively scenes attendant upon the breaking of flying clay targets one of the strongest attractions of the show.

SING SING, N.Y., March 7 -- The charter election here is developing into a scandal which will doubtless cause an investigation by the Grand Jury. The scandal began to develop this afternoon when the Democratic primaries officers met in obedience to the order of Justice Marean to recount the ballots cast at the primary election on Feb. 19.

Otto Keller, twenty-six years old, a dishwasher of 6 Chatham Square, and John Young, a laborer, of 11 Bowery, were acquitted of a charge of attempted burglary in the third degree in General Sessions yesterday afternoon, and immediately rearrested and taken to Police Headquarters on a charge of murder.

ALBANY, March 7 -- A few days ago, and quite by chance. Arthur Butts, who represents the Corporation Counsel of New York City at Albany, came across a bill which gave him quite a shock. It was apparently a modest little bill, one of which the title seemed designed to attract no special attention, and, moreover, it had been put away where it was likely to escape the observation of those most interested in it.

BOSTON, March 7 -- Consul General Artruro de Brigarde of the Republic of Colombia has brought proceedings in the Supreme Court by the order of his Government to prevent the payment of certain drafts alleged to have been extorted from fellowcountrymen by Raphael Uribe Uribe and Pablo Emilio Obregon, two revolutionary leaders.
ALBANY, March 7 -- In the Senate to-day Mr. Ahearn introduced a bill incorporating the Naval Arch Association of New York.

Charged with attempting to bribe officials at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to pass bills rendered by him for goods not delivered, B. C. Anderson, proprietor of a brass foundry at 209 King: Street, Brooklyn, was yesterday arrested by Deputy United States Marshal John E. Thorne on a warrant issued by Justice Thomas of the United States District Court.

Last night, as they lay on beds in Mills Hotel No. 1. about thirty Yale students, most of them from the Divinity School, pondered over the experiences of a very busy day. From afar off, as they lost consciousness in sleep, came the voice of a lecturer upon sociology -- " These the causes; these the results " -- almost drowned by the shouts of barkers setting forth the advantage of Bowery merchandise.

LONDON, March 8 -- The Government has published a dispatch from the British Ambassador at St. Petersburg, the Right Hon. Sir Charles Stewart Scott, relating to the assurance given on Feb. 6 by the Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Count Lamsdorf, concerning Manchuria. It appears that the Russian Minister consented on Feb. 27 to the publication of the dispatch as accurately representing Russia's attitude in the proceedings in Manchuria.

MANILA, March 7 -- Additional inducements have been made to the insurgents to surrender their guns. Gen. MacArthur has directed all department commanders to release one prisoner for every rifle surrdered. An insurgent who surrenders his gun will be permitted to name the prisoner to be released, provided no exceptional circumstances require this man's detention, in which case another selection will be allowed.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Alice Nielsen, who has been singing here this week under the management of Prank L. Perley, will cease to star under his management at the end of the London season that is to begin at the Shaftesbury Theatre in that city on Easter Monday. Just when that season will end is not determined, and will depend entirely upon the success met with by Miss Nielsen and the company in London.

Two policemen arraigned a prisoner in the West Side Court yesterday afternoon, and, after the evidence was heard, they were painfully surprised by the action of Magistrate Cornell. The Magistrate discharged the prisoner in double quick time, extending his congratulations in doing so, referred to the policemen as a disgrace to the force, and directed the Sergeant of the court squad to report to Commissioner Murphy full details of their conduct.

The trial heats and one final event in the skating championships of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League were decided in the presence of a large crowd at the Clermont Avenue Skating Rink, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon.

Senator Mark Hanna came to New York yesterday to do political work of importance to the Republican Party. He was cheerful and happy and the only time he became serious was when interviewers tried to broach the subject of politics.

Henrietta Smith, twelve years old, and her brother, John, aged eight, had a merry war for a time yesterday morning throwing lighted matches at each other in the family sitting room of their home, at 204 First Avenue, while their mother was out of the room. Each of the opposing forces was armed with a box of big, red-headed sulphur matches, which make a fine flare when lighted.

HONOLULU, March 1 -- The first Territorial Legislature of Hawaii began its sessions in Honolulu Feb. 20, and has been in session since. J.A. Akina, (independent.) a Hawaiian-Chinese member from the Island of Kauai, was elected Speaker of the House, and Dr. Nicholas Russell of Hawaii, a white man, was chosen President of the Senate.

BERLIN, March 7 -- Emperor William arrived here this morning. The Empress and Count von Bulow met him at the station. When the Emperor reached the castle Prof. Bergmann visited him, and later the following bulletin was issued: ...

Money market tendencies caused no apprehension on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The advanced rate of Wednesday was not maintained, the bulk of the day's call business being at a maximum of 2 1/2 per cent. Because of details in financing two or three important consolidation projects, it may be that tomorrow's bank statement will include big figures affecting some of the items exceptionally.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Ex-Judge W.N. Cohen, Senator Platt's adviser upon police bill legislation, was in Albany to-day. He was at the Capitol, and had a long interview with Gov. Odell. When he left the executive chamber he was asked if he had brought up the new State Police bill, which he was reported to have drawn up at the suggestion of Senator Platt.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Senators Platt and Depew of New York are both opposing the proposition to nominate Col. Sanger for the office of Assistant Secretary of War. Senator Platt saw the Secretary of War on the subject to-day and entered a formal protest on the ground that Col. Sanger is not a consistent Republican. Senator Depew also has indicated his opposition.

TAMPA, Fla., March 7 -- An important professional golf game took place to-day, when in a thirty-six-hole four-ball match for a purse Lawrence Auchterlonie of Bellair and James M. Watson of Winter Park played against James Feulis of Tampa Bay and William Marshall of Kissimmee. The crowd that followed the players was rewarded by seeing golf of a very high order.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Senator Stranahan to-day introduced a mortgage tax bill, mainly framed along the lines of a similar measure introduced last year. The bill adds to the mortgage tax law an entirely new article containing twenty new sections.

TRENTON, N.J., March 7 -- The man whose body was found on the Pennsylania Railroad tracks near the Clinton Street Station last night and who was believed to be one of two men operating as pickpockets on a train going from Philadelphia to New York, was identified to-night by his wife. She gave her husband's name as William Hazen and their address as 53 Market Street, New York City.

CORSICANA, Texas, March 7 -- Mrs. Conway Younger, a farmer's wife, was murdered last night by a negro. A posse of 200 men, headed by Younger, are, by the aid of bloodhounds, following the trail of the murderer, who doubtless will meet a terrible death at the hands of the pursuers. Younger returned from the fields last evening to find his wife missing.

In their search for evidence by which to convict Charley Garez, or Jaurez, the Brazilian who was arrested early Tuesday morning after he was found secreted in a closet in the apartment of Commodore and Mrs. Weston of Newark, N.J., at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the private detectives employed by the hotel yesterday made an important discovery.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 7 -- The following vote was taken to-day for United States Senator: Alien, (Fus.,) 47; Hitchcock, (Fus.,) 47; D.E. Thompson, 36; Grouse, 9; Currie, 16; Meiklejohn, 29; Hinshaw, 22; Rosewater, 14; scattering, 14.

Yesterday was trial day at Police Headquarters, and again Commissioner Murphy turned over the task of meting out justice to delinquent members of the force to Deputy Commissioner Devery. This official, with a dignity and solemnity that kept even the rapt spectators in a state of awe, handed out justice so rapidly that the unhappy recipients hardly knew that they had received it until they stood once more outside the tribune.

WHEELING, West Va., March 7 -- The new Wheeling and Cleveland Road is to be built, making the fourth railroad from the Wheeling district to the lakes. The Wheeling and Lake Erie bought thirty-one acres of land on the river front opposite Wheeling, and it was alleged this would shut out the new line.

So much has been written lately of a denunciatory or despairing nature as to what it is "possible" or "impossible" for the negroes of the South to do for themselves, that it is interesting to come across proofs of what they actually are doing.

BOSTON, Mass., March 7 -- Harry Gray Bixby died at noon to-day at the Perkins Hospital at Newton, having been ill with pneumonia about ten days. He was a few months less than forty-eight years old. He was at one time the champion tennis player and champion amateur rifle shot of New England.

-- A deteriorated and demoralized Department of Street Cleaning prevents New York from getting all the benefit it should, as regards the condition of its pavements, from the recent banishment of thousands and thousands of horses from the city limits, but there is another good result of this equine exodus with which even Tammany cannot interfere.
PEKING, March 7 -- The Ministers of the powers have resolved to modify the legation plan so as to follow the offices of the five Government boards to remain in the occupation of the Chinese.

ALBANY, March 7 -- A new Pure Beer bill will be submitted to the Assembly to-morrow morning by the Excise Committee. It is the work of the sub-committee of that body, and will be known as the Committee on Excise's bill. It embodies the principal features of the Stevens and Burnett Pure Beer bills, as well as some suggestions made by other prominent pure-beer advocates, both outside and inside the Legislature.

HACKBNSACK, N. J., March 7 -- Mrs. Mary A. Davis of New Bridge was not seen about her home yesterday nor to-day and an entrance was forced. She was found dead in bed. Her pet bulldog sprang upon the bed when the neighbors entered and refused to allow any one to approach the body.

Three more games were played in the amateur handicap billiard tournament at Daly's yesterday, Bash winning the two evening events and Gershel the afternoon match. As Bash before had participated in three games, his string was completed, he having three victories to his credit. Two games will be played to-day.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Senator Brackett's bills amending the general stock and corporation laws, which were made caucus measures last night, were taken up in the Senate this morning. Mr. Brackett offered an amendment changing Chapter 35 of the present law so that any number of stockholders may confer the right upon one person to vote for them "in order to secure solidarity of action."

Yesterday was rather brisk. As far as Lenten amusements were concerned there was quite an attractive programme. Besides there was the wedding of Miss Susan Graham Varnum and Mr. Edward De Rose at Grace Church Chantry. Although the public carnival ball which was given last evening does not enter on the calendar of social events, it was nevertheless the attraction for many of the very gay set, especially the masculine element.

MADRID, March 8 -- Gen. Weyler, Minister of War in the new Cabinet, asserts that he will use all his energy in the reorganization of the army in order to render it useful for service in all circumstances. He does not yet know whether he will maintain as a whole the reform proposed by his predecessor.

Passers-by in Sixth Avenue, and in the neighborhood of Sixth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, witnessed a wildly exciting burglar chase shortly after 10 o'clock last evening, which ended when two of the thieves surrendered at the muzzles of the revolvers of Central Office Detectives Price and McCafferty, while the third lost himself amid the spectators, scattering in all directions to escape a possible fusillade.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 7 -- In the course of an address before the annual conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church of New Jersey to-day, the Rev. A.B. Leonard, Corresponding Secretary of the General Missionary Society, arraigned United States Attorney General John W. Griggs for his action in connection with the army canteen question.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 7 -- The last rivet was driven to-day in the steel plating covering the longitudinal angle frames, and the solid steel rings of the mainmast of the Belmont Cup defender. Furthermore, a lot of steel plates and longitudinal braces has been cut out and laid along the floor of the north boat shop. The plates have been cut and turned for both large and small spars.

The Lelpsic Philharmonic Orchestra has made a tremendous success in Poughkeepsie, and the New York critics have been soundly berated for not discovering its greatness. One of the Poughkeepsie papers says: "Some of the critics of New York have already sprinkled cold water on the American tour of the Leipsic Philharmonic Orchestra and its director.

LONDON, March 7 -- Money grew firmer to-day. The revenue collections continue to denude the market and short loans are scarce, in spite of considerable borrowings from the Bank of England. Discounts were firm. In view of the dearness of money bill holders are disposed to retain them, regarding the present recovery as temporary, pending the imminence of heavy disbursements upon the part of the Government.

Still further contraction occurred yesterday in the trading in the steel stocks on the curb, and with few exceptions the trading in other parts of the list was limited. Prices continued irregular, a few issues showing decided weakness, while others were well bought and closed with substantial gains.

COLUMBIA, S.C., March 7 -- The Grand Jury of Anderson County to-day made its report to Judge W.C. Benet, and declared that a practical enslavement of negroes has been conducted in that county. The presentment was prepared by a special committee, which visited the convict stockade camps in Anderson County and found confined therein negroes guiltless of any felony, but undergoing a term of servitude under voluntary contracts which they had signed in partial ignorance.

HAVANA, March 7 -- The Cuban Constitutional Convention met in secret session at 2 o'clock this afternoon for a formal discussion of the Senate amendment. The Conservative element scored a victory. It was decided to continue the sessions of the convention and to refer the amendment to the Special Committee on Relations, with instructions to bring in a report.

PHILADELPHIA, March 7 -- The weekly handicap games of the University of Pennsylvania, which were to be contested last Saturday, were run off at Franklin Field to-day, and despite the inclement weather, a good many of the men turned out. Of the events scheduled the sixty-yards run excited most interest, as its result derided who should get the medal.

Rumors daily current in Wall Street of obstacles to the conclusion of the negotiations for the consolidation of the iron and steel properties listed for merger in the United States Steel Corporation should be accepted for what they are worth -- which is very little. That there is more or less dissatisfaction with the basis on which the several properties are valued is quite probable.
LONDON, March 8 -- The Copenhagen correspondent of The Daily Mail says:

ALBANY, March 7 -- The Assembly Committee on Cities to-night favorably reported the Morgan Ramapo Repeal bill by a unanimous vote. The committee was in session until 8 o'clock, and the discussion upon the measure was a protracted one, but is said to have been without special incident.

An action to recover $150 on a check alleged to have been given in payment of a gambling debt at "Honest John" Kelly's place, in West Fifty-first Street, has been set down for trial on the preferred calendar of the City Court for March 18. The complainant in the case is Frederick T. Holmes, who seeks to recover the face value of the check from the maker, Julius Klausner.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., March 7 -- The body of Mrs. C.W. Wygant, wife of Lieut. F. W. Wygant, United States Army, was brought here to-day and buried in the Baptist Cemetery at Scotch Plains.

TRENTON, N.J., March 7 -- The Senate this morning passed a resolution introduced by Mr. Reed requesting the State Riparian Commission to inform the Senate as to the riparian rights, for commercial uses, that would be lost if the Legislature should pass the Senate bill giving the Palisades Commission power to acquire the water front along the Hudson River, for the preservation of the Palisades and the establishment of a State park.

The four-story building, 146 Fifth Avenue, west side, 538 feet north of Nineteenth Street, has been sold for about $100,000. The property last appeared in the official records in May, 1858, when it was conveyed to Ann E. Gawtry for a nominal consideration. The name of the buyer in the present transaction could not be learned.

It is a run decade since the cry of a "Billion Dollar Congress" seemed to the opposition a promising platform for a Presidential campaign. The Fifty-sixth Congress has exceeded that, and come unpleasantly near the billion and a half. But for the fortunate garrulity of Senator CARTER, who talked the River and Harbor bill to death, its expenditure might fairly be called, in numbers not too round, a billion and a half.

The Erasmus Hall High School skaters carried off the honors in the senior championship skating races of the Long Island Interscholastic Athletic League at the Clermont Avenue Rink yesterday afternoon, winning three of the four events, and the same proportion of seconds and thirds as well.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 8 -- Ex-President Benjamin Harrison is a very sick man and his closest friends are alarmed. His condition is more serious than is generally believed. However, Dr. Henry Jameson, the family physician, who has sole charge of the case, said to-night there was no immediate danger; in fact, he was not at all alarmed, he said, as to the outcome.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 8 -- William Schreiber, the young bank clerk who plundered the Elizabethport Bank last August of $109,000, has been traced to Los Angeles, Cal., where he cashed three United States 4 per cent, bonds which were part of his plunder. The bonds were of the issue of 1895, and were for $1,000 each.

How many persons take the trouble to investigate any literary question for themselves? How many of them always seek for some handy volume in which there is a more or less careful summing up of the matter and then content themselves with that? There are periodicals which endeavor to summarize the mass of information poured into the world on certain topics.
Nathan Wise has sold the plot at the northeast corner of Broadway and One Hundred and Forty-fifth Street, 99.11 by 375.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., March 8 -- George H. Daniels, General Passenger Agent of the New York Central Railroad, was the guest of honor at the Board of Trade banquet to-night, the largest event in the history of Canajoharie. Addresses were made by Congressman J.R. Stewart. Titus Sheard, William G. Arkell, and John A. Sleicher of Albany.

Just as early risers in the neighborhood of Fifty-ninth Street and First Avenue were waking up yesterday morning, they were startled by hearing three pistol shots in the almost deserted streets. Two minutes later Patrolman Decker of the East Fifty-first Street Station ran around the corner and found the body of a conductor of a Fifty-ninth Street crosstown car lying beside Car No. 233, which stood at the eastern terminal of the line.

DOVER, Del., March 8 -- The Legislature adjourned sine die this afternoon, amid scenes of the greatest excitement, without having made a choice for Senator either for the, long or the short term. As Gov. Hunn declared this afternoon that he would not appoint a Senator, and as Senator Kenny's term expired March 3, the State is without representation in the upper chamber of Congress.

HELENA, Mon., March 8 -- Gov. Joseph Toole to-day vetoed the bill commonly known as "the change of venue bill." It provides that when "judicial prejudice is shown by oral testimony a change of venue can be demanded, and if refused by the Judge himself appeal can be taken to the Supreme Court, and that body can grant such change of venue."

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- Ever since the termination of the American campaign in China, the Navy Department has been desirous of having medals or other tokens of recognition bestowed upon two British sailors for heroic aid extended to a boatload of American and British wounded at Taku on June 22 last.

WILLIAM H. CONDON, New York, writes to THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW with reference to F.W. Page's communication in THE SATURDAY REVIEW of Jan. 20: "Mr. Page states that he has looked in vain through the operations in the Shenandoah Valley in Vol. XII. Series of the War of the Rebellion to find that Gen. Shields claimed a victory over Gen. Jackson at any time.'

BOSTON, March 7 -- Messrs. Little, Brown Company's Spring announcements include "The Love Letters of the King," by Mr. Richard Le Gallienne, and the second title. "The Life Romantic," shows that his cheerful little affectations will adorn it, but it is said that it is reasonably cheerful and quite free from the morbid spirit of his former story.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The President to-day issued an Executive order abolishing the Cuban export duty on tobacco from April 1 next. This action was taken on the earnest recommendation, indorsed by Gen. Wood, of the Cuban Economic Commission which recently visited Washington. A previous order had been issued fixing an export duty of 50 per cent. on Cuban tobacco from April 1.

For the lover of biography there is a never-ending charm in the story of the national heroes, the popular idols who in every clime and age have stood out prominently as exponents of racial ideals. A biographical series sufficiently comprehensive to embrace Nelson, Cicero, Jeanne d'Arc, Bismarck. Saladin, and Saint Louis, Robert Bruce, Robert E. Lee, and Charlemagne, must in the natural course of things include finally the object of every Irishman's worship.

The April Century will contain an article bearing the title of "The Queen at Os- borne." Although presented anonymously, it is known to be written by an American lady who at one time enjoyed the favor of England's late Queen.
