HELENA, Montana, March 8 -- At halfpast 3 this morning, although the Legislature clock testified that it was not midnight. Paris Gibson of Great Falls was elected United State Senator for the term expiring March 4, 1905. Mr. Gibson has always been a strong Democrat.

In 1898 Mr. Albert SonnichsenY, Quarter master of the transport Zealandia, left San Francisco for Manila and reached Manila Bay on the 23d of July. The United States troops having been disembarked, the two camps of Americans and Filipinos were side by side. After the capture of Manila, Aug. 13, Mr. Sonnichsen attached himself to the Utah Battery, Aguinaldo, who had taken some 6,000 Spaniards prisoners, now entertained ideas of a Filipino republic.

LONDON, Feb. 20 -- The Queen's death of course led to an outburst of poetry from the minor poets. That was to have been expected. A minor poet can always write a funeral ode at a moment's notice, and, like the young woman in "Huckleberry Finn," he can usually "get in ahead of the undertaker."

AIKEN, S.C., March 8 -- There was great interest among the Winter colony in the polo game between teams of women that was scheduled for to-day. The weather had moderated and was delightful, and a large number witnessed the contest. The women have practiced for some time. Those who rode "man fashion" seemed quite at home.

Yesterday had its sewing classes and its evening Badminton Club. Otherwise it was dull. Already the plans arranged for weekend parties were perfected, and this morning there will be many departures from town. Mrs. Arthur Paget arrived in the course of the day from Washington. She will remain in New York about a fortnight longer and then go abroad.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It may be of interest to some of your feminine readers, and especially to those whose contributions adorn the pages of "Woman; Can She Reason?" to learn that "Cynic" has at length capitulated to the charms (or shall we call them fascinations?) of one of that sex whose mental deficiencies he assailed.

That twelve treaties of commercial reciprocity with foreign countries were refused consideration by the Senate; that to each of these treaties the Administration is committed by the fact that it negotiated it in good faith; and that a strong effort will be made by the President and Secretary of State to have them ratified, or at least some of them, before the Senate adjourns, are facts of greater significance than seems to be generally appreciated.

Readers in general have come to realize that the present time is remarkable in the matter of the large demand for popular books; but very few, we think, realize fully the significance of the great sales which are being exploited by publishers. There are now in full swing of favor eleven books which have averaged a sale of almost 100,000 copies.
Dr. ALONZO T. SMITH, a prominent physician, died in Syracuse yesterday, aged eighty-one years. He was the oldest alumnus of the Geneva Medical College.

Gen. George W. Mindil, jewelry examiner at the Public Stores in this city, has made a report to Appraiser Wakeman on the importation of precious stones and pearls for the month of February last. The report indicates an enormously increasing demand for costly personal adornments by the fashionable and wealthy classes throughout the United States, and is significant of prosperity in the trade.

A dispute over a day's wages alleged to be due to William Crashaw, a member of the New York district of the Iron Mol;dewrs' National Union, led to a strike of the union iron molders in Frederick W. Davis's foundry in Brooklyn last week, followed by a suit in the Lee Avenue Court, Brooklyn, yesterday for the recovery of the money.

"K.P.G.," Glenolden, Penn., in reply to "F.C.'s criticism in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW of Feb. 23, of kipling's latest romance, writes: "I am thoroughly enjoying every word of Kim as it comes but, and eagerly look forward each month to the next installment.

MR. ANDREW CARNEGIE -- The other day seventy-five librarians, representing the Illinois State Library Association, met in Lincoln, that State, and unanimously elected Mr. Andrew Carnegie an honorary member of the association. The worthy motives which inspired such action may be gathered from the resolutions which were adopted on the occasion:
ALBANY, March 8 -- The following bills were introduced in the Assembly this morning:

To the reader to whom a book comes finished and who has never given a thought to its making, except carelessly to pass upon its final effectiveness, the amount of care such preparation involves would seem surprising if fully known. A well-known English bibliographer has said that next in importance after writing or editing a volume comes its typographical production.

For a couple of hours before dusk yesterday afternoon there was some excellent sport on the Harlem River Speedway. The bright, Springlike weather had brought the light-harness horsemen and their fast steppers out in full force, and the road being in prime condition for brushing, all took advantage of it, with the result that the spectators were treated to a number of hotly contested races.

Lexington Avenue, near Grand Central Palace presented a gay appearance last Thursday night. Up the sidewalk, out of the surrounding darkness into the blaze of the electric lights of the Palace moved a continuous procession of "chappies," young and old, in evening dress and opera hats, and with an air of expectant enjoyment.

That colors affect the mind with different force has been known for ages, but it is curious that artists who deal with colors professionally have done little or nothing to formulate the impressions that different hues produce. The ancients believed that certain kinds of music roused certain emotions, and it was part of their theories of medicine that music ministered to a mind diseased.

Mr. Laurence Hutton, in one of his lectures entitled "The Collecting of the Collection of Masks from Life and Death." which are now in the University Library, tells the story of the posthumous return of Aaron Burr, 1772, to his Alma Mater, in a way that cannot fail to interest Princeton men the world over.

BERLIN, March 8 -- Emperor William has received congratulations on his escape from serious injury from nearly every European potentate, including the King of Denmark, the Queen of the Netherlands, the King of the Belgians, the King of Roumania, the Queen Regent of Spain, the King of Italy, Emperor Francis Joseph, President Loubet, and the Pope.

In his preface the author of "Justice to the Jews" describes how in the writing of that work his attention was called to the Talmud, "this remarkable production of antiquity." Mr. Peters, then, hopeful of gaining a knowledge of the Jewish religion and believing that extracts from, the Talmud would lead Christian scholars to study the subject further, has compiled the volume under notice.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 8 -- A serious riot occurred here yesterday. For hours the city was overrun by a riotous crowd of probably 1,300 persons, who shouted "Down with the Americans!" and other similar cries.
In the New York Interclub Bowling League tournament on the Knickerbocker Athletic Club alleys last night the home team won three games from the Harlem Republican Club. The scores:

ALBANY, March 8 -- The business of 1900 of the fire and marine insurance companies in New York State shows aggregate receipts of $187,371,063 and disbursements of $161,316,628, an increase, as compared with 1899, of $11,637,813 in receipts, and an increase of $2,669,430 in disbursements. The whole number of companies reporting last year was 182, being 4 less than in 1899.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2 @63c. There were no sales.

At a meeting of the New York Historical Society on Tuesday evening of this week, with Dean Hoffman, the new President, in the chair, it was unanimously decided to drop the project of an amalgamation or affiliation with the New York Public Library on the basis of accepting the Lenox Library Building as the future home of the society.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read all the studied articles on "The Old Man in Doubt," and so far fall to find any relief for him. Neither ethics nor creeds will play any part in the salvation of souls. The writings of Renan and all others will never dispel doubt. The Bible is the panacea of all spiritual wants.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 8 -- The Rawson twins, whose escapades as boys kept the northern part of Bergen County alive for ten or twelve years, but who have settled down since they became of age to be hard-working young men, are once more in the public eye. Their grandmother was Laura Keene, the actress.
Corporation Counsel Whalen has had prepared papers in two test cases which mark the beginning of one of the most important legal battles waged during the administration of Mayor Van Wyck.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 8 -- Shortstop Monte Cross to-day signed a Philadelphia National League Club contract for the coming season. Cross is the first of the old Philadelphia players to sign a National contract.

The seventh public rehearsal of the fifty-ninth season of the Philharmonic Society took place yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall amid the customary surroundings of such entertainments, even to the insatiable encore seekers. The only real blot on the concert was the forcing of the soloist to destroy the impression he had made with a piece of Tschaikowsky's by adding one of those short tunes so dear to the encore lover.

Acting Captain John Townsend of the West Thirtieth Street Police Station was about to retire at 12:30 o'clock this morning when a citizen ran up to him and asked a private conference. They remained together less than five minutes, when the Captain, putting on his hat and coat as he ran, darted out of the house and toward Sixth Avenue, followed closely by a number of reporters who had seen the move.

The attendance at the Sportsmen's Show yesterday reached the high-water mark of the week, Madison Square Garden being comfortably filled both afternoon and evening. The crowd in the morning was light, unquestionably because of the withdrawal of the usual attraction of the trap shooting on the roof and the transfer of that attractive feature of the exhibition to Inter-State Park and the consequent absence of the wing shots and their friends.

The work that is being done at Tuskegee, Ala., for the education of the negroes of the South is a peculiar and excellent work, and it deserves the most generous support from the people of the North, because it is helping the negroes to help themselves, and its wonderful success is ample proof that they can help themselves.

The Pratt Institute of Brooklyn has opened an exhibition in basketry which has a liberal contingent from Indian tribes the Mokis, Apaches and Pimas, the Alas- kans and Aleuts of the extreme Nortwest, and in connection with the exhibit it is announced that the Department of Domestic Art has work in basketry to show, which is the result of a class organized last November.
CAMDEN, N.J., March 8 -- At to-day's session of the annual Conference of the New Jersey Methodist Church the twentieth century revival movement and the new constitution were considered.

"Rattling" would be a mild descriptive adjective to apply to Mr. Arthur W. Marchmont's story "In the Name ot a Woman." The romance simply re-echoes with the reports of small arms. When the opportunity presents itself raplers flash and clatter, and what is rare of late, the hero is very handy with that obsolete yet delightful weapon, the swordstick.

That the dressmaker's path may henceforth be strewn with roses, and that such evil things as "misfits" may not disturb her serenity when she asks the courts to collect her bills, was the object of organizing the Dressmakers' Protective Association of America yesterday, at the offices of Le Costume Royal, 28 West Twenty-third Street.

The stock market yesterday developed much irregularity, but the undertone was generally and substantially strong. In the early trading prices were lower, London having sent over quotations well below Thursday's close here. Almost at the outset, however, strength developed, and from these low prices quotations went up, in some cases by leaps and bounds, until at one time the market had all the earmarks of an old-time bull market.

The statement had been made that there is a "strike" back of the resolution introduced into the City Council on Tuesday and referred to the Committee on Fire, providing for the removal of gas meters from the cellars of all buildings in Greater New York to a fire-proof vault in the yard or areaway, and further providing that connections be of iron.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. William Dean has published an article lately respecting the captors of Major Andre which seems to require an answer. He has made some ungracious personal allusions to me which were entirely uncalled for. He cays in his article: "He [meaning me] never applied to any of the descendants of John Dean, whom he bitterly attacks."
MANILA, March 8 -- The Manila Board of Health has announced that on an estimated population of 300,000 for the City of Manila the annual death rate is 34 per 1,000.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 8 -- Hennessy Son, owners of the horse W.J. Baker, filed with the Stewards to-day certificates of veterinary surgeons showing that the horse was ill. These were accepted in explanation of his bad race yesteiday, and the ban of suspension was removed. The weather was cloudy and the track fast.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- So far as is known the United States was the first of the powers at Peking to found a regular Chinese court of justice in the Chinese capital in place of the arbitrary military courts which have been acting since the entrance of the allies into the city. The War Department has just received a copy of an order issued by Gen.

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 8 -- Senator Christopher L. Magee of Pittsburg died this evening after an illness of more than two years. His death was unexpected, as it was generally believed by his friends that he was improving in health. His condition took a turn for the worse last night, and the members of his family were hurriedly summoned to Harrisburg.

Capts. James S. Kennedy, Frank P. Kenvon, and Dwight B. Taylor, Assistant Surgeons United States Volunteers, recently appointed, will proceed to San Francisco and report to the commanding General, Department of California, for transportation to Manila, where they will report to the Commanding General, Division of the Philippines, for assignment to duty.

ALBANY, March 8 -- In the Assembly this morning Mr. Rierdon of New York, in the interest of the youth, objected to the advancement of Mr. Plank's bill making it a misdemeanor for any person to wrongfully view a baseball or football game. The bill was laid over.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Morgan bill for the unconditional repeal of the Ramapo Company's charter was favorably reported to the Assembly to-day by the Committee on Cities. Mr. McKeown, on the part of the minority, moved that the bill be taken up and passed. Speaker Nixon objected.
LONDON, March 9 -- The Pretoria correspondent of The Times, wiring Wednesday, says.

OMAHA, Neb., March 8 -- Ernest J. Wolter, a merchant of Schuyler, Neb., is in jail here on a charge of attempting to extort money from Thomas Kearns. United States Senator from Utah. The arrest -was made by Post Office Inspector W.T. Sullivan of Denver.

Word has been received here from Joplin, Mo., that H.M. Rogers of that city has applied for a receiver for the International Zinc Company, which was exploited here, and the stock of which was widely advertised and sold throughout the United States, the defunct corporation of Joshua Brown Co. acting as the fiscal agents of the concern.
LONDON, March 9 -- Consuelo, Duchess of Manchester, and Sir John and Lady Lister-Kaye will sail for New York to-day.

A simple-hearted writer in the latest number of Scribner's discusses the subject of "Machinery and the Real Culture." The substance of his mild contention, as we understand it, is that there is no machine-made "culture" worth much, and that what is turned out in large quantities at small prices is not rare and not extraordinarily precious.

LONDON, March 9 -- In the House of Commons yesterday the Right Hon. W. St. John Brodrick, Secretary of State for War, prefaced his Introduction of the army estimates for 1901-2 by saying that the war in South Africa had brought to light many faults, even in those portions of the army system which were believed to be the best.

The scarcity of water in the Boroughs of Brooklyn and the Bronx has caused a great number of complaints to be made to the Water Supply Department. Chief Engineer Birdsall did not offer any hope yesterday of immediate improvement, and he said that the entire city was in danger of water famine.

We shall await with interest the disclosure by the Hon. HYATT C. HATCH, member of the Assembly from Atlanta. Steuben County, of the names of "the former residents of Steuben County who are large real estate owners in New York City," and who have induced him to bring in the remarkable bill described in our Albany dispatches yesterday.

The Church Extension Committee of the New York Classis of the Reformed Church in America is to meet at the Reformed Church Building. 25 East Twenty-second Street, on Monday at 3 o'clock. It is to receive at that time applications from churches for financial assistance, which the Classis is at this time in a position to grant, by reason of the receipt of some $15,000 from the sale of the property of the Holland Church.

That is, on the face of it, a very discouraging report that we get from San Juan de Porto Rico. That the American Superintendent of Schools should have been mobbed and hooted and even assaulted seems to indicate some animosity to Americans in the island which we fondly fancied did not exist.

CITY ISLAND, March 8 -- The steam yacht Cosette, recently purchased by W.S. Compton of New London, has begun the overhauling process, preparatory to going into commission, at the Jacob yard. The yacht will cruise in Southern waters in the early Spring. Work on John Hyslop's keel sloop is rapidly progressing at the same yard.

ALBANY, March 8 -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided in the case of Ralph J. Treat vs. Controller Coler of New York City, that the law requiring the use of stone dressed in this State in the performance of public contracts within the State and prohibiting the use of stone dressed in other States on such work, is unconstitutional.

CHICAGO, March 8 -- A highly sensational attempt to rob the home of William McLaughlin, the millionaire coffee merchant. No. 97 Rush Street, was made to-night, Scores of shots were fired and Frederick McLaughlin, a son of the merchant, narrowly escaped death. The residence is in the fashionable district of the North side.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

MANILA, March 8 -- Disappointment among American business men here with the limitations of the Spooner amendment to the Army bill is increasing as its provisions become better known. It is considered to be especially unfortunate in apparently prohibiting the issuing of licenses for the cutting of timber upon public lands.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- It is understood the final adjournment of the extraordinary session of the Senate will take place to-morrow. The adjournment would have taken place to-day had the new Senator from Oregon, Mr. Mitchell, been present to take the oath of office.

It is exactly in the line of our whole policy and procedure in China that we should be the first Power to establish a court of justice in its respective "holding" at the Chinese capital. And we have established a court of "justice according to law," which of course, in the estimation of all the suitors and defendants who come before it, means according to Chinese law.

Final details are now practically completed for the actual annexation of the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad to the Pennsylvania system. The Pennsylvania's controlling financiers joined William K. Vanderbilt and J.P. Morgan about a year ago in the purchase of a majority of the Chesapeake and Ohio's capital stock -- this being one of the earliest moves toward the development of the community of interest policy among important American railroads.

There has been unusual activity lately among the sometimes amusing busybodies whose principal delight in life seems to be to discover the "originals" of personages in fiction. Zangwill's latest novel, for instance, is held to contain "thinly disguised" portrayals of at least two men prominent in English public life.

The latest disguise of "Alfred Parsons," who, as reported, tried to swindle President Hadley of Yale, was stripped from him by Capt. Titus yesterday, and he was proclaimed to be none other than Ross Raymond, a swindler almost without a rival. The Captain says many guesses as to his identity had preceded his arrival in this city as a prisoner.

The committee of three of the Chamber of Commerce, consisting of John Claflin, ex-Mayor Schieren of Brooklyn, and ex-Mayor Hewitt, which was appointed on Thursday to make an investigation to see whether the crowding at the terminals of the Third Avenue line of the Manhattan Elevated Railroad and the Brooklyn Bridge cannot be relieved in some way, will meet next Monday at 3 o'clock.

LONDON, March 9 -- The reconstruction of the interior of the steamer Ophir, of the Orient Line, which is being converted into a royal yacht for the forthcoming tour of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York, is now nearly completed. The royal suite of apartments is paneled in rosewood, satinwood, and Sheraton satin.

When Matthew Arnold was writing those delightful papers of his "On the Study of Celtic Literature" it is highly improbable that it occurred to him that any member of the House of Commons would ever endeavor to address that house in his own ancestral tongue, whether that tongue happened to be Welsh or Erse of Ireland or Gaelic of the Scottish Highlands.

Mr. Giles's volume on the history of Chinese literature is the most recent addition to the series of "Literatures of the World," edited by Edmund Gosse and published by the Appletons. In many respects it differs from all its predecessors in the series, and in one thing it is unique; it has no competitors, for it is the only attempt at a history of Chinese literature which has ever been made in any language.

Marcus A. Bettman, the oil producer and banker who failed in March, 1898, with liabilities of over $1,000,000, will have to pay to the heirs of Sigmund Schneittacher $14,694.47. This sum he used in his business ventures while he was administrator of the estate.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Senate, in executive session, to-day confirmed all the nominations to office that have been made during the special session. There was a recess, while the doors were closed in order to permit the various committees to make reports upon the nominations, and all were favorably reported.

"I am always glad to talk about servants, if it will do anything toward solving the servant problem," said a woman engaged in philanthropic work, which includes an employment bureau for colored persons. "Our work here has been increasing largely, and a great many women come to us saying that they wish colored girls, for they are tired of the impudence of white servants.

The United States is a country where histrionic ambitions flourish. Would-be Booths and Bernhardts are numerous in every part of the land, and particularly in that part -- strange to say -- which prides itself upon its Puritan ancestry. Investigation shows a surprising amount of amateur dramatic work, and New England has the greatest share.

Although last week lacked such transactions as made its immediate predecessor one of almost spectacular activity, it developed a creditable amount of business, showing that large variety which has been altogether the best feature of recent dealing.

Every one has heard a good deal about the Stundists, the Shelapouty, the Doukhobors, and other dissenters of evangelical type, some of them with a strong tendency toward Quakerism. These deserving people, who are the best specimens of their race, were, and still are, subjected to the most revolting persecutions.

When Judge Jacobs in Special Sessions recently paroled for a month nearly fifty boys and young men found guilty of various minor offenses, he was only carrying out a probationary system of dealing with youthful criminals which has been quietly introduced by Principal David Willard of the Boys' School in the Tombs Prison, the results of which are being watched with the utmost interest by various philanthropic organizations.

DALLAS, March 9. -- A cyclone did terrible work in Northeastern Texas this afternoon. Its most severe blow was at Will's Point, in Van Zandt County, forty-eight miles east of Dallas. The force of the cyclone struck the town at 1 P.M., and wrecked twenty-five buildings, including the oil mill, the Johnson Cotton Gin Company's plant, the Texas and Pacific station, the public school, and numerous stores.

Three meetings of golf interest will be held during the coming week, and one of them will be particularly important to local golfers, because it will fix the course for the Metropolitan golf championship. The Executive Committee of the Metropolitan Association has changed the date of its meeting from Tuesday to Thursday evening.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From a leading article in THE TIMES in relation to the influence of muscular exercise upon health and longevity, some readers may draw conclusions not strictly in agreement with facts. Of all the animals the deer is one of the most active and one of the most healthy, always dying of old age if not killed by accident or by the hand of an enemy.

To the music of yelling natives and howling dogs our picturesque caravan started at a frightful speed, some of the dogs every now and then slipping on the smooth spots of the ice and sprawling on their sides or backs while being dragged along by the others. Ahead were seen masses of heaped-up ice.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9. -- The local market was stronger in the majority of the issues to-day. Lehigh Valley continued to be absorbed, the price being slightly higher in the early trading. The Readings were firmer, and Choctaw common advanced from 42 3/8 to 42 3/4. Union Traction was an active and interesting feature.
Army. Capt. Thomas B. Dugan, Seventh Cavalry, is transferred to the Twelfth Cavalry and will report to the commanding officer of the latter regiment at Fort Sam Houston, Texas, for duty as Adjutant.

To the Editor of The New York Times: "If a man die, shall he live again?" Often when the outer world is hushed, this question, like the "Bells of Iss," rings up from the soul. And if perchance a friend should catch the echo, he shrugs his shoulders or hands an open Bible. But the question will intrude itself.

BOSTON, Mass., March 9. -- Thomas W. Lawson is compelled by certain statements which have been made within a few days regarding the inability of his boat, the Independence, to enter the trial cup races because of his non-membership in the New York Yacht Club, to make a statement which he says he had not intended to make until a later period, if at all.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You quote from John Gilmer Speed (Sunday, March 3) in a magazine article as to the conduct of the crowd at Brooklyn Bridge "rush" hours. That writer does not overstate the rudeness of it by any means, but in one direction he certainly understates.

James H. Hart, a large property owner of Brooklyn, has obtained in the Supreme Court, that borough, a temporary Injunction restraining the Brooklyn Union Gas Company from shutting off the gas in his apartment houses at Broadway and Gates Avenue, because he has refused to pay a bill presented to him.

"Between the grip and the smallpox this has been a bad Winter for the auctioneers," said a leading member of the trade to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter yesterday. "I do not mean that there haven't been as many auction sales as usual -- there has not been much difference in that respect -- but there have been fewer purchasers, and our commissions and general profits have been correspondingly lower.

In these days "Uncle Tom's Cabin" must be ranked with the "romantic plays." It has no youthful and potent hero, of course, for George Harris, who says many brave words about the duty of caring for one's wife, in Acts I. and II., disappears in gunpowder smoke long before the play is half finished.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Noticing your excellent account of the proposal to build a Naval Arch in Battery Park, it seems to me that the more appropriate memorial would be that of a City Gate, to be erected in Battery Park as a monument to the brave and God-fearing men who laid the foundation of New York's greatness, and opened up opportunities for the oppressed and distressed of all peoples.

In a quiet country walk we know from the sound heard that a cart is passing along the highway, that water is near by the murmur it makes in going over the pebbles, and a faint rumble of distant thunder indicates some disturbance of the atmosphere in the direction whence the sound proceeds.

The Rev. Robert Bayard Snowden, rector of St. Jude's Protestant Episcopal Church at Blythebourne, Brooklyn, and a well-known misisonary worker and writer on religious topics, died yesterday at his home at Eleventh Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, Brooklyn. He was born in New York City Nov. 21, 1833, and was the son of Arthur H. Snowden.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is impossible for a true Democrat not to echo your appreciative editorial to-day on the first term of William McKinley. Every Democrat who places patriotism above party and principle higher than all, must feel that the practical instrument to his hand to-day is the policy of William McKinley.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The State Department to-day gave a voluntary and emphatic denial of all stories to the effect that the United States is entering into secret negotiations with any power in regard to the Manchuria question. The statement given to THE NEW YORK TIMES, and published this morning, was repeated to all inquirers, and offered as the probable explanation of the London story.

NILES, Mich., March 9. -- Great excitement prevails here to-night over the disappearance of C.A. Johnson, cashier of the First National Bank, which closed its doors yesterday after a short run on its funds by scared depositors. None of the officials of the bank seems to know where Johnson is, but President W.K. Lacy insists that Johnson is in Chicago suffering from a complete mental collapse.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- After swearing in the new Senator from Oregon, John H. Mitchell, and confirming all the pending nominations, the Senate adjourned without day early this afternoon.

Before the people of the United Provinces emerged victorious from their heroic struggle with Philip of Spain, the Hollanders had been subject for many centuries to the alternate dominion of Prankish or German Emperors. It was not until the seventeenth century that Holland justified her existence as a separate nation by that remarkable display of commercial energy which gave her for a brief period the supremacy of the sea.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The police authorities of Washington are engaged in their quadriennial task of figuring up the damage done by Pennsylvania troops at the inauguration, for the purpose of presenting a bill to the State of Pennsylvania. They have been at it ever since the inauguration, but have not reached the end.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The Tageblatt's special correspondent, who has been traveling in Northern Manchuria, Mongolia, and the borders of Siberia and China for a year, and whose reports, hitherto, have been correct without exception, has sent to his paper a long letter, published to-day, containing details regarding the Russo-Chinese agreement on the subject of Manchuria, Mongolia, and Turkestan.

ORANGE, N.J., March 9. -- A crowd of men numbering about 300, mostly Italians, to-night tried to burn an isolation hospital now being constructed by the Board of Health, and a small-sized riot followed. The Police and Fire Departments were called upon for assistance, and it looked at one time as if the crowd would accomplish its purpose.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., March 9. -- At the Democratic Town Convention, held here this afternoon, William H. Jones of Woodbury was unanimously renominated for the office of Town Clerk. James L. Long of Oyster Bay and all the other town officers were also renominated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have earned the gratitude of the public by your persistent campaign against spitting. I have long been convinced, however, that the efforts to stop the nuisance were begun in the wrong way. There is something to me ludicrous in the signs now displayed in the cars: $500 or imprisonment, or both, for an expectoration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the advocates of personal immortality have occupied the greater portion of the space allotted by you to the discussion of an old man's doubts, possibly you will spare a little room for a few considerations from the other side.

While chatting of the collection of money for the Associated Hospitals, recently concluded, and the scant courtesy sometimes shown the volunteer collectors who annually make their appeals for this charity, Mr. Max Nathan, head of the Nathan Manufacturing Company, who collects from the steel and iron trade, had this pleasant experience to relate: "A few days ago," he said, "I called on George G.W. McMurtry, President of the American Sheet Steel Company.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 9. -- Meetings were held in Jefferson and other Alabama counties to-day by Democrats for the nomination of delegates to County Conventions on March 14. These County Conventions will name delegates from the counties to a Constitutional Convention and will also select delegates to the State Convention of March 19, the latter will select delegates from the State at large and Senatorial and Congressional districts to the Constitutional Convention.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9. -- Anticipating the convention of the United Mine Workers of America at Hazleton, Penn., next week, coal operators throughout the anthracite region to-day posted notices announcing that the 10 per cent. advance in wages and other concessions made to the miners last November would be continued until April 1, 1902, and that local differences would be adjusted with the employes of the respective collieries.

I shall be told that the spread of Christianity, which is inevitable, will extinguish probably very speedily, the separateness of Asia, and with it all its consequences. Will it? Let us look at that belief a little closely, and without preconceived ideas. I do not find in history that a common Christianity in any degree removes hatreds of race or nationality, or prevents continuous outbreaks of bitter hostility; but we may let that pass.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 1. -- Reforms in currency and in transportation are hardly less important to foreign interests in China than is the upsetting of the present office-holding class. Scientific treatment of both subjects has made accessible an understanding of their shortcomings, perhaps without leaving concrete impressions of what may befall one doing business or having occasion to travel in China.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Behold how great a matter a little fire kindleth! Mark Twain has come out against sunrise on principle, and, as usual, be has followers. If you read the neatly-written letters sent to the newspapers by people who have evidently learned grammar, you see another new fad caught up without regard to fact or common sense.
The Hon. Hoke Smith of Atlanta, Ga., is to deliver the address before the graduating law class at Washington and Lee University, Lexington, Va., at commencement next June.
The imports of dry goods and general merchandise for the week were valued at $12,844,423. The imports of specie amounted to $91,001, and the exports of specie to $1,251,230.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Vice President Roosevelt has made such rapid progress in Parliamentary procedure since the special session of the Senate began that the spectators are convinced he has been burning the midnight lamp over the rules every night.

Dr. John B. Lynch of 148 West Twenty-second Street and head of the medical staff of the institutions for the blind connected with the Department of Charities and Correction, procured a summons in Jefferson Market Court on Friday for Metaye de Guichainville of 342 West Eighteenth Street, who, he told Magistrate Pool, had written him several threatening letters and had also written to different persons letters containing calumnies of the basest nature concerning him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The other day at the Water-Color Exhibition, two gentlemen stood near me, before the painting of the Constitution towed by her small boats, escaping from the British fleet. After looking at it for some moments, one said, with a suggestive smile: "Just a little ahead." In the pause which followed an American mind swept through the records of our navy and our ships and yachts.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 9. -- The official organ of the Holy Synod to-day published the formal excommunication of Count Tolstoi, which was announced early in the year, as follows:

Cattle. -- From the hilltop on which we stand the cattle look like a number of black dots on the veld, and might be mistaken for a party of horsemen if you are in a hurry. Therefore be careful to make quite certain before reporting. Watch them closely with your glasses for ten minutes, or half an hour if necessary, and by their movements you will know them.

At times during the past week the money market has seemed to present threatening aspects; but depressing effects have not resulted, and some disturbing factors have disappeared. In truth, at the close of the week there appears to be general agreement in banking circles that stringency is out of the range of probability, that continuing money-market ease can be depended Upon.

Some facts and figures, compiled from the most trustworthy data at present available, relative to the elements composing the United States Steel Corporation will be of interest as showing its magnitude as a material enterprise, its productive capacity its present earnings, and the assets represented by its unprecedented capitalization.

A fog impenetrable in its density enveloped the harbor yesterday. Not in months has the water front of the metropolis presented such a hazy appearance. From the Battery not a sign of the opposite shores was visible during practically the entire day. Governors, Staten, and Liberty Islands and the Jersey shore were completely veiled from view by the enshrouding vapor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a bill now pending in the Judiciary Committee of the Assembly which should be protested against by every woman in the State. It has been the proud boast of jurists and of lawyers that the statutes in New York were in all respects fair and just to women; it has even been claimed that women had better rights here than anywhere else in the world.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 9. -- The annual address of Bishop Mallalieu occupied the greater portion of to-day's session of the sixty-fifth annual New Jersey Conference of the Methodist Church. The Bishop deprecated combinations of capital, denounced sensational newspapers, and condemned certain classes of books.
SHREVEPORT, La., March 9. -- A terrible wind, rain, and hail storm swept this section to-night, much property being destroyed, but no lives are reported lost.

The identity of a young woman who committed suicide in Lubben's Hotel, Jersey City, yesterday, by inhaling illuminating gas, had not been disclosed up to a late hour last night, although the dead woman was recognized during the afternoon by a relative or personal friend who had received a letter telling of the woman's intention to take her life.
None of this week's changes of bill at any of the theatres brings out a new play.

There is one woman in town who if she lives to see Josef Hofmann with gray hair will always think of him as a very jolly boy. That was her impression of him the first time she saw him, and she will never forget it. It was in the years of the young pianist's first appearance, and he was only a boy.

PARIS, March 9. -- F.O. Matthiessen, the former Treasurer of the American Sugar Refining Company and a Director of that concern, as well as of several other important companies, died at his residence here, 6 Place des Etats Unis, yesterday of diabetes. His remains will be taken home for interment.
Does a conference deferred make the heart of a boss sick?

A petition was filed in the Bankruptcy Court in Brooklyn yesterday to have the affairs of John K. Searles wound up in bankruptcy. The petition was filed by William W. Cook of 44 Wall Street, as the attorney for the petitioners, the Western Reserve National Bank of Warren, Ohio; the Duluth Furnace Company of Duluth, Minn., and Thomas E. Thomas of Niles, Ohio, whose claims against Mr. Searles are something over $90,000.

LAKEWOOD, March 9. -- A number of Americans have now arrived at that enviable stage of success which encourages the aesthetic expenditure of wealth quite as much as the accumulative spirit of money-getting. Some tangible expression of this development of picturesque instincts may be noted by the observer In and about Lakewood.

We are beginning to appreciate our historical relics just as they have almost disappeared. When IRVING wrote his "Knickerbocker," there was a very considerable number in New York of historical relics worth preserving. But at that time nobody took any interest in their preservation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I notice the report of some remarks by Controller Coler, in which he is reported as saying that Blackwell's Island should not be used as a park, but should be used for hospitals.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Money for call and time loans brought 4@4 1/2 per cent, to-day. New York exchange was quoted at 30c discount before and 20c after call. Interest in the local exchange continues to centre in the elevated stocks. Metropolitan Elevated preferred had a small advance, while Lake Street Elevated was fairly active.

One of the most popular as well as one of the most profitable studies to undertake during Lent is the making of hats. There are any number of pretty girls, and others not so pretty, who feel that they need the aid of a becoming hat to increase their charms, and there are doctors' wives, and lawyers' and ministers' wives, also, who are learning to make their own hats.

LONDON, March 9. -- The reply of the British Government to the note conveying the amendments of the United States Senate to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty should be formally delivered by the British Ambassador at Washington to Secretary Hay within a few days. The Foreign Office here did not originally contemplate delaying the British reply until now.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Army officers in the Pullman Building declare the abolishment of the canteen at military posts is responsible for disorderly acts of soldiers from Fort Sheridan in the saloons of Highwood. Since the canteen at the army post was dispensed with a dozen saloons have been opened at Highwood and attractions provided by the proprietors to induce soldiers to visit their places.
The Leipsic Philharmonic Orchestra's last New York concert will taKe place at Carnegie Hall to-night under the direction of its conductor, Hans Winderstein. The programme follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article in Friday last's issue upon the mercenary cliques of American artists in Paris conspiring to overreach and suppress those in this country, and incidentally to degrade their countrymen, is timely, as Galling attention to an important public interest which should represent in the general line of progress an element of our advanced civilization.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The report of the United States Geological Survey on the production of precious stones, as prepared by George F. Kunz, special agent in charge of that investigation, for the division of mining and mineral resources, shows that the total value of the output of precious stones in the United States for 1900 is $232,210, as compared with $185,770 in 1899, a gain of $46,440, or 25 per cent.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 9. -- A formal application was made in the Probate Court, in this city, this afternoon for letters of administration to be granted to Edward L. Norton and Edward S. Percival of New York City on the estate of George Francis Gilman, the millionaire, of Black Rock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Apropos of the theory of "reincarnation" to which I invited the attention of "An Old Man in Doubt," on the 26th ult., I am glad to see that in your issue of the 4th "X" gives so clearly the reasons why "reincarnated" solves so many of the problems of life.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The authorities of the Treasury Department are satisfied that the bubonic plague exists in California and that the situation is critical. There have been six deaths there recently from the disease, and the local health authorities there do not deny that they were genuine cases.

Judge Lacombe of the United States Circuit Court is considering the granting of an injunction restraining the officers of the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association from placing liens on policies matured or unmatured issued prior to Jan. 1, 1901. The application was made by Lawyer J.M. Keatinge in the interest of William Miller, the holder of a ten-thousand-dollar policy issued in 1893.

Six fencing cluts, three representing universities -- Cornell, Yale, and Columbia -- contended for over tour hours last night in the Fencers' Club, 37 West Twenty-second Street for the President's medals, given by Newbold Morris. Each club sent three fencers, and the student element was opposed by competitors from the Fencers' Club, the New York Athletic Club, and the New York Turn Verein.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I ask you to explain the cause of the sphinxlike silence which seems to shroud the popular protest against the conditions of our streets? Have the people become reconciled to this deplorable state of affairs? Are they willing to go back to filth and disease? It must be so.

William J. Bryan came to New York yesterday. No politicians received him at the Grand Central Station when he arrived. He went to the Hoffman House, and during the day not a politician except Dr. Girdner, a close personal friend, visited him.

At the recent meeting of the Newspaper Publishers' Association held in this city Melville E. Stone, General Manager of The Associated Press, delivered an address, entitled "The Commercial Side of the Newspaper," in which exceptional interest was taken. Mr. Stone took the position that the making of a newspaper is nothing more than a business, a trade, and said:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I beg that you will continue to arouse the people of our State to the importance of supporting Senator Slater's bill for the absolute repeal of the personal tax of 2 1/2 per cent. as regards mortgages.

A feature of the past week on the local bowling alleys was the opening of the Metropolis three-men team tournament, which began on Thursday at Cadieu Cashau's Monarch Palace alleys. Twenty-sixth Street and Sixth Avenue. Twenty-one teams are entered, and keen competition is expected. On the opening night Meyer of the Putnam team rolled 266, the highest score made on the Monarch Palace alleys during the present season.

"Yes," said Mrs. Emeline Jones, the New York cook, who knows more about cooking terrapin, Maryland style, with the brown sauce, than most people do about creamed oysters, "it is usually the ladies who ask for the terrapin without bones. They don't like to take them out when they are eating. The gentlemen don't mind them. If you see the bones in the terrapin you know just what it is.

As unexpected as it was unprecedented, the crowd that attended the Sportsmen's Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday overrode the efforts of the officials to provide for visitors and made such a crush in all parts of the great hall that movement in any direction was next to impossible.

The officials of the Water Supply Department claim that New York City -- all five boroughs -- is facing a water famine. The engineers say that they are helpless. The millions of dollars which are now available to spend for increasing the water supply will not relieve the situation. Sixty hours of a continuous hard rainfall is what the officials claim is needed to place the city beyond the dangers of a widespread water famine.

CLEVELAND, March 9. -- At the conclusion of a conference here to-day between H.L. Taylor, attorney for the Players' Protective Association, and Charles Zimmer, President of that organization, the following jointly signed statement concerning the pending baseball controversy was given out:

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Of the thousands who filled the Pension Bureau building last Monday night and admired the beautiful decorations for the inaugural ball, there was probably not one who gave more than a passing thought to the eight great columns which stand four at each end of the building.

The conclusion of the first presentation of "Der King des Nibelungen" came around on Wednesday night, four days having intervened since the previous work in the series had been heard. This fact in itself is a sample of the disadvantageous circumstances in which these dramas are heard by this public.

Gov. Odell did not come to the Fifth Avenue Hotel yesterday to see Senator Platt. It was said that the Governor was busy in Newburg on "personal matters." The rumor that notices had been sent to all the State leaders to come to New York yesterday found many believers among the politicians.

Most visitors to the Nimrud Gallery of Assyrian antiquities in the British Museum have at some time stopped to gaze with wondering curiosity at a monstrous figure that there confronts them. It is that of a strange composite creature of a powerful human form, with the crested head of an eagle and two pairs of pinions, one set raised aloft, the other deflected.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- The nominations for Mayor have been made and the city campaign has begun. It is to be a short one, and the people are correspondingly grateful. The Republican nomination was given to Judge Hanecy by ex-Congressman Lorimer, who has really come to be the leader of the Republican machine both in the city and State.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In your editorials favoring free trade, you frequently use the argument that it will reduce the cost of production of our manufactures. I beg you will give details of how this may be done. Take the cotton and steel manufactures for example. Your kind attention will much oblige

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Secretary of War and Mrs. Root, who since coming to Washington have occupied the large residence 1,626 Rhode Island Avenue, to-day concluded the lease of a new home, and on June 15 will take possession of the commodious residence of Gen. and Mrs. A.E Bates, 1,775 N Street.

Col. Asa Bird Gardiner has returned to this city from Savannah, Ga., having forever settled the doubt which existed as to the spot in which the remains of Gen. Nathanaal Greene and those of his son. George Washington Greene, were buried. He brought with him the plate which was on Gen. Greene's coffin, and also several of the metal buttons which were on the uniform of that distinguished American.

The third week in Lent has passed, and already Mi-Careme is here. It has not been a quiet Lent, if one judges it by the usual standards. Although there have been no large entertainments, the dinners, the musicales, the various seeing classes, and the clubs have all united in making it very gay.
The recent decision of the Court of Appeals as to the power of a city officer to remove a subordinate from a position obtained through competition is radical and sweeping.

LONDON, March 9. -- Money was in fair demand to-day and easier. Advances were readily obtainable. At the closing it was reported they were offered at 2 per cent. Discounts were weak. There will be considerable movement next week. A large amount is due Monday for the repayment to the Bank, and arrangements for the settlement, Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Inauguration day having come and gone, the Court of Honor and the big stands for spectators having undergone wrecking, the noisy and slouchy militia having returned whence they came, the capital has begun its long short-session Summer, a season not set down in the calendar, but which lasts from the day one session of Congress stops until the next begins.

Saturday is always a tolerably busy day in the world of music. The Metropolitan Opera House contributes its two regular weekly performances and there are concerts to amuse the more serious minded. The opera matinees have established themselves in the favor of the suburbanite, to whom they afford opportunities to hear the famous singers of Mr. Grau's aggregation at a convenient hour.

H.A. Gouge, for many years official measurer for the Atlantic Yacht Club, has made a novel suggestion for the adoption of a new rule for the measurement of racing yachts, in the computation of allowances. His plan of measurement and the reasons he advances for recommending the rule are incorporated in the following communication to THE TIMES:

The one hundred and twenty-third anniversary of the birth of Robert Emmet, the Irish patriot martyr, was celebrated under the auspices of the Clan-Na-Gael last night by a concert and mass meeting in the Academy of Music. City Magistrate Henry A. Brann was the Chairman of the meeting, and the oration was delivered by Mayor John Daly of Limerick, Ireland, who appeared on the platform with the solden chain of office around his neck.

ORANGE, N.J., March 10. -- The fifteenth anniversary of the pastorate of the Rev. Dr. James Meeker Ludlow at the Munn Avenue Presbyterian Church. East Orange, will be celebrated on Friday night. The occasion also marks Dr. Ludlow's sixtieth birthday. Among former parishoners of the clergyman who have written letters that will be read at the service is Vice President Theodore Roosevelt.

ORANGE, N.J., March 10. -- Big crowds to-day visited the scene of last night's attempts to burn down the new building being erected for use as a pest house. They were kept at a distance, and had to be content to look at the little frame building from the streets, a considerable distance away.

The presence of mind of Miss Anna F. O'Conner, a teacher in the grammar grade of Public School 158, at Seventy-seventh Street and Avenue A, proved very valuable during a service for the Sodality of the Children of Mary, which was held in the Church of St. Jean the Baptist, in East Seventy-sixth Street yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, March 11. -- "The Japanese battleship Hatsuse, just completed in England, has been ordered to proceed hither with all possible speed," says the Yokohama correspondent of The Dally Mail. "Other orders given to the Japanese Navy indicate the seriousness with which the Japanese Government views the situation in the Far East.

The 592 cabin passengers who arrived in New York yesterday on transatiantic liners, and about four times as many of their friends and the usual sightseers, can bear testimony to the efficiency of the new customs rules, which were enforced for the first time yesterday. The new officials and those who have been retained were all extremely careful in taking declarations and ransacking ocean voyagers' trunks.

A map showing the location of over 300 gambling places in New York, which was prepared by the Tammany Committee of Five, is in Commissioner Murphy's safe at Police Headquarters. The diagram, according to Commissioner Murphy, is being carefully guarded. He said yesterday that no person outside of the Tammany Committee of Five has ever seen the document.
The National headquarters of the League of American Wheelmen have been moved, and are now located at 221 Columbus Avenue, Boston.

At the regular meeting of the White Rats of America, which took place at the Gramercy Lyceum yesterday afternoon, ninety-eight more vaudeville actors entered the order. Ezra Kendall, Will Cressy, and Joe La Fluer were the best known of the eighty-one men, and Rosa Gore of Crimmins and Gore, Adele Archer, Gladys Van, and Marion Ferguson of the women.

With the coming of Spring the local bowling tournaments enter upon their final stage. The Brooklyn Bank Clerks' series was concluded last Thursday, and this week the Harlem Navy and Commercial Leagues will come to an end, the former to-morrow evening, and the latter on Wednesday.

-- Hard as it is to write or speak calmly about the mantrap maintained by the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company at the City Hall terminus of its Third Avenue line, it is even more difficult to keep within parliamentary bounds when discussing the declaration of its officials that they realize and lament the horrors of the condition existing there, but are without the power to remedy it.

HACKENSACK, N.J., March 10. -- An expressman drove out to Fairview yesterday afternoon, and from the house of Mrs. John Keel took two trunks. He wanted to be prepaid for the work, but Mrs. Keel insisted the toll should be charged to the persons to whom they were directed. One of the trunks belonged to Harry Berger twenty-one years old, and the other to Mrs. Keel's daughter Lulu.
The March number of the Deutsche Kevue contains an article by Sir Robert Hart on China in general and the Boxers in particular. In an introductory letter to the editor, Sir Robert Hart says:

CHICAGO, March 10. -- One of the worst windstorms of the season struck Chicago early to-day, and during the two hours that it was at its height damaged property throughout the city to the extent of $175,000. Many heavy plate glass windows were blown in. Telegraph and telephone companies were the worst sufferers, and it will be some time before order can be restored.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 10. -- The delegates from this section to the United Mine Workers' convention, at Hazleton, will leave for that city to-morrow morning. The convention will be much larger than the one held in the same town last Fall. Some of the locals send as high as ten delegates.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., March 10. -- Major James Clark Abrams, who for the past forty years has been a prominent figure in National Guard circles and who has served during the whole of that period in the Seventh Regiment of New York City, died to-day at the home of his daughter, Mrs. George W. Gibson, at 814 Union Street, this city.

"No call for women as stenographers?" exclaimed in answer to a question an uptown woman who has had some years of practical experience as a stenographer, and who teaches in a philanthropic establishment as well as in a small school of her own bringing her into contact with many classes of students and employers.

It is one of the best ways of carrying medicine bottles, or bottles containing toilet articles, that has ever been invented. The sole leather cases are round, and each will contain four three-cornered bottles separated by partitions of leather. These take up a minimum of room, and can be carried with the least amount of risk.
COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., March 10. -- This village had a tramp scare and a fire last night. The fire it is believed was started by the tramps sleeping in a barn.

NATURE OF EX-KING MILAN'S DEATH QUESTIONED. -- The rumors which have been going the rounds of the European press to the effect that ex-King Milan did not die from pneumonia, but by his own hand, are said to have no other foundation than some correspondence between Milan and Queen Nathalie which was recently published in Le Temps of Paris.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, March 10. -- Fire this morning destroyed the College of Medicine and Literary Buildings, at the University of Iowa. The loss is not less than $250,000. Both buildings were burned in two hours' time.

BOSTON, March 10. -- "The general conditions are very much better in Boston," said Health Commissioner Edwin L. Pillsbury to-day, after his trip to New York to investigate the system used in sanitary work there. "The visit was very interesting. In Boston I think we have a great problem, but, with all respect for New York, I'm not ashamed of Boston."

LONDON, March 10. -- Another marking -- time week has gone by, and it is getting very wearisome, as those well understand who may have tried that exercise in military drill. Our money market is completely overshadowed by the dread of a large Government loan. We know it must come soon, and also that it must take the form of a long-term issue or of permanent stock.

A telegraph wire, which broke at Grand and Berry Streets, Williamsburg, last night, shortly before midnight, fell over a trolley wire at that point and trailed along the sidewalk, and the electricity with which it became charged killed one man and badly injured another.

The Rev. Dr. William R. Huntington of Grace Church preached the annual sermon to. the New England Society of the City of New York yesterday afternoon. He took as his text the forty-third verse of the Eighteenth Psalm: "A people whom I have not known shall serve me." The Latin translation of this, he recalled, was placed on the corporate seal of New England in 1630 by the Council of that Territory.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 10. -- The illness of Gen. Harrison, although not critical at this time, is so serious that his physician, Dr. Henry Jamteson, to-day spent most of his time at his bedside and called into consultation Dr. Bvan Hadley. Dr. Frank Dorsey also has been for several days in constant attendance on the exPresident.

Judge GAYNOR'S characterization of the crowding of the cars of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system as "indecent and immoral" is good as far as it goes. However, if moved to venture an obiter dictum, he might have gone still further without transcending the ultimate limits of truth.

It is whispered in Paris that a social revolution is impending at the Grand Opera. As at the Theatre Francais, and as used to be the case at the old Theatre Italien, there is one night of the week at the opera which is particularly fashionable. The "chic" evening at the Italien was Saturday, that at the Comedie is Tuesday, and that at the Opera used to be Friday, and is now Wednesday.

Following are the returns or foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The 125 or more tenants in the Windermere Apartments at Ninth Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street were router from their beds at one o'clock this morning by a fire which started in Mr. Rabinowitz's delicatessen store on the ground floor. The smoke filled the halls and caused a panic. The fire escapes were filled and there was great excitement.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Passengers for the Bronx on the elevated roads have been treated recently to a series of delays that are as annoying as unnecessary. It is no longer possible to estimate one's traveling time in advance. I find that I am from twenty to thirty minutes behind former schedule time when I take a train between 6 and 7 P.M. for home.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Senator McComas of Maryland to-night gave out an interview concerning the Election bill which is now before the extra session of the Legislature of his State, in which he says:

Just how strong the American contingent in English racing will prove in the coming season remains for later events to decide, but one fact stands out conspicuously in the entry lists for the important English stake fixtures, that never before was America so strongly represented on the English turf.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 10. -- As a result of the proceedings yesterday, when an unsuccessful attempt was made to have a temporary administrator appointed for the estate of George Francis Gilman, the millionaire tea and coffee merchant, the mansion at Black Rock is in the joint possession of Edward S. Percival of New York, one of the heirs at law, and Mrs. Blakeley Hall.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, March 10. -- Eight Deputy Sheriffs are at Worthington, Ohio, with orders to land John Wilcox, a wealthy farmer of that Vicinity, in the county jail, dead or alive. Wilcox inaugurated a reign of terror ait Worthington, seriously injuring two men and less seriously hurting half a dozen more.

Dr. Arthur Chittenden, an ambulance surgeon of the New York Hospital, distinguished himself last night by capturing a burglar single-handed in the home of Mrs, Gertrude A. Gonnan, at 226 Madison Avenue. While waiting for assistance from the West Thirtieth Street Police Station the doctor sat on His captive, whom he had felled to the floor with a few deft "punches" on the head.

HAVANA, March 10. -- Although the political demonstrations have ended, the radical element in the Cuban Constitutional Convention has not given up hope that the United States will recede from, the position taken regarding the Platt amendment.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10. -- Thomas Applegate, a farmer, living near Ellisville, seven miles south of this city, was found dead in his barn this morning with his skull crushed in and his body badly cut and bruised. His wife says she thinks he was drunk, and was killed by a vicious horse.

PARIS, Feb. 19. -- Bright and in comparison with recent experiences, mild weather has made a huge success of the concluding day of the carnival. The sleet and slush of Sunday routed the confetti throwers, but they have had their, revenge this afternoon, and an enormous crowd has given itself over heart and soul to the pleasure, so absorbing to some minds, so inexplicable to others, of pelting and being pelted.
BOSTON, March 10. -- "We shall have an Emperor in Washington within twenty-five years unless we can create a public sentiment which, regardless of legislation, will regulate the trusts."

BERLIN, March 10. -- The activity of the Boerse last week was confined again to a few specialties. Apart from these, the Boerse was inactive. Quotations for imperial and Prussian loans showed slight changes. Nevertheless, all 4 per cent. loans were firm upon a good demand from the public.

A spirited horse, owned by Dr. E.F. Foerster of 268 Hooper Street, "Williamsburg, while being driven by the physician's wife, and attached to a pneumatic-tired road cart, yesterday afternoon became frightened at an elevated train, at Broadway and Hooper Street, and ran away. Seated beside Mrs. Foerster at the time was a pet fox terrier dog.

From The London Chronicle. Yesterday -- Washington's Birthday -- was a legal holiday in every State in the United States, with the single exception of Mississippi, whose Legislature has never given the force of law to the general custom. American holidays are a source of perplexity and vexation to our international traders, as they differ so greatly in different States.

ALBANY, March 10. -- The fourth of Gov. Odell's tax bills, the one taxing general corporations, is to be very generally amended, and it is highly probable that if the Brackett bills recasting the general corporation laws pass the tax bill will simply provide for an annual tax on the capital employed and a reduction of the organization tax from one-eighth to onetwentieth of one per cent.

One can imagine that the rumor that the leaders of the Boers are willing to treat for peace on the basis of some admission of British supremacy in South Africa arouses quite as much enthusiasm in London as in any village of the Transvaal. There can be no Englishman who does not feel both the truth and the bitterness of Lord SALISBURY'S remark that "Great Britain's teeth are all in South Africa."

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., March 10. -- Society turned out in force Saturday afternoon to witness an exhibition match at court tennis between Alfred Kirton, marker of the Tuxedo Tennis and Racquet Club, and John Hammond, marker of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. The match was a good one from the start, although Kirton' won in three straight sets by the score of 6 -- 1, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 3.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 10. -- A heavy wind and thunder storm passed over Arkansas yesterday. There is only one death reported in this state, that of John Turner, aged twelve, at Pine Prairie. The tornado wrecked everything in its path at Pine Prairie, which is in the extreme southwestern part of the State.

The Republican organization politicians have suddenly become interested in the report of the Charter Revision Commission, which was made public on Dec. 1 last. As the time for the closing of the session of the Legislature approaches, the New York City politicians find that there are many laws which should be enacted, for the good of the party.

BALTIMORE, March 11. -- The Crescent Democratic Club, one of the leading political organizations of this city, celebrated its twenty-ninth anniversary to-night by listening to addresses on democracy, delivered by leading local speakers. The occasion was rendered more interesting by the receipt of letters from ex-President Grover Cleveland and ex-United States Senator David B. Hill. Mr. Cleveland says:

The lecture on the theatre which Heinrich Conried delivered yesterday afternoon in the Carnegie Lyceum to the students of Mr. Sargent's school of acting was uncommonly interesting. Conried has authority of presence, of course, and can hold the attention of an audience as few lecturers can, while his revelations of fact and opinion were all clear and sensible, if not always of vital importance to the cause of dramatic art in this time and place.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Vice President Roosevelt had a half hour's talk with the President to-day, but nothing was disclosed as to the nature of his visit. The Vice President will leave Washington for his home at Oyster Bay some time this week. His plans, while not completely matured, contemplate a quiet Summer at Oyster Bay. The Vice President will not accompany the President on his trip to the Pacific Coast.

-- One of the British maritime journals expresses a natural wonder that the United States should spend many thousands of dollars every year on the maintenance of a most excellent Life Saving Service along the coast, and yet use hardly a cent in perfecting charts and sailing directions for the general benefit of navigation interests.

The handicap match of the Seventh Regiment Rifle Club on the armory ranges Saturday evening resulted in a tie for the first three places and a double tie for the next two, but the ties, being deceided according to the rules, gave Private A. Stevens of Company C first prize, with a score of 68, handicap 4, and net score of 64.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" bas been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes the payment of the mortgage.

TRENTON, N.J., March 11. -- Although the authorities have not yet completed their investigation into the death of Thomas Applegate, the farmer who was found ad in his barn, near Ellisville, yesterday, and whose wife advanced the theory that he was killed by a vicious horse, they are more than ever convinced that murder was committed

CHICAOO, March 11. -- By the explosion of the boiler In the Doremus Laundry, 458 West Madison Street, this morning, eight people were instantly killed, forty-two were injured, and several are missing.
TRENTON, N.J., March 11.-- Gov. Voorhees sent to the Senate to-night the name of David Baird of Camden as a member of the State Board of Assessors, to succeed Gen. Bird W. Spencer of Passaic.

CHICAGO, March 11 -- The Davenport, Rock Island and Northwestern Railway, owned by John W. Gates and some of his business associates, has been sold to the Burlington system for a price said to be about S4,000,000. The road is a small one, extending from Moline, Ill., by way of Rock Island and a large bridge across the Mississippi River, to Davenport and Clinton, Iowa.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 11. -- A meeting of horsemen training at Montgomery Park was held to-day to take action in regard to the ban placed by the Western Jockey Cub upon the tracks not licensed by that body About thirty horse owners were present. T.P. Hayes, Vice President of the Horsemen's Protective Association, presided.

BOSTON, March 11 -- Money on calb rules from 2 1/2 to 4 per cent., mostly 3 per cent. Time money is quoted from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent. for four to six months on high-grade collateral and 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent. when collateral consists largely of coppers. Mercantile paper is quiet, with sales at 3 1/2 to 4 per cent. for best names.

Mrs. Blakely Hall came to this city from Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday to consult with her attorneys about her contest for the millions of George Francis Gilman, the tea merchant. Frazier Gilman, the oldest half-brother of the dead-millionaire, arrived from Hudson, S.D., to see that his own rights were protected, and instituted suit in the Supreme Court for the partition of the estate.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The long expected answer from the British Government to the State Department's communication reciting the action of the Senate upon the Hay-Pauncefote treaty was received at noon to-day. Lord Pauncefote the British Ambassador, already had acquainted Secretary Hay with the fact that he had received a communication from his Government on the subject, and it is believed it has been in his possession for several days.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The rejection of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty by the British Government, without terms and without any counter proposition leaves a clear-cut issue between the two Governments. If there is to be any treaty about the Nicaragua Canal, negotiations must be begun absolutely from the beginning. When the new negotiations are begun Great Britain will be able to submit her counter proposition, if she has any.

ALBANY, March 11. -- The Brackett Corporation bills, amended and made Republican caucus measures, were on the files of the Senate to-night. Some of the features of the Fish bills on the Assembly side have been incorporated in them and several things have been eliminated.

Many of the gamblers who a month ago infested New York have gone to Chicago, Philadelphia, and Boston, according to the statement made last evening to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter by Lewis F. Nixon, who was Chairman of the Tammany Committee of Five.

LONDON, March 12. -- The morning papers express approval of Lord Lansdowne's reply to the amendment of the United States Senate to the Hay-Pauncefote Treaty. All repudiate any feeling save a friendly desire to arrive at an amicable and equitable settlement.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Four votes too few in the Assembly defeated the concurrent resolution of M.E. Lewis, proposing an amendment to the Constitution to prohibit the Legislature from granting to any person, association, firm, or corporation an exemption from taxation on real or personal property. This is an indication that any canal legislation proposed this year will be defeated.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- James Henry Smith of New York arrived here to-day. Mr. Smith joined the Stuyvesant Fish party when it reached Chicago this afternoon, as did Mr. and Mrs. A. Lanfear Norrie. After a short stop, the private car Marion, in which the party is traveling, will proceed westward over the Illinois Central.

The formal transfer of the ownership of the famous race horse Kinley Mack, top weight for all the great Spring handicaps, from the well-known racing firm Eastin Larabie, to the ownership of J.B. Haggin, the millionaire turfman and breeder of Kentucky and California, was filed yesterday with the Secretary of the Jockey Club and with the Secretaries of the several New York racing associations in whose stake fixtures Kinley Mack is engaged.

CENTRAL VILLAGE, Conn., March 11. -- In an address before the Lyeeum Society to-night, Dr. J.L. Gardner discussed the needs of the village and what would benefit it. Although his remarks were peculiarly applicable to this village, many of his recommendations could without loss or injury be acted upon by other villages throughout the country.

The way in which the water supply of this great city is managed is a shame and a disgrace. This is strong language, but not stronger than the facts warrant. Neither intelligence, capacity, nor honesty is displayed in the conduct of the department charged with this grave responsibility.

Without doubt, from the time when the Chinese crisis became acute, about eight months ago, we, meaning the United States of America, have proved our faith by our works, and have done nothing incompatible with our initial professions. Our course has not by any means commended us to all the organs of European opinion.

The officials of the Department of Water Supply said on Saturday that all five boroughs of the city were facing a water famine. Yesterday Chief Engineer Birdsall said that 3,500,000,000 gallons of water -- or enough to supply the Borough of Manhattan for fourteen days -- had run to waste over the Croton Dam.
BERLIN, March 11. -- In the Reichstag today, in a debate on the budget for German East Africa, Herr Bebel, the Socialist leader, made a very severe attack upon the administration of the colonies.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 11. -- Dr. Henry Jameson has been in constant attendance on ex-President Harrison, and, with Dr. Evan Hadley, has alternated in a close watch for the slightest sign of improvement or relapse.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 11. -- Five favorites won at Tanforan to-day, while a well-played second choice took the other event. Tommy Burns was in good form, riding four winners. Results: Six and one-half furlongs -- Pupil, 110, (O'Connor,) 1: Formero, 116, 2: Gonfalon, 110, 3. Time -- 1:22 3/4 Mile, purse -- Kenilworth. 115. (Burns,) 1: Brutal, 116, 2: Ada N., 10O, 3.

LONDON, March 12. -- The Japanese Legation in London has received a bundle of dispatches from Tokio relative to Russia's movements in Manchuria, but the Japanese Minister here is unwilling to admit that Japan is alarmed over the recent changes in the situation.

OMAHA, Neb., March 11. -- James Callahan talked freely to-day for the first time of the Cudahy kidnapping. He admitted that he knew Pat Crowe well, but says he does not know the Cudahys. Callahan denied being with Pat Crowe when he bought the horse which figured in the kidnapping.
