PITTSBURG, March 11. -- A coal contract worth upward of $2,000,000, to be fulfilled in case of wage trouble in the anthracite fields next month, was closed here to-day at the Duquesne Hotel. The coal is to go to supply Eastern markets of the anthracite colliers from the mines of the new combination of the operators of the Kanawha and New River districts of West Virginia.

AN AWARD THAT WAS DISASTROUS. -- John Schreyer has had an unfortunate experience through being overpersuaded to employ counsel to seek compensation for the loss he sustained from the taking of lands to which he had title for the extension of Lexington Avenue above Seventy-seventh Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 11. -- Ten of the eleven boat clubs which comprise the Schuylkill Navy voted in meeting to-night to send a committee consisting of Gordon S. Carrigan, Robert J. Milligan, Charles M. Margerum, F.C. Schoettle, and Rufus Sadler to New York on Saturday and petition the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen to award to Philadelphia its annual championship regatta this year.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11. -- Golfers are gathering from every direction for the tournament this week. Among the amateurs who have just arrived are W.B. Cheney of South Manchester, Conn., and Edward P. Martin of Chicago. A four-ball match was the feature to-day. C.B. Cory and Bernard Nichols played W.H. Davis and George Low.

The Fire Department is one, we might perhaps say the one, in which, in spite of Tammany, we have all managed to take a reasonable civic pride. But the pride we have managed to take in it would not long survive such a showing as is made by the bill that has been sent to Albany, with at least the implied approval of the majority of men on the working force of the department.

Stimulated by the favorable reports from the coal regions indicating that a strike of the miners will be averted, and by the assurances of representative bankers that ease in money is to continue, the stock market yesterday opened strong and generally maintained its strength.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 11. -- To-day, three days before the Legislature comes to a close, the House, by a vote of 25 to 17, and after an exciting debate, passed the Evans Senate bill amending that portion of the Revised Statutes of Utah relating to prosecutions for adultery. Having passed the Senate last week by a vote of 11 to 7, the document now goes to the Governor for signature.

Hans S. Beattie, who for more than twenty years has been a close political and business associate of William C. Whitney, has resigned as Treasurer of the Metropolitan Street Railroad Company, and at the same time he has brought suit against the company for $100,000 for breach of contract. The papers in the case are now in the hands of a Deputy Sheriff, who will serve them to-day on the officials of the company.

The rose is the queen of flowers in the milliner's as well as in the florist's shops this year. There are big roses and little roses and roses of intermediate sizes. The small roses are massed closely together, and form wreaths on the edges of hats, or they are in tight bunches, showing only a glimpse of color.

WICHITA, Kan., March 11. -- No verdict was reached by the jury which last week heard evidence in the trial of Mrs. Carrie Nation for smashing a "joint" here several weeks ago. The jury stood 7 to 5 for conviction, and was discharged to-day.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 11. -- The fight between Mrs. Helen Blakely Hall on one side, and the blood relations of George Francis Gilman on the other, for the possession of the millions of the dead tea merchant, is now on in earnest. There is an armed neutrality at the Black Rock mansion between the contending forces.

OGDENSBURG, N.Y., March 11. -- Several hollow spruce spars are being made at Spalding's St. Lawrence Boat Works here for Herreshoff of Bristol, R.I., for the yacht now being built by them to compete in the trial races for selecting America's representative against Sir Thomas Lipton's Shamrock II.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 -- The Philadelphia market was revived from its protracted slumber, and for this change the Readings, Lehigh Valley, and the Choctaws were responsible. Nearly everything was higher, and some smart gains were experienced. The coalers supplied vigor to the market.

Mr. and Mrs. Louis Stix of 35 West Seventy-first Street celebrated the golden anniversary of their wedding, in Cincinnati, Ohio, on March 11, 1851, with a dinner to seventy-five children, grandchildren, and relatives at Delmonico's last night, followed by a reception to more than 200 friends.
Frank M. Whitmark and Marie Madison have recently completed a drama entitled "Authority," which will be given an elaborate production at one of the prominent theatres in this city early next season.

ALBANY, March 11. -- Gov. Odell to-night sent four veto messages to the Legislature. Two went to the Senate and two to the Assembly. The Governor has sent more veto messages to the Legislature than any Governor since the first year of the term of Gov. Morton.

Thirteen athletic events, some of which were run off in from two to five heats, made a lively evening last night in the Fourth Regiment Armory of Jersey City, when the annual games of the Armory Athletic Association were held. The feature of the contests was several open events, and, hardly without exception, they were all hotly contested.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- For some time complaints from Peking about Gen. Chaffee's lack of interest in the punishment of the Chinese have been appearing in the London papers, and have given great gratification to the War Department officials. Gen. Chaffee has consistently refused to take part in punitive expeditions, even when invited to do so by Count von Waldersee, and has neglected to participate in the military executions ordered in Peking.
Major Walter Whitney, Surgeon. United States Volunteers, recently appointed, will report to the commanding officer at Fort Walla Walla, Washington, for duty.

ALBANY, March 11. -- In the Assembly to-night, when the bills taxing insurance companies and savings banks were reached on second reading, Mr. Fitzgerald objected and asked that they so over until to-morrow morning, as they would give rise to protracted debate. Mr. Sullivan of New York suggested that they be made a special order for to-morrow morning.

Leonard F. Rose, a clerk in the Pennsylvania Railroad freight office, Jersey City, is now a resident of Canada. He left between two days as the result of a discovery that he had contracted two marriages in a period of about two months. No action can be taken by the police for the reason that neither wife will make a complaint.

Undoubtedly we need an active, sensitive, and sound public conscience in this country, but we seriously doubt whether we are likely to get such a conscience through fear of an "Emperor in twenty-five years," as intimated by President HADLEY in his Boston address on Sunday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having noticed occasional reference in THE TIMES to the missionary spirit as vindictive for the suffering experienced from the Boxers, I wish to give an incident just received from a missionary correspondent.

MARINETTE, Wis., March 11. -- A fierce blizzard swept over Northern Wisconsin yesterday and last night. Wind, snow, and sleet combined to make it the worst storm in years. Trains on all lines are many hours late and street traffic is practically blocked. Telegraphic comtnunication in nearly all directions is cut off.

LONDON, March 11. -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with repayments to the Bank of Eng:land, and supplies improved. Discounts were easier, sympathetically. Apart from the requirements for settlement repayments to the Bank of England, the demands for the next few days will be slight.

LONDON, March 12. -- In the House of Commons yesterday Charles Mackinnon Douglas (Liberal) introduced a motion calling for an inquiry regarding the retirement of Major Gen. Colvile, who was sent home from South Africa by Lord Roberts for al- leged inefficiency in the field.

Trading was very quiet yesterday in the market for outside securities. The steel stocks were fairly active, but even in these issues the totals were very small compared to those recorded in them some days ago. Elsewhere the list supplied but a small amount of business, only a few issues reaching a total of 1,000 shares or more.

Abram S. Hewitt, Charles A. Schieren, and John Claflin did not meet yesterday at the Chamber of Commerce as a committee to consider plans to abate conditions which prevail at the Brooklyn Bridge and Manhattan Railway terminals during "rush" hours. The weather prevented Mr. Hewitt from leaving his home, and the committee will meet to-day.

The five-story building 115 and 117 Spring Street, 50 by 100, is reported to have been sold. Further particulars regarding the transaction could not be obtained yesterday from the owners, Rothschild Brothers Co. The property is on the north side of Spring Street, 50 feet east of Greene Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Before the Board of Public Improvements the representative of the excellent Society for the Preservation of Scenic and Historical Places was incorrectly reported as stating that "Fort Washington and Fort George have disappeared, the one occupying the site of the new Columbia University and the other being where the new Custom House is in process of erection."

The old banking house of Vermilye Co. of 20 Nassau Street found itself confronted yesterday by a rival Vermilye Co., which had extensively advertised itself in the Sunday newspapers as a "banking house," able to "execute orders on the New York, Boston, and Philadelphia Stock Exchanges, the Chicago Board of Trade, and the New York Cotton Exchange."

The New York Central has decided to build a new station in Troy, and to eliminate over twenty-one grade crossings on its Auburn line at Syracuse, at a total expense of over $350,000. The plans for the new passenger station at Troy have been under consideration for a long time, but, owing to the diversity of opinion among the citizens nothing was done in the matter.

How can a dog be marked in evidence? was a question which puzzled Justice Giegerich and all the lawyers concerned in a trial in Part VIII. of the Supreme Court yesterday. Finally the mark "Exhibit A" was entered in the stenographer's note book. No attempt was made to mark the dog.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 11. -- The following is the reply sent by Rear Admiral Sampson to Secretary Long in regard to the matter of publication of the letter sent by Gunner Morgan to the former:
To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of the renewed interest in stenography, the following observations on this subject may be of value to some of the readers of your excellent paper:

There was very little doing in town socially yesterday. There were a few luncheons, including one given by Mrs. W.D. Sloane, and whist parties, and in the evening there was the regular meeting of the Monday Evening Bowling Club, at which Mrs. Henry L. Burnett and others received; Mrs. Ogden Goelet gave a dinner, and at the opera there was a large audience.

FISHKILL LANDING, March 11. -- Five persons narrowly escaped death last night on the New York Central trestle near Dutchess Junction, about a mile below here. Another of the party, a young woman, was badly hurt, and it is doubtful if she will recover.

NEWBURG, N.Y., March 12 -- The will of Addison Cammack, the Wall Street operator, who died Feb. 5, was probated here to-day. One-half of the property is left to the widow, Mary H. Cammack, the remainder being divided equally between the children, Addison and Hattie.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 12. -- The intermittent decrease in natural gas pressure caused by a failing supply resulted in a meeting of producers in this city to-day, called by M. B. Daly of Toledo. The meeting was chiefly attended by representatives of companies who secure their supply of gas from the Sugar Grove Field, thirty miles south of the city, but many other preminent oil men from Ohio and Pennsylvania are in attendance.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Will you be good enough to advise of Gen. Harrison's condition? The President is very much pained to learn by the latest reports of the serious character of the General's illness.

WASHINGTON, March 12 -- Caesar Celso Moreno, for years a familiar character on the streets and at the Capitol, died at Providence Hospital to-day from a stroke of paralysis. Moreno had a picturesque and adventurous career. He had visited nearly every civilized portion of the globe and claimed several rulers as his friends.

The action of the people of Orange, N. J., on Monday night, in destroying the emergency hospital provided by the Board of Health for the isolation of cases of contagious disease is not without precedent, but it is none the less an act illustrating the readiness with which well-ordered and generally law-abiding communities revert to barbarism when their fears or evil passions are aroused.

The Associated Cycling Clubs of the City of New York completed their organization for the coming season at a meeting held at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club last night. Former City Magistrate Charles E. Simms, Jr., was elected Chairman of the Rights of Wheelmen and Legislation Committee, C. P. Stinson, Chairman of the Social Intercourse Committee; M.L. Bridgeman, Chairman of the Race Committee, and George C. Wheeler, Chairman of the Streets and Roads Committee.

ALBANY, March 12 -- The advocates of canal legislation are basing great hopes upon the message which Gov. Odell will send to the Legislature on the subject. The Governor has been laboring with his message ever since the report of State Engineer Bond was submitted to him, and his conclusions will undoubtedly decide the course of the Legislature upon the question of the further improvement of the canals.

ORANGE, N.J., March 12 -- The ruins of the smallpox hospital, which was demolished with axes yesterday, were set on fire early this morning and entirely consumed. The persons living in the vicinity of the site of the pesthouse seemed to be afraid that a new structure would be reared on the little that was left of the one wrecked yesterday, and decided to wipe out every trace of the objectionable building.

Security market conditions, judged by the tests of yesterday's market, are in satisfactory form. Strength was shown throughout the list, some issues scoring substantial advances. Almost every trade influence is on the helpful side; and especially is this betokened in the record which railway earnings are making -- the current exhibit surpassing anything hitherto known in the business world.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Blakely Hall cannot be found here. No one connected with his newspaper will admit knowing his address. They even disclaim knowing whether he is in Chicago or not. He was at the Palmer House, but the clerk says he is not there now.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., March 12 -- An- other of the suits growing out of the wrecking of the Middlesex County Bank by George M. Valentine is now awaiting decision by Justice Garretson of the Supreme Court. It raises a novel point.

Four Police Captains were transferred yesterday by the orders of Commissioner Murphy. The announcement of the transfers came directly from Deputy Commissioner Devery, who, like Commissioner Murphy, refused absolutely to give any reason for the changes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 12 -- There were eighty starters in the open golf tournament here to-day, including eight professionals and a number of well-known amateurs, who are awaiting the annual Palm Beach tournament, which begins on Thursday. The first prize, of the value of $100, was won by George Low, professional of the Dyker Meadow Golf Club of Brooklyn, who took the amount in cash.

In the tournament of the New York Interclub Bowling League last night, the New York Athletic Club bowlers won three games from the West Side Republican Club team, on the New York Athletic Club alleys, and the Knickerbocker Athletic Club five won three games from the Catholic Club team, on the Catholic Club alleys.

McKEESPORT, Penn., March 12 -- The McKeesport brewing plant, valued at $100,000, was completely demolished this morning by an explosion of the "cooker." Two persons were killed and two injured by the collapse of the building, following the explosion, and one man is missing. Another man, who was standing on a freight car watching the rescuers at work, was knocked from the car and was beheaded by a passing engine.

ALBANY, March 12 -- F.M. Brooks, the President of the Brooklyn Young Republican Club, appeared before the Assembly Committee on Judiciary to-day and made an argument in favor of the Morgan bill, which provides for the making of nominations for public office by enrolled voters on the first two days of registration.

BOSTON, March 12 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 2, 2 1/2, and 3 per cent. The advance was attributed to shifting of loans in connection with payments for the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy new stock issue. New York funds continued heavy, with sales at 12 1/2 @ 15c discount for cash.

-- One of the Philadelphia newspapers is claiming entire credit for bringing to light the contract labor abuses to which the local authorities of Anderson County, S.C., have just put a summary end, and these claims have created no little irritation among the officials and citizens of the county.

The escape of a beaver from the cramped quarters provided for his family in the artificial lake and his gallant but futile efforts to evade recapture were responsible for the most novel form of entertainment furnished at the Sportsmen's Show, in Madison Square Garden, yesterday, and at the same time gave a hint to the management that will result in plenty of excitement for the beavers for the remainder of the week.

Mr. John E. Parsons and Mrs. Florence V.C. Field Bishop, the widow of David Wolfe Bishop, were married yesterday at Grace Church Chantry by the Rev. Dr. William R. Huntingdon. The announcement of the engagement of Mr. Parsons to Mrs. Bishop was made about a fortnight ago in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, March 12 -- Money was abundant to-day and easier.

The endeavor of the Police Department to retain and prevent the destruction of the gambling paraphernalia captured in the recent raids of the Committee of Fifteen on Tenderloin gambling houses was frustrated yesterday by Justice Jerome.

ALBANY, March 12. -- There was a hearing to-day before the Assembly Committee on Cities on the bill introduced by Mr. Delaney to create a Department of Public Printing in the City of New York. Henry Moreland, President of the Allied Trades Council, and John E. McLaughlin, State Organizer of the Typographical Union, appeared before the committee in advocacy of the bill.

All the gayety of the week will centre upon the day which is chosen for MiCareme, and that will be to-morrow. Last evening there were several dinners, among which was the one given by Gen. and Mrs. Louis Fitzgerald for Miss Thompson and Stephen Pell. Mr. and Mrs. Howard Wainwright also gave a dinner, and Mr. and Mrs. M. Orme Wilson gave one of twenty covers in the afternoon.

A funeral service which was no less remarkable than impressive filled the Bedford Street Methodist Episcopal Church, at Bedford and Merton Streets, to its utmost capacity last evening. Two stanch members of that house of worship passed away in the same hour -- the President and the Secretary of the Board of Trustees.

Street railway companies owe the city $224,291.98, according to a report submitted to the Mayor yesterday by the Commissioners of Accounts, John C. Hertle and Edward Owen, on the subject of car license, rees, and taxes on gross receipts due from these corporations for a period of ten years ended Oct 1, 1900.

ALBANY, March 12 -- Two of the tax measures recommended by Gov. Odell, the first the bill to tax insurance companies, was passed by a vote of 101 to 13; the other bill, the one taxing the surplus of savings banks, was passed by a vote of 101 to 24, after long and earnest debate. Both measures had already passed the Senate.
According to Joplin (Mo.) dispatches, all grades of zinc have been advanced 50 cents a ton.
RALPH S. TARBELL, 45 years old, for many years one of the owners of The South Bend (Ind.) Tribune, is dead at Los Angeles, Cal.

At the regular monthly meeting of the Bar Association last night the member took a decided stand against special legislation which allows individuals to become members of the bar of this State without complying with the usual rules and requirements for admission.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Westminster Gazette says it hears there are rumors that imported grain may be made to pay a portion of the budget. It adds that the tax would take the form of the reimposition of the shilling registration charge, abolished by the Right Hon. Robert Lowe, (Chancellor of the Exchequer from 1868 to 1873.)

ANSONIA, Conn., March 12 -- The slender trunk of a young oak tree was all that held Charles Blackman and George Bush for twelve hours last night above a seething, roaring floe of Ice. Noticing large quantities of driftwood coming down the Housatonic River during the early hours of yesterday's freshet, the men rowed to Two Mile Island to gather it in.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Foreign Office officials are nettled at the statement, cabled here, that no opening is left for further action in the case of Great Britain's reply to the United States' note referring to the Senate's amendments to the Hay-Pauncefote treaty. It is pointed out that Great Britain's reply invites further proposals from the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The advice given by your correspondents to the "Old Man in Doubt" can only be classified under two headings: Either the human reason or a revelation can give to him the infallible answer. And an answer is demanded by every doubter, who has not fully surrendered to despair.

LONDON, March 13 -- The British naval estimates for 1901-02 amount to L30,875,500, an increase of over L2,000,000 compared with the previous year, chiefly for shipbuilding. There is an increase of 3.745 in the number of officers and men.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Secretary of the Treasury Gage, who has come to Chicago to attend to some private business, was interviewed by newspaper reporters to-day with reference to his order placing a countervailing duty on Russian sugar. In reply to one of the questions put to him, Mr. Gage said, with emphasis:

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- Despite the fact that the All Brooklyn hockey team was outplayed to-night at the Ice Palace by the Quaker City seven, the visitors won the match by the narrow margin of 4 goals to 3. Quaker City outplayed Brooklyn in all the points of the game, excepting the positions of point and goal keeper.

Holding a stick of caddy in his hand, Louts Sitkin, three years old, of 225 East Twenty-eighth Street, started to run across the street yesterday morning to give his five-year-old brother a bite. He never reached his brother, however, for just as he gained the middle of the street an airmotor car came along and struck him.

A committee representing the Manufacturers' Association and several other Brooklyn organizations appeared at the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday. For months the members of the committee have been studying the water supply of Brooklyn, and they now advocate the passage of bond issues for $1,800,000 to prevent a water famine in that borough.

BOSTON, March 12 -- The keel trough in the fin of the Independence was tested today and found to be absolutely watertight. The big trough was filled completely with water, and not a drop came through the riveted seams. After it had all been pumped out and thoroughly dried the work of stowing the lead began, and several tons both in pigs and in line shot were disposed about the bottom before the day closed.

PARIS, March 12 -- The Committee of the Union of the French Rifle Societies met this afternoon and considered the invitation of the National Rifle Association of America to engage in a competition at Sea Girt this year for the Centennial Trophy, which has reached the union through Ambassador Cambon.

At the offices of "Vermilye Co., bankers and brokers," on the second floor of the Exchange Court Building, at 52 Broadway, a member of the new firm said yesterday that a conference of the partners had been called, and that the firm expects to begin operations in a day or so. From what this partner said, it was inferred that some part of $20,000 capital was still lacking.
Elections were held yesterday in all the townships, villages, and boroughs of New Jersey. In most of the places the contests were confined to local issues.

An accident in which Peter C. Nelson, Captain of the Long Island Railroad tug Cyosset, was drowned, the superstructure of the tug wrecked, and a float on which were seventeen coal-laden freight cars capsized and the cars dumped into the middle of East River occurred at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.
CHICAGO, March 12 -- John Hare, the English actor, to-night said he was about to retire from the stage for an indefinite time, if not permanently.

CHICAGO, March 12 -- Incorporation papers were filed in Springfield to-day by Isidor Latzer. Adolf Reinach, and John J. Adam, all of Chicago, for a secret organization to be known as the "Consumers, Merchants and Manufacturers' Secret Anti-Trust Society." Mr. Latzer, who is at the head of the organization, is a manufacturer, and his colleagues are two of his clerks.
PEKING, March 12 -- A general meeting of the foreign Ministers was held this morning, at which reports of committees were heard.

William Geoghegan, known to two generations as the "Poet Geoshegan," died yesterday morning at his home, 107 West Ninety-fourth Street He was for many, years a familiar figure in the old Thirteenth Ward, and was prominent in Tammany politics. Two years ago he was knocked down by a cable car, and had not been well since.

Although transactions in yesterday's market for outside securities did not assume any unusual proportions, the trading was more distributed than on any recent day and several issues recently much neglected assumed places of some prominence. Business in the issues which have been steadily active to a few cases showed increases, but the total for the day was much below the records of many days in the recent past.
LONDON, March 13 -- The Daily News this morning makes the following important statement:

The second performance of Wagner's "Der King des Nibelungren" at the Metropolitan Opera House began yesterday afternoon. This matinee series will be of benefit to those suburbanites who cannot conveniently attend the night representations, and it will also afford opportunities to hear the works to those women who are so unfortunate as to be without escorts to the serious proceedings of the Wagnerian drama in the evenings.

CONSTANTINOPLE, March 12 -- Ahmed Shefik Bey, the Khedive's secretary, who was sent here to settle the differences between the Sultan of Turkey and the Khedive of Egypt, will return to Egypt today. It is understood that his mission has failed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to an article in your paper this morning headed "Tax on Bronx Churches," I feel that it sets many of us taxpayers to thinking and asking ourselves why we should suffer our taxes to be increased or be taxed so that church property of all creeds and colors may be free from all tax.

The taking of testimony in the action of Thomas J. O'Neill, a lawyer, against Police Magistrate Leroy B. Crane came to a sudden adjournment yesterday on the application of the defendant's counsel to have the case dismissed on the ground that the plaintiff had not shown that the Magistrate had been in partnership with his brother.

LUCENA, Philippine Islands, March 12 -- The United States Army transport Sumner, with the American Philippine Commission and its party on board, arrived off Lucena last evening. This morning the Commissioners' party, consisting of fifty persons, crossed the shallow bar in the ship's boats and were driven to this town.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The splendid efficiency of our present Municipal Government was beautifully illustrated to the curious thousands assembled, by the complete destruction by fire last evening of the fine and comparatively new station of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company at Willis Avenue.

The twentieth annual report of the Missouri Pacific Railway Company for the year ended Dec. 31, 1900, was made public yesterday. The report states that freight and passenger traffic was voluminous beyond previous experience. Passenger rates were well maintained. The strike on the St. Louis street railways increased the revenue from suburban trains.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You are greatly to be commended for the publication of so much intelligent discussion. If our religious (sic) teachers would only encourage such interchanges of views on immortality, for instance, the public mind would be broadened and interest in the churches increased.

ALBANY, March 12 -- "Our constituency will not agree to an absolute exemption of mortgages from taxation, and I do not believe such a bill can pass," said Senator Stranahan to-day. "The nearest approach to absolute exemption," continued Mr. Stranahan, "will be found in my bill, which I believe will pass, and which taxes mortgages one-half of 1 per cent.

Engineer BIRDSALL of the Water Department should use pencil and paper more freely before making statements for publication which are likely to be scrutinized. For example: He is authority for the statement that on Saturday last the water in Croton Lake was so far depleted that it stood 9 feet below the crest of the dam.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 12 -- Gen. Benjamin Harrison can live but a few hours. His condition up to an early hour this morning was encouraging to his physicians, but at that time he became restless, and an hour or so later Dr. Jameson, who had left the ex-President's bedside at midnight for his own home, was hastily summoned by Dr. Dorsey, who has remained constantly in the sick room for several days past.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the issue of Saturday, March 9, there is a statement by the Chief Engineer of the Water Supply Department of this city that the inhabitants of the Borough of the Bronx are getting at present 8,000,000 gallons of water a day, which would be about forty gallons a head, a quantity greater than is received by the inhabitants of towns where the supply is metered.

That "cheap" and "dear" are relative terms is strikingly illustrated by the fact that at a time when the corporation supplying gas to New York is bemoaning the necessity for compliance with the law which fixes a dollar a thousand as the maximum charge to meter consumers, the people of London are holding public meetings to protest against the maintenance of a scale of gas prices which in this country would be considered very satisfactory.

Deprived of the services of Howard, their best forward, and pursued by constant illluck, the hockey team of the New York Athletic Club yielded after forty-three minutes of desperately contested play to the seven of the St. Nicholas Club in the game to decide the league championship at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12 -- A number of new high records were made in the market to-day. Choctaw, on strong buying, rose above the top figures of the boom of 1899, and a revival in the long-languid steel stocks took place.

MONTREAL, Quebec, March 12 -- The 5,000 Doukhobortsis, or Russian Quakers, who were brought out to Canada a few years since in order to escape the persecutions to which they were subjected in the Czar's domains, now threaten to leave Canada because they consider the free laws of this country too oppressive for them.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 12 -- The will of Francis O. Matthiessen, who died in Paris on March 8, but who had a country home at Irvington-on-the-Hudson, was filed to-day in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. No estimate is given as to the value of the estate.
Senator Platt will go to Washington today, where he will have a talk with President McKinley with reference to the appointment of Col. William Cary Sanger of Brooklyn as Assistant Secretary of War.

That is the little rhyme on the inside of the cover of one of the Eastern novelties. It is a Little hatbox, a gay little flowered box which when it opens discloses a real little love of a bonnet in miniature. The little box is probably not more than two inches square, and the little hat or bonnet in proportion, the genuine thing trimmed modishly with flowers, lace, and silk.

Two South American States, Argentina and Uruguay, have set an example of enlightened statesmanship which we should have looked for more naturally in countries claiming an older and more uniformly developed if not a higher civilization. They have agreed upon a treaty of sanitary protection, relating generally to contagious and infectious diseases, and especially to the bubonic plague.

ST. JOSEPH, Mich., March 13. -- There is now but little hope that the First National Bank of Niles will ever open its doors. Joseph W. Selden, National Bank Examiner, has been appointed receiver, and as far as the examination has gone there has been disclosed a rotten state of affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- There are many indications that Col. William Gary Sanger will soon be appointed Assistant Secretary of War, and with confidence on the part of the Administration that, when the Senate has opportunity to act upon his nomination, there will not be sufficient opposition to prevent his confirmation.

With the passing of the danger of a water famine has come a new cause for complaint in the muddy condition of water all over the city. The turbid state of the supply is most marked in "Washington Heights, Harlem and the upper sections, where the residents claim that nothing quite so bad has ever been observed before.

We expressed the belief yesterday morning that there was some hocus-pocus going on at Albany whereby some more or less scurvy politicians there desired and intended to make a pretense of an intense eagerness of abolishing the special and outrageous powers of the Ramapo Water Company, while in reality conserving them.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- A report from Peking that the Russian Minister has taken a stand against the creation of new lists of Chinese officials for punishment, after China has punished all those enumerated in the original list, shows that Russia has gone a step further than the United States, although in the same general direction.

LONDON, March 14. -- All the morning papers publish long memoirs of Gen. Benjamin Harrison and editorials dealing with his career. The Daily Chronicle says: "It may be long before America finds another President as capable, honorable, and conservative."

The conditions producing the depression in the iron and steel industries of Great Britain, so generally attributed to American competition, must be looked for at home as well as abroad. This was very clearly illustrated in the recent bidding for a quantity of tramway girder rails needed by the corporation of Yarmouth.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Taft Commission has been ordered to forward to the War Department its recommendations for the form of government to be adopted in the Philippines. This is in accordance with the original instructions, by the terms of which the commission was to prepare such recommendations whenever ordered to do so.
MADRID, March 13. -- Spanish fours closed to-day at 79,00. Gold was quoted at 34.87.

PHILADELPHIA, March 13. -- Union Traction was the overshadowing feature in the market to-day. The trading was extensive at steadily declining figures. There was weakness in many stocks, but some showed marked gains. American Railways was higher than in a long time. The common and preferred of Pennsylvania Steel were up 4 points, the former reaching 71 and the latter 94.

Three costly roulette and red and black wheels, taken in the recent raid of the Committee of Fifteen on the gambling house 118 West Thirty-fifth Street, were yesterday chopped up by order of Justice Jerome, while the rueful prisoners charged with being the operators of the machines sat near the scene of destruction with impotently wrathful countenances.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 13. -- Arthur H. Fenn played Bernard Nichols a thirty-six-hole match here to-day and beat him by seven up and six to play, at the same time winning the purse of $150. This was a bad punishment for Nichols, but his great difficulty was in putting on the sand. However, these are the same style of greens as those at Ormond, where he beat Vardon last year.

In the tournament of the Life Insurance Bowling League on Ehlers's alleys last night the Mutual Benefit and the Germania teams each won two games, the Equitable and the Mutual Life No. 1 teams each won one game and lost one, and the Metropolitan and the Prudential teams each lost two games.

The taking of testimony in the action of Lawyer Thomas J. O'Neill against City Magistrate Leroy B. Crane was closed yesterday in the Supreme Court. The case will go to the jury this morning. Justice Clarke denied the motion of the defendant to have the case dismissed on the grounds that the plaintiff had not proved that the Magistrate was a partner with his brother in the practice of law.

The schedule for the coming season has been adopted by the Amateur Baseball League. The first game is to be played on May 25, and will be between teams representing the New York Athletic Club and the Morristown Field Club. Games will thereafter be played on every Saturday and on holidays up to and including Sept. 14.

CORSICANA, Texas, March 13. -- John Henderson, colored, who several days ago brutally-murdered Mrs. Younger, a farmer's wife, living just outside this city, was burned to death in the Court House square here at noon to-day. A written confession of the crime, attested by Justice Roberts, was secured from the prisoner.

WOODMERE, L.I., March 13. -- Bert Brower, who was held two months ago to await the action of the Grand Jury on a charge of breach of promise brought by Anna Stringer, the daughter of Louis Stringer, was married last night to Miss Stringer by the Rev. William B. Sears, at the bride's home.

Wednesday, the eve of Mi-Careme, was dull. A meeting of the Post Graduate Sewing Class, a tea at the Nurses and Child's Hospital, and at the Tennis Building a meeting of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club, which meets every Wednesday -- these affairs were the principal events of yesterday.

BELLAIR, Fla., March 13. -- The golf tournament was continued here to-day, the event being the men's thirty-six hole medal play handicap. A.G. Lockwood, winner of the scratch competition on the previous day, started plus 7, a heavy handicap, which proved too much for him to overcome.

A correspondent whose letter on the consumption and waste of water appeared in THE TIMES of yesterday makes some statements which would be interesting if not wholly inaccurate. One of these is that in estimating the water consumption of New York "it is fair to allow one bath to each person, offsettins those who never bathe against those who take two baths a day."

LONDON, March 13. -- The Gazette to-day announces the appointment of Mrs. George Cornwallis West and Mrs. Jennie Blow as Ladies of Grace of the Order of St. John of Jerusalem, and of J.J. Van Alen as an Honorary Knight of Grace of the order, in connection, respectively, with their work in fitting out the American hospital ship Maine and a field hospital for South Africa.

The following-named First Lieutenants will report to Major John M. Banister, (Surgeon.) President of the board appointed to meet at the United States Military Academy. West Point, Jan. 12, for examination as to their fitness for promotion; Albert E. Saxton, Eighth Cavalry; Frank Parker. Fifth Cavalry; William G. Silis. Eighth Cavalry, Girard Sturtevant, Twenty-third Infantry; Andrew J. Hero, George Blakely, Frank W. Coe, and William R. Smith, Artillery Corps.

Col. Michael C. Murphy, Commissioner of Police, ridiculed yesterday the report that after the adjournment of the Legislature, or at any other time, he was to go back to the Health Department and that John B. Sexton was "slated" to succeed him. "I have nothing to say on the subject," he added. "Let those who start such rumors talk about them."

The Presidential career of Mr. HARRISON is to be praised or condemned according to the opinion held of the policy of his party. There was nothing distinctly original in it, nor can he be said to have left the impress of his personality upon his party in the degree that might have been expected from his actual talent and character.
BOSTON, March 13. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 and 3 per cent. New York funds from 15 to 17 cents discount for cash.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In last Sunday's TIMES your esteemed, dramatic critic takes Mr. Howells to task for saying that the version of "Hamlet" employed by Mme. Bernhardt and her company was in "rhymed French alexandrines," the actual translation used having been in the prose of MM. Morand and Schwob.

Controller Coler announced yesterday that he would sell $2,500,000 of bonds of the City of New York bearing 3 1/2 per cent. interest. The bonds will be issued for the construction of the Rapid Transit Railroad, and bids will be opened for the issue on March 25.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am glad to see that you are opposing the plan of adding $2,000,000 more to the cost of the thirteen-milllon-dollar abortion, alias the County Court House. It would then be a bigger abortion than ever, and the worst of it is that it would probably be a permanent abortion.

Many persons crossing Fifth Avenue in the vicinity of Madison Square narrowly, escaped being knocked down yesterday morning by a runaway horse attached to a coupe. The animal Known as "Fox" is owned by Richard Deeves, a builder living at 58 West Eighty-third Street, and was being driven by Christopher Healey, the coachman.

Henry N. Smith, a former partner of Jay Gould, died on Tuesday in a sanitarium at Stamford, Conn. For the past year he had been in bad health, having had two strokes of paralysis. Mr. Smith was for a long time a prominent operator in Wall Street, and his name was connected conspicuously with the events of the famous Black Friday.
LONDON, March 14. -- Lord Salisbury spoke last evening at the annual banquet of the Associated Chambers of Commerce Of the United Kingdom.

ORANGE, N.J., March 13. -- A special meeting of the Orange Common Council was called this evening by Mayor Stetson to act on the application of the Board of Health for formal permission to erect a pesthouse to handle the present cases of smallpox in Orange. A communication from the Mayor was read asking the Common Council to designate a place for the erection of the pesthouse.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Gov. Odell will send to the Legislature to-morrow a special message on the canal improvement question, together with the report of State Engineer Bond, on the surveys made under his direction as to route and cost of a proposed State barge canal. The Governor declines to indicate what line of policy he will pursue in his message.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- Senor Martinez Silva, Minister of Foreign Affairs for the Republic of Colombia and at present accredited as Colombian Minister to Washington, had another conference with Secretary Hay to-day, in connection with the Informal discussion concerning the Panama Canal route lying within Colombia.

TRENTON, N.J., March 13. -- The Senate this morning gave its exclusive attention to the discussion of Senator McCarter's bill providing for district sewage commissions. The bill is intended principally to establish a commission taking in the municipalities along the Passaic River, and giving the Commission power to abolish the pollution of the river and to apportion the cost to the different municipalities.

ALBANY, March 13. -- Some of the Albany comrades of Gen. John Palmer in the Grand Army of the Republic to-day sent to Senator Platt a statement setting forth their reasons why Gen. Palmer should not be appointed Commissioner of Pensions. Gen. Palmer is a member of Grand Army of the Republic Post No. 5, in Albany.

Nine persons were injured in a trolley accident just outside of Westfield, N.J., last evening. That all who were in the car escaped with their lives is wonderful. The car leaped from the rails, turned a somersault down an embankment, and landed upside down.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The Russian Ambassador, Count Cassini, was seen today concerning the reiterated reports as to Russia's designs on Manchuria. Count Cassini said he was not authorized to make any official declaration on the part of his Government, but in view of the constant reports he consented to state his individual views, based upon his long service in China and his familiarity with the general policy Russia has consistently maintained toward China.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 13. -- Judge Nobbs of the Probate Court said to-day that before any settlement of the estate of George F. Gilman could be arranged the claimants must come into court and comply with the laws of this State. He reiterated the statement that he holds that the jurisdiction of his court extends over all the personal estate, wherever found, and over such of the real estate as is within this State.

The local agents of the Bank or Montreal announced yesterday that the bank would offer to the highest bidder in public competition $1,500,000 of 3 1/2 per cent. forty-year bonds of the City of Montreal.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 13. -- Benjamin Harrison, ex-President of the United States, died at 4:45 o'clock this afternoon. His death was quiet and painless, there being a gradual sinking until the end came, which was marked by a single gasp for breath as life departed from the body of the great statesman.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 13. -- The following tribute to the memory of Gen. Harrison is from ex-Attorney General W.H.H. Miller, who was closely associated with the ex-President in his official, professional, and social life:
LONDON, March 13. -- Money was in fair demand to-day and fairly plentiful. The recent squeeze was regarded as practically ended.

Wagner's "Tristan und Isolde" was sung once again at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. Nearly every seat in the house was occupied and most of the standing room was filled. These facts are significant in view of the frequent attempts of our friends across the water to belittle the depth and breadth of our affection for the highest forms of music.

BRISTOL, March 13. -- The work of construction on the hull of the Bristol boat is fast narrowing down to a small space, telling plainly that in a few weeks preparations will be under way to get the craft out of the south shop. It is claimed that more rivets were headed up on the boat to-day than on any other day since that line of work was begun.

A.G. Batchelder, Chairman of the Board of Control of the National Cycling Association, will sail for Europe on Saturday to attend the Spring meeting of the International Cyclists' Union, which begins at Allessandria, Italy, on April 7, and to obtain the entries of the leading European racing cyclists in the cycling meets at Buffalo in August.

ALBANY, March 13. -- The bill of Mr. Coughtry increasing the tax from 5 to 7 per cent. upon the gross receipts of all running track associations will be reported favorably to-morrow by the Assembly General Laws Committee. The bill is opposed by the State Racing Commission. A hearing was given during the afternoon, and August Belmont of New York City, as President of the New York State Racing Association, opposed the measure.

More or less irregularity developed in the stock market yesterday, but on the whole the undertone was strong and closing prices for the day generally showed net advances, some of them not unsubstantial. It was a market, however, of specialties, and not a few comparatively insignificant stocks were taken in hand and moved up, to the neglect of securities much better known and usually much more active.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 13. -- George Brinkcrhoff was beaten and robbed by William Robinson and George Hift tonight. Brinkerhoff was serving two women customers in his grocery store, when Robinson came in, seized the grocer by the throat, and demanded a can of beans and his money. Hift, it is alleged, proceeded to take his money.

The Industrial Federation of America has opened offices at 149 Broadway and issued a prospectus describing the scheme of its promoters to raise several million dollars for the purpose of building up an industrial community to be established on land, which is now mostly covered by the waters of Jamaica Bay -- at least, at high tide.

Coroners' Physician Philip O'Hanlon performed yesterday an autopsy on the body of Herbert C. Wadman. whose body was exhumed from St. Michael's Cemetery, upon a Supreme Court order obtained by the District Attorney. Wadman entered Bellevue Hospital early in March, and after three days in the Bellevue insane pavilion was transferred to the Manhattan State Hospital.

A scheme of a private corporation to connect Newtown Creek with Flushing Bay was laid bare at a meeting of the Board of Public Improvements yesterday. President Bowley of the Borough of Queens claimed that the "Newtown and Flushing Canal Company" was seeking to obtain enormously valuable wharf rights and a franchise in perpetuity to construct and maintain a canal, with docks, basins, wharves, and piers.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 13. -- John Vliet, the oldest hotel keeper in Middlesex County, died at Spotswood, N.J., this morning, aged seventy-nine years. He was known as the blind barkeeper, and for over fifty years he kept a hotel and had never had any trouble with the excise authorities.

ALBANY, March 13. -- The Senate has passed the bill of Senator Humphrey, putting National building associations more directly under control of the Bank Superintendent and forbidding building and loan associations generally to invest in second mortgages, year, 36; nays, 12.
ALBANY, March 13. -- Ramapo legislation was given a set-back to-day. The two houses are now in a wrangle over the subject, and the outcome is shrouded in doubt.
NEWPORT, March 13. -- Mrs. F.O. French has returned to Harborview after an extended visit with her daughters, Mrs. A.G. Vanderbilt, in New York, and Mrs. Eaton, in Washington.

PITTSBURG, March 13. -- Two communications from Andrew Carnegie, which are officially made public to-night, tell of the steel king's retirement from active business life, and of his donation of $5,000,000 -- $1,000,000 for the libraries at Braddock. Homestead and Duquesne and $4,000,000 for the endowment of a fund for superanuated and disabled employes of the Carnegie Company.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes the payment of the mortgage.

WASHINGTON, March 13. -- The outlook for a renewal of negotiations between America and Great Britain over the Nicaragua Canal is very gloomy. The President and Secretary Hay are both giving considerable thought to the subject of how to reopen negotiations, but so far all the information they have received is of such a character as to indicate that nothing can be done for the present.

LONDON, March 13. -- The St. James's Gazette this afternon announces that "Herreshoff, Junior," has been commissioned by a shipbuilder of Glasgow to design a 65-foot racing yacht, to be built on the Clyde.

QUEENSTOWN, March 13. -- Capt. Oortgiese or the Dutch steamer La Flandre, from Antwerp for Philadelphia, which was towed into Queenstown on Monday by the British steamer West Point, has made a statement relating his experiences.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 14. -- At the regular quarterly meeting of the University Trustees here to-day President Patton recommended the following changes in the academy courses:

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 14. -- Charles W. Ryan, cashier of the Halifax National Bank, was shot to death by Henry Rowe and Weston Keiper, of Lykens, at noon to-day, during an attempt at a daring bank robbery. The robbers were captured by a party of citizens soon after the crime, and were brought to the Harrisburg Jail, together with F. B. Straley, of Lykens, who is suspected or being an accomplice.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- E. Theophilus Liefeld, United States Consul at Freiburg, has sent to the State Department a report on " Sulphur in Russia." Mr. Liefeld says:

Theodore Conkling, a woolen manufacturer, giving 329 Amsterdam Avenue as his address, was locked up in the West Sixty-eighth Street Station last night. The charge was attempted felonious assault. It was made by his divorced wife, Ella S. Conkling, who resides at 62 West Seventieth Street.

The elaborate statement of the purposes of Russia in Manchuria which has been given out by the Russian Ambassador in Washington has of course attracted the attention of all Americans intelligently interested in the situation in China. It cannot be said to have assuaged the curiosity it has excited.

To the Editor of The New York Times: All New York firemen must feel thankful for your article in to-day's issue of your valuable paper. It shows clearly that THE TIMES does not believe the "two-platoon bill" now before the Legislature is for the best interests of the firemen or the city; still, THE TIMES discusses it in the most kindly manner, and I assure you all firemen do appreciate your generous intentions.

BALTIMORE, March 14. -- The market to-day reversed the record of Wednesday. Seaboards were halted in their declines and redirected on an upward scale. Statements to the effect that the April interest on the bond certificates was assured acted as an effective stimulus to buying.

ALBANY, March 14. -- Ex-Sheriff William V. Molloy of Westchester County, the well-known turfman, died to-day at the Union Hotel on the Troy Road, surrounded by his immediate relatives. The Rev. Henry T. Newey of St. Patrick's Cathedral, New . York City, was present.

Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE'S epistles "urbiet orbi," in which he takes the people of Pittsburg, and, incidentally, those of the rest of the planet, into his confidence as to his feelings and his intentions, have a degree of human interest higher than usually attaches to the personal communications of very rich men.

Military honors marked the funeral of Major James C. Abrams, the senior Major of the Seventh Regiment and for over forty years a member of that regiment, which took place yesterday. The regiment gathered in the armory shortly after noon, and went by an elevated train to One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, from which point it marched to the home of the late Major, at 146 West One Hundred and Thirtieth Street.

ALBANY, March 14. -- Gov. Odell has determined to recommend to the Legislature the continuation of the nine-foot improvement to the canal begun under George W. Aldridge. He had intended to send a message to the Legislature to-day, but the message is delayed. State Engineer Bond, However, completed his portion of the work By adding to the other surveys an estimate of cost for continuing the improvement.

PRINCETON, N. J., March 14. -- A meeting of the Board of Governors of the University Golf Association has decided to have the new golf course opened not later than June 1. Work on it will be resumed next week. The following members of last year's team are still in the Universitv: Griswold, Jr., '99; Pyne 2d, '03; Cooke. '01; Dahlgren, '03; Garretson, '03;.

Justice Scott of the Supreme Court has denied an application for an injunction made by Oscar J. Friedlander, a policy holder in the Mutual Reserve Fund Life Association, to restrain it from putting into operation the amendments to its by-laws. This is a test case. The insurance which may be affected by it amounts to about $25,000,000 of the old assessment business of that company.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Thomas F. Clark, Vice President of the Western Union Telegraph Company, testified before the Industrial Commission to-day concerning the relations of the telegraph to the public. He devoted much of his time to the consideration of the wisdom of Government ownership of the telegraph.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 14. -- A conference was held this afternoon between State Treasurer Gallup and Attorney General Phelps in regard to the course of action of the State in the hearing on Monday next on the estate of George P. Gilman.

The Rev. Dr. Frederick B. Meyer, one of the leading evangelists of England, arrived here yesterday on the White Star Line steamship Majestic. He was met at the pier by William R. Moody, a son of the late evangelist, Dwight L. Moody, and at 11 o'clock Dr. Meyer left for Richmond, Va., where he was scheduled to hold an evangelistic service last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have a few ideas relative to the obviation of the "crush" at the Park Row end of the Brooklyn Bridge, and I trust you may think well enough of them to place them where they "will do the most good."

RALEIGH, N. C., March 14. -- The impeachment trial of Judges Furches and Douglas began this afternoon in the Senate Chamber before a notable assembly, embracing several hundred women. There was much form and ceremony, as first the nine managers on the part of the House and their five lawyers entered, and then as Judge Furches and the seven lawyers for the defense entered.

OGDENSBURG, N. Y., March 14. -- While heavily laden cars of copper, en route from Canada to New York, were being taken from the transfer steamer Armstrong, at the New York Central slip, to-day, a coupling broke as the last car was running on to the apron. Before it could be blocked the car ran back on the steamer, smashing the dead woods and crashing through the boat rail.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The torpedo boat Stocklon, which arrived at Norfolk yesterday, has been ordered in reserve commission with the other torpedo boats gathered there to await the Spring manoeuvres of the flotilla.

CITY ISLAND, N. Y., March 14. -- Charles Compton's steam yacht Cosette, after having her bottom repainted at the Jacob yard, was launched from the Marine Railway and proceeded for Providence, where she will be overhauled and prepared for a cruise in Southern waters. The house which inclosed W. Gould Brokaw's schooner yacht Amorita while alterations were made has been removed, presenting the yacht to full view.

The nineteen bells in the great chime of St. Patrick's Cathedral were rung yesterday by means of a system of compressed air, the St. Patrick chime being the first in the world to be so operated. The newly installed system was being officially tested in the presence of the rector and trustees of the Cathedral and numerous mechanical experts.

W. Allston Flags, Vice President of the Metropolitan Golf Association, gave a dinner last evening at the Union Club to the members of the Executive Committee, and the affair resolved itself into the first meeting of the new board of the association. After the dinner President Percy Chubb called the meeting to order.
LONDON, March 13. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times says:

ATLANTA, Ga., March 14. -- President Wilburn has called a special meeting of the stockholders of the Chattanooga, Rome, and Southern Railroad for May 15 to consider the sale and conveyance of that property to the Central of Georgia. It is understood here that the headquarters of the road will be removed to Savannah.

NEWARK, N. J., March 14. -- The body of W. W. Blackford, night operator in the towerhouse of the Lehigh Valley Railroad at Park View, was found in the tower early this morning by other employes of the road. A revolver was found on the floor of the structure, and it was discovered that he had died from a bullet wound.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 14. -- The arrangements for the funeral of Gen. Benjamin Harrison, ex-President of the United States, have been completed. The body will lie in state at the Capitol Saturday from 11 o'clock in the morning until 10 o'clock in the evening, and the funeral services will be held from the First Presbyterian Church Sunday afternoon at 2 o'clock, the Rev. M. L. Haines officiating.

LONDON, March 15. -- A Parliamentary paper was issued last evening containing Lord Wolseley's memorandum to Lord Salisbury, dated Nov. 12, 1900, and the critical minutes upon the same by Lord Lansdowne and Mr. Brodrick.

The large plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, owned by the Paran Stevens estate, has been sold. The name of the buyer, or further particulars regarding the transaction, could not be learned yesterday. The property has been held at $900,000, and the price in the present sale is said to be not far from that figure.
LONDON, March 15. -- The disclosure of the civil list proposals of the Government by The Times yesterday has created a flutter.

DALLAS, Texas, March 14. -- So far as is known, Gov. Sayors has made no sign as to his intentions in connection with the burning yesterday of John Henderson. That he has been in communication by wire with District Attorney Kirven and other authorities of the Corsicana Judicial District is well known.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideraion" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes the payment of the mortgage.

The market for outside securities yesterday was stronger and more active than it had been for the last few days. A number of substantial gains were made, and few issues closed lower than they did the previous day. In some cases the fluctuations were accompanied by active trading, while in others they were principally the result of small offerings.

The approach of St. Patrick's Day was borne in upon the clerks in the foreign mail department of the Post Office yesterday with the arrival of the White Star steamship Majestic, which brought over 1,800 bags, of mail matter. By far the larger part of the huge consignment was from Ireland, and the greater part of this mail matter consisted of shamrock.

One of those odd collections that seem only fit for a historical society may be seen at the ivory shops of Kaldenberg Brothers. It is a series of portraits in colored wax made in Mexico by the late Gen. Jose Galindo, representing thirty of the men who were instrumental in freeing Mexico from Maximilian and the French.

Yesterday did not seem in the least like Lent. There were a number of entertainments, including the Roman festival and the Venetian carnival. There were also dinners and smaller entertainments and the usual meeting of sewing classes, the most notable of which was that of Miss Learys Bellevue Sewing and Knitting Class, and a fair in which the very young set were interested.

A large and brilliantly attired audience greeted the Venetian Carnival, in the large ballroom of the Waldorf, last evening. For some years the anniversary of the opening of the hotel has been celebrated by an entertainment given by the Decorative Art Society, and for which Mr. Boldt gives the free use of the ballroom, not only for the affair itself, but also for the rehearsals.

ALBANY, March 14. -- The Senate this afternoon passed the Morgan Unconditional Ramapo Repeal bill unanimously, and it is now before the Governor. When the Senate met this morning Senator Slater moved that the Committee on Judiciary be discharged from the further consideration of the bill. Senator Brackett, the Chairman of the committee, resisted the motion.

CLOVERPORT, Ky., March 14. -- In the biting air of the early morning hours the citizens of Cloverport look on, almost powerless to act, to-day, while fire destroyed about $500,000 worth of property and left 1,000 persons -- half the population -- homeless. Every business house was burned, and the distress of hundreds of women and children was relieved only when trains, loaded with supplies, arrived from Louisville and Henderson.

RALEIGH, N. C., March 14. -- Gov. Aycock to-day sent a special message to the General Assembly owing to the fact that a deficit has been found in the accounts of State prisons in the Treasury Department amounting to about $4,000, so far as has been ascertained to the present time.
Mayor Hoos of Jersey City has created a sensation in local political circles by a speech he made at a dinner given by the MinkaKwa Club, a Republican organization, on Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Such information as has come to the hands of officials here indicates that the Russian agreement with China regarding Manchuria consists of twelve articles, not nine, as has been published.

The New York Library Club met yesterday afternoon In the assembly room of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, at 150 Fifth Avenue. The President, Wllberforce Eames, of the Lenox Branch of the Public Library, presided.

ALBANY, March 14. -- In the Assembly to-day the three bills of Mr. Davis defining the powers of the Fire Commissioners of New York City relative to selecting uniforms for the firemen were advanced to third reading and recommitted at the request of the introducer.

Those who watched Mr. Jean de Reszke feigning death in the last act of "Tristan und Isolde," at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night, secretly hoped that the result might not be the same as that of his previous appearance in the same role. It may be recalled that he was then seized with an attack of grip, and was unable to sing for nearly three weeks.
WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Carl Bailey Hurst, Consul General at Vienna, has sent to the State Department the following report on "Peat Wood in Austria":

BUFFALO, March 14. -- With the return of Director General Buchanan from Washington, the plans for opening the Pan-American Exposition are assuming definite shape. It has been decided that the exposition shall be opened on May 1. At that time President McKinley and his Cabinet are expected to be on their way to the Pacific Coast.
Mayor Van Wyck sent to Albany yesterday the Atlantic Avenue Improvement bill with a veto message, in which his reasons for disapproving the bill are set forth.

Police Captains Thomas, Westervelt, Donohue, and other members of the police force who failed to suppress gambling houses and other illegal resorts found to exist in many precincts by the Committees of Five and Fifteen, may be indicted by the Grand Jury next week.

NICE, March 14. -- There has been a slight improvement during the past week in the condition of ex-President Charles P. Clark of the New YorK, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, who is suffering from a severe attack of heart disease. His doctors hope that the improvement will be maintained, in view of the patient's strong constitution.

BOSTON, March 14. -- Time money is quoted from 3 1/2 to 4 per cent, for four to six months. Business paper ranges from 3 1/4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Call money rules from 3 to 4 per cent. Call loans are still outstanding at 2 1/2 per cent., and a few exceptionally strong borrowers probably could obtain large blocks at this figure.

NORWOOD, Mass., March 14. -- Kalph G. Bateman killed Ella F. White, at the young woman's home here last night, and then committed suicide by shooting. Bateman was twenty-two years of age. Miss White was twenty. They were alone together when the tragedy occurred. The police think jealousy was the motive.

BERLIN, March, 14. -- The death of Benjamin Harrison is generally commented upon this evening by the German press, with the exception of the semi-official organs, but a high official of the Foreign Office said to-day:
Justice Lawrence took occasion in the Supreme Court yesterday to rebuke a lawyer whom he considered had made an unusual proposition to him in the matter of appointing a referee.

William Marconi, the inventor of the wireless telegraphic system, was an arrival on the White Star liner Majestic from Liverpool yesterday morning. Mr. Marconi will spend one month in America, during which time he will visit the New England coast and other places, and consider the advisability of various sites as wireless telegraphic stations.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 14. -- Results at Oakland: Half mile -- Zirl, 110, (Dominlck.) 1; Jarretierre d'Or, 114, 2; Killdoe, 115, 3. Time -- 0:49. Futurity Course -- Mike Strauss. 116. (Dominick.) 1; Alleviate, 118, 2; Midiove, 113, 3. Time -- 1; 11 3/4. Six furlongs -- The Light, 106, (Mounce.) 1; Duckoy, 110. 2; Tame Irishman. 107, 3. Time -- 1:14 3/4.

ST. LOUIS, March 14. -- "Manon Lescaut," a new play, was successfully produced at the Century Theatre this evening. The author, Theodore Burt Sayre, in his dramatization from the famous novel, has departed from the book to a considerable extent, but the scenes he has invented are as strong as those of the original writer.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- Representative Fitzgerald of New York was a prosecuting witness to-day at Police Headquarters, appearing to complain of the conduct of Officer Kilmartin in arresting him on inauguration day at Pennsylvania Avenue and Fifteenth Street.

Silas C. Croft, Surveyor of the Ports issued a formal statement yesterday stating that the practice of countersigning cards of admission to the baggage inclosure of the various steamship wharves had been discontinued because the privilege was so abused that the Inspectors were hampered in their examination of the baggage.

WASHINGTON, March 14. -- The National capital is in mourning to-day for ex-President Harrison. Flags are at half-mast, not only upon all the public buildings, but upon the hotels, stores, and many of the private residences. President McKinley, who was deeply affected by the death of Gen. Harrison, directed that the doors of the Executive Mansion be closed to visitors and denied himself to callers, except those who had business of urgent importance.
PARIS, March 13. -- Count Boni de Castellane boxed the ears of Fernand de Rodays, editor of Le Figaro, yesterday morning, and M. de Rodays later sent his seconds to the Count.

Miss Fanny Johnson, who will be remembered by the New York theatre-going public as the impersonator until recently of the character of Dolores, the leading role in the musical comedy, " Florodora," at the Casino Theatre, was married Wednesday evening to Prof. William Van Bergen Van Dyck of Rutgers College.

First Lieut. William M. Cruikshank. Artillery Corps, is detailed as recorder of the hoard of officers appointed to meet at San Antonio. Texas, vice Capt. Frederick W. Sibley, Second Cavalry, relieved.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- Secretary Long to-day rendered a decision on that feature of the recent enactment of Congress promoting officers for gallant service and providing that the promotion of these officers shall not interfere with the regular order of promotions. It was difficult to reconcile these extra promotions and the regular promotions, and Congress provided that the promotions for gallantry should be carried on the naval list as "additional names."

ALBANY, March 15 -- Gov. Odell to-day vetoed five bills. Two are amendments to the Code of Civil Procedure introduced by Senator Donneliy. In his veto message on the bill relating to additional allowances in settling of accounts in Surrogates' courts, the Governor says:
There can be but one opinion as to the generosity and sagacity of the offer made by Mr. CARNEGIE to aid in the establishment of circulating libraries in the City of New York.

The fight to save the Palisades from destruction by quarrymen, which has been in progress for some time, Will be of no avail unless some action is taken in the matter by the New Jersey Legislature before its adjournment, which is set for Thursday next.

BOSTON, March 15 -- Judge Aldrich, in the United States Circuit Court, has granted an order restraining Mrs. Lydia Wrlght-Pearson, executrix of the will of James C. Pearson of Wakefield, who died in Boston Jan. 9, two days after the issue of a policy for $240,000 by the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, from bringing a suit at law against the insurance company.

J.A. Altsheler's new novel, entitled "The Wilderness Road," and said to be it a romance of early expansion, is to be published this month by D. Appleton Co. The scene is laid in Kentucky toward the end of the eighteenth century.

OF INTEREST TO AUTHORS -- The Graften Press is a new publishing concern that has just been organized by F.H. Hitchcock, who has been for the past ten years in charge of the Manufacturing Department of D. Appleton Co. This new firm has already a number of books which it will publish during the coming month, and several of their publications are expected to be popular.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The Census Office has received through the State Department a Consular report on the population of the German Empire and its changes during the past century. That population is now about 56,000,000, larger than that of any other country in Europe, except Russia, which has in Europe alone over 106,000,000 subjects.

Eugenie Bashford Tonkin applied to Justice Lawrence, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, for a writ of habeas corpus directing her mother-in-law to produce her husband in court. Mrs. Tonkin, in her petition says that on March 5 last her husband. Harold G. Tonkin, left her to go and call on his mother, Mrs. Virginia Tonkin, at the Hotel Majestic.

BOSTON, March 15 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in somewhat less demand. The 3 per cent, rate had disappeared, and all loans were at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 15 cents' discount for cash.

Gustav v. Seyffertitz, the leading comedian of the Irving Place Theatre, was given a benefit last night. On this occasion there was performed for the first time in this country a new farce-comedy in three acts by Benno Jacobson, entitled "Women of To-day," which is said to be the success of the season at the Residenz Theatre, in Berlin.

BOSTON, Mrch 15 -- Three lives were sacrificed, nearly a dozen men were more or less injured, and many thousands of dollars damage was the result of a fire that started in the press room of The Daily Advertiser and Record in the seven-story, granitefront building in newspaper row, Washington Street, to-night.

A motor vehicle that can run almost as fast as an express train, a French chauffeur who isn't afraid to make it do so, and Bicycle Policeman Jim Donahoe, who can do a sprint himself, figured in a small comedy in Fifth Avenue last night.

How many years-nay, how many decades of years -- have elapsed since the United States has produced a love story preaching nothing, proving nothing, illustrating no period of history? It is so much easier to mingle one's theories with the thread of one's fiction; to draw one thread of destiny slightly, to leave another slack, that one's sociological ideas may be better exemplified by the villain's evil fate or by the heroine's happiness!

LONDON, March 15 -- The demand for money to-day was fairly brisk, and prices were firm, in connection with the Settlement and Indian bill operations, involving the payment of u1,500,000. Discounts were firm. The increased pressure is expected to be temporary.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 15 -- For the second day of the annual golf tournament there was a clear sky and cool air. The most interesting match of the morning was that between C.B. Cory and T.T. Reid, which Reid won by 3 up and 2 to play. In the afternoon C.F. Watson, Jr., defeated W.B. Cheney, (who won the gold qualification medal yesterday,) by 1 up, and T.T. Reid beat Clayton Dixon, 2 up.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 15 -- New Rochelle is to have a library building donated by Andrew Carnegie if the site for the building is provided and $4,000 yearly is raised for the maintenance of the institution. The offer was made to William K. Palmer, who is a resident of this city. The Common Council will be asked to provide the maintenance fund, and it is expected the site will be given.

Stimulated by the decidedly strong tone of the Stock Exchange market, the curb market yesterday showed increased activity accompanied by substantial strength in many parts of the list. The steel stocks were more active than they had been, and many other issues added fairly large amounts to the day's total.
WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The following order has been issued from the War Department, accompanying the President's proclamation relative to ex-President Harrison:
DOVER, Del., March 15 -- The Anglo-American Zinc and Lead Company of New York was incorporated here to-day, with a capital of $10,000,000.
Changes in the stations and duties of officers of the Medical Department:

The Executive Committee of the united States Tennis Association met last night at the Waldorf-Astoria to consider tournament dates for the coming season. Those Who were present were J.S. Clark, Richard Stevens, Palmer E. Presby, Dr. John White, O.S. Campbell, R.D. Wrenn, Raymond D. Little. W.A. Larmed, and Dwight F. Davis.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- report is in circulation in this city that John G. Johnson, a leading member of the Philadelphia bar and one of the most prominent lawyers in this country, has been offered the portfolio of Attorney General in President McKinley's Cabinet, to succeed Attorney General Griggs.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Ex-Congressman Rowland Blennerhasset Mahany of Buffalo has been in Albany for the past few days, and has spent most of his time at the Capitol presenting to members of the Senate and the Legislature a plan he has for gerrymandering the Buffalo Congressional districts so as to make both of them surely Republican.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Assemblyman Babcock introduced a bill to-day which provides that no person shall practice hypnotism, mesmerism, suggestive therapeutics, and allied phenomena after May 1 unless previously registered and legally authorized, or unless authorized by the Regents. No one can practice who has been convicted of a felony.

Police Commissioner Murphy decided yesterday, " for the Rood of the service," to direct Inspectors Walter L. Thompson and John Harley, of the Fourth and Third Inspection Districts, respectively, to shift commands. Col. Murphy said that the change should not be taken as a reflection on either officer.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 15 -- At the meeting of the Yale University Corporation held to-day it was announced by President A.T. Hadley that he had received a letter of acceptance from Justice David J. Brewer of the United States Supreme Court in response to the invitation that he deliver the commemorative address at the bi-centennial celebration of next October.
