The rifle experts who are competing in the championship events held on the Zettler Rifle Club's range, 159 West Twenty-third Street, in connection With the Sportsmen's Show, yesterday vainly tried to equal or beat the record mark of the 100-shot event, made by L.P. Ittel of Pittsburg. Their failure left Ittel with a lead in the event that promises a final victory.

LONDON, March 16 -- A dispatch from Lord Kitchener given out yesterday is silent upon the subject of the peace negotiations, and this leads to the conclusion that nothing has yet been accomplished of a sufficiently definite character to justify the lending of official support to the view that the war is over.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 15 -- The arrangements at the Harrison home for the lying in state to-morrow and the funeral services Sunday were practically completed to-night. The body was dressed and removed to the front parlor to-day, where it will lie until taken to the State House.

LONDON, March 16 -- The House of Lords was unusually crowded yesterday, in anticipation of the reply of Viscount Wolseley, the ex-Commander in Chief, to the criticism of the ex-War Secretary, the Marquis of Lansdowne, now Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs. The galleries were full of peeresses and others.

In the tournament of the New York Royal Arcanum Bowling League on Starr's alleys last night. Our Council team No. 1 won two games, De Vinne Council won one game and lost one, and Stanley Council lost two games. The scores:

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- A picture of the world's commerce in 1900 is presented in some figures just published by the Treasury Bureau of Statistics as a part of the Monthly Summary of Commerce and Finance. It shows the imports and exports of twenty of the principal countries of the world down to the latest attainable date, in many cases including the final month of the year 1900.

The information that J. Pierpont Morgan had greatly lightened the task of liquidating its debt which the city branch of the Young Men's Christian Association set for itself at the beginning of the year, by the gift of $100,000, leaked out yesterday. The sum required was $300,000. It took Mr. Morgan just two minutes to make up his mind to give one-third of that amount.

The Board of Managers of the New York Produce Exchange has suspended about forty members of the Exchange for nonpayment of extra gratuity fund assessments. The list of members suspended include some of the oldest members on the floor of the Exchange.

Many of our esteemed daily and general contemporaries, in various parts of the country, have joined us in having fun with the extraordinary behavior of the "Reading Committee," if that be the proper name of it, of the Boston Public Library. That was undoubtedly an extraordinary list of exclusions that the library save.

Chronic spitters will, on and after April 1 next, be Vigorously hunted down by specially appointed Health Inspectors, and a systematic effort made to exterminate them by the health officials, just as in the case of microbes, Croton water animalculae, and other pests which menace the public health.

A further rise of prices occurred on the stock market yesterday in the face of not a little short selling and more or less profit taking. In some cases exceptional strength developed, and it was recorded as gratifying that this showed especially in the higher class of stocks, the so-called "cats and dogs" being much less conspicuous than in former days.

A gentleman, who doubtless believed that by being rich and successful in business he had attained the highest success in life, recently expressed his disapproval of college men on the ground that they, were always in "dreamland." Now, there is no great difficulty in determining What this gentleman meant by dreamland."

In recommending the appropriation or $20,000,000 for the completion of the plan of 1895, in part carried out under Mr. ALDRIDGE, Gov. ODELL, seems to us to be influenced by a mistaken sense of economy. In order to avoid the expenditure of a large sum for corresponding grain he urges the spending of a smaller but still considerable sum, for which we shall get no proportionate advantage.

Mr. JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S address before the British Women's Emigration Society, delivered on Friday, was rather a noteworthy performance. Some little time age The Saturday Review published the sketch of a project for offsetting and ultimately abolishing the numerical superiority of the farmers of Dutch descent in South Africa, by directing thither as great a share as might be of British emigration.
John C. Umberfield has sold the fivestory American basement dwelling. 1 West Eighty-sixth Street, adjoining the corner of Central Park West, 22 by 100.

While a revival of interest in the longspun-out novels of Anthony Trollope is probably out of the question, yet Mr. G, S. Street's earnest plea for Trollope as a twentieth century novelist, in the current number of The Cornhill Magazine, does honor equally to its author's head and heart.
PHILADELPHIA, March 13 -- Pitcher Dugglesby and First Baseman Delehanty have signed contracts to play with the Philadelphia National League Baseball Club during the coming season.

ALBANY, March 15 -- Herbert R. Limburger, associate counsel for the Ramapo Water Company, was at the Capitol to-day. Mr. Limburger said no particular importance should be given to his visit. It was noticed that he made frequent and protracted use of the long-distance telephone between Albany and New York during the course of the day.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 13th inst., "Justice," in a communication to your, paper, protests against the injustice of not taxing churches, and rightly argues that the person who really believes in any particular Church will cheerfully pay his proportion of the tax that should rightfully be assessed on that class of property.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- An order was sent to Gen. Chaffee to-day for the evacuation of China by American troops, leaving only a legation guard of 130 men. The troops will be removed from China by the end of April. The dispatch to Gen. Chaffee is as follows:

ALBANY, March 15 -- Assemblyman Frisble of Schoharie, the minority leader in the Assembly, to-day introduced a bill which provides that there shall be a minority representation of the party casting the second highest number of votes at the last preceding State or National election upon all Boards of Managers and all Boards of Trustees of all charitable, correctional, and eleemosynary institutions in the State.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Through the liberality of a well-known public-spirited citizen of New York the Metropolitan Museum has lately become possessed of a possible portrait of Columbus which has been attributed to Sebastla, no Luriano, commonly known as del Plomto.

There is now on view at the Victoria Museum, South Kensington, London, a loan exhibition of modern illustrations, for books, magazines, and newspapers, well arranged after months of labor by an intelligent committee of artists and experts, under the auspices of the Board of Education or what used to be styled "the Science and Art Department."

MOBILE, Ala., March 15 -- News has just reached here of the most horrible catastrophe in the history of Alabama. A big turpentine camp, situated across the bay in Baldwin County was burned at an early hour this morning, and sixty persons, mostly colored, are supposed to have perished in the fire.

Plans have already been perfected for a trip to San Francisco and return by the Epworth Leaguers and their friends next Summer. The fare for the round, trip has been fixed at $67. The trip will include a novel feature. A tour of the Yosemite Valley is to be made in automobiles. Not all who go will be Methodists, but many of those who have already been booked are members of other denominations.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 15 -- The Twin City Rapid Transit Company has settled all its differences with the State officials, and filed a certified copy of its articles of incorporation with the Secretary of State to-day. The company has also paid its license fee of $2,325, as required under the Somerville law.

CAMDEN, N.J., March 15 -- Walter Atkins, sixteen years old, was brought here to-day a prisoner and lodged in the County Jail, charged with attempted murder. He had a narrow escape from being lynched last night at Berlin, fourteen miles from this city. Atkinson lives in this city. Yesterday he rode out to Berlin on his bicycle.

LONDON, March 15 -- Although the New York Chamber of Commerce has not yet officially replied to the invitation of the London Chamber of Commerce the London Chamber fully anticipates that the Americans will visit this city as its guests early in June, and it is, provisionally, preparing extensive festivities.

BERLIN, March 15 -- The Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow made an important Speech in the Reichstag to-day, in which he admitted that differences of opinion had arisen between the powers in regard to Chinese affairs.

CANTON, Ohio. March 15 -- President and Mrs. McKinley and party reached Canton shortly before 11 A.M., the regular train hauling their two special coaches being an hour late. They were met at the station by a number of old friends, and went direct to the Barber residence, the old home of Mrs. McKinley, where Mrs. McKinley will remain until the return to Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- William L. Elkins to-day was shown a dispatch from London, associating the name of Mr. Widener and himself with that of Charles T. Yerkes in a deal to control the underground railroads and street railroads of that city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is not pleasant to be robbed on a train by expert thieves who by magnetism, magic, or some other occult process relieved me last week of a pocketbook containing about $30 in bills and a number of unused railroad tickets. Nor is it at all comforting to know that one of the thieves, to escape capture, leaped from the train and perished in the attempt.
PHILADELPHIA, March 15 -- Everything was better in the local market today, the greatest improvement being in Weisbach. Reading was in great demand. The steel stocks were dormant.

Senator BRACKETT'S trust in the chapter of accidents has not been justified. It is, of course, possible that, if he had gained the delay of a week for which he was finally reduced to pleading, the chapter of accidents might have turned up a paragraph which would have helped him, by bringing forward a new and burning question which would, for the time, have eclipsed this question.

OLYMPIA, Washington, March 15 -- Representative Easterday of Pierce County and Senator Ruth of Thurston County came to blows on the floor of the Senate. The trouble arose over Ruth's vote in favor of postponing a bill to repeal the present libel laws of the State.
The affairs of the Virginia Iron, Coal and Coke Company are to be investigated in the United States Court.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, March 15 -- The duel which had been arranged to take place to-day between Paul Deroulede and Andre Buffet, growing out of the controversy over the action of the Royalists at the time of the coup d etat planned by M. Deroulede and M. Marcel-Habert, on the occasion of the funeral of President Faure has been abandoned on consequence of the authorities having issued a decree expelling both the would-be combatants from Switzerland.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am naturally an optimist, and although there are a great many things in our present civilization which fill me with sadness, yet I think we are slowly reaching upward to a sweeter and nobler social condition, broader and more democratic in its scope, than has ever been achieved by the human race.

The last of the week, especially in Lent, is apt to be very quiet. Last evening there was a concert in aid of the Sunshine Mission at the Victoria Hotel, under the patronage of Mrs. Arthur Twombly; the regular meeting of the Friday Badminton Club, and a dinner at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Langdon Schroeder.

Frank Moss, in a speech before the Patria Club, at the Hotel Savoy, said last night that to his knowledge Judge Gaynor and Lucien Knapp had before consolidation refused bribes amounting to many thousands of dollars from the Ramapo and another water company.
MONTE CARLO, March 15 -- There was a poor attendance to-day at the lawn tennis tournament here in the men's doubles the Doherty brothers beat Garmendia, an American, and Hardy, 6 -- 2, 6-1.

While the rehabilitation of Marat is not exactly a new idea, and was undertaken briefly but vigorously five years or so ago in the Pall Mall Magazine by Mr. Morse Stephens, who wrote also the considerate article on the same subject in the latest edition of the Eneyclopaedia Britannica, yet it is safe to say that nine out of ten readers of Mr. Bax's book will take it up burdened with all the old prejudices.

After the crowded walls of exhibitions of the usual sort it is pleasant to see a gallery that shows wide spaces of wall between frame and frame. The dozen paintings by American artists at the Montross Gallery deserve such generous treatment. Here is "The Flying Dutchman," by Albert Pinkham Ryder, exhibited once before, but so many years ago that a new generation of picture-lovers has arisen between whiles.

According to the promoters of a bill introduced into the Assembly by Assemblyman Waldo R. Blackwell of Brooklyn, the present Supreme Court Reporter of the State, Marcus T. Hun, receives a larger income from his office than any Federal official, with the sole exception of the President of the United States.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 15 -- The Toledo and Chicago Railroad Company was to-day incorporated, to construct and operate a railroad from the Wabash line at Montpelier, Ohio, to Toledo, a distance of sixty-five miles. The capital stock is $250,000 and the incorporators are B.C. Winston of New York and F.J. Reynolds, George H. Beckwith, C.H. Newton, and C.L. Reynolds of Toledo.

WASHINGTON, March 15 -- The cry " The White House is on fire! " brought out to-night one of the most distinguished looking crowds that ever watched a conflagration in a wooden reviewing stand. Where they all came from was a mystery, but within a few minutes after the alarm the neighborhood of the White House was crowded with Cabinet officers, Senators, Representatives, Generals, Admirals, diplomats, and Supreme Court Justices.

-- For reasons not very easy to understand, but which seem to be of a nature entirely sentimental -- a fact making it distinctly surprising that they should have weight with practical scientists -- many men of prominence in the electrical industries are strenuously opposed to the use of the mysterious energy they manipulate in the execution of the death penalty.

Lawyer H. Clinton Rhoads of Philadelpphia notified Acting District Attorney Le Barbier yesterday that the Supreme Court would be asked in a few days to reopen the proceedings by which Isaac Michaelson, who killed Alexander Scherman in July last, was declared insane. Mr. Rhoads, as counsel for the widow of the dead man, insists that the homicide is not insane and that he should stand trial for his crime.

The situation in Venezuela, according to a man who is familiar with Venezuelan matters and who spoke freely concerning them yesterday, is critical and the rumors of serious friction between the Venezuelan Government and F.B. Loomis, United States Minister Plenipotentiary at Caracas, arc true.

BALTIMORE, March 15 -- The stock market was less active to-day, but it manifested considerable strength in special groups. Seaboard securities were in large demand in New York, and that gave them a quick upward impetus which took some local traders by surprise. The bond certificates reached their highest figure since the recent advance was inaugurated.
EXETER, N.H., March 15 -- The will of Jacob Wendell of the firm of Jacob Wendell Co., filed for probate, makes the following bequests:

Brooklyn Democrats assert that, in addition to running its own branch of the Police Department, the borough is also to enjoy home rule as affecting its Fire Department. The revocation of an order by Commissioner Scannell, retiring Chief of Battalion John J. Fanning of Brooklyn, was pointed to yesterday as significant in this connection.

The Kings County Grand Jury has taken up the matter of Brooklyn's water supply, and yesterday it summoned the Brooklyn Aldermen before it and questioned some of them about the delay in bond issues for the extension and improvement of the borough's water system.

The person who planned the series of volumes entitled "Mediaeval Towns" was undoubtedly one of the thousands who have found by experience that the best guide books do not furnish the historical details which the student of history longs for when he visits the seats of ancient empire.

A clear-sighted and experienced officer of the regular army now serving on the Island of Luzon writes to a high official of the War Department, under date of Nov. 4, as follows: "The establishment of schools and the teaching of English are of the first importance. Great efforts are being made in this direction in Manila, but it is the outside towns, barrios, and sitios that furnish the insurgent soldier and many of the leaders.

F.D. Fisher, the engineer in charge of the Degnon-McLean Company's work on Sections 1 and 2 of the subway tunnel, is a very busy man. Along the distance over which he has charge, stretching from Chambers to Great Jones Street, there can be seen every phase of the tunneling, from the removal of paving stones to the roofing of the steel structure that is to cover the roadbeds.

Another Important step in the development of the United States Steel Corporation has been taken. As a result of negotiations which have been going on for some time, it is announced authoritatively that all the Rockefeller interests in the mines in the great lakes region are to be united with the Steel Trust.

It is a sad reflection that in this world of trouble nothing in the way of good comes unattended by a countervailing evil. This is not pessimism; it is simply a safe generalization from coincidences observed ever since mankind began to "take notice," as they say of infants. What suggests it at the moment is a fact which has escaped the attention of the literary critics -- the relation between books and microbes.
CHICAGO, March 16 -- The money market was unchanged, call and time loans going at 4@4 1/4 per cent. New York exchange was discounted at 25c.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The Civil Service Commission to-day announced that it is now ready to receive applications and hold examinations for the Government service in the Philippine Islands. The examinations are entirely separate and distinct from those for the United States service, the Civil Service Commission acting merely as the agent of the Philippine Civil Service Board in the United States.

To the Editor of The New York Times: And to each gallon of Croton water to be filtered two grains of common alum. Filter the water through any filter. It will come through perfectly clear and will not contain any alum in solution.

A custom which prevailed among many of the Cuban women who were in Cambridge was that of wearing narrow-toed, high heeled shoes. The Cubans have naturally small hands and feet, and perhaps it is pardonable for a people to affect to exaggerate a little the thing upon which they pride themselves.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 16. -- Coach Ward had the University of Pennsylvania crews on the river to-day for the first time this season, and at the conclusion of the practice the veteran coach and several members of the Red and Blue Rowing Committee who were his guests on the launch Ben Franklin seemed highly, pleased with the combination.
To the Editor of The New York Times: An article in THE TIMES of Feb. 22 attracted my attention. It was headed "An Old Man's Doubts." The writer desires to find a rock upon which he may rest.
Police Commissioner Murphy has practically refused to prefer charges against or brings to trial Police Captains Thomas, Donohue, Westervelt, or Albertson.

NEWPORT, R.I., March 16 -- Good weather has arrived at Newport unusually early this year, and the improvements about the cottage colony and the new cottages in course of erection are being pushed ahead vigorously. In some instances this work is being done by two sets of workmen, so that there will be no delay in completing the work in time for the occupancy of the places by the time the season opens.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The bill to tax mortgages, recently introduced in the Legislature, is not so stupid, although stupid enough, as it is wicked.

HAZLETON, Penn., March 16 -- The United Mine Workers Convention adjourned to-day before noon. The convention, after an all-morning conference, instructed the National Executive Board to negotiate for another joint conference with the operators, failing to secure which the board has authority to declare a general strike in the anthracite fields.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 16. -- Coach Courtney of the Cornell crews this morning issued his call for all candidates for the Varsity and freshman crews to report at the boat house this afternoon. The signal flag on the boathouse came as a surprise to crew men, who had not expected to get on the water before the middle of next week.

Ever since the respective billiard championship tournaments this season of the National Association of Amateur Billiard Players and the Class A event under the auspices of the Amateur Athletic Union, lovers of the game have deplored, more than at any other time since the unfortunate split occurred about three years ago, the present situation, which is particularly noticeable in the local world.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- The Treasury officials are actively making preparations to carry into effect the war revenue reduction act which becomes operative on July 1, 1901, and with a view to giving the public all information on the subject possible at this time, the internal revenue bureau to-day issued the following statement:

LONDON, March 16. -- So little trustworthy information comes to us from South Africa and so completely silent is the Ministry that we are altogether in the dark about the alleged peace negotiations with Botha. That terms of some kind have been proposed, and that the Boer leader is considering them with some of his associates, appear true, but there is evidently no general cessation of hostilities.

One of the last acts of the House of Representatives prior to adjournment was to pass the Senate bill providing for the creation of a National standardizing bureau. This was a wise, though somewhat tardy, compliance with the insistent demands of scientific investigators, manufacturers, exporters, and of more than one department of the Government service, notably the Ordnance Bureau of the army and the constructive branch of the Navy Department.
BOSTON, March 16 -- At the Clearing House this morning money was in better supply, or at least the demand was smaller. Loans were still at 2 1/2 per cent.

The Committee of Fifteen made another big raid last night on the Bonheur Studio at 132 West Seventy-ninth Street. The raid was planned some days ago, it being started by an advertisement in a newspaper. Moses P. Phillips was the chief prisoner made.

"Maxey" Long, the middle-distance running champion, again distinguished himself last night, at the eighteenth annual indoor games of the Twenty-third Regiment Athletic Association, which were held in the armory of the regiment in Brooklyn. Long's special performance came in the 440-yard run, when he reduced the indoor record for the distance from 0:51 1-5 to 0:51.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been having a rather interesting experience lately in a quest for a copy of the fourth annual report of the Fish, Game, and Forest Commission, which has been recently issued. My experience has suggested a series of problems connected with the distribution of State documents that I am unable to solve.

BERLIN, March 16 -- There was a quiet tendency on the Boerse to-day, and prices were firm. Investment securities and locals were higher. Banks were supported. Americans and Canadian Pacifics were maintained.

LONDON, March 17. -- A dispatch from Lord Kitchener, dated Pretoria, March 16, announces that the notorious Abel Erasmus of Lydenberg has been brought in, with his family, by Lieut. Col. Park's column.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16. -- It was stated that out of a total of 50,000 common and 15,000 preferred shares of the Pennsylvania Steel Company all but about 8,000 shares of common and 3,000 shares of preferred stock has been deposited with the Girard Trust Company, assenting to the plan for increasing its capital to $9,000,000.

There is no reason whatever to doubt the good faith or Commissioner SHEA in his offer to co-operate with the committee of the Chamber of Commerce, to the utmost of his official power, in ameliorating the conditions which make the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge a daily scandal and danger.

To the Editor at The New York Times: Talk about the rottenness of Tammany Hall! Please let up a minute and listen to this complaint of the rottenness of the paper from which the present internal revenue stamps are made, and examine the perforations. Poor Uncle Sam! His receipts from internal revenue are too small or perhaps his poverty-stricken condition is accountable for the rottenness.
BERLIN, March 16 -- Miss Sibyl Sanderson's appearance here has been successful. Although the public was at first cool, it is now appreciative.

The regular monthly supper of the Male Teachers' Association of the City of New York was held at the Hotel Albert, East Eleventh Street and University Place, last evening. About 150 teachers from all the boroughs were present. George H. Chatfield, the President of the association, was the toastmaster, and the principal speakers were State Superintendent of Schools Charles H. Skinner and Samuel L. Clemens, (Mark Twain.)

LANCASTER, Penn., March 16 -- Congressman Marriott Broslus, Chairman of the Committee on Banking and Currency, died at 3 o'clock this morning from a stroke of apoplexy. He was stricken at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. He at once became unconscious and remained in that condition until death. At no time was there any hope entertained for his recovery.

Eugene Zimmerman of Cincinnati, the father of the Duchess of Manchester, sailed for Ireland to visit the Duke and Duchess on the Cunarder Umbria yesterday. When seen on the pier Mr. Zimmerman was not inclined to talk for publication, saying that he thought his family had furnished its share of the news of recent date.

Of all the cities of Germany, Nuremberg is perhaps, to the art student, the most quaint and fascinating, and well may it be called the "Pompeii of the Middle Ages." It is one of the very few cities retaining in an almost perfect state the feudal walls and turrets with which they were invested by the Middle Ages.
Andrew Carnegie's offer of $5,200,000 will be accepted by the city, and as a result New York will have the greatest public library system in the world.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- The State Department has not yet received any request from Venezuela for the recall of Minister Loomis, but there would be little surprise if such a request were made. This is not because Minister Loomis has given any just cause of complaint, but because unofficial advices received from Venezuela Indicate that the American Minister is regarded there with considerable hostility.

The purchase a few days ago of the Boreel Building property by the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company for what was said to be "a trifle under" $2,500,000, has recalled to the mind of a business man of this city some interesting figures about the valuation of Broadway property in and about the Boreel property neighborhood as officially recorded in 1815.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being an ardent admirer of your musical reviews and criticisms, I trust that you will permit me to say a few words regarding the chorus of hysterical adulation showered, upon Mr. Jean de Reszke, which may be fully justified in some cases, but which is very much overdone in others.

Several large transactions actually closed and others in active negotiation have kept the business of the last week well up to recent standards. The bulk of trading is still among speculators and builders, and if any considerable number of the operations which have been projected are carried forward, this Summer will show some record-breaking statistics as to the number of large structures, office buildings, apartment houses, and hotels in course of erection.

A deficiency judgment was entered yesterday against John J. Bannan for $19,990 and Isabella Jane Foghill and Edward L. Foghill for $14,876 in favor of the New York Life Insurance and Trust Company, growing out of the foreclosure sale of 156 West One Hundred and Fifth Street.

LAKEWOOD, March 16 -- The Country Club is a promising expression of the revival of early American tastes. Like newer inventions, it has very evidently "come to stay." and will doubtless multiply and wax strong with each year's increase of wealth and leisure. At present these rural social orders are limited in number, and for the most part are restricted to the moneyed East.

BUFFALO, March 16. -- The visiting editors from New York, Pennsylvania, and New Jersey, the guests of the Lackawanna Railroad, who arrived here last night, visited the grounds of the Pan-American Exposition to-day. They were surprised at the extent and beauty of the various exposition buildings and at the nearness to completion of all the plans of the managers, who are convinced that the grounds will be in perfect condition for the opening, May 1.
The weekly statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $714,675. The banks now hold a surplus of $10,002,600 above the legal requirement.

Earl Li Hung Chang knows every thrust and every parry; he has hunted out every seam in the armor; and he can cut into every unprotected, vital point. He has come into the negotiations to represent the hamiliated power; but there is reason to believe that he is better prepared to fight a losing battle than would be all his opponents combined.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With your kind permission. Mr Editor, I would like a little further to discuss the question of "Immortality," raised by "An Old Man in Doubt," if the controversy has not been closed. Of course all true science and any revelation of the Supreme Being must harmonize so far as the former has advanced and the latter is understood.

The mystery caused by the absence of Mrs. Edward Bradley from her husband's bedside during his illness and at his death, which occurred on Friday last at his home. 19 West Thirtieth Street, was yesterday cleared by the announcement by Mrs. Bradley that her marriage to Dr. Bradley had been secretly annuled on Jan. 5 last.

WASHINGTON, March 16 -- Civil Government will be established in the Philippines on May 15. The continual victories of Gen. MacArthur and the creation of newly organized communities wherever the Taft Commission has gone have indicated to the Administration that the Islands are now sufficiently pacified to permit the experiment.

BERLIN, March 16. -- The most striking feature of yesterday's and to-day's debates in the Reichstag on Chinese affairs was the unanimously manifested feeling of weariness over the "China adventure." It was a regular chorus of "Let us get out from China."

A little woman who has gone into the uphoistering business says that there never was work of any other kind as good for nervousness. She is a delicate-looking woman, slender and not over-strong, and the work is hard, but she is in love with her work, and says that in the fascination of it she forgets all personal ills, and that this is a world of sin and woe.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The discussion as to the immortality of the soul which has been going on of late in the columns of THE TIMES indicates a deep and widespread interest in that most fascinating subject. To multitudes of persons this appears to be a far more momentous and engrossing matter than any of the problems pertaining strictly to the earth life, however vast and important these may be.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The time-honored question about the watchspring dissolved in acid, asked by every schoolboy when first learning of the conservation of energy, has most likely puzzled many a wise head. But almost all other, questions analogous to this one may be easily answered after a little thought and the perusal of the first principles of chemistry.
PARIS, March 17 -- In the duel fought yesterday between Count Boni de Castellane and M. de Rodays, editor of Le Figaro, the latter was wounded in the thigh. Count Boni was not touched.

LONDON, March 16 -- Money was in moderate demand to-day. On the Stock Exchange business was dull, in consequence of the Anglo-Russian trouble at Tien-Tsin, though nothing serious in this connection is anticipated. Consols were offered. Home rails were weak. Americans were unsatisfactory, especially Wabash, this being generally due to profit taking.

PHILADELPHIA, March 16 -- Save for the reappearance of selling pressure in Union Traction stock, the price at one time falling to 30 1/3, the local market was languid but firm. A further advance of 1 1/2 points was scored by Welsbach stock, making a new high figure for the new shares. Renewed buying orders lifted Philadelphia Electric to 6 1/4 , but the market otherwise was devoid of feature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In compliance with the invitation embodied in the communications of correspondents which appeared in THE TIMES of the 10th inst., dealing with the subject of reincarnation, as viewed by C.W. Bond and R. T. M., I beg leave to submit the following:

Mme. Marcella Sembrich has been invited by Angelo Neumann to join his company, which will next year undertake an artistic enterprise of international importance unrivaled since the German impresario took his historic "Wagner Theatre" to Italy in the early eighties. Herr Neumann is to travel through Europe with a company of singers organized to give the finest possible representations of eight operas of the late Giuseppe Verdi.

WASHINGTON, March 16. -- No official confirmation of the state of things at Tien-tsin described in the press dispatches has been received. If, however, the dispatches are correct, and Russia claims territory in which British railroad property is situated, the incident sheds a flood of light on the question of the sincerity of Russia's pretensions that she has not engaged and will not engage in any private arrangement with China.

PORTSMOUTH, March 16. -- Amid the firing of a royal salute by the assembled fleet and hearty cheers from the great concourse of people gathered at all points of vantage, the steamship Ophir, with the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York on board, started at about 4 o'clock this afternoon on the voyage which is not to terminate until their Royal Highnesses have made a tour of the world.

Russia has undertaken to "pacify" Manchuria, and doubtless after her own fashion will succeed in "pacifying" it. She has got all that she wants. She will be fully employed for the next few years in restoring and enlarging the Manchurian railway system, making good her hold upon the new territory, and preparing for the next step.

A burglary with the addition of comedy features was committed on Friday night in a barber shop at 10 Court Square, Brooklyn. John Ben is the proprietor of the shop, which is patronized by politicians, police officials, and others who gather daily in the Borough Hall district.

William Barclay Parsons, who recently returned from China, where he spent several months doing engineering work in behalf of a railroad syndicate, was asked yesterday what he thought of the cablegram sent the other day to the American Asiatic Association of this city by the American Association of China, an organization with its headquarters in Shanghai.

The young Vice Principal of the Bayonne High School, Peter James Crowley, whose sudden disappearance from the school on March 4 caused many rumors to be circulated concerning him, shot himself yesterday morning in the right side as he was being driven through the streets of Jersey City to St. Francis's Hospital, where he had told the cab driver to take him.
TROY, N.Y., March 16. -- The Troy Times publishes this afternoon the following interview with Frank S. Black of this city, ex-Governor of the State, on the canal message of Gov. Odell:

Senator Thomas C. Platt spent a busy day yesterday conferring with Republican leaders at the Fifth Avenue Hotel concerning the new Police bill, which, according to the Senator, is to be introduced and passed before the adjournment of the Legislature.

The late Gen. Harrison was the only man ever elected President who during his college days was a member of a Greek letter society. The society whose alumni rolls are honored with his name is the Phi Delta Theta. which is one of the famous "Miami Triad" of fraternities, the other two being the Beta Theta Pi and the Sigma Chi.

CHICAGO, March 16. -- A special from Davenport, Iowa says: "General Manager E.E. Hughes of the Davenport, Rock Island and North-western Railroad has issued an official statement in denial of the report that the road has been bought by the Burlington. He states that negotiations are under way looking to operating contracts with the Milwaukee and the 'Q,' which, if consummated, would secure the new Kansas City 'cut-off' of the former road.

LONDON, March 16. -- Ellen Terry will signalize her first appearance in London after Sir Henry Irving's tour of the provinces by appearing in "Nance Oldfield" at the Coronet Theatre on March 25. The event will be particularly interesting, as the piece to be given as a curtain-raiser is Purcell's "Masque of Love," the pictorial treatment of which has been intrusted to Gordon Craig. who is Ellen Terry's son.

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 21 -- For some time past there have been rumors in Stockholm that numerous Russian spies have been sent by the War Department in St. Petersburg to investigate the Swedish system of national defense. According to these rumors the spies in question entered Sweden disguised as workingmen.

Representative bankers and brokers in Wall Street are not only confident of the market's present position, but are predicting higher prices, warranted, it is declared by conditions and pending developments. Some views on the subject are herewith presented:

Several weeks ago a letter was received at the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES containing a query as to what becomes of the energy possessed by a wound-up watch-spring when the spring is dissolved in acid. The question was referred to Prof. William Hallock of the Physics Department of Columbia University, whose explanation of the problem was printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES on March 3.
Hamlin Garland, the author, has bought from his father and brother the old Garland homestead, in West Salem, Wis., and it is probable he will again made his home there.

BOSTON, Mass., March 16 -- The talk about the proposed four-cornered trotting match between The Abbot, Cresceus, Charley Herr, and Boralma, and the refusal of John J. Scannell, owner of The Abbot, to allow his horse to start against more than one horse at a time or in a sweepstake, has brought out a challenge for Boralma to race The Abbot for $25,000.

NEW ORLEANS, March 16. -- The fourthousand-dollar Crescent City Derby was a horse race from end to end, and though at the finish the victory rest with Henry Clay Rye, an outsider, the result was very popular. The Morris colt Choice was scratched during the morning, and this eliminated art important factor.

There is one kind of business, according to a New York man prominent in it, that does not enjoy the existing easy financial conditions. It is that or publishing devotional and religious literature. This publisher explained this anomalous condition as follows:

LONDON, March 16. -- James Gordon Bennett's new steam yacht Lysistrata, designed by George L. Watson and built by W. Denny Brothers, has just completed her trials, and is said to have given the greatest satisfaction to her owner, designer, and builders. Over an eighty-five-knot course on the Clyde, the Lysistrata showed a mean speed of 19 1/2 knots, and without forced draught 16 1/2 knots.
WASHINGTON, March 16 -- In view of criticisms of the methods employed in the examination of baggage at the Port of New York, Assistant Secretary Spauldlng today said:

Most parts of the list of outside securities were relatively quiet yesterday, but the activity of the steel stocks made the day's total a fairly large one. These issues were in better demand than they had been for ten days or more, and they all advanced considerably. With less active trading, some other issues advanced substantially, the market being generally strong in sympathy with the Stock Exchange market.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., March 16 -- Out of twenty-four propositions for a site for the new Carnegie Library, the committee in charge finally decided upon a lot 60 by 99 feet beside the public square at a cost of $5,500. Their action was announced Thursday, and as the site is situated in the upper portion of the business district, it created intense dissatisfaction among the downtown residents.

The "upholstress" has come to town. Or she has been in town for some time, and people are now beginning to learn that there is such a person. It is a fad that a great many New York women have adopted the past Winter. They send for the upholstress, who goes to the house and will upholster the furniture from garret to cellar, if necessary, at the rate of $2 a day.

TOLEDO, March 16. -- The first steps were taken to-day in the organization of a new National golfer's association, which will be very democratic and will give a membership to every golf player desiring one. The movement is the result of the refusal of the United States Golf Association to give the Toledo Golf Club a membership on the ground that it uses a public golf links.

The usual two performances of opera took place at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday. In the afternoon Puccini'a "Tosca" was performed and in the evening Verdi's "La Traviata" was sung. At both performance's the audiences were very large and warmly enthusiastic. To a stranger this might have seemed a "most amusing paradox," for these two operas, though both products of Italy, are diametrically opposed in spirit, form, and style.

The old French vineyards that for so many centuries furnished our people with their national drink, which was both quickening and refining, occupied 2,500,000 hectares, and yielded every year an average of 55,000,000 hectoliters of wine. We might say that, in respect to the generations which lived some 25 years ago, the capital of the first founding of this enormous source of riches was entirely liquidated.

Councilman Herman Sulzer, manager of the Harlem River Park and Casino, who had a host of friends and acquaintances, died in the residence portion of his place of amusement, on Second Avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street, at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. His body was hardly cold in death when some one sent a messenger to 141 West One Hundred and Tenth Street.

The early Spring seems to be the season for the dissemination of doctrines and theories relating to that everlasting "decline of the drama" as well as for coughs and colds. Mr. Howells generally sets forth his opinions on contemporary theatricals at this time of the year, and he has been unusually entertaining in his pronouncements in both his Editor's Easy Chair of Harper's and his article in The North American Review.

One of the great Wagnerian singers asked me a few days ago whether it was correct for Wotan to wear a hat in "Siegfried," or if hats were known at such an early period. My answer was impromptu, but since that time I have thought of the matter. Hats were worn by the ancients. The slaves in Rome wore them long before the Christian era, and even the nobles wore them when traveling.

The fish is called by the Maories the kakawai. Its habitat is very extensive in the North Island, and it may be found on the Wairarapa Plains, the Forty-mile Bush, , New Zealand. It is generally discovered when a man is digging out rabbits or making post holes in the Summer time, and it lies at a depth of a foot or two feet under the soil.

Although a busy man of affairs, ex-State Senator Frederick G. Gibbs for more than a quarter of a century has found time in the whirl of politics and business to devote considerable attention to the fine arts.

There seems to be a strong tendency among some classes in England to turn at last to JOSEPH CHAMBERLAIN'S device, a British Customs Union, or Zollverein, to raise the heavy sums required by the Government and at the same time to satisfy the longings of the colonies to secure trade advantages in the markets of the mother country.

Wall Street has a good times stock market in reality. It is evident in activity, it is evident in strength -- it is evident in many ways exceptional; and even the professional speculators of the Stock Exchange seem finally ready to join in the improving movement of the security market.

Testimony was taken at the office of Corbin Corbin, in Jersey City, yesterday in the suit brought by the Honduras Company of Georgia against the Honduras Syndicate, now pending in the United States District Court at Trenton, N.J.

It has been a very gay week indeed. The Celebration of Mi-Careme is rather an innovation. Last year and the year before one large entertainment was given, but this Winter there were two noteworthy affairs on the same night, and from all over the country at the different Winter resorts came stories of dances and other large functions being held.

NATICK, Mass., March 16. -- The depositors of the Natick Five-Cent Savings Bank to-day continued the run which was begun yesterday, and the line-up in front of the door began as early as 8:30. By 10 o'clock there were nearly seventy persons who were waiting to draw their money.

Miles,. Ternina and Olitzka, MM. Cremonini, Campanari, and Plancon will appear in an operatic matinee at the ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Monday afternoon, March 25, at 2:30, when a novel and very interesting programme under the direction of Signor Mancinelli will be given. The novelty will consist of excerpts of Puccini's opera," Tosca," by consent of Mr. Maurice Grau.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The change in the condition of the coiled spring and the dissipation of its energy being accomplished by chemical means, it would seem that it is the chemical or physical structure thereof to which our attention should be directed in endeavoring to account for these phenomena.

If quarters for servants had anything to do with the settlement of the servant question, it would be practically settled for people of wealth. The servants' quarters of the modern house are everything that can be desired, and contain every hygienic comfort and convenience.
The final games in the Harlem Navy and the Commercial Bowling Leagues were rolled during the past week, leaving only the ties yet to be decided.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Upon my return to the city after an absence of several days, my attention has been called to your editorial of March 3, "Expert Testimony in Criminal Cases."

The present theatrical week brings three new plays to the city, the first of which will be produced to-morrow evening at the Lyceum Theatre, when Capt. R. Marshall's one-act play entitled "The Shades of Night "will be presented. The play will follow the farce which has been the attraction for the last two weeks at this house, the curtain going up on "The Lash of a Whip" at 8:15 instead of 8:30.
A.S. HATHAWAY, formerly Assistant Engineer of the Newburg Fire Department, is dead at Walden, N.Y., aged sixty-three years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Several times recently I have read statements from different people to the effect that the demand for capable young men in business is greater than the supply. The case of Mr. Perkins has also been quoted to show that the chances of success are greater than is commonly supposed.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 16 -- Beneath a canopy of black, placed in the rotunda of the Capitol Building, the casket covered with the silken folds of the Stars and Stripes, surrounded by thousands of blossoms, while over all swung the great battle flag that flew from the warship Indiana during the naval battle of Santiago, the body of ex-President Harrison lay in state for nine hours to-day.
The Central Manufacturers' Mutual Insurance Company of Ohio has applied for a license to do business in the State of Massachusetts.

BANGOR, March 16 -- Ruel Clement, a well-to-do young farmer of Levant, near Bangor, died the other day, and his death undoubtedly resulted from blind faith in the efficacy of prayers as taught by the sect known as "The Holy Ghost and Us" community, which has its headquarters at the famous "Shiloh Temple," in Durham, Androscoggin County.

ELLSWORTH, Me., March 16. -- The greater portion of the crew of the Belmont cup defender will be Maine sailors, twentytwo having been selected by Capt. Rhoades. Six of the number sailed on the Columbia two years ago, while the rest have all had considerable experience in handling boats and sails.

I do not propose to apologize for the looting that was done in China. If I did I should have to begin with the Chinese themselves. In every town from Taku to Peking the first evidences of looting bore the imprint of Chinese enterprise. As the allied troops advanced, vast caravans of carts and coolies made away with the wealth and treasures of the cities.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes the payment of the mortgage.
Enthusiastic followers of the trail turned out in goodly numbers yesterday in the weekly runs over hill and dale.
Mrs. Carrie Cabus, the wife of a retired carriage manufacturer, living on the second floor of the flathouse 352 West Eighteenth Street, went into the kitchen of their apartment last evening.

The trainmen employed on the Brooklyn Bridge were thrown into a panic yesterday by a new move on the part of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company. At 9 o'clock Saturday night, the hour when the number of local bridge trains is reduced to three of two cars each, nine Inspectors of the trolley company were placed on the platforms, and the motormen told to instruct them in the operation of the cars.

The American liner New York of the International Navigation Company came into port last night twenty-four hours late with her port propeller useless and over a score of her steerage passengers and stewards more or less injured owing to an escape of ammonia from her refrigerating plant, the two accidents having followed each other on two consecutive days, Thursday and Friday of last week.

BELVIDERE, N.J., March 17. -- That part of the town known as "Harlem," on East Water Street, was thrown into intense excitement this morning by the appearance of a neatly attired woman on her front porch, with a cheerful smile on her face, but with a look of determination. Her right hand was concealed beneath an embroidered apron.

From The Washington Star. "Most billiard cues," said a New York manufacturer the other day, are made in two pieces, the cue proper and the handle. The cue is made generally of maple, and the butt, which is wedge-shaped, is inserted into a handle of rosewood, snakewood, ebony, mahogany, walnut, or some other fancy dark wood, which is cut to dovetail with the long part.

Local horsemen took full advantage of the balmy atmosphere yesterday morning and flocked to the Speedway in sufficient numbers to guarantee the many pedestrians on the walks brushes in plenty. Although the footing was a trifle heavy in spots, along the upper stretch few could resist the temptation to step their favorites, and the result was some excellent sport.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 17. -- Surrounded by fully 15,000 of his fellow-citizens, the body of Benjamin Harrison was this afternoon interred in the family lot, in Crown Hill Cemetery. Close by the grave were the members of his family, President McKinley and other visitors of distinction, and the more intimate friends of Gen. Harrison.

The prompt offer of Mr. HEWITT to supply two of the sites for circulating libraries on what may be called the Carnegie foundation is an indication of the co-operation that may be expected from the philanthropic citizens of New York.

It is announced from Pittsburg, on what purports to be the authority of his intimate friends, that Mr. ANDREW CARNEGIE purposes to found a technical college in or near that city with an endowment of twenty-five millions of dollars. For many reasons we hope this report is untrue.

BERLIN, March 17. -- Responding to numerous favorable impulses, the Berlin Boerse was decidedly strong last week. Speculators were disposed to take an optimistic view of South African developments, expecting an early end of the Anglo-Boer war, with a buoyant effect upon the business situation throughout Europe.

The presence of Police Inspector Kane, Capt. Schmittberger, and thirty detectives and policemen stationed around the various dance halls, concert pavilions, and similar resorts that reign in the neighborhood known as "Little Coney Island," One Hundred and Tenth Street, between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway, yesterday afternoon, caused a decided change in the atmosphere of that locality.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding weeK last year. In the case of the exports of General merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

WASHINGTON, March 17. -- Najib Taky-Ud-Deen is the name of an officer in the American Army. He has been an officer for about two weeks, and the following appeared in the army orders on Friday along with the customary lot of orders about officers with such plebeian and ordinary names as John and Thomas.

THE MINING STRIKES IN FRANCE. -- The mining strikes in France and the fact that the Government, through its Minister of Commerce, M. Millerand, is committed to the attempt to bring about some radical legislation on the subject, which will improve the position of the employed and tend toward making strikes less frequent and demoralizing, call attention to the development of the mining industry in that country.

The women of New York, through 2,000 or more of them who gathered at Carnegie Hall in mass meeting yesterday afternoon, uttered no uncertain protest against the protected vice of New York City. Ringing speeches were made by a number of representative women, and resolutions voicing their sentiments were adopted.

WINDSOR, England, March 17. -- With King Edward's special permission a deputation of the Royal Munster Fusiliers, including Gen. Laurine and Col. Johnston. visited the mausoleum at Frogmore this afternoon and laid a beautiful Celtic cross of shamrocks and lilies upon the tomb of Queen Victoria in memory of St. Patrick and of Queen Victoria's command a year ago to the Irish soldiers to wear the shamrock.

That men who belong to prominent and exclusive clubs are in the employ of gambling house keepers is the belief of Justice William Travers Jerome. This belief is strengthened by a list he has secured of well-known men who are deeply in debt to the proprietor of one of these illegal resorts. Among the debtors is a Columbia University student, who owes no less than $3,800, and is unable to pay.

Senator PLATT continues to predict that another police bill will be passed at this session of the Legislature. He does not now stick to the notion of a State Constabulary, such as alone would satisfy him early in the year, but is said to be contemplating a revival of the old metropolitan plan.
LONDON, March 18. -- The Tien-Tsin correspondent of The Standard says:
LONDON, March 18. -- Dr. Morrison, wiring to The Times from Peking, says:
CHICAGO, March 17. -- The Tribune tomorrow will say:

The phenomenal strength displayed by the market on Saturday, actual buoyancy being maintained up to the very close, encourages Wall Street in the belief that the present week will witness a continued demonstration of strength. There is expectation, indeed, that at the opening to-day prices in not a few stocks will be well above Saturday's close -- and this because of the knowledge that coming developments will warrant these and even much higher prices.

The critical auditors who usually attend the meetings of the People's Institute had no knotty problems to propound to the speakers at the celebration of the institute's third anniversary last evening, who included William H. Baldwin. Chairman of the Committee of Fifteen: Robert Fulton Cutting, Edwin Markham, the poet; William E. Dodge. Prof. Sprague Smith, and H.A. Goulden. Mr. Baldwin told things on the platform concerning the future plans of the committee.

The case of attempted assault against Mrs. Ida Weimann, the friend of the late Councilman Herman Sulzer, upon his widow was called yesterday morning in Harlem Court before Magistrate Mayo after an adjournment from Saturday.

Copyright, 1901, THE HEW YORK TIMES. LONDON, March 17. -- We are still twirling our thumbs and waiting on events. One week looks like another in the money market. It begins with an effort on the part of bill brokers to drive the bank rate down another 1/2 per cent. Wednesday sees this effort exhausted and the brokers in a state of repentance.

MANILA, P.I., Feb. 17. -- Ever since the occupation of Manila by the Americans there has Been an undercurrent of hostility toward them in the English business circles. This has been assumed to be due to the fact that, prior to the arrival of the Americans, the English had almost a monopoly in certain lines of business transacted from this port, and that they naturally resent the arrival of a keen and powerful rival.

Perhaps the most useful result of the American occupation of Cuba during the period of nation building which is still in progress is seen in the sanitary reforms which have been begun and, as far as time has permitted, carried forward to a point making their successful completion a simple matter of following lines already marked out.

Charles Freedman, a young married man, living at 860 Broadway, Williamsburg, in what is supposed to have been a fit of temporary insanity, attempted to murder his family last night. The victims in the case, only one of whom is dead, were his wife, Ellen, his three-year-old daughter Ellen, and a baby girl, Jessie, the last-named of whom was brained and instantly killed.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, March 17. -- News has reached here that the United States Consular Agent at Barcelona, Venezuela, Ignacio H. Baiz, has been arrested by Venezuelan officials and imprisoned without adequate cause. This is the second time he has been treated in this fashion within the last five months, and he will resign unless protected by the Washington Government.

PALATKA, Fla., March 17. -- Two Pullman sleeping cars, the Tabita and Elmer of train No. 32 of the Plant system. Tampa to Jacksonville, were completely burned at an early hour this mormlng at Buffalo Bluff, seven miles from this city. All that remains or them is a mass of twisted iron, the wheels and trucks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Was the late water famine unavoidable, and what is the remedy against such recurrences? While asking these questions, I will also express my sentiments upon them. I fail to see why any portion of our city should be subjected to the periodical distress and discomfort which of late it has suffered in consequence of insufficiency of water.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 18 -- A theft of $3,000 worth of diamonds from Edwards Sloan, wholesale jewelers, and a threat to kidnap the young son of George H. Edwards unless $1,000 should be paid immediately for the return of the gems, is a story with which the local detectives are wrestling .

BALTIMORE, March 33 -- Sidney Scott, aged sixteen years, of Brooklyn, N.Y., who ran away from home a year ago, is detained at Police Headquarters here for his parents. The lad has had all the adventure he wants, and is anxious to get back home. He says he worked on farms in Northern New York until October last year, when he came to this city.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 18 -- The family fight for the millions of the late tea merchant, George Francis Gilman, began in the Probate Court here this afternoon. The half-blood relatives were not represented in court, and the much-vaunted basis for the claim of Mrs. Blakeley Hall to the entire estate of the deceased failed to materialize.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The canal legislation recommended by Gov. Odell in his message to the Legislature last week will fall to bring about any great increase of traffic on the canals unless it is enforced by the passage of the Remsen bill, or some similar bill. This Is the bill which removes the fifty-thousand-dollar capitalization limit upon corporations formed to do business upon the canals.

In its broadening tendencies and in show of buoyancy the security market continues to favor those prophets who have been insisting that, business conditions being all right. Wall Street was in for a further breaking of Good Times records. In yesterday's market the volume of trading ran beyond anything recently reached, and advances in quotations were generally the rule.

The twelve prisoners taken in the Committee of Fifteen's Sunday night raids on alleged gambling houses at 132A West Seventy-ninth Street, 63 West Thirty-sixth Street, and 10 Madison Street, were haled before Justice Jerome in his Law Library, Magistrate's Court, yesterday.

A case came up before Magistrate Cornell, in the West Side Police Court, yesterday, the decision of which will affect every bicycle rider and motor vehicle owner in the State. The question raised was whether the amended laws demand that bicycles and motor vehicles shall be equipped with bells wherewith to give warning to pedestrians and others.

SAN JOSE, Cal., March 18 -- Burton Downing of the Garden City Wheel Club has broken the world's five-mile amateur straightaway road record over the Gilroy course. His time was 8:48. The record of 9:01 was formerly held by Bunt Smith.

Encouraged by the Ramapo repeal legislation, which, it was largely instrumental in securing, the Merchants' Association will to-day begin an agitation in favor of immediate measures for securing for New York additional supplies o water in anticipation of future needs With this movement we are entirely in sympathy, provided it is not permitteed to obscure the more pressing issue o; minimizing the existing waste.

A Metropolitan Police bill, to be passed and approved probably before the close of the current month, was agreed upon yesterday at a two hours' conference between Senator Platt and Gov. Odell. The district to be embraced will include the counties of New York, Kings, Queens, Richmond, Nassau, Westchester, and a part of Putnam.

Perhaps the very best showing that could follow the various demonstrations that have been made of the weak points of the British Army administration is that which has actually been made. That is the showing that the British people are making of a willingness to learn from experience. That is the one possible compensation for an experience which has been so bitter.

BERLIN, March 18 -- A sensation has been caused by an article sent to Germany, through the Russian semi-official telegraph agency, by M. de Witte. Russian Minister of Finance. Various interpretations are placed upon it.

Ex-Senator David B. Hill and Bird S. Coler were the principal speakers at the annual dinner of the St. Patrick's Society of Brooklyn at the Pouch Gallery last night. Mr. Hill responded to the toast "The United States." His speech was an arraignment of the English policy in South Africa and a criticism of the non-interference of the United States.

The Authors' Club entertained Frederic Harrison, the well-known British publicist and President of the London Positivist Committee, in their rooms in Carnegle Hall last evening. George Cary Eggleston presided. There were about fifty or sixty authors and their friends present.

BOSTON, March 18 -- An important decision relating to copyright was given by Judge Colt of the United States Circuit Court to-day sustaining demurrers filed by the respondents in a case in which a publishing house sought to obtain damages from two of the large business concerns of this city for alleged infringement in handling "The Professor at the Breakfast Table," by Oliver Wendell Holmes, and "The Minister's Wooing," by Harriet Beeeher Stowe.

ALBANY, March 18 -- The bill introduced by Assemblyman Lynn to amend the public health law in relation to the use of type in books, newspapers, or serial literature, by giving to the Board of Health the power to regulate the size of type used, came up in the Assembly to-night on the order of second reading.

One of the largest gatherings that ever crowded into the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall was assembled there last night at the meeting of the Armstrong Association, held to raise funds for the Tuskegee (Ala.) Normal and Industrial Institute, at which Bishop Potter, Morris K. Jesup, and William H. Baldwin, Jr., the Chairman of the Committee of Fifteen, made speeches and Paul Laurence Dunbar read several of his poems.

The domestic troubles of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Van Dyck Paine are being aired to a considerable extent before Justice Freedman, in Part VI., Special Term of the Supreme Court. The trial of the case began yesterday. It should have started last Thursday, but just as it was being called Mrs. Paine fainted, and then went into convulsions.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Gov. Odell returned to Albany to-night. When asked if his conference with Senator Platt indicated any change in the police situation, he said it did not. The situation, he said, was the same now as it had been since the passage of the Single Commissioner bill.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 18 -- The students organized yesterday what was intended to be an imposing demonstration in front of the Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan, the occasion being the anniversary of the death of Vetrora, the girl who committed suicide some years ago in a dungeon of the political prison in the fortress of St. Peter and St. Paul in order to escape infamous persecutions.

LONDON, March 19 -- The officials of the Foreign Office have not yet received official confirmation of Russia's alleged backdown in regard to Manchuria, Turkestan, and Mongolia, as Intimated in the dispatch to The Times, and inquiries on the subject are being made at St. Petersburg and Peking.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 18 -- The condition of Eugene S. Reynal. suffering from scarlet fever at Gedney Farm Manor, the residence of Howard Willetts, where he was married on Saturday to Miss Adelaide Fitzgerald, who is also a fever patient, was pronounced very favorable this afternoon by Dr. H.E. Schmid. who now considers him out of danger.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- The arrest of Ignacio H. Baiz, the United States Consular Agent at Barcelona, Venezuela, has not yet been reported to the State Department. Baiz was arrested some time ago. and Minister Loomis then reported the fact to the State Department. He was directed promptly to secure an apology from Venezuela.

An unexpected feature in the two-mile bicycle race last night in the Twelfth Regiment athletic games held in the armory. Columbus Avenue and Sixty-second Street, added considerable excitement and consternation to competitors and spectators alike. The armory track is twelve laps to the mile and decidedly tricky for bicycle riding, and falls invariably occur in every set of games.

The annual dinner of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, which was held at Delmonico's last evening, brought together a large number of men prominent in city, State and National life. There were nearly 500 persons present in all. It was the one hundred and seventeenth annual banquet of the society, and was characterized by the eloquence and cheerfulness for which these affairs have become known.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- From an authoritative source the information is obtained that the occasion for the various reports about Pension Commissioner Evans's retirement are based first upon his tender of resignation, along with many other heads of bureaus, at the time of the inauguration.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- A gigantic trolley scheme, which is to give Philadelphia 3-cent fares and connect it directly with New York by means of an independent line of electric railway, is being worked up by a number of capitalists and trolley promoters, with A. L. Johnson of New York and Robert E .Wright of Alientown at their head.

INVALID CHARITABLE BEQUESTS. -- William C. Herring, who died in 1894, by his will made charitable bequests to various organizations, some incorporated and some unincorporated. In an action brought by E.H. Pratt, as administrator, with the will annexed for the construction of the instrument, several of the bequests were held good at the Special Term.

Lawyer H.W. Bates, charged by numerous persons with taking money from them under pretense of being able to place them on the police force and Fire Department, obtained an adjournment of his case until to-morrow in the Centre Street Court yesterday.

The fourth and fifth sets in the tournament for the championship tennis doubles of the Young Men's Christian Association were played yesterday in the gymnasium court of the clubhouse, when W.D. Bourne and C.A. Blood met E.T. Price and D.N. Smallwood, and L.W. Ely and H.P. Berens met George Wilson and J.C. Wilson, Jr.

CHICAGO, March 18 -- Wheat broke sharply to-day under a deluge of long holdings. May closing with a net decline of 1 1/8c as a result of the bearishness of the day's news. May wheat opened 3/8@5/8c lower, at 77 1/8c to 76 7/8c, with long interests endeavoring to rid themselves of holdings which suddenly became worth less to them when they summed up the situation early.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Assemblyman Hyatt C. Hatch of Steuben County, who introduced the bill making all the assessments for Greater New York reviewable by the Board of Tax Commissioners, has introduced some other measures which have excited comment. One is a bill providing for a State curfew.

PHILADELPHIA, March 18 -- Philadelphia to-day caught the fever, which broke out in New York, and the tendency here was upward in everything except the Readings. The greatest strength was in Union Traction and Philadelphia. Responding to the move in the New York steel stocks, all the minor issues of that family hardened.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 18 -- C.S. Francis, now Minister to Greece, has secured the services of James Ten Eyck to coach his son, John M. Francis, in single sculling this Spring. The new coach will come in a private capacity and will reach Ithaca May 1.

The accumulation of orders in the steel stocks at the opening of the outside market yesterday resulted for a time in all other issues being neglected. Indeed, throughout the whole day the stocks of the United States Steel Corporation were the centre of Interest, and the transactions in them far overshadowed those in all other issues.

The fine weather prompted many to remain in the country. Lake-wood, Tuxedo, and many of the country houses were filled over Sunday. In town everything wore an air of Lenten quiet in the morning many attended the memorial services for the late Fernando Yznaga at the Church of the Transfiguration.

ROMBLON, Romblon Island, March 17 (by mail from Boac, Island of Marinduque, March 16) -- The question of attaching the Island of Marinduque to the Province of Tayabas, discussed by the American Philippines Commission since their arrival here, has been decided in the negative. The sentiment of the people was wholly in favor of forming a separate province.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Private John H. Schmidt, Company A. Thirty-sixth Volunteer Infantry, was convicted by courtmartial at Lingayan, P.I., of murder, and sentenced to death by hanging. The President has commuted the sentence to dishonorable discharge and confinement at hard labor for life.

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- Senator Stewart has never been conspicuous as an admirer of Great Britain, and he is not at all likely to approve any course of action that would tend to give Great Britain any advantage over the United States. His talk, therefore, about the failure of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty is all the more interesting.

Eight Columbia crews took their initial spin on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon under fair conditions. The water was smooth, but the wind was bleak, so that the new rowing suits covering the men from neck to heels, were much appreciated.

ALBANY, March 18 -- A large number of spectators gathered in the Assembly Chamber at to-night's session. Mr. Harburger of New York secured recognition from the Speaker, and for the third time asked the Speaker to Insist that the Attorney General furnish the House with an opinion as to whether as legislator can draw two salaries from the State while serving as such, in accordance with a resolution offered by him.

ALBANY, March 18 -- Andrew Carnegie's gift of $3,200,000 to New York City for public library use may be lawfully accepted if a bill introduced by Assemblyman Price of Kings to-night becomes a law. The bill amends the Public Library jet applying to New York, by providing as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 18 -- There is a divergence of opinion in two of the official publications of the State Department which has led some zealous pro-Boers to declare that the United States has officially recognized the annexation of the Transvaal and the Orange Free State in advance of any other nation.

A conference was held in Mayor Van Wyck's office yesterday to discuss the details involved in the acceptance of Andrew Carnegie's gift of $5,200,000 to the city for sixty-five public libraries. There were present Mayor Van Wyck. Controller Coler. Corporation Counsel Whalen, Deputy Controller Levey, and George L. Rives, one of the Trustees of the New York Public Library.

Christian W. Feigenspan, Jr., of Newark defeated Thomas W. Morfey of Queens L.I., in a 100-bird match for $100 a side at the Inter State Park yesterday afternoon, killing 95 birds to Morfey's 90. Feigenspan missed three birds and two died out of bounds, while Morfey missed six and hao four die outside.
BOSTON, Mass., March 18 -- Thomas W. Lawson to-night puts forth the following statement:

The popular conception of the incorrigible boy was overturned yesterday in the Harlem Police Court, when Edward Schier, fourteen years old, of 500 West One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Mayo. The prisoner's last escapade was the stealing of a minister's watch, but he didn't look as if he would do such a wicked thing.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@63c. There were no sales.
BOSTON, Mass., March 18 -- Thomas W. Lawson to-night puts forth the following statement:

The popular conception of the incorrigible boy was overturned yesterday in the Harlem Police Court, when Edward Schier, fourteen years old, of 500 West One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street, was arraigned before Magistrate Mayo. The prisoner's last escapade was the stealing of a minister's watch, but he didn't look as if he would do such a wicked thing.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 61 1/2@63c. There were no sales.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 19. -- A murder was committed late last night at Kensico about three miles north of here. Damieno Sanbastino, an Italian, aged thirty-five and unmarried, was shot in the mouth with a gun by another Italian named P. Notali, who has fled.

BERLIN, March 19. -- In the debate in the Reichstag to-day, on the third reading of the budget, Count von Bulow replied to a criticism of his recent speech by Prince Bismarck. The latter had said that the Chancellor insisted too much on Germany's interests in Manchuria, and that Germany's interests would have suffered even if Kiao-Chou had not been leased.

CLEVELAND, March 19. -- The Emperor of Austria has made Theodore Kundtz of Cleveland a Knight of the Order of Franz Josef, one of the highest non-hereditary Austrian honors. The decoration is believed to be the second conferred upon a citizen of the United States, Dr. Gerster of New York having received a similar decoration in 1893 for his work in assisting destitute Hungarian immigrants.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Wu Ting-Fang, the Chinese Minister, delivered the convocation address of the University of Chicago at the Studebaker Theatre this afternoon. His subject was "Chinese Civilization," and a large and representative audience heard him.
Dr. JOHN SARGENT, the oldest physician in Jefferson County, N.Y., is dead at Woodville, aged eighty-seven years.

PHILADELPHIA, March 19. -- The Philadelphia market showed the usual indifference to the buoyancy in New York. Exceptions were shown in Consolidated Lake Superior, the Readings, and Cambria Steel, in which advances ranging up to 3/4 per cent. were experienced. There was considerable activity in United States Steel common, though the stock at no time reached the curb figure in New York.

Under the auspices of the Imperial Council of the Order of the Mystic Shrine and with the protection of about three score of policemen, funeral services over the body of the late Councilman Herman Sulzer, owner of Sulzer's Harlem River Park, were held yesterday afternoon in the Scottish Rite Hall, at Madison Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19. -- Gov. Voorhees gave the Legislature a surprise this afternoon by sending to both houses a vigorous message calling attention to violations throughout the State of the Constitional amendment against gambling, and submitting the draft of a bill for the Legislature's consideration and passage if the bill met with approval.

LONDON, March 20. -- The Bight Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, Secretary of State for the Colonies, informed the House of Commons yesterday afternoon that Commandant Gen. Botha had rejected the peace terms offered to him.

Coroner Jacob E. Bausch and Coroners Physician Philip F. O'Hanlon yesterday made an examination of the body of Mrs. Carrie Cabus, wife of Joseph Cabus, of 352 West Eighteenth Street, whose death Sunday night was reported by the police of the West Thirty-seventh Street Station as being the result of an attack made upon her by the pet fox terrier of the household while she was lying on the floor in a fit.

Trading in the United States Steel stocks on the curb yesterday broke all records in these issues, and as other parts of the list also showed considerable activity, the day was one of the largest in the history of the outside market.
