All the steel stocks were much more active than on Monday, and at the same time showed great strength, all of them ending the day considerably above the previous day's prices.

-- Now The Poughkeepsie Eagle takes up the defense of the Poughkeepsie musical critics who differed so radically from those of New York as to the merits of the Leipsic Philharmonic Orchestra, and it is pleasant to note that The Eagle, unlike one of its neighbors, can discuss a difference of opinion without assuming as a premise that disagreement with itself is convincing evidence of criminality.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- The State Department has received from United States Consuls Fowler at Che-Foo and Ragsdale, at Tien-Tsin, reports intended to show the effect of the Boxer troubles in North China upon United States trade with particular regard to what Americans lost in America through the outbreak, rather than in China.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Probably no two persons to whom wealth does not belong will agree in all respects as to the proper distribution of it for civic or other purposes, but that Andrew Carnegie has made a magnificent offer to the metropolis, which ought to be immediately accepted, it seems to me, there cannot be the shadow of a doubt.

The City of New York added 20,000 gallons a day to its water supply yesterday. It was done by means of a little digging on Beaver Street, and finally by plugging up a service pipe which should have been plugged up at some period more than eight years ago. The leak was in the vault under the Corn Exchange Bank Building, through which at least 59,500,000 gallons of Corton water have been wasted.

The former Commissioners of Police have plainly been guilty of a cruel and outrageous fraud with reference to the recent promotion of certain Sergeants to the position of Captain. The facts are given in another column as they are presented in a memorial of the New York Civil Service Reform Association to the Civil Service Commission at Albany, with a petition that the legal powers of the commission be used to secure a thorough investigation.
WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 19. -- At a meeting of the Board of Trade to-night the following communication was addressed to T.D. Nichols, President of District No. 1, United Mine Workers of America:

Lawyer Benjamin Steinhardt, representing William Campbell, arrested in The. Alien's poolroom, at 80 Sixth Avenue, on March 4, astonished Justice Jerome and Assistant District Attorneys Gans and Schurman by an unexpected argument during the prisoner's hearing, charged with violating Section 351 of the Penal Code, yesterday.

LONDON, March 20. -- Some of yesterday's afternoon newspapers said the Tien-Tsin difficulty had been arranged. It was added that the arrangement enabled the British to proceed with the construction of the railroad siding, but, if Russia's concession proved to be earlier than that of Great Britain, the latter was to acknowledge the claim of Russia.

TIEN-TSIN, March 19. -- Regarding the attack made by a number of excited French soldiers on some members of the Sikh regiment on Sunday in the French concession, Gen. Lorn Campbell says it was merely a childish outbreak against the orders of their own General, who had forbidden the French soldiers to enter the British concession.

Unless plans miscarry, a complete change in the policy of the Metropolitan Opera House will occur shortly after the close of the operatic season on April 29, when grand opera performances given by the finest artists in the world will give place to vaudeville at prices ranging from 15 to 50 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Should the demands made by the United States upon Cuba, in the initial stage of the organization of the Cuban Government, be acceded to by the Cubans, that island would become the ward of Uncle Sam.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., March 19. -- The insurrection of the convict miners in the State shaft at Lansing was brought to a close at 11:30 o'clock to-night and the mutinous convicts are being placed in their cells as fast as they can be brought to the surface. The imprisoned guards have been released and are again above the surface.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 19. -- For several weeks past the State Civil Service Commission has had before it charges made by the Civil Service Reform Association relative to appointments of Police Captains in New York City. President William M. Collier of the commission was seen to-night and asked what action the commission had decided to take upon the Reform Association's memorial.

CHICAGO, March 19. -- Miss Edna C. McCoy, daughter of Mrs. Alice Halloway-McCoy of the Auditorium Annex, was married to-day to Francis Ware of New York, the Rev. Mr. Merrill of the Sixth Presbyterian Church officiating. Mr. and Mrs. Ware have gone to Iowa for a brief visit, after which they will leave for California, returning to Chicago about May 1.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 19. -- In the Republican Senatorial caucus to-night David E. Thompson of Lincoln was nominated for the short term vacancy on the seventh ballot, receiving 50 votes, 5 more than necessary under the rules of the caucus.

ALBANY, March 19. -- When the House reconvened this morning Mr. Harburger in an impassioned speech moved to discharge the Committee on Electricity. Gas, and Water Supply from the further consideration of his bill for cheaper gas for New York City. He accused the Chairman of the committee, Mr. Rogers of Broome, of "being owned body and soul by the gas companies."

To-day marks the practical completion of two most important financial events. One is the closing of the deposit of the steel stocks of the constituent companies which go to form the United States Steel Corporation. The other event is the closing of the subscriptions for $40,000,000 worth of Union Pacific 4 per cent. convertible gold bonds to be issued in payment for the stock acquired of the Southern Pacific Company.

BALTIMORE, March 19. -- The stock market to-day manifested the same propensities noticeable Monday, except that the recuperative tendencies of the Maryland Brewing Company's issues were not as pronounced. The local speculators seem to have been diverted by Wall Street's activities, for they are turning their operations in that direction rather than into the home market.
LONDON, March 20. -- Dr. Morrison, wiring to The Times from Peking, says:

CHICAGO, March 19. -- There is uneasiness here among speculators in provisions over a report that two operators have secured control of the pork market. It is confidently announced in certain quarters that there will be a "squeeze" in the May delivery. One of the manipulators of the deal is said to be a prominent packer.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 19. -- Judge Nobbs of the Bridgeport Probate Court appointed the Bridgeport Trust Company sole administrator on the estate of the late George Francis Gilman to-day. The appointment was made in the face of strenuous opposition on the part of Attorneys Stiles Judson.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Mr. Mariscal, Secretary of Foreign Relations of Mexico, in a telegram from the Mexican capital dated yesterday, says to Ambassador Azpiroz: "President Diaz's health is completely restored; his illness never presented any alarming symptoms nor indicated brain disorder.

ALBANY, March 10. -- To all inquiries about the police situation to-day Gov. Odell returned his stereotyped answer: "Nothing at all to say." The Governor is evidently determined to maintain an eloquent silence until such time as he is ready to act, which, according to the best-informed opinion here, will not be until "something more breaks loose in New York."

More tears, considerable laughter, some anger, and letters and poetry in liberal quantities were the features of the second day's hearing, before Justice Freedman, in the Supreme Court, of the Paine divorce case.

The sale of the world's champion trotter, The Abbot, 2:03 1/4, for $40,000 to "Fred" Gerken, was completed practically yesterday, as the latest development in the negotiations pending for the arrangement of a match between that great horse and the fast young trotter Boralma, owned by the Boston millionaire, Thomas W. Lawson.

No class of people in the city as a class are more generally interested in the proposed liberal gift of Andrew Carnegie than the public school teachers. What they would especially like to see is some way in which a portion of the funds may be used to establish suitable libraries in the public schools of the city for the use of the pupils.

With the Rose Show and numerous dinners and teas and luncheons, it was very gay yesterday. In fact, Lent seems to be growing much more lively as the Passion tide advances and from the number of engagements ahead, it would look as if there will be even some social affairs in Holy Week itself.
TUTUILA, Samoa, March 5. -- The following is a translation of a letter addressed by the people of Tutuila, through their Governors, to President McKinley:

All work on the new parts of the building of the American Museum of Natural History, at Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West, has been suspended, and an investigation is being made of the contracts awarded, without authority, it is claimed, by the former Superintendent of Buildings at the museum.

It is not long since the American policy in China was strongly disapproved in the English press as half-hearted, timid, and vacillating, and not equal to the demands of the situation. In this criticism The London Spectator joined, though it did not indulge in the contemptuous tone adopted by some of the other papers, and notably by The London Saturday Review.
In the tournament of the New York Interclub Bowling League the Knickerbocker Athletic Club bowlers won two of three games with the Harlem Wheelmen on the Harlem Wheelmen alleys. The scores:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., March 19. -- The will of Mrs. Love M. Palmer, widow of Dr. Palmer, formerly a professor in the University of Michigan, was filed for probate to-day. It contains specific legacies amounting to $70,500, the greater part of which is divided between the University of Michigan and various missionary societies.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- Secretary of Agriculture Wilson estimated to-day that over $6,000,000 worth of young live stock throughout the country was saved during 1900 by the prompt use of medicine for blackleg sent out by the department.

BOSTON, March 19. -- At the Clearing House this morning, money between the banks was in better supply at 2 1/2 per cent. It was reported that money was offered near the close at 2 per cent. The large lending banks, however, are not quoting below 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 12 1/2 cents discount for cash.

That is a sweetly solemn thought to which The Evening Post yesterday gave utterance. It is the thought that Mr. CARNEGIE'S munificence may lead to the employment of HORGAN SLATTERY to design sixty-five libraries, presumably, though The Post does not say so, with the usual "rake-off" in favor of that eminent private citizen, Mr. JOHN F. CARROLL.

TRENTON, N.J., March 19. -- The Senate to-day passed Senator Wakelee's bill for the better preservation of the Palisades. This bill permits the Palisades Commission to acquire the riparian rights along the river edge and to purchase ground inland for the making of a State park. Mr. Wakelee, the introducer, said this improvement would cost about $500,000 and that New York State would appropriate fourfifths of this amount.

Herbert Kelcey and Effie Shannon acted the two principal characters in a lurid and violent play called "Manon Lescaut" at Wallack's Theatre last evening. Theodore Burt Sayre manufactured the play, which, whatever its defects may be, is at least as worthy of sane consideration as the silly thing called "My Lady Dainty," in which these two popular and comely actors were employed earlier in this season of so many theatrical inanities.

It is directly charged by the Civil Service Reform Association that the promotion to the rank of Captain of sixteen Police Sergeants by the late Board of Commissioners on Dec. 27 last was In direct violation of the law, and the body has addressed a memorial to the State Civil Service Commission urging that the promotions be set aside.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., March 19. -- The will of Gen. Harrison was filed for probate late to-day. He bequeaths to the Union Trust Company, as trustee. If his wife shall survive him, $123,000, to be invested, the interest to be paid to her during the term of her life.

One element active and clearly disclosed in yesterday's market was that some financial interests having most important relations with the security market were desirous of heading off any development which might lead to too much enthusiasm. Repressive influences were exerted, and quotations were forced to stand searching tests.

Senator HILL seems particularly to enjoy that position of "greater freedom and less responsibility" which Mr. GLADSTONE once referred to as the perquisite of one out of office. It is obvious, however, that there ought, in the case of Mr. HILL, to be some sense of responsibility due to the possibility of returning to office and even of aspiring to higher office than he has yet held.
LONDON, March 20. -- The St. Petersburg correspondent of The Daily Express says:

After long and dangerous delay, New Jersey is moving in the matter of better provision than has hitherto been made for the protection of the rapidly growing communities of Essex and Hudson Counties from the consequences of failure to make suitable provision for the sanitary requirements of villages which have expanded into towns and of towns which have grown into cities.
ST. PETERSBURG, March 19. -- Answering a question of the correspondent of The Associated Press, a competent official said to-day:

Considerable interest has been caused in local golf circles over the announcement that has come from Toledo, Ohio, to the effect that the Toledo Golf Club has taken the initiative toward organizing a rival association in opposition to the United States Golf Association. The reason for this step, as the Toledo members themselves admit, is due to the refusal of the larger association to admit their club to membership.
PARIS, March 19. -- Mlle. Sophie Croizette died here this morning.
LONDON, March 19. -- Money was in moderate demand to-day, and supplies were inconsiderable, influenced by calls aggregating u1,250,000. Discounts had a hardening tendency.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, March 19. -- Inquiry at the offices of the Burlington Road elicited an absolute denial that J.J. Hill or the Morgan-Harriman syndicate had secured control of the Burlington system. It was claimed they would have to purchase $90,000,000 worth of stock to secure it, and there are but 80,000 shares on the market, the rest being held by people who would require considerably more than the market price.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 19. -- Serious riots occurred in St. Petersburg to-day on the occasion of a solemn mass in the Cathedral of Our Lady of Kazan for the repose of the soul of M. Bogoliepoff, the Minister of Public Instruction, who was shot and fatally wounded by Karpovitch. The police fired their revolvers, and it is rumored that five students were killed and eighty others either seriously or slightly injured.

WASHINGTON, March 19. -- A distinguished company gathered to-day at the Home for the Aged, under the care of the Little Sisters of the Poor, to serve the midday dinner which always marks the feast of St. Joseph at this institution. The occasion is always made a gala time by the benefactors of the home.

ALBANY, March 20 -- There was a largely attended hearing before the Senate and Assembly Committee on Taxation to-day on the new Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill. The principal argument was made by Lawson Purdy, Secretary of the New York Tax Reform Association. He said:

The Texas and Pacific Railway yesterday issued its annual report for the year ended Dec. 31, 1900. The gross earnings show an increase of 17.48 per cent., and the net earnings an increase of 29.29 per cent, compared with the previous year; while the proportion of expenses to earnings decreased 2.97 per cent.

MARSEILLES, March 20 -- The situation here is very disquieting, owing to the increasingly aggressive attitude of the strikers. During disorders to-day the towns-people were panic-stricken, and stores, restaurants, and cafes were hurriedly closed. The leading thoroughfares of the city were deserted.

BALTIMORE, March 20 -- The market was dominated by the operations in trust companies' shares, the interest centring so absorbingly there as to subject the general list to the effects of neglect. The buying of the trust company securities was first stimulated by the report of the purchase of the Guardian by the Maryland Trust, on the basis of one share of the latter being exchanged for two shares of the former.

"Salammbo" grand opera, in five acts and eight tableaus, words by Camille du Locle, music by Ernest Reyer, was performed at the Metropolitan Opera House last night for the first time in New York. Though this opera is now eleven years old, having been made known to the world at Brussels in 1890, its composer has hitherto been a stranger to this city, but today there will be many inquiries about him.

J.P. Morgan Co., the syndicate managers of the United States Steel Corporation, issued a circular last night to shareholders of the constituent companies, extending the time for the deposit of stocks until April 1, "in view of the fact that there are stockholders who desire to participate in the plan, but who have been unable to deposit the certificates for their stock" within the time which expired yesterday by limitation.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Collector of Customs Bidwell of New York was in the city to-day conferring with Assistant Secretary of the Treasury Spaulding regarding the reorganized conditions at the New York Custom House. He brought figures to show that the duties collected from passengers on four steamers arriving last Thursday, Friday, and Saturday were $22,000 greater than from passengers aboard steamers of the same lines on corresponding days last year.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading of "Firemen and Legislation" an article appeared in your issue of March 13, signed "Cushing Stetson." A more cruel and heartless attack upon firemen is hardly possible. The writer of the same positively does not understand the situation, or he had not been properly instructed.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The joint Committees on Cities of the Senate and Assembly gave the final hearing this afternoon on the proposed revision of the charter. The hearing was not largely attended, and the greatest opposition to the commission's recommendations came from the Republican members of the Board of Aldermen, who through Assemblyman Weekes presented these objections to the changes in which they figure:

It is quite safe to say that the city will gratefully accept Mr. CARNEGIE'S offer, coupled with his conditions. Those conditions will have been imposed in accordance with the sensible rule he has imposed upon himself of not putting himself in the position of supplying that for which there is no evidence of a demand.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- A private cablegram received here to-day from Brussels announces the marriage and death yesterday in that city of Miss Ursula Rose Boudinot, daughter of the late Elias Lewis Boudinot of this city.

Mayor Van Wyck gave a public hearing yesterday on Assemblyman Wilson's bill providing that a commission be appointed to make uniform and codify the laws and usages of the municipal courts and also the laws and rules relating to clerks, Marshals, and other court attendants.

For the first time recently the bear contingent of Stock Exchange traders made aggressive drives yesterday against market quotations. They sold stocks freely and exhibited much adroit generalship; and at one time they seemed to have prices pretty generally inclined downward.

ILOILO, Island of Panay, March 20 -- The Philippine Commission was welcomed on its arrival here to-day by Gen. Hughes and his staff and a number of citizens. The Iloilo Province is prepared for organization and the other provinces, it is believed, will be ready by the time the commission returns from the south.

The will of Councilman Herman Sulzer was filed in the office of the Surrogate late yesterday evening. The will is dated Nov. 11, 1898, and has three codicils attached, dated June 12, 1899; Nov. 12, 1899, and Sept. 17, 1900. Ida Herrmann Weimann and William F. Grell, the Sheriff of New York County, are named as executor and executrix of the will.

ALFRED PELL died at his residence, 15 East Thirty-fifth Street, yesterday after a very short illness. Mr. Pell was born Aug. 6, 1823, and was formerly manager of the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company. Subsequently he became manager of the Commercial Union Fire Insurance Company.

Coroner's Physician O'Hanlon performed an autopsy yesterday on the body of Mrs. Caroline Cabus, who was found dead in her home, at 352 West Eighteenth Street, Sunday night last with several wounds in her neck and with her pet, a fox terrier, at her throat. The result of the autopsy showed that death had resulted from internal hemorrhage resulting from a stab wound in the neck.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Secretary Gage said to-day that the report that he proposed to buy bonds with the increasing surplus was not Justified by anything that he had said about the condition of the Treasury or because he contemplated a bond purchase. There was no such purchase in contemplation, and there would be no immediate use of the surplus in that way.

The Columbia crews practiced as usual on the Harlem yesterday afternoon, but under very disagreeable weather conditions. The strong north wind kicked up quite a sea on the open stretches of the narrow river, and the cold, misty rain which accompanied it chilled and benumbed the men's hands until they had difficulty in handling the oars.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The story of how the farmers of the State sold the Charter Revision Commission a "gold brick" was told to-day before the Senate Committee on Cities at the hearing in the Senate Chamber on the revised charter. The rural member thought it was the best joke he had heard for a long time.

TIEN-TSIN, March 20 -- Ninety British marines arrived here last night from the Taku forts to replace the Indian Guards on the disputed land. A detachment of fusiliers is expected, and a special train bearing reinforcements of Australian troops left Peking for Tien-Tsin at 10 o'clock this morning.

In the third consecutive year Yale University won the championship of the Intercollegiate Hockey League, by defeating Brown University by a score of 5 -- 1, at the St. Nicholas Rink last evening. The game was the deciding one of the series for college honors, and although the Providence team made a plucky struggle, it had to yield before the superior finish of Yale play.

A hearing was held yesterday before the Committee on Streets and Highways of the Municipal Council on the application for a franchise of the Domestic Gas, Light and Coke Company. The promoters of the company claim to have "men of millions" back of the enterprise. They ask for the right to lay gas mains in any and every street of the Greater New York -- a franchise valued by experts at about $50,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- There has been a constant stream of telegrams from Commissioner Ruckhill to the State Department and from the department to the Commissioner during the past few days. All of them deal with the question of indemnity now being argued at Peking. The department will not make them public because the state the case is still chaotic and no uniform basis for indemnity claims has been reached.

The final games in the tournament of the Morning Newspaper Bowling League were rolled on Thum's Germania alleys yesterday afternoon. The Commercial Bulletin team won first place, The Journal second, and The Herald and The World are tied for third and fourth places. The tie will be decided next Wednesday afternoon.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Gov. Odell has positively and, formally declined to sign any Police bill. He has repudiated the new bill drawn by Senator Platt and his friends, and said to-night that if the measure came to him he would veto it, even if it was made plain that it would be passed over his veto.

ALBANY, March 20 -- Despite protestation at a hearing this afternoon the Assembly Committee on General Laws decided to report favorably the bill introduced by Mr. Bedell, making stock quotation ticker companies responsible for misuse of their bokers, but compelling them to furnish them on application.

ALBANY, March 20 -- The Ramapo Water Company, deprived of the extraordinary privileges granted under the act of 1895 by the recent passage of the Morgan bill, will make an effort to have the Legislature grant it the rights and powers conferred upon similar corporations under the general transportation corporations act.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Senator Hanna, Representative Grosvenor, and Representative Dick of Ohio has a very extended conference to-day with the President. They were closeted with him for almost two hours. Senator Foraker called during the progress of the conference, but remained only a short time.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- Secretary Root's order regarding the muster-out of the volunteers next June makes some unusually stringent provisions to avoid the padding of the pension roll. Under it a thorough physical examination must be made of all officers and enlisted men except Generals, officers of the general staff, and officers detached from the regular army immediately prior to their muster-out or discharge.
In fulfillment of a prophecy made by himself, A. L. Floyd, a Boston cotton manufacturer, was stricken ill in front of 62 Park Avenue late yesterday afternoon and died almost immediately.
BOSTON, March 20 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in good supply at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 10 @ 12 1/2 cents discount for cash.

Internal Revenue Collector Thompson and two deputies yesterday afternoon raided an alleged illicit distillery in the basement of the seven-story tenement house at 211 Eldridge Street and captured two men, who are believed to be the proprietors of the place. The prisoners are Marmann Lowenstein, the landlord of the tenement, and Joseph Levy, the janitor of the premises.

In view of the statement of Edward M. Shepard, counsel for the American Museum of Natural History, that contracts had been awarded by William Wallace, formerly Superintendent of building of the institution, without authority of the Board of Trustees, an effort was made by a NEW YORK TIMES reporter yesterday to ascertain the methods which have been practiced in the government of the institution and the appropriation of its moneys.

BRIDGEPORT, March 20 -- Daniel Davenport, Mrs. Blakeley Hall's attorney, today entered suit against the First National Bank to recover on a check of $10,000, drawn by George P. Gilman Jan. 4, 1901, to Mrs. Hall's order, on the ground that the bank has several times refused to cash the check when presented by her.

SOUTHAMPTON, March 21 -- The American liner St. Louis, with Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Carnegie on board, docked here at 2 o'clock this morning. Only a few passengers debarked. Mr. and Mrs. Carnegie had given strict orders that they should not be awakened until 6 o'clock.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 20 -- The Halcyon Hall hotel property at Millbrook was sold at auction under foreclosure sale here to-day. The mortgage had been given to secure a series of bonds, and suit was brought by Col. Frederick C. Wagner and Thomas Taft, Trustees for the bondholders, against the Halcyon Hall Company.

John Daly, Mayor of Limerick, about 100 members of the Clan-na-Gael, some fifty-odd chorus girls attached to the Alice Nielson Opera Company, and a union jack, waved by Ernest E. Clark of 159 West Forty-fourth Street, all united to make the departure of the White Star liner Majestic yesterday an event to be remembered by the last-named person.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20 -- In the stock market to-day high prices in the morning were followed by recessions in the afternoon, which brought the list down to near closing prices of last night. The bulk of the trading in the morning centred in the United States Steel stocks. The Readings improved in the early trading, but declined in the afternoon.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 20.-- The Texas Legislature has been called upon for the first time in the history of that body to perform the functions of a divorce court. Several months ago Frank Williams and Bettie Green, both belonging to prominent families of Brown County, eloped and were married.

Clinton L. Ressiter, President of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit and Brooklyn Heights Railroad Companies, resigned as President and Director of both companies yesterday afternoon at special meetings of the Boards of Directors held at the office of Anthony N. Brady, Chairman of the Board, at 54 Wall Street.

The body of William Dietz, a jeweler, fifty-five years old, of 60 Avenue A, Manhattan, was found yesterday on a grave in Evergreens Cemetery by James O'Brien, a gravedigger. Beside the body was a bottle which had contained carbolic acid. The body was removed to the Morgue.
The testimony in the Paine divorce suit was closed yesterday afternoon, and this morning Justice Freedman, in Part VI., Special Term of the Supreme Court, will listen to the summing up of counsel.

WASHINGTON, March 20 -- An interesting suggestion, connecting the latest developments of the Chinese question with the riots in St. Petersburg and other Russian cities, was made to-day by a public man of diplomatic experience who is well qualified to discuss European affairs. His theory is that Russia's bellicose attitude at Tien-Tain and her apparent disposition to provoke Great Britain are directly connected with the conditions at home.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 20 -- The new election bill, having for its object the practical disfranchisement of most of the 50,000 illiterate voters of the State, passed the Senate shortly after midday. It was immediately sent to the House, where all the amendments made by the Senate were concurred in, and the bill passed.

We have long been pointing out to parsons holding office under a Tammany administration of the affairs of this municipality that in order to discharge their functions with personal safety they needed the continual advice of a first-rate criminal lawyer. The leaders have acted upon that prudent presumption.
Andrew Carnegie will receive on his arrival in England a cablegram from Mayor Van Wyck as follows New York March 19, 1901. Andrew Carnegie, steamship St. Louis, Southampton, England;

ALBANY, March 21 -- Gov. Odell is evidently experiencing no regrets for the positive attitude of opposition he felt compelled to assume on police legislation last evening, when Frank Platt, on behalf of his father, Senator Platt, undertook to give him orders.

SOUTHAMPTON, March 21 -- Andrew Carnegie, who arrived from New York on the American liner St. Louis at an early hour this morning, was interviewed when he debarked. He expressed surprise that his donation for New York libraries had caused anything of a sensation.

A man recorded as Gabriel Navarro was last night under restraint in the insane pavilion at Bellevue Hospital. He was sent there for examination from the Jefferson Market Police Count, where he was accused of attempting to shoot an elevator boy at the Broadway Central Hotel and on information that for several weeks his conduct had suggested an unbalanced mind.

The bill for the construction of a distributing reservoir in Forest Park, Brooklyn, to cost $1,500,000 will not become a law in its present shape. There was a hearing before Mayor Van Wyck yesterday on the bill. The Mayor declared that the bill made it mandatory on the city authorities to locate a reservoir, and "directed" that the work be done.

The police of Berlin recently demanded of the Royal Porcelain Factory that certain nude statuettes in the show window of their shop, on a principal street of the city, be removed. This excess of modesty on the part of a police which has been greatly injured in its repute owing to several terrible scandals during late years has excited a good deal of satire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the newspaper comment upon the organization of the billion-dollar steel company I have been struck with the absence of any reference to the effect upon the workingman, who is certainly an important factor in the success of the enterprise.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Rear Admiral Walker, retired. Chairman of the Isthmian Canal Commission, said to-day that the report that the commission, in making its full report. "may present the points in favor of the Panama route," was quite within the limits of reason and possibility.

LONDON, March 21 -- Isaac Henderson, formerly publisher of The Evening Post of New York, and for many years a resident of Rome, has written a play entitled "The Mummy and the Humming Bird," which Mr. Wyndham will produce in London when he withdraws "Mrs. Dane's Defence." The latter play, however, continues to enjoy extraordinary popularity, and some time will elapse before London will have a chance of judging the production of the American dramatist.

A tremendous dynamite explosion shortly after noon yesterday in the Rapid Transit tunnel at One Hundred and Eighty-first Street and Broadway shook up houses for blocks around, injured four workmen, and might have killed thirty-five others but for the prompt action of Engineer John J. Mullen, who promptly started the air compressors and supplied fresh air and drove out the choking dynamite fumes until the men could be rescued.

TROY, N.Y., March 21 -- Charles C. Burns, aged forty-two, of New York, died in this city this morning from heart disease induced by Bright's disease. He had been ill since last June and was here visiting relatives. Mr. Burns was Treasurer of the National Starch Manufacturing Company, Secretary of the Kings County Gas Light Company, a member of the University Club of New York, and Treasurer of the Hobart College Alumni Association.

BOSTON, March 21 -- Work on the Independence's regulation rudder, the rough castings for which arrived here some days ago, is progressing in the shops of the Atlantic Works. The casting is being drilled and shaped for the sheathing. The casting is twenty-seven feet in length, the stock of the frame, that part which extends up through the hull to the deck, is round, and will be about four inches in diameter when smoothed down.

Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court yesterday, overruled a defense interposed by Rudolph Keppler, as President of the New York Stock Exchange, in a suit brought by Henry C. Bernheim as administrator of the estate of Abram C. Bernhelm for the recovery of $18,500 paid by Abram C. Bernheim for his seat on the Exchange.

The failure of the agents authorized by Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell, owner of The Abbott, 2:03 1/4, champion trotter of the world, and Thomas W. Lawson, owner of Boralma, 2:08, to arrange a match race on Wednesday, did not discourage Mr. Scannell in his hope of still being able to make the match which has been so much talked about.

BOSTON, March 21 -- The death of Charles P. Clark, ex-President of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company, to-day at Nice, in the southern part of France, was announced in a cablegram received this afternoon by his son, C. Peter Clark, General Superintendent of the Eastern District, from his mother, who is now in France.

L.J. Phillips Co. have sold for Hamilton M. Weed the five-story American basement fire-proof dwelling, 301 West One Hundred and Fifth Street. 18 by 60 by 100.11. This is the second house sold out of a row of four recently completed.

OAKDALE, L.I., March 21 -- Delegates from the building trades unions of New York City came here to-day and ordered out about 100 mechanics who were employed on William K. Vanderbilt's Summer residence, Idle Hour. In consequence 75 of the workmen went back to Manhattan, and those who lived near here returned to their homes.

"The Price of Peace," a London picture play, devised for the big stage of Drury Lane Theatre by Cecil Raleigh, and exhibited there from early last Autumn until the beginning of the pantomime season, was put forward at the Broadway Theatre last night by Jacob Lit, with all the original scenery by Emden, Perkins, Bruce Smith, and other London painters and its elaborate mechanical devices.

The prettiest ornaments to be seen in the baroque pearls are pins in the form of large daisies. The petals are of the pearls, each formed of a single one, slender and oblong. In the centre there is a large stone, a diamond or a topaz. Some of the brooches have double rows of petals.

LONDON, March 21 -- The demand for money to-day was active, and, in spite of the heavy borrowing from the Bank of England, the supply was not large. Tomorrow L2,750,000 will be required to meet the Exchequer bond installment. Discounts were quiet and harder. There was some uneasiness regarding French exchange and the possibility of exports of gold to Paris.

HAVANA, March 21 -- An element of doubt now exists as to what will be the final attitude of the Cuban Constitutional Convention. The preponderance of public opinion in favor of the Senate amendment during the last few days is having its ef- fect upon the Radical members, and Gen. Sanguity's utterances through the press to- day further tend to reduce the strength of the Radicals.

CHICAGO, March 21 -- What is alleged to be a concerted effort to break from the restrictions to the working rules of the Chicago Board of Trade, which are claimed to be irksome and unjust, developed to-day when nearly every prominent Board of Trade firm purchased seats on the Milwaukee Chamber of Commerce.

PHILADELPHIA, March 21 -- There was a heavy demand for the Readings to-day, mostly in the common stock. The whole group was stronger and closed at the top. Lehigh Valley jumped upward near the close. Union Traction went down on selling orders. The steel stocks were irregular. Cambria sold at 17 3/8, and Bethlehem Steel was a shade off at 18 1/2.
Col. A.M. Shook, formerly of the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railway Company, was asked last evening by a TIMES reporter the following questions:

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- By direction of Postmaster General Smith, Superintendent Beavers of the Salary and Allowance Division of the department has instituted important changes in the New York postal service which, it is believed, will reduce the clerical work in the main office in New York at least 50 per cent, and expedite all mails destined for points in the United States outide of New York City.

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Without displacing the pending proposition regarding the indemnity China is to pay to the powers, the United States Government has advanced another and a radical proposition, namely: To divide the total indemnity collected -- say $200,000,000 -- into eight equal parts, of which the United States would receive one.

The final hearing before the New York Harbor Line Board on the application of the New Jersey Riparian Commission to have the harbor lines changed so as to permit of a concession being granted under which the Cragin syndicate could, at an expense of $5,000,000, construct between Ellis and Bedlow's Islands an island having dry dock and terminal facilities, was had yesterday at the Army Building.

A Philadelphia chemist, who is apparently something of a humorist as well, has been making analyses of Schuylkill water since the recent paroxysmal rains, and finds by calculation in the amount of water which is daily delivered into the mains of that city, 280,000,000 gallons, five hundred tons of solids.

BRISTOL, R.I., March 21 -- In addition to the bracing of the Belmont syndicate boat by the usual bilge stringers, running from stem to stern, diagonal braces running from the bilges in board toward the floor plates and fastened at either end by rivets, are being placed in position. The diagonals are of light bulbed angles and placed several feet apart.

TRENTON, March 21 -- W.L. Brokaw and Stephen Harmon, two Princeton students, were arrested here to-night and are now locked up in the police station charged with atrocious assault and battery upon Augustus La Rue, a prominent and aged citizen of Trenton.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 21 -- Another claimant for a share in the Oilman estate came to the front to-night in the per- son of Miss Katherine Kupfer, the daugll- ter of the dead millionaire's former barber.

Through counsel for certain of the creditors or Jacob Lorillard, who filed a petition in bankruptcy before Judge Brown on March 23, 1900, it became known yesterday that notices had been received this morning by the creditors that all proceedings in the application for discharge were to be discontinued.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In spite of Prof. Hallock's expressed disapproval of "those who know nothing of the subject" taking an interest in scientific questions, and, through the courtesy of THE TIMES, striving to obtain information from "those who know" by publishing their own opinions, guesses, theories, or observation's, with the implied object of having them criticised, I hope the "coiled spring" discussion will not be dropped.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., March 21 -- Capt. Charles Barr has obtained a crew of forty men, most of them Scandinavians, for the old cup defender Columbia. The crew will report for duty April 5, as that is the time set for the launching. Lem Miller will be first mate and Chris Christiansen second mate.

Considerable strength showed in the outside market yesterday, and a number of stocks closed with substantial net gains. The steel stocks were all much less active than they had been for the last few days and at the same time the fluctuations in them were much smaller.
In the tournament of the New York InterClub Bowling League on the West Side Republican Club alleys last night the home team won two of three games with the Catholic Club five. The scores:

LONDON, March 22 -- In the House of Lords yesterday afternoon the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, the Marquis of Lahsdowne, announced that Russia and Great Britain had agreed to withdraw their troops from the disputed territory at Tien-Tsin, and to reserve the question of title and proprietary rights for subsequent examination.

GLASGOW, March 21 -- Capt. Sycamore and the crew of Shamrock II, have arrived here, and have gone to work preparing the cup challenger's gear. The men have been selected from the crews of the Bona, the Caprice, and the Iverna. They number 33, making, with the four officers, a total of thirty-seven men as the crew to be carried by the challenger.
LONDON, March 22 -- The Daily Chronicle, professing to be able to give an outline of the negotiations between Lord Kitchener and Commandant Gen. Botha. says:

WASHINGTON, March 21 -- Under the army reorganization law, which provides for an Increase of 20 per cent, in the artillery arm of the service, an order has been issued organizing twelve companies of coast artillery, in addition to those now in service. The number of these companies, the place where organized, and the officers assigned to each, are as follows:

A fire which destroyed the old terminal of the Sea Beach Railroad, at the foot of Sixty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, caused a loss of $25,000, and resulted in the death of one fireman and injuries to three others, occurred at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.

BALTIMORE, March 21 -- The market today swung in interest from the trust company group back to Seaboards. The former were largely in evidence in the day's trading, but they were not in such urgent demand as yesterday, nor did they continue their upward flight. Maryland and Guardian both fell back.

The official announcement by Mr. CHAMBERLAIN that the conference with Gen. BOTHA of Lord KITCHENER had ended in a rejection by the Boer leader of the British General's terms of peace has evidently produced a profound sensation in England. The most irrational manifestations of this sensation have been made by those organs of public opinion which profess shame that it should have been Great Britain which, as they express it, "sued for peace."

There is plainly an open rupture between Senator PLATT and Gov. ODELL. Mr. PLATT, claiming to represent the "organization," has, through his own son, laid before the Governor a bill to place the police force of this city in the hands of the State Government, and asked the Governor to urge its passage in the Legislature.

ALBANY, March 21 -- The Greater New York Charter Revision bill will be ready for introduction on Tuesday or Wednesday. It will combine four-fifths of the recommendations of the Revision Commission, and will include the provisions of the recently signed New York Single-Headed Police Commission law, and also the Bureau of Elections law.

The North German Lloyd liner Lahn, while bound in, about 2 A.M. yesterday morning, collided with the four-masted schooner Henry W. Cramp, about nine miles east of the Hook. The schooner was anchored at the time. The weather was very misty, and Second Officer August Tietbaar, who was on the Lahn's bridge at the time, thought the sailing vessel was a pilot boat.

BOSTON, March 21 -- The outlook for sports in the coming season has induced baseball men in New England cities to agitate the matter of a New England League and one of six clubs was organized this afternoon. The circuit proposed will include Manchester, Lowell, Haverhill, Lewiston, Bangor, and probably Portland.

ASHTABULA, Ohio. March 21 -- Latest moves concerning the site of the recently projected Carnegie Tube Works at Conneaut indicate that the new steel combination will utilize the land in the near future. The corps of civil engineers which was withdrawn from the new territory following the announcement that the tube works had been abandoned, has returned.

PEKING, March 22--2 A.M. -- Count von Waldersee, Gen. Barrow, and Gen. Wogack have been in consultation, and Gen. Wogack has agreed to withdraw the Russian troops from the disputed ground at TienTsin, provided the British also withdraw. He insisted also upon a guarantee that work on the railway siding should not proceed until the matter had been diplomatically adjusted.

The Bellevue Hospital pavilion for the insane came to the front yesterday with another good story. Through somebody's carelessness a young man in full possession of his mental faculties was locked up for seven hours with the forty or more insane patients in the pavilion. The victim of the error was Frank Malek, a strong young German cigarmaker, nineteen years old, living with his parents and several brothers and sisters at 423 East Seventy-third Street.

-- When Mr. WAUHOPE LYNN introduced in the Assembly his grotesquely absurd Large Type bill, it was regarded as a characteristic piece of nonsense, and nobody paid any attention to it or him, all assuming that even in Albany there was enough wisdom floating around to prevent the cumbering of the statute book with a law of that kind.
Mayor Van Wyck announced yesterday the appointment of the four Election Commissioners under the recent act of the Legislature.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As the season draws to a close, gratitude for the pleasure I have received in reading the musical criticisms of THE NEW YORK TIMES impels me to record my feelings on paper.

Lord LANSDOWNE'S announcement, in the House of Lords, that the immediate dispute between Russia and Great Britain had been settled was really the an- nouncement of a foregone conclusion. Nevertheless, the relief with which it has been received in London will be felt in all other capitals.
Senator Thomas C. Platt gave out the following statement last night in relation to the alleged quarrel between himself and Gov. Odell:...

LONDON, March 22 -- The King's Bench Division of the High Court of Justice was again a centre of interest yesterday, owing to the continuation of the hearing of the libel actions brought against The Star and The Morning Leader by Arthur Chamberlain, brother of the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, and Neville Chamberlain, a son of Mr. Arthur Chamberlain.

President Coogan announced yesterday that the action of the Local Board of Improvements, approving the plan to extend Waverley Place through from Broadway to Lafayette Place had been rescinded. The taxpayers in the vicinity have protested against this improvement.
The report of the Bank of Huntington will be found in another column.

After early hesitancy, due in a large measure to the disquieting news in respect to the Anglo-Russian dispute at Tien-Tsin, the stock market yesterday took on a tone of aggressive strength, which was continued up to the very close. The result was that final figures in practically every important stock on the list showed net gains, many of them substantial.

Charged with the conversion of $50,000 worth of hides and skins belonging to H. W. Peabody Co. of 17 State Street. Arnold Weber, a well-known broker and warehouseman, who made an assignment Feb. 11 last, has been lodged in Ludlow Street Jail in default of $50,000 bail.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter headed "Accusation Against Churches" in this morning's issue will find many advocates who will thank the writer for sounding a keynote of abuses in religious denominations as well as what is done for or in the name of charity.

LONDON, March 22 -- To an English interviewer, after his arrival in London, Mr. Carnegie talked freely concerning the Steel Trust, which, he thought, would not affect Great Britain much one way or the other. He said:

There is something in the air of Iowa that breeds independence and courage. No braver or more faithful man ever sate in the Senate than Mr. GRIMES, who, almost alone, saved his party from the incalculable blunder of a verdict of guilty in the famous impeachment trial of ANDREW JOHNSON.

"Paddy," a bulldog, said to have been the victor in a dozen hotly contested fights, came to an inglorious death by hanging yesterday. His untimely demise is attributed to his hatred of cats. Next to worsting one of his own kind in the pit, "Paddy" delighted in baiting a cat.

The attempt to defeat the plan of the Rapid Transit Commissioners for the construction of the extension of the underground system to Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, resulted in many bitter wrangles at a hearing yesterday. The Railroad Committee of the Municipal Council conducted the hearing.

The opening ride at the new Durland Riding Academy, in West Sixty-sixth Street, was held last night before a large crowd, which held the balconies and boxes of the gayly decorated building and made standing room a premium. In addition to the ride, which, commanded by Louis Parisette, was the first event on the programme, a number of exhibitions and competitions were held.

LONDON, March 22. -- The Cambridge crew in a capital full-course (Putney to Mortlake) trial to-day finished strongly in 19 minutes and 43 seconds, with an average of 32 strokes to the minute. A Leander eight took the Light Blues over the last mile.

There have been many interesting communications lately in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW on the subject of books for children, and -- not the same thing at all -- the books children care to read. The children of these days are most fortunate in the provision made for their mental needs when we consider the lack of children's books experienced by the children of a century, and less, ago.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 22. -- Ethan O. Thompson, senior member of the clothing firm of E.O. Thompson Sons, with stores in New York and Philadelphia, died at his home, 54 Hawthorne Place, Montclair, yesterday afternoon, of heart disease. He had lived in Montclair four years, and was seventy years old.

"If a private individual conducted his business as the City of New York conducts its schools," said one of the members of the supervising corps of teachers of this city, in speaking of the management of the city schools, "he would go into bankruptcy in a year. The system of school administration is neither economical nor effective.

The New York Home for Deaconesses, a Methodist Episcopal training school, which has occupied small quarters in West Fourteenth Street for several years, has purchased the property formerly known as the New York Christian Home, Madison Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street, which removed a year or more ago to Washington Heights.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. Foster's Providence experiment of a standard-literature room is interesting and attractive. An opinion a priori regarding its effect on the taste of the public would not be worth very much. That can only be found out by trial, and localities differ so much that what may be true of Providence in this regard may not be true of New York or some other place.

The terms proposed by Sir ALFRED MILNER and Lord KITCHENER and rejected by Gen. BOTHA for the speedy publication or which we were wishing yesterday, are now made public. The differences between the two positions do not seem to be irreconcilable. If they are not, it behooves both parties to reconcile them.

The current Atlantic contains an excellent article on "Animals in Literature," by Mr. George S. Hellman, in which he questions whether our present interest in books about animals is simply a passing fad, or whether the general interest in the subject will continue, whatever may be the fate of individual books, Mr. Hellman says:

BOSTON, Mass., March 22. -- The Hull (Mass.) Yacht Club's special committee in charge of the races for the cups and cash prizes offered by Thomas W. Lawson this afternoon decided on Sept. 2, Labor Day, as the date for the race, or a day later, not less than one week after the America's Cup races.

New York, like every great metropolis, is not one city but many. East, west, everywhere within city limits, are communities living their lives and dreaming their dreams with little or no reference one to another. Sometimes a traveler from one group passes over into another, but he seldom gives in returning a true and comprehensive idea of the strange folk among whom he has been sojourning.

The lower gallery at Clausen's is set with a score of little canvases that seem the product of one who lives in a land where it is always afternoon. No rude and noisy male sets his foot there; only maidens draped and maidens partly clad, and maidens mid noddings on dwell in this favored land, where every girl is beautiful and every gown, when there is a gown, is made of liberty silk.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have read with interest the article in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW relating to the Providence Public Library and the work being done there to inculcate a taste for reading above and beyond the ephemeral publications of the present day.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I have read with interest the communication in your SATURDAY REVIEW of the 16th inst on "The Grave of Paul Jones's Brother.'' I should be glad to know of the authority for the statement therein that the famous seaman ever said that his assumption of the name "Jones" was "a concession to republican simplicity."

The German philosopher and author Nietzsche died Aug. 28, 1900. Since then his disciple and, one might say, his pupil, Dr. Peter Gast, together with other disciples, aided by Nietzsche's sister, Elizabeth, have been engaged in preparing the philosopher's letters for publication. The first volume has just appeared from the press of Schuster Loeffer of Berlin under the title of "Friedrich Nietzsche's Gesammelte Briefe."
On Wednesday next, March 27, the National Arts Club will give a reception, at its house in West Thirty-fourth Street, to the Franco-American artist, Andre Castaigne.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 22. -- The Bridgeport Trust Company, administrator of the estate of George Francis Gilman, placed Sheriff David Fenelon in charge of the Black Rock property this evening. The Sheriff found Mrs. Potts, mother of Mrs. Blakeley Hall, in charge, and an old man named Edward Sanborn.

Sewing classes and the Evening Badminton made up the sum of entertaining yesterday. Badminton and sewing classes will again be the principal events on todays programme. As usual, there will be something of an exodus to the country. There is again a large house party at Chatsworth, where Miss Mary Field is entertaining a few friends.

LONDON, March 23. -- The Parliamentary papers giving details of the negotiations between the Boer Commander in Chief, Gen. Botha, and Lord Kitchener, commanding the British forces in South Africa, were issued yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., March 22. -- Three boys from the Heffley School of Brooklyn and four members of the Brooklyn Skating Club, representing the Victoria Hockey team of Brooklyn, gave the champion Quaker City Hockey team a close match to-night at the Ice Palace, holding the local players down to three goals and scoring one themselves.

We congratulate Senator PLATT on the accuracy and candor of his statement of the difference between him and Gov. ODELL. After describing the inefficiency and corruption of the Tammany police, he says, in the interview published by us yesterday morning:

Irregularity in prices marked yesterday's market, due chiefly to contests between manipulative factions. The bear party has mustered enough courage to make raids here and there in the list of stocks which have been most conspicuous and strong in recent Stock Exchange activity.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Your request for an opinion as to the wisdom of the step taken by the Providence Public Library in providing a special room containing what is termed the literature of power, intended not for study, but for enjoyment, and "the probable success of this step in securing a more general reading of books that are meant for all times," is received.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 22. -- The annual indoor handicap track meet was held in Cornell Armory to-night, and all the events were closely contested. The Cornell indoor records were broken. R.W. Rogers of New York City put the sixteen-pound shot 40 feet 3 inches, beating his own record by 1 foot 5 inches, and W.A. Frederick beat the indoor pole vault record by three-quarters of an inch.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: Mr. Foster of Providence is very much to be envied in having in his fine new library building space to enable him to devote one room to be used, not so much for study purposes as for the enjoyment of good books, a pleasure which belongs so much more fargely to a private library than to the ordinary free public library.

ALBANY, March 22. -- Gov. Odell will go to New York to-morrow to attend the Lotos Club dinner. In anticipation of his probable meeting with Senator Platt the Governor to-night gave out the following statement:

To The New Yort Times Saturday Review: I see so many paragraphs in your excellent literary review that interest me, and suggest comments I should like to make or opinions I should like to controvert that I end by leaving that task to others. This is doubtless a relief to you, as your table must be almost hidden out of sight under the communications you receive.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: It was a genuine pleasure to me to learn of the room which has been set aside in the Providence Public Library to be used for standard books.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It has been a problem to know how to make the great reading public realize that there is something worth reading in the "old books," and thus to divert them from the "latest books." The increasing demand for the new books without regard to their nature or contents can well be viewed with alarm; "anything new!" is the cry.

ALBANY, March 22. -- The Assembly Committee on Taxation and Retrenchment has made several amendments to the Lewis bill, relating to the exemptions of foreign and domestic laundry, manufacturing, and mining corporations from the operations of the law. Assemblyman Lewis says the practical effect of the amendments is to reduce the number of exemptions from the tax and put foreign corporations on the same plan as domestic companies.

MARSEILLES, March 22. -- The men employed on the street-car lines in this city struck this morning. A few cars were at first run under the protection of policemen, but after some serious outbreaks the service was stopped.

LONDON, March 10. -- The change in the character of the two leading Liberal newspapers since the beginning of the South African war is a noteworthy event. Before the war The Daily Chronicle was to my mind, by far the best newspaper in England, with, of course, the exception of The Times.

In the quiet way peculiar to the Stewards of The Jockey Club, the application of Samuel Hildreth, the most prominent owner-trainer on the American turf last season, for a license to train horses, has been shelved. The first intimation of this action on Hildreth's application came from Hildreth himself.

TRENTON, N.J., March 22. -- The Governor to-day signed the Palisades Park bill and the Appropriation bill which carries an item of $50,000 to aid in the purpose of preserving the Palisades and establishing an inter-State park along the top of the bluff on the high rocks.

SIR EDWIN ARNOLD. -- It may be recalled that a few weeks ago we published a letter from the author of "The Light of Asia" and "The Light of the World," which showed how he was fighting against a terrible disease which threatened every moment to overpower him. He now writes:

The teams of Americus and Yonkers Councils and the second team of Our Council tied in the New York Royal Arcanum Bowling League tournament on Starr's alleys last night, each winning one game and losing one. The scores:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The editorial page of THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW is to me one of the most interesting and suggestive features of the paper, and I hope you will permit me to compliment you on such a well-balanced and illuminating treatment of the literary topics of the day as is always to be found upon this page.

BOSTON, March 22. -- The Rev. Dr. William C. Winslow, Vice President of the Egyptian Exploration Fund, stated to-day, that, in addition to the papyri from Oxyrhychus presented to several universities is a valuable lot of forty-three papyri from several sites in the Fayum, which have been received for distribution.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 22. -- Fire tonight completely wiped out the big piano establishment of William Rohlfing Sons, on Broadway, and wrought further destruction to adjoining property, entailing a loss close to $300,000, fully covered by insurance.

BERLIN, March 22. -- A syndicate of leading Berlin and provincial banks, headed by the Imperial Bank, has taken over an imperial 3 per cent, loan of 300,000,000 marks, (about $72,000,000) which will be issued early in April.
NEWPORT, R.I., March 22. -- Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hall of New York are at their Washington Street cottage.

LONDON, March 23. -- The Foreign Office takes a pessimistic view of what is likely to happen in the immediate future in the Far East, in spite of the settlement of the TienTsin incident. It entertains grave fears that the relations between Japan and Russia may shortly reach the danger point.

LONDON, March 23. -- With the exception of the pro-Boer organs, all the morning papers comment upon the peace negotiations and recognize that the Government has gone to the utmost point of leniency. The Daily Mail, which denounces the "weakness of the Government" in the severest terms, says:

HAVANA, March 22. -- The Committee on Relations of the Cuban Constitutional Convention met to-day to consider the report drawn up by its Secretary, Senor Juan Gualberto Gomez, on the Platt amendment. In substance the report rejects four clauses -- the clauses dealing with coaling stations, foreign relations, the right to intervent to preserve peace, and the entering into treaties covering the points in question.

With an advantage of something more than 100 pounds dead weight in his favor, the latest Turkish wrestler to come to America, Nouroulah, fell upon and all but smothered James McWeeney of Chicago in Grand Central Palace last night. The Turk weighed 320 pounds and McWeeney 190. There was no betting and hardly any semblance of a contest.

Running to summon a physician to attend his dying mother, Charles Pfeiffer, thirty-six years old, of 186 Dresden Street, Brooklyn, dropped dead yesterday morning in the street near his home. When his body was carried back to the house his mother was found in bed dead. Pfeiffer's death was caused by heart disease: that of his mother was due to Bright's disease.

A new feature of the marriage of President of the Health Board John B. Sexton, which caused much surprise among his friends when it was announced two days ago, came to light yesterday. It now appears that Mrs. Mary E. Gioe. Mr. Sexton's bride, instead of being a widow as supposed, was really a divorced woman.

BOSTON, March 22. -- The championship sweepstakes for the great trotting horses now in training, which has been under discussion for two weeks, was announced to-day by Thomas W. Lawson as having been agreed to and all the details arranged. Boralma, (2:08,) owned by Mr. Lawson; Cresceus, (2:04,) owned by George W. Ketcham of Toledo, Ohio, and Charley Herr, (2:07,) owned by David Cahill of Lexington, Ky., are entered.

Mr. Frederic Harrison was entertained at the Authors Club last Monday evening in the clubrooms in the Carnegie Building. About sixty members and their friends were present. The welcome extended the well-known English critic, historian, and Positivist was most cordial. The brief impromptu address which he made was frequently interrupted with warm applause.

Men there have to be who sit in judgment on words, to define their exact meaning, note their origin and connections and pursue their ancestry into the earliest days of literature and sometimes to the furthest climes. If they tabulate their work in a dictionary, we call them lexicographers; if they write essays and books about words, we call them philologists, while in either case the vulgar call them word-sharps -- or bores.

Charles W. Super in The Conservative Review. The importance of environment is confirmed by the birthplace of noted French litterateurs. Out of 5,233 such men, 1,229 were born in Paris, 2,664 in other large cities, 1,265 in other localities, and 93 in country seats. Of women the proportion falling to cities is much larger, rising as high as 84 per cent. or the entire number," while about one-half were natives of the capital.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, March 22. -- The Leader to-morrow will print the following:

In Helen S. Dyer's interesting story or Pandita Ramabai, she gives a full account of the early years of this gifted woman, and how she came to undertake a herculean task. Pandita Ramabai's father was a Brahmin scholar with broader ideas about women than his caste entertained. He taught his second wife to read; also her children Ramabai being one of these.

There were many striking and suggestive remarks in the speech of acknowledgment of his welcome that Mr. Frederic Harrison made the other evening at the Authors Club, and that is reported in our columns to-day. One of them was the suggestion, in respect apparently to Mr. Carnegie's lavish benefactions, that such benefactions to private persons were out of the question in the British Islands.

The Rev. Mr. Tuckwell, late Fellow of New College, Oxford, has given us a volume containing such intimate and characteristic views not only of the Oxford of the last seventy years, but also of a long line of its celebrated men, both masters and pupils, as to make it of much importance.

Elsewhere in this issue we print letters from several prominent librarians in the United States, giving favorable opinions as to the wisdom of the step taken by the Providence Public Library in setting apart a room devoted to the permanent literature of the world. Every one is familiar with the enormous sales in recent years of works of fiction of the ephemeral Kind.

The Reform Club Committee on City Affairs has submitted a report on the proposed revision of the charter which may be studied with advantage by all the members of the Legislature who care to approach that matter with honest independence and not merely in obedience to party dictation.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I would state that this poem can be found in "Edison's Handy Encyclopaedia," published by Laird Lee, Chicago, (edition of 1891.) the cost of which is not more than 25 cents, as compared with $2.50, the price you quote your correspondent of another book containing it.

Mystery surrounds the death of a woman, supposed to be Mrs. Lillian B. Robinson, who was found dead in bed yesterday morning at 321 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street. Coroners' Physician O'Hanlon has been called upon to make an investigation and will make an autopsy on the body to-day.

ALBANY, March 22. -- For the first time this session the Assembly convened without the formality of a prayer. In the absence of Speaker Nixon the chair was occupied by Mr. Kelsey of Livingston, while the majority leadership in the absence of Mr. Allds was assumed by M.E. Lewis of Monroe.

On March 2 there appeared in these columns an editorial article entitled "Room for the Literature of Power." It was based on the recent action of the Providence Public Library, in setting apart a room containing what is called "The Standard Library" -- a room not intended for study, says Mr. William E. Foster, the librarian, but as "a place for the enjoyment of books, pure and simple."

The application, on behalf of certain alleged but unidentified "millionaires" for the franchise privileges needed to enable them to undertake the gas business in New York in competition with the Consolidated Gas Company, will bring up the whole question of the ethics of gas competition.
On Wednesday, March 13, Bangs Co. sold an interesting collection of books, which included much Americana. The principal prices were as follows:

For the purpose of erecting a building to carry on an experimental school, the Trustees of the Teachers' College of Columbia University were presented with $100,000 yesterday. The donors are a New York business man and his wife. They stipulated, when giving the money, that their names should not be made public, at least for a time.
"Old Bowen's Legacy," by Edwin Asa Dix, author of "Deacon Bradbury," will appear April 17 from The Century Company. some of the old characters are therein reproduced.

Henry Myers died on Wednesday last in Jacksonville, Fla. Major Myers, as he was generally called, was born seventy-three years ago in Savannah, Ga., and was the son of Mordecai Myers. Early in life he was appointed Paymaster in the United States Navy. When Georgia soceded he entered the Confederate Navy, and was ordered to the Sumter, Commander Semmes.

WASHINGTON, March 22. -- Col. Abraham K. Arnold, First Cavalry, will be retired for age on March 24. His retirement will make Lieut. Col. James M. Bell a Colonel of Cavalry. Col. Bell is now a Brigadier General of Volunteers, and is on his Way to this country from the Philippines. He will be placed in command of one of the new cavalry regiments, and organize it for service in the Philippines.

A young man wearing a Newmarket coat, white vest, patent leather shoes, and black hat, describing himself as Charles G. Blake, twenty-one years old, of 56 West Thirty-sixth Street, was taken to the East Fifty-first Street Station, a prisoner, by Capt. Lantry and Detectives Cooney and McCauley of that station shortly after midnight.

Looking at the maps to be found in Mr. Herbert Vivian's volume on Abyssinia, it may be seen how the Lion-Land exists only on sufferance. Around it on its possible water front there are the French, the British, and the Italian Somalliands. The Red Sea, the 'Gulf of Aden, are the appreaches to the Suez Canal.

More irregularity in prices showed yesterday in the outside market than on any day during the present week. The steel stocks continued active, but no longer were traded in to the enormous extent that they were on Tuesday and Wednesday. In this group prices were somewhat reactionary, but in most cases the declines were not substantial.

The Legal Aid Society celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of its existence last night with a banquet at the Waldorf-Astoria. About 200 of the most prominent members of the society assembled in the large ballroom, in response to the invitations, which for the first time asked for the presence at a banquet of the society of the society's women, who have done so much to make its work a success.

While every loyal Englishman deplores the death of Queen Victoria, the change in monarchs is not without its mitigating circumstances to a great many of them, and chief among the class benefited must perhaps be placed the artists and designers. It is understood that several artists are already at work designing new postage stamps, of which even a greater variety is used in the United Kingdom than in the United States.

Philadelphia, March 23. -- Directors of Brooklyn Club have received most eminent legal advice in this country assuring us we have two years contract with all our last year players. Therefore John M. Ward has been directed to institute action against our players who fall to report to us next month, as provided in their contracts.

SHANGHAI. Feb, 15. -- When the managing editor of a Chinese daily reaches his Office at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, he has perhaps less trouble than foreigners in that station, but quite enough to interfere with the placid enjoyment of the cup of tea that awaits him, and to make him wish that his superior talent had been employed in some line less bothersome.

The Bank Clerks' Bowling League of Brooklyn, which has just completed its first tournament, will celebrate the conclusion of the series with an entertainment on Saturday evening. The record of the tournament just completed is as follows:

SCRANTON, Penn., March 23. -- President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers, accompanied by District Presidents T.D. Nichols, T.P. Duffy, and John Fahy, left here to-day, ostensibly for New York. Last night Mr. Mitchell held a long conference over the long-distance telephone, and it is believed that the departure of the mine workers officials was the result of this interview.

BALTIMORE, March 23. -- O. Hammond, the organizer of the Hammond Independent Ice Company, which is going to fight the Ice Trust In New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, and other cities this Summer, stated here to-night that organization was effected at Dover, Del., to-day, with these Directors:

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., March 23. -- The cutter sloop Carmita, owned by R.K. Forest, has been overhauled and launched at the Hawkins yards. Capt. W.A. Walters, who is in charge of the yacht, has been under a physician's care for the past few days as the outcome of an accident by falling from the Carmita's deck to the ground.

PARIS, March 23. -- An official dispatch from Saigon, capital of 'French' CochinChina, announces the death of Major Ducros, an important witness who was favorable to Dreyfus at the Rennes court-martial. The Major took part in the recent campaign In North China, and was killed by a fall from his horse.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 7. -- The recent disturbances at the Universities of Kieff, Odessa, St Petersburg, and Moscow are a convincing proof of the deeply rooted discontent among Russian students, whose principal grievance is that the Government has dissolved all existing undergraduate societies and associations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last month West Virginia radically changed her statute for incorporating companies, and neither the empirical knowledge nor forms in vogue will be useful to promoters. This new law, intended to make the misuse of prerogative more attractive and profitable, has features calculated to increase distrust In charterpeddling legislation.

Bernard Zahn, son of Henry Zahn, of the firm of Sayles, Zahn Co. of 128 Sixth Avenue, was yesterday arrested by Deputy Sheriff Walgering on an order issued by Justice McAdam, in an action brought against him by Horace S. Stevens to recover $30,000 damages for alienation of the affections of the latter's wife. Ada E. Stevens.

A large audience filled the theatre of the Berkeley Lyceum yesterday morning, when Frederic Harrison. President of the London Positivist Committee, delivered a lecture upon republicanism and democracy. The talk was given under the auspices of the League for Political Education, and the speaker was introduced by John Graham Brooks.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- The Spanish Minister. Duke de Arcos, to-day received from Secretary Hay a Treasury warrant for $100,000, and the United States received the final cession of "any and all islands of the Philippine Archipelago lying outside of the line described in Article 3 of the treaty of peace between Spain and the United States of Dec. 19, 1898."

WEDNESDAY. MARCH 27. -- By William M. Ryan. foreclosure sale. Richard H. Clarke. referee. One Hundred and Fifty-ninth Street, north side. 250 feet west of Amsterdam Avenue, 50 by 99.11. vacant. Due on judgment. $8.660.

DENVER, Col., March 23. -- To save the lives of thousands of persons belonging to other States from death by tuberculosis is the object of an organization of Denver physicians and other professional men and women for the establishment and maintenance of the Rocky Mountain Industrial Sanatorium, which has just been incorporated here.

Last Sunday this department was given over to some consideration of the sources of "Der Ring des NIbelungen," but the subject was far from being exhausted. Indeed, it could not be exhausted in a long series of such articles as are practicable in a dally paper, and so fascinating is the research into these antique legends that this writer is afraid to loose the reins of his desire.

Supreme Court Justice Gilbert Collins, at Jersey City, yesterday granted an application made by Otto Gerdeau of 41 Dey Street, Manhattan, for a writ of certiorari to review an assessment of $5,000 levied against Mr. Gerdeau by the Jersey City Tax Board for personal property. Mr. Gerdeau is an importer of rattan products.
