To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial to-day on missionaries darkens counsel. "Missionaries" to us mean of course American missionaries. We have no concern with any others. We have not first hand knowledge with regard to them, and their responsibility is with their own countries.

CAPE MAY, N.J., March 23. -- The first experimental oyster farm in the United States has proved so successful that two permanent farms are being constructed at Dias Creek, about eight miles north of here, which takes up about two miles of the Delaware Bay shore of Cape May County, one by ex-Senator Maurice A. Rodgers of Camden County, N.J., and the other by William Schellenburg, of the same place.

That the battle for the millions left by the tea merchant George Francis Gilman, who died at Bridgeport on March 3, will be a stubborn and prolonged one was clearly presaged, in the opinion of lawyers able to judge of such things, by the vigorous difference of opinion among even heirs of the whole blood upon the question of the appointment of administrators, which was mooted before Judge E.P. Nobbs of the Bridgeport Probate Court.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Representative Babcock, Chairman of the Republican Congressional Committee, created a stir in political circles of the country just before the last Congress came to an end by introducing a bill intended to restrain certain trusts that were then arranging a gigantic deal.

LAKEWOOD, March 23. -- At this season of the year very few society women are to be found in New York. All have retired to the country, exactly as their English sisters are in the habit of doing at the end of the London season. This custom is practiced first and foremost for fashionable reasons, since it amounts to a social departure to be seen too frequently In town during Lent.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 23. -- Privy Councillor Pobiedonostseff, Chief Procurator of the Holy Synod, narrowly escaped assassination early yesterday morning. While he was writing in his study, shortly after midnight, two bullets shattered a window, passed close to him, and buried themselves in the ceiling.

LOWELL, Mass., March 23. -- By a defeat of the Burke Temperance Institute basketball team to-night, the New York Twentythird Street Young Men's Christian Association team claims the basket-ball championship of America. The score was 27 to 18.

The statement given out by Gov. ODELL as to his differences with Senator PLATT contains the following passage, in which he refers to Mr. PLATT'S statement in a dignified and candid spirit: I have read with great interest Senator PLATT'S authorized interview in this morning's papers. His reasons for, and my ob" Section to, further police legislation are in the main correctly set forth.

Ben the donkey, diplomat, politician, and all around coy old bachelor, is the star attraction in the deer house of the Central Park Menagerie these days. He is but a very little gentleman, with a splotched white and brown hide, and the longest ears and the pettiest face that ever grew on a descendant of Mr. Balaam's charger.

By a decision handed down by Justice Russell, in the Supreme Court yesterday, Robert M.S. Putnam, John Risley Putnam, and Israel Putnam, the sons of the late Judge John R. Putnam of Saratoga, are declared to be equally entitled to a trust fund of $100,000, left by their grandfather, Robert Shoemaker, to their mother in trust, and on her death to her heirs.

Pour men, Corcoran. O'Brlen, Tuohy, and Moore, who have been locked up since March 16 because they acted suspiciously at the Union Square Bank on the morning of that day, were before Justice McAdam in the Supreme Court yesterday on a writ of habeas corpus obtained by their lawyer in an effort to secure their release.

From The Klmberley Bandolier. During the month we have had some distinguished visitors, including the editor of The Bandolier, who, I am sorry to say, had the misfortune to fall into the sheep-dipping tank in the dark; we understand this was owing to his leaving his eye-glass in Kimberley.

Through the ineffective work of Hayward at goal the fast and dashing play of the other members of the all New York hockey team was set at naught in the last international hockey match with the Ottawas at the St. Nicholas Skating Rink last night. The Canadians won a victory by the good-sized score of 5 -- 1.

ASHTABULA, Ohio, March 23. -- It is reported here on good authority that the new steel combination will not favor Mr. Carnegie's favorite plan to ship steel from Conneaut Harbor, Ohio, via the Great Lakes, Welland Canal, and St. Lawrence River, to Europe. This project was inaugurated by the Carnegie Company last Fall, when the steamer Monks Haven cleared with about 1,000 tons of steel bound for Avcnsmouth, England.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The correspondence recently published in THE TIMES on the energy of a coiled spring has a significance quite distinct from an elucidation of the elementary principles of physics involved. It shows very clearly that a considerable proportion of the people of this city, readers of such an excellent newspaper as THE TIMES, have but little respect for professional attainments and knowledge.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 23. -- In connection with a report that a number of Fusionists were considering the advisability of voting for Republicans for United States Senators, or absenting themselves so that a less number might elect, W.J. Bryan was asked this evening whether he thought any Democrat or Populist would take the responsibility of giving this aid to the Republicans, Mr. Bryan said:

The showing made by the real estate dealings of the last few days might be made the basis of unfavorable comment, for not only has there been no transaction of the first importance -- if an exception be made of that affecting the Orphan Asylum block -- but the general run of business has been of inferior quality and smaller volume.

William C. Whitney yesterday, through his secretary, confirmed the announcement by cable from London that he had secured control of the three-year-old Volodyovski, the present favorite for the English Derby, which recently figured in litigation between the executors of the estate of Lord William Beresford and Lady Meux.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Secretary Root was with the President for almost two hours to-day, going over the lists of army appointments to be made under the Army Reorganization bill. These appointments are to be announced from time to time as agreed upon.

CHICAGO. March 23. -- The first details of the great hardship and suffering endured by the two corps of soldiers and engineers who attempted to construct a telegraph line between Dawson City and Port St. Michael have reached Dr. Eugene S. Willard of Evanston in a letter from his son, P.E. Willard, who was one of the parties.

ST. PAUL, Minn., March 23. -- The Lake Superior iron mining region is convinced that its interests do not lie with the United States Steel Corporation, and that the formation of that trust will throttle all individual initiative and enterprise here, both in steel making and in iron mining and exploration.

A month ago the oracles of Wall Street became suddenly very blue because so many important market operators were taking vacations. The wiseacres were sure that Mr. Rockefeller, Mr. Ryan, and other financiers of that calibre, away for a period of rest, must have unloaded their securities and were prepared to see substantial reactions before their return to the city to buy back what they had let go.

Booker T. Washington in The Outlook. I met Mr. Cleveland for the first time when, as President, he visited the Atlanta Exposition. At the request of myself and others he consented to spend an hour in the Negro Building, for the purpose of inspecting the negro exhibit and of giving the colored people in attendance an opportunity to shake hands with him.
The fourth evening concert of the Kneisel Quarte will be given in Mendelssohn Hull on Tuesday evening at 8:15 o'clock. The programme will be as follows:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Feb. 15. -- The press and many public men in Australia are urging that King Edward's titles should include some recognition of his sovereignty over these lands. Various suggestions have been discussed. Some prefer "Emperor" or "King of Greater Britain," while others wish to see Federated Australia raised to the rank of a kingdom, as specially mentioned in the royal list of titles.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 23. -- Princeton won from Rutgers this afternoon in the first game of the baseball season by the score of 21 to 1. This auspicious commencement of the baseball season at Nassau was due in part to the weakness of Rutgers, but more perhaps to Underhill's splendid work in the box and hard hitting by most of Princeton's men.

"New York ought to start a crusade against concert recitations in all grades of schools," says the Principal of one of the largest schools in the city who is recognized as a thoroughly competent eduator, "No one thing is more responsible in all our cities for poorly done and poorly digested work on the part of the pupil.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Representative Mercer of Nebraska was one of the President's callers to-day. He briefly discussed the Senatorial situation in Nebraska with Mr. McKinley. Mr. Mercer left tonight for Nebraska.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 23. -- Through J.T. Marchand, its special agent, the Inter-State Commerce Commisison is said to have come into possession of absolute proof that rebates have been regularly paid by the railroads on east-bound shipments of packing house products from Kansas City, and criminal prosecutions for violation of the Inter-State Commerce act may result.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The idea of uplifting the colored race in the South has become immensely popular, if one may be allowed to form an opinion from the crowds of people who were unable to grain entrance to the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall on the evening of the 18th inst. to hear the matters discussed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Conceding the munificence and magnificence of Mr. Carnegie's offer to the city of sixty-five library buildings, let it not be precipitately assumed that such offer can be wisely or safely accepted upon the conditions imposed.

Allan Hale Sexton, forty-five years old, was found dead yesterday afternoon in his apartments in the rear of the fifth floor of the Benedict Apartments, SO Washington Square East. According to the report of an ambulance surgeon. the man had been dead about three days. Death is believed to have been due to heart disease.

Report of Smithsonian Institution. From the effective character of their weapons of offense and defense, rattlesnakes have a great advantage in the struggle for existence against all animals except man and his domestic companion, the pig. Hence, in unsettled localities in North America they are abundant, especially in the warm regions of the South and West.

Valentine Unold, twenty-one years old, of 19 East One Hundred and Fourteenth Street, while riding a bicycle yesterday afternoon, was knocked down and run over at Forty-first Street and Fifth Avenue by a carriage owned, the police say, by John D. Rockefeller. The coachman started to drive off, but was prevented by the crowd which collected, and pulled the coachman from his seat.

The bank statement issued yesterday, shortly before the close of business, made a much more favorable showing than generally had been expected. Reserves increased $269,825. loans decreased $4,033,600, specie decreased $939,800. legal-tenders decreased $222,200, and deposits decreased $5,727,300.

This is Passion Sunday, From now until Easter, which is a fortnight away, there will be very little entertaining. Palm Sunday will begin Holy Week, and during that time many of the Lenten clubs and sewing classes will not meet. The Easter season, with its many weddings, its promise of some dances, and its coaching parade in May would seem to revive the tradition of gayeties after Lent.

"Its a blessed thing for everybody concerned that committees of 'five,' 'fifteen,' or any other number, don't operate on the Atlantic," remarked the Purser of one of the great transatlantic liners a few days ago, as he finished reading a story about "John Doe" in one at the morning papers. "Talk about gambling in New York, it can't touch the article we encounter at sea.

CHICAGO, March 23. -- A certain local wit has said that the Chicago University had a faculty for attracting attention, and this has been proved true on more than one oc casion. It is, indeed, a dull month when some one connected with the institution of learning on the Midway does not propose something which is startling in its novelty.

BRISTOL, March 23. -- The deck of the Belmont yacht is plated nearly the whole length, with but two small spaces at the bow and stern, which will be covered in the coming week. The greater part of this work of plating the deck was accomplished the past week. The plates, which are very thin, are galvanized before being laid in position.

A crowd of unusually good proportions was gathered in a down-town auction room the other day. and the auctioneer, surrounded by a bewildering array of Oriental tapestries, curios, and objets d'art, held aloft a rare and beautiful vase of great age and exquisite workmanship.

John and Joseph Lapis, who conduct a barbers' shop at 164 Hamilton Avenue, Brooklyn, found on Friday that burglars had made an attempt to break into the place. Believing that the thieves would return that night to complete the job, the brothers made preparations to receive them.

HELENA, Mon., March 23. -- Two common miners took a lease on a mine in Madison County, shipped two carloads of ore which netted them $21,000, and in addition they took out a quantity of second-class ore for which they received $1,200, making, a total of $22,200 for one year's work for two men. This is indeed a fortune for these two men, whose total capital stock was muscle.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I desire for fairness sake to add to your statement of March 21 that "the amount of good accomplished by Christian missionaries in China is infinitesimal compared with the injury resulting from the great revolt of the conservative forces of that empire against foreign aggressions, chiefly (sic) those or the energetic but not always discreet teachers and exemplars of the Christian religion."

To the Editor of The New York Times: The hint in to-day's paper to some of your "all-knowing correspondents" to come to your assistance in the matter of exposing the venerable character of the tale which Moncure D. Conway palmed off at the Authors' Club the other night, on the occasion or the reception to Frederlo Harrison, was wholly unnecessary.

PHILADELPHIA. March 23. -- Mrs. C.E. M. Hodge to-day made an unsuccessful attempt to recover possession of her fiveyear-old daughter Guida, who. it was reported, was abducted from the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, in New York, last week by Richard L. Maxwell, a divorced husband of the woman.
TUESDAY. MARCH 26. -- By William M. Ryan. public auction sale. 28 Bayard Street, north side, 126.3. feet west of Chrystie Street. 16.9 by 50 and irregular, three-story brick building, with store.

"The Price of Peace" may not be the artistic equal of some of its Drury Lane predecessors, such as "The Great Ruby," for instance. It is surely all as likely and as interesting as "Hearts Are Trumps." It will run well at the Broadway Theatre because "popular prices" now prevail there, because its pictures are splendid, and its few really dramatic scenes genuine thrillers and shockers.

STANDERTON, Transvaal Colony, March 22. -- Four hundred Boers under the Boer commander Buys have wrecked a supply train north of Vlaklaagte. They overpowered the escort, and carried off several wagonloads of provisions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a somewhat singular fact that from Ferdinand Palmo's time up to the erection of the Metropolitan Opera House every building devoted to Italian opera in this city came to grief and subsequently fell into the hands of theatrical people who made them successes as temples of the drama.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I noticed in your issue of March 14 an article headed. "Compliment to Americans." In Paragraph 4 of this article it is stated: "There is no direct connection between the modern order and the famous old order, which was founded at the end of the eleventh century."

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Assistant Secretary Hackett has received a report from Commander B.F. Tilley, commanding the naval station at Tutuila, Samoa, dated Auckland, March 2, 1901, saying that the repairs to the Abarenda have been. completed. He adds that the health of the ship's company is excellent, and that everything is reported to be in a satisfactory state at Tutuila.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23. -- There was considerable activity in the local market today. most of it being in the Choctaws, Consolidated Lake Superior, Lehigh Valley, and Philadelphia Company of Pittsburg. In the first two named the highest prices ever recorded were made, and during the activity Choctaw common crossed the preferred.

Four performances of opera in two days constitute a pretty good record, yet that is what the Metropolitan had achieved last night. The usual two Saturday entertainments took place, the opera in the afternoon being Reyer's "Salammbo," and that in the evening being Gounod's "Faust." It was therefore a day of French music.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is really gratifying if amid all the pseudo-discussion of many of the questions which arise in the daily press there be found even one who is capable of seeing a point, and what is quite as much to the point, of indicating real objections, and "J.A.D." is evidently such a person, if he will pardon the statement.

MANILA. March 23. -- Gen. Funston is now engaged in a daring project which promises to be the greatest and most romantic achievement of his eventful careeri. In January, from his hiding place in the Province of Isabella, Aguinaldo wrote letters anathematizing the sub-chiefs who had taken the oath of allegiance to the United States.

From The Army and Navy Journal. We observe that Mark Twain has taken a friend of his, Mr. William j. Lampton, to task because he has been guilty of writing a patriotic poem. In a letter to Mr. Lampion, described by The Philadelphia. North American as a " gently satirical epistle," Mr. Clemens says:

LONDON, March 24. -- The Colonial Secretary, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, in the House of Commons yesterday, replying to a question, said no specific objections had been made by Gen. Botha to any of the peace terms offered by Lord Kitchener, and Gen. Botha made no counter-proposals.
To the Editor of The New York Times: In speaking of the contemplated production of Goethe's "Faust" at the Irving Place Theatre Mr. Dithmar says in this morning's TIMES:

CHICAGO, March 23. -- Official announcement was made here to-day that the controversy between the Chicago Board of Trade and the telegraph companies over the collection and dissemination of market quotations has been settled. Within a week, if not sooner, it is expected quotations will be sent out from this market to all parts of the country, as they were before the trouble started many months ago.

Four detectives assigned to investigate the theft of two sealskin sacques and a Persian lamb sacque, stolen from A. Reichbard Son's fur store, at 41 Bleecker Street. March 2, arrested several men and a woman yesterday afternoon and seized a quantity of goods, including the three sacques which the accused persons had in their possession.

Manager Conried or the Irving Place Theatre will have the theatrical field clear for himself this week in so far as any new production is concerned. He will present the First Part of Goethe's "Faust," in two divisions, the performances being for the benefit of Carl Emmerich and Miss Ada Merito.

From The Review of Reviews. It is not fortresses or naval stations or commercial relations that are chiefly important to us as regards Cuba, but something wholly different. Through our entire lifetime as a nation we have been sorely plagued and incalculably harmed by epidemic diseases that have visited us from the West Indian ports, and particularly from Havana.

WASHINGTON. March 23. -- Spring is in sight at the Nation's capital, and in a few days it will have asserted itself as it seems to do usually with greater swiftness and steadiness than in the latitude of New York. Already the public gardeners have been clearing the reservations, removing the top dressing that had made them very untidy for weeks, and are trimming the shrubbery.

With the dates of the launching of the three Americans cup contestants within hailing distance, yachtsmen are already calculating from the meagre details, obtainable the probable outcome of the coming season's sport. The Shamrock II., according to the latest reports, will launch in the last week of April.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You seem to be kindly disposed to give all persons a chance to present their opinion on any question that comes before the public, whether it agrees with your views or not, therefore, I would kindly ask your indulgence to say a few words from the standpoint of an American workingman.

BERKELEY, Cal., March 23. -- Charter Day was celebrated here to-day, the occasion being the thirty-third anniversary of the founding of the University of California. The Faculty, in caps and gowns, assembled at 10:30 A. M. and marched across the college campus to the gymnasium, where the exercises were held.

From The Fortnightly Review. In France we have a budget of just twenty-five millions, a peace strength of 600,000 men, and a cost per head of a little more than u40; in Germany, where the ordinary budget runs to twenty-six millions. the cost per head in a grand total of 612,000 men runs out at u42 per annum;

The Committee of Fifteen, satisfied that they have closed up all the gambling houses, turned their attention last night to dives in the Tenderloin, on Eighth Avenue, and in the "red-light district," and closed them up, arresting the alleged proprietors, their managers, and a number of women employes of the places.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 23. -- A special meeting of the stockholders of the Union Pacific Railroad Company was held in this city to-day, among those present being President Horace G. Burt, Secretary Alexander Millar, General Solicitor W.R. Kelly, and Attorney Lawrence A. Greer or New York.

BERLIN, March 23. -- In the lower house of the Diet to-day President von Kroecher communicated the result of his audience with Emperor William yesterday, when the officers of the Reichstag and Diet expressed the indignation experienced by the members of their respective houses at the recent outrage at Bremen.

CAIRO, Feb. 28. -- The most important discovery at Alexandria, both in ancient and modern times, has lately been made through a happy accident. While an ordinary laborer was working at Korn El Shogafa, one of the dirtiest and most neglected quarters of the city, his pickaxe came against a rock which gave a hollow, echoing sound.

The mansion of Charles T. Yerkes at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street is to be altered and enlarged from plans by Architect H.S. Cobb. A three-story extension. 28 by 98.3 is to be built at the rear and connected with the present dwelling. The cost of the improvement has been estimated by the architect at $75,000.

WASHINGTON, March 23. -- R.R. Poole, Commissioner of Agriculture for Alabama, testified before the Industrial Commission to-day concerning agricultural conditions in that State. He said the State was prosperous, and that, during the past five or six years, a large proportion of the mortgages held upon property there had been lifted, and farm lands had advanced in price until they are now held at antebellum prices.

BERLIN, March 23. -- Internationals were quiet on the Boerse to-day. Home funds were harder, Americans were dull, and mines were animated, stimulated by American reports causing bear covering, in addition to reports that the prices of steel were being raised and that the syndicate was reducing the coal output.

BANGOR, Me., March 23. -- With the coming of Spring the outlook for the shipbuilding industry in Maine has perceptibly brightened, and there is reason to believe that the good record of 1900 will be equaled if not exceeded this year. Maine shipbuilding has not yet recovered from the slump that followed the phenomenal year of 1890, when 74,466 tons of new vessels were launched from the yards of the State.
The Des Moines Life Insurance Company has been licensed to do business in Kansas.
WASHINGTON, March 23. -- Consul General Guenther of Frankfort, under date of Feb. 11, 1901, writes to the State Department as follows:

An unexpected upset occurred in the New York Royal Arcanum Bowling League last week, Yonkers Council losing a second game and dropping to second place. Our Council No. 1 taking the lead and Our Council team No. 2 going from second place to fifth. In the Brooklyn inter-club series the Carleton Club defeated the Crescent Athletic Club and now seems certain of first place.

Of late years we have had occasion to note a lamentable decline of the kind of oratory which delighted our immediate ancestors, and still gives pleasure to those who have time and opportunity to read the memorable speeches of the exponents of a school of eloquence which belongs distinctly to the past.

Gov. Benjamin B. Odell, Jr., was the guest of honor at a dinner given by the Lotos Club last evening, and many complimentary thinges were said about him by the speakers. The Governor had hardly steeped into the dining hall, which was tastefully decorated for the occasion, when he was cheered.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- Whatever may have been the intention of Rear Admiral Sampson, in 1901, in opposing the idea of raising men out of the ranks of the navy and putting them in the line, it is interesting to know that the letter and spirit of his refusal to indorse the application of Gunner Morgan to be permitted to stand examination were diametrically contrary to the sentiments uttered in 1888 by Rear Admiral Schley.

After Robert H. Moulton, who shot two theatrical men in the rathskeller of the Pabst Hotel on Friday morning, was taken from the West Side Court to the Prison Ward in Bellevue Hospital on Friday evening, he relapsed into a state of stupor, answering questions in dull and unintelligible terms.
The Wyoming Legislature passed a bill making Feb. 12, Lincoln's Birthday, a legal holiday in that State.

There are some points of difference between Mr. BRYAN and Mr. GORMAN, who is reported to aspire to succeed Mr. BRYAN as a Presidential candidate. The chief of these is that the personal integrity of Mr. BRYAN has never been questioned. He has been a member of the National Legislature.

NILES, Mich., March 24 -- W.J. Gilbert, former Mayor of this town, reputed to be wealthy and one of the best known and most respected residents of Berrien County, was found dead to-day in a storehouse in the rear of his residence, where he had ended his life with a bullet.

GLEN GARDNER, N.J., March 24 -- This village was a sea of flame this morning. Eleven buildings and a lumber and coal yard were wiped out of existence. They were all burning at the same time, while rivers of flame flowed down the mountain side from oil tanks wrecked in a collision on the railroad.

Joseph A. Conlin, who formerly lived at 318 East Thirty-second Street, and who was employed as a clerk in Post Office Branch H, at Lexington Avenue and Forty-fourth Street, until he disappeared on Feb. 22 with $40,000 worth of Government property in the shape of money, money orders, and stamps, arrived here yesterday afternoon in the custody of Post Office Inspectors James and Jacobs, United States Marshal J.R. Shine, and Detective Ryan.

Chicago has decided to make a strong bid for the Olympian games in 1904. The International Olympian committee will meet in Prague, in June, in conformity with the resolutions adopted when the games were revived in 1896 by being held in Athens. It was then agreed to hold the games in different cities of the world every four years, and last year they were held in Paris.

--Health legislation of an entirely new kind is contemplated in Italy. There the responsibility of mosquitoes for malaria is quite generally regarded as a demonstrated fact, and a bill drawn in recognition of it is already under serious consideration. It provides for the official declaration of affected zones, and for the gratuitous distribution in such regions of quinine to the poor by the municipal authorities until the extermination of the anopheles mosquitoes can be accomplished.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24 -- Trouble between the local and New branches of the National Association of Bridge and Structural Iron Workers is likely to cause a general strike on the big Prudential Building in course of construction here.

Okayama, in the far-off land of the Mikado, enjoys the distinction. It is believed, of being the place where the first marriage service of the twentieth century was celebrated. The Rev. Dr. James H. Pettee, a representative of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions at Okayama, says he performed the ceremony.

Detective Sergeant McCafferty of the Central Office last night arrested Samuel Hurburger, a thief, who for ten years has been considered by the police of New York and London as one of the shrewdest as well as most desperate of criminals. The arrest was the result of a chance meeting at Forty-second and Sixth Avenue, and was accomplished only after a lively chase and a threat of "stop or I'll shoot" by the detective.

BOSTON, March 24 -- The Police Commissioner's order of yesterday forbidding the sale of liquor and food in the same room in which bars are located, on Sundays and holidays, had the effect of driving patrons of second-class hotels to the second stories to-day. Washstands and bedsteads, in many cases were the improvised serving tables, and around them the guests crowded while they were served by waiters.

GLASGOW, March 24 -- Sir Thomas Lipton was at Dumbarton yesterday making arrangements to launch the Shamrock II., and the ceremony has been definitely fixed for April 20. The Marchioness of Dufferin will christen the yacht.

A veritable co-operative Commonwealth on a small scale, which has been in existence in this city for eighteen months unknown to the general pubiic, has expanded until its members think it necessary to establish a rural branch near Rossville, S.I. The members are known as the "Straight Edgers."

ST. PETERSBURG, March 24 -- The political situation is so serious that Emperor Nicholas held a meeting of the Ministers yesterday to consider the state of public affairs. The Czar presided at the Council, which was convened at the Tsarskoe-Selo Palace. It was decided not to abolish the law for drafting recalcitrant students into the army, but for the present to refrain from applying the law.

ALBANY, March 24 -- Gov. Odell arrived in Albany at 4:20. He was seen to-night at the Executive Mansion and approved of the decision of the conference in New York that there would be no further police legislation at this session. When asked if he had any comment to make, he said:

Senator Platt yesterday deemed discretion the better part of valor and capitulated as gracefully as possible to Gov. Odell on the question of further police legislation for New York at this session of the Legislature.

THE NEW YORK TIMES in an able editorial defends Pension Commissioner H. Clay Evans from the attacks of his enemies, and expresses the earnest wish that the President retain Mr. Evans in his present office. THE TIMES takes the generally accepted view of the opposition to Mr. Evans -- that is, that it emanates directly and solely from the pension sharks and those who would draw a pension, though not entitled to one.

President Alexander E. Orr, of the Board of Rapid Transit Railroad Commissioners wrote a letter on Saturday to Albert L. Johnson in reference to the proposition submitted by Mr. Johnson, who is desirous of building a tunnel under the East River to South Brooklyn, under the Narrows to Staten Island and across to New Jersey to connect with his projected trolley line from Philadelphia to New York.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 24 -- The information is given out to-day that no papers belonging to the late George Francis Gilman can be found anywhere. Attorneys Canfield and Judson, counsel for a number of heirs; Edward S. Percival, and a representative of the Bridgeport Trust Company, administrator of the estate, have been unable to find any papers, deeds, or even bits of jewelry.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- A British journalist named Story recently visited the Naval Observatory in search of information about sun spots. He was startled to find that the observatory does not photograph sun spots on Sundays or legal holidays, and in looking over the records he discovered that there were also a few other days on which the sun spots had not been photographed.

WASHINGTON, March 24 -- Mr. de Assis-Brasil, the Minister to the United States from the Republic of Brazil, attributes no significance whatever to the report coming from Rio Janeiro of a conspiracy there against the Government. The Minister has received no information of impending trouble, but on the contrary says the country is very quiet.

"Now that the matter of the revision of the course of study is being undertaken by the Board of Education," remarked a teacher of one of the specialties that bristle in the present public schools course. "It strikes me that the committee would do well to work on a plan for having fewer branches taught, and having these taught more thoroughly.

The views of Col. A.M. SHOOK of Alabama, published in our issue of Friday, have occasioned some surprise on account of their pronouncedly pessimistic tone. Col. SHOOK is an ironmaster of large experience, for many years prominently identified with the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railway Company, and one of the best-known representatives of this industry in the South.

They used to have a mortgage on St. Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church, Seventy-sixth Street, near Columbus Avenue. For something like fourteen years the Church property was incumbered to the extent of $100,000. But yesterday afternoon at the close of service there was none.
Col. Edward C. James, one of the leading members of the New York bar, died at Palm Beach, Fla., at 9 o'clock yesterday morning.

MIDDLEBURY, Vt., March 24 -- Nelson Jones, aged about twenty-five years, of Shoreham, was lodged in the Addison County Jail at 2 o'clock this morning on a warrant charging him with the murder of Ida Fosburgh at Shoreham, on March 12, by poisoning. The fact of the arrest was kept quiet during the day and but few people in the town were aware that Jones had been brought here and placed in jail.

DULUTH, Minn., March 24 -- In four weeks the market value of the stock of the Lake Superior Consolidated Iron Mines of this city has risen from $18,000,000 to $36,000,000. Of this stock, John D. Rockefeller has held until now about 90 per cent., so that his profits in the rise have been about $16,000,000.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 25 -- Krapovich, the assassin of M. Bogolepoff, Minister of Public Instruction, has been sentenced to hard labor for life. He will be imprisoned in the Schluesselburg Fortress, on an island in the Neva.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am one of that large class of business men constantly (and rightfully) appealed to for financial aid in supporting and carrying forward foreign missions. I have just been invited to again assist during the present year in the support of a missionary in China.

The agents of the West Indian islands in London are confident that the Government will embrace in their new tax bills a duty on imported sugar with exemption of West Indian sugar, or an extra duty on sugar receiving an export bounty. In other words, they are counting on special favor for colonial sugar in the markets of the United Kingdom.
The hundred or more tenants of the Winchester apartment house at 400 West Fifty-seventh Street, which was heavily damaged by fire three weeks ago, got another fright last night.

THE RUSSIANIZATION OF FINLAND -- The withdrawal of the so-called Finnish Army bill by the Russian Minister of War, announced in a St. Petersburg dispatch yesterday, has not been interpreted that the scheme of Russianization of Finland has met with a serious defeat, but simply that the Russian Treasury is not at present in a condition to meet the extra expense that would be involved were the bill to be promulgated as a law.

With clattering side arms and the rattle of steel-shod hoofs, the advance guard of the Military Show took possession of Madison Square Garden yesterday, and with the readiness of tried campaigners, converted the Fourth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street corner into a cavalryman's camp, and were in comfortable quarters in less than half an hour.

PATERSON, N.J., March 24 -- Very Rev. Dean McNulty was out last night making one of his customary trips to the saloons of the city. He did not touch the uptown district this time, but devoted his visits to saloons along Market Street and in the Sandy Hill district. He merely peeped into several places, and seeing no sign of any doing out of the ordinary kept on his way.

In the course of the mails we now have the remarks of the London press upon the British rejection of the Senate's amendments to the Hay-Pauncefote convention. Without exception they are friendly in tone and abound in professions of readiness to meet the desires of the United States when those desires are compatible with British interests.

The Committee of Fifteen has sent to Gov. Odell a letter expressing approval of the legislation proposed by the Tenement House Commission in regard to the suppression of the social evil in tenement houses. The text of the letter is as follows:

PITTSBURG, March 25 -- The Rev. Dr. Henry T. McClelland, member of the Freedman's Board of Missions, former Professor of Theology at the Western Theological Seminary, and one of the best-known Presbyterian ministers in the country, had a sensational encounter with burglars last night.

Mr. ORR has made a perfectly clear and reasonable proposition to Mr. ALBERT L. JOHNSON as to the construction of a rapid transit road under the East River, and we greatly hope that Mr. JOHNSON will consider it in the spirit in which it is made. He has indulged lately in some rather loose talk about the action of the Rapid Transit Commission, of which Mr. ORR is the President.
PEKING, March 25 -- The foreign Ministers seem utterly unable to agree as to the best method of policing the legation quarter.

Six indictments, resulting from the recent raids of the District Attorney and the Committee of Fifteen, were handed up to Judge Newburger by the Grand Jury yesterday. Three were for keeping gaming houses and three were for bookmaking.

During the absence of Frank S. Bond, Vice President of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad, from his home, 38 West Fifty-first Street, yesterday, a woman and a vanload of furniture arrived at the residence. Bernard Smith, the butler employed by Mr. Bond, had considerable trouble with both.

PEKING, March 25 -- The special committee of Ministers appointed to consider the question of China's ability to meet the indemnity claims is already well forward with the work of investigating the resources of the empire. Sir Robert Hart, Director General of the Imperial Maritime Customs, has been examined, as have also the managers of representative Chinese banks, many pawnbrokers, and Chinese financiers.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Library Enabling act, providing for the acceptance by the City of New York of the gift of $5,200,000 by Andrew Carnegie for the establishment of branch libraries there, was introduced in both houses of the Legislature tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Representative Henry A. Cooper of Wisconsin, the Chairman of the Insular Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives, who has just returned from Cuba, believes that the chief danger in the Cuban situation is the policy of depreciation of the islanders which has been pursued in some newspapers.

BOSTON, March 25 -- At the regular bimonthly meeting of the Directors of the American Peace Society, held here to-day. It was voted unanimously to publish the following open letter to President McKinley:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Set me down as one who believes that the City of New York gets full return for the money expended on its public school system.

The stockholders of the North Jersey Street Railway Company held their annual meeting in Jersey City yesterday and re-elected all the old Directors except that Henry Lembeck, resigned, was replaced by J.E. Hulshizer, Jr.
STUTTGART, March 25 -- There is no truth in the report that Baron Schott von Schottenstein, the ex-Premier of Wurtemberg, has committed suicide at Ulm.
GLEN GARDNER, N.J., March 25 -- The losses by yesterday's remarkable fire here, as figured up to-day, were as follows:

Ex-Alderman Charles A. Parks of Fourteenth Street and Eighth Avenue is again on trial before Judge McMahon in General Sessions charged with assaulting George Wenner of 1,000 Forrest Avenue on May 10 last. Wenner says that in an argument in Parks's saloon at the above address Parks struck him over the head with a lead pipe.

The first day of Passion Week began quietly, and there were few entertainments. The prospects for to-day are not much brighter. Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Gurnee, Jr., will give a dinner this evening, and Mrs. H. De Berkeley Parsons will give a bridge whist party, and there is the usual meeting of Lenten classes.

ALBANY, March 25 -- An expression of William Barnes, the Chairman of the Executive Committee, in his paper to-day indicates that the conference of Republican leaders at the Fifth Avenue Hotel Sunday was far from being the harmonious gathering which has been described. Mr. Barnes was at the conference and therefore knows all that occurred.

Up to within the last hour of trading yesterday the stock market showed substantial strength, with quotations quite generally advancing. Then, under the pressure of realizing sales and heavy selling for the short account, prices fell off, in some instances rather sharply, with a result that at the close much irregularity showed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 25 -- Carry Herrmann, the son of Eshcr-Silk Gown, and an 8 to 5 favorite in the Kentucky Derby, was sold to-day by Charles Head Smith of Chicago to Capt. Sam S. Brown, the Pittsburg coal king, for $20,000. The deal was confirmed by Trainers "Charley" Hughes and "Bob" Tucker and will to-morrow be transferred to the Tucker stable.

BALTIMORE, March 25 -- The market was quite animated to-day and was strong. During the trading the United Railways group, which for some time past had been quiescent with an easing tendency, was caught by a spurt of activity and advanced materially. This change was attributed to preliminary reports of earnings, all of which, so it was claimed, pointed to important and substantial increases.

Senator M.A. Hanna of Ohio is in the city "killing time," as he expresses it, until the weather settles sufficiently to warrant his return to Cleveland. He is accompanied by Mrs. Hanna, who will do some shopping.

PARIS, March 26 -- The Chamber of Deputies was in session until a late hour last evening in order to conclude the debate on Article XIV. of the proposed law of associations, which was finally adopted by a vote of 318 to 237.

At the opening of the outside market yesterday prices showed considerable strength but later in the day a good deal of irregularity appeared, and the market closed with quotations little changed from those of Saturday. The steel stocks remained active, and furnished a large part of the day's business.
BOSTON, March 25 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 and 2 per cent. New York funds sold at 10, 12 1/2, and 15c discount for cash.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- As the result of a decision to-day by Assistant United States Attorney General James M. Beck, master in the suit pending in the United States Circuit Court to set aside the assignment of The Philadelphia Record by William M. Singerly for the benefit of the creditors of the defunct Chestnut Street National Bank, of which Mr. Singerly was President.
LONDON, March 25 -- Charlotte Mary Yonge, the author, died yesterday in Winchester.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 25 -- The baseball game scheduled here to-day between the teams of University of North Carolina and Lafayette was called off on account of rain in the last half of the fifth Inning. Lafayette was up, with two out, and nobody on base. The score at that stage was a tie at 2. The score:

The third performance or "Die Meistersinger von Nurnberg" ushered in the final week of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. The audience was one of profitable proportions and mellow mood. And so it should have been, for the performance was one of uncommon interest.

It is probable that we did President HADLEY some injustice the other day in commenting on his address in the Old South Church, in Boston, in which he made his widely misreported remark about an Emperor in Washington within twenty-five years. It appears that this remark was not in the nature of a prediction at all, but a piece of rhetorical emphasis.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., March 25 -- The heavy rains and thaw throughout Wisconsin for the past three days has caused high water in many places throughout the State, and business has been interrupted temporarily, at least. Sheboygan, Oshkosh, Fond du Lac. Saukville, and this city are having the worst experiences.

CHARLES S. MAY, Lieutenant Governor of Michigan from 1863 to 1865, and an eminent member of the Michigan bar, died suddenly yesterday at his home, Island View, Gull Lake, of heart disease, aged seventy-one.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Colonial Secretary, the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, when asked in the House of Commons yesterday if it were possible to change the offer of peace terms to the Boers, said the negotiations were closed, and there was no intention of reopening them.

John E. Parsons, David B. Ogden, Edward M. Shepard, and Henry B. Closson, forming the law firm of Parsons, Shepard Ogden, are the defendants in an action brought by James W. Murphy and Michael McCormack to recover $19,721.04 with interest from 1896.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- The fifth annual meeting of the American Academy of Political and Social Science will be held here April 12 and 13, the general topic being "America's Race Problems." The annual address on "The Causes of Race Superiority" will be given by Prof. Edward A. Ross, formerly of Leland Stanford Junior University and now of the University of Nebraska.

ALBANY, March 25 -- There was quite a lively discussion in the Senate to-night over the bill of Senator Ambler, placing the investigation of food products, as to their purity. In the hands of the Agricultural Department and forbidding the use of alum in baking powder.

The Martin Engel Association ball last night was quite up to the mark set by those who evolve its tickets of invitation. These tickets were an innovation, or rather they contained an innovation, namely, that no gentleman would be admitted unless he wore a "full-dress suit." Happily, this is as far as the edict went.

Albert L. Johnson made a formal proposition last evening to construct a tunnel under the East River from the New York City Hall to Brooklyn, under that borough to South Brooklyn, under the Narrows to Staten Island, and clear across to the Jersey shore.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 25 -- The canceling of to-night's Harvard-Princeton basket ball game by Princeton is taken by many Harvard men to mean a cessation of all athletic relations between the two universities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Rev. Mr. Gamewell, (the missionary who built the fortifications for the protection of the legations in Peking,) in a lecture at Columbia University a few days ago showed stereopticon pictures of Chinese students educated by the Chinese system, which, as he said, "does not educate," its only benefit being the preparation for position under the Chinese Government.

Chinatown was in a state of excitement last night, for the members of On Leong Tong, aristocrats and controllers of purse strings, were signalizing their annual fete by the firing of more cannon crackers and other noisy explosives than the quarter had seen since it celebrated the last Fourth of July.

RALEIGH, N.C., March 25 -- A case begun in the Superior Court and appealed to and just decided by the Supreme Court, is strange and unusual in some respects and shows the intense partisan feeling of the average colored voter who resides in a Southern State, and how loyal the great body of these voters are to the cause of the Republican Party.

PHILADELPHIA, March 25 -- The market was strong in the special issues that have been dominating the list for the last three days, but wavered in other stocks. A new point of interest was the sudden weakness in Philadelphia Traction and Electric and People's 4s. Until to-day both had steadily ignored the heaviness in Union Traction.

CHICAGO, March 25 -- In the Circuit Court to-day Lambert Tree, Jr., the son of ex-Judge Tree, ex-Minister to Russia, filed a bill asking absolute divorce from his wife, who is the daughter of Marshall Field. The grounds alleged in the bill are desertion. Mrs. Tree is now traveling in the south of France.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The answer for the British Government expressing it inability to accept the Hay-Pauncefote treaty in the form amended by the United States Senate was made public to-day. It is in the form of a communication from Lord Lansdowne, British Minister of Foreign Affairs, to Lord Pauncefote, and asks the latter to read the dispatch to the Secretary of State and to leave a copy in his hands.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- G. Poster Sanford, the former Yale athlete and coach, and later Columbia's head football coach, said to-day that he intended to reenter Yale at once. He will take a post-graduate course in the Law School.

LONDON, March 25 -- Money was much wanted to-day, and discounts were firm. In view of the monetary requirements this week. The decline in consols from the closing price Saturday of 95 9-16 to 9 was due to large cash sales, the prospects of dearer money and the expected colonial loan issue.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- The National Republican Committee is about to suspend business for the Summer, and on Monday next will not, as usual, open the rooms that have been in charge of Perry S. Heath. All sorts of explanations have been suggested for this interruption of political business under Mr. Hanna's direction.

OMAHA, Neb., March 25 -- A dozen transcontinental trains on the various lines in Nebraska are snowbound to-night and several hundred east-bound passengers for New York and inter-State points are indefinitely delayed. The roads hope to get the trains moving by to-morrow.

ANSONIA, Conn., March 25 -- During the morning service in the First Baptist Church at Shelton yesterday a strong odor of coal gas pervaded the room. Thinking it would pass away, the pastor, the Rev. Thomas A.T. Hanna, continued his sermon, and no one wishing to be the first to leave, the congregation remained seated.

LONDON, March 26 -- The Chinese Minister, Sir Chih-Chen-Lo-Feng-Luh, called at the Foreign Office yesterday afternoon and urged the British Government to bring pressure to bear in order to prevent Russia drom securing the necessary signatures to the Manchuria agreement.

The crowd that filled Madison Square Garden last night left no possible room for doubt an to the popularity of the "Soldiers' Show," as the annual tournament held by the Military Athletic League has come to be known.

The letter of the Committee of Fifteen to the Governor of the State is strong, sincere, and convincing. The condition of affairs which the committee has to present is presented without mincing or flinching. Open and notorious vice is no longer confined to known and avoidable buildings, or even quarters.

WASHINGTON, March 25 -- Some disappointment is expressed by friends of civil service reform in and out of the service of the Government because the President has chosen ex-Representative Rodenberg of Illinois to be a Civil Service Commissioner to succeed the Hon. Mark S. Brewer.

After spending nearly twenty hours in the bay owing to the fog the Cunard Line steamship Etruria arrived at her dock at 2:30 yesterday afternoon, with decks damaged and rails bent as the result of a two days' storm which she had encountered on one of the most eventful voyages in her history.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 25 -- The Yale fencing team took the Columbia fencers into camp to-night in College Street Hall after an interesting and prolonged struggle, the Yale men winning at the end only on two two-minute tests after a draw, through the excellent work of S. 11, Delafield.

The Columbia crews practiced, as usual, on the Harlem yesterday afternoon, under the direction or Coach Hanlan. A change was made in the order of the first "Varsity boat. Townsend rowing No. 3 in place of O'Loughlin, who was absent. There were also a number of changes in the other boats.

Wall Street was full of all sorts of rumors yesterday regarding the supposed impending strike of coal miners throughout the anthracite region. These rumors had started last Saturday with the arrival in the city of President Mitchell of the United Mine Workers and three District Presidents, when it was said that the party called at the office of J. Pierpont Morgan with the object of securing Mr. Morgan's recognition of the union.

Bridge Commissioner Shea held a, consultation with Mayor Van Wyck yesterday morning regarding the contract for the foundation tower on the Brooklyn side of what is now known to the city officials as East River Bridge No. 3. The amount or the contract is in the neighborhood of $800,000.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 24 (Afternoon.) -- In military circles it is reported that the officers of the Cossack Guard Regiment have petitioned the authorities not to employ them henceforth in suppressing riots, holding that to pit them against defenseless men and women is beneath their dignity.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 25 -- The worst storm ever experienced in this part of Alabama broke over this city at 10 o'clock this morning. Telegraph wires are in such condition that it is impossible to ascertain what has occurred outside of Jefferson County, of which Birmingham is the chief city, but in this county alone twenty-five people are known to have been killed, and over fifty have been more or less severely wounded.
RALEIGH, N.C., March 25 -- A suit in the Superior Court here against the Seaboard Air Line Railway has developed one of the most novel accidents known to the annals of jurisprudence.

HAVANA, March 25 -- A stockholder of the Havana Gas Company has filed a complaint alleging the practice of extortion by persons claiming to have influence in Washington to regulate the duty on crude oil. It is said that the company has paid $40,000 in commissions during the last two years.

ALBANY, March 25 -- The Philip William Ebling Brewing Company of New York City to-day filed with the Secretary of State a certificate of an increase of its capital stock from $750,000 to $1,25,000,000. The certificate states that the capital of the company actually paid in is $750,000 and that the amount of the debts and liabilities of the company is $430,055.
ALBANY, March 25 -- Gov. Odell surprised the Legislature to-night with five vetoes of bills of members in which he enunciated several new ideas he has as to legislation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The item in this morning's issue of THE TIMES reporting the denial by the President of seven petitions for pardon and covering the Attorney General's indorsement upon the application for pardon of Joe Martin, shows a disposition which, without right or justification, has too long prevailed in the Attorney General's office.

More litigation has developed over the estate of Christian F.T. Steinway, one of the founders of the Steinway piano business. The present action is brought by Henry W. T. Steinway, a nephew, who demands an accounting of the estate. The action is directed against Charles H. Steinway, Frederick T. Steinway, and Henry Ziegler, as executors and trustees under the will of C.F.T. Steinway, and about twenty-five heirs at law.

The poet has told us that when KOSCIUSKO fell, hope for a season bade the world farewell. When PLATT sinks hope rises. Let us all fervently pray that it be not merely for a season, but for all time. It has been a cherished habit of THE TIMES to indulge in illusions about the fall of this boss.

The members of the Hundred Year Club may not last through the century they say they are going to live, but during the lifetime of their club, whatever it may be, they will hear if not learn much that is remarkable.
CHICAGO, March 26 -- New York exchange was quoted at 50 cents' discount to-day. Money for time and call loans was figured at 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 26. -- The proposed amendments to the charter of New York City will probably be made with the full consent of the Tammany delegation in the Legislature and the consent of Mayor Van Wyck so that the bill will not be vetoed and the Legislature will not be required to pass the bill a second time.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A.M. Thakara, American Consul at Havre, France, in a report to the State Department gives the opinion that there is at present no profitable market in France for American coal. This condition is due to the fact that there has been a decided fall in the price of British coal during the past four months.

The properly owners in the vicinity of the proposed Waverley Place extension denounced the plan as being contrary to public interests at a hearing held in the City Hall yesterday. In addition to those who spoke, many others wanted to be heard, but President James J. Coogan cut the proceedings short to prevent further protest.

Bridget Scanlon, wife of Peter Scanlon, a retired contractor, was shot dead at her home on the second floor of 345 East Seventy-seventh Street late yesterday afternoon by her nineteen-year-old daughter, Nora Scanlon. The girl was arrested and taken to the East Sixty-seventh Street Station, but was released very shortly by order of Coroner Fitzpatrick, who after an investigation said the shooting was unquestionably an accident.
A petition was presented to Mayor Van Wyck yesterday requesting that proceedings be taken before the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for the removal of City Magistrate Joseph Pool.

ALBANY, March 26. -- Frank H. Platt came to Albany to-day and had an interview with Gov. Odell. Mr. Platt said he did not come to Albany especially to see the Governor. He said he had a case on in the Court of Appeals. Mr. Platt Was with the Governor for a half hour or more. He was asked if he had brought up any amendments to the charter which Senator Platt wanted adopted.

To the Editor of The New York Times: According to the principle, "Altera pars audiatur," you will probably permit me to answer the "Moral Mugwump," who in to-day's issue of your valuable paper favors the withdrawing of all Christian missionaries from China. I am surprised at the shortsightedness of the writer -- to say the least!

The Board of Aldermen, at the meeting; yesterday, held a spirited debate as to whether $500,000 should be spent for repairs to the Millburn Reservoir on Long Island. The reservoir was built at a cost of $1,500,000, but will not hold water, and has never been in use. The engineers of the Water Supply Department claim that the reservoir can be coated with cement for $500,000.

-- A committee appointed by the Texas Legislature has been investigating the present condition of the district devastated by the Galveston storm, and, incidentally, it has discovered some decidedly unpleasant circumstances connected with the distribution of the money and supplies contributed for the relief of the flood sufferers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The evidence produced through the blatherskite proceedings of the Lexow upheaval brought about a demand for a new excise law which would take the saloons out of politics and lift their owners to the plane of manhood and citizenship, as well as do away with blackmailing by the police.
Silver bullion certificates were quoted on the Stock Exchange at 62@63. There were no sales.

BOSTON, March 26 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in better demand. The reason assigned was that funds were more concentrated. Loans were made at 2 1/2 @ 3 per cent. New York funds sold at 10 and 12 1/2 cents discount for cash.

With the purpose of ascertaining the ex act conditions prevailing in the hospitals for contagious diseases on North Brother Island, a party of newspaper men accompanied the Commissioners of Health on an inspection tour yesterday afternoon.

Minetta Brook, once a placid stream dividing Manhattan Island from the North to the East River, is responding to the rains in a way that results in trouble for Thomas P. Galligan, who is digging in its Sixth Avenue channel. Mr. Galligan is in charge of the work of preparing the soil for the erection of a mammoth dry goods store for Simpson, Crawford Simpson.

LONDON, March 27. -- A fashionably dressed man committed suicide in a hansom cab near Regent's Park last evening. The visiting cards found on his person give the name "Howard Douglas Campbell," and there were letters in his pockets addressed to him by the Duke of Argyll.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the United States statistics of export any one familiar with the general run of our export business will observe some errors when looking over the figures issued from Washington. Take the following:

BRISTOL, R.I., March 26 -- The bracing of the cup defender on the bilges in and about the region of the mainmast step is practically completed. A few workmen are now finishing up. The greater number of hands engaged on this work for the past two weeks have been sent to other parts of the craft, to aid in completing the bracing.

Francis L. Wandell, a lawyer, with offices at 49 Chambers Street, is suing his wife for an absolute divorce. He names Dr. A. Norton Brockway, a Harlem physician, who is a married man, as the co-respondent. The case is now on trial before Justice Blanchard in the Supreme Court.
The Royal Insurance Company of Liverpool has acquired the Lancashire Insurance Company of Manchester, England.

BALTIMORE, March 26 -- The market to-day continued its animation, with a steady to firm tone. There were no large advances scored, such as distinguished Monday's trading, but a number of small gains were recorded by various secondary issues, while the advances previously established by the leaders were all well held.

The Rev. Edward S. Philipps of St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church, Hazleton, Penn., arrived in this city last evening and registered at the Ashland House, where he had a conference with John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers. Father Philipps was seen late last night by a NEW YORK TIMES reporter, and said he had great hopes that his mission of peace would be successful.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 19. -- "Seances" are "the thing" in the small towns of Porto Rico these days. Senor Don Matienzo Cintron, a member of the Executive Council of Porto Rico, is at the head of the movement, which is dangerously contagious. He is traveling about the country holding seances, while the minutes of the Executive Council record him "absent" from the weekly sessions.

LONDON, March 27. -- The Pretoria and Bloemfontein correspondents of The Times send long dispatches admitting that Lord Kitchener's policy and operations have failed to achieve the results hoped for, and pointing out that the British public must be prepared to return to the original policy of occuping districts and studding the country with military posts as the only means of effecting complete pacification.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., March 26. -- Grand River to-night reached the highwater mark of 1893 -- 12 feet 6 inches -- and is rising an inch an hour. The Rouge, Flat, and Thorn Apple, three big tributaries, are pouring a swollen flood into the Grand. All the factories along the canals in this city have been shut down, and their basements are flooded.

At the March general meeting of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, held last night at the Yachtsmen's Club, 47 West Forty-third Street, the racing schedule for the coming season was adopted and made public. The meeting was presided over by President Pierce. Thirtyfive representatives of the various clubs attended, and, following the adoption of the schedule, voted on amendments to the racing rules.

Christian, Jew, and the believer in the teachings of Confucius met on equal terms last night at Calvary Baptist Church, West Fifty-seventh Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, to discuss the Golden Rule. The gathering was held under the auspices of the Baron and Baroness de Hirsch Monument Association.

LONDON, March 26. -- The Atlantic Transport liner Minneapolis. Capt. Layland, from New York March 16 for London, has towed into St. Michael's, Azores, the new British bark Comet of 2.837 tons, Capt. Davts, from Greenock March 8 for Philadelphia. The Minneapolis picked up the Comet at sea. The bark was dismasted in a gale.

LONDON, March 27. -- A dispatch to the Exchange Telegraph Company from Paris states on the highest authority that a mine has been discovered beneath the palace of Emperor Nicholas at Tzarskoe-Selo, seventeen miles south of St. Petersburg.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 26. -- Smallpox, to some extent, is prevalent in Porto Rico. Ponce, the city which rejoices in the reputation of being the city with the highest death rate, has the greatest number of cases, and it is there that the disease first started. It could have been nipped in the bud had proper action been taken in the beginning.

CHICAGO, March 26. -- No doubt longer exists in the railway world that the Chicago Great Western road will soon pass from its present control. Ansell Oppenheim, First Vice President of the road, in speaking of the matter, said:

SOMERSET, Ohio, March 26. -- Seven bandits partially wrecked the State Bank of Somerset early to-day by exploding a heavy charge of nitro-glycerine in the vault doors, secured $500, appropriated two livery rigs, held a posse of citizens at bay, and escaped in the face of a heavy fire.
LONDON, March 26 -- Money was much wanted to-day and supplies were restricted and dependent on the Bank of England. Discounts were firm.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- The crisis brought about through the expiration of the period allowed for the signature by China of the Manchuria agreement was the principal topic before the Cabinet to-day. To make clear to the public the complete disapproval on the part of the United States Government of this kind of secret treaty making, it was deemed proper to give out for publication the following memorandum:

Even the weather was Lenten yesterday. It was a dismal day, and there were not many entertainments to relieve its monotony. Mrs. H. De Berkeley Parsons gave a bridge whist party, and in the evening there were a number of dinners, including those given by Mrs. Ogden Mills, a very small affair; Mrs. Eugene Schieffelin, and Mrs. Strong.

In spite of the disagreeable weather the three Columbia Varsity crews had their usual practice on the Harlem yesterday afternoon, but the enthusiasm of the candidates for the freshman crew was so dampened that not enough of them appeared to send out either of their two boats.

Albert T. Patrick, accused of forging William M. Rice's signature to checks aggregating $223,000, and to wills and assignments transfering the remainder of the millionaire's property to himself, and then extinguishing the feeble spark of life in the old man's body, was again arraigned for examination, charged with murder, before Justice Jerome, sitting as a Magistrate, in the Law Library of the District Attorney's office, yesterday.
LONDON, March 27. -- The Morning Post, in the course of a sarcastic editorial dealing with the memorandum of the United States Government on the Manchuria Convention, says:

The three articles which Mr. GEORGE KENNAN has published in The Outlook on the Philippines have been very instructive. He has made a careful study, with the full co-operation of the Government at Washington, of official reports and correspondence, and has had the advantage of access to much private correspondence from officers in the field and of intercourse with officers who have returned from the islands.

George R. Read has sold for the New York Infant Asylum to Daniel Slawson, for about $140,000, the plot of thirty-four lots on the west side of Broadway, between One Hundred and Sixty-eighth and One Hundred and Sixty-ninth Streets.

BERLIN, March 26. -- Dr. Stuebel, Director of the Colonial Department, has started for London, to assist in expediting the conclusion of the negotiations regarding the indemnity to be demanded of China. Dr. Stuebel was selected for this task by the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, because he was formerly Consul General of Germany at Shanghai and is specially conversant with Chinese affairs.

ALBANY, March 26. -- The Lynn bill to amend the railroad law in relation to the acquisition of property by street surface railroads came up in the Assembly to-day on the order of second reading. Assemblyman Sullivan of New York City characterized the bill as an effort "to give the Metropolitan Traction Company the right to acquire the world."
A hearing was held before the local Board of Improvements of the Eleventh and Twelfth Districts yesterday on the proposed approach to the new East River Bridge in the Borough of Manhattan.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Complete statistics of the production in the United States during the year 1900, of Bessemer steel ingots and castings and Bessemer steel rails, have been obtained by the American Iron and Steel Association from the manufacturers.

President Alexander E. Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission was asked yesterday if he would make any statement regarding the published answer given out by Albert L. Johnson in reply to his letter of two days ago.

Tod Sloan, the most-talked-of jockey in the United States and the rider who, after being engaged to ride the horses of the Prince of Wales last year, was suddenly released, and then notified by the English Jockey Club that it would be useless for him to apply for a license this year, is in New York, after a Winter in San Francisco, where he rode with only limited success at the Winter race meetings.

After a long day's session, the Passenger Committee of the Trunk Line Association failed yesterday to reach an agreement on the question of adjusting the differential rate between New York and Chicago west bound. The proposition under discussion was to abolish all second-class rates and to make the fare over all differential lines to Chicago $18.
LONDON, March 27. -- The Shanghai correspondent of The Times, wiring yesterday, says:

"If the city is not sufficiently rich to supply common schools enough for the population," asked a teacher in one of the Brooklyn schools, "why should it give secondary education free, or, at all events, why give a college education free?" This is a question that very frequently crops up when teachers meet and talk of the lack of accommodations for the elementary pupils in the various sections of the city.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 26. -- The Post says: "Owing to the passage by the Legislature of Nevada of a valued policy law over the Governor's veto, the coast representatives of nearly all the standard Insurance companies have decided to write no new risks in the State of Nevada. Existing policies will be allowed to expire."

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 26. -- William Dearduff, twenty years old, a clerk, was arrested to-day charged with stealing $3,110 worth of diamond rings from his employers, Edwards Sloan, wholesale jewelers. Later, when confronted with the rings, which had been found hidden in the basement of the firm's building.

The fog that since Sunday has enshrouded the bay showed no signs of lifting yesterday. Ocean liners, ferryboats, and tugs moved at the slowest possible speed, their whistles keeping up an incessant din. Outgoing vessels had a difficult task in making their way down the bay and past the Hook, and consumed hours before they finally Cleared the Bar and proceeded on their voyages.
Councilman Francisco proposed at the meeting of the Municipal Council yesterday to erect in each of the five boroughs of the Greater New York a monument to Andrew Carnegie. Councilman Cassidy said:

ALBANY, March 26. -- "What J.P. Morgan and other private bankers want is all the privileges that other corporations get, and the right to antagonize and compete with banking corporations and yet not pay any tax for the privilege." Senator Krum made this remark to John B. Pine this afternoon at the hearing on the bill to tax private bankers 1 per cent. on their capital.

The problem of properly adjusting the relations between the employer and the employe was discussed yesterday evening at the meeting of the Get-Together Club, which was held in the concert room of Madison Square Garden, and was preceded by a dinner at which nearly 500 members of the club were seated.

PHILADELPHIA, March 26 -- Two houses selling Union Traction poured the stock on the market to-day until it went down from 30 1/2 to 29 3/8, the lowest for the year. It recovered to 30 and then sagged off to 29 5/8. The Street had to get a new theory for the weakness, and a rumor was circulated that a bill providing for placing the company's wires underground would be introduced in Councils next week.

PARIS, March 26. -- The Chamber of Deputies to-day entered upon the discussion of Article XV, of the proposed Law of Associations, which deals with the property of illegal associations. An amendment of small importance was adopted, and the Chamber adjourned.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 26. -- Five young women of this city are certain they saw an apparition this morning. They claim they saw an exact picture of a dead friend, whose body lay on a bed in the room where they were, suddenly appear outlined against the wall surrounded by a cloud.

Samuel L. Clemens has instituted an action in the United States Circuit Court against Butler Brothers, publishers of this city and Chicago. The action is brought through Augustus T. Gurlitz, who is also counsel for Rudyard Kipling, in a suit against R.F. Fenno Co., publishers, of this city, on alleged infringement of trade mark and copyright.

WASHINGTON, March 26. -- A new and important phase of the Chinese negotiations has been presented by the action of the Ministers at Peking in agreeing yesterday to submit to their various Governments the question whether Articles VIII. and IX. of the joint note shall be carried out by the military authorities of all the powers interested in China, or only by those powers continuing to take part in the application of these articles.
Our neighbor The Sun has done an injustice to our neighbor the Staats-Zeitung for which we are confident it will atone handsomely when reason shall recapture the seat surrendered to resentment.

As we were saying the other day, every Japanese believes that his country will sooner or later have to fight for its life with Russia. "Why not now?" is the question that the Japanese seem to be asking themselves, in view of the recent Russian provocations. And they are getting no satisfactory answer.

The preliminaries in the New York Athletic Club's wrestling tournament for the club's championships were held last night, in the clubhouse gymnasium, on Fiftyninth Street and Sixth Avenue, when the candidates in four classes met and in bouts limited to ten minutes each, with an allowance of five minutes additional should there be no fall in ten minutes, eliminated those of the club's wrestlers who were not of championship quality.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- The market was dominated by the Readings and the Choctaws, but the strength in these failed to cause even a ripple in other stocks. Union Traction and Cambria Steel were both under selling pressure all day. There was a notable recovery in Consolidated Lake Superior, and the National Asphalt issues came into prominence for the first time in over a month.

BALTIMORE, March 27. -- The market today disclosed no relaxation in either its activity or strength. The animated dealings in Seaboards and United Railways imparted a marked firmness to the whole list.

Let no one in purchasing matting take to the Japanese because of its extra wearing qualities, as a slip of the pen made it appear in a paragraph upon Summer carpetings in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Tuesday. The Japanese mattings are delightfully attractive, they wear well, and many people will use nothing else at any cost.

C. P. H. Gilbert, architect, is preparing plans for the new fire-proof residence to be erected on the property 11 and 13 West Fifty-third Street for Col. William Barbour. The building will be 44 feet in width and six stories in height, the front to be of a very light buff limestone. A contract has been awarded, and the work of demolishing the present houses will be begun immediately.

The committee of business men from the anthracite coal mining districts who, it was arranged, should accompany the Rev. Edward S. Philipps to the office of J. Pierpont Morgan and try to bring about a settlement of the dispute between the miners and the coal operators, reached this city early yesterday morning.

Part I., Special Term, of the Supreme Court was turned into a regular Police Court yesterday morning, and Justice McAdam sat as a committing Magistrate. This was due to the refusal on Tuesday of Magistrate Pool to entertain the complaint of Deputy Sheriff Pendergast against Neil Toelberg.

ALBANY, March 27. -- The Senate Cities Committee and the Assembly Cities Committee held separate meetings to-night to finally decide upon the questions embraced in the report of the Charter Revision Commission. Members of the Charter Revision Commission were present at the meetings. It was nearly 12 o'clock before the meetings were adjourned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you kindly permit a constant reader of your paper to take an exception to a statement made by a "Moral Mugwump"? Germany is asked to improve her barbarians, who have not advanced since the days of Caesar. This is a very untrue and exaggerated piece of rhetoric, which shows little knowledge and little fairness of judgment.

Ex-President Graver Cleveland delivered last night, at Alexander Hall. Princeton University, the first of two lectures on the national boundary dispute between Great Britain and Venezuela, which dispute involved the boundary line separating Venezuela from the English colony of British Guiana.

Major Gen. Joseph Wheeler.
