United States Army, was the reviewing officer at the Madison Square Garden Military Athletic Tournament last night, and the crowd cheered the famous soldier in a way to make the gallant veteran blush with pride. Despite the matinee of the afternoon, the amphitheatre of the huge building was packed to the limit, the fine weather having induced the attendance of many who had not made the venture during the recent rains.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., March 27. -- The sloop Belle, commanded by Capt. Eli Johnson, stranded on the shoals at Holly Beach last night. There was a high wind prevailing at the time. Several members of the crew lashed themselves to stanchions. As soon as the vessel struck a rocket was fired, and was seen by the crew of the life-saving station.
LONDON, March 28. -- Dr. Morrison, wiring to The Times from Peking yesterday, says:

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The Industrial Commission has made public a report upon the taxation of corporations prepared by its expert agent, George Clapperton. The report makes a volume of 178 pages. The greater part of it is devoted to a summary of the tax system of the States of Massachusetts, Connecticut, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Indiana, Michigan, Illinois, Wisconsin, Iowa, and Texas.

It was learned yesterday on good authority that F. D. Underwood, Second Vice President and General Manager of the Baltimore and Ohio, had decided to accept the position of President of the Brie Railroad which had been offered to him. Mr. Underwood, it was said, would take charge about April 1.

Under the title "England and America; Strangers Yet," Mr. ARNOLD WHITE contributes an important article to the current number of The Anglo-Saxon Review. His point is that it is urgently necessary that the two great branches of the English-speaking race should really understand each other, but that the facilities for such an understanding have not yet been provided.

ALBANY, March 27. -- A new police bill offered by a Republican organization Senator, despite the decision of the conference in New York City last Sunday, put the leaders here to-night in a state of ferment for a time.

ALBANY, March 27. -- There will be some things in the revised charter which Gov. Odell does not like. One of them is the two-year term for the Mayor. Gov. Odall was one of those who believed in a four-year term, but Senator Platt insisted upon the two-year term, and the Governor has agreed to the proposition.
A meeting of the Board of Education was held last night. President Miles M. O'Brien was in the chair.

The appointment of Mr. RODENBERG of Illinois to the Civil Service Commission is a mistake of which the best and only sufficient correction is the withdrawal of the appointment. Unless so corrected it will strengthen the spoilsmen and weaken the merit system. That is a process that has gone on pretty steadily for the last three years.

Attired in a new suit of light color and cut in the latest English walking style, Capt. Chapman of the Tenderloin Police Station yesterday appeared in a new role. He decided that it was too long a journey for justice to the Jefferson Market Police Court, so he established himself as a Magistrate and heard a case in the station house, according to precedents set by Justice Jerome.

From every part of Brooklyn where there is a public school to use them, there come complaints that the teachers of the schools have the greatest difficulty in obtaining supplies for the use of the children. One Principal, for example, complains that supplies ordered in November last had not been delivered to him on the 15th inst.

ALBANY, March 27. -- A large delegation interested in the question of good roads had an audience with Gov. Odell to-day and asked for an appropriation of $515,000. This is the amount which has been appropriated by the various counties upon the theory that the appropriation made by them would be duplicated by the State.

LONDON, March 27. -- The Oxford and Cambridge crews did some fast rowing this morning against scratch crews from the Thames and Leander Clubs respectively. Both easily left the pace-makers behind. Seldom has there been such uncertainty as to the result of a race between the two universities.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Official news of the capture of Aguinaldo had not reached the War Department up to a late hour to-night. The President had retired before news arrived, and will hear of the capture for the first time in the morning.
CLEVELAND, March 27. -- The Plain Dealer to-morrow will say:

One outcome of the proceedings of the Local Board of Public Improvements of the Thirteenth District on Tuesday night, at which time it was decided to approve the petition for the extension of Waverley Place to Lafayette Place, will very likely be the making of a complaint against ex-President of the Borough James J. Coogan for wrongfully exercising the functions of the office.

Commissioner Murphy issued yesterday a typewritten statement in regard to lessening the area of the Nineteenth Precinct. It was styled " change of boundary of the Nineteenth and establishment of a new precinct." The boundaries of the Nineteenth "as proposed by the Commissioner," the statement set forth, would be Forty-second Street, Seventh Avenue, Twenty-seventh Street, and Fourth Avenue, and of the new preeinet, its designation by number to be determined hereafter.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 27. -- President Hadley of Yale University delivered an address yesterday at Stanford University before a large audience. He gave some novel views in regard to a combination of American universities in the nature of co-operation by which the special excellences of each may be shared by all students and rivalry be devoted to stimulation of scholarship rather than to build up one college at the expense of another.

ALBANY, March 27. -- The bill regulating the practice of Christian Science healing in New York State has apparently no chance of passage by the Legislature, although Assemblyman Bell probably will insist upon a vote upon it. Mr. Bell had the bill laid aside yesterday because, after a canvass of the Assembly, he ascertained that he could not muster enough votes to pass the measure.

In the sixtieth competition on the armory rifle range for the Abeel Trophy, open to teams of ten men from each company of the Seventh Regiment, G won the prize in the last tournament that is likely to be held until next November. The scores made were as follows:

ST. PETERSBURG, March 27. -- The correspondent of the Associated Press is informed on competent authority that the Russo-Chinese agreement will probably be signed shortly, but that the negotiations continue and that result is not yet certain. The details will, possibly, be slightly modified, but the arrangements will be substantially as demanded.
WASHINGTON, March 27. -- Secretary Long to-day cabled an order to Admiral Rodgers, on board the cruiser Now York, at Tangier to proceed at once with that vessel to Manila.

The developments now in progress in Canada and Mexico, while not immediately formidable as threatening competition with the iron and steel industries of the United States, are of interest as showing that countries not hitherto included among the important iron and steel producers of the world are waking up to the fact that favoring natural conditions are everywhere the elements of success in manufacturing, and that this country has no monopoly of such advantages.

The first accident to happen to the mechanism of the air motor cars run by the Metropolitan Company on Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets occurred yesterday afternoon. A car freshly charged had been run out from the barn on Twelfth Avenue to the tracks on Twenty-fourth Street, just in front of the machine shops of the Compressed Air Company, where the mechanical equipment is made.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 27. -- A mob of breaker boys and men and women sympathizers with the striking girls of the Bamford silk mills of this city set upon Superintendent Spears and his assistant this evening, and for a time it looked as if there would be bloodshed. The Superintendent was on his way to this city when the crowd of breaker boys met him and fired volley after volley of mud and stones.

C. K. G. Billings carried off the choice prizes last night in the Horse Show at Durland's new Riding Academy, Sixty-sixth Street, near Central Park West. Besides winning first and second in the Speedway Cup class for trotters, his pair of harness horses, Gov. Blair and Mate, triumphed over Frank Jay Gould's famous roadsters, Burlingham and Sandringhum.

LONDON, March 28. -- The English inanimate bird-shooting clubs were delighted at the reception yesterday of a dispatch from the United States announcing that the American clubs agree to their challenge to meet the English clubs in this country some time in the coming Summer. A meeting will be held in London to discuss the arrangements.

The final scheduled games in the tournament of the Life Insurance Bowling League were decided on Ehler's alleys last night. The Mutual Life Insurance Company Team No. 2 leads in the series, but several postponed games yet to be rolled may alter the present standing. The scores:

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The "Exes" who are to face each other on the St. Louis Exposition Commission have not yet been named, but assurance is given at the White House that eight members of the commission have practically been decided upon, and that the ninth man only stops the procession.

Acting upon the initiative of Gen. Francis Vinton Greene, Capt. Alfred T. Mahan, United States Navy, (retired:) George Macculloch Miller, and others, the Church Club of New York decided last night to take immediate steps to establish a diocese of the Protestant Episcopal Church of America in the Philippine Islands, with a resident Bishop and duly appointed ministers.

The defense in the action for absolute divorce brought by Francis L. Wandell against his wife was commenced yesterday afternoon before Justice Blanchard in the Supreme Court with Mrs. Wandell as the first witness. Her lawyer, J. Stewart Ross, in his opening address to the jury said: " This action is the result of a conspiracy and a fraud."

The week continues to proceed quietly with the same measure of Lenten dullness. Yesterday, perhaps, was a bit gayer, because there were meetings of sewing classes and of the Knickerbocker Bowling Club. The White Star pier presented an animated scene. The Oceanic departed with a long list of passengers, many of them members of the fashionable world, and there were crowds to see them off.

C. Albert Stevens died yesterday at the Albemarle Hotel. Although Mr. Stevens had been suffering from pneumonia for some days, his death was unexpected, even to his wife, who left his bedside only a few moments before the end came.

ALBANY, March 27. -- In the Assembly this morning Mr. Morgan of Kings introduced a privileged resolution withdrawing the Forest Park Storage Reserve bill for Brooklyn from the Mayor of New York for amendment, so as to make it permissive. It is understood that the Mayor will then approve of it.

ALBANY, March 27. -- Senator Slater to-day introduced a bill appropriating $400,000 for the use of the Palisade Commission in purchasing the Palisade Mountains. The provisions of the bill are as follows:

Albert L. Johnson said yesterday that he intended to hold a series of mass meetings throughout the city for the purpose of putting before the people his plans for a tunnel to South Brooklyn, Staten Island, and New Jersey. The first of these meetings, he said, will be held on Staten Island.

All the east side seemed to converge toward New Irving Hall, at Broome and Norfolk Street, last night. Fully 5,000 eager listeners assembled there to hear the speakers at a mass meeting of Russian Socialists. Outside the hall the street was crowded with those who could not get in, end as fast as any of the audience tired and went home their places were fought for.

The engagement here of about $500,000 of gold for export to Europe starts discussion in Wall Street as to money market possibilities. The amount is small and its shippers explain that the engagement is a special transaction -- which is intended to signify that the shipment is made independent of current exchange market rates, there seeming to be actually a slight loss in the exportation.

BERLIN, March 27. -- The Cologne Gazette says, regarding the rumors that Crown Prince Frederick William intends to marry an Austrian Princess, that it is reliably informed that the Crown Prince will, under no circumstances, marry a Roman Catholic, but either a German or an English Princess.

The crew of the Long Beach Live Saving Station took seven persons off of the little Norwegian fruit steamer Gwent yesterday morning. The vessel was aground near the " point," and a happier lot of passengers never welcomed a lifeboat. The names of those who were rescued follow:

ROCHESTER, March 27. -- Advices from all points in the northern and western parts of the State report serious damage by flood. The waters of rivers and the smaller tributary streams are reported as overflowing their banks, causing widespread inundations which threaten to destroy much property, if not bring about loss of life before they begin to subside.
NICE, March 27. -- The landscape painter Cazin died here to-day.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The British Government has protested against China making a convention with any power touching territorial or financial affairs until the present troubles in that country are concluded. The fact of the British protest was made known here for the first time to-day by a dispatch from one of the European Foreign Offices.

The contest over the adoption of a plan for the Manhattan approach to the terminal of the new East River Bridge has been begun before the local Boards of Public improvements of the Eleventh and Twelfth Districts.

A raiding party of internal revenue agents yesterday came upon a saloon, a billiard room, a Jewish synagogue, and a whisky still all doing business under the same roof in the house at 202 Varet Street, Brooklyn. The still, which was really what the officers were after, was working right up to its full capacity of fifty gallons, and was full of half-made spirits when the posse pounced upon it.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- President McKinley would be without a Cabinet in a week if he should attempt to make good all the reports that are issuing from Washington concerning imminent Cabinet changes. So far as the President is informed, the office of Attorney General is the only one he will have to fill during the year, or perhaps in the next four years.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., March 27. -- The sloop yacht Memory, now lying at the Jacob yard, has been sold by E. Hope Norton to J. C. Bavier of New York. The raceabout Spindrift has been sold to Samuel Comly of Port Chester by Mr. Pierre. The Spindrift is also laid up at the Jacob yard. The Gardiner Cox designed sloop for Otto Lohrke of Shelter Island. N. Y., has been completed.

The Imperial Insurance Department of Berlin reports that 17,000,000 persons are now insured in Germany. Last year, 454,451 accidents occurred, and the sum of 86,535,632 marks was paid out for claims, as against 78,680,632 marks in 1890.

PEKING, March 27. -- The Ministers of the powers do not consider that the murder of the Rev. J. Stonehouse of the London Missionary Society, who was killed by Chinese brigands fourteen miles east of Tien-Tain recently, affects the Chinese situation politically. They are perfectly aware that the country around Shi-Nan is infested with robbers, who are naturally hostile to foreigners, and would take any opportunity to kill one.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- There are more arrivals here of members of Congress who recently visited Cuba, and each newcomer has views to express concerning the situation and the future prospects in the island. Representative Stevens of Minnesota, who left New York on March 6, and has had a comparatively long visit in Cuba, says that nothing but freedom for Cuba affords a settlement of the Cuban question.

PHILADELPHIA, March 27. -- The newly-elected Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company held their first meeting to-day, at which the allotment of the new issue of stock was determined upon. The board decided to issue the stock to shareholders at the rate of 33 1-3 per cent, of their present holdings at the price of $60 per share.

WASHINGTON, March 27. -- The racing season of the East, under the jurisdiction of The Jockey Club, will open to-morrow with the Spring meeting of the Washington Jockey Club on the Bennings race track. More horses are now stabled at the course than were ever collected there before in the history of the track, and there is every promise of the best class of racing that Washington has enjoyed in years.

Major Frank Heath, Ordnance Department, will proceed to the works of Warner a Swasey, Cleveland, and the works of William Heckert, Flndlay Ohio, on official business pertaining to the inspection of azimuth instruments in process of manufacture for the Ordnance Department.

YONKERS, N.Y., March 28 -- Mrs. Katherine Wegener of this city was arrested today by Detective William Welch in the New York County Court House. The young woman was brought here, and tonight was arraigned upon a charge of grand larceny and released under ball of $1,000.
IOLA, Kan., March 28 -- Business in Iola, the home of Gen. Funston, was practically suspended to-day, while the citizens gave vent to the enthusiasm they felt over the Kansas soldier's feat.

Jeremiah C. Lyons has bought from Anson R. Flower, through Douglas Robinson Co., the four-story brownstone-front Dwelling 603 Fifth Avenue, 22.5 by 100. Mr. Lyons will convert the house into one if the American basement type.

NEWPORT, March 28 -- This evening Lorillard Spencer had a narrow escape from injury. He was being driven down Dearborn Street in a public cab. when the breeching parted and the animal took fright, dashing down the street at a terrific speed, and into a barber shop, which was filled with customers.

BALTIMORE, March 28 -- The stock marKet seems to be sweeping upward on a rapidly rising bull wave. The tone seems to be buoyant to the point almost of enthusiasm. The buying fever is rampant. Sales are frequent and in large blocks. The aggregate volume of to-day mounted very close to the highest record.

Writing begging letters has proved so profitable to the family of Patrick McCann, fifty-five years old, of 335 East Forty-sixth Street, that he has done no work at all for two years, according to the stories of neighbors. Agents Fogarty and Pisarra of the Gerry society made a descent upon the place last night and arrested McCann and his wife Mary, forty-nine years old, and their four children.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Major Gen. Otis, formerly in command of the army in the Philippines, and now in command of the Department of the Lakes, expressed satisfaction to-day over the capture of Aguinaldo.

CHICAGO, March 28 -- Representatives of ten of the largest cereal mills not affiliated with the American Cereal Company met here to-day to take final steps in the consummation of a combine projected by O.C. Barber, President of the Diamond Match Company. The new combine will be known as the Great Western Cereal Company, and will, it is said, have an authorized capitalization of $4,500,000, $1,500,000 of which will be preferred stock.

BOSTON, March 28 -- Rear Admiral Robley D. Evans, arrived here to-day. He praised Gen. Punston for the capture of Aguinaldo and declared that he was entitled to a regular army commission. In speaking of the matter the Rear Admiral said:

Championship wrestling for New York Athletic Club honors drew a large percentage of members to the gymnasium of the clubhouse, Sixth Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, last evening. The preliminary bouts were concluded early in the week, and the final contests were sufficiently keen and spirited to give the lovers of the sport plenty of interest.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The fourth and last of Gov. Odells tax bills, the Lewis measure, offering inducements to domestic corporations doing business in the State with their factories located in other States to locate their manufactories in New York, passed the Assembly to-day by a vote of 90 ayes.

AIKEN, S.C., March 28. -- The annual tournament of the Palmetto Golf Club is the event of this week in Alken. The sensational feature of to-day's play in the third round for the Southern Cross Cup was the defeat of E.H. Harriman by Reglnald Brooks, who won from the former by a narrow margin of 1 up.
BERLIN, March 28. -- A resolution pre pared by the Budget Committee, introduced into the Upper House of the Diet to-day, read as follows:

A scandal involving the suspension of a minister from the Brooklyn Presbytery, which has been kept a secret by that body for some months, became public yesterday. The clergyman concerned is the Rev. Dr. Alfred H. Moment, who has been supplying the pulpit of Immanuel Presbyterian Church, in Flatbush.

ALBANY, March 28 -- The most important feature of the proposed new charter which was left open after last night's protracted session of the Senate Cities Committee was the educational feature. An educational provision was agreed upon by the committee to-day. Senator Eisberg, who had most to do with drawing up the provision, said at it:

LONDON, March 29 -- In the House of Lords yesterday the Marquis of Lansdowne, the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, announced that no further military operations by the British troops in China were contemplated for the present. When Field Marshal Count von Waldersee ordered preparations for the recent expedition, the British Government instructed Gen. Gaselee to communicate with the home Government before participating therein.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- Next to the capture of Aguinaldo himself, the chief interest of the day centred in the reward which the Government would give to Gen. Funston for the brilliant and successful consummation of his project. He stands to-day on the records of the War Department as second on the list of Brigadier Generals of Volunteers, being preceded by Brig. Gen. James F. Smith of California.

William S. Devery is never uninteresting to a layman when he sits at Police Headquarters in judgment over members of the uniformed force, to which, he contends, he still belongs, although his functions as First Deputy Commissioner have been delegated to him by Col. Murphy. Mr. Devery rose from the ranks, and knows all the tricks of the trade, so that the delinquent wights who appear before him cannot deceive or feaze him.

Assistant District Attorney James W. Osborne continued yesterday his efforts to adduce sufficient testimony from Albert T. Patrick's employes and friends to warrant Justice Jerome in holding the lawyer for the action of the grand jury on a charge of murdering William Marsh Rice on Sept. 23, 1900, to get possession of the old man's millions.

Each year it is customary for the Authors' Club to have upon some designated evening a memorial meeting for such members of the club as have died during the year preceding. Last night tribute was paid to the memories of Charles Dudley Warner, Stephen Crane, Moses Coit Tyler, and William Lyne Wilson.

LONDON, March 29 -- The statement of the Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain, the Colonial Secretary, that the Government had printed all it knew about the Botha-Kitchener peace negotiations and that nothing had transpired since, caused the Right Hon. James Bryce (Liberal) to analyze, in the House of Commons yesterday, the terms offered.

WASHINGTON, March 28. -- The Spring meeting of the Washington Jockey Club, which opened the racing season of 1901 in the East, began at Bennings to-day. The attendance was the largest ever seen on the first day of the Spring meeting, and the track was in good shape.

LINCOLN, Neb., March 28 -- After a deadlock of two and one-half months the Republicans of the Nebraska Legislature nominated J.H. Millard of Omaha and Gov. Charles H. Dietrich of Hastings for the long and short terms, respectively, in the United States Senate. A joint session of the Legislature was held at noon to ratify the caucus nomination.

ITHACA, March 28 -- When asked this afternoon what he believed the Government of the United States should do with Aguinaldo, President Schurman of Cornell University and President of the first Philippine Commission, said:
PHILADELPHIA, March 28 -- The activity in Wall Street found no response in this city, except in the United States Steel issues, in which there was lively trading.

Yesterday was not a gay day in town. There were a few teas and recitals and several sewing class meetings, and in the evening there were club meetings and number of dinners, including a large one, at which James J. Van Alen was the host -- he not having sailed Wednesday on the Oceanic, although booked.

The shares (" when issued") of the United States Steel Corporation -- the billion-dollar steel trust -- were buoyant yesterday, the first day of their quotation upon the Stock Exchange. The entire stock market was strong, but the steel trust issues were much the most conspicuous feature, transactions in the common and preferred stocks approximating a quarter of a million shares.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- P.C. Knox of Pittsburg to whom the President has decided to offer the Attorney Generalship, arrived at the White House about noon to-day. He was with the President for over an hour. After he left the White House the following official statement was made:

John Mitchell, President of the United Mine Workers, left this city for Wilkesbarre, Penn., at 5:55 P.M. yesterday on a Lehigh Valley train to attend a convention of the Executive Committee of the anthracite districts of the union, which will be held in Wilkesbarre at 10 A.M. to-day, where he will make his first official report of the result of his visit to New York.

Although the total transactions in the outside market yesterday were smaller than on many days recently, owing to the listing of the United States Steel stocks, the market showed much life. A number of issues were traded in quite actively, and prices generally advanced. The copper stocks attracted considerable attention.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

The Larchmont Yacht Club yesterday announced its racing fixtures for the coming season. A Spring regatta, open to all classes, will open the season on June 15. On Thursday, July 4, the twentieth annual regatta, open to all classes,will take place, and on Saturday, July 13, will begin the club's Race Week.
Vigorous opposition was expressed yesterday by City Superintendent Maxwell to the Ahearn bill, which was reported by the Senate Cities Committee at Albany on Wednesday.

Stealing a yard of jewelry was the charge made against George H. Heesemann of 444 Central Park West, who was arraigned in the West Side Police Court yesterday afternoon. He was arrested in the courtroom, where he had gone on a summons issued to the executors of the estate of his father-in-law.

The final match in the tournament of the New York Interclub Bowling League was decided on the Catholic Club alleys last night, the home team losing two of the three games to the Harlem Republican Club. The scores:

The investigation by Capt. Jensen, skipper of the American bark Silicon, last Sunday afternoon of what, through his glass, appeared to be a bit of driftwood, about 120 miles south-southeast of Cape Hatteras, led to the rescue of ten famished, almost naked Italian sailors.

AGUINALDO has given us such a deal of trouble that now that we have him in hand no sane person who is not a public enemy would venture to suggest that we should make any disposition of his person which would now or ever leave him free to seize opportunities to do further mischief.
Ex-President Cleveland delivered last night, in Alexander Hall. Princeton University, the second and concluding lecture on the national boundary dispute between Great Britain and Venezuela.
TRENTON, N.J., March 28 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals this afternoon, by a vote of 9 to 5, decided to reverse the Chancellor's decision in the American Smelting and Refining Company case.

The clash of arms and the rattle of volleying rifles, with the accompaniment of music on military brass, kept impressionable spectators dancing with excitement at the Soldiers' Show last night in Madison Square Garden. The military exhibitions were quite as attractive and entertaining as on former nights, and the athletic sports were the best of the week.
CHICAGO, March 28 -- Forty cents' discount was to-day's rate for New York exchange. Money for call and time loans was unchanged at 4@4 1/2 per cent.

Cyrus E. Staples, a broker, of Montague Street Brooklyn, representing a syndicate, has made a proposition to the stockholders of the Kings County Bank, through its President and Directors, to acquire at least two-thirds of the stock of the bank, for the purpose, it is understood of establishing a new trust company in Brooklyn.

The mass meeting of the people of Peking to petition Gen. CHAFFEE that the Americans continue their share in the municipal management there suggests many things of interest not only in China but at home.

Ground has just been broken for the two new high schools for boys, and work will be pushed forward on the new buildings as quickly as possible. The work on the new high school for girls, for which ground was broken on Dec. 18, has progressed steadily. The basement walls are now up level with the sidewalk and part of the first tier of beams have been put in.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The news of Aguinaldo's capture was received everywhere in official circles with intense gratification, but perhaps nowhere did it create more satisfaction than at the White House. The first official news to reach the Executive Mansion was Gen. MacArthur's dispatch announcing the capture.

An old couple, brother and sister, were found dead in their home, at 152 Virginia Avenue, Jersey City, yesterday. They had been dead a month or six weeks. The woman's name was Susan Mead, as inscribed in a Bible found on a table, but the man's Christian name could not be learned, although they had occupied the house for eight years.

WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The War Department has not had time as yet to consider the exact status of Aguinalda, whether he is to be tried, and what punishment If any, is to be meted out to him. But there are certain general principles which are said to be clearly established, and the first question asked is as to whether Aguinaldo is to be tried as a military or as a civil offender.

WASHINGTON, March 29 -- Gen. Stewart Van Vliet, one of the oldest of the retired officers of the United States Army and a member of the famous Class of 1840 of the Military Academy at West Point, died at his residence in this city to-day. His death removes a unique figure from Washington, for there was hardly a resident of the capital who did not know him by sight.

BOSTON, March 28 -- At the Clearing House this morning money loaned at 2 1/2 and 3 per cent. One large lending bank marked up all its outstanding loans from 2 1/2 to 3 per cent. New York funds sold at 12 1/2 and 15 cents discount for cash.

ALBANY, March 28 -- It would have been a hard task to find in Albany to-day three more disgusted men than Assemblymen Otto Kelsey of Livingston and Gerhardi Davis and Julius Seymour of New York. Ever since the session opened these three Assemblymen have been students of the Charter Revision Commission's report.

The Rapid Transit Commissioners rejected at the meeting yesterday the offer of Albert L. Johnson to construct a tunnel to South Brooklyn and under the Narrows and Staten Island to the New Jersey shore. President Orr had requested that the offer to build the tunnel be made specific, and when Mr. Johnson's reply was read yesterday the Commissioners declared that they were disappointed.
MANILA, March 28 -- The story of the capture of Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo, March 23, as related by Gen. Funston, his captor, is as follows:

Acting as spokesman for a number of his comrades, one of the older firemen in the New York Fire Department said yesterday that the real cause of the opposition of Commissioner Scannell and others high in authority in the department to the proposed Two-Platoon bill now before the Legislature at Albany was that, should the bill become a law.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 28 -- After two weeks, one of the most interesting trials ever held in this State is ended. Chief Justice Furches and Associate Justice Douglas were to-day declared not guilty in the impeachment proceedings before the Senate of North Carolina at Raleigh.

Some thirty or forty young people were on the stage of the Empire Theatre yesterday afternoon to receive their diplomas as graduates of the Empire Theatre School of Acting, of which Franklin H. Sargent is the head. They were addressed by Richard Mansfield, the Rev. Walter E. Bentley, Secretary of the Actors' Church Alliance, and Anna Warren Story.
The Brokerage Committee of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange has revoked the brokerage certificates held by Frank E. Jilson, D. Sherwood, Joel Jacobs, and Jacob Horowitz.
LONDON, March 28. -- Dr. G.H. Ward-Humphries intends at once to put in commission the cutter yacht Niagara, which he has purchased from Howard Gould. The Niagara will be renamed the Japonica.

ALBANY, March 28 -- In the Assembly today Assemblyman Bell gave notice that he would call up his Christian Scientist bill next Wednesday. Mr. Bell now says he has hopes of passing the measure. His new found hopes are based upon what he termed "a Christian Science vision" which he had last night.

BUFFALO, March 28. -- "Dan" McLeod, the Scotch wrestler, defeated "Mort" Henderson of Rochester to-night at the Olympic Club, securing three falls in less than half an hour. McLeod weighed 167 pounds and Henderson 220. McLeod had to get three falls in an hour to win.
LONDON, March 28 -- Countess Russell obtained a divorce this morning upon the ground of the bigamy of Earl Russell with Mrs. Somerville. The suit was not defended.

An important meeting of the Joint Passenger Committee was held in this city yesterday at the offices of the Trunk Line Association. All the roads of the Trunk Line and the Central Traffic Associations were represented. The first matter to be disposed of was the appointment of a joint agent to take charge of the interests of the railroads at Buffalo during the coming Pan-American Exposition.

BERLIN, March 28. -- The Emperor this morning led the Emperor Alexander Grenadier Regiment from the Lustgarten to the regiment's new barracks. This was his first appearance on horseback since the attack on him at Bremen.

PARIS, March 30. -- The Law of Associations bill, one of the most important measures considered by the French Parliament during the last decade, was passed last evening by the Chamber of Deputies by a vote of 303 to 220 amid prolonged Ministerial cheers.

In these two volumes we have a memoir of Eugene Schuyier, with essays, and "Italian Influences," the latter a collection of essays, reviews, and magazine articles, such as "The Footsteps of Dante," "The Italy of Bawthorne," and "Corinne," crowded with incidents that appeal to the cultivated reader and having the charm of a literary style pervaded by the simplicity and freshness of nature.

Gen. FUNSTON'S scheme for the capture of AGUINALDO was of a character to strike nine people out of ten as a piece of crazy, reckless folly, and that, no doubt, is the judgment that everybody would be now passing upon it if the expedition had ended in the betrayal of its leader by his native allies.

A very lively meeting was neld in the banquet hall of the Waldorf-Astoria last night, when the representatives of independent organizations, headed by Gen, A. P. Ketchum, met to elect permanent officers and formulate a plan of action for the coming Mayoralty campaign.

On receipt of the decision of the New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals (on the application to restrain the American Smelting Company's proposed increase of capital) one of the New Jersey attorneys for the corporation is quoted as declaring that the effect would be to drive capital away from New Jersey.

LONDON, March 29. -- Money was in active demand to-day, in view of the approaching end of the month. Notwithstanding the tightness of money and the weakness of foreign exchanges, discounts were easier.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: While in Charleston, S.C., soon alter the close of the civil war, I purchased a book with the following title page, "Secret History; or, the Horrors of St. Domingo, in-a series of letters written by a lady at Cape Francois, to Colonel Burr, late Vice President of the United states, Principally During the Command of Count Rochambeau, Philadelphia:

David L. Short and Morris Meyer, the two witnesses to the alleged will of Millionaire William Marsh Rice, which leaves Albert T. Patrick, who is now charged with murdering the old man, all his property, were arrested late yesterday afternoon by Detective Brindley of the District Attorney's office, charged with forgery in the first degree.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst yesterday received a copy of the letter written to him by Gov. Odell in reply to the one sent by Dr. Parkhurst commending the Governor for his attitude in his controversy with Senator Platt over the Police bill. The letter originally addressed to him by Gov. Odell went astray, owing to a clerical error, and did not reach the clergyman.

Prince Peter A. Kropotkin, the famous Russian Anarchist, was in this city, at the Gerard Hotel, last night, and he is to lecture to-day before the League for Political Education at the Berkeley Theatre. For the past month he has been in Boston delivering a course of lectures on Russian literature before the Lowell Institute.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 29. -- The gymnasts of Wesleyan University gave their seventh annual exhibition in the Fayerweather Gymnasium last night. Many of the feats of the class squads were very difficult, and all were performed with a finish and precision unequaled in the past.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 29. -- J.P. Holm, editor of The Perth Amboy Folkeblad, came to this city a few days ago to transact some business, and after finishing it saw that he had barely time to catch a train for home, at Lyons Farms, on the Lehigh Valley Railroad. He started on a run along North Broad Street toward the station.

Patrons of Williams's roadhouse, at Lenox Avenue and One Hundred and Eleventh Street, had their fill of excitement last evening, when Mrs. Sophie Hemming and her husband. Harry S. Hemming, met after a period of separation. He had surprised her sitting at a table with a woman acquaintance, while two men known to both were sitting at an adjoining table.
Years ago the favorite question for newspaper discussion, when politics were at a standstill and no myterious murder filled the air, was, "What becomes of all the pins?".

What the study of the Indian antiquities of a Pennsylvania county may lead to is seen when one inspects the museum of the Backs County Historical Society i the old settlement of Doylestown, and visits "Indian House," the studio of Mr. Henry C. Mercer. Starting with interest in the remains of the aborigines.
The advertisements of Redmond, Kerr Co. and the Fidelity Trust Company, offering for sale the Elizabeth, Plainfield and Central Jersey bonds, have been withdrawn, the bonds having all been sold.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Senator Ellsworth in the Senate and Assemblyman Allds in the Assembly to-day introduced a bill making a large number of changes in the staff of employes of the Senate and Assembly.
BOSTON, March 29. -- A special cable from London says:
DUBLIN, March 29. -- James Stephens, the well-known Fenian and leader or the 1866 movement, died here this morning.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Senator Raines introduced a bill to-day, the title of which is "A Bill to Facilitate Transportation Connections with wharves, docks, and piers in the cities of the State." The bill defines the character of bridges and approaches thereto which may be erected between New York and New Jersey across the Hudson.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Senator Stranahan to-day reported to the Senate the amended Charter Revision bill for New York City. He asked unanimous consent that the bill be ordered to a third reading. The consent was granted, and the bill was ordered placed on the third reading calendar.

WASHINGTON, March 29. -- Another big crowd was in attendance at the Bennings track this afternoon, the bright sunshine and brisk air making ideal racing weather. The day's card was generally a well-filled one, and the track was in improved condition and fast. The talent found some dificulty in picking the winners, only two favorites passing under the wire first.

That is a curious controversy which has arisen between the Commissioners of the new East River Bridge, or some of them, and the property owners concerned, about the line that the Manhattan approach to the new East River Bridge should follow.

One of the features of English scholarship, for several generations, was the translation, into classic Latin or Greek, of modern works. The late Charles Stuart Calverley, reviewing a collection of such translations, "Home Tennysonianae," described this knack of putting living thoughts into dead languages as "a beautiful but obsolescent art."

One day last Summer a native or Saranac Lake village was asked who was the most famous man that ever lived in that neighborhood. He thought a while, scraped one foot on a sidewalk nailhead to help him recollect, then said:

The hitherto unpublished letter containing Philo Norton McGiffin's own story of the famous naval battle of the Yalu will be presented in full in Cyrus Townsend Brady's forthcoming book "Under Tops is and Tents." which will come from Charles Scribner's Sons' March 30. This was the first encounter in history between modern warships.

ST. LOUIS, March 20. -- The February Grand Jury made its final report to-day to Judge Wood. According to the report most of the jury's time was occupied investigating election frauds perpetrated in the November election. Two hundred and one indictments were returned during the session out of 227 cases which have been considered.

What Carlyle owed to Emerson, Felix Gras, the capoulle du fellbrige, the novelist of Provence, owes to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Janvier. How tenderly the latter regarded the poets who wrote in that labial language of the South of France, the Provencal, he has revealed to us in the pases of his delightful "Embassy to Provence."

BALTIMORE, March 29. -- The stock market has lost none of its bull zest. Activity along general lines continued unabated today, the chief point of difference being the Seaboard group. They sold readily and were decidedly firm, but the aggregate sales were less than on Thursday. Among the leading spots of bull interest were the United Railway issues.

The high jumpers brought one of the most successful horse shows ever held in Durland's Riding Academy to a close last night. Foxwood, the small chestnut owned by the Gerkendale Farm, added another blue ribbon to those he has already won during the week, while the winning of first prize by the bay gelding Governor Blair made the sixth blue ribbon won by the string belonging to C.K.G. Billings.

BERLIN, March 29 -- The Liberal papers discuss Emperor William's speech to the Emperor Alexander. Grenadier Regiment yesterday. The National Zeitung expresses its inability to comprehend what current events induced the Emperor to refer to the revolution of 1848, and says it does not see any signs at his Majesty needing a body guard.

At a student mass meeting held yesterday afternoon at the Columbia University, plans were made for meeting the athletic difficulties of the university, which, if successfully carried out, will furnish a solution for the grave problem confronting Columbia's sports. Francis S. Bangs, '78, the new graduate athletic Treasurer, was the principal speaker.

In a collision In North River yesterday morning at 7 o'clock the steam lighter Edgewater was sunk by the Jersey Central Railroad ferryboat Elizabeth. The accident occurred Just off the Liberty Street slip, the Edgewater sinking in a few minutes after the contact. The Edgewater, which was in command of Capt. J.J. Laverty, was on the way to Edgewater, N.J., laden with a cargo of seventy tons of bone black.
ALBANY, March 29. -- The Senate Committee on Cities has incorporated in the Greater New York Charier bill, reported to the Senate to-day, the following provision.

Schedules in bankruptcy of Grant Brothers, stock brokers, of 43 Broadway, show liabilities of $499,839 and nominal assets of $357,458. The assets consist of notes, $15,532; office furniture, , $218; debts due, $186,865; stocks and bonds, $220; unliquidated claims, $154,372, and amount realized by the assignee, $249.
To-morrow is Palm Sunday, and many of the city's churches are to have special musical services.

Emile Zola's "labor," ("Travell,") which is now running as a serim in Harper's Weekly will be presented next month in book form. Two pictures are presented: the distress and immorality of French factory hands, and the selfishness and intrigues of capitalists -- all revealed through dramatic and human scenes, significant of the eternal conflict between labor and capital.

ALBANY, March 29. -- Assistant Corporation Counsel Butts of New York City today issued a statement showing that there are now before the Legislature bills which, if they become laws, he says, will compel New York City to expend $32,421,400. The statement was prepared under authorization of Corporation Counsel Whalen, who was in this city this week, investigating the condition of New York City legislation.

ALBANY, March 29. -- The members of the Cities Committee of the Assembly are still ruffled over the action of the Senate Committee in reporting the New York Charter bill without consulting them in its preparation. They will not carry their resentment to the extent of offering a separate bill, but when the Senate bill comes over to the Assembly it is the intention to object to its second reading.

After a ten years' tenure of the old tobacco factory at Ninety-ninth Street and Second Avenue, Public School No. 109 will be removed on April 20 to the new building on the northerly side of Ninety-ninth Street; running to One Hundredth Street, 200 feet east of Third Avenue.

Following closely upon the publication yesterday of the suspension from the Brooklyn Presbytery of the Rev. Dr. Alfred H. Moment, who filled the pulpit of Immanuel Presbyterian Church, in Flatbush, action was taken late yesterday afternoon in the suit to foreclose a mortgage on the property of the church.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- The trial tests of various types of field guns for the army, which were scheduled to have taken place on March 20 at the Sandy Hook Proving Grounds, under the supervision of the Army Board on Ordnance and Fortifications, and which, through the non-appearance of guns expected to have been submitted by various gun factories, did not take place, have been postponed indefinitely.

In time of peace prepare for war is recognized by most reasonable being as a sound maxim. It is a pretty good general proposition that the people who are best prepared for war are least likely to set into it, and that those who know most about war are most anxious, to keep out of it. These statements we shall not stop to elaborate or to demonstrate, but they will bear thinking over.

LONDON, March 10. -- Miss Zoe Proctor has compiled a "Birthday Book " from the writings of Mrs. John Oliver Hobbes Craigle. This settles Mrs. Craigio's position in the literary world. A writer must be undeniably popular when it becomes worth while to serve up his or her remarks in the shape of birthday hash.

The intense interest displayed in the works of Richard Wagner by the public of this and other cities has its literary as well as its musical side. No doubt many of those who think they are reveling in the choicest secrets of Baireuth art are confining their attention to the listing of leading motives.

NEW ORLEANS, La., March 29. -- In his lecture room at Tulane University to-night Prof. A.L. Metz succeeded in making a small block of solidified air which was as substantial (for the time being) as a block of ice. It was about an inch in diameter, and lasted about fifteen minutes in a fully exposed condition.
To The New York Times Saturday Review: The Russians have a proverb which, freely tranlated, means "A lie gets fat while the truth goes a-begging."

The Boston Herald reads a lecture to the Wealthy and conservative class in Cuba upon the vice of political indifference. Of the demand In their behalf for the protection of our Government it has this to say:

Slawson Hobbs have sold for Charles N. Taintor for about $75,000 the plot, 52.6 by 96, on the east side of Broadway, 52.4 feet south of Seventy-fifth Street, now occupied by old buildings. The purchaser is James Byrnes.

MANILA, March 29 -- After being convinced of Aguinaldo's capture. Geronimo, the insurgent leader in the Province of Morong. Luzon, has surrendered with six officers, forty-six men, and fifty rifles to Col. J. Milton Thompson of the forty-second Regiment at San Mateo.

At the request of the Governments with which they were negotiated, the time for the ratification of five of the eleven treaties of reciprocity which the Senate permitted to lapse has been extended. In the case of the French treaty the date has been set forward eighteen months, to Sept. 24, 1902.

WASHINGTON, March 20. -- Attorney General Griggs late this afternoon took leave of his associates in the Department of Justice, and to-morrow he will depart for his home, in Paterson, N.J. During the leavetaking Solicitor General Richards, on behalf of the officers and employes of the department, presented to the retiring Attorney General a large solidsilver claret pitcher of classic shape and unique design.

Another day of sewing classes, small meetings, calls, and shopping. The retreat at the Sacred Heart Convent ended, the women who have been following these pious exercises have returned to the world. The Evening Badminton Club met last night at the Berkeley Armory. To-day the original Badminton Club will have its weekly meeting, also in the armory.

It was somewhat surprising the other day to find in a short article a bitter complaint made of the Iack of interest American book lovers take in the most excellent specimens of American bookmaking, the writer of the article in question stating that his opinion is fully supplemented by the testimony of those best qualified to judge-that is, by the experience of the leading booksellers.

BUFFALO, March 29. -- Justice Lambert, in Special Tern, this morning granted a temporary injunction, restraining the Board of Assessors from adding the State franchise tax to the tax of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad. The franchise tax amounts to $158,500.
The decision that seems now final in the Legislature as to the schools in the revision of the charter is quite satisfactory.

PHILADELPHIA, March 29. -- The market here had a stronger tone to-day, due largely to heavier trading in New York. The pressure was lifted from Union Traction because of the New York Rapid Transit Commission's treatment of Mr. Johnson's requests, and though there was heavy selling, the price advanced 1/2 over yesterday.

In yesterday's market for outside securities only a few issues showed unusual activity, but there was a fair amount of general trading and the day's total was reasonably large. Prices showed considerable strength in certain parts of the list, while very few issues showed any material recession from Thursday's prices.

A delegation of labor leaders called on Mayor Van Wyck yesterday to demand that the contracts made by the city be abrogated if the contractors would not pay workmen the prevailing rate of wages. Mayor Van Wyck told the delegation that the prevailing rate of wages clause of the labor law had been declared unconstitutional by the Court of Appeals.
CHICAGO, March 29. -- New York exchange was at 20 cents discount before and 30 cents after call to-day. Money for call and time loans was unchanged at 4@41/2 per cent.

Poor Boston! By what miracle of constitutional robustness does she endure all the attacks made upon her in fiction! Here is one more in "Truth Dexter," by Mr. Sidney McCall, the story of a preternaturally innocent young Southern wife who comes to the city under peculiar circumstances and encounters a woman who, besides belonging to all the clubs, is a siren desirous of having all men belong to her.

There may have been room for more people in Madison Square Garden last night at the Military Show, but if so, the crowd in attendance most successfully hid it. All other nights of the show were thrown into total eclipse, at any rate, and standing room was at a premium, even the space back of the arena seats being so choked up by the visitors that movement in any direction was next to impossible.

In times like these of ours when literature is so copious, and bookmaking is one of the most hardpressed of industries, it comes somewhat as a surprise to be reminded by Mr. Sturgis's new publication that nothing of the kind already exists in the English language. Scholars and publishers cannot be accused of ignorance of the deficiency, so if we would have an explanation probably we must look to the public for it.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., March 29. -- The threatened strike of 143,000 miners in the hard-coal region will not take place. At a meeting of the Executive Committee of the United Mine Workers of the three anthracite districts, held in this city to-day. It was decided that the men should continue at work.

For several years past Prof. Muller, in the intervals of more important work, was occupied in jotting down reminiscences of his early life. In 1808 and 1809 he issued the two volumes of "Auld Lang Syne," which contained reminiscences of his friends, but very much about his own life and achievements.
BOSTON, March 20. -- "To the memory of the gallant men who fell with dust of failure on their lips that others might be taught the lesson of the wilderness."

The Cheyne Hospital, Chelsea was founded in 1875 with the object of caring for children suffering from chronic and incurable diseases, who, for this reason, are excluded from general hospitals. Although many of these little patients are beyond all hope of recovery, careful medical attention and nursing, combined with good food and pleasant surroundings, do much to alleviate their sufferings.

Ex-Senator David B. Hill has been retained by District Attorney Philbin to argue before the Court of Appeals in June the State's case against Roland Burnham Molineux, now under sentence of death in Sing Sing, charged with poisoning Mrs. Kate J. Adams in 1898.

Last evening's presentation of the second half of the first part of Goethe's "Faust" must be placed among the most successful performances this year of a classic play b the German stock company at the Irving Place Theatre. For this success are responsible, first, the excellent portrayal of Margaretha by Miss Ada Merito, and secondly, the fine performance of Franz Klerschner as Mephistopheles.

SALT LAKE, Utah, March 29. -- The Standard Oil Company has agreed to pay 55,000,000 for a patent controlled by Salt Lake men. The invention is a device to convert petroleum into a gas that produces intense heat and light at a cost much smaller than by any other known process.

Policemen of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth and the Alexander Avenue Stations arrested several men early yesterday morning who are, the officers assert, members of a dangerous band of burglars. This band has been committing depredations in Harlem and the Bronx for some weeks past.

BOSTON, March 29. -- The Post to-day says: "The proposed consolidation of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad Company with the Great Northern and Northern Pacific Railroads has reached a final stage. The long-delayed plan, it is said, is ready for submission to the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy stockholders.

Ex-President CLEVELAND'S Frinceton lecture on the part taken by the United States in the Venezuela boundary dispute will be read with satisfaction by all Americans who respect historical truth and have not been taught to be ashamed of deeds that give a higher distinction to their country.

Contractor John Shields, who is building Section 11 of the rapid-transit subway, between One Hundred and Fourth and One Hundred and Twenty-fifth Streets, along Broadway, has struck so many unlookedfor complications during the last few weeks that he is beginning to think the fates are in league to prevent him from executing his contract.

Abraham Gruber made a speech last night in which he paid his respects to the Commit-, tee of Fifteen and the Citizens Union, declaring that if these agencies continued in the way they were going it would be impossible to place successfully in power an antiTammany ticket. F.M. Brooks, President of the Young Republican Club of Brooklyn, had preceded him at a meeting of the Lafayette Club in Bethany Congregational Church.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Representative Russell of Connecticut, a member of the Ways and Means Committee, does not approve of Representative Babcock's proposition to amend the tariff so as to withdraw from monopolies and trusts the advantages given to them by excessive protective duties.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your article in to-day's issue tells the position of the so-called Bell bill exactly. This bill has received the indorsement of nearly every newspaper in the State, has been indorsed by the medical profession of all schools, and by right-minded citizens generally.

ALBANY, March 30 -- The Canal Improvement bill in all probability will go to the Legislature next Tuesday morning. State Engineer Bond, Superintendent of Public Works Partridge, and Attorney General Davies have been collaborating in the preparation of the bill and it is practically completed.

CITY OF MEXICO, March 21 -- The sickness of President Dlaz in midwinter and his prolonged stay of nearly two months in the hot lands of the States of Guerrero and Morelos, have given rise to many rumors. Some have gone so far as to decide that the grand General and noble President was becoming "loco," or crazy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That the views held by the majority or people on social questions are formed largely by their environment seems clearly apparent from the endless encomiastic letters and editorials in the press regarding Andrew Carnegie and his library bobby. Here Is a man who Is giving away millIons of dollars with which to establish libraries throughout the country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Will you allow "Moral Mugwump" a word with "German-American" and with the Rev. John A.W. Haas, who have both replied to his letter regarding missionaries in China, and who have both taken decided exception to his use of the word "barbarian in connection with the Germans?

Much has been published of late about various mechanical contrivances for the relief of deafness, but no patent has ever been obtained or advertisement given to a simple mechanism used intermittently for years in an old Westchester County Quaker family, among whom this malady seems to be a heritage of the aged.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Our foreign policy has displayed rather less timidity of late years than was its wont at one time. Circumstances have given us courage, and by coming into more active contact with foreign powers we have begun to appreciate the fact that none of them is in a position to go to war with us.

LONDON, March 30 -- Money was wanted to-day, and the supplies were more plentiful and inclined to be easier. A small number of bills were offered for discount, holders preferring to await developments. An easier condition is anticipated next week.

NEW HAVEN, March 30 -- The first handicap run of the series projected for the Yale track team candidates was held late this afternoon. The event was the Handicap mile run. About fifteen men competed. The event was won by L.L. Gray, 1901. (23 yards;) W.D. Waldron, 1903, (20 yards.) second; H.K. Love, 1904, third. Time -- 4:55 1-5.

Oesus was by no means the richest of ancients, despite his having had his be adopted as the synonym for wealth, glory and grandeur of Sardanapalus, magnificence of the Roman Emperors, dazzling splendors of the Pharaohs, of eopatra of Darius, of Alexander, were idences of material resources far exceeding those of Croesus.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The ground hog may be an early and doubtful weather prophet, but the shad is an unfailing harbinger of Spring, when it is seen here on the streets, carried by the gills and delivered at a price far below what has been charged for weeks for travel-worn shad from Wilmington or further South.

The dedication of the new church house of the Madison Square Presbyterian Church took place yesterday aternoon at 2 o'clock. The dedicatory exercises were presided over by Robert W. De Forest, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, and were held in the assembly room of the house. The new building is at the northwest corner of Thirtieth Street and Third Avenue.

A tenement house fire, which started in the basement of a bakery at 97 Norfolk Street about 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning, resulted in the loss of three lives and slight injuries to three other persons. The building in which the fire started fronts on Norfolk Street at the corner of Delancey Street.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Gen. Funston was appointed a Brigadier General in the . regular army by the President to-night. The announcement was made about 10 o'clock, although just before the close of business at the War Department this afternoon Secretary Root stated emphatically that no consideration whatever had been given to the subject of the reward lo be given Gen. Funston.

Controller Coler declared yesterday that there should be no delay in awarding the contract for the building of the rapid transit tunnel to Brooklyn. An effort will be made to have the plan of the Rapid Transit Commissioners for an extension under the East River to Flarbush and Atlantic Avenues passed.

WASHINGTON. March 20 -- The idea of Emillo Agulnaldo as an American office holder, which was first suggested by President Schurman of the old Phillppine Commission is not beyond the possibilities of the future. There are ex-insurgents in the American service, and many of those who have been of the greatest value to the Americans, whether as employees or not, are men who never surrendered, but were captured.

LENOX, March 30 -- The Lenox cottagers are to have their way about the entrance of the trolley into the town. It will pass from Pittsfield over what is known as the Holmes Road, going past the residences of Col. Cutting and Mrs. William Pollock, and enter the town at the Lenox Railroad station.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 25 -- Allusion to the Chinese as a people of song is certainly not common, and one persisting in it might lay some claim to originality. Yet with no people is the departure from natural tone, which may be classed as song, in more general use. Their speech is a cadence. At least one dialect in the North abounds in words whose meaning depends altogether on inflection.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The State Department has recalled Minister Francis B. Loomis from Caracas to Washington. The explanation officially given at the department is that he is coming home for consultation. There is no explanation of why he is coming home, nor whether he is coming home not to return.

There seemed at first impassable barriers between the teacher and scholars. First, there was the language, and, second, the difference of habits and customs, and the absence of any interpreter or intermediary to bring the two together. The children could all say "American" or "Americano," which they thought would please the vanity of the teacher, and they repeated it often.

BANGOR, March 30 -- Several new railroads will be built in Maine this year, and although none of them is to be of great importance in itself, yet they will have a considerable influence upon traffic in various localities. The Maine Central Company will build a branch line from Augusta to Winthrop, via Manchester Forks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On first consideration the proability of the city spending from five to twenty million dollars for suitable approaches to the new bridge seems wildly extravagant, but it is as necessary to provide adequate facilities of approach to a structure of this kind as it is to build the structure.
Her demeanor was indeed rather more scientific than Christian.

LONDON, March 30 -- Oxford's coxswain snatched a victory from Cambridge to-day in a boat-steering race after the Light Blues (Cambridge) had led by a length and a hair at Barnes's Bridge, an advantage which at that point is supposed to mean a sure victory.

The outlook at Albany seems to warrant the prediction that the bill prepared by the County Medical Society of New York, regulating the practice of Christian Science healing in this State, has no chance of securing a favorable consideration, and that if forced to a vote it will be defeated.

A large audience welcomed Prince Krapotkia, the Russian scientist and Anarchist, in the Berkeley Lyceum Theatre yesterday morning. Every seat was filled, extra chairs were brought in, and people stood in the rear of the theatre upstairs and down. The audience was a representative one, interested in the two writers, Turgueneff and Tolstoi, of whom Prince Krapotkin spoke.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although a fireman, I had time to read the letter of "A Fireman." advocating the double platoon system in your issue of the 15th. I agree entirely with your editorials upon the subject. I am opposed to the bill because I think it would be against the best interests of the force.

Investigation of the past life of Frederick C. Burlingame, who was convicted last week of burglary in General Sessions, set on foot by Judge Cowing, to whom had come many appeals for clemency, revealed yesterday evidence which, it is believed, will fasten on the "gentleman burglar" many similar crimes committed in recent years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Sunday, March 24, is a letter from "A.J.H." on "Mortgage Tax Exemption," which doubtless sets forth the sentiment of a large proportion of mortgagors on this subject.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., March 30 -- Lehigh opened the baseball season this afternoon in a whirlwind fashion by defeating Rutgers by a score of 16 to 0. Rutgers went to pieces in the first inning, miserabie fielding, coupled with Lehlgh's hard hitting, netting the Brown and White 11 runs.

Palm Sunday is the beginning of a week of prayer and meditation for many, and of at least partial abstinence from Worldly and social pleasures. There is no programme for the coming week whatever. A few of the sewing classes will meet, but all the Lenten clubs, or the majority of them, will close their season.

CHICAGO, March 30 -- Carried upward by the bullishness of almost the entire West, the corn market to-day continued on its record-breaking career. The volume of business was larger than any previous day this week. May closed 5/8@3/4 over yesterday.

Men and women who now and then take the trouble to think about the present and future state of human society will miss a fine intellectual pleasure if they fail to read Count LEO TOLSTOI'S message to the American people in the April number of The North American Review.

Roland Reed, the comedian, died at 10 o'clock yesterday morning at the home of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Rush, 361 West One Hundred and Twenty-second Street. At his bedside there were his daughter, Florence Reed, and Mrs. Rush. His wife was in Philadelphia.

Following precedent, the Building Trades Council of New York, Which comprises the majority of the allied building trades protective organizations throughout the city, has sent to a large number of owners of buildings, general contractors, architects, and builders, a circular requesting that only union laborers and union-made materials be employed in the erectionof buildings in future. The letter is as follows:

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, March 30 -- The steamer Cristobal Colon, which was sunk in the channel at the entrance to San Juan harbor by the Spaniards in the earlier days in the war with Spain, and which has ever since been a serious menace to navigation, was blown up yesterday, thus widening the passage to the harbor by forty feet.
Dr. William J. O'Sullivan returned from Europe yesterday and brought news of Richard Croker's health and ideas. The Tammany leader, he says, weighs just 201 pounds and is in perfect physical health.

Keir Hardle, M.P. for Merthyr-Tydvil and editor of The Labor Leader, of England, recently made the statement in his paper that although wages in America are double those of the English workingman, yet the cost of labor in making steel in the United States is only one-half the cost in England.

"Speakin' of the fourteen different kinds of shivers now bein' throwed into the Czar of the Roossians by them 'ar college stoodents," remarked the man With a roll in his walk and the topmast of a tattooed ship showing on his chest above the collar of his jacket, "don't s'prise me any at all, considerin' the general panicky state of that God-forsaken country.
CHICAGO, March 30 -- New York exchange was quoted to-day at 30 cents discount. Money for call and time loans was unchanged.

Recorder Goff will swear in to-morrow the April Grand Jury, to which District Attorney Philbin is expected to submit the evidence in his possession, collected by the Committee of Five and Fifteen against police officials adjudged responsible for the existence in their precincts of gambling houses and other resorts of questionable repute.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a confusion in the minds of many regarding the literal meaning of "Pollice Presso" and "Pollice Verso."

AIKEN, S.C., March 30 -- The finals for the Southern Cross and Aiken Cups were played here to-day on the links of the Palmetto Golf Club. A heavy rain made the attendance small and prevented good scores. Marion Wright won the Southern Cross Cup from Reginald Brooks, defeating the Newport amateur by 2 up and 1 to play.

SIMLA, Feb. 28 -- There is unfortunately no longer any doubt that famine of a somewhat intense description will again be present in several districts of India during the coming Summer. That this would be the case in the Bombay Deccan country has long been foreseen, and I alluded in the fact in a recent letter.

It seems that the principal feature of the British Parliament during the past week has been the debates about the negotiations for peace with the Boers. That is, indeed the most urgent question now before the British Empire; the necessity of closing up that account, so as to give the British Empire its due opportunity in other fields.
There is a serious as well as a ludicrous side to the talk of the Rev. Dr. PARKHURST about the municipal situation.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL, 3 -- By William M. Ryan partition sale, by order of the heirs, Broadway, west side, 51.3 feet south at Forty-second Street, running through to Seventh Avenue, 92 by 124.7 by 89 by 99.11, seven-story hotel, known as the Rossmore.
The college baseball season in New York was opened yesterday at Jasper Oval, where Columbia defeated New York University in a long-drawn-out game by a score of 22 to 5.

BALTIMORE, March 30 -- Benjamin F. Newcomer, financier and philanthropist, was stricken last night by apoplexy and died to-day at his home in this city. Mr. Newcomer was born in 1827, the family descending from Swiss settlers. He was educated for a civil engineer, but to 1842 went into business with his father and Samuel Stonebraker, and for many years the house did an immense grain and flour milling business.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30 -- The Yale 'Varsity baseball team opened the season at Yale Field this afternoon by winning a slow and erratic same with Manhattan College by a score of 19 to 5. Yale put in her best team up to the fifth inning, and then tried out a lot of youngsters.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The wa revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "considertion" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

To the Editor of The New York Time: In your issue of March 24 I find a workingman's opinions concerning Andrew Carnegie's gifts. There are few who do not commend his multitudinous acts of large beneficence. Many, however, do forget and fail utterly to commend, or indeed, even to recognize the greater work that he has done.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After reading the statements made by Robert Martin concerning the conditions of the hospitals on North Brother Island, my sense of justice induces me to write to THE TIMES.

Until quite recently the great roads leading out of and into London were practically forgotten. They were also, to some extent, disused, which accounts for the encroachments and obstacles which have grown up and prevent their being widened. The period of disuse covered the interval between the total absorption of the old wagon transport from the country by the railways and of the coach traffic by the passenger trains, and the growth of Greater London.

QUEENS, L.I., March 30 -- Preparatory to the Grand American Handicap, which will be shot this week, beginning Wednesday, at Inter-State Park, the New Utrecht Rod and Gun Club to-day at that park held a preliminary pigeon shoot, framed on the same lines as the Grand American. The unusual number of fifty-seven expert shots participated, and good birds, aided by a high northwesterly wind, made lively sport.

For the few scores of missionaries at work in 1800, at the close of the century we have 13,607, with an army of 73,615 native helpers by their side, distributed in over 5,000 central stations through all the unevangelized peoples of the earth. In this single fact we have the promise of final victory.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The crowd at Bennings to-day was large, despite the threatening weather. Charley Moore, at 30 to 1, furnished the surprise, of the day in the fifth race. A more exciting race has seldom been seen on the Bennlngs track than the last event, when First Whip poked her nose in front of Alsike and snatched the race from Father Daly's horse.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 30 -- About 500 Cornellans turned out this afternoon to see their team win its first game of the season with the team from Rochester University. The field was heavy as a result of the rains, of the past week, and the base running was miserably slow. The score:

RICHMOND, Va., March 30 -- The Rev. John Jasper, the famous colored advocate of the "Sun do move" theory, died at his home here to-day, aged ninety years. He had for many years been pastor of the Sixth Mount Zion Church, and was held in high esteem by the people of his race. He was once taken on a tour of the North, delivering his "Sun Do Move" lecture or sermon.

George P. Thompson, a traveling salesman, was severely horsewhipped in the corridor outside the office of his brother, Frederick B. Thompson of the firm of F. B. Thompson Co., at 105 Hudson Street, yesterday, by an elderly woman, who gave the name of "Mrs. F.E. Brown," and who charged Mr. Thompson with having made remarks about her daughter.

To the Editor of The New York Time: I rise to say amen! to what "A Moral Mugwamp" (are there immoral Mugmups'n wrote for THE TIM" this morning, albeit I would put the case of the missionaries in somewhat different shape. Missionarying is, or It should be, a private undertaking.

NEW LONDON, Conn., March 30 -- At the conclusion of the conference between the Yale and Harvard Regatta, Committees, held here this afternoon, it was announced that the course would be changed somewhat, moving the finish line to the westward or New London side of the Thames. This course is practically the same as the crews rowed two years ago.

Sousa comes again to the Metropolitan Opera House this evening for the first of his Spring series of popular concerts of military music. The soloists for the first concert are Blanche Duffield, soprano, and Bertha Bucklin, violiniste, who have been heard at the Metropolitan before. The chief instrumentalists, as heretofore, will be Mr. Arthur Pryor, whom a Brussels paper last Summer dubbed "the Paganini of the trombone."

BOSTON, March 30 -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 3 and 2 1/2 per cent. One leading bank made some fairly large loans at 3 per cent., and yet money was offered at 2 1/2 per cent. at the close. New York funds sold at 17 and 15 cents discount for cash.

Another move to fasten on Albert T. Patrick the murder of old William Marsh Rice, the Texas millionaire, was made by Assistant District Attorney Osbarne yesterday when Patrick was charged, with David L. Short and Morris Meyer, arrested I riday, with forging the will leaving Patrick all of the old man's possessions.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- The following statement, prepared at the Internal Revenue Bureau, shows the receipts, by items, from the War Revenue act only from June 13, 1898, the date on which the act went into effect, to Feb. 28, 1901, cents omitted:

-- It took some courage to introduce at Albany, as Assemblyman SEYMOUR has done, a bill making it "the rule of the road" to turn to the left instead of to the right, for the advocate of the innovation is sure to be charged with a shameful desire to ape English customs, and the consequences to his political future may be serious.

LONDON, March 30 -- In reply to a question asked by a representative of The Associated Press regarding the controversy as to the selection of a defender in the races for the America's Cup, Sir Thomas Lipton made this statement to-day:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to add my testimony to what Dr. Barton has said about the Colored Mission in West Thirtieth Street.

NEWPORT, March 30 -- The villa of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Drexel, on Ochre Point, is being put in condition for the return of the owners, who will arrive here from Europe on May 1. Their steam yacht Sultana will follow later.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 30 -- The New Haven Country Club golf team to-day defeated the Yale golf team in the first match game of the season on the New Haven links. The contest between Capts. Robertson of Yale and Zimmerman of the country club was won by the latter. The scores were:

Out at the Sandy Hook proving ground, where militant Uncle Sam puts to the final test all the latest discoveries in the art of war, there are now in progress, and have been for some months, a series of more than ordinarily important experiment.
