More than ordinarily important, too, are said to be the results achieved.

In old Egypt there was a burial-place for sacred cats as well as sacred bulls; and the reason was no doubt the same namely, that they had a place in the symbolic worship. A cemetery of cats existed near Bubastis; which is the modern Tel Basta, not far from Zag-a-zig Junction on the railway.

The outside market yesterday was active and strong. The issues which for many days past have been the most active ones continued in demand and some other stocks became active. Prices were generally advanced, and in some cases showed net gains at many points. A few declines were noted, but for the most part they were not substantial, and did not occur in prominent issues.

BERLIN, March 30 -- Emperor William's speeches in connection with the dedication of the new barracks, near the imperial castle, of the Emperor Alexander Grenadier Regiment, are still the sensation of the hour. The Vorwaerts to-day vouches for its version of his Majesty's speech. The Hamburger Correspondent also says that the version published by the Kreuz Zeltung is much milder than the Emperor's original words.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 30 -- Well-informed observers believe that the position of the Minister of the Interior, M. Slpiaguine, is untenable, and they anticipate bis resignation within a short time as a result of the inability of the police to control the turbulent elements.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30 -- Tufts College baseball team failed to come up to what Princetonians expected and was defeated this afternoon on University Field by the score of 23 to 4. After the first inning the Tigers found Tufts' pitchers -- there were three of them -- easy to hit. The second inning alone netted Princeton ten runs.

More than three-quarters of a million shares of stock were dealt in in the two hours of business on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with a continuance of the upward movement which has been a feature of the market all week. As on previous days, the market strength was almost general, and confined to no one group of stocks.

THE HAGUE, March 15 -- The nation's gift to the Queen of the Netherlands on the occasion of her marriage was, after much debate, decided on, and designs were submitted to her Majesty for a complete set of sapphires. Later it was decided to alter the present to sapphires and diamonds, and just one month from the day of her Majesty's marriage a part of the costly and extremely beautiful gift was presented to her.

LONDON, March 30 -- Herbert Gladstone, member of Parliament for West Leeds, has issued a letter to his constituents containing a striking indictment of the Government which, The Daily News declares, will be welcomed by all Liberals as a bugle call to action and as worthy of the writer's father's son.

WASHINGTON, March 30 -- ln addition to the selection of a Major General and two Brigadier Generals, the appointment was announced of two Majors and twenty-five Captains in the Paymaster's Department, twenty-one Captains in the Commissary Department, thirty-seven Captains in the Quartermaster's Department, and seventeen Chaplains.

HONOLULU, March 23, (via San Francisco, March 30) -- The sessions of the House this week were enlivened by the receipt of two communications from the Governor and one from the Secretary at Territory, in answer to resolutions which the House had sent to the officials of the administrative department.

BALTIMORE, March 30 -- The local market to-day was fairly active, with Seaboards as the pronounced leaders. The general underlying tone continued quite strong, though the prominence of Seaboards interfered somewhat with the free trading in other issues. The same expectations prevailed with regard to the several more important local groups, the gossip about deals being as insistent as ever.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer of the letter, "To the Missionary Clergy and Laity." in THE TIMES of to-day asks if it is advisable to continue missionary activity In China. He practically answers his own question when he says?

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report in your issue of the 28th inst. of our meeting in New Irving Hall, headed. "Russians Meet and Denounce the Czar," while essentially correct, contains a passage, which, I trust you, with your usual fairness, will permit me to set right in one or two details.
The weekly statement of the New York City banks showed a decrease in the surplus reserve of $2,401,925. The banks now hold a surplus of $7,870,500 above the legal requirement.
Morphine eating was the novel plea which secured the release in the Essex Market Police Court yesterday of a young man charged with stealing a Spring overcoat.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 30 -- The Alumni Weekly to-day prints a letter written by Sir Francis Knollys, private secretary to King Edward VII. when the latter was Prince of Wales. The letter is dated April 10. 1871, and is a reply to a letter sent him under fictitious names by three students of the class of 1871 informing the Prince of his unanimous election to the Princeton Medical Faculty, an organization which never existed.

To The Editor of The New York Times: In your article concerning "Spelling in the Common Schools" in yesterday's issue, you begin by expressing satisfaction that more attention is to be paid to teaching children to spell, and proceed to speak on the whole unfavorably of the efforts to make a given amount of attention go further by simplifying spelling.

Ex-Surrogate John H.V. Arnold, who was stricken with apoplexy in his office, at 206 Broadway, Friday afternoon, died at half-past 8 o'clock yesterday morning in the Hudson Street Hospital, where he had been removed. He was unconscious until the end came. Members of his family had been hastily summoned by the hospital authorities.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 30 -- The application of Mrs. Bly E.F. Withaus for a modification of the decree of divorce granted to her from her husband. Prof. Rudolph A. Witthaus, has been denied by Justice Martin J. Keogh. The application was made with a view of securing a larger amount of alimony.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., March 30 -- Great has been the building boom at this place since the Summer season closed last year. About forty handsome cottages have been erected. Some of them are completed: the rest are in various stages of completion, but all will be ready for occupancy when the warm weather makes the dwellers in the city yearn for ocean breezes.

A well-known gambler of the Tenderloin stood yesterday afternoon in front of Tom O'Rourke's, on Broadway. He is called "Bart," though his old friends, who knew, him when he was a right bower of the famous Murray, when the latter was a faro king on Broadway, near Fourth Street, in the seventies, know that his real name is Theodore C. Moore.

The Poughkeepsie Eastman Club, an organization of alumni of the Eastman Business College at Poughkeepsie, held its second annual banquet last night at the Young Men's Christian Association Hall on Twenty-third Street, near Fourth Avenue. One hundred and fifty guests sat down to the tables.

BRISTOL, March 30 -- The finishing of the Bristol cup defender, now fast drawing to a close, with the probability of an early launching, causes special attention to be paid to numerous small fittings that are intended to give complete form to the craft before she is ready to take her initial spin in the bay.

The two or three glorious days that came last week with a flood of sunshine and with the balmy breezes that seem made for carrying the perfume of the early flowers of the year, served to fill the uptown streets with two unfailing harbingers of Spring -- the sparrow and the small boy with the top.

BERLIN, March 30 -- It is learned on the best authority that, regarding the Chinese indemnity and the mode of apportioning it, there is no divergence of opinion between the United States and Germany, notwithstanding the numerous statements to the contrary. The American Ambassador and the representatives of the German Foreign Office hold almost daily conferences on the subject of China.

The close of the season of grand opera seems to be the most natural topic for comment on the Sunday following the last performance. But in good sooth the recent season calls for no remarks of deep significance. It is both trite and provocative of troubled blood to make special capital of the fact that the Wagner performances occupied nearly one-half of the season.

The story told in another column of this issue of the work done by the Army Surgeons in Cuba in fixing upon the mosquito the responsibility for the conveyance of the infection of yellow fever from one human being to another is of the greatest interest to all for whom exact experiments pointing to indisputable conclusions have a value which does not attach to speculations.

LAKEWOOD, March 30 -- Lakewood is especially blessed in beautiful drives. Consequently driving is one of the most popuher pastimes, both with residents and hote patrons. The former possess some very smart traps, and these stylish vehicles with their attendant footmen, add much to the attractiveness of favorite highways.

Writing to THE TIMES of the "fads" or "special courses" in the public school system of the city, a recently retired teacher has this to say: "One Principal told the writer in his classroom to pay no attention to the Manual Training Supervisor's suggestions, as she would like to have you spend all day on her work.'
To the Editor of The New York Times: Correspondents like your "Moral Mugwump" of the 26th last honor themselves and your honorble TIMES.
WASHINGTON, March 30 -- Late this afternoon the President announced that he had made the following appointments:

The sun rises to-morrow at about 5:30 and sets a few minutes after 6 o'clock, giving us a little less than twelve and three-quarter hours of daylight, conclusive proof in itself that we have gotten the better of the inhabitants south of the equator. When the month closes, this daylight interval will be increased to fourteen hours or thereabout.

LONDON, March 30 -- The fifty-fourth Liverpool Spring Cup for 1,000 sovereigns, one mile and three furlongs, was won to-day by Lord Stanley's chestnut colt Pellisson, by Prisoner, out of Red Spider, with "Johnnie" Reiff in the saddle. There were twenty-six entries and ten horses ran.

ALBANY, March 31. -- Assemblyman John A. Weekes, Jr., will introduce in the Assembly to-morrow night a bill which will provide for a Committee of Fifteen to make an investigation of the administration of New York City's Municipal Government, with a view to ascertaining what retrenchment is possible without impairment of the efficiency of any of the departments.

PATERSON, N. J., March 31. -- Judge Dixon and a jury in the Passaic Circuit Court will be requested to determine the value of two stolen kisses. Lawyer Abram Klenert, counsel for Harry C. Sleight, and Louise P. Sleight, his wife, has sued Charles G. Myron, a New York provision dealer, for $1,000.

Exercising the amiable faculty which is their most notable characteristic -- that of seeing only the element of evil which exists in the majority of human transactions and of ignoring all the other elements -- the anti-imperialists are throwing up their holy hands -- in hysterical horror because of the deception involved in the capture of AGUINALDO.

Prince Krapotkin, a Russian Anarchist exile, who has come to this country to lecture in behalf of Russia's oppressed people, spoke to a large and enthusiastic audience at the Grand Central Palace yesterday afternoon at 3 o'clock.

It has been a remarkable record that Wall Street has made for the first quarter of 1901; and the last month of the quarter has been in various respects the most notable not only of that period, but of years -- not so much, however, in volume of transactions as in other important elements.

READING, Penn., March 31. -- George F. Baer to-night confirmed absolutely the statement that he will shortly become President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company. Mr. Baer will not only be the President of the Philadelphia and Reading Railway Company, but of the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company and the Reading Company.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The monthly settlement has passed off under a tighter money market than usual, and with larger bull engtnemen Is than had been expected. The husbanding of their resources by the banks for the imperial loan caused a scarcity of money.

BERLIN, March 31. -- There is the highest authority for the statement that the investigation into the causes of the attack upon Emperor William by Dietrich Wetland in Bremen has not yet been concluded, but is still being vigorously pushed.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., March 31. -- James Jennings McComb died at his residence here at 10:30 o'clock this morning. Death was caused by a complication of diseases resulting from kidney trouble. He had been ill for several months and critically so for some weeks.

After brooding for a long time over the failure of a young woman to requite his affection, Francis N. Zabriskie, son of the late Rev. Francis N. Zabriskie of Princeton, N.J., killed himself yesterday afternoon in his apartment at the Beverwyck, 41 West Twenty-seventh Street. His body was found by another young man, Edward Madden, who said he was the dead man's most intimate friend.

John Paton, the banker and philanthropist, who died of pneumonia at his home in the West End of London Saturday, was one of the foremost Scotch-Canadian residents in this city for many years. He was born at Ancrum, Roxburghshire, Scotland, on May 26, 1831, his father, the Rev. John Paton, being pastor of the church at that place.

The acquirement by W.L. Stow of the control of the Mexican Central Railroad is preliminary to ambitious operations by a group of American capitalists. Some of these colleagues of Mr. Stow are prominent in the Standard Oil quarter, and they have close relations to interests with which Mr. J.P. Morgan is identified.
George L. Rives, President of the Charter Revision Commission, issued the following statement yesterday:

Despite the cold wind and rough water there was considerable rowing on the Harlem River yesterday, all the crews in active training rowing as usual. The Junior eight of the Dauntless Rowing Club was out both in the morning and the afternoon, rowing in the following order: Bow, Desvesnine: 2, R. Corney; 3, Mills; 4, P. Reese, Jr.; 5, J. Crawford; 6, C. Schafer; 7, C. Wilson; stroke, W. Hulse; coxswain, E. H. Anderson.

At the close of February two-thirds of the fiscal year had passed. The Bureau of Statistics has just sent out the advanced sheets of its latest monthly summary, covering this period. The totals, compared with those of the corresponding portion of last year, are interesting. The following table shows them:

PITTSBURG, March 31. -- Mrs. Ann Ward, aged sixty years, is lying in a critical condition from the effects of brutal treatment by three masked burglars at her home, at Thirty-eighth and Carson Streets, early this morning. Mrs. Ward and her daughter were awakened by the presence of the burglars at their bedside, each woman finding a revolver pointed directly at her head.

BOSTON, March 31. -- President William J. Tucker of Dartmouth College took the Christian Church to task for its part in the Chinese troubles during a Lenten sermon at the Old South Church this evening. His strongest sentences were these:

A dispute that came near ending in a fistfight occurred last evening in Broadway, at Sixty-fourth Street, between Lawyer J. Campbell Thompson, living at Riverside Drive and Ninety-fifth Street, and a cabman employed at Pierce's Stables, Broadway and Fifty-eighth Street.

The loss of two lives and injuries to several persons resulted from a fire which was started by the explosion of a kerosene lamp in the hallway of the five-story tenement house, 37 Moore Street, Brooklyn, shortly after 9 o'clock last night.

Believing that their little son was dying, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Park, of 406 West One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street, called in a Catholic priest to baptize him, in the hope that it would save his life, promising to educate him in the Roman Catholic faith should he recover. The child is suffering from pneumonia.
Capt. Max Schmittberger of the West One Hundredth Street Police Station enforced the excise laws yesterday as they have not been for a long time. His policemen made many arrests.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- Secretary Gage was questioned to-day as to his probable action with respect to the cash accumulations in the Treasury, and particularly as to whether he contemplated buying bonds for the sinking fund.

Maddened when told that his wedding would have to be postponed for at least two years an Italian last night made an attempt to murder his fiancee and her parents, and then commit suicide. He shot the girl in the thigh, slightly wounded her mother, and then inflicted two wounds upon himself.

LONDON, April 1. -- The Cape Town correspondent of The Daily Mall, after referring to the fact that the Cape Government was compelled last year to have recourse to the United States and Germany for locomotives and trucks, says: "British manufacturers must wake up, as further larse orders for steel rails will shortly be given out, to relay the permanent way after the heavy war traffic.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 31. -- A petition presented by J.M. Francis, 1902, the leading single sculler in the university, to the Athletic Council, asking that James A. Ten Eyck be recognized as coach of all the single seullers at Cornell, and that Francis be allowed to represent the university at Poughkeepsie this year under Ten Eyck's coaching, provided he beat out all other competitors, was refused yesterday.

Another surgeon has succeeded in removing the stomach of a patient suffering from a tumor in that organ. On last Saturday almost the entire stomach of D.G. Bodman, an expert accountant, living at $3 Third Avenue, Newark, was taken out, and last night the patient was reported as doing well.

WASHINGTON, March 31. -- The Navy Department early this morning received a cablegram from Admiral Remey, commander in chief of the Asiatic Station, giving a brief account of a fire in the sailroom of the gunboat Petrel and of the death of the commanding officer, Lieut. Commander Jesse Mims Roper, as a result of a heroic effort to rescue the men below.

BALLSTON, N.Y., March 31. -- Neil Gilmour, ex-State Superintendent of Public Instruction, died at 8:13 o'clock this morning from an embolism arising from valvular disease of the heart, with which he had been an invalid for five months. He was born in Paisley, Scotland, Jan. 8, 1840, and came to this village in youth.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., March 31. -- The old cup defender Columbia has been thoroughly overhauled and prepared for serviceable condition for the trial races with the new Herreshoff yacht building at Bristol, and is now lying on the marine railway at the Hawkins Yard. Inside fittings have been added, and the work of polishing the Tobin bronze underbody is nearly completed.

Germany is plainly threatened with two dangers, as to one of which the United States may sympathize. In the attempt of the Government to strengthen itself in the Parliament by concessions to the Agrarians who demand protective taxes on food products it invites serious disturbance of its relations with several powerful neighbors.

BERLIN, March 31. -- The Berlin papers publish a speech said to have been de livered by Empero William May 20 of last year at a luncheon following a parade of the Guards. His Majesty referred to the occasion of a parade of the Guards, May 29, 1888, before Emperor Frederick, who was then seriously ill, and continued as follows:

LONDON, March 31. -- The Stock Exchange was startled last week by consols dropping to 95 1/8 Although they subsequently recovered, they closed at 95 1/2 with no prospect of a material rise. If this continues. British credit may soon be down to the German level.

MANILA, March 31. -- Interest in the capture and fate of Aguinaldo is well-nigh overshadowed in Manila by sensational developments, present and prospective, of frauds in the Commissary Department. How widely these extend has not yet been ascertained, but enough is already known to justify the belief that they are farreaching.

Following are the returns of foreign, commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The famous roadsters of New York measured pace on the Speedway yesterday between double lines of spectators that extended from end to end of the splendid drive on either side of the road. The crowd was estimated by the police at anywhere between 15,000 and 20,000, and a more appreciative gathering never assembled at a Grand Circuit meeting.

Twenty thousand pigeons were yesterday morning in the coops at Inter-State Park, Queens, L.I., ready to be butchered to make a trap-shooters' holiday. This is Grand American Handicap week at the park. To decide the principal event, more than 5,000 of these emblems of peace will be required to furnish living targets for the marksmen.

Ex-Mayor Hewitt of New York has added to his reputation as a philanthropist by offering to provide two of sixty-five sites required for the branch library buildings which Mr. Carnegie promised to erect if New York would provide the sites and insure the maintenance of the libraries. Mr. Hewitt in making his offer made the wise suggestion that as far as possible the buildings devoted to libraries be made centres of popular education and enjoyment.

-- A few moments after the fire in the Ballroom of the Petrel was discovered every man on the gunboat knew that his life was in deadly peril, and if they had all jumped into the water and made for the shore with all possible speed it would have been only obedience to the often-mentioned and much-excusing instinct of self-preservation.

W.H. Gebhard has sold to a syndicate, represented by Whitehouse Porter, the entire block bounded by Fifth and Madison Avenues, One Hundred and Seventh and One Hundred and Eighth Streets. Included in the purchase is a plot of five lots, evened by Isaac M. Berinstein, on the south side of One Hundred and Seventh Street, facing the above property.

An audience of more than 1,500 persons gathered at Cooper Union last night to hear an explanation of the plans and purposes of the Civic Council. The meeting was under the auspices of the People's Institute. George Tombleson presided. Ernest H. Crosby, the President of the Council, made the first address, and he epitomized the purposes of the organization.

Robert MacKellar of Peekskill, N.Y. died at his home, in that place, yesterday morning. He was eighty-three years of age. He was born in this city and was a son of Archibald and Abigail Eraser MacKellar. His father was in business in Old Slip, in the early part of the century. Robert MacKellar first worked for John Harper, the publisher, and then went to Charlestown, S.C., for two years.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- The consolidation of practically all the flour mills in this section was completed to-day with the transfer by the executors of the estate of James McCormick at Harrisburg, Penn., of the Paxton Mills, and the leasing by the same persons of the Steelton Flouring Mill Company to the Eastern Hilling and Export Company.

Current advices from London report an ominous stringency in the money market. The discount rate is stiffening, bankers are becoming timid, and some uneasiness is felt lest these symptoms should be indicative of an approaching panic. In the present temper of the British people it would seemingly not require much to bring about this result.

William P. Gill, a Brooklyn newspaper man, has brought an action in the Supreme Court to recover $20,000 damages for alleged false imprisonment against Col. John G. Eddy, Lieut. Col. Hewlings H. Quick, and ex-Capt. George E. Libbey of the Forty-seventh Regiment, Brooklyn.

Does Mr. THOMAS C. PLATT still hold his place as fiscal agent of the Republican Party? It is of public knowledge that Gov. ODELL has attacked if not destroyed his supremacy as boss. The Governor openly and flagrantly disobeyed Mr. PLATT'S orders in regard to the Police bill, and a boss who cannot enforce obedience to orders is practically dethroned and may be safely defied by the daring and the strong.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 1. -- A movement has been inaugurated to consolidate all the independent oil companies and firms operating in the Beaumont oil field into one great corporation. The promoter of this enterprise is Robert A. Greer of Beaumont, a member of the State Legislature, and one of the most prominent lawyers in Texas.

ALBANY, April 1. -- The three-platoon police provision which was inserted in the Senate bill on the revision of the New York charter is to be stricken out. This statement was made to-night on the floor of the Senate by Senator Stranahan, just before adjournment. He said:

BALTIMORE, April 1. -- The Keen Hagerty Manufacturing Company of this city has been purchased by the National Enameling and Stamping Company. The Keen Hagerty Company is one of the largest manufacturers of pieced and heavy polished, stamped, and japanned tinware, galvanized ware, and gray flint enameled ware in the United States.

TRENTON, N. J., April 1. -- A movement was started to-day by the Trenton Ministerial Union to keep the Delaware and Raritan Canal closed on Sundays. The Rev. George H. Ingram, Secretary of the union, informed the members that the canal had been opened yesterday for the first time in forty-five years on a Sunday.

TRENTON, N.J., April 1. -- The United States Steel Corporation to-day filed an amended certificate of incorporation increasing its capital stock from $3,000 to $1,100,000,000. The stock is divided into 11,000,000 shares, half of which are to be preferred, bearing 7 per cent, cumulative dividends.

The suicide of Francis N. Zabriskie, at the Beverwyck Apartment House, 41 West Twenty-seventh Street, on Sunday afternoon, gave rise to various rumors yesterday as to the probable cause for the young man's act. Until Coroner's Physician O'Hanlon saw the body there was a report current that Zabriskie had not committed suicide at all, but had been murdered.

BALTIMORE, April 1 -- The stock market was very active again to-day, but swung back into its more or less specialized phase. Seaboards received marked attention and sold rapidly and buoyantly. The sales outside of Seaboards were comparatively few; but the strength of Seaboards proved a sustaining force to the market, despite their monopolizing activity.

LONDON, April 1 -- A large sum in the shape of dividends and interest payments was released to-day, but the money was much wanted to pay calls, for considerable repayments to the Bank of England and also for the tenders sent in for the million in six months' Treasury bills, for which the applications amounted to u4,685,000, the acceptances averaging 3 9-20 per cent.

BOSTON, April 1 -- Money on call rules from 3@3 1/2 per cent. Time money ranges from 3 1/2@4 1/2 per cent, for four to six months, according to the character of the collateral. There is no increase in the supply of commercial paper. The best names sell from 3 3/4@4 1/2 per cent. Mill paper would sell at 3 1/2 per cent.

The Rev. Dr. Josiah Strong, President of the League for Social Service, was the principal speaker at the opening session of the Eleventh Annual Conference of Missions, at the Amity Baptist Church, on West Fifty-fourth Street, yesterday afternoon. Dr. Strong's subject was, "The Application of the Christian Law of Service to Labor and Capital."

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- After China's original refusal to sign the Manchuria treaty, Russia amended it in some particulars, and then presented it again with what was practically an ultimatum. China was told that no further amendments would be made; that the treaty was in its final form, and that she must accept it by April 1.

Dealings in the stock market yesterday ran up to the enormous total of over 1,800,000 recorded transactions, while, were the unrecorded trading and the stop-loss orders included, the aggregate would approximate close to the two-million-and-a-quarter mark. Of this total, the stocks of the United States Steel Corporation contributed nearly 420,000 shares -- more than one-fifth of the entire market transactions.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 1. -- One of the hardest fought municipal campaigns in the history of St. Louis closed to-night with mass meetings held in every part of the city by most of the six parties having tickets in the field. The tickets to be voted to-morrow are the Democratic, Republican, Good Government, Public Ownership, Socialist-Democratic, and Socialist-Labor.

NEWPORT, April 1 -- The Dowager Duchess of Manchester, Lady Lister-Kaye, Mrs. C.S. Dodge, Edward Wickes, Mr. and Mrs. C. Lawrence, Mrs. William H. Osgood, and James J. Van Alen have returned to New York.

One of the first men to appear on the eastern end of Fulton Street yesterday morning was the crier for one of the shops on the north side of that thoroughfare a block away from the Fulton Ferry. He carried a hammer in his hand, and looking about him to see that the coast was clear, drew from his pocket a long metal spike about three-quarters of an inch in diameter.

Trading in the outside market yesterday was more active than at any time since the transfer to the Stock Exchange of the shares of the United States Steel Corporation. The market was strong and the unusually large transactions were very generally accompanied by substantial advances in prices.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 1. -- The most interesting municipal election held in this city in years resulted to-day in the election of Tom L. Johnson (Dem.) to the office of Mayor over William J. Ackers (Rep.) by a plurality that may go as high as 6,000. Only the head of the Republican ticket was defeated, the candidates for the minor offices on that ticket being successful.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 1. -- Spring football practice was started at Harvard to-day when some thirty men reported to Captain Campbell for preliminary work. Naturally the work was very light, for the men were soft after an interval of four months, since the Fall work. The practice will be continued until the April recess, and along toward the end there will be one or two scrub games played to make the work more interesting.

DETROIT, Mich., April 1. -- Robert M. Montgomery of Grand Rapids, Republican, has been re-elected Justice of the Supreme Court by about 40,000 majority, and Frank W. Fletcher of Alpena and Henry W. Carey of Manistee, Republican candidates for Regents of the State University, have also been elected by a majority almost as large.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- Senator Proctor of Vermont has just returned from Cuba, where he has been making observations concerning conditions in the island. The Senator says he found a disposition among many leading Cubans to accept the terms of the Platt amendment as the most satisfactory solution of the relations between the United States and Cuba.

Mrs. Addie M. Francis, the most intimate woman friend of Albert T. Patrick, charged with the murder of the millionaire, William Marsh Rice, the identity of whom as the "woman in the case" has heretofore been only a matter of conjueture, underwent a severe examination yesterday on the witness stand.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Under the caption of "An Air Motor Accident," in your to-day's issue, you state that" the first accident to happen to the mechanism of the air-motor cars on Twenty-eighth and Twenty-ninth Streets occurred yesterday afternoon." Now, where are your reporters' eyes?

At a meeting of the Trustees of Columbia University, held yesterday, the Committee on Buildings and Grounds, which was authorized last November to prepare plans for the new College Hall, to be erected as soon as the necessary funds are raised, presented a report which was approved and accepted.

Police Commissioner Murphy yesterday afternoon presented to Patrick J. Darcy, a patrolman on the staff of Deputy Commissioner Devery, a bronze medal for bravery. Honorable mention also goes with this medal, which is the first medal that Commissioner Murphy has presented to any one since he became Police Commissioner.

In the interesting interview with Mr. RIVES, printed in yesterday's TIMES, concerning the proposed changes in the revision of the charter, perhaps the most important topic was the length of the Mayor's term. The revisers propose that it shall be, as now, maintained at four years.

If the Legislature shall sanction the investigation proposed by Assemblyman WEEKES, "with a view to ascertaining what retrenchment is possible in the administration of New York without impairment of the efficiency of any of the departments," its report will show something very different from what Mr. WEEKES promises.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 1. -- James Ten Eyck will come to Ithaca to coach J.M. Francis, 1902, but his pupil will be kept from representing the university on the water this year. Francis will prepare for the Sumdmer races and will represent the Laureate Boat Club of Troy.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 -- This was about the liveliest day of the year in the Philadelphia market and the trading embraced a wider range of stocks than for many a day. New high records were made for the Readings and American Railways, and Lehigh Valley rose to its best price since 1896.

To The Editor of The New York Times: While the letter in THE TIMES of Wednesday, March 27, signed "German-American," is, despite the allusion to Hengist and Horsa, but little to the purpose as a reply to "Moral Mugwump's" sensible communication, it at least breathes the true masterful German missionary spirit.

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The monthly statement of the public debt, issued to-day by the Treasury Department, shows that at the close of business March 30, 1901, the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,007,142,909, which is a decrease, as compared with March 1, 1901, of $18,876,595.

MERRICK, L.I., April 1. -- Twelve cottages on the grounds of the Long Island Camp Meeting Association were destroyed by fire this morning and six others were slightly burned. A tract of woodland was also swept by the flames. The total loss will be about $30,000.

The city officials declared yesterday that they were ready to receive a legislative investigation committee if the bill prepared by Assemblyman Weekes of New York is passed. Controller Coler, Corporation Counsel Whalen, and the various heads of departments said they did not fear the outcome of "an honest investigation" into the city's affairs.

ALBANY, April 1. -- Assemblyman Bell will press his Christian Scientist bill with the amendments which prohibit Christian Scientists from treating contagious or infectious diseases or performing operative surgery, but allow them to treat all other kinds of diseases or infirmities. "I will move the bill Wednesday with the amendments," said Mr. Bell to-night.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 1 -- A. determined effort will be made here to secure an annual appropriation of $4,000 for the maintenance of the new library building for the establishment of which Andrew Carnegie has made a conditional offer of $40,000.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 1. -- The trial of Peter Karpovich, the assassin of M. Bogoliepoff, the Russian Minister of Public Instruction, was strictly secret. Admittance was only by card. Among those present were the Ministers of Justice, of the Interior, and of Finances. Only fifty cards were distributed.

The April Grand Jury, which is expected to consider the evidence now in District Attorney Philbin's possession against police officials who have been found by the Committee of Fifteen lax in the suppression of the laws against gambling and disorderly houses, was yesterday sworn in by Recorder Goff, in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- The report of the West Point Court of Inquiry in the Booz case, signed by Gen. John. R. Brooke, as President, and Capt James T. Dean, as recorder, was made public to-day at the War Department. It bears the following indorsement by Secretary Root:
LONDON, April 2. -- The Odessa correspondent of The Daily Express says:

WASHINGTON, April 1. -- The card at Bennings to-day, while interesting, proved an enigma to the talent, not an out-and-out favorite winning in any of the events. Some scratching reduced the fields in several races. Summaries:

In Holy Week, there are hardly any social arrangements. Every one is busy going to church, attending lectures, looking after charities, and shopping. Sunday was quite gay in New York and the suburbs. Miss May Callender gave the last of her musical informal afternoons, which was very largely attended.

WASHINGTON, April 1 -- At the close of June, or very soon thereafter, the Pension Bureau will report the business of that office for the fiscal year. The promise now is that the showing will be very like that of June, 1900, although there may be a slight increase in the pension roll in consequence of the new obligations imposed by the war with Spain and the Filipino insurrection.

Conditions were favorable for fast going on the Speedway yesterday, and the select gathering of trotters and pacers on the course furnished excellent sport for the crowd of spectators who lined the curb of the upper stretch.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 1. -- Over fifty golfers from various parts of the country took part in the United North and South championship tournament on the Pinehurst links to-day. Dr. L.L. Harpan of the Columbia Golf Club of Washington, D.C., who won the all-Florida golf championship at St. Augustine last week, led the qualifying first sixteen, with a score of 169 for 26 holes.

The New York Northfield-Hermon Club, composed of former students of the schools at Northfield and Mount Hermon, Mass., has determined to raise a quarter of a million dollars toward the endowment fund of $3,000,000 new being solicited for those institutions.

Army. Col. Alfred Mordecal, Ordnance Department, will proceed to Fort Rosecrans, California; thence to Fort Stevens, Oregon, and Fort Columbia, Washington, via Benicia Arsenal, on official business pertaining to the repair of the armament at the posts named.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacoa, April 1 -- The Colonial authorities of the Island of Trinidad (British) have been directed to prepare evidence for the use of the British Minister at Caracas, W.H.D. Haggard, who has been instructed to make representations to the Venezuelan Government regarding the action of the Venezuelan gunboat Augusto in landing men on the Island of Patos (British) and destroying four neutral vessels containing British cargoes.

President George J. Gould of the Manhattan Railway Company has directed that the plan for building four west side substations, in connection with the new main power house at Seventy-fourth Street and East River, be abandoned.

Yale, Columbia, and Cornell have picked their teams for the inter-collegiate fencing championship, which will be held on Saturday evening in the New York Athletic Club. Yale will be represented by S.N. Arnold, E.H. Delafield, and W.E. Meyer. The first two, with K. Spalding, composed the team that defeated the Columbia fencers in the dual competition at New Haven last week.

The Rapid Transit Commission having attentively examined the tunnel projects of Mr. A.L. JOHNSON and finding them unworthy of adoption, has returned them to their inventor. Thereupon Mr. JOHNSON begins to talk about an appeal from the commission to the people in mass meeting assembled.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on ail conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
The annual report of Commissioners of Accounts Hertle and Owen, showing the work done in examining city accounts for the year ended Dec. 31, 1900, was made public yesterday.

PITTSBURG, April 1. -- Just before being taken into the United Steel Company, the Edgar Thomson Mill of the Carnegie Company established a new world's record in the production of Bessemer steel: 1,995 gross tons of steel were produced in 133 heats. The best previous record was 1,800 tons in 120 heats.

John Grant Lyman, President of the International Zinc Company, through his counsel, yesterday asked Justice Truax in the Supreme Court to vacate the attachments obtained against his property. Charles F. Stewart, who seeks to recover $26,550, obtained the attachments.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- Carter H. Harrison has again been elected Mayor of Chicago, and will next week commence his third term as the Chief Executive of the city. His total plurality over Judge Elbridge Hanecy, the Republican nominee, will be in the neighborhood of 28,257 votes. The total vote of the city is: Harrison, 156,952; Hanecy, 128,695.

A painful incident in connection with the election of Mr. TOM L. JOHNSON to be Mayor of Cleveland is the circulation of the report that Senator HANNA spent $100,000 in a futile effort to defeat him. We regard as quite superfluous Mr. HANNA'S indignant denial of this atrocious campaign slander.

For the next three days there will be nothing of interest in society. There is much planning about country house parties as well as arranging for the weddings which are to take place after Easter. This week also brings the young sons of the fashionable set home for their Easter holidays, and the Grand Central Station is filled with anxious and affectionate parents, eager to greet their offspring.

Capt. Justus M. Wheate, Assistant Surgeon, United States Volunteers, will proceed to San Francisco and report to the commanding General, Department of California, for transportation to Manila, where he will report to the commanding General, Division of the Philippines, for assignment to duty.

It is eighteen years since the civil service law was passed. In that time its application has been greatly extended, each succeeding Administration, Republican, Democratic, again Republican, and again Democratic, contributing to the extension, until the present one, in which the movement has been reversed.

ALBANY, N.Y., April 2. -- The bill introduced by Assemblyman Weekes providing for an investigation into the running of the municipal departments of New York City by a committee of fifteen will not be passed. Mr. Weekes had an interview with Gov. Odell to-day to learn how the Governor viewed the bill and received no encouragement to push it.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Inquiry was made at the White House to-day to learn when and how often recently J. Pierpont Morgan had been a visitor upon the President.

The action for absolute divorce of Lydell Whitehead against Elizabeth Whitehead is on trial before Justice Beach in the Supreme Court. Mr. Whitehead is the President of the Whitehead Brothers Construction and Molding Sand Company. He is worth several million dollars, and is well known at Saratoga, where he has a Summer home.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 2. -- The Superior Councillor of the Chinese Legation, as Charge d'Affaires, is continuing the negotiations regarding the Manchuria agreement. The illness of the Chinese Minister, Yang-Yu, is now admitted to be due to apoplexy, which will probably incapacitate him from work for a long period.

A representative of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co. yesterday repeated the statewent of Monday that Mr. Morgan's recent visits to Washington to see the President had no reference to the Panama Canal project. The report that such was the case was characterized as absurd.

The Municipal Assembly at the sessions yesterday approved of the issue of bonds in the sum of $5,300,000 for public improvements. The sum of $3,500,000 was appropriated for school purposes. Two million dollars is to be spent in the Borough of Manhattan and the Bronx, $1,200,000 in Brooklyn, and $300,000 in the Borough of Queens.

The interests represented on the Board of Directors of the United States Steel Corporation are quite as varied as the multiplex functions the trust itself will perform. A great steamship company, and even one of the largest dry goods establishments in the country are represented. The Board, as announced, is as follows:

BOSTON, April 2. -- At the Clearing House this morning the feature was the heaviness in New Tork funds, which sold at 17 and 20 cents discount for cash. Money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 and 3 per cent. Some banks paid 3 per cent., rather than sell their New York funds at 20 cents discount.
WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The Secretary of the Treasury has bought in New York $2,000,000 of short term bonds for the sinking fund.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The War Department received to-day information from Gen. MacArthur that Aguinaldo has taken the oath of allegiance to the United States under the terms of amnesty offered by Gen. MacArthur by direction of the President. The cablegram as given out by the department is as follows:

BOSTON, April 2. -- Preliminaries for the trials of the yacht Independence have been made, and it is likely that after a few spins off Boston Light immediately after the fitting out of the yacht she will proceed at once to Marblehead, which place will be her headquarters during the season.

Lemuel E. Quigg, ex-President of the Republican County Committee, was asked yesterday whether he knew who presented the three-platoon police amendment to the Senate Committee on Cities; if he had any knowledge of the raising of a corruption fund, and if he was interested in the passage of the amendment.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., April 2. -- County elections were held throughout the State to-day, and nearly all the cities and towns electod tickets. As a rule, party lines were eliminated. Joshua Eric Dodge was elected to the Supreme bench without opposition. Four non-partisan Judges were elected in Milwaukee County.

There is a dispute as to whether two patrolmen. Peter Byrnes and James McCormick, rescued Mrs. Hall, sixty-five years old, and Mamie Curran, thirteen years old, from the burning five-story tenement, at 430 West Fifty-second Street, last evening. The policemen say that when they arrived the house was filled with dense smoke, and that the inmates were panic-stricken.

Commissioner Henry S. Kearney of the Department of Buildings, Lighting, and Supplies yesterday declared himself opposed to the building of a prison for women in Brooklyn, and suggested that the present institution be abolished except so far as it might be used as a place of detention for women not yet convicted.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 2. -- Wretched wet weather came in with the second day of the Pinehurst Golf Club's tournament, and miniature ponds formed on the putting greens. It rained so hard that the ladies' handicap was postponed until tomorrow, as were also the driving and approaching competitions.

CHICAGO, April 2. -- The fact that Hobart Chatfield Chatfield -- Taylor is taking lessons in dramatic elocution in the studio of Mrs. Millward Adams, who has fitted so many people for the stage, has led to the story that the well-known writer is about to become an actor. This is further strengthened by the fact that Mr. Chatfleld-Taylor is very fond of the theatre and has lately extended his acquaintance among actors.

President Orr of the Rapid Transit Commission has written a letter to Councilman John T. Oakley, Chairman of the Railroad Committee of the Municipal Council, and Alderman James J. Bridges, Chairman of the Committee on Streets and Highways, placing the responsibility for any further delays in the construction of the rapid transit tunnel to Brooklyn on the shoulders of the Municipal Assembly.

MANILA, April 2. -- Constancia Problete, who is President of the Women's Peace League, was permitted to have a long interview with Aguinaldo. At the time of the interview Aguinaldo had, not yet taken the oath of allegiance to the United States. She reports having found him in a quandary, professedly desirous of peace, yet reluctant to abandon the idea of Filipino independence.

COPENHAGEN, April 2. -- The one hundredth anniversary of the naval battle which was fought off Copenhagen in 1801 between the British and the Danes was celebrated here to-day. The city was generally decorated with flags, and there was a naval and military parade.

People who have for the last few years ridden in the surface cars of the several boroughs of Greater New York have noticed a little sign, unless they happened to be sitting directly beneath it. It called their attention to the legal penalties for expectoration. But for the most part people have observed it, and then disregarded it.

BOSTON, April 2. -- The plans for an international canoe race between boats representing the Royal Canoe Club of England and the Winchester Boat Club of Winchester took definite shape to-day, when the following challenge was mailed to the honorable Secretary of the Royal Canoe Club:

ALBANY, April 2. -- Gov. Odell to-night sent for leading members of the Senate and Assembly Cities Committees, and there was a conference in the Executive Chamber on the subject of charter revision for Greater New York, which lasted until midnight. Senator Stranahan, Chairman or the Senate Cities Committee, and Asemblyman Keisey.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Copies of what was probably the full text of the last proclamatlon issued by Aguinaldo previous to his capture by Gen. Funston have been received at the War Department, where they attracted much attention. The proclamation is contained in the Filipinos Anti-Europa, the organ of the Filipino insurgents, published at Madrid, Spain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 2. -- There was considerable reaction to-day in the stocks that were booming yesterday. Union Traction, which closed last night at 33, fell back to 32 1/2, and Lehigh Valley fell from 30 to 37 8/4, closing at 38. The story that the Reading Company had taken over the Lehigh Valley stock at 40 was stamped as unfounded by President Baer.

ALBANY, April 2. -- In the House this morning Mr. Smith of New York asked unanimous consent to withdraw his bill introduced Jan. 29 to ratify the laying out of property bounded by Fifty-fourth. Fifty-second streets, Eleventh and Twelfth Avenues; stating that the Board of Public Works of New York City had removed the assessment.
LONDON, April 2. -- Olga Nethersole, the actress, who underwent a surgical operation last week, is progressing excellently and expects to go out at the end o this week.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The air was raw and penetrating at the Bennings track to-day, but the crowd was again large and some good sport was witnessed. Two favorites landed first money. From a good-sized field Scorpio, at 25 to 1, won the fifth by a length ahead of Animosity, the favorite, second.

ALBANY, April 2. -- In round numbers $26,000,000 for the improvement of the canals, making a barge canal for 450-ton barges instead of a 300-ton barge canal, as recommended by the Governor, is the plan that will be submitted by bill to the people.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- Gen. MacArthur has informed the War Department of the death of Major William R. Hall, Surgeon at Manila, this morning, of acute osteomyelitis, (inflammation of the marrow of bones.) He was a graduate of the Medical Department of the University of Michigan in the class of 1865.

The purchasers of the Paran Stevens estate's property at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, whose names are still withheld, have also acquired the adjoining property, 391 Fifth Avenue, 28 by 125. The owner of record of the latter is Louisa Minturn, who bought it in January, 1895, for $200,000.

A crowd that packed Madison Square Garden greeted Buffalo Bill, his Wild West, and his Congress of Rough Riders of the World last night. Col. Cody, in all his history, never gave a better show, and for three hours the immense audience sat and cheered and allowed itself to be thrilled.

The championship tournament of Greater New York and vicinity was continued on Thum's White Elephant alleys last night, each team rolling two games, total pins counting, and the Invincible Bowling Club obtained the lead in the series with a total of 1,860.

Vigorous protest against centralization and emphatic pleas for home rule in education were voiced at a mass meeting at the Academy of Music, Brooklyn, last night. The meeting was called in opposition to the school section reported by the Cities Committee on Charter Revision, at Albany.

BALTIMORE, April 2. -- The market today continued aggressively active. While Seaboards were the undisputed feature of the trading, they did not monopolize the Street's attention. Other Issues figured more or less prominently and with a buoyant tone. Among the most active securities in the list were some of the trust company shares, International and Citizens' both, on expectations of important developments, bounding upward.

The report of the referee, William Henry Willls, recommending the removal of Willis S. Paine and Waldo Grant Morse as executors of the estate of Mrs. Ruby Tilden Paine, was filed in the Surrogates' office yesterday afternoon. The testatrix was a niece of the late Samuel J. Tilden and received over $300,000 from his estate.

ST. LOUIS, April 2. -- The indications are that Rolla Wells (Dem.) has been elected Mayor of St. Louis by a plurality of about 10,000. The Post Dispatch says George W. Parker, the Republican candidate, admits that he has been defeated. The result of the election, however, cannot be absolutely determined at this hour.

Mr. PHILBIN has clearly been doing some excellent work in the District Attorney's office. By the energy, industry, and system he has introduced, he has succeeded in dispatching accumulated business so that the present Grand Jury will be able to give a reasonable amount of time to the special work in connection with the evidence against the police authorities without delaying the criminal cases arising in regular course.

LONDON, April 3. -- The annual report of the British Consul at Chicago, which Consular district includes St. Louis, St. Paul, Milwaukee, Kansas City, Omaha, and other cities, pays a great tribute to the enterprise and prosperity of these Western cities.

WASHINGTON, April 2. -- The danger menacing travelers to Central and South American ports, through the lack of quarantine facilities in those countries, has been called to the attention of the Marine Hospital Service by P.M. De Leon, United States Consul General to Ecuador.

The blowing out of a stopcock on a boiler in the engine room of Fleitman Co., at 484 Broome Street, yesterday, released all the steam in the boller, scalding to death Henry Otten, twenty-eight years old, of 566 Lexington Avenue, the fireman of the boiler, and severely scalding the engineer, Richard Kruse, fifty years old, of 620 Melrose Avenue.

Pigeon slaughter -- and maiming -- was continued yesterday at the trap-shooting tournament at Inter-State Park. Long Island, and there was no official action taken to mitigate the sufferings of the birds. Agents of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals were on the grounds; so were uniformed policemen.
Silver bullion certificates were last quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 3/4@61. There were no sales.

District Attorney John B. Merrill of Queens County will subpoena, every member of the Municipal Council's Committee on Water Supply to appear at the Queens County Court House one week from today. He says he will ask them why the ordinance providing for revenues to improve Flushing's water works has been delayed.

In taking the oath of allegiance AGUINALDO has effaced himself as a world personage. History can make nothing of a soldier of liberty who joins forces with the oppressor, and contemporary anti-imperialist estimates of his character are made worthless by his complete surrender.

NEW ORLEANS, April 2. -- Proceedings were brought in the United States Court here to-day by representatives of the Boer Governments to prevent the sailing from here of the steamship Anglo-Australian, loaded with mules consigned to British Government officials in South Africa. Judge Parlange, after reading the petition, issued an order requiring the defendants to show cause on April 6 why a preliminary injunction should not be granted.

Mr. and Mrs. Booker T. Washington were the guests of honor last evening at the annual dinner of the Social Reform Club, held in the Clarendon Hotel, at which over 200 members of the club, the majority of whom were women, were present.

It seems that the exchange of functions between those two eminent members of Tammany Hall, Col. MURPHY and Mr. SEXTON, may yet be overruled to the public good. Nobody, that we know of, has ever approved, upon public grounds, anything that the former did in the Board of Health or the latter in the Board of Police.
"I say he is a d -- d liar, and I will tell him so when I see him. His statement is absolutely and wholly untrue."

Now that the matter of the government of our public schools is about to be thrashed out at Albany, when the report of the Charter Revision Committee is under consideration, the teachers of the public schools find plenty of food for gossip. Many openly favor taking from the Mayor the power of appointment of members of the proposed board and allowing them to be elected by popular vote.

Funeral services over the remains of Roland Reed, the actor, who died on Saturday last, were held yesterday morning from his late residence, 361 West One Hundred and Twenty-second Street. The services were conducted by the Rev. Father Huntman of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, assisted by the Rev. Father McMullen.

ALBANY, April 3. -- There is a legislative feud on between Senator Brackett of Saratoga and Senator Donnelly of New York. It came about through Senator Donnelly's obstruction in the Senate to-day of a measure in which Senator Brackett manifests a deep interest. The bill in question is an act to organize and establish a police department for the village of Saratoga Springs, and defining its powers and duties.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You are to be congratulated upon the admirable and humane work done by your representative in reporting the so-called "Grand American pigeon-shooting handicap." In three or four days 20,000 pigeons are slaughtered at this meeting, and no small proportion of them are maimed and left to die in agony for hours.

President Vreeland of the Metropolitan Street Railway Company said yesterday that his company was now ready to begin work on most of the proposed changes on the various lines which it had had under consideration for some time. The campany has, however, made some changes in its plans.

The final games in the Life Insurance Bowling League tournament were rolled on Ehler's alleys last night. The Mutual Life team No. 2 wins first prize, and the Mutual Benefit team is second. The scores:

Senator M.A. Hanna of Ohio and Albert L. Johnson, brother of the Mayor-elect of Cleveland, had not come to blows at a late hour last night. The Senator was looking for Mr. Johnson yesterday to tell him that he lied if he said the former had spent $100,000 to defeat Tom L. Johnson in Cleveland.

PITTSBURG, April 3. -- Pittsburg was today the centre of a snowstorm which began early in the morning, continued with great force until afternoon, did thousands of dollars' worth of damage, and rendered practically useless for a time every electric wire in the city, suspended all street-car travel, and in the early hours isolated the city from the outside world.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 3. -- The old Cup defender Columbia was launched from the marine railway at the Hawkins yard at 10:30 o'clock last evening, and taken to an anchorage in the centre of the harbor. As soon as the storm abates preparations will be made for her to go to Bristol, R.L.

Justice Stiner of the Eighth Municipal Court, must decide whether Justice Jerome can legally use his hatchets on roulette wheels. The case was submitted to Justice Stiner yesterday, and Assistant District Attorney Howard S. Gans and Assistant Corporation Counsel Dansig requested him not to pass upon it for a few days, during which time the Corporation Counsel hopes to show that Justice Stiner has no jurisdiction.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, April 3. -- The Macedonian Congress has been convoked for April 17.

PONCE, Porto Rico, March 28. -- Another expedition of Hawaiian-bound emigrants sailed for New Orleans on the steamer Californian, Capt. Dyer, from Guanica. yesterday. There were 899 in the party, divided as follows: Adult males, 395; adult females, 252; boys, 81; girls, 82; infants, sex unclassified, 89.

LONDON, April 4. -- R. D'Oyly Carte, the theatrical manager and impresario, died yesterday morning in London. He had been an invalid a long time, and was obliged to use a bath-chair, but he nevertheless closely attended to business connected with his theatre. He suffered from weakness of the heart, which was aggravated by the shock he sustained as a result of the death of Sir Arthur Sullivan.

MANILA, April 3. -- Chief Justice Arellano, who administered to Emilio Aguinaldo the oath of allegiance to the United States Government, described to-day the conditions leading up to and attending the ceremony, which was semi-private.

A great number of mortgages upon property in this State are now overdue and payable. They might at any time be foreclosed. They are allowed to remain because both parties to the contract are satisfied with the conditions. The mortgageor is content to pay and the mortgagee is content to receive the agreed rate of interest.

"We can do nothing more than we have done and are doing to prevent the slaughter of pigeons at Inter-State Park, Queens, Long Island,' said John P. Haines, President of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, yesterday.
BOSTON, April 3. -- At the Clearing House this morning money seemed to be in large supply; loans were made at 3 and 2 1/2 per cent., mostly 2 1/2 per cent.

Anger was evinced yesterday by Superintendent Blauvelt of the Bureau of Contagious Diseases of the Health Department at the conduct of the management of the Grand Hotel, at Broadway and Thirtieth Street, in allowing a party of guests, one of whom had scarlet fever, to depart from the hotel during Tuesday night without notifying the Board of Health.

Father James M. Galliean, the well-known priest, who since the 20th of July, 1875, has been in charge of the parish of the Holy Name of Jesus, died at the rectory of that church. Ninety-sixth Street near Amsterdam Avenue, yesterday morning. Father Galligan's death was due to general debility caused by overwork.

The purchase of $2,000,000 Government bonds by the National Treasury on Tuesday was yesterday supplemented by further purchases approximating $1,000,000, which invests with especial interest the official statement issued by Secretary Gage discussing the National surplus; wherein he says:

As two members of the second Columbia 'Varsity crew did not appear at the boat houses yesterday afternoon that crew was not taken out and Coach Hanlan had but four eights to coach instead of the usual five. The absentees, Bradley and Weekes, are both suffering from colds due to the damp and cold weather of the past week.

ALBANY, April 3. -- There are now pending before the courts in the various cities of the State a dozen or more cases brought to test the Constitutionality of the provision of last year's law prohibiting the use of preservatives in milk. Among these cases is one against John S. Bieseker of New York City.

Only one of the new playing rules adopted this season by the National Baseball League will be accepted by the Eastern League of Professional Baseball Clubs in the latter's games this year. The Spring meeting of the Eastern League was held yesterday at the Victoria Hotel, and the new National rule which will be enforced is that which curtails the old custom of warming-up practice by pitchers during the progress of a game.

PARIS, April 3. -- The Franco-Italian fetes at Toulon next week are now the chief topic of interest in the French press, and the subject is much discussed in political and diplomatic circles. Spectacularly the festivities will be very brilliant, while it is generally conceded that the occasion will rank as one of the most important historic events since the Franco-Russian demonstration at the same port.
Ex-Mayor William C. Farr of Bayonne, yesterday began suit in the Hudson County Supreme Court, at Jersey City, against Dr. Alexander Dallas, for libel, claiming $50,000 damages.

A fireman who signs himself "A Real Fireman" has written a letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES, in which he takes issue with many of the statements made in the letter signed "One of the Older Firemen in the New York Fire Department," which appeared in the issue of March 29.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Among the members of the House of Representatives who have endeavored to inform themselves of the conditions and prospects in Cuba by personal visitation is Representative John Dalzell of Pennsylvania, who has Just reached Washington after a stay of two weeks on the island.

PHILADELPHIA, April 3. -- Cambria, Bethlehem Steel, and United Gas Improvement were the features of to-day's market, all making spirited advances, while the rest of the market seemed oblivious to the doings in Wall Street. There was a heavy demand for Cambria and it lifted the price from 17 1/2 to 20, while good buying sent Bethlehem from 18 to 19 1/2.

ALBANY, April 3. -- The Christian Science bill is dead. The Assembly to-day by a viva voce vote decided to recommit it to the Committee on Public Health, together with amendments offered by Dr. Henry. Judge Lynn, Mr. Harburger, and Mr. Bennett. Assemblyman Bell, who introduced the bill, made the following statement at the post mortem:

ALBANY, April 3. -- The Twenty-third Street Taxpayers' Association of the City of New York was incorporated to-day, to establish a concert of action among householders and real estate owners in New York City for the advancement of their interests and for the enforcement of State and municipal laws and ordinances relating to real estate.
In the opinion of recent arrivals from Venezuela there is little probability of any serious clash between that republic and the Government of the United States.

EAST CHANGE, N.J., April 3. -- Representatives of certain Essex County capitalists, among them Francis M. Eppley, a well-known trolley promoter, of West Orange, and former Mayor George A. Smith of Vailsburg, are busy trying to secure rights of way for a new trolley line that it is proposed to operate between Bloomfield and Irvington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read -- I wish I could say with incredulity -- the account in to-day's TIMES of the infernal, devilish cruelty perpetrated at Inter-State Park, L.I., in the name of "sport" Have men no manhood or women no shame, that they can look on at such scenes unprotesting?

The Board of Public Improvements voted yesterday to close Bradley Avenue, in the Borough of Queens. A protest against this action was made by Rudolph Horack, President of the Taxpayers' Association of that borough. President Horack said:

BALTIMORE, April 3. -- The trading today seemed to suggest that this market is as much without a top as New York appears, to be. Despite the sharp rise which Seaboards have scored in the past three days, the buying continued unabated, and prices recorded another big advance. The demand seemed to be insatiable for the Seaboards, the out-of-town absorptions exceeding the local ones.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- It was a blustery and disagreeable day at Bennings, and the track was very heavy. Notwithstanding this, there was a good-sized crowd present, and the card was an interesting one. Much to the surprise of everybody. Gold Fox won the last race by a head over Intrusive, whose riding was alleged to be faulty. Summaries:

TOKOHAMA, March 22. -- Japan is passing through a peculiar political experience. The House of Peers stubbornly refused to pass the taxation bill at a time of acknowledged crisis in internal as well as foreign affairs. The power of the Emperor was invoked, with the result that the Peers receded from their position and passed the bill by a unanimous vote without amendment or change.

Over 200 pigeon shooters, eager for slaughter, gathered at Inter-State Park, Queens, L.I., yesterday morning, in anticipation of the opening of the Grand American Handicap, the shooting event that has caused the devotees of the so-called sport to assemble in New York from all parts of the United States.
Mrs. MARIA TODD, widow of Ohio's famous war Governor, died last night at Youngstown, Ohio, aged eighty-eight years.

MANILA, Feb. 25. -- Judge Henry C. Ide of the Philippine Commission has just completed the preparation of a new code of court procedure for the islands. A criminal code is in course of preparation by Commissioner Luke E. Wright. There will be no provision for jury trials in either branch and practice as to law and equity will be similar.

Questioned yesterday about the statement that the poolrooms are opening. Police Commissioner Murphy said that he had received about seventy letters which made such an assertion and had investigated them.

ALBANY, April 3. -- The Charter Revision bill will be in Mayor Van Wyck's hands Monday. The Assembly Cities Committee held a long session to-night and perfected all its amendments to the Senate bill. The amended bill will be reported to the Assembly to-morrow and passed.

To-day being Maundy Thursday, all the Roman Catholic Churches will have elaborate services. It is the first of the three most notable days of Holy Week. In all the churches the sacrament will be exposed, and one of the acts of devotion is to make a pilgrimage to the different shrines.

The proprietors of a number of hand laundries, who have been trying to fix a uniform scale of prices for their customers, are now confronted with a demand from their employes. The ironers who work in the laundries where gas is used to heat the irons, It was announced yesterday, have formed a union, with headquarters at 62 Pitt Street, and have made a demand for an increase of wages and recognition of the union.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The report from Manila, that the President has invited Aguinaldo to visit the United States, and that he will sail from Manila April 18, cannot be verified here. But the fact that the report is not received with surprise or positively denied justifies the impression given that the suggestion is one originating in Manila, and that it may have been urged upon the War Department and the President for early acceptance.
ALBANY, April 3. -- In the Assembly today, the Sanders bill, for the protection of the public health by preventing contagious diseases from spreading through the use of old bottles was "killed."

In the outside market yesterday business continued active and at the same time unusual strength appeared in several prominent issues. The whole market was strong, and very few issues showed any recession from the previous day's prices, while among the net grains were a number that amounted to several points.

The City Club held its annual meeting last night. In accordance with a report submitted by the club's council, a bill is to be introduced into the next Legislature requiring corporations to file statements of their expenditures. The object of the bill will be to prevent the corporations from making political contributions.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 3. -- At a meeting of the City Council in Kansas City, Kan., last night some measures granting valuable franchises to the Metropolitan Street Railway Company were up for consideration. The balconies were crowded with citizens who oppose the measure, and when the Franchise Committee reported favorably upon the bills, the crowd surged to the floor of the chamber, and only the more conservative element saved the Councilmen from violence.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Gen. MacArthur to-day sent a dispatch to the War Department to the effect that the commissary frauds recently unearthed there are not as serious as reported. He says:

DENVER, April 3. -- Nearly complete returns show that R.R. Wright, Republican, was elected Mayor of this city yesterday by about 1,700 plurality over E.T. Wells, Democrat. The remainder of the Republican ticket had pluralities of 5,000. Mayor Johnson, who ran for re-election as an independent Democrat, polled 4,500 votes.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- The St. Petersburg dispatch to The Associated Press, printed this morning, has aroused interest in official circles here. For the same reason that prevented the correspondent from quoting any Russian Government official as a source of the suggestion contained in his dispatch, it is not possible to cite official authority for the comment that has been made here.

ALBANY, April 3. -- The New York and Port Chester Railroad Company was incorporated to-day, to operate an electric street surface road twenty-five miles long, from the Harlem River at Port Morris through the Borough of the Bronx to Mount Vernon, Pelham Manor, New Rochelle, Larchmont, Orienta, Mamaroneck, Milton, Rye, and Port Chester, to the Connecticut line, with a branch to Clason's Point, on the East River.

CHICAGO, April 3. -- A strong effort was made by bears on the Board of Trade today to crowd George H. Phillips, the "Corn King," to the wall. He was driven clear out of the wheat market, but added to his holdings in corn and oats.

Excitement marked the close of the second day's hearing in the Whitehead divorce case, now on trial before Justice Beach, in the Supreme Court. The plaintiff, Lydell Whitehead, had rested his case. Then Charles L. Hoffman, of counsel for the respondent, proceeded to outline to the jury what he proposed to prove in behalf of Mrs. Whitehead.

Whether little Willie McCormick of High Bridge was kidnapped or not, his father, mother, and many of the neighbors are firmly convinced that he was. Mrs. McCormick was hopeful up to yesterday morning that her little son would be found, but in the afternoon her daughters say she gave up hope, and last night she was completely prostrated.

Russia seems to have been ill-advised in her recent procedures against China with respect to Manchuria. Her course seems to indicate the chief defect in Russian diplomacy. What Russia does know is how to deal with Asiatics. According to Mr. KIPLING'S picturesque statement of the case, the Russian is "a very good fellow until he tucks in his shirt."

AIKEN, S.C., April 3. -- The tournament of the Palmetto Golf Club closed to-day. The principal event was the handicap foursomes, in which Reginald Brooks and Herbert Harriman defeated Joseph Harriman and Marion Wright, by a score of 4 up and 3 to play. In the singles, C.M. Hinkle beat H.B. Duryea, 1 up, and Major J.C. Mallory defeated Charles Weltz by 6 up and 3 to play.

One good man at the head of the city affairs could settle every problem that confronts it. Who governs the city now? The Legislature, a little, without knowing much about it; and the Mayor and the Municipal Assembly a little. I am of the opinion that we'll need President Hadley's autocrat before twenty-five years.

WASHINGTON, April 3. -- Commissioner of Internal Revenue Yerkes has issued a comprehensive set of regulations governing special taxes of brokers, dealers, traders, and taxes on transactions set out in Paragraphs 2 and 3 of Schedule A of the new Revenue Reduction act of March 2, 1901. These regulations are addressed to Collectors of Internal Revenue for whose guidance they are intended.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 3. -- This town was carried for no license yesterday, and a money system of working the highways was adopted. The Town Board was authorized to have charge of the town dock.

BANGOR, April 3. -- One of the notable laws passed by the Legislature of Maine at the session just closed is one fixing a penalty for the shooting of human beings by mistake for wild game. The law says:

LONDON, April 3. -- At the first day's racing to-day of the Northampton and Pytchley Hunt Spring meeting, A. McIntyre, an American jockey, who rode A. Bailey's three-year-old chestnut filly Ravensden, in the Mile Selling Plate, was disqualified for boring. The race was awarded to the aged chestnut gelding King of Pearls, on which Lester Reiff, another American jockey, had the mount.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Rudolf Koenig, writing under the heading, "Hearts That Lie Over the Sea," to your paper, makes several statements which I, as an American, would like to emphatically resent and deny.
CHICAGO, April 3. -- New York exchange ruled at 25 cents discount to-day. Money was quoted at 4@4 1/2 per cent. for call and time loans.
WASHINGTON, April 3. -- A report from the Kentucky, now in Chinese waters, mentions incidentally that in target practice a thirteen-inch shell exploded at the muzzle of the gun.

NEWARK, N.J., April 4 -- Vice Chancellor Pitney to-day issued an order to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for the San Domingo Improvement Company and the San Domingo Finance Company, on an application made by the German-American Investment Company, of which William P. Dewey, nephew of Admiral Dewey, is Treasurer and counsel, with offices at 290 Broadway, New York.

The flower and quintessence of absurdity in the apotheosis of Mrs. NATION has been reached in the City of Concord, Neb., where she has been made the dictator of the municipal policy. What sort of government will result from this arrangement, and to what extent the newly elected city officers have invited indictment for pledging themselves to respect an authority outside of and superior to the law, is at best a matter of conjecture.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am delighted with the energetic protests from your readers against that wanton, wholesale slaughter of innocent birds. I hope that you will receive more letters on this subject, to devote perhaps some extra space in next Sunday's edition to the advancement of kind feeling toward helpless and innocent creatures.

American citizens have reason to be proud of the attitude their Government has preserved since the beginning of the present troubles in China. So far as we have been able to observe, they all are so. We have remarked no discordant note in the chorus of praise and congratulation, whether from expansionists or anti-expansionists.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every November, from all, points of the compass, a Jot of "sports" gather around a tract of land on Long Island to hunt deer. The consequent slaughtering they call "hunting."

-- Assemblyman J.H.
