The tendency now is to easier money. The press, commenting on these conditions, sees in them indications of dull business.

The announcement made last week that the Municipal Assembly had approved the issue of bonds in the sum of $5,300,000 for public improvements, of which $3,500,000 was appropriated for school purposes, was by no means so satisfactory to those who are interested in educational matters as might be supposed.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Daniel F. Doherty, an English ticket-of-leave man, who is well known in gambling resorts of New York and London, has caused the arrest here of his former wife, Mary Doherty, whom she charges with obtaining money from him under false pretenses.

It is discovered that there is is the charter as passed by the Legislature a provision authorizing the payment of money to private schools. Nothing like this was in the old charter or in any which preceded it. The clause was not inserted by the Charter Revising Commission.

Quietness is the last word in dress among society women, the society women who know how to dress well, and the gloves they are wearing this Spring are suede. They wear them for all purposes, morning gloves as well as for dress occasions. There is nothing new in these styles; the only thing to be noticed about the gloves is the fineness of the quality of the kid and the excellent fit.

Relay racing by teams of several men, each of whom runs a portion of the total set distance and then gives place to the next man, who takes up the race afresh, has become a popular and interesting feature of athletic metings within the past year or two, and is undoubtedly largely responsible for the increasing interest in track athletics.

CHICAGO, April 7 -- Ten thousand persons participated to-day in the dedication of the Second Church of Christ, Scientist, at Wrightwood and Pine Grove Avenues. So great was the assemblage that a quadruple service was held. After the first service the side doors were opened, and the audience passed out, while another group of worshippers entered through the front doors and participated in a repetition of the service.

WASHINGTON, April 7 -- The police of Alexandria have been outwitted by a pair of young lovers determined to marry. A telegram from Colonial Beach last Wednesday asked the police of Alexandria and Washington to look out for Miss Dorcas Butler,' a sixteen-year-old girl from Oak Grove, who had eloped with Joseph Jackson.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 7 -- The races to-day at Panama Park drew only a light attendance. Walthour's fine riding in the ten-mile handicap and in his ten miles effort against time were the events of the day. In the former he had Cadwell, Vetter, and Brown to race against, but he caught his men and passed them at the tape by a magnificent spurt.

Because Andrew Maneely, a wealthy resident of Brooklyn, is firm in his purpose to marry a young woman with whom he has fallen in love, his grown-up children are sadly at odds with him and an interesting mix-up of love and law is promised. Mr. Maneely lives at 324 Clermont Avenue, is the proprietor of a kindling wood yard at Gouverneur and Front Streets, Manhattan, and is also interested in a large coal business.

Now that Ramapo is out of the way, the Merchants' Association officers are endeavoring to devise some means whereby the city's water supply may be made ample in the near future. They are according to a statement given out yesterday, determined that the results of the work done by the Water Supply Committee of the association "shall not be lost or shelved by the city authorities."

All negotiations by the chiefs of the various railroad organizations for a settlement of the differences between the employes of the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the company have been declared off as far as the men are concerned. A strike over the entire system may take place any time within the next forty-eight hours unless General Manager Warren, who virtually refused a conference with the chiefs, opens negotiations himself.

GAGAYAN, Mindanao, P.I., April 7 -- In response to interrogatories from Secretary of War Root, the Philippine Commission has prepared recommendations as to the form of general civil government to be established for the Philippines July 1 and to continue until Congress shall have organized a permanent government for the archipeigo.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

The two young sons of Patrick Edward O'Brien of 530 West Fifty-third Street, who was the Citizens' Union candidate for Alderman from the Seventeenth Assembly District the year Seth Low ran for Mayor, were arrested on last Friday afternoon, at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street, on a charge of begging.
Easter inside the churches was more like itsalf than it was out of doors. The crowds, the gorgeous floral decorations, the special musical programmes, had all their usual charm.

PATERSON, N.J., April 7 -- There is promise of a contest over the distribution of the estate of the late Nathaniel Townsend, a former Mayor of Paterson and former Sheriff of Passaic County. An action brought by Miss Jane Townsend, the maiden daughter, who has filed an exception against the final account of the estate, appears to foreshadow a bitter feud.

The Cincinnati Citizens' Saengerfest Fund Committee is jubilant over the payment of all the obligations incurred, for the Jubilee Saengerfest, the last payment of $61,900 having been made a few days ago.

Judge ASPINALL of Brooklyn did a wise thing the other day in discouraging the disposition of the Kings County Grand Jury to amuse itself by formulating presentments against two Aldermen and a Councilman who have "held up" the issue of bonds for improvements necessary in connection with the waiter system of Brooklyn. Such expressions of opinion on the part of a Grand Jury are like throwing snowballs at a bomb-proof.

The excommunication of TOLSTOI was a matter of Church discipline, of which persona outside the Church, and certainly those outside the Russian Empire, are in no position to judge. But his expulsion from the Russias is a measure of national policy upon which the people of every civilized country have the right to an opinion.

As many of the Harlem River rowing clubs begin their practice upon the water on the first Sunday in April, yesterday, in spite of the cold wind and rough water, was the busiest day the local oarsmen have had this season. On less than eight eights were seen besides several fours and a host of smaller boats.

At the annual stockholders' meeting of the old and widely known concern of WILLIAM JESSOP SONS, Limited, of Sheffield, held a few days ago, the Chairman, Mr. WILLIAM JESSOP, made an announcement which is of interest on both sides of the ocean. It was that the company had decided to build an American plant and begin manufacturing in this country what their trade here called for.

Charles F. Fearing, who is to be buried at Woodlawn to-day, was long a prominent and popular figure in social and club life, and many good stories are told of him by his friends of the Union Club, which he joined in 1886, and to which his father, his brother, his uncles, and other members of his family also belonged.

HAVANA, April 3 -- Since the adoption of the completed draft of the Cuban Constitution at the session of the convention held on Feb. 21 the minds of the delegates have wandered irresolute between opposite opinons. The nationalist sentiment inspires them to desire with ardor the large freedom of unconditioned sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- One of the most interesting features in connection with the establishment of a general Civil Government in the Philippines is the question as to who still be in supreme authority under the President. The law says that "all military, civil, and judicial powers necessary to govern the Philippine Islands shall be vested in such person and persons as the President shall direct."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I observe that there have been discovered in the revised charter now in the hands of Mayor Van Wyck several "surreptitiously inserted amendments," the responsibility for which nobody seems to know anything about. Like Topsy, they were not born -- they were not in the original bill -- but simply grew.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Hearings on the question of combinations of capital were begun by the Industrial Commission to-day, and probably will be concluded this week. Prof. J.W. Jenks of Cornell University is conducting the examination of the witnesses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: My attention has been caled to a short editorial in THE TIMES of last Thursday, in which you speak of Senator Stranahan's "Mortgage Tax Bill" in a way which I believe the facts do not justify.

Business in the outside market yesterday was fairly active, but prices showed much irregularity. The course of the Stock Exchange market naturally exercised an unfavorable influence and resulted in a number of net declines from last week's figures. Few of the day's changes were due to other than general conditions, and where special influences were at work net gains were generally recorded.
ALBANY, April 8. -- Gov. Odell has signed the following bills:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I heartily agree with a "Lady Patron" and others in their condemnation of profanity in public and discourtesy in street cars. Permit me, however, to say the animal man is, no more deserving of censure than those of the gentler sex who occupy space enough for two and refuse to move an inch to allow another person to occupy a seat.

Martin Engel, the east side Tammany politician, after nearly four years spent as a member of the Municipal Council, made his first public speech yesterday. It lasted less than two minutes and was marked by criticism of a Tammany Alderman who voted against the wishes of Councilman Engel.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 8 -- University of Virginia's baseball team met its first defeat of the season here this afternoon, losing to Yale by a score of 9 to 6. The game was well played considering the windy, disagreeable weather, and nearly 1,000 people witnessed the contest. Garvan was in the box for the visitors until the sixth inning, when he was replaced by Patton, who allowed the Southerners only one hit.

The revised charted for the City of New York, which has been passed by the Legislature at Albany and is now in the hands of the Mayor, continues to furnish surprises that puzzle and startle the members of the Revised Charter Commission. Some of these new provisions received a full share of condemnation yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES errs, as it seems to me, in refusing to take Mr. Tom L. Johnson more seriously. His battle in Cleveland was a notable one, fought upon the distinct understanding that his success there, would mean his appearance in the arena of National politics.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held, to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 8 -- The phenomenal movement of homeseekers to the Northwestern States which has been steadily increasing since Feb. 12, when the first low rates of the season were put in effect, astonishes railroad officials and emigration agents. Between Feb. 12 and April 1 25,000 homeseekers have gone to new homes through the St. Paul gateway.

The ministers of the New York Presbytery who are opposed to the revision of the church creed gained another victory yesterday on the occasion of the balloting for Commissioners to the General Assembly, which meets in Philadelphia next month. The total number of commissioners from the Presbytery is fourteen, seven pastors and seven elders, and it is said that nine of the fourteen are conservatives.

The jury in the Whitehead divorce case, which has been on trial for a week in the Supreme Court, took the case at 4:45 yesterday afternoon and will give a sealed verdict to Justice Beach when court opens this morning.

There are some novel features in the dispute of the New Jersey Central with a portion of its employes which are extremely interesting, and which take it quite out of the usual category of labor differences.

WASHINGTON, April 8. -- The room which Attorney General Knox is to occupy in the Department of Justice Building has been renovated. A number of workmen were busy to-day removing the pictures which are to be exhibited at Buffalo. The department will make as elaborate an exhibit the Government Building as the limitation's of its work will allow.
ALBANY, April 8. -- The Assembly tonight passed the following bills.

There is nothing mean about the professional politician. He is in the business for profit, and he intends to get as much of it as is consistent with a permanent supply. But he knows that he cannot have it all, and he understands that he must work for the advantage of the class and not for his personal pocket exclusively.
Two runaways, one of them among the most exciting that have taken place on the Speedway this Spring, occurred within twenty minutes of each other yesterday afternoon.

Lovers of polo in the vicinity of New York and Brooklyn may not have an opportunity to see the big polo championships played on the parade field in Prospect Park this season, as has been the custom for several years in the past. The Bostonians are making a determined effort to secure that honor for their own city, and they have unanimously decided upon the Brookline Country Club.

"A good deal of nonsense is being printed about the charter provision which grants so-called subsidies to newspapers in the Boroughs of Queens, Richmond, and the Bronx," said Arthur G. Bedell, one of the publishers of The Bronx Borough Record, to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday.

BOSTON, Mass., April 8. -- The flood scare all over New England, due to rising waters under the influence of nearly five days of rain, has flattened out, for late to-night the reports indicated that a change for the better would come by daylight. The losses will be heavy, no doubt, but nothing to be compared with some of the freshets of recent Springs.

ALBANY, April 8. -- A large number of builders in New York City have requested Gov. Odell to give a hearing upon the Tenement House bill which passed the Legislature last week. The Governor has acceded to the reauest and set the hearing for Wednesday. It is said that from 100 to 15O boss builders will journey to Albany to make their protest against the bill.

Inquiry made yesterday failed to establish that poolrooms and gambling houses are open in the sense that others than professionals can obtain admission to the latter, and that bets are made on horse racing with the accompaniment of blackboards and shouters of odds and cashiers departments.

NICE, April 8. -- President Loubet's visit to the Mediterranean coast opened under excellent auspices. The weather during the past few days was unusually chilly, but it brightened to-day, and sunshine welcomed the President's arrival in the morning.

The London Times has an intelligent and evidently experienced correspondent at Shanghai who has been giving the readers of that journal some very interesting correspondence about the Far East. The sixth of his letters has appeared in the batch of London Timeses brought by the last mail.

Though responses from foreign Governments and the rifle shooting organizations of the different countries that have been invited to take part in the proposed great international rifle shooting tournament that the National Rifle Association of America has planned for next September have been most gratifying and give promise of success for the big scheme the very first positive acceptance of the general invitation to Old-World marksmen has come from Ireland.

The little phrase of seventeen words in the revised charter passed by the Legislature giving the Board of Education of thin city the power to allow equal distribution of the school fund to public schools and "any other private school" in its discretion continues to occupy public attention. This phrase was inserted by Senator Stranahan of the Cities Committee, as he himself says, at the last minute.

The strike at William K. Vanderbilt's Summer home, Idle Hour, Oakdale, L.I., was declared off yesterday, and all the strikers, 175 in number, returned to work. The strike was settled through the intervention of Mr. Vanderbilt himself, who is in a hurry to have the building finished. A strike in any one of the trades would delay work on the entire building.

CHICAGO, April 8. -- Money for call and time loans ruled at 4@5 per cent. The flurry in New York did not affect rates here. New York exchange was quoted at 50 cents' discount before and 35 cents' discount after call.

ALBANY, April 8. -- A protest against the proposed expenditure of $26,000.000 for canai improvement work was submitted tonight to the Senate and Assembly. It was signed by Elliot B. Norris. Master of the New York State Grange. Patrons of Husbandry: James Ward President of the New York State Farmers' Congress, and John I. Platt. Secretary of the New York State Tax and Transportation Reform Association.
WASHINGTON, April 8. -- To-day's statement of the Treasury balances in the general fund, exclusive of the $150,000,000 gold reserve in the Division of Redemption, shows:

A circular was issued by Emerson McMillin Co. yesterday to the stockholders of the Western Gas Company of Milwaukee, the Grand Rapids Gas Light Company of Michigan, the Madison Gas Light Company of Wisconsin, and the St. Joseph Gas Company of Missouri, inviting them to consolidate their interests by exchanging their shares for the common and preferred stock of a new company, which may be known as the American Light and Traction Company.

The inadequacy of Brooklyn's water supply was the subject discussed at a public hearing held yesterday before the Committee on Water Supply of the Board of Aldermen. A resolution which pased the Board of Estimate on May 1, 1900, appropriating $500,000 for repairs to the Millburn reservoir on Long Island, and which has since been the cause of much trouble, was also talked about.

LONDON, April 9 -- The Turkish Freemasons have sent to King Edward a curious appeal on behalf of the unfortunate Murad, elder brother of Abdul Hamid, who reigned as Sultan of Turkey for three months, and was then deposed on the ground of insanity.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The municipal ownership humbug has apparently been worked successfully in electing a Mayor of Cleveland, Ohio, whose interest in the dear people did not develop and manifest itself until he had succeeded in squeezing a few millions out of the pockets of these same dear people, concerning whose welfare he is now so solicitous.

-- Taking seriously our little joke, made when we thought Assemblyman SEYMOUR had introduced a bill making it the "rule of the road" to turn to the left instead of the right, The Rider and Driver solemnly declares that fear of Anglophopic denunciation should not be allowed to interfere with the institution of a much-needed reform in our highway customs.

Mme, Bernhardt and M. Coquelin reappeared in this city last night, acting in M. Edmond Rostand's poetic play. "L'Aiglon," at the Metropolitan Opera House. It is perhaps not so difficult as it might seem at the first glance to account for Mr. Grau's selection of the huge temple of music in upper Broadway for the farewell appearances of the two French artists.
ALBANY, April 8 -- A member of the Legislature of prominent standing, in discussing the charter to-night, made the following interesting statement:

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- The commission appointed by the President under the act of Congress approved March 2, 1901, to carry into effect the stipulations of Article 7 of the treaty between the United States and Spain at the conclusion of the late war, met at the Department of Justice Building to-day.

Francis K. Pendleton has sold through S. Osgood Pell Co. the plot at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, 100.8 by 100. Nothing could be learned yesterday regarding the identity of the buyer beyond a statement by Mr. Pell that the property has been bought as a residence site by "one of the steel men."

There was war in the Holland Society last night. The members, wearing the orange usual upon the nights of their annual meetings, fiercely characterized each other as calumniators, defamers of a fellow-member, and in one case what might have been taken for the lie circumstantial was passed.

PHILADELPHIA, April 8.-Not having participated in the recent extraordinary boom in Wall Street, the local stocks ignored the demoralizing influences in New York. Nearly everything on the list opened with an advance, but later in the day prices yielded. Notable strength, however, was shown in Cambria Steel, Philadelphia. Company, and Lehigh Navigation.

The differences among the interests involved in the American Smelting and Refining Company have been settled. These differences have existed since the company proposed to take in the Guggenheim smelting properties, and to act as its own selling agent after the merger. They resulted in the retirement of H.H. Rogers and Leonard Lewisohn of the United Metals Selling Company from the Directorate of the American Smelting Company.

The disclosure of the identity of the mysterious couple married Saturday by Supreme Court Justice Edward W. Hatch in the Marble Court House of the Appellate Division has caused great surprise in Christian Science circles and was the chief topic of gossip at their meetings Sunday and yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- Georgetown succumbed to Underhill's masterly pitching and Princeton's superior batting in a close and exciting game at Georgetown today. Princeton bunched three hits in the fourth and firth innings and four in the eighth, batting out a well-earned victory. The score:

ALBANY, April 8. -- A message was received from the Assembly in the Senate stating that it non-concurred in the Appropriation bill and asking for a conference. The Senators named were Higgins, Brown, and Martin.

PEKING, April 8 -- Rumors which have been current during the past few days of the outbreak of a rebellion, headed by Gen. Tung-Fu-Siang, (the former commander of the Northern Army,) in the Provinces of Mongolia and Shen-Si, have been absolutely authenticated. Li-Hung-Chang and Prince Ching have received information on the subject, which proves that the Court is seriously alarmed.

BOSTON, April 8. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 per cent. One bank President thought the supply was larger than at any previous time for a week. New York funds were in better demand, with sales at 10c discount for cash.

Easter Monday was hardly ideal for the first day of the Spring season. It was cold, gray, raw, and cloudy. There was much activity socially, however, and the gayety was quite in contrast to the quiet which had prevailed during the previous fortnight. There were a great many weddings, although but few of them were elaborate church ceremonials, and to each of them was invited but a limited number of guests.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., April 8 -- By an ingenious scheme hatched in the brain of I.K. Baxter, the champion amateur high jumper of the world, track prospects at the University of Pennsylvania were considerably brightened to-day. He announced that he would be eligible for the intercollegiates this year.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 8 -- The last of the rivets on the topside plates of the cup defender Constitution were headed up to-day in the Herreshoff shops. This practically concludes the work of riveting on the new racer. A large force of workmen are now engaged all over the null in smoothing up the rivet heads with files and other implements making fair progress.

Under the advice of one set of officials who were incompetent and with the help of another set who were corrupt the people of New York a few years ago threw nine millions of their money into the canals. Not one cent of that great sum ever has or ever will come back to the people in the form of immediate benefit or remote advantage.

LONDON, April 9. -- Some time after the arrival of C. Morland Agnew at Liverpool a dispatch was received from him, in which he asked his son to meet him at Euston with two clerks from the office and a detective.

CHICAGO, April 8 -- Pessimistic students of the rate situation are indulging in gloomy predictions as to what the immediate future has in store for the railroads. They fear widespread trouble, in which the entire territory from the Atlantic to the Pacific is likely to be involved.

LONDON, April 8. -- The death of George Murray Smith, the well-known English publisher, was announced here to-day. He was a member of the firm of Smith, Elder Co, and published some of the first editions of the works of William Makepeace Thackeray.

WASHINGTON, April 8 -- To-day's racing at the Bennings track was without special feature. The patronage continues very good, but the weather is still unsettled, interfering somewhat with the sport. The favorites in the first four races won, and long shots in the remaining two. The Easter Monday stepelechase had but three starters, Queenship, the favorite, winning, with Prince Midas second.

The fifty-third session of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church began at the Hansan Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Hanson Place and St. Felix Street, Brooklyn, yesterday, with the examination of candidates for admission to the conference. There were about a dozen applicants, but it was said by members of the Examining Committee that few would be accepted as the conference is already very much overcrowded.

Isaac H. Clothier, according to a report current yesterday, has sold the plot of three lots on the north side of Eighty-eighth Street, 206.1 feet east of Fifth Avenue. Mr. Clothier's attorney in this city, when asked whether such a deal had been effected, replied that he could not say anything in regard to it.

WILLEMSTAD, Island of Curacao, April 9. -- Francis B. Loomis, the United States Minister to Venezuela, sailed from La Guayra yesterday on the United States auxiliary cruiser Scorpion. When Mr. Loomis left Caracas, the capital, the railroad station was crowded with people representing the best classes of the inhabitants, showing the esteem in which Mr. Loomis was held.

After three days' work by the men under Capt. Titus of the Detective Bureau, a young man was arrested yesterday who confessed that he was the writer of the letter received by George H. Penniman of 1,071 Fifth Avenue, in which it was threatened that Mr. Penniman's house would be blown up by dynamite unless he left $500 in a stipulated spot in Central Park.

BOSTON, April 9 -- The Traveler to-day says: "An eight-point advance in United States Rubber preferred stock and three points in the common to-day was attributed to a prospective change in the management of the company, whereby the Converse faction will be dominant, and Charles R. Flint will retire."

ALBANY, April 9. -- The Weekes Common Law Marriage bill passed the Senate to-day and now goes to the Governor. The passage of the bill by the Senate was the culmination of a two years' hard fight in the Legislature.
The contest over the will of Mrs. Eliza Jane Evans, who, after making a number of charitable bequests, left nearly $80,000 to a negro Pullman car porter, is on trial before Surrogate Fitzgerald.

There is no denying that the Historical Society has not, in the past, filled the highest measure of its usefulness. Not only has its membership not by any means included all who, by virtue of their studies and interests, ought to belong to it. But also its collections, in various kinds, are by no means so well known and so generally used as their great value and importance deserve.

The stockholders' annual meeting of the Maurice Grau Opera Company was held yesterday afternoon in the offices of the company at the Metropolitan Opera House. Maurice Grau presided, and he informed the stockholders that owing to the extremely busy time he had been having for the past fortnight in connection with the affairs of the opera company and the Bernhardt-Coquelin engagement, he was prevented from preparing a resume of the season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In Saturday's issue, under "Topics of the Times," there is a paragraph in which, upon a not very representative or wellchosen remark of Dr. Smith, you make certain generalizations which are neither logical nor happy.

BOSTON, April 9. -- The first match in the National court tennis championships was played on the Boston Athletic Association court to-day. The contestants were P.S. Sears of the Boston Athletic Association and O.S. Campbell of the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. Sears was the winner, the scores being 6-2, 6-3, 3-6, and 6-0.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE NEW YORK TIMES has always been so active in furthering worthy efforts and in assisting those seeking justice that I venture to solicit its support in the efforts now being made by the druggist of Greater New York to secure uniformity throughout the State in the pharmacy laws, and in amending some defects in existing acts.

SCHWERIN, April 9. -- The Grand Duke of Mecklenburg-Schwerin, Friedrich Franz IV., who attained his majority to-day, made his State entry into this city this morning. He was received at the railroad station by Duke Johann Albrecht, his uncle, who has been Regent of the Grand Duchy and the Grand Duke's guardian during his minority, and by a number of princely guests.

The Associated Merchants' Company is the name of a corporation, organized under a special act of the Connecticut Legislature, which has taken over the dry goods business of the H.B. Claflin Company, the Adams Dry Goods Company, and the business of James McCreery Co. of this city.

ALBANY, April 9 -- Both the Senate and Assembly, the former in open session and the latter in committee, took some action on the Twenty-six-Million-Dollar Canal Improvement bill. In the Senate the bill was unanimously advanced to third reading and amended so as to include the Oneida feeder and provide for the imposition of an annual tax for seventeen years to pay for the work to be done.

A pretty effect in foulard gowns is given in an attractive silk with a brown figure made up with black lace trimmings. The result is excellent. There is a bit of blue at the neck to give a light touch to the gown.
WASHINGTON April 9. -- The mystery of the alleged refusal of Minister de Giers to receive communications from the Chinese Commissioners at Peking is now cleared up.

The Republican leaders, we should say, must understand by this time that the changes made by the Legislature in the report of the Charter Commission are exceedingly unpopular in this city. This is especially true of the changes that were made openly for party motives. It is to be assumed that the leaders desire the defeat of Tammany at the election next Fall.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 9. -- Princeton won the first of her two games scheduled with Virginia this afternoon by a score of 19 to 10. The heavy batting by both teams was the leading feature of the game, each side making twelve hits. Princeton bunched her hits in three innings, scoring heavily.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Messrs. Fitzgerald, Lynn, Sullivan, and Seymour of New York in the Assembly to-day opposed the passage of the Vacheron bill to set aside the public markets of New York City exclusively for the use of farmers and market gardeners. Mr. Sullivan moved, to recommit the bill to the Cities Committee for a hearing.

There was a strange scene in the courtroom of Magistrate Marsh, at Stapleton, S.I., yesterday afternoon. It was caused by the announcement of the death of Mrs. Margaret Liverpool. The woman was popular among the colored residents of Port Richmond, and was the "Mother" of a colored Pythian Lodge, and the courtroom was filled with members of the lodge and her friends and fellow-women members of the auxiliary of the lodge.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 9 -- The one hundred and second session of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church was begun in this city to-day, and will continue until Monday next. This session of the Conference will be presided over by Bishop Daniel A. Goodsell, D.D., LL. D., who will be the guest of Commissioner of Public Works Samuel Cooper.

Now lying on the bottom of East River is the first tangible connection between Brooklyn and Manhattan of the many that must pass from borough to borough before there is the sound of traffic on the new East River Bridge. Three strands of one of the four cables upon which the temporary structure will be suspended were dropped into the water yesterday, unwinding from reels on a float towed across.

Corroboration of Valet Jones's sworn story of how he murdered Millionaire William M. Rice at Lawyer Patrick's instigation was adduced by Assistant District Attorney Osborne from many witnesses yesterday. Miss Lilian Sheerin and Miss Lillie Mellett, telephone operators, testified to the calling of Patrick on the phone by Jones on the day of the old millionaire's death.

That Monday's reaction exerted healthful influence was amply shown in yesterday's security market. Following the weakness then displayed, and disposing of the apprehension then much proclaimed, there was in yesterday's market new life, new buoyancy, a broadening out beyond recent limits.

The Mayor, Assistant Corporation Counsel Ladd, and their corps of assistants continued their work yesterday of looking for changes that had been made in the charter by the Legislature. Alfred M. Downs, the Mayor's secretary, said that the work was a very laborious one, and that it would take every minute that the law allowed.

LONDON, April 10 -- London gave an enthusiastic welcome to "The Fortune Teller," which was produced last evening at the Shaftesbury Theatre by the Alice Neilsen Opera Company. Unless all signs fail, the piece is in for a run at least as long as that of "The Belle of New York."

The Rev. Dr. Huntington, rector of Grace Church, admitted last evening that the Easter collection had reached $107,000 up to date. The amount was believed to be about $100,000 when the silver plates were handed in after the morning service. Those who wrote promises on slips of paper more than kept them, however, and the original amount has been swelled.

Official action in regard to Columbia's proposed new athletic association was taken yesterday when announcement unexpectedly was made that the plan for the new organization had been abandoned and that the association therefore was disbanded. Present conditions are too unsettled to foretell the ultimate effect of the move.
TOLEDO, Ohio, April 9. -- An order of sale of the Detroit and Lima Northern Railway was made to-day. The sale will be held at Lima, May 23, at 2 o'clock in the afternoon.

By the will of Mrs. Edna J. McPherson, widow of United States Senator John R. McPherson of New Jersey, which was filed for probate in Jersey City yesterday, Yale University will, at the expiration of a trust created by the testatrix, come into at least $750,000, and possibly more.
Advance of about 25 per cent. by the American Can Company in the price of tin cans.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The State Department is somewhat skeptical about Gen. Tung-Fu-Siang having actually started a rebellion. That there has been a clash of some kind between Tung's troops and others is regarded as possible, but that Tung has actually unfurled the standard of revolt is strongly doubted.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 9. -- A meeting of stockholders held here at noon to-day in the Carlisle Building consummated a big railroad deal which gives Cincinnati a new trunk line and makes the Norfolk and Western Railroad an active competitor of the Northern trunk lines.

Thomas Lawson's yacht Independence will be in the trial races that will determine the selection of a defender of the America's Cup against Sir Thomas Lipton's challenger, Shamrock II. This statement was made yesterday by a yachtsman who is a recognized authority and who is thoroughly in touch with everything connected with the building and the proposed racing of the yachts now nearing completion for the international event.

BALTIMORE, April 9 -- The stock market to-day during the early hours of trading disclosed the continuing influence of yesterday's weakness in Wall Street. Small traders who had entered the market or slim margins had placed peremptory orders with the brokers to sell. The pressure curried the price of Seaboards somewhat below Monday's closing.
A call for a mass meeting of anti-Tammany Democrats will be issued for a gathering in Carnegie Hall on the evening of April 18 to start the Mayoralty campaign.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The heroic bronze equestrian statue of Major Gen. John A. Logan, which rests on an imposing bronze pedestal in Iowa Circle, was unveiled to-day, and given to the Nation in the presence of the President, the Cabinet, the widow, and the relatives of the gallant soldier, many of his comrades in arms, and a vast multitude of people.

NICE, April 9. -- It was announced here this morning that the Russian squadron was about to arrive at Villefranche, and the news aroused great enthusiasm. Big crowds went to welcome the Russians. It appears that Admiral Birileff yesterday disembarked at Barcelona, and was summoned to the Russian Legation at Madrid, where a dispatch from the Czar was communicated to him, instructing him to return to the Riviera and salute President Loubet.

ALBANY, April 9. -- Senator Raines to-day introduced a bill to tax all interest-bearing evidences of indebtedness and dividend-bearing securities one-fifth of 1 per cent. of the principal or par value, to be levied annually for State purposes. The tax is to be levied in the form of a stamp. Mr. Raines gives the following description of his bill:
We think that the Governor has done well in signing the bill for the improvement of Atlantic Avenue, in the Borough of Brooklyn.

The Easter season progresses and there are promises of small entertainments of various kinds. The weddings, however, seem to be the principal social events. The young people who have come from school and college have the monopoly, as at Christmas time, and many of the dances and cotillions are given for them.

The police took Myrtle May Flannigan, a mill girl, out of her room on the top floor of 821 Tenth Avenue, about 11:30 o'clock on Monday night, unconscious from the effects of carbolic acid which she had swallowed. She died at the Roosevelt Hospital early yesterday morning.

The first great disappointment of the racing season of 1901 has come in the announcement that William C. Whitney's great colt Bailyhoo Bey, in all probability, is a "roarer." If he races at all, it is said, he will have to take a place in a lower class than he was intended for and run as a sprinter instead of going into the first rank and contending for the classic stakes for the three-year-old division.

A general recovery from the declines of the previous day occurred yesterday in the market for outside securities. The advances in most cases were mot large, but many fractional gains were recorded, and the general character of the market was one of greater strength. Only a few issues were actively traded in, and the total transactions for the day were probably smaller than those of any day for some time past.

The All Brooklyn bowlers won the first two of their three games with the Erie (Penn.) team in the Inter-State League series on Cordes Holden's alleys, Brooklyn, last night, scoring 1,032 in the second game, but lost the third game to the visitors by 14 pins. To-night the Erie team will meet the All New York bowlers on Starr's alleys.

The meeting last night of the Kings County Republican General Committee, in the Johnston Building, on Nevins Street, Brooklyn, at which the matter of the Congressional reapportionment was presented for consideration, was a heated and lively session.

The Administration, while expressing great confidence in Gen. WOOD, is beginning to realise that he has lost the confidence of a very considerable portion of the Cuban public and has failed to realize the trend of public sentiment.

PARIS, April 10. -- The unexpected return of the Russian squadron dwarfed interest in all other events in the programme at Nice yesterday. The news was on the lips of every one in Paris, and joy was expressed by both the public and the press.

Football with the players on horseback was played last night at the equestrian entertainment at Dickel's Riding Academy, when two teams, one representing the academy and the other the American Horse Exchange, played two fifteen-minute halves. Though no one was hurt, all the men were very much bruised and shaken up at the conclusion of the contest, which was won by Dickel's Academy by a score of 3 goals to 1.

-- At first thought, one is disposed to smile at the news that the people of Elkton, Md., have just held a municipal election in which the only question at issue was whether there should, or should not, be hog pens within the city limits. On this issue the voters were divided, on it the opposing candidates took their stands.

WASHINGTON, April 9. -- The maiden hurdle race over six jumps was the most interesting event at the Bennings track to-day. Ten horses competed, and all finished except Berto, who fell, Charawind, the favorite, took first money by a neck, Roxbury second, twenty lengths ahead of Conover, third. Summaries:

Miles M. O'Brien, President of the Board of Edupatlon, was in the West Side Police Court yesterday morning to see that justice was done his son, Thomas, eighteen years old, who had been arrested with three other boys the previous evening on a charge of disorderly conduct.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9 -- Some improvement was seen in the Philadelphia market, but trading fell off considerably. What animation there was centred in Philadelphia Electric. Cambria Steel, and the Readings Electric Company of America began to show life, but did not get above 8 1/2.

Francis Stevens Conover, who died yesterday at his home, on Bayard Lane, Princeton, N.J., was the son of Commodore Thomas Anderson Conover. He was born in New York Nov. 24, 1822, but spent his boyhood at Castle Point, Hoboken, at the home of his grandfather, John Stevens.

Congressman FLEMING of Georgia, who was elected in a thorough-going freesilver district, is ready to desert the Bryan issue of 16 to 1. He would like to see the gold and silver wings of the Democratic Party come together "to calmly analyze the situation and ascertain whether there now exists between them any such difference of principle on living issues as would justify them in remaining any longer apart."

TOULON, April 10. -- Enormous crowds on the quays to-day watched the arrival of the St. Louis, with President Loubet, escorted by a squadron of warships. The land batteries and the Italian and Spanish ships joined in the general salute as the St. Louis entered the port, passing the Italian ships, whose sides were manned by their cheering crews while the bands played the "Marseillaise."

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

DULUTH, Minn., April 10. -- Edwin Ball, for several years General Manager of the Minnesota Iron Company, has been selected as manager for all the iron mines of the Tennessee Iron and Coal Company. Mr. Ball, who has the reputation of being one of the most practical men in the country, will leave for Birmingham, Ala., his new headquarters, May 1.

BOSTON, Mass., April 10. -- The Court Tennis matches to-day for the championship of the Boston Athletic Association were between Austin Potter and Philip Stockton, in which the latter won, and J. Crane, Jr., beat P.S. Sears. The deciding match will be played on Friday by Crane and Stockton.

Twenty-five preparatory school lads, all enthusiasts on golf and hopeful of positions on college teams in the near future, assembled yesterday on the Oakland Club links, near Bayside, L.I., to fight for interscholastic championship golf honors. The high wind and chilly air handicapped the play severely, and the scores developed no surprises in low figures.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., April 10. -- County Clerk Crumb, when seen at his home here to-night, said:

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Eastern men, it is said, are carrying on negotiations with the owners of Chicago's great department stores looking toward forming a syndicate placing these stores under one management. For more than a year J. Pierpont Morgan and the men associated with him are said to have been casting longing eyes toward the Chicago field.
CHICAGO, April 10. -- Money for call and time loans to-day was in the market at 4@5 per cent. New York exchange was quoted at 50 cents discount.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 10. -- The wedding of Miss Lydia Platt Ackerman and Arthur Murphy took place this afternoon at Grace Church. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Ellen R. and the late J. Hervey Ackerman. Her brothers are New York business men. The bridegroom is the son of the Rev. T. Logan Murphy, the newly appointed curate of the American Church at Paris.

BALTIMORE, April 10. -- The market to-day about halted its downward proclivities and exerted some energies in the effort to recover. The principal channel through which these efforts were made was the Seaboard group. There was more readiness to buy and less anxiety to sell these isues to-day, which, in effect, carried them well above Tuesday's closing.

Mayor Van Wyck advised yesterday that the citizens of New York adopt the "shotgun method" in dealing with the State Legislature for passing bills such as the new charter and the Atlantic Avenue improvement measure. The Mayor became more excited yesterday than at any time since he has been in the Mayor's office.

BERLIN, April 10. -- Emperor William has written an account of the capture of the Taku forts, based upon the oral recital of the incidents of the battle furnished to him by Capt. Lans, who commanded the German gunboat Iltis. The imperial narrative dwells particularly upon the part taken by the Iltis in the engagement.
ALBANY, April 10. -- Something has been said about the "jokers" concealed in the New York charter. There are not only "jokers" but jokes. The following is a sample of the charter's jokes:

CHICAGO, April 10. -- Improvement of the Catholic educational system and plans for unifying the educational work of the Church, and raising it to a level in effectiveness with the State and non-sectarian institutions for higher learning, were discussed at the third annual convention of representatives of Catholic colleges, which opened hero to-day.
Replying to the public utterances of Gov. Allen of Porto Rico since his arrival in Washington Wencesiao Borda, Porto Rican Commissioner, yesterday made a statement, in part as follows:

ALBANY, April 10. -- As a result of a threat of 2,000 men to strike unless the demands of part of their number were complied with, the Delaware and Hudson Company has agreed to pay the machinists, boilermakers, and car builders employed in its shops at Carbonville, Penn., Green Island, and Oneonta a uniform rate of time and a quarter for all work performed on Sundays and overtime.

LONDON, April 11. -- The offer of a reward for the return of the gold stolen from the Kalser Wilhelm der Grosse or for the discovery of the thieves appears to effectually dispose of the theory first advanced, that the bars were stolen previous to having been put on board the steamer.

Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, charged with instigating the murder of millionaire William Marsh Rice by Valet Jones, the selfconfessed murderer, will to-day learn whether his counsel have lost their stubbornly contested initial encounter in the legal battle for his freedom or whether he will be held on the homicide charge for the action of the Grand Jury.

At the first regular session of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, held at the Hanson Place Methodist Church, Brooklyn, a heated discussion was caused by the report of the action of a clergyman who had left the Methodist Church to become a Christian Scientist.
Col. Wallace F. Randolph, Artillery Corps, is detailed as Chief of Artillery.

ALBANY, April 10. -- Fully 300 New Yorkers interested in the construction of buildings in New York City appeared before Gov. Odell at the hearing given by him today on the bills amending the State law governing the construction of tenement houses, recommended by the commission appointed by Gov. Roosevelt.

GLASGOW, April 11. -- The Shamrock I., refitted for racing, left the dock at Greenock yesterday for Gourock, where her sails will be bent, and where she will be made ready for the trials with the challenger for the America's Cup.
PARIS, April 10. -- Le Siecle, the leading Dreyfusard organ in France and the most persistent champion of Great Britain in the Transvaal, to-day announces its failure and approaching sale at auction.

BOSTON, April 10. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks loaned at 2 and 2 1/2 per cent. Clearing House rates, however, are no longer a factor in the money market. Few of the larger banks appear as lenders, and it is not quite so popular as it was to be a borrower. New York funds sold at 5, 10, and 15 cents' discount for cash.

PARIS, April 11. -- President Loubet fully appreciates the value of the word "ally" in connection with the relations of France to Russia, and he again took an opportunity to pronounce it on board the Alexander II. yesterday morning. When accepting tea from Admiral Birileff, he said:

FLUSHING, L.I., April 10. -- Play was resumed in the Amateur Athletic Union's Metropolitan Association championship basket ball tournament here to-night, when the teams of the National Athletic Club of Brooklyn and the Greenpoint Young Men's Christian Association met. The score stood 8 to 8 at the end of the first half, and the crowd was quite enthusiastic, the final score being 20 to 10 in favor of National A.C. Line-up:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- Color was to-day given to reports that have been circulating at the War Department for some time, that the President does not intend to follow the retirement of Brig. Gen. Lieber, Judge Advocate General, with the promotion successively of Col. Clous and Col. Barr and Col. Hunter, and so reach Col. G. W. Davis, who would be able to hold the office for the staff term of four years.

ALBANY, April 10. -- The canal men took a much more serious view of the opposition of the New York commercial organizations to the $26,000,000 proposition to-day when they saw the anti-canal men distributing in the Assembly copies of the resolutions passed at the joint meeting in New York.
WASHINGTON, April 30. -- "If you ever capture John Alfred Skoog you will have to be quick as chain lightning or he will kill either you or himself."

Mrs. Helen Potts Hall, wife of Blakeley Hall, the newspaper publisher, and formerly an actress, now avers that she was the adopted daughter of the late tea merchant and eccentric millionaire of Bridgeport, George Francis Gilman. She made known her secret yesterday in suits filed here and in Hartford, Conn., in which she claims the entire estate of the deceased.
ALBANY, April 10. -- "I never said the charter would have to be amended and never suggested any amendments. I don't believe there is a so-called 'job' in the bill. I am familiar with the amendments."
MANILA, April 10. -- Lieut. Mapes of the Twenty-third Infantry has captured $40,000 of insurgent funds, and three officers belonging to Gen. Cailles's staff, near Manila.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10. -- Except in the metal stocks, the Philadelphia market showed no inclination to follow the movement in New York. There was much interest in Cambria Steel, and the stock rose steadily from 20 5/8 to 21 5/8. Bethlehem responded with a rise of 5/8, and a vigorous demand set in for the common shares of the United States Steel, the price moving all day equal with the advance in New York.

It came to light yesterday that Albert Jensen, who attempted suicide on Tuesday afternoon on West Street, in the presence of a large crowd of pursuers, by shooting himself twice in the head, was not the victim of delirium tremens, as was first supposed, but is in reality an escaped convict and a noted counterfeiter.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- With the exception of two races the fields at Bennings to-day were meagre in size, and the contests were not exciting. Two favorites won. Jockey T. Bruns rode three successful mounts. Summary:

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The marriage of Horace Westcott of this city and Miss Emma Keats Rodgers, only daughter of the late Capt. John Rodgers, United States Army, occurred at noon to-day at the residence of the bride's mother. The ceremony was witnessed only by a small family party.

When Mr. ERNEST VAN DYCK, the wittiest person in Mr. MAURICE GRAU'S opera company, said, "JEAN DE RESZKE is the last of the prima donnas," he forgot the Australian nightingale, Mme. MELBA. It seems, however, that this eminent dispenser of trills and grupetti never forgets her own position.

At the dedication of a new Christian Science meeting place in this city on Sunday last, an interesting statement was made to the effect that the members of the congregation had been instrumental in causing a miracle to be performed. The alleged miracle consisted in praying a change into the inscription on a tenton granite block.

LONDON, April 10. -- Harry Vardon made his first appearance to-day since his return from the United States. He met "Jack" White in a thirty-six-hole match on the links at Seaford for a prize of u25. The weather was miserable. White won by six up and four to play.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The would-be keepers of grog shops for soldiers at Fort Monroe seem likely to be disappointed. They had expected that the War Department would hold that the Chamberlain and Hygeia Hotels, being on Government reservations, would be subject to the prohibition of the law against the sale of liquors on military reservations.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10. -- Prof. John Thomas Duffield, D.D., LL. D., died at his home, on University Place, here at 8 o'colck this morning. His death was caused by heart disease. He had been ill for a few days with asthma and seemed to be recovering, when death suddenly came. He was born in McConnellsburg, Penn., Feb. 19, 1823.

Yesterday was moderately gay. The town is filled with young people, who have come home from school to pass their Easter holidays. Various parties were arranged for the play and other theatrical attractions. In the afternoon the Knickerbocker Bowling Club held a meeting, and in the evening, the whist club met at the residence of Mrs. Gerrish.

The Grievance Committee of the Central Railroad of New Jersey employes, it was learned late last night, has been summoned to New York and will have a conference to-day with General Manager Warren. The reopening of the negotiations, it was believed on all sides, means the settlement of all the trouble amicably and no strike.

Negotiations are reported which contemplate such a change in the control of the Chicago Terminal Transfer Company as will at once give participating use of the property to many of the important railways entering Chicago. Standard Oil interests, represented by John D. Rockefeller personally, some time ago acquired a majority of the company's stock, and it is believed that development plans of extraordinary character are in contemplation.

The bill introduced by Senator Ellsworth at Albany providing for the appointment of referees in New York County has succeeded in raising a storm of protests from lawyers in this city. Even the Justices of the Supreme Court are opposed to the bill, and yesterday they held a meeting and seriously discussed the advisability of sending a delegation to Albany to protest against the measure.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 10. -- A wedding of much interest to society people of Boston and this city took place to-day, when Dean George Hodges of the Episcopal Theological School, formerly rector of Calvary Episcopal Church at Pittsburg, Penn., was married to Miss Julia Shelley, formerly of New York City.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is rumored in the public press of to-day that $58,000 has been paid for a seat in the Exchange. On the basis of a membership of 1,100, this would yield an aggregate value of $63,800,000 for all of the seats in the Exchange. In other words, at this rate, the real estate, franchise, and good-will of this institution is worth in the open market $63,800,000.

ALBANY, April 10. -- Majority Leader Allds in the Assembly this morning introduced the final adjournment concurrent resolution which fixes Tuesday, the 23d instant, at the hour of noon as the date. The resolution was sent to the Senate, where it was referred to the Finance Committee.

After many postponements the New York baseball club opened its season with Yale University yesterday on the Polo Grounds, and in a fast, well-played game was defeated by a score of 5 to 4. The collegians played pluckily, for up to the last inning they were three runs behind, and looked to be out of it.

The members of the Tenement House Commission have received their reward for the prudence, circumspection, and consideration of all interests involved which they have shown throughout their public-spirited work. In fact, the commission was a highly expert body, in respect that every interest which had a fair claim to be represented before it was represented in it.

With very few exceptions the retail dry goods men of this city are loath to discuss the Associated Merchants' Company which has been organized by John Claflin, which is being financed by J.P. Morgan Co. One thing was learned yesterday, however, and that is that no plans have yet been perfected for absorbing other New York establishments than the three that have already been taken over.

CLEVELAND, April 10. -- A report was circulated here to-day confirmatory of the statement published several days ago that control of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railroad had passed into the hands of George J. Gould and his associates and would become a part of the Wabash system. To-day's report represented Russell Sage of New York as saying that Mr. Gould and his friends had purchased the road.

Students of industrial statistics will be interested in the announcement that Russia has made her first shipment of pig iron to a foreign market, and thus in a small way joined the ranks of the competitors for the trade of nations. The first cargo of Russian pig iron was shipped from Kertch, for delivery at Marseilles.

LONDON, April 11. -- "It is semi-offlcially asserted here," says the Cape Town correspondent of The Daily Telegraph, "that Gen. Botha has had another interview with Lord Kitchener, in which he informed him that he had seen Gen. De Wet, who still refused to entertain the idea of surrender on any terms.

WASHINGTON, April 10. -- The April report of the Statistician of the Department of Agriculture will show the average condition of Winter wheat April 1 to have been 91.7, against 82.1 April 1, 1900, 77.9 at the corresponding date in 1899, and 82.9 the mean of the April averages of the last ten years.

Horace S. Ely Co. have sold for the Young Men's Christian Association its property at the southwest corner of Fourth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, having frontages of 84 feet on the avenue and 174 feet on the street. The buyers are the New-York Realty Company (Flake Dowling) and the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company.

Is it beyond the power of the people of this community to break the alliance between Tammany and the Republican organization? Are the gentlemen at Albany really determined that CROKER shall name the next Mayor?

OCEAN SIDE, L.I., April 10. -- The Presbytery of Nassau, at its closing meeting, instructed the Rev. M. Buttinghausen of Elmont and W.E. Decker of Springfield, its delegates to the General Assembly, to be held in Philadelphia next month, to vote for a short creed. The delegates accepted the conditions.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 10. -- Princeton won her second victory over Virginia this afternoon in a pretty exhibition of baseball by a score of 9 to 5. The score:

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 10. -- Ex-Gov. W.O. Bradley, chief counsel for ex-Gov. W.S. Taylor, in the Gubernatorial contest case before the Legislature last year, gave sensational testimony to-day in the trial of Capt. Garnett D. Ripley, who is charged with conspiracy, with others, to bring about the murder of William. Goebel.

Herbert A. Sherman has sold for Francis N. Pendleton to Joseph Hamershlag the plot, 50 by 126, on Fifth Avenue, 95 feet south of Eighty-ninth Street, together with the plot, 106 by 100.8, on the south side of Eighty-ninth Street, 100 feet east of Fifth Avenue. These two parcels form an "L" around the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-ninth Street, recently purchased as a residence site by "William B. Leeds.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The salt industry of the country received attention from the Industrial Commission to-day, Archibald S. White, President of the National Salt Company, being the witness. He said that the annual consumption of salt in the United States amounts to about 13000,000 barrels, of which the National Company supplied last year between 8,000,000 and 9,000,000 barrels.

ALBANY, April 11. -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff is very indignant over the charge made by a New York newspaper that he had inserted in the new charter the provision for borough advertising. He said this morning: "Any suggestion that I had anything to do with the amendment is without truth.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- Educational legislation in the United States was attacked to-day in the discussions at the Roman Catholic educational conference as being unfair, partial, and prejudicial to the private rights of individuals and to religious institutions, in the tendency of the laws to absolute State control of schools.

LONDON, April 12. -- H. V. Esmond's comedy, "The Wilderness," which was produced last evening at the St. James's Theatre, is declared by the critics to be charmingly fresh and original. Its motive is the discovery by a worldly girl, who is scheming to marry a rich man, that she is really very much in love with him.

ALBANY, April 11. -- After the hardest fight of the session in the Assembly, the canal men won a victory to-day, which they are confident means the passage by the Legislature of the bill providing for the submission to the people of the $26,000,000 improvement proposition.

"Unless people generally awake to a realizing sense of the importance of vaccination we will have the smallpox with us all Summer," said Dr. F. H. Dillingham, Assistant Sanitary Superintendent, yesterday. "The public has become indifferent. While the coming of warm weather may result in improved conditons, the one important fact to be emphasized is the necessity for vaccination."

Mrs. Elizabeth R. Grafton. Mrs. Elizabeth R. Grafton, widow of Capt. Joseph Grafton, died at her home, 307 Fifth Avenue, last night, of old age. She was the daughter of Henry Remsen, a member of the old New York family, and was born in this city seventy-seven years ago, and had lived here all her life.

The opinion expressed by an Assemblyman from this city that it is best to put through the twenty-six-million-dollar canal improvement bill because that measure will help to build up "sentiment for a larger canal," which the people can be asked to authorize next year, exhibits, we fear, about the average of legislative intelligence upon the subject of the canals.

During the past month attention has been called anew to the possibly serious effect on the money market of the large accumulation of cash in the Treasury, due to excess of receipts over expenditures. That effect was recognized by Secretary GAGE, and was anticipated by the purchase of a considerable, though not large, amount of such bonds as were available.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 11. -- Mrs. Jennie Wilson, wife of Charles Wilson, of 227 Waverley Place, New York City, entered the police station here this afternoon and asked that transportation be given to her and her three children to help them to reach Syracuse, where she intended visiting her sister, Mrs. Daniel Miller.

A temporary injunction restraining the Presbyterian Hospital from proceeding with the erection of the new home for nurses on East Seventy-first Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, was issued by Justice Freedman in the Supreme Court yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: -- Building operations in the Bronx are going on extensively, and have been, for several years; but no home dwellings are erected; nothing but tenement houses of a more or less, pretentious character, called flats. One of the principal inducements held out to would-be tenants, is steam heat; the generally unreasonable high rents are a secondary consideration.

ST. PAUL, April 11. -- The Minnesota and International Railroad, incorporated by the Northern Pacific, and of which C. S. Mellen is President, to-day asked permission of the Secretary of State to increase its capital stock for the purpose of buying the Brainord and Northern Railroad, a majority of stock of which is owned by the Northern Pacific.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- It is to be feared that American manufacturers of fire preventing and extinguishing apparatus are going to lose a rare and valuable opportunity, through their unaccountable indifference to the special international exposition of that whole class of appliances and methods which is to be held at Berlin during the coming Summer.

DANVILLE, N. Y., April 11. -- The mysterious search in the backyard of the former home of Alonzo Whiteman, who is now in the Tombs in New York awaiting sentence for grand larceny, is agitating the entire town. Digging began in the garden early Tuesday and continued uninterruptedly until last night.

Painters and also architects while traveling in Europe are apt to take notes of places that strike them pleasantly, and these notes are sometimes valuable to themselves and interesting to their friends. But now and then there is one who becomes fascinated by the hobby and makes a serious pursuit of what began as a jotting down of memoranda for reference.

Clark H. Abbott, counsel for the Seaman's Branch of the Legal Aid Society, recovered from the sailing ship Ems yesterday two men who, it is believed, had been shanghaied. Mr. Abbott learned that a number of sailors had disappeared mysteriously from different sailors boarding houses Wednesday night.

Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, accused by Valet Charles F. Jones of originating the scheme to kill old William Marsh Rice for his millions, and of directing the successful execution of the murder, will not know until Monday whether his accuser's confession has been sufficiently corroborated in the eyes of the law to warrant Justice Jerome in holding him prisoner to await the action of the Grand Jury.

LONDON, April 11. -- The reply of Oxford and Cambridge to the challenge of Harvard and Yale Universities for a series of track games this Summer agrees that New York shall be the place of meeting and that the programme shall be the same as in 1899, except that for the three-mile run a two-mile run is substituted.
PITTSBURG, April 11. -- The Commercial Gazette to-morrow will say:

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- Prices generally were better to-day in the local market, but the only wide advances were in Cambria Steel, Lehigh Navigation, which scored the highest figure yet made, and Pennsylvania Steel certificates. The buying of Lehigh Navigation was good. Some of it came from New York, and was accompanied by a variety of stories affecting developments in the property, but officials of the company said they knew of no negotiations.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- Yale played exceptionally good bail to-day against the Athletics of the American League, and the professionals won only after a sharp battle lasting eleven innings. Robertson pitched a splendid game and never once lost his nerve. Except in the last inning he received fine support.

MINEOLA. L.I., April 11. -- Thomas H. Bacon, Chairman of the Horse Department of the Queens-Nassau Counties Agricultural Society, has prepared an interesting programme for the Summer meeting of the society to be held on the fair grounds here on June 19 and 20. The premium list amounts to $2,250. Frank T. Walker of the Parkway Driving Club has been enfaged as Starting Judge.

ORANGE, N.J., April 11. -- Orange society folk turned out in force this afternoon to witness the marriage of Miss Bertha Zimmermann Gerhard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Frederick Gerhard of Nuthurst, East Orange, to G. Johnston Bradish of New York, in Grace Episcopal Church, this city.

FLUSHING, L. I., April 11. -- Two games were played to-night in the championship basket ball tournament of the Amateur Athletic Union, Metropolitan Association. The big armory of the Seventeenth Separate Company, on Amity Street here, contained an enthusiastic crowd of spectators, and fast, hard basket ball of the most scientific character was played.

Justice Freedman in the Supreme Court handed down a decision yesterday as to the right to arrest on "Joe Doe" or "John Black" warrants. The decision was in the application for a writ of habeas corpus applied for by Max Joseph, who had been arrested as "John Black No. 1" in a raid made on the New York Cafe by the Committee of Fifteen.

In the shop windows where wallpapers are exhibted one sees usually an example of cretonne-covered furniture to show what can be done in the way of matching furniture and papers. One of the conveniences of the cretonne-furnished bedroom is the big screen. It is high and broad, and one of the greatest of comforts, besides being one of the cheapest of screens.

The Albany correspondent of The Brooklyn Eagle succeeded in getting Senator Stranahan, Senator Elsberg, and Assemblyman Kelsey, three out of the 200 legislators, to deny that there was an agreement on both sides, on the clause in the charier revision, by which sectarian schools may receive public money from a Board of Education, which will probably be constituted by Tammany Hall.

The Legislature has taken a step in the right direction in passing the Weekes bill, amending the existing law relative to what in this State is known as the common law marriage. It should be followed next year by a radical amendment of the statutes relative to dower right in real estate.

LONDON, April 11. -- Large repayments to the Bank of England to-day caused a good request for money, especially for weekly advances covering Exchequer bonds payment of April 12, when a considerable squeeze is anticipated. Discounts were firm.

ALBANY, April 11. -- Gov. Odell, Leader Allds, and Assemblyman Kelsey have prepared a bill intended to curb the State printing expenses and save between $60,000 and $70,000 a year. Gov. Odell sent a message to the Legislature asking for immediate action and calling attention to the great growth of cost from $46,500, in 1880, to $394,800, in 1900.

LONDON, April 12. -- A dispatch from St. Petersburg, dated April 11, says that the stories of plots against the life of the Czar which found their way into the American press through English, German, Austrian, and French channels, were common talk on the streets of St Petersburg months before they were published, but their inherent improbability and falsity as to details caused them to be generally disbelieved.

GREENFORT, L. L., April 11. -- The famous racing cutter yacht-Senta was examined by the experts of the Greenport Yacht Basin and Construction Company here today and found to be badly strained. The boat wrenched herself severely on the voyage across the Atlantic Ocean. Her underbody and sides were treated, roughly, and with her battered appearance she looks anything but the trim racing cutter that she will be in a few days.

PHILADELPHIA, April 11. -- The stockholders of the Pennsylvania Canal, a portion of the State's system of interior waterways, and an important factor in early transportation days, by a unanimous vote to-day decided to abandon it. This action ratifies a resolution adopted by the Directors authorizing the President, Gen. Isaac Wistar, to dispose of the property of the company.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 11. -- There was a lively time in the works of the American Tobacco Company this afternoon, when the 350 girls employed objected to being vaccinated by the physicians sent there by the health officers. Two smallpox patients died here to-day, one of whom was a girl, who, although sick with the disease, worked in the factory until Saturday last.
Warden John M. Fox of the Blackwell's Island Workhouse was seized with an attack of apoplexy at Second Avenue and Seventieth Street yesterday morning and died within a minute.

The test cases involving the imposition of a countervailing duty on Russian sugar came up yesterday before the Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers. The matter had attracted a great deal of attention on account of the action of the Russian Government in imposing heavy additional duties upon various American products because of the action af the United States Government in imposing a countervailing duty on Russian sugar.

NEWARK, N. J., April 11. -- Mrs. Julia Lotary of Hoboken, married scarcely six months, has filed a bill in chancery by which she seeks to recover control of property representing her wedding dower, which she alleges is being dissipated by her husband, Alfred Lotary, a young Hoboken lawyer.

B.B. Crowninshield, designer of the Lawson yacht Independence, which is to compete with the Constitution and the Columbia for the honor of defending the America's Cup against Sir Thomas Lipton's challenger. Shamrock II., has announced the side plan of the Boston built yacht.

Enos Wilder, Jr., of St. Paul's School, Concord. N. H., and Pierre A. Proal of Blake School, this city, are the survivors in the interscholastic golf tournament, who will fight out the final round to-day for championship honors. Two match play rounds were played yesterday on the links of the Oakland Golf Club, near Bayside, L.I., and the annual competition will be finished to-day.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- The Department of Agriculture has received a dispatch from a prominent packing company of Chicago announcing that it has just been advised that the British Government has excluded all beef, except home-bred, from the British Army contracts. This, it is stated, is to be effective June 1 next.

The provision of terminal facilities for important cities is becoming a more and more onerous problem in railroad management. In New York it is very far from solution, owing partly to the island location of the city and due further to the enormous outlay involved in the purchase of real estate.

Councilman Stewart M. Brice has been adjudged guilty of contempt by Justice Scott of the Supreme Court, and unless he secures a stay periding an appeal, must serve ten days in the county (Dudlow Street) Jail. In addition he must pay $473.35, which includes costs and a fee of $150 to the attorneys who prosecuted the case.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., April 11. -- Every man in the car shops of the Central Railroad of New Jersey at Ashley went on strike at noon to-day because Superintendent Thomas refused to reinstate thirty employes who had been laid off a few days ago. The employes claimed that the men were discharged because they were prominent in the labor union, while Superintendent Thomas said it was because of slack work.

PARIS, April 12. -- At the conclusion of the festivities at Toulon last night. President Loubet proceeded to his home at Montelimar, in the Department of the Drome, to visit his aged mother and take a few days' repose after the fatigues of the many functions of the week, which have kept him occupied from early morning until late at night.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- In addition to the gift of $1,000,000 to Armour Institute, announced yesterday, Mrs. P. D. Armour purposes soon to erect and equip a new building for the institute. Gen. John C. Black, one of the Trustees, said to-day:

People interested in music and musical literature regret the lack of a source of information regarding the musical literature in America. There should be a complete catalogue, showing what exists and where it can be had. About German music information can be readily obtained, by means of the "Hofmeister Verzeichnis," which is used by the leading music dealers in large towns.
John T. Woodward has been chosen Manager and Secretary of the Vernon Insurance Company of Indianapolis, to succeed M. V. McGHiard, resigned.

Columbia students talked much yesterday of President Low's innovations in university athletics, and the sentiment was generally expressed that the President's action was entirely justifiable. The students feel that the unhealthy condition of athletics for the past two years has made necessary such a course.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- There was interesting sport at Bennings to-day. The weather was delightful, and the crowd very large. Outsiders landed first money in four of the events and only one favorite, The Rogue in the fifth race, won. From a field of sixteen starters False Alarm, at 10 to 1 took the first race, a head in front of Brahmin, who was two lengths in front of the favorite.

With a life, of silence before him, beginning with to-day, Willam Crampton, a public lecturer of Brooklyn, put in yesterday talking against time into the gaping funnel of a photograph receiver, storing up lectures pending the loss of his tongue. For to-day the knife of a surgeon in Seney Hospital will make of Mr. Crampton a "tongueless lecturer."

The New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, now in session at the Hanson Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, was again disturbed yesterday morning by a discussion relating to the withdrawal of the Rev. S. E. Simonson, who is now a Christian Scientist. The excitement was caused by a resolution which had been rushed through without debate.

CHICAGO, April 11. -- Money to-day was slightly firmer, although the rates were unchanged at 4 to 5 per cent. New York exchange was quoted at 50 cents discount in the morning and at 45 and 40 cents discount in the afternoon.

ALBANY, April 11. -- Senator Humphrey, as soon as the Senate convened this morning, moved that the Committee on Judiciary be discharged from further consideration of Assemblyman Kelsey's bill permitting women property owners to vote upon appropriations in all villages of the State.
