ALBANY, April 11. -- Senator Ellsworth's bill providing for the appointment by the Appellate Division of twenty referees for the Supreme Court, and twenty, for the City Court of New York, was advanced to third reading after a sharp debate in the Senate to-day.

PEKING, April 11. -- Robert M. Me Wade, United States Consul at Canton, reports that 10,000 deaths from the plague have occurred there during the past six weeks, and that there are 13 cases of smallpox on board the United States monitor Monterey.

WASHINGTON, April 11. -- Representative Landis of Indiana has examined critically the Logan Statue recently unveiled and turned over to the, care of the District of Columbia. He directs attention to the tablet on the east side of the pedestal representing Senator Logan being sworn into office by Vice President Arthur.
TOULON, April 11. -- On behalf of the King of Italy the Duke of Genoa this morning distributed a number of decorations to the French Ministers and military, naval, and civil officials.

When the State Civil Service Commission convened in the New York Life Building yesterday morning for its second day of probing into the charges of outrageous violation of the law by the old Police Board in the promotion of sixteen Sergeants to the rank of Captain on Dec. 27 last, it found nearly a score of members of the force who had, come, in answer to subpoenas, to help it with its labors.

The cross streams of hurrying people on Brooklyn Bridge paused yesterday in their journey. The howling of sirens drew their attention up the river. As they looked a long black loop resting momentarily, an end on either shore, came from out of the water. From each side of the river it arose rapidly nearing the centre of the stream.
No change in the Bank of England's rate of discount.
There is no doubt that the facts as they are known fully require the investigation now making into recent police promotions by the State Civil Service Commission.

Having heard that secret opposition to the pending Rapid Transit' bill had been developed at Albany, the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners decided at their meeting yesterday to send a telegram to the Chairman of the Cities Committee of the Assembly, Otto C. Kelsey, asking permission for the board to appear before that committee on Monday next.

A bright springtime day and crowds of carriages in the park and on the avenue. There were quite a number of small entertainments during the early afternoon. There was but one wedding in town, that of Miss Giovanina Saint Seigne to Mr. T. Charles Farrelly, at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

SAN JUAN, Porto Rico, April 11. -- Francis B. Loomis, United States Minister to Venezuela, who arrived here last night on the Scorpion, sailed for the United States this afternoon by the Red D Line steamer Caracas. He emphatically declined to disclose the nature of his report to President McKinley; but, judging from casual remarks which he let fall, he is evidently quite antagonistic to President Castro.

Prices were very irregular in the outside market yesterday, and although the early transactions brought a number of advances, few net gains showed at the end of the day. The reactionary condition of the market followed in a general way the course of prices on the Exchange, advancing with that market early in the day and declining with it later.

BOSTON, April 11. -- At the Clearing House this morning money between the banks was in good supply, with loans at 2 @2 1/2 per cent., mostly at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 10@15c discount for cash. One large banking house says that all its loans outstanding are at 3 per cent., and that it borrowed new money at that figure yesterday.

In a neat brochure, with rubricated covers, the "Fourth Annual Report" of the Cedar Rapids (Iowa) Free Public Library has been published. The report takes notice of new quarters which were secured for the library during the past year. Over 1,000 volumes were also added by gift and purchase.

CHICAGO, April 12. -- A declaration of the Catholic position on education in the United States was adopted to-day at the closing session of the National conference of the Association of Catholic Colleges. The resolution comprising the declaration received the unanimous assent of the representatives of seventy different colleges -- practically the entire collegiate system of the Catholic Church in America.

Incidental to a deal which will result in the improvement of the entire block front on Central Park West between Ninetieth and Ninety-first Street, Russell Sage has sold his four lots at the northwest corner of Ninetieth Street to Edward Oppenheimer. Mr. Oppenheimer, who already owned two lots on the Ninety-first Street corner, has also acquired the two intervening lots from Ottinger Brother, and has resold the entire block front to John V. Signell.

The letters in this volume of over four hundred pages, with the exception of fewer than half a dozen, addressed to Bismarck's children on special occasions, such as birthdays, and a few to his wife's father and mother, were written to Johanna von Puttkamer, either before or after her marriage to him. The first bears date of Jan. 29, 1847, and the last before their marriage July 4 in the same year.
LONDON, April 13. -- In the course of a long article. The Statist says:

The solicitude shown by the Merchants' Association lest the good work done by it to assist in defeating the Ramapo job shall be lost or shelved by the city authorities is natural, perhaps, but it is unnecessary. Disinterested public service is not wasted, and its results never represent lost effort.

Representatives of the Reading Railroad were elected yesterday into the Board of Directors of the Central Railroad of New Jersey, and a majority of this board is now controlled by the Reading Railroad. The new Directors are President G. F. Baer of the Reading, Joseph S. Harris, J. Lowber Welsh, Charles Steele, all Directors of the Reading, and E. P. Thomas of the Erie Railroad.

The publication in a new cheap edition of the "Love Letters of Dorothy Osborne to Sir William Temple," by the publishers of the first American edition of the book, originally issued over twelve years ago, opens an interesting question. In 1888 Messrs. Dodd, Mead Co. published a beautifully made edition of the book, the typographical beauty of which was entirely equaled by the charm of its text.

By what arguments do the advocates of the $26,000,000 canal bill hope to persuade the people of the State to accept their makeshift plans and authorize the expenditure? They must see, for it is as plain as noonday, that when to the habitual reluctance of the rural counties to vote money for the canals is added the organized opposition of the commercial bodies of the cities, the makeshift will surely be rejected at the polls.

ALBANY, April 12. -- The Brooks bill to permit boxing exhibitions throughout the State under the direction of the Amateur Athletic Union, on second reading in the Assembly this morning, was objected to by M. E. Lewis of Monroe. Mr. Kelsey moved to recommit the bill, but owing to the absence of Mr. Brooks, withdrew his motion, and the bill went over until Monday night.

BOMBAY, April 12. -- Ibu Raschid has recovered the Kingdom of Nejd, Central Arabia, after defeating Mabaronk. Sheik of Koweit, who recently seized the City of Nejd and deposed Ibu Raschid, after a pitched battle.

There was a lively clash between ex-Judge William M. K. Olcott and Anthony Comstock, Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of Vice, before Magistrate Cornell, in the Centre Street Police Court, yesterday afternoon. Mr. Olcott appeared as counsel for William C. Hallock of 200 West One Hundred and Thirty-fourth Street, who was arrested a few days ago on charges made by Mr. Comstock.

Robert Cochran Bacot died at his home, 179 Prospect Street, East Orange, yesterday morning, after a short illness. He was stricken with "paralysis on Sunday, and sank rapidly. Mr. Bacot was eighty-three years old. SHe was a descendant of a Huguenot family that settled in South Carolina about 1670.

A controversy the outcome of which conservative churchmen say they would not dare predict has arisen in the Protestant Episcopal Church over the methods used in the consecration of the Venerable Reginald Heber Weller, Jr., as Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Fond du Lac, Wis., on Nov. 8, 1900.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 12. -- The largest price of the season for an untried two-year-old thoroughbred was received by S. K. Hughes here to-day, when John Manning of New York bought by telegraph, for an English turfman, the chestnut colt J. N. Camden, by St. Savior-Orlie, by Imp. Deceiver, for $7,500.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers held last night in two of the buildings at Columbia University what they called a "conversazione" -- an exhibition of various electrical appliances that had been recently invented, or the models of which had been improved of late. There was a special display of Nikola TesIa's oscillator, the inventor snowing an audience that packed a large auditorium in Havemeyer Hall how many kinds of sparks his contrivance could generate.
Author of the "Literary Landmark" books, "Plays and Players," "Edwin Booth," "Lester Wallack,"

YONKERS, N. Y., April 12. -- For a time to-day the police thought they might have Willie McCormick. The boy turned out not to be the missing High Bridge lad, but a boy and man are held while an investigation is to be made.

The Commission of the Palisades Inter-State Park seems to have made the very usual mistake of undertaking too much and laying out its plans on a scale so magnificent that it is finding difficulty in carrying them out. The Commissioners have submitted the following memorandum of contemplated expenses to the Finance Committee of the Senate at Albany:

PITTSBURG, Penn., April 12. -- Thomas D. Kahro, a Mount Washington grocer, was shot and killed in his home by three burglars while defending his wife, who was being chloroformed, this morning. A few hours later the rendezvous of the alleged robbers was discovered at 32 Fulton Street, and a force of detectives put to work on the case.

According to B. Gerson Oppenheim, a lawyer, who has just returned from the City of Mexico, the many creditors of Lewis G. Tewksbury are to be made more than happy. They are not only to get the full amount of their claims, but'are also to receive interest. Tewksbury left claims aggregating over $600,000 behind him when he disappeared.

Between those who fancy any incident outside of their own experience to be impossible, and those always anxious to accuse a novelist of borrowing from the current newspaper, Mrs. Helen Campbell's "Ballantyne" is likely to be well discussed. One of its most important characters is an educated and refined woman passing as a man, and for years deceiving intimate associates and housemates.

In the outside market yesterday trading was less active than it had been for the last few days, and prices were once again irregular. The general tendency of the market was reactionary, and only a few issues ended the day with net gains. The copper stocks were among the issues which showed strength, and this group also supplied several of the most active stocks of the day.

In modern poetry, one thing the careful observer finds obvious and significant is its many-styled architectural expression. In other words, it is not merely Popeian or Wordsworthian -- for it flows in all the known forms. It may be that the rules of verse have at last become too easy and familiar.

An order for the commitment of Councilman Stewart M. Brice to the county jail was prepared by L. Laflin Kellogg yesterday and made returnable at 10:30 o'clock Monday morning. It is expected that James W. Gerard, Jr., attorney for Mr. Brice, will in the meantime take steps looking to an appeal, and that a stay will be granted until the case is finally determined in a, higher court.

There are indications of trouble ahead for the members of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, now holding sessions at the Baneon Place Methodist Episcopal Church, Brooklyn, in the matter of appointments and transfers. A prominent member of the conference said yesterday that the "shake-up " impending would be the greatest in the history of the conference and that a great many ministers would necessarily be disappointed.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 12. -- W. Gould Brokaw's fast schooner yacht Amorita, after being overhauled and prepared for commission at the Jacob yard, has been launched from the marine railway and tied up at the wharf, where the masts will be stepped and other spars put aboard.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The last but one day of the Spring meeting of the Washington Jockey Club witnessed almost a record-breaking crowd at the Bennings track this afternoon. The sport, while good, lacked vim, as the fields in nearly all the races were very small as a result o numerous scratches.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: An exceptional value is given to the comments on the "Standard Library" by some of the best-known American librarians, in your issue of March 23 by the wide difference in the points of view represented. May the time never come when all librarians shall think alike on a detail like this.
In its daily trade review, always conservative, The American Metal Market makes these observations:

The skill and good sense of President LOUBET and M. DELCASSE have brought the incident at Toulon to a happy close, and in this they have been aided by the display of like qualities on the part of the representative pf Italy, the Duke of GEXOA, commanding the Italian fleet, and by the Russian Government.

YONKERS, N. Y., April 12. -- At to-day's session of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church at this place Bishop Goodsell in his sermon, preached especially to the clergy as to their method of conducting their churches and their general pastoral work, took occasion to caution them against dragging politics into their pulpits.
The first report of the Committee of Fifteen shows in a sensible and business-like manner that the work of the committee is proceeding on right lines and with satisfactory and promising results.

BOSTON, April 12. -- At the Clearing House this morning, money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 per cent., and was in good supply. New York funds sold at 12 1/2, 15, and 17 cents discount for cash. On call, money rules from 3@4 per cent., mostly 3 1/2@4 per cent. Time money ranges from 3 3/4@4 1/2 per cent., according to the character of the collateral.

A romance of real life ended in the plainly furnished little room at 57 East Eleventh Street yesterday morning just as the day was dawning. It ended with the death of Ellen Anne Griffin, who had lived there for many years entirely alone, except for the little black-and-tan dog who, at the very last, sat patiently beside the bed and licked the hands of its mistress until they grew cold.

Is not the labor in vain? The theme of Mrs. Fraser's book is so familiar and so repulsive that we look for extraordinary art to commend it -- look and do not find. "A Little Grey Shop" is an unwholesome story of base actions, feeble motives, crises that are meant to be exciting and fail of their purpose, entanglement and sin and folly and flabbiness and incongruity.

There was a great deal going on yesterday. The Hewitt entertainment, the last meeting of several dancing classes, the Coquelin matinee, and other affairs kept the social world very busy. The Spring weather was an inspiration for those who went to the Park and on the avenue in carriages. There was an almost endless procession of handsome turnouts the entire afternoon.

ALBANY, April 12. -- Gov. Odell has signed the four tenement house bills which the Legislature passed on the recommendation of the Roosevelt Tenement House Commission. The Governor filed the following memorandum with the bill providing for the manner of construction of tenement houses:

Henry Savage Landor has selected the title of "China and the Allies" for his new illustrated two-volume work on the complicated questions of the Far East which Charles Scribner's Sons are about to publish.

In the following list "mtg " stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

Partisan influence in police appointments was freely admitted yesterday by President Bernard J. York of the old Police Board, who was the first witness before the State Civil Service Commission, which is investigating the promotions of sixteen Sergeants to Captaincies made by that body on Dec. 27 last.

EDINBURGH, April 12. -- The Bank of Scotland denies all knowledge of the forging of their bank notes of u20 by the alleged forgers John A. Skoog and Emil Mobert, now in custody in New York, and say that no counterfeit notes of their own issues have come to their notice. The police of Edinburgh also deny any knowledge of the counterfeiting of Scotch bank notes.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 12. -- Great Medicine Chief White Beaver (Col. D. Frank Powell) conferred to-day on Going Away, a full-blood Winnebago Indian, the title of Medicine Chief of the Winnebago Nation, to succeed John Thunder, who was buried at sundown last Sunday, near Black River Falls, Wis., with much pomp and ceremony.

LONDON, April 13. -- "Although doubtless it will be the chief topic of the season, there are many reasons why the contest for the America's Cup," says The Field, "will not arouse great enthusiasm. The main reason is that, as is now fully admitted in the United States, as well as here, the mode of measurement necessitated encourages useless dangers in the type of yacht.

BALTIMORE, April 12. -- The consolidation of the former independent telephone companies of Maryland, Pennsylvania, and West Virginia with the United Telegraph and Telephone Company will, it appears, be followed in a few days by the latter securing control of the United Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore.

The scrub race, for which the Columbia University oarsmen have been practicing for several days past, was decided on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon and was won by the strengthened third 'Varsity crew, with the first 'Varsity crew second, the second 'Varsity boat third, and the first freshman crew fourth.

PHILADELPHIA, April 12. -- Many stocks in the market to-day attained their highest figures for several months, and there was much animation in the trading. The steel stocks dominated. Demand for Bethlehem Steel was heavy and persistent all the morning, the price mounting up to 21 3/4 at noon, the highest in nearly two years.

What more natural than that John Curtis, a Harvard graduate, should be on board a Greek caique and bound for Crete? John was an athlete, and besides that was well up, not alone in the Greek of Homer, but he had a fair smatter of the modern tongue, such as is spoken in Athens. That caique was loaded with arms and ammunition for the Cretans, who were just then fighting for their liberty.

LONDON, April 12. -- Money was firm today, though the pressure did not equal expectations. Considerable preparations for the settlement and Exchequer bonds payments were made ahead. A half million received trom India yesterday helped the market. The demand for discounts was fairly active.

MONTEREY, Cal., April 12. -- Apostie George Q. Cannon of the Mormon Church died here to-day. Mr. Cannon slept considerably yesterday and the fore part of last night. A bulletin was issued about midnight stating that he was resting easy. The change for the worse came a few hours later, and he passed quietly away early this morning.

The representatives of the engineers and the firemen on the Central Railroad of New Jersey resumed their conference yesterday morning with the officials of the company in the office of Division Superintendent Wentz. They spent from 10 to 5 o'clock trying to straighten out the tangle which almost led to a general tie-up of the system, and then the conference adjourned until this morning.

The account which Mr. Leonard Courtney has given us of the "working constitution" of the United Kingdom is very different from the brilliant and philosophic essay of the late Mr. Walter Bagehot. His general idea of the nature of English institutions and of the way in which they are carried on is in harmony with that of Bagehot, but much more attention is given to their detailed operation.

If we can trust the reports of authors, the relation between themselves and their publishers is all the time changing for the worse. This is the more peculiar since, always upon the report of the authors, it has always been as bad as it could possibly be. Who does not remember that amenity of the late Oliver Goldsmith:

John R. Rogers, known in theatrical circles as the former husband of Minnie Palmer and as "Yours merrily, Rogers," has sued the Actors' Fund to recover $6,500, which he claims to be due him on a diamond known as the "Cleveland Gem." The action has been begun in the Supreme Court by Leventritt Brennan, his counsel.

BOSTON, April 11. -- Messrs. Little, Brown Co. are this week publishing a new edition of Dr. Benjamin W. Wells's "Modern German Literature," with two new chapters substituted for the eleventh, which formerly closed the volume, and with such corrections and revisions of the early chapters as were deemed necessary.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- Capt. and Mrs. Warren Beach of New York gave this afternoon one of the largest teas of the year. Assisting were Mrs. Richard Mulligan, Mrs. Richardson, Mrs. Charles H. Campbell, Mrs. Hinckley, Mrs. W. A. Beach of Syracuse, Miss Sheridan, the Misses de Peyster, and Miss Alice Ward. Capt. and Mrs. Beach will give a dance next Wednesday evening for young people.

Howard Conkling presided at the meeting of the Madison Square Republican Club last night at 1146 Broadway, when another of the series of lectures was given. Abraham Gruber was the speaker, and he took for his subject, "Give the Rank and File a Chance."

Counsel for Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, now in the Tombs charged by Valet Jones with instigating the murder of William M. Rice, received another setback yesterday when Recorder Goff, in response to their motion to fix ball for Morris Meyers and David L. Short, named $20,000 as a proper bail for each.

NEWPORT, April 12. -- Mrs. William T. Bull has completed arrangements for the interior improvements to Dudley Place. Dr. and Mrs. Bull will take possession of the house in June. Mrs. Bull, who has been spending a week here as the guest of her brother-in-law, Congressman Bull, returns to New York to-morrow with her children.

HAWTHORNE ABTICLES. -- The Cornhill Booklet for April contains three short sketches by Nathaniel Hawthorne, contributed to the second volume of "The American Magazine of Useful and Entertaining Knowledge," published in Boston in 1838. Hawthorne, the preface states, edited this periodical, from 1836 1838, and is said to haver written and prepared nearly all of its contents.

NEWARK, N. J., April 11. -- David G. Bodman, whose stomach was removed two weeks ago, died from exhaustion to-day. The operation upon Bodman attracted attention throughout the surgical world. It was decided upon as the only means of saving the man's life, as he was suffering from cancer of the stomach.

The will of Fernando Yznaga, who died on March 6, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday afternoon. Under the will his entire estate, worth over $2,000,000, goes to his sister, Consuelo, Dowager Duchess of Manchester, mother of the young Duke of Manchester, who married the daughter of Eugene Zimmermann of Cincinnati, Ohio.
LONDON, April 12. -- Harry Vardon met James Braid to-day on the links at Eltham in a thirty-six-hole match. Both played brilliant golf, Vardon winning by two holes up and one to play.
CHICAGO, April 12. -- New York exchange was quoted to-day at 25 cents discount before and 20 cents discount after call. Money for time and call loans was unchanged at 4@5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The Industrial Commission listened with great interest for two hours to-day, while John Norris, Business Manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, described the origin, development, and operations of the International Paper Company, and at the close of his speech and the discussion following it, he was thanked by Thomas W. Phillips, the Vice Chairman of the commission, for the contribution he had made to the information possessed by the commission.

HACKENSACK, N. J., April 12. -- Eight persons, half a dozen dogs, and several horses were bitten to-day by a dog. The town is in terror, for though twice shot and once struck with a heavy club, the dog is still at large.

Pierre A. Proal of Blake School will hold the Interscholastic golf championship honors for the coming year. He is the immediate successor of Harry Hollins, now in Harvard, who won the title last year while a student in Cutler School, and the previous year G. Owen Winston. Jr., also a Cutler School lad, took the championship.

WASHINGTON, April 12. -- The Industrial Commission listened with great interest for two hours to-day, while John Norris, Business Manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, described the origin, development, and operations of the International Paper Company, and at the close of his speech and the discussion following it, he was thanked by Thomas W. Phillips, the Vice Chairman of the commission, for the contribution he had made to the information possessed by the commission.

WHITESBURG, Ky., April 12. -- Two men were killed and two wounded in a fight between Sheriff John W. Wright and his Deputies, on one side, and the desperadoes who robbed and murdered aged Mrs. Jemima Hall and her son, on the other. The fight occurred on the mountain top between Boone's Fork and Millstone Creek.

The story of this ring belongs certainly in the category of the truths that are stranger than ficition. Dr. Thode's account of it from the moment it was brought to him by the librarian of St. Mark's to his triumphant discovery of its probable owner, has the inimitable not of personal interest and excitement.

Brevet Brigadier Gen. John Porter Hatch died at his home 202 West One Hundred and Third Street late Friday night. He had suffered for some time from heart disease. He retired early in the evening and was found dead in bed about 11 o'clock.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 13 -- The prize for the best record over the new course, eighteen holes, of the New Haven Golf Club has been won by G.W. Butts, 1902, of Yale, who to-day went over the course in a total of 91 strokes. The first nine holes were done in 42, and the second in 49 strokes.

NEW ORLEANS, April 13 -- Judge Parlange, in the United States Circuit Court to-day handed down a decision dismissing the suit for injunction brought by Boer representatives with a view to preventing the shipment of mules and horses out of New Orleans to the British Army in South Africa.

From The Engineering Magazine. Americans are twenty years in advance of other nations (except Canada) in the art of bridge design and construction. The steel of which a bridge is made represents about half of its cost. Steel is now made in the United States at much less cost than in any other country.
Silver bullion certificates were last quoted on the Stock Exchange at 59 3/4 @ 61. There were no sales.
To the Editor of The Note York Times: Over the signature of John M. Bishop in your issue of Sunday, April 6, appears an article on the battle of Shiloh, April 6 and 7, 1862.

TRENTON, April 13 -- The New Jersey State exhibit for the Buffalo Exposition is being collected on the top floor of the State House, and will be shipped next week, and nearly all of it will be in place by the opening day of the exposition. It is not definitely known just when New Jersey will have her day at the exposition.

A new match for Fire Commissioner John J. Scannell's champion trotting gelding, The Abbot, 2:03 1/4, and George Ketcham's champion stallion. Cresceus, 2:04, has been arranged in part, and in all probability will be completed to-morrow, when the owners will meet in person or by representatives and come to an agreement.

From Ainslee's. One bright Spring afternoon a Chinese official and his little boy called at our home, on Filial Piety Lane, in Peking. Father and son were dressed exactly alike -- boots of black velvet, trousers of blue silk, over which hung a long garment also of blue silk, waistcoat of blue brocade, and skullcap of black satin.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Members of the Senate and the House of Representatives who are here lingering for Spring to arrive in more northern latitudes or for a little patronage to drop into patient laps are wondering why there was any talk about the necessity for a session or the Fifty-seventh Congress earlier than next December.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is announced that the Senate Taxation Committee has reported favorably the Stranahan bill, which imposes a tax of one-half of 1 per cent. upon mortgages except those held by trust companies, State and National banks, educational institutions, building and loan associations, and mortgages securing serial bonds, which are usually mortgages issued by corporations.

J. Novicow in The International Review. Russian thought has become a stagnant pool. The liberals have not to a marked degree the courage of their convictions, nor do the reactionaries dare engage in any too great violence. We live from day to day, and no one knows whither one is tending. It seems even as if people were delighted not to go anywhere.

BOSTON, April 13 -- At the Clearing House money between the banks loaned at 2 1/2 per cent., and was in good supply. New York funds sold at 15c discount for cash. There are call loans outstanding as low as 3 and even 2 1/2 per cent., though new money is quoted at 3 1/2 per cent., and some banks ask as high as 4 per cent.

-- Minnesota's new marriage late, seems to be an attempt, presumably well intentioned, to remedy some very obvious evils in the way long ago suggested by doctors and others who for one reason or another were inclined to view humanity in a scientific and wholly unsentimental manner.

A volume of " Original and Selected Poems" by a member of the Lorillard family is to be found in the shop of a Canal Street dealer. It is a curiosity in literature for many reasons. There is not, and there never was, another copy of it in existence. It is in manuscript, and the flyleaf bears this inscription: " Presented by Mary Lorillard Ronalds to her Father; 1832."

LONDON, April 13 -- The gossips have been alert as usual during holiday week, but on the eve of the reassembling of Parliament no man not actually in the confidence of Sir Michael Hicks-Beach definitely knows anything about the anxiously awaited budget. Speculators assume that a tax on sugar is inevitable, and have been acting accordingly.

No less than six competitors are in the field for the polo championships this coming year. Never before in the history of polo in America have there been so many aspirants for the big tournament of the season. The decision will be made on Tuesday night at the annual meeting of the Polo Association, which will convene in the Metropolitan club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street, New York, Buffalo.

TITLE TO REALTY -- After the death of Jacob Miller, in 1874, certain real estate owned by him, including 544 Second Avenue, was sold at auction, pursuant to the provisions of his will. The purchaser of the Second Avenue premises was Dorcas M. Crampton, (a daughter of the testator, and at the time of the sale the wife of one of the executors named in the will,) she being the highest bidder.
The weekly statement of the New York City banks showed an increase in the surplus reserve of $2,120,225. The banks now hold a surplus of $7,938,200 above the legal requirement.
WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Frank W. Mahin, United States Consul at Reichenberg, Austria, has sent the following report to the State Department:

Dr. L.L. Seaman has just returned from China, whither he went via the Philippine Islapds last Fall. He was during the Spanish war the Major Surgeon in the First Regiment of Engineers, and afterward he was attached to the Seventeenth Infantry in the Philippines. He has spent most of the last three years in the colonies of the United States.

Most readers, we imagine, must have been startled by the announcement made yesterday, that the Park Department had before it a project for the commemoration, in one of the public pleasaunces, of an image, in the form of a bust, of Mr. CHARLES BROADWAY ROUSS.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Bennings meeting closed to-day with the largest crowd ever seen upon the grounds. The racing was good throughout, and Moor, who won the Bennings Spring Handicap, broke the track record for seven furlongs, his time being 1:28 1-5. Last Cord won the Hunters' Steeplechase. The favorites were beaten in each race.

Only a few stocks were active in yesterday's market for outside securities, but prices in a number of cases became firmer. The strength of the Stock Exchange market exercised a favorable influence, and in several issues the gains were substantial. The copper stocks were again the most active issues, further favorable reports in regard to the copper situation bringing them into special prominence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to thank you for the very impartial stand you have taken in condemning certain parts of the revised charter of the Greater New York, and particularly that part which refers to the appropriating of certain amounts of money belonging to our educational fund for the support of private schools, or, as you may call them, private religious schools.

"The Coal Trade." by Frederick E. Saward, editor of The Coal Trade Journal, just issued, has been annually published since 1872. The new issue is, like the others, a valuable work of reference, carefully compiled, and gives full and up-to-date information on production, prices, transportation, and other elements of the trade at home and abroad.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Leaving out of account the refraction effects of the earth's atmosphere, which modify considerably the conclusions, at the equinoxes the circle of illumination on the earth bisects all the parallels of latitude; therefore, at all places daylight and darkness are equal and each equal to twelve hours.

From St. Nicholas. The "automaton chess player" once set all Europe to guessing. Houdin explains this trick. The figure was a Turk, apparently too small to hold a man inside, and it played chess successfully against the best players in the world -- being rarely beaten.

Residents of the fashionable neighborbood in the vicinity of Park Avenue and East Thirty-fourth Street protest against the damage done to their property and health by the blasting connected with the excavation, for the rapid transit tunnel and the station which is to be located at that point.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The revised charter which has been sent to Mayor Van Wyck for his formal action is a thing of shreds and patches, so far as those provisions which are rated to be honest and well-intentioned are concerned. These lack consistency and are not proportioned one to the other.
The following is the programme arranged by Mr. David Bispham for his second popular recital this afternoon, in Caruegie Hall, at 3:30, when he will be assisted by Mr. Rudolf von Scarpa.

HALIFAX, N.S., April 13 -- According to a Chariottetown (Prince Edward Island) newspaper, Bishop Frederick Courtney of Halifax requested the rector of St. Peters Episcopal Church, Chariottetown, (the Rev. James Simpson) to discontinue certain ritualistic practices, and it is further stated that the request has not been complied with.

Churchmen and laymen yesterday, continued to discuss the controversy that has resulted from the ritual observed in the consecration of the Venerable Reginald Heber Weller, Jr., as Bishop Coadjutor of the Diocese of Fond du Lac, Wis. Ministers of the Protestant Episcopal Church seen yesterday were not unanimous in condemning the seven Bishops who participated in the consecration offices, and the opinion was expressed that they had acted clearly within their rights.

The rejection of the Platt amendment by the Cuban Constitutional Convention would be matter for more serious consideration in this country if the members of the convention were or felt that they were the representatives of public opinion in Cuba. They have the credentials -- nobody can dispute that.
GLASGOW, April 13 -- It has been provisionally arranged that the cup challenger will have her first trial with the Shamrock I., either in the Solent or outside the Isle of Wight. May 4.

J.A.R. Marriot in The Fortnightly Review. In the opinion of many most competent to judge, Fenianism was not primarily an Irish movement. Organized mainly in America, and directed largely from Paris, it never attained a real hold upon the mass of the Irish peasants. Unlike most Irish agitation it was essentially urban in character, finding its most congenial soil among the Irish population of the great towns of England and America.

The Board of Classification of the United States General Appraisers yesterday announced a decision regarding the levying of duties upon material used in the construction of the International Bridge across the Niagara River The merchandise imported was dressed stone, which was assessed at 50 per cent ad valorem.

FLUSHING, L.I., April 13 -- Only three men of the new West Side Athletic Club of New York appeared for the game scheduled in the Amateur Athletic Union's Metropolitan Association championship tournament to-night, and declining to compete with so short a team, the West Side men withdrew and forfeited their remaining games in the tournament.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the Washington correspondence of your newspaper, issue of last Sunday, appeared reference to a flag on exhibition in the National Museum at Washington, which is represented to be the flag used on board the United States ship Bon Homme Richard in the battle with her British Majesty's ship Serapis off Flamborough Head, Sept. 23, 1779.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 2 -- There have been two rumors here during the past week connected with Franco-Russian relations. Of these rumors, one concerns the French Bonapartists, The report has once more been revived that Gen. Prince Louis Napoleon will be formally proclaimed leader of the Bonapartist Party and claimant of the French throne, in place of his brother, Prince Victor, who will definitely abandon all his claims as head of the Bonapartes.

In the closing days of April a number of visitors from the North will go to Hampton for the annual Spring exercises, to Winston, N.C., for the annual conference, and afterward to Tuskeegee, Ala. These visits are of the greatest interest to those taking part in them, and ought to be of essential service in spreading a vivid and accurate impression of what is doing in the way of education at the South.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The case of Sergt. J.H. Helms of the Marine Corps. who recently was recommended by Capt. Rockwell of the flagship Chicago for a medal of honor and a gratuity as a reward for rescuing Ishi Tomizi, a warrant officers' cook, from drowning in the harbor of Montevideo last January, developed an interesting correspondence which has just been made public.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The President, Mrs. McKinley and party will leave Washington by the Southern Railway Monday morning, April 29, at 10:30 o'clock, for a tour to the Pacific Coast and return, covering a period of between six and seven weeks. They will have a train consisting of a private car for the President and Mrs. McKinley, two Pullman compartment cars, two Pullman sleepers, a dining car and a combination car.

NEWPORT, April 13. -- A large number of the cottagers spent to-night here, and many of them attended the performance of "The Girl from Maxim's " at the Opera House. Mrs. Charles M. Oelrichs gave a dinner this evening.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 13 -- This aftercon at 3 o'clock John J. Griffin, commercial agent of the Norfolk and Western Railroad Company, was shot to death in the rooms of Barnard B. Evans in this city. The arrest of Evans subsequently created a pronounced sensation.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 13 -- Harvard's baseball team played the first game on her Southern trip here this afternoon, defeating Virginia 8 to 5. The game was played in a drizzling rain, though this did not prevent a good exhibition by both teams. Harvard played with dash, and only errors at critical points cost them several of Virginia's runs.

Two more of the local bowling leagues completed their schedules during the past week. In the Royal Arcanum tournament of the Borough of the Bronx, Suburban Council won first place, with Morrisania, Fordham, and Bronx Councils tied for second, third, and fourth places. Claremont Council was fifth, King's Bridge sixth, and Free Will seventh.
No 53 Pitt Street, for a six-story brick flat, 22 by $6.4; Max Goldberg of 140 Stanton Street, owner; Kurtzer Rohl, architects; cost. $17,000.
Mrs. Anna Martha Reiss announces the engagement of her daughter Katharine to Mr. Frank Paul of New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In view of Mr. Fermin's letter in this morning's TIMES a few additional points on the present Pharmacy law of this State and of the effort that is being made to modify the worst phases of it will no doubt be of interest to your readers.

From Chambers's Journal. Ancient Indian coins display great variety. Besides gold, silver, and copper coins, there have been found in various parts of the country coins of brass, nickel, tin, and lead. Even at the beginning of the nineteenth century articles other than orthodox coin passed current.

The musical season drags its slow length along, loath to die. It has been an extraordinary season in many ways. It has introduced to this public more new performers and more new works than are usually heard in one Winter. Such Winters make music lovers regret that Mr. Krehbiel abandoned the publication of his invaluable "Review of the New York Musical Season."

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Frank H. Mason, Consul General of the United States at Berlin, reports an improvement in the incandescent gas light mantle which is said to be of the highest importance. The inventor, or discoverer, rather, is Rudolph Langhans, an Austrian engineer. Almost endless experiments have been made with the hope of strengthening the mantles, which are an ashlike structure.

SIMLA, March 14 -- I have alluded once or twice in recent letters to the scarcity which has again overtaken parts of Bombay Presidency, owing to the failure of the Autumn rains. Gujerat, hitherto the most favored and fertile of provinces, and on this account the one least able to bear up against the strain of famine, will again suffer severely.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 13 -- E. Wetherbee's new steam yacht, now under construction at Robert Jacob's yards here, from designs of Gary, Smith Barbey, is rapidly progressing. The yacht has been planked and caulked, and the inside fittings will be next in order.

BALTIMORE, April 13 -- The local market to-day was rather dull and featureless. Seaboards continued to yield fractionally, the reduction in buying demand being the chief explanation. A change of sentiment at this point is expected soon, because brokers are advising their clients that the stocks are a good buy at prevailing figures.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is surprising that some or those who clearly recognize the truth that any tax whatever upon mortgages is shifted to the borrower are ready to accept the Stranahan measure as a compromise on existing conditions. The letter of Charles A. Miller of Utica is an indication of this.
Ohio papers are proudly saying of Gen. Funston: "Another Ohio-born man."

From The Review of Reviews. I know from personal observation that our cousins across the water do not prescribe or swallow one-fourth as much medicine as we do in our country. With but few exceptions, the entire vegetable and mineral kingdoms have given us little of specific value; but still, up to the present day the bulk of our books on materia medica is made up of a description of many valueless drugs and preparations.

With much that was said and done at the conference of the Association of Catholic Colleges which has just closed its sessions at Chicago all reasonable men of whatever religious belief must be in entire sympathy. One of the main objects of the Catholic instructors at the conference was to arouse interest among the churches in the movement for the establishment of high schools as a connecting link between the parochial schools and the colleges.

Augustine Birrell in The Century. The first tiling that strikes you about Cologne Cathedral is its glorious profusion, its boundless wealth. There is so much of everything. Bricks and mortar were never so multiplied, magnified, and glorified. I should like to see the original specifications. It is more than a building; it is a city by itself.
WASHINGTON, April 13. -- Commissioner Rockhill has presented to the Envoys at Peking the American plan for lumping the indemtities and keeping them down to $200,000,000 or less.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- Franklin Simmons, the sculptor who made the statue of Gen. John A. Logan, just unveiled here, conies to his own defense in reply to the many criticisms made of the tablet on his latest work that assembles with bold disregard of history several public men to witness and participate in the ceremonies of the Senate at the time that Logan was sworn into office.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The exact status of the Isthmian canal negotiations is as follows: After the -- adjournment of the Senate and the lapse of the pending Hay Pauncefote treaty, Secretary Hay decided to pursue the subject further. But to avoid the possibility of another failure, for the same reasons which brought about the loss of the Hay-Pauncefote treaty, the Secretary determined to reverse the usual method of procedure in framing treaties.

As the result of the conference yesterday and late Friday night at the Fifth Avenue Hotel of Senator Platt, Gov. Odell, and other Republican State leaders the indications are that the amended charter for Greater New York will be passed in its present form, regardless of any action that may be taken by Mayor Van Wyck.

From The Spectator. Police prevention is not perfect, though it does much, for if it were perfect there would be no assassinations, and there are. The problem is therefore to prevent a man in the street from reaching the King either by bombshell, bullet, or knife, and experience shows that it is nearly, if not quite, insoluble.

The cornerstone of the new Hall of Records was laid yesterday. The ceremonies began shortly after noon, when a committee of the Hull of Records Association called on Randolph Guggenheimer. President of the Municipal Council, in the City Hall, and presented him with a handsome silver trowel to be used at the laying of the cornerstone.

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The State Department allowed it to be known to-day that its confidence in Mr. Loomis is entirely undisturbed by the alleged interview with him at San Juan, Porto Rico. The department does not believe that Mr. Loomis said the things he is credited with saying.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The comments of a member of the Brooklyn Board of Education concerning the excessive salaries of school teachers, published in a recent issue of THE TIMES, were right to the point. Fifteen years ago, when calories were considerably lower than at present, the number of applicants for vacant positions were greater than the vacancies.

LONDON, April 13 -- Further borrowings from the banks have relieved the stringency somewhat. Discounts were steady. Business on the Stock Exchange to-day was quiet. Funds were higher, and high-class securities were fairly steady. Dealings are not expected to broaden until the Budget statement.

BERLIN, April 13 -- Miss Melville of Brooklyn, N.Y., has appeared here semi-publicly, with a quintet, rendering her own compositions, which have been highly praised. Miss Melville is a pupil of Prof. Boies of Berlin. Mrs. Powel Webster of Brooklyn, after a successful debut, has been engaged for five years for the Royal Berlin Opera.

BUFFALO, N.Y., April 13 -- David B. Hill addressed the members of the Jefferson Club and their guests at the Teck Theatre to-night. His theme was "Thomas Jefferson." Admission was by ticket, and every available seat was occupied. On the platform with ex-Senator Hill, besides men prominent in the ranks of the Democratic Party of this city, were Frederick Cook of Rochester and Albert E. Hoyt of Albany.

Two hundred and seventeen members of the New York East Conference were present at the opening of the fourth session yesterday morning. A vote was to be taken on the admission of applicants for Deacon's orders, and some discussion arose over the matter.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- The annual convention of the American Academy of Political and Social Science came to an end to-night. At to-day's sessions one of the principal papers read was by Senator Platt of Connecticut, who discussed the conditions in Cuba. He said in part:

Within the past week H.A. Pressey, who is in charge of part of the field work of the United States Geological Survey in the East, spent a day in driving over the lower valley of the Passaic River, in New Jersey, to make a preliminary investigation in connection with the pollution of the river by sewage and other impurities.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- Higher prices for Cambria, Bethlehem, and Pennsylvania Steel shares, the highest in fact in many months, stimulated a decided broadening interest in Philadelphia. All the coalers were in demand at higher prices. Choctaw common recovered its dividend, while the preferred gained one-half of it.

From The Chautauquan. The Andrian husbandman lays up his terrace and leads his little aqueduct to water it. When he has got his footing, so to speak, in one little shelf of soil or a dozen of them, he plants his olive, fig, and vine, his bit of barley or wheat, his patch of onions, potatoes, and beans.

Gen. Daniel Butterfield was stricken with paralysis of the right side at his home, 616 Fifth Avenue, Friday morning while in bed. Since then, with the exception of one brief interval, he has been utterly helpless, physically, though his mind is perfectly clear, and as late as yesterday afternoon he dictated a number of business letters to his secretary.
Mayor Van Wyck heard protests against the new charter at a public hearing held yesterday. Two speakers favored certain sections of the charter, and a dozen others made bitter attacks on the bill.
Mrs. David Short, wife of one of the defendants in the Rice will ease, last night gave out a statement which is in part as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, April 13. -- An immense armor-plate plant is now nearing completion at Eddystone, thirteen miles from this city. This plant, which is practically an extension of Krupp'c German gun works, is known as the Gruson Iron Works, and will manufacture the coast defenses known as Gruson rotating turrets.

From The Westminster Review. And how is a foreigner to guess that a word of three syllables spelled "business" should be pronounced "biz-ness"? It is not such words as these the pronunciation of which constitutes the hallmark of the classes. The most familiar of all these is the inevitable word "girl."

WASHINGTON, April 13 -- The Controller of the Treasury has reaffirmed a decision of his office disallowing a claim for $629 from Lieut. Col. J.W. Jacobs, Deputy Quartermaster General. The original decision of the Controller on June 30, 1899, disallowed the amount for the reason that it was "extended without authority of law for subsistence, wines, and liquors, furnished foreign military attaches accompanying the army into the field."

To the Editor of The New York Times: During the past year or two it has come to be the habit of an occasional Englishman, and once in a while an English-Irishman -- a quaint bird, that -- to invite discussion in THE TIMES on the Irish question, and at a time, too, mind you, when England's own troubles might be deemed ample to occupy all their attention.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 13 -- The Directors of the Kentucky Trotting Horse Breeders' Association met to-day and arranged for the stakes to be decided at the Fall meeting. There are fourteen stakes besides the great match races between The Abbot and Boralma and Cresceus and Charley Herr, the former being for $30,000 and the latter for $7,000.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., April 13 -- The holdings of the Lookout Mountain Line and Lulu Lake Railroad Company, including two inclines, Point Hotel, electric line on top of the mountain, and a broad-gauged road upon the mountain, were transferred to-day to Clarence P. King and associates of Philadelphia.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to comment on the statement made by your correspondent "M.T. R." in his plea against municipal ownership. He says: "Across the water, where municipal ownership has been experimented with more largely than in this country, we learn that venal politicians have succeeded in keeping themselves in power in some cases almost indefinitely by promises of increased wages, shorter hours, and other advantages.

From Good Words. The death watch (Anobium domesticum) sometimes plays havoc among the books especially where they are little used and comprise some of the good old sort, leather-bound, with thick, heavy boards. But not only may the bindings be attacked; the more important reading may suffer also.

Haskins Sells, the certified public accountants of this city, who have been examining the municipal books of Chicago, have issued another statement. The firm was employed by the Merchants' Club of Chicago and practically completed its work on March 21, when a report was transmitted to a special committee of the club.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I beg leave to comment on the statement made by your correspondent "M.T. R." in his plea against municipal ownership. He says: "Across the water, where municipal ownership has been experimented with more largely than in this country, we learn that venal politicians have succeeded in keeping themselves in power in some cases almost indefinitely by promises of increased wages, shorter hours, and other advantages.

It is not Wall Street's fault that Wall Street has not been blue this week. Ample efforts have been exerted to bring about a condition of depression and distress. There have been crowding "arguments" predicated upon gold exports, money market squeezes, foreign war complications -- the list of prophesied disturbances is too long for recital.

ALBANY, April 13 -- C.P. Williams, the successful bidder for the State Department printing last year, has issued a circular in which he charges that the State Printing Board did not award him the contract, although he was the lowest bidder, until he had promised in writing to sub-let the contract to a man to be afterward named.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 13 -- The links of the Golf Club of Lakewood presented a lively appearance to-day, for the largest field of competitors of the Spring season played in the open handicap, which was won by W.D. Stockly in a net score of 78 from 12 strokes handicap. W.H. Davis, however, won the best score prize, making the excellent record of 86 for the course.

Some unknown cause frightened a big bay horse attached to a hansom cab in which a man and woman were being driven up Broadway shortly after 9 o'clock last night. The beast got the bit between his teeth at Twenty-fourth Street, and for the next seven blocks there was the liveliest runaway that the Tenderloin has had in some weeks.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 13 -- Pleasure Bay will be in different hands this year. The Avenel Hotel, which had been in charge of the Atlantic Coast Railway Company ever since that company has been running trolley cars there, has leased the place, and it is said that the vaudeville and other entertainments associated with it in past seasons will be dropped.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In contrast to the prevailing superficial, hysterical, and flippant metropolitan journalism your columns are conducted, as a rule, on such a sane, logical, and educational basis that it really grieves me to find inconsistencies which fairly baffle one's common sense.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reply to several articles that have appeared during the last few days in the correspondent columns of our local papers. I beg to submit to our operagoing public the following:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The most admirable feature in the conduet of your influential journal, in my opinion, is its rare quality of fairness. Unlike the most of your contemporaries, you are willing to allow in the space devoted to correspondence an expression of views entirely antagonistic to those advocated in your editorial columns.

From The Contemporary Review. In mediaeval times each soldier took what he could, and kept what he took. If any question arose it was decided by the commander on the battlefield or by the Court of Chivalry. Sometimes a special commission issued to determine nice points. By a development, the steps of which need not here be retraced, it became recognized that prize captured on land or at sea was the King's property.

Capt. Lantry of the East Fifty-first Street Station, walking through East Fifty-first Street late yesterday afternoon, saw a man sketching the plan of the outside rear part of the W.H. Vanderbilt mansion at Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue. The home is now occupied by Mrs. W.D. Sioane.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The paramount question which confronts the City and State of New York is how best to hold the ebb and flow of the commerce of the mighty West and Northwest through this State and port to and from the markets of the Old World, and at the same time augment farming, manufactures, industrial, financial, and realty interests of this great Commonwealth.

When Mr. NAGLE was appointed Commissioner of Street Cleaning he promised to maintain the standard established by Col. WARING and to keep the streets clean, for the reason that it was good politics to do so. In his first official declaration he dwelt at length upon the obligation he was under to satisfy the public expectation in this respect for the good of the organization he represented.

LONDON, April 13 -- The friends of the American jockeys now in England are so far badly disappointed at the season's work. Not a single American appeared at Leicester yesterday. L Reiff has lost fifteen out of twenty races. J. Reiff thirty-one out of thirty-six, and Maher, sixteen out of twenty.

From The Westminster Review. The Blue Mountains range along its centre, with caps lost in the clouds, shoulders mantled with forest trees of huge dimensions, while shrubs of Jamaican individuality skirt the feet. Pasture land is verdant with guinea grass, growing wild, and to the height of five or six feet, a rich sustaining food for the cattle.

If the carefully laid plans of Nils J. Rose. Superintendent of Landscape Gardening, do not miscarry, and it is not likely that they will, New York parks and public grounds will be more pleasing to the eye this year than during any previous season. The work of preparation has covered the entire Winter, and already an earnest has been given, in the Spring exhibition at the Central Park Conservatories.

Harry Pipp, thirty-eight years old, keeps a roadhouse at Unionport Road and Morris Park Avenue, Westchester. He had a wife about thirty-five years old, of whom he was very jealous and on whom he had kept a strict watch of late. They lived next door to, the roadhouse. He had been drinking when he went into his house from his bar-room at 11:30 o'clock last night.

When Mr. NAGLE was appointed Commissioner of Street Cleaning he promised to maintain the standard established by Col. WARING and to keep the streets clean, for the reason that it was good politics to do so. In his first official declaration he dwelt at length upon the obligation he was under to satisfy the public expectation in this respect for the good of the organization he represented.

LONDON, April 13 -- The friends of the American jockeys now in England are so far badly disappointed at the season's work. Not a single American appeared at Leicester yesterday. L Reiff has lost fifteen out of twenty races. J. Reiff thirty-one out of thirty-six, and Maher, sixteen out of twenty.

BERLIN, April 13 -- The correspondent of The Associated Press hears to-night from an authoritative source that the Chinese indemnities for war expenses, exclusive of the claims of private individuals and missions, have been fixed as follows:

Ex-Register Hugh McLaughlin, leader of the Kings County Democracy, returned home from Florida last evening, and said some caustic things relative to the revised charter and other matters of public interest. Mr. McLaughlin "roasted" those responsible for some of the charter changes, and also took occasion to remark that he had not changed his opinion of ex-Chief of Police Devery.

PATERSON, N.J., April 14 -- The belief that Peter Paquillo was killed by another than his brother Sabbatto, who is under arrest, is growing into a certainty. When Sabbatto was arraigned he admitted that he killed his brother, but a little daughter of the dead man said her uncle did not fire the fatal shot.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 14 -- The Coroner's jury this afternoon rendered a verdict that to the best of its belief the death of Capt. J.J. Griffin, who was found dying in the rooms of Major B.B. Evans yesterday, was caused by a gunshot wound inflicted at the hands of Major Evans. The news of the tragedy excited intense interest over the State.

The Women's Executive Committee of their Metropolitan Association is to meet on Wednesday to make up the list of team competitions, arid it is Quite probable that he links will be selected for the coming women's championship, which will be played in June. Entries for the women's team championships close to-day.

Robert Monrce, thirty-nine years old, a theatrical manager, living at 205 East Fourteenth Street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital yesterday afternoon, suffering from a gunshot wound in the thigh. The wound is not dangerous.

H.T. Bosman of Hongkong, accompanied by his wife and servant, is staying at the Waldorf-Astoria. No one would suspect Mr. Bosnian's identity from reading his autograph, which appears in a bold English hand upon the register; indeed, it is hard to realize even after meeting him that he is an Asiatic in blood as well as by birth, although he has all the physical characteristics of the Oriental.
LONDON, April 14 -- Queen Alexandra arrived in London last evening from Copenhagen.

LONDON, April 14 -- Our money market remains in the dark about its future, and the past week, therefore, has been devoid of interesting movements. All minds are turned toward budget day, and dealers in credit are cautious in accepting commitments, save on their own terms, until they see what taxes are to be imposed and how much additional debt is to be raised.

The announcement by William Brookfield that he intends to inject a new element into the coming municipal campaign and his attack on the present Republican County Committee have awakened the liveliest kind of interest among politicians of both the dominant parties. Mr. Brookfield enjoys the confidence of that class of Republicans and independents who do not mingle with matters political for "revenue only."

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 14 -- James Tobin shot and probably fatally wounded his wife Bridget this afternoon. Then he called a cab, took her to a physician's, and then to the hospital. The woman says the shooting was not accidental; her husband claims it was.

For the first time since they were organized, the principal building trades unions in this city decided yesterday to go into politics and to start an independent labor party. This decision was reached at a meeting of delegates from twenty-one unions represented in the Board of Walking Delegates, held yesterday afternoon in Ledwith's Hall, Forty-fifth Street and Third Avenue, Philip Weinseimer of the Amalgamated Society of Plumbers and Gasfitters presiding.

LONDON, April 15 -- Sir Edward William Watkin, ex-Chairman of the Southeastern Railway, the Manchester, Sheffield and Lincolnshire Railway, and the Metropolitan and East London Railway, died yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 14 -- Secretary Root is so well pleased with the success of his scheme for barring out callers by locking the door and admitting only those who are acquainted with a certain cipher knock that he now has the doors locked at 2 o'clock instead of 3.

BOSTON, Mass., April 14 -- The lake yacht Illinois, which was launched about ten days ago at Lawley's yard, has not been shipped to Chicago. It was expected that she would be shipped last Friday, but it seems that she has not been altogether satisfactory. She was given several trials and carried a lee helm.

Some time this week there will be a very lively time in the elephant house In Central Park. William Snyder, the keeper of the two big elephants. Julie and Tom, which are comined there, is making preparations to perform his regular Spring work as a chiropodist on the two elephants, and he is looking forward with dread to the work of pruning their big toenails, which he intends to do this week.

MANCHESTER, April 14 -- The sluggish fluctuations in cotton continue to dislocate business in this market. Indian buyers are holding off, awaiting the progress of events rather than anticipating their wants. Unless there is an increase in buying soon the looms will be idle in the Blackburn district.

The three members of the Faculty of the School of Pedagogy of the New York University who resigned from their professorships a few days ago issued a statement yesterday in which they characterize certain action of Chancellor Henry M. MacCracken and members of the University Council as "unjust and unwarranted," and in which intimation is made of neglect of duty on the part of the Chancellor.
West Farms, in the Bronx, had a fire early this morning which destroyed several buildings, threatened to burn down the village, and caused two alarms to be sent in.
One Newfoundland dog yesterday gained a wholesome respect for cats of sufficiently high social standing to ride in automobiles.

LONDON, April 14 -- Activity on the Stock Exchange last week was practically confined to the American department and the mining markets. There is a general impression that it would be advisable to await the forthcoming budget statement before entering upon fresh transactions. The markets on the whole keep firm in spite of the limited dealings and of the settlement, which passed off without excitement.

The Democrats who are opposed to Tammany Hall's domination in municipal affairs have called a mass meeting at Carnegie Hall for Thursday next, when steps will be taken for the formation of an organization which will represent the sentiments and aspirations of the Democracy of the metropolis.

ALBANY, April 14 -- Gov. Odell returned to Albany this evening. He said he had nothing to say about the charter. He does not regard it as proper for him to discuss the bill in advance of its coming to him for his action.

The open handicap cross country run of the Shamrock Harriers, held over the Jerome Avenue course yesterday afternoon, proved the largest and most interesting event of the kind which has been witnessed this season. There were some sixty starters, of whom forty-five finished, and thirty-two prizes, including fifteen team medals, were awarded.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 14 -- The much-discussed absorption of the Tennessee Coal and Iron Company by the United States Steel Corporation is believed to be a fact here. All denials are that "the trust has not absorbed the company."

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 -- The Record to-morrow will say: "The famous 'hat trimmings' cases, involving about $20,000,000, and which since 1884 has been the subject of bitter legal battle between the Government and a number of importers, have at last been settled.

"Did Funston do Right?" was the subject of a sermon preached last night in the Westminster Presbyterian Church, Clinton Street and First Place, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Frederick Campbell. After praising the courage, the heroism, and motives of Gen. Funston in the expedition which resulted in the capture of Aguinaldo, the Fillplno chieftain, the preacher severely criticised the methods employed to make a prisoner of the leader of the insurrectionists.

-- We are in receipt of a holographic -- that's such a good word! -- of a holographic letter from Mr. JOHN CARROLL LATHROP, the "Second Reader" of the new Eddyite temple on Central Park West, and in it -- the letter -- Mr. LATHROP presents what he says are the exact facts in regard to the cornerstone miracle described by him to gaping multitudes the day the temple was opened.

The colloquial use of the term "trust" to designate the merger of manufacturing properties is misleading. The combinations in which all classes of the American public are at the moment more interested than in any other one thing are not trusts, but actual and practically irrevocable mergers.
So far as a money indemnity is con- cerned, the suggestion made in Peking by the American Commissioner is sound enough, but there is practically little reason to hope that it will be adopted.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 14 -- While leading to pasture a cow, which he had just taken in trade for a horse. Matthew Eganey of Dunellen was severely gored this afternoon.

The announcement made on behalf of the women of New York by Miss HELEN VARICK BOSWELL at the recent meeting of the Republican Club is calculated to awaken grave apprehension among those who are hopeful of redeeming New York from the disgrace and damage of Tammany control.

PEKING, April 14 -- Komoura Yutaro, the Japanese Minister, accompanied by Gen. Yamaguchi, the Japanese commander, recently called upon Prince Ching and notified him that the return of Emperor Kwang-Su to Peking was urgently desired. Prince Ching was informed that the Emperor's wishes would be respected by the foreign troops and that every courtesy would be shown him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has occurred to me that one of the exceptional opportunities that come to nations, as to individuals, presents itself just at this time to the several powers whose representatives are wrestling with the problem of "indemnity."

Two men supposed to be George T. Buckley and P.J. Sweeney of Scranton, Penn., were found unconscious from the effects of illuminating gas in a room in the Ashland House early yesterday morning, and died in spite of all efforts to save them. Both are believed to have been employes of the Delaware and Lackawanna Railroad Company, because both had passes over that road in their possession.

Saturday's bank statement disposed of a long list of dismal Wall Street forecasts, professional speculators for a fall having been sure that Clearing House surplus reserves were to be still further impaired if not wholly extinguished; and upon this theory short interest in the market had been much extended.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Col. James G. Berret, ex-Mayor of Washington and one of its best-known citizens, died here today, aged eighty-six years. He was a native of Baltimore and had been twice a member of the Maryland Legislature, and in 1858 and in 1860 was elected Mayor of Washington as a Democrat.

Edward Eastman of 101 First Street, one of the two men shot by James Donovan, a Bowery saloon keeper and ex-convict, in "Silver Dollar" Smith's salon at 64 Essex Street on Saturday night, died in the Gouverneur Hospital yesterday. The shot which struck the other man, Samuel Frankel, was stopped by his watch and he was only slightly wounded.

BERLIN, April 14 -- The American situation engaged extraordinary attention on the Boerse last week. There was a sharp fall at the beginning of the week, responding to New York; the loss was not recovered.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is such an unusual occurrence for a rich man to espouse the cause of justice that the country at large is to be congratulated upon the election of Tom L. Johnson as Mayor of Cleveland.

"It is felt here," says the New York correspondent of The London Times in a dispatch to his newspaper, "that nothing ever so discredited the United States as Mr. CLEVELAND'S handling "of the Venezuela matter."

BOSTON, April 15 -- Ever since the publication of the sail plan of the yacht Independence, experts have been discussing the chances of the local cup candidate. To those who examined closely into the plans of the hull, made public some weeks ago, the figures which make known the enormous sail spread which the yacht will carry came hardly in the nature of a surprise.

MANILA, April 15 -- The trial of Commissary Sergeant John Meston, charged with complicity in the commissary frauds, is finished. No verdict was announced, and Meston's conviction is uncertain. Other trials of those implicated will follow.

LONDON, April 16 -- The British newspapers and magazines, commenting upon the alternating periods of hope and apprehension which characterize the later stages of the South African campaign, compare these with the later stages of the American War of Independence, as though to emphasize these fluctuations.

LONDON, April 15 -- Money was in good supply to-day and easier, owing to the recent borrowings from the Bank of England and Government disbursements. Uncertainty prevails as to the market's ability to repay the borrowings. Discounts were easier. There is much uncertainty regarding the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- In the United States Supreme Court an opinion was handed down to-day in the case of Fairbank vs. the United States. The case involved the constitutionality of the war revenue law j imposing a tax upon export bills of lading. The court decided against the Government, holding that provision of the law unconstitutional.

This is a story of a wicked woman and her new frock. The frock was to be trimmed with passementerie, but it must be passementerie of just such and such a kind, and, above all, it must have a touch of heliotrope in it. The woman looked all over town, but no passementerie which was "so and so" and had the "bit of heliotrope" in it could be found.

BERLIN, April 15 -- Herr von Wildenbruch's drama, "Der General Feldoberst," (The Field Marshal General,) was enthusiastically received at its premiere last evening in Weimar. The Grand Duke warmly congratulated the poet. Emperor William has forbidden a performance in Berlin, because the play shows one of his ancestors to a disadvantage.

BALTIMORE, April 15 -- The market today disclosed a decidedly improved tone, the general movement, though slow, being obviously upward. Cotton Duck took the lead. Prevailing rumors about the absorption of more mills and the known advantages to be derived from the compacting of the management have bought the stock into ready demand, the advance since last week being quite conspicuous.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- "The Carnegie of civil service reform has not come," said William Dudley Foulke of Indiana, Chairman of a committee of investigation of the National Civil Service Reform League, in a conversation to-day. He said that President Harrison put off until near the close of his Administration the inclusion of the free delivery offices in the classified service.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- A telegram received here announces the death to-day, at St. Augustine, Fla., of Gen. A.C. McClurg, head of the publishing house of A.C. McClurg Co. Gen. McClurg's health began to fail a year ago, and during last Winter he went to Palm Beach, Fla., later removing to St. Augustine, where his death occurred.

FLUSHING, L.I., April 15 -- The basket ball contests for the Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union championship continued to-night in the armory of the Seventeenth Separate Company. The first game of the night was between the Seventeenth Separate Company team and the Mohawk Athletic Club team, composed of the school boys of Flushing.

A story was circulated yesterday to the effect that the securities stolen from the Manhattan Savings Bank in the great burglary perpetrated in that institution in 1878, when $11,000 in cash and $2,747,700 in securities, mostly Government bonds, were taken from the vaults and never recovered, were in this city and would be delivered to the officials of the bank for a small consideration.

NEWPORT, R.I., April 15 -- The Regatta Committee of the Newport Yacht Racing Association, consisting of Ralph N. Ellis, Woodbury Kane, and A. Cass Canfield, are at work arranging for the season's yachting fixtures off Newport.

PHILADELPHIA, April 13 -- As was the case Saturday, the market to-day was dominated by the steel stocks. Enormous trading took place in Cambria, while Bethlehem and Pennsylvania Steel common were dealt in extensively. The first named lost considerable ground after a buoyant opening.

A tax bill urged in the Senate with great pertinacity is that introduced by Senator STRANAHAN, now known as No. 1,515. It "amends the tax law in relation to the taxation of mortgage indebtedness." It is novel in principle, complicated in method, and wholly objectionable.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The United State Supreme Court, through Chief Justice Fuller, to-day issued an order granting leave to file a motion for a rule against the Circuit Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit to permit the filing of an appeal in that court from a decision of the Supreme Court of Hawaii in the Wilders Steamship Company case.

AMHERST, Mass., April 15 -- President Harris announced several gifts to Amherst College at chapel to-day. The donations include one of $50,000 to the endowment fund, the names of givers not being revealed; $3,500 to the scholarship fund of the current year, from alumni; $800 for cases in the Appleton cabinet, and $100 scholarship from the class of 1900.

CHICAGO, April 15 -- Roswell Miller, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul Railroad Company, asserted to-day that the negotiations looking to the purphase of his company by James J. Hill were off and would not be renewed, and that there was no doubt Hill had obtained control of the Burlington.
ROME, April 15 -- At the secret consistory held to-day, Archbishop Martinelli, the Papal Delegate in the United States was preconized a Cardinal.
