PARIS, April 16 -- A dispatch received here from Rome says the Pope, at yesterday's consistory, spoke of the French law against religious associations, dwelling on the inconsistency of a country which proclaimed liberty for all while refusing even the existence of associations whose members made a profession of practicing the precepts of the Gospel.

Much uneasiness is felt abroad concerning the steady decline in British securities. The shrinkage has been practically continuous since the early part of 1898, and has been especially accelerated since March, 1899. Consols, which, unlike United States bonds, are a speculative as well as an investment feature, have declined nearly 19 points from their highest price of 114, and are fluctuating feebly between 95 and 96.

An expert witness in the Eighth Municipal Court Judge Steiner sitting, took off his shoes yesterday in order to demonstrate that he was telling the truth. His testimony evidently carried weight, as it resulted in a verdict of $208 against George Carpenter, a real estate dealer, the amount being the purchase price of a single pair of shoes.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- Louis Herzog was surprised by the terms of the will of James J. McComb specifying that he was to marry Fanny McComb. When seen at his father's residence to-day he said: "I do not care to speak of Mr. McComb's will further than to acknowledge that I am the man mentioned.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 15 -- Spring football practice began at Yale to-day, when the full squad of backs, centre, and end rushes reported to Capt. Charles Gould. About seventy men have been enrolled, and will be given work for a month on the 'Varsity gridiron by members of last year's team.
NEWPORT, April 15 -- Mrs. Theodore A. Havemeyer, who has let her villa, has decided to spend the Summer here, and has rented a cottage.
SHANGHAI, April 16 -- Advices from Sian-Foo to the local Mandarins assert that the Court is preparing to go to Sian-Yang, in the province of Hu-Pe.

The amount of damage which is being done by blasting along the line of the subway is sufficiently great to demand attention from the contractor, who is likely to have considerable claims to settle before the work is finished. We do not think that the sub-contractors are careless, or at least not especially so.
ALBANY, April 15 -- The Senate to-night received from Gov. Odell the appointment of Henry H. Lyman as State Excise Commissioner, to succeed himself. He was immediately confirmed.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- The Chinese Minister has returned from Atlantic City, and was at the State Department to-day in conference with Secretary Hay. The Minister is somewhat concerned over the delay in bringing about a final adjustment of Chinese affairs, and also over the reports that the indemnities reach a very large figure, which, he fears, will be beyond the ability of China to meet.

In the outside market yesterday copper was practically the only active group. Most of the issues which recently have held places of most prominence were more or less neglected and showed relatively small totals at the end of the day. Trading in the copper stocks was lively, and several of the group showed marked strength.

Alexander E. Orr, President of the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners, replied yesterday to the three questions propounded by Albert L. Johnson in regard to the pending amendment to the Rapid Transit act of 1894. Mr. Johnson's questions were as follows:

ALBANY, April 15 -- Considerable opposition developed to-night in the Assembly to the Costello Compromise Employers' Liability bill on final passage. Mr. Hyman of New York moved to strike out. The bill, he said, did not explain anything and it was not wanted by organized labor.

While the Governor and his conservative friends and advisers are about the work of cutting bad things out of the amended charter, they would do well to apply the knife to Section 1,089, giving special privileges to a part of the graduates of the New York City Normal College.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Juvenal and Pliny are the only writers of antiquity who give the symbolic language of the thumb in words so plain as to be unmistakable.

At the opening of the fifth day's session of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday a resolution condemning the Raines law and requesting the Legislature of this State to repeal it was introduced by the Rev. T.L. Poulson and passed without discussion. The resolution follows:

All the Alaska trading and navigation companies have been consolidated into two organizations, giving them a monopoly of the commercial wharfage, trading, and navigation in the Yukon, Klondike, and Cape Nome gold regions.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., April 15 -- Daniel C. French, the designer of the Garfield Memorial in Fairmount Park, Philadelphia; the Richard M. Hunt Memorial in Central Park, New York, and many other monuments, will receive a commission from the Lawton Monument Association to construct a memorial to Gen. Henry W. Lawton, who was killed in the Philippines.

LONDON, April 16 -- Sir Henry Irving and Miss Ellen Terry received a tumultuous welcome last evening at the Lyceum Theatre, where "Coriolanus" was presented, with all the wealth of setting and scenery for which Irving is famous. The house was crowded to its utmost capacity.
Senator Orville H. Platt of Connecticut, author of what is known as the Platt amendment relating to Cuba, is at the Murray Hill Hotel.

Ernest Russell Bartlett, a wealthy young business man and member of a well-known family, was killed in a runaway accident in St. Nicholas Avenue last evening. He was about thirty-one years old, and occupied handsome bachelor apartments in the Benedick, 80 Washington Square East.

The city has the bronze bust of Charles Broadway Rouss. It was unveiled in the Arsenal in Central Park yesterday in the presence of eighteen residents of New York, six women of the South, and a few attaches of the Park Department.

A dispute has arisen between A.R. Borman, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and Gen. G.W. Wingate in regard to a transaction which grew out of the divorce proceedings instituted by Franz Kaltenborn against Mr. Borman's daughter. Louise B. Kaltenbom. A decree was awarded to the husband by Justice Keogh, at a Special Term of the Supreme Court, sitting at White Plains, Westchester County.

ALBANY, April 15. -- The opponents of the $26,000,000 Canal Improvement bill are confident to-night that they have the measure beaten. They do not expect to stop its passage in the Senate, but say it will not pass the Assembly.

Although a raw, rainy, and disagreeable day, the avenue and residence streets of New York were gay with equipages and pedestrians yesterday afternoon. There is a great deal of shopping being done just now, and many people are getting their country houses ready for Summer. There are few formal entertainments, but the week promises much in the way of numerous weddings and dances.

PHILADELPHIA, April 15 -- "Miss Bob White," a comic opera by Willard Spenser, the author of "Little Tycoon" and "Princess Bonnie," was produced to-night for the first time on any stage at the Chestnut Street Theatre, under the management of Messrs. Nixon and Zimmermann. The audience was large and fashionable and the opera was voted a success in every respect.

Delegates from the following seven rowing clubs were present at the annual meeting of the Long Island Amateur Rowing Association at the Carleton Hotel, Brooklyn, last night: Seawanhaka Boat Club of Brooklyn, Ravenswood Boat Club at Astoria. Flushing Boat Club of Flushing, Wahnetah Boat Club of Flushing, Varuna Boat Club of Brooklyn, Nautilus Boat Club of Brooklyn, and Brooklyn Rowing Club.

Mrs. Minnie Turner applied to Justice O'Gorman in the Supreme Court yesterday for an injunction restraining the Mutual Life Insurance Company from paying to Mrs. Fannie L. Thurber the quarterly dividend on a fourteen-thousand-dollar paidup policy of insurance on the life of her husband, Edmund Z. Thurber.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 15 -- The Delaware General Electric Railway Company to-day filed with the Recorder of Deeds for Kent County a mortgage for $1,000,000 given to the Knickerbocker Trust Company of New York City, for the construction of the Kent County trolley, work on which is to be begun this week.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Consul General W.R. Holloway, at St. Petersburg, in a report to the State Department tells of the rigid censorship of all matter printed in the Russian language. This censorship extends even to advertising matter, and of this Mr. Holloway says:

That was, we think, a very interesting interview which we printed yesterday with Mr. H.T. BOSMAN of Hongkong. It is the more interesting and much the more important because Mr. BOSMAN, being in a manner a native Chinaman, is also a British subject and a holder of British distinctions.

WASHINGTON, April 15 -- Mgr. James McMahon died to-day at the Catholic University, where he had made his headquarters for the last eight years, although not officially attached to the institution. The cause of his death was weakness due to old age. He will be burled here.

William Brookfield left town early yesterday without making any answer to the comments of Lemuel E. Quigg, William H. Ten Eyck, and Frederick S. Gibbs on Mr. Brookfield's declared intention to organize a Republican Committee of Seventy and his attack on some members of the Republican County Committee.

A big bay horse, its feet entangled in the iron bars of an electric car fender and held as securely as if in the jaws of a steel trap, lay at the corner of Sixth Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street for three-quarters of an hour last night, during which time his dilemma caused confusion and a blockade of three of the important surface lines, the cars being laden with passengers to overflowing.

Summonses were issued yesterday against Police Captains Josiah Westervelt am John D. Herlihy to appear to-day in the Centre Street Police Court before Magistrate Cornell to answer charges of neglect of duty. The summonses were secured by District Attorney Philbin. The two Captains will be charged specifically with failure to suppress poolrooms and disorderly houses in the Second Precinct and the so-called "Red-Light District" after receiving due notice of the existence of such resorts.

BOSTON, April 15 -- The annual horse show opened this morning under fair auspices. The judging went on without interruption all day. Thomas W. Lawson's entries proved winners or figured in the awards in some capacity in nearly every class. Summary:

ALBANY, April 16 -- Despite the fact that the Senate Republican caucus last night decided to pass the Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill in its present shape, there is every indication to-night that unless it is considerably amended it will meet with the same opposition as the Canal bill met in the Assembly.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The financial condition of Japan at present is far from encouraging, and her bankers, statesmen, and business men are exerting every effort to avoid a panic.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Solicitor General Richards to-day filed with the United States Supreme Court a brief in opposition to the application for bail filed about ten days ago in behalf of ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter, now confined in the United States penitentiary at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., upon conviction of fraud in connection with harbor improvements, , at Savannah, Ga.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The Court of Appeals to-day decided that the courts may review the finding's of the Board of Examination, which, recommended to Gov. Roosevelt that Major Clinton H. Smith of the Seventy-first Regiment be removed from the National Guard of the State of New York, and on which recommendation he was dismissed in June, 1900.

MANILA, April 16 -- A court-martial has been convened and will meet to-morrow to try Lieut. Frederick Boyer, who is charged with the embezzlement of commissary stores. Capt. Frederick J. Barrows of the Thirtieth Volunteer Infantry, who was arrested under similar charges, will be tried later.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your paper of Saturday, April 13, was a fair and thoughtful letter from Allan C. Hamilton on "The Future of the Negro," in which Mr. Hamilton, as "a Southerner who knows both the good and bad qualities of the negro," declares with Booker T. Washington that "he sees hope for the negro in the future, with continued peace between the two races."

Wall Street has for some time presented the amazing spectacle of value affected by rumor to a hitherto unprecedented extent. This is not a comment on the real and solid appreciation that justly reflects underlying conditions, but on the wide advances that have followed the publication of alleged news of deals and combinations, some of which are the baseless fabric of vision.

LONDON, April 17 -- The Associated Press is authoritatively informed that J Pierpont Morgan has bought the Gains borough picture recently recovered in Chicago, though the price is not yet finally determined upon.

About as unlucky a looking mascot as one would wish to see was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday in the person of Thomas Davis, a thirteen-year-old negro boy, who said he was from Greenville, S.C., and was "mighty anxious to get back there an' stay there."

ALBANY, April 16 -- Senator MeCarren to-day introduced a bill providing for a new terminal at the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge. The Commissioner of Bridges is authorized to prepare and submit to the Board of Estimate specifications for the construction of a loop system for pedestrians, railroads, and vehicles.

CEBU, Island of Cebu, P.I., April 16 -- Cebu is the first island to be visited by the Philippine Commission in which the insurrection is still active. It is unsafe to leaves the City of Cebu without an armed escort. The delegates from the towns of the island who are now here are anxious for the establishment of a Provincial Government which, they believe, would assist in ending the insurrection in Cebu.

BALTIMORE, April 16 -- The market to-day disclosed a further upward tendency with Cotton Duck as the undisputed leader. The announcement in a morning paper that the company had absorbed the remaining outstanding mills, thus leaving the concern without serious competition, caused the stock to open with a jump of 2 points, from 23 to 25.

FLUSHING, L.I., April 16 -- At the Seventeenth Separate Company Armory here to-night the Greenpoint Young Men's Christian Association basket-ball team took a game by forfeit from the New West Side Athletic Club team. After a long and tiresome delay in waiting for the National Athletic Club team's appearance, the three men present of that team -- Reed, Cypiot, and Braedon -- decided to play the Mohawk Athletic Club team, although short two men.

Lawyer Albert T. Patrick, accused by Falet Charles F. Jones of histigating the murder of Millionaire William Marsh Rice, will probably be indicted for murder in the first degree to-day, or, at the latest, within the next three days. Valet Jones may also be indicted for the murder. The latter is it present in the House of Detention, charged only with forgery.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 16. -- The city election held to-day resulted in the election of Judge John P. Studley, the Republican candidate, who defeated Mayor Cornelius Driscoll, by a majoritv of 914 votes. The rest of the Democratic ticket was elected. The result of the election conies as a surprise to the Republicans in the size of the majority accorded their candidate.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16 -- Most of the activity in the market to-day was in the steel stocks. Cambria and Bethlehem were a little steadier, though with a smaller volume of buying than yesterday. There was much interest in Diamond Steel, the price rising to 6 1/2. Tidewater Steel got up to 8 1/4.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The Court of Appeals to-day confirmed the grant of 35 36-100 acres of land under the waters of the East River by the State Land Board to the Astoria Light, Heat and Power Company of New York City.

The litle reading room situated above the Squirrel Inn, at Grand Street and the Bowery, was packed to its utmost capacity last night with a crowd of men of all nationalities who had gathered to hear Gen. Joseph Wheeler tell them how to succeed in life.

BOSTON, April 16 -- David Barrie, Sir Thomas Lipton's representative in America, arrived in Boston from New York to-day to get a tender for Shamrock II. Mr. Barrie says he already has a boat provisionally engaged in New York, but he is here trying to find a better one.
Major Joseph Smith Bryce, United States Army, (retired,) who for some time prior to his death was the oldest living graduate of West Point, died at the Fifth Avenue Hotel early yesterday morning.

The delegates to the New York East Conference devoted the last hours of the fifty-third session yesterday to animated debate over the admission of women to the legislative assemblies of the Methodist Church, the assessment of active ministers for the benefit of needy ministers and conference claimants, and to the consideration of the admission of applicants on trial.

Alfred Bunge, a middle-aged man, who, the police say, is known also as Carl Schwartz, James Martin, Carl Meyer, and Anton Benger, was held in $500 bail yesterday in the Ewen Street Police Court, Williamsburg, on the charge that he had threatened to kill Mrs. Marie Dirrmeier, a widow forty years old, who lives at 686 Hart Street, Williamsburg.

William Brookfield, who purposes to lead an anti-Platt Republican movement for purer politics in municipal affairs, left for Central New York yesterday. On his return next week he promises to issue a manifesto and may appoint the Committee of Seventy, which conservative Republicans have asked for.

BALTIMORE, Md., April 16. -- Prof. Henry Augustus Rowland of the Johns Hopkins University and the author of many valuable scientific discoveries died at his home in this city at 3 o'clock this morning. He had not been well for several months, but his condition had only been alarming for a few days.

SYDNEY, March 19 -- The demand for a "white" Australia is one which, it seems, there can be no resisting. However much Australians may be at issue with each other on the subject of the federal tariff, they are almost unanimous in regard to that of colored labor. They will have no Chinese, Japanese, Kanakas, or any of the numerous varieties of black, brown, and yellow, into which Asiatic and Polynesian peoples are divided.

According to our own and other dispatches from Albany, the plan for the "improvement" of the canals at an expense of $26,000,000 cannot pass the Assembly, and is therefore, doomed to defeat for this session. It is not a matter for regret.
PARIS, April 16 -- A dispatch from St. Germain, near this city, describes the extraordinary case of Julienne Landrieux, a servant girl, from whose body dozens of needles are being extracted.

LONDON, April 17 -- Another dispatch from Earl Roberts on the subject of the South African campaign, dated April 2, 1900, has been published in The London Gazette. It largely concerns the transport service, and says the mule transport consisted of what are called in South Africa buck wagons, each carrying a load of 3,500 pounds, drawn by ten mules, with two native drivers.
Gov. H.D. Candler of Georgia, who is at the Fifth Avenue Hotel, yesterday denied to a NEW YORK TIMES reporter the published statements that his visit to New York was to borrow money for his State.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., March 20 -- A royal commission was appointed by the New Zealand Parliament last year to report on the pro's and con's of federation, and also upon the possibility and desirability of a reciprocal commercial treaty with the Australian Commonwealth. It has recently held sittings and taken evidence in the various centres of the colony, and has now crossed over to Australia to obtain the necessary information on that side.

The claim has been made by some poolroom keepers within the past few days that immunity had been promised them, and yesterday a large number of poolrooms were doing business. The promiscuous public was not admitted to these houses, however, and all but those intimately known were told, in the phraseology of the places, that there was "nothing doing."

BOSTON, April 16 -- Money at the Clearing House rules at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 12 1/2 cents discount. Money on call rules from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent., some loans on more speculative copper shares being quoted at the latter figure. There is money still outstanding as low as 3 per cent.

A very cheering indication for the morality of New York has just been furnished by the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church. The conference has requested the Legislature of New York to "enact such amendments to the liquor tax law as will effectually prevent the continuance of Raines law hotels and concert halls."

The poor Lepidoptera are having a harder time than ever this year. They may be safely said to be on their last legs. They can go no lower, for butterflies are at last appearing, brilliant as ever, in the Japanese mattings.

A reactionary tendency appeared in the outside market yesterday, and although transactions in most parts of the list were small, a number of declines were recorded. The copper stocks were an exception, especially Union Copper, which was very active and decidedly strong. The progress reported in the plans to enlarge the field of the Amalgamted Copper Company was a favorable influence which explained much of the strength of the copper shares.
JOHANNESBURG, April 16 -- A cage filled with natives fell down a deep shaft of the Geldenhuis Mine. Twenty-six of the natives were killed.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Secretary Long has bad compiled, in response to an inquiry from the West, a table showing the proportion of native-born and foreign-born sailors in the United States Navy. This shows that during the Spanish-American war, out of a total force of 22,828, the total of native-born sailors was 15,406 and of foreign-born 7,422.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES of April 10 publishes a special dispatch from Plainfield describing the shooting of one child by another with a toy pistol, which the children had loaded, "contrary to the mother's orders."

HAMPTON, Va., April 16 -- The Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute began the celebration of its thirty-third anniversary here to-day. The occasion was a notable one, because of the number of distinguished men and women who have come from a distance to attend.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Four special bills to revise the New York charter in respect to those provisions which have excited much adverse criticism were introduced in the Senate to-day by Senator Stranahan and in the Assembly by Assemblyman Kelsey. Briefly stated, the four bills are as follows:

A burglar who uses a rope ladder is being eagerly sought after by Capt. Schmittberger of the West One Hundredth Street Station. According to the police they have received no fewer than a dozen complaints from the residents of fashionable houses on the upper west side that their houses have either been robbed or that they have seen a man in the rooms on the upper floors, who, when discovered, would mysteriously disappear.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Later figures are coming in respecting the Chinese indemnity claims, which slightly modify these claims as reported from other sources. For instance, the French claim is now given as $56,000,000, instead of $65,000,000, as reported. The Russian claim is about $87,500,000. The claim of Great Britain is only about $21,000,000.

It is not at all surprising that the leaders of the labor organizations which assert control in the various branches of the steel industry should desire nothing so much as to "try a fall" with the new steel merger. This was to have been expected. They doubtless reasoned that if they did not demand and, if possible, compel recognition at the outset they would stand very little chance of successfully demanding it later on.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The Canal bill is dead. Its fate was definitely determined to-day when Tammany withdrew its support from it. Mr. Fitzgerald, the Tammany leader in the Assembly, announced this afternoon that the Tammany members would vote against the measure. When this announcement was made the canal men gave up hope.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., April 16 -- The jury in the case of Etta Kellogg Williams, the actress, against the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company, rendered a vendict in favor of the plaintiff to the amount of $5,000 in the Supreme Court here this afternoon.

ALBANY, April 16 -- The aggregate of the tentative valuations of the special franchises of corporations operating in New York City, as fixed by the State Board of Tax Commissioners for the next tax year, is $217,930,932, which is a reduction of $1,612,419 from the aggregate of the final valuations fixed by the State board on those franchises one year ago, at which time the aggregate was $219,543,351.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- Quite the most sumptuous book ever issued from the Government Printing Office is about to make its appearance. It is a "History of the United States Capitol," prepared by Glenn Brown, and ordered published by the Fifty-sixth Congress at its first session.

YONKERS, N.Y., April 16 -- With the appointment of the ministers to the various, churches this evening the work of this year's meeting of the New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church came to an end.

A dozen landscapes and marines by Charles Melville Dewey may be seen for the next week or two in the upper gallery at Knoedler's. Most of them were painted in England, whither Mr. Dewey betakes himself for the Summer. They have the soft atmosphere of the South of England and the Channel.

Keystone sentiment, Key West fragrance, and keynote eloquence were very much in evidence at an informal "smoker" given by the Pennsylvania Society in the large parlor of the Savoy Hotel last night. Officers were chosen, but that was a mere formality, too, as the nominating committee had prepared an acceptable slate in advance of the meeting.

ST. PAUL, April 16 -- James J. Hill, before leaving St. Paul for the West, announced the success of the long-pending deal for the control of the Burlington Railway. He said he had concluded negotiations for the purchase of the Burlington system, and added:

SOMERVILLE, Mass., April 16 -- The Rev. Dr. Justln Dewey Fulton, for many years prominent as a Baptist minister in Brooklyn, and who attracted great attention by his vehement crusade against the Roman Catholic Church, died at his home here to-day of paralysis.

FARGO, N.D., April 16. --The decision of the United States Supreme Court invalidating North Dakota divorces where the permanency of the residence of the plaintiff is not established, was not unexpected by North Dakota attorneys. During the eight year period in which the ninety-day law was in vogue all reputable attorneys advised their clients against attempting to palm off "fake" residences in all cases where there was a likelihood of contests.

CHICAGO, April 16 -- A replevin suit to recover the solid silver service of the battleship Illinois has been begun in the Circuit Court by the Towle Manufacturing Company. The corporation claims that the sliver service is a part of its goods and chattels, and that it was taken possession of by the defendants April 5.

WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The President and Mrs. McKinley and about thirty invited guests, including several members of the Cabinet, were entertained at the White House to-night by Miss Katharaine Pelton of New York, a young American singer, who recently has returned from Europe, having spent three years in study abroad.
To the Editor of The New York Times: There are several ways in which rich philanthropists could distinguish themselves and reap rich harvests by the seed they could sow.

Conceding all that the English college athletes of Oxford and Cambridge asked, the Athletic Committee representing Harvard and Yale Universities last night took the final step in arranging for the international athletic meet which college men on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean have been talking of for nearly three months.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Senator Tim Sullivan essayed to lead the minority to-day in the absence of Senator Grady, but after just one effort concluded he did not like the job and turned it over to Senator Trainor. Under the order of the introduction of bills Senator Slater handed up a bill to repeal Chapter 107 of the laws of 1875 entitled "An act in relation to the treatment of animals."

FREDKRICK, Md., April 16. -- The first election held in the State under the new election law was the municipal election in this city to-day. Owing to the arrangement of the names of the candidates in alphabetical order the count was slow, and the official result was not known until late to-night.

BOSTON, April 16 -- The blue ribbons were showered equally upon Thomas W. Lawson and Eben D. Jordan at the Boston Horse Show to-day, and competition in most of the blooded classes, either shown out of band or to a vehicle, narrowed down to these two prominent gentlemen.

PITTSBURG, April 16.-- The strike at the W. Dewees Wood plant of the American Sheet Steel Company, at McKeesport, is still on. The mill is being operated in a crippled condition. The strikers are patrolling the streets for the purpose of inducing the workmen to remain away from the mill, but they are keeping off the company's property and no trouble has occurred.

It was more than usually gay yesterday, with many small affairs and a few dances in the evening. Miss Leary had her regular Tuesday reception, the Neighborhood Amusement Club met at the residence of Amos F. Eno, 32 Fifth Avenue, and Mrs. Charles T. Barney gave a dinner dance for her daughter, Miss Helen Barney.

PHOENIX, Ariz., April 16 -- Richard Clawson, W.C. Whitney's jockey, who was reported dying with consumption here several weeks ago, is recovering. Clawson is planning to ride again the latter part of the present season.

Mrs. Eunice C. Kuster, wife of Louis E. Kuster, a lawyer of 32 Nassau Street, is to be brought before Justice Andrews in the Supreme Court to-day on a writ of habeas corpus obtained in her behalf by her lawyer, Maurice S. Hyman. Mrs. Kuster is now in the pavilion for the insane at Bellevue Hospital, where she was committed on the complaint of her husband.

Delegates from twenty-three of the twenty-five polo clubs forming the Polo Association met in their annual meeting last night at the Metropolitan Club, Fifth Avenue and Sixtieth Street. Three new clubs have been added since the previous meeting. Squadron A. Great Neck, L.I., and Bryn Mawr, Penn., the last one being admitted last night.

-- New York State is still without a law against shooting matches with live pigeons as targets, but the law is coming, if not exactly in due time, at least at a time not very far in the future, for the people of the State have spoken their minds on the subject and the interests that will be adversely affected by the abolition of the contemptible "sport" have no particular influence in a political way.

The gentlemen who have called a meeting of Democrats in Carnegie Hall tomorrow night for the purpose of organizing a Democratic Party in the City of New York, and Mr. WILLIAM BROOKFIELD, with his plan for a Committee of Seventy to undertake substantially the same service for the Republican Party, have begun a campaign against the false pretenses under which both political parties are doing works of sin in this community.

The forty-fourth annual session of the Newark Methodist Conference was concluded yesterday at the First Methodist Church, Hoboken. The morning session was devoted to the consideration of the Constitution as amended last. The only clause that created any discussion was that proposing to admit women to the General Conference.

Mark D. Wilber, once a Senator of the State of Michigan, was interviewed yesterday about the much-discussed canal question, with the different phases of which he has been familiar for many years. He was the chief mover in the Michigan Ship Canal debates in the Senate of that State, and since then he has traveled almost everywhere in the world where there were extended canal problems to be studied.
WASHINGTON, April 16 -- The Weather Bureau's general summary of crop conditions for the last week is as follows:

Lieut. Henry Hughes Hough, United States Navy, and Miss Flaurence Olyphant Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gray Ward, were married at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan, rector of the church, and the Rev. Reese F. Alsop of St. Ann's Church, Brooklyn.

Police Captains John D. Herlihy of " Red Light District " notoriety, and Josiah Westervell, formerly of the Second Precinct, stood on the bridge of the Centre Street Police Court, before Magistrate Cornell, at the head of a line of drunks, disorderly persons, and common thieves, yesterday, in obedience to the summonses obtained against them by District Attorney Philbin.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 16. -- About 100switchmen employed in the Lackawanna Railroad yard in this city quit work at noon to-day because two of their number, Michael Herrity and Patrick Toomey, were discharged. Yardmaster B. E. Knowles dismissed the two men and placed two men from Hoboken in their places.

ALBANY, April 16 -- Unless the Assembly Committee on Rules takes a different view of the proposed amendments to the rapid transit bill now in that committee, they will not report the measure and the amendments will die. The bill has been opposed by Chairman Kelsey of the Assembly Cities Committee because of a belief that its contents were of a suspicious nature.

Justice McAdam, in the Supreme Court, yesterday, handed down a decision in which he found that the Standard Gaslight Company must pay to the German-American Insurance Company of New York $500 which it had been compelled to pay on a fire loss arising out of a leak in a gas pipe.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., April 17. -- New York State seems to have furnished the largest number of applicants for South Dakota divorce of any State in the Union, among them many persons of prominence from the Empire State.

We deem it a public duty to call the attention of Postmaster VAN COTT to the negligence of the Custodian of the General Post Office Building in matters which affect the public comfort and reflect discredit upon the administration of the office. The conditions existing at the close of business yesterday were so bad as to challenge the attention of even the casual passer-by.
ALBANY, April 17. -- The Assembly to-day passed the bill of Senator Trainor providing for the establishment of an inebriates' home in the City of New York.

The wedding of Stephen Hyatt Pell, son of the late John Howland Pell, and Miss Sarah Gibbs Thompson, only daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Means Thompson, was solemnized yesterday afternoon at 3:30 o'clock in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, by the Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan.

The ostensible object of the visit of the commission of the Cuban Constitutional Convention to Washington is to discuss with the President the establishment of relations with the United States upon some other basis than that of the Platt amendment. In the nature of things this discussion must be fruitless, even if the President consents to be a party to it.

LONDON, April 18. -- The scene in Bow Church yesterday during the consecration of the Right Rev. Dr. A.F.W. Ingram as Bishop of London resembled a political meeting rather than a religious service. John Kensit, the anti-Ritualist, entered his expected protest against the appointment.

Capt. Julius A. Penn, Seventh Infantry, and Capt. William A. Shunk, Eighth Cavalry, will report at San Francisco to Col. Stephen P. Jocelyn, Fourteenth Infantry, chief mustering officer, for duty temporarily as his assistant.

LONDON, April 17. -- Money was plentiful to-day, owing to Government disbursements, which are expected to continue on a large scale, partly with the view to prepare for the introduction of the loan. The indebtedness to the Bank is believed to be practically liquidated. The issue of a million of nine months' Treasury bills April 23 to replace the same amount due April 30 is expected to have little effect.

Dr. Paul Erdtmann, son of William Erdtmann, General Manager of the German department of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, has been sued for an absolute divorce by his wife, Elise Erdtmann. Mrs. Erdtmann applied to Justices O'Gorman, in the Supreme Court, yesterday for counsel fees and alimony pending the trial of the case.

TERRE HAUTE, Ind., April 17. -- It is now disclosed that a large building just completed and supposed to be a warehouse for a cereal food mill is to be the largest match factory in the world. It will be an anti-trust plant and is to be in operation by June 1. The machinery has arrived from Germany.

BOSTON, April 17. -- Money at the Clearing House ruled at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 12 1/2 cents discount. The time money market is steady and unchanged at 4@4 1/2 per cent, for all periods, on railroads and good mixed collateral, and 4 1/2@5 per cent, on all industrials. The market for commercial paper is dull.

A stiff handicap list is the revised schedule for the coming year of the new metropolitan handicap ratings which was issued yesterday. The new schedule contains 217 names, graded at ten strokes or under, and these are all eligible for the metropolitan championship, which will be played in May on the links of the Apawamis Golf Club.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, April 17. -- The Le Mars National Bank, at Le Mars, Iowa, did not open for business to-day. Thomas F. Ward, Vice President and manager of the institution, is a self-confessed embezzler to the amount of $25,000 or $30,000. He has also absconded. It is alleged he took $30,000 with him or lost it during the past few days in speculation, as it is missing from the vault of the bank.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- David H. Lane could not be found at his residence to-night, and inquiry there as to his whereabouts was met with the response that no one in the house knew where he was, Mr. Lane's friends make light of the suit brought against him by a chorus girl in New York.
CHICAGO, April 17. -- Money to-day was slightly firmer at 4 1/2@5 per cent, for call and time loans. New York exchange was quoted at 20c premium.

The Cramp Shipbuilding Company will be interested in the twenty-story office building to be erected at a cost of $900,000 at 72 and 74 Broadway, and will probably have its offices in the new structure. William M. Cramp of Philadelphia, the head of that concern, is one of the Directors in the recently incorporated Century Building Company, which took title yesterday to the property from Peter Marie for a consideration of $1,100,000.

Justice William J. Gaynor of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, has written a letter to Senator N.A. Fisberg in answer to an inquiry as to his opinion of proposed jury legislation, and relating to the method of obtaining juries in New York and Kings Counties. The Justice condemns the act compelling the drawing of a special panel.

ALBANY, April 17. -- The bill to submit the proposition for the expenditure of $26,000,000 for canal improvement to the people of the State at the next election was killed in the Senate this morning by a vote of 31 yeas to 16 nays. Senator McCarren offered an amendment providing for an expenditure of $60,000,000 instead of $26,000,000.
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 17. -- The silver jubilee of Mother Superior Rosalie of St. Joseph's Academy is being celebrated at the academy. Mother Rosalie is also the Principal of the academy.

DUBUQUE, Ia., April 17. -- In the presence of the high priests of his Church and before an audience that occupied every foot of space in St. Raphael's Cathedral and overflowed into the surrounding streets, Archbishop John J. Keane was to-day invested with the pallium, the insignia of the high position he occupies in the Roman Catholic Church.

PITTSBURG, April 17. -- No general strike of the men in the employ of the American Sheet Steel Company was ordered to-day. President Shaffer of the Amalgamated Association is still determined to issue the order, if necessary, and follow it by an order calling out all the organized employes of the United States Steel Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- At the meeting of the Directors of the Reading Company this afternoon, the first since George F. Baer was made President, W.R. Taylor, the former Secretary of the company, was elected Vice President, and Albert H. Moore was made Secretary.

Julius Gutman, a salesman, living at 98 Lenox Avenue, was a juror in the Supreme Court yesterday, and when he was called to serve in a case in which the Metropolitan Street Railway Company was defendant he told Justice Truax that he had become so prejudiced by listening to testimony in other cases against the same road that he could never render a verdict in its favor.

Squads of policemen, each accompanied by a representative of the Committee of Fifteen and detectives from Superintendent McCullagh's office, moved simultaneously on seven alleged poolrooms shortly before 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Superintendent McCullagh sat in his office, at 585 Broadway, and directed the movements of the raiders by telephone up to the time they began to move upon those who were charged in warrants issued by Justice Jerome with violating the Penal Code.
LONDON, April 18. -- A South African Blue Book, containing recent dispatches from Sir Alfred Milner and other official correspondence, was issued last night.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
Francis B. Loomis, United States Minister to Venezuela, is at the Hotel Victoria. He arrived on the steamship Caracas too late on Tuesday to pass quarantine that day.

The portico of the Pabst Hotel was, Jan. 17 last, found to be an illegal structure, squatting on $34,000 worth of public property in Forty-second Street, between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, by Justice D.F. Martin, sitting in the Tenth District Municipal Court, and he fined its proprietor, James B. Regan, $5 for maintaining it for one day, Aug. 3, 1900.

HAMPTON, Va., April 17. -- The Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute completed to-day the celebration of its thirty-third anniversary. The Board of Trustees held its annual meeting here this morning with President Robert C. Ogden in the chair to hear the annual report of the Principal and Treasurer of the school and to transact other business.

The Brooklyn baseball team lost the second game they have played this season at Washington Park yesterday to the Eastern League team from Toronto by a score of 6 to 5. The Canadians played a fast game and backed their pitched in good shape. The latter was very successful against the Brooklyns, holding the champions down to eleven hits, four of which were made by Davis, the new left fielder.

The Grand Jury yesterday failed to indict and dismissed the complaint against George Brotherton, held for the action of that body by Justice Jerome, charged with conducting a gambling house at 116 and 118 West Forty-second Street. This dismissal gave rise to rumors of dissension in the Grand Jury, and talk of a conflict between that body and the District Attorney. These vague rumors were emphatically denied by Assistant District Attorney Byrne.

Magistrate Zeller, in the Yorkville Police Court, yesterday, discharged De Wolf Hopper and Dan Daly, the actors and William A. Brady, the theatrical manager, who were arrested on Sunday night at the Academy of Music by Inspector Walter Thompson, charged with violating the Sunday law relating to the giving or performances in costume.

In yesterday's stock market Atchison common stock sold at 67 1/4, at which price it has more than doubled the price at which it was quoted a year ago -- this market value surpassing any figure reached since the property's reorganization. This quotation shows the important advance of 25 points over the figure quoted at New Year's.

PHILADELPHIA, April 17. -- The steel stocks again dominated the market, and the whole list had a more healthy look. Cambria Steel was erratic. It broke nearly a point to 21 5/8, and then shot up quickly to 23 5/8. Most of the offerings were taken by an inside house. Diamond State Steel got up to 7 in the forenoon, and held most of the advance.

NEWPORT, April 17. -- Newport will been fete in August, when the North Atlantic Squadron will be here. A committee, consisting of Mayor Garrettson, Congressman Bull, Hermann Oelrichs, Commodore Gerry, and a number of prominent cottagers and citizens, will soon begin to arrange plans for the entertainment of the officers.

The public clamor against the inhumanity of trap shooting with live birds, which found spontaneous and unmistakable expression during the recent championship contest of experts, has led to the introduction in Senate and Assembly of bills repealing the law of 1875, which permits sportsmen's clubs to use live birds in trap-shooting tournaments.

Richard Pennefather Rothwell, an eminent mining engineer and writer on industrial topics, died at his home, 250 West One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, yesterday morning, of cancer of the stomach, from which he had been severely ill for five weeks. He was born at Ingersoll, Ontario, Canada, May 1, 1837.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Superintendent of Insurance Hendricks to-day filed in the Insurance Department the report of an examination of the Manhattan Fire Insurance Company of New York. The officers of the company were given a hearing on this report at the New York office of the department yesterday forenoon, and, as a result thereof, the report was immediately filed and made public.

The decisions handed down by the Supreme Court of the United States in three cases lately before it on appeal, declaring null and void divorces obtained in States of which the parties in interest were not residents in a sense entitling them to claim the benefit of easy facilities there offered for the dissolution of unsatisfactory marriage relations, make for good in many ways.

Under the influence of the irregularity of the Stock Exchange market the outside market yesterday was quieter and at the same time somewhat weak. The transactions were relatively light, even in the copper shares, which recently have supplied such a large amount of business in the outside market.

WASHINGTON, April 17 -- A report has gained some circulation here to-night that the President contemplates removing the tariff duties from trade between Porto Rico and the United States in three months. Ignorance of the origin of this report is declared by Senator Foraker, the person who was most prominent in the making of the Porto Rico temporary Government bill, and he adds that there is not a word of truth in it.

BOSTON, April 17. -- David Barrie Sir Thomas Lipton's representative on this side of the Atlantic, as a guest of Designer Crowninshield, visited the Lawson cup yacht Independence, building at the Atlantic Works, to-day. He examined the boat closely, but would not express any opinion as to her racing qualities.

The relations of Roman Catholics to the public library movement and the interests which they desire conserved were discussed yesterday by Archbishop Corrigan at a tea given by the Cathedral Library Reading Circle and Auxiliary at the Hotel Majestic, Seventy-second Street and Central Park West.

ALBANY, April 17. -- Assemblyman Leon Sanders of New York attacked the Klsberg Commissioner of Jurors bill for New York County and Kings County on to-day's calendar in the Assembly. Mr. Morgan of Kings explained that the bill was designed to appoint a Commissioner of Jurors and to provide for a special jury in civil and criminal actions, and would be a saving of $50,000.

The first convention of the Mayoralty campaign, that of the Citizens' Union, will be held in the large hall of Cooper Union to-night. There will be about 450 delegates, representing every district in Greater New York, and including some of the most prominent citizens of the municipality.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 17. -- Miss Elizabeth Lathrop Brinckerhoff, daughter of Mayor A.E. Brinckerhoff of Englewood, senior member of the firm of Vermilye Co., bankers of 20 Nassau Street, New York, was married at 4 o'clock this afternoon to William Bushnell Chapin of Philadelphia.

BALTIMORE, April 17. -- The market alternated between an early strong bull movement and a later slight reactionary tendency. The bull movement was led by Seaboards, which manifested a persistent upward inclination which carried some of the stocks a full point above Tuesday's closing.

Just why theatrical managers believe that the public loses its senses in the Spring no one has been able to find out, but it is a familiar fact that about this time every year, what is called "the silly season" begins. This delectable period was begun in proper form last night at the Herald Square Theatre, with the production of a musical farce in three acts, entitled "The Prima Donna."

ALBANY, April 17. -- The Senate Committee on Commerce and Navigation to-day voted to report the New York and New Jersey Bridge bill. The vote stood 5 to 1. Senator Elsberg, the Chairman of the committee, cast the negative vote. The action of the committee was a great surprise, it having been given out that the bill was to be allowed to slumber.

LONDON, April 17. -- At the second day's racing at Newmarket to-day an all-aged selling plate for two-year-olds and upward, the winner to be sold by auction for 400 sovereigns, five furlongs, was won by Valenza, with "Patsy" McDermott (American) in the saddle. Oxbridge came in second with "Danny" Maher up, and Lothdoon was third. Eleven horses ran.

-- Judging from the results recorded every month in the reports of Major W.C. GORGAS, the Chief Sanitary Officer of Har vana -- and results attained form an excellent basis for judgment -- that particular representative of American rule in Cuba is showing an almost atrocious disregard for the sensitive feelings of the anti-imperialists.

The announced intention of Mr. H.C. FRICK and associated capitalists to build on the Delaware River, near Philadelphia, great steel plant, is significant of the recognition by the shrewd leaders, of this industry of the inevitable change in the tariff policy of this country, which will deprive the plants of the Middle West of the advantage they now enjoy in proximity to the great deposits of ores most suitable for steel production.

ALBANY, April 17. -- There is trouble ahead for the Mortgage Tax bill. Republicans in both the Senate and the Assembly are talking of bolting, notwithstanding the action of the Senate in making the bill a caucus measure. To-day some of the Republicans who have given special attention to the matter went to the Governor and asked him to call a conference upon the bill.
The Pennsylvania Casualty Company has been admitted to Louisiana, Georgia, and North Carolina.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., April 17. -- Miss Louise Frelinghuysen Chambers, daughter of Mr. F.F. Chambers, Treasurer of the Lackawanna Railroad, and Louis Charles Mack, son of Adolph Mack, President of the Raritan Woolen Mills, were married at high noon to-day at the home of the bride's parents, 110 West End Avenue.

DENVER, Col., April 17. -- The filing of the incorporation papers of the Colorado Grande Development Company this morning made public for the first time the wonderful find of manganese iron in Eastern Utah, which Denver capitalists are now about to develop. The discovery is said to be the largest and purest deposit of manganese iron known, and is expected to distinctly influence the entire field of iron and steel manufacture of this country.

At the meeting of the Board of Public Schools in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx which was held last night at the Board of Education Building, Park Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, the Superintendent of Public Schools in these boroughs, John Jasper, submitted what he called a "report relative to the schools in the Boroughs of Manhattan and the Bronx."

HAMPTON, Va., April 18. -- In the celebration of its thirty-third anniversary Tuesday and Wednesday, the Hampton Normal and Agricultural Institute has again invited and received the fullest public inspection. Probably few if any schools in the country so frequently and so widely open their doors to the visits of all classes of people as does this school for Indians and negroes on the shores of Hampton Roads.

FLUSHING, L.I., April 18. -- Play was resumed here to-night at the armory of the Seventeenth Separate Company, in the championship tournament of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union basketball competition. The chief game of the night was the match between the Seventeenth Separate Company of Flushing and the famous "Rubber Five" team of the Greenpoint Young Men's Christian Association.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- In the United States Supreme Court to-day, J.M. Wilson, representing ex-Capt. Oberlin M. Carter, filed a motion to strike from its tiles the brief of Solicitor General Richards in that case as "scandalous and irrelevant." This motion is based on the assertion that the Solicitor General goes outside of the record in his brief.

BOSTON, April 18. -- Money at the Clearing House ruled at 2 1/2 per cent. New York funds sold at 12 1/2 and 15c discount. On call, money rules from 3 to 4 per cent. mostly 3 1/2 @ 4 per cent. Time money is quoted from 4 to 5 per cent., according to dates and collateral, the longer dates being the Cheapest.

The twelfth annual convention of the American Association for the Advancement or Physical Culture opened yesterday in the hall of the Board of Education, Fiftyninth Street and Park Avenue. About 150 delegates, men and women, were present, representing all the best known schools and colleges of the United States.

BOSTON, April 18. -- A dispatch to The Transcript from Montreal says that an application for incorporation is now being considered by the Canadian Parliament from a concern which asks most extraordinary powers, perhaps greater than has ever before been requested from the Dominion of Canada.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The written opinion of Justice Gray of the United States Supreme Court on the divorce cases passed on by the court last Monday became available to-day, thus affording the first opportunity for inspection of Justice Gray's language.

The latest work of the Committee of Fifteen is producing what is known in medicine as "cumulative effect." It presses on the attention of the public, on the courts, and, especially on Commissioner MURPHY, Mayor VAN WYCK, and the managers of Tammany Hall, the proof, not merely that there are illegal gambling places still running, but that it would have been perfectly easy for the police to shut them long ago.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This consideration "has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 18. -- Chief of Police Massey this afternoon received word from Henry B. Duncan, near this city, that a boy who was in the company of five men had applied at his home for something to eat. He thinks the lad was Willie McCormick, who was kidnapped from New York. A squad of policemen failed to find the men.
CHICAGO, April 18. -- Money was easier to-day, rates for call and time loans being 4 @ 4 1/2 per cent. New York exchange was quoted at 20c premium.

ROCHESTER, April 18. -- The belief that existed here early this morning that the $150,000 fire which resulted in the destruction of the East Rochester car shops of the New York Central, and between fifty and sixty freight cars, was of incendiary origin, amounts to-day almost to a conviction.

The Merchants' Association has sent out a second circular setting forth in an entirely fair and moderate fashion the fact that its fight against the Ramapo steal saved the city from enormous waste, and worse. The work of the association cost heavily, and resulted in a debt of about $17,000.

The season of the Chicago Orchestra closed at the Auditorium last Saturday night. The twenty-two programmes contained 103 different compositions, representing forty-two different composers. Beethoven was represented by the greatest number of works, he having sixteen to his credit, one of these -- the andante con variaziom from the "Kreutzer" sonata -- having been once repeated.

Henry Anthony Barclay, Jr., and Miss Rosalie Xavier Paul, only daughter of Lieut. Col. Charles A. Paul, United States Army, were married at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, by the Rev. Dr. D. Parker Morgan, rector of the church.

NEWARK, N.J., April 18. -- The Board of Trade rooms were crowded to-night with business men who came to further the calling of an extra session of the Legislature to deal with the pollution of the Passaic River. That something must be done to remedy the existing state of affairs is the consensus of opinion of Newark's citizens.

With the racegoing public willing to submit to any possible discomfort or inconvenience for the privilege of attending the Aqueduct races, and horse owners all but fighting for the chance to run their horses for the small purses offered there, the Queens County Jockey Club is having a season of most amazing prosperity.

The new attitude of the United States toward the commerce of the world is receiving constantly growing attention abroad. The London Times during the current week publishes a long letter from its Vienna correspondent detailing the growth, jealousy, and alarm aroused on the Continent by American competition.

BALTIMORE, April 18. -- The local market to-day exhibited an improved tone, which was well maintained from start to finish. Seaboards figured with a fair degree of strength, the stocks scoring for themselves net gains before the close. Cotton Duck also firmed up perceptibly, the sentiment on that stock growing quite bullish after the Exchange had closed.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The criticism of Gen. Funston's manner of capturing Aguinaldo, reported as the utterance of the Rev. Frederick Campbell in yesterday's TIMES, suggests questions in the mind of one who believes all warfare to be wrong, and absolutely at variance with Christ's teaching, which he would be glad to have answered.

ALBANY, April 18. -- A caucus of the Republican members of the Assembly was held to-night on the call of Speaker Nixon in the Assembly library to take action upon the Stranahan Excise bill. The bill was debated in the House Wednesday, and the Republican opposition which developed was so powerful that Leader Allds was obliged to put the motion to adjourn to save the bill from defeat.

John J. Howard. John J. Howard, Supervising Inspector of the immigration service on Ellis Island, died at his home, 149 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, yesterday from pneumonia, after an illness of eleven days. He was born in Indianapolis, Ind., sixty-three years ago. His parents were Massachusetts people.

The Greater New York Democracy held the first mass meeting and perfected temporary organization in Carnegie Hall last evening. Resolutions were passed, speeches were made, and an address was issued to the voters of New York declaring that the primary object of the organization was the overthrow of Tammany Hall and Richard Croker, who was denounced by nearly every speaker.

There was excitement at the convention of the Citizens' Union held in the large hall of Cooper Union last night. Delegates on the floor charged that the organization was run by a clique that had everything cut and dried for the body to swallow.

The great strike in the steel trade, at no time imminent, has been "called off" before it was declared on. The threat to call out every steel worker in the mills of the United States Steel Corporation if certain things were not done was never anything more than an empty boast, for the reason that only a small proportion of the men in these mills would have responded to such a call.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 18. -- The steam yacht Columbia, recently purchased by Montgomery Rollins of Boston, has been launched from the marine railway at the Jacobs Yards, and has been tied up in the basin to be prepared for commission. W. Gould Brokaw's fast schooner yacht Amerita has had her spars set and the work of rigging her is nearing completion.

TACOMA, Washington, April 18. -- Further investigations this week reveal that the Scandinavian-American Bank at Whatcom and the Bank of Blaine, which failed, practically have no assets, their condition being worse than was at first supposed. These banks were controlled by H. St. John of Chicago, who has since gone to England, leaving no word of when he will return.

A member of the legal firm of Epstein Brothers added some humor yesterday to a very dry case which was on trial before Justice Giegerich, in the Supreme Court. The action was that of William E. Smith, is trustee in bankruptcy of William R. Smith, against "Burdette," a corporation. The plaintiff claimed $8,080.94 as the balance due on bills for millinery goods.

Surrounded by 100 nuns vowed to celibacy, and dressed in black, and 100 little girls in white, and a gayly dressed party of friends and relatives of the outside world, Miss May Matilda O'Ryan of Sillerly, Quebec, and Dr. Gustave A. Taschereau of St. Ferdinand, N.S., were wedded yesterday morning in the Convent of the Ursuline Nuns, at Bedford Park.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., April 18. -- Wu Ting-Fang, Chinese Minister, was the guest of honor at a dinner given to-night by the Southern Manufacturers' Club. Mr. Wu made an address, in which he gave a general review of the trade conditions between the South and the Orient. In the course of his address he said:

"The history of my untiring and unremitting fight against gambling and racetrack betting in this State if written out at length would fill a large volume," said Benjamin Steinhardt, the lawyer, to a reporter for THE NEW YORK TIMES at his home, 248 West Seventy-second Street, last night.

Police Commissioner Murphy was still confident yesterday, in spite of raids by the Committee of Fifteen the night before, that the Captains under him had done their duty. The raids, he said, were merely of a political character, and had not resulted in the production of any evidence to show that the places raided were poolrooms.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 18. -- The Harvard crew candidates began rowing to-day after a week's rest. There were four creys on the river, the first and second Newell and the first and second Weld. These crews will race on April 28, at which time the Varsity crew and substitutes will be chosen.

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The three days' pool tournament between Alfred De Oro, the Cuban, and Frank Sherman, the American, for the world's championship, ended to-night in a victory for De Oro, who made a total of 600 points against 498 for his opponent.

Nearly two hundred patrons of the automobile attended the annual dinner of the Automobile Club of America last evening, held in the Astor gallery of the Waldorf-Astoria. Not all, however, had surrendered absolute allegiance to the motor vehicle, for dispersed here and there were several well-known lovers and owners of fast horses, including Albert C. Bostwick and Dr. H.H. Kane.

OTTAWA, Ontario, April 18. -- The Crow's Nest Southern Railway charter was passed by the Railway Committee to-day. This was after the agreement entered into by the Government, the Crow's Nest Coal Company, and the Crow's Nest Southern Road was read. The agreement provides that neither the coal company nor the Crow's Nest Railway shall sell coke or coal outside of Canada at prices which discriminate unfairly against Canadian consumers.

PITTSBURG, April 18. -- There will be no strike in the plants of the American Sheet Steel Company. The trouble that broke out in McKeesport last week and which for a time threatened to cause a general strike of all union iron and steel workers in the country has been settled in an amicable manner.

ALBANY, April 18. -- Senator Ellsworth's till providing for the appointment by the Appellate Division of twenty referees for the Supreme Court of the First Department and twenty for the City Court of New York passed the Senate to-day by a vote of 20 to 17. The bill was fought by Senator Ponnelly, who said the bar of New York County was opposed to it.
LONDON, April 19. -- The press comment on Sir Michael Hicks-Beach's budget speech is of a very mixed character.

The National League season in Brooklyn will be inaugurated to-day between the champions and Philadelphia. As the champions won their opening game yesterday, a large crowd is expected to welcome them home. From a pole 100 feet high will fly the pennant won last year, while the Twenty-third Regiment Band will furnish the music.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It seems to be very difficult for some persons to see the injustice of the taxation of mortgages. The following illustration, it seems, ought to make it clear to the dullest comprehension. Suppose there are two adjoining houses, assessed at $10,000 each and owned free and clear by, say, A and B.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., April 18. -- Mrs. D.M. Sawyer and Miss Amy Sawyer, the mother and sister of the student drowned at Lakeville, sailed yesterday noon on the White Star liner Majestic for a Summer outing in Europe.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 18. -- The Directors of the Suffolk County Agricultural Society have decided to make important improvements on the race track at the fair grounds here. Horsemen have complained that the track is too narrow, and especially so on the first turn, where several accidents have occurred.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., April 18. -- Mrs. J.C. St. John, who came here yesterday from Brooklyn suffering from a well-developed case of smallpox, is now quarantined at the residence of her father, Oliver D. Woodruff, and refuses to receive medical attention.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent "M.T.R.," in his plea against municipal ownership, ably brings out some sterling arguments and facts, which are substantially met by "Austral" when he indicates Glasgow as an apt illustration of the benefits of municipal ownership when officials are honest.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., April 18. -- The party of Northern educators and men of affairs who are visiting institutions in the South as the guests of R.C. Ogden, left Hampton. Va., last evening in three special cars, arriving this morning at Greensboro, where they visited the State Normal and Industrial College for young women.

WALTHAM, Mass., April 18. -- Negotiations were completed to-day whereby the plant of the United States Watch Company was purchased by the Philadelphia Watch Case Company of Riverside, N.J. It is stated that the new management intends to boom business here and that additional buildings will be erected.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I want to make a suggestion as to threecent fares. How would it do to have double-deck cars -- as they do in many parts of Europe -- and limit the number of passengers (practically) to those who can be seated? I would further suggest that seats on the "upper deck" be charged at 3 cents and on the "lower deck" at 5 cents.

Additional raids were made by the Committee of Fifteen between midnight and 1 o'clock this morning. A dozen or more places were visited. Most of them were in the Tenderloin. A few were along the Bowery. The places visited were mostly concert halls and cafes. The proprietor in most cases or his manager, a bartender or two, and in some instances a doorkeeper, were arrested.

There appeared at the Outdoor Poor Department headquarters yesterday a man and his wife and four children, who for three months have been tramping toward this city from the mines at Fayette City, Penn., living on the charity of the residents along the streets and high roads over which they passed.
HACKENSACK, N.J., April 18. -- Henry P. Mattjetscheck, a member of the Hackensack Wheelmen, tells a weird story of the death of a pet parrot which until yesterday formed a part of his household.

"What you gwine to do wid dat tuhkey bone?" "I'm gwine keep him foh membunce. Say, you know who gimme dat bone? " "Not dat nice lady?" "No. Course not. It was Teddy." The curly-headed pickaninny was able to answer as he did, for it was none other than Vice President Roosevelt who did the honors at the "West Side Boys' Home last night.
The most interesting fact connected with the British budget, introduced by Sir MICHAEL HICKS-BEACH yesterday, is that there is in it not the faintest trace of protection.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Among the changes made by the Assembly in the charter one very serious change in Section 1,172 in respect to the Sanitary Code demands critical attention. Necessarily very great power must be devolved upon the Board of Health, and despotic powers are conferred upon the board in cases of emergency and for preventing the spread of pestilence.

ALBANY, April 18. -- After the Stranahan Excise bill was disposed of by the Republican caucus to-night, the Stranahan Mortgage Tax bill was taken up for discussion. It was announced that this bill was not to be made a matter of caucus, but the opinions of the members as to the advisability of its passage were invited.

In his shop, at 44 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, early yesterday morning, Owen Ahearn, sixty years old, known in the neighborhood as "Jimmie the Junkman," had a desperate fight with two robbers. The old man sleeps in a room in the rear of his shop. At 4 o'clock yesterday morning he was awakened by some one knocking at the front door.
PITTSBURG, April 18. -- The Commercial Gazette to-morrow, in its treatment of the McKeesport strike, will say:

WASHINGTON, April 18. -- The Secretary of State received a cable message this morning from Mr. Squiers, United States Charge at Peking, saying: "Winter Palace occupied by von Waldersee accidentally destroyed by fire; Gen. Schwartzkopf, Chief of Staff, fatally burned."
Negotiations said to be on foot looking to a "deal" between the Philadelphia Company of Pittsburg and the Pittsburg Gas Company.

In view of the comments which have been elicited by the use of the term "Books of Power," as applied to the Standard Library of the Providence Public Library, readers will be interested to know that this term or its equivalent, "Literature of Power," is not Mr. Foster's, but Thomas De Quincey's, who makes use of it in his essay on Pope as follows:

The telephone bell in the West Thirtieth Street Station rang vigorously at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon. Sergt. Todd, who was on duty, picked up the receiver and shouted "Hello." He listened for a moment and then was seen to stagger and rush to the desk. Policeman Ryan was the first bluecoat he saw.

The State Civil Service Commission yesterday resumed its public examination into the promotions of Police Captains made by the old Police Board last December. William E. Delemater, Deputy Clerk at Police Headquarters, took the stand first, and said that the board had been divided in its vote to appoint William S. Devery Chief, the Mayor casting the deciding vote.

The Sons of the Revolution last evening at Delmonico's celebrated the one hundred and twenty-sixth, anniversary of the battle of Lexlngton. The meeting was attended by nearly 250 members. Frederick S. Tallmadge, the President of the society, presided. Dr. Sidney H. Carney, Jr., read a paper on "Medical Men in the Revolution."

Richard Ingle may have been too much for the Calverts, but in her pleasant new story of "Sir Christopher," Mrs. Maud Wilder Goodwin conquers him by a pen stroke or two, so let no twentieth century woman, grudging her tears as a needless expenditure of nervous force, hesitate to Tead the tale, lest the pirate's name presage dismal adventures for the liero and neroine and other-virtuous folk.
All three teams tied in the New York Royal Arcanum Bowling League tournament on Starr's alleys last night. The scores:

To The New York Times Saturday Review: I notice an inquiry by "Reader" in your issue of April 6 for a list of books referred to in your editorial of March 2, which he says "would greatly aid those who desired to know what was considered books of power," and also that Mr. Norman Astley asks for a list of the Providence collection, and calls it "a godsend to the average reader."

In a dark woodbin in the cellar of the tenement at 458 Warren Street, Brooklyn, early last evening thirteen-year-old Louis Gates was found hanging by the neck from a rafter, dead, a suicide. The boy disappeared on Wednesday afternoon, and is believed to have taken his life at that time.

ALBANY, April 19 -- Lieut. Gov. Woodruff, when asked to-day concerning the amendment to the New York charter which provides for the appointment instead of the election of City Magistrates in Brooklyn, Queens, and Richmond, said:
MANILA, April 19 -- The following is Aguinaldo's address to the Filipino people, made public this evening:

To The yew York Times Saturday Review: In the last Issue of THE SATURDAY REVIEW, a very interesting editorial article notes the small sales of genuine love letters like those of Dorothy Osborne, the Brownings, and Robert Louis Stevenson, as compared with "An Englishwoman's Love Letters" and others of a like nature, the inference being that the first-mentioned books are not read to anything like the same extent as the latter.

The interview we published with "W. D. FOULKE of Indiana the other day has involved him in a controversy with our friends of The Evening Post, who think that he defends the course of the President as to the merit system too much in the spirit of an advocate holding a brief for Mr. McKINLEY.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 -- The Philadelphia market was brighter to-day, and strength broke out in new spots at the expense of stocks, which throughout the week, had been most active. The steel issues rested, while good advances were recorded in American Railways, Electric Company of America, Marsden, and Union Traction.
CHICAGO, April 19 -- Money rates were unchanged for call and time loans. New York exchange was quoted at par.
Nothing could be more absolutely direct than the author's manner of telling his tale, which is deeply impressive solely by virtue of its truth to human nature.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: It is now some time since we have had a controversy in THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, and I suggest that we take up the following subject and call for the views of your readers.

Columbia's freshmen defeated the sophomores yesterday at Columbia Oval in the annual Spring track games held for the class championship. Thirteen events were run off, and the freshmen captured eight firsts. The final score in points was: Freshmen, 82 1/2; sophomores, 59 1/2. Summaries :
There is a legend of venerable origin and authority as to what happens when the blind lead the blind.

The block bounded by Madison and Park Avenues, Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets, purchased recently by the New York Realty Company and the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company from the Roman Catholic Orphan Asylum, has all been resold with the exception of four lots, and the erection of fine dwellings upon the property will be begun shortly by the various purchasers.
ALBANY, April 19 -- The Slater Anti-Pigeon Shooting: bill was passed in the Senate to-day, 26 yeas to 13 nays, after some debate.

The auction room has been so full of surprises this season that one need not be astonished to learn that Shelley's "Alastor," London, 1816, in the original boards, uncut, recently fetched u66 at Sotheby's. This is of course, a record price, though it is not "about four times more than copies have hitherto realized," as a London paper said.

"My New Curate," which originally appeared in The American Ecclesiastical Review as the diary of an Irish parish priest, and was then published in book form by Marlier Co. of Boston, is now selling in its tenth edition. How the story came to be written is told in a biographical sketch of Father Sheehan, recently published in one of the magazines.

SOUTHINGTON, Conn., April 19 -- Mrs. J.C. St. John of New York, who is sick with smallpox at the residence of her father, Oliver D. Woodruff of this town, still refuses to have medical attendance, but a trained nurse who volunteered her services to the health officer is now in charge of the sick woman.

MARY JOHNSTON'S NEW STORY, -- In her new story, the first three chapters of which will appear in The Atlantic Monthly for May, Miss Mary Johnston's indeed, it seems rather to have gained in richness and perfection of style. One might almost glance an illustration of the grace and charm of Miss Johnston's style with a certainty of finding a delicacy and exquisiteness of touch and expression.

Mrs. Catherine Sulzer and her two children, through counsel, yesterday asked Surrogate Thomas to appoint a temporary administrator for the estate of Herman Sulzer. The Surrogate reserved his decision. The contention made for Mrs. Sulzer and her children was that as they had instituted a contest of the will, it was necessary to have a temporary administrator in order to prevent the estate from being dissipated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The position taken by THE TIMES upon Senator Stranahan's bill is generally commended. It does not follow because the Senate made the bill a party measure that it will become a law. But there is a strong probability that it well be pressed through. If the party in power choose to assume the responsibility of passing an objectionable measure, that does not relieve the situation.

THE NEW YORK TIMES presents the views of city officials, predecessors of the Mayor, prominent lawyers, revisionists, and other citizens on the message of Mayor Van Wyck. explaining his veto of the revised charter and on the provisions of the amended instrument itself.

A stimulating influence in yesterday's market was the publication of the British budget statement, in that it contained no proposal looking to import duties likely to curtail trade with the United States. There had been many predictions that Great Britain would be forced to adopt protective taxes, but she remains true to the policy of taxation for revenue only.

To The Editor of The New York Times: I was very much surprised at an editorial in your paper on the 13th in regard to the appeal which the Merchants' Association has made for funds to carry on their work in connection with the water supply of New York City.

Prices were somewhat stronger on the curb yesterday, but the market shared relatively little in the extraordinary activity and strength of the Stock Exchange market.
