Skinner, United States Navy, and comprises six astronomers and assistants from the Naval Observatory and five scientists, from other institutions, who will assist in the astro-physical work.

The will of George Pennefather Rothwell was filed for probate in the Surrogates' office yesterday. Accompanying the will and the three codicils were the articles of separation of Mr. Rothwell and his wife. Mr. Rothwell died at his home, 250 West One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Street, on April 17.

BOSTON, April 22. -- Money is in good supply; in fact, note brokers all complain of the scarcity of commercial paper and collateral loans. On call, money rules from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent., mostly 3 1/2@4 per cent. Time money is quoted at 4@4 1/2 per cent. for four to six months on good mixed Stock Exchange collateral.

BRISTOL, April 22. -- As the situation now exists, the new cup defender Constitution, that is to measure speed and skill against Shamrock II., will not be launched until after Hay 4. The date has not yet been decided upon and cannot be for several days, but under present circumstances it must be a date later than May 4.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- The market opened strong, with almost all issues in good demand, the only weakness being in steel stocks. The railroad stocks furnished the bulk of the early dealings. Pennsylvania advanced to 80 11-16, the highest figure yet recorded in this city. The Readings had a good rise, which is assumed to be the preliminary to a greater one.

It was discovered yesterday that three cases of smallpox were removed from the New York Foundling Asylum on Saturday last and taken to North Brother Island. The cases were not reported by the Board of Health until yesterday. The oldest of the three afflicted children is four years and the youngest eight months.
ALBANY, April 22. -- The New York Charter Amendment bill was passed over Mayor Van Wyck's veto by both branches of the Legislature to-day, and the six supplemental bills will be passed to-morrow.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 22. -- A bill that has just been passed by the Florida Legislature now in session at Tallahassee is attracting considerable attention from its peculiar wording, and also because Major St. Clair Abrams of this city, a lawyer, well-known throughout the State, has written a long open letter in one of the local newspapers strongly denouncing it.

A lurid story in an evening paper yesterday, setting forth the indignation of Philadelphia artists with the National Arts Club, because they had received an invitation to contribute paintings to the exhibit of the Arts Club at the Pan-American, but so late that they could not send them in time, is a story that had its origin, in the heated imagination of some one rather picturesquely misinformed.

The Court of Appeals has just handed down a decision in the case of Joseph Nowack, by Barnett Nowack, his guardian ad litem, against the Metropolitan Street Railway Company, which is of interest to all persons who have occasion to prosecute claims against corporations.

There was a blare of trumpets, the rattle of curtain rings in the hands of a trembling flunky, the stare of a multitude, and the "colossal consolidation of zoological, equestric, and arenic elements" of the programme as the Forepaugh-Sells circus came out into the arena of Madison Square Garden last night.

Work on the yachts building and fitting out at Shooter's Island is being rushed in earnest, and the yard is crowded with boats of all sizes and types, most of which must be gotten overboard in time for the opening of the racing season. Interest in the larger boats now nearing completion centres in the two 68-foot water-line schooners now on the stocks.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Commissioner of Internal Revenue Yerkes has held that persons engaged in taking orders for transactions described in Paragraph 3, Section 8. of the Act of March 2, 1901, (Bucket Shops,) are imperatively required by the statute to issue a memorandum for every such order, and to affix and cancel the requisite stamp thereon.

CHICAGO, April 22. -- Bullishness was rampant in the wheat and corn markets today. Corn, after an exciting day, during which prices were over the highest previous level, closed with an advance of 2 cents, while wheat registered a gain of 1 1/2. Oats closed 3/8 cent higher and provisions practically unchanged.

Patrick McAvoy, a laborer of the town of Hastings, yesterday discovered a man and a woman attempting to bury alive a two-weeks-old infant in some dense woods half a mile north of Yonkers. Just in time to save the child's life, McAvoy succeeded in disinterring it, the would-be murderers having fled from the new grave when they say their victim's rescuer pursuing them.

The question whether the five-million-dollar plan or the seventeen-million-dollar project for an approach to the new East River Bridge will be adopted by the city was discussed yesterday at the meeting of the local Boards of Improvements of the Eleventh and Twelfth Districts. The officials of the local boards have declared in favor of the five-milllon-dollar approach to be constructed by the widening of Delancey and Broome Streets to the Bowery.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES and some of the other papers have thus far won a victory in the name of humanity by the passage by the Senate of a bill to prevent the slaughter of pigeons.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The bill introduced by Mr. Bedell to amend the tax law in relation to the taxation of public franchises as real property, which passed the Assembly some time ago, was passed to-night by the Senate. It makes an important change in the franchise tax law by providing the following new section:
LONDON, April 23. -- According to a dispatch from St. Petersburg to The Daily Mail, official information has been received that renewed military activity is beginning in Manchuria.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Speaking of gas consumers' rights and liabilities of gas companies. It is a source of gratification for me to learn the fact that this German-American Fire Insurance Company has brought the Standard Gaslight Company to its knees, so to speak. and got a judgment against it for $500 in the Supreme Court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A scheme is on foot to save an inconsiderable sum of money by changing a portion of the subway to an elevated structure. The portion referred to begins at a point on Lenox Avenue at One Hundred and Forty-first Street and extends to Westchester Avenue, in the Bronx.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22. -- The will of Francis O. Matthiessen, who died in Paris on March 8, but who had a country home at Irvington-on-the-Hudson, was admitted to probate in the Surrogate's office to-day. No estimate is given as to the value of the estate, but it is thought to be about $15,000,000.
One-sixth of the new British loan has already been taken in the United States.

The crew of the French training ship Duguay Trouin was entertained by the French Chamber of Commerce last night with a banquet at Sherry's. The guests and their entertainers to the number of about a hundred sat down around an immense horseshoe table.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Raines bill, giving the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company the right to build a bridge across the Hudson River and construct approaches and terminals in the New York side, at and about Fifty-ninth Street, passed the Senate this afternoon by a vote of 28 to 18.
LONDON, April 23. -- The Right Rev. William Stubbs, D.D. Bishop of Oxford, died yesterday morning.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., April 22. -- A faithful Italian trackwalker, because the fasts flying Erie Western expres, commonly known as No. 7, was half an hour late, averted a serious railroad catastrophe early Sunday morning at Nobody's Switch. Train No. 7 left this village a half hour late and was thundering along to make up time.

It is to be regretted that the members of the Tree Planting Association, who have just issued their annual appeal to property owners to aid in beautifying our city by planting trees in our streets, are so abnormally sensitive to the suggestion that their effort is largely wasted for the reason that trees, if planted, will not grow in our city soil.

Again yesterday the transactions in the outside market were on a relatively-small scale. The tremendous dealings on the Stock Exchange instead of accelerating business on the curb have had a contrary effect, and for some days past the outside market has been more or less neglected, owing to the extreme attention commanded by the business on the Exchange.

Rainy weather and the bad condition of the grounds were responsible for the postponement of the New York-Boston, Chicago-Cincinnati, and St. Louis-Pittsburg baseball games yesterday. The only game played was that between Brooklyn and Philadelphia, and in this Brooklyn met her first defeat.

WASHINGTON, April 22. -- Immigration Commissioner Powderly, in undertaking to enforce the laws to guard against the importation of persons excluded from the United States for different reasons, encounters many difficulties, including the ingenuity of would-be immigrants, the cupidity of those who are constrained, for various reasons, to dodge the laws, and also some defects in the laws.

Interest in the annual Spring games of the Twenty-second Regiment, held at the armory last night, centred in the contest for the company trophy for team work, which last Fall resulted in a tie between Companies I and E. The competition last night was between I and E. and was undecided up to the last event, an obstacle race, at which time the score was Company F, 33 points; Company I, 31 points.

PEKING, April 22. -- A personage from Sian-Foo who is closely connected with the Court denies that Gen. Tung-Fu-Siang is in a state of open rebellion. The person in question thinks that the missionarie's who reported that he was in rebellion must have heard accounts of his harsh treatment of bandits falling into his hands.

Herbert A. Sherman has sold for Edward Kemp the block front on the west side of Broad Street, between Beaver and Marketfield Streets, now occupied by a fourstory building. The plot has frontages of 44 feet on Broad Street, 66.3 feet on Beaver Street, and 66 feet on Marketfield Street. Mr. Kemp bought this property about two years ago for $175,000.

KINGSTON, N.Y., April 22. -- The trout season has been open for seven days, and although there are hundreds of anxious anglers in the Catskills testing their luck, the trout for various reasons do not satisfy the eager sportsmen as readily as in former years. Since Sunday of last week every train has brought scores of men who each year make a pilgrimage to the Catskills, to be among the first to whip the streams.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 22. -- In a head-on collision at Bayway at 7 o'clock this morning two passenger trains on the Central Railway of New Jersey were badly wrecked and five passengers, all of them mechanics and laborers on their way to work, were injured.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., April 22. -- In the matter of the proving of the last will and testament of James Jennings McComb of Dobbs Ferry, the witnesses, with the exception of two were present in the Westchester County Surrogate's Court this morning and swore to the signature of the testator to the will and codicils.

A new war play came to town last night. It made its appearance at the American Theatre, where its debut was witnesed by a very large and demonstrative audience. The name of this new drama is "Winchester," but that does not necessarily mean that Sheridan and the famous ride are figures in its action.

PHILADELPHIA, April 22. -- Pitcher White, who came here from the George-town University team, made his National League debut to-day, and Brooklyn's defeat was principally due to his excellent work. He was in fine form and had perfect control and kept the visitors' hits well scattered.

TOPEKA, Kan., April 22. -- An application was made to-day to the State Charter Board by A.L. Williams, general attorney for the Union Pacific Railroad Company, for permission to increase the capital stock of the Union Pacific Railroad Company $100,000,000. The Union Pacific's capital is at present $190,000,000.

Could the "Veteran Observer," who thirty years since gravely discussed in the columns of THE TIMES, to the bepuzzlement of the public, the possibility that New York should within the lifetime of his younger readers be lending money for the commercial enterprises of Russia, comment on yesterday's issue of his favorite paper he would do so with the glad emphasis of the prophet whose predictions have been surprisingly sustained if not completely verified.

NEWPORT, April 22. -- Gunner Charles Morgan, United States Navy, whose recent correspondence with Rear Admiral Sampson attracted so much attention, has brought suit in Newport County for divorce against his wife, Mary Morgan, who has been making her home in Erie, Penn.
ALBANY, April 22. -- In the Senate to-day upon an emergency message from Gov. Odell the Annual Supply bill was passed. The annual Appropriation bill also was passed, as were the following:

LONDON, April 23. -- At the National Sporting Club, London, last night, "Jack" Roberts of England knocked out "Billy" Smith, the American, in the eighth round The fight was for the nine-stone champion-ship of England.

It is high commendation to say of the work done at Albany during the session that it has been remarkably free from evidences of corporation influence. Gov. ODELL has shown a disposition to treat corporation interests like other interests, with fairness to them and with justice to the public; and the Governor has had the Legislature well in hand, insomuch that its course has many times been visibly shaped by his influence.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The joint committee of the Legislature on Statutory Revision Commission bills has made its report. There was before the committee for consideration fifty-two bills, consisting of proposed general laws, such as the education law, the prison law, and the wills law; the code bills, which carry out the commission's plan of code separation, and amendments to existing general laws.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The bill of Senator Slater prohibiting the shooting of live pigeons was killed in the Assembly to-night after a brief debate, it failing to receive the constitutional majority. The defeat of the measure was followed by charges and counter-charges of lobbying.

ALBANY, April 22. -- A peculiar spectacle was seen to-day when the bill introduced by Senator Brackett to amend the Penal Code relative to pool selling, bookmaking, bets, and wagers, came up for disposition in the Assembly. Assemblyman Sullivan took the floor and made a speech in favor of the measure.

At a full meeting of the Executive Committee of the Council of the New York University, held in William F. Havemeyer's office, 32 Nassau Street, yesterday afternoon, it was decided to demand the resignations from the School of Pedagogy of Profs. Frederick Monteser, Ph. D., and Linnaeus Edford La Fetra and Dean Edward R. Shaw.
LONDON, April 22. -- The Executive Committee of the British clay bird shooters met this evening and cabled the committee of the American club as follows:

BERLIN, April 22. -- With reference to statements cabled from the United States of a plot said to have been concocted against Emperor William and other European rulers by Anarchists in Argentina and New Jersey, extreme reticence is observed in official circles in Berlin.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Persons interested in the question of the terminal of Brooklyn Bridge should read the admirable editorial on the subject in Engineering News of last week. It shows that the proposed revival of the horseshoe loop will not now be of use, the conditions having completely changed.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 11. -- A curious story is being told in the press of Mexico in regard to a life insurance policy issued by one of the strongest companies in the United States in favor of a man named John Rye.

The suit brought by the German-American Investment Company to have the San Domingo Improvement Company and the San Domingo Finance Company declared insolvent was again before Vice Chancellor Pitney, at Jersey City, yesterday on argument as to the appointment of a receiver. Complainants also ask for an order requiring the defendant companies to pay a claim of $28,000 and $14,000 interest on bonds amounting to $137,000 issued by the San Domingo Government.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Being a resident of this borough for some time and deeply interested in the education, advancement, and prosperity of my countrymen; also, the further strengthening of our united and determined efforts to assist our people in our native land to obtain their freedom, I respectfully request that you give space to the following suggestion in the columns of your valuable and interesting paper.

BALTIMORE, April 22. -- It Is stated that when the Johns Hopkins University Trustees have succeeded in raising the $1,000,000 endowment which will assure the university the gift from William Keyser, Frances M. Jencks, and William Wyman of land estimated to be worth another $1,000,000 for a new site outside the city, they will receive a handsome gift from Henry Walters.

ALBANY, April 22. -- The Congressional Reapportionment bill was debated and passed in the Asembly to-night by a strict party vote. The principal attack was made on the bill by Minority Leader Frisbie. He said, in part:

MANILA, April 22. -- A press representative visited Emilio Aguinaldo this afternoon at 56 Solano Street, whither he was removed from the Malacanan, and found him in a large room up stairs, furnished with a table, a typewriting machine, three settees, and twenty chairs. His wife, who was entertaining a number of Filipino women, sat at one end of the room, while Aguinaldo, smoking a cigar and chatting with Benito Legardo, occupied the opposite corner.

It is becoming more and more evident to the rank and file of Wall Street that the public in the present market is not a credulous nor ignorant quantity to be duped at pleasure. On the contrary, the public mind is keen and alert and is sifting out fact from fiction with creditable correctness.

LONDON, April 22. -- To-day The Daily Telegraph concludes a series or rowing articles by "An Old Blue," who, in addition to being an English university oarsman, acted at one time as a Harvard coach, and therefore is supposed, from the English point of view, to speak with authority on American athletics.

The stock brokerage firm of John Kelly Co. at 32 Broadway, of which John Kelly, the gambler widely known as "Honest John Kelly," was at the head, filed a general deed of assignment for the benefit of creditors yesterday. The assignee named in the deed is Thomas L. Reynolds of 494 Lenox Avenue.

Magistrate Zeller in the Yorkville Police Court yesterday denounced Lawyer Richard S. Wallace of 194 Lexington Avenue as a disgrace to the profession and, after ordering a complaint of grand larceny made out against him, held him in $1,000 bail for examination.

Having concluded his theatrical season in this country Daniel Frohman will this morning sail for England on the American liner St. Louis. His attractions in this country, which do not require his personal attention -- E.H. Sothern, who is on tour, and "San Toy," which occupies Daly's Theatre -- will continue until the end of June with a possibility of the musical comedy remaining for a longer period.

So great was the crowd that gathered in the vestry room of the Temple Emanu-El for the public meeting of the Alliance Israelite Universelle last evening that the seats and aisles were filled long before the time announced for the beginning of the speaking. It was finally decided to have the meeting in the temple, and even there the main floor and gallery were filled almost immediately.

The Iowa Life Underwriters' Association has been reorganized and the following officers elected: President -- Cyrus Flick; Vice President -- George B. Peck; Secretary -- C.S. Hunter; Treasurer -- R.P. Dart.
Following a luncheon at Delmonico's yesterday, the "Republican Women of the State of New York" organized a State association.

Although the United States has little reason to fear any combination, commercial or political, among the countries of Europe, that is no good cause for ignoring the fact that the commercial policy of our Government is really injurious to these countries as well as to our own.

The irregularity of the Stock Exchange market resulted in a similar condition in the outside market yesterday, and prices fluctuated rather widely. The majority of the net changes resulting from the day's transactions appeared on the side of declines, the market being under considerable selling pressure.

Gen. Leonard A. Wood, Military Governor of Cuba, with Mrs. Wood and his private secretary, arrived here last night from Havana on the Ward liner Morro Castle. Other passengers on the vessel were Michael J. Dady of Brooklyn, the successful bidder for large contracts in Cuba; Mrs. Dady, and Shen Ksun, a member of the Chinese Legation in Havana.

NEWARK, N.J., April 23. -- Judge Andrew Kirkpatrick of the United States Court does not like Vice Chancellor Pitney's advice to the receiver appointed by him yesterday for the Plainfield Furniture Company.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Venezuela has received the first installment of a stunning rebuke, and there is more of it coming. Three powers have already signified to her that they will not respect the decisions of her courts, and that certain decrees issued by her executive are null and void. Two other powers are about to issue the same notice to her, if they have not already issued it, and others are expected.

The principal event of yesterday was the wedding of Miss Isabel Stillman and Bercy Rockefeller, which is described in another column. The continued gloomy and chilly weather discouraged the party which had engaged the Pioneer for the day, and it went out sans passengers. Reginald Rives was the whip.

CAMDEN, N.J., April 23. -- The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Electric Company bf America was held here today. The annual report shows: Net profits for the year 1900, $410,695; profit from operation of plants, $374.528; other income, $36,156. The total assets of the company are $3,810,819.
The ship Lyndhurst arrived from Japan yesterday after a voyage of nearly six months' duration, and which was marked by three startling and tragic events.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 23. -- The universities were reopened yesterday. With the permission of the Minister of Public Instruction, Gen. Vannoffsky, the students held a meeting and, after a four hours' debate, adopted the following resolution by a vote of 1,561 to 228:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 23. -- The Yale Dramatic Association gave a most successful rendition of Thomas Heywood's Elizabethan period play, "The Fair Maid of the West," in the Hyperion Theatre tonight. A large audience of college people turned out to see the undergraduates. It was a fairly enthusiastic one.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, April 23. -- Referring to the telegram from the British clay target shooters, saying that the London match between the American and English teams must be held early in July instead of in August, Secretary Paul North of the American team said to-day: "Unfortunately we had already arranged for two shooting tournaments in this country during July.

LONDON, April 24. -- Although Edna May, in "The Girl from Up There," had a kindly reception at the Duke of York's Theatre last night, and received abundant applause, the expectations of the public were rather disappointed, as another "Belle of New York" had been looked for.

BOSTON, Mass., April 23. -- Speaking today before the Massachusetts Board of Trade, Senator George F. Hoar made some remarks on the restriction of debate in Congress, a matter to which he said he had given more thought than to any other, except the welfare of races. In the course of his address he said:

A quarrel between a few messenger boys and an Italian fruit vendor in Broad Street about 12:30 o'clock yesterday quickly developed into a small-sized riot, which caused the suspension of business among the curb brokers for half an hour and resulted in bringing all of the reserves from the Old Slip and Church Street Stations and ten men from Police Headquarters to the scene.

Plans of the Get Together Club for their dinner at the Pouch Gallery, Brooklyn, on Monday evening have been much deranged by the refusal of the Rev. Dr. Newell Dwight Hillis, pastor of Rlymouth Church, the Rev. Dr. S.D. McConnell, rector of Holy Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, and Dr. Rossiter Raymond to be among the speakers upon that occasion, when Prof. George D. Herron, the Socialist lecturer, is expected as one of the principal guests.

ALBANY, April 23. -- Both branches of the Legislature adjourned sine die this afternoon, the Senate at 12:45 and the Assembly at 1:02 o'clock. Contrary to the custom which has been in vogue for many years, there were no presentations either in the Assembly or the Senate. The customary social features were absent in both houses.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Representative Babcock, who has provoked some of the immovable high tariff men in his own party by proposing to strike from the tariff those duties that simply take from the consumer without giving revenue to the Government, has reached Washington after a Western trip more stoutly in favor of the revision he suggested than he was before he secured testimony as to its soundness and its popularity throughout the western country.

With seven days remaining, the present month of April has already exceeded in the fall of rain any April since 1893. In that year the rainfall for April amounted to 6.36 inches. Up to yesterday the rainfall for this month was 5.47 inches. If the month keeps it up at the present rate it will be pretty apt to break all records for rain in the history of the Weather Department.

LONDON, April 24. -- Gilbert Parker, the author and Conservative member of the House of Commons from Gravesend, presided at the St. George's Day banquet in London last evening. A message was read from the St. George Society of New York and a reply thereto was cabled to that city.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Systematic frauds by which the lines of the Washington Traction and Electric Company loss probably $50,000 have been discovered. Eight of the employes, six conductors and two firemen, are under arrest charged with conspiracy.

The annual report of the Finance Department, just issued, shows that the total of municipal expenditures in New York in 1900 somewhat exceeded $130,000,000. The budget for that year, including county expenses and interest, redemption, $c., was $90,778,972. The remainder of the sum representing the year's expenditures for municipal purposes was provided by general revenue and through bond issues for specific purposes.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., April 23. -- It is stated that more than $3,000 was secured in the hold-up of the Choctaw, Oklahoma and Gulf passenger train last midnight near Iron Mountain Crossing, four and a half miles west of Memphis. The train left Memphis at 11:40 last night and reached Little Rock half an hour late, at 6 o'clock this morning.

WISCASSET, Me., April 23. -- An attempt was made to rob the First National Bank here early this morning. The vault and interior of the bank building were badly damaged by a heavy explosion which shook the entire town, waking all the inhabitants. The robbers fled, leaving their tools behind.
Major James B. Houston, Additional Paymaster. United States Volunteers, will remain on temporary duty at San Francisco until May 28.

BALTIMORE, April 23. -- The market to-day was weak, occasioned by the depressing influence of the declines in Seaboard and Cotton Duck. The former broke under the weight of heavy offering on the part of New York. The bulk of these offerings was from one firm, which is known to be a large holder of the stocks, bought during the bull bulge of several weeks ago.

The action of the Legislature in granting to the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company the franchise for an elevated passenger and freight belt line over the dock property of the city aroused strong opposition and condemnation in official and business circles yesterday. Controller Coler declared that the legal measure against the violation of the city's rights would be carried, if necessary, to the United States Supreme Court.
CHICAGO, April 23. -- Money to-day was unchanged, being bad for call and time loans at 4 1/2@5 per cent. New York exchange was quoted at 15 cents discount.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- President McKinley to-day pardoned Joseph N. Wolfson. He was convicted in 1896 in the United States District Court of Louisiana of being in collusion with the bookkeeper of the Union National Bank of New Orleans in the embezzlement of $640,000 of the funds of the bank.

ALBANY, April 23. -- Speaker Nixon, in closing the session of the Assembly, reviewed the work accomplished by the Legislature during the past year, commented on the reduction of the tax rate, and the many economical measures that have been passed, and in closing recommended the passage of a uniform mortgage tax law at the next session.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 23. -- The remarkable memory of Mrs. Naomi Cannon, who is eighty-three years of age, and who lives with her son-in-law, City Treasurer Charles E. Schou, in this city, has, it is said, influenced materially the decision of a will contest in Providence, R.I., which involved not only fortune, but the legitimacy of the principal legatee, which was attacked by the testator's wife.

A company has been formed to build a new railroad bridge over the St. Lawrence River at Montreal, which is to cost $6,000,000. The company which will build the bridge is the Montreal Bridge Company. Henry Hogan is President, Percival Clement, President of the Rutland Railroad, is Vice President, and the Directors include Dr. W.S. Webb, Hiram Steele, J.R. Thibeaudeau, T. Berthaum, R. Bickerdike, and Mayor Prefontaine of Montreal.

Members of the Dauntless Rowing Club have read with mingled amusement and indignation the cabled dispatches from London advising the Stewards of the Henley regatta to scrutinize carefully the American entries, particularly those of the University of Pennsylvania and the Dauntless Club of New York.

A bold and successful burglary was accomplished during the early hours of yesterday morning at the residence or Charles B. Hubbell, at 20 West Eleventh Street, the thieves making an entrance through the front door of the house, quietly packing up all the silverware they could find, amounting in all to about $500 in value, and then decamping by the way they had come and leaving no clue behind.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23. -- The Choctaws and American Railways made new high records to-day, and their strength stiffened the whole list. The phenomenal rise of nearly 4 points in Choctaw common, to 60 1/4, and 3 1/2 points, to 55, for the preferred, was based on a statement that the Atchison system had offered $65 per share for both stocks and had deposited $100,000 as a guarantee of good faith.

ALBANY, April 23. -- The Raines Bridge bill, which is designed, according to its caption, "to facilitate the construction of a bridge over the North River and an elevated approach along West Street from the Battery to Fifty-ninth Street," passed the Assembly this morning by a vote of 95 yeas to 46 nays.

The wedding of Percy Avery Rockefeller, son of William Rockefeller, and Miss Isabel Stillman, daughter of James Stillman, was celebrated at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Forty-fourth Street and Madison Avenue, by the Rev. Dr. David H. Greer, rector of the church.

Contracts were signed yesterday afternoon for the sale of the Powers estate tract of about 320 lots, in the Fort George section of Washington Heights, to a syndicate, among the members of which are Max Marx, Nathan Wise, Gutwillig Brothers, Adolph M. Bendheim, and John G. Miller.

ALBANY, April 23. -- An attempt was made during the last moments of the Senate session to pass the bill to allow ex-Assemblyman E.C. Brennan and Assemblyman Rierdon to practice law without taking the regular examinations. The bill was in charge of Senator Tim Sullivan, who labored heroically to have it passed against an obstinate minority.

A recent dispatch from Washington called attention to the very large amount of gold now in the Treasury, larger than ever before, and, according to the dispatch, greater than the amount of gold in the national banks of any other country.

President Eugene A. Hoffman of the New York Historical Society has added to the membership of the original committee of five appointed to secure subscriptions for the new building, and yesterday its first appeal was issued to the members regarding its plans and the necessity for prompt action.

The investigation which President Morris K. Jesup of the American Museum of Natural History commissioned Edward M. Shepard, the counsel for the museum, to make of the contracts for work on the museum building awarded by William Wallace, formerly superintendent of the museum buildings, has been concluded.

LONDON, April 24. -- Applications for the new war loan continue to pour into the Bank of England. The subscribers yesterday, though numerous, were mostly small investors. It is estimated that the loan was subscribed for six or seven times over, and it is expected that the list will be closed to-day, as it is not desired to lock up too much money.
ALBANY, April 23. -- The tax rate for 1901 is one and twenty one-hundredths mills, the lowest in forty years. It is based on the following:

The declination of Carol Norton, the Christian Scientist, to meet the Rev. Dr. James M. Buckley, editor of The Christian Advocate, in debate on the subject of Christian Science created a sensation at the Nineteenth Century Club last evening. About 400 persons attended the meeting, which was held at Sherry's.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 23. -- G. Edward Ide's keel sloop Cara is receiving the usual attention, preparatory to launching and going into commission, at the Woods yard, and Charles Bancker's sloop Hebe is undergoing the same process in addition to a few minor changes. A wheel and gear will take the place of the present cumber-some tiller, which it was found last year did not act satisfactorily.

The woman who goes South need not spend $4 or $5 for baby alligators and have the trouble of bringing them home for the pleasure of her children. They can be found in New York, and healthy little twelve-inch reptiles can be bought for $1 aprece. They can be tamed with but little trouble, will learn to know the voice of their owner, and eat from the hand.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., April 23. -- The Rev. H.J. Hayter appeared in the Bradley Beach Council Chamber last night and set up his right to a seat in the board. He was elected last March. He was in Florida at the time, and he qualified before a Florida Commissioner and his papers arrived the last day limited by law.

WASHINGTON, April 23. -- Following is the Weather Bureau's weeekly summary of crop conditions: This is the fourth consecutive week of abnormally cold weather over nearly the whole country, with the most marked temperature deficiency of the season in the central valleys and Southern States, and heavy precipitation throughout the Ohio Valley and over the greater portion of the Atlantic Coast and Gulf districts.

ST. LOUIS, April 23. -- Articles of incorporation of the Louisiana Purchase Exposition Company were filed with the Recorder of Deeds this afternoon by Attorney Stanley Stoner, acting for James H.G. Lair, chief counsel for the company. The capital stock is $6,000,000. According to the articles of incorporation 10 per cent of the $5,000,000 subscribed is paid in.

An interesting suit is now engaging the attention of the Texas jurists which involves a new question, and one which the geologists will have to take a hand in settling. The law of that State makes certain provisions for the sale of lands which are the property of the Commonwealth to any one who shall locate thereon a claim to minerals in the ground.

LONDON, April 23. -- An excellent programme and Summer-like weather attracted unusual crowds to the Epsom Spring Meeting to-day. Americans were only placed once in the first three events, when Richard Croker's Scotchman II, ridden by L. Reiff, was third in the Nork Park Plate, L.W. Humby's Royal George winning.

CHICAGO, April 23. -- John H. Clark, President of the Chicago Telephone Company, will retire within the next week. He will be succeeded by John I. Sabin of San Francisco. Mr. Sabin also will become President of the Central Union Telephons Company, which controls the Bell system, covering Illinois, Iowa, Indiana, and Ohio, succeeding W.A. Jackson, who also will retire.

Mr. CARLYLE in his affable fashion once said to ANTHONY TROLLOPE, "You are going straight to perdition, and you are going the vulgarest way." During the last twenty years a good many American newspapers have taken the broad road to perdition and they have traveled it in the vulgarest way.

Prison bars and close confinement in the gloomy Tombs have failed to prevent Edwin Stoddard, imprisoned under the name of Paul D. Hart, and known across the continent as a notorious swindler, from pursuing his nefarious occupation.
The Board of Public Improvements met yesterday and decided to give a public hearing on May 15 on the plans for the approach to the new East River Bridge, in the Borough of Manhattan.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
Army. Second Lieut. Edward M. Offley, recently appointed, is assigned to the Twelfth Cavalry, and will join that regiment at Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

The will of Joel Goldenberg, who died suddenly at Broadway and Broome Street on April 19, was filed in the Surrogates' Office yesterday. Mr. Goldenberg was a member of the lace importing firm of Goldenberg Brothers Co. He was a bachelor, and in his will he leaves a large share of his estate to charitable institutions.

BONN, April 24 -- At the grand kommers given here to-night in his Majesty's honor, after the matriculation at Bonn University to-day of Crown Prince Frederick William, Emperor William spoke as follows:
LONDON, April 25 -- The House of Commons yesterday passed the second reading of the Deceased Wife's Sister bill by 290 to 106 votes.

During the last session of the New Jersey Legislature, P.J. Flynn of Brooklyn, who is building Jersey City's new water plant at Boonton, N.J., sought legislation that would enable the Morris Canal Company to vacate its right to draw water from the Rockaway River, but failed. The reason for seeking this legislation was that his contract requires him to furnish to Jersey City the full flow of the Rockaway water shed.

Walter W. Price, a member of the late firm of Price, McCormick Co., was married yesterday afternoon to Miss Ysobel Haskins, who for the last five years has been identified with the theatrical stage. The ceremony was performed at the residence of Mrs. E.G. Davis, at 366 West Fifty-seventh Street, where Mrs. Price's aunt, Mrs. Charles Hannington, has been living.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The Secretary of War to-day made public the names of the 588 men selected for First and Second Lieutenants in the regular army under the Reorganization bill. All of these men have had service either in the State or National volunteers or in the regular army. They have been ordered for examination and should they pass will be appointed.4

PORTLAND, Me., April 24 -- One man was shot and instantly killed, another so seriously wounded that he died to-night, two others fatally wounded, and Deputy Marshal Willard Frith slightly wounded by George H. Brainerd of Boston in the New England Telegraph and Telephone Company's Building here this afternoon.

BOSTON, April 24 -- At Libbie's to-day, in selling the French library, the first of the Grolier Club vellum books brought $1,600, the top price for a single volume. It was catalogued as "A Decree of Star Chamber Concerning Printing, Made July 11, 1637. Reprinted for the Grolier Club from the first edition, 1637, New York, 1884."

A novel method of disciplining an attorney was resorted to by the Appellate. Division in Brooklyn yesterday. On Friday last the court, by Justice Jenks, rendered an opinion severely condemning the professional conduct of Felix Reifschneider, Jr., and ordering him to appear before the court in person.

One feature of the mission work of the American Missionary Association at Cape Prince of Wales, Alaska, consists of a herd of reindeer cared for by the missionary, Mr. Lopp, and his native assistants. Secretary C.J. Ryder, D.D. recently wrote to the Interior Department at Washington asking for facts, and received the following report:

LONDON, April 25 -- The date of Lord Salisbury's return to London from the Riviera is still problematical, and the rumors of Cabinet troubles over the budget are assuming greater consistency in the lobbies of Parliament.
VICTORIA, B.C., April 24 -- In an interview in The Kobe Herald, Minister Conger, who is on his way to San Francisco, said:

Standing on the deck of the steamship Pocahontas, in Jersey City, yesterday, a dozen camels gazed sadly at the gray gloom of sky and water. What their reflections were no one can tell, but that they were not highly pleased with their first experience of American climatic conditions may be inferred from the manner in which they asserted themselves when an effort was made to take them from the steamer.

A satisfaction of judgment was filed yesterday in the United States Circuit Court, in the case of James Allison against the New York Life Insurance Company, in which case Oscar Hammerstein recovers the sum of $31,038.25, that amount covering the fixtures in the Olympia Theatre.

In the drizzling rain a man in a light brown overcoat left the Criminal Courts Building about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon and walked down Centre Street. At the Staats-Zeitung Building two other men joined him. It was just at the time when the crowds were pouring from the big skyscrapers, and all the streets leading to the bridge were black with hurrying people.

LONDON, April 25 -- J.X. Merriman, (ex-Treasurer of Cape Colony and now a representative of the Afrikander Bond in England,) spoke at a meeting of the League of Liberals, yesterday, against aggression and militarism. He said military law, the abnegation of all law, was established in Cape Colony.

Controller Coler, who delivered an address on "Greater New York and Its Possibilities," under the auspices of the St. Vincent de Paul Society, at Carnegie Hall last night, took occasion to denounce in unmeasured terms legislation at Albany which he considered adverse to the city's interests and inimical to the principle of home rule.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading "Should the Underground Be Overground," a correspondent in to-day's TIMES attacks a plan by which, without added cost, seven and a half instead of three square miles of Bronx territory would be developed by the rapid transit system now under construction.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 -- The continued demand for the Choctaws around the highest recorded level was the feature of the market to-day. The stock is presumably passing into new hands preparatory to a transfer of control-in all probability to the Atchison or Missouri Pacific. American Alkali was strong at the opening, but weakened on rumors of a call coincident with a new capitalization plan.
CHICAGO, April 24 -- New York exchange was quoted to-day at 10 cents discount. Money for call and time loans, 4 1/2@5 per cent.

The proceedings for annulment of marriage instituted by Mrs. Grace Clarke Bates, daughter of Thomas B. Clarke, the art collector, against Harry Wakefield Bates have been held before Justice Fitzgerald, in Part V., Special Term, of the Supreme Court, this week. They have been conducted in a quiet manner, and at all the stages the persons interested are referred to as "plaintiff" or "defendant."

CHICAGO, April 24 -- The American League season was formally opened here to-day with decorations, music, and the hoisting of the championship pennant. Hoffer's wildness at the start gave the champions their first game. Bradley, Shugart, and both outfields did sensational fielding. Score:

"Have you found out who stole the gold?" was asked of Capt. Engelbart and the other officers of the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse when that vessel reached her dock on North River yesterday morning. The answer, however, was in the negative.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The commission of five delegates to the Cuban Constitutional Convention, who were sent to Washington to confer with the President regarding Cuban relations with this country, arrived here this morning, together With an interpreter, and representatives of the Havana press.

Judge Rufus B. Cowing's associates on the General Sessions bench and his friends throughout the city were surprised greatly to learn yesterday of his marriage Tuesday in Detroit to Mrs. Marie A. Harral, the widow of a former physician of this city.

The regular Spring exhibition by woman painters is held this year at Clausen's Gallery. While not so large as that shown last year in the galleries of the Arts Club, and lacking as it does pictures as fine as three or four in the eleventh exhibition, the quality of the exhibits is evener and the general impression is a good one.

ALBANY, April 24 -- By the passage of the Humphrey bill to amend the banking law relative to building and loan corporations or associations, and co-operative loan associations, Superintendent of Banks Kilburn has received all the power which he asked for the regulation of these associations.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: In the Republican platform of 1900 there is a boast of the great prosperity of the country due to the fact that during Mr. McKinley's Administration we had shipped out of the country wealth to the amount of $1,483,537,094. The assumption in the platform is that this sum has been paid to us in gold.

LONDON, April 24 -- Under the influence of mid-Summer weather, the scenes in London this morning closely resembled those of a Derby Day. From an early hour a string of vehicles, from the coster's donkey barrow to the four-in-hand, passed, bound for Epsom, to see the race for the City and Suburban.

The Mayor's office was crowded yesterday until nearly 6 o'clock with persons interested in hearings on legislative bills. There were many measures up for discussion. The Mayor declared against the bill which sought to establish an inebriates' home in the city. The establishment was to be put under the charge of private persons and would to all intents and purposes be a private institution supported by city money.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- The candidates selected from New York for Lieutenancies are mostly former members of the National Guard regiments. Several are selected who served in the provisional regiments organized after the departure of the original National Guard regiments for the front in the Spanish war.

The North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, which arrived Tuesday noon and anchored down the bay to await the lifting of the fog, came up to her berth at the Cunard piers yesterday morning. Four hundred and ninety persons were in the cabins of the Kaiser, and a formidable array of friends and acquaintances were at the pier to meet them.

The conference which was begun two weeks ago between officials of the Central Railroad of New Jersey and Grievance Committees of the road's employes terminated yesterday afternoon in an agreem ent which both sides declared perfectly satisfactory. When the conference met yesterday morning in the office of General Superintendent J.H. Olhausen in the station at Communipaw, the only business to be disposed of was the consideration of the requests of the telegraphers.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 24 -- Frank A. Wilmot, President of the Manufacturers' Association of Bridgeport, and also President of the Wilmot Hobbs Manufacturing Company, has written a letter to Congressman J.W. Babcock of Wisconsin, indorsing his proposed tariff reform measure for the placing of various raw materials on the free list.

Rumors of purchases on the south side of Cedar Street, east of Nassau Street, by the Mutual life Insurance Company were revived yesterday. The company recently bought 62 and 64 Cedar Street, and, according to present reports, have also acquired 52, 54, and 56, adjoining the Continental Building.

LONDON, April 16 -- It is a popular delusion in London that Sir Henry Irving is the one actor of his era who is held in public reverence. The "reception" he got when he appeared on the Lyceum stage the other night in the red toga of Caius Marcius was as boisterously affectionate as possible, but so are nearly all theatrical "receptions."

OMAHA, Neb., April 24 -- The case of the State against James Callahan was briefly presented to the jury by County Attorney Shields to-day. E.A. Cudahy, one of the central figures in the kidnapping incident, took the stand. Mr. Shields said that the State would seek to identify Callahan, one of the men who, in the guise of a Sarpy County official, seized young Cudahy in front of his home.

The Union League Club, by a vote of nearly three to one, last night decided not to dispense with the services of the colored help. The meeting was one of the largest in the history of the organization, 484 votes being cast on one proposition.
The recent pronunciamlento of AGUINALDO must have caused a thrill of horror to run through the whole embattled ranks of the anti-imperialists -- "few and faint, but fearless still."
Assistant United States Treasurer Jordan, at the New York Sub Treasury yesterday. talking of the editorial comment of THE NEW YORK TIMES on the accumulation of

INDIANAPOLIS, April 24 -- The editor of The Journal is in receipt of a letter from Col. W.R. Holloway, United States Consul-General at St. Petersburg, dated April 9, in which these statements are made:

In the absorbing interest of great mergers with capitalizations which a few years ago would have been deemed impossible, we are apt to overlook the fact that a great deal is going on in the world which makes for good in very much larger degree than do the operations of the Wall Street financiers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am a daily and somewhat careful reader of your paper, and noting how willing you are to be corrected or called to account for any shortcomings, the more readily do I take exception to the article in your "Topics of the Times" column of yesterday upon the proposed monument soon to be erected at Yori-hama, Japan.

The wretched weather has had its effect upon all social movements. Many house parties which had been planned have been given up for the present, and golf is almost at a standstill. There has been little following of the hounds at Meadow Brook, and the coach Pioneer, which was taken by Worthington Whitehouse went out without his guests yesterday morning.

Irregularity continued yesterday in the outside market, and at the same time there was a falling off in transactions. In some parts of the market there was a good show of strength and a number of advances which in some cases amounted to as much as 2 points resulted from the buying orders that found their way to the market.

The northerly end of the block bounded by Broadway, Seventh Avenue, and Forty-second Street, all that part of it which is not covered by the Pabst Hotel, has been sold by Amos F. Eno, through Douglas Robinson Co., to the Subway Realty Company.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 24 -- The dredger which began operations here Monday afternoon is fast making a deep channel in the harbor for the launching of the Constitution. Several mechanics are fixing the timbers of the marine railway in the slip where the wood has become decayed somewhat.
Count ARVID POSSE, ex-Premier of Sweden, died at Stockholm yesterday. He was eighty-one years old.

It has been observed with a good deal of annoyance and vexation by the management of the New York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company for some time past, that the per annum earnings of the Hudson and Harlem Divisions of the system, while fairly satisfactory on the whole, were just a shade short of being up to what they should be.

Proofs are multiplying that both sides in China are learning something. It is very evident, by the international recriminations of responsibility in Europe, that nobody there is particularly proud of the manner in which "Christian civilization" has been propagated by the allied forces under the command of the Count VON WALDERSEE.

NEWARK, N.J., April 24 -- The controversy in Brooklyn over Dr. George D. Herron, late Professor of Applied Christianity of Iowa State University, has disturbed several of those whose names appear on the committee under whose management Dr. Herron is advertised to lecture in this city.

WASHINGTON, April 24 -- There has been considerable speculation about the division of the work of the Cabinet officers after the departure of the President and some of his Secretaries for the West. Last year, when most of the Cabinet were away, Secretary Root assumed a large part of the duties of the Secretary of State in addition to his own.

-- When Surgeon General STERNBERG, in his recent formal order, informed his subordinates that hereafter the existence of malaria at any army post would be regarded as proof that a previous order in relation to the destruction of mosquitoes had not been obeyed, ill-informed critics may have thought that he was accepting a new theory somewhat hastily.

CLAYTON, N.M., April 24 -- message was received to-night through Gov. Otero from President McKinley granting Thomas Ketchum, alias "Black Jack," who was to have been hanged here Friday, April 26, a reprieve until May 25, 1901. The prisoner arrived here to-day by a special train over the Colorado and Southern Railroad.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., April 24 -- Vice President Theodore Roosevelt was advanced to-night to the third degree of the Masonic Order in Matinecock Lodge, No. 806. About 300 members of the order attended, including Grand Master Charles W. Mead of the Grand Lodge of the State and his entire staff.

NEWPORT, April 24 -- An important real estate sale was reported to-day by De Blois Eldridge, who sold the Francis M. Freeman estate, on the southwest corner of Bellevue and Victoria Avenues, known as Tower Top, to W. Storrs Wells of New York. Mr. Wells is building a handsome house on the corner of Bellevue and Ruggles Avenues, which land adjoins that of the Freeman estate.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 24 -- During the first day of the trial of Charles R. Eastman, accused of murdering his brother-in-law, Richard H. Grogan, Jr., on July 4, 1900, the Court made an important ruling in favor of the defense by refusing to admit practically all the evidence which the prosecution intended to present as showing the dying declarations of Grogan.

BOSTON, April 25 -- The French library sale at Libbie's closed to-day with high prices, the top figure being $1,300 for a copy of Poe's " Al Aaraaf, Tamerlane and Minor Poems." A first edition of Poe's "Murders in the Rue Morgue," originally picked up in a Boston book stall for 15 cents, was sold for $1,000, a Boston man who was acting for a collector securing the volume.

LONDON, April 25 -- The Vice President of the Grand Trunk Railroad authorizes a denial of the report, telegraphed to New York, from Montreal, that negotiations are on foot for the consolidation of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the Grand Trunk Railway, and the Richelieu and Ontario Navigation Company.

The sudden resurrection by the District Attorney's office of three indictments for perjury and poolselling, found five years ago against John C. Dudley, formerly an employe of Peter De Lacy, caused Lawyer Benjamin Steinhardt, who has recently been waging war on gambling at race tracks, to demand of District Attorney Philbin yesterday if the latter intended to lend his office to the furtherance "of such methods of intimidation."

LONDON, April 25. -- At the first day's racing of the Sandown Park second Spring meeting to-day the Sandown Park Stud Produce Stakes was won by the Irena colt, ridden by Lester Reiff. The Tudor Plate, for three-year-olds, at one mile, was won by George Faber's Pietermaritzburg. Desaymar, owned by Sir J. Blundell Maple, was second, and Richard Croker's, Viper, with Lester Reiff in the saddle, was third.

The annual amateur wrestling and sparring championship contests of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union, which can not be held as usual in the State on account of the existing law prohibiting sparring exhibitions, were begun last night at the Lyric Theatre, Hoboken, under the auspices of the Valencia Boat Club of that city.
The Merriman estate has sold the plot on Fifth Avenue, 100 feet north of Eighty-third Street. 30 by 100.

WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Representative Livingston of Georgia, the leading Democrat on the Appropriations Committee in the last House of Representatives, is not surprised to hear expressions of favor from Southern men for the politics of the Republican Party, notably among bankers, railroad men, cotton manufacturers, and others engaged in big business enterprises.

Yesterday was another day of weddings, the most notable of which was that of Miss Nathalie F. Moss and Johnston Livingston, 2d, at Calvary Church. All arrangements for out-of-door amusements in the suburbs were practically suspended. The meets at Meadow Brook have not taken place with much regularity, owing to the weather conditions.

In the following list "mtg " stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The present minister of the Congregational church is a reader of THE TIMES because it prints only what is fit to come into the family circle, and begs to say a word for his people in reply to the letter about the saloon license on Palmer's Hill which Mr. Havemeyer and his neighbors successfully resisted.

Confronted with the record of his imprisonment. Grand Juror John W. Fleck, father of Alderman Frederick F. Fleck, who swore on April 16 to Recorder Golf that he had never been convicted of any crime, admitted reluctantly yesterday that he had perjured himself.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 25 -- Attorney General Knowlton, at the opening of the trial of Charles E. Eastman, the Harvard instructor, for the alleged murder of his brother-in-law, Richard H. Grogah, Jr., today attempted to have the court reverse its decision of yesterday to exclude the dying statements of Grogan to the effect that Eastman had murdered him.

There was trouble in the air at the Aqueduct race track yesterday, and expectations of something disagreeable extended even to those persons in the crowd who were innocent of anything other than the desire to gel the money of some one else without giving anything in return. In the ring the men who formerly were bookmakers and now are "layers" were ill at ease all day.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 25. -- Judge Gray of the United States Court, in this city, filed an order in Trenton to-day for the American Smelting and Refining Company and M. Guggenheim Sons to show cause on May 13, at Trenton, why they ...

We have already tried to do justice to the candor shown by the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in denouncing the Raines law hotels which have sprung up by the thousand in New York since the passage of the statute after which they are named.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, April 25 -- The highwater mark of the flood passed down this part of the Ohio Valley earlier to-night than was expected, and the stage of water became almost stationary from 6 to 10 o'clock at fractions above 59.1 feet, and afterward at 59.2 feet, when it became permanently stationary here and at Upper points.

NEWARK, N.J., April 25 -- An action for $23,000 for damages for breach of promise of marriage, brought by Miss Ida Smith, a school teacher, against Charles W. Compton. a retired undertaker, reputed to be wealthy, was brought to trial here this afternoon before Judge Swayze. It is said that Mr. Compton, who is about sixty years old, sought his liberty after reflection on the ground that he was too old to marry again.

LONDON, April 26. -- "I have received information which may prove to be important," says the Shanghai correspondent of The Morning Post. " My informant declares that all the disaffected elements in the Yang-tse provinces, including the organization known as the 'Kolaoh-Wei,' the so-called 'Reformers,' salt smugglers, and disbanded Chinese soldiers, are combining for the purpose of organizing general risings in May or June.

BONX, April 25. -- Emperor William, in civil dress, and accompanied by Crown Prince Frederick William, attended the inaugural kommers of the Students' Union in Beethoven to-night. Upon entering the building the Emperor donned the distinctive cap of the Borussia Corps. Among the guests present was Prince Adolph of Schaumburg-Lippe.

A select and well-appointed gambling place in the financial district was successfully raided yesterday afternoon on evidence obtained by agents of the Society for the Prevention of Crime. Participating in the descent on the players on the second floor of 52 Broad Street were Justice William Travers Jerome, Frank Moss, counsel for the society; Assistant District Attorney H.S. Gans, W.M. Fuller, Clerk of the Court of Special Sessions, and Detective Sergeant John T. Cuff.
BOSTON, April 25. -- Money at the Clearing House ruled at 3 per cent. New York funds sold at 17 and 20 cents discount. Exchanges, $27,350,018; balances, $1,994,767.

People living near and having business in the vicinity of Thirty-fourth Street and Second Avenue and for two or three blocks round about were startled last evening by the sound of an explosion, followed by shrieking of women.
ALBANY, April 25 -- Gov. Odeli has signed the following bills:

At the dinner of the Credit Men's Association, held last night at the Drug Club, William and John Streets, Col. Abraham Gruber attacked fiercely the legislative measure granting a franchise of West Street to the promoters of the North River Bridge scheme. Marcus W. Marks, member of the National Clothiers' Association, proposed a plan involving the formation of an organization whose members would not only represent a particular branch of merchant trade, but all branches.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The Cuban delegation from the convention framing a Constitution for the new island republic saw President McKinley twice to-day, once in the early part of the day, when there were introductions and a formal exchange of expressions of friendship between the United States and Cuba, and again at night when the members of the delegation were the guests of honor at a state dinner at the White House.
SARATOGA, N.Y., April 25 -- Ex-Congressman James Madison Marvin died at his home here to-day.

PASSAIC, N.J., April 25. -- There was another lively scene at the American Cigar Factory, on Canal Street, this morning, when Policemen Flynn and Lockwood attempted to disperse the strikers who had gathered around the mill. The girls attacked the two policemen Vigorously, using their umbrellas as weapons and plying them without mercy on the officers' heads.

Montgomery Schuyler, Jr., of Columbia University, lectured in Public School No. 3, at Grove and Hudson Streets, last night on the "Story of the Alphabet." Mr. Schuyler first spoke of the novelty of the subject, about which very little is known to most persons, although the letters of the alphabet are constantly before their eyes.

Circumstances prior to the death of Mrs. Anna Bennett wife of Frederick W. Bennett of 733 Quincy Street, in New York Hospital Wednesday, were deemed by her husband yesterday such as to cause him to ask Deputy Commissioner York of Brooklyn to investigate.
The following statement was sent to the office of THE NEW YORK TIMES last evening:

The Washington Post, commenting on a recent article in THE TIMES with reference to the probable , effect of a strong public demand for the preservation of the merit system upon the action of President McKINLEY, says:

PHILADELPHIA, April 25. -- The market was buoyant to-day in sympathy with New York, Pennsylvania passing 80. The Choctaws maintained their leadership, advancing 3/4 for the common and a point for the preferred. A Director of the Choctaw Company says that the present owners of the property have no idea of selling except under extraordinary conditions.

BOSTON, April 25. -- The inside history of an enterprise which cost the poor people of New England millions in the aggregate, and of which there is scarcely an asset left, is given in the report filed to-day of Stephen H. Tyng, appointed by the United States Circuit Court Auditor in the case of W.L. Clark vs. the Van Choate Electric Company, to pass upon claims presented by creditors of the company.

LONDON, April 26. -- The House of Commons had a dull sitting last evening devoted to the discussion and formal passing of the budget resolutions. The Irish members made an ineffectual attempt to get the tea duty reduced from 6d. to 4d. Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said he sympathized with the Indian producer and the Irish consumer, but, under existing conditions, he was unable to hold out a hope of reduction.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 25. -- More than sixty golfers drove off from the first tee of the Lakewood Golf Club's links this morning in the opening round lot the annual Spring tournament. Fifty-seven turned in cards, in itself a splendid illustration of the enthusiasm of the players and their complete indifference to the weather when a good competition is in sight.

In the story of old dog Tray, that fabled animal was represented as a dog of correct principles who lost his reputation and his life through keeping bad company. The New York and New Jersey Bridge Company has got into a similar fix by adopting for the attainment of commendable ends methods that have come into evil repute in this community.

ATLANTIC, CITY, N.J., April 25. -- The three-masted schooner Emma C. Knowles, Capt. Rogers, which sailed from Charleston, S.C., April 14 for Fall River, with a cargo of lumber, was sighted six miles off this city to-day, almost a total wreck. There was no life on the vessel, and the fate of her crew is to-night unknown.

CHICAGO, April 25. -- With George H. Phillips apparently unloading his May corn holdings and Armour Co. buying at his price. May corn to-day went shooting up to 49 cents. From the opening nearly, to the close of the day's trading things moved fast in the corn pit, and the attendant excitement pleased the crowded gallery and filled most of the brokers' offices with excited men.

ALBANY, April 25 -- The Governor has signed the bill of Mr. Doughty, providing for registration of automobiles with the Secretary of State and allowing them to run on any highway in the State at a speed not to exceed fifteen miles an hour, outside of incorporated cities and villages.

LONDON, April 25. -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes: Total reserve increased u763.(B)0, circulation decreased u37,000, bullion increased u2,849,000, other securities increased u2,849,000, other deposits increased L5,281,000, public deposits decreased u1,418,000, notes reserve increased u780,000, Government securities increased u294,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25. -- Edwin H. Conger, United States Minister to China, accompanied by his wife, daughter, and Miss Pierce, arrived from China this afternoon on the steamer Nippon Maru. Owing to quarantine regulations and the necessity of giving personal supervision to the landing of his baggage.

OMAHA, Neb., April 25 -- In the trial of James Callahan on the charge of connection with the kidnapping of Edward Tudahy, Jr., Dec. 18, 1900, the victim took he stand and absolutely identified Callahan as the "dark man" in the case. After selling of his confinement in a deserted house, which he described minutely, young Cudahy was addressed by Attorney Cowin as follows:

FRANKFORT-ON-MAIN, April 23. -- It is feared that nearly 200 persons were killed and injured by the bursting of the boilers of the Griesheim Electro-Chemical Works, where the smokeless powder is made, near Griesheim, this afternoon. The explosion was audible here. The factory caught fire, and before long the conflagration had assumed enormous proportions.

Of course it is a great pity that we have not enough specially trained and tried officers to expand a regular army of 25,000 men to an army of three times that size. But the evident fact is that we have not. And most of the criticism that we have seen upon the manner in which the additional commissions are issued seems to us factious and peevish.

Livingston -- Moss. Johnston Livingston, son of the late Robert Cambridge Livingston, and nephew of Johnston Livingston first, and Miss Nathalie Fellowes Moss, a daughter of Cortlandt D. Moss, were married at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon in Calvary Church, Twenty-first Street and Fourth Avenue, by the Rev. Ralph L. Brydges, assisted by the Rev. Dr. J. Lewis Parks, rector of the church.

The City of New York, through its constituted officials, formulated a vigorous protest yesterday which it is to make to the Governor of the State next Tuesday against the granting of the proposed elevated railroad franchises to the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company.

--If the secrecy which, abroad always, and here almost always, is thrown about the construction of a cup defender lacks even the excuse of business utility. It is indeed a pity to continue a policy that, for sensitive people, lowers and commercializes international' yachting to an extent small, but appreciable, and therefore serious.

MANILA, March 10 -- Of all significant scenes witnessed during the first tours of the United States Philippine Commission in organizing Provincial Governments in Luzon, the most striking was the dramatic episode which wound, up the public sessions at Bulacan, the old capital of the province of that name.

Very few stocks were active in yesterday's market for outside securities. Attention was still kept from the curb market by the activity of the Stock Exchange market, and, with the exception of the bank and a few other stocks, there were few issues active enough to excite much interest.

WASHINGTON, April 25 -- The plan of operations of the Geological Survey for the next fiscal year was announced to-day. Numerous parties are to be sent to all sections of the country to engage in geological, topographical, hydrographic, and other lines of survey work. An important feature will be an investigation, in co-operation with the Coast and Geodetic Survey, of certain unmarked parts of the northwest boundary between the United States and Canada.

In consequence of the publicity given to the domestic troubles of the Rev. Dr. George D. Herron, and the strenuous objections of others who had been scheduled, to speak with him at the April dinner of the Get-Together Club, the Committee of Direction of the organization, at a meeting held yesterday afternoon, decided to abandon the dinner.

The Citizens Union Convention at its adjourned session last night completed its paeliminary work for the campaign. A platform declaring for municipal ownership was adopted, a Campaign Committee was appointed and a protest against the New York and New Jersey Bridge bill was unanimously passed.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 25. -- The sloop yacht Edilon to-day arrived from the lower bay and hauled out at the Jacob yard to be repainted and prepared for commission. The Edilon recently was purchased by J.M. Goethiesus, Jr., of New York. The naphtha power yacht Ida May has been sold to Dr. Huel of New York.

John Curry, a banker of 'Windsor, Ontario, who arrived on the steamship Teutonic, got into trouble yesterday with the customs authorities because he did not declare jewelry worth in the neighborhood of $2,500, which he says he was carrying to the Canadian relatives of a friend who died abroad.

BOSTON, April 25. -- Sir Thomas Lipton has cabled the Hull-Massachusetts Yacht Club that at this time he cannot say whether or not he will bring the Shamrock to Boston for the race against the Independence and possibly the Constitution. The owner of the Shamrock says he will wait until he comes to New York before giving a definite answer.

During the past week the dispatches in the daily edition of THE TIMES have given much interesting information regarding the annual Spring meeting -- a sort of birthday celebration -- at Hampton Institute, in Virginia; the annual conference on the subject of Southern education, held this year at Salem-Winston, N.C., and the schools at Atlanta, Ga., and Tuskeegee, Ala.

William Fitzgerald, who said that he lived at the Hotel St. Denis, was arrested last night by detectives from the West Sixty-eighth Street Station, charged with passing a worthless check. He said he had no occupation at present, but claimed to have frequently been employed as a musical critic on a local newspaper, but would not say which one.
BOSTON, Mass., April 26. -- D. A. Tompkins of Charlotte, N. C., in the course of an address before the Chamber of Commerce here to-day, said of the new South:...

Dr. McConnell has done his best to prevent the indolent reviewer from skipping any part of his book. He has furnished no chapter headings or table of contents, nor have his pages any captions but the one which is the title of the whole. But it is no hardship to read through a book so keen and bright as this at every turn, and with such frank indifference to the demands of a traditional orthodoxy.

A correspondent writes to us to complain of the issue of a sumptuous book under the pretense of issuing a, "public document." The publication against which he expostulates is "The History of the Capitol," by Mr. Glenn Brown, architect, of Washington. It appears that this work has been issued from the Government Printing Office, and that, according to our correspondent, only three hundred copies have been issued.
WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The following cablegram, dated to-day, has been received at the State Department from H.G. Squiers, the United States Charge at Peking:

The conversion of the old and distinguished house of Tefft, Weller Co. into a corporation is in line with modern tendencies, and that this particular case -- the first important one under New York's revised law-meets with approval is evidenced by the immediate flotation of its stock.

Assistant District Attorney Le Barbier, in view of Lawyer Benjamin Steinhardt's attack on the District Attorney's office Thursday in Justice Fursman's court, in regard to the resurrection of three indictments for perjury and poolselling, found five years ago, has unearthed an interesting history of the test action brought by Mr. Steinhardt.

LONDON, April 26. -- At the second day's racing of the Sandown Park Second Spring Meeting to-day the Princess of Wales's Handicap, at five furlongs, was won by H.J. King's Esmeralda II., with Lester Reiff in the saddle, Richard Croker's Harrow, "Johnnie" Reiff having, the mount, came in second.

Two moods and two only have inspired Mr. John J. Enneking of Boston while painting the landscapes, two score and ten of them in number, which are hung in the dining room of the Lotos Club. There is his mood of sombreness, which is not exactly melancholy, and his mood of jollity, which is not exactly a broad laugh.

LONDON, April 10. -- It must have been more than forty years ago that every one was reading the "Heir of Redcliffe," and weeping over the death of Sir Guy. I remember when in college that I heard a knot of young men discussing the book, and every one admitted that he had cried when he came to the death scene.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 26. -- A charter was issued at Dover to-day to the General Engineering Company of Brooklyn, which is to construct, maintain, and operate gas and electric works; capital, $250,000.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

NEWARK, N.J., April 26. -- The Trustees of the Peddle Memorial Church, in this city, have canceled the permit to Dr. George D. Herron to deliver a lecture in the church. The lecture was advertised for the evening of May 6, the subject being "The Economics of the Kingdom of Heaven." The decision of the Trustees is the outcome of the controversy in Brooklyn over the charges made against Dr. Herron.

Surely there can be no better adjunct to the history of early New York and its surroundings than an abstract of the wills on file in the Surrogates Office of this city. The volume under notice, the twenty-fifth of a series, is published under the provisions of the Publication Fund at the New York Historical Society.
WASHINGTON, April 25. -- Adalbert Hay, son of the Secretary of State, has resigned his position as United States Consul General at Pretoria. The resignation takes effect to-morrow.

If the men who made the Citizens' Union platform should come into control of the City Government and should attempt to put into practice the multitude of principles they have publicly professed the voters would put them out at the end of two years and eagerly return to Tammany or to anything to be rid of them and end the chaos and confusion of a nostrum administration.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The aggregate of the final valuation of franchises operated by corporations in New York City, as fixed by the State Board of Tax Commissioners under the Franchise Tax act, is $8,345,157 less than the aggregate of the valuations fixed by the board in 1900.

Abundant proof that Police Captain Westervelt was many times advised of the existence of a poolroom at 20 Dey Street, raided by District Attorney Philbin in February, was yesterday adduced by Assistant District Attorney Schurman from the official records of the Church Street Station, in the hearing before Magistrate Cornell to determine whether criminal proceedings ought to be instituted against the officer.
