The following statement was issued yesterday by Ernest H. Crosby regarding the refusal of the Rev. Dr. Hillis of Plymouth Church and others to speak with Prof. George D. Herron at a dinner of the Get Together Club, in Brooklyn, and in consequence of which the dinner was abandoned.

The rainfall on the Croton Watershed since April 1 last has been, according to G.W. Birdsall, Chief Engineer of the Department of Water Supply, 7.6 inches. The watershed covers an area of 338 square miles. It has been roughly estimated that a rainfall of one inch on the Croton Water-shed laid 6,000,000,000 gallons of water on the earth's surface in that district.

This new edition of de Charlevoix's "New France" may be said to be presented in a popular although limited edition. Heretofore the original work, as well as the Shea translation of it, has been principally confined to the reference shelves of libraries and the private collections of historians and bibliophiles.

The international chess cable match between the teams, of the English universities, Cambridge and Oxford, and the American universities, Columbia, Harvard, Yale, and Princeton, began yesterday at 10:30 o'clock.

PEKIKG, April 26. -- The Chinese regulars who retired beyond the Great Wall have reappeared at another point within the international area. Strong representations have been made to the Chinese Plenipotentiaries in regard to the necessity for the troops immediate retirement.

We do not think that the veteran advocate of uniform and universal suffrage for women, Miss SUSAN B. ANTHONY, is quite justified in her confidence that the bill passed by the late Legislature will "prove an opening wedge," and that she will live to see the obnoxious word "male" stricken from the Constitution of this State.

CLAYTON, N.M., April 26. -- Thomas E. Ketchum, alias "Black Jack," the notorious outlaw who had terrorized the people of the Southwest for the past fifteen years, was hanged here this afternoon for train robbery. His head was severed from the body by the rope as if by a guillotine. The execution took place inside a stockade built for the occasion.

The College of Pharmacy last evening graduated 125 students, five of whom were women, at the seventy-first annual commencement of the institution. The exercises were held in Carnegie Hall. The degree of Doctor of Pharmacy was conferred upon eleven post-graduate students.

Our last week's issue contained a letter commenting on a recent editorial article as to the small sales of really fine books, like "Dorothy Osborne's Letters," or the Browning "Love Letters," or the Stevenson "Letters," as compared with ephemeral books like "An Englishwoman's Love Letters," and books of like nature.

A NEW LIFE OF POE. -- That distinguished-looking poet of the National capital, Col. John A. Joyce, is at present in Baltimore collecting data for a new biography of Edgar Allan Poe. The Colonel wears his hair long, and its white locks fall over his shoulders or wave in the wind. He has already visited the Church House where Poe died, and the Westminster Cemetery, where he is buried.

Capt. F. Norton Goddard, who has for some months been active in the suppression of policy shops, announced at a meeting of the Civic Club last night the formation of a "company" of half a dozen who will take over his work and continue the fight against policy sellers until New York is rid of the evil.
LONDON, April 20. -- The attendance this evening was larger. The four games still in progress are sufficiently even to inspire a hope that the British chances are not entirely lost.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- The Japanese Minister and Mme. Takahira gave their first large entertainment this evening, when they were at home to some 600 guests. The host and hostess were assisted by the members of the Japanese Legation, Durham White Stephens, Midovi Komatz, Baron Nishi, and Takashi Nakamura.

Mayor Van Wyck gave hearings on a large number of legislative bills yesterday. A delegation of property owners appeared in favor of the bill permitting the building of a viaduct as an extension of the Southern Boulevard. H.H. Brown of the King's Bridge Taxpayers' Association said the work could be done now for half what it would cost in a few years.

A volume of short stories from the pen of Mary E. Wilkins is sure to awaken pleasant expectations in the minds of readers, and in the case of "Understudies," her latest production of this kind, the expectations will not be disappointed. It would be idle to say that these little sketches are works of large literary importance.

As there may be intemperance in everything, there may be dissipation in so good a thing as reading. Healthful reading is one of the most beneficial of all mental exercises, though it is not, as some mistakenly imagine, the best. But when reading is done without intellectual stimulation, merely to kill time, it becomes a low form of dissipation, for it dissipates the mentality.

BOSTON, April 26. -- Prof. De Sumichrast's outspoken criticism of Rostand and his plays has brought him into disfavor with Mme. Bernhardt. Yesterday both she and M. Coquelin absented themselves from a reception which had been gotten up in their honor. To-day when a reporter called on Mme. Bernhardt she uttered these explosive words:

The men who are at present figuring as the shareholders of the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company do not intend themselves to construct either the bridge or the approaches allowed by the Raines bill, and against which such a determined protest is to be made to the Governor of the State.

A collection of short stories by W.D. Howells will be published by Harper Brothers early in May under the title of "A Pair of Patient Lovers." The book includes besides the story which gives the title to the volume, "The Pursuit of the Piano," "A Circle in the Water." "The Magis of a Voice." and "A Different Case." It will appear uniform with the library edition of Howells's works.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The hearing to-day before Gov. Odell upon the Costello Employers' Liability bill was remarkable both for the strong language used and for the incidents which attended it. It indicated a wide and a deep interest in the legislation. There were strong delegations present to argue both for and against the bill.

In painting or in sculpture I do not know that any of the great artists who have done things wonderfully good have also done things correspondingly bad. In mechanics the man who turns out creditable work may toe relied on for a continuance of it. He who carves you a fine jewel or makes you a fitting shoe establishes precedent on which you may rely.

Since the first appearance of Kipling's great poem, "Recessional," in the columns of The London Times, there have been many stories circulated both in this country and in England regarding the circumstances which surrounded its publication. One story said that the author received as high as a sovereign a line.

The true starting point in family history investigations is wills. Here one secures evidence correct beyond question, and it usually becomes unexpectedly interesting and valuable. When the will is that of one's first ancestor in this country, it really serves to construct the roots and trunk of the prospective tree.
Four teams bowled double games for total pins in the championship tournament of Greater New York and vicinity on Thum's White Elephant Alleys last night. The scores:

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, April 26. -- It is not likely that more emigration agents will come here. Those already here had 2,000 natives recruited for Hawaii, and expected to ship 1,000 of them on the steamer Californian Wednesday, but she sailed with only 544 emigrants.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26. -- After three days given up to what may be called "eye-witness" testimony in the case of Charles R. Eastman, the Harvard instructor who is charged with the murder of Richard H. Grogan, Jr., the State this morning directed attention to the revolvers which figured in the tragedy.
B.C. F.T. Barry have sold for Oscar Kaufman the four-story dwelling 111 East Sixty-fifth Street, 20 by 100.5.

BOSTON, April 26. -- Money on call is about 1/2 per cent. firmer than it was a week ago. There are 3 1/2 per cent loans still outstanding, but there is no free supply of new money under 4 per cent. In time money banks and trust companies are receiving four to six months' collateral loans at 4@4 1/4 per cent.

A stunning gown made up as a gown for a Spring wedding is of white crepe de chine made up with soft lace as simply as possible, for the wearer has a figure which Venus might envy. This gown has the skirt flounced with point d'Alengon lace edged with tucks and with folds stitched on the upper edge above it, everything giving out at the lower edge with a delightfully wavy, expanding effect.

ALBANY, April 26. -- Fifteen thousand dollars of State funds is tied up in the failure of the banking house of Le Roy C. Partridge of Ovid, Seneca County, which was the chief depository of the Willard State Hospital. The State is protected, however, by a bond of $25,000.

LONDON, April 27. -- The unstable character of the Government majority received a pointed illustration last evening in the House of Commons during the discussion on money votes. Numerous divisions were taken in a thinned house, the Government majorities ranging from 40 to 60.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- In the habeas corpus proceedings brought by Mrs. C.E.M. Hedge against her first husband. Richard L. Maxwell, for the possession of her five-year-old daughter Guida, Judge Stevenson decided to-day that the mother was not a fit custodian, but that she could see her daughter at proper Intervals.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- One of the most prominent and interesting collections of relics in the National Museum is that of the clothing, camp equipage, furniture, china and silverware, and other objects once the property of George Washington. It has been in the possession of the Government since the Arlington property of Gen. R.E. Lee was seized early in the rebellion.

The outside market yesterday showed a good deal of strength and trading was quite broad, although very few issues showed totals beyond the recent average. The principal feature of the market was the very heavy transactions to the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy purchase bonds, trading in which began on Thursday.

We do not wish to toe too exacting toward a man of such avowedly good intentions as the Rev. Dr. RAINSFORD. A professional "idealist" probably feels himself entitled to indulgence in departure from the conventions prevailing among men of lower aspirations and more pressing if not more practical aims.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- Ideal golfing weather favored the women players in the first of the season's point scoring handicap tournaments for the trophy annually offered by the Women's Golf Association of Philadelphia, played over the course of the Philadelphia Country Club, at Bala, to-day. Interest centred in the doings of Miss Frances C. Griscom, the National champion, who was handicapped at plus 2.

How long present business conditions will last is a question the answer to which is likely to depend a good deal upon the temperament of the one who makes it. The term "boom," which has been so thoroughly incorporated into commercial nomenclature that it can no longer be regarded as an Americanism, but is as freely used in Great Britain and on the Continent as in this country, is of nautical origin.
CHICAGO, April 26. -- Money to-day was unchanged, the rates for call and time loans being about 4 1/2@5 per cent. New York exchange was quoted at 5 cents premium.

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- The market was stronger than for some days, the feature of the day being the upward movement in the Choctaws. Save for Choctaw common and United States Steel the price level averaged only 1/4 above last night. Almost every stock shared in the betterment, but the greatest advance was that of 2 1/2 points in Choctaw common.

ALBANY, April 26. -- The following is the full text of the Krum law taxing banks, signed by Gov. Odell yesterday. The bracketed parts indicate matter stricken out of existing law and parts in fullface type are new matter:

In point of entertainments, Friday is always a dull day, but the appearance of the sunshine brought people out on the Avenue and in the Park. There are a number of house parties arranged for the country over Sunday, and quite a number have gone to Lakewood for the golf and out to Hempstead for the meet this afternoon.

Mr Augustus John Cuthbert Hare prepared for publication the concluding volumes of his "Story of My Life." with the exception of the last two chapters, as early as 1896. so that many of the people of whom he writes have since died, while others referred to as children are now grown up.

At Wallack's Theatre yesterday afternoon a special matinee was given for the purpose of making known in this city "King Washington," a romantic drama of the Revolutionary period. This play is in five acts, and is the work of Robert Lewis Weed. It is founded on the novel of the same name by Adelaide Skeel and William H. Brearly.

We know so kittle about China, in spite of all the pains that have been taken to enlighten us, that we are probably incapable of appreciating the changes that have taken place there since the Boxers, with the approbation and encouragement of the Chinese Government, entered upon the task of exterminating the foreigners.

At home and abroad, with varying degrees of intermittency, the wail of the literary pessimist ascends to high heaven, or descends -- possibly -- to regions less empyrean, and the burden of his wail is that the modern literary lemon "runs to rind." Yet every year some rare new blossom is added to the flora of the literary world.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Although the announcement has been made that upon the retirement of Brig. Gen. John M. Wilson as Chief of Engineers and the appointment and immediate retirement of Col. Henry M. Robert the office will be filled by the advancement of Col. George L. Gillespie, It is not considered as a determination beyond recall.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 26. -- The Hasty Pudding Club gave its initial play this evening. It was styled "The Dynamiters," the book being by J.G. Forbes, the lyrics by F.R. Dubois, and the music by M.H. Pride. Tammany Hall came in for a share of the burlesque in the person of Marcana de la Croca, supposed to be a faithful imitation of the Tammany Chief.

ST. PAUL, Minn., April 26. -- President Hughitt of the Chicago and Northwestern system to-day completed the purchase of the Minnesota and Wisconsin Railway, running north and south through St. Croix and Pierce Counties, Wis. The road is only twenty-six miles long, but it enters territory which is destined to become of great importance.
Prominent men in the world of finance, commerce, and industry gave a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria in honor of Senator Jules Siegfried, ex-Minister of Commerce of the French Republic.

Mr. Melvil Dewey, the Director of the State Library, probably represents the best conclusions as to the reading public that have been arrived at in this country from experience in library management. He is not only a master of what we may call the newer arts in library work, but has been widely observant of the tastes and habits of the reading public.
LONDON, April 27. -- The Reuter Telegram Company has received the following dispatch from Peking, dated yesterday:

Gens. Joseph Wheeler and O.O. Howard and Stewart L. Woodford were among the guests at the first annual banquet of the Patria Club in the Hotel Savoy last night. Both they and the Rev. Dr. W.S. Crowe and Prof. George Gunton made speeches. More than a hundred diners were present, many being women. The President of the club, Col. Charles H. Denison, was toastmaster.

Last week we printed lists of books most in demand at the leading book shops and libraries of Washington, Boston, Philadelphia, Chicago, Cincinnati, Baltimore, and St. Louis. The lists were compiled down to the 16th of the month. The following lists, including the demand for books in New York show the situation during April up to Thursday, the 25th:

PHILADELPHIA, April 26. -- When an army of writ servers swarmed about the residence of Dr. George B. Wood, at 129 South Eighteenth Street, in that exclusive section of Philadelphia known as Rittenhouse Square, to-day, the entire neighborhood of millionaries was agog. No such commotion has been known in this section for many a day, and as Dr. Wood is one of the wealthiest physicians of the city, interest was at a fever heat.

WASHINGTON, April 26. -- Gen. Pedro E. Betancourt, one of the most influential members of the Cuban delegation, was seen by a reporter to-day, and in response to inquiries made some interesting general statements as to the purposes of the visit and impressions which the delegates have obtained.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: The standard library so happily introduced by Mr. Foster at Providence is only one of several modern developments. The old library was a storehouse concerned only with getting in, Now it is thought of chiefly as a great lending bureau, and as such is doing a magnificent work, but another generation will see a further development almost as great as from the passive reservoir to the active fountain.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27.-- White pitched his second game for the local National League baseball club to-day and again came out a winner. He was hit more frequently than on the occasion of his first appearance, but the hits were scattered and his support was good. The game was close and interesting.

Joachim was six years in Leipsic. Mendelssohn's constant advice to his pupil was to never play anything but the best music conscientiously, with more thought for the composition than for the effect which was produced. Young as he was, Joachim had his own standard, he responded to Mendelssohn's serious views, he did not care for virtuosity, and from what he had heard rather shrank from an introduction to Liszt.

Idle Gift, a stallion with a long pedigree, holds the unique honor of being the only stallion hich hag a complete set of books to himself in the county Clerk's office. In fact, Idle Gift has more honor than any human being in this respect, because no person yet has especially prepared books and certificates kept for years with only his name ever being recorded in them by the clerks in the office.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., April 26. -- The inclement weather of the past two weeks has greatly retarded building operations all along the coast, and some fear is expressed by owners of new cottages that their residences will not be ready for occupancy by the time the warm weather sets in.

GALENA, Ill., April 27. -- Exercises in commemoration of the seventy-ninth anni versary of the birth of Gen. U. S. Grant were held to-day in this city. The Rev. Dr. Frank W. Gunsaulus was orator of the day. A special train bearing Dr. Gunsaulus and a party of guests arrived from Chicago shortly after noon.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- In Chicago to-day there were handled about 30,000 shares of the issues, usually bought and sold in Wall Street, and as the session proceeded the business increased to such an extent that it was proposed to prolong the two hours call to 12 o'clock. The plan, however, was overruled.

The Czar is a very tall man, with a handsome face and a noble bearing. His manner is most vivacious, and he is quick at repartee; but, with his great natural gifts, it is a pity his tastes are not a little less barbarous. He was very cheerful and conversational, and we became great friends. My daughter and he exchanged snuffboxes; the Czar's was embellished with his monogram, and my daughter treasures it.

Senator Timothy D. Sullivan is fostering a $1,000,000 "water grab" which is now before Mayor Van Wyck for signature. Shortly before 2 o'clock yesterday the information was given out from a reliable source that Mayor Van Wyck had not signed the bill. No statement was made as to whether the bill would become law by the Mayor's signature or be killed by his veto.

Harry Sierk, whom his landlady at 173 "West Forty-fifth Street believes is the son of a Western millionaire, others that he is a floor walker in a dry goods store, got into a scrape on Friday evening which necessitated his appearance in the West Side Police Court yesterday. A wine appetite and a beer purse precipitates the trouble for him.

The color scheme at the Pan-American Exposition is not merely one of the important features of the whole; it is without rival the most important. On it, more than on the distribution of the buildings, more than the landscape engineering, more than the architecture and sculpture, depends the success of the exposition when it opens in May.

Away back in the nineteenth century, before I grew baldheaded, I was apprentice on the China tea clipper Spoondrift of London. It was part of my duty to act as a sort of factotum to Capt. Eagles, the commander of the clipper, and some queer sights, I saw in his company. The strangest incident, perhaps, was one that happened at Hongkong.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27 -- Everything conspired to make the seventh annual relay carnival of the University of Pennsylvania a success to-day. The weather was ideal for outdoor sports, there being just enough wind, chilly in its nature, to keep the scantily clad athletes on the move, and as a result the events were contested in a keenly exciting manner.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- Ex-Representative J. Hamilton Lewis wants to make the tariff the issue in 1904. He declared today that the shibboleth of the Democratic Party in the next campaign should be "High wages and more markets."

In a loosely played same of baseball yesterday Princeton beat Manhattan at Jasper Field by the score of 16 to 12. The spirit of rivalry was very keen during the contest, for Princeton in a former encounter had defeated Manhattan, 5 to 4. Naturally, the Manhattan boys were anxious to wipe out that defeat, and they had everything on hand to help them, with the exception of a, baseball team strong enough to do so.

Opposition to the bill recently passed by both branches of the Legislature, changing the method of appointing referees, was voiced at a meeting held in Part III., Trial Term, of the Supreme Court yesterday. Many prominent members of the bar were present, and a large number of signatures were affixed to a petition requesting Gov. Odell not to sign the bill. Resolutions to the same effect were adopted.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 27. -- W. J. Bryan said this evening in reference to the Rose water interview in New York, relating to his political plans for the future, that he would not be a candidate for Governor in 1902. He said: "I have no political plans for the future. I am not in a position to say that I will be a candidate for-anything at any time."

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- The wrecked schooner Emma C. Knowles passed in the Delaware Breakwater this morning in tow of the tug Frank W. Munn. The Emma C. Knowles was first sighted by the steamer Suningdale on the afternoon of April 24 off Atlantic City. She was lying on her beam ends, with decks awash, deckhouse gone, and appeared to have been in collision.

An able entomologist, M. Dagin, has been treating Parisians to a lecture on The Joys of Insect-Eating! In course of which he smacked his lips, As quietly he boasted That he had tried a hundred kinds -- Braised, minced, fried, raw, and roasted!

It has been evident from the first that two policies are in conflict there, and that one authority of weight is urging lenity, while another is counseling, and, indeed, ordering, savage repression. It is now stated that, as we should have expected, the Ministers, and especially the Procurator of the Holy Synod, the Minister most immediately threatened, are in favor of greater severity, while the Czar himself deprecates or disallows further repression.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27.-- Harvard's baseball team defeated Dartmouth for the second time this afternoon by a score of 7 to 2. The Harvard team did not play as well as yesterday. The batting was only a little better, but the wretched fielding of Dartmouth allowed Harvard to score many runs.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Mexican Government has taken steps to resume diplomatic communication with South American countries, the first move in that direction being the appointment of a Mexican Minister to the Argentine Republic.

With, the growth of interest in the decorating of historic sites in New York with memorial tablets, it may not be far distant when some society will place a modest little bronze plate on the building at 56 Wall Street, recalling the fact that Capt. Kidd, the pirate bold, lived there for several years over two centuries ago.

Some of the gentlemen who listened to the speech of M. JULES SIEGFRIED at the dinner given to him on Friday evening may have been a little uncomfortable in the consciousness of how much their party and even they themselves are responsible for the condition of things which the French Senator and ex-Minister of Commerce described and deplored.

The South Classis of Bergen held a secret meeting at Jersey City to consider the case at the Rev. John Heiniger, who resigned from the pastorate of the First German Evangelical Church, and who subsequently asked for a certificate of dismissal from the classis in order that he might unite with the Evangelical Lutheran Synod.

The work of the Alliance Israelite Universelle, which was the subject discussed at the meeting before which Bishop Potter spoke in the Temple Emanu-El last week, was again outlined yesterday morning in the sermon at the Rev. Dr. H. Pereira Mendes in the Shearith Israel Synagogue, Central Park West and Seventieth Street.

BOSTON, Mass., April 27. -- The tone of the money market is slightly easier, though Boston rates have not yet changed. On call money ranges from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent., mostly at 4 per cent. Time money is quoted from 3 3/4 to 4 1/2 per cent, for four to six months and 3 3/4 to 4 per cent for a year. Business paper sells from 4 to 5 per cent.

Perhaps the most mystifying feature of British Army life (and the one most discussed by the rank and file of the army) is that law which makes the wearing of uniform compulsory with the men and noncommissioned officers at all times, while prescribing it for officers only when on actual duty.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 27. -- Findlay Douglas scored his long-sought triumph over Walter J. Travis to-day, beating him in the final round for the Lakewood Club Cup one up in a nineteen-hole match. The finish was as sensational as could be wished for in any golf championship, and Lakewood's cottage and hotel community were represented in large numbers on the links.

SIMLA, March 28. -- The census returns for all India were made up and published within fourteen days of the actual taking of the census, a smart piece of work, considering the enormous area of the country, the difficulties of communication in many tracts, and the fact that a population of close on 300,000,000 was being dealt with.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just received Mr. W.J. Kinsley's reply to a recent article in THE TIMES, charging that "professional experts in matters of handwriting can change sides and joggle the tricks and accidents of the pen to prove or disprove any hypothesis."

After many ups and downs the third international chess match by cable ended yesterday in a draw, to the satisfaction of all concerned. By 6 o'clock four games had been finished, of which each, side had scored two. The American's then offered a draw on the two remaining boards, and hardly had the message been transmitted when a similar offer was received on this side.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Americans and Canadian Pacifies advanced on the Boerse today in response to New York and London. Banks were firm. Mines were heavy, in consequence of the coke syndicate deciding to further restrict the output for May.

The dual meeting between the athletes of the Thirteenth and the Twenty-second Regiments and the teams of the Battery E and the Company I Athletic Associations took place last night at the armory of the Thirteenth Regiment, Sumner and Putnam Avenues, Brooklyn. The games, which were the last of the indoor season, were hotly contested throughout, though the Battery E team defeated the Company I men by a score of 30 to 14 points.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In response to questions from a number of correspondents I beg that you will allow me space for a few suggestions in regard to the problem of tree planting in those streets where asphalt pavement and stone flagging laid in cement would apparently interfere with the necessary reception of moisture by the roots of trees, and therefore with their normal growth.
PARIS, April 27. -- Three masked burglars entered the American Express Company's office last night and escaped with 30,000 francs.

LONDON, April 27. -- Owing to the approach of the opening of the Buffalo Exhibition, Americans were maintained above parity on the Stock Exchange here to day. But there was little business done owing to the New York Stock Exchange being closed. Northern Pacific common, Wabash, and St. Paul made notable substantial advances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of the 23d there appeared a well-written appeal to the Irish, or those of Irish extraction, who are now residents of the Borough of the Bronx, urging the desirability of forming an organization for purposes which are clearly stated in the letter; one of which is to labor for the restoration of Irish Nationality.

PHILADELPHIA, April 27. -- The closing of the New York Stock Exchange to-day concentrated attention on the local market. That the Philadelphia Exchange made the most of it was manifested from the fact that over 20,000 shares of United States Steel common were dealt in, and heavy transactions were made in the Readings and Pennsylvania, the two leading arbitrage stocks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your editorial of Tuesday on "Trees in Cities" you speak of the members of the Tree Planting Association as being "abnormally sensitive to the suggestion that their effort is largely wasted for the reason that trees, if planted, will not grow in our city soil."

From one point of view it is to be regretted that electric lamps throw out so little heat. For many household tasks heat is demanded, and far beyond the electrician's ability of economical supply. Twelve lamps of standard size, each of slxteencandle power, require for their maintenance one horse-power.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 10. -- The Indecisive attitude of the Russian Government is largely responsible for the prevailing uneasiness in all classes of society here. After the attempt upon the life of M. Pobiedonostseff and the murder of M. Bogoliepoff, two courses were left open to the Government -- to adopt a liberal policy and deal leniently with the students, or a repressive policy, as outlined by Pobiedonostseff.

CHICAGO, April 27. -- In the leading article to be published in the forthcoming Monthly Bulletin of the Chicago Health Department, entitled "Influenza as a Factor of Recent Mortality," it is stated that pneumonia has displaced consumption as the principal cause of death in this city during the last ten years.

Two Southerners paid their tributes to the memory of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant last night at the big banquet of the Grant Monument Association in the "Waldorf-Astorla. They were Gen. Joseph Wheeler and Clark Howell of Atlanta. Two other speakers were Congressman C. B. Landis of Indiana and ex-Senator William E. Chandler of New Hampshire.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 27. -- Major F. K. Huger of this city has accepted the position of General Superintendent of Construction of the Pittsburg, McKeesport and Connellsville Railroad. He has been for many years Superintendent of the Knoxville division of the Southern Railway.

"It is all right enough to talk about your city circus enthusiast," said an old-time circus man as he stood at an exit of Madison Square Garden watching the crowd file into the street," but if you want to see real circus goers, men who would sell the shirts off their backs and sit on the benches dressed in a smile, you want to go to an Indian State.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27. -- Harvard was defeated at lacrosse to-day by the Crescent Athletic Club of Brooklyn, N.Y., by the score of 8 to 4. The Harvard team, owing to weather conditions, had previously played only practice games, and most of the men were green at the game. They showed good fighting qualities, but were weak in the fine points, especially in dodg- ing and stick work.

Not before in many decades have such elaborate arrangements been made to protest against any legislative measure in the State of New York as have been effected to present to Gov. Odell on next Tuesday reasons why he should not approve the bill granting elevated railroad franchises along the water front of this city to the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company.

Extensive plans are being laid by the organizers of the new Seabright Polo Club for great activity in that popular resort this season. The Polo Club has just secured a lease of a large tract of ground on the Rumson Road, about a mile above the Golf Club.

PARIS, April 27. -- Count de Cornulier, after two days' trial on the charge of murdering his wife last November as she was leaving the house of a lawyer named Leroux, was acquitted to-day amid the applause of those in court.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 27. -- This evening Senator Beveridge delivered the principal address at the annual meeting of the Grant Club, the leading social and political club of the State, on the subject, "The American Situation -- We Will Fight It Out on This Line." He spoke at considerable length, devoting most of his attention to the Philippines and Cuba, foreign trade and the tariff, and the control of great combinations.

The programme of the farewell of Mr. Grau's opera singers and of Mme. Bernhardt and M. Coquelin at the Metropolitan Opera House to-morrow night is the same as published last week, except that the mad scene from "Lucia di Lammermoor" will precede instead of follow the third act of "Die Walkure."

That was rather a neat stroke that the Parkhurat society made on Thursday in "pulling a game" down in Broad Street. The evidence they secured as to the character of the place seems to have been quite conclusive. One does not maintain a roulette wheel for prayer meeting's nor a faro "layout" for the meetings of a social and literary club.
The Home Fire and Marine Insurance Company of San Francisco has been licensed by the State Insurance Department to do business in this State.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is indeed true that many children are denied attendance in our public schools through lack of funds to build sufficient schools to keep pace with the growth in population. It is also true that many classes are overcrowded. A class numbering more than fifty cannot be properly conducted, and a Principal that allows his classes to run over that number commits an error.

It is a safe generalization that the less a man attempts to establish during life the conditions which shall continue after his death, the better for his survivors. With the law of mort main we have no particular concern. Generally speaking, the dead hand does not guide wisely, and the longer its hold is maintained the worse for those whose destinies are con- trolled by it.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The New Yorker who settles in Washington is likely to think he is in wonderland until he gets his bearings and accustoms himself to the revolution in his ideas. To him everything seems topsy-turvy, and the very hours of the day are all mixed up.

PITTSBURG, April 27. -- The fifteenth annual dinner of the Americus Republican Club, commemorating the birth of Gen. U. S. Grant, was held to-night at the Hotel Schenley, with 500 guests present. At each plate was placed a dainty souvenir, in the form of the old army canteen, with Gen. grant's likeness engraved on the cover.

The letter carriers of Philadelphia are not to be permitted to wear shirtwaists this Summer, but their uniform suits will be made of much lighter material than has been customary in hot weather heretofore.

The prettiest things that are made in the way of costumes are designed by modistes for individual women. There are among other conceptions, some charming little silk coats recently made. One that has been designed for an attractive girl and which is to be worn with a gown of black lace, is very striking.

LONDON, April 27. -- The temporary reduction of the Government's majority to thirty-three in the House of Commons on Friday night must not be taken as a very serious omen. Nevertheless the subject under discussion -- the emolument of law officers of the Crown -- was peculiarly a Government measure, and if the twenty-one Irish members had not absented themselves the Government's majority would have been only twelve.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It appears that in all that portion of the city lying west of Central Park and north of Sixty-sixth Street, there is no savings bank. In view of the large population of that district, no argument is required to prove that there is a crying need for such an institution, and that a bank in which the people had confidence would be assured of a great business.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I wish to commend your editorials of the 14th and 21st on the question of Catholic schools. As a member of that church, living in a parish that supports the largest school in Brooklyn, permit me to state that the great majority of the Catholics of this city do not wish State aid in conducting their educational institutions.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 27. -- The Mount Morris, steam tender to the Herreschoff cup defender Constitution, arrived from Brooklyn to-day, with Capt. Rhodes, skipper, and the Long Island sailors for the Constitution's crew on board, numbering twenty-four men. The vessel was delayed by gales.
BOSTON, April 27. -- The final dinner of the famous old Bird Club this afternoon was merry despite the fact that it was a leavetaking.

UTICA, April 27. -- Hiram Cronk of Dunbrook, the only remaining survivor of the War of 1812, will celebrate his one hundred and first birthday at his home on Monday. Mr. Cronk was born in Frankfort, Herkimer County, and was barely fifteen years old when the second war with Great Britain began.

Some time ago, while experimenting with, the electric arc, W. Duddell, an English physicist, made the remarkable discovery that it could be made to play tunes. He found that the slightest alteration -- even so little as one-ten-thousandth part -- in the current passing through the arc caused a variation in the hot vapor column surrounding the ends of the carbons, which produced audible sounds.

MATAWAN, N.J., April 27. -- In a little hut in the woods near Union Hill, where he had lived the life of a hermit for thirty years, Joshua Smith was found starving to death yesterday by the Overseers of the Poor of Marlborough Township. The man was living amid the accumulated filth of years, his clothing was in tatters, and his black hair hung in a tangled mass down his back nearly to the waist.

BOSTON, April 27. -- Under a decision made by Chief Justice Mason of the Superior Court, Manager A.H. Chamberlyn loses his lease of the Columbia Theatre, a temporary injunction secured some weeks ago restraining J.B. Grace from taking possession of the theatre having been dissolved.

Never until this last twelvemonth has New York been a Mecca for miners. Nowadays the trains are bringing in almost daily additions to the already large colony of these folk, attracted hither by the rumor that one of the greatest tunnels in the world was to be made in the very city itself.
STANFORD, Conn., April 27. -- Miss Ida C. Clark, a prominent society woman, daughter of David H. Clark, died at her home here to-day of spinal meningitis, resulting from an accident.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 27. -- An attempt was made last night to blow up the Midland Plaster Mine, situated a short distance from here. A fuse leading to 500 pounds of dynamite, so placed that its explosion would wreck the mine, was discovered by an employe, who destroyed it.

When the case of one Thomas Smith was called yesterday in the Gates Avenue Police Court, Brooklyn, and the complaint against him was read, there was surprise and indignation in the courtroom. Smith, a little Englishman, was charged with "stealing a horse's feet."

Several remarkable rescues were made last night at a fire caused by the explosion of a kerosene stove in the apartments of John Savage, who lived on the first floor of the three-story building at 60 North Third Street, Brooklyn. Mrs. Catherine Carney, sixty-five years old, who lived with her married daughter, was taken to the Eastern District Hospital suffering from asphyxiation.

Orb-weaving spiders scatter rubbish in their webs till they look like old things that have been up two or three months, and then they get in line with the chips and bits of bark that they themselves have put there. The trick of imitating spots on grass-stems, scales on trees, lichens, and the like, is wonderful.
Theodore Japst, a carpenter, died yesterday in the German Hospital, in Brooklyn, of lockjaw. For three days he suffered agony.

The evil which exists in every large city is necessarily so much in evidence and obtrudes itself so offensively upon the attention that it is perhaps natural for teachers and preachers, as representing the forces which make for good, to lose heart and speak despairingly of what appears to them the tendency of city life to corrupt good manners through evil associations.

The experiment tried yesterday by the Consolidated Exchange management of keeping that Exchange open, notwithstanding that the Stock Exchange was closed, was, at the conclusion of the day's business, pronounced by the management an "unqualified success." The volume of trading ran up to a total of 265,200 shares, the biggest Saturday the Consolidated had ever known, establishing a new record for a half day on that board.

Mr. ERNEST H. CROSBY regrets vehemently that the dinner of the Get Together Club in Brooklyn has been abandoned because of the refusal of certain gentlemen to appear in public at the same table with one of the guests of honor who was believed by them to have been guilty of peculiarly base conduct toward his wife.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Permit me to commend your editorial of to-day, in which you demonstrate to the Woman's Christian Association and the members of the New York East Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church the utter fallacy of creating reforms by such measures as the Raines law hotel and the abolition of the army canteen.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., April 27. -- More forged mortgages to the amount of $5,600, alleged to have been made by ex-Mayor Hadley Jones, turned up to-day. They were held by women clients of Jones. Information has been received here that banks in Providence, R.I.; Ashtabula, Ohio; Troy, Newburg, and Tarrytown, N. Y., loaned money to Jones, taking as col- lateral alleged forged stock certificates of the National Herkimer County Bank.

The Poles have no dealings with the Germans, who in consequence feel supremely uncomfortable in the province and never permanently settle there. Their little world is a world only of public officers, a foreign garrison. The Poles decline to take part in anything which recognizes German rule. They do not enter the civil service, or ask for commissions in the Prussian Army, though they must of course serve their time.

A bright pupil in the Girls' High School in Twelfth Street was instructed to write for the edification of her class in English a brief essay on the approaching picnic season. She was evidently not partial to picnics, for here is what she wrote:

ITHACA, N.Y., April. 27. -- Cornell and Columbia gave an excellent exhibition of baseball on Percy Field this afternoon, the game finally going to Cornell by the score of 2 to 1. The fielding on both sides was excellent, though three, costly errors were made. In the third Costello overthrew to first, allowing Columbia, to make her single score, and in the fourth, by Willard's overthrow, Cornell was allowed to make the winning run.

In a game replete with fielding features, the-Brooklyn National League baseball team defeated the Bostons yesterday at Washington Park by the score of 6 to 3. Hughes, the Brooklyn star of the season before last, pitched his first home game, and, with the exception of one inning, the, third, succeeded in blanking the visitors.

Because women spend so much, they are hardly ever in the field for investing when the chance comes along. No person can invest unless he has the wherewithal. Most great fortunes have been started by men who saved and saved and saved, and finally had a few hundred or a few thousand dollars to invest whenever the opportunity should come.

Victor Winters, a blind man, sixty-one years old, was found wandering about at One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Pleasant Avenue by a policeman of the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station yesterday afternoon. The man was taken to the East One Hundred and Twenty-sixth Street Station.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is a remarkable fact that those who strive so hard to build up a defense for the sentimental salaries paid to school teachers avoid all reference to the truth that the advances have been made right in face of the fact that the city found it perfectly practicable to obtain all the teachers needed at salaries existing before each advance.

Speaking about the necessity of "half day" or "part time" classes in many of the public schools, owing to their overcrowding in some parts of the city, a gentleman who has been connected with the school government of Brooklyn for more than a half dozen years, while rather deploring the necessity of such a thing, agrees with a vast majority of teachers of modern ideas, that such classes are by no means an evil.

NEW HAVEN, April 27. -- The authorities managing the Yale bicentennial to-day gave out the following official programme for the coming celebration in October of the two hundredth anniversary of the college. The programme differs in a number of ways from that tentatively adopted. There will be no large athletic gathering, as had been at first planned.

The first game in the inter-university lacrosse championship was played yesterday at Columbia Oval between Columbia and the University of Pennsylvania, and resulted in a victory for the Pennsylvanians by a score of 4 to 3. The game was witnessed by the largest crowd that ever turned out at a Columbia lacrosse game.

THE GLASGOW INTERNATIONAL, EXPOSITION. -- An international exposition covering about the same area as that of the Pan-American Exposition will be opened at Glasgow next Thursday by the Duke of Fife on behalf of King Edward. Like many exhibitions of this character, it is hardly expected that all the exhibits will be in place on the opening day, or that the exteriors of the buildings will be finished.
The precincts of Manhattan Island and its self-conscious environs do not constitute the only locality where an unsuspecting youth in search of adventure may buy a "gold brick."

Still higher mounts the security market-the past week crowded with new record-breaking figures. With buoyancy there is continued activity -- every phase of Stock Exchange development still challenging wonder. And especially does the speculative element of Wall Street continue its attitude of amazement at the advancing market.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The German Ambassador entertained at dinner this evening. His guests included the Secretary of the Interior and Mrs. Hitchcock, the Spanish Minister and Duchess De Areos, Senator Depew, Mr. and Mrs. Hill, Mr. and Mrs. Crackanthorpe, Mme. Calderon, Mrs. Jackson, Mrs. Perrin, Miss MacVeagh, Miss Gertrude Myer, Count Tarnowski, Baron Ambrozy, both of the Austrian Legation; Jesse Brown, Lieut. and Mme. Von Rebeur, and Count von Hacke.

The Eighth Street burglar alarm has been muzzled. For many months it has startled nighthawks and disturbed the slumbers of sleepers in the neighborhood of lower Fifth Avenue, University Place, and Greene and Eighth Streets. It had become an institution. Policemen smiled at it.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., April 27. -- The annual meeting of the Central New York Golf League was held here to-day. Clubs from Albany, Rochester, Utica, and Watertown, Elmira and Syracuse were represented. Judge Teller of Auburn was re-elected President E. C. Herendeen of Elmira was chosen secretary.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The 1st of May is approaching, with the consequent changing of the venue of the metropolitan law office and the reconstruction of the door, sign, letterhead,

Stories were rife about Bronx Paris: yes terday of an exciting collision between a big white motor vehicle containing three men and a thoroughbred racehorse on its way to Morris Park racetrack, in Pelham Avenue and Southern Boulevard. The horse was thrown into the vehicle by the collision and fell upon one of the men on the front seat, apparently injuring him seriously.

In the minds of the majority of persons, the musical season in this town will really come to an end on Monday night, when the opera singers will be heard here for the last time. To the writer of this department of THE NEW YORK TIMES the performance of the second act of "Tristan und Isolde" will mark the end of the operatic year, but perhaps we shall hear some other music later.

The educated class in Russia is quite powerless as against the Government, and the associated industrials are nearly so. Their numbers are lost In those of the peasants, and their employers wish for quiet. The grand protection for them is the wish of Ministers of Finance that Russia should become a little more taxable.

ALBANY, April 27. -- Richard Murphy, son of ex-United States Senator Edward Murphy of. Troy and Miss Elizabeth W. McConihe, sister of Judge McConihe, also of Troy, were married to-day in Albany. Two ceremonies were performed. The first by Judge M.J. Severence, Jr., in the City Court, and the second by the Right Rev. Thomas M.A. Burke, the Catholic Bishop of Albany, at the Episcopal residence.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27. -- The Steamship Managers' Association has been formed here. It includes every steamship line of importance on the Pacific Coast. R.P. Schwerin of the Pacific Mail was elected Chairman of the association. The question of co-operation in the steamship business on the Pacific Coast was discussed and a definite understanding was reached.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- There was a constant stream of callers at the White House to-day. Most of them called simply to say good-bye to the President, who leaves here Monday for his long trip to the Pacific Coast. Secretary Cortelyou has sent to each member of the President's party a handsome itinerary of the trip.

BERLIN, April 27. -- Cable dispatches from America, especially those reprinted in England, imputing to Germany Shylock-like tendencies in insisting on the pound of flesh in China, and also representing Germany's indemnity as higher than the facts warrant, have created here, both officially and privately, disagreeable surprise.

WASHINGTON, April 27. -- The Cuban delegation completed its labors in Washington to-day. In the morning the delegates met Secretary Root, who escorted them to the White House, where they had a final and decisive talk with the President. Then they paid visits of courtesy to each of the officials whom they have met, and finally they started for New York at 11 o'clock tonight, homeward bound. They will sail for Havana Wednesday.

ALBANY, April 27. -- The Albany Law School, one of the professional branches of Union University, will celebrate its semi-centennial next May 29. The Alumni Association is preparing for the event, and its Committee of Arrangements has Justice Judson S. Landon as Chairman, and William R. Davidson as Secretary.

SOUTH BETHLEHEM, Penn., April 27. -- In a fiercely contested and interesting game, Swarthmore defeated Lehigh here this afternoon by a score of 4 goals to 2. Many of Lehlgh's shots at goal were spoiled by Downing, Swarthmore's goal. For Lehigh, Symington, Lattig, and Miller played a fast game, while Downing, Blaus, and F. McVaugh excelled, for Swarthmore.
"Yes, certainly," said the milliner, "if I ever open a regular millinery shop with a stock on hand I shall have a man for one of my saleswomen." Then she laughed.

CANTON, March 15. -- In respect to imperial complications. Canton is much like Manila in respect to plague. It has enough to do to attend to its own affairs without going outside to look for trouble. In a general way it takes cognizance of what is happening in the North, but the eyes and ears of the Viceroy have abundant occupation in watching and hearing matters of much more intimate concern.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 28. -- The Rev. Dr. Dickey of Philadelphia, Moderator of the Presbyterian General Assembly and member of the Committee of Creed Revision, which made a report Friday, is in St. Louis. When seen in regard to the committee's report, Dr. Dickey said:

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Arbitration of all disputes and opposition to sympathetic strikes are the foundation principles of a new central labor body, to be known as the Chicago Building Trades League, which was organized here to-night. The new organization is backed by fifteen of the-eighteen strong trades in the building industry, representing 15,000 workmen.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Two singles, a double, and a triple, followed by Green's muff, gave the Cincinnati National League baseball team four runs in the sixth inning. A base on balls and a balk helped them to the other two runs and the game. Phillips was very effective and kept the hits scattered, except in one inning.

David Welch, who was Assistant District Attorney under John R. Fellows, was removed from his home in the Park Madison apartment house, Madison Avenue and Twenty-fifth Street, to North Brother Island ill with smallpox yesterday afternoon. Mr. Welch was taken sick Friday night and called in Dr. Emil Heuel of 350 Willis Avenue.

It has come to be known as the "Midnight Club." Upon whom rests the responsibility of christening it will remain probably as much of a mystery as the origin of the Sphinx. To describe it, in short: It is a literary workshop, its busiest and most active moments being those, that mark the ending of one day and the beginning of another.

In the eighth annual report of the State Charities Aid Association to the State Commission of Lunacy, which has just been issued, there is the important recommendation that reception hospitals for the insane be established in this and other cities of the State. No place to which people seized by sudden mania can be taken for early and preventive treatment, except the insane pavilion at Bellevue Hospital, exists in this borough.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., April 28. -- Dr. M. B. Baldwin of Wardencliffe has been burned to death, and several persons have had narrow escapes as the result of a forest fire which started yesterday dust west of Wading River Station, and has spread in all directions, but especially toward the east and south.

Mrs. Booth-Tucker, Consul of the Salvation Army, gave her lecture "Love and Sorrow" in the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon. The lecture was illustrated by stereopticon. Mrs. Booth-Tucker described in forceful way conditions that made the Salvation Army a need. Then she told of the institutions maintained by the army in various parts of the country.

Away up in the northern section of the city a band of some twenty persons traversed the ground yesterday which their fathers covered right speedily during the days of the Revolution. The persons who traversed this ground not unmindful of its historic significance were either members of the City History Club, or anxious to be.

Henry Loeffler, thirty-eight years old, a real estate dealer of Garden City, L. I., was arraigned yesterday in the Lee Avenue Police Court, Williamsburg, and remanded without bail to answer charges of grand larceny. Loeffler was arrested Saturday night on a warrant obtained by Charles W. Flummer, a truckman of 897 Pulaski Street, and Mathew Seibert, a plumber of 315 Bleecker Street.

The seventy-eighth annual meeting of the Hebrew Benevolent and Orphan Asylum Society was held at the asylum, Amsterdam Avenue and One Hundred and Thirty-sixth and One Hundred and Thirty-eighth Streets, yesterday morning. The annual reports of the President. Board, of Trustees, and the other officers of the society were submitted.

The corruptions of TWEED were brought home to the thieves of the ring and their guilt proved when Mr. TILDEN got access to the books of the Broadway Bank. The money stolen from the city by means of overpayments for the Court House work was then traced through the various steps of its distribution into the deposit accounts of the members of the ring.
James Harvey Dunham, head of the dry goods firm of James H. Dunham Co. of 340 Broadway, died yesterday of pneumonia at his home, 37 East Thirty-sixth Street.

The annual metropolitan team championship cross-country run was decided over the course of the Star Athletic Club, Long Island City, yesterday afternoon, and was won by the Pastime Athletic Club, with 35 points. The Xavier Athletic Association was second, with 37 points, and the Star Athletic Club was third, with 48 points.

LONDON, April 28. -- The issue of the new loan has had a perceptible effect in hardening the rates of the money market. As far as I can estimate the proportion taken by the ultimate investors of the u30,000,000 offered is fair, perhaps about one-fifth, but I shall be better able to tell a month hence.

It is worth noting that in the speeches made in various parts of the country on GRANT'S birthday, Saturday, the two subjects most generally treated by the Republican orators were expansion and protection, and the treatment of the latter was conspicuous for the extreme caution shown by those who referred to it.

If the poet who wanted to know "what a so rare as a day in June?" had asked the question yesterday. It is safe to say that the general answer would have been a day in April." It would have been deep-seated pessimism, indeed, that would not have been dispelled by such a day as was vouchsafed the people of New York yesterday.

"I see by the papers that the soldiers in the Philippine Islands is fairly killin' themselves with them ar' native drinks since they went an' tuck away th' canteens from 'em," remarked the aged coxswain to a party of landsmen outside the navy yard gate the other day; "but I swallows that statement with a bit o' salt.

MANCHESTER, April 28. -- Pending the appearance of the American cotton report, to be issued in May, the general opinion seems to be that the supply of good grade cotton will prove inadequate for the present season's requirements, and that this shortage will develop a squeeze which will affect seriously ordinary business conditions.

LONDON, April 28. -- The Stock Exchange enjoyed a fair amount of dealing during the past week, while its tone has been decidedly cheerful. Consols remained the weakest of the securities, having sold down to 93 7/8, which is the lowest price since 1890. They finished, however, above the lowest quotation.

As Prince Henri de Croy of Belgium, who arrived in Hoboken on the Holland-American liner Potsdam, yesterday morning, was preparing to leave the pier he was accosted by Customs Inspector Andrew McCort, and informed that an examination of his person would De necessary. As a result of that examination the Inspector found a magnificent emerald and diamond bracelet, a gentleman's ring, two Angora shawls, and three snuffboxes.

HACKENSACK, N.J., April 28. -- Two burglars forced an entrance into the house of Mrs. Rachel Hamilton about 2 o'clock yesterday morning. They went through the house and departed with $500 worth of bcoty including silverware and a lot of clothing.
WASHINGTON, April 28. -- It was reported to-night that a rather significant incident has been unearthed by the detectives which may have some relation to the McCormick case.

Since the admission by Lawyer Burton N. Harrison at the mass meeting of the Merchants' Association on Friday that the present managers of the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company did not really intend to build the bridge, but that certain capitalists expected to finance it, there has been abundant speculation as to the identity of these undisclosed financial interests.

With full military honors Major Francis D. Beard, the well-known horseman and National Guardsman, was buried yesterday afternoon in Greenwood Cemetery. The funeral services were held at the home of Mr. Beard's mother, 140 Amity Street, Brooklyn, the body having been brought on from Lakewood, where Mr. Beard's death occurred on Thursday night.

CHICAGO, April 28. -- Major Gen. E. S. Otis, commander of the Department of the Lakes, as the guest of honor at a banquet given by the Chicago Bankers' Club, freely discussed the financial difficulties encountered by the American administration in the Philippines. Speaking of the Spanish Bank at Manila he said:

Frederick and Richard Steffens of 944 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, were drowned off Rockaway Shoals yesterday morning after their boat upset. Henry Styne of 170 Underbill Avenue, Brooklyn, who was with them at the time, clung to the capsized vessel and was rescued by Capt. Nathan Wilson.

"If I was asked to criticise our school system," remarked the Principal of one of the largest schools in the city, "I should say that the great fault of the management lies in the fact that New York depends too much on herself. West and east of us are schools that are better than ours, and conducted on what are conceded to be better methods.

The Rev. Dr. Charles H. Parkhurst preached yesterday morning, at the Madison Square Presbyterian Church, upon topics connected with his recent trip South to attend the conference held at Winston-Salem, in North Carolina. He said, in part:

John Miller, alias Dutch John, said by the police to be an ex-convict, walked into Roosevelt Hospital late yesterday afternoon and asked for a doctor. He was hardly able to stand, was white as a ghost, and blood was trickling from his trousers legs to the floor.

From The London Globe. One of the most peculiar institutions in China is the organization of the postal service. With the increase of the population and with the gradual opening up of the coast line of the country it became imperative to devise some means of facilitating intercourse, and the mercantile firms therefore joined hands and established Post Offices.

MANILA, April 29. -- Capt. Wilson Chase, with a detachment of the Twenty-first Infantry, on April 20, surprised the camp of the insurgent Gen. Cailles at Dugot-Dugot, situated nine miles northeast of Cayinti, in the Province of Laguna. Cailles was at his camp at the time of the American attack, but managed to escape.

By his defeat of Walter J. Travis, the presenet National champion, last Saturday in the final round at Lakewood, Findlay S. Douglas has brought himself prominently to the front as the possible United States champion for the coming year. His stock, to quote the expressions of the Wall Street golfers who watched the match, jumped considerably above par, and his tournament play for the remainder of the season will be watched with the keenest interest.

THE POLITICAL CRISIS IN JAPAN. -- The crisis which overtook the Ito Government of Japan, and which is likely to reassert itself at the coming session of the Japanese Parliament, is described in mail advices from Tokio as an attempt of the Marquis Ito and his political colleagues to introduce European methods of legislation into Japan before the hitherto hereditary rulers of the country are ready to receive them.

ORANGE, N. J., April 28. -- Well-authenticated rumors that have been in circulation in the Oranges for several days are to the effect that the management of the Lackawanna Railroad proposes making a number of radical improvements and changes in the location of its tracks and stations in the Oranges.

That sound sense and unfailing judgment may guide the councils of the Greater New fork Democracy in the work of organization will be the hope of every New Yorker who wants to see the Tammany rascals turned out.

Saturday's weekly Clearing House statement having shown that the, banks are still gaining instead of losing in surplus reserves, security market sentiment improves -- or, at least, there is disappearance of any anxiety over immediate money market difficulties. And except as to money rates, and the possibility of restriction in banking accommodation, there has lately been no adverse " argument " over which professional speculators have bothered.

BERLIN, April 28. -- The money market now shows greater ease than it has shown for several years. The Reichsbank rate of discount is the lowest that has been in force since June, 1890, and the private rate is unusually low. Money for the monthly settlement is abundant. The Seehandlung is making great offerings of call money, of which only a small part has been taken, although rates are continually relaxing.

-- Some of the Massachusetts papers manifest an inclination to exult over the exclusion of evidence in the Eastman trial, taking the ground that it proves the peculiar wisdom of the Massachusetts judiciary. We read, for instance, that "Judges GASKILL and AIKEN showed by their decision that all the rights of accused men are safe, and that nothing besides absolute justice is sought, in the courts of Massachusetts."
To the Editor of The New York Times: Suggestions to travelers in parlor or sleeping cars:

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., April 28. -- Two burglars were caught here to-night. They forced an entrance into the house of A. Ferra, formerly Consul General at New York for Portugal. There was a servant in the house, and the alarm was given while they were at work.
"Peking, April 28. -- The following reports only arrived last night, owing to the difficulty of communication.

From The Omaha (Neb).) Bee. The officers of the Populist State Central Committee are making a desperate attempt to raise enough money to pay off the indebtedness incurred by the committee during the last campaign, but so far they have been able to raise only $904.61 on a frantic demand of $5.651.

BUFFALO, April 28. -- To-day's attendance at the Pan-American Exposition was a record breaker for a pre-exposition crowd. Fully 30,000 persons passed through the gates, about 75 per cent, of them paying for admission. Although the Exposition is still far from complete, every one seemed satisfied with what there was to see.

During the last ten years there has been no reduction in the amount charged the orange growers for carrying their freight across the continent, although the freights charged for almost every other line of merchandise all over the country have been diminished. The volume or the product has increased nearly tenfold during that period.

OMAHA, Neb., April 28. -- After considering over night the guilt or innocence of James Callahan, the jury announced this morning that he was not guilty of complicity in the kidnapping of Edward Cudahy, Jr. The verdict was an evident surprise to the Court, and Judge Baker expressed his disgust in emphatic terms.

Herman P. Angot of 1 Maiden Lane, the man who purchased the poison which resulted in the death of J. M. Elliott, was arraigned in the Jefferson Market Court yesterday morning. He went to Police Headquarters as soon as he heard of Elliott's death and surrendered himself.

Arms that project from the canvas, horses that have walked out from their painted places, painted figures modestly veiled by draperies of real mosquito netting, are some of the realistic and ideal tributes members of the Art Students' League forming the Society of American Fakirs will pay to-day and to-morrow to their masters of the Society of American Artists.

An audience such as has never before packed itself into the Metropolitan Opera House crowded that capacious auditorium last night to bid farewell to the grand opera stars who had sung there during the season and to say adieu to M. Coquelin and Mme. Bernhardt. Incidentally, the receipts for the performance were about $19,000.
In the financial cable dispatch from the London correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, printed yesterday, occurs this significant passage:

NEWPORT, April 29. -- De Blois Eldridge have let for the Misses Woolsey their cottage in Rhode Island Avenue to Major J.C. Mallery of New York for the coming season. This will be the first time the Mallerys have spent a season here in ten years.

LONDON, April 29. -- Money was much wanted to-day in connection with repayments to the Bank of England. The supply was better, in consequence of the release of money subscribed for the loan. Discounts were easier. There was an indisposition to work freely, in view of the uncertainty of the outlook.

The Municipal Art Society held a meeting in the Fine Arts Building, in West Fifty-seventh Street, last evening. The question before it was whether it was "to be or not to be." Only about thirty persons attended the meeting, and they were pretty equally divided upon the subject.

BRISTOL, Tenn., April 29. -- The first day of the President's long tour to the Pacific Coast lay through a historic section in Virginia, across the Valleys of the Rapidan and James, in sight of the homes of Madison and Jefferson, up past the peaks of Otter, so dear to the hearts of the Virginian, and into the picturesque Blue Ridge Mountains.

LONDON, April 30. -- The first step in the direction of the consolidation of some of the biggest transatlantic shipping interests has been accomplished by the purchase by J.P. Morgan Co. of the Leyland Line of steamers. A deposit on the purchase money has been paid.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., April 29. -- Because they had an amount of courage that is not equaled by many men is the only reason Addie Melrose and May Compton are alive to-day. Miss Melrose and Miss Compton are school girls residing a few miles out of Ashatee, where they daily attend the district school.
ALBANY, April 29. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the following bills:

A terrific explosion, probably designed to set fire to a building, seriously injured a little boy in front of David Lubitt's shoe store, at 85 Manhattan Avenue, Brooklyn, last evening, and caused a panic in the neighborhood, which is thickly populated.

A Madison Avenue electric car, going north, and running at a high rate of speed on the heavy down grade beginning at Eighty-eighth Street, hit a Fifth Avenue stage coach last night at Eighty-ninth Street. The coach was overturned, and it slid along the pavement for fifty feet. Three women riding inside of it, two on top, and the driver were injured, some seriously.

The Stock Exchange yesterday celebrated its first day in its new temporary quarters in the Produce Exchange Building by giving to Wall Street and the financial world generally a market unparalleled in the history of the Exchange. Records were smashed all around, beginning with the first hour and ending with the last.
Coroner's Physician Albert T. Weston, after a narrow escape from death by blood poisoning, is rapidly recovering in the German Memorial Hospital, One Hundred and Sixth Street and Central Park West.

Before no former Governor or New York will there have appeared a more representative and able delegation than that which will to-day at Albany protest against the signing by Gov. Odell of the bill granting railroad franchises along West Street to the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company.

-- Prolonged and wearisome conflict with an enemy whom circumstances have forced to avoid decisive encounters and largely to supplement courage with deceptions of various kinds, does not tend to produce affectionate feelings toward that enemy. It is little wonder, therefore, that Gen. YOUNG does not love the Filipinos, but one can regret that he allowed himself to talk about them in public as he did at the Grant dinner in Pittsburg.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., April 20. -- A very exciting brush between three of the one-class cruising raceabouts designed and built by Robert Jacob for the Manhassett Bay Yacht Club took place at Manhassett Bay yesterday. The participants were Guy Standing's Fire Fly, George Cory's Arizona, and Morgan and Phillips's Bab.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29. -- The Kentucky Derby has passed into history, and not one of the 25,000 people who saw it can say aught except that it was a race from the flag until the good son of Falsetto passed under the wire a winner in the good time of 2:07 3/4.

Mrs. Belle Wadman, widow of Herbert C. Wadman, whose body, covered with bruises and contusions, arrived at the Morgue March 6 last, after the patient's short stay in the insane pavilion of Bellevue and the Manhattan State Hospital, related on the witness stand at the inquest before Coroner Zucca yesterday grave particulars of her investigations into the causes of her husband's death.

Dr. PARKHURST, on his return from a Southern trip, took occasion on Sunday to give to his congregation some of his impressions of what was apparently to him almost a newly discovered country. Much of what he had to say was sensible and all of it was clearly intended to be impartial and friendly.

BOSTON, April 29. -- The daughter of Prof. Charles A. Pitkin of Thayer Academy, South Braintree, to-day eloped with one of his students, Jordan L. Mott of New York, a scion of and the third of the millionaire iron family of that name. The elopement terminated at the Park Street Church, where the knot was tied by the Rev. John Lindsay Withrow of that parish.

Miss Frances Wallace led the field yesterday on the Dyker Meadow golf links, near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, in the qualifying round for the club championship and the cup presented by Mrs. T.M. Lloyd. Her score for the eighteen holes was 106 strokes, beating the second best by 4 strokes, made by Miss Grace Chauncey.

The will of Edward Augustus Hammond, who left an estate worth about $2,000,000, is to be contested by his relatives. The formal exceptions to the admission of the will were filed with Probate Clerk Washburn, in the Surrogates' office, yesterday.

BOSTON, April 29. -- At the Clearing House to-day the rate between banks was 3 per cent, and New York funds sold at 15 and 17 cents discount. On call money ranges from 3 1/2 to 4 1/2 per cent., mostly 4 per cent. Time money is quoted from 3 3/4 to 5 per cent., according to names, dates, and collateral.

PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., April 29. -- The forest fire that started at Wading River Saturday afternoon was not under control until this morning, despite the efforts of hundreds of fanners and others from this place, Wardencliffe, and Wading River. The fire started just west of the Long Island Railroad engine house, at Wading River, and burned west.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The United States Supreme Court to-day decided, in the case brought by ex-Congressman Stephen V. White of Brooklyn that a "call," as the word is used in the Stock Exchange, is an agreement to sell, and therefore subject to taxation at the rate of 2 cents per hundred dollars under the war revenue law.

MATAWAN, N.J., April 29. -- Matawan was the scene of a disastrous incendiary fire early this morning, the Bissell Block being completely destroyed. A building adjoining the Bissell Block, which was occupied by the Adams Express Company, was also burned. The loss has not been estimated, but it will certainly reach many thousand dollars.

It was announced by Chancellor MacCracken of the New York University yesterday afternoon that during the day the resignation of the last remaining professor in the School of Pedagogy had been placed in his hands.
BOSTON, April 29. -- The Directors of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad to-day declared a dividend of $2 per share for the four months ending July 1, payable June 15.
SOUTHAMPTON, April 29. -- The Shamrock II. has arrived here in tow of Sir Thomas Lipton's steam yacht Erin.

One of the most exciting poolroom raids of recent days was made yesterday afternoon at West Twentieth Street and Eleventh Avenue by Frank Moss, acting for the Society for the Prevention of Crime. The place was in the back room of a saloon, on the ground, floor, and, according to an excise certificate that hung on the wall near the bar, the establishment was run by one Henry Kolz.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the two bills of Senator Elsberg having for their object the appointnfent of a new regular Commissioner of Jurors in New York and Kings Counties by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court to take the places of the present regular Juror Commissioner and the Special Commissioner of Jurors in criminal cases.

MANILA, April 29. -- The trial of Capt. James C. Reed, ex-Depot Commissary at Manila, who was arrested about a fortnight ago for alleged participation in the commissary frauds, was begun here to-day, and bids fair to develop into a celebrated case. Capt. Reed is charged with soliciting and receiving bribes and with other official misconduct.

The Spring games of the First Regiment, National Guard, New Jersey, will be held at the armory, Sussex Avenue and Jay Street, Newark, to-morrow evening. The following events are open to all members of the Military Athletic League; 75-yard run, handicap; quarter-mile run, handicap; half-mile run, handicap; one-mile run, handicap.

NEW HAVEN, April 29. -- An event of importance in the photographic and artistic circles of Yale has been the first annual exhibition of the newly formed Camera Club. The club was organized in February, and has since obtained a total of thirty active members. From time to time lectures and demonstrations have been delivered to the club by experts.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "RS" for revenue stamps.The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cebts for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.
Never, in the history of "royal" or of Presidential "progresses," has the Chief Magistrate of any people undertaken such an errand as that upon which Mr. McKINLEY yesterday left Washington.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Absence from the city for several days has prevented me from seeking an earlier opportunity to reply to the criticisms of the Citizens' Union platform which have appeared in several of our daily papers. The position of the union seems to me to be wholly misunderstood, and I trust I may recite a few facts which will put the matter in a clearer light.
WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The following army appointments were announced today:

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- The Taft commission mission is about to extend the time within which amnesty, may be accepted by the Filipino insurgents until the very date of setting up civil government, which will not be later than July 1.
