The War Department is now encouraged to hope that by the time the Government of the Philippines has been established there will be practically no "unreconstructed" Filipinos.

ALBANY, April 29. -- Gov. Odell to-day grave a hearing to those interested in the Adler bill, which exempts those who observe Saturday as their Sabbath from the provisions of the O'Connell bill which requires all butchers' shops to close on Sunday. The hearing was attended by large delegations.

PEKING, April 29. -- The Generals of the powers held a conference this morning to consider the question of the withdrawal of the troops. They decided to address a note to the Ministers, informing them that, when the Ministers are able to announce the lump sum demanded as indemnity and the Chinese have agreed to the principle of payment, arrangements will he possible for withdrawal.

WASHINGTON, April 29. -- One of the last acts of the President before leaving the White House on his tour to the Pacific Coast was the signing of the commission of Mr. Pruden, one of his assistant secretaries, as a Major and Paymaster.

Joe Friedman, a young real estate dealer who had accumulated about $50,000 worth of property, had considerable difficulty in making his will, which was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. After making a number of charitable and other bequests Mr. Friedman cuts off two brothers with $1 each and gives another brother $1,000.
LONDON, April 29. -- Viscount Barrington died this morning at Westbury Manor, Bucks.

COPENHAGEN, April 20. -- Bjornstjerne Bjornson's new drama. "Paul Lang." has been produced here for the first time. The author and his family were present. They received constant ovations. Bjornson made a speech of thanks.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 29. -- Frank A. Vanderlip, ex-Assistant Secretary of the United States Treasury, was received by the Finance Minister, M. Witte, to-day, and had a long and interesting conversation with him. Mr. Vanderlip was greatly impressed with M. Witte's knowledge of American affairs and appreciation of American methods.

PHILADELPHIA, April 20. -- Chief Engineer William H. Brown of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-night made a positive denial of the story that the company is interested in the North River bridge project.

NEWPORT, April 29. -- The new steam yacht Alvina, the property of Charles Fletcher of Providence, departed from this port to-day for Lawley's yard, Boston, where she is to be fitted up for a tour of the world. The owner will take a party of friends on the voyage. The Alvina is a twin screw vessel, most luxuriously appointed.
BERLIN, April 29. -- A supplementary dispatch received here to-day from Field Marshal von Waldersee concerning the recent engagements near the Great wall, says:
ALBANY, April 29. -- Gov. Odell to-day signed the Stranahan bill amending the New York City Rapid Transit act. The bill provides that the city may hereafter acquire:

BALTIMORE, April 29. -- Though the market to-day was not especially active, there was confidence enough present to induce buyers to measure up to the demands of holders by making purchases at advanced figures. Several of the recent leaders in activity participated in the improvement, notably the Seaboards and Cotton Duck.

Two policemen attached to the Macdougal Street Station engaged in a free fight while in uniform yesterday afternoon in front of 26 Charlton Street. The Marquis of Queensberry rules, as well as all rules of civilized warfare, were ignored by the "guardians of the peace," who battered away at each other until separated by people in the neighborhood.

Without doubt the German military excursion from Peking to the Great Wall has had some practical military lessons. It was a march under a nearer approximation to "service conditions" than can be attained even in the most comprehensive system of manoeuvres in time of peace.

ALBANY, April 29. -- The Fish. act, which has become a law, makes an imporant amendment to the real property law relating to the investment by trustees of the funds of a minor, a lunatic, an habitual diunkard, or an absentee. The act adds a new section to the real property law to be known as Section 94. This section is as follows:

The property 18 and 20 West Twenty-fifth Street, two dwellings remodeled for business purposes on a plot 50 by 98.9, has been sold. The buyer's name could not be Jearned yesterday, but the purchase is probably made for improvement. The plot has unusual advantages in the matter of light and air.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29. -- A further boom in the Choctaws and a rise in the United States Steel stocks were the features of the market to-day. A sensational spurt of 3 3/8 points took place in Chootaw common at the start, and after some irregular, fluctuations the price, ended at the highest, the preferred following close with a gain of 2 1/4.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 29. -- The proceedings to-day at the Eastman trial again favored the defense, and the Harvard instructor left the courtroom this afternoon with a smile on his face on account of the favorable evidence of one of the principal Government witnesses and a comforting decision by the Court in ruling, out the defendant's testimony before the Grand Jury which indicted him.

Conditions thoroughly favored the racing at the Aqueduct track yesterday, and though the Queens County course long has been regarded as a place that appeals only to the "professional" element, there were many in the crowd who are patrons of the sport for the sport's sake, and who were out for the first time this season.

George O'Brien, who is alleged to have jumped his bail while awaiting examination on a charge of larceny in Brooklyn, has been rearrested, and is now locked up in that borough. O'Brien's capture on Saturday at Asbury Park, N.J., was effected in a most unusual and exciting manner, a party of fox hunters riding him down when he was escaping from pursuing detectives across country.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following may be objectionable to some people, who waste their affections on dogs, but facts are incontrovertible.
BOSTON, April 30 -- Money loaned between the banks at the Clearing House today at 3 per cent., and New York funds sold at 12 1/2@17c discount. Exchanges, $31,519,632; balances, $2,596,850.

LONDON, May 1 -- The discussion in the House of Commons yesterday on a private bill conferring additional powers on the London and Northwestern Railway led to a great deal of acrimonious recrimination.
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Chicago's participation in the prosperity of the country is illustrated by the clearances of the local banks for the month of April.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., April 30 -- Thomas G. Esterbrook, at one time one of the star players of the National League, died here at the City Hospital to-night. Esterbrook was being taken to the Middletown State Hospital by his brother and an attendant. Near Tuxedo he jumped from the window of the train.

LONDON, May 1 -- The Leyland Line deal provokes unusual discussion in the English papers, which reveals the existence of not a little apprehension as to the possibility of the United States dominating the Atlantic carrying trade.
WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Following is the Weather Bureau's weekly summary of crop conditions:

Deputy Sheriff Strauss has received an attachment for $1.674 against F.A. Rogers Co., (corporation.) stock brokers, at 38 Wall Street, in favor of Henri L. Falco, on claims for money deposited by him and Harris B. McKenzie for stock operations. Mr. Falco alleged that between March 14 and April 26 he deposited $987 and received back $402, leaving a balance of $385.

Lieut. Gov. Timothy L. Woodruff and John D. Rockefeller were the guests of honor and principal speakers of the evening at the meeting of the Young Men's Eible Class of the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, held last night in the church parlers at 8 West Forty-sixth Street. John D. Rockefeller, Jr., is the leader of the Class.
Senator Raines, the author of the bill, was the first to speak in its favor. He said:

LONDON, May 1 -- The semi-annual meeting of the shareholders of the Grand Trunk Railway here yesterday was largely attended. The Directors' report, showing a decrease in the receipts and an increase in the expenses, was accepted without criticism.

The Committee of Fifteen made four raids on alleged gambling houses between midnight and 1 o'clock this morning. The places raided were 111 East Fourteenth Street, 54 West Thirty-first Street, known as the Metropole Club; 52 West Twenty-eighth Street, and 432 Sixth Avenue, between Twenty-seventh and Twenty-eighth Streets.

The Stock Exchange had another day of record smashing. Recorded transactions ran up to the enormous total of over 3,200,000 shares to be exact. 3,270,851 -- which is more than 600,000 shares greater than the record established on the day previous, and almost 1,000,000 shares greater than the record previous to that.

Gov. ODELL has taken the right course as to the Referees bill. He has killed it because it was a bad bill; but he has pointed out very clearly to its critics and opponents that the evils to which the bill was professedly addressed are serious, and it rests with them to propose an adequate remedy.

MANILA, April 30 -- The trial of Capt. James C. Reed. ex-Depot Commissary at Manila, charged with soliciting and receiving bribes, and other official misconduct, which began here yesterday, was continued to-day, and was fiercely contested.

MERIDEN, Conn., April 30 -- The Yale University baseball team suffered defeat today at the hands of the Meriden team of the Connecticut State League. The local players took the lead early by a slaughter of the freshman pitcher, Patton, in the first inning, but could do but little after Robertson went into the box.

BOSTON, April 30 -- In the course of a speech this evening at the banquet of the Home Market Club. Senator Hoar paid his respects to those who oppose the granting of the Degree of Doctor of Laws by Harvard University to President McKinley. He spoke as follows:

The most ambitious event at the Aqueduct race track yesterday and the most satisfactory to the general public in its result was the single stake on the programme, the Woodhaven, selling, for two-year-olds, which not only was won by the popular favorite, but had as its second horse the second choice in the betting.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., April 30 -- President McKinley, at the banquet given to him here to-night, made an important and entirely unexpected speech upon the future policy of the United Stales regarding the expansion of its foreign commerce.

Miss Jennie Lewis, twenty-live years old boarding at 42 West Eighty-third Street while out walking with her friend. Miss Emily F. Ireland, a trained nurse, of 421 West Fifty-seventh Street, became violently insane yesterday morning, and turning on her friend, began to attack her, exclaiming:
CHICAGO, April 30 -- Money to-day was about the same as yesterday, the rates for call and time loans being 4 1/2@5 per cent. New York Exchange was quoted at 10 cents discount.

To-day the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway's Directors meet to take action on the question of whether at dividend shall be declared on the common stock. While an important event awaited with more than ordinary interest, it is nevertheless simply a question as to whether the management of the road will see fit to distribute a portion of the accumulated surplus to stockholders, for the existence of a handsome surplus is well known.
LONDON, April 30 -- Money was in strong demand to-day owing to month-end requirements and repayments to the Bank of England. Discounts were steady.

PHILADELPHIA, April 30 -- The local interests were chiefly centred in Bethlehem Steel and Cambria Steel on the insistent theory that they are to be taken into the new Pennsylvania Steel Company. The Readings also were stronger, but the advance was comparatively small. A new high record was made by Consolidated Lake Superior preferred.

Three physicians testified yesterday to the bruises and contusions on the body of Herbert C. Wadman, after his death in the Manhattan State Hospital on March 5 last, at the inquest being held by Coroner Zucca.
The first speaker at the hearing was Corporation Counsel Whalen, who read his argument against the bill. He said:

BALTIMORE, April 30 -- The wedding of Miss Katherine Abbey, daughter of Mrs. Henry Abbey of 940 Calvert Street, and Frederick A. Dallett of East Orange, N.J., took place at noon to-day at St. Paul's Church, the Rev. Dr. T.S.B. Hodges officiating. It was a large affair and many guests from New York were present.

Theodosius F. Secor. Theodosius P. Secor, a pioneer shipbuilder and engineer, died at his home, 1,177 Dean Street, Brooklyn, on Monday, after an illness covering a period of three months. He was ninety-three years old.

Part II., Special Term of the Supreme Court, which is usually a very sombre place, had the appearance of a gayly decorated Chinese tea room yesterday during the hearing of the habeas corpus proceedings which were instituted to prevent little Rosie and Lillie Yip Chu from being taken to China by their foster father, Chu Ying Yuen, a Mott Street merchant.

Brooklyn won the baseball game from Boston yesterday at Washington Park by the narrowest margin, gaining their victory in the ninth inning by the score of 2 to 1. For six innings the Bostons held the lead, and then Long, the Captain and shortstop of that team, virtually lost the game for his club by making two errors which were directly responsible for the tying of the score by Brooklyn.

The Cuban Commissioners were entertained at an informal dinner at the Metropolitan Club last evening. The affair was arranged by a number of bankers and merchant who have business relations with the island Covers were laid for fifty guests.

An unusually strong team has been picked to represent the Metropolitan Golf Association in its third competition with All Philadelphia next Saturday on the links of the Philadelphia Cricket Club, at Wissahickon Heights. The personnel of the team was announced yesterday afternoon, and golfers will see at a glance that it possesses a dozen players of rare ability.

The news from Manila makes it increasingly evident that the capture of AGUINALDO, followed, so to speak, by his surrender and his voluntary adhesion to the American cause, meant and marked the collapse of all organized resistance in Luzon. Every day's dispatches assure us more fully of that.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Chinese Minister to-day stated that up to this time no move has been made toward negotiating in the United States a part of the Chinese loan to meet the indemnities. Minister Wu says the interest rates have been too high thus far to induce the Chinese Government to look in this direction for its investments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There are many millionaires, but I have heard of only a few who have shown a charitable disposition. One was that of our noble citizen, Mr. Andrew Carnegie, who wishes to improve the mind by furnishing books to read, which is very good and very commendable, but there are still more deserving charities, one of which is homes for old men and old women.
Army. Second Lieut. John B. Barnes, recently appointed is assigned to the Twenty-ninth infantry, and will join that regiment at Fort Sheridan.

A correspondent makes a suggestion about the placing of the Sherman Monument, which is evidently calculated to attract the interest of everybody concerned. To us it seems that it ought to prove the means of reconciling the various views which have been put forth on the subject.

The Edison bowlers won two games in the Metropolis tournament on Cadieu Cashau's Monarch Palace Alleys last night and made a new high team score of 633. The team is now certain of first prize in the tournament and probably will win the high score prize, while Wenzel, who averaged 219 last night, will win the first individual average prize.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- The Inter-State Commerce Commission to-day heard representations from officers of numerous railroad companies throughout the country as to the forms of reports of railroad accidents required under the law enacted at the last session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Until to-day the War Department has been reckoning on the existence of two important insurgent commands and two lesser bands, which are large enough to be annoying. These four, with a few scattered remnants here and there, were all that remained of the great Filipino rebellion which has kept an American army busy for more than two years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would seem a pity to allow the opportunity presented by the controversy which has arisen over Senator Ellsworth's referee bill to pass without some more general discussion of the merits of the present system, which the new measure is intended to supplant in this department.

The 1st of May brings a truce to weddings. Some one remarked yesterday that it seemed as if everybody was getting married. In town and suburb there were a large number of brides and bridegrooms. With the exception of the wedding of Miss Huntingtor to the Rev. Alexander W. Bostwick, at Calvary Church, the majority of the weddings were home affairs, and only intimate friends and relatives were asked.

-- Judging from the amazing story told by Lieut. RICHARD H. TOWNLEY of the navy when he took the stand to explain his own share in the proceedings for which Capt. J. C. REED is now undergoing a court-martial trial in Manila, the young man is in the greatest need of enlightenment as to the difference between "character" and "reputation."

In refraining from telegraphing abstracts of the speeches of welcome addressed to President McKINLEY by the spokesmen of local delegations at his various stopping places. The Associated Press shows a wise discrimination. It is enough to read what the President has to say ex officio and to see with what skill he avoids saying anything indiscreet.

It is a gratifying indication of returning sanity among the friends of temperance that there is a growing protest among them against further teaching in the schools of alleged facts about alcohol and its effects upon the human system which are demonstrably false and misleading.

ALBANY, April 30 -- For four hours today Gov. Odell sat in a pivot chair in the reception room of the Executive Chamber and listened to arguments for and against the Raines North River Bridge bill. The delegations which attended the hearing were impressive in character, and the Governor gave all who wished to be heard an opportunity to speak.

CHICAGO, April 30 -- With two out and three men on bases in to-day's National League baseball game. Dexter hit over Dobbs's head, sending in two runs and winning a hard-fought contest. Both teams batted hard, Green and Crawford excelling. The score:
The handsome twelve-story building 30 West Forty-fourth Street, erected by the Yale Club Company, will be formally opened to-day.

That the vehement protestation of Commissioner MURPHY, immediately after his appointment, of a purpose to purify the Police Department and hold derelict Captains responsible for violations of law in their precincts was "playing to the galleries" no one doubted who had any knowledge of his political and official record.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., April 30 -- For the second event in the Lakewood polo series to-day the Camden (S.C.) players met and were soundly thrashed by Lakewood's second team in a contest for the Herbert Trophies. As the score shows, 6 1/2 goals to 4 1/4 this with the losers' allowance of 5 goals by handicap, is not a state of affairs to rejoice over.

It can be stated definitely and authoritatively, that the new lessee and manager of the Manhattan Theatre will be Harris Grey Fiske, who takes possession of the building to-day. Brady Ziegfeld, who lease has expired, vacated the premises yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 30 -- Mgr. Sebastian Martinelli to-night received from the hands of a member of the Papal Guard of Pope Leo XIII., Count Stanislaus Colacicchi, who had just arrived from Rome, the consistorial letter formally advising him of his elevation to the Cardinalate, and the red zuchetta emblematic of that high office.

BRISTOL, R.I., April 30 -- To-day John Hyslop, the New York Yacht Club measurer, came from New York to measure two new racing sloops of the twenty-one-foot class, named Rogue and Oonagh, and, incidentally, viewed the Constitution in the South shop.

Proceedings looking toward the preferment of formal charges of willful neglect of duty against Patrolman Joseph Donohue of the West Twentieth Street Station for permitting the escape of John C. Kinnehan, alias King, alias Hart, suspected of trying to "tip off" the poolroom at Eleventh Avenue and Twentieth Street, raided by the City Vigilance League Monday, were begun yesterday before Justice Jerome, sitting as a committing Magistrate.

The right of 797 drivers in the StreetCleaning Department to recover from the city $1,336,000 for extra work under the eight-hour labor law was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division in an opinion by Justice O'Brien. The action was brought by Patrick J. McNulty, as assignee of the claimants, and is for extra work performed by them in working more than eight hours per day between Jan. 1, 1892, and April 26, 1894.

Capt. Josiah A. Westervelt, who commanded the Ninth Precinct, whose station house is in Charles Street, became yesterday a private citizen by his invocation of the law which provides that a member of the uniformed force who has served twenty-five years and is more than fifty-five years old must, on his own application, provided that there are no charges within the department pending against him, be retired.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in the First Department, has handed down a decision sustaining the demurrer of the defendants in the case of Joseph W. Thompson and Charles H. Bellows, two of the individual underwriters at the Commercial Lloyds. They sued the Colonial Assurance Company for their individual shares of the amount due under the rein surance contract.

Sixty-five years of married life were celebrated last night by Mr. and Mrs. Theodore N. Ayres at their home, in Astoria. Besides the members of their family, the celebration was taken part in by the congregation of Trinity Methodist Episcopal Church, of which Mr. Ayres is the oldest members.

When the North German Lloyd liner Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse sailed yesterday she had 1,400 passengers on board. To see this great number of travelers off there were, it was estimated, no fewer than 3,000 persons on the Cunard pier, from which the vessel sailed.

There was a hearing in the Mayor's office yesterday on the McCarren Bridge bill, drawn for the purpose of allowing the city officials to relieve the crush at certain hours at the New York terminal of the bridge. Ex-Mayor Abram S. Hewitt appeared and made a strong plea for the approval of the bill.

PRINCETON, May 1. -- By hard hitting Princeton rolled up 21 runs against Cornell to-day, while the latter, unable to do more than make scattering hits, made but two runs. Underbill, who has been suffering from a sore arm, pitched the first six innings and held Cornell down to four hits. He did some clever fielding also.

PARIS, May 1. -- The Foreign Office has received a dispatch from Peking, announcing that M. Pichon, the French Minister, presented to-day ihe report of the Committee on Indemnity. The amount China is to pay has been fixed at 1,363,000,000 francs ($273,000,000.)

Yesterday the regular May Day strikes occurred all over the country, from San Francisco to Maine, but none of them attained sufficient proportions to make it important outside of the locality directly affected. Most of them were by men engaged in the building trades and allied branches, the workmen demanding either shorter hours or more pay, or both.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The third anniversary of the battle of Manila Bay was celebrated here to-night by a banquet at the Raleigh Hotel, participated in by officers of the American fleet who took part in that conflict. These numbered about twenty-five persons, less than one-fourth of those who were in the battle.

Mayor Van Wyck yesterday appointed James G. Tighe a City Magistrate in place of Henry Bristow, resigned. Mayor Van Wyck at the same time announced that he would not make appointments of five other City Magistrates who he claimed in his veto message of the charter would cease to hold office on May I.

Two important Tammany functions were held last evening in the Second Assembly District. At one affair Patrick Divver received a silver service worth $800, and at the other Councilman Thomas P. Foley gave to the political workers of the district fifty kegs of beer, 3,000 sandwiches, many bottles of whisky, and presented James J. Corbett as a side attraction at a stag affair.

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, May 1 -- The fire which broke out on the pier here yesterday afternoon destroyed that structure and its entire contents in forty-five minutes. The total loss is estimated at about $300,000, but the losers are believed to be fully insured, with the exception of about $75,000 worth of cargo awaiting steamers.

BOSTON, May 1. -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks loaned at 3 per cent. New York funds sold at 15 and 10 2-3 cents discount for cash. Ex-changes, $34.242.006; balances, $2.956.425. Call money loans, 4 and 4 1/2 per cent., according to the character of names and collateral. Time money, practically on a 4 per cent. basis, with exceptions both above and below this figure.

Notwithstanding the fact that there was no London market during the day, and that for that reason few orders came from abroad, the transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday ran up to the total of over 2,700,000 shares. This, while considerably below the record figure of the day previous.

Dr. Roger Sherman Tracy, Registrar of Records in the Health Department, retired yesterday from official service, which began nearly thirty-one years ago. He receives $100 a month as a pension, the largest amount that he could get under the law, although his salary was $4,000 a year.

There was a Socialist-Labor Party mass meeting in Cooper Union last night to celebrate the 1st of May, which was fixed by the Paris Labor Congress in 1889 as the International Labor Day. The large hall was crowded. Some few among the several thousands seemed to be Americanborn, but accent and foreign mannerisms predominated.

The patrolmen of the police force who during the session of the Legislature failed to secure the passage of a measure that would bring about a three-platoon system of duty, and be mandatory on the Police Commissioner are endeavoring to attain what they aimed at in another way. In the various station houses in the city these communications, emanating from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, have been placarded:

ALBANY, May 1. -- It is as certain as anything which has not been positively settled that the Governor will veto the Raines North River Bridge bill. If there was a limitation upon the franchise which the bill grants to the New York and New Jersey Bridge Company there might be a possibility that the Governor would act upon the bill favorably.

LONDON, May 2. -- At a meeting of the Miners' Federation in London yesterday, attended by delegates from all parts of the United Kingdom, it was recommended that all miners quit work unless the coal tax is withdrawn. Another meeting was summoned for May 7 to finally decide the matter to fix a date for the stoppage of work should that step be resolved upon.

The committee of employes of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company which visited President Greatsinger on Tuesday again called at the offices of the company yesterday and saw J. C. Brackenridge, the General Manager of the system.

Daily fluctuations in the security market are frequently confusing in character. So many varying impulses control traders that regularity of movement is impossible, and there are recurring periods when the dominant influence becomes obscured by the momentary situation.

With eyes closed and hands describing curves in midair, Mrs. Margaret Gaule glided up and down the aisles in Lyric Hall last evening, seeing things and voicing messages from an unseen world. No one else saw anything unusual, but as for hearing -- the torrent of speech that flowed from the lips of the medium would have effectually shut out the voice of even the most eloquent and leather-voiced spirit.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The Board of Directors of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company to-day declared a semi-annual dividend of 2 1/2 per cent. The previous dividend was 2 1/2 per cent, and half per cent, extra.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 1. -- The Rhode Island Jockey Club has been incorporated under the laws of this State, the incorporators being William R. Travers, Henry K. Eldridge, Francis M. Ware, Edwin D. morgan, center Hitchcock. Prescott Lawrence. Oliver H.P. Belmont, and Egerton L. Winthrop. Jr.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The Philadelphia team won the final game on the home grounds to-day before its first Eastern trip, defeating New York by the score of 6 to 1. Both pitchers were effective, but in the fifth inning the Phlladelphlas, by bunching hits, scored four runs. Each team played a good fielding game, Ganzel catching two difficult drives.

Henry W. Bates, the lawyer who was accused of receiving money from various young men under a guarantee that he would place them on the Fire and Police Departments, was convicted yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions. The specific charge against Bates was a violation of Section 53 of the Penal Code, which makes it a misdemeanor to receive money for the purpose of assuring municipal positions to any one.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- The public debt statement issued by the Treasury Department to-day shows that at the close of business April 30 the debt, less cash in the Treasury, amounted to $1,072,745,256, a decrease for the month of $4,397,653. This decrease is largely accounted for by the purchase of bonds for the sinking fund.

Some of the liveliest sport witnessed on the Speedway this Spring took place yesterday afternoon, when several of the crack trotters and pacers met in a series of friendly brushes. Despite the rain, the roadbed was in prime condition. Among the star performers were Honor Bright, driven by John F. Cockerill; Alves, handled by Nathan Straus; George Wallace, driven by Louis Kahn, and Moth Miller, driven by Dr. David Randall.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- The ministerial committee to investigate the canteen arrived at Fort Sheridan this morning, and was received by Col. Van Home, Capt. Ely. Capt. Madden, Capt. Morrow, Major Thorpe, Lieut. Rosa, and Chaplain Vattman. Dr. Parkhurst of the Anti-Saloon League, the Chairman, was asked by Col. Van Horne to deny an assertion attributed to him in a newspaper, that officers drank champagne for which there were no bills.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your excellent editorial on the above subject you seem to have overlooked one important fact. Is It not true that the wonderful progress of the South during the last two or three decades is in a large measure due to Northern enterprise, capital, and labor?

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each 5500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

May brings a temporary cessation of weddings. Yesterday had no gathering of any note. On Friday the last meeting of the bridge class arranged by Mrs. Gouverneur Kortright will take place at the residence of Mrs. Joseph Pulitzer, and on Saturday there will be the meet of the Coaching Club and the fete champetre at Claremont.

A stock broker who thought there was some money in a side line, such as a liquor store, has suddenly discovered that there is more in the straight brokerage business. Accordingly, Justice Andrews, in the Supreme Court, signed an order yesterday to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed for a liquor store at 63 Nassau Street.

The new Chamber of Commerce Building, to be erected on the site of the old Real Estate Exchange, at Liberty Street and Liberty Place, will be constructed of white Vermont marble, with a white granite base. The design is classical and is monumental in character.

The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir MICHAEL HICKS-BEACH, has lately received a suggestion from the food reformers which is claimed to have the double merit of pointing out a new tax and incidentally doing a great deal of good to the people of Great Britain. The combination of a tax and a benefit is a rare one.

Ex-Senator Edward Murphy. Jr., and members of his family formed a happy party at the Hoffman House last night. Included in it were the ex-Senator's son Richard and the latter's bride, who was Miss Elizabeth W. McConlhe of Troy.

CHICAGO, May 1. -- To-day's session in the grain pits was a strenuous one. Sharp advances were scored for delivery the present month, while July options showed moderate sympathetic strength. May corn and oats were said to be practically cornered, and showed at the close gains of 1 1/4 and 1 cent, respectively.

The final list of fifty strong men to represent Columbia in the intercollegiate strength test competition was completed early yesterday morning, and has been sent to Dr. Dudley A. Sargent, the Director of the Harvard Gymnasium, for intercollegiate comparison. The total number of points made by Columbia's athletes was 65,271.5.

The Military Order of the Loyal Legion of the United States, Commandery of the State of New York, held its annual meeting at Delmonico's last night. The business session was followed by a banquet, at which Gen. Henry L. Burnett, the Commander, presided. Among the speakers were the Rev. Dr. Joseph H. Twitchell of Hartford, Conn.; Gen. John R. Brooke, United States Army, and Gen. James H. Wilson.

BOSTON, May 1. -- The annual meeting of the Mexican Central Railroad was held here at noon to-day, and the Board of Directors agreed upon by the other Mexican Central interests and the New York investors who have secured control of the road was elected. Under the agreement the new board consists of seventeen members, of which seven were members of the old Mexican Central Board, while ten represent the new interests.

The unfinished seven-story apartment house at the southeast corner of Riverside Drive and Ninety-fourth Street has been sold by Bernard S. Levy to Potts Partridge, builders, through I. Randolph Jacobs Co. The same brokers have secured a, building loan of $110,000 for the purchasers, and the structure will be completed immediately.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your "Topics of the Times" -- always so interesting -- you attempt to criticise a writer in your last Sunday's paper, who tried to solve what you term the "difficult task" of educating the children of our land whether in "sectarian" or "non-sectarian" methods.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 1. -- As the result of action taken at the annual meeting of the Wheeling and Lake Erie Railroad Company, held here to-day, the property practically becomes a part of the Gould system.

LONDON, May 1. -- The Two Thousand Guineas, first of the classic races of the year, attracted a large attendance at New-market to-day. The field was the largest which has faced a starter for this event since 1852, when Shotover won. William C. Whitney's Prince Charles II. and Pierre Lorillard's Exedo represented American owners, while six American jockeys were distributed among the seventeen runners.

At 4:01 o'clock yesterday afternoon a crap game was in progress in Mott Street, where it empties into Park Row. At 4:02 six small players were flying in six different directions, while a seventh, who had won most of the money, was writhing in the grasp of a tall man.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Pennsylvania and Columbia met on Franklin Field this afternoon and the Quakers won by a score of 22 to 2. The New Yorkers played listlessly throughout. The Quakers excelled at batting and found Gearin easy to hit for seven innings. Layton pitched six innings, and with the exception of the first did well.

Barnard College entered upon a new epoch in its career yesterday with the installation of Miss Laura D. Gill as Dean of the Faculty. In honor of the event all the college building's were elaborately decorated with flags and flowers and a rich showing of the colors of Columbia University. The Trustees of Columbia and of Barnard and Teachers Colleges, the University Council and Faculty, and students of Barnard all joined in the ceremonies.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 1. -- The people of Texas are running mad in regard to oil speculation. The wonderful discovery in the Beaumont field has led to the organization of over 200 oil companies in this State within the past three months. The charters of twenty-five new oil companies were filed in the office of the Secretary of State here to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 1. -- Secretary Root has got into hot water with the Woman's Confederate organization of Richmond. He has issued an order for the reburial of the Confederate dead at Arlington Cemetery and at the Soldiers' home in a place at Arlington to be selected by the Quartermaster General of the army.

In their persistent search for evidence against the elusive "John Doe," intermediary between the police and the gambling syndicate, the individual who is supposed to deal out protection to vice and make it safe to disobey the laws, the Committee of Fifteen yesterday rifled three safes, two of which had to be forced open, and secured a quantity of incriminating evidence.

It was so very pleasant on Tuesday that Central Park workmen or whoever is in charge of them, decided that Summer was here, and that there would be an immediate demand for the use of the tennis courts. So a force of men was at work all Tuesday marking out the courts on the thick and velvety lawns which had been carefully and closely mowed on Monday.

The Directors of the New York, Susquehanna and Western have elected E. B. Thomas Chairman of the board, F. D. Underwood President, G. M. Cummings First Vice President, J. A. Middleton Second Vice President, J. W. Flatten Treasurer, and L. D. Smith Assistant Secretary.

No man is wise enough or experienced enough to understand the present course of the stock market or to make any confident prediction as to its future behavior, whether the rule of high and still higher prices with enormous daily transactions is to continue, or if the reaction which everybody vagruely predicts because it must come some time is to be gradual or severe.

Transfer Tug No. 8 of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company was steaming up the East River about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, when a deck hand saw a, man floating down the river on an improvised raft, consisting of a long plank, on top of which a wooden bench had been placed.

Judgment for a penalty for a violation of the public health law recovered by the people against William Park for selling " Eiffel Tower lemonade " with no lemon juice has been affirmed by the Appellate Division. It appeared on the trial that the circular issued wiith defendant's preparation stated that 38,000,000 of Messina lemons were used in one year in the manufacture of the lemonade.

PITTSBURG, May 1. -- When the annual congress of the Sons of American Revolution was called to order this morning Registrar General A. Howard Clark made his report for the past year, which showed the total active members in the society 9,908. There are thirty-nine societies, the largest being in Massachusetts.

NEWARK, N.J., May 1. -- The Progressive Tailoring Company, a concern conducted by Frank Walters at 833 Broad Street, which undertook to clothe everybody for $1 a week on the endless chain principle, was raided to-day by anxious patrons who claimed to be unable to get clothing to which they were entitled.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- The Readings and Lehigh Valley were the features of the market to-day. The Reading issues dominated the list from the start, and increased in activity and buoyancy as the day drew to a close. They rose to the highest figures yet touched since the reorganization. The second preferred ruled here above the New York price all day, but the common was in greatest demand.
In his little speech at Roanoke President McKINLEY made a reference to our foreign trade relations which is significant:

NEW ORLEANS, May 1. -- Booming cannon, blaring bands, and shrieking steam whistles greeted the Presidential train as it drew into the station late this afternoon. This is the first time New Orleans has ever had a visit from the Chief Magistrate of the Nation, and it was a royal reception that the old city extended to President McKinley.

COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa, May 1. -- Edwin H. Conger. United States Minister to China, was enthusiastically welcomed this morning by the people of his State as he set foot on Iowa soil here. His private car arrived in the eity station of the Northwestern Road promptly at 11 o'clock, and was greeted by more than a thousand people who had assembled to do the first honors to the returning Minister.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1. -- Oil reached Marcus Hook for the first time to-day through the new pipe line, and the occasion was celebrated in a quiet way by the officers of the United States Pipe Company, the owner of the new enterprise. The line from Bradford to Freemansburg, near Bethlehem, has been in operation for some time, but from the latter point to tide-water the work has been but recently completed.

These seem to be pretty high-handed proceedings which the raiders of the gambling houses have been taking, the threats to shoot the fleeing patron of a "game," the threats to blow up safes with dynamite in order to secure evidence against their owners. Perhaps the raids cannot be altogether acquitted of something sensational in their operation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is much discussion at the present time in reference to the conferring upon President McKinley of the degree of Doctor of Laws by Harvard University. This discussion, it seems to me, is not only illtimed, but also shows the lack of sentiment, the lack of patriotism, so to speak, of the dissenters.
CHICAGO, May 1. -- New York exchange was quoted at par to-day. Money for call and time loans was rated at 4 1/2@5 per cent.

A team of athletes from the New York National Guard regiments journeyed to Newark last night to compete in the Spring games of the First Regirment, National Guard of New Jersey, which were held in the armory, Sussex Avenue and Jay Street, and won honors in all of the open events with great ease.

PARIS, May 2. -- The leader of the three burglars who robbed the American Express Company's office here on the night of April 26 of 30,000 francs has been arrested. His name is George Miler, and he was born in Chicago. Another of the burglars has been arrested at Amiens.
NEWPORT, May 1. -- On Friday evening the officers of the War College and Training and Torpedo Stations will give a dance at the War College.

Columbia's Varsity lacrosse team defeated Hobart yesterday at Jasper Oval in the annual game of the two institutions by a score of 4 to 0. The fast playing of Columbia's defense and the magnificent work of Lindsay between the goal posts were the only things that kept the visitors from scoring, for they played a fast, aggressive game.

LOUDONVILLE, Ohio, May 2 -- A fire which started in the American House livery barn to-night caused a loss of $75,000. The losses are partly covered by insurance. The fire was started by the upsetting of a lantern in the hay loft of the livery barn. A steamer and hose from Mansfield arrived at 10 o'clock, and a steamer from Wooster arrived at 11 o'clock.

LONDON, May 3 -- There was a large attendance in the House of Commons yesterday afternoon in anticipation of the debate on the new export tax on coal. The Government had issued an urgent whip to the Unionist members, and had taken other strong precautions to secure a majority in case of an unexpectedly early vote.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 2 -- Attorney General Grey, when asked to-day if it was true, as has been claimed, that the State appropriation of $50,000 and lands to the riparian line to the Palsade Commission was unconstitutional, declined to commit himself. He said the question had not been officially presented to him.

The Board of Trade Journal for the present week contains some most interesting statistics showing the development of the foreign trade of Japan during the year 1900. The total volume amounts to u49,852,000, as against u44,138,000 in 1899: her imports having risen from u22,346,000 to u29,125,000, while the exports fell from u21,792,000 to u20,727,000.

All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street, already one of the finest church foundations in America, is to have one and probably two new buildings. It was said yesterday that one which is certain will cost $80,000, and that it will be in memory of the two sons of Dr. Humphrey, who were recently drowned in the River Nile.

Testimony was given at Coroner Zucea's inquest into the death of Herbert C. Wadman, the Bellevue and Manhattan State Hospital insane patient, yesterday, tending to fix the time of the infliction of the bruises and fractured ribs, revealed after death by the autopsy, as the afternoon of his arrival, on March 2, in the Manhattan State Hospital.

The police, by an unlooked-for spurt, threw a bombshell into a nest of speculators at 53 New Street yesterday afternoon and arrested enough men to thoroughly frighten the others. No less than 500 men, all of them afflicted with the prevailing stock-buying fever in its most malignant form, were in the place.

Locked tightly within the inner office of President Alexander S. Webb, in the building of the College of the City of New York, are the several hundred copies constituting the last issue of the college publication The Review. Spread over the pages of this edition is the attack of Student Weather-wax of the institution supported by city money on Richard Croker.

LONDON, May 2 -- At the second day's racing of the Newmarket First Spring Meeting to-day the Thursday Welter Handicap Plate was won by Lord Harewood's chestnut colt, by Sir Hugo, out of Ice, ridden by "Johnnie'' Reiff.

SAYVILLE, L.I., May 2 -- A lunatic from the State Hospital at Central Islip is at large, and the residents about Oakdale, Islip, and this place are in fear of a visit from him. During the recent forest fires the hospital buildings were at one time threatened, and a number of the inmates who are employed at work around the grounds were called upon to assist in fighting the flames.
GLASGOW, May 2 -- The Duke and Duchess of Fire opened the Glasgow Exhibition this afternoon. The weather was fine, and the town was beautifully decorated for the occasion.

Fordham College's baseball team for the second time in two years defeated the Cornell nine yesterday on the former's grounds. The home team made seven runs during the first six innings, but in the seventh Cornell by bunching hits scored four runs. The score:

ALBANY, May 2 -- A change of practice of interest to all lawyers is made by the McCarren law amending Section 885 of the Code of Civil Procedure relating to deposition to be used on motion. The new law is as follows:

The feverish excitement of the trading on the Stock Exchange increased. If anything, yesterday, and the speculative movement has broadened until It seems to have embraced nearly everybody, from big operators to clerks and messenger boys in the financial district.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 2 -- There was a lively meeting at the Mount Moriah Baptist Church, Springwood Avenue, Tuesday night, when another clash took place between the pastor, Rev. William H. Wallace, and his congregation.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- A veteran of the civil war, not a member of the Union Veterans' Union, has sought an opportunity to protest against the recent announcement by the "General" in command of the local society of that name, and to representations made for it, that he says are not supported by facts.

CHICAGO, May 2 -- Money was easier, call and time loan rates being 4@4 1/2. The better rate in New York caused Chicago banks to lend about $2,000,000 there. New York offered 5 per cent, here in Chicago. New York exchange was quoted at par.

They were discussing the modern novel after the ticker had ceased its song and the heat and worry of the day's battle was ended. It was the issue of a story that has been most widely advertised, and whose author has been dined and wined and boomed in the most approved fashion of modern advertising.

MOUNTAIN VIEW, Oklahoma Territory, May 2 -- Thousands of people are pouring into Southwestern Oklahoma and camping in and about the Kiowa, Comanche, Apache, and Wichita Indian Reservations for the opening scheduled for some time in August. It will be possible for the Government to have the land ready for settlement much sooner than Aug. 6, the last day on which the land may be opened.

NEWARK, N.J., May 2 -- Louis Dudley, who was indicted for alleged interference with James W. Hodgkinson, Chief of the Fire Department of Orange, on March 9 last, when the chief and his men were trying to put out a fire that threatened to destroy the temporary Isolation Hospital, was convicted to-day in the Court of Quarter Sessions.

May and Flora Hengler, who are professionally known as the Hengler Sisters, have signed a contract with Weber and Fields to become members at their stock company next season. The addition of these two dancers, who are regarded as the leaders in their particular style of dancing, will undoubtedly strengthen the company in this particular department, which the management have always endeavored to make a feature of their performance.

BETHLEHEM, Penn., May 2 -- The trials for the team that will meet the Rutgers track team on Wednesday were held on Lehigh Field this alternoon. Although the track was not in the best condition, very good time was made. The results of the shot putting and hurdles were particularly pleasing.

The Illinois Central Railroad has taken the lead in an interesting and beneficial movement, which promises to have important results and should be imitated by every progressive and intelligently managed railroad in the country. Its officers have equipped a train with the machinery for constructing sample stretches of highway and will send it out to give object lessons in good road building all the way from Chicago to New Orleans.

PHILADELPHIA, May 2 -- The Reading stocks were again the feature of the market. While the common was selling at 43 3/4 in Wall Street it commanded 44 1/8 here, and the same situation was seen in the first and second preferred. In the final dealings the Readings yielded slightly. Street sentiment is bullish on the coal situation, and ultimately higher prices are expected for Reading and Lehigh Valley.

Miss Grace Chauncey and Mrs. Howard F. Whitney will meet in the final round next week on the Dyker Meadow golf links near Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, to determine the championship holder of the club. Besides winning that enviable title the victor will receive the silver cup offered by Mrs. T.M. Lloyd.

Not since the first plans for the rapid transit subway were adopted has the Board of Rapid Transit Commissioners had a more important meeting than the one held yesterday afternoon in its rooms at 320 Broadway. Three far-reaching decisions were agreed upon. There will be a tunnel under the Harlem River into the Bronx, and not an elevated structure.

ALBANY, May 2 -- Ex-Judge Robert Earl of Herkimer, formerly a member of the Appellate Court, will sit as referee in New York on May 21 to pass upon appeals taken by some of the big corporations of New York City from the assessments made by the Tax Commissioners under the Franchise Tax law.
WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Midovi Komatse, Secretary of the Japanese Legation, in an interview to-day made an interesting statement on the financial situation in Japan. He said:

CHICAGO, May 2 -- May corn soared to 55 to-day and closed 4 cents over yesterday at 53 1/2. July closed 1 1/4 cents higher. The tight grip of the leading bull on the May delivery was more than ever apparent. Prices fluctuated violently within a range of 5 cents, but actual transactions in the pit were small.

The Church Association for the Advancement of the Interest of Labor, which was organized about twelve years ago in the Protestant Episcopal Church, held its annual supper at the Tuxedo Building. Fifty-ninth Street and Madison Avenue, last night.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- This morning's report from Peking that the representative of the United States has objected to the proposition to permit the Chinese Government to increase its customs duties, seems to have been obtained from unofficial sources. Mr. Rockhill has not been instructed to oppose an increase in the customs.

The story of a controversy between Municipal Judge Hermann Bolte and the law firm of Benjamin Looser over a request made by the lawyers to the Judge to allow them to have a case which was brought in his court tried before some other Judge, came out yesterday in an argument before Justice O'Gorman for a writ of mandamus to compel Judge Bolte to comply with the request.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the title "Southern Shiftlessness" in your issue of to-day is a communication signed by "A Constant Reader of THE TIMES," In which, referring to a recent article, he puts this query: "Is it not true that the wonderful progress of the South during the last two or three decades is in a large measure due to Northern enterprise, capital, and labor?"

ALBANY, May 2 -- The first piece of State legislation made necessary by the acquisition of the new possessions was passed by the Legislature this year, and has become a law. It is known as the Elsberg law to amend the real property law relative to the acknowledgment of conveyances.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- Cardinal Martinelli took the oath of his new office and subscribed to the profession of faith at the Papal Legation to-day. The oath was administered by Mgr.Conaty of the Catholic University and was witnessed by Mgr. Marchetti, the Papal Ablegate. The ceremony was private and was very simple.

The smashing of a slot machine in the Court of Special Sessions, during which the head of a hammer wielded by Anthony Comstock flew off and struck the bench just in front of the Court, came very near disturbing the usual dignity of the three black-robed Justices yesterday.

A lively game of baseball was contested yesterday by the Brooklyn and Philadelphia clubs at Washington Park, and the champions were the victors by the score of 5 to 4. It was the first game of the second series between the teams, and McCann, the pitcher who opposed the Quakers on the occasion of their first appearance at the opening of the Brooklyn grounds, was again in the box, with McGuire as catcher.

A dividend of $1 a share was declared yesterday on the common stock of the Norfolk and Western Railway. This is the first payment on this stock since the reorganization of the company in 1896. Dividends at the rate of 4 per cent, have been paid on the preferred stock since 1897.

The Aqueduct race meeting, prelude to the regular racing season on the great tracks of the metropolitan circuit, ended yesterday, and with it the time of prosperity for horses of the selling and cheap handicap class came to a close until the slack days of midsummer arrive to give them another chance.
NEWPORT, R.I., May 2 -- The Tax Assessors have made up the valuation and taxes for the year, which are; Real estate, $32,161,900; personal, $7,575,700; total,$39,737,600.

According to advices received by a prominent New York yachtsman, the two English racing yachts Alisa and Eelin, recently bought abroad for two American yachtsmen, are racing across the Atlantic. It was not generally understood that the yachts were to make a race of the trip to this side, as they did not leave their home ports within several days of each other.

A large crowd gathered in the arcade of the Equitable Building yesterday afternoon to witness the unveiling of a statue of Henry B. Hyde, founder of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. The sculptor of the statue,which is of bronze, was John Quiney Adams Ward, and the unveiling was set for yesterday, because it was the second anniversary of Mr. Hyde s death.

No warrant was issued yesterday charging the proprietor of Shanley's restaurant with violating the excise laws in selling ale to Justice William Travers Jerome and Col. Robert Grier Monroe between 3 and 4 o'clock Wednesday morning. The charge had been made by President Frederick Bruce Russell of the Law and Order League.

ALBANY, May 2 -- A curious defect in the real property law is remedied by a bill introduced by Assemblyman Seymour, which has become a law. Under the law as it stood, if a wife died and left property to her husband and he had no heirs at his death, there was no provision for the reversion of the property to the wife's line.

A meeting of the Executive Committee of the Metropolitan District Cricket League was held yesterday at the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, and representatives were in attendance from the Knickerbocker Athletic Club, Manhattan Cricket Club, Montclair Athletic Club, Kings County Cricket Club, and Nelson Lodge Cricket Club.

BUFFALO, May 2 -- So far as the Buffalo churches that were represented by the committee appointed some time ago, with the Rev. O.P. Gifford of the Delaware Avenue Baptist Church at its head, are concerned, no further action will be taken looking toward the closing of the Pan-American Exposition on Sunday.

Dodge Oleott, Colgate Co. and Johnson Johnson, the three teams tied for second place in the Wholesale Drug Trade Bowling Association tournament, bowled off the tie last night on Reid's alleys. Each won a game, and it was decided the team having the highest total pins should take the second prize.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 2 -- Stamford speculators in stock who have been investing through the local branch of Rogers Co. of Boston were thrown into a state of worry to-day by the announcement that the firm would hereafter require its clientage to put up an additional three points on all pending deals as well as new ones.

Overcrowding at the Manhattan entrance to the Brooklyn Bridge, and especially upon the City Hall station of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company, received yesterday the official censure of the Grand Jury in a presentment handed up by that body to Recorder Goff just before being discharged.

BOSTON, May 2 -- Libble Co. began to-day the sale of autographs, literary and dramatic, of the late Frederick W. French. Among the bidders were Evert Jansen Wendell, the New York collector, and Mr. Benjamin, the autograph dealer of New York, who secured some of the choicest items.

NEWPORT, May 2 -- Works on The Elms, the handsome new villa for Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Berwind, is being pushed rapidly, and by the first week in July they will be in possession of what is now regarded as one of the handsomest and largest villas here, ranking easily next to The Breakers. Mr. and Mrs. Berwind will open their new home with a large house party and ball.

Mr. RUSSELL SAGE does not have quite a fair show in the highly enlightening discussion of industrial and railroad combinations in the May North American Review, for, after disclosing his position by opening fire on the trusts, he must perforce stand by his silent batteries and endure a bombardment from the enemy's heaviest guns.

LONDON, May 2 -- Further repayments of money due to the Bank of England caused money to be in good demand to-day. Discounts were steady. The condition of the market was uncertain, the weakness of Paris exchange causing nervousness.

WASHINGTON, May 2 -- The prospect of the elimination in the South of the negro vote and the removal of the fear of negro domination as an incident of the withdrawal of universal suffrage are leading Southern Democrats to express themselves in a way calculated to excite surprise and concern among some of the old party leaders.

OCEAN GROVE, May 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Aaron E. Ballard, Vice President of the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association of the Methodist Episcopal Church, made public to-day the programme of special services to be held this Summer on the camp grounds. These services will begin on Saturday, June 22, and continue daily until Sunday, Sept. 1.

How to prevent cut prices was the principal topic at the annual convention of the Proprietary Association -- manufacturers of patent medicines -- which continued at the Murray Hill Hotel yesterday. C.F. Shoemaker, Chairman of the Proprietary Committee of the National Wholesale Druggists' Association, in an address, recommended more stringent agreements with allied bodies not to supply jobbers selling to price cutters.

The high mortality among children in cities has always been believed by careful students of vital statistics to be due to causes which are distinctly remediable under proper conditions. That this is true is indicated by the remarkable showing of the Hebrew Orphan Asylum in this city.

-- Since the recent poisoning cases among English beer drinkers, resulting from the use of sulphuric acid containing arsenic in the manufacture of glucose. Sir LAUDER BRUNTON and Dr. TUNNICLIFFE have been making an elaborate investigation of distilled liquors, with a view to supplementing the experiments conducted twenty years ago by DUJARDIN-BEAUMETZ.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 2 -- As a change from the soul-stirring polo contest that was fought to a finish here yesterday, to-day's mild canter of the local Freebooters and Lakewood's second organization attracted a somewhat smaller audience, and the uncertain weather premonitions of the early morning hours evidently had a negative effect upon both players and their ponies.

The property 48 and 50 Maiden Lane, extending through to 33 and 35 Liberty Street, has been sold by Samuel F. Myers, through Brokers Pease Elliman. The buyer is Frank D. Allen, who represents a Western capitalist. Upon the expiration of existing leases, in about two years, a modern office building will be erected on the site.

Mrs. Jules Reynal died last night at her home, 263 Madison Avenue. Mrs. Reynal had been slowly sinking since Sunday last, when surgeons operated on her and removed a cancerous growth of a malignant type.

As time goes on and the plans of "the allies" are more developed in China, American citizens have the more reason to congratulate themselves that their country is not involved in the proceedings of "Christendom" in that empire. They do appreciate it. Our Chinese policy, ever since the outbreak of the Boxer movement and the siege of the legations, has commanded the unanimous assent of our own people.
The general target practice of the New York Militia was started on the State range at Creedmoor yesterday.

Lieut. Col. Edward E. Dravo, Chief Commissary of the Department of the East, on Governors Island, is in a particularly cheerful mood these days, by reason of news from Arizona which promises him a substantial fortune. Col. Dravo came to Governors Island in October, after having served for over a year in the Philippines.
LONDON, May 2 -- The Middlesex Gun Club has cabled an acceptance of the challenge of the American team for June 11.

The annual Spring games of the New York University were held yesterday afternoon on Ohio Field. New figures were established in three events. F.P. Heartsill, 1903, a new an this year, gained double honors, winning the mile and two-mile runs and breaking the college records in both.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial in to-day's issue on the subject of "referees" is both discriminating and adequate. It invites consideration of the difficult subject, and it prompts a suggestion which is the result of some thought and much experience. The present system is certainly not satisfactory, though there is not a Judge on the bench whose motives are to be questioned or whose actions condemned.

Evidence of a strongly incriminating character, pointing directly toward certain persons who have all along been supposedly engaged in protecting vicious resorts in the City of New York, has at last been secured by the Committee of Fifteen. The evidence was a result of the raid Tuesday night on the "Winona Club," of 111 East Fourteenth Street.

Business men in the upper section of Broadway. Brooklyn, have decided to organize the Empire National Bank, with a capital stock of $200,000. A meeting for the discussion of the project was held Wednesday night at 1.726 Broadway, with A. Stewart Walsh as Chairman. Fifty thousand dollars of the amount of stock required was subscribed, and at the next meeting, to be held on Wednesday next.

In the course of the police trials at Headquarters yesterday, Deputy Commissioner Devery fiercely attacked Justice Jerome, amid enthusiastic cheers from the policemen who were crowding into the courtroom. The first outbreak was during the trial of Policeman M.J. McManus, who only a few days ago was released from the penitentiary after serving a three-months' term for failure to provide for his children, who are in a public institution.

The season of large public dinners, which may be said now to have almost come to a close, has been remarkable this year for gatherings brought together as tributes to prominent writers. We believe the earliest of note were the dinners given in recognition of Mark Twain's return home after a long and triumphant sojourn in other lands, one of these occurring at the Lotos Club, the other at the Aldine.

Friday is not a very gay or busy day even in the height of the season. Yesterday the only events were the last meeting of the Bridge Club, at the residence of Mrs. Joseph Pulltzer, and the coach party given by Mr. and Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin, Jr.

Readers of Dr. John Fiske's "Old Virginia and Her Neighbors" will recall the lofty praise which he accorded to Sir Edwin Sandys as a far-seeing prophet of republican institutions in America. In its general effect Mr. Alexander Brown's book is little more than an expansion of that lofty praise.

WHAT BOYS AND GIRLS READ -- Some interesting facts concerning the "best read" books are offered by the Principal of the English Department of the Central High School of Springfield, Mass., who contributes an article to-the current number of The Journal of Education. These facts pertain, of course, to the boys and girls attending the High School.

To The New York Times Saturday Review: In the notable controversy which raged about your clever correspondent "Cynic " two years ago it was said that woman is the equal of man "in everything but physical strength and selfishness." This assertion of equality, varied by one of superiority, is frequently made.

As our Tammany officials go, and as they do not go, we have to admit that Commissioner SHEA is a very fairly faithful public servant. We ought not to forget that he was the one Commissioner who vigorously backed up Mr. COLER'S original protest against the rushing through of the Ramapo job.

Mrs. S.P. McL. Greene, who is still best remembered by her once much-talked of "Cape Cod Folks" and by the law suits which followed its publication, although she later became the author of "Vesty of the Basins," has written a new story for Harper Brothers which will be published in the early Autumn under the title of "Flood Tide."
The current issue of The Library, an English quarterly, contains a particularly striking article upon William Morris, accompanied by a fine photogravure portrait.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I, a Southerner, beg to thank you for your admirable editorial of April 30 with Dr. Parkhurst's remarks on "Southern Shiftlessness" as your text?

NEWARK, N.J., May 3 -- Two appeals from assessments on riparian lands along the Hudson River water front were decided this afternoon by the State Board of Taxation, the decision in both cases being in favor of Jersey City. The plaintiffs were the Central Railroad of New Jersey and the National Storage Company.

Commissioner Murphy yesterday afternoon overruled the decision of Deputy commissioner Devery in the case of Patrolman Michael J. McManus by issuing an order continuing the suspension of McManus if he is still under suspension, and placing him under suspension without pay if he has been relieved of suspension.

When the hearing in the McPherson will case was resumed before Judge John A. Blair in the Orphans' Court at Jersey City yesterday there was a clash between counsel, brought about by a charge from Mrs. Muir's counsel to the effect that Aaron S. Baldwin, who was named in Mrs. McPherson's will as executor, had unduly influenced her in the making of the bequests.

There is a large class of novels of which the reader says, "I have read something like this before." There is no charge of plagiarism intended in the remark; the book is not definite enough for that, being merely a type. To this class belongs "The Inlander," by Harrison Robertson. The hero is a modern Don Quixote.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- President Stuyvesant Fish of the Illinois Central Railroad tonight, after a conference with W.J. Hanrahan, Vice President and General Manager of the company, issued a circular announcing a pension plan for the 40,000 employes of the company. The plan, which is to take effect July 1, is said to be more liberal in its provisions than has heretofore been adopted by any other road.

The young athletes of the Erasmus Hall High School of Fiatbush defeated the representatives of the Adelpbi Academy in a dual set of games held, at the Adelphi Field, Classon Avenue and Park Place, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon by a score of 75 points to 35. Summaries:

BOSTON, Mass., May 3 -- To-day's baseball game between New York and Boston was a pitchers' battle, in which Matthewson excelled. Lowe scored Boston's only run on a single, two outs, and a passed ball. Barry's misjudgments were responsible for both of New York's tallies. The score:

There has of late been a ferment of discussion in public and in private of the subject of love letters. It is as if the new century were coming in under the vernal equinox and all the wanton lapwings and burnished doves of the press were going through the process that Tennyson has immortalized; the fancy of young men and of old, to say nothing of the women, is lightly turned to thoughts of love.

PARIS, May 3 -- The French Foreign Office corrects the figures of the indemnity to be demanded from China, as cabled to the Foreign Office by M. Pichon, the French Minister at Peking, purporting to be taken from the report of the Committee on Indemnity, and telegraphed to New York on May 1.

This book is written apparently more as a panegyric of Gen. Meade than an attempt to present impartial history. The first part is written indifferently, and is full of long and involved sentences. For example, on Page 36, we have a single sentence of fourteen lines. In this sentence unfavorable and unwarranted comments are made as to the charge of the Fifth United States Cavalry, ordered by Gen. Philip St. George Cooke.

Success in book collecting was wonderfully well illustrated at the French sale last week in Boston, by C.F. Libble Co., 1718 books bringing a total of $65,000, which must have represented a profit of fully 40 per cent. Frederick William French, whose library was so profitably sold, was born in Boston Sept. 10, 1842, and died there July 18, 1900.

DALLAS, Texas, May 3 -- The largest reception and banquet yet tendered the visiting committees of the New York Merchants' Association and Chamber of Commerce were given to-night by representative Texas merchants. Covers were laid for 250 guests, and fifteen speakers responded to the toasts.

The latest talk in insurance circles regarding the impaired Manhattan Fire Insurance Company mentions a plan to organize a new company in Cleveland, Ohio, which would reinsure the business of the Manhattan. This report came from Chicago sources at the time when it was announced locally that the Manhattan Directors had decided to make good their impairment.

A spirited horse, attached to a light wagon, owned and driven by James Clarke, a publisher, at 33 Union Square and living at 400 West End Avenue, ran away on Columbus Avenue yesterday afternoon, doing considerable damage and injuring Mr. Clarke and Mrs. Carrie Laupe of 525 West Fiftieth Street.

ALBANY, May 3 -- A conference between Gov. Odell, Senators Ellsworth and Higgins, Speaker Nixon, and Assemblyman Allds on the annual appropriation and supply bills to-day resulted in cuts aggregating between $700,000 and $800,000. Senator Higgins thought the aggregate scaling would foot up $700,000, and Speaker Nixon put it $100,000 higher.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 3 -- Arrangements are being made at the Woods yard at this palce to determine the weight of the raceabout Whipple Wing, owned by H.M. Crane, Jr. Shear poles have been adjusted over the yacht and an attempt will be made to-morrow by using a large set of lever scales over the boat.

Although Alexander S. Webb, President of the College of the City of New York, announced yesterday that his orders to the editors of the College Review, in which appeared one article by a student attacking Richard Croker and another attacking religious belief, had resulted in the suppression of almost every copy of the review, there were a great many of the students who had copies in their possession.

The second issue of the new Elston Press, a beautifully made reprint of Richard de Bury's Philobibion, originally finished in 1345, and first printed at Cologne in 1473, from de Bury's own manuscript, has just appeared from Mr. Clarke Conwell's press.

Cornell added another baseball victory to her list yesterday afternoon, when the Ithacans defeated the New York University nine at Ohio Field in hollow fashion. At the start the game was an interesting one, but in the fourth inning Cornell took the lead and was never headed. In the seventh inning the home team went to pieces and seemed to have no idea of the game at all.

Some declines occurred yesterday in the market for outside securities, but in few cases did these reactions prove as heavy as many that occurred in the Stock Exchange market. Activity was restricted to a small number of stocks, and a number of issues which recently supplied a fairly large amount of business were left much to themselves.
EDWARD E. CHAPMAN, a lumber dealer, died of heart trouble at Syracuse yesterday morning, aged seventy-five years. He had been ill but two days.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- The Yale athletic games to-day were marred by an accident to D. Boardman, 1901, who in some way injured a leg while running, and was unable to continue. He was carried to the clubhouse, where physicians attended to him, and ordered him sent to his room. Summary of the games:

On April 16-19, John Anderson. Jr., said the interesting library of Benjamin Betts of Brooklyn, with additions from other sources. The additions, however, formed the most important feature of the sale. Among them was a copy of Col. James Smith's "Account of His Remarkable Occurrences During His Captivity with the indians in the Years 1755-9," printed in Lexington, Ky., in 1799.
BERLIN, May 3 -- The upper and lower houses of the Diet met jointly at 6:30 P.M., and the Imperial Chancellor, Count von Bulow, read a royal message, declaring the Diet closed.
Justice Jerome left town yesterday afternoon with the announcement that there would be no more raids on gambling houses and other resorts until he returned.

The undue prevalence of fiction among readers who read for amusement is about as hackneyed a thesis as could now be undertaken. Since the first promulgation of the "Arabian Nights," which are about the earliest examples of professed fiction, there has never been a time when the teller of tales took himself so seriously as he is taking himself now.

The Twelfth Night Club is richer by $2,025,50 this morning and the new clubhouse, which it hopes to have soon, is so much nearer a reality. The benefit of the club yesterday, in which a goodly number of its members and most of the prominent theatrical people in New York took part, was a great success and netted the sum mentioned.
Copyright, 1901, by John R. Whitney. SUBJECT -- The Great Commission -- Matt., xxviii., 16-20.
An accomplished writer of acknowledged authority as a book reviewer, at the conclusion of a three and a half column review recently of "A Century of American Diplomacy," said:
LONDON, May 4 -- The Statist, after discussing the recent developments of American finance, says to-day:

It is often said of some charming woman that she is a person of literary taste because she reads a great deal. Now, the mere act of reading does not demonstrate the possession of literary inclinations. As we had occasion to say recently in some remarks on dissipation in reading, it is often only a poor and unprofitable method of killing time.

CHICAGO, May 3 -- Money for call and time loans ranges from 4 to 4 1/2 per cent. Local banks loaned several millions in New York to-day and New York paid 5@3 1/2 per cent. for money here. New York exchange was quoted at par.

As the old New York frontier our author treats the region of the Susquehanna, of its bead waters and its affluents. He accepts the statement in a letter to the Council of Safety from the inhabitants of Harpersfield in 1777, that they and the neighboring settlements were "the entire frontier of the State," and that there was "not a man on the outside of us but such as have taken protection of Brant."

The latest volume in the series of "The Story of the Nations" is a creditable and valuable work. The two volumes have been prepared for the purpose of telling the story of the American Colonies in a manner that would meet the requirements of the general reader rather than those of the special student.

A remarkable event in the book-collecting world will occur during the week of May 6 to 11 in London, when Sotheby. Wilkinson Hodge will sell the unique copy of the excessively rare first edition of Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress," which THE NEW YORK TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW described a few weeks ago.
YULEE, Fla., May 3 -- The following is the account of a special correspondent who left Jacksonville early in the evening, and at a time when the excitement was at its height:

While the most experienced financiers confess themselves unable to foresee the course of the unprecedented market for securities now prevailing, and all are sure that there is bound to be a reaction, the most conservative admit that there is a basis for a marked advance in prices and that the present speculation is a part of the necessary process of adjustment to the higher level.
LONDON, May 3 -- The sensational movement in Americans completely overshadowed dealings in all other departments on the Stock Exchange to-day. The trading was on an enormous scale.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 3 -- At the opening of to-day's session of the Eastman murder trial, Judge Gaskill, as presiding Justice, in a very concise opinion, decided to exclude the testimony of the defendant before the Grand Jury which indicted him.
