The State sought to introduce this testimony. Immediately after the announcement of the Court's decision Attorney General Knowlton rested the State's case.

The Amelia Relief Society will celebrate the fifth anniversary of its existence next Tuesday afternoon at the new Harlem Casino. One Hundred and Twenty-fourth Street and Seventh Avenue, by giving a luncheon. About 250 ladles will attend, and suitable souvenirs will be presented to each member.

ALBANY, May 3 -- New interest was given to the speculation about the North River Bridge bill by the advancement of the suggestion to-day that it was a New York Central measure. When the bill was pending before the Legislature it was the current belief that the New York Central was opposed to it.

In the North Side National Bowling League tournament on Pump's North Side Palace alleys last night, the Hyperion team won two games, the Friendship five won one game and lost one, and the Home City team lost two games. The scores:

A brace of supposed burglars were captured by the police in Brooklyn late yesterday afternoon, after an exciting chase through the streets. One of the fugitives was dropped in his tracks by a bullet from the policeman's revolver. His pal was caught and clubbed into submission after he had been pursued over fences and through back yards.

A decided innovation in the construction of down-town office buildings is revealed by the purchase of the building at Thames and Temple Streets, for a century known as "Old Tom's," by the Central Realty, Bond and Trust Company, which owns the Boreel Building, on the adjoining Broadway block, between Cedar and Thames Streets.

"Without a Warrant," by Hildegards Brooks, is another story of adventure, and its heroine, Kate Harlowe, is another recruit to the ever-growing ranks of heroines in boys' clothes: she differs from the other ladies who lately have clattered through the pages of fiction, riding on special missions or leading troops to battle, inasmuch as she was kidnapped and forced to put on the disguise.

The National Committee on Industrial Conciliation recently organized by the National Civic Federation will meet in this city next Tuesday to organize and determine the scope and character of the work to be taken up.

The prices realized at the sale of the library of the late F.W. French in Boston last week suggest some interesting problems to the collector. The large sum secured for the entire library ($69,500) and the record-breaking prices for some of the items nearly take one's breath away.

The old Delmonieo's, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, is to be rehabilitated, and for those to whom the building was known for so many years as the headquarters of epicures and bon vivants. It will be perhaps good news to learn that it is to be a restaurant once more.

In the current security market all action is on a gigantic scale. Results are accomplished in hours which formerly required days. Advances of 10 to 20 points in stocks of $100,000,000 or more capital take place in the twinkling of an eye. When the securities of the United States Steel Corporation were listed it was common comment that they were "too big to move much."

WASHINGTON, May 3 -- Michael G. McCormick, uncle of the missing New York boy, has received fully 100 letters regarding the case, to two of which, signed "A.E. C.," he attaches importance. These two letters, together with another one received to-day by The Evening Star from the same writer, are being investigated by the police.

The Brooklyns won their second straight game of baseball from the Philadelphias at Washington Park yesterday by the score of 5 to 1. All through the contest a high wind blew across the field, and, although the sun shone brightly. It was cold, the players appearing in sweaters, the spectators with coats buttoned tightly and collars turned up.
Champion Lasker played twenty-three chess games simultaneously yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club quarters. The games were played against members of the club.

BAY SHORE, L.I., May 3 -- In a collision, between runabouts here last night William L. Peck, a millionaire manufacturer, and Mrs. Lydia Graham were badly hurt. Mr. Peck and his niece, Mrs. Baird, and Mrs. Graham and her daughter, Miss Daisy Graham, were driving spirited horses hitched to light runabouts in the same direction at a rapid gait.

A friendly contest was begun before Justice Collins, in the Hudson County Supreme Court, at Jersey City, yesterday, to test the constitutionality of the Stokes school law, passed by the last Legislature. The novel feature of the case was that exCongressman Allan L. McDermott, who is Corporation Counsel, and his son, Walter McDermott, were the opposing lawyers.

Arbor Day was celebrated yesterday in all public schools according to programmes planned by the Principals. In the outlying districts in most instances a tree was planted by the pupils with appropriate exercises, but in congested portions of the city where this was impossible, seeds or vines were distributed among the pupils who were told how to plant and care for them in window gardens.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 3 -- The polo games were played at Lakewood to-day, and the second had more ginger to the square inch in one period than the first had in the whole four bouts. The latter was between George Gould and Albert Kennedy, and Mr. Gould's two little sons, Kingdon and Jay.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 3 -- The State shooting range was occupied here to-day by the Second Signal Corps under the command of Capt. Baldwin; Troop C, Capt Chanles I. Debevoice, and the Third Battery, N.G.N.Y., Capt. H. S. Rasquin. The weather was very unfavorable for shooting, a stiff northwest wind blowing all day.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted on the Stack Exchange. There were no sales.

This varied collection of stories proves convincingly that Mr. Long's richest field as a writer is among the Japanese. The little tale with the impressive title. "The Honorable Christmas Gift of Yoshida Aramidzu," is perfect among its more or less attractive companions. It appeals with the pathetic charm of "Mme. Butterfly" to the sympathy and imagination of the reader.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., May 3 -- The list of books written by Yale professors which will be published in connection with the bi-centennial celebration, to be held next October, includes several important contributions to literature and science. All the books are written by well-known leaders in their several departments of study.

When the print department of the New York Public Library was established in 1899 a speedy recognition of its usefulness and a rapid growth seemed assured. Not long afterward -- in May of the following year -- the first noteworthy accession was made to the newly created department. Mr. S.P. Avery's large and very valuable collection of modern etchings and lithographs.

The political importance of the visit of the Cuban delegates to Washington has been unduly magnified. Their mission may very well be compared to the opening of a door before one attempts to pass through it, to putting the horse before the cart, to a motion to adjourn, or to any other act consecrated by immemorial usage to the accomplishment of a desired end.

With a splendidly balanced field of sixteen good and thoroughly trained horses named to start, every prospect of fair weather, and the race-going public hungrily eager for the first big turf contest of the new reason's racing, the running of the Metropolitan Handicap at the Morris Park race course this afternoon gives rare promise of fine sport.

Of course with Penelope falling a victim to the tiny god in the first volume, and Francesea in the second, all intelligent readers know there had to be a third book for Salemina, and so "Penelope's Irish Experiences" come rather as an expected and foregone conclusion than a very great surprise.

The greatest interest attaching to the story of an old mediaeval town like Assist seems to be almost equally divided between the charm of its old legends, which have grown up about all its old buildings, and the architectural beauty of the latter, and the interest of the pictures and frescoes adorning them.

The public owes a decided debt to Mrs. Charlotte Martin for having persuaded Anno Hartley Gilbert -- the Mrs. Gilbert of whom young and old are the devoted admirers, the only actress on the stage playing old women's parts who receives on her first entrance the applause usually accorded only to the heroine of the play -- to allow her to set down these stage reminiscences, whose only fault is their great brevity.

"Five Tears of My Life," by Alfred Dreyfus, was published this week by McClure, Phillips Co. The author briefly outlines his career up to the day of his arrest, Oct. 13, 1894; then he begins the story of those five years of imprisonment, carried on for a time by the diary he kept while at Devil's Island.

The property 5 and 7 West Thirty-fourth Street, running through to 8, 10, and 12 West Thirty-fifth Street, having a frontage of 50 feet on either street, has been sold. Nothing could be learned yesterday concerning the identity of the purchaser or the future of the property, No. 5 West Thirty-fourth Street is owned by the Hawkins estate, while No. 7 was the residence of the late Henry Hilton.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 4 -- The most disastrous fire in the history of this city began yesterday shortly after noon in a small factory, from a defective wire, according to the best belief, and burned for nearly ten hours, in that time a property damage estimated from $10,000,000 to $15,000,000 was caused.

Two things fill the soul of W.J. BRYAN with uneasiness. The conditions demanded by the "reorganization element" in the Democratic Party are impossible, he says, because the abandonment of the principles upon which the party was borne to the bottom of the deep sea of defeat in 1896 and 1900 "will not only drive away many Democrats, but will repel allies and keep young men away."

A meeting of the newly elected Board of Directors of the Mexican Central Railway was held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The only business transacted was the election of H. Clay Pierce of St. Louis to be Chairman of the Board of Directors, succeeding E.R. Morse of Boston. Speaking of the future management of the property, one of the Directors said:

The popular test of the activity of a library is the number of volumes it circulates each year. In the case of public libraries this test is accepted as the true one by those who appropriate each year the public money required for the library. Even where the institution is not a public library, but receives a yearly grant from the local Legislature, the number of books circulated is the basis for estimating this grant.

ALBANY, May 3 -- A private dispatch received in this city to-night announces the appointment of the Rev. Father F.Z. Rooker, formerly of this city, and now a member of the Papal Legation at Washington, as Private Chamberlain to the Pope. The appointment is made by the Pope, and entitles Father Rooker to the title of Monsignor.

A mass meeting was held at Columbia yesterday for the purpose of considering the present football situation and of devising ways and means for raising the fund of $2,500 which is required by President Low before the continuance of the sport can be assured. The manager of the team reported that of the total amount $1,000 has been actually paid in, but that promises have been received for about $1,000 more.

George B.M. Harvey, President of Harper Brothers and editor of The North American Review, who sailed for New York on Friday last, after three busy weeks with authors in London and Paris, arrived here yesterday. In an Interview he spoke freely of the results of his trip, and expressed views regarding the future prospects of literary development in England and America.

Refreshed, it may be, by his agricultural pursuits, having written a most pleasing volume on English farm life, Mr. Rider Haggard has once more taken to his pen, and in "Lysbeth" he drives long furrows in the field of romance. In a prefatory note the author explains what is the method which best serves his purpose in the historical romance.
WASHINGTON, May 3 -- It is the present intention of Paul Kruger to visit the United States in the Autumn.

PHILADELPHIA, May 3 -- In the market to-day the Choctaws again came to the front, moving up to new high records. The market, not having participated in the New York boom, was little disturbed by to-day's slump, except in stocks having quotations in both markets. The Readings suffered considerably, as did also Pennsylvania, but many of the exclusively local stocks presented the anomaly of advancing at a time of severe depression in Wall Street.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 3 -- Out of Dixie the Presidential party to-day traveled into the heart of the great Southwest. The waving rice fields of Western Louisiana were passed during the night, and the new oil fields of Texas just at the peep of day, too early to be seen by the President.

NEWARK, N.J., May 3 -- Louis R. Coudert, a nephew of Frederic R. Coudert of New York, was to-day appointed by Referee in Bankruptcy Frederick W. Leonard trustee for the creditors of the stock broking firm of Carley, Rosengarten Carley. As soon as he files his bond the books and assets of the defunct firm will be turned over to him.

ITHACA, May 3 -- With the starting of a subscription among the business men of Ithaca it is now certain that the financial crisis of Cornell's athletic managements has been successfully tided over. Yesterday afternoon the Business Men's Association of the city of its own accord started a subscription, and by this afternoon over $700 had been raised for the benefit of the Cornell crews.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 3 -- The naval officers of Coaster Harbor Island gave a dance in the east lecture room of the War College this evening. Many people from Newport, Fort Adams, and the Torpedo Station attended. The stairways, hall, and dining room were prettily decorated with flags and potted plants.
BOSTON, May 3 -- Some of the literary autographs brought very good prices at the French sale-to-day, running higher, as a rule, than those of the dramatic list.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 3 -- The Rev. W.S. Rainsford, rector of St. George's Church, New York City, is likely to be chosen Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Minnesota, in which event he would succeed Bishop Whipple, who is very old and feeble, when the latter lays down his work in that capacity.

DES MOINES, Iowa, May 3 -- Edwin H. Conger, United States Minister to China, was formally introduced to Des Moines at a public meeting held in the Auditorium this afternoon. The reception was tendered by the two Grand Army posts, the city, citizens generally, and the missionary societies represented in China.
PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- The University of Pennsylvania baseball team defeated the Cornell nine this afternoon on Franklin Field by the score of 13 to 7. The score:

The stern frown of the preacher, who looks upon superstition as the ally of the Evil One; the scornful sneer of the teacher, who sees in it a part of the livery of bondage, have driven this quaint combination of ancestral traditions to the remote chimney corners of old black aunties, from which it is difficult for the stranger to unearth them.

LONDON, April 25. -- The new playhouse near Westminster Abbey, in which Mrs. Langtry has resumed her vocation of London theatre manager, richly deserves its name -- the Imperial. The former theatre on the same site, adjoining the rear of the big music hall and show place called the Aquarium, was named Imperial years ago, however, and some of Mrs. Langtry's earlier performances were given there.

BOSTON, May 4. -- Boston won to-day's baseball game from New York by bunching hits in the fifth inning, when four singles and a sacrifice netted them three runs. The fielding of Taylor was a feature. The score:
A woman, who is described as Nellie O'Neil of 112 East Ninety-eighth Street, was last night taken to Bellevue Hospital and placed in the pavilion for the insane for examination.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of your correspondents, signed H. Clay Peters of Brooklyn, evidently needs information more than refutation in regard to parish schools. He seems to convey the impression that "where there are no mothers or sisters to give this, (spiritual education at home,) the parochial school offers it, and for this reason we favor them."

A Frenchman, or rather, a group of Frenchmen -- there is already some slight unpleasantness in regard to the question to whom the credit is due -- have made a discovery with which they propose to stagger humanity. It is hardly necessary to say that they had no intention of making their discovery public through an American paper, but the news has leaked out, and it seems highly important that Field Marshal Count von Waldersee.
A test of the results of the placing of the army canteens, or post exchanges, on a temperance basis, will be furnished next week in the neighborhood of New York, when the enlisted men are paid off.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I had hoped that some one more competent than I would have traversed the very courteous editorial in your issue of April 21 concerning the position of the Cathedral Library, but since your correspondents have drifted into the discussion of the school question.

F.G. Ireland, Chief Examiner of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, has forwarded the following letter to Solomon Lincoln. President of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, with reference to the recent protest against conferring the degree of LL. D. on the President:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Chance took me into a certain Christian Science temple on a Wednesday evening not so long ago. I heard many strange experiences narrated, chiefly to the detriment of "materia medica," as they style the trade of the despised physician -- a grand mutual admiration society the congregations of these temples seem to be.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 4. -- It is believed that the Constitution will be ready for her trial spin on Monday, May 13, and the trial will take place in Lower Narragansett Bay, between this place and Newport. To-day the crew and all the mechanics that could be mustered spread themselves over the deck, flattening the deck covering to the steel plates so that it would lie with an even surface from stem to stern.

Mayor Van Wyck returned to Albany with his veto yesterday the bill of Senator Sullivan "for the relief of the Woodside Water Company." The object of the bill was to give to the Board of Estimate the right to pass upon the claim of the Woodside Water Company for $46,000 for water furnished Long Island City before consolidation.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 4. -- A good deal has been accomplished, says a close personal friend of J.J. Hill, in the consolidation of the Burlington Railroad with the Northern Pacific and Great Northern, but the undertaking outlined in New York in 1898, just after peace was declared in the war with Spain, has only begun.

BOSTON, May 4. -- While yachtsmen here were generally delighted that a meeting between the two yachts Constitution and Independence had been arranged for on July 2, 4, and 6, those closely connected with the Boston boat regret that the dates for these races were not put off until a few weeks later.
From The Nineteenth Century. Mrs. Wilfrid Meynell has preserved for us the story of a young lady who, whatever her other attractions, was obviously not a reader of Browning's poetry.

CREEDMOOR, May 4. -- Squadron A.N. G.N.Y., occupied the range to-day, under the command of Major O.B. Bridgman. There were about 225 officers and men present of whom all qualified as marksmen. The weather was quite favorable in the forenoon, but a stiff wind came up in the afternoon, rendering it rather difficult at the long ranges.
"Variety is the spice of life," ticked the old typewriter to his companion on the table, "and life is a complex thing surely. Who knows it better than I?"

From The Gentleman's Magazine. Aug. 17, 1443, in Catholic Bearn, Gaston XI., husband of Eleanore of Aragon, in his Rubrique de Blasphemateurs, prescribed but 20 sols Morlaas, or a day in the pillory, as an adequate punishment for him who should deny or blaspheme in a public place, God or the Blessed Virgin, or commit perjury; and merely 6 sols to be paid by each of those who heard such blasphemy, without denouncing it forthwith.

Broadway turned with languid interest as to the music of bands and the glare of calcium, a parade passed from the west through Twenty-sixth Street and around Madison Square. There were men, women, and even children among the 5,000 marchers, all walking as though they were tired. Around the eastern side of the square they passed until they had massed about a number of carts on which their speakers stood.

DENVER, Col., May 4. -- John C. Henry, one of the foremost electrical experts of America, died to-day at his home in this city. Mr. Henry was born in Woodstock, Ont.. fifty-three years ago. He perfected many inventions in connection with the overhead trolley. In 1894 his health failed in New York and he had since lived here.

From "Abstracts of Wills," New York Historical Society. Inventory of estate of Asser Levy of New York, Feb. 9, 168 2-3 Lot and Building at the Water Gate. u218. Sloughter House and pen without the gate, in company with Gerritt Janse Roos, with all privileges according to Patent. u18.

BOSTON, May 4. -- The formal organization took place this afternoon of the American National Bank of Boston, an entirely new institution, in the success of which many prominent men are concerned. The bank is to have a capital of $200,000, made up of 2,000 shares of the par value of $100 each.

To get to the Pan-American Exposition, and have, as he expressed it, lots of "dough to spend," Isador Bloch, an eighteen-year-old errand boy employed by Henry Dazian, theatrical costumer, of 26 Union Square, committed forgery and yesterday was arrested.

CREEDMOOR, May 4. -- Hugh McWhirten, janitor of Public School No. 33 had a lively time with two Italians this morning. One of the men drew a knife and chased the janitor around the school a dozen times before the Jamaica police came to the rescue.

A State's bonds fluctuate with its financial condition, and also with its political situation. No investor desires drop in the value of his securities. If he buys the obligations of a foreign State he will naturally study all the factors which are likely to affect their value. If the State in question is ambitious, aggressive, a military power, it is more likely to get into difficulties than an unambitious one.

The Dressmakers' Protective Association, organized last March, and which expects to include in its membership dressmakers from the Atlantic to the Pacific and from the lakes to the Gulf, has determined to adopt two very protective measures.

About this time in the year the fancy of the average well-to-do city householder lightly turns to thoughts of country board. The circulars of the hotels and boarding places which have him on their lists reach him by every mail. He reads them with an interest difficult to understand in view of his long experience of the difference between promise and performance in whatever pertains to country board.

BALTIMORE, May 4. -- Johns Hopkins scored its fifth victory of the season in lacrosse to-day by defeating Columbia University 7 goals to 10. The Johns Hopkins men excelled in team play, and their stick work was far superior to that of the New Yorkers. Although the Hopkins attack lacked the services of Putts, the new in-home, its work was of a high order.

OSWEGO, N.Y., May 4. -- Henry H. Lyman, State Commissioner of Excise, died at 8:45 o'clock this evening. His death was not unexpected, as his condition became serious three weeks ago yesterday. Then there was a rally. He continued to improve until last Sunday, when a change for the worse came.
As the Confederate reunion is to be held in Memphis, Tenn., May 28, 29, and 30, the decorations of the graves of the Southern soldiers will be postponed in many Southern cities to June 3.

None too encouraging in its beginning, last week finally witnessed the closing of a good volume of business -- lacking, perhaps, any single transaction of the first magnitude, but still sufficient to show that attention has not yet been withdrawn from those sections which have furnished so large a part of this Spring's dealings.

Sir: Is there no one to cry shame on the recent proceedings of certain newspapers of the metropolis for the indecent and cruel treatment of a worthy family in this community which has recently been bereaved of its head?

ALBANY, May 4. -- Articles of incorporation of the "School of Methods" of New York City were filed with the Secretary of State to-day. The objects are "to associate together men and women who take the teacnings of Jesus Christ seriously and who wish to study by practical and experimental methods how to apply the Golden Rule to the problems of social and industrial life," c.

Although it had been planned to have the dinner to Miles M. O'Brien, President of the Board of Education, a small and informal affair over 150 guests were present. The dinner was given at the Htel Savoy last evening. It was under the auspices of the Commercial Education Department of the New York State Teachers' Association.

PARIS, April 26. -- "We have spent all our money in making ourselves beautiful. We have ruined ourselves in carpets," said J.F. Raffaelli to me, as we strolled together on the eve of Varnishing Day through the half-finished galleries of the Beaux Arts Salon.

On the part of the East Side Branch of the Rapid Transit Subway that is in this borough considerable work has been done. Beginning with the shaft which has been sunk at Central Park West and One Hundred and Fourth Street, about 2,000 feel have been excavated up to One Hundred and Thirty-second Street and Lenox Avenue.

It is necessary to keep clearly in mind that the Athenians of the fifth century had two distinct and important Spring festivals of Dionysos. The Anthesteria occupied three days at the beginning of March, the first day being called "Jar-opening," the second the "pourings." This second day was "polluted," says Photios, and the spirits of earlier men were abroad.

After winning two games of baseball from Philadelphia, Brooklyn lost the final contest of the present series yesterday by the score of 8 to 4. Their victory was due to the masterly pitching of Orth, who held the champions down to four hits, and to the poor support given the Brooklyn pitcher. McJames, who was off the team last year, pitched his first game this year for the Brooklyns, and did good work.

From The London Express. The results of the census in France, so far as they are known, offer no consolation to those who view with alarm the shrinkage in what has been termed the "human capital" of their country.

The fete champetre held at Claremont yesterday for the benefit of St. Rose's Settlement, a philanthropic and educational institution in the district of "Little Italy," was favored by ideal Spring weather, and there was nothing to mar the affair save that at times the breezes were perhaps a trifle too bracing for those on the lawn.

This astonishing and record-breaking series of performances in Wall Street, concerning which the lambs gambol and the wolves look on with circumspection, is really not one in which precedents are of any great account. We have not, as the wolves are apt fondly to fancy, "been there before."

BATH, Me., May 4. -- President Edward W. Hyde, upon his return from New York, where he has been attending a meeting of prominent shipbuilders, denied the report that the Bath Iron Works or the Hyde Windlass Company had been sold to the combination. He said that there was no intention of making such a sale.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 4. -- The beautiful weather of the past week has accelerated the movement from town toward the Summer resorts along the coast.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- Twelve of the strongest golfers from the metropolitan district of New York visited the Philadelphia Cricket Club links to-day to play the third inter-city competition with an all-Philadelphia team. This inter-city team series was started one year ago, and matches are to be played semi-annually, one in each city.

From The Boston Herald. Some interesting evidence showing how many hard, round shekels have been secured from hard-up Harvard students by an energetic money lender came out in a hearing given by the Committee on Licenses of the Cambridge Board of Aldermen last Monday.

From The London News. At the Lambeth Police Court Mr. Hopkins gave judgment in an important case which had admittedly been raised for the purpose of testing the legality of certain forms of automatic machines to which the police have taken objection.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That letter of "A Constant Reader of THE NEW YORK TIMES" (and, by the way, he is no more constant than your humble servant) in to-day's issue, after your very manly and kind editorial on "Southern Shiftlessness," in which he brings in a conversation between a peasant and "I," is nothing short of impudence.

From The London Mail. We are told by the Volunteers who reach here from over the sea, writes a correspondent in Pretoria, who had the misfortune to be a passenger in the thirtieth train blown up by Boers during the war, that in South Africa life is very hard and without luxury.

PHILADELPHIA, May 4. -- The early morning slump in New York was reflected but slightly in the local market. Reading common dropped from 21 5/8, yesterday's closing price, to 20 11-16, but the loss was soon regained. The general list was firmer, except for Lehigh Navigation, which reacted a point, to 75.

Through the early Spring judders spent his spare time sitting alone on the broad stoop of his boarding house. He looked melancholy. He was melancholy. He would sit there with his hat on the back of his head and his chin in his hand, the train of his thought broken only by the occasional swish of a Summer gown.

In the Adams Street Police Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, there was a heated controversy over the question of the removal to a hospital of a sick woman who had been arrested on a charge of intoxication. The dispute was between Chief Clerk Chambers of the court and Miss Meury, a prison missionary, on the one side, and Ambulance Surgeon Crane of the Brooklyn Hospital.

Copyright, 1901. LONDON, May 4. -- As the debate in Parliament on the coal export duty clause of the budget was adjourned until Monday. It is folly to speculate, as the Government papers do, on how large the Government's majority might have been if a division had been forced on Thursday night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Why is it that this enterprising, wide-awake, up-to-date city should allow its streets to be unnumbered? If it were not for a few landmarks, a bay window on one house, a certain style of curtaining in another, a yellow front door to another house, or a stoop going sideways, one would never be able to find his or her way around the town.

Dr. Felix Adler, the leader and founder of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, was presented with a unique token of esteem at the closing exercises in commemoration of the twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of the society, which were held at the Madison Square Garden Concert Hall last night.

LONDON, May 4. -- From Rome comes a seemingly well-authenticated story to-day that Cardinal Rampolla, in view of the fact that a Papal Secretary so rarely succeeds to the tiara, is about to cause his own dismissal from his high office in order to strengthen his eligibility.

BALTIMORE, May 4. -- Cardinal Gibbons, Primate of the Roman Catholic Church in America, will next Wednesday, May 8, confer upon the Most Rev. Monsignor Sebastian Martinelli, Titular Archbishop of Ephesus and Apostolic Delegate to the United States, the red biretta, the insignia of the Cardinalate.

As finally passed by the Legislature, the bill rearranging the Congressional districts of this city, which, by the Governor's signature, becomes the law, makes all previously printed maps and descriptive outlines of the districts useless. As a gerrymander the bill is a gem, as a glance at the map will show.

From The Contemporary Review. The long series of disasters, the stagnation of commerce, the glutting of the markets, the scarcity of hard cash, the weakening of credit, the fall in securities of every description, the crash of industries, the ruin of individuals, the misery of large numbers of the unemployed, constitute a spectacle unparelleled in the history of the Russian Empire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to your criticism of my attitude on Jean de Reszke as the master of tone production, published in THE TIMES on the 28th day of April of this year. I beg to state that I have not receded one jot from my contention that the statement that Jean de Reszke is never at fault in his voice technic is erroneous and contrary to fact.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt has been assessed on $3,000,000 personal property this year. President Feitner of the Department of Taxes notified all the members of the Vanderbilt family whose names are on the assessment books that if they desired to make applications for reduction of the assessments they would have to appear in person and submit to an examination by the officials of the Tax Department.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent contribution to your interesting, free-for-all columns, in regard to "Southern Shiftlessness," brings to mind an experience of mine near Richmond. I spent a half-year in that city as a tutor, and used what spare hours I had at ray disposal in reading Virginia history.

DEL RIO, Texas, May 4. -- The President and his party spent the forenoon viewing the sights of the quaint old city of San Antonio, with its historic Spanish missions and its thrilling memories of the war for Texan independence, and then started on the long stretch across the Texas desert for El Paso.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 4. -- Ten thousand persons are homeless, and many of them left on afternoon and night trains for St. Augustine and other coast cities and near-by towns, while numerous river craft took many to little places on the St. John's River. Supply stations have been established in various parts of the city, and all day they have been thronged by the hungry.

SWATOW, China, March 25. -- Marriage customs in China do not vary essentially in general features, but they are subject to such local variation as to present novelties wherever they may be observed. The woman is in no section supposed to have voice or choice in the selection of her mate. She must take what others provide for her, and consider herself lucky that she has not been overlooked in the distribution of husbands.

"I have to thank the maker of bargain-counter opera glasses more than the average man can imagine," chattered the oculist whose patient was awaiting an examination to find out what was the matter with his eyesight. "Do you happen to have a pair of them in your worldly possessions?

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Secretary Root received a telegram from the Mayor of Jacksonville to-night asking that the St. Francis Barracks in that city be put at the disposal of the Mayor to house 1,000 homeless people. Secretary Root immediately sent a dispatch to Gen. Brooke in command of the Department of the East to direct the officer in charge of the barracks to grant the people of Jacksonville every facility possible.

The London Statist -- a financial journal whose writers temper the aridity of ordinary economic discussion by the play of extraordinary fancy -- pictures a combination by which the same group of American financiers shall control the great industrial corporations of this country, the transcontinental railways, the Atlantic and Pacific carrying trade, and the lines to both coasts of South America.

The entire printing and bookbinding plant of D. Appleton Co., the big publishing firm, situated at the corner of Kent Avenue and Hewes Street, Brooklyn, has been transferred to the Trow Publishing Company of this city. The Trow Company leased the building for a term of years, but the machinery was bought outright.
Army. The retirement from active service May 3 of Col. Charles I. Wilson, Assistant Paymaster General, is announced.

It is not often that the business men of New York eagerly desire an early Summer, which shall make its advent known by a burst of red-hot weather. In the present instance, however, a good many conservative leaders of finance look to this as the one chance of effecting a gradual and comfortable restoration of normal conditions in Wall Street.

That the recent raids of the committee of Fifteen and the relentless methods of Justice Jerome in opening their safes have completely demoralized the gambling fraternity of New York was evident in the policy pursued by poolrooms yesterday.

ALBANY, May 4. -- In view of the approaching municipal campaign in New York there are two bills passed by the Legislature and approved by the Governor which will have special interest for the politicians. They are laws relating to the elective franchise and have thus far escaped attention.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 4. -- At the session of the New Jersey Conference of the African Methodist Episcopal Church yesterday, Bishop Derrick took the Rev. Dr. Parkhurst to task for his recent remarks on the negro and the South. The Bishop declared that Dr. Parkhurst was simply striving to create a sensation, and in doing so he had done the negro a great injustice, as well as the South.

Total transactions in the outside market yesterday were the smallest that have been recorded in many days. Business was even much lighter than it was the previous Saturday. Only a few stocks attracted any attention at all, and only a few changes in prices were large enough to be worthy of note.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 4. -- In one of the prettiest and most exciting boat races that has ever been witnessed here, the Naval Cadets came out victorious in their annual eight-oared shell race with the Yale College crew, which was for a distance of two miles over a straight course.
Mr. Alexander Lambert will give the last concert this season of the New York College of Music at Mendelssohn Hall on Friday evening, May 24.

From The Nineteenth Century. It is certain that the time has come when women have both the ability and the power to act as the natural and most efficient censors of the theatre: if they chose to boycott obpectionable plays, these plays would become impossible instead of being the phenomenally successful things they are.
The annual meeting of the Maritime Law Association of the United States was held on Friday at the rooms of the Bar Association in Forty-fourth Street. The President, R.D. Benedict, was in the chair.

For two hours and ten minutes yesterday at the Polo Grounds the red and white man battled for supremacy -- this time at baseball. At the end the Carlisle Indians, gathering in a circle, shouted, "Min ne wa ka, ka wa we, min ne wa ka, ka wa we -- Columbia. Columbia -- wh-ir-rp!" for their team was the victor by the score of 16 to 3.

A holiday crowd of not less than 20,000 people yesterday saw Clarence H. Mackay's famous horse Banastar win the Metropolitan Handicap, the first great event of the New York racing season, at Morris Park. The race was as spectacular in its running and in its result as the most exacting patron of the turf could ask for.

BOSTON, May 4. -- Money at the Clearing House to-day ruled at 3 per cent., New York funds sold at 25c and 30c discount. Exchanges, $30,908,225; for the week, $181,364,488; balances, $2,699,983, for week, $14,640,793. Call loans were made at from 5 to 6 per cent. Time money ruled at 4 and 4 1/2 per cent.

SOUTHAMPTON, May 4. -- The trial of the Shamrock II, to-day had a rather unfortunate conclusion, for she went ashore on a bank close to the Warner Lightship. The trial was practically over, and she came sharp around the lightship to return to her moorings, when she grounded on the sand.

Among the many strange occupations in this city is that of the professional grappler -- the man who makes his living with grappling irons, recovering from the bottoms of the rivers whatever has fallen overboard from piers or from vessels. At first sight this means of earning a livelihood seems at best a miserable one.
From The London Mail. For the society dame who wishes to be quite twencent and chic, there is now one kind of dog, and one only -- the toy bull.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- This morning's dispatch from Manila announcing that civil government was yesterday established in that city, excites an interest at the War Department that it does not satisfy. The problem of civil government for Manila has been one of the most difficult of many puzzling questions arising in the Philippines.

BALTIMORE, Md., May 4. -- The first real test of the new election law in Maryland, intended to disfranchise illiterates, will be made next Tuesday at the election of City Councilmen. There are 10,157 illiterates in this city, according to the latest estimates, 4,020 white and 6,137 colored.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 4. -- Interesting ceremonies marked this afternoon the launching of the M.S. Dollar, the first ship constructed at the yards of the New York Shipbuilding Company. The vessel was named by Miss Marie Morse, daughter of Henry G. Morse, President of the company.

BERLIN, May 4. -- Theodor Moeller has been appointed Minister of Commerce in succession to Herr Brefeld. He is a National Liberal of the Right wing. Whenever he has come in contact with the Emperor the latter has expressed a liking for him. Herr Moeller is a wealthy Westphalian machine manufacturer.

"There is one man on this tunnel work who has been talked, written, and fussed about less than any other." said a Rapid Transit Tunnel engineer, "and that is what we call a 'rockman.' To the general public every man in overalls and soiled jumper is an ordinary laborer, but there is a vast distinction between a laborer and a rockman.
WASHINGTON, May 4. -- Secretary Gage to-day bought four lots of short 4 per cent, bonds aggregating $101,700 three lots at $113,62 and one lot at $113,6230.

Gen. Daniel E. Sickles returned last week from an extended tour in Cuba. When seen at his residence yesterday by a reporter of THE NEW YORK TIMES Gen. Sickles readily consented to talk of his experiences in the island.

There was a mild shake-up in the Police Department yesterday, as a result of which Inspector Adam A. Cross was man an Acting Deputy Chief and a number of other Inspectors were shifted around "for the good of the service."

From The National Review. In the Antarctic Circle the monotony and solitude are more predominant than in the Arctic. The lack of large mammals, as, for instance, the polar bear, the polar fox, walrus, musk oxen, and, of course, the lack of population, like the Esquimo and Samoyed, make life on the land near the south pole extremely solitary.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 4. -- Jacksonville's great fire, which began yesterday, has burned itself out. One hundred and forty-eight blocks of a beautiful city have been laid waste. The loss will not be known even approximately for a week, but it is believed it will amount to $10,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial this morning entitled "A Multi-Millionaire's Experience" is quite delicious. Why do you suppose that it is more commendable in Mr. John D. Rockefeller to make a speech to a Bible class than it would be in anybody else? Who do you think envies him for that?

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Mayor Harrison begins his third term with several new members in his Cabinet. The change which interested the people most was the nomination of a man to succeed Joseph Kipley as Superintendent of Police. Capt. O'Neill is the man to whom Chicagoans must now look for the police protection which lately they have not been getting.

The most prejudiced student of the social and industrial problems of the South would find it difficult to close his eyes to the significance of the fact that the white people of two Southern cities have invited a negro to address them in public meeting on the needs of the colored people of their section and the duty of the white race toward them.

LONDON, May 4. -- Richard Redhead, who wrote the tune of the "Rock of Ages," is dead. He had been organist of St. Mary Magdalene's Church, Paddington, since 1864: set several well-known hymns to music, and composed various pieces.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 4. -- Jacksonville's great fire, which began yesterday, has burned itself out. One hundred and forty-eight blocks of a beautiful city have been laid waste. The loss will not be known even approximately for a week, but it is believed it will amount to $10,000,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial this morning entitled "A Multi-Millionaire's Experience" is quite delicious. Why do you suppose that it is more commendable in Mr. John D. Rockefeller to make a speech to a Bible class than it would be in anybody else? Who do you think envies him for that?

CHICAGO, May 4. -- Unless the demands of the striking granite cutters on the new Post Office Building are granted on Monday morning, a strike will be begun by the union against every contract in the country held by John Pierce.

A strong effort was made yesterday by members of the Automobile Club of America to be arrested in Central Park for running their vehicles faster than three and a half miles an hour when in sight of horses, but the policemen stationed in the Park failed to put the exact letter of the new Park Department law into operation.

WASHINGTON, May 4. -- This city has plainly caught some of the fever that has affected Wall Street during the week, for talk about the stock market has been heard everywhere in the departments, and the offices of the stock brokers, big and little, with or without responsible and solvent Wall Street correspondents, have been thronged from opening to close of the market every day.

ROANOKE ISLAND, N.C., May 1. -- On landing at the little wharf of this small island in Albemarle Sound a stranger can hardly realize that an island so remote and insignificant can fill so great a space in American history.

More notable than anything else in Wall Street discussion during the past week has been the fashion of warnings issued from almost every source against confidence in the market. Authorities rated as conservative were sure that danger signs were showing and that it was necessary for traders to slacken speed, sell out, and wait for lower prices.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 4. -- The fifth annual interscholastic meet was won by Mercersburg Academy, with 31 points; second, Hill School, 29; third, Phillips Andover, 22; fourth, Lawrenceville, 15.

TRENTON, May 4. -- A law that has just been placed on the statute books of New Jersey affects that class of seashore cottagers who are known as "dead beats." It is known as "the Francis dead beat law," because it owes its existence to Senator Charles A. Francis of Monmouth County, a merchant of Long Branch, where there are many cottagers.

The Committee of One Hundred chosen by the convention of the Citizens' Union held last month to select candidates and confer with other anti-Tammany organizations and to report to an adjourned meeting of the convention, which will meet some time near the first of September, met at the Citizens' Union headquarters, at 34 Union Square East, last night and perfected an organization.

If there was any one thing Jenkins thoroughly dreaded, it was the long journey homeward on the elevated train, when his day's duties were over. The trip downtown in the morning he didn't seem to mind. He had his paper to read and he invariably found some one of his neighbors and acquaintances on the platform, and the time passed quickly and pleasantly with chatting and story telling.

LONDON, May 4. -- Charles Wyndham will soon revive Jones's smartest comedy, "The Case of Rebellious Susan." He and Mary Moore are resuming their former roles of Susan and Sir Richard Kato, with Violet Venbrugh taking up the part of Mrs. Quesnel.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 4. -- The Herbert polo trophies were won to-day before a large and distinguished crowd on the first field at Georgian Court by Raymond Herbert, James Proctor, Seward Cary, and George Woodman, after four periods of spirited play against George Gould, Randolph Snowden, George McFadden, and Lemuel Altemus of Bryn Mawr.

THE COMING SPANISH ELECTIONS. -- The tranquillity in Spain which followed the return of Senor Sagasta to power has now been disturbed by the announcement that the general elections will be held May 12, to be followed by a meeting of the Cortes on June 20. According to the Spanish electoral system, there is little doubt that the Ministerial Party, which is Liberal, will return an overwhelming majority.

PATERSON, N.J., May 5. -- Omar Carl- bone, a Haledon silk weaver, filed a petition for an absolute divorce from his wife, Inez Kometz Caribone, on the ground of desertion. Lawyer Robert McDermott has been retained by Carlbone, who rests his claim for a legal separation on a three hours' honeymoon and a letter written by the bride, who declared that he had seen her for the last time.

ALBANY, May 5. -- Superintendent Charles R. Skinner of the State Department of Public Instruction, in his annual report, just issued, states that the sum expended for the maintenance of the public schools of the State during the last school year was $33,421,491, an increase of $5,368,500 over the previous year.

How much of the excitement manifested by the British colliery owners and their workmen over the new export duty on coal is simulated and how much is genuine it is difficult to tell. The owners appear to be using it as a basis for a threat to cut down the wages of miners and pit workers.

The fourth game of the series of match games at chess was played at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday afternoon and evening, when Richardson, the Brooklyn expert, was pitted against Champion Lasker. For the fourth consecutive time Lasker lost the toss for the move.

BUFFALO, May 5 -- The first Sunday of the Pan-American Exposition's official existence brought out a good-sized crowd. Peaceful strolling along the terrace and the esplanade, restful sitting on the green benches within hearing of the sacred band concert on the plaza, and uninterrupted sauntering on the Midway were the few indulgences of the Sunday sightseers.

The annual meeting of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews was held yesterday morning at the Institution, One Hundred and Fifth Street and Columbus Avenue. President Simon Borg occupied the chair. Charles Minzesheimer, Chairman of the Finance Committee, read the report of this committee which showed the home to be in a flourishing condition.

In the erratic changes of price on Saturday on the Stock Exchange it is, perhaps, worth remarking that the keenest interest, the most anxious apprehension, and the most unsettling nervousness were felt by those who had not strictly bought stocks, but had put up a certain sum as "margin," that is, had paid for the privilege of betting on the course of the market.

The disappearance of Emily Eleanor Franko, aged eight years, from her home, 1,323 Park Avenue, on Sunday, April 28, was reported to the police at Headquarters yesterday afternoon by her grandfather, Charles W. Marsch. The mother of the missing child is Mrs. Edwin B. Franko, an actress in the Weber Fields' road company.

William Bass, twenty-one years old, a self-confessed jewelry thief, complained too much of his physical woes before robbing his landlady. This afforded Detective Everett clue, and the young man was finally found in the Charity Hospital on Blackwell's Island.

Paul S. Howe, formerly a divinity stu- dent in the General Theological Seminary, now a lecturer for the Board of Education, was held in $1,000 bail yesterday on a charge of assault, and as he did not secure a bondsman was locked up. Howe had made a counter-charge against William A. Atkinson, a senior in the seminary, but the latter was discharged after testimony had been taken.

Morris Goldstein, a twelve-year-old boy, who gave his address as 56 Hester Street, Manhattan, was arrested and locked up at Coney Island yesterday on a charge of larceny from the person. During the afternoon Detective Bachirs, it is charged, caught Goldstein in the act of passing to a confederate, Harry Cohen, who said his home was at 604 East Ninth Street.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 5. -- Agnes Bur- roughs, who played Lady Isabel in "East Lynne" here last night, stopped the play and called the audience names. The audi- ence had become excited, owing to a disarrangement of the clothes of the child when handled by Miss Burroughs. Boys yelled and hooted.

Horse thieves made a bold effort early yesterday morning to steal four horses from a stable at 1,850 Anthony Avenue, owned by Stephen J. Noonan, a dealer and horse trainer living at 577 Burnside Avenue, Tremont.

Miss Frances Raymond, an actress, com- mitted suicide by inhaling gas yesterday in her home, a handsomely furnished five-room flat at 129 West Ninetieth Street. From clippings found in the apartment, letters, manuscripts, , the police learned that the woman once played with one of the Frohman traveling companies in the part of Lucy Hawkesworth in "The Girl I Left Behind Me."

PHILADELPHIA, May 5. -- The National Municipal League will begin the session of its ninth annual conference on Wednesday afternoon of this week. The meeting will be held at Rochester, N.Y., and will continue throughout Thursday and Friday. On the latter evening the visiting delegations will be given a banquet by the Rochester branch of the league.

CHICAGO, May 5. -- Seven persons were burned to death, three fatally injured, and several others slightly burned and other- wise injured in a fire that destroyed a three-story apartment building at 9,316 Marquette Avenue, South Chicago, early today.

The tenants on the lower floors of the apartment house at 1,186 Lexington Avenue were alarmed yesterday afternoon by a woman's shrieks. Going into the hallway they saw one of the servants rushing up and down, tearing out her hair in handfulls and crying in some foreign tongue. She was recognized by another servant as Susie Suneck, eighteen years old, a recently arrived Bohemian girl employed by Frederick Correll, who has apartments in the building.

JACKSONVILLE Fla., May 5. -- The hunger of 10,000 homeless people was satisfied to-day upon the arrival of relief trains and boats bringing provisions from the neighboring towns. Early this morning a commissary was established in the centre of the city, and thousands were fed during the day.

When SAM HOUSTON was elected President of the Republic of Texas it is recorded that "advancing to the table he delivered a brief, extemporaneous inaugural address." The first President of Texas, like the present President of the United States, possessed a happy facility in the oratory of occasion which is as keenly enjoyed in that State as anywhere else in the Union.

There was a lively riot in the Ravens- wood section of Queens Borough yesterday afternoon. In it one man was so severely hurt that he may not live, several men were bruised, and two buildings badly dam- aged.

The Rev. Luther O. Dyott, the new pastor of the United Congregational Church, at Hooper Street and Lee Avenue, Williamsburg, yesterday began his pastorate by advocating that there be more Christianity and less churchianity.

EL PASO, Texas, May 5. -- The Presidential party reached El Paso, the gateway of Mexico, at 9 o'clock this morning, and will remain here until noon to-morrow. Presi- dent Diaz of Mexico had hoped to meet the President here and shake hands across the border, but as the Mexican Congress is in session, he could not leave the capital.

The first of the bi-weekly games of the Star Athletic Club for the present season were held yesterday afternoon on the club grounds, at Long Island City. J. Hoban made the best individual record, with a score of 14 points. R.W. Kennedy was second, with 8 points, and W. Loosee third, with 7 points.

The Jacksonville Emergency Committee, composed of Abram S. Hewitt, John Claflin, John D. Crimmins, Alexander E. Orr, Charles Stewart Smith, and William F. King, yesterday received the following telegrams:

A report by the Investigating Committee of the National Civil Service Reform League, on conditions in the Indian Service -- with particular reference to the appointment of agents -- under the present Administration, has been presented to the Council of the League. The facts and recommendations contained in the report have also been submitted by the committee to President McKinley.

Secretary J.V.S. Oddie of the New York Yacht Club announced last night that the committee on the challenge of the Royal Ulster Yacht Club and the Regatta Committee of the club will leave the Grand Central Station to-day at 1:02 P.M. to witness the launching of the Constitution at Bristol.

Following are the returns of foreign commerce at the Port of New York for the week ended Friday last, as compared with the corresponding week last year. In the case of the exports of general merchandise the returns are for the week ended Tuesday:

It is said that leading Republicans will have a conference at the Fifth Avenue Hotel to-morrow relative to appointments to be filled, and incidentally something may be said about bills which have not yet been vetoed or approved.

It is a matter of close and anxious study with the Tammany politicians what is to be the effect on popular sentiment of the exposures now making as to the corruption of the police management. There is, of course, a considerable element in the population of a city like this which will not at all be estranged from Tammany by these disclosures.

BERLIN, May 5. -- The Boerse greeted the political developments of last week Jubilantly. Even the highest financial circles are gratified at the fall of Dr. Von Miquel and Herr Brefeld, believing that a reform of the Boerse law is now made more practicable.

An invasion or the Twelfth Assembly District, a Tammany stronghold of which City Clerk P.J. Scully is leader, was made last night by representatives of the City Democracy. It was very successful, too, because after a powwow the Oriental Club, with headquarters at 454 Grand Street, one of the strongest Democratic organizations in the district, went over bodily to the City Democracy.

A report which was circulated several weeks ago to the effect that the American Federation of Labor was organizing the employes of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit Company was reaffirmed at the meeting of the Central Federated Union yesterday by Herman Robinson. Robinson is the general organizer of the American Federation of Labor for New York and Brooklyn, and also Financial Secretary of the Central Federated Union.

Five teams of college golfers are now at Atlantic City eager to begin the competition for intercollegiate championship honors. Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Columbia, and the University of Pennsylvania will meet to-morrow in the first round for the team championship on the links of the Atlantic City Country Club.

LONDON, May 5. -- Every topic of interest gave way last week to the extraordinary gamble in your railroad securities. As the prices went rocketing up day after day the feeling of apprehension became great lest the excitement might end in a catastrophe. We had the reflection of your dangerous turmoil here, but with us the speculation was confined within a narrow limit.

The policemen at the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station are in mourning. Their official shoeshiner, Jumbo Jim, is dead. He will be buried to-day from the Morgue, but Jim will not rest in Potter's Field.

-- Presumably it was a commendable fear of possible harm to the readers of two articles in The College Review, one a denunciation of Mr. RICHARD CROKER and the other an attack on religion, that prompted the attempt by the head of the College of the City of New York to order the suppression of the issue in which they appeared.

"All out!" was the reply received by late-comers at the Harlem River boathouses yesterday afternoon when they applied for a shell, a gig, or any other kind of a craft in which to get afloat. Not only were all the small boats out from almost all the houses, but the large ones as well, and in many cases a wait of several hours was necessary before a boat could be obtained.

HAVANA, May 5. -- The special commission of the Cuban Constitutional Convention, who went to Washington to obtain a better knowledge of the intentions of the United States Government regarding Cuba, arrived here early this morning. They were met by a delegation of Cubans and by Col. Scott, representing the military Governor.

MERIDIA, Yucatan, May 5. -- There is great enthusiasm over the national holiday and thanksgiving services were held in all the churches over the downfall of the Mayas stronghold, Chan Santa Cruz. The federal troops are rapidly taking possession of the stronghold places held by the Indians.

"Yes," said the woman who likes to befriend the milliner, "if you wish to be really comfortable always keep two hats on hand and wear them alternately. If you wear a hat much of the time you will find that it is a great relief. Different hats rest upon different parts of the head, and so, even though the hats may both be light, it will be found that a change will be very agreeable."

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., May 5. -- Following hard upon the resignation of Prof. Lovejoy of Stanford University last week comes the announcement that Profs. Lapsley and Warren of Harvard will retire at the end of this semester and will not re- turn, although they were offered full professorships and a large increase of sal- ary.

The first bulletin of the census of 1900 having relation to any branch of the metallurgical industries of the United States is that on the coke industry, prepared by EDWARD W. PARKER of the Geological Survey. Its statistics are indicative of the rapid development of the business of iron and steel manufacture in this country.
BOSTON, May 6. -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks loaned at 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at 17, 20, and 25 cents discount. Exchanges, $18,682,529; balances, $1,913,700.
Among the best things that can be found for decorating cozy corners and the like are punkahs. Little ones, painted and decorated and very effective, can be found for only 25 cents apiece.

BERLIN, May 6. -- The National Zeitung publishes a statement, evidently inspired, regarding the withdrawal of the troops from the Province of Pe-chl-Li. The withdrawal, it apoears, will be under Count von Waldersee's command, no nation proceeding alone.

Fighting gamely for his liberty, until pronounced guilty of grand larceny, J. Edwin Stoddard, forger, blackmailer, and ex-convict, whose aliases are legion, declined the assignment of counsel before Recorder Goff yesterday, conducted his own defense, summed up eloquently, took his conviction defiantly, and then under the kind words of the Court broke down completely, admitted his guilt, and on the spot made full restitution to his victim.

Judgment for $1,050 was entered yesterday against Stewart M. Brice, the Councilman, in favor of Oliver C. Ewart for balance due on a note made by Mr. Brice on Aug. 24. 1900, for $2,000, payable to C. H. Moore, who indorsed it to the plaintiff, Mr. Ewart. One thousand dollars has been paid on the note.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 6. -- Lakewood will close its most successful polo tournament this week with three big competitions for the Georgian Court Cups, presented by Mrs. George J. Gould. These are the chief trophies of the event, and will bring out four teams, composed of some of the best material in this city and Philadelphia.

The most amazing feature of the racing at the Morris Park track yesterday was the attendance. Clubhouse, grand stand, and field were crowded to the point of discomfort for individuals, and that, too, in spite of the fact that the programme offered was the most thoroughly commonplace that was ever run off at the great Westchester course.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6. -- This, the thirteenth day of the Eastman murder trial, was spent by the defense in piling up additional evidence to support the contention that relations between the defendant and the victim of the shooting, Richard H. Grogan, Jr., were at all times pleasant. No mention was made of rim-fire or centre-fire bullets or revolvers.

At the Knickerbocker Theatre yesterday afternoon a performance was given at which were offered once more two dramatic pieces performed last at Wallack's Theatre at a special matinee, on Oct. 26. These were Browning's "In a Balcony" and W. B. Yeats's "The Land of Heart's Desire." The former was enacted by the same actors as before, while in the allotment of parts in the latter there were changes.

SOUTHAMPTON. May 6. -- The Shamrock yachts had a second spin to-day, and the result indicates the view that the cup challenger is vastly superior to the ok boat when going close-hauled; but that the older boat can travel equally fast when going off and before the wind.

The United States Army Quartermaster's Department, in this city, received orders from the War Department yesterday to close contracts with the four steamship companies running from New York to the West Indies for the transfer of men and supplies to and from the United States military depots in Cuba and Porto Rico.
BERLIN. May 6. -- The new Ministers are gazetted as follows: Baron von Rheinbaben, Minister of Finance.

For the third time, Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy of New Dorp, Staten Island, was called to the bar in Judge Newburger's court in General Sessions yesterday to defend himself of the charge of having murdered Emetine C. Reynolds in the Grand Hotel three years ago.
Details of the sale of the Rossmore Hotel property, on Broadway, near Forty-second Street, will be found in another column.
The following cases of smallpox were reported to the Board of Health yesterday:

WASHINGTON. May 6. -- Senor Silva, the Colombian Minister to the United States, has presented to the State Department a proposition from the Panama Canal Company that appraisers be appointed to fix the value of the company's property with a view to its sale to the Untied States. The proposition is signed by President Hutin of the company.

Two blind men and a cripple were sentenced to one month's imprisonment each in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for soliciting alms. Policeman Hayes tells a strange story or poetic retribution of one of the sightless ones, Charles Berkowitz, who has long stood at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, where he sells trinkets from a satchel.

Announcements of large increases in the pay roll of the Board of Public Improvements and the Department of Charities were made yesterday. President Holahan appointed twenty-four men to the Topographical Department of his office at a salary of S1,320 each. On April 15 twentyfour men were appointed to the same department at a salary of $1,200 each.
The Security Life and Savings Company of Des Moines has been admitted to Illinois by Superintendent Van Cleave.

First Lieut. Frederick W. Lewis, Eighth Infantry, will proceed to Buffalo, at such time as may be designated by the Superintendent of the Military Academy at West Point, to supervise the exhibit of the Academy at the Pan-American Exposition.

DEMING, N. M. May 6. -- Shortly after leaving El Paso the train crossed the line into New Mexico, and ran through the grazing section of the territory. It was a hot and dusty ride. The first stop In the Territory was made at Deming, where the President was welcomed by Gov. Otero and his staff. There was a big crowd and a band at the station, and the President was given a warm greeting.

Demonstrations of foreign interest in the American security market was furnished by quotations from London yesterday morning. Following the depression at the end of last week, and in view of the heavy sales that then came from London, that market was not expected to show much animation; but the unexpected happened.

In some respects the stock market of yesterday was the most remarkable of any that Wall Street has yet seen. Trading was not on so extensive a scale as on recent "record" days, total transactions amounting to about 2,300,000 shares, which is considerably below the high figure; but what the market lacked in this respect it made up in others.
A highly appreciative audience at the Fourteenth Street Theatre last night saw a revival of "Sweet Inniscarra."

WILKESBARRE, Penn., May 6. -- E.J. Fisher, an extensive junk dealer of this city, was to-day sentenced in court to six months in the county jail. The prisoner was convicted of receiving stolen brass, and his answers led to the breaking up of a gang of thieves who had been robbing the railroads for years.

During the trial of Mrs. Belle Devlin on a charge of assault brought by Mrs. Benjamin S. Hill of 213 Grand Street, the Judges in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, yesterday heard some interesting things with regard to the alleged dual life led by Mr. Hill, who is a wealthy tea merchant and churchman of Brooklyn.

MELBOURNE, May 6. -- The Duke and Ductless of Cornwall and York landed from the steamship Ophir at 2 o'clock this afternoon. They were received at the pier head by the Earl of Hopetoun, Governor General, and the State and Federal Ministers. After the Ministers had been presented, the party passed down the quarter of a mile of carpeted pier, and entered carriages.

An action for libel to recover $25,000 from The Daily Telegraph Company, which was brought by Charles Francis Seymour, Earl of Yarmouth, whose stage name is Eric Hope, is now on trial before Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court. The actual taking of testimony will commence to-day.

Champion Lasker was pitted against the Empire State champion, Finn, at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday. The latter won the toss for the move, and started with a Ruy Lopez, which was defended with 3. .P-QR3. Finn succeeded in keeping Lasker at bay all through the afternoon sitting and had more than an even game.

Judge Warren W. Foster, swearing in the May Grand Jury, in General Sessions yesterday, directed that body's especial attention to the prevalence of "get-richquick" syndicates, and other fraudulent co-operative pools, offering investments in oil wells, gold mines, and similar enterprises.

BALTIMORE, May 6. -- The first important election to be held under the new ballot law devised by the Democrats to disfranchise illiterates will take place in this city to-morrow, when a new City Council will be chosen. The election will be interesting principally because of its bearing upon the new law and the opportunity which it will afford for testing its efficacy from a Democratic point of view.

The handsomely furnished home of Mrs. T. C. Lyman and her three daughters at 24 East Seventy-sixth Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, was gutted by fire late yesterday afternoon. The blaze and incidents connected with it were quite spectacular, and there was abundant excitement in the neighborhood for a time.

John D. Germon, the actor, who was injured while playing a small part in a revival of "Held by the Enemy," in the American Theatre Stock Company, last January, died at Roosevelt Hospital yesterday morning of blood poisoning. It was during the second act of the play that the accident occurred, while Germon was carrying a magnesia lamp, which exploded.

WASHINGTON. May 6. -- Commander B. T. Tilley Commandant of the naval station at Tutuila, Samoa, has reported to the Navy Department, under the date of Pago Pago, April 17, regarding conditions in that new acquisition to the American Republic. He says that for the first time in four months he made a visit to Manua with the United States ship Abarenda and found the natives entirely contented and prosperous.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The Hartford has sailed from Port Royal for Plymouth.

For the second time this season the New York baseball team played on the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Philadelphias contesting the game with them. The liveliest kind of ball was played, the New Yorks winning by the score of 4 to 0. The makeup of the team was slightly different from its first appearance.

SCRANTON, Penn., May 6. -- Leonard S. Outram of London, England, a member of E.H. Sothern's company, playing the part of the King in "Hamlet," also at times Polonius, was found dead in bed at the home of his brother-in-law, James Paul, in Carbondale, to-day, where he had gone to visit after the company's appearance here Saturday evening.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 6. -- The body of Harry Bonnetheau, a real estate dealer, was recovered to-day from the St. John's River Mr. Bonnetheau's widow and son are supposed to be in New York City. The bodies of two negroes were also recovered. All are victims of Friday's fire.

Wall Street was treated yesterday to another batch of favorable railway statements, all for the fourth week of April. The increases reported, as compared with the earnings in the corresponding week last year, were: Missouri Pacific, $227,000; Southern Railway, $118,420; Canadian Pacific, $104,000; Texas and Pacific, $80,590; Louisville and Nashville, $82,000; St. Louis and San Francisco, $56,000; Chesapeake and Ohio, $43,800, and Norfolk and Western, $33.6OO.

-- Somebody recently criticised Gen. JOHN W. FOSTER, the ex-Secretary of State, because, all through his "Century of American Diplomacy," he treats "United States" as a singular noun instead of as a plural one. This has moved the General to investigate that often mooted question with some care, and his conclusion is that, despite the wording of the Constitution, there is full justification for saying "the United States is," and not "the United States are."
CHICAGO, May 6. -- Money for call and time loans to-day was rated at 4@4 1/2. Chicago loaned much money in the East, where higher rates prevailed. New York exchange was quoted at 10 cents premium.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Inquiry here confirms the report that the United States is working, and finds support in its effort, toward the opening of all China to the trade of the world. This does not mean the abolition of customs duties, but the making of every Chinese city a mart for the world's goods, instead of the limitation of foreign commerce to the few existing treaty ports.

Southeastern Texas is now passing through one of those paroxysms of speculative excitement which for a time turn the heads of the most conservative. The opening of the oil field near Beaumont has created a "boom" of gigantic proportions. People are flocking thither from all directions to see the wonderful Lucas "gusher" and speculate in oil stocks.

At the annual meeting of the Woodruff Boat Club held at the clubhouse, on Jamaica Bay, Rockaway Beach, on Saturday evening, the following officers were elected for the coming season: President -- Harry Jacquilard; Vice President -- Otto Gruhn; Secretary -- William E. Heitz: Treasurer and Captain -- John Stoecklein: Board of Directors -- Charles F. Reinhardt, George Jacquilard, and A. Werbelly.
At Classon-on-the-Sound De La Salle's baseball team defeated the Sacred Heart Academy team by a score of 12 to 10 after a very interesting game. The score:

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 6. -- The range was occupied to-day by a detachment of the Thirteenth Regiment Heavy Artillery, N.G.N.Y., composed of Batteries B, M. F, D, G, and L, under the command of Lieut. Col. George D. Russell. The weather was favorable, with a light 8 o'clock wind in the morning, changing to a 5 o'clock light wind in the afternoon.

Many persons have written to THE NEWYORK TIMES inquiring for the names of legislators who voted for and against the repeal of the law permitting live pigeon shooting from traps when that measure came up at Albany, only to be defeated in the Assembly. In the Senate the repealing act was passed.

BOSTON, May 6. -- Both pitchers were extremely effective in to-day's baseball game, but Hughes's gifts proved costly, two bases on balls and a single netting Boston two runs in the third. Kittridge's throwing was excellent, cutting off both Sheckard and Keeler in attempted steals. The score:
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 6. -- The doors of the Cuyahoga Savings and Banking Company, at 1461 Woodland Avenue, were not opened for business to-day. The following notice was posted on the window:

There seems but little disposition to leave town Just now. Although there is not very much of a special nature going on there are many little affairs, such as dinners and luncheons and parties to the play. The one gathering was at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the annual reception took place.

BALTIMROE. May 6. -- The market today was quite firm, the general trend being upward though no notable bulges were recorded. Seaboards were probably the nearest to what might be termed leadership. The advance in this stock, while not a wide one nevertheless, was a substantial one, and demonstrated the strong bull tone underlying the group.

New York City has at last decided to issue "cow bonds." Those not initiated into the intricacies of the city's finances will hardly understand the significance of this announcement, which was made for the first time in the history of the municipality yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Estimate.

For about half an hour yesterday morning Washington Street, between Morris and Rector Streets, was the scene of more excitement than the members of the Syrian colony there have seen in some time. George Faur, a notion merchant, of 63 Washington Street, and Joseph Aboarab, an importer, of 45 Washington Street, both Syrians, engaged in a rough-and-tumble fight.

Since the election of last year the Democratic leaders of the South as well as those of the North have been watching with keen interest the tendencies of public opinion in that section. They have been forced to admit that the dividing line between the two National parties has become perceptibly less distinct.

Coach Hanlan yesterday made up the "second" crew, which will represent Columbia in the second crew race with the Cornell and the Pennsylvania crews at Ithaca on May 30. The men, with their present positions, are as follows: Bow, A. Weekes; No. 2. Brinckernoff; 3, Townsend; 4, Iselin; 5, Niezer; 6, Huffaker; 7, Bartholomew; stroke, Stevenson; coxswain, Comstock.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against John T. Baldwin, F. Henry Baldwin, Willard C. Baldwin, Jr., and John T. Baldwin Co., corporation, all composing the firm of John T. Baldwin Co., dealers in woolen rags at 62 Thompson Street, by Benjamin Loeser for the following creditors: William Hughes, $3.101; Patrick McMeel, $511, and John Sinnott, ,$2,509.
Silver bullion certificates were not quoted on the Stock Exchange. There were no sales.

There was issued from the Finance Department yesterday a comparative statement of the cost of the City Government for 1901, showing that mandatory and practically mandatory acts of the Legislature forced the city officials to spend $81,377,125 or the $98,100,413 appropriated in the annual budget for this year.
