ISAAC HALL, one of the last survivors of the famous Quantrell band of guerrillas, is dead at Hunter's Depot, Ky. He was with Quantrell when the guerrilla raider received his death wound.

Thousands of Democrats in this city, men of wealth, standing, and respectability, busy men, quite outside of politics, must have read over the list of district leaders of the newly organized Greater New York Democracy, if they read it at all, with the feeling that they knew none of these men: and for that reason they would dismiss the matter from their minds as one void of interest for them.

George J. Paour, a member of the Syrian firm of D.J. Faour and Brother, bankers and jobbers, at 63 Washington Street, while going to the Western National Bank yesterday morning was attacked by five men in front of the Syrian restaurant, at 83 Washington Street.

Police Captain Bason and his detectives from the Classon Avenue Police Station, Brooklyn, shortly before midnight last night raided the alleged disorderly house 403 Vanderbilt Avenue, and arrested Josephine Atwater, thirty-five years old, four other women, and three men. The house, a three-story and basement brick dwelling, stands in the heart of what is known as the "Hill Section" of Brooklyn.

E.O. Presby, won the first prize in the amateur billiard tournament which has been going on at the Metropolitan Academy by defeating Dr. Walter G. Douglas last night by the score of 200 to 139. A great deal of interest was taken in the contest, as the two men were tied for first place, each having won six games with but one defeat.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, May 6. -- Burlington Passenger Train No. 3 to-day, while passing Thayer, a small town, eighteen miles east of Creston, struck an engine attached to a freight train which was endeavoring to get out of the way by backing on the side track, and was derailed, killing Engineer S.D. Brown of Burlington, and injuring thirty persons.

RICHMOND, Va., May 6. -- The Richmond Locomotive Works, of which Joseph Bryan was President, were sold to-day for $3,000,000. The deal has been pending for some time. Joseph Leiter, who is the buyer, came here about a month ago and Inspected the plant.

There is good reason to believe that Gov. Odell will sign the McCarren bill, providing for better facilities at the Manhattan terminal of Brooklyn Bridge; also that he will veto the North River Bridge bill, and the Employers' Liability bill.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

In addition to a notable gathering of well-known horsemen, a number of men prominent socially or politically will be the guests of the Road Drivers Association on Saturday afternoon and reviewing its parade over the Speedway. Among those who have accepted are Michael C. Murphy, Commissioner of Police; Randolph Guggenheimer, ex-Mayor Thomas F. Gilroy, Paul Dana, Frank Bower, President of the Belmont Driving Club, Philadelphia; Charles T. Chapin.

About 150 representatives of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York will attend Julia Marlowe's performance of "When Knighthood Was In Flower," at the Criterion Theatre this evening. They will be present in a body, and acting as a host of the party will be Richard A. McCurdy, President of the company, and George A. Brinkerhoff, the New York representative.

AUSTIN. Texas, May 6. -- Ex-Gov. J. S. Hogg left here to-day for New York City to complete the details of the organization of a company which purposes to develop and transport fuel oil from the Beaumont field to their iron ore fields of New Birmingham, Texas, which wore recently acquired by Mr. Hogg and others.

The attentions of Vincenzo Teresi recently of Italy, to the attractive daughter of E. P. Wright, traveling agent for the American Steel and Wire Company of 44 East Twenty-first Street, brought him into the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday afternoon. Mr. Wright says Teresi is a count, but the latter denies that he possesses any such title.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against the Manhattan Ice Company, whose office was at 44 Broadway, by the following persons: Henry and Charles Stern, as Stern Brothers, $300; Emanuel M. Yaretzky, $276, and Jacob Mendelowitz, $3,000.

More life showed in the outside market yesterday than during the last days of the past week, and some substantial advances resulted from the day's trading. The market opened strong, and throughout the day there was a better demand for stocks than had been the case recently. The Denver and Southwestern issues were notably strong, and American Can among the industrials showed much improvement.
KLERKSDORP, Transvaal Colony, May 6. -- Gen. De La Rey's force of 4,000 Boers, which has been In the hills around Hartebeestfontein, has broken up.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The announcement was made a few days ago that as soon as the Cuban Commission that visited Washington should reach Havana, a statement would be issued simultaneously from Havana and the War Department setting forth the results of the conference held here between the visiting Cubans and the President and Secretary of War.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6. -- The Classical Club Of Harvard produced a Greek play to-night for the first time since the famous production of the "Oedipus Tyrannus" in 1881. The play to-night consisted of scenes from the "Birds" of Aristophanes, a Greek comedy. The music for the lyric and choral passages was written by Prof. J. K. Paine of the department of music.

BELLEFONTE, May 6. -- Jesse R. King near Millheim to-day shot and fatally wounded his bride of two months, and when an officer attempted to arrest him shot himself through the heart and died almost instantly.

ROCHESTER, May 6. -- The first break in the Erie Canal occurred this morning at a point known as the Eastern Wide Waters, situated just east of the city line. Water was being let into the canal, but at the Monroe Avenue lock it was being filled too rapidly, and as a result the canal overflowed its banks, and tore away a portion of the embankment.

Refusing to touch a mouthful of food. Valet Charles F. Jones, the self-confessed murderer of Millionaire William Marsh Rice, and who once before attempted to kill himself in the Tombs by cutting his throat, is slowly starving to death in the House of Detention.

Local fire underwriters still possess very meagre and unsatisfactory reports as to the probable extent of the losses of their companies in the Jacksonville fire. Many of the offices yesterday received lump estimates of their losses in the burned section. There is in many cases a prospect of some salvage, regarding which it will take some time to obtain an adequate idea.
WASHINGTON, May 6. -- An order issued to-day by the War Department honorably discharges a number of volunteer officers, as follows:

BRISTOL. R. I., May 6. -- With her hull gaily decorated with flags and her deck well filled with sailors, the yacht Constitution was christened this evening by Mrs. W. Butler Duncan. who broke the traditional bottle of wine on her glistening how just as she started slowly down the w ys into the sea.

While a mail wagon driven by Frank Smythe, thirty-seven years old, of 617 East Fifteenth Street, was crossing Lexington Avenue at Thirty-fifth Street last evening, it was struck by a south-bound electric car and hurled against the curb, being badly wrecked. Smythe was thrown against an iron railing and received severe bruises. He was partially stunned.

That is a most significant suggestion which comes to us from the Shanghai correspondent of The London Times. It is that Manchuria, instead of being shut up to the exclusive exploitation of Russia, should be opened on equal terms to the industrial enterprise of all nations. We do not attach much importance to the mild "dementi" which emanates also from London.
In the Supreme Court yesterday Justice O'Gorman wrote the following decision in regard to a lawyer named William S. Katzenstein, which was posted in the Clerk's office of Part I., Special term:

Several additions to the educational force of Columbia University were made yesterday at the regular monthly meeting of the Trustees. Prof. Henry S. Redfield of the Cornell Law School was appointed Professor of Law, and Dr. Benjamin Duryea Woodward, 38, Assistant Commissioner at the Paris Exposition, was made Adjunct Professor of Romance Languages in Barnard College.
The Presbyterian Union held its annual meeting last evening at the Hotel Savoy. E.M. Stiger presided, and the following officers were elected:

LONDON, May 6. -- Americans were the chief centre of attraction on the Stock Exchange to-day, which was increasingly excited with active buying. There was a sensational advance in St. Paul and Northern Pacific common reached 113. After a strong opening irregularity developed with rapid fluctuations.

Vice Chancellor Pitney, at Jersey City, yesterday heard testimony on the application of Calvin O. Geer for an injunction restraining the Amalgamated Copper Company from absorbing the Boston and Montana and the Butte and Boston Mining Companies.

BENSON, Ariz., May 6. -- The Presidential special reached Benson at 8:35 o'clock tonight. The station was illuminated and the President spoke a few words to the crowd. The train will stop at Tucson. It is due at Phoenix in the morning.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 6. -- Anthony Comstock, with a force of officers late this afternoon raided the hotel kept by Admiral Dot, the famous dwarf, and the billiard room of E.H. Sniffin. From Dot's hotel one slot machine was taken and from Sniffin's three. The men were arrested. They were arraigned before Justice Capron and paroled until Monday next.
In the Supreme Court yesterday justice O'Gorman wrote the following decision in regard to a lawyer named William S. Katzenstein, which was posted in the Clerk's office of Part I., Special term:

BALTIMROE, May 6 -- The market today was quite firm, the general trend being upward, though no notable bulges were recorded. Seaboards were probably the nearest to what might be termed leadership. The advance in this stock, while not a wide one nevertheless, was a substantial one, and demonstrated the strong bull tone underlying the group.
CHICAGO, May 6. -- Money for call and time loans to-day was rated at 4@4 1/2. Chicago loaned much money in the East, where higher rates prevailed. New York exchange was quoted at 10 cents premium.

-- Somebody recently criticised Gen. JOHN W. FOSTER, the ex-Secretary of State, because, all through his "Century of American Diplomacy," he treats "United States" as a singular noun instead of as a plural one. This has moved the General to investigate that often mooted question with some care, and his conclusion is that, despite the wording of the Constitution, there is full justification for saying "the United States is," and not "the United States are."

At the Knickerbocker Theatre yesterday afternoon a performance was given at which were offered once more two dramatic pieces performed last at Wallack's Theatre at a special matinee, on Oct. 26. These were Browning's "In a Balcony" and W. B. Yeats's "The Land of Heart's Desire." The former was enacted by the same actors as before, while in the allotment of parts in the latter there were changes.
BERLIN. May 6. -- The new Ministers are gazetted as follows:

There is good reason to believe that Gov. Odell will sign the McCarren bill, providing for better facilities at the Manhattan terminal of Brooklyn Bridge; also that he will veto the North River Bridge bill, and the Employers' Liability bill.

SOUTHAMPTON, May 6. -- The Shamrock yachts had a second spin to-day, and the result indicates the view that the cup challenger is vastly superior to the old boat when going close-hauled; but that the older boat can travel equally fast when going off and before the wind.

Southeastern Texas is now passing through one of those paroxysms of speculative excitement which for a time turn the heads of the most conservative. The opening of the oil field near Beaumont has created a "boom" of gigantic proportions. People are flocking thither from all directions to see the wonderful Lucas "gusher" and speculate in oil stocks.

During the trial of Mrs. Belle Devlin on a charge of assault brought by Mrs, Benjamin S. Hill of 213 Grand Street, the Judges in the Court of Special Sessions, Brooklyn, yesterday heard some interesting things with regard to the alleged dual life led by Mr. Hill, who is a wealthy tea merchant and churchman of Brooklyn.

Thousands of Democrats in this city, men of wealth, standing, and respectability, busy men, quite outside of politics, must have read over the list of district leaders of the newly organized Greater New York Democracy, if they read it at all, with the feeling that they knew none of these men: and for that reason they would dismiss the matter from their minds as one void of interest for them.

Coach Hanlan yesterday made up the "second" crew, which will represent Columbia in the second crew race with the Cornell and the Pennsylvania crews at Ithaca on May 30. The men, with their present positions, are as follows: Bow. A. Weekes; No. 2, Brinckerhoff; 3, Townsend; 4, Iselin; 5, Niezer; 6, Huffaker; 7, Bartholomew; stroke, Stevenson; coxswain, Comstock.

BRISTOL, R.I., May 6 -- With her hull gaily decorated with flags and her deck well filled with sailors, the yacht Constitution was christened this evening by Mrs. W. Butler Duncan, who broke the traditional bottle of wine on her glistening bow just as she started slowly down the ways into the sea.

Two facts came to light yesterday which are regarded as prophetic of future energetic action on the part of the Committee of Fifteen in its efforts to secure evidence against those who profit by dealing out police protection to the gamblers and other chronic lawbreakers of the City of New York.

OTTUMWA, Iowa, May 6. -- Burlington Passenger Train No. 3 to-day, while passing Thayer, a small town, eighteen miles east of Creston, struck an engine attached to a freight train which was endeavoring to get out of the way by backing on the aide track, and was derailed, killing Engineer S.D. Brown of Burlington, and injuring thirty persons.

George J. Faour, a member of the Syrian firm of D.J. Faour and Brother, bankers and jobbers, at 63 Washington Street, while going to the Western National Bank yesterday morning was attacked by five men in front of the Syrian restaurant, at 83 Washington Street.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against the Manhattan Ice Company, whose office was at 44 Broadway, by the following persons: Henry and Charles Stern, as Stern Brothers, $300; Emanuel M. Yaretzky, $276, and Jacob Mendelowitz, $3,000.
