It is that Manchuria, instead of being shut up to the exclusive exploitation of Russia, should be opened on equal terms to the industrial enterprise of all nations. We do not attach much importance to the mild "dementi" which emanates also from London.

The United States Army Quartermaster's Department, in this city, received orders from the War Department yesterday to close contracts with the four steamship companies running from New York to the West Indies for the transfer of men and supplies to and from the United States military depots in Cuba and Porto Rico.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, May 6 -- The doors of the Cuyahoga Savings and Banking Company, at 1461 Woodland Avenue, were not opened for business to-day. The following notice was posted on the window:

In some respects the stock market of yesterday was the most remarkable of any that Wall Street has yet seen. Trading was not on so extensive a scale as on recent "record" days, total transactions amounting to about 2,300,000 shares, which is considerably below the high figure; but what the market lacked in this respect it made up in others.

MELBOURNE, May 6. -- The Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York landed from the steamship Ophir at 2 o'clock this afternoon. They were received at the pier head by the Earl of Hopetoun, Governor General, and the State and Federal Ministers. After the Ministers had been presented, the party passed down the quarter of a mile of carpeted pier, and entered carriages.
BOSTON, May 6 -- At the Clearing House to-day money between the banks loaned at 4 per cent., and New York funds sold at 17, 20, and 25 cents discount. Exchanges, $18,682,529; balances, $1,913,700.

An action for libel to recover $25,000 from The Dally Telegraph Company, which was brought by Charles Francis Seymour, Earl of Yarmouth, whose stage name is Eric Hope, is now on trial before Justice Leventritt, in the Supreme Court. The actual taking of testimony will commence to-day.

AUSTIN, Texas, May 6 -- Ex-Gov. J.S. Hogg left here to-day for New York City to complete the details of the organization of a company which purposes to develop and transport fuel oil from the Beaumont field to their iron ore fields of New Birmhingham, Texas, which were recently acquired by Mr. Hogg and others.

More life showed in the outside market yesterday than during the last days of the past week, and some substantial advances resulted from the day's trading. The market opened strong, and throughout the day there was a better demand for stocks than had been the case recently. The Denver and Southwestern issues were notably strong, and American Can among the industrials showed much improvement.

About 150 representatives of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York will attend Julia Marlowe's performance of "When Knighthood Was In Flower," at the Criterion Theatre this evening. They will be present in a body, and acting as a, host of the party will be Richard A. McCurdy, President of the company, and George A. Brinkerhoff, the New York representative.

For the second time this season the New York baseball team played on the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Philadelphias contesting the game with them. The liveliest kind of ball was played, the New Yorks winning by the score of 4 to 0. The makeup of the team was slightly different from its first appearance, Nelson, a new man, replacing Murphy at second.

CREEDMOOR, L.I., May 6 -- The range was occupied to-day by a detachment of the Thirteenth Regiment Heavy Artillery, N.G.N.Y., composed of Batteries B, M, P, D, G, and L,. under the command of Lieut. Col. George D. Russell. The weather was favorable,' with a light 8 o'clock wind in the morning, changing to a 5 o'clock light wind in the afternoon.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 6 -- John Hyslop's new keel yawl has been launched from the boat shops of the Jacob yard and tied up in the marine basin to be fitted out with hollow spars and other rigging gear. The launching was an informal affair.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- Two reasons have governed the Taft Commission in its decision to withhold municipal government from the City of Manila, while granting it to many smaller towns. The principal one is the complexity of the problem of municipal government in a large city, as compared with that in smaller ones.

Refusing to touch a mouthful of food. Valet Charles F. Jones, the self-confessed murderer of Millionaire William Marsh Rice, and who once before attempted to kill himself in the Tombs by cutting his throat, is slowly starving to death in the House of Detention.

The most amazing feature of the racing at the Morris Park track yesterday was the attendance. Clubhouse, grand stand, and field were crowded to the point of discomfort for individuals, and that, too, in spite of the fact that the programme offered was the most thoroughly commonplace that was ever run off at the great Westchester course.

Many persons have written to THE NEW YORK TIMES inquiring for the names of legislators who voted for and against the repeal of the law permitting live pigeon shooting from traps when that measure came up at Albany, only to be defeated in the Assembly. In the Senate the repealing act was passed.

A petition in involuntary bankruptcy was filed yesterday against John T. Baldwin, F. Henry Baldwin, Willard C. Baldwin, Jr., and John T. Baldwin Co., corporation, all composing the firm of John T. Baldwin Co., dealers in woolen rags at 62 Thompson Street, by Benjamin Loeser for the following creditors: William Hughes, $3,101; Patrick McMeel, $511, and John Sinnott, ,$2,509.

LONDON, May 6. -- Americans were the chief centre of attraction on the Stock Exchange to-day, which was increasingly excited with active buying. There was a sensational advance in St. Paul and Northern Pacific common reached 113. After a strong opening irregularity developed with rapid fluctuations.

The Rossmore Hotel, running through from Broadway to Seventh Avenue, just south of Forty-second Street, has been sold for something over $700,000. The property has been bought by a syndicate, the makeup of which could not be learned yesterday. A rumor, however, that James J. Corbett and George F. Considine are interested in the deal as future tenants of the property was denied.

DEMING, N.M., May 6 -- Shortly after leaving El Paso the train crossed the line into New Mexico, and ran through the grazing section of the territory. It was a hot and dusty ride. The first stop in the Territory was made at Deming, where the President was welcomed by Gov. Otero and his staff.

Fighting gamely for his liberty, until pronounced guilty of grand larceny, J. Edwin Stoddard, forger, blackmailer, and ex-convict, whose aliases are legion, declined the assignment of counsel before Recorder Goff yesterday, conducted his own defense, summed up eloquently, took his conviction defiantly, and then under the kind words of the Court broke down completely, admitted his guilt, and on the spot made full restitution to his victim.

The handsomely furnished home of Mrs. T.C. Lyman and her three daughters at 24 East Seventy-sixth Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues, was gutted by fire late yesterday afternoon. The blaze and incidents connected with it were quite spectacular, and there was abundant excitement in the neighborhood for a time.
ISAAC HALL, one of the last survivors of the famous Quantrell band of guerrillas, is dead at Hunter's Depot, Ky. He was with Quantrell when the guerrilla raider received his death wound.

A well-dressed elderly man was stricken with apoplexy in the Grand Street Ferry house, Brooklyn, last night, and was taken to the Eastern District Hospital, where it was said he would die before morning. Before he lapsed into unconsciousness he described himself as Henry Dietrich, sixty-five years old, of 86 Avenue D. Manhattan.

New York City has at last decided to issue "cow bonds." Those not initiated into the intricacies of the city's finances will hardly understand the significance of this announcement, which was made for the first time in the history of the municipality yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Estimate.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 6. -- The body of Harry Bonnetheau, a real estate dealer, was recovered to-day from the St. John's River Mr. Bonnetheau's widow and son are supposed to be in New York City. The bodies of two negroes were also recovered. All are victims of Friday's fire.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, except in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

There seems but little disposition to leave town just now. Although there is not very much of a special nature going on, there are many little affairs, such as dinners and luncheons and parties to the play. The one gathering was at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where the annual reception took place.

Even before the embers of the disastrous Jacksonville fire have had time to cool New York has come to the front with assistance which is as generous as it is prompt. Over $59,000 was subscribed yesterday, and by to-night at 7 o'clock the first relief train will speed on its way to the stricken city.

Demonstrations of foreign interest in the American security market was furnished by quotations from London yesterday morning. Following the depression at the end of last week, and in view of the heavy sales that then came from London, that market was not expected to show much animation; but the unexpected happened.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 6 -- A New York paper Saturday morning contained the marriage notice of Paul MacCormac, a young millionaire of this city, and Miss Grace Clark of New Haven, Conn. The announcement was received with great surprise in this city, and to-day the young man makes the announcement that the matter was all a joke which he perpetrated to get even with a local newspaper man.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., May 6 -- Lakewood will close its most successful polo tournament this week with three big competitions for the Georgian Court Cups, presented by Mrs. George J. Gould. These are the chief trophies of the event, and will bring out four teams, composed of some of the best material in this city and Philadelphia.

First Lieut. Frederick W. Lewis, Eighth Infantry, will proceed to Buffalo, at such time as may be designated by the Superintendent of the Military Academy at West Point, to supervise the exhibit of the Academy at the Pan-American Exposition.

For the third time, Dr. Samuel J. Kennedy of New Dorp, Staten Island, was called to the bar in Judge Newburger's court in General Sessions yesterday to defend himself of the charge of having murdered Emeline C. Reynolds in the Grand Hotel three years ago.

Since the election of last year the Democratic leaders of the South as well as those of the North have been watching with keen interest the tendencies of public opinion in that section. They have been forced to admit that the dividing line between the two National parties has become perceptibly less distinct.

WASHINGTON, May 6. -- The Quartermaster General's department to-day received a dispatch from Capt. Parsons, at Jacksonville, Fla., saying that he had arrived there with the hospital tents sent by the War Department. He adds that the reports of the loss have not been exaggerated and that 15,00 people are homeless.

Two blind men and a cripple were sentenced to one month's imprisonment each in the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday for soliciting aims. Policeman Hayes tells a strange story or poetic retribution of one of the sightless ones, Charles Berkowitz, who has long stood at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street, where he sells trinkets from a satchel.

It was Justice William Travers Jerome's intention last evening to spend the greater part of the night consulting with his counsel and preparing the return he is to make this morning to the writ of prohibition asked for by those arrested at the gambling place at 111 East Fourteenth Street, restraining the Justice from acting as a committing Magistrate in their cases.
BERLIN, May 8. -- The syndicate controlling the Differdingen steel plant and the Dannenbaum colliery is in financial difficulties, and has asked its creditors for a moratorium.

In his essay on SHELLEY Mr. BAGEHOT observes that mathematicians place great reliance on x, the symbol of the unknown quantity. All the offices of Wall Street might be searched in vain for an algebra, but the game over which that thoroughfare has gone mad is altogether algebraic.

CREEDMOOR, May 8. -- The range was occupied here to-day by the Eighth Regiment, N.G.N.Y., under the command of Col. J.M. Jarvis. There were about 400 officers and men present, of whom 252 qualified as marksmen and received the State decoration. The weather was very favorable.

CHICAGO, May 8. -- "If the great trusts in this country encroach on European markets to the detriment of European manufacture 1 predict a combination of the commercial countries of Europe to raise tariffs on American goods to almost prohibitive figures."

The tenth annual open games of Trinity Sohool were held yesterday afternoon at the University Oval. There was a spirited competition for the team prize, which was won by the athletes of the Montclair High School with a score of 20 points. The summaries follow:

LONDON, May 9. -- The annual meeting of the Iron and Steel Institute began yesterday. It was attended by all the prominent engineers in Great Britain, while almost all the American engineering centres were represented. Andrew Carnegie was one of those present.

To Mrs. A. W. INGALSBE, President, and Miss MARCIA ANDERSON, Secretary, of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union of Columbus, Ohio, the reply of Gen. MACARTHUR to the communication they have made to the Secretary of War upon the immorality of the American Army in the Philippines may seem rather tart.

Additional subscriptions to aid the Jacksonville fire sufferers continued coming in to the Joint Relief Committee of the Merchants' Association and the Chamber of Commerce all day yesterday. When the books were closed for the day, at 5 o'clock, $4,176.50 had been taken in, the total subscription for the three days thus far being $36.769.

LONDON, May 9. -- In the absence of Lord Salisbury, the Right Hon. A.J. Balfour. the Government leader in the House of Commons, was the principal speaker at the annual meeting yesterday, in the Albert Hall, of the Grand Habitation of the Primrose League. An enormous audience filled the hall.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 8. -- The annual convention of the National Municipal League began its three-day session to-day in the Chamber of Commerce rooms. The delegates were welcomed to the city by Mayor Carnahan and James C. Carter of New York made the response on behalf of the league.

Through the courtesy of The Scientific American THE NEW YORK TIMES is enabled to present to its readers this morning the first full and accurate description of the new cup defender Constitution. The article, which The Scientific American will print to-day, covers the whole construction of the yacht, giving dimensions, sail area, and, in fact, everything of interest connected with the boat.

There dripped from the back of Columbia University's library yesterday a yellow coze. About the campus were lying bits of clething and fragments of hats, with here and there an occasional barrel stave. At about the same hour some 400 students were exchanging what appeared to be bundles of rags for clothing marking more effectually the lines and curves of their figures.

Charles Francis Seymour, Earl of Yarmouth, who has adopted the stage name of Eric Hope, heard numerous opinions yesterday of both his financial and histrionic ability. These opinions were by no means favorable, as they were given by witnesses for the defense in the action for libel brought by the Earl against The Daily Telegraph Publishing Company for certain articles reflecting on the Earl.

NEWARK, N.J., May 8 -- Miss Ida E. Smith, who last week obtained a verdict of $7,500 in her $30,OUO suit for breach of promise of marriage against Charles W. Compton, has filed a bill in the Court of Chancery to set aside the conveyance of all her former suitor's real estate to his three sisters.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 8. -- Last Fall the Campbell Wall Paper Company built a large plant at this place and announced they would pay out in salaries every week about $4,090 to employes, and that it was intended to do a large business. Yesterday the company caused the following notice to be issued:

Some discussion resulted at the annual meeting of the Civil Service Reform Association last night over a motion to empower the Law Committee to act in challenging the appointment of Inspector Cross to the position of Deputy Chief, under the civil service law, governing temporary appointments. It was decided to refer the matter to the Law Committee for consideration.

By winning yesterday's baseball game from Philadelphia, New York made it three straight victories. It was a contest full of features, the umpire came in for no end of fault finding, and its most exciting period was in Philadelphia's half of the ninth inning. The score stood 7 to 9, Philadelphia needing the two runs necessary to tie.

Two exciting incidents, both due to absent-mindedness on the part of the persons most concerned, marked the departure of the American liner St. Paul for Southampton yesterday. Three persons who had gone aboard the vessel to bid a relative good-bye came very near to being compelled to cross the Atlantic, while two others who had booked in the first cabin came just as near to being left behind.

PHILADELPHIA, May 8 -- Judge McPherson to-day made an order in the United States District Court, quashing the indictment which charged Herman Keck with diamond smuggling. Keck, who is a resident of Cincinnati, Ohio, was accused of smuggling 563 diamonds into the Port of Philadelphia on a steamship in May, 1896.

WASHINGTON, May 8. -- The Treasury Department has ordered that the daily shipments of currency from New York to New Orleans be increased from $250,000 to $500,000 on account of the demand for currency by Jacksonville, Fla., made necessary on account of the fire.

Messrs. Harvey Fisk Sons and William C. Sheldon Co. as managers have completed arrangements for the formation of the American Locomotive Company, with an authorized capital of $50,000,000, of which one-half will be preferred and one-half common stock.

Charles M. Schwab, President of the United States Steel Corporation and drawing a salary of $800,000 a year, found time to mingle with a couple of hundred east side boys last night at the commencement exercise of the St. George's Evening Trade school. In the St. George's Church Memorial Building, at 207 East Sixteenth Street, and to point out to them the magnificent vista of success that is spread before every American boy.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, May 8. -- The German fruit steamer Schleswig, Capt. Schiuter, which cleared from Mobile on April 27 for Cuba, went ashore yesterday near Port Maria on the northern coast of Jamaica.

For a day so late in the season yesterday was quite gay, although people are now making their Summer plans and rapidly going to the country. The European exodus is, however, about over. The ships which left yesterday and Which leave to-day have very few well-known New Yorkers on board.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., May 8 -- The President and his party had their first taste of the hospitality of California to-day. The introduction to the land of sunshine, fruit, and flowers was like a dream of paradise after three days spent in the alkali deserts of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.

BOSTON, May 8 -- "What will you give," asked Bishop Lawrence at the Diocesan Convention here to-day, "for the future of the boy whose pin money is the gain at his father's game at the club?" The Bishop was uttering a solemn warning against National sins. He said:
PRINCETON, N.J., May 8. -- Lafayette's baseball team was easy for Princeton here to-day, the final score being 21 to 3. The score:

ST. LOUIS, May 8. -- A deal involving $9,250,000 was made in insurance circles today when the Hope Mutual Fire Insurance Company of St. Louis sold its business to and reinsured us risks in the National Fire Insurance Company of Hartford. Conn. Henry Schmitt, Secretary of the Hope Mutual Fire Insurance Company, in confirming the deal, said:

William E. Spier, ex-Treasurer of the International Paper Company and owner of the celebrated stallion Directum, died at his home, 29 West Seventy-second Street, yesterday morning from complications which set in after an operation last Saturday for mastoiditis. He was born in Glens Falls fifty-two years ago.

BOSTON, May 8 -- Money at the Clearing House to-day was quoted at 4 per cent, and New York funds, in better demand, sold at 12 1/2 and 10 cents' discount. Exchanges, $20,718,423; balances, $1,985,842.

Brokers and others for whom the subject has especial interest are convinced that we are about to witness a period of great activity in real estate. This applies particularly to valuable improved New York property. Just now the market is quiet, but those who have had long experience are making their preparations for a "boom."

VINELAND, N. J., May 8. -- A warrant charging Clifford Blakley with disorderly conduct was placed in the hands of Chief of Police Willard H. Nickerson of this place this afternoon. Blakley works in the shoe manufactory of John R. Potts Co. The Chief, instead of going to the factory to arrest the young man, went into the Mayor's office and called up the factory on the phone.

NEWARK, N.J., May 8. -- After many years of fighting, Mrs. Woods, one time housekeeper for Dr. Dennis Dowling Mulcahey, a noted physician of this city, now dead, has established her claim that she was his wife. This result was reached this afternoon, when a jury decided Mamie Woods to be the lawful daughter of the doctor.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 8. -- Charles Foster, ex-Congressman, ex-Governor of Ohio, and Secretary of the United States Treasury during President Harrison's time, filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy in the United States District Court here at 4:30 o clock this afternoon.

Although the transactions in the outside market yesterday were not very large, there were many wide fluctuations in price. The heavy declines on the Stock Exchange naturally lea to considerable selling of certain outside stocks, and this selling in some cases proved sufficient to bring about net losses as large as many of those recorded in the larger market.

BALTIMORE, May 8. -- Sebastian Martinelli, titular Archbishop of Ephesus and Cardinal-elect of the Church of Rome, to-day received at the hands of Cardinal Gibbons the red biretta, and donned the robes which will hereafter mark his rank. The ceremony, which is the second step in his elevation to his new position, was marked by all the pomp and brilliancy usually attendant upon such occasions.

The halls and corridors of the Waldorf-Astoria presented a remarkable spectacle last night. Until the early hours of the morning an excited crowd of men surged restlessly from the cafe through the bar into the billiard room and back again, anxiously awaiting the results of a conference which was supposed to be going on in a private room somewhere up stairs.

Topsy turvydom was in order at the Morris Park race track yesterday, and straight through the afternoon the very things that were least expected were the things that happened. The stake fixture, the Bouquet, selling, for two-year-olds, at five furlongs down the Eclipse Course, produced the greatest upset, and one that provoked visitors to the point of resentment by a wholesale wrecking of hopes.

The family troubles of ex-Sheriff James O'Brien had a preliminary airing in the Supreme Court yesterday, when Mrs. Ella Abigail O'Brien applied, through counsel, to Justice Freedman for alimony and counsel fees pending the trial of her action for separation. This action is brought on the ground of abandonment and failure to support.

The annual dinner of the Sphinx Club, the local organization of the advertising men, was served in the Waldorf-Astoria last night. The principal speakers were Robert C. Ogden and William F. King. President of the Merchants' Association. H.B. Harding, the club's President, was in the chair.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 8. -- Harvard triumphed over her athletic rival, Yale, to-day, in a most emphatic manner, when she won the intercollegiate team golf championship in the final round at thirty-six holes, played over the course of the Atlantic City Country Club. Harvard's team of six players won by 23 holes to 11.

BOSTON, May 8. -- A clean hit by Crolius in the twelfth inning of to-day's baseball game brought Demontreville home and scored the winning run of the game for Boston. With, the score 6 to 5 in favor of Brooklyn in the last half of the ninth, and with two out, Hamilton made a single which brought in Lowe's run and tied the score.
NEWPORT, May 8 -- Mrs. J.B.M. Grosvenor, John Boit, Mrs. Paul Dahlgren and Miss Romola Dahlgren, Mr. and Mrs. Gibson Fahnestock, and Judge and Mrs. John Clinton Gray have arrived for the season.

Shortly before 9 o'clock last night a man who gave his name as Dr. Samuel Hess of 818 Lexington Avenue drove up to Police Headquarters in a cab and at once went to the Bureau of Information, where he had a long conversation with the Sergeant with regard to his mother, Mrs. Bertha Hess, who, he said, has been missing since last Tuesday.

PITTSBURG, May 8. -- The Commercial Gazette this morning publishes the following statement of Joshua Rhodes of Pittsburg, retired as Chairman of the Board of Directors of the National Tube Company, now a constituent of the United States Steel Corporation:

Ten $1,000 bills in an envelope were, according to the sworn testimony of Bernard M. Ewing before Vice Chancellor H.C. Pitney in Chambers in Jersey City, on April 15 last, handed by him Oct. 20, 1900, to a man he "supposed " to be the representative of Thomas F. Nevins, once Chief of the Brooklyn Fire Department.

BOSTON, May 8. -- The Board of Overseers of Harvard University, at their regular meeting here to-day, voted to grant the degree of Doctor of Laws to President McKinley. The degree will be conferred at commencement in June.

To the lay mind, nothing could be neater or more conclusive than the disposition made by Justice JEROME of the protest against his taking charge, as committing Magistrate, of cases in which he had appeared as a collector of evidence. And certainly nothing in its kind could have been more amusing.

SAN JUAN DE PORTO RICO, May 8. -- Hand bills that are being circulated here reproduce an interview with Wenceslao Borda. Jr., published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, April 25, in which he was quoted as saying: "So hopeless is the state of affairs that fathers sell their daughters to keep them from dying of hunger." The people are indignant, and should Mr. Borda arrive in Porto Rico now, he would be liable to attack.

-- About all the mishaps that can befall a "story" in a newspaper office descended Monday upon an unoffending little tale from the Syrian colony which came to us in the course of the day. We will not undertake to make clear to the unprofessional mind exactly what happened to this bit of news.

BOSTON, May 9 -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 4 per cent, and New York funds sold at 10 cents discount and par. Money on call ranges from 4 to 5 per cent. Time money is mostly nominal at from 4 1/2 to 5 per cent. Considerable paper was sold Wednesday at 4 per cent. Exchanges, $26,209,936; balances, $1,654,960.

During the present week two groups of American capitalists have given to the world an exhibition of the use of vast power for private ends unrestrained by any sense of public responsibility. Possessing the strength of Titans, they have behaved like cowboys on a spree, mad with rum, and shooting wildly at each other in entire disregard of the safety of the bystanders.

The one change in the conditions attending the racing at the Morris Park track yesterday war in the weather, but the dreary outlook and drizzling rain had little effect on the attendance. As on every earlier day of the meeting a big crowd was out, and as on every earlier day, tried with a marked degree of ill-success to pick the winners.

NEW BRUNSWICK, May 9 -- A Good Language Club has been formed here. No member is permitted to swear without paying for it. Fiaes of 2 cents are imposed on each ordinary cuss word. Words of real blasphemy by the members call for fines of 25 cents each. The initiation fee is 10 cents.

In the following list "mtg" stands for mortgage and "R S" for revenue stamps. The war revenue law provides that stamps shall be placed on all conveyances at the rate of 50 cents for each $500 of consideration. This "consideration" has been held to mean only the equity above the mortgage, cept in the rare cases where the purchaser assumes payment of the mortgage.

It is no wonder that the remarks attributed to Gen. CHAFFEE, by rumor and unofficial report, as having been made at a "smoking concert" offered toy the commander of the British troops in China to what there were left of the American troops in China, should have fluttered some of the "Continental commanders" in China in their dovecotes.

The thirty-fifth annual meeting of the National Board of Fire Underwriters was held yesterday in the assembly room of the New York-Board. President George P. Sheldon was in the chair, and the list of those present included Cecil F. Shallcross, P.E. Rasor, H.W. Eaton, W.N. Kremer, G.L. Chase, W.B. Clark, Frank Lock, James D. Nichols, U.C. Crosby, and S.Y. Tupper.

LONDON, May 10 -- While it is hoped, rather than believed, that the British market is not committed to a great extent to American railroad securities, it cannot be denied that the settlement which will begin Monday is anticipated with keen apprehension.

BOSTON, May 9 -- Pittenger pitched a beautiful game for Boston to-day, striking out seven men and allowing only one base on balls. In the fifth inning Hamilton made a bunt down third base line, and beat it out to first. A very difficult running catch by Crolius in the ninth was a feature. Attendance, 2,000.

Incarcerated in the Bedford Avenue Police Station, Williamsburg, is Ah Lin, a Chinese fireman from the tramp steamship Taff, which is docked at the foot of South Filth Street, discharging a cargo of sugar. With six other Chinamen, members of the crew of the Taff. Ah Lin since the arrival of his ship in port contemplated in wonder the sight of the greater city as viewed from aboard ship.
LONDON, May 10 -- In the House of Commons yesterday the Government's civil list proposals were adopted by a vote of 307 to 58.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 9 -- What is supposed to have been a plan to kidnap a number of children was frustrated by the South Orange police yesterday, when they arrested two men as vagrants. The men when arrested said they came from Michigan, but they had with them fifteen pictures of children, all of them pretty little tots, evidently of refined parentage.

In my strolls around town with some of my friends I had some difficulty in finding the home pointed out by tradition as being the birthplace and home of the boyhood of President Andrew Johnson. Knowing the general locality, I asked an intelligent-looking liveryman if he could tell me where Andrew Johnson had lived.
Contract Surgeon P. Conover Field will proceed to New Brunswick, N.J., and upon arrival report by letter to the Surgeon General of the Army for annulment of contract.
CHICAGO, May 9 -- Money to-day was firm and unchanged at about 5 per cent. for call and time loans. New York exchange was quoted at 75 cents' premium.

The weather of yesterday, checked somewhat the numerous parties which had been arranged for coaching for the country and for the races. To-morrow, however, New York society will be gathered in full force at Morris Park. It is one of the fashionable days of the season. There, will be another house party at Chatsworth over Sunday.

The strongest banks in the financial district took a hand in the stock market panic when it was most turbulent yesterday, and by forming a pool had soon collected $19,500,000 to loan to approved borrowers in Wall Street at the market rate. Frederick D. Tappen of the Gallatin National Bank headed the syndicate.
Late last evening a gentleman familiar with the transactions which led to the break in the Northern Pacific corner, made the following statement of the matter:

Wall Street continues prolific of the marvelous. After having inaugurated the century with a market of unexampled strength and volume, it yesterday produced a panic eclipsing all previous ones, creating for the future a new standard of comparison. None of the dramatic scenes incident to panic was lacking.

Conditions that to some extent were the same as occurred on the Stock Exchange ruled in the outside market yesterday. The transactions were much larger than they were on recent days, and the sales of stocks were accompanied by declines which in many cases amounted to as much as 10 points, While in a few the recessions were much heavier.

NEW HAVEN, May 9 -- The Rev. Dr. William S. Ament, the well-known American Board missionary at Peking answered his critics this evening at the Dwight Place Church, which has determined to personally support him when he returns to China.

LONDON, May 9 -- Money was firm and in good demand to-day. Supplies were limited; discounts were firm. There was some nervousness regarding the effect of calls in connection with the recent large new capital issues. The London County Council loan has been oversubscribed three times, and the list has been closed.

With what a lone man termed "the delightful consistency of traditional inconsistency," the members of the Woman's Municipal League, at their annual meeting yesterday, indorsed a motion directly in opposition to one of their expressed principles. This little slip was emphasized by the fact that one woman called attention to it.

BERLIN, May 9 -- Baron von Thielmann, Imperial Secretary of the Treasury, admitted to the Budget Committee of the Reichstag to-day that there would be a deficit for the next fiscal year of an amount between 70,000,000 and 80,000,000 marks.

Improvements that have resulted in the practical rebuilding and remodeling of the stands and grounds of Celtic Park have been completed, and the park, owned by the Greater New York Irish-American Athletic Club, will open its Summer season one of the most completely equipped places of the kind about the city.
F.E. GARDNER, a prominent merchant and Postmaster at Richville, N.Y., is dead.

READING, Penn., May 9 -- The tie-up at the tube mill of the Reading Iron Company continues here, and nearly 2,000 men are on strike because of a disagreement concerning wages. A grievance committee of the strikers sent a letter to Superintendent William B. Williams asking for a general advance of 10 per cent, in wages and that the employes be paid every two weeks, instead of monthly.

ROCHESTER, May 9 -- President James C. Carter of New York arrived in Rochester this morning and assumed the duties of presiding officer at this morning's session of the National Municipal League. Election of officers was the first thing on the programme. These officers were unanimously elected for the ensuing year:

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 9 -- The ruins of Greenleaf Crosby's jewelry store early this morning was the scene of some excitement, and it is supposed that some was wounded by a bullet from a rifle. The Jacksonville Light Infantry was guarding the Bay Street section, where there are vaults of four or five banks and the vault of the Greenleaf Crosby store.

Few of the prominent operators and financial men of the Street would identify themselves in talking of the situation that developed yesterday. None would attempt to closely analyze conditions or speak of the causes of the shrinkage in stock values and the hysterical condition of the market. All who talked were, however, firmly of the opinion that the worst was over and hopeful for the near future.

Results are published of an "anti-skidding motor contest," the name of which explains itself. Whether the great problem of automobillsm will ever be solved remains to be seen. But in any case users of motor cars, who know the agonies of skidding when putting on the brake or of side-slipping around corners, will obtain a hint or two from the accounts of the trials made in the contest.

In the sudden death yesterday of exPolice Commissioner John McClave at his home, 124 West Seventy-second Street, New York's business and political life has lost a prominent figure. Mr. McCLave's death was entirely unexpected, although he had suffered from a heart affection for some years. But one member of his family was present when he was seized with the fatal attack.

The plot, 50 by 100, on the west side of Fifth Avenue, 50 feel south of Forty-fifth Street, has been sold by the estate of J.C. Hoagland to the New York Realty Corporation, through Broker E.S. Willard. The price paid for the property is said to have been about $365,000.

Justice Freedman, in Part I. of the Supreme Court, disposed in short order of the motion for a writ of prohibition restraining Justice William Travers Jerome from sitting as a committing Magistrate in the case of four alleged gamblers arrested in 111 East Fourteenth Street. The motion was denied, with $10 costs, because Justice Jerome had already heard the cases in question.

In the Special Term of the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, yesterday, Justice Gaynor's order to show cause why the Justices of the Appellate Division of the Second Department should not be enjoined from appointing a successor to William E. Melody in the office of Commissioner of Jurors was argued.

The greatest general panic that Wall Street has ever known came upon the stock market yesterday, with the result that before it was checked many fortunes, the accumulation in some cases of years, had been completely swept away.

TROY, N.Y., May 9 -- The body of Samuel Bolton, Jr., a prominent brewer and business man of this city, was found to-day in a vat of hot beer. Mr. Bolton had but a short time before returned from a pleasure drive, and chatted pleasantly with friends. About noon his hat was seen beside the vat of boiling beer and an investigation brought to light his body in the steaming liquid.

Lasker and Showalter played a match game at the Manhattan Chess Club yesterday afternoon and evening. Lasker lost the toss, and so the Kentuckian opened hostilities with a Ruy Lopez. The champion played the Berliner defense, viz.: 3., Kt -- B3.

Before the Royal British Nurses' Association Dr. Richard Greene lectured on "Ancient Medicine and Ancient Medical Men." He pointed out that the more highly civilized a race became the less it would attribute disease to supernatural agencies, and the more it would ascribe it to mechanical or natural agencies.

It will be small comfort to those who have lost their wagers on the course of the stock market in the last few days to reflect that the reaction that has taken place has probably saved some of them from worse losses, and has almost certainly saved the country from more widespread and more serious disturbance.

ALBANY, May 9 -- The Theatrical Legal Aid Society of New York City was incorporated to-day, to render legal aid gratuitously to theatrical people. The Directors are Isaac B. Brown, Joseph Nathan, Abram Davis, Everett J. Evans, and Charles Levy of New York City.

ST. PAUL, Minn., May 9 -- The greatest excitement prevailed here to-day at the Northern Pacific general offices. President Mellen kept in touch with the movement in stocks and fairly gasped for breath when it began to climb. He said he could not understand it. The Northern Pacific officials say that if it was a fight for control, the preferred stock would be bought up.
SOUTHAMPTON, May 9 -- In a black squall off the Needles to-day Shamrock II. carried away her gaff topsail yard, crumpled her gaff, and was towed by the Erin to Southampton for repairs.

The married women of the Woodcliffe section of North Hudson have organized a Woman's Vigilance League, and woe to the spouse who ignores home alleys and goes to New York to knock over the pins. The close proximity of some new bowling alleys in New York to the West Shore Ferry has proved too strong an attraction to the men, with the result that home contests have been abandoned.

NEWARK, N.J., May 9 -- H.H. Stevens of the New Brunswick Gun Club of New Brunswick, N.J., won the individual live bird crap shooting championship of the State at the New Jersey Sportsmen's Association's tournament on the grounds of the East Side Gun Club. Foundry and Perry Streets, here to-day.

A "corner" more complete and more disastrous in its results than any that Wall Street has ever before known came to its culmination yesterday. All eyes for the past three days have been fixed upon the course of Northern Pacific, the "corner" in which was daily seen to be working out the ruin of many unfortunate speculators who had been caught in this unlocked for whirlpool.

The joint committee of the Chamber of Commerce and the Merchants' Association reported yesterday that $5,523 more had been subscribed during the day to the fund for the Jacksonville sufferers. The total subscription thus far since the lists were opened last Monday is $42,292.

Expensive presents, including a saddle horse, watch, and bicycle, were made to his secretly wedded wife by Frank B. Hoffmire, who when arraigned in Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday charged with having abandoned her, testified that the most money he ever earned in his life was $7.50 a week by working in a Detroit stove foundry.

PHILADELPHIA, May 9 -- The first of a Series of meetings important to the whole glass-blowing industry will be held in Pittsburg on Saturday, when the Wage Scale Committee, composed of manufacturers and union men, will meet. This committee will in turn report to a General Conference Committee, which will begin a weeks session on Tuesday next.

Amid the tumult in the Wall Street district yesterday there was one important element that fattened as never before, perhaps. In and out through the surging multitude of brokers and "lambs" moved, in the even tenor of his way, the messenger boy. He was about the only plutocrat throughout that whole district who was not racked with doubt and fear.

John Donnelly, thirty-two years of age, of 314 East Thirty-sixth Street, was sentenced to three months on the Island on April 17 by Magistrate Zeller in the Yorkville Police Court for being drunk and disorderly. Yesterday Magistrate Zeller, who is not sitting in Yorkville, but who called at the court, received a pathetic letter from Donnelly, which brought about the latter's release.

A sensational story which appeared yesterday, and in which Henry M. Flagler, the Standard Oil millionaire, figured prominently, has caused a heated controversy between at least two lawyers, and threats of wholesale arrests for conspiracy are freely made.

It is not at all discouraging that Mr. GOMPERS and Mr. MITCHELL, were hissed and hooted by a portion of the audience at Cooper Union on Wednesday evening, when they undertook to explain the plans of the Committee of Conciliation of the Civic Confederation. The disturbers seem to have been of the class who call themselves Socialists, and are entirely convinced of the implacable and treacherous hostility of "Capital" to "Labor."

The Social Halls Association is the name of an organization incorporated at Albany yesterday with a capital stock of $100,000. Its general purposes are set down as "the buying, selling, owning, controlling, improving, and leasing of real estate in the City of New York, the establishment and conducting of public baths, gymnasiums, libraries, bowling alleys, billiard rooms, restaurants, roof gardens, public halls, "

AGREEMENT TO GIVE OFFICE IN A PROPOSED CORPORATION -- Robert Flaherty entered into an agreement with the members of the firm of Cary Whitridge by which the parties agreed to form a mortgage insurance corporation. In return for his services Flaherty was to be made sole general agent at a fixed salary.

Technicalities of music, the intricacies of the law, and a study of ways and means for the elevation of the blind have all come within the scope of Edward J. Nolan, blind since he was two years old. He was born in Chicago in 1864. When he reached school age his parents sent him to the Illinois School for the Blind in Jacksonville, where he remained until his eighteenth year.

WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The suggestion made by Perry S. Heath, in London, that Senator Hanna should be the Republican candidate for President in 1904 annoyed the object of Mr. Heath's remarks and has caused many prominent Republicans here to smile derisively when their opinions were asked for.

Two men stood over a ticker as the fatal quotations were clicked off in a Broadway broker's office. One finally said, as he dropped the tape after reading the latest register, "That let me out; thirty thousand to the bad and no hope of a rally." Then he nonchalantly lighted a cigar and started for home.

A good roads meeting will be held at Durland's Academy. West Sixty-sixth Street, near Eighth Avenue, to-night, under the auspices of the Road Drivers' Association, as a preliminary to the Speedway parade to-morrow afternoon, and will be attended by Gen. Miles and many prominent horsemen, as well as a number of city officials.

LONDON, May 10 -- Not in the memory of the oldest stock broker in London has there been such a panic as prevailed yesterday afternoon in Americans. After the closing of the Stock Exchange hundreds of dealers tried to get into the narrow confines of Shorter's Court, where outside dealings are done, and to raise or reduce, as the case might be.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES is mistaken in its article of May 1 entitled, "Misleading Instruction in Public Schools," when it assumes that any one in any way responsible for the study of temperance physiology believes in or would countenance "teaching error for effect."

The Earl of Yarmouth was called to the witness stand just before Justice Blanchard adjourned court yesterday to testify in his own behalf in his action for $25,000 damages against The Daily Telegraph Publishing Company for printing criticisms of his ability as an actor and also of his financial condition.

Robert R. Simmons, Treasurer for the Waite Comedy Company, now playing at the Metropolis Theatre, in the Bronx, who disappeared on Monday, leaving a note to the effect that he had taken $300 from the box office and meant to commit suicide, has been heard from indirectly.

MELBOURNE, May 9 -- The opening of the first Federal Parliament by the Duke of Cornwall and York at noon to-day was a most impressive ceremony. The capacity of the Exhibition Building, the scene of the ceremony, is 12,000 persons, but the available space was taxed to the utmost. The decorations consisted of regimental standards, trophies of arms, and floral festoons.

The history of other famous "corners" in Wall Street begins with the story of the Morris Canal stock, which was engineered by a pool, and when the "corner" was reached the "shorts" appealed to the Board of Brokers, who decided in their favor on the ground that the members of the pool were practically conspirators.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 9 -- Under cloudy skies and with occasional showers the individual championship for intercollegiate golf honors began this morning on the links of the Atlantic City Country Club. There were thirty starters in the 18-hole qualifying round, representing Harvard, Yale, Princeton, Columbia, and the University or Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, May 9 -- The Secretary of the Treasury has addressed the following letter to the attorney for the "Durkee" claimants:
NEWPORT, May 9 -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Warren Spalding of New York are visiting here.

The story of the destruction of the "corner" in Northern Pacific common stock is the story of how the panic was stopped. THE NEW YORK TIMES told yesterday of the injunction papers that had been taken out to restrain those making the "corner" from requiring deliveries of the stock. The fact that such legal proceedings could be taken in such an emergency as existed was a revelation to Wall Street.

SAN LUIS OBISPO, Cal., May 10. -- The route of the President's train northward from Los Angelos to-day lay through the Santa Clara Valley, nestling under fogswathed mountains, to the coast, where it ran for hours along the edge of cliffs overhanging the Pacific Ocean. At every stopping place there was a flower show, rivaling in beauty the floral parade which the President witnessed yesterday at Los Angeles.

Many accusers confronted Robert A. Ahearn, an ex-convict, living at 163 East One Hundred and Thirty-third Street, who was arraigned in Harlem Police Court yesterday morning charged with stealing a horse and surrey from George Zache, a liveryman of 314 East One Hundred and Twenty-second Street, with passing bad checks upon him and others, and with bigamy, but he maintained his self-possession in the face of all his troubles.

NEWPORT, May 10. -- Mrs. E.J. Berwind, who is on her way back from Europe, will spend the greater part of next week here with Mr. Berwind, inspecting their new villa. The Elms, which will be in readiness for their occupancy in July.

DETROIT, Mich., May 10. -- Fully 10,000 men and boys ran riot in the main streets of this city for more than three hours, and a continual running fight with police, both mounted and on foot, caused an exciting time in the heart of the city to-night. The net result, so far as known, is twelve citizens and five policemen injured.

PASSAIC, N.J., May 10. -- From one State into another by rail and by wagon, John Bliss, a wealthy resident of Wellington, is giving chase to the man who ran away with his wife and baby, and he swears that when he catches up with the couple he will kill the man on sight.
DUBLIN, May 10. -- The police of Cork, Limerick, and other towns of Ireland seized all the copies of William O'Brien's weekly paper. The Irish People, found at the newsdealers' shops this morning.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Gov. Odell will announce his decision to-morrow on the Raines North River Bridge measure, the Employers' Liability bill, and all other bills which are pending before him. It is regaided here as absolutely certain that the Bridge bill and the Employers Liability bill will be vetoed.

CITY ISLAND, N.Y., May 10. -- The old cup defender Columbia left this afternoon in tow of her tender, the steamer Park City, for Bristol, R.I., where she will be hauled out and furthermore prepared for the trial race with the Constitution. A heavy northeast storm prevailed here all day, but despite this fact the Columbia proceeded eastward.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 10. -- Principal Ira W. Travell of this city to-day began to put into operation the scheme outlined by him some time ago in a paper read before the State High School Teachers' Association at Newark. This is the establishment of a senate, composed of scholars, to govern the school.

BALTIMORE, May 10. -- The market today completely obliterated all signs of Thursday's break. The moment it was found New York had recovered from its paroxysm of fear, the buying began here with a touch of genuine aggressiveness. Prices hardened instantly. Advances followed in such quick succession that speculators were unable to tell which was the best security to pick as a winner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The playful satire that sometimes appears in your editorial columns is charming, but I venture to suggest that there may be things more in need of it than the work of the Tree Planting Association.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10. -- To-day witnesed a marked improvement in the stock market, and much of yesterday's loss was regained. New York's confidence was well reflected here. The greatest strength was manifested in the steel issues. The Morgan group showed remarkable recuperative force.

"The Last Confessions of Marie Bashkirtseff and Her Corresoonaence with Guy de Maupassant," with a preface by Jeannette L. Glider, will shortly be published by the Frederick A. Stokes Company. Some extracts of this volume were translated from a French source a few months ago for THE TIMES SATURDAY REVIEW, and they revealed the same elements which node the diary of the young Russian artist so popular a dozen years ago.
Capt, John M. Carson. Jr., Quartermaster, will proceed to Jeffersonville, Ind., and thence to St. Louis, on official business pertaining to the Quartermaster's Department.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- No one can enforce total abstinence. That is only a theory. We can restrict the liquor trade, which the canteen did, but we cannot wipe it out. I am a Knight of Father Mathew. a total abstainer, and would see every one in the world belong, but I know it is impossible, and I do not join those crusades.

The Railroad Committee of the Municipal Council held a secret session yesterday to discuss the proposed extension of the Rapid Transit tunnel to Brooklyn. It was expected that there would be some action, as nearly all the members of the committee have declared publicly that they favored the project.

BOSTON, May 10. -- Etchings and mezzotints, from the collection of the late Frederick W. French, were sold at Libble's today. New York dealers got the highest-priced pieces. The offering's consisted of etchings by Bartelozzi, Seymour Haden. J. McNeill Whistler, A.H. Haig. Van Huyden, Anders Zorn, and others, and the whole of the Buhot collection, which was purchased by Mr. French from Felix Buhot's widow.

Dealers in pictures and frames, oil paintings and prints are giving more and more time and space to collections of the current work of American artists, and some of them, such is Clausen and Macbeth and Montross, have pursued this course so long that the public looks to their several galleries for what is new and striking in native work.
In Volume IV. of the "Public Papers of George Clinton " is to be found matter of singular interest. Mr. Hush Hastings, the State Historian, writes:

LONDON, May 3. -- There is no dearth of portraits of Mr. Rudyard Kipling, but of them all the most notable are the Collier portrait and the new etching by W. Strang. The latter is attracting a great deal of attention, and I am not sure whether the admirers of Mr. Kipling should be pleased or displeased thereat.
LONDON, May 10. -- Money was in fair demand to-day and supplies were larger. The uncertainty as to the future maintained discounts.

Panic is ended. The almost incredible declines of Thursday were to a large extent obliterated yesterday. Normal conditions, normal methods, are again the order of the day. Wall Street has passed through an unheard-of crisis, emerging with flying colors, its credit unshaken, its mechanism in good order.

The conference of Presidents, Vice Presidents, and executive officers of lines west of Buffalo and Pittsburg and east of Chicago and St. Louis at the offices of the Trunk Line Association, which has been going on for two days, adjourned yesterday afternoon after having reached an agreement whereby the unsettled condition in east-bound export rates will be arranged on a pliable basis to meet the fluctuations in steamship rates.

Whatever else Mr. Howells is or is not, be is pretty unfailingly readable, and bookish readers rarely let go of any piece Oi his prose with which they may happen to fall in, without reading it through. That kind of compulsion which his workmanship exerts upon the person who happens to take it up is exemplified in his remarks in the current number at The North American Review upon "The New Poetic Drama."

In the outside market yesterday prices responded to the improved conditions with almost as much buoyancy as did those on the board. The market opened above the closing prices of the previous day, and in most instances still further gains were recorded. Trading, except in a few stocks, was not very active, but few purchases were needed to bring prices materially above the low figures of Thursday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 10. -- Charles Hitchcock, Jr., a Yale sophomore, and Howard Lindsley, a Harvard junior, will meet to-morrow in the final round of the intercollegiate golf tournament for the individual championship. Two match play rounds were finished to-day on the links of the Atlantic City Country Club, and as the tournament has been replete in surprises from the start, the events to-day proved no exception to that rule.

The annual aquatic carnival of Columbia University was held last night in the gymnasium, swimming pool. In addition to the regular university championship races there was a relay race with Yale, which was won by the New Haven university. On the final lap of this race J.W. Spencer. Columbia's champion, and Frederick Wenck, the Amateur American Union champion, from Yale, took the water at the same moment.
WICHITA, Kan., May 10. -- J.L. Chandler, a farmer, of Ioland, Day County, Oklahoma, was taken from his home last night and lynched, presumably by cattlemen.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Washington speculators are indulging in rest after plunging wildly to the music of Wall Street for a week or more. The brokers have been at work all night for several nights getting their accounts unraveled, and meanwhile have been importuned by many unfortunates who have seen their investments fly away just at the moment they were confidently expecting to become rich by a favorable turn.

BUFFALO, May 10 -- This evening 650 carpenters and joiners employed at the exposition grounds went on strike. Unless the men's demands are granted by the Exposition Company the Walking Delegates threaten to call out every man employed at the exposition grounds to-morrow morning.

Scores, perhaps hundreds, of customers whose margins went in the twinkling of an eye Thursday owe it to their brokers that they were not "wiped out" completely when the crash came. No man, whether he was a regular speculator or an occasional dabbler in securities, could foresee even the possibility of a slump so tremendous, and very few outsiders were prepared to save themselves from utter ruin.

Some artists, archaeologists, and critics were listening lately to a story told by one of them concerning the late Mr. Ruskln: an anecdote of many years back, I suppose. It ran this way: Mr. Ruskln, being in the shop of a well-known Bond Street bookseller, looked over with him a set of the etchings of the celebrated Goya, the Spanish painter.

ALBANY, May 10. -- Superintendent Francis Hendricks of the State Insurance Department has sent to District Attorney Philbin of New York County a letter inclosing a copy of the financial statement of the Manhattan Fire Insurance Company of New York City, which the department has found to be of a fraudulent character.

Walter Harper Holt, one of the most conspicuous men in public life in the Borough of Richmond and Auditor from that borough in the Department of Finance, died yesterday at his home. 90 Heberton Avenue, Port Richmond, Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- An impression seems to prevail, and has even found expression in print, that the examinations now being conducted for Lieutenancies in the army will be final; that persons failing to pass them will have no further chance. This would, if it were a fact, handicap the Candidates who are now serving in the Philippines or have been there until recently.

Some one endeavoring to pluck out the heart of Hamlet's mystery has written a big book, convincing, to the writer, that it is a mere matter of punctuation. Take, this writer says, Hamlet's exclamation, "O all you host of heaven! O earth; What else? And shall I couple hell?" and put a question-mark after couple, and an exclamation point after hell, and the whole business is cleared up.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Anent your editorial of April 29, " Southern Shiftlessness." and the several letters commenting thereon, it strikes me that none of these touch the ease of the matter. That shiftlessness tends to poverty -- the South is poor, therefore the South is shiftlees, is a syllogism that proves nothing.

With the swallowing of an extremely bitter pill, in the shape of its own decision of last Winter, when a record or bar of 2:10 was recorded against the trotter John A. McKerron, the Board of Review of the National Trotting Association yesterday concluded its Spring sitting in the Murray Hill Hotel, and adjourned.

The death of William Stubbs, Bishop of Oxford, has removed the leader of that group of historians whose works, issued mainly during the decades between 1800 and 1890. are still among the choicest products of English scholarship. Freeman, Green, Gardlner, Creighton. Seeley, were among his colaborers. Others of lesser note shared in the labor and the honor.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., May 10. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad Company has enjoined the Jamestown and Chautauqua Company from crossing its tracks, and has also derailed two locomotives in such a way that the new line cannot cross. The company is building on both sides of the Pennsylvania's tracks.
BOSTON, May 10. -- Money loaned at the Clearing House to-day at 4 per cent. and New York funds sold at 5 cents' discount. Exchanges, $30,315,997; balances, $2,513,450.

Plans to place signs on all street corners were discussed yesterday at a public hearing before the Committee on Streets and Highways of the Board of Aldermen. Many representatives of taxpayers' organizations were present. They urged the city to take action so that people while traveling about the city could know the names of streets.

Another chapter was added yesterday to the strange history of the famous "Old Red Strad" violin of Jean Joseph Bott, once conductor of the Royal Opera in Saxe-Meiningen, whose two centuries of existence, since its creation in the Cremona workshop of Antonio Stradivarlus has been replete with romance and vicissitude.

LONDON, May 11. -- At the conclusion of the questions in the House of Commons yesterday John Dillon (Nationalist) moved the adjournment of the House in order to call attention to the seizure of The Irish People. Mr. Dillon complained that the action of the authorities was grossly Illegal, and asked whether it was due to the attack on Mr. Wyndham, the Chief Secretary for Ireland, or to the attack on the King.

Subscriptions for the relief of the Jacksonville fire sufferers continued pouring into the joint committee of the Chamber of Commerce and the Merchants' Associon yesterday. In exact figures $1,212 was added to the list yesterday, which brings the fund for the week, to date, up to $13,254.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The neglect of the Washington Market building has long been a noted disgrace to the hundred-million-dollar budget of this city. The surprise, therefore, can be appreciated when, looking out of a window a few mornings ago, lo, and behold! there was a man actually at work placing a new gutter along the skylight annex of a shed over the sidewalk on Washington Street.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 10. -- Princeton's schedule of football games for next Fall was made public to-night by Manager Robert C. Gordon, as follows:

It is a significant fact, as indicating the drift of public opinion in the West, that Representative TAWNEY of Minnesota has asked the State Department to ascertain through investigations by our Consuls abroad to what extent American manufactures and products are sold to foreign buyers cheaper than to consumers at home.

MONTREAL, Quebec, May 10. -- Archbishop Bond of the Anglican Diocese of Montreal to-day made public his reasons for accepting the resignation of Prof. Steen as lecturer in the Diocesan College, and also for opposing the professor's nomination as special minister at Christ Church Cathedral.

The world has had almost a surfeit of Eastern and Northern China; the China of many airocities, of siege and suffering, of war and diplomacy. Books have multiplied and those travelers who could not secure the attention of a fellow-mortal by means of the printed page have hunted him to the fastness of his own lyceum and lectured to him.

The sale of W.H. Arnold's second collection, which was dispersed on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoon at Bangs's, was very successful. The most Important book sold was Milton's " Paradise Lost," first Issue of the first edition, which was secured by Charles Scribner's Sons for $830. This was a fine copy in the original calf, with the original blank leaf before the title page and measuring 7 by 5 7-10 Inches.

The suspense and uncertainty that for over six weeks has tortured the family of Willie McCorraick, the ten-year-old boy who disappeared from his home in High Bridge on March 27, was ended yesterday when the body of the lad was found floating in Cromwell's Creek, within half a dozen blocks of where the family lives.

Samuel Goldsucker has sold for the Knickerbocker Real Estate Company to Harry I. Toolitz, 15, 17, and 10 East Fifty-ninth Street, north side, 75 feet west of Madison Avenue. The plot is 75 by 100, and is now occupied by four-story brownstonefront apartment houses.

Arrangements are being completed for broadening the scope of the Summer schools and vacation playgrounds. The experience of the Board of Education during the past four years with this feature of the system has been so satisfying that the work is to be extended as far as the funds available and the space to be had will permit.

Never before has there been so much building in the Young Men's Christian Association of New York City as at this time. Two new buildings will be completed in a short time; ground is about to be broken for another, plans are being prepared for a fourth, and money is being raised for the erection of a fifth and Sixth.
Lord Yarmouth proved himself a selfpossessed and at times a witty witness in his own behalf yesterday in his action against The Daily Telegraph Publishing Company for $25,000 damages for libel.

The Appletons having transferred their entire printing plant in Brooklyn to the Trow Company, which is so favorably known through recent excellent specimens of fine typography, it would seem that the possession of an individual printing plant, no matter how large and fully equipped, may be no more advantageous from a financial than from an artistic standpoint.

ROME, May 10. -- Signer Guiccardini, the reporter of the Budget Committee, announced to-day in the Chamber of Deputies that it was possible to count on a surplus of 50,000,000 lire, ($9,500,000.) out of which eighteen millions could be expended on railroads. Provision is also made for a sinking fund, leaving a net surplus of from eighteen to twenty millions.

CLARA MORRIS AND THE KEANS. -- The May McClure's contains a chapter of Clara Morris's autobiography, which deals with Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kean. She relates how the latter, by lire and influence, forced her way to the top of the Vatican and thereby got the proper pattern for the robe her husband wore in his great production of "Henry VIII," he appearing as Cardinal Wolsey.

LONDON, May 10 -- The eager competition among publishers' to secure Justin McCarthy's new "History of the Reign" of Queen Anne" has ended in the sale of the work to Harper Brothers. It is expected that the work will be finished this year. The same firm will publish later Mr. McCarthy's" Personal Reminiscences."

Two-cent stamps, (Buffalo Exposition series.) worth considerably more than their face value, may be the sequel to a blunder said to have been made by the Bureau of Printing and Engraving at Washington. These stamps are in two colors, being the first of that kind issued since 1869, and, according to philatelists, anything odd about them immediately enhances their value.

It may not be amiss at this time or seirexamination that we are passing through to change the topic, American literature, which has become somewhat too familiar. If not too serious, to that of American authors. There are two or three questions which the curious might ask about our authors which would have remained unanswered but for the painstaking of Mr. Adams in his "Dictionary of American Authors."

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court yesterday, in a suit brought by the Sanitary Utilization Company, upheld a judgment of the Special Term which declared unconstitutional the law which was passed in April last year, without the acceptance of the city, amending Section 1,212 of the Greater New York charter.

-- Now that the relation of mosquitoes to malaria has become a matter of common knowledge. It is discovered that years and years ago not a few students of nature approached marvelously near to the great fact, and left recorded in their books hints that should. It now seems, have set both themselves and others on the right track.

WASHINGTON, May 10. -- Returns to the statistician of the Department of Agriculture made up to May 1 show the area under Winter wheat in cultivation on that date to have been about 28,267,000 acres. This is 2,015,000 acres, or 6.7 per cent., less than the area sown last Fall, but 2,032,000 acres, or 7.7 per cent., in excess of the Winter wheat acreage harvested last year.

WINSTED, Conn., May 10. -- Watson Frisbie, a Woodbury farmer who came to town to-day to do some shopping, furnished plenty of amusement to the townspeople and incidentally came near causing the death of his horse. The farmer hitched the animal to a freight car that was standing on a siding at Pomperang Station, tied a bag of oats on its head, and left it there.
